editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.p: PARADISI IN SOLE Paradi≈øus Terrestris. or A Garden of all ≈øorts of plea≈øant flowers which our English ayre will permitt to be nour≈øed vp: with A Kitchen garden of all manner of herbes, rootes, & fruites, for meate or ≈øau≈øe v≈øed with vs, and An Orchard of all ≈øorte of fruitbearing Trees and ≈øhrubbes fit for our Land together With the right orderinge planting & pre≈øeruing of them and their v≈øes & vertues

div.head: TO THE QVEENES MOST EXCELLENT MAIESTIE.
div.p: KNowing your Maie≈øtie ≈øo much delighted with all the faire Flowers of a Garden, and furni≈øhed with them as farre beyond others, as you are eminent before them; this my VVorke of a Garden, long before this intended to be publi≈øhed, and but now only fini≈øhed, ≈øeemed as it were de≈øtined, to bee fir≈øt offered into your Highne≈ø≈øe hands, as of right challenging the proprietie of Patronage from all others. Accept, I be≈øeech your Maie≈øtie, this ≈øpeaking Garden, that may informe you in all the particulars of your ≈øtore, as well as wants, when you cannot ≈øee any of them fre≈øh vpon the ground: and it ≈øhall further encourage him to accompli≈øh the remainder; who, in praying that your Highne≈ø≈øe may enioy the heauenly Paradi≈øe, after the many yeares fruition of this earthly, ≈øubmitteth to be

closer.signed: Your Maiesties in all humble deuotion, IOHN PARKINSON.

div.head: TO THE COVRTEOVS READER.
div.p:
ALthough the ancient Heathens did appropriate the fir≈øt inuention of the knowledge of Herbes, and ≈øo con≈øequently of Phy≈øicke, ≈øome vnto Chiron the Centaure, and others vnto Apollo or Aeculapius his ≈øonne; yet wee that are Chri≈øtians haue out of a better Schoole learned, that God, the Creator of Heauen and Earth, at the beginning when he created Adam, inspired him with the knowledge of all naturall things (which ≈øucce≈øsiuely de≈øcended to Noah afterwardes, and to his Posterity): for, as he was able to giue names to all the liuing Creatures, according to their ≈øeuerall natures; ≈øo no doubt but hee had al≈øo the knowledge, both what Herbes and Fruits were fit, eyther for Meate or Medicine, for V≈øe or for Delight. And that Adam might exerci≈øe this knowledge, God planted a Garden for him to liue in, (wherein euen in his innocency he was to labour and ≈øpend his time) which hee ≈øtored with the best and choy≈øe≈øt Herbes and Fruits the earth could produce, that he might haue not onely for nece≈øsitie whereon to feede, but for plea≈øure al≈øo; the place or garden called Paradi≈øe importing as much, and more plainly the words ≈øet downe in Gene≈øis the ≈øecond, which are the≈øe; Out of the ground the Lord God made to grow euerie tree plea≈øant to the ≈øight and good for meate; and in the 24. of Numbers, the Parable of Balaam, mentioning the Aloe trees that God planted; and in other places if there were neede to recite them. But my purpo≈øe is onely to ≈øhew you, that Paradi≈øe was a place (whether you will call it a Garden, or Orchard, or both, no doubt of ≈øome large extent) wherein Adam was fir≈øt placed to abide; that God was the Planter thereof, hauing furni≈øhed it with trees and herbes, as well plea≈øant to the ≈øight, as good for meate, and that hee being to dre≈ø≈øe and keepe this place, mu≈øt of nece≈øsity know all the things that grew therein, and to what v≈øes they ≈øerued, or el≈øe his labour about them, and knowledge in them, had been in vaine. And although Adam lost the place for his tran≈øgre≈øsion, yet he lo≈øt not the naturall knowledge, nor v≈øe of them: but that, as God made the whole world, and all the Creatures therein for Man, ≈øo hee may v≈øe all things as well of plea≈øure as of nece≈øsitie, to bee helpes vnto him to ≈øerue his God. Let men therefore, according to their fir≈øt in≈øtitution, ≈øo v≈øe their ≈øeruice, that they al≈øo in them may remember their ≈øeruice to God, and not (like our Grand-mother Eve) ≈øet their affections ≈øo ≈øtrongly on the plea≈øure in them, as to de≈øerue the lo≈ø≈øe of them in this Paradi≈øe, yea and of Heauen al≈øo. For truly from all ≈øorts of Herbes and Flowers we may draw matter at all times not only to magnifie the Creator that hath giuen them ≈øuch diuer≈øities of formes, ≈øents and colours, that the mo≈øt cunning
Worke-man cannot imitate, and ≈øuch vertues and properties, that although wee know many, yet many more lye hidden and vnknowne, but many good in≈øtructions al≈øo to our ≈øelues: That as many herbes and flowers with their fragrant ≈øweete ≈ømels doe comfort, and as it were reuiue the ≈øpirits, and perfume a whole hou≈øe; euen ≈øo ≈øuch men as liue vertuou≈øly, labouring to doe good, and profit the Church of God and the Common wealth by their paines or penne, doe as it were ≈øend forth a plea≈øing ≈øauour of ≈øweet in≈øtructions, not only to that time wherein they liue, and are fre≈øh, but being drye, withered and dead, cea≈øe not in all after ages to doe as much or more. Many herbes and flowers that haue ≈ømall beautie or ≈øauour to commend them, haue much more good v≈øe and vertue: ≈øo many men of excellent rare parts and good qualities doe lye hid vnknown and not re≈øpected, vntill time and v≈øe of them doe ≈øet forth their properties. Againe, many flowers haue a glorious ≈øhew of beauty and brauery, yet ≈øtinking in ≈ømell, or el≈øe of no other v≈øe: ≈øo many doe make a glorious o≈øtentation, and flouri≈øh in the world, when as if they ≈øtinke not horribly before God, and all good men, yet ≈øurely they haue no other vertue then their out≈øide to commend them, or leaue behind them. Some al≈øo ri≈øe vp and appear like a Lilly among Thornes, or as a goodly Flower among many Weedes or Gra≈ø≈øe, eyther by their honourable authoritie, or eminence of learning or riches, whereby they excell others, and thereby may doe good to many. The frailty al≈øo of Mans life is learned by the ≈øoone fading of them before their flowring, or in their pride, or ≈øoone after, being either cropt by the hand of the ≈øpectator, or by a ≈øudden bla≈øt withered and parched, or by the reuolution of time decaying of it owne nature: as al≈øo that the faire≈øt flowers or fruits fir≈øt ripe, are ≈øoone≈øt and fir≈øt gathered. The mutabilitie al≈øo of ≈øtates and per≈øons, by this, that as where many goodly flowers & fruits did grow this yeare and age, in another they are quite pulled or digged vp, and eyther weedes and gra≈ø≈øe grow in their place, or ≈øome building erected thereon, and their place is no more known. The Ciuill re≈øpects to be learned from them are many al≈øo: for the delight of the varieties both of formes, colours and properties of Herbes and Flowers, hath euer beene powerfull ouer dull, vnnurtured, ru≈øticke and ≈øauage people, led only by Natures in≈øtinct; how much
„Äà‚óä„Äâ powerfull is it, or ≈øhould be in the mindes of generous per≈øons? for it may well bee ≈øaid, he is not humane, that is not allured with this obiect. The ≈øtudy, knowledge, and trauel in them, as they haue been entertained of great Kings, Princes and Potentates, without di≈øparagement to their Greatne≈ø≈øe, or hinderance to their more ≈øerious and weighty Affaires: ≈øo no doubt vnto all that are capable thereof, it is not onely plea≈øant, but profitable, by comforting the minde, ≈øpirits and ≈øen≈øes with an harmele≈ø≈øe delight, and by enabling the iudgement to conferre and apply helpe to many dangerous di≈øea≈øes. It is al≈øo an In≈øtructer in the verity of the genuine Plants of the Ancients, and a Correcter of the many errours whereunto the world by continuance hath bin diuerted, and almo≈øt therein fixed, by eradicating in time, and by degrees, the pertinacious wilfulne≈ø≈øe of many, who becau≈øe they were brought vp in their errours, are mo≈øt vnwilling to leaue them without con≈øideration of the good or euill, the right or wrong, they draw on therewith. And for my ≈øelfe I may well ≈øay, that had not mine owne paines and ≈øtudies by a naturall inclination beene more powerfull in mee then any others helpe (although ≈øome through an euill di≈øpo≈øition and ignorance haue ≈øo far traduced me as to ≈øay this was rather another mans worke then mine owne, but I leaue them to their folly) I had neuer done ≈øo much as I here publi≈øh; nor been fit or prepared for a larger, as time may ≈øuddenly (by Gods permi≈øsion) bring to light, if the maleuolent di≈øpo≈øitions of degenerate ≈øpirits doe not hinder the accompli≈øhment.
But per≈øwading my ≈øelfe there is no ≈øhowre that produceth not ≈øome fruit, or no word but worketh ≈øome effect, eyther of good to per≈øwade, or of reproofe to euince; I could not but declare my minde herein, let others iudge or ≈øay what they plea≈øe. For I haue alwaies held it a thing vnfit, to conceale or bury that knowledge God hath giuen, and not to impart it, and further others therewith as much as is conuenient, yet without ostentation, which I haue euer hated. Now further to informe the courteous Reader, both of the occa≈øion that led me on to this worke, and the other occurrences to it. Fir≈øt, hauing peru≈øed many Herbals in Latine, I ob≈øerued that mo≈øt of them haue eyther neglected or not knowne the many diuer≈øities of the flower Plants, and rare fruits are known to vs at this time, and (except Clu≈øius) haue made mention but of a very few. In Engli≈øh likewi≈øe we haue ≈øome extant, as Turner and Dodonaeus tran≈ølated, who haue haue ≈øaid little of Flowers, Gerard who is la≈øt, hath no doubt giuen vs the knowledge of as many as he attained vnto in his time, but ≈øince his daies we haue had many more varieties, then he or they euer heard of, as may be perceiued by the ≈øtore I haue here produced. And none of them haue particularly ≈øeuered tho≈øe that are beautifull flower plants, fit to ≈øtore a garden of delight and plea≈øure, from the wilde and vnfit: but haue enterlaced many, one among another, whereby many that haue de≈øired to haue faire flowers, haue not known either what to choo≈øe, or what to de≈øire. Diuers Bookes of Flowers al≈øo haue been ≈øet forth, ≈øome in our owne Countrey, and more in others, all which are as it were but handfuls ≈ønatched from the plentifull Trea≈øury of Nature, none of them being willing or able to open all ≈øorts, and declare them fully; but the greate≈øt hinderance of all mens delight was, that none of them had giuen any de≈øcription of them, but the bare name only. To ≈øatisfie therefore their de≈øires that are louers of ≈øuch Delights, I took vpon me this labour and charge, and haue here ≈øelected and ≈øet forth a Garden of all the chiefe≈øt for choyce, and faire≈øt for ≈øhew, from among all the ≈øeuerall Tribes and Kindreds of Natures beauty, and haue ranked them as neere as I could, or as the worke would permit, in affinity one vnto another. Secondly, and for their ≈øakes that are ≈øtudious in Authors, I haue ≈øet down the names haue bin formerly giuen vnto them, with ≈øome of their errours, not intending to cumber this worke with all that might bee ≈øaid of them, becau≈øe the deciding of the many controuer≈øies, doubts, and que≈øtions that concerne them, pertaine more fitly to a generall Hi≈øtory: yet I haue beene in ≈øome places more copious and ample then at the fir≈øt I had intended, the occa≈øion drawing on my de≈øire to informe others with what I thought was fit to be known, re≈øeruing what el≈øe might be ≈øaid to another time & worke; wherein (God willing) I will inlarge my ≈øelfe, the ≈øubiect matter requiring it at my hands, in what my ≈ømall ability can effect. Thirdly, I haue al≈øo to embelli≈øh this Worke ≈øet forth the figures of all ≈øuch plants and flowers as are materiall and different one from another: but not as ≈øome others haue done, that is, a number of the figures of one ≈øort of plant that haue nothing to di≈øtingui≈øh them but the colour, for that I hold to be ≈øuperfluous and wa≈øte. Fourthly, I haue al≈øo ≈øet down the ∆≤ertues and Properties of them in a briefe manner, rather de≈øiring to giue you the knowledge of a few certaine and true, then to relate, as others haue done, a needle≈øs and fal≈øe multiplicitie, that ≈øo there might as well profit as plea≈øure be taken from them, and that nothing might be wanting to accompli≈øh it fully. And ≈øo much for this fir≈øt part, my Garden of plea≈øant and delightfull Flowers. My next Garden con≈øi≈øteth of Herbes and Rootes, fit to be eaten of the rich and poor as nouri≈øhment and food, as ≈øawce or condiment, as ≈øallet or refre≈øhing, for plea≈øure or profit; where I doe as well play the Gardiner, to ≈øhew you (in briefe, but not at large) the times
and manner of ≈øowing, ≈øetting, planting, replanting, and the like (although all the≈øe things, and many more then are true, are ≈øet down very largely in the ≈øeuerall bookes that others haue written of this ≈øubiect) as al≈øo to ≈øhew ≈øome of the Kitchen v≈øes (becau≈øe they are Kitchen herbes &c.) although I confe≈ø≈øe but very ≈øparingly, not intending a treati≈øe of cookery, but briefly to giue a touch thereof; and al≈øo the Phy≈øicall properties, to ≈øhew ≈øomewhat that others haue not ≈øet forth; yet not to play the Empericke, and giue you receipts of medicines for all di≈øea≈øes, but only to ≈øhew in ≈øome ≈øort the qualities of Herbes, to quicken the minds of the ≈øtudious. And la≈øtly an Orchard of all ≈øorts of dome≈øticke or forraine, rare and good fruits, fit for this our Land and Countrey, which is at this time better ≈øtored and furni≈øhed then euer in any age before. I haue herein endeauoured, as in the other Gardens, to ≈øet forth the varieties of euery ≈øort in as briefe a manner as po≈øsibly could be, without ≈øuperfluous repetitions of de≈øcriptions, and onely with e≈øpeciall notes of difference in leaues, flowers and fruits. Some few properties al≈øo are ≈øet downe, rather the chiefe≈øt then the mo≈øt, as the worke did require. And moreouer before euery of the≈øe parts I haue giuen Treati≈øes of the ordering, preparing and keeping the ≈øeuerall Gardens and Orchard, with what≈øoeuer I thought was conuenient to be known for euery of them.

Thus haue I ≈øhewed you both the occa≈øion and ≈øcope of this Worke, and herein haue ≈øpent my time, paines and charge, which if well accepted, I ≈øhall thinke well employed, and may the ≈øooner ha≈øten the fourth Part, A Garden of Simples; which will be quiet no longer at home, then that it can bring his Ma≈øter newes of faire weather for the iourney.

closer.signed: Thine in what he may, IOHN PARKINSON.

div.head: Ioanni Parkin≈øono Pharmacopoeo Londinen≈øi ≈øclerti≈ø≈øimo Botanico con≈øummati≈øsimo T.D.M. S.P.D.
div.p: POema panegyricum Opus tuum indefe≈ø≈øi laboris, vtilitatis eximiae po≈øtulat, & meriti iure √† me extorqueret (mi Parkin≈øone) ≈øi fauentibus Mu≈øis, & ≈øecundo Apolline in bicipiti ≈øomniare Parna≈ø≈øo, & repent√® Poetae mihi prodire liceret. In foetus tui bouis auibus in lucem editi, & prolixiorem nepotum ≈øeriem promittentis laudes, alii Deopleni Enthou≈øia≈øtae carmine ≈øuos pangant elenchos; quos ≈øub figmentis ampullata hyperbolicarum vocum mulcedine, vates fer√® auribus mentibu≈øue in≈øinuant. Veritas nuditatis amans, fuco natiuum candorem obumbranti non illu≈øtranti perpetuum indixit bellum: In ≈øimplicitate, quam a≈ø≈øertionum neruo≈øa breuitas exprimit, exultat. Audi quid de te ≈øentiam, Tu mihi ≈øis in po≈øterum Crateuas Brittannus; inter omnes, quotquot mihi hic innotuerunt, periti≈øsimus, exercitati≈øsimus, oculati≈ø≈øimus, & emuncti≈øsimae naris Botanicus: Cuius opera in fortunata hac In≈øula rem herbariam tractari, emendari, augeri, & popularibus tuis vernaculo ≈øermone ad amu≈øsim tradi, non decentiae modo, ≈øed etiam nece≈øsitatis e≈øt. Macte tua ≈øedulitate (Vir optime) neque te laborum tam arduis lucubrationibus datorum hactenus poeniteat, vel deinceps impendendorum pigeat. Difficilia quae pulchra. Leniet debitae laudis dulcedo vigiliarum acerbitatem, & Olympicum ≈øtadium cito pede, √† carceribus ad metas alacriter decurrentem nobile manet „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Sed memento Artem longam, Vitam e≈ø≈øe breuem. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Vide quid ad antiquum illum, cuius ≈øi non animam, ≈øaltem genium indui≈øti, Crateuam ≈øcribat Hippocrates, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Nobili≈øsimam Medicinae partem Botanicam e≈ø≈øe reputa. Florae nunc lita≈øti & Pomonae, Apollini vt audio propediem HORTO MEDICO facturus. Amab√≤ integrae Ve≈øtae ≈øacra conficito, eiu≈øque variegatum multis ≈øimplicium morbifugorum myriadibus ≈øinum ab≈øolut√® pandito, quem ≈øine velo nobis exhibeas. Nulla dies abeat ≈øine linea. Sic tandem fructus gloriae referes vberrimos, quos iu≈øt√® ≈øudoribus partos, vt in cruda & viridi ≈øenectute decerpas diu, ii≈øque longum fruaris opto. Vale. div.l: EXtollunt alij quos (Parkin≈øone) labores
Da mihi iam veniam comminui≈ø≈øe tuos.
Extremos poteris credi migra≈ø≈øe per Indos:
Cum liber haud aliud quam tuus hortus hic est:
Ip≈øe habitare Indos tecum facis, haud petis Indos
I nunc, & tua me comminui≈ø≈øe refer.

Vidi ego ≈øplendentem varigatis vndique gemmis
∆≤na fuit Salomon, turba quid ergo fuit?
Vt vario ≈øplendent Pallacia regia ≈øumptu,
Et Procerum turbis Atria tota nitent:
Tunc cum fe≈øta dies veniam dedit e≈ø≈øe ≈øuperbis
Quo≈øque fious texit, nunc tria rura tegunt:
Plena tuo pariter ≈øpectatur Curia in Horto,
Hic Princeps, Dux hic, Spon≈øaque pulchra Ducis.
Quaeque dies e≈øt fe≈øta dies, nec parcius vnquam
Luxuriant, lauta haec; Quotidiana tamen.
Ecce velut Patriae Paradi≈øi haud immemor Exul,
Hunc naturali pingit amore ≈øibi.
Pingit & ad vivum ≈øub eodem nomine, & hic e≈øt
Fronticuli ≈øudor quem cerebrique dedit:
A≈øtat Adam medius Paradi≈øo no≈øter in i≈øto
Et ≈øpecies nomen cuique dat ip≈øe ≈øuum.

div.head: THE ORDERING OF THE GARDEN OF PLEASVRE.
CHAP. I. The ≈øituation of a Garden of plea≈øure, with the nature of ≈øoyles, and how to amend the defects that are in many ≈øorts of ≈øituations and grounds.
div.p:
THE ≈øeuerall ≈øituations of mens dwellings, are for the mo≈øt part vnauoideable and vnremoueable; for mo≈øt men cannot appoint forth ≈øuch a manner of ≈øituation for their dwelling, as is mo≈øt fit to auoide all the inconueniences of winde and weather, but mu≈øt bee content with ≈øuch as the place will afford them; yet all men doe well know, that ≈øome ≈øituations are more excellent than others: according therfore to the ≈øeuerall ≈øituation of mens dwellings, ≈øo are the ≈øituations of their gardens al≈øo for the mo≈øt part. And although diuers doe diuer≈øly preferre their owne ≈øeuerall places which they haue cho≈øen, or wherein they dwell. As ≈øome tho≈øe places that are neare vnto a riuer or brooke to be be≈øt for the plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of the water, the ca≈øe of tran≈øportation of them≈øelues, their friends and goods, as al≈øo for the fertility of the ≈øoyle, which is ≈øeldome bad neare vnto a riuers ≈øide; And others extoll the ≈øide or top of an hill, bee it ≈ømall or great, for the pro≈øpects ≈øake; And againe, ≈øome the plaine or champian ground, for the euen leuell thereof: euery one of which, as they haue their commodities accompanying them, ≈øo haue they al≈øo their di≈øcommodities belonging vnto them, according to the Latine Prouerbe, Omne commodum fert ≈øuum incommodum. Yet to ≈øhew you for euerie of the≈øe ≈øituations which is the fitte≈øt place to plant your garden in, and how to defend it from the iniuries of the cold windes and fro≈øts that may annoy it, will, I hope, be well accepted. And fir≈øt, for the water ≈øide, I ≈øuppo≈øe the North ≈øide of the water to be the be≈øt ≈øide for your garden, that it may haue the comfort of the South Sunne to lye vpon it and face it, and the dwelling hou≈øe to bee aboue it, to defend the cold windes and fro≈øts both from your herbes, and flowers, and early fruits. And ≈øo likewi≈øe I iudge for the hill ≈øide, that it may lye full open to the South Sunne, and the hou≈øe aboue it, both for the comfort the ground ≈øhall receiue of the water and raine de≈øcending into it, and of defence from winter and colds. Now for the plaine leuell ground, the buildings of the hou≈øe ≈øhould be on the North ≈øide of the garden, that ≈øo they might bee a defence of much ≈øufficiency to ≈øafeguard it from many iniurious cold nights and dayes, which el≈øe might ≈øpoyle the pride thereof in the bud. But becau≈øe euery one cannot ≈øo appoint his dwelling, as I here appoint the fitte≈øt place for it to be, euery ones plea≈øure thereof ≈øhall be according to the ≈øite, co≈øt, and endeauours they be≈øtow, to cau≈øe it come neare≈øt to this proportion, by ≈øuch helpes of bricke or ≈øtone wals to defend it, or by the helpe of high growne and well ≈øpread trees, planted on the North ≈øide thereof, to keepe it the warmer. And euery of the≈øe three ≈øituations, hauing the faire≈øt buildings of the hou≈øe facing the garden in this manner before ≈øpecified, be≈øides the benefit of ≈øhelter it ≈øhall haue from them, the buildings and roomes abutting thereon, ≈øhall haue reciprocally the beautifull pro≈øpect into it, and haue both ≈øight and ≈øent of what≈øoeuer is excellent, and worthy to giue content out from it, which is one of the greate≈øt plea≈øures a garden can yeeld his Ma≈øter. Now hauing ≈øhewed you the be≈øt place where this your
garden ≈øhould be, let me likewi≈øe adui≈øe you where it ≈øhould not be, at lea≈øt that it is the wor≈øt place wherein it may be, if it be either on the We≈øt or Ea≈øt ≈øide of your hou≈øe, or that it ≈øtand in a moori≈øh ground, or other vnwhol≈øome ayre (for many, both fruits, herbes, and flowers that are tender, participate with the ayre, taking in a manner their chiefe≈øt thriuing from thence) or neare any common Lay-≈øtalles, or common Sewers, or el≈øe neare any great Brew-hou≈øe, Dye-hou≈øe, or any other place where there is much ≈ømoake, whether it be of ≈øtraw, wood, or e≈øpecially of ≈øea-coales, which of all other is the wor≈øt, as our Citie of London can giue proofe ≈øufficient, wherein neither herbe nor tree will long pro≈øper, nor hath done euer ≈øince the v≈øe of ≈øea-coales beganne to bee frequent therein. And likewi≈øe that it is much the wor≈øe, if it bee neare vnto any Barnes or Stackes of corne or hey, becau≈øe that from thence will continually with the winde bee brought into the garden the ≈øtrawe and chaffe of the corne, the du≈øt and ≈øeede of the hey to choake or pe≈øter it. Next vnto the place or ≈øituation, let mee ≈øhew you the grounds or ≈øoyles for it, eyther naturall or artificiall. No man will deny, but the naturall blacke mould is not only the fatte≈øt and riche≈øt, but farre exceedeth any other either naturall or artificiall, as well in goodne≈ø≈øe as durability. And next thereunto, I hold the ≈øandy loame (which is light and yet firme, but not loo≈øe as ≈øand, nor ≈øtiffe like vnto clay) to be little inferiour for this our Garden of plea≈øure; for that it doth cau≈øe all bulbous and tuberous rooted plants to thriue ≈øufficiently therein, as likewi≈øe all other flower-plants, Ro≈øes, Trees, &c. which if it ≈øhall decay by much turning and working out the heart of it, may ≈øoone be helped with old ≈øtable manure of hor≈øes, being well turned in, when it is old and almo≈øt conuerted to mould. Other grounds, as chalke, ≈øand, grauell, or clay, are euery of them one more or le≈ø≈øe fertill or barren than other; and therefore doe require ≈øuch helpes as is mo≈øt fit for them. And tho≈øe grounds that are ouer dry, loo≈øe, and du≈øtie, the manure of ≈øtall fedde bea≈øts and cattell being buried or trenched into the earth, and when it is thorough rotten (which will require twice the time that the ≈øtable ≈øoyle of hor≈øes will) well turned and mixed with the earth, is the be≈øt ≈øoyle to temper both the heate and drine≈ø≈øe of them. So contrariwi≈øe the ≈øtable dung of hor≈øes is the be≈øt for cold grounds, to giue them heate and life. But of all other ≈øorts of grounds, the ≈øtiffe clay is the very wor≈øt for this purpo≈øe, for that although you ≈øhould digge out the whole compa≈ø≈øe of your Garden, carry it away, and bring other good mould in the ≈øtead thereof, and fill vp the place, yet the nature of that clay is ≈øo predominant, that in a ≈ømall time it will eate out the heart of the good mould, and conuert it to its owne nature, or very neare vnto it: ≈øo that to bring it to any good, there mu≈øt bee continuall labour be≈øtowed thereon, by bringing into it good ≈øtore of chalke, lime, or ≈øand, or el≈øe a≈øhes eyther of wood or of ≈øea-coales (which is the be≈øt for this ground) well mixed and turned in with it. And as this ≈øtiffe clay is the wor≈øt, ≈øo what ground ≈øoeuer commeth neare≈øt vnto the nature thereof, is neare≈øt vnto it in badne≈ø≈øe, the ≈øignes whereof are the ouermuch moy≈øture thereof in Winter, and the much cleauing and chapping thereof in Summer, when the heate of the yeare hath con≈øumed the moy≈øture, which tyed and bound it fa≈øt together, as al≈øo the ≈øtiffe and hard working therein: but if the nature of the clay bee not too ≈øtiffe, but as it were tempered and mixed with ≈øand or other earths, your old ≈øtable ≈øoyle of hor≈øes will helpe well the ≈ømall rifting or chapping thereof, to be plentifully be≈øtowed therin in a fit ≈øea≈øon. Some al≈øo do commend the ca≈øting of ponds and ditches, to helpe to manure the≈øe ≈øtiffe chapping grounds. Other grounds, that are ouermoi≈øt by ≈øprings, that lye too neare the vpper face of the earth, be≈øides that the beds thereof had need to be laid vp higher, and the allies, as trenches and furrowes, to lye lower, the ground it ≈øelfe had neede to haue ≈øome good ≈øtore of chalke-≈øtones be≈øtowed thereon, ≈øome certaine yeares, if it may be, before it be laid into a Garden, that the Winter fro≈øts may breake the chalke ≈ømall, and the Raine di≈ø≈øolue it into mould, that ≈øo they may bee well mixed together; than which, there is not any better manure to ≈øoyle ≈øuch a moi≈øt ground, to helpe to dry vp the moy≈øture, and to giue heate and life to the coldne≈ø≈øe thereof, which doth alwayes accompany the≈øe moi≈øt grounds, and al≈øo to cau≈øe it abide longer in heart than any other. For the ≈øandy and grauelly grounds, although I know the well mollified manure of bea≈øts and cattell to be excellent good, yet I know al≈øo, that ≈øome commend a white Marle, and ≈øome a clay to be well ≈øpread thereon, and after turned thereinto: and for the chalkie ground, √® conuer≈øo, I commend fatte clay to helpe it. You mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that the le≈ø≈øe rich or more barren that your ground is, there needeth
the more care, labour, and co≈øt to bee be≈øtowed thereon, both to order it rightly, & ≈øo to pre≈øerue it from time to time: for no artificiall or forc't ground can endure good any long time, but that within a few yeares it mu≈øt be refre≈øhed more or le≈ø≈øe, according as it doth require. Yet you ≈øhall likewi≈øe vnder≈øtand, that this Garden of plea≈øure ≈øtored with the≈øe Out-landi≈øh flowers; that is, bulbous and tuberous rooted plants, and other fine flowers, that I haue hereafter de≈øcribed, and a≈ø≈øigned vnto it, needeth not ≈øo much or ≈øo often manuring with ≈øoyle, &c. as another Garden planted with the other ≈øorts of Engli≈øh flowers, or a Garden of ordinary Kitchin herbes doth. Your ground likewi≈øe for this Garden had neede to bee well clean≈øed from all annoyances (that may hinder the well doing or pro≈øpering of the flowers therein) as ≈øtones, weedes, rootes of trees, bu≈øhes, &c. and all other things cumber≈øome or hurtfull; and therefore the earth being not naturally fine enough of it ≈øelfe, is v≈øed to bee ≈øifted to make it the finer, and that either through a hurdle made of ≈øticks, or lathes, or through ≈øquare or round ≈øieues platted with fine and ≈øtrong thin ≈øtickes, or with wyers in the bottome. Or el≈øe the whole earth of the Garden being cour≈øe, may be ca≈øt in the ≈øame manner that men v≈øe to try or fine ≈øand from grauell, that is, again≈øt a wall; whereby the cour≈øer and more ≈øtony, falling downe from the fine, is to betaken away from the foote of the heape, the finer ≈øand and ground remaining ≈øtill aboue, and on the heape. Or el≈øe in the want of a wall to ca≈øt it again≈øt, I haue ≈øeene earth fined by it ≈øelfe in this manner: Hauing made the floore or vpper part of a large plat of ground cleane from ≈øtones, &c. let there a rea≈øonable round heape of fine earth be ≈øet in the mid≈øt thereof, or in≈øtead thereof a large Garden flower-pot, or other great pot, the bottome turned vpwards, and then poure your cour≈øe earth on the top or head thereof, one ≈øhouell full after another ≈øomewhat gently, and thereby all the cour≈øe ≈øtuffe and ≈øtones will fall downe to the bottome round about the heape, which mu≈øt continually be carefully taken away, and thus you may make your earth as fine as if it were ca≈øt again≈øt a wall, the heape being growne great, ≈øeruing in ≈øtead thereof. Tho≈øe that will not prepare their grounds in ≈øome of the≈øe manners afore≈øaid, ≈øhall ≈øoone finde to their lo≈ø≈øe the neglect thereof: for the tra≈øh and ≈øtones ≈øhall ≈øo hinder the encrea≈øe of their roots, that they will be halfe lo≈øt in the earth among the ≈øtones, which el≈øe might be ≈øaued to ≈øerue to plant where≈øoeuer they plea≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. II. The frame or forme of a Garden of delight and plea≈øure, with the ≈øeuerall varieties thereof.
div.p:
ALthough many men mu≈øt be content with any plat of ground, of what forme or quantity ≈øoeuer it bee, more or le≈ø≈øe, for their Garden, becau≈øe a more large or conuenient cannot bee had to their habitation: Yet I per≈øwade my ≈øelfe, that Gentlemen of the better ≈øort and quality, will prouide ≈øuch a parcell of ground to bee laid out for their Garden, and in ≈øuch conuenient manner, as may be fit and an≈øwerable to the degree they hold. To pre≈øcribe one forme for euery man to follow, were too great pre≈øumption and folly: for euery man will plea≈øe his owne fancie, according to the extent he de≈øigneth out for that purpo≈øe, be it orbicular or round, triangular or three ≈øquare, quadrangular or foure ≈øquare, or more long than broad. I will onely ≈øhew you here the ≈øeuerall formes that many men haue taken and delighted in, let euery man chu≈øe which him liketh be≈øt, or may mo≈øt fitly agree to that proportion of ground hee hath ≈øet out for that purpo≈øe. The orbicular or round forme is held in it owne proper exi≈øtence to be the mo≈øt ab≈øolute forme, containing within it all other formes what≈øoeuer; but few I thinke will chu≈øe ≈øuch a proportion to be ioyned to their habitation, being not accepted any where I think, but for the generall Garden to the Vniuer≈øity at Padoa. The triangular or three ≈øquare is ≈øuch a forme al≈øo, as is ≈øeldome cho≈øen by any that may make another choi≈øe, and as I thinke is onely had where another forme cannot be had, nece≈ø≈øitie con≈øtraining them to be therewith content. The foure ≈øquare forme is the mo≈øt v≈øually accepted with all, and doth be≈øt agree to any mans dwelling, being (as I ≈øaid before) behinde the hou≈øe, all the backe windowes thereof opening into it. Yet if it bee longer than the breadth, or broader than the length, the proportion of walkes, ≈øquares, and knots may be ≈øoon brought to the ≈øquare forme, and be ≈øo ca≈øt, as the beauty thereof may
diagrams of formal pleasure gardens
bee no le≈ø≈øe than the foure ≈øquare proportion, or any other better forme, if any be. To forme it therfore with walks, cro≈ø≈øe the middle both waies, and round about it al≈øo with hedges, with ≈øquares, knots and trayles, or any other worke within the foure ≈øquare parts, is according as euery mans conceit alloweth of it, and they will be at the charge: For there may be therein walkes eyther open or clo≈øe, eyther publike or priuate, a maze or wilderne≈ø≈øe, a rocke or mount, with a fountaine in the mid≈øt thereof to conuey water to euery part of the Garden, eyther in pipes vnder the ground, or brought by hand, and emptied into large Ci≈øternes or great Turkie Iarres, placed in conuenient places, to ≈øerue as an ea≈øe to water the neare≈øt parts thereunto. Arbours al≈øo being both gracefull and nece≈ø≈øary, may be appointed in ≈øuch conuenient places, as the corners, or el≈øe where, as may be mo≈øt fit, to ≈øerue both for ≈øhadow and re≈øt after walking. And becau≈øe many are de≈øirous to ≈øee the formes of trayles, knots, and other compartiments, and becau≈øe the open knots are more proper for the≈øe Out-landi≈øh flowers; I haue here cau≈øed ≈øome to be drawne, to ≈øatisfie their de≈øires, not intending to cumber this worke with ouer manie, in that it would be almo≈øt endle≈ø≈øe, to expre≈ø≈øe ≈øo many as might bee conceiued and ≈øet downe, for that euery man may inuent others farre differing from the≈øe, or any other can be ≈øet forth. Let euery man therefore, if hee like of the≈øe, take what may plea≈øe his mind, or out of the≈øe or his own conceit, frame any other to his fancy, or cau≈øe others to be done as he liketh be≈øt, ob≈øeruing this decorum, that according to his ground he do ca≈øt out his knots, with conuenient roome for allies and walkes; for the fairer and larger your allies and walkes be, the more grace your Garden ≈øhall haue, the le≈ø≈øe harme the herbes and flowers ≈øhall receiue, by pa≈ø≈øing by them that grow next vnto the allies ≈øides, and the better ≈øhall your Weeders clean≈øe both the beds and the allies.

div.head: CHAP. III. The many ≈øorts of herbes and other things, wherewith the beds and parts of knots are bordered to ≈øet out the forme of them, with their commodities and di≈øcommodities.
div.p:
IT is nece≈ø≈øary al≈øo, that I ≈øhew you the ≈øeuerall materials, wherewith the≈øe knots and trayles are ≈øet forth and bordered; which are of two ≈øorts: The one are liuing herbes, and the other are dead materials; as leade, boords, bones, tyles, &c. Of herbes, there are many ≈øorts wherewith the knots and beds in a Garden are v≈øed to bee ≈øet, to ≈øhew forth the forme of them, and to pre≈øerue them the longer in their forme, as al≈øo to be as greene, and ≈øweete herbes, while they grow, to be cut to perfume the hou≈øe, keeping them in ≈øuch order and proportion, as may be mo≈øt conuenient for their ≈øeuerall natures, and euery mans plea≈øure and fancy: Of all which, I intend to giue you the knowledge here in this place; and fir≈øt, to begin with that which hath beene mo≈øt anciently receiued, which is Thrift. This is an euerliuing greene herbe, which many take to border their beds, and ≈øet their knots and trayles, and therein much delight, becau≈øe it will grow thicke and bu≈øhie, and may be kept, being cut with a paire of Garden ≈øheeres, in ≈øome good hand≈øome manner and proportion for a time, and be≈øides, in the Summer time ≈øend forth many ≈øhort ≈øtalkes of plea≈øant flowers, to decke vp an hou≈øe among other ≈øweete herbes: Yet the≈øe inconueniences doe accompany it; it will not onely in a ≈ømall time ouergrow the knot or trayle in many places, by growing ≈øo thicke and bu≈øhie, that it will put out the forme of a knot in many places: but al≈øo much thereof will dye with the fro≈øts and ≈ønowes in Winter, and with the drought in Summer, whereby many voide places will be ≈øeene in the knot, which doth much deforme it, and mu≈øt therefore bee yearely refre≈øhed: the thickne≈ø≈øe al≈øo and bu≈øhing thereof doth hide and ≈øhelter ≈ønayles and other ≈ømall noy≈øome wormes ≈øo plentifully, that Gilloflowers, and other fine herbes and flowers being planted therein, are much ≈øpoyled by them, and cannot be helped without much indu≈øtry, and very great and daily attendance to de≈øtroy them. Germander is another herbe, in former times al≈øo much v≈øed, and yet al≈øo in many places; and becau≈øe it will grow thicke, and may be kept al≈øo in ≈øome forme and proportion with cutting, and that the cuttings are much v≈øed as a ≈øtrawing herbe for hou≈øes, being pretty and ≈øweete, is al≈øo much affected by diuers: but this al≈øo will often dye and grow out of forme, and be≈øides that, the ≈øtalkes will grow too great, hard and ≈øtubby, the rootes doe ≈øo farre ≈øhoote vnder ground, that vpon a little continuance thereof, will
≈øpread into many places within the knot, which it continually they be not plucked vp, they will ≈øpoile the whole knot it ≈øelfe; and therefore once in three or foure yeares at the mo≈øt, it mu≈øt be taken vp and new ≈øet, or el≈øe it will grow too royni≈øh and cumber≈øome. Hy≈ø≈øope hath al≈øo been v≈øed to be ≈øet about a knot, and being ≈øweet, will ≈øerue for ≈øtrewings, as Germander: But this, although the rootes doe not runne or creep like it, yet the ≈øtalkes doe quickly grow great aboue ground, and dye often after the fir≈øt yeares ≈øetting, whereby the grace of the knot will be much lo≈øt. Marierome, Sauorie, and Thyme, in the like manner being ≈øweete herbes, are v≈øed to border vp beds and knots, and will be kept for a little while, with cutting, into ≈øome conformity; but all and euery of them ≈øerue mo≈øt commonly but for one yeares v≈øe, and will ≈øoone decay and peri≈øh: and therefore none of the≈øe, no more than any of the former, doe I commend for a good bordering herbe for this purpo≈øe. Lauander Cotton al≈øo being finely ≈ølipped and ≈øet, is of many, and tho≈øe of the highe≈øt re≈øpect of late daies, accepted, both for the beauty and forme of the herbe, being of a whiti≈øh greene mealy colour, for his ≈øent ≈ømelling ≈øomewhat ≈øtrong, and being euerliuing and abiding greene all the Winter, will, by cutting, be kept in as euen proportion as any other herbe may be. This will likewi≈øe ≈øoone grow great and ≈øtubbed, notwith≈øtanding the cutting, and be≈øides will now and then peri≈øh in ≈øome places, e≈øpecially if you doe not ≈øtrike or put off the ≈ønow, before the Sunne lying vpon it di≈ø≈øolue it: The rarity & nouelty of this herbe, being for the mo≈øt part but in the Gardens of great per≈øons, doth cau≈øe it to be of the greater regard, it mu≈øt therfore be renewed wholly euery ≈øecond or third yeare at the mo≈øt, becau≈øe of the great growing therof. Slips of Iuniper or Yew are al≈øo receiued of ≈øome & planted, becau≈øe they are alwayes green, and that the Iuniper e≈øpecially hath not that ill ≈øent that Boxe hath, which I will pre≈øently commend vnto you, yet both Iuniper and Yew will ≈øoon grow too great and ≈øtubbed, and force you to take vp your knot ≈øooner, than if it were planted with Boxe. Which la≈øtly, I chiefly and aboue all other herbes commend vnto you, and being a ≈ømall, lowe, or dwarfe kinde, is called French or Dutch Boxe, and ≈øerueth very well to ≈øet out any knot, or border out any beds: for be≈øides that it is euer greene, it being rea≈øonable thicke ≈øet, will ea≈øily be cut and formed into any fa≈øhion one will, according to the nature thereof, which is to grow very ≈ølowly, and will not in a long time ri≈øe to be of any height, but ≈øhooting forth many ≈ømall branches from the roote, will grow very thicke, and yet not require ≈øo great tending, nor ≈øo much peri≈øh as any of the former, and is onely receiued into the Gardens of tho≈øe that are curious. This (as I before ≈øaid) I commend and hold to bee the be≈øt and ≈øure≈øt herbe to abide faire and greene in all the bitter ≈øtormes of the ≈øharpe≈øt Winter, and all the great heates and droughts of Summer, and doth recompence the want of a good ≈øweet ≈øent with his fre≈øh verdure, euen proportion, and long la≈øting continuance. Yet the≈øe inconueniences it hath, that be≈øides the vnplea≈øing ≈øent which many mi≈ølike, and yet is but ≈ømall, the rootes of this Boxe do ≈øo much ≈øpread them≈øelues into the ground of the knot, and doe draw from thence ≈øo much nouri≈øhment, that it robbeth all the herbes that grow neare it of their ≈øap and ≈øub≈øtance, thereby making all the earth about it barren, or at lea≈øt le≈ø≈øe fertile. Wherefore to ≈øhew you the remedy of this inconuenience of ≈øpreading, without either taking vp the Boxe of the border, or the herbes and flowers in the knot, is I thinke a ≈øecret knowne but vnto a few, which is this: You ≈øhall take a broad pointed Iron like vnto a Sli≈øe or Che≈ø≈øill, which thru≈øt downe right into the ground a good depth all along the in≈øide of the border of Boxe ≈øomewhat clo≈øe thereunto, you may thereby cut away the ≈øpreading rootes thereof, which draw ≈øo much moi≈øture from the other herbes on the in≈øide, and by this meanes both pre≈øerue your herbes and flowers in the knot, and your Boxe al≈øo, for that the Boxe will be nouri≈øhed ≈øufficiently from the re≈øt of the rootes it ≈øhooteth on all the other ≈øides. And thus much for the liuing herbes, that ≈øerue to ≈øet or border vp any knot. Now for the dead materials, they are al≈øo, as I ≈øaid before diuers: as fir≈øt, Leade, which ≈øome that are curious doe border their knots withall, cau≈øing it to be cut of the breadth of foure fingers, bowing the lower edge a little outward, that it may lye vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the ground, and that it may ≈øtand the fa≈øter, and making the vpper edge either plain, or cut out like vnto the battlements of a Church: this fa≈øhion hath delighted ≈øome, who haue accounted it ≈øtately (at the lea≈øt co≈øtly) and fit for their degree, and the rather, becau≈øe it will be bowed and bended into any round ≈øquare, angular, or other proportion as one li≈øteth, and is not much to be mi≈øliked, in that the Leade
doth not ea≈øily breake or ≈øpoile without much iniury, and keepeth vp a knot for a very long time in his due proportion: but in my opinion, the Leade is ouer-hot for Summer, and ouer-cold for Winter. Others doe take Oaken inch boords, and ≈øawing them foure or fiue inches broad, do hold vp their knot therewith: but in that the≈øe boordes cannot bee drawne compa≈ø≈øe into any ≈ømall ≈øcantling, they mu≈øt ≈øerue rather for long outright beds, or ≈øuch knots as haue no rounds, halfe rounds, or compa≈ø≈øings in them. And be≈øides, the≈øe boordes are not long la≈øting, becau≈øe they ≈øtand continually in the weather, e≈øpecially the ends where they are fa≈øtned together will ≈øoone≈øt rot and peri≈øh, and ≈øo the whole forme will be ≈øpoyled. To preuent that fault, ≈øome others haue cho≈øen the ≈øhanke bones of Sheep, which after they haue beene well clean≈øed and boyled, to take out the fat from them, are ≈øtucke into the ground the ≈ømall end downewards, and the knockle head vpwards, and thus being ≈øet ≈øide to ≈øide, or end to end clo≈øe together, they ≈øet out the whole knot therewith, which heads of bones although they looke not white the fir≈øt yeare, yet after they haue abiden ≈øome fro≈øts and heates will become white, and prettily grace out the ground: but this inconuenience is incident to them, that the Winter fro≈øts will rai≈øe them out of the ground oftentimes, and if by chance the knockle head of any doe breake, or be ≈øtrucke off with any ones foot, &c. going by, from your ≈øtore, that lyeth by you of the ≈øame ≈øort, ≈øet another in the place, hauing fir≈øt taken away the broken peece: although the≈øe will la≈øt long in forme and order, yet becau≈øe they are but bones many mi≈ølike them, and indeed I know but few that v≈øe them. Tyles are al≈øo v≈øed by ≈øome, which by rea≈øon they may bee brought compa≈ø≈øe into any fa≈øhion many are plea≈øed with them, who doe not take the whole Tyle at length, but halfe Tyles, and other broken peeces ≈øet ≈øomewhat deepe into the ground, that they may ≈øtand fa≈øt, and the≈øe take vp but little roome, and keepe vp the edge of the beds and knots in a pretty comely manner, but they are often out of frame, in that many of them are broken and ≈øpoiled, both with mens feete pa≈ø≈øing by, the weather and weight of the earth beating them downe and breaking them, but e≈øpecially the fro≈øts in Winter doe ≈øo cracke off their edges, both at the toppes and ≈øides that ≈øtand clo≈øe one vnto another, that they mu≈øt bee continually tended and repaired, with fre≈øh and ≈øound ones put in the place of them that are broken or decayed. And la≈øtly (for it is the late≈øt inuention) round whiti≈øh or blewi≈øh pebble ≈øtones, of ≈øome rea≈øonable proportion and bigne≈ø≈øe, neither too great nor too little, haue beene v≈øed by ≈øome to be ≈øet, or rather in a manner but laide vpon the ground to fa≈øhion out the traile or knot, or all along by the large grauelly walke ≈øides to ≈øet out the walke, and maketh a pretty hand≈øome ≈øhew, and becau≈øe the ≈øtones will not decay with the iniuries of any time or weather, and will be placed in their places againe, if any ≈øhould be thru≈øt out by any accident, as al≈øo that their ≈øight is ≈øo con≈øpicuous vpon the ground, e≈øpecially if they be not hid with the ≈øtore of herbes growing in the knot; is accounted both for durability, beauty of the ≈øight, hand≈øomne≈ø≈øe in the worke, and ea≈øe in the working and charge, to be of all other dead materials the chiefe≈øt. And thus, Gentlemen, I haue ≈øhewed you all the varieties that I know are v≈øed by any in our Countrey, that are worth the reciting (but as for the fa≈øhion of Iawe-bones, v≈øed by ≈øome in the Low-Countries, and other places beyond the Seas, being too gro≈ø≈øe and ba≈øe, I make no mention of them) among which euery one may take what plea≈øeth him be≈øt, or may mo≈øt fitly be had, or may be≈øt agree with the ground or knot. Moreouer, all the≈øe herbes that ≈øerue for borderings, doe ≈øerue as well to be ≈øet vpon the ground of a leuelled knot; that is, where the allies and foot-pathes are of the ≈øame leuell with the knot, as they may ≈øerue al≈øo for the rai≈øed knot, that is, where the beds of the knot are rai≈øed higher than the allies: but both Leade, Boordes, Bones, and Tyles, are only for the rai≈øed ground, be it knot or beds. The pebble ≈øtones againe are onely for the leuelled ground, becau≈øe they are ≈øo ≈øhallow, that as I ≈øaid before, they rather lye vpon the earth than are thru≈øt any way into it. All this that I haue here ≈øet downe, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand is proper for the knots alone of a Garden. But for to border the whole ≈øquare or knot about, to ≈øerue as a hedge thereunto, euery one taketh what liketh him be≈øt; as either Priuet alone, or ≈øweete Bryer, and white Thorne enterlaced together, and Ro≈øes of one, or two, or more ≈øorts placed here and there among≈øt them. Some al≈øo take Lauander, Ro≈øemary, Sage, Southernwood, Lauander Cotton, or ≈øome ≈øuch other thing. Some againe plant Cornell Trees, and pla≈øh them, or keepe them lowe, to
forme them into an hedge. And ≈øome againe take a lowe prickly ≈øhrubbe, that abideth alwayes greene, de≈øcribed in the end of this Booke, called in Latine Pyracantha, which in time will make an euer greene hedge or border, and when it beareth fruit, which are red berries like vnto Hawthorne berries, make a glorious ≈øhew among the greene leaues in the Winter time, when no other ≈øhrubbes haue fruit or leaues.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The nature and names of diners Out-landi≈øh flowers, that for their pride, beauty, and earline≈ø≈øe, are to be planted in Gardens of plea≈øure for delight.
div.p:
HAuing thus formed out a Garden, and diuided it into his fit and due proportion, with all the gracefull knots, arbours, walkes, &c. likewi≈øe what is fit to keepe it in the ≈øame comely order, is appointed vnto it, both for the borders of the ≈øquares, and for the knots and beds them≈øelues; let vs now come and furni≈øh the inward parts, and beds with tho≈øe fine flowers that (being ≈øtrangers vnto vs, and giuing the beauty and brauery of their colours ≈øo early before many of our owne bred flowers, the more to entice vs to their delight) are mo≈øt be≈øeeming it: and namely, with Daffodils, Fritillarias, Iacinthes, Saffron-flowers, Lillies, Flowerdeluces, Tulipas, Anemones, French Cow≈ølips, or Beares eares, and a number of ≈øuch other flowers, very beautifull, delightfull, and plea≈øant, hereafter de≈øcribed at full, whereof although many haue little ≈øweete ≈øent to commend them, yet their earline≈ø≈øe and exceeding great beautie and varietie doth ≈øo farre counteruaile that defect (and yet I mu≈øt tell you with all, that there is among the many ≈øorts of them ≈øome, and that not a few, that doe excell in ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, being ≈øo ≈øtrong and heady, that they rather offend by too much than by too little ≈øent, and ≈øome againe are of ≈øo milde and moderate temper, that they ≈øcarce come ≈øhort of your mo≈øt delicate and dantie≈øt flowers) that they are almo≈øt in all places with all per≈øons, e≈øpecially with the better ≈øort of the Gentry of the Land, as greatly de≈øired and accepted as any other the mo≈øt choi≈øe≈øt, and the rather, for that the mo≈øt part of the≈øe Out-landi≈øh flowers, do ≈øhew forth their beauty and colours ≈øo early in the yeare, that they ≈øeeme to make a Garden of delight euen in the Winter time, and doe ≈øo giue their flowers one after another, that all their brauery is not fully ≈øpent, vntil that Gilliflowers, the pride of our Engli≈øh Gardens, do ≈øhew them≈øelues: So that who≈øoeuer would haue of euery ≈øort of the≈øe flowers, may haue for euery moneth ≈øeuerall colours and varieties, euen from Chri≈øtmas vntill Mid≈øommer, or after; and then, after ≈øome little re≈øpite, vntill Chri≈øtmas againe, and that in ≈øome plenty, with great content and without forcing; ≈øo that euery man may haue them in euery place, if they will take any care of them. And becau≈øe there bee many Gentlewomen and others, that would gladly haue ≈øome fine flowers to furni≈øh their Gardens, but know not what the names of tho≈øe things are that they de≈øire, nor what are the times of their flowring, nor the skill and knowledge of their right ordering, planting, di≈øplanting, tran≈øplanting, and replanting; I haue here for their ≈øakes ≈øet downe the nature, names, times, and manner of ordering in a briefe manner, referring the more ample declaration of them to the worke following. And fir≈øt of their names and natures: Of Daffodils there are almo≈øt an hundred ≈øorts, as they are ≈øeuerally de≈øcribed hereafter, euery one to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from other, both in their times, formes, and colours, ≈øome being eyther white, or yellow, or mixt, or el≈øe being ≈ømall or great, ≈øingle or double, and ≈øome hauing but one flower vpon a ≈øtalke, others many, whereof many are ≈øo exceeding ≈øweete, that a very few are ≈øufficient to perfume a whole chamber, and be≈øides, many of them be ≈øo faire and double, eyther one vpon a ≈øtalke, or many vpon a ≈øtalke, that one or two ≈øtalkes of flowers are in ≈øtead of a whole no≈øe-gay, or bundell of flowers tyed together. This I doe affirme vpon good knowledge and certaine experience, and not as a great many others doe, tell of the wonders of another world, which them≈øelues neuer ≈øaw nor euer heard of, except ≈øome ≈øuperficiall relation, which them≈øelues haue augmented according to their owne fan≈øie and conceit. Againe, let me here al≈øo by the way tell you, that many idle and ignorant Gardiners and others, who get names by ≈øtealth, as they doe many other things, doe call
≈øome of the≈øe Daffodils Narci≈ø≈øes, when as all know that know any Latine, that Narci≈ø≈øus is the Latine name, and Daffodill the Engli≈øh of one and the ≈øame thing; and therefore alone without any other Epithite cannot properly di≈øtingui≈øh ≈øeuerall things. I would willingly therefore that all would grow iudicious, and call euery thing by his proper Engli≈øh name in ≈øpeaking Engli≈øh, or el≈øe by ≈øuch Latine name as euery thing hath that hath not a proper Engli≈øh name, that thereby they may di≈øtingui≈øh the ≈øeuerall varieties of things and not confound them, as al≈øo to take away all excu≈øes of mi≈øtaking; as for example: The ≈øingle Engli≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill (which groweth wilde in many Woods, Groues, and Orchards in England.) The double Engli≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill. The French ≈øingle white Daffodill many vpon a ≈øtalke. The French double yellow Daffodill. The great, or the little, or the lea≈øt Spani≈øh yellow ba≈øtard Daffodill, or the great or little Spani≈øh white Daffodill. The Turkie ≈øingle white Daffodill, or, The Turkie ≈øingle or double white Daffodill many vpon a ≈øtalke, &c. Of Fritillaria, or the checkerd Daffodill, there are halfe a ≈øcore ≈øeuerall ≈øorts, both white and red, both yellow and blacke, which are a wonderfull grace and ornament to a Garden in regard of the Checker like ≈øpots are in the flowers. Of Iacinthes there are aboue halfe an hundred ≈øorts, as they are ≈øpecified hereafter; ≈øome like vnto little bells or ≈øtarres, others like vnto little bottles or pearles, both white and blew, sky-coloured and blu≈øh, and ≈øome ≈øtarlike of many pretty various formes, and all to giue delight to them that will be curious to ob≈øerue them. Of Crocus or Saffron flowers, there are al≈øo twenty ≈øorts; ≈øome of the Spring time, others flowring onely in the Autume or Fall, earlier or later than another, ≈øome whereof abide but a while, others indure aboue a moneth in their glorious beauty. The Colchicum or Medowe Saffron, which ≈øome call the ≈øonne before the father, but not properly, is of many ≈øorts al≈øo; ≈øome flowring in the Spring of the yeare, but the mo≈øt in Autume, whereof ≈øome haue faire double flowers very delightfull to behold, and ≈øome party coloured both ≈øingle and double ≈øo variable, that it would make any one admire the worke of the Creatour in the various ≈øpots and ≈øtripes of the≈øe flowers. Then haue wee of Lillies twenty ≈øeuerall ≈øorts and colours, among whom I mu≈øt reckon the Crowne Imperiall, that for his ≈øtately forme de≈øerueth ≈øome ≈øpeciall place in this Garden, as al≈øo the Martagons, both white and red, both blu≈øh and yellow, that require to be ≈øet by them≈øelues apart, as it were in a ≈ømall round or ≈øquare of a knot, without many other, or tall flowers growing neare them. But to tell you of all the ≈øorts of Tulipas (which are the pride of delight) they are ≈øo many, and as I may ≈øay, almo≈øt infinite, doth both pa≈ø≈øe my ability, and as I beleeue the skill of any other. They are of two e≈øpeciall ≈øorts, ≈øome flowring earlier, and others later than their fellowes, and that naturally in all grounds, wherein there is ≈øuch a wonderfull variety and mixture of colours, that it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible for the wit of man to de≈øcipher them thoroughly, and to giue names that may be true & ≈øeuerall di≈øtinctions to euery flower, three≈øcore ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of colours ≈øimple and mixed of each kind I can reckon vp that I haue, and of e≈øpeciall note, and yet I doubt not, but for euery one of them there are ten others differing from them, which may be ≈øeen at ≈øeuerall times, and in ≈øeuerall places: & be≈øides this glory of variety in colors that the≈øe flowers haue, they carry ≈øo ≈øtately & delightfull a forme, & do abide ≈øo long in their brauery (enduring aboue three whole moneths from the fir≈øt vnto the la≈øt) that there is no Lady or Gentlewoman of any worth that is not caught with this delight, or not delighted with the≈øe flowers. The Anemones likewi≈øe or Windeflowers are ≈øo full of variety and ≈øo dainty, ≈øo plea≈øant and ≈øo delight≈øome flowers, that the ≈øight of them doth enforce an earne≈øt longing de≈øire in the minde of any one to be a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øour of ≈øome of them at the lea≈øt: For without all doubt, this one kinde of flower, ≈øo variable in colours, ≈øo differing in forme (being almo≈øt as many ≈øorts of them double as ≈øingle) ≈øo plentifull in bearing flowers, and ≈øo durable in la≈øting, and al≈øo ≈øo ea≈øie both to pre≈øerue and to encrea≈øe, is of it ≈øelfe alone almo≈øt ≈øufficient to furni≈øh a garden with their flowers for almo≈øt halfe the yeare, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew you in a fit and conuenient place. The Beares eares or French Cow≈ølips mu≈øt not want their de≈øerued commendations, ≈øeeing that their flowers, being many ≈øet together vpon a ≈øtalke, doe ≈øeeme euery one of them to bee a No≈øegay alone of it ≈øelfe: and be≈øides the many differing colours that are to be ≈øeene in them, as white, yellow, blu≈øh, purple, red, tawney, murrey, haire colour, &c. which encrea≈øe much delight in all ≈øorts of the Gentry of the Land, they are not vnfurni≈øhed with a pretty ≈øweete ≈øent,
which doth adde an encrea≈øe of plea≈øure in tho≈øe that make them an ornament for their wearing. Flowerdeluces al≈øo are of many ≈øorts, but diuided into two e≈øpeciall kindes; the one bearing a leafe like a flagge, who≈øe rootes are tuberous, thicke and ≈øhort (one kinde of them being the Orris rootes that are ≈øold at the Apothecaries, whereof ≈øweete powders are made to lye among garments) the other hauing round rootes like vnto Onions, and narrow long leaues ≈øomewhat like gra≈ø≈øe: Of both the≈øe kindes there is much variety, e≈øpecially in their colours. The greater Flagge kinde is frequent enough and di≈øper≈øed in this Land, and well doth ≈øerue to decke vp both a Garden and Hou≈øe with natures beauties: But the chiefe of all is your Sable flower, ≈øo fit for a mourning habit, that I thinke in the whole compa≈ø≈øe of natures ≈øtore, there is not a more patheticall, or of greater corre≈øpondency, nor yet among all the flowers I know any one comming neare vnto the colour of it. The other kinde which hath bulbous or Onion like rootes, diuer≈øifieth it ≈øelfe al≈øo into ≈øo many fine colours, being of a more neate ≈øhape and ≈øuccinct forme than the former, that it mu≈øt not bee wanting to furni≈øh this Garden. The Hepatica or Noble Liuerwoort is another flower of account, whereof ≈øome are white, others red, or blew, or purple, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling Violets, but that there are white threads in the midde≈øt of their flowers, which adde the more grace vnto them; and one kinde of them is ≈øo double, that it re≈øembleth a double thicke Da≈øie or Marigold, but being ≈ømall and of an excellent blew colour, is like vnto a Button: but that which commendeth the flower as much as the beauty, is the earline≈ø≈øe in flowring, for that it is one of the very fir≈øt flowers that open them≈øelues after Chri≈øtmas, euen in the mid≈øt of Winter. The Cyclamen or Sowebread is a flower of rare receipt, becau≈øe it is naturally hard to encrea≈øe, and that the flowers are like vnto red or blu≈øh coloured Violets, flowring in the end of Summer or beginning of Autumne: the leaues likewi≈øe hereof haue no ≈ømall delight in their plea≈øant colour, being ≈øpotted and circled white vpon greene, and that which mo≈øt preferreth it, is the Phy≈øicall properties thereof for women, which I will declare when I ≈øhall ≈øhew you the ≈øeuerall de≈øcriptions of the varieties in his proper place. Many other ≈øorts of flowers there are fit to furni≈øh this Garden, as Leucoium or Bulbous Violet, both early and late flowring. Mu≈øcari or Muske Grape flower. Starre flowers of diuers ≈øorts. Phalangium or Spiderwort, the chiefe of many is that ≈øort who≈øe flowers are like vnto a white Lilly. Winter Crowfoote or Wolfes bane. The Chri≈øtmas flower like vnto a ≈øingle white Ro≈øe. Bell flowers of many kindes. Yellow Larkes ≈øpurre, the prettie≈øt flower of a ≈øcore in a Garden. Flower-gentle or Floramour. Flower of the Sunne. The Maruaile of Peru or of the world. Double Mar≈øh Marigold or double yellow Buttons, much differing and farre exceeding your double yellow Crowfoote, which ≈øome call Batchelours Buttons. Double French Marigolds that ≈ømell well, and is a greater kinde than the ordinary, and farre ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth it. The double red Ranunculus or Crowfoote (farre excelling the mo≈øt glorious double Anemone) and is like vnto our great yellow double Crowfoote. Thus hauing giuen you the knowledge of ≈øome of the choi≈øe≈øt flowers for the beds of this Garden, let me al≈øo ≈øhew you what are fitte≈øt for your borders, and for your arbours. The Ia≈ømine white and yellow. The double Hony≈øockle. The Ladies Bower, both white, and red, and purple ≈øingle and double, are the fitte≈øt of Outlandi≈øh plants to ≈øet by arbours and banqueting hou≈øes, that are open, both before and aboue to helpe to couer them, and to giue both ≈øight, ≈ømell, and delight. The ≈øorts of Ro≈øes are fitte≈øt for ≈øtandards in the hedges or borders. The Cherry Bay or Laurocera≈øus. The Ro≈øe Bay or Oleander. The white and the blew Syringa or Pipe tree, are all gracefull and delightfull to ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances in the borders of knots; for ≈øome of them giue beautifull and ≈øweete flowers. The Pyracantha or Prickly Corall tree doth remaine with greene leaues all the yeare, and may be pla≈øhed, or laid downe, or tyed to make a fine hedge to border the whole knot, as is ≈øaid before. The Wilde Bay or Laurus Tinus, doth chiefly de≈øire to be ≈øheltered vnder a wall, where it will be≈øt thriue, and giue you his beautifull flowers in Winter for your delight, in recompence of his fenced dwelling. The Dwarfe Bay or Me≈øereon, is mo≈øt commonly either placed in the mid≈øt of a knot, or at the corners thereof, and ≈øometimes all along a walke for the more grace. And thus to fit euery ones fancy, I haue ≈øhewed you the variety of natures ≈øtore in ≈øome part for you to di≈øpo≈øe of them to your be≈øt content.

div.head: CHAP. V. The nature and names of tho≈øe that are called v≈øually Engli≈øh flowers.
div.p:
THo≈øe flowers that haue beene v≈øually planted in former times in Gardens of this Kingdome (when as our forefathers knew few or none of tho≈øe that are recited before) haue by time and cu≈øtome attained the name of Engli≈øh flowers, although the mo≈øt of them were neuer naturall of this our Land, but brought in from other Countries at one time or other, by tho≈øe that tooke plea≈øure in them where they fir≈øt ≈øaw them: and I doubt not, but many other ≈øorts than here are ≈øet downe, or now knowne to vs, haue beene brought, which either haue peri≈øhed by their negligence or want of skill that brought them, or el≈øe becau≈øe they could not abide our cold Winters; tho≈øe onely remaining with vs that haue endured of them≈øelues, and by their encrea≈øing haue beene di≈øtributed ouer the whole Land. If I ≈øhould make any large di≈øcour≈øe of them, being ≈øo well knowne to all, I doubt I ≈øhould make a long tale to ≈ømall purpo≈øe: I will therefore but briefly recite them, that you may haue them together in one place, with ≈øome little declaration of the nature and quality of them, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe to other matters. And fir≈øt of Primro≈øes and Cow≈ølips, whereof there are many prettie varieties; ≈øome better knowne in the We≈øt parts of this Kingdome, others in the North, than in any other, vntill of late being ob≈øerued by ≈øome curious louers of varieties, they haue been tran≈øplanted diuer≈øly, and ≈øo made more common: for although we haue had formerly in the≈øe parts about London greene Primro≈øes v≈øually, yet we neuer ≈øaw or heard of greene Cow≈ølips both ≈øingle and double but of late dayes, and ≈øo likewi≈øe for Primro≈øes to be both ≈øingle and double from one roote, and diuers vpon one ≈øtalke of diuers fa≈øhions, I am ≈øure is not v≈øuall: all which de≈øire rather to bee planted vnder ≈øome hedge, or fence, or in the ≈øhade, than in the Sunne. Single Ro≈øe Campions, both white, red, and blu≈øh, and the double red Ro≈øe Campion al≈øo is knowne ≈øufficiently, and will abide moderate Sunne as well as the ≈øhade. The flower of Bri≈øtow or None-≈øuch is likewi≈øe another kinde of Campion, whereof there is both white flowring plants and blu≈øh as well as Orange colour, all of them being ≈øingle flowers require a moderate Sunne and not the ≈øhadow: But the Orange colour None-≈øuch with double flowers, as it is rare and not common, ≈øo for his brauery doth well de≈øerue a Ma≈øter of account that will take care to keepe and pre≈øerue it. Batchelours Buttons both white and red, are kindes of wilde Campions of a very double forme, and will rea≈øonably well like the Sunne but not the ≈øhade. Wall-flowers are common in euery Garden, as well the ordinary double as the ≈øingle, and the double kinde de≈øireth no more ≈øhade than the ≈øingle, but the greater kindes both double and ≈øingle mu≈øt haue the Sunne. Stock-Gilloflowers likewi≈øe are almo≈øt as common as Wall-flowers, e≈øpecially the ≈øingle kindes in euery womans Garden, but the double kindes are much more rare, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed but of a few, and tho≈øe onely that will bee carefull to pre≈øerue them in Winter; for be≈øides that the mo≈øt of them are more tender, they yeeld no ≈øeede as the ≈øingle kindes doe to pre≈øerue them, although one kinde from the ≈øowing of the ≈øeed yeeld double flowers: They will all require the comfort of the Sunne, e≈øpecially the double kindes, and to be defended from cold, yet ≈øo as in the Summer they doe not want water wherein they much ioy, and which is as it were their life. Queenes Gilloflowers (which ≈øome call Dames Violets, and ≈øome Winter Gilloflowers, are a kinde of Stock-Gilloflower) planted in Gardens to ≈øerue to fill vp the parts thereof for want of better things, hauing in mine opinion neither ≈øight nor ≈øent much to commend them. Violets are the Springs chiefe flowers for beauty, ≈ømell, and v≈øe, both ≈øingle and double, the more ≈øhadie and moi≈øt they ≈øtand the better. Snapdragon are flowers of much more delight, and in that they are more tender to keep, and will hardly endure the ≈øharpe Winters, vnle≈ø≈øe they ≈øtand well defended, are ≈øcarce ≈øeene in many Gardens. Columbines ≈øingle and double, of many ≈øorts, fa≈øhions, and colours, very variable both ≈øpeckled and party coloured, are flowers of that re≈øpect, as that no Garden would willingly bee without them, that could tell how to haue them, yet the rarer the flowers are, the more trouble to keepe; the ordinary ≈øorts on the contrary
part will not be lo≈øt, doe what one will. Larkes heeles, or ≈øpurres, or toes, as in ≈øeuerall Countries they are called, exceed in the varietie of colours, both ≈øingle and double, any of the former times; for vntill of late dayes none of the mo≈øt plea≈øant colours were ≈øeene or heard of: but now the ≈øingle kindes are rea≈øonable well di≈øper≈øt ouer the Land, yet the double kindes of all tho≈øe plea≈øant colours (and ≈øome other al≈øo as beautifull) which ≈øtand like little double Ro≈øes, are enioyed but of a few: all of them ri≈øe from ≈øeed, and mu≈øt be ≈øowne euery yeare, the double as well as the ≈øingle. Pan≈øyes or Hartes ea≈øes of diuers colours, and although without ≈øent, yet not without ≈øome re≈øpect and delight. Double Poppies are flowers of a great and goodly proportion, adorning a Garden with their variable colours to the delight of the beholders, wherein there is ≈øome ≈øpeciall care to be taken, le≈øt they turne ≈øingle; and that is, if you ≈øee them grow vp too thicke, that you mu≈øt pull them vp, and not ≈øuffer them to grow within le≈ø≈øe than halfe a yard di≈øtance, or more one from another. Double Dai≈øies are flowers not to be forgotten, although they be common enough in euery Garden, being both white and red, both blu≈øh and ≈øpeckled, or party coloured, be≈øides that which is called Iacke an Apes on hor≈øebacke, they require a moi≈øt and ≈øhadowie place; for they are ≈øcorched away, if they ≈øtand in the Sunne in any dry place. Double Marigolds al≈øo are the mo≈øt common in all Gardens. And ≈øo are the French Marigolds that haue a ≈øtrong heady ≈øent, both ≈øingle and double, who≈øe glorious ≈øhew for colour would cau≈øe any to beleeue there were ≈øome rare goodne≈ø≈øe or vertue in them. The≈øe all are ≈øometimes pre≈øerued in the Winter, if they bee well defended from the cold. But what ≈øhall I ≈øay to the Queene of delight and of flowers, Carnations and Gilloflowers, who≈øe brauery, variety, and ≈øweete ≈ømell ioyned together, tyeth euery ones affection with great earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe, both to like and to haue them? Tho≈øe that were knowne, and enioyed in former times with much acceptation, are now for the mo≈øt part le≈ø≈øe accounted of, except a very few: for now there are ≈øo many other varieties of later inuention, that troubleth the other both in number, beauty, and worth: The names of them doe differ very variably, in that names are impo≈øed and altered as euerie ones fancy will haue them, that carryed or ≈øent them into the ≈øeuerall Countries from London, where their true≈øt name is to be had, in mine opinion. I will here but giue you the names of ≈øome, and referre you to the worke en≈øuing for your further knowledge. The red and the gray Hulo. The old Carnation, differing from them both. The Gran Pere. The Camber≈øiue. The Sauadge. The Chri≈øtall. The Prince. The white Carnation, or Delicate. The ground Carnation. The French Carnation. The Douer. The Oxford. The Bri≈øtow. The We≈øtmin≈øter. The Daintie. The Granado, and many other Gilloflowers too tedious to recite in this place, becau≈øe I haue amply declared them in the booke following. But there is another ≈øort of great delight and varietie, called the Orange tawny Gilloflower, which for the mo≈øt part hath ri≈øen from ≈øeed, and doth giue ≈øeed in a more plentifull manner than any of the former ≈øorts, and likewi≈øe by the ≈øowing of the ≈øeed there hath been gained ≈øo many varieties of that excellent worth and re≈øpect, that it can hardly be expre≈ø≈øed or beleeued, and called by diuers names according to the marking of the flowers; as The Infanta. The Stript Tawny. The Speckled Tawny. The Flackt Tawny. The Gri≈øeld Tawny, and many others, euery one to bee di≈øtingui≈øhed from others: Some al≈øo haue their flowers more double and large than others, and ≈øome from the ≈øame ≈øeed haue ≈øingle flowers like broad ≈øingle Pinkes: the further relation of them, viz. their order to ≈øowe, encrea≈øe, and pre≈øerue them, you ≈øhall haue in the ≈øub≈øequent di≈øcour≈øe in a place by it ≈øelfe. Pinkes likewi≈øe both ≈øingle and double are of much variety, all of them very ≈øweete, comming neare the Gilloflowers. Sweete Williams and Sweete Iohns, both ≈øingle and double, both white, red, and ≈øpotted, as they are kindes of wilde Pinkes, ≈øo for their grace and beauty helpe to furni≈øh a Garden, yet de≈øire not to ≈øtand ≈øo open to the Sunne as the former. Double and ≈øingle Peonies are fit flowers to furni≈øh a Garden, and by rea≈øon of their durability, giue out fre≈øh plea≈øure euery yeare without any further trouble of ≈øowing. And la≈øtly, Hollihocks both ≈øingle and double, of many and ≈øundry colours, yeeld out their flowers like Ro≈øes on their tall branches, like Trees, to ≈øute you with flowers, when almo≈øt you haue no other to grace out your Garden: the ≈øingle and double doe both yeeld ≈øeed, and yet doe after their ≈øeeding abide many yeares. Thus haue I ≈øhewed you mo≈øt of the Engli≈øh, as well as (I did before) the Outlandi≈øh
flowers, that are fit to furni≈øh the knots, trailes, beds, and borders of this Garden. Ro≈øes onely, as I ≈øaid before, I re≈øerue to circle or encompa≈ø≈øe all the re≈øt, becau≈øe that for the mo≈øt part they are planted in the outer borders of the quarters, and ≈øometimes by them≈øelues in the middle of long beds, the ≈øorts or kindes whereof are many, as they are declared in their proper place: but the White Ro≈øe, the Red, and the Damaske, are the mo≈øt ancient Standards in England, and therefore accounted naturall.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The order and manner to plant and replant all the ≈øorts of Out-landi≈øh flowers ≈øpoken of before, as well tho≈øe with bulbous rootes, as others with ≈øtringie rootes.
div.p:
WHereas it is the v≈øuall cu≈øtome of mo≈øt in this Land, to turne vp their Gardens, and to plant them againe in the Spring of the yeare, which is the be≈øt time that may bee cho≈øen for all Engli≈øh flowers, yet it is not ≈øo for your Out-landi≈øh flowers. And herein indeede hath beene not onely the errour of a great many to hinder their rootes from bearing out their flowers as they ≈øhould, but al≈øo to hinder many to take delight in them, becau≈øe as they ≈øay they will not thriue and pro≈øper with them, when as the whole fault is in the want of knowledge of the fit and conuenient time wherein they ≈øhould bee planted. And becau≈øe our Engli≈øh Gardiners are all or the mo≈øt of them vtterly ignorant in the ordering of the≈øe Out-landi≈øh flowers, as not being trained vp to know them, I haue here taken vpon mee the forme of a new Gardiner, to giue in≈øtructions to tho≈øe that will take plea≈øure in them, that they may be the better enabled with the≈øe helpes I ≈øhall ≈øhew them, both to know how they ≈øhould be ordered, and to direct their Gardiners ‚Ä¢ hat are ignorant thereof, rightly to di≈øpo≈øe them according to their naturall qualities. And I doe wi≈øhall Gentlemen and Gentlewomen, whom it may concerne for their owne good, to bee as carefull whom they tru≈øt with the planting and replanting of the≈øe fine flowers, as they would be with ≈øo many Iewels; for the rootes of many of them being ≈ømall, and of great value, may be ≈øoone conueyed away, and a cleanly tale faire told, that ≈øuch a roote is rotten, or peri≈øhed in the ground if none be ≈øeene where it ≈øhould be, or el≈øe that the flower hath changed his colour, when it hath been taken away, or a counterfeit one hath beene put in the place thereof; and thus many haue been deceiued of their daintie≈øt flowers, without remedy or true knowledge of the defect. You ≈øhall therefore, if you will take the right cour≈øe that is proper for the≈øe kindes of flowers, not ≈øet or plant them among your Engli≈øh flowers; for that when the one may be remoued, the other may not be ≈øtirred: but plant tho≈øe rootes that are bulbous, or round like Onions, eyther in knots or beds by them≈øelues which is the be≈øt, or with but very few Engli≈øh or Out-landi≈øh flower plants that haue ≈øtringie rootes: For you mu≈øt take this for a generall rule, that all tho≈øe rootes that are like Lillies or Onions, are to bee planted in the moneths of Iuly or Augu≈øt, or vnto the middle or end of September at the furthe≈øt, if you will haue them to pro≈øper as they ≈øhould; and not in the Spring of the yeare, when other gardening is v≈øed. Yet I mu≈øt likewi≈øe giue you to vnder≈øtand, that if Tulipas, and Daffodils, and ≈øome other that are firme and hard rootes, and not limber or ≈øpongie, being taken vp out of the ground in their fit ≈øea≈øon, that is, in Iune, Iuly, and Augu≈øt, and likewi≈øe kept well and dry, may bee re≈øerued out of the ground vntill Chri≈øtmas or after, and then (if they could not be ≈øet ≈øooner) being ≈øet, will thriue rea≈øonable well, but not altogether ≈øo well as the former, being ≈øet long before: but if you ≈øhall remoue the≈øe bulbous rootes againe, either pre≈øently after their planting hauing ≈øhot their ≈ømall fibres vnder the round rootes, and ≈øprung likewi≈øe vpwards, or before they be in flower at the ≈øoone≈øt (yet Tulipas, Daffodils, and many other bulbous, may be ≈øafely remoued being in flower, and tran≈øplanted into other places, ≈øo as they be not kept too long out of the ground) you ≈øhall much endanger them either vtterly to peri≈øh, or to be hindered from bearing out their flowers they then would haue
borne, and for two or three years after from bearing flowers againe.
