For the order of their planting there are diuers wayes, ≈øome whereof I will ≈øhew you in this place: Your knot or beds being prepared fitly, as before is declared, you may place and order your rootes therein thus, Eyther many rootes of one kind ≈øet together in a round or clu≈øter, or longwi≈øe cro≈ø≈øe a bed one by another, whereby the beauty of many flowers of one kinde being together, may make a faire ≈øhew well plea≈øing to many; Or el≈øe you may plant one or two in a place di≈øper≈øedly ouer the whole knot, or in a proportion or diameter one place an≈øwering another of the knot, as your ≈øtore will ≈øuffer you, or your knot permit: Or you may al≈øo mingle the≈øe rootes in their planting many of diuers ≈øorts together, that they may giue the more glorious ≈øhew when they are in flower; and that you may ≈øo doe, you mu≈øt fir≈øt ob≈øerue the ≈øeuerall kindes of them, which doe flower at one and the ≈øame time, and then to place them in ≈øuch order and ≈øo neare one vnto another, that their flowers appearing together of ≈øeuerall colours, will cau≈øe the more admiration in the beholders: as thus, The Vernall Crocus or Saffron flowers of the Spring, white, purple, yellow, and ≈øtript, with ≈øome Vernall Colchicum or Medow Saffron among them, ≈øome Deus Caninus or Dogges teeth, and ≈øome of the ≈ømall early Leucoium or Bulbous Violet, all planted in ≈øome proportion as neare one vnto another as is fit for them, will giue ≈øuch a grace to the Garden, that the place will ≈øeeme like a peece of tape≈øtry of many glorious colours, to encrea≈øe euery ones delight: Or el≈øe many of one ≈øort together, as the blew, white and blu≈øh Grape flowers in the ≈øame manner intermingled, doe make a maruellous delectable ≈øhew, e≈øpecially becau≈øe all of them ri≈øe almo≈øt to an equall height, which cau≈øeth the greater grace, as well neare hand as farre of. The like order may be kept with many other things, as the Hepatica, white, blew, purple, and red ≈øet or ≈øowne together, will make many to beleeue that one roote doth beare all tho≈øe colours: But aboue and beyond all others, the Tulipas may be ≈øo matched, one colour an≈øwering and ≈øetting of another, that the place where they ≈øtand may re≈øemble a peece of curious needle-worke, or peece of painting: and I haue knowne in a Garden, the Ma≈øter as much commended for this artificiall forme in placing the colours of Tulipas, as for the goodne≈ø≈øe of his flowers, or any other thing. The diuers ≈øorts and colours of Anemones or Winde-flowers may be ≈øo ordered likewi≈øe, which are very beautifull, to haue the ≈øeuerall varieties planted one neare vnto another, that their ≈øeuerall colours appearing in one place will be a very great grace in a Garden, or if they be di≈øper≈øed among the other ≈øorts of flowers, they will make a glorious ≈øhew. Another order in planting you may ob≈øerue; which is this, That tho≈øe plants that grow low, as the Aconitum Hyemale or Winter-wolues bane, the Vernall Crocus or Saffron-flowers of diuers ≈øorts, the little early Leucoium or Bulbous Violet, and ≈øome ≈øuch other as ri≈øe not vp high, as al≈øo ≈øome Anemones may be very well placed ≈øomewhat neare or about your Martagons, Lillies, or Crownes Imperiall, both becau≈øe the≈øe little plants will flower earlier than they, and ≈øo will bee gone and pa≈øt, before the other greater plants will ri≈øe vp to any height to hinder them; which is a way may well be admitted in tho≈øe Gardens that are ≈ømall, to ≈øaue roome, and to place things to the mo≈øt aduantage. Thus hauing ≈øhewed you diuers wayes and orders how to plant your rootes, that your flowers may giue the greater grace in the Garden, let mee ≈øhew you likewi≈øe how to ≈øet the≈øe kindes of rootes into the ground; for many know not well eyther which end to ≈øet vpwards or downewards, nor yet to what depth they ≈øhould be placed in the ground. Daffodils if they be great rootes, will require (as mu≈øt bee ob≈øerued in all other great plants) to bee planted ≈øomewhat deeper then the ≈ømaller of the ≈øame kinde, as al≈øo that the tops or heads of the rootes be about two or three fingers breadth hid vnderground. The Tulipas likewi≈øe if you ≈øet them deepe, they will be the ≈øafer from fro≈øts if your ground be cold, which will al≈øo cau≈øe them to be a little later before they be in flower, yet v≈øually if the mould be good, they are to be ≈øet a good hand breadth deep within the ground, ≈øo that there may be three or foure inches of earth at the lea≈øt aboue the head, which is the ≈ømaller end of the roote: for if they ≈øhall lye too neare the vpper face or cru≈øt of the earth, the colds & fro≈øts will pierce and pinch them the ≈øooner. After the ≈øame order and manner mu≈øt Hyacinthes, whether great or ≈ømall, and other ≈øuch great rootes be planted. Your greater rootes, as Martagons, Lillies, and Crownes Imperiall, mu≈øt be ≈øet much deeper then any other bulbous roote, becau≈øe they are greater rootes then others, and by them≈øelues al≈øo, as
is mo≈øt v≈øuall either in ≈øome ≈øquare, round, triangle, or other ≈ømall part in the Garden, becau≈øe they ≈øpread and take vp a very great deale of ground. All of them likewi≈øe are to be ≈øet with the broad end of the roote downewards, and the ≈ømall end vpwards, that is, both Lillies, Daffodils, Hyacinthes, and Tulipas, and all other ≈øorts of round rootes, which ≈øhew one end to bee ≈ømaller than another. But the Colchicum or Medow-Saffron onely requireth an exception to this generall rule, in regard the roote thereof hath a ≈ømall eminence or part on the one ≈øide thereof, which mu≈øt bee ≈øet or planted downeward, and not vpward; for you ≈øhall ob≈øerue, if the roote lye a little moi≈øt out of the ground, that it will ≈øhoote fibres out at the ≈ømall long end thereof, although you may perceiue when you take it vp, that the fibres were at the other broad end or ≈øide of the roote. As for the Crowne Imperiall, which is a broad round roote and flat withall, hauing a hole in the middle, for the mo≈øt part quite thorow, when it is taken vp in his due time out of the ground, you ≈øhall perceiue the ≈øcales or cloues of the rootes to bee a little open on the vpper≈øide, and clo≈øe and flat on the vnder≈øide, which will direct you which part to ≈øet vpward, as al≈øo that the hole is bigger aboue then it is below. The Per≈øian Lilly is almo≈øt like vnto the Crowne Imperiall, but that the roote thereof is not ≈øo flat, and that it hath a ≈ømaller head at the one part, whereby it may be di≈øcerned the plainer how to be ≈øet. The Fritillaria is a ≈ømall white root diuided as it were into two parts, ≈øo that many haue doubted, as formerly in the Crowne Imperiall, what part to ≈øet vppermo≈øt; you ≈øhall therefore marke, that the two parts of the roote are ioyned together at the bottome, where it ≈øhooteth out fibres or ≈ømall ≈øtringie rootes, as all other ≈øorts of bulbous rootes doe, and withall you ≈øhall ≈øee, that betweene the two parts of the roote a ≈ømall head will appeare, which is the burgeon that will ≈øpring vp to beare leaues and flowers. In the rootes of Anemones there are ≈ømall round ≈øwelling heads, ea≈øie enough to be ob≈øerued if you marke it, which mu≈øt be ≈øet vpwards. All other ≈øorts of ≈øtringie rooted plants (and not bulbous or tuberous rooted) that lo≈øe their greene leaues in Winter, will ≈øhew a head from whence the leaues and flowers will ≈øpring, and all others that keepe their greene leaues, are to bee planted in the ≈øame manner that other herbes and flower-plants are accu≈øtomed to be. But yet for the better thriuing of the ≈øtringie rooted plants, when you will plant them, let me informe you of the be≈øt way of planting, and the mo≈øt ≈øure to cau≈øe any plant to comprehend in the ground without failing, and is no common way with any Gardiner in this Kingdome, that euer I heard or knew, which is thus: Pre≈øuming that the ≈øtringie rooted plant is fre≈øh and not old gathered, and a plant that being remoued will grow againe, make a hole in the ground large enough where you meane to ≈øet this roote, and rai≈øe the earth within the hole a little higher in the middle then on the ≈øides, and ≈øet the roote thereon, ≈øpreading the ≈øtrings all abroad about the middle, that they may as it were couer the middle, and then put the earth gently round about it, pre≈ø≈øing it a little clo≈øe, and afterwards water it well, if it be in Summer, or in a dry time, or otherwi≈øe moderately: thus ≈øhall euery ≈øeuerall ≈øtring of the roote haue earth enough to cau≈øe it to ≈øhoote forth, and thereby to encrea≈øe farre better than by the v≈øuall way, which is without any great care and re≈øpect to thru≈øt the rootes together into the ground. Diuers other flower plants are but annuall, to bee new ≈øowne euery yeare; as the Maruaile of the world, the Indian Cre≈ø≈øes, or yellow Larkes heeles, the Flower of the Sunne, and diuers other: they therefore that will take plea≈øure in them, that they may enioy their flowers the earlier in the yeare, and thereby haue ripe ≈øeede of them while warme weather la≈øteth, mu≈øt nur≈øe vp their ≈øeedes in a bed of hot dung, as Melons and Cowcumbers are, but your bed mu≈øt be prouided earlier for the≈øe ≈øeeds, than for Melons, &c. that they may haue the more comfort of the Summer, which are to be carefully tended after they are tran≈øplanted from the hot bed, and couered with ≈øtraw from colds, whereby you ≈øhall not faile to gaine ripe ≈øeed euery yeare, which otherwi≈øe if you ≈øhould mi≈ø≈øe of a very kindly & hot Summer, you ≈øhould neuer haue. Some of the≈øe ≈øeedes neede likewi≈øe to be tran≈øplanted from the bed of dung vnder a warme wall, as the Flower of the Sunne, and the Maruaile of the world, and ≈øome others, and that for a while after their tran≈øplanting, as al≈øo in the heate of Summer, you water them at the roote with water that hath ≈øtood a day or two in the Sunne, hauing fir≈øt laid a round wi≈øpe of hay or ≈øuch other thing round about the roote, that ≈øo all helpes may further their giuing of ripe ≈øeede. One or two rules more I will giue you concerning
the≈øe dainty flowers, the fir≈øt whereof is this, That you ≈øhall not bee carefull to water any of your bulbous or tuberous rooted plants at any time; for they all of them do better pro≈øper in a dry ground than in a wet, onely all ≈øorts of tuberous rooted Flower deluces vpon their remouall had neede of a little water, and ≈øome will doe ≈øo al≈øo to ≈øuch Tulipas and other bulbous rootes as they tran≈øplant, when they are in flower, and this is I grant in ≈øome ≈øort tolerable, if it bee not too much, and done onely to cau≈øe the ≈øtalke and flower to abide ≈øometime the longer before they wither, but el≈øe in no other ca≈øe to be permitted. The ≈øecond rule is, That I would adui≈øe you to water none of your dainty flowers or herbes, with any water that hath pre≈øently before been drawne out of a well or pumpe, but onely with ≈øuch water that hath ≈øtood open in the Sunne in ≈øome ci≈øterne, tubbe, or pot for a day at the lea≈øt, if more the better: for that water which is pre≈øently drawne out of a well, &c. is ≈øo cold, that it pre≈øently chilleth & killeth any dainty plant be it younger or elder grown, wherof I haue had ≈øufficient proofe: and therfore I giue you this caution by mine own experience. Thus haue I directed you from point to point, in all the particulars of preparing & planting that belong to this Garden, ≈øauing only that yet I would further enforme you, of the time of the flowring of the≈øe Out-landi≈øh plants, according to the ≈øeuerall moneths in the yeare, that euery one may know what flowers euery moneth yeeldeth, and may chu≈øe what them liketh be≈øt, in that they may ≈øee hat there is no moneth, but glorieth in ≈øome peculiar ≈øorts of rare flowers. I would likewi≈øe rather in this place ≈øhew you, the true and be≈øt manner & order to encrea≈øe and pre≈øerue all ≈øorts of Gilloflowers & Carnations, then ioyne it with the Chapter of Gilloflowers in the worke following, becau≈øe it would in that place take vp too much roome. And la≈øtly, I mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity oppo≈øe three ≈øundry errours, that haue po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the mindes of many both in former and later times, which are, that any flower may be made to grow double by art, that was but ≈øingle before by nature: And that one may by art cau≈øe any flower to grow of what colour they will: And that any plants may be forced to flower out of their due ≈øea≈øons, either earlier or later, by an art which ≈øome can v≈øe. All which being declared. I then ≈øuppo≈øe enough is ≈øpoken for an introduction to this worke, referring many other things to the ≈øeuerall directions in the Chapters of the booke.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The ≈øeuerall times of the flowring of the≈øe Out-landi≈øh flowers, according to the ≈øeuerall moneths of the yeare.
div.p:
I Intend in this place onely to giue you briefly, the names of ≈øome of the chiefe≈øt of the≈øe Out-landi≈øh flowers, according to the ≈øeuerall moneths of the yeare wherein they flower, that euery one ≈øeeing what ≈øorts of flowers euery moneth yeeldeth, may take of them which they like be≈øt. I begin with Ianuary, as the fir≈øt moneth of the yeare, wherein if the fro≈øts be not extreme, you ≈øhall haue the≈øe flowers of plants; the Chri≈øtmas flower or Helleborus niger verus, Winter wolues bane or Aconitum hyemale, Hepatica or Noble Liuer wort blew and red, and of ≈øhrubbes, the Laurus Tinus or Wilde Bay tree, and Me≈øereon or the dwarfe Bay: but becau≈øe Ianuarie is oftentimes too deepe in fro≈øts and ≈ønow, I therefore referre the Hepaticas vnto the moneth following, which is February, wherein the weather beginneth to be a little milder, and then they will flower much better, as al≈øo diuers ≈øorts of Crocus or Saffron flower will appeare, the little early Summer foole or Leucoium bulbo≈øum, and towards the latter end thereof the Vernall Colchicum, the Dogges tooth Violet or Deus Caminus, and ≈øome Anemones, both ≈øingle and double, which in ≈øome places will flower all the Winter long. March will yeeld more varieties; for be≈øides that it holdeth ≈øome of the flowers of the former moneth, it will yeeld you both the double blew Hepatica, and the white and the blu≈øh ≈øingle: then al≈øo you ≈øhall haue diuers other ≈øorts of Crocus or Saffron flowers, Double yellow Daffodils, Orientall Iacinths and others, the Crowne Imperiall, diuers ≈øorts of early Tulipas, ≈øome ≈øorts of French Cow≈ølips, both tawney, murry, yellow, and blu≈øh, the early Fritillaria or checkerd Daffodill,
and ≈øome other ≈øorts of early Daffodils, and many ≈øorts of Anemones. In Aprill commeth on the pride of the≈øe ≈øtrangers; for herein you may behold all the ≈øorts of Auricula Vr≈øi or Beares Eares, many ≈øorts of Anemones, both ≈øingle and double, both the ≈øorts of Tulipas, the earlier vntill the middle of the moneth, and the later then beginning; which are of ≈øo many different colours, that it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to expre≈ø≈øe them, the white, red, blacke, and yellow Fritillarias, the Mu≈øcari or Muske Grape flower, both a≈øh colour and yellow. Diuers other ≈øorts of Iacinths and Daffodils, both ≈øingle and double, the ≈ømaller ≈øorts of Flowerdeluces, the Veluet Flowerdeluce and double Hony≈øuckles, with diuers others. May likewi≈øe at the beginning ≈øeemeth as glorious as Aprill, although toward the end it doth decline, in regard the heate of the Sunne hath by this time drawne forth all the ≈øtore of natures tendere≈øt dainties, which are v≈øually ≈øpent by the end of this moneth, and then tho≈øe of ≈øtronger con≈øtitution come forward. Herein are to bee ≈øeene at the beginning the middle flowring Tulipas, and at the end the later ≈øort: ≈øome kindes of Daffodils, the Day Lillies, the great white Starre flower, the Flowerdeluce of Con≈øtantinople or the mourning Sable flower, the other ≈øorts of Flowerdeluces. Single and double white Crowfoote, and ≈øingle and double red Crowfoot, the glory of a Garden: the early red Martagon, the Per≈øian Lilly, the yellow Martagon, the Gladiolus or Corne flagge, both white, red, and blu≈øh: the double yellow Ro≈øe, and ≈øome other ≈øorts of Ro≈øes. In Iune doe flower the white and the blu≈øh Martagon, the Martagon Imperiall, the mountaine Lillies, and the other ≈øorts of white and red Lillies, the bulbous Flowerdeluces of diuers ≈øorts, the red flowred Ladies bower, the ≈øingle and double purple flowred Ladies bower, the white Syringa or Pipetree, for the blew Pipe tree flowreth earlier, the white and the yellow Ia≈ømin. Iuly holdeth in flower ≈øome of the Ladies bowers and Ia≈ø
‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ be≈øides doth glory in the Female Bal≈øame apple, the Indian Cre≈ø≈øes or yellow
‚Ä¢ ar ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ purres, the purple Flower-gentle and the Ro≈øe Bay. In Augu≈øt begin ≈øome of the Autumne bulbous flowers to appeare, as the white and the purple Colchicum or Medow Saffron, the purple mountaine Crocus or Saffron flower, the little Autumne Leucoium and Autumne Iacinth, the Italian Starrewort, called of ≈øome the purple Marigold, the Meruaile of Peru or of the world, the Flower of the S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne, the great blew Bell-flower, the great double French Marigold. September flouri≈øheth with the Flower of the Sunne; the Meruaile of the world, the purple Marigold, and blew Bell-flower ≈øpoken of before, and likewi≈øe the other ≈øorts of Medow Saffron, and the double kinde likewi≈øe, the ≈øiluer Crocus, the Autumne yellow Daffodill, Cyclamen al≈øo or Sowbread ≈øhew their flowers in the end of this moneth. October al≈øo will ≈øhew the flowers of Cyclamen, and ≈øome of the Medow Saffrons. In Nouember, as al≈øo ≈øometimes in the moneth before, the party coloured Medow Saffron may bee ≈øeene, that will longe≈øt hold his flower, becau≈øe it is the late≈øt that ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, and the a≈øh coloured mountaine Crocus. And euen December it ≈øelfe will not want the true blacke Hellebor or Chri≈øtmas flower, and the glorious ≈øhew of the Laurus Tinus or wilde Bay tree. Thus haue I ≈øhewed you ≈øome of the flowers for euery moneth, but I referre you to the more ample declarion of them and all the others, vnto the work following.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The true manner and order to encrea≈øe and pre≈øerue all ≈øorts of Gilloflowers, as well by ≈ølippes as ≈øeedes.
div.p:
BEcau≈øe that Carnations and Gilloflowers bee the chiefe≈øt flowers of account in all our Engli≈øh Gardens, I haue thought good to entreate ≈øomewhat amply of them, and that a part by it ≈øelfe, as I ≈øaid a little before, in regard there is ≈øo much to be ≈øaid concerning them, and that if all the matters to be entreated of ≈øhould haue beene in≈øerted in the Chapter of Gilloflowers, it would haue made it too tedious and large, and taken vp too much roome. The particular matters whereof I mean in this place to entreate are the≈øe: How to encrea≈øe Gilloflowers by planting and by
≈øowing, and how to pre≈øerue them being encrea≈øed, both in Summer from noy≈øome and hurtfull vermine that de≈øtroy them, and in Winter from fro≈øts, ≈ønowes, and windes, that ≈øpoile them. There are two wayes of planting, whereby to encrea≈øe the≈øe faire flowers; the one is by ≈ølipping, which is the old and ready v≈øuall way, be≈øt knowne in this Kingdome; the other is more ≈øure, perfect, ready, and of later inuention, videlicet, by laying downe the branches. The way to encrea≈øe Gilloflowers by ≈ølipping, is ≈øo common with all that euer kept any of them, that I thinke mo≈øt per≈øons may thinke meidle, to ≈øpend time to ≈øet downe in writing that which is ≈øo well known vnto all: Yet giue me leaue to tell them that ≈øo might imagine, that (when they haue heard or read what I haue written thereof, if they did know fully as much before) what I here write, was not to informe them, but ≈øuch as did not know the be≈øt, or ≈øo good a way as I teach them: For I am a≈ø≈øured, the greate≈øt number doe v≈øe, and follow the mo≈øt v≈øuall way, and that is not alwaies the be≈øt, e≈øpecially when by good experience a better way is found, and may be learned; and therefore if ≈øome can doe a thing better than others, I thinke it is no ≈øhame to learne it of them. You ≈øhall not then (to take the ≈øure≈øt cour≈øe) take any long ≈øpindled branches, nor tho≈øe branches that haue any young ≈øhootes from the ioynts on them, nor yet ≈øliue or teare any ≈ølippe or branch from the roote; for all the≈øe waies are v≈øuall and common with mo≈øt, which cau≈øeth ≈øo many good rootes to rot and peri≈øh, and al≈øo ≈øo many ≈ølippes to be lo≈øt, when as for the mo≈øt part, not the one halfe, or with ≈øome, not a third part doth grow and thriue of tho≈øe ≈ølippes they ≈øet. And although many that haue ≈øtore of plants, doe not ≈øo much care what hauocke they make to gaine ≈øome, yet to ≈øaue both labour and plants, I doe wi≈øh them to ob≈øerue the≈øe orders: Take from tho≈øe rootes from whence you intend to make your encrea≈øe, tho≈øe ≈øhootes onely that are rea≈øonable ≈øtrong, but yet young, and not either too ≈ømall and ≈ølender, or hauing any ≈øhootes from th ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ vpon them; cut the≈øe ≈ølippes or ≈øhootes off from the ≈øtemme or roote with a knife, as conueniently as the ≈øhoote or branch will permit, that is, either clo≈øe vnto the maine branch, if it be ≈øhort, or leauing a ioynt or two behinde you, if it be long enough, at which it may ≈øhoote anew: When you haue cut off your ≈ølippes, you may either ≈øet them by and by, or el≈øe as the be≈øt Gardiners v≈øe to doe, ca≈øt them into a tubbe or pot with water for a day or two, and then hauing prepared a place conuenient to ≈øet them in, which had neede to bee of the fine≈øt, riche≈øt, and be≈øt mould you can prouide, that they may thriue therein the better, cut off your ≈ølippe clo≈øe at the ioynt, and hauing cut away the lowe≈øt leaues clo≈øe to the ≈øtalke, and the vppermo≈øt euen at the top, with a little ≈øticke make a little hole in the earth, and put your ≈ølippe therein ≈øo deep, as that the vpper leaues may be wholly aboue the ground, (≈øome v≈øe to cleane the ≈øtalke in the middle, and put a little earth or clay within the cleft, but many good and skilfull Gardiners doe not v≈øe it), put the earth a little clo≈øe to the ≈ølippe with your finger and thumbe, and there let it re≈øt, and in this manner doe with as many ≈ølippes as you haue, ≈øetting them ≈øomewhat clo≈øe together, and not too farre in ≈øunder, both to ≈øaue ground and co≈øt thereon, in that a ≈ømall compa≈ø≈øe will ≈øerue for the fir≈øt planting, and al≈øo the better to giue them ≈øhadow: For you mu≈øt remember in any ca≈øe, that the≈øe ≈ølippes new ≈øet, haue no ≈øight of the Sunne, vntill they be well taken in the ground, and ≈øhot aboue ground, and al≈øo that they want not water, both vpon the new planting and after. When the≈øe ≈ølippes are well growne vp, they mu≈øt be tran≈øplanted into ≈øuch other places as you thinke meete; that is, either into the ground in beds, or otherwi≈øe, or into pots, which that you may the more ≈øafely doe, after you haue well watered the ground, for halfe a day before you intend to tran≈øplant them, you ≈øhall ≈øeparate them ≈øeuerally, by putting down a broad pointed knife on each ≈øide of the ≈ølippe, ≈øo cutting it out, take euery one by it ≈øelfe, with the earth cleauing clo≈øe vnto the root, which by rea≈øon of the moi≈øture it had formerly, and that which you gaue pre≈øently before, will be ≈øufficient with any care had, to cau≈øe it to hold fa≈øt vnto the roote for the tran≈øplanting of it: for if the earth were dry, and that it ≈øhould fall away from the roote in the tran≈øplanting, it would hazzard and endanger the roote very much, i ‚Ä¢ it did thriue at all. You mu≈øt remember al≈øo, that vpon the remouing of the≈øe ≈ølips, you ≈øhadow them from the heate of the Sunne for a while with ≈øome ≈øtraw or other thing, vntill they haue taken hold in their new place. Thus although it bee a little more labour and care than the ordinary way is, yet it is ≈øurer, and will giue you plants that
will be ≈øo ≈øtrongly growne before Winter, that with the care hereafter ≈øpecified, you ≈øhall haue them beare flowers the next yeare after, and yeeld you encrea≈øe of ≈ølippes al≈øo. To giue you any ≈øet time, wherein the≈øe ≈ølippes will take roote, and begin to ≈øhoote aboue ground, is very hard to doe; for that euery ≈ølip, or yet euery kinde of Gilloflower is not alike apt to grow; nor is euery earth in like manner fit to produce and bring forward the ≈ølippes that are ≈øet therein: but if both the ≈ølippe be apt to grow, and the earth of the be≈øt, fit to produce, I thinke within a fortnight or three weekes, you ≈øhall ≈øee them begin to put forth young leaues in the middle, or el≈øe it may be a moneth and more before you ≈øhall ≈øee any ≈øpringing. The be≈øt time likewi≈øe when to plant, is a ≈øpeciall thing to be knowne, and of as great con≈øequence as any thing el≈øe: For if you ≈ølippe and ≈øet in September, as many v≈øe to doe, or yet in Augu≈øt, as ≈øome may thinke will doe well, yet (vnle≈ø≈øe they be the mo≈øt ordinary ≈øorts, which are likely to grow at any time, and in any place) the mo≈øt of them, if not all, will either a≈ø≈øuredly peri≈øh, or neuer pro≈øper well: for the more excellent and dainty the Gilloflower is, the more tender for the mo≈øt part, and hard to nur≈øe vp will the ≈ølippes be. The be≈øt time therefore is, that you cut off ≈øuch ≈ølippes as are likely, and ≈øuch as your rootes may ≈øpare, from the beginning of May vntill the middle of Iune at the furthe≈øt, and order them as I haue ≈øhewed you before, that ≈øo you may haue faire plants, plenty of flowers, and encrea≈øe ≈øufficient for new ≈øupply, without offence or lo≈ø≈øe of your ≈øtore. For the enriching likewi≈øe of your earth, wherein you ≈øhall plant your ≈ølippes, that they may the better thriue and pro≈øper, diuers haue v≈øed diuers ≈øorts of manure; as ≈øtable ≈øoyle of hor≈øe, bea≈øts or kine, of ≈øheepe, and pigeons, all which are very good when they are thoroughly turned to mould, to mixe with your other earth, or being ≈øteeped in water, may ≈øerue to water the earth at times, and turned in with it. And ≈øome haue likewi≈øe proued Tanners earth, that is, their barke, which after they haue v≈øed, doth lye on heapes and rot in their yards, or the like mould from wood-≈øtackes or yards; but e≈øpecially, and beyond all other is commended the Willow earth, that is, that mould which is found in the hollow of old Willow trees, to be the mo≈øt principall to mixe with other good earth for this purpo≈øe. And as I haue now giuen you directions for the fir≈øt way to encrea≈øe them by ≈ølipping, ≈øo before I come to the other way, let mee giue you a caueat or two for the pre≈øeruing of them, when they are beginning to runne vtterly to decay and peri≈øh. The one is, that whereas many are ouer greedy to haue their plants to giue them flowers, and therefore let them runne all to flower, ≈øo farre ≈øpending them≈øelues thereby, that after they haue done flowring, they grow ≈øo weake, hauing out ≈øpent them≈øelues, that they cannot po≈ø≈øibly be pre≈øerued from the iniuries of the ≈øucceeding Winter; you ≈øhall therefore keepe the kinde of any ≈øort you are delighted withall, if you carefully looke that too many branches doe not runne vp and ≈øpindle for flowers, but rather either cut ≈øome of them downe, before they are run vp too high, within two or three ioynts of the rootes; or el≈øe plucke away the innermo≈øt leaues where it ≈øpringeth forwards, which you ≈øee in the middle of euery branch, before it be runne vp too high, which will cau≈øe them to breake out the fa≈øter into ≈ølips and ≈øuckers at the ioynts, to hinder their forward luxurie, and to pre≈øerue them the longer: The other is, If you ≈øhall perceiue any of your Gilloflower leaues to change their naturall fre≈øh verdure, and turne yellowi≈øh, or begin to wither in anie part or branch thereof, it is a ≈øure ≈øigne that the roote is infected with ≈øome cancker or rottenne≈ø≈øe, and will ≈øoone ≈øhew it ≈øelfe in all the re≈øt of the branches, whereby the plant will quickly be lo≈øt: to pre≈øerue it therefore, you ≈øhall be time, before it be runne too farre, (for otherwi≈øe it is impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øaue it) either couer all or mo≈øt of the branches with fre≈øh earth, or el≈øe take the faire≈øt ≈ølippes from it, as many as you can po≈ø≈øibly, and ca≈øt them into a pot or tubbe with water, and let them there abide for two or three daies at the lea≈øt: the fir≈øt way hath recouered many, being taken in time. Thus you ≈øhall ≈øee them recouer their former ≈øtiffene≈ø≈øe and colour, and then you may plant them as you haue beene heretofore directed; and although many of them may peri≈øh, yet ≈øhall you haue ≈øome of them that will grow to continue the kinde againe. The other or ≈øecond way to encrea≈øe Gilloflowers by planting, is, as I ≈øaid before, by in laying or laying downe the branches of them, and is a way of later inuention, and as frequently v≈øed, not onely for the tawney or yellow Gilloflower, and all the varieties therof, but with the other kinds of Gilloflowers, whereof experience hath ≈øhewed
that they will likewi≈øe take if they be ≈øo v≈øed; the manner whereof is thus: You mu≈øt choo≈øe out the younge≈øt, likelie≈øt, and lowe≈øt branches that are neare≈øt the ground (for the vpper branches will ≈øooner breake at the ioynt, than bend downe ≈øo low into the earth, without ≈øome pot with earth rai≈øed vp vnto them) and cut it on the vnder≈øide thereof vpwards at the ≈øecond ioynt next vnto the roote, to the middle of the branch, and no more, and not quite thorough in any ca≈øe, and then from that ≈øecond ioynt vnto the third, ≈ølit or cut the branch in the middle longwi≈øe, that ≈øo it may be the more ea≈øily bended into the ground, the cut ioynt ≈øeeming like the end of a ≈ølippe, when you haue bended downe the branch where it is cut into the ground (which mu≈øt bee done very gently for feare of breaking) with a little ≈øticke or two thru≈øt ≈ølopewi≈øe, cro≈ø≈øe ouer it, keepe it downe within the earth, and rai≈øe vp ≈øufficient earth ouer it, that there it may lye and take roote, which commonly will be effected within ≈øixe weekes or two moneths in the Summer time, and then (or longer if you doubt the time too ≈øhort for it to take ≈øufficient roote) you may take or cut it away, and tran≈øplant it where you thinke good, yet ≈øo as in any ca≈øe you ≈øhadow it from the heate of the Sunne, vntill it haue taken good hold in the ground. The other way to encrea≈øe Gilloflowers, is by ≈øowing the ≈øeede: It is not v≈øuall with all ≈øorts of Gilloflowers to giue ≈øeede, but ≈øuch of them as doe yeeld ≈øeede may be encrea≈øed thereby, in the ≈øame manner as is here ≈øet downe. The Orange tawney Gilloflower and the varieties thereof is the mo≈øt v≈øuall kinde, (and it is a kinde by it ≈øelfe, how various ≈øoeuer the plants be that ri≈øe from the ≈øeede) that doth giue ≈øeede, and is ≈øowne, and from thence ari≈øeth ≈øo many varieties of colours, both plaine and mixt, both ≈øingle and double, that one can hardly ≈øet them downe in writing: yet ≈øuch as I haue ob≈øerued and marked, you ≈øhall finde expre≈ø≈øed in the Chapter of Gilloflowers in the worke following. Fir≈øt therefore make choi≈øe of your ≈øeede that you intend to ≈øowe (if you doe not de≈øire to haue as many more ≈øingle flowers as double) that it bee taken from double flowers, and not from ≈øingle, and from the be≈øt colours, how≈øoeuer ≈øome may boa≈øt to haue had double and ≈øtript flowers from the ≈øeede of a ≈øingle one; which if it were ≈øo, yet one Swallow (as we ≈øay) maketh no Summer, nor a thing comming by chance cannot bee reckoned for a certaine and con≈øtant rule; you may be a≈ø≈øured they will not v≈øually doe ≈øo: but the be≈øt, faire≈øt, and mo≈øt double flowers come alwaies, or for the mo≈øt part, from the ≈øeede of tho≈øe flowers that were be≈øt, faire≈øt, and mo≈øt double, and I doe adui≈øe you to take the be≈øt and mo≈øt double: for euen from them you ≈øhall haue ≈øingle ones enow, you neede not to ≈øowe any wor≈øer ≈øort. And againe, ≈øee that your ≈øeede bee new, of the la≈øt yeares gathering, and al≈øo that it was full ripe before it was gathered, le≈øt you lo≈øe your labour, or mi≈ø≈øe of your purpo≈øe, which is, to haue faire and double flowers. Hauing now made choi≈øe of your ≈øeede, and prepared you a bedde to ≈øowe them on, the earth whereof mu≈øt be rich and good, and likewi≈øe ≈øifted to make it the finer; for the better it is, the better ≈øhall your profit and plea≈øure bee: hereon, being fir≈øt made leuell, plaine, and ≈ømooth, ≈øowe your ≈øeede ≈øomewhat thinne, and not too thicke in any ca≈øe, and as euenly as you can, that they be not too many in one place, and too few in another, which afterwards couer with fine ≈øifted earth ouer them about one fingers thickne≈ø≈øe; let this be done in the middle of Aprill, if the time of the yeare be temperate, and not too cold, or el≈øe ≈øtay vntill the end of the moneth: after they are ≈øprung vp and growne to be ≈øomewhat bigge, let them bee drawne forth that are too clo≈øe and neare one vnto another, and plant them in ≈øuch place where they ≈øhall continue, ≈øo that they ≈øtand halfe a yard of ground di≈øtance a≈øunder, which after the planting, let be ≈øhadowed for a time, as is before ≈øpecified; and this may bee done in the end of Iuly, or ≈øooner if there becau≈øe. I haue not ≈øet downe in all this di≈øcour≈øe of planting, tran≈øplanting, ≈øowing, ≈øetting, &c. any mention of watering tho≈øe ≈ølips or plants, not doubting but that euery ones rea≈øon will induce them to thinke, that they cannot pro≈øper without watering: But let this Caueat be a ≈øufficient remembrance vnto you, that you neuer water any of the≈øe Gilloflowers, nor yet indeede any other fine herbe or plant with cold water, ≈øuch as you haue pre≈øently before drawne out from a pumpe or Well, &c. but with ≈øuch water as hath ≈øtood open in the aire in a ci≈øterne, tubbe, or pot, for one whole day at the lea≈øt; if it be two or three daies it will be neuer the wor≈øe, but rather the better, as I haue related before: yet take e≈øpeciall heede that you doe not giue them too much to ouer-glut them at any time, but temperately to irrorate,
bedew or ≈øprinkle them often. From the ≈øeedes of the≈øe Gilloflowers hath ri≈øen both white, red, blu≈øh, ≈øtamell, tawny lighter and ≈øadder, marbled, ≈øpeckled, ≈øtriped, flaked, and that in diuers manners, both ≈øingle and double flowers, as you ≈øhall ≈øee them ≈øet downe in a more ample manner in the Chapter of Gilloflowers. And thus much for their encrea≈øe by the two wayes of planting and ≈øowing: For as for a third way, by grafting one into or vpon another, I know none ≈øuch to be true, nor to be of any more worth than an old Wiues tale, both nature, rea≈øon, and experience, all conte≈øting again≈øt ≈øuch an idle fancy, let men make what o≈øtentation they plea≈øe. It now re≈øteth, that we al≈øo ≈øhew you the manner how to pre≈øerue them, as well in Summer from all noy≈øome and hurtfull things, as in the Winter and Spring from the ≈øharp and chilling colds, and the ≈øharpe and bitter killing windes in March. The hurtfull things in the Summer are e≈øpecially the≈øe, too much heate of the Sunne which ≈øcorcheth them, which you mu≈øt be carefull to preuent, by placing boughes, boords, clothes or mats, &c. before them, if they bee in the ground; or el≈øe if they bee in pots, to remoue into them into the ≈øhadow, to giue them refre≈øhing from the heate, and giue them water al≈øo for their life: too much water, or too little is another annoyance, which you mu≈øt order as you ≈øee there is iu≈øt cau≈øe, by withholding or giuing them water gently out of a watering pot, and not ca≈øt on by di≈øhfuls: Some al≈øo to water their Gilloflowers, v≈øe to ≈øet their pots into tubbes or pots halfe full of water, that ≈øo the water may ≈øoake in at the lower holes in each flower pot, to giue moi≈øture to the roots of the Gilloflowers onely, without ca≈øting any water vpon the leaues, and a≈ø≈øuredly it is an excellent way to moi≈øten the rootes ≈øo ≈øufficiently at one time, that it doth ≈øaue a great deale of paines many other times. Earwickes are a mo≈øt infe≈øtuous vermine, to ≈øpoyle the whole beauty of your flowers, and that in one night or day; for the≈øe creatures delighting to creepe into any hollow or ≈øhadowie place, doe creepe into the long greene pods of the Gilloflowers, and doe eate away the white bottomes of their leaues, which are ≈øweete, whereby the leaues of the flowers being loo≈øe, doe either fall away of them≈øelues before, or when they are gathered, or handled, or pre≈øently wither within the pods before they are gathered, and blowne away with the winde. To auoide which inconuenience, many haue deui≈øed many waies and inuentions to de≈øtroy them, as pots with double verges or brimmes, containing a hollow gutter betweene them, which being filled with water, will not ≈øuffer the≈øe ≈ømall vermine to pa≈ø≈øe ouer it to the Gilloflowers to ≈øpoile them. Others haue v≈øed old ≈øhooes, and ≈øuch like hollow things to bee ≈øet by them to take them in: but the be≈øt and mo≈øt v≈øuall things now v≈øed, are eyther long hollow canes, or el≈øe bea≈øts hoofes, which being turned downe vpon ≈øtickes ends ≈øet into the ground, or into the pots of earth, will ≈øoone draw into them many Earwickes, lying hid therein from ≈øunne, winde, and raine, and by care and diligence may ≈øoone bee de≈øtroyed, if euery morning and euening one take the hoofes gently off from the ≈øtickes, and knocking them again≈øt the ground in a plain allie, ≈øhake out all the Earwicks that are crept into them, which quickly with ones foot may be trode to peeces. For ≈øodain bla≈øting with thunder and lightening, or fierce ≈øharpe windes, &c. I know no other remedy, vnle≈ø≈øe you can couer them therefrom when you fir≈øt fore≈øee the danger, but patiently to abide the lo≈ø≈øe, what≈øoeuer ≈øome haue adui≈øed, to lay litter about them to auoide bla≈øting; for if any ≈øhall make tryall thereof, I am in doubt, he ≈øhall more endanger his rootes thereby, being the Summer time, when any ≈øuch feare of bla≈øting is, than any wi≈øe ≈øaue them from it, or doe them any good. For the Winter pre≈øeruation of them, ≈øome haue adui≈øed to couer them with Bee-hiues, or el≈øe with ≈ømall Willow ≈øtickes, prickt cro≈ø≈øewi≈øe into the ground ouer your flowers, and bowed archwi≈øe, and with litter laid thereon, to couer the Gilloflowers quite ouer, after they haue beene ≈øprinkled with ≈øope a≈øhes and lyme mixt together: and this way is commended by ≈øome that haue written thereof, to be ≈øuch an admirable defence vnto them in Winter, that neither Ants, nor Snailes, nor Earwickes ≈øhall touch them, becau≈øe of the ≈øope a≈øhes and lyme, and neyther fro≈øts nor ≈øtormes ≈øhall hurt them, becau≈øe of the litter which ≈øo well will defend them; and hereby al≈øo your Gilloflowers will bee ready to flower, not onely in the Spring very early, but euen all the Winter. But who≈øoeuer ≈øhall follow the≈øe directions, may peraduenture finde them in ≈øome part true, as they are there ≈øet downe for the Winter time, and while they are kept clo≈øe and couered; but let them bee a≈ø≈øured,
that all ≈øuch plants, or the mo≈øt part of them, will certainely peri≈øh and dye before the Summer be at an end: for the ≈øope a≈øhes and lyme will burne vp and ≈øpoile any herbe; and againe, it is impo≈ø≈øible for any plant that is kept ≈øo warme in Winter, to abide eyther the cold or the winde in the Spring following, or any heate of the Sun, but that both of them will ≈øcorch them, and carry them quite away. One great hurt vnto them, and to all other herbes that wee pre≈øerue in Winter, is to ≈øuffer the ≈ønow to lye vpon them any time after it is fallen, for that it doth ≈øo chill them, that the Sunne afterward, although in Winter, doth ≈øcorch them and burne them vp: looke therefore vnto your Gilloflowers in tho≈øe times, and ≈øhake or ≈øtrike off the ≈ønow gently off from them, not ≈øuffering it to abide on them any day or night if you can; for a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe, if it doth not abide on them, the better they will be. The fro≈øts likewi≈øe is another great annoyance vnto them, to corrupt the rootes, and to cau≈øe them to ≈øwell, rot, and breake: to preuent which inconuenience, I would adui≈øe you to take the ≈øtraw or litter of your hor≈øe ≈øtable, and lay ≈øome thereof about euery roote of your Gilloflowers (e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the be≈øt account) clo≈øe vnto them vpon the ground, but be as carefull as you can, that none thereof lye vpon the greene leaues, or as little as may be, and by this onely way haue they been better defended from the fro≈øts that ≈øpoile them in Winter, then by any other that I haue ≈øeen or knowne. The windes in March, and Sunne≈øhine dayes then, are one of the greate≈øt inconueniences that happeneth vnto them: for they that haue had hundreds of plants, that haue kept faire and greene all the Winter vntill the beginning or middle of March, before the end thereof, haue had ≈øcarce one of many, that either hath not vtterly peri≈øhed, or been ≈øo tainted, that quickly after haue not been lo≈øt; which hath happened chiefly by the neglect of the≈øe cautions before ≈øpecified, or in not defending them from the bitter ≈øharpe windes and ≈øunne in this moneth of March. You ≈øhall therefore for their better pre≈øeruation, be≈øides the litter laid about the rootes, which I adui≈øe you not to remoue as yet, ≈øhelter them ≈øomewhat from the windes, with eyther bottomle≈ø≈øe pots, pales, or ≈øuch like things, to keep away the violent force both of windes and ≈øun for that moneth, and for ≈øometime before & after it al≈øo: yet ≈øo, that they be not couered clo≈øe aboue, but open to receiue ayre & raine. Some al≈øo v≈øe to wind withes of hey or ≈øtraw about the rootes of their Gilloflowers, and fa≈øten them with ≈øtickes thru≈øt into the ground, which ≈øerue very well in the ≈øtead of the other. Thus haue I ≈øhewed you the whole pre≈øeruation of the≈øe worthy and dainty flowers, with the whole manner of ordering them for their encrea≈øe: if any one haue any other better way, I ≈øhall be as willing to learne it of them, as I haue beene to giue them or any others the knowledge of that I haue here ≈øet downe.

div.head: CHAP. IX. That there is not any art whereby any flower may be made to grow double, that was naturally ≈øingle, nor of any other ≈øent or colour than it fir≈øt had by nature; nor that the ≈øowing or planting of herbes one deeper than other, will cau≈øe them to be in flower one after another, euery moneth in the yeare.
div.p:
THe wonderfull de≈øire that many haue to ≈øee faire, double, and ≈øweete flowers, hath tran≈øported them beyond both rea≈øon and nature, feigning and boa≈øting often of what they would haue, as if they had it. And I thinke, from this de≈øire and boa≈øting hath ri≈øen all the fal≈øe tales and reports, of making flowers double as they li≈øt, and of giuing them colour and ≈øent as they plea≈øe, and to flower likewi≈øe at what time they will, I doubt not, but that ≈øome of the≈øe errours are ancient, and continued long by tradition, and others are of later inuention: and therefore the more to be condemned, that men of wit and iudgement in the≈øe dayes ≈øhould expo≈øe them≈øelues in their writings, to be rather laughed at, then beleeued for ≈øuch idle tales. And although in the contradiction of them, I know I ≈øhall vndergoe many calumnies, yet notwith≈øtanding, I will endeauour to ≈øet downe and declare ≈øo much, as I hope may by rea≈øon
per≈øwade many in the truth, although I cannot hope of all, ≈øome being ≈øo ≈øtrongly wedded to their owne will, and the errours they haue beene bred in, that no rea≈øon may alter them. Fir≈øt therefore I ≈øay, that if there were any art to make ≈øome flowers to grow double, that naturally were ≈øingle, by the ≈øame art, all ≈øorts of flowers that are ≈øingle by nature, may be made to grow double: but the ≈øorts of flowers that are ≈øingle by nature, whereof ≈øome are double, were neuer made double by art; for many ≈øorts abide ≈øtill ≈øingle, whereof there was neuer ≈øeene double: and therefore there is no ≈øuch art in any mans knowledge to bring it to pa≈ø≈øe. If any man ≈øhall ≈øay, that becau≈øe there are many flowers double, whereof there are ≈øingle al≈øo of the ≈øame kin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , as for example, Violets, Marigolds, Dai≈øyes, Daffodils, Anemones, and many other, that therefore tho≈øe double flowers were ≈øo made by the art of man: viz. by the ob≈øeruation of the change of the Moone, the con≈øtellations or coniunctions of Planets, or ≈øome other Starres or cele≈øtiall bodies. Although I doe confe≈ø≈øe and acknowledge, that I thinke ≈øome con≈øtellations, and peraduenture changes of the Moone, &c. were appointed by the God of nature, as conducing and helping to the making of tho≈øe flowers double, that nature hath ≈øo produced; yet I doe deny, that any man hath or ≈øhall euer be able to proue, that it was done by any art of man, or that any man can tell the true cau≈øes and ≈øea≈øons, what changes of the Moone, or con≈øtellations of the Planets, wrought together for the producing of tho≈øe double flowers, or can imitate nature, or rather the God of nature, to doe the like. If it ≈øhall bee demanded, From whence then came the≈øe double flowers that we haue, if they were not ≈øo made by art? I an≈øwer, that a≈ø≈øuredly all ≈øuch flowers did fir≈øt grow wilde, and were ≈øo found double, as they doe now grow in Gardens, but for how long before they were found they became double, no man can tell; we onely haue them as nature hath produced them, and ≈øo they remaine. Againe, if any ≈øhall ≈øay, that it is likely that the≈øe double flowers were forced ≈øo to be, by the often planting and tran≈øplanting of them, becau≈øe it is ob≈øerued in mo≈øt of them, that if they ≈øtand long in any one place, and not be often remoued, they will grow ≈øtill le≈ø≈øe double, and in the end turne ≈øingle. I doe confe≈ø≈øe, that Facilior e≈øt de≈øcen≈øus qu√†m a≈øcen≈øus, and that the vnfruitfulne≈ø≈øe of the ground they are planted in, or the neglect or little care had of them, or the growing of them too thicke or too long, are oftentimes a cau≈øe of the dimini≈øhing of the flowers doublene≈ø≈øe; but withall you ≈øhall ob≈øerue, that the ≈øame rootes that did beare double flowers (and not any other that neuer were double before) haue returned to their former doublene≈ø≈øe againe, by good ordering and looking vnto: ≈øingle flowers haue only beene made ≈øomewhat fairer or larger, by being planted in the richer and more fruitfull ground of the Garden, than they were found wilde by nature; but neuer made to grow double, as that which is naturally ≈øo found of it ≈øelfe: For I will ≈øhew you mine owne experience in the matter. I haue been as inqui≈øitiue as any man might be, with euery one I knew, that made any ≈øuch report, or that I thought could ≈øay any thing therein, but I neuer could finde any one, that could a≈ø≈øuredly re≈øolue me, that he knew certainly any ≈øuch thing to be done: all that they could ≈øay was but report, for the ob≈øeruation of the Moone, to remoue plants before the change, that is, as ≈øome ≈øay, the full of the Moone, others the new Moone, whereupon I haue made tryall at many times, and in many ≈øorts of plants, accordingly, and as I thought fit, by planting & tran≈øplanting them, but I could neuer ≈øee the effect de≈øired, but rather in many of them the lo≈ø≈øe of my plants. And were there indeed ≈øuch a certaine art, to make ≈øingle flowers to grow double, it would haue beene knowne certainly to ≈øome that would practi≈øe it, and there are ≈øo many ≈øingle flowers, whereof there were neuer any of the kinde ≈øeene double, that to produce ≈øuch of them to be double, would procure both credit and coyne enough to him that ≈øhould v≈øe it; but Vltra po≈ø≈øe non e≈øt e≈ø≈øe: and therefore let no man beleeue any ≈øuch reports, bee they neuer ≈øo ancient; for they are but meere tales and fables. Concerning colours and ≈øents, the many rules and directions extant in manie mens writings, to cau≈øe flowers to grow yellow, red, greene, or white, that neuer were ≈øo naturally, as al≈øo to be of the ≈øent of Cinamon, Muske, &c. would almo≈øt per≈øwade any, that the matters thus ≈øet downe by ≈øuch per≈øons, and with ≈øome ≈øhew of probability, were con≈øtant and a≈ø≈øured proofes thereof: but when they come to the triall, they all vani≈øh away like ≈ømoake. I will in a few words ≈øhew you the matters and manners of their proceedings to effect this purpo≈øe: Fir≈øt (they ≈øay) if you ≈øhall ≈øteepe
your ≈øeedes in the lees of red Wine, you ≈øhall haue the flowers of tho≈øe plants to be of a purple colour. If you will haue Lillies or Gilloflowers to be of a Scarlet red colour, you ≈øhall put Vermillion or Cynaber betweene the rinde and the ≈ømall heads growing about the roote: if you will haue them blew, you ≈øhall di≈ø≈øolue Azur or By≈øe between the rinde and the heads: if yellow, Orpiment: if greene, Vardigrea≈øe, and thus of any other colour. Others doe adui≈øe to open the head of the roote, and poure into it any colour di≈ø≈øolued, ≈øo that there be no fretting or corroding thing therein for feare of hurting the roote, and looke what colour you put in, iu≈øt ≈øuch or neare vnto it ≈øhall the colour of the flower bee. Some againe doe adui≈øe to water the plants you would haue changed, with ≈øuch coloured liquor as you de≈øire the flower to be of, and they ≈øhall grow to be ≈øo. Al≈øo to make Ro≈øes to bee yellow, that you ≈øhould graft a white Ro≈øe (≈øome ≈øay a Damaske) vpon a Broome ≈øtalke, and the flower will be yellow, ≈øuppo≈øing becau≈øe the Broome flower is yellow, therefore the Ro≈øe will be yellow. Some affirme the like, if a Ro≈øe be grafted on a Barbery bu≈øh, becau≈øe both the blo≈ø≈øome and the barke of the Barbery is yellow, &c. In the like manner for ≈øents, they haue ≈øet downe in their writings, that by putting Cloues, Muske, Cinamon, Benzoin, or any other ≈øuch ≈øweete thing, brui≈øed with Ro≈øe water, between the barke and the body of trees, the fruit of them will ≈ømell and ta≈øte of the ≈øame that is put vnto them; and if they bee put vnto the toppe of the rootes, or el≈øe bound vnto the head of the roote, they will cau≈øe the flowers to ≈ømell of that ≈øent the matter put vnto them is of: as al≈øo to ≈øteep the ≈øeeds of Ro≈øes, and other plants in the water of ≈øuch like ≈øweet things, and then to ≈øowe them, and water them morning and euening with ≈øuch like liquor, vntill they be growne vp; be≈øides a number of ≈øuch like rules and directions ≈øet downe in bookes, ≈øo confidently, as if the matters were without all doubt or que≈øtion: whenas without all doubt and que≈øtion I will a≈ø≈øure you, that they are all but meere idle tales & fancies, without all rea≈øon or truth, or ≈øhadow of rea≈øon or truth: For ≈øents and colours are both ≈øuch qualities as follow the e≈ø≈øence of plants, euen as formes are al≈øo; and one may as well make any plant to grow of what forme you will, as to make it of what ≈øent or colour you will; and if any man can forme plants at his will and plea≈øure, he can doe as much as God him≈øelfe that created them. For the things they would adde vnto the plants to giue them colour, are all corporeall, or of a bodily ≈øub≈øtance, and what≈øoeuer ≈øhould giue any colour vnto a liuing and growing plant, mu≈øt be ≈øpirituall: for no ≈øolide corporeall ≈øub≈øtance can ioyne it ≈øelfe with the life and e≈ø≈øence of an herbe or tree, and the ≈øpirituall part of the colour thereof is not the ≈øame with the bodily ≈øub≈øtance, but is a meere vapour that ri≈øeth from the ≈øub≈øtance, and feedeth the plant, whereby it groweth, ≈øo that there is no ground or colour of rea≈øon, that a ≈øub≈øtantiall colour ≈øhould giue colour to a growing herbe or tree: but for ≈øent (which is a meere vapour) you will ≈øay there is more probability. Yet con≈øider al≈øo, that what ≈øweete ≈øent ≈øoeuer you binde or put vnto the rootes of herbes or trees, mu≈øt be either buried, or as good as buried in the earth, or barke of the tree, whereby the ≈øub≈øtance will in a ≈ømall time corrupt and rot, and before it can ioyne it ≈øelfe with the life, ≈øpirit, and e≈ø≈øence of the plant, the ≈øent al≈øo will peri≈øh with the ≈øub≈øtance: For no heterogeneall things can bee mixed naturally together, as Iron and Clay; and no other thing but homogeneall, can be nouri≈øhment or conuertible into the ≈øub≈øtance of man or bea≈øt: And as the ≈øtomach of man or bea≈øt altereth both formes, ≈øents, and colours of all dige≈øtible things; ≈øo what≈øoeuer ≈øent or colour is whol≈øome, and not poy≈øonfull to nature, being receiued into the body of man or bea≈øt, doth neither change the bloud or skinne into that colour or ≈øent was receiued: no more doth any colour or ≈øent to any plant; for the plants are onely nouri≈øhed by the moi≈øture they draw naturally vnto them, be it of wine or any other liquor is put vnto them, and not by any corporeall ≈øub≈øtance, or heterogeneall vapour or ≈øent, becau≈øe the earth like vnto the ≈øtomach doth ≈øoone alter them, before they are conuerted into the nature and ≈øub≈øtance of the plant. Now for the la≈øt part I vndertooke to confute, that no man can by art make all flowers to ≈øpring at what time of the yeare hee will; although, as I haue here before ≈øhewed, there are flowers for euery moneth of the yeare, yet I hope there is not any one, that hath any knowledge in flowers and gardening, but knoweth that the flowers that appeare and ≈øhew them≈øelues in the ≈øeuerall moneths of the yeare, are not one and the ≈øame, and ≈øo made to flower by art; but that they are ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of plants, which
will flower naturally and con≈øtantly in the ≈øame moneths one yeare, that they v≈øe to doe in another, or with but little alteration, if the yeares proue not alike kindly: As for example, tho≈øe plants that doe flower in Ianuary and February, will by no art or indu≈øtry of man be cau≈øed to flower in Summer or in Autumne; and tho≈øe that flower in Aprill and May, will not flower in Ianuary or February; or tho≈øe in Iuly, Augu≈øt, &c. either in the Winter or Spring: but euery one knoweth their owne appointed naturall times, which they con≈øtantly ob≈øerue and keepe, according to the temperature of the yeare, or the temper of the climate, being further North or South, to bring them on earlier or later, as it doth with all other fruits, flowers, and growing greene herbes, &c. except that by chance, ≈øome one or other extraordinarily may be hindered in their due ≈øea≈øon of flowring, and ≈øo giue their flowers out of time, or el≈øe to giue their flowers twice in the yeare, by the ≈øuperaboundance of nouri≈øhment, or the mildne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øea≈øon, by moderate ≈øhowers of raine, &c. as it ≈øometimes al≈øo happeneth with fruits, which chance, as it is ≈øeldome, and not con≈øtant, ≈øo we then terme it but Lu≈øus naturae: or el≈øe by forcing them in hot ≈øtoues, which then will peri≈øh, when they haue giuen their flowers or fruits. It is not then, as ≈øome haue written, the ≈øowing of the ≈øeedes of Lillies, or any other plants a foote deepe, or halfe a foote deepe, or two inches deepe, that will cau≈øe them to be in flower one after another, as they are ≈øowne euery moneth of the yeare; for it were too gro≈ø≈øe to thinke, that any man of rea≈øon and iudgement would ≈øo beleeue. Nor is it likewi≈øe in the power of any man, to make the ≈øame plants to abide a moneth, two, or three, or longer in their beauty of flowring, then naturally they v≈øe to doe; for I thinke that were no humane art, but a ≈øupernaturall worke. For nature ≈øtill bendeth and tendeth to perfection, that is, after flowring to giue fruit or ≈øeede; nor can it bee hindered in the cour≈øe thereof without manife≈øt danger of de≈øtruction, euen as it is in all other fruit-bearing creatures, which ≈øtay no longer, then their appointed time is naturall vnto them, without apparent damage. Some things I grant may be ≈øo ordered in the planting, that according to that order and time which is ob≈øerued in their planting, they ≈øhall ≈øhew forth their faire flowers, and they are Anemones, which will in that manner, that I haue ≈øhewed in the worke following, flower in ≈øeuerall moneths of the yeare; which thing as it is incident to none or very few other plants, and is found out but of late, ≈øo likewi≈øe is it knowne but vnto a very few. Thus haue I ≈øhewed you the true ≈øolution of the≈øe doubts: And although they haue not beene amplified with ≈øuch Philo≈øophicall arguments and rea≈øons, as one of greater learning might haue done, yet are they truely and ≈øincerely ≈øet downe, that they may ≈øerue tanquam galcatum, again≈øt all the calumnies and obiections of wilfull and obdurate per≈øons, that will not be reformed. As fir≈øt, that all double flowers were ≈øo found wilde, being the worke of nature alone, and not the art of any man, by planting or tran≈øplanting, at or before the new or full Moone, or any other ob≈øeruation of time, that hath cau≈øed the flower to grow double, that naturally was ≈øingle: Secondly, that the rules and directions, to cau≈øe flowers to bee of contrary or different colours or ≈øents, from that they were or would be naturally, are meere fancies of men, without any ground of rea≈øon or truth. And thirdly, that there is no power or art in man, to cau≈øe flowers to ≈øhew their beauty diuers moneths before their naturall time, nor to abide in their beauty longer then the appointed naturall time for euery one of them.

div.head: Corona Imperialis. The Crowne Imperiall.
div.p:
BEcau≈øe the Lilly is the more ≈øtately flower among manie: and among≈øt the wonderfull varietie of Lillies, knowne to vs in the≈øe daies, much more then in former times, whereof ≈øome are white, others blu≈øh, ≈øome purple, others red or yellow, ≈øome ≈øpotted, others without ≈øpots, ≈øome ≈øtanding vpright, others hanging or turning downewards, The Crowne Imperiall for his ≈øtately beautifulne≈øs, de≈øerueth the fir≈øt place in this our Garden of delight, to be here entreated of before all other Lillies: but becau≈øe it is ≈øo well knowne to mo≈øt per≈øons, being in a manner euery where common, I ≈øhall neede onely to giue you a relation of the chiefe parts thereof (as I intend in ≈øuch other things) which are the≈øe: The roote is yellowi≈øh on the out≈øide, compo≈øed of fewer, but much thicker ≈øcales, then any other Lilly but the Per≈øian, and doth grow ≈øometimes to be as great as a pretty bigge childes head, but ≈øomewhat flat withall, from the ≈øides whereof, and not from the bottome, it ≈øhooteth forth thicke long fibres, which peri≈øh euery yeare, hauing a hole in the mid≈øt thereof, at the end of the yeare, when the old ≈øtalke is dry and withered, and out of the which a new ≈øtalke doth ≈øpring againe (from a bud or head to be ≈øeen within the hollowne≈ø≈øe on the one ≈øide) the yeare following: the ≈øtalke then filling vp the hollowne≈ø≈øe, ri≈øeth vp three or foure foote high, being great, round, and of a purpli≈øh colour at the bottome, but greene aboue, be≈øet from thence to the middle thereof with many long and broad greene leaues, very like to the leaues of our ordinary white Lilly, but ≈øomewhat ≈øhorter and narrower, confu≈øedly without order, and from the middle is bare or naked without leaues, for a certaine ≈øpace vpwards, and then beareth foure, ≈øixe, or tenne flowers, more or le≈ø≈øe, according to the age of the plant, and the fertility of the ≈øoyle where it groweth: The buddes at the fir≈øt appearing are whiti≈øh, ≈øtanding vpright among a bu≈øh or tuft of greene leaues, ≈ømaller then tho≈øe below, and ≈øtanding aboue the flowers, after a while they turne them≈øelues, and hang downewards euerie one vpon his owne foote≈øtalke, round about the great ≈øtemme or ≈øtalke, ≈øometimes of an euen depth, and other while one lower or higher than another, which flowers are neare the forme of an ordinary Lilly, yet ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer and clo≈øer, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe leaues of an Orange colour, ≈øtriped with purpli≈øh lines and veines, which adde a great grace to the flowers: At the bottome of the flower next vnto the ≈øtalke, euery
leafe thereof hath on the out≈øide a certaine bunch or eminence, of a darke purpli≈øh colour, and on the in≈øide there lyeth in tho≈øe hollow bunched places, certaine cleare drops of water like vnto pearles, of a very ≈øweete ta≈øte almo≈øt like ≈øugar: in the mid≈øt of each flower is a long white ≈øtile or pointell, forked or diuided at the end, and ≈øixe white chiues tipt with yellowi≈øh pendents, ≈øtanding clo≈øe about it: after the flowers are pa≈øt, appeare ≈øixe ≈øquare ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels ≈øtanding vpright, winged as it were or welted on the edges, yet ≈øeeming but three ≈øquare, becau≈øe each couple of tho≈øe welted edges are ioyned clo≈øer together, wherein are contained broad, flat, and thinne ≈øeedes, of a pale browni≈øh colour, like vnto other Lillies, but much greater and thicker al≈øo. The ≈øtalke of this plant doth oftentimes grow flat, two, three, or foure fingers broad, and then beareth many more flowers, but for the mo≈øt part ≈ømaller then when it beareth round ≈øtalkes. And ≈øometimes it happeneth the ≈øtalke to be diuided at the top, carrying two or three tufts of greene leaues, without any flowers on them. And ≈øometimes likewi≈øe, to beare two or three rowes or crownes of flowers one aboue another vpon one ≈øtalke, which is ≈øeldome and ≈øcarce ≈øeene, and be≈øides, is but meere accidentall: the whole plant and euery part thereof, as well rootes, as leaues and flowers, doe ≈ømell ≈øomewhat ≈øtrong as it were the ≈øauour of a Foxe, ≈øo that if any doe but come neare it, he cannot but ≈ømell it, which yet is not vnwhol≈øome.

I haue not ob≈øerued any variety in the colour of this flower, more then that it will be fairer in a cleare open ayre, and paler, or as it were bla≈øted in a muddy or ≈ømoakie ayre. And although ≈øome haue boa≈øted of one with white flowers, yet I could neuer heare that any ≈øuch hath endured in one vniforme colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This plant was fir≈øt brought from Con≈øtantinople into the≈øe Chri≈øtian Countries, and by the relation of ≈øome that ≈øent it, groweth naturally in Per≈øia.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth mo≈øt commonly in the end of March, if the weather be milde, and ≈øpringeth not out of the ground vntill the end of February, or beginning of March, ≈øo quicke it is in the ≈øpringing: the heads with ≈øeed are ripe in the end of May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is of ≈øome called Lilium Per≈øicum, the Per≈øian Lilly: but becau≈øe wee haue another, which is more v≈øually called by that name, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in the next Chapter, I had rather with Alphon≈øus Pancius the Duke of Florence his Phy≈øitian, (who fir≈øt ≈øent the figure thereof vnto M≈ør. Iohn de Brancion) call it Corona Imperialis, The Crowne Imperiall, then by any other name, as al≈øo for that this name is now more generally receiued. It hath been ≈øent al≈øo by the name Tu≈øai, and Tu≈øchai, and Turfani, or Turfanda, being, as it is like, the Turki≈øh names.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: For any Phy≈øicall Vertues that are in it, I know of none, nor haue heard that any hath been found out: notwith≈øtanding the ≈øtrong ≈øent would per≈øwade it might be applyed to good purpo≈øe.

div.head: Lilium Per≈øicum. The Per≈øian Lilly.
div.p:
THe roote of the Per≈øian Lilly is very like vnto the root of the Crowne Imperiall, and lo≈øing his fibres in like maner euery yeare, hauing a hole therin likewi≈øe where the old ≈øtalke grew, but whiter, rounder, and a little longer, ≈ømaller, and not ≈øtinking at all like it, from whence ≈øpringeth vp a round whiti≈øh greene ≈øtalke, not
1 Corona Imperialis. The Crowne Imperiall. 2 Liliu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Per≈øicum. The Per≈øian Lilly. 3 Martagon Imperiale. The Martagon Imperiall. depiction of flowers
much lower than the Crowne Imperiall, but much ≈ømaller, be≈øet from the bottome to the middle thereof, with many long and narrow leaues, of a whiti≈øh or blewi≈øh greene colour, almo≈øt like to the leafe of a Tulipa: from the middle vpwards, to the toppe of the ≈øtalke, ≈øtand many flowers one aboue another round about it, with leaues at the foote of euery one of them, each whereof is pendulous or hanging downe the head, like vnto the Crowne Imperiall, and not turning vp any of the flowers againe, but ≈ømaller than in any other kinde of Lilly, yea not ≈øo bigge as the flower of a Fritillaria, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe leaues a peece, of a dead or ouerworne purpli≈øh colour, hauing in the mid≈øt a ≈ømall long pointell, with certaine chiues tipt with yellow pendents: after the flowers are pa≈øt (which abide open a long time, and for the mo≈øt part flower by degrees, the lowe≈øt fir≈øt, and ≈øo vpwards) if the weather be temperate, come ≈øixe ≈øquare heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øeeming to be but three ≈øquare, by rea≈øon of the wings, very like to the heads of the Crowne Imperiall, but ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter, wherein are contained ≈øuch like flat ≈øeed, but ≈ømaller al≈øo, and of a darker colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This was, as it is thought, fir≈øt brought from Per≈øia vnto Con≈øtantinople, and from thence, ≈øent vnto vs by the meanes of diuers Turkie Merchants, and in e≈øpeciall, by the procurement of Mr. Nicholas Lete, a worthy Merchant, and a louer of all faire flowers.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It ≈øpringeth out of the ground very neare a moneth before the Crowne Imperiall, but doth not flower till it bee quite pa≈øt (that is to ≈øay) not vntill the latter end of Aprill, or beginning of May: the ≈øeed (when it doth come to perfection, as it ≈øeldome doth) is not ripe vntill Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath been ≈øent by the name of Pennachio Per≈øiano, and wee thereupon doe mo≈øt v≈øually call it Lilium Per≈øicum, The Per≈øian Lilly. Clu≈øius ≈øaith it hath been ≈øent into the Low-Countries vnder the name of Su≈øam giul, and he thereupon thinking it came from Su≈øis in Per≈øia, called it Lilium Su≈øianum, The Lilly of Su≈øis.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Wee haue not yet heard, that this hath beene applyed for any Phy≈øicall re≈øpect.

div.head: Martagon Imperiale, ≈øiue Lilium Montanum maius, The Martagon Imperiall.
div.p:
VNder this title of Lilium Montanum, or Lilium Silue≈øtre, I do comprehend only tho≈øe kindes of Lillies, which carry diuers circles of greene leaues ≈øet together at certaine di≈øtances, round about the ≈øtalke, and not ≈øpar≈øedly as the two former, and as other kindes that follow, doe. And although there bee many of this ≈øort, yet becau≈øe their chiefe≈øt difference is in the colour of the flower, wee will containe them all in one Chapter, and begin with the mo≈øt ≈øtately of them all, becau≈øe of the number of flowers it beareth vpon one ≈øtalke. The Imperiall Lilly hath a ≈øcaly roote, like vnto all the re≈øt of the Lillies, but of a paler yellow colour, clo≈øely compact or ≈øet together, being ≈øhort and ≈ømall oftentimes, in compari≈øon of the greatne≈ø≈øe of the
≈øtemme growing from it. The ≈øtalke is browni≈øh and round at the bottome, and ≈øometimes flat from the middle vpwards, three foote high or more, be≈øet at certaine di≈øtances with rondles or circles of many broad leaues, larger and broader for the mo≈øt part than any other of this kinde, and of a darke green colour: It hath two or three, and ≈øometimes foure of the≈øe rondles or circles of leaues, and bare without any leafe betweene; but aboue toward the tops of the ≈øtalkes, it hath here and there ≈øome leaues vpon it, but ≈ømaller than any of the other leaues: at the toppe of the ≈øtalke come forth many flowers, ≈øometime three or foure ≈øcore, thicke thru≈øt, or confu≈øedly ≈øet together, and not thinne or ≈øpar≈øedly one aboue another, as in the le≈ø≈øer of this kinde of Mountaine Lilly. It hath been ≈øometimes al≈øo ob≈øerued in this kinde, that it hath borne manie flowers at three ≈øeuerall ≈øpaces of the ≈øtalke, one aboue another, which hath made a goodly ≈øhew; each flower whereof is pendulous, hanging downe, and each leafe of the flower turning vp againe, being thicke or fle≈øhy, of a fine delayed purple colour, ≈øpotted with many blacki≈øh or browni≈øh ≈øpots, of a very plea≈øant ≈øweet ≈øent, which maketh it the more acceptable: in the middle of the flower hangeth downe a ≈øtile or pointell, knobbed or buttoned at the end with ≈øixe yellow chiues, tipt with loo≈øe pendents of an Orient red or Vermillion colour, which will ea≈øily ≈øticke like du≈øt vpon any thing that toucheth them: the heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels are ≈ømall and round, with ≈ømall edges about them, wherein is contained flat browne ≈øeede like other Lillies, but le≈ø≈øer. The root is very apt to encrea≈øe or ≈øet of, as we call it, wherby the plant ≈øeldome commeth to ≈øo great a head of flowers, but ri≈øeth vp with many ≈øtalkes, and then carry fewer flowers.

Of this kinde there is ≈øometimes one found, that beareth flowers without any ≈øpots:Martagon Imperiale flore non punctato. the leaues whereof and ≈øtalke likewi≈øe are paler, but not el≈øe differing.

div.head: Martagon flore albo. The White Martagon.
div.p: We haue al≈øo ≈øome other of this kind, the fir≈øt wherof hath his ≈øtalke & leafe greener than the former, the ≈øtalke is a little higher, but not bearing ≈øo thicke a head of flowers, although much more plentifull than the le≈ø≈øer Mountaine Lilly, being altogether of a fine white colour, without any ≈øpots, or but very few, and that but ≈øometimes al≈øo: the pendents in the middle of this flower are not red, as the former, but yellow; the roote of this, and of the other two that follow, are of a pale yellow colour, the cloues or ≈øcales of them being brittle, and not clo≈øely compact, yet ≈øo as if two, and ≈øometimes three ≈øcales or cloues grew one vpon the head or vpper part of another; which difference is a ≈øpeciall note to know the≈øe three kindes, from any other kinde of Mountaine Lilly, as in all old rootes that I haue ≈øeene, I haue ob≈øerued, as al≈øo in them that are rea≈øonably well growne, but in the young rootes it is not yet ≈øo manife≈øt.

div.head: Martagon flore albo maculato. The White ≈øpotted Martagon.
div.p: The ≈øecond is like vnto the fir≈øt in all things, ≈øaue in this, that the flowers hereof are not altogether ≈øo white, and be≈øides hath many reddi≈øh ≈øpots on the in≈øide of the leaues of the flower, and the ≈øtalke al≈øo is not ≈øo greene but browni≈øh.

div.head: Martagon flore carneo. The blu≈øh Martagon.
div.p: A third ≈øort there is of this kinde, who≈øe flowers are wholly of a delayed fle≈øh colour, with many ≈øpots on the flowers, and this is the difference hereof from the former.

div.head: Lilium Montanum ≈øiue ≈øilue≈øtre minus. The le≈ø≈øer Mountaine Lilly.
div.p:
The le≈ø≈øer Mountaine Lilly is ≈øo like in root vnto the greater that is fir≈øt de≈øcribed, that it is hard to di≈øtingui≈øh them a≈øunder; but when this is ≈øprung vp out of the ground, which is a moneth after the fir≈øt: it al≈øo carrieth his leaues in rondles about the ≈øtalke, although not altogether ≈øo great nor ≈øo many. The flowers are more thinly ≈øet on the ≈øtalkes one aboue another, with more di≈øtance betweene each flower than the former, and are of a little deeper fle≈øh colour or purple, ≈øpotted in the ≈øame manner. The buds
1 Martagon flore albo. The white Martagon. 2 Martagon ≈øine Lilium Canaden≈øe maculatum. The ≈øpotted Martagon, or Lilly of Canada. 3 Martagon Pomponeum. The Martagon Pompony, or early red Martagon. depiction of flowers
or heads of flowers, in ≈øome of the≈øe before they be blowne, are hoary white, or hairie, whereas in others, there is no hoarine≈ø≈øe at all, but the buddes are ≈ømooth and purpli≈øh: in others, things this differeth not from the former.
Of this ≈øort al≈øo there is one that hath but few ≈øpots on the flowers,Lilium Montanum non maculatum. who≈øe colour is ≈øomewhat paler than the other.

div.head: Martagon Canaden≈øe maculatum. The ≈øpotted Martagon of Canada.
div.p: Although this ≈øtrange Lilly hath not his flowers hanging downe, and turning vp again, as the former kinds ≈øet forth in this Chapter; yet becau≈øe the green leaues ≈øtand at ≈øeuerall ioynts as they do, I mu≈øt needs in≈øert it here, not knowing where more fitly to place it. It hath a ≈ømall ≈øcaly roote, with many ≈ømall long fibres thereat, from whence ri≈øeth vp a rea≈øonable great ≈øtalke, almo≈øt as high as any of the former, bearing at three or foure di≈øtances many long and narrow greene leaues, but not ≈øo many or ≈øo broad as the former, with diuers ribbes in them: from among the vppermo≈øt rundle of leaues breake forth foure or fiue flowers together, euery one ≈øtanding on a long ≈ølender foote ≈øtalke, being almo≈øt as large as a red Lilly, but a little bending downewards, and of a faire yellow colour, ≈øpotted on the in≈øide with diuers blacki≈øh purple ≈øpots or ≈øtrakes, hauing a middle pointell, and ≈øixe chiues, with pendents on them.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Lillies haue been found in the diuers Countries of Germany, as Au≈øtria, Hungaria, Pannonia, Stiria, &c. and are all made Deni≈øons in our London Gardens, where they flouri≈øh as in their owne naturall places. The la≈øt was was brought into France from Canada by the French Colonie, and from thence vnto vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower about the later end of Iune for the mo≈øt part, yet the fir≈øt ≈øpringeth out of the ground a moneth at the lea≈øt before the other, which are mo≈øt v≈øually in flower before it, like vnto the Serotine Tulipas, all of them being early vp, and neuer the neere.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is v≈øually called Martagon Imperiale, the Imperiall Martagon, and is Lilium Montanum maius, the greate≈øt Mountaine Lilly; for ≈øo it de≈øerueth the name, becau≈øe of the number of flowers vpon a head or ≈øtalke. Some haue called it Lilium Sara≈øenicum, and ≈øome Hemerocallis, but neither of them doth ≈øo fitly agree vnto it.

The ≈øecond is Lilium Montanum maius flore albo, and of ≈øome Martagon Imperiale flore albo, but mo≈øt v≈øually Martagon flore albo, the white Martagon. The ≈øecond ≈øort of this ≈øecond kinde, is called Martagon flore albo maculato, the ≈øpotted white Martagon. And the third, Martagon flore carneo, the blu≈øh Martagon.

The third kinde is called Lilium Montanum, the Mountaine Lilly, and ≈øome adde the title
‚Ä¢ inus, the le≈ø≈øer, to know it more di≈øtinctly from the other. Some al≈øo Lilium Silue≈øtre, as Clu≈øius, and ≈øome others, and of Matthiolus Martagon. Of diuers women here in England, from the Dutch name, Lilly of Nazareth. The la≈øt hath his title Americanum & Canaden≈øe, and in Engli≈øh accordingly.

div.head: 1. Martagon Pomponeum ≈øine Lilium rubrum praecox, vel Lilium Macedonicum. The early red Martagon, or Martagon Pompony.
div.p: AS in the former Chapter we de≈øcribed vnto you ≈øuch Lillies, who≈øe flowers being pendulous, turne their leaues backe againe, and haue their greene leaues, ≈øet by ≈øpaces about the ≈øtalke: ≈øo in this wee will ≈øet downe tho≈øe ≈øorts, which carry their greene leaues more ≈øpar≈øedly, and all along the ≈øtalke, their flowers hanging downe, and turning vp againe as the former, and begin with that which is of greate≈øt beauty, or at lea≈øt of mo≈øt rarity.

1. Martagon Pomponeum angusti folium praecox.1. This rare Martagon hath a ≈øcaly root clo≈øely compact, with broader and thinner ≈øcales than others, in time growing very great, and of a more deepe yellow colour then the former, from whence doth ≈øpring vp a round greene ≈øtalke in ≈øome plants, and flat in others, two or three foote high, bearing a number of ≈ømall, long, and narrow greene leaues, very like vnto the leaues of Pinkes, but greener, ≈øet very thicke together, and without order about the ≈øtalke, vp almo≈øt vnto the toppe, and le≈ø≈øer by degrees vpwards, where ≈øtand many flowers, according to the age of the plant, and thriuing in the place where it groweth; in tho≈øe that are young, but a few, and more ≈øpar≈øedly, and in others that are old many more, and thicker ≈øet: for I haue reckoned three≈øcore flowers and more, growing thicke together on one plant with mee, and an hundred flowers on another: the≈øe flowers are of a pale or yellowi≈øh red colour, and not ≈øo deep red as the red Martagon of Con≈øtantinople, hereafter ≈øet down, nor fully ≈øo large: yet of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, that is, euery flower hanging downe, and turning vp his leaues againe. It is not ≈øo plentifull in bearing of ≈øeede as the other Lillies, but when it doth, it differeth not but in being le≈ø≈øe.
2. Martagon angusti folium magis ≈øerotinum.There is another, who≈øe greene leaues are not ≈øo thicke ≈øet on the ≈øtalke, but el≈øe differeth not but in flowring a fortnight later.

There is another al≈øo of this kind, ≈øo like vnto the former in root, ≈øtalk, flower, & maner of growing, 3. Martagon Pomponeum latifolium praecox. that the difference is hardly di≈øcerned; but con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in the≈øe two points: Fir≈øt, that the leaues of this are a little broader and ≈øhorter then the former; and ≈øecondly, that it beareth his flowers a fortnight earlier than the fir≈øt. In the colour or forme of the flower, there can no difference bee di≈øcerned, nor (as I ≈øaid) in any other thing. All the≈øe Lillies doe ≈øpring very late out of the ground, euen as the yellow Martagons doe, but are ≈øooner in flower then any others.

4. Martagon flore phaeniceo.A fourth kinde hereof hath of late been knowne to vs, who≈øe leaues are broader and ≈øhorter then the la≈øt, and the flowers of a paler red, tending to yellow, of ≈øome called a golden red colour: but flowreth not ≈øo early as they.

div.head: 2. Lilium rubrum Byzantinum, ≈øiue Martagon Con≈øtantinopolitanum. The red Martagon of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: 1. The red Martagon of Con≈øtantinople is become ≈øo common euery where, and ≈øo well knowne to all louers of the≈øe delights, that I ≈øhall ≈øeeme vnto them to lo≈øe time, to be≈øtow many lines vpon it; yet becau≈øe it is ≈øo faire a flower, and was at the fir≈øt ≈øo highly e≈øteemed, it de≈øerueth his place and commendations, how≈øoeuer encrea≈øing the plenty hath not made it dainty. It ri≈øeth out of the ground early in the ≈øpring, before many other Lillies, from a great thicke yellow ≈øcaly root, bearing a round browni≈øh ≈øtalke, be≈øet with many faire greene leaues confu≈øedly thereon, but not ≈øo broad as the common white Lilly, vpon the toppe whereof ≈øtand one, two, or three, or more flowers, vpon long foote≈øtalkes, which hang downe their heads, and turne vp their leaues againe, of an excellent red crim≈øon colour, and ≈øometimes paler, hauing a long pointell in the middle, compa≈ø≈øed with ≈øixe whiti≈øh chiues, tipt with loo≈øe yellow pendents, of a rea≈øonable good ≈øent, but ≈øomewhat faint. It likewi≈øe beareth ≈øeede in heads, like vnto the other, but greater.

div.head: Martagon Con≈øtantinopolitanum maculatum. The red ≈øpotted Martagon of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: We haue another of this kinde, that groweth ≈øomewhat greater and higher, with a larger flower, and of a deeper colour, ≈øpotted with diuers blacke ≈øpots, or ≈øtrakes and lines, as is to be ≈øeene in the Mountaine Lillies, and in ≈øome other hereafter to be de≈øcribed; but is not ≈øo in the former of this kinde, which hath no ≈øhew of ≈øpots at all. The whole plant as it is rare, ≈øo it is of much more beauty then the former.

div.head: 2. Martagon Pannonicum, ≈øiue Exoticum flore ≈øpadiceo. The bright red Martagon of Hungarie.
