div.p: Although this Martagon or Lilly bee of another Countrey, yet by rea≈øon of the neerene≈ø≈øe both in leafe and flower vnto the former, may more fitly be placed next vnto them, then in any other place. It hath his roote very like the other, but the leaues are ≈øomewhat larger, and more ≈øpar≈øedly ≈øet vpon the ≈øtalke, el≈øe not much vnlike: the flowers bend downe, and turne vp their leaues againe, but ≈øomewhat larger, and of a bright red, tending to an Orenge colour, that is, ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh, and not crim≈øon, like the other.

div.head: 3. Martagon Luteum punctatum. The Yellow ≈øpotted Martagon.
div.p: 1. This Yellow Martagon hath a great ≈øcaly or cloued roote, and yellow, like vnto all the≈øe ≈øorts of turning Lillies, from whence ≈øpringeth vp a round greene ≈øtrong ≈øtalke, three foote high at the lea≈øt, confu≈øedly ≈øet with narrow long greene leaues, white on the edges vp to the very toppe thereof almo≈øt, hauing diuers flowers on the head, turning vp againe as the former doe, of a faint yellowi≈øh, or greeni≈øh yellow colour, with many blacke ≈øpots or ≈øtrakes about the middle of the leafe of euery flower, and a forked pointell, with ≈øixe chiues about it, tipt with reddi≈øh pendents, of a heauie ≈øtrong ≈ømell, not very plea≈øant to many. It beareth ≈øeede very plentifully, in great heads, like vnto the other former Lillies, but a little paler.

div.head: 2. Martagon Luteum non maculatum. The Yellow Martagon without ≈øpots.
div.p: The other yellow Martagon differeth in no other thing from the former, but onely that it hath no ≈øpots at all vpon any of the leaues of the flowers; agreeing with the former, in colour, forme, height, and all things el≈øe.

div.head: 3. Martagon Luteum ≈øerotinum. The late flowring Yellow Martagon.
div.p: There is yet another yellow Martagon, that hath no other difference then the time of his flowring, which is not vntill Iuly, vnle≈ø≈øe in this, that the flower is of a deeper yellow colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The knowledge of the fir≈øt kindes of the≈øe early Martagons hath come from Italy, from whence they haue bin ≈øent into the Low-Countries, and to vs, and, as it ≈øeemeth by the name, whereby they haue bin ≈øent by ≈øome into the≈øe parts, his originall ≈øhould be from the mountaines in Macedonia.

The ≈øecond ≈øort is ≈øufficiently knowne by his name, being fir≈øt brought from Con≈øtantinople, his naturall place being not farre from thence, as it is likely. But the next ≈øort of this ≈øecond kinde, doth plainly tell vs his place of birth to be the mountaines of Pannonia or Hungarie.
The third kindes grow on the Pyrenaean mountaines, where they haue been ≈øearched out, and found by diuers louers of plants, as al≈øo in the Kingdome of Naples.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt early Martagons flower in the end of May, or beginning of Iune, and that is a moneth at the lea≈øt before tho≈øe that come from Con≈øtantinople, which is the ≈øecond kinde. The two fir≈øt yellow Martagons flower ≈øomewhat more early, then the early red Martagons, and ≈øometimes at the ≈øame time with them. But the third yellow Martagon, as is ≈øaid, flowreth a moneth later or more, and is in flower when the red Martagon of Con≈øtantinople flowreth. And although the early red and yellow Martagons, ≈øpring later then the other Martagons or Lillies, yet they are in flower before them.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt early red Lillies or Martagons haue beene ≈øent vnto vs by ≈øeuerall names, as Martagon Pomponeum, and thereafter are called Martagon of Pompony, and al≈øo Lilium or Martagon Macedonicum, the Lilly or Martagon of Macedonia. They are al≈øo called by Clu≈øius Lilium rubrum praecox, the one angustiore folio, the other latiore folio. And the la≈øt of this kinde hath the title flore phaeniceo added or giuen vnto it, that is, the Martagon or Lilly of Macedonia with gold red flowers.

The Martagons of Con≈øtantinople haue beene ≈øent by the Turki≈øh name Zufiniare, and is called Martagon, or Lilium Byzantinum by ≈øome, and Hemerocallis Chalcedonica by others; but by the name of the Martagon of Con≈øtantinople they are mo≈øt commonly receiued with vs, with the di≈øtinction of maculatum to the one, to di≈øtingui≈øh the ≈øorts. The la≈øt kinde in this cla≈øsis, hath his name in his title, as it hath been ≈øent vnto vs.
The Yellow Martagons are di≈øtingui≈øhed in their ≈øeuerall titles, as much as is conuenient for them.

div.head: Lilium Aureum & Lilium Rubrum. The Gold and Red Lillies.
div.p: THere are yet ≈øome other kindes of red Lillies to bee de≈øcribed, which differ from all the former, and remaine to be ≈øpoken of in this place. Some of them grow high, and ≈øome lowe, ≈øome haue ≈ømall knots, which wee call bulbes, growing vpon the ≈øtalkes, at the ioynts of the leaues or flowers, and ≈øome haue none: all which ≈øhall be intreated of in their ≈øeuerall orders.

div.head: Lilium pumilum cruentum. The dwarfe red Lilly.
div.p: The dwarfered Lilly hath a ≈øcaly roote, ≈øomewhat like vnto other Lillies, but white, and not yellow at all, and the cloues or ≈øcales thicker, ≈øhorter, and fewer in number, then in mo≈øt of the former: the ≈øtalke hereof is not aboue a foote and a halfe high, round and greene, ≈øet confu≈øedly with many faire and ≈øhort greene leaues, on the toppe of which doe ≈øtand ≈øometimes but a few flowers, and ≈øometimes many of a faire purpli≈øh red colour, and a little paler in the middle, euery flower ≈øtanding vpright, and not hanging downe, as in the former, on the leaues whereof here and there are ≈øome blacke ≈øpots, lines or markes, and in the middle of the flower a long pointell, with ≈øome chiues about it, as is in the re≈øt of the≈øe Lillies.

Lilium rubrum multiplici flore.This kinde is ≈øometimes found to yeeld double flowers, as if all the ≈øingle flowers ≈øhould grow into one, and ≈øo make it con≈øi≈øt of many leaues, which notwith≈øtanding
1 Martagon rubrum ≈øiue luteum. The red or the yellow Martagon. 2 Lilium Bulbiferum. The red bulbed Lilly. 3 Lilium aureum. The gold red Lilly. 4 Lilium album. The white Lilly. depiction of flowers
his ≈øo continuing ≈øundry yeares, vpon tran≈øplanting, will redire ad ingentum, that is, quickly come againe to his old by as or forme.

div.head: Lilium Aureum. The Gold red Lilly.
div.p: The ≈øecond red Lilly without bulbes groweth much higher then the fir≈øt, and almo≈øt as high as any other Lilly: the roote hereof is white and ≈øcaly, the leaues are ≈øomewhat longer, and of a darke or ≈øad greene colour; the flowers are many and large, ≈øtanding vpright as all the≈øe ≈øorts of red Lillies doe, of a paler red colour tending to an Orenge on the in≈øide, with many blacke ≈øpots, and lines on them, as in the former, and more yellow on the out≈øide: the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels are like vnto the roundi≈øh heads of other Lillies, and ≈øo are the ≈øeedes in them likewi≈øe.

div.head: 1. Lilium minus bulbiferum. The dwarfe bulbed Lilly.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the Lillies that carrieth bulbes on the ≈øtalke, hath a white ≈øcaly roote like the former; from whence ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall round ≈øtalke, not much higher then the fir≈øt dwarfe Lilly, ≈øeeming to be edged, hauing many leaues thereon of a ≈øad green colour ≈øet about it, clo≈øe thru≈øt together: the greene heads for flowers, will haue a kind of woolline≈ø≈øe on them, before the flowers begin to open, and betweene the≈øe heads of flowers, as al≈øo vnder them, and among the vppermo≈øt leaues, appeare ≈ømall bulbes or heads, which being ripe if they be put into the ground, or if they fall of them≈øelues, will ≈øhoote forth leaues, and beare flowers within two or three yeares like the mother plant, and ≈øo will the bulbes of the other hereafter de≈øcribed: the flowers of this Lilly are of a faire gold yellow colour, ≈øhadowed ouer with a ≈øhew of purple, but not ≈øo red as the fir≈øt, or the next to bee de≈øcribed. This Lilly will ≈øhoote ≈øtrings vnder ground, like as the la≈øt red Lilly will doe al≈øo, whereat will grow white bulbed roots, like the rootes of the mother plant, thereby quickly encrea≈øing it ≈øelfe.

div.head: 2. Lilium Cruentum bulbiferum. The Fierie red bulbed Lilly.
div.p: The ≈øecond bulbed Lilly ri≈øeth vp with his ≈øtalke as high as any of the≈øe Lillies, carrying many long and narrow darke greene leaues about it, and at the toppe many faire red flowers, as large or larger then any of the former, and of a deeper red colour, with ≈øpots on them likewi≈øe, hauing greater bulbes growing about the toppe of the ≈øtalke and among the flowers, then any el≈øe.

div.head: Lilium Cruentum flore pleno. The Fierie red double Lilly.
div.p: The difference of this doth chiefly con≈øi≈øt in the flower, which is compo≈øed of manie leaues, as if many flowers went to make one, ≈øpotted with black ≈øpots, and without any bulbes when it thus beareth, which is but accidentall, as the former double Lilly is ≈øaid to be.

div.head: 3. Lilium maius bulbiferum. The greater bulbed red Lilly.
div.p: The third red Lilly with bulbes, ri≈øeth vp almo≈øt as high as the la≈øt, and is the mo≈øt common kinde we haue bearing bulbes. It hath many leaues about the ≈øtalke, but not of ≈øo ≈øad a greene colour as the former: the flowers are of as pale a reddi≈øh yellow colour as any of the former, and comming neere≈øt vnto the colour of the Gold red Lilly. This is more plentifull in bulbes, and in ≈øhooting ≈øtrings, to encrea≈øe rootes vnder ground, then the others.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The≈øe Lillies doe all grew in Gardens, but their naturall places of growing is the Mountaines and the Vallies neere them in Italy, as Matthiolus
≈øaith: and in many Countries of Germany, as Hungarie, Au≈øtria, Stiria, and Bohemia, as Clu≈øius and other doe report.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part in Iune, yet the fir≈øt of the≈øe is the earlie≈øt of all the re≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: All the≈øe Lillies are called Lilia Rubra, Red Lillies: Some call them Lilium Aureum, Lilium Purpureum, Lilium Puniceum, & Lilium Cruentum. Some al≈øo call them Martagon Chimi≈øtarum. Clu≈øius calleth the≈øe bulbed Lillies Martagon Bulbiferum. It is thought to be Hyacinthus Poetarum, but I referre the di≈øcu≈ø≈øing thereof to a fitter time. Wee haue, to di≈øtingui≈øh them mo≈øt fitly (as I take it) giuen their proper names in their ≈øeuerall titles.

div.head: Lilium Album. The White Lilly.
div.p: NOw remaineth onely the White Lilly, of all the whole family or ≈øtocke of the Lillies, to bee ≈øpoken of, which is of two ≈øorts. The one is our common or vulgar White Lilly; and the other, that which was brought from Con≈øtantinople.

div.head: Lilium Album vulgare. The ordinary White Lilly.
div.p: The ordinary White Lilly ≈øcarce needeth any de≈øcription, it is ≈øo well knowne, and ≈øo frequent in euery Garden; but to ≈øay ≈øomewhat thereof, as I v≈øe to doe of euery thing, be it neuer ≈øo common and knowne; it hath a cloued or ≈øcaly roote, yellower and bigger then any of the red Lillies: the ≈øtalke is of a blacki≈øh greene colour, and ri≈øeth as high as mo≈øt of the Lillies, hauing many faire, broad, and long greene leaues thereon, larger and longer beneath, and ≈ømaller vpon the ≈øtalke vpwards; the flowers are many or few, according to the age of the plant, fertility of the ≈øoile, and time of ≈øtanding where it groweth: and ≈øtand vpon long greene foot≈øtalkes, of a faire white colour, with a long pointell in the middle, and white chiues tipt with yellow pendents about it; the ≈ømell is ≈øomewhat heady and ≈øtrong.

div.head: Lilium Album Byzantinum. The White Lilly of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: The other White Lilly, differeth but little from the former White Lilly, either in roote, leafe, or flower, but only that this v≈øually groweth with more number of flowers, then euer we ≈øaw in our ordinary White Lilly: for I haue ≈øeene the ≈øtalke of this Lilly turne flat, of the breadth of an hand, bearing neere two hundred flowers vpon a head, yet mo≈øt commonly it beareth not aboue a dozen, or twenty flowers, but ≈ømaller then the ordinary, as the greene leaues are likewi≈øe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth onely in Gardens, and hath not beene declared where it is found wilde, by any that I can heare of. The other hath beene ≈øent from Con≈øtantinople, among other rootes, and therefore is likely to grow in ≈øome parts neere thereunto.

div.head: The Time.
div.p:
They flower in Iune or thereabouts, but ≈øhoote forth greene leaues in
Autumne, which abide greene all the Winter, the ≈øtalke ≈øpringing vp betweene the lower leaues in the Spring.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called Lilium Album, the White Lilly, by mo≈øt Writers; but by Poets Ro≈øa Iunonis, Iuno's Ro≈øe. The other hath his name in his title.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: This Lilly aboue all the re≈øt, yea, and I thinke this onely, and none of the re≈øt is v≈øed in medicines now adayes, although in former times Empericks v≈øed the red; and therefore I haue ≈øpoken nothing of them in the end of their Chapters, re≈øeruing what is to be ≈øaid in this. This hath a mollifying, dige≈øting, and clean≈øing quality, helping to ≈øuppurate tumours, and to dige≈øt them, for which purpo≈øe the roote is much v≈øed. The water of the flowers di≈øtilled, is of excellent vertue for women in trauell of childe bearing, to procure an ea≈øie deliuery, as Matthiolus and Camerarius report. It is v≈øed al≈øo of diuers women outwardly, for their fa ‚Ä¢ es to clean≈øe the skin, and make it white and fre≈øh. Diuers other properties there are in the≈øe Lillies, which my purpo≈øe is not to declare in this place. Nor is it the ≈øcope of this worke; this that hath been ≈øaid is ≈øufficient: for were it not, that I would giue you ≈øome ta≈øte of the qua ‚Ä¢ ities of plants (as I ≈øaid in my Preface) as I goe along with them, a generall worke were fitter to declare them then this.

div.head: Fritillaria. The checkerd Daffodill.
div.p: ALthough diuers learned men do by the name giuen vnto this delightfull plant, thinke it doth in ≈øome things partake with a Tulipa or Daffodill, and haue therefore placed it betweene them; yet I, finding it mo≈øt like vnto a little Lilly, both in roote, ≈øtalke, leafe, flower, and ≈øeede, haue (as you ≈øee here) placed it next vnto the Lillies, and before them. Hereof there are many ≈øorts found out of late, as white, red, blacke, and yellow, be≈øides the purple, which was fir≈øt knowne; and of each of them there are al≈øo diuers ≈øorts: and fir≈øt of that which is mo≈øt frequent, and then of the re≈øt, euery one in his place and order.

div.head: 1. Frillaria vulgaris. The common checkerd Daffodill.
div.p:
The ordinary checkerd Daffodill (as it is v≈øually called, but might more properly be called the ≈ømall checkerd Lilly) hath a ≈ømall round white roote, and ≈øomewhat flat, made as it were of two cloues, and diuided in a maner into two parts, yet ioyning together at the bottome or ≈øeate of the roote, which holdeth them both together: from betweene this cleft or diui≈øion, the budde for the ≈øtalke &c. appeareth, which in time ri≈øeth vp a foote, or a foote and a halfe high, being round and of a browni≈øh greene colour, e≈øpecially neere vnto the ground, whereon there ≈øtandeth di≈øper≈øedly foure or fiue narrow long and greene leaues, being a little hollow: at the toppe of the ≈øtalke, betweene the vpper leaues (which are ≈ømaller then the lowe≈øt) the flower ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, hanging or turning downe the head, but not turning vp againe any of his leaues, as ≈øome of the Lillies before de≈øcribed doe; (≈øometimes this ≈øtalke beareth two flowers, and very ≈øeldome three) con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe leaues, of a reddi≈øh purple colour, ≈øpotted diuer≈øly with great ≈øpots, appearing like vnto ≈øquare checkers, of a deeper colour; the in≈øide of the flower is of a brighter colour then the out≈øide, which hath ≈øome greenne≈ø≈øe at the bottome of euery leafe: within the flower there appeare
1 Fritillaria vulgaris. The common Fritillaria. 2 Fritillaria flore atrorubente. The darke red Fritillaria. 4 Fritillaria alba. The white Fritillaria. 7 Fritillaria lutea punctata. The yellow checkerd Fritillaria. 8 Fritillaria lutea Italica. The great yellow Italian Fritillaria. 10 Fritillaria lutea Lu≈øitanica. The ≈ømall yellow Fritillaria of Portugall. 11 Fritillaria Pyrenaea. The blacke Fritillaria. 12 Fritillaria vmbellifera. The Spani≈øh blacke Fritillaria. depiction of flowers
≈øixe chiues tipt with yellow pendents, and a three-forked ≈øtile or pointell compa≈ø≈øing a greene head, which when the flower is pa≈øt, ri≈øeth vpright againe, and becommeth the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell, being ≈øomewhat long and round, yet hauing a ≈ømall ≈øhew of edges, flat at the head, like the head of a Lilly, and without any crowne as the Tulipa hath, wherein is contained pale coloured flat ≈øeede, like vnto a Lilly, but ≈ømaller.

Fritillaria vulgaris pallidior, praecox, & ≈øerotina.There is ≈øome variety to be ≈øeene in this flower; for in ≈øome the colour is paler, and in others againe of a very high or deepe colour: ≈øometimes al≈øo they haue eight leaues, and ≈øometimes ten or twelue, as if two flowers were made one, which ≈øome thereupon haue called a Double Fritillaria. Some of them likewi≈øe doe flower very early, euen with or before the early flowring Tulipas; and ≈øome againe flower not vntill a moneth or more after the former.

div.head: 2. Fritillaria flore atrorubente. The bloud red Fritillaria.
div.p: The roote of this Fritillaria is ≈øomewhat rounder and clo≈øer then the former, from whence the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp, being ≈øhorter and lower then in any other of the≈øe kindes, hauing one or two leaues thereon, and at the top thereof two or three more ≈øet clo≈øer together, which are broader, ≈øhorter, and whiter then any of them before, almo≈øt like vnto the leaues of the yellow Fritillaria, from among which toppe leaues commeth forth the flower, ≈øomewhat bending downe, or rather ≈øtanding forth, being larger then any of the former, and almo≈øt equall in bigne≈ø≈øe vnto the yellow Fritillaria, of a duskie gray colour all ouer on the out≈øide, and of a very darke red colour on the in≈øide, diuer≈øly ≈øpotted or ≈øtraked: this very hardly encrea≈øeth by the roote, and as ≈øeldome giueth ripe ≈øeede, but flowreth with the other fir≈øt ≈øorts, and before the blacke, and abideth le≈ø≈øe time in flower then any.

div.head: 3. Fritillaria maxima purpurea ≈øiuerubra. The great purple or red Fritillaria.
div.p: This great Fritillaria hath his roote equall to the bigne≈ø≈øe of the re≈øt of his parts, from whence ri≈øeth vp one, & oftentimes two ≈øtalks, hauing one, two or three flowers a peece on them, as nature and the ≈øea≈øons are fitting: euery one of the≈øe flowers are larger and greater then any of the former de≈øcribed, and pendulous as they are, of a ≈øad red or purpli≈øh colour, with many thwart lines on them, and ≈ømall long markes, which hardly ≈øeeme checkerwi≈øe, nor are ≈øo eminent or con≈øpicuous as in the former: the ≈øtalke is ≈øtrong and high, whereon are ≈øet diuers long whiti≈øh greene leaues, larger and broader then tho≈øe of the former.

div.head: 4. Fritillaria alba. The white Fritillaria.
div.p: The white Fritillaria is ≈øo like vnto the fir≈øt, that I ≈øhall not neede to make another de≈øcription of this: it ≈øhall (I hope) be ≈øufficient to ≈øhew the chiefe differences, and ≈øo proceed to the re≈øt. The ≈øtalke and leaues of this are wholly greene, whereby it may ea≈øily be knowne from the former, which, as is ≈øaid, is browni≈øh at the bottome. The flower is white, without almo≈øt any ≈øhew of ≈øpot or marke in it, yet in ≈øome the markes are ≈øomewhat more plainly to be≈øeene, and in ≈øome againe there is a ≈øhew of a faint kinde of blu≈øh colour to be ≈øeene in the flower, e≈øpecially in the in≈øide, the bottomes of the leaues of euery flower ≈øometimes are greeni≈øh, hauing al≈øo a ≈ømall li≈øt of greene, comming downe towards the middle of each leafe: the head or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell, as al≈øo the ≈øeede and the roote, are ≈øo like vnto the former, that the mo≈øt cunning cannot di≈øtingui≈øh them.

div.head: 5. Fritillaria flore duplici albicante. The double blu≈øh Fritillaria.
div.p:
This Fritillaria hath a round flatti≈øh white roote, very like vnto the la≈øt Fritillaria, bearing a ≈øtalke with long greene leaues thereon, little differing from it, or the fir≈øt ordinary Fritillaria: the flower is ≈øaid to be con≈øtant, compo≈øed of many leaues, being ten at the lea≈øt, and mo≈øt v≈øually twelue, of a pale whiti≈øh purple colour, ≈øpotted like vnto the paler ordinary Fritillaria that is early, ≈øo that one would verily thinke it were
but an accidentall kinde thereof, whereas it is (as is ≈øaid before) held to bee con≈øtant, continuing in this manner.

div.head: 6. Fritillaria flore luteo puro. The pure yellow Fritillaria.
div.p: The pure yellow Fritillaria hath a more round, and not ≈øo flat a whiti≈øh roote as the former kindes, and of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe; from the middle ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke a foote and a halfe high, and ≈øometimes higher, whereon are ≈øet without order diuers long and ≈øomewhat broad leaues of a whiti≈øh greene colour, like vnto the leaues of the blacke Fritillaria, but not aboue halfe ≈øo broad: the flower is ≈øomewhat ≈ømall and long, not much vnlike to the blacke for ≈øhape and fa≈øhion, but that the leaues are ≈ømaller and rounder pointed, of a faint yellowi≈øh colour, without any ≈øhew of ≈øpots or checkers at all, eyther within or without the flower, hauing ≈øome chiues and yellow pendents in the middle, as is to be ≈øeene in all of them: the ≈øeede is like the fir≈øt kinde.

div.head: 7. Fritillaria flore luteo vario ≈øiue punctato. The checkerd yellow Fritillaria.
div.p: This Fritillaria groweth not much lower then the former, and browni≈øh at the ri≈øing vp, hauing his leaues whiter, broader, and ≈øhorter then it, and almo≈øt round pointed. The flower is greater, and larger ≈øpread then any other before, of a faire pale yellow colour, ≈øpotted in very good order, with fine ≈ømall checkers, which adde a wonderfull plea≈øing beauty thereunto: it hath al≈øo ≈øome li≈øts of greene running downe the backe of euery leafe. It ≈øeldome giueth ≈øeede; the roote al≈øo is like the other, but not ≈øo flat.

div.head: 8. Fritillaria lutea maxima Italica. The great yellow Italian Fritillaria.
div.p: This kinde of Fritillaria ri≈øeth vp with a round and browne greene ≈øtalke, whereon are ≈øet diuers leaues ≈øomewhat broad and ≈øhort, which compa≈ø≈øe the ≈øtalke at the bottome of them, of a darke greene colour; at the toppe of the ≈øtalke, which bendeth a little downewards, doe mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øtand three or foure leaues, betweene which commeth forth mo≈øt v≈øually but one flower, which is longer then the la≈øt, hanging downe the head as all the others doe, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe leaues, of a darke yellowi≈øh purple colour, ≈øpotted with ≈øome ≈ømall red checkers. This kinde flowreth late, and not vntill all the re≈øt are pa≈øt.

div.head: 9. Fritillaria Italorum polyanthos flore paruo. The ≈ømall Italian Fritillaria.
div.p: This ≈ømall Italian Fritillaria carrieth more ≈øtore of flowers on the ≈øtalke, but they are much ≈ømaller, and of a yellowi≈øh greene colour, ≈øpotted with long and ≈ømall darke red checkers or markes: the ≈øtalke hath diuers ≈ømall ≈øhort greene leaues thereon, vnto the very toppe.

div.head: 10. Fritillaria lutea Iuncifoliu Lufitanica. The ≈ømall yellow Fritillaria of Portugall.
div.p: The leaues of this Fritillaria are ≈øo ≈ømall, narrow and long, that it hath cau≈øed them to take the name of ru≈øhes, as if you ≈øhould call it, The ru≈øh leafed Fritillaria, which ≈øtand on a long weake round ≈øtalke, ≈øet without order: the flower is ≈ømall and yellow, but thicker checkerd with red ≈øpots then any of the other yellow Fritillaria's; the ≈øtalk of the flower, at the head thereof, being al≈øo of a yellowi≈øh colour.

div.head: 11. Fritillaria Pyrenaea fiue Apenniuea. The blacke Fritillaria.
div.p:
The roote of this kinde doth often grow ≈øo great, that it ≈øeemeth like vnto the roote of a ≈ømall Crowne Imperiall: the ≈øtalke is ≈øtrong, round, and high, ≈øet without order, with broader and whiter greene leaues then any of the former, bearing one, two, or three flowers; ≈øometimes at the toppe, being not ≈øo large as tho≈øe of the ordinary purple Fritillaria, but ≈ømaller, longer, and rounder, ≈øometimes a little turning vp the brims or edges of the leaues againe, and are of a yellowi≈øh ≈øhining greene colour on
the in≈øide, ≈øometimes ≈øpotted with red ≈øpots almo≈øt through the whole in≈øide of the flower, vnto the very edge, which abideth of a pale yellow colour, and ≈øometimes there are very few ≈øpots to be ≈øeene, and tho≈øe from the middle onely on the in≈øide (for on the out≈øide there neuer appeareth any ≈øpots at all in this kinde) and ≈øometimes with no ≈øhew of ≈øpots at all, ≈øometimes al≈øo of a more pale greene, and ≈øometime of a more yellow colour: the out≈øide of the flowers doe likewi≈øe vary, for in ≈øome the out≈øide of the leaues are of a darke ≈øullen yellow, &c. el≈øe more pale yellow, and in other of a darke purpli≈øh yellow colour, which in ≈øome is ≈øo deepe, and ≈øo much, that it rather ≈øeemeth blacke then purple or yellow, and this e≈øpecially about the bottome of the flower, next vnto the ≈øtalke, but the edges are ≈øtill of a yellowi≈øh greene: the head of ≈øeede, and the ≈øeede likewi≈øe is like vnto the former, but bigger in all re≈øpects.

div.head: 12. Fritillaria Hi≈øpanica vmbellifera. The Spani≈øh blacke Fritillaria.
div.p: This Fritillaria is no doubt of kindred to the la≈øt recited, it is ≈øo like, but greater in all parts thereof, as if growing in a more fruitfull ≈øoile, it were the ≈øtronger and lu≈øtier to beare more ≈øtore of flowers: the flowers grow foure or fiue from the head together, hanging downe round about the ≈øtalke, like vnto a Crowne Imperiall, and are of a yellowi≈øh greene colour on the in≈øide, ≈øpotted with a few red ≈øpots, the out≈øide being blacki≈øh as the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the≈øe plants was fir≈øt brought to our knowledge from France, where it groweth plentifully about Orleance; the other ≈øorts grow in diuers other Countries, as ≈øome in Portugall, Spaine, Italy, &c. as their names doe import, and as in time they haue been ob≈øerued by tho≈øe that were curious ≈øearchers of the≈øe rarities, haue been ≈øent to vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The early kindes doe flower in the beginning of Aprill or thereabouts, according to the mildene≈ø≈øe or ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe of the precedent Winter. The other doe flower after the fir≈øt are pa≈øt, for a moneths ≈øpace one after another, and the great yellow is very late, not flowring vntill about the middle or end of May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: This hath receiued diuers names: ≈øome calling it Flos Meleagridis, the Ginny Hen Flower, of the variety of the colours in the flower, agreeing with the feathers of that Bird. Some call it Narci≈ø≈øus Caparonius, of the name of the fir≈øt inuentor or finder thereof, called Noel Caperon, an Apothecary dwelling in Orleance, at the time he fir≈øt found it, and was ≈øhortly after the finding thereof taken away in the Ma≈ø≈øacre in France. It is now generally called Fritillaria, of the word Fritillus, which diuers doe take for the Che≈ø≈øe borde or table whereon they play, whereunto, by rea≈øon of the re≈øemblance of the great ≈øquares or ≈øpots ≈øo like it, they did pre≈øently referre it. It is called by Lobel Lilionarci≈ø≈øus purpureus variegatus, & te≈ø≈øulatus, making it a kinde of Tulipa; but as I ≈øaid in the beginning of the Chapter, it doth mo≈øt neerely re≈øemble a ≈ømall pendulous Lilly, and might therefore rightly hold the name of Lilium variegatum, or in Engli≈øh, the checkerd Lilly. But becau≈øe the errour which fir≈øt referred it to a Daffodill, is growne ≈øtrong by cu≈øtome of continuance, I leaue to euery one their owne will, to call it in Engli≈øh eyther Fritillaria, as it is called of mo≈øt, or the checkerd Daffodill, or the Ginnie Hen flower, or, as I doe, the checkerd Lilly. I ≈øhall not neede in this place further to explaine the ≈øeuerall names of euery of them, hauing giuen you them in their titles.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: I haue not found or heard by any others of any property peculiar in this plant, to be applied either inwardly or outwardly for any di≈øea≈øe: the chiefe or onely v≈øe thereof is, to be an ornament for the Gardens of the curious louers of the≈øe delights, and to be worne of them abroad, which for the gallant beauty of many of them, de≈øerueth their courteous entertainment, among many other the like plea≈øures.

div.head: Tulipa. The Turkes Cap.
div.p:
NExt vnto the Lillies, and before the Narci≈ø≈øi or Daffodils, the di≈øcour≈øe of Tulipas de≈øerueth his place, for that it partaketh of both their natures; agreeing with the Lillies in leaues, flowers, and ≈øeede, and ≈øomewhat with the Daffodils in rootes. There are not onely diuers kindes of Tulipas, but ≈øundry diuer≈øities of colours in them, found out in the≈øe later dayes by many the ≈øearchers of natures varieties, which haue not formerly been ob≈øerued: our age being more delighted in the ≈øearch, curio≈øity, and rarities of the≈øe plea≈øant delights, then any age I thinke before. But indeede, this flower, aboue many other, de≈øerueth his true commendations and acceptance with all louers of the≈øe beauties, both for the ≈øtately a≈øpect, and for the admirable varietie of colours, that daily doe ari≈øe in them, farre beyond all other plants that grow, in ≈øo much, that I doubt, although I ≈øhall in this Chapter ≈øet downe the varieties of a great many, I ≈øhall leaue more vn≈øpoken of, then I ≈øhall de≈øcribe; for I may well ≈øay, there is in this one plant no end of diuer≈øity to be expected, euery yeare yeelding a mixture and variety that hath not before been ob≈øerued, and all this ari≈øing from the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede. The chiefe diui≈øion of Tulipas, is into two ≈øorts: Praecoces, early flowring Tulipas, and Serotinae, late flowring Tulipas. For that ≈øort which is called Mediae or Dubiae, that is, which flower in the middle time betweene them both, and may be thought to be a kinde or ≈øort by it ≈øelfe, as well as any of the other two: yet becau≈øe they doe neerer participate with the Serotinae then with the Praecoces, not onely in the colour of the leafe, being of the ≈øame greenne≈ø≈øe with the Serotinae, and mo≈øt v≈øually al≈øo, for that it beareth his ≈øtalke and flower, high and large like as the Serotinae doe; but e≈øpecially, for that the ≈øeede of a Media Tulipa did neuer bring forth a Praecox flower (although I know Clu≈øius, an indu≈øtrious, learned, and painfull ≈øearcher and publi≈øher of the≈øe rarities, ≈øaith otherwi≈øe) ≈øo farre as euer I could, by mine owne care or knowledge, in ≈øowing their ≈øeede apart, or the a≈ø≈øurance of any others, the louers and ≈øowers of Tulipa ≈øeede, ob≈øerue, learne, or know: and becau≈øe al≈øo that the ≈øeede of the Serotinae bringeth forth Medias, and the ≈øeede of Medias Serotinae, they may well bee comprehended vnder the generall title of Serotinae: But becau≈øe they haue generally receiued the name of Media, or middle flowring Tulipas, to di≈øtingui≈øh betweene them, and tho≈øe that v≈øually doe flower after them; I am content to ≈øet them downe, and ≈øpeake of them ≈øeuerally, as of three ≈øorts. Vnto the place and ranke likewi≈øe of the Praecoces, or early flowring Tulipas, there are ≈øome other ≈øeuerall kinds of Tulipas to be added, which are notably differing, not onely from the former Praecox Tulipa, but euery one of them, one from another, in ≈øome ≈øpeciall note or other: as the Tulipa Bolonien≈øis flore rubro, the red Bolonia Tulipa. Tulipa Bolonien≈øis flore luteo, the yellow Bolonia Tulipa. Tulipa Per≈øica, the Per≈øian Tulipa. Tulipa Cretica, the Candie Tulipa, and others: all which ≈øhall bee de≈øcribed and entreated of, euery one apart by it ≈øelfe, in the end of the ranke of the Praecoces, becau≈øe all of them flower much about their time. To begin then with the Praecox, or early flowring Tulipas, and after them with the Medias and Serotines, I ≈øhall for the better method, diuide their flowers into foure primary or principall colours, that is to ≈øay, White, Purple, Red, and Yellow, and vnder euery one of the≈øe colours, ≈øet downe the ≈øeuerall varieties
of mixtures we haue ≈øeene and ob≈øerued in them, that ≈øo they may be both the better de≈øcribed by me, and the better conceiued by others, and euery one placed in their proper ranke. Yet I ≈øhall in this, as I intend to doe in diuers other plants that are variable, giue but one de≈øcription in generall of the plant, and then ≈øet downe the varietie of forme or colour afterwards briefly by them≈øelues.

div.head: Tulipa praecox. The early flowring Tulipa.

figure.head: 1 Tulipa praecox alba ≈øiue rubra, &c. vnius coloris. The early white or red Tulipa, &c. being of one colour. 2 Tulipa praecox purpurea oris albis. The early purple Tulipa with white edges, or the Prince. 3 Tulipa praecox variegata. The early ≈øtript Tulipa. 4 Tulipa praecox rubra otis luteis. The early red Tulipa with yellow edges, or the Duke.

9 A Prince or Bracklar, that is, a deepe or pale purple, with white edges, greater or ≈ømaller, and a yellow bottome, or circled with white, which varieth much, both in the purple & edges, ≈øo that a faire deep purple, with great white edges, is called, The be≈øt or chiefe Prince, and

10 A paler purple with white edges, called a Doue coloured Prince.
11 Purpurea Cherme≈øiua, rubicandioris coloris, albidis vel albis oris.
11 A Crim≈øon Prince or Bracklar.
12 Purpurea, vel ob≈øoleta albidis oris Princeps Brancion.
12 A Brancion Prince, or purple Brancion.
13 Purpurea diluta, oris dilutioris purpurei coloris.
13 A purple with more pale purple edges.
14 Purpurea in exterioribus, carnei vero ad medium intus, oris albis, fundoluteo.
14 Purple without, and blu≈øh halfe way within, with white edges, and a yellow bottome.
15 Purpurea albo plumata extra, oris albis, purpura≈øcens intus, fundo luteo, vel orbe albo.
15 Purple feathered with white on the out ≈øide, with white edges, and pale purple within, the ground being a little yellow, or circled with white.

16 Alia, minus elegans plumata, minoribu≈ø
que oris albidis.
16 Another very neere vnto it, but not ≈øo fairely feathered, being more ob≈øcure, and the edges not ≈øo great or whiti≈øh.
Tulipa praecox rubra.
The early red Tulipa.
1 Rubra vulgaris fundo luteo, & aliquando nigro.
1 An ordinary red, with a yellow, & ≈øometimes a blacke bottome.
2 Rubra ≈øatura oris luteis paruis, dicta Roan.
2 A deep red, with a ≈ømall edge of yellow, called a Roane.
3 Baro, i.e. rubra megis inten≈øa, oris luteis paruis.
3 A Baron, that is, a faire red with a ≈ømall yellow edge.
4 Dux maior & minor, i.e. rubra magis aut minus elegans ≈øatura, oris luteis maximis, vel minoribus, & fundo luteo magno. Alia alijs e≈øt magis amoena, in alijs etiam fundo nigro vel ob≈øcuro viridi.

4 A Duke, a greater and a le≈ø≈øer, that is, a more or le≈øs faire deep red, with greater or le≈ø≈øer yellow edges, and a great yellow bottome. Some of this ≈øort are much more or le≈ø≈øe faire then others, ≈øome al≈øo haue a blacke or darke greene bottome.
5 Duci≈ø≈øa, i.e. Duci ≈øimilis, at plus lutei qu√†m rubri, oris magnis luteis, & rubore magis aut minus intus in gyrum acto, fundo item luteo magno.

5 A Dutche≈ø≈øe, that is like vnto the Duke, but more yellow then red, with greater yellow edges, and the red more or le≈ø≈øe circling the middle of the flower on the in≈øide, with a large yellow bottome.
6 Testamentum Brancion, i.e. rubra ≈øanguinea ≈øatura, aut minus rubra, oris pallidis, magnis vel paruis: alia alijs magis aut minus elegans diuer ≈øimodo.

6 A Te≈øtament Brancion, or a Brancion Duke, that is, a faire deepe red, or le≈ø≈øe red, with a pale yellow or butter coloured edge, ≈øome larger others ≈ømaller: and ≈øome more plea≈øing then others, in a very variable manner.
7 Flambans, ex rubore & flauedine radiata, vel ≈øtriata fundo luteo.
7 A Flambant, differing from the Dutche≈ø≈øe; for this hath no ≈øuch great yellow edge, but ≈øtreaks of yellow through the leafe vnto the very edge.

8 Mali Aurantij coloris, ex rubore, & flauedine integr√®, non ≈øeparatim mixta, oris luteis paruis, vel ab≈ø
que oris.
8 An Orenge colour, that is, a reddi≈øh yellow, or a red and yellow equally mixed, with ≈ømall yellow edges, and ≈øometimes without.
9 Minij, ≈øiue Cinabaris coloris, i.e. ex purpurea, rubedine, & flauedine radiata, vnguibus luteis, & aliquando oris.
9 A Vermillion, that is, a purpli≈øh red, ≈øtreamed with yellow, the bottome yellow, and ≈øometimes the edges.
10 Rex Tuliparum, i.e. ex ≈øanguineo & aureo radiatim mixta, √† flammea diuer≈øa, fundo luteo, orbe rubro.
10 The Kings flower, that is, a crim≈øon or bloud red, ≈øtreamed with a gold yellow, differing from the Flambant, the bottome yellow, circled with red.
11 Tunica Morionis, i.e. ex rubore & aureo ≈øeparatim diui≈øa.
11 A Fooles coate, parted with red and yellow guardes.
Tulipa praecox lutea.
The early yellow Tulipa.
1 Lutea ≈øiue flaua.
1 A faire gold yellow without mixture.
2 Pallida lutea ≈øiue ≈øtraminea.
2 A ≈øtrawe colour.
3 Aurea, oris rubicundis.
3 A faire yellow with reddi≈øh edges.
4 Straminea, oris rubris.
4 A ≈øtrawe colour, with red edges.
5 Aurea, rubore perfu≈øa extra.
5 A faire yellow, reddi≈øh on the out≈øide onely.
6 Aurea, vel magis pallida, rubore in gyrum acta ≈øimillima Duci≈ø≈øae, ni≈øi minus rubedinis habet.
6 A gold or paler yellow, circled on the in≈øide a little with red, very like the Dutche≈ø≈øe, but that it hath le≈ø≈øe red therein.
7 Aurea, extremitatibus rubris, dici pote≈øt, Morionis Pilaeus praecox.
7 A gold yellow with red toppes, and may be called, The early Fooles Cap.

div.head: Tulipa de Caffa. The Tulipa of Caffa.
div.p: There is another ≈øort or kinde of early Tulipa, differing from the former, who≈øe pale greene leaues being as broad and large as they, and ≈øometimes crumpled or waued at the edges, in ≈øome haue the edges onely of the ≈øaid leaues for a good breadth, of a whiti≈øh or whiti≈øh yellow colour, and in others, the leaues are li≈øted or parted with whiti≈øh yellow and greene: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth not vp ≈øo high as the former, and beareth a flower at the toppe like vnto the former, in ≈øome of a reddi≈øh yellow colour, with a ru≈ø≈øet coloured ground or bottome, and in others, of other ≈øeuerall colours: the ≈øeede and roote is ≈øo like vnto others of this kinde, that they cannot be di≈øtingui≈øhed.

There is (as I doe heare) of this kinde, both Praecoces, and Serotinae, early flowring, and late flowring, whereof although wee haue not ≈øo exact knowledge, as of the re≈øt, yet I thought good to ≈øpeake ≈øo much, as I could hitherto vnder≈øtand of them, and giue others leaue (if I doe not) hereafter to amplifie it.

div.head: Tulipa Bolonien≈øis, ≈øiue Bombycina flore rubro major. The greater red Bolonia Tulipa.
div.p: There are likewi≈øe other kindes of early Tulipas to bee ≈øpoken of, and fir≈øt of the red Bolonia Tulipa; the roote whereof is plainly di≈øcerned, to be differing from all others: for that it is longer, and not hauing ≈øo plaine an eminence at the bottome thereof, as the former and later Tulipas, but more e≈øpecially becau≈øe the toppe is plentifully ≈øtored with a yellowi≈øh ≈øilke-like woolline≈ø≈øe: the out≈øide likewi≈øe or skinne is of a brighter or paler red, not ≈øo ea≈øie to be pilled away, and runneth vnder ground both downeright and ≈øidewi≈øe (e≈øpecially in the Countrey ground and ayre, where it will encrea≈øe aboundantly, but not either in our London ayre, or forc't grounds) ≈øomewhat like vnto the yellow Bolonia Tulipa next following. It ≈øhooteth out of the ground with broad and long leaues, like the former; but neither ≈øo broad, nor of ≈øo white or mealy a greene colour as the former, but more darke then the late flowring Tulipa, ≈øo that this may bee ea≈øily di≈øcerned by his leafe from any other Tulipa aboue the ground, by one that is skilfull. It beareth likewi≈øe three or foure leaues vpon the ≈øtalke, like the former, and a flower al≈øo at the toppe of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, but that the leaues hereof are alwayes long, and ≈øomewhat narrow, hauing a large blacke bottome, made like vnto a cheuerne, the point whereof ri≈øeth vp vnto the middle of the leafe, higher then any other Tulipa; the flower is of a pale red colour, nothing ≈øo liuely as in the early or late red Tulipas, yet ≈øweeter for the mo≈øt part then any of them, and neere≈øt vnto the yellow Bolonia Tulipa, which is much about the ≈øame ≈øent.

div.head: Tulipa pumilio rubra, ≈øiue Bergomen≈øis rubra media & minor. The dwarfe red Bergomo Tulipa, a bigger and a le≈ø≈øer.
div.p: There are two other ≈øorts hereof, and becau≈øe they were found about Bergomo, do carry that name, the one bigger or le≈ø≈øer then another, yet neither ≈øo great as the former, hauing very little other difference to bee ob≈øerued in them, then that they are ≈ømaller in all parts of them.

div.head: Tulipa Bolonien≈øis flore luteo. The yellow Bolonia Tulipa.
div.p: The roote of this Tulipa may likewi≈øe bee knowne from the former red (or any other Tulipa) in that it ≈øeldome commeth to bee ≈øo bigge, and is not ≈øo woolly at the toppe, and the skinne or out≈øide is ≈øomewhat paler, harder, and ≈øharper pointed: but the bottome is like the former red, and not ≈øo eminent as the early or late Tulipas. This beareth much longer and narrower leaues then any (except the Per≈øian & dwarfe yellow Tulipas) and of a whiti≈øh greene colour: it beareth ≈øometimes but one flower on a ≈øtalke, and ≈øometimes two or three wholly yellow, but ≈ømaller, & more open then the other kinds, and (as I ≈øaid) ≈ømelleth ≈øweete, the head for ≈øeede is ≈ømaller then in others, and hath not that crowne at the head thereof, yet the ≈øeed is like, but ≈ømaller.

div.head: Tulipa Narbonen≈øis, ≈øiue Mon≈øpelien≈øis vel pumilio. The French or dwarfe yellow Tulipa.
div.p: This Tulipa is very like vnto the yellow Bolonia Tulipa, both in roote, leafe, and flower, as al≈øo in the colour thereof, being yellow: the onely difference is, that it is in all things le≈ø≈øer and lower, and is not ≈øo apt to beare, nor ≈øo plentifull to encrea≈øe by the roote.

div.head: Tulipa Italica maior & minor. The Italian Tulipa the greater and the le≈ø≈øer.
div.p: Both the≈øe kindes of Tulipas doe ≈øo neere re≈øemble the la≈øt kinde, that I might almo≈øt ≈øay they were the ≈øame, but that ≈øome difference which I ≈øaw in them, maketh mee ≈øet them apart; and con≈øi≈øteth in the≈øe things, the ≈øtalkes of neither of both the≈øe ri≈øe ≈øo high, as of the fir≈øt yellow Bolonia Tulipa: the leaues of both ≈øorts are writhed in and out at the edges, or made like a waue of the ≈øea, lying neerer the ground, and the flower being yellow within, is browni≈øh or reddi≈øh on the backe, in the middle of the three outer leaues the edges appearing yellow. Both the≈øe kindes doe differ one from the other in nothing, but in that one is bigger, and the other ≈ømaller then the other which I ≈øaw with Iohn Trade≈øcante, my very good friend often remembred.

div.head: Tulipa Lu≈øitanica, ≈øiue pumilio ver≈øicolor. The dwarfe ≈øtript Tulipa.
div.p: This dwarfe Tulipa is al≈øo of the ≈øame kindred with the three la≈øt de≈øcribed; for there is no other difference in this from them, then that the flower hath ≈øome red veins running in the leaues thereof.

There are two other ≈øorts of dwarfe Tulipas with white flowers, whereof Lobel hath made mention in the Appendix to his Aduer≈øaria; the one whereof is the ≈øame that Clu≈øius ≈øetteth forth, vnder the title of Pumilio altera: but becau≈øe I haue not ≈øeen either of them both, I ≈øpeake no further of them.

div.head: Tulipa pumilio alba. The white dwarfe Tulipa.
div.p: But that white flower that Iohn Trade≈øcante ≈øhewed me, and as hee ≈øaith, was deliuered him for a white Pumilio, had a ≈øtalke longer then they ≈øet out theirs to haue, and the flower al≈øo larger, but yet had narrower leaues then other ≈øorts of white Tulipas haue.

div.head: Tulipa Bicolor. The ≈ømall party coloured Tulipa.
div.p: Vnto the≈øe kindes, I may well adde this kinde of Tulipa al≈øo, which was ≈øent out of Italy, who≈øe leaues are ≈ømall, long, and narrow, and of a darke greene colour, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of an Hyacinth: the flower is ≈ømall al≈øo, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe leaues, as all other Tulipas doe, three whereof are wholly of a red colour, and the other three wholly of a yellow.

div.head: Tulipa Per≈øica. The Per≈øian Tulipa.
div.p:
This rare Tulipa, wherewith we haue beene but lately acquainted, doth mo≈øt fitly de≈øerue to be de≈øcribed in this place, becau≈øe it doth ≈øo neerely participate with the Bolonia and Italian Tulipas, in roote, leafe, and flower: the roote hereof is ≈ømall, couered with a thicke hard blacki≈øh ≈øhell or skinne, with a yellowi≈øh woolline≈ø≈øe both at the toppe, and vnder the ≈øhell. It ri≈øeth out of the ground at the fir≈øt, with one very long and ≈ømall round leafe, which when it is three or foure inches high, doth open it ≈øelfe, and ≈øhew forth another ≈ømall leafe (as long almo≈øt as the former) breaking out of the one ≈øide thereat, and after it a third, and ≈øometimes a fourth, and a fift; but each ≈øhorter then other, which afterwards be of the breadth of the dwarfe yellow Tulipa, or ≈øomewhat broader, but much longer then any other, and abiding more hollow, and of the colour of the early Tulipas on the in≈øide: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a foot and a halfe
1 Tulipa Bombycina flore rubro. The red Bolonia Tulipa. 2 Tulipa Bolonien≈øis flore luteo. The yellow Bolonia Tulipa. 3 Tulipa pupilio rubra fiue lutea. The red or yellow dwarfe Tulipa. 4 Folium Tulipa de Caffa per totum ≈øtriatum. The leafe of the Tulipa of Caffa ≈øtriped throughout the whole leafe. 5 Folium Tulipa de Caffa per oras ≈øtriatum. The leafe of the Tulipa of Caffa ≈øtriped at the edges onely. 6 Tulipa Perfica. The Per≈øian Tulipa. 7 Tulipa Cretica. The Tulipa of Candie. 8 Tulipa Armeniaca. The Tulipa of Armenia. depiction of flowers
high ≈øometimes, bearing one flower thereon, compo≈øed of ≈øixe long and pointed leaues of the forme of other ≈ømall Tulipas, and not ≈øhewing much bigger then the yellow Italian Tulipa, and is wholly white, both in≈øide and out≈øide of all the leaues, except the three outtermo≈øt, which haue on the backe of them, from the middle toward the edges, a ≈øhew of a browni≈øh blu≈øh, or pale red colour, yet deeper in the mid≈øt, and the edges remaining wholly white: the bottomes of all the≈øe leaues are of a darke or dun tawnie colour, and the chiues and tippes of a darki≈øh purple or tawnie al≈øo. This doth beare ≈øeed but ≈øeldome in our Country, that euer I could vnder≈øtand, but when it doth, it is ≈ømall like vnto the Bolonia or dwarfe yellow Tulipas, being not ≈øo plentifull al≈øo in parting, or ≈øetting of by the roote as they, and neuer groweth nor abideth ≈øo great as it is brought vnto vs, and ≈øeldome likewi≈øe flowreth after the fir≈øt yeare: for the rootes for the mo≈øt part with euery one grow le≈ø≈øe and le≈ø≈øe, decaying euery yeare, and ≈øo peri≈øh for the mo≈øt part by rea≈øon of the fro≈øts and cold, and yet they haue been ≈øet deepe to defend them, although of their owne nature they will runne downe deep into the ground.

div.head: Tulipa B√Ωzantina duobus floribus Clu≈øij. The ≈ømall Tulipa of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: The ≈ømall Tulipa of Con≈øtantinople, beareth for the mo≈øt part but two leaues on the ≈øtalke, which are faire and broad, almo≈øt like vnto the Candy Tulipa, next hereunto to be de≈øcribed: the ≈øtalke it ≈øelfe ri≈øeth not aboue a foote high, bearing ≈øometimes but one flower, but mo≈øt commonly two thereon, one below another, and are no bigger then the flowers of the yellow Bolonia Tulipa, but differing in colour; for this is on the out≈øide of a purpli≈øh colour, mixed with white and greene, and on the in≈øide of a faire blu≈øh colour, the bottome and chiues being yellow, and the tippes or pendents blacki≈øh: the roote is very like the yellow Bolonia Tulipa.

div.head: Tulipa Cretica. The Tulipa of Candie.
div.p: This Tulipa is of later knowledge with vs then the Per≈øian, but doth more hardly thriue, in regard of our cold climate; the de≈øcription whereof, for ≈øo much as wee haue knowledge, by the ≈øight of the roote and leafe, and relation from others of the flower, (for I haue not yet heard that it hath very often flowred in our Country) is as followeth. It beareth faire broad leaues, re≈øembling the leaues of a Lilly, of a greeni≈øh colour, and not very whiti≈øh: the ≈øtalke beareth thereon one flower, larger and more open then many other, which is eyther wholly white, or of a deepe red colour, or el≈øe is variably mixed, white with a fine reddi≈øh purple, the bottomes being yellow, with purpli≈øh chiues tipt with blacki≈øh pendents: the roote is ≈ømall, and ≈øomewhat like the dwarfe yellow Tulipa, but ≈øomewhat bigger.

div.head: Tulipa Armeniaca. The Tulipa of Armenia.
div.p: This ≈ømall Tulipa is much differing from all the former (except the ≈ømall or dwarfe white Tulipas remembred by Lobel and Clu≈øius, as is before ≈øet downe) in that it beareth three or foure ≈ømall, long, and ≈øomewhat narrow greene leaues, altogether at one ioynt or place; the ≈øtalke being not high, and naked or without leaues from them to the toppe, where it beareth one ≈ømall flower like vnto an ordinary red Tulipa, but ≈øomewhat more yellow, tending to an Orenge colour with a blacke bottome: the roote is not much bigger then the ordinary yellow Bolonia Tulipa, before ≈øet downe.
And the≈øe are the ≈øorts of this fir≈øt Cla≈øsis of early Tulipas.

div.head: Tulipa media. The meaner or middle flowring Tulipa.
div.p:
For any other, or further de≈øcription of this kinde of Tulipa, it ≈øhall not neede, hauing giuen it ≈øufficiently in the former early Tulipa, the maine difference con≈øi≈øting fir≈øt in the time of flowring, which is about a moneth after the early Tulipas, yet ≈øome more ≈øome le≈ø≈øe: for euen in the Praecoces, or early ones, ≈øome flower a little earlier, and later then others, and then in the colours of the flowers; for wee haue ob≈øerued many
colours, and mixtures, or varieties of colours in the Medias, which we could neuer ≈øee in the Praecoces, and ≈øo al≈øo ≈øome in the Praecoces, which are not in the Medias: yet there is farre greater varieties of mixture of colours in the≈øe Medias, then hath been ob≈øerued in all the Praecoces, (although Clu≈øius ≈øaith otherwi≈øe) eyther by my ≈øelfe, or by any other that I haue conuer≈øed with about this matter, and all this hath happened by the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede, as I ≈øaid before. I will therefore in this place not trouble you with any further circum≈øtance, then to di≈øtingui≈øh them, as I haue done in the former early Tulipas, into their foure primary colours, and vnder them, giue you their ≈øeuerall varieties and names, for ≈øo much as hath come to my knowledge, not doubting, but that many that haue trauelled in the ≈øowing of the ≈øeed of Tulipas many yeares, may ob≈øerue each of them to haue ≈øome variety that others haue not: and therefore I thinke no one man can come to the knowledge of all particular di≈øtinctions.

row.cell: Tulipa media alba.
The white meane flowring Tulipa.
1 Niuea, fundo albo vel luteo.

2 A ≈øiluer colour, that is, a very pale or whiti≈øh a≈øhe colour, with a yellowi≈øh bottome and purple chiues.
3 Margarit ‚Ä¢ na alba, carneo diluti≈øsima.
3 A Pearle colour, that is, white, with a wa≈øh or ≈øhew of blu≈øh.
4 Alba, fundo caeruleo vel nigro.
4 A white, with a blew or black bottome.
5 Albida.
5 A Creame colour.
6 Alb ‚Ä¢ , oris rubris. Haec tria genera in aliquibus con≈øtanter tenent oras, in a ‚Ä¢ ijs di≈øpergunt.
6 A white, with red edges. The≈øe three ≈øorts doe hold their edges con≈øtant in ≈øome, but well ≈øpread in others.
7 Alba, purpureis oris. Haec tria genera in aliquibus con≈øtanter tenent oras, in a ‚Ä¢ ijs di≈øpergunt.
7 A white, with purple edges. The≈øe three ≈øorts doe hold their edges con≈øtant in ≈øome, but well ≈øpread in others.
8 Alba, oris coccineis. Haec tria genera in aliquibus con≈øtanter tenent oras, in a ‚Ä¢ ijs di≈øpergunt.

9 Albida primum, deinde albidior, oris purpureis, & venis intr√≤ re≈øpicientibus, dicta nobis Hackquenay.
9 A pale or whiti≈øh yellow, which after a few dayes groweth more white, with purpli≈øh red edges, and ≈øome ≈øtreakes running inward from the edge, which we call an Hackney.

12 Alba, purpurea rubedine plumata, diuer≈øarum ≈øpecierum, quae cum ≈øuperiore, vel albo, vel luteo, vel paruo caeruleo constant fundo, quae con≈øtanter tenent punctatos colores, & non di≈øpergunt, ≈øed po≈øt trium aut quatuor dierum ≈øpatium pulchriores apparent.

12 A white, ≈øpeckled with a reddi≈øh purple, more or le≈ø≈øe, of diuers ≈øorts, with white, yellow, or blew bottomes, all which doe hold their markes con≈øtant, and doe not ≈øpread their colours, but ≈øhew fairer after they haue ≈øtood blown three or foure dayes.

13 Panni argentei coloris, i.e. alba, plumata, punctata, ≈øtriata, vel diuer≈øimod√® variata, rubedine dilutiore, vel ≈øaturatiore purpurea, interius vel exterius, vel vtrin
que , diuer≈øarum ≈øpecierum.

que fundo, vel fundo purpureo caruleo, vel caeruleo albo circundato, diuers√® ≈øignata, vel variata intus ad medietatem foliorum, ≈øur≈øum in orbem vt plurimum, vel ad oras pertingens amplas & albas. Hae ≈øpecies tantoper√® multiplicantur, vt vix ≈øint explicabiles.

Huc reddenda e≈ø≈øet viridium Tuliparum cla≈øsis, quae diuer≈øarum etiam constat ≈øpecierum. Vna viridis inten≈øior, cuius flos ≈øemper fer√® ≈øemiclau≈øus manet ≈øtaminibus fi ‚Ä¢ briatis. Altera remi≈øsior, in≈øtar P≈øittaci pennarum viridium, luteo variata oris albis. Tertia adhuc dilutiori viriditate oris purpureis. Quarta, cujus folia equaliter purpura diluta, & viriditate diui≈øa ≈øunt. Quinta, folijs longi≈øsimis ≈øtellaemodo expan≈øis, ex rubore & viriditate coacta.

Vnto the≈øe may be added the greene Tulipa, which is al≈øo of diuers ≈øorts. One hauing a great flower of a deepe green colour, ≈øeldome opening it ≈øelfe, but abiding alwaies as it were halfe ≈øhut vp and clo≈øed, the chiues being as it were feathered. Another of a paler or yellowi≈øh green, paned with yellow, and is called, The Parret, &c. with white edges. A third of a more yellowi≈øh green, with red or purpli≈øh edges. A fourth, hath the leaues of the flower equally almo≈øt parted, with greene and a light purple colour, which abiding a long time in flower, groweth in time to be fairer marked: for at the fir≈øt it doth not ≈øhew it ≈øelfe ≈øo plainely diuided. Some call this a greene Swi≈ø≈øer. A fifth hath the longe≈øt leaues ≈øtanding like a ≈øtarre, con≈øi≈øting of greene and purple.

div.head: Tulipa Serotina. The late flowring Tulipa.
div.p: The late flowring Tulipa hath had his de≈øcription expre≈ø≈øed in the precedent di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øo that I ≈øhall not neede to make a repetition of what hath already beene ≈øet downe. The greate≈øt matter of knowledge in this kinde is this, That it hath no ≈øuch plentifull variety of colours or mixtures in his flowers, as are in the two former ≈øorts, but is confined within the≈øe limits here expre≈ø≈øed, as farre as hath come to our knowledge.

An ordinary red, or el≈øe a deeper red like blacke bloud, with a blacke or yellow bottome, or blacke circled with yellow, called the Suns eye.

div.p: There yet remaine many ob≈øeruations, concerning the≈øe beautifull flowers, fit to be knowne, which could not, without too much prolixity, be comprehended within the body of the de≈øcription of them; but are re≈øerued to bee intreated of a part by them≈øelues.

All ≈øorts of Tulipas beare v≈øually but one ≈øtalke, and that without any branches: but ≈øometimes nature is ≈øo plentifull in bearing, that it hath two or three ≈øtalkes, and ≈øometimes two, or more branches out of one ≈øtalke (euery ≈øtalke or branch bearing one flower at the toppe) but this is but ≈øeldome ≈øeene; and when it doth happen once, it is hardly ≈øeene againe in the ≈øame roote, but is a great ≈øigne, that the roote that doth thus, being an old roote, will the ≈øame yeare part into diuers rootes, whereof euery one, being of a rea≈øonable greatne≈ø≈øe, will beare both his ≈øtalke and flower the next yeare, agreeing with the mother plant in colour, as all the of-≈øets of Tulipas doe for the mo≈øt part: for although the young of-≈øets of ≈øome doe vary from the maine roote, euen while it groweth with them, yet being ≈øeparated, it will bee of the ≈øame colour with the mother plant.

There groweth oftentimes in the Medias, and ≈øometimes al≈øo in the Praecoces, but more ≈øeldome, a ≈ømall bulbe or roote, hard aboue the ground, at the bottome of the ≈øtalke, and betweene it and the lower leafe, which when the ≈øtalke is dry, and it ripe, being put into the ground, will bring forth in time a flower like vnto the mother plant, from whence it was taken.

The flowers al≈øo of Tulipas con≈øi≈øt mo≈øt commonly of ≈øixe leaues, but ≈øometimes they are ≈øeene to haue eight or tenne, or more leaues; but v≈øually, tho≈øe rootes beare but their ordinary number of ≈øixe leaues the next yeare: the head for ≈øeede then, is for the mo≈øt part foure ≈øquare, which at all other times is but three ≈øquare, or when the flower wanteth a leafe or two, as ≈øometimes al≈øo it doth, it then is flat, hauing but two ≈øides.

The forme of the flower is al≈øo very variable; for the leaues of ≈øome Tulipas are all ≈øharpe pointed, or all blunt and round pointed, and many haue the three outer leaues ≈øharpe pointed, and the three inner round or pointed, and ≈øome contrariwi≈øe, the three outermo≈øt round pointed, and the three inner ≈øharpe pointed. Againe, ≈øome haue all the leaues of the flowers long and narrow, and ≈øome haue them broader and ≈øhorter. Some Praecoces al≈øo haue their flowers very large and great, equall vnto eyther the Media, or Serotina, which mo≈øt commonly are the large≈øt, and others haue them as ≈ømall as the Bolonia Tulipa.

The bottomes of the leaues of the flowers are al≈øo variably diuer≈øified, and ≈øo are both the chiues or threeds that ≈øtand vp about the head, and the tips or pendents that are hanging loo≈øe on the toppes of them; and by the difference of the bottomes or chiues, many flowers are di≈øtingui≈øhed, which el≈øe are very like in colour, and alike al≈øo marked.

For the ≈ømell al≈øo there is ≈øome diuer≈øity; for that the flowers of ≈øome are very ≈øweete, of others nothing at all, and ≈øome betweene both, of a ≈ømall ≈øent, but not offen≈øiue: and yet ≈øome I haue ob≈øerued haue had a ≈øtrong ill ≈øent; but how to ≈øhew you to di≈øtingui≈øh them, more then by your owne ≈øen≈øe, I cannot: for the ≈øeedes of ≈øweete ≈ømelling Tulipas doe not follow their mother plant, no more then they doe in the colour.

And la≈øtly, take this, which is not the lea≈øt ob≈øeruation, worth the noting, that I haue ob≈øerued in many: When they haue beene of one entire colour for diuers yeares, yet in ≈øome yeare they haue altered very much, as if it had not beene the ≈øame, viz. from a purple or ≈øtamell, it hath beene variably either parted, or mixed, or ≈øtriped with white, eyther in part, or through the whole flower, and ≈øo in a red or yellow flower, that it hath had eyther red or yellow edges, or yellow or red ≈øpots, lines, veines, or flames, running through the red or yellow colour, and ≈øometimes it hath happened, that three leaues haue been equally parted in the middle with red and yellow, the other three abiding of one colour, and in ≈øome the red had ≈øome yellow in it, and the yellow ≈øome red ≈øpots in it al≈øo; whereof I haue ob≈øerued, that all ≈øuch flowers, not hauing their originall in that manner, (for ≈øome that haue ≈øuch or the like markes from the beginning, that is, from the fir≈øt and ≈øecond yeares flowring, are con≈øtant, and doe not change) but as I ≈øaid, were of one colour at the fir≈øt, doe ≈øhew the
weakne≈ø≈øe and decay of the roote, and that this extraordinary beauty in the flower, is but as the brightne≈ø≈øe of a light, vpon the very extingui≈øhing thereof, and doth plainly declare, that it can doe his Ma≈øter no more ≈øeruice, and therefore with this iollity doth bid him good night. I know there is a common opinion among many (and very confidently maintained) that a Tulipa with a white flower, hath changed to beare a red or yellow, and ≈øo of the red or yellow, and other colours, that they are likewi≈øe incon≈øtant, as though no flowers were certaine: but I could neuer either ≈øee or heare for certaine any ≈øuch alteration, nor any other variation, but what is formerly expre≈ø≈øed. Let not therefore any iudicious be carried away with any ≈øuch idle conceit, but rather ≈øu≈øpect ≈øome deceit in their Gardeners or others, by taking vp one, and putting in another in the place, or el≈øe their owne mi≈øtaking.

Now for the ≈øowing, planting, tran≈øplanting, choi≈øe, and ordering of Tulipas, which is not the lea≈øt of regard, concerning this ≈øubiect in hand, but (as I think) would be willingly entertained; What I haue by my be≈øt endeauours learned, by mine owne paines in almo≈øt forty yeares trauell, or from others informations, I am willing here to ≈øet downe; not doubting, but that ≈øome may adde what hath not come to my knowledge.

Fir≈øt, in the ≈øowing of ≈øeedes of Tulipas, I haue not ob≈øerued (what≈øoeuer others haue written) nor could of certainty learne of others, that there doth ari≈øe from the ≈øeedes of Praecoces any Medias or Serotine Tulipas, (or but very ≈øeldome) nor am certainly a≈ø≈øured of any: but that the ≈øeedes of all Praecoces (≈øo they be not doubtfull, or of the la≈øt flowring ≈øorts) will bring Praecoces: And I am out of doubt, that I neuer ≈øaw, nor could learne, that euer the ≈øeede of the Medias or Serotines haue giuen Praecoces; but Medias or Serotines, according to their naturall kinde. But if there ≈øhould bee any degeneration, I rather incline to thinke, that it ≈øooner commeth to pa≈ø≈øe (√† meliore ad peius, for facilis e≈øt de≈øcen≈øus, that is) that Praecoces may giue Medias, then that Medias or Serotines ≈øhould giue Praecoces.

For the choi≈øe of your ≈øeede to ≈øowe. Fir≈øt, for the Praecoces, Clu≈øius ≈øaith, that the Praecox Tulipa, that beareth a white flower, is the be≈øt to giue the greate≈øt variety of colours. Some among vs haue reported, that they haue found great variety ri≈øe from the ≈øeede of the red Praecox, which I can more hardly beleeue: but Clu≈øius his experience hath the greater probability, but e≈øpecially if it haue ≈øome mixture of red or purple in it. The purple I haue found to be the be≈øt, next thereunto is the purple with white edges, and ≈øo likewi≈øe the red with yellow edges, each of them will bring mo≈øt of their owne colours. Then the choi≈øe of the be≈øt Medias, is to take tho≈øe colours that are light, rather white then yellow, and purple then red; yea white, not yellow, purple, not red: but the≈øe againe to be ≈øpotted is the be≈øt, and the more the better; but withall, or aboue all in the≈øe, re≈øpect the ground or bottome of the flower, (which in the Praecox Tulipa cannot, becau≈øe you ≈øhall ≈øeldome ≈øee any other ground in them but yellow) for if the flower be white, or whiti≈øh, ≈øpotted, or edged, and ≈øtraked, and the bottome blew or purple (≈øuch as is found in the Holias, and in the Cloth of ≈øiluer, this is beyond all other the mo≈øt excellent, and out of que≈øtion the choi≈øe≈øt of an hundred, to haue the greate≈øt and mo≈øt plea≈øant variety and rarity. And ≈øo in degree, the meaner in beauty you ≈øowe, the le≈ø≈øer ≈øhall your plea≈øure in rarities be. Be≈øtowe not your time in ≈øowing red or yellow Tulipa ≈øeede, or the diuers mixtures of them; for they will (as I haue found by experience) ≈øeldome be worth your paines. The Serotina, or late flowring Tulipa, becau≈øe it is ≈øeldome ≈øeene, with any e≈øpeciall beautifull variety, you may ea≈øily your ≈øelues ghe≈ø≈øe that it can bring forth (euen as I haue al≈øo learned) no raritie, and little or no diuer≈øity at all.

The time and manner to ≈øowe the≈øe ≈øeedes is next to be con≈øidered. You may not ≈øowe them in the ≈øpring of the yeare, if you hope to haue any good of them; but in the Autumne, or pre≈øently after they be thorough ripe and dry: yet if you ≈øowe them not vntill the end of October, they will come forward neuer the wor≈øe, but rather the better; for it is often ≈øeene, that ouer early ≈øowing cau≈øeth them to ≈øpring out of the ground ouer early, ≈øo that if a ≈øharpe ≈øpring chance to follow, it may goe neere to ≈øpoile all, or the mo≈øt of your ≈øeede. Wee v≈øually ≈øowe the ≈øame yeares ≈øeede, yet if you chance to keepe of your owne, or haue from others ≈øuch ≈øeed, as is two years old, they will thriue and doe well enough, e≈øpecially if they were ripe and well gathered:
You mu≈øt not ≈øowe them too thicke, for ≈øo doing hath lo≈øt many a pecke of good ≈øeede, as I can tell; for if the ≈øeede lye one vpon another, that it hath not roome vpon the ≈øprouting, to enter and take roote in the earth, it peri≈øheth by and by. Some v≈øe to tread downe the ground, where they meane to ≈øowe their ≈øeede, and hauing ≈øowne them thereon, doe couer them ouer the thickne≈ø≈øe of a mans thumbe with fine ≈øifted earth, and they thinke they doe well, and haue good rea≈øon for it: for con≈øidering the nature of the young Tulipa rootes, is to runne downe deeper into the ground, euery yeare more then other, they thinke to hinder their quicke de≈øcent by the fa≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the ground, that ≈øo they may encrea≈øe the better. This way may plea≈øe ≈øome, but I doe not v≈øe it, nor can finde the rea≈øon ≈øufficient; for they doe not con≈øider, that the ≈øtiffene≈ø≈øe of the earth, doth cau≈øe the rootes of the young Tulipas to bee long before they grow great, in that a ≈øtiffe ground doth more hinder the well thriuing of the rootes, then a loo≈øe doth, and although the rootes doe runne downe deeper in a loo≈øe earth, yet they may ea≈øily by tran≈øplanting be holpen, and rai≈øed vp high enough. I haue al≈øo ≈øeene ≈øome Tulipas not once remoued from their ≈øowing to their flowring; but if you will not lo≈øe them, you mu≈øt take them vp while their leafe or ≈øtalke is fre≈øh, and not withered: for if you doe not follow the ≈øtalke downe to the roote, be it neuer ≈øo deepe, you will leaue them behinde you. The ground al≈øo mu≈øt be re≈øpected; for the finer, ≈øofter, and richer the mould is, wherein you ≈øowe your ≈øeede, the greater ≈øhall be your encrea≈øe and varietie: Sift it therefore from all ≈øtones and rubbi≈øh, and let it be either fat naturall ground of it ≈øelfe, or being muckt, that it bee thoroughly rotten: but ≈øome I know, to mend their ground, doe make ≈øuch a mixture of grounds, that they marre it in the making.

After the ≈øeede is thus ≈øowne, the fir≈øt yeares ≈øpringing bringeth forth leaues, little bigger then the ordinary gra≈ø≈øe leaues; the ≈øecond yeare bigger, and ≈øo by degrees euery yeare bigger then other. The leaues of the Praecoces while they are young, may be di≈øcerned from the Medias by this note, which I haue ob≈øerued. The leaues of them doe wholly ≈øtand vp aboue the ground, ≈øhewing the ≈ømall foot≈øtalkes, whereby euerie leafe doth ≈øtand, but the leaues of the Medias or Serotines doe neuer wholly appeare out of the ground, but the lower part which is broad, abideth vnder the vpper face of the earth. Tho≈øe Tulipas now growing to bee three yeares old, (yet ≈øome at the ≈øecond, if the ground and ayre be corre≈øpondent) are to bee taken vp out of the ground, wherein yee ≈øhall finde they haue runne deepe, and to be anew planted, after they haue been a little dryed and clean≈øed, eyther in the ≈øame, or another ground againe, placing them rea≈øonable neare one vnto another, according to their greatne≈ø≈øe, which being planted and couered ouer with earth againe, of about an inch or two thickne≈ø≈øe, may be left vntaken vp againe for two yeare longer, if you will, or el≈øe remoued euery yeare after, as you plea≈øe; and thus by tran≈øplanting them in their due ≈øea≈øon (which is ≈øtill in the end of Iuly, or beginning of Augu≈øt, or thereabouts) you ≈øhall according to your ≈øeede and ≈øoyle, haue ≈øome come to bearing, in the fifth yeare after the flowring, (and ≈øome haue had them in the fourth, but that hath beene but few, and none of the be≈øt, or in a rich ground) ≈øome in the ≈øixth and ≈øeuenth, and ≈øome peraduenture, not vntill the eighth or tenth yeare: but ≈øtill remember, that as your rootes growe greater, that in re-planting you giue them the more roome to be di≈øtant one from another, or el≈øe the one will hinder, if not rot the other.

The ≈øeede of the Praecoces, doe not thriue and come forward ≈øo fa≈øt as the Medias or Serotines, nor doe giue any of-≈øets in their running downe as the Medias doe, which v≈øually leaue a ≈ømall roote at the head of the other that is runne downe euery yeare; and be≈øides, are more tender, and require more care and attendance then the Medias, and therefore they are the more re≈øpected.

This is a generall and certaine rule in all Tulipas, that all the while they beare but one leafe, they will not beare flower, whether they bee ≈øeedlings, or the of-≈øets of elder rootes, or the rootes them≈øelues, that haue heretofore borne flowers; but when they ≈øhew a ≈øecond leafe, breaking out of the fir≈øt, it is a certaine ≈øigne, that it will then beare a flower, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øome ca≈øualty hinder it, as fro≈øt or raine, to nip or ≈øpoile the bud, or other vntimely accident befall it.

To ≈øet or plant your be≈øt and bearing Tulipas ≈øomewhat deeper then other rootes, I hold it the be≈øt way; for if the ground bee either cold, or lye too open to the cold
Northerne ayre, they will be the better defended therein, and not ≈øuffer the fro≈øts or cold to pierce them ≈øo ≈øoone: for the deepe fro≈øts and ≈ønowes doe pinch the Praecoces chiefly, if they bee too neare the vppermo≈øt cru≈øt of the earth; and therefore many, with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, couer ouer their ground before Winter, with either fre≈øh or old rotten dung, and that will maruellou≈øly pre≈øerue them. The like cour≈øe you may hold with ≈øeedlings, to cau≈øe them to come on the forwarder, ≈øo it bee after the fir≈øt yeares ≈øowing, and not till then.

To remoue Tulipas after they haue ≈øhot forth their fibres or ≈ømall ≈øtrings, which grow vnder the great round rootes, (that is, from September vntill they bee in flower) is very dangerous; for by remouing them when they haue taken fa≈øt hold in the ground, you doe both hinder them in the bearing out their flower, and be≈øides, put them in hazzard to peri≈øh, at lea≈øt to bee put backe from bearing for a while after, as oftentimes I haue proued by experience: But when they are now ri≈øen to flower, and ≈øo for any time after, you may ≈øafely take them vp if you will, and remoue them without danger, if you haue any good regard vnto them, vnle≈ø≈øe it be a young bearing roote, which you ≈øhall in ≈øo doing much hinder, becau≈øe it is yet tender, by rea≈øon it now beareth his fir≈øt flower. But all Tulipa roots when their ≈øtalke and leaues are dry, may mo≈øt ≈øafely then be taken vp out of the ground, and be ≈øo kept (≈øo that they lye in a dry, and not in a moi≈øt place) for ≈øixe moneths, without any great harme: yea I haue knowne them that haue had them nine moneths out of the ground, and haue done rea≈øonable well, but this you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand withall, that they haue not been young but elder rootes, and they haue been orderly taken vp and pre≈øerued. The dryer you keep a Tulipa roote the better, ≈øo as you let it not lye in the ≈øunne or winde, which will pierce it and ≈øpoile it.

Thus Gentlewomen for your delights, (for the≈øe plea≈øures are the delights of lea≈øure, which hath bred your loue & liking to them, and although you are herein predominant, yet cannot they be barred from your beloued, who I doubt not, wil ≈øhare with you in the delight as much as is fit) haue I taken this paines, to ≈øet downe, and bring to your knowledge ≈øuch rules of art, as my ≈ømall skill hath enabled mee withall concerning this ≈øubiect, which of all other, ≈øeemed fitte≈øt in this manner to be enlarged, both for the varietie of matter, and excellency of beautie herein, and al≈øo that the≈øe rules ≈øet forth together in one place, might ≈øaue many repetitions in other places, ≈øo that for the planting and ordering of all other bulbous rootes, and the ≈øowing the ≈øeedes of them, you may haue recour≈øe vnto the≈øe rules, (tanquam ad normam & examen) which may ≈øerue in generall for all other, little diuer≈øitie of particulars needing exception.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The greater Tulipas haue fir≈øt beene ≈øent vs from Con≈øtantinople, and other parts of Turkie, where it is ≈øaid they grow naturally wilde in the Fields, Woods, and Mountaines; as Thracia, Macedonia, Pontus about the Euxine Sea, Cappadocia, Bithynia, and about Tripolis and Aleppo in Syria al≈øo: the le≈ø≈øer haue come from other ≈øeuerall places, as their names doe de≈øcipher it out vnto vs; as Armenia, Per≈øia, Candye, Portugall, Spaine, Italy, and France. They are all now made Denizens in our Gardens, where they yeeld vs more delight, and more encrea≈øe for their proportion, by rea≈øon of the culture, then they did vnto their owne naturals.

div.head: The Time.
div.p:
The≈øe doe flower ≈øome earlier, ≈øome later, for three whole moneths together at the lea≈øt, therein adorning out a Garden mo≈øt gloriou≈øly, in that being but one kinde of flower, it is ≈øo full of variety, as no other (except the Daffodils, which yet are not comparable, in that they yeeld not that alluring plea≈øant variety) doe the like be≈øides. Some of the Praecoces haue beene in flower with vs, (for I ≈øpeake not of their owne naturall places, where the Winters are milder, and the Spring earlier then ours) in the moneth of Ianuary, when the Winter before hath beene milde, but many in February,
and all the Praecoces, from the beginning to the end of March, if the yeare be kindly: at what time the Medias doe begin, and abide all Aprill, and part of May, when the Serotines flower and fade; but this, as I ≈øaid, if the yeare be kindly, or el≈øe each kinde will be a moneth later. The ≈øeede is ripe in Iune and Iuly, according to their early or late flowring.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
There haue beene diuers opinions among our moderne Writers, by what name this plant was knowne to the ancient Authors. Some would haue it be Co≈ømo≈øandalos, of the Ancient. Dodonaeus referreth it to
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ of Theophra≈øtus, in his ≈øeuenth Booke and thirteenth Chapter: but thereof he is ≈øo briefe, that be≈øides the bare name, wee cannot finde him to make any further relation of forme, or quality. And Bauhinus, vpon Matthiolus Commentaries of Dio≈øcorides, and in his Pinax al≈øo, followeth his opinion. Camerarius in his Hortus Medicus is of opinion, it may be referred to the Helychry≈øum of Crateua. Ge≈øner, as I thinke, fir≈øt of all, and after him Lobel, Camerarius, Clu≈øius and many others, referre it to the Satyrium of Dio≈øcorides: and ≈øurely this opinion is the mo≈øt probable for many rea≈øons. Fir≈øt, for that this plant doth grow very frequent in many places of Greece, and the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, which were no doubt ≈øufficiently knowne both to Theophra≈øtus, and Dio≈øcorides, and was accounted among bulbous rootes, although by ≈øundry names. And ≈øecondly, as Dio≈øcorides ≈øetteth forth his Satyrium, ≈øo this mo≈øt commonly beareth three leaues vpon a ≈øtalke (although ≈øometimes with vs it hath foure or fiue) like vnto a Lilly, whereof ≈øome are often ≈øeen to be both red, in the fir≈øt ≈øpringing, and al≈øo vpon the decaying, e≈øpecially in a dry time, and in a dry ground: the flower likewi≈øe of ≈øome is white, and like a Lilly; the roote is round, and as white within as the white of an egge, couered with a browne coate, hauing a ≈øweeti≈øh, but not vnplea≈øant ta≈øte, as any man without danger many try. This de≈øcription doth ≈øo liuely ≈øet forth this plant, that I thinke wee ≈øhall not neede to be any longer in doubt, where to finde Dio≈øcorides his Satyrium Triphyllum, ≈øeeing wee haue ≈øuch plenty growing with vs. And thirdly, there is no doubt, but that it hath the ≈øame qualities, as you ≈øhall hereafter heare further. And la≈øtly, that plant likewi≈øe that beareth a red flower, may very well agree with his Erythronium; for the de≈øcriptions in Dio≈øcorides are both alike, as are their qualities, the greate≈øt doubt may be in the ≈øeede, which yet may agree vnto Lin or Flaxe as fitly, or rather more then many other plants doe, in many of his compari≈øons, which yet wee receiue for currant. For the ≈øeede of Tulipas are flat, hard, and ≈øhining as the ≈øeede of Linum or Flaxe, although of another colour, and bigger, as Dio≈øcorides him≈øelfe ≈øetteth it downe. But if there ≈øhould be a mi≈øtaking in the writing of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ for „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in the Greeke Text, as the ≈ølippe is both ea≈øie and likely, it were then out of all que≈øtion the ≈øame: for the ≈øeede is very like vnto the ≈øeede of Lillies, as any man may ea≈øily di≈øcerne that know them, or will compare them. It is generally called by all the late Writers, Tulipa, which is deriued from the name Tulpan, whereby the Turkes of Dalmatia doe entitle their head Tyres, or Caps; and this flower being blowne, laide open, and inuerted, doth very well re≈øemble them. We haue receiued the early kinde from Con≈øtantinople, by the name of Cafa lale, and the other by the name of Cauela lale. Lobel and others doe call it Lilio-narci≈ø≈øus, becau≈øe it doth re≈øemble a Lilly in the leafe, flower, and ≈øeede, and a Daffodill in the roote. We call it in Engli≈øh the Turkes Cap, but mo≈øt v≈øually Tulipa, as mo≈øt other Chri≈øtian Countries that delight therein doe. Dale≈øchampius calleth it Oulada.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
Dio≈øcorides writeth, that his fir≈øt Satyrium is profitable for them that
haue a convul≈øion in their necke, (which wee call a cricke in the necke) if it be drunke in har≈øh (which we call red) wine.

That the roots of Tulipas are nouri≈øhing, there is no doubt, the plea≈øant, or at lea≈øt the no vnplea≈øant ta≈øte, may hereunto per≈øwade; for diuers haue had them ≈øent by their friends from beyond Sea, and mi≈øtaking them to bee Onions, haue v≈øed them as Onions in their pottage or broth, and neuer found any cau≈øe of mi≈ølike, or any ≈øen≈øe of euill quality produced by them, but accounted them ≈øweete Onions.

Further, I haue made tryall of them my ≈øelfe in this manner. I haue pre≈øerued the rootes of the≈øe Tulipas in Sugar, as I haue done the rootes of Eringus, Orchis, or any other ≈øuch like, and haue found them to be almo≈øt as plea≈øant as the Eringus rootes, being firme and ≈øound, fit to be pre≈øented to the curious; but for force of Venereous quality, I cannot ≈øay, either from my ≈øelfe, not hauing eaten many, or from any other, on whom I haue be≈øtowed them: but ≈øurely, if there be any ≈øpeciall propertie in the rootes of Orchis, or ≈øome other tending to that purpo≈øe, I thinke this may as well haue it as they. It ≈øhould ≈øeeme, that Dio≈øcorides doth attribute a great Venereous faculty to the ≈øeede, whereof I know not any hath made any e≈øpeciall experiment with vs as yet.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus. The Daffodill.
