div.p: THere hath beene great confu≈øion among many of our moderne Writers of plants, in not di≈øtingui≈øhing the manifold varieties of Daffodils; for euery one almo≈øt, without con≈øideration of kinde or forme, or other ≈øpeciall note, giueth names ≈øo diuer≈øly one from another, that if any one ≈øhall receiue from ≈øeuerall places the Catalogues of their names (as I haue had many) as they ≈øet them down, and compare the one Catalogue with the other, he ≈øhall ≈øcarce haue three names in a dozen to agree together, one calling that by one name, which another calleth by another, that very few can tell what they meane. And this their confu≈øion, in not di≈øtingui≈øhing the name of Narci≈ø≈øus from P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus, is of all other in this kinde the greate≈øt and gro≈ø≈øe≈øt errour. To auoide therefore that gulfe, whereof I complaine that ≈øo manie haue bin endrenched; and to reduce the Daffodils into ≈øuch a methodicall order, that euery one may know, to what Cla≈øsis or forme any one doth appertaine, I will fir≈øt diuide them into two principall or primary kindes: that is, into Narci≈ø≈øos, true Daffodils, and P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øos, ba≈øtard Daffodils: which di≈øtinction I hold to be mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie to be ≈øet downe fir≈øt of all that euery one may be named without confu≈øion vnder his owne primary kind, and then to let the other parts of the ≈øubdiui≈øion follow, as is proper to them, and fitte≈øt to expre≈ø≈øe them. Now to cau≈øe you to vnder≈øtand the difference betweene a true Daffodill and a fal≈øe, is this; it con≈øi≈øteth onely in the flower, (when as in all other parts they cannot bee di≈øtingui≈øhed) and chiefly in the middle cup or chalice; for that we doe in a manner onely account tho≈øe to bee P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øos, ba≈øtard Daffodils, who≈øe middle cup is altogether as long, and ≈øometime a little longer then the outter leaues that doe encompa≈ø≈øe it, ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth rather like a trunke or long no≈øe, then a cup or chalice, ≈øuch as almo≈øt all the Narci≈øsi, or true Daffodils haue; I ≈øay almo≈øt, becau≈øe I know that ≈øome of them haue their middle cup ≈øo ≈ømall, that we rather call it a crowne then a cup; and againe, ≈øome of them haue them ≈øo long, that they may ≈øeem to be of the number of the P≈øeudonarci≈øsi, or ba≈øtard Daffodils: but yet may ea≈øily be knowne from them, in that, although the cup of ≈øome of the true Daffodils be great, yet it is wider open at the brim or edge, and not ≈øo long and narrow all alike as the ba≈øtard kindes are, and this is the chiefe and onely way to know how to ≈øeuer the≈øe kindes, which rule holdeth certaine in all, except that kinde which is called Narcci≈ø≈øus luncifolius reflexo flora, who≈øe cup is narrow, and as long as the leaues that turne vp againe.
Secondly, I will ≈øubdiuide each of the≈øe again apart by them≈øelues, into foure ≈øorts; and fir≈øt the Narci≈ø≈øos, or true Daffodils into
Latifolios, broad leafed Daffodils.
Angu≈øtifolios, narrow leafed Daffodils.
Iuncifolios, Ru≈øhe Daffodils, and
Marinos, Sea Daffodils.
The≈øe ≈øorts againe doe comprehend vnder them ≈øome other diui≈øions, whereby they may the better be di≈øtingui≈øhed, and yet ≈øtill bee referred to one of tho≈øe foure former ≈øorts: as
Monanthos, that is, Daffodils that beare but one flower, or two at the mo≈øt vpon a ≈øtalke, and
Polyanthos, tho≈øe that beare many flowers together vpon a ≈øtalke: as al≈øo
Simplici flore, tho≈øe that beare ≈øingle flowers, and
Multiplici flore, or flore pleno, that is, haue double flowers.
Vernales, tho≈øe that flower in the Spring, and among them ≈øome that are earlier; and therefore called
Praecoces, early flowring Daffodils, and
Autumnales, tho≈øe that flower in Autumne onely.

And la≈øtly, with the P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øos, or ba≈øtard Daffodils, I will keepe the ≈øame order, to di≈øtingui≈øh them likewi≈øe into their foure ≈øeuerall ≈øorts; and as with the true Daffodils, ≈øo with the≈øe fal≈øe, de≈øcribe vnder euery ≈øort: fir≈øt, tho≈øe that beare ≈øingle flowers, whether one or many vpon a ≈øtalke; and then tho≈øe that beare double flowers, one or many al≈øo. As for the di≈øtinctions of maior and minor, greater and le≈ø≈øer, and of maximus and minimus, greate≈øt and lea≈øt, they doe not onely belong to the≈øe Daffodils; and therefore mu≈øt be v≈øed as occa≈øion permitteth, but vnto all other ≈øort of plants. To begin therefore, I thinke fitte≈øt with that ≈øtately Daffodill, which for his excellency carrieth the name of None ≈øuch.

div.head: 1. Narci≈ø≈øus latifolius omnium maximus, amplo calice flauo, ≈øiue Nompareille. The great None ≈øuch Daffodill, or Incomparable Daffodill.
div.p: This Narci≈ø≈øus Nompareille hath three or foure long and broad leaues, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke two foote high at the lea≈øt, at the toppe whereof, out of a thinne skinnie huske, as all Daffodils haue, commeth forth one large ≈øingle flower, and no more v≈øually, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe very pale yellow large leaues, almo≈øt round at the point, with a large cuppe in the middle, ≈øomewhat yellower then the leaues, the bottome whereof next vnto the ≈øtalke is narrow and round, ri≈øing wider to the mouth, which is very large and open, and vneuenly cut in or indented about the edges. The cup doth very well re≈øemble the chalice, that in former dayes with vs, and beyond the Seas is ≈øtill v≈øed to hold the Sacramentall Wine, that is with a narrower bottome, and a wide mouth. After the flower is pa≈øt, ≈øometimes there commeth (for it doth not often) a round greene head, and blacke round ≈øeede therein, like vnto other Daffodils, but greater. The roote is great, as other Daffodils that beare large flowers, and is couered ouer with a browni≈øh coate or skinne. The flower hath little or no ≈øent at all.
Flore geminatoThis doth ≈øometimes bring forth a flower with ten or twelue leaues, and a cup much larger, as if it would be two, euen as the flower ≈øeemeth.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus omnium maximus flore & calice flauo. The great yellow Incomparable Daffodill.
div.p: This other kinde differeth neither in forme, nor bigne≈ø≈øe of leafe or flower from the former, but in the colour of the circling leaues of the flower, which are of the ≈øame yellow colour with the cup.

Flore geminato.This doth ≈øometimes degenerate and grow luxurious al≈øo, bringing forth two flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, each di≈øtinct from other, and ≈øometimes two flowers thru≈øt together, as if they were but one, although it be but ≈øeldome; for it is not a peculiar kinde that is con≈øtant, yearly abiding in the ≈øame forme.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus maximus gri≈øeus calice flauo. The gray Peerle≈ø≈øe Daffodill.
div.p: This Peerle≈ø≈øe Daffodill well de≈øerueth his place among the≈øe kindes, for that it doth much re≈øemble them, and peraduenture is but a difference rai≈øed from the ≈øeede of the former, it is ≈øo like in leafe and flower, but that the leaues ≈øeeme to be ≈øomewhat greater, and the ≈øixe outer leaues of the flower to be of a gli≈øtering whiti≈øh gray colour, and the cup yellow, as the former, but larger.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus latifolius flauo flore amplo calice, ≈øiue Mattene≈ø≈øe. The le≈ø≈øer yellow Nompareille, or the Lady Mattene≈ø≈øes Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill, are ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of the fir≈øt kind, but not altogether ≈øo long or broad: the ≈øtalke likewi≈øe ri≈øeth not vp fully ≈øo high, and beareth one flower like the former, but le≈ø≈øer, and both the cuppe and the leaues are of one colour, that is, of a pale yellow, yet more yellow then in the former: the cup of this al≈øo is le≈ø≈øer, and a little differing; for it is neither fully ≈øo ≈ømall in the bottome, nor ≈øo large at the edges, nor ≈øo crumpled at the brimmes, ≈øo that all the≈øe differences doe plainly ≈øhew it to be another kinde, quite from the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The places of none of the≈øe are certainly knowne to vs where they grow naturally, but we haue them onely in our Gardens, and haue beene ≈øent, and procured from diuers places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower ≈øometimes in the end of March, but chiefly in Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt and ≈øecond haue been ≈øent vs by the name of Narci≈ø≈øe Nompareille, as it is called in French; and in Latine, Narci≈ø≈øus omnium maximus amplo calice flauo, and Narci≈ø≈øus Incomparabilis, that is, the Incomparable Daffodill, or the greate≈øt Daffodill of all other, with a large yellow cuppe: but a≈ø≈øuredly, although this Daffodill doth exceed many other, both in length and bigne≈ø≈øe, yet the great Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill, which ≈øhall be ≈øpoken of hereafter, is in my per≈øwa≈øion oftentimes a farre higher and larger flower; and therefore this name was giuen but relatiuely, we may call it in Engli≈øh, The great None ≈øuch Daffodill, or the Incomparable Daffodill, or the great Peerle≈ø≈øe Daffodill, or the Nompareille Daffodill, which you will: for they all doe an≈øwer either the French or the Latine name; and becau≈øe this name Nomparcille is growne currant by c ‚Ä¢ ≈øtome, I know not well how to alter it. The third kinde may pa≈ø≈øe with the title giuen it, without controule. The la≈øt is very well knowne beyond the Seas, e≈øpecially in the Low Countries, and tho≈øe parts, by the Lady Mattene≈ø≈øe Daffodill, becau≈øe Clu≈øius receiued it from her. We may call it in Engli≈øh, for the corre≈øpondency with the former, The le≈ø≈øer yellow Nompareille, or Peerle≈ø≈øe Daffodill, or the Lady Mattene≈ø≈øe Daffodill, which you will.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Indicus flore rubro, dictus Iacobaeus. The Indian Daffodill with a red flower.
div.p:
This Indian Daffodill is ≈øo differing, both in forme, not hauing a cuppe, and in colour, being red, from the whole Family of the Daffodils (except the next that followeth, and the Autumne Daffodils) that ≈øome might iu≈øtly que≈øtion the fitne≈ø≈øe of his place here. But becau≈øe as all the plants, whether bulbous or other, that come from
the Indies, either Ea≈øt or We≈øt (although they differ very notably, from tho≈øe that grow in the≈øe parts of the world) mu≈øt in a generall ≈øuruey and mu≈øter be ranked euery one, as neere as the ≈øurueiours wit will direct him, vnder ≈øome other growing with vs, that is of neere≈øt likene≈ø≈øe; Euen ≈øo vntill ≈øome other can direct his place more fitly, I ≈øhall require you to accept of him in this, with this de≈øcription that followeth, which I mu≈øt tell you al≈øo, is more by relation then knowledge, or ≈øight of the plant it ≈øelfe. This Daffodill hath diuers broad leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the common or ordinary white Daffodill, of a grayi≈øh greene colour; from the ≈øides whereof, as al≈øo from the middle of them, ri≈øe vp ≈øometimes two ≈øtalkes together, but mo≈øt v≈øually one after another (for very often it flowreth twice in a Summer) and often al≈øo but one ≈øtalke alone, which is of a faint reddi≈øh colour, about a foote high or more, at the toppe whereof, out of a deepe red skinne or huske, commeth forth one flower bending downewards, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe long leaues without any cup in the middle, of an excellent red colour, tending to a crim≈øon; three of the≈øe leaues that turne vpwards, are ≈øomewhat larger then tho≈øe three that hang downewards, hauing ≈øixe threads or chiues in the middle, tipt with yellow pendents, and a three forked ≈øtile longer then the re≈øt, and turning vp the end thereof againe: the roote is round and bigge, of a browni≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and white within. This is ≈øet forth by Aldinus, Cardinall Farne≈øius his Phy≈øitian, that at Rome it ro≈øe vp with ≈øtalkes of flowers, before any leaues appeared.

div.head: The Place. Time, and Names.
div.p: This naturally groweth in the We≈øt Indies, from whence it was brought into Spaine, where it bore both in Iune and Iuly, and by the Indians in their tongue named AZCAL XOCHITL, and hath beene ≈øent from Spaine, vnto diuers louers of plants, into ≈øeuerall parts of Chri≈øtendome, but haue not thriued long in the≈øe tran≈øalpine colder Countries, ≈øo far as I can heare.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Trapezunticus flore luteo praecoci≈øsimus. The early Daffodill of Trebizond.
div.p: Becau≈øe this Daffodill is ≈øo like in flower vnto the former, although differing in colour, I thought it the fitte≈øt place to ioyne it the next thereunto. This early Daffodill hath three or foure ≈øhort very greene leaues, ≈øo like vnto the leaues of the Autumne Daffodill, that many may ea≈øily bee deceiued in mi≈øtaking one for another, the difference con≈øi≈øting chiefly in this, that the leaues of this are not ≈øo broad or ≈øo long, nor ri≈øe vp in Autumne: in the mid≈øt of the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a ≈øhort green ≈øtalke, an handfull high, or not much higher v≈øually, (I ≈øpeake of it as it hath often flowred with mee, whether the cau≈øe be the coldne≈ø≈øe of the time wherein it flowreth, or the nature of the plant, or of our climate, I am in ≈øome doubt; but I doe well remember, that the ≈øtalkes of ≈øome plants, that haue flowred later with me then the fir≈øt, haue by the greater ≈øtrength, and comfort of the Sunne, ri≈øen a good deale higher then the fir≈øt) bearing at the top, out of a whiti≈øh thinne skinne ≈øtriped with greene, one flower a little bending downewards, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe leaues, laid open almo≈øt in the ≈øame manner with the former Indian Daffodill, whereof ≈øome doe a little turne vp their points againe, of a faire pale yellow colour, hauing ≈øixe white chiues within it, tipt with yellow pendents, and a longer pointell: the roote is not very great, but blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, ≈øo like vnto the Autumne Daffodill, but that it is yellow vnder the fir≈øt or outermo≈øt coate, that one may ea≈øily mi≈øtake one for another.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It was ≈øent vs from Con≈øtantinople among other rootes, but as wee may ghe≈ø≈øe by the name, it ≈øhould come thither from Trapezunte or Trebizond.

div.head: The Time.
div.p:
It flowreth ≈øometimes in December, if the former part of the Winter
1 Narci≈ø≈øus No ‚Ä¢ pareille. The incomparable Daffodill. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus Mattene≈øe. The le≈ø≈øer yellow Nomparelle Daffodill. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus Iacobaeus flore rubro. The red Indian Daffodill. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus Trapezunticus. The early Daffodill of Trabe≈øond. 5 Narci≈ø≈øus Montanus albus apophy≈øious traeditus. The white winged Daffodill. 6 Narci≈ø≈øus Montanus, ≈øiue Nompareille totus albus. The white Nompareille, or Peerle≈ø≈øe Daffodill. 7 Narci≈ø≈øus albus oblongo calice. The white Daffodill with a long cup. depiction of flowers
haue been milde; but mo≈øt v≈øually about the end of Ianuary, or el≈øe in Februarie the beginning or the end.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Wee doe v≈øually call it from the Turki≈øh name, Narci≈ø≈øus Trapezunticus, and ≈øome al≈øo call it Narci≈ø≈øus vernus praecox, as Clu≈øius doth, in Engli≈øh, The early Daffodill of Trebizond.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Montanus albus apophy≈øibus praeditus. The white Mountaine Daffodill with eares, or The white winged Daffodill.
div.p: This Mountaine Daffodill ri≈øeth vp with three or foure broad leaues, ≈øomewhat long, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke a foote and a halfe high, whereon ≈øtandeth one large flower, and ≈øometimes two, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe white leaues a peece, not very broad, and without any ≈øhew of yellowne≈ø≈øe in them, three whereof haue v≈øually each of them on the backe part, at the bottome vpon the one ≈øide of them, and not on both, a little ≈ømall white peece of a leafe like an eare, the other three hauing none at all: the cup is almo≈øt as large, or not much le≈ø≈øe then the ≈ømall Nompareille, ≈ømall at the bottome, and very large, open at the brimme, of a faire yellow colour, and ≈øometimes the edges or brimmes of the cup will haue a deeper yellow colour about it, like as if it were di≈øcoloured with Saffron: the flower is verie ≈øweete, the roote is great and white, couered with a pale coate or skinne, not verie blacke, and is not very apt to encrea≈øe, ≈øeldome giuing of-≈øets; neither haue I euer gathered ≈øeede thereof, becau≈øe it pa≈ø≈øeth away without bearing any with me.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Montanus, ≈øiue Nompareille totus albus ample calice. The white Nompareille Daffodill.
div.p: This white Nompareille Daffodill, is in roote and leafe very like vnto the former mountain or winged Daffodill, but that they are a little larger: the ≈øtalke from among the leaues ri≈øeth vp not much higher then it, bearing at the top one large flower, compo≈øed of ≈øixe long white leaues, each whereof is as it were folded halfe way together, in the middle whereof ≈øtandeth forth a large white cup, broader at the mouth or brims then at the bottome, very like vnto the le≈ø≈øer Nompareille Daffodill before remembred, which hath cau≈øed it to be ≈øo entituled: the ≈øent whereof is no le≈ø≈øe ≈øweete then the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The naturall places of the≈øe Daffodils are not certainly knowne to vs; but by the names they carry, they ≈øhould ≈øeeme to bee bred in the Mountaines.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe flower not ≈øo early as many other kindes doe, but rather are to bee accounted among the late flowring Daffodils; for they ≈øhew not their flowers vntill the beginning of May, or the latter end of Aprill, with the ≈øoone≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The names ≈øet downe ouer the heads of either of them be ≈øuch, whereby they are knowne to vs: yet ≈øome doe call the fir≈øt Narci≈ø≈øus auriculatus, that is to ≈øay, The Daffodill with eares: and the other, Narci≈ø≈øus Nompareille totus albus, that is to ≈øay, The white Nompareille, or Peerle≈ø≈øe Daffodill.

div.head: 1. Narci≈ø≈øus albus oblongo calice luteo praecox minor. The ≈ømall early white Daffodill with a long cup.
div.p: The leaues of this early Daffodill are broad, very greene, and not whiti≈øh as others, three or foure ≈øtanding together, about a foote long or better, among which ri≈øeth vp a greene ≈øtalke, not full ≈øo high as the leaues, bearing one flower at the toppe thereof of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe, but not ≈øo great as the later kindes that follow are, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix whiti≈øh leaues, but not perfect white, hauing a ≈øhew of a Creame colour appearing in them; in the middle is a long round yellow cup, about halfe an inch long or better. The ≈ømell of this flower is rea≈øonable ≈øweete, the roote is of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe, yet le≈ø≈øer then the rootes of the later kindes.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus pallidus oblongo calice flauo praecox. The early Strawe coloured Daffodill with a long cup.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill are as greene as the former, but much narrower; and the leaues of the flower are more enclining to yellow, but yet very pale, as if it were a light ≈øtrawe colour, and ≈øeeme to bee a little more narrow and pointed then the former: the cup of this, is as long and yellow as the precedent. The ≈ømell whereof is very like the former, yet neither of them being ≈øo ≈øweete as tho≈øe that follow.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus albus oblongo calice luteo ≈øerotinus maior. The great late flowring white Daffodill with a long cup.
div.p: This later flowring Daffodill hath his leaues ≈øomewhat narrow & long, of a grayi≈øh or whiti≈øh greene colour, among which the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a foote and a halfe high, bearing one flower at the toppe, made of ≈øix white leaues, hauing the cup in the middle thereof as long as the former, and of a deepe yellow: the edges of this cuppe are ≈øometimes plaine, and ≈øometimes a little crumpled; they are often al≈øo circled at the brimmes with a Saffron colour, and often al≈øo without it, the ≈ømell whereof is very plea≈øant, and not heady: the roote hereof is rea≈øonable bigge, and couered ouer rather with a pale then blacki≈øh skinne. This flower doth ≈øometimes alter his forme into eight leaues, which being narrow and long, ≈øeeme like a white ≈øtarre, compa≈ø≈øing a yellow trunke.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus totus pallidus oblongo calice ≈øerotinus minor. The late pale coloured Daffodill with a long cup.
div.p: There is another of this kinde, who≈øe flower is wholly of a pale white, or yellowi≈øh colour, differing neither in leafe nor roote from the former.

div.head: 5. Narci≈ø≈øus pallidus oblongo calice flauo ≈øerotinus. The Strawe coloured late flowring Daffodill with a long yellow cup.
div.p: The chiefe difference of this Daffodill from the former, con≈øi≈øteth in the colour of the top of the flower, which is of a more yellow colour, and a little larger then the former, and the brimmes or edges of the cup of a deeper yellow, or Saffron colour. The ≈ømell of this is no le≈ø≈øe ≈øweete then in the former.

div.head: 6. Narci≈ø≈øus albus oblongo calice flauo ≈øerotinus, duobus floribus in caule. The late white Daffodill with a long cup, and two flowers on a ≈øtalke.
div.p: This Daffodill is ≈øurely a kinde of it ≈øelfe, although it be ≈øo like the former, abiding con≈øtant in his forme and manner of flowring, v≈øually bearing without mi≈ø≈øing two flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, very like vnto the former great white kinde, that one cannot know any greater matter of difference betweene them, then that it beareth two flowers on a ≈øtalke: the cuppes whereof are ≈øeldome touched with any ≈øhew of Saffron colour on them at the brimmes or edges, as ≈øome of the former haue.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Daffodils doe grow on the Pyrenaean mountaines, and haue been ≈øought out, and brought into the≈øe parts, by tho≈øe curious or couetous ≈øearchers of the≈øe delights, that haue made vs partakers of them.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The former kindes flower earlier by a fortnight then the later, the one in the later end of March, and the other not vntill the middle of Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their names are giuen to euery one of them in their ≈øeuerall titles, as fitly as may be≈øt agree with their natures; and therefore I ≈øhall not neede to ≈øpeake any further of them.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus medioluteus vulgaris. The common white Daffodill called Primro≈øe Peerle≈ø≈øe.
div.p: This Daffodill is ≈øo common in euery Countrey Garden almo≈øt through England, that I doubt I ≈øhall but ≈øpend my time in vaine, to de≈øcribe that which is ≈øo well knowne, yet for their ≈øakes that know it not, I will ≈øet downe the de≈øcription of it in this manner. It hath long limber and broad leaues, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, bearing at the toppe out of a skinnie huske ≈øometimes but one flower, but mo≈øt commonly two flowers, and ≈øeldome three or more, but larger for the mo≈øt part, then any that beare many flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, of a pale whiti≈øh Creame colour, tending ≈øomewhat neare vnto the colour of a pale Primro≈øe (which hath cau≈øed our Countrey Gentlewomen, I thinke, to entitle it Primro≈øe Peerle≈ø≈øe) with a ≈ømall round flat Crowne, rather then a cup in the middle, of a pale yellow colour, with ≈øome pale chiues ≈øtanding therein, being of a ≈øweete, but ≈øtuffing ≈øent: the roote is rea≈øonable great, and encrea≈øing more then a better plant.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus mediocroceus ≈øerotinus. The late flowring white Daffodill.
div.p: This Daffodill hath much ≈ømaller leaues, and ≈øhorter then the la≈øt, the ≈øtalke al≈øo ri≈øeth not ≈øo high by much, and beareth but one flower thereon, of a pure white colour, made of ≈øix ≈ømall leaues, and ≈øomewhat narrow, ≈øtanding ≈øeuerally one from another, and not ≈øo clo≈øe together as the former, but appearing like a ≈øtarre: the cup is ≈ømall and round, of a pale yellow colour, but ≈øaffrony about the brims, hauing ≈øix ≈ømall pale chiues in the middle, the ≈ømell whereof is much ≈øweeter then in the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is thought to grow naturally in England, but I could neuer heare of his naturall place. I am ≈øure it is plentifull enough in all Country Gardens, ≈øo that wee ≈øcarce giue it place in our more curious parkes. The ≈øecond liueth onely with them that delight in varieties.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt Daffodill flowreth in the middle time, being neither of the earlie≈øt, nor of the late≈øt; but about the middle, or end of Aprill. The other flowreth with the late≈øt in May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: I ≈øhall not neede to trouble you with further repetitions of names, they hauing been ≈øet downe in their titles, which are proper to them.

figure.head: 1 Narci≈ø≈øus vulgaris medio luteus. The common white Daffodill, or Primro≈øe Peerle≈ø≈øe. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpureus maximus. The great white purple ringe ‚Ä¢ Daffodill. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpurous praecox. The early purple ringed Daffodill. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpureus ≈øtellarus. The ≈øtarry purple ringed Daffodill. 5 Narci≈ø≈øus Per≈øicus. The Per≈øian Daffodill. 6 Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis minor. The le≈ø≈øer Winter Daffodill. 7 Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis maior. The greater Winter Daffodill.

div.head: 1. Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpureus praecox. The early purple ringed Daffodill.
div.p: This early Daffodill hath many long grayi≈øh greene leaues, ≈øomewhat narrower and ≈øtiffer then the former common white Daffodill, among which ri≈øeth vp a long naked hollow ≈øtalke (as all other Daffodils haue) bearing at the toppe one flower, and ≈øeldome two, made of ≈øixe long white leaues, ≈øtanding clo≈øe together about the ≈øtalke; the cup is yellow, and ≈øo flat, that it might rather bee called a crowne: for it ≈øtandeth very clo≈øe to the middle, and very open at the brimmes, circled with a reddi≈øh or purple coloured ring, hauing certaine chiues in the middle of it al≈øo. The ≈ømell hereof is very ≈øweete, exceeding many other.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpureus ≈øerotinus. The late purple ringed Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill are alwayes broader then the former early one, and ≈øome are very neare twice as broad: the flower is very like the former, being large, and his leaues ≈øtanding clo≈øe one to the ≈øide of another; the ring likewi≈øe that compa≈ø≈øeth the yellow coronet, is ≈øometimes of a paler reddi≈øh purple, and ≈øometimes as deepe a red as the former: ≈øo that it differeth not in any other materiall point, then that it flowreth not vntill the other is pa≈øt and gone. The ≈øent of this is like the former, the roote hereof is greater, as well as the leafe and flower.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpureus maximus. The great white purple ringed Daffodill.
div.p: There is another kinde, who≈øe flower (as well as leaues and rootes) is larger then any other of this kinde, which onely maketh it a di≈øtinct ≈øort from the other: it flowreth al≈øo with the later ≈øort of the≈øe purple ringed Daffodils.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus medio purpureus ≈øtellaris. The ≈øtarry purple ringed Daffodill.
div.p: This Daffodill hath his leaues a little narrower and greener then the former ≈øorts, the flower al≈øo of this hath his ≈øixe white leaues not ≈øo broad, but narrower, and ≈øeeming longer then they, not clo≈øing together, but ≈øtanding apart one from another, making it ≈øeeme like a white ≈øtarre: it hath al≈øo a yellow coronet in the middle, circled about with purple, like the former. This doth ≈ømell nothing ≈øo ≈øweete as the fir≈øt, but yet hath a good ≈øent.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt, third, and fourth of the≈øe Daffodils, haue alwayes beene ≈øent vs from Con≈øtantinople among other bulbous rootes, ≈øo that wee know no further of their naturall places.
The ≈øecond groweth in many places of Europe, both in Germany, France, and Italy, as Clu≈øius hath noted.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth very early in March, euen with the fir≈øt Daffodils. The ≈øecond, third, and fourth, about a moneth after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The early and ≈øtarre Daffodils, haue been ≈øent vs by the Turki≈øh name of Deuebohini, and Serincade. But their names, they haue receiued ≈øince, to bee endenizond with vs, are ≈øet downe in their ≈øeuerall titles.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Per≈øicus. The Per≈øian Daffodill.
div.p:
This Per≈øian Daffodill differeth from all other kindes of Daffodils in his manner of
growing, for it neuer hath leaues and flowers at one time together, wherein it is like vnto a Colchicum, yet in roote and leafe it is a Daffodill. The roote is a little blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, ≈øomewhat like the roote of the Autumne Daffodill, from whence ri≈øeth vp a naked foote ≈øtalke, bearing one pale yellow flower, breaking through a thinne skinne, which fir≈øt enclo≈øed it, compo≈øed of ≈øix leaues, the three outermo≈øt being a little larger then the re≈øt, in the middle of the flower there are ≈øix ≈ømall chiues, and a longer pointell. The whole flower is of an vnplea≈øant ≈øent: After the flower is pa≈øt, come vp the leaues, ≈øometimes before Winter, but mo≈øt v≈øually after the deepe of Winter is pa≈øt with vs, in the beginning of the yeare, which are broad, long, and of a pale greene colour, like the leaues of other Daffodils, but not greene as the Autumne Daffodill is, and be≈øides they doe a little twine them≈øelues, as ≈øome of the Pancratium, or ba≈øtard Sea Daffodils doe.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis maior. The greater Autumne or Winter Daffodill.
div.p: The greater Autumne Daffodill ri≈øeth vp with three or foure faire broad and ≈øhort leaues at the fir≈øt, but afterwards grow longer, of a very deepe or darke greene colour, in the middle of which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øhort, ≈øtiffe, round foote≈øtalke, bearing one faire yellow flower on the head thereof (inclo≈øed at the fir≈øt in a thinne skinne, or huske) and con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øix leaues as the former, with certaine chiues in the middle, as all or mo≈øt other Daffodils haue, which pa≈ø≈øeth away without ≈øhew of any ≈øeed, or head for ≈øeed, although vnder the head there is a little greene knot, which peraduenture would beare ≈øeede, if our ≈øharpe Winters did not hinder it. The roote is great and round, couered ouer with a blacki≈øh skinne or coate.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis minor. The le≈ø≈øer Autumne or Winter Daffodill.
div.p: Clu≈øius ≈øetteth downe, that the manner of the flowring of this le≈ø≈øer Daffodill, is more like vnto the Per≈øian Daffodill, then vnto the former greater Autumne kind; but I doe finde that it doth in the ≈øame ≈øort, as the greater kinde, ri≈øe vp with his leaues fir≈øt, and the flowers a while after: the flower of this is le≈ø≈øer, and a little paler then the flower of the greater kinde, but con≈øi≈øting in like ≈øort of ≈øix leaues, narrow and ≈øharpe pointed; the greene leaues al≈øo are almo≈øt of as deepe a greene colour, as the greater kinde, but ≈ømaller and narrower, and a little hollow in the middle. The roote is al≈øo alike, but le≈ø≈øer, and couered with a blacki≈øh skinne as the former. This hath ≈øometimes borne blacke round ≈øeede in three ≈øquare heads.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The Per≈øian Daffodill hath beene ≈øent ≈øometimes, but very ≈øeldome, among other rootes from Con≈øtantinople, and it is probable by the name whereby it was ≈øent, that it ≈øhould naturally grow in Per≈øia.
The other two haue likewi≈øe beene ≈øent from Con≈øtantinople, and as it is thought, grow in Thracia, or thereabouts.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all doe flower much about one time, that is, about the end of September, and in October.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt hath been ≈øent by the name of Serincade Per≈øiana, and thereupon is called Narci≈ø≈øus Per≈øicus, The Per≈øian Daffodill.

The other two haue been thought by diuers to be Colchica, and ≈øo haue they called them, vpon no other ground, but that their flower is in forme and time ≈øomewhat like Colchicum, when as if they had marked them better, they might plainly di≈øcerne, that in all other things they did re≈øemble Daffodils; but now the names of C ‚Ä¢ lchicum luteum maius, & minus, is quite
lo≈øt, time hauing worne them out, and they are called by mo≈øt Herbari≈øts now adayes, Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis maior & minor, The greater and the le≈ø≈øer Autumne Daffodill.

Thus farre haue I proceeded with tho≈øe Daffodils, that hauing broad leaues, beare but one ≈øingle flower, or two at the mo≈øt vpon a ≈øtalke: And now to proceed with the re≈øt, that haue broad leaues, and beare ≈øingle flowers, but many vpon a ≈øtalke.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Africanus aureus maior. The great yellow Daffodill of Africa.
div.p: This braue and ≈øtately Daffodill hath many very long and broad leaues, of a better greene colour, then many others that are grayi≈øh, among which appeareth a ≈øtalke, not ri≈øing to the height of the leaues, bearing at the toppe out of a skinnie ho≈øe many faire, goodly, and large flowers, to the number of ten or twelue, if the roote bee well growne, and ≈øtand in a warme place, euery one being larger then any of the French, Spani≈øh, or Turkie Daffodils, that beare many ≈øingle flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, and commeth neere vnto the bigne≈ø≈øe of the Engli≈øh Daffodill, called Primro≈øe Peerle≈ø≈øe, before de≈øcribed, or that French kinde hereafter de≈øcribed, that beareth the large≈øt flowers, many vpon a ≈øtalke (which ≈øome would make to bee a kinde of that Engli≈øh Daffodill, but bearing more flowers) and of a faire ≈øhining yellow colour, hauing large, round, and open cups or boules, yellower then the outer leaues; and is of ≈øo exceeding ≈øweete a ≈øent, that it doth rather offend the ≈øen≈øes by the aboundance thereof: the roote is great, and couered with a blacki≈øh browne coate or skinne.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Africanus aureus minor. The le≈ø≈øer Barbary Daffodill.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer kinde is very neere the ≈øame with the former, but that it lacketh ≈øomewhat of his ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe of height, largene≈ø≈øe or flower and cup (being of a paler yellow) and beauty of colour, for it beareth neither of the≈øe equall vnto the former, but is in them all inferiour. And thus by this priuatiue, you may vnder≈øtand his po≈øitiue, and that ≈øhall be ≈øufficient at this time.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Byzantinus totus luteus. The yellow Turkie Daffodill.
div.p: Whereas the la≈øt de≈øcribed, came ≈øhort of the beauty of the former, ≈øo this lacketh of that beauty is in the la≈øt; for this, although it haue very long leaues, and a high ≈øtalke, yet the flowers are neither ≈øo many, as not being aboue foure or fiue, nor ≈øo large, being not much greater then the ordinary French Daffodill hereafter de≈øcribed, nor the colour ≈øo faire, but much paler, and the cup al≈øo ≈ømaller; and herein con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe≈øt differences betweene this, and both the other, but that the ≈øent of this is al≈øo weaker.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt and the ≈øecond grow in Barbary, about Argier, and Fez, as by the relation of them, that haue brought them into the≈øe parts, wee haue been enformed.
The la≈øt hath been often brought from Con≈øtantinople among other varieties of Daffodils, but from whence they receiued them, I could neuer learne.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe Daffodils do flower very early, euen with the fir≈øt ≈øort of Daffodils, I meane after they haue been accu≈øtomed vnto our climate: for oftentimes vpon their fir≈øt bringing ouer, they flower in Ianuary or February, e≈øpecially if they be pre≈øerued from the fro≈øts, and kept in any warme place; for they are very tender, and will ≈øoone peri≈øh, being left abroad.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is called by diuers in French, Narci≈ø≈øe d'Algiers, and in many
places of the Low Countries, Narci≈ø≈øen van Heck, or Narci≈ø≈øus Heckius; by diuers others Narci≈ø≈øus Africanus aureus maior, we may call it in Engli≈øh, The great African Daffodill, or the great Barbary Daffodill, or the great yellow Daffodill of Argiers, which you plea≈øe.
The ≈øecond hath no other variation of name, then a diminutiue of the former, as is ≈øet downe in the title.

The third is no doubt the ≈øame, that Clu≈øius ≈øetteth downe in the twelfth Chapter of his ≈øecond Booke of the Hi≈øtory of more rare plants, and maketh the fourth ≈øort, which came from Con≈øtantinople, and may al≈øo be the ≈øame, which he maketh his fifth, which (as he ≈øaith) he receiued from Doctour Simor Touar of Seuill in Spaine. Wee call it, from the place from whence we receiued it, Narci≈ø≈øus Byzantinus, with the addition of totus luteus, to put a difference from other ≈øorts that come from thence al≈øo: in Engli≈øh, The yellow ≈øingle Daffodill of Turkie.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Sulphureus maior. The greater Lemon coloured Daffodill.
div.p: The greater of the≈øe Daffodils, beareth three or foure greene and very long leaues, a foote and a halfe long at the lea≈øt, among which ri≈øeth vp a round, yet cre≈øted ≈øtalke, not ≈øo high as the leaues, bearing fiue or ≈øixe ≈øingle flowers thereon, euery one of them being greater then the ordinary French or Italian Daffodils, with many flowers vpon a ≈øtalke; of a faint, but yet plea≈øant yellow colour at the fir≈øt, which after they haue been in flower a fortnight or thereabouts, change into a deeper, or more ≈øullen yellow colour: the cup in the middle is likewi≈øe larger, then in tho≈øe formerly named, and of a deeper yellow colour then the outer leaues, hauing onely three chiues within it. The ≈ømell is very plea≈øant.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Sulphureus minor. The le≈ø≈øer Lemon coloured Daffodill.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer Daffodill hath broader and ≈øhorter leaues then the former, of the colour of other Daffodils, and not greene like the former: the ≈øtalke of this ri≈øeth vp higher then the leaues, bearing foure or fiue flowers vpon ≈øhorter foote≈øtalkes, and no bigger then the French Daffodill, of a pale yellow, which mo≈øt doe call a Brim≈øtone colour, the cup or rather crowne in the middle, is ≈ømall, and broad open, of a little deeper yellow, hauing many chiues within it, and is as it were ≈øprinkled ouer with a kinde of mealine≈ø≈øe. The ≈ømell of this is not full ≈øo plea≈øant as the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Both the≈øe haue been gathered on the Pyrenaean Mountaines, and both likewi≈øe haue been ≈øent out of Italy.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They both flower in the middle time of the Daffodils flowring, that is, in Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue their Latine names expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, and ≈øo are their Engli≈øh al≈øo, if you plea≈øe ≈øo to let them pa≈ø≈øe; or el≈øe according to the Latine, you may call them, The greater and the le≈ø≈øer Brim≈øtone coloured Daffodils; ≈øome haue called them Narci≈ø≈øus Italicus, but the Italians them≈øelues haue ≈øent them by the name of Narci≈ø≈øo Solfarigno.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus totus albus polyanthos. The milke white Daffodill many vpon a ≈øtalke.
div.p:
The leaues of this Daffodill are of a meane ≈øize, both for length and breadth, yet ≈øomewhat greener then in the ordinary ≈øorts, that haue ≈øome whitene≈ø≈øe in them: the
flowers are many vpon the ≈øtalke, as ≈ømall for the mo≈øt part, as any of the≈øe kindes that beare many together, being wholly of a milke, or rather ≈ønow white colour, both the cuppe, which is ≈ømall, and the outer leaues that compa≈ø≈øe it; after which come ≈ømall heads, wherein is contained round blacke ≈øeede, as all other Daffodils doe, although ≈øome greater, and others le≈ø≈øer, according to the proportion of the plants: the roote is couered ouer with a blacki≈øh skinne or coate; the ≈ømell is very ≈øweete.

There are two other ≈øorts more of this kinde, the differences whereof are, that the one hath his leaues ≈øomewhat broader, and the flowers greater then the former: And the other ≈ømaller leaues and flowers al≈øo, who≈øe cups being ≈ømall, are neuer ≈øeene fully open, but as it were halfe clo≈øed at the brimmes.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus latifolius totus albus, mediocri calice reflexus. The milke white Daffodill with the great cup.
div.p: There is yet another ≈øort of the≈øe milke white Daffodils, who≈øe leaues are as broad as any of the former, and who≈øe cup in the middle of the flower, is ≈øomewhat larger then in any of the le≈ø≈øer ≈øorts, and le≈ø≈øer then in the greater kinde: but the leaues of the flowers doe a little turne them≈øelues vpwards, which maketh a chiefe difference.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe Daffodils grow in Spaine, from whence I receiued many that flouri≈øhed a while, but peri≈øhed by ≈øome fierce cold Winters: they likewi≈øe grow in France, from whence many al≈øo haue been brought vnto vs. They haue likewi≈øe been ≈øent from Con≈øtantinople to vs, among other kindes of Daffodils.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They that come from Con≈øtantinople, for the mo≈øt part doe flower earlier then the other, euen after they are accu≈øtomed to our ayre. Some of them flower notwith≈øtanding in the end of March, the re≈øt in Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are v≈øually called Narci≈ø≈øus totus albus polyanthos, adding thereunto the differences of maior, medius, and minor, that is, The milke white Daffodill, the greater, the middle, and the le≈ø≈øer; for ≈øo ≈øome doe di≈øtingui≈øh them. The la≈øt, for di≈øtinction, hath his name in his title ≈øufficient to expre≈ø≈øe him.

div.head: 1. Narci≈ø≈øus Narbonen≈øis, ≈øiue medio luteus praecox, The early French Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill, ≈øpring vp out of the ground a moneth or two ≈øometimes before the other of this kinde, that follow; being al≈øo ≈øhorter, and narrower: the ≈øtalke likewi≈øe is not very high, bearing diuers flowers at the top, breaking through a thinne skinne, as is v≈øuall with all the Daffodils, euery one whereof is ≈ømall, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix white leaues, and a ≈ømall yellow cup in the middle, which is of a prettie ≈ømall ≈øent, nothing ≈øo ≈øtrong as many others: the roote is great and round, and ≈øeldome parteth into of-≈øets, euen as all the other that follow, bearing many ≈øingle flowers, doe.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus Narbonen≈øis vulgaris. The ordinary French Daffodill.
div.p:
This Daffodill hath long and broad greene leaues, a little hollowi≈øh in the middle, and edged on both ≈øides; the ≈øtalke is a foote and a halfe high, bearing at the toppe diuers flowers, ≈øomewhat larger then the former, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix white leaues, ≈øomewhat round; the cup is yellow in the middle, ≈ømall and round, like vnto an Acorne cuppe, or a little fuller in the middle: this is the forme of that ≈øort which was fir≈øt
1 Narci≈ø≈øus Africanus aureus maior. The great yellow Daffodill of Africa. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus Africanus luteus minor. The le≈ø≈øer yellow Daffodill of Africa. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus Narbonen≈øis medio luteus. The French Daffodill. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus Pi≈øanus, vel totus albus. The Italian Daffodill, or the all white Daffodill. 5 Narci≈ø≈øus Mu≈ø≈øart. Mu≈ø≈øart his Daffodill. 6 Narci≈ø≈øus Anglicus polyanthos. The great Engli≈øh Daffodill. depiction of flowers
brought vnto vs: But ≈øince there is found out ≈øome, who≈øe cup is ≈øhorter, others flatter, ≈øome of a paler, others of a deeper yellow colour, and ≈øome that haue their cuppe longer then the re≈øt. The rootes of them all are couered with a blacki≈øh skin or coate.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus Narbonen≈øis maior amplo flore. The French Daffodill with great flowers.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill are ≈øomewhat like vnto the la≈øt, but not ≈øo broad, yet full as long, and ≈øpring ≈øooner out of the ground, yet not ≈øo early as the fir≈øt of the≈øe kindes: the ≈øtalke hereof is flatter, and ri≈øeth higher, bearing foure or fiue flowers, much larger then any of this kinde; for euery one of them doth equall the Engli≈øh Daffodill, before de≈øcribed, but whiter then it, and the yellow cup larger, and more open then in any of the re≈øt. The roote of this is not ≈øo great, or round, as the former, but is more plentifull in of-≈øets, then any other of the≈øe French, or Italian kindes.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus Pi≈øaenus. The Italian Daffodill.
div.p: This Italian Daffodill hath his leaues as large, or larger then the ≈øecond French Daffodill, and his ≈øtalke ≈øomewhat higher, bearing many white flowers, very like vnto the common French Daffodill, but ≈øomewhat larger al≈øo; and the yellow cup in the middle likewi≈øe is larger, and rounder, then is v≈øually ≈øeen in any of the French kinds, except the la≈øt with the greate≈øt flowers.

div.head: 5. Narci≈ø≈øus mediocroceus polyanthos. The French Daffodill with Saffron coloured cups.
div.p: This French Daffodill hath diuers leaues of a grayi≈øh greene colour, not ≈øo broad or long as the la≈øt recited Daffodill, but comming neerer vnto the ≈øecond French kinde, the flowers likewi≈øe are white, and many vpon a ≈øtalke, like thereunto, but the yellow cup is ≈øomewhat large, and circled with a Saffron like brimme or edge, which maketh the chiefe≈øt difference.

div.head: 6. Narci≈ø≈øus mediocroceus alter, dictus Mu≈ø≈øart. Mu≈ø≈øart his Daffodill.
div.p: The affinity between this & the la≈øt, (for it is not the ≈øame to be expre≈ø≈øed vnder one title) hath made me ioyne it next vnto it, yet becau≈øe it hath a notable difference, it de≈øerueth a place by him≈øelfe. The leaues are large and long, and the flowers, being white, are larger al≈øo then in any other, except the greate≈øt, but the cup hereof is ≈ømall and ≈øhort, rather ≈øeeming a coronet then a cup, of a deepe Saffron colour all about the brimmes or edges.

div.head: 7. Narci≈ø≈øus Anglicus polyanthos. The great Engli≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: This Daffodill hath his leaues not much broader or longer, then the French kinde with great flowers, before de≈øcribed, the ≈øtalke with flowers ri≈øeth not fully ≈øo high as it, bearing many flowers thereon, not altogether ≈øo white, yet whiter then the former Engli≈øh Daffodill, called Primro≈øe Peerle≈ø≈øe, but nothing ≈øo large, and with ≈øhort, broad, and almo≈øt round leaues, ≈øtanding clo≈øe one vnto another: the yellow cup in the middle is bowle fa≈øhion, being ≈øomewhat deeper then in any of the former kinds, but not much greater: the ≈ømell hereof is very ≈øweete and plea≈øant.

div.head: 8. Narci≈ø≈øus Narbonen≈øis, ≈øiue medio luteus ≈øerotinus maior. The greater late flowring French Daffodill.
div.p:
The roote as well as the leaues of this Daffodill, are greater, larger, broader, and longer then in any other of the former French, or Italian kindes; the ≈øtalke is as high as any of them, bearing at the toppe fiue or ≈øixe white flowers, ≈øtanding open ≈øpread like a ≈øtarre, and not clo≈øe together, euery one whereof is large, and round pointed,
the cup is yellow, ≈ømall and ≈øhort, yet not lying flat to the flower, but a little ≈øtanding out with ≈øome threads in the middle, as all the former Daffodils haue. This is not ≈øo ≈øweete as the earlier kindes.

div.head: 9. Narci≈ø≈øus medioluteus alter ≈øerotinus calice breui. The le≈ø≈øer late flowring French Daffodill.
div.p: This Daffodill is of the ≈øame kinde with the la≈øt de≈øcribed, the onely difference is, that it is le≈ø≈øer, and the yellow cuppe in the middle of the flower, is ≈øomewhat ≈øhorter then the former, although the former be ≈øhorter then many others, otherwi≈øe it differeth not, no not in time; for it flowreth late as the former doth.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe Daffodils haue been brought vs from diuers places: The fir≈øt and ≈øecond grow naturally in many places of Spaine, that are open to the Sea: they grow likewi≈øe about Mompelier, and tho≈øe parts in France. They haue been likewi≈øe ≈øent among many other ≈øorts of Daffodils from Con≈øtantinople, ≈øo that I may thinke, they grow in ≈øome places neere thereunto.
The fourth groweth plentifully in Italy, about Pi≈øa in Tu≈øcane, from whence we haue had plants to furni≈øh our Gardens.
The ≈øeuenth is accounted beyond Sea to be naturall of our Country, but I know not any with vs that haue it, but they haue had it from them.
The re≈øt haue been brought at diuers times, but wee know no further of their naturall places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth earlier then any of the re≈øt by a moneth, euen in the beginning of March, or earlier, if the weather be milde. The other in Aprill, ≈øome a little before or after another. The late kinds flower not vntill May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: There can be no more ≈øaid of the names of any of them, then hath beene ≈øet out in their titles; for they di≈øtingui≈øh euery ≈øort as fitly as we can: onely ≈øome doe call the fir≈øt two ≈øorts, by the name of Donax Narbonen≈øis.

After all the≈øe Daffodils, that hauing broad leaues beare ≈øingle flowers, either one or many vpon a ≈øtalke, I ≈øhall now goe on to ≈øet forth tho≈øe broad leafed Daffodils, that carry double flowers, either one or many vpon a ≈øtalke together, in the ≈øame order that we haue v≈øed before.

div.head: 1. Narci≈ø≈øus albus multiplex. The double white Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill are not very broad, but rather of a meane ≈øize, being of the ≈øame largene≈ø≈øe with the leaues of the purple ringed Daffodill, the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp to be a foote and a halfe high, bearing out of a thinne white skinne or ho≈øe, one flower and no more, con≈øi≈øting of many leaues, of a faire white colour, the flower is larger then any other double white Daffodill, hauing euery leafe, e≈øpecially the outermo≈øt, as large almo≈øt as any leafe of the ≈øingle Daffodill with the yellow cup, or purple ring. Sometimes it happeneth, that the flower is very little double, and almo≈øt ≈øingle, but that is either in a bad ground, or for that it hath ≈øtood long in a place without remouing; for then it hath ≈øuch a great encrea≈øe of rootes about it, that it draweth away into many parts, the nouri≈øhment that ≈øhould be for a few: but if you doe tran≈øplant it, taking away the of-≈øets, and ≈øet his rootes ≈øingle, it will then thriue, and beare his flower as goodly and double, as I haue before de≈øcribed it: and is very ≈øweete.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus mediopurpureus multiplex. The double purple ringed Daffodill.
div.p:
There is little difference in the leaues of this kinde, from the leaues of the ≈øingle purple
ringed Daffodill; for it is probable it is of the ≈øame kinde, but by natures gift (and not by any humane art) made more plentifull, which abideth con≈øtant, and hath not that dalliance, which oftentimes nature ≈øheweth, to recreate the ≈øen≈øes of men for the pre≈øent, and appeareth not againe in the ≈øame forme: the chiefe≈øt difference is, that the flower (being but ≈øometimes one on a ≈øtalke, and ≈øometimes two) con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øix white outer leaues, as large as the leaues of the ≈øingle kinde, hauing many ≈ømall yellow peeces, edged with purple circles round about them, in≈øtead of a cup; and in the middle of the≈øe peeces, ≈øtand other ≈øix white leaues, le≈ø≈øer then the former, and a yellow cup edged with a purple circle likewi≈øe, parted into peeces, and they comprehend a few other white leaues, ≈ømaller then any of the other, hauing among them ≈øome broken peeces of the cup, with a few chiues al≈øo in the middle of the flower. The flower is very ≈øweete.

There is of this kinde another, who≈øe flower hath not ≈øo plaine a di≈øtinction, of a triple rowe of leaues in it: but the whole flower is confu≈øedly ≈øet together, the outer leaues being not ≈øo large, and the inner leaues larger then the former; the broken yellow cuppe, which is tipt with purple, running diuer≈øly among the leaues; ≈øo that it ≈øheweth a fairer, and more double flower then the former, as it is indeed.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus medioluteus corona duplici. The Turkie Daffodill with a double crowne.
div.p: This Daffodill hath three or foure leaues, as large and long almo≈øt, as the great double Daffodill of Con≈øtantinople next following hath: the ≈øtalke likewi≈øe is very neere as great, but as high altogether, bearing at the toppe foure or fiue flowers, the leaues whereof are as large, as of the fir≈øt or ≈øecond kinde of French Daffodils, before de≈øcribed, but not altogether of ≈øo pure a white colour; and being ≈øix in number, ≈øtand like the former ≈øingle French Daffodils, but that the yellow cup in the middle of this is thicke and double, or as it were crumpled together, not ≈øtanding very high to be con≈øpicuous, but abiding lowe and ≈øhort, ≈øo that it is not pre≈øently marked, vnle≈ø≈øe one looke vpon it preci≈øely; yet is exceeding ≈øweete. The roote is like vnto the roote of the purple ringed Daffodill, or ≈øomewhat bigger.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus Chalcedonicus flore pleno albo polyanthos. The double white Daffodill of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This beautifull and goodly Daffodill (wherewith all Flori≈øts greatly de≈øire to bee acquainted, as well for the beauty of his double flowers, as al≈øo for his ≈øuperabounding ≈øweete ≈ømell, one ≈øtalke with flowers being in≈øtead of a no≈øegay) hath many very broad, and very long leaues, ≈øomewhat greener then gray, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtrong round ≈øtalke, being ≈øometimes almo≈øt flat, and ribbed, bearing foure or fiue, or more white flowers at the toppe, euery one being very great, large, and double, the leaues being confu≈øedly ≈øet together, hauing little peeces of a yellow cup running among them, without any ≈øhew of that purple ring that is in the former, and fall away without bearing ≈øeed, euen as all, or mo≈øt other double flowers doe: the ≈ømell is ≈øo exceeding ≈øweet and ≈øtrong, that it will ≈øoone offend the ≈øen≈øes of any, that ≈øhall ≈ømell much vnto it: the roote is great and thicke, couered with a blacki≈øh coate.

div.head: 5. Narci≈ø≈øus Chalcedonicus ≈øimbriatus multiplex polyanthos. The great double purple ringed Daffodill of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This Daffodill differeth very little or nothing in leafe from the former, the onely difference is in the flowers, which although they bee double, and beare many vpon a ≈øtalke, like vnto them, yet this hath the peeces of the yellow cuppes tipt with purple, as if they were ≈øhred or ≈øcattered among the white leaues, whereas the other hath only the yellow, without any ≈øhew of purple tips vpon them: the ≈ømell of this is as ≈øtrong as of the other.

figure.head: 1 Narci≈ø≈øus albus multiplex. The double white Daffodill. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus medioluteus corona duplici. The Turkie Daffodill with a double crowne. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus mediopurpureus multiplex. The double purple ringed Daffodill. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus Chalcedonicus flore pleno albo polyanthos. The double white Daffodill of Con≈øtantinople.

div.head: 6. Narci≈ø≈øus Cyprius flore pleno luteo polyanthos. The double yellow Daffodill of Cyprus.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill are almo≈øt as broad and long as the former, the ≈øtalke is a foot high and more, bearing foure or fiue flowers on the top, euery one very double, and of a fine pale yellow colour, of a ≈øtrong heady ≈øent. The root of this is al≈øo like the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the≈øe Daffodils, was fir≈øt brought into England by Mr. Iohn de Franqueuille the elder, who gathered it in his owne Countrey of Cambray, where it groweth wilde, from who≈øe ≈øonne, Mr. Iohn de Franqueuille, now liuing, we all haue had it. The re≈øt haue come from Con≈øtantinople at ≈øeuerall times; and the la≈øt is thought to come from Cyprus. Wee haue it credibly affirmed al≈øo, that it groweth in Barbary about Fez and Argiers. Some of the double white kindes grow in Candy, and about Aleppo al≈øo.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Turkie kindes doe for the mo≈øt part all flower early, in the end of March, or beginning of Aprill at the furthe≈øt, and the fir≈øt double, about the middle or end of Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: All the≈øe Daffodils, except the fir≈øt, haue had diuers Turki≈øh names ≈øet vpon the packets, wherein they haue been ≈øent, but there is ≈ømall regard of certainty to be expected from them; for that the name Serincade, without any more addition, which is a ≈øingle Daffodill, hath beene impo≈øed vpon that parcell of rootes, that haue borne mo≈øt of them double flowers of diuers ≈øorts; and the name Serincade Catamer lale, which ≈øignifieth a double flowred Daffodill, hath had many ≈øingle white flowers, with yellow cups, and ≈øome who≈øe flowers haue been wholly white, cuppe and all, and ≈øome purple ringed, and double al≈øo among them. Their names, whereby they are knowne and called with vs, are, as fitly as may be, impo≈øed in their titles: And this I hope ≈øhall ≈øuffice, to haue ≈øpoken of the≈øe ≈øorts of Daffodils.

Hauing fini≈øhed the di≈øcour≈øe of the former ≈øort of broad leafed Daffodils, it is fit to proceede to the next, which are Angustifolios Narci≈ø≈øos, tho≈øe Daffodils that haue narrow leaues, and fir≈øt to ≈øet downe tho≈øe that beare ≈øingle flowers, whether one or many flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, and then tho≈øe that beare double flowers in the ≈øame manner.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Virgineus. The Virginia Daffodill.
div.p: This plant I thought fitte≈øt to place here in the beginning of this Cla≈øsis, not finding where better to ≈øhroud it. It hath two or three long, and very narrow leaues, as greene as the leaues of the great Leucoium bulbo≈øum, and ≈øhining withall, which grow ≈øometimes reddi≈øh, e≈øpecially at the edges: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a ≈øpanne high, bearing one flower and no more on the head thereof, ≈øtanding vpright like a little Lilly or Tulipa, made of ≈øix leaues, wholly white, both within and without, except that at the bottome next to the ≈øtalke, and a little on the back≈øide of the three outer leaues, it hath a ≈ømall da≈øh or ≈øhew of a reddi≈øh purple colour: it hath in the middle a few chiues, ≈øtanding about a ≈ømall head pointed; which head groweth to bee ≈ømall and long, containing ≈ømall blacki≈øh flat ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, long, and round, a little blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and white on the in≈øide.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This bulbous plant was brought vs from Virginia, where they grow aboundantly; but they hardly thriue and abide in our Gardens to beare flowers.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in May, and ≈øeldome before.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The Indians in Virginia do call it Attamu≈øco, ≈øome among vs do call it Lilionarci≈ø≈øus Virginianus, of the likene≈ø≈øe of the flower to a Lilly, and the leaues and roote to a Daffodill. Wee for breuity doe call it Narci≈ø≈øus Virgineus, that is, The Daffodill of Virginia, or el≈øe you may call it according to the former Latine name, The Lilly Daffodill of Virginia, which you will; for both names may ≈øerue well to expre≈ø≈øe the plant.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus angu≈øtifolius albidus praecox oblongo calice. The early white narrow leafed Daffodill with a long cup.
div.p: This Daffodill hath three or foure narrow, long, and very greene leaues, a foote long for the mo≈øt part: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth not vp ≈øo high as the leaues, whereon ≈øtandeth one flower, not altogether ≈øo great as the late flowring Daffodill, with a long cuppe, de≈øcribed before among the broad leafed ones, which con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øix pale coloured leaues, not pure white, but hauing a wa≈øh of light yellow among the white: the cuppe in the middle is round and long, yet not ≈øo long as to bee accounted a ba≈øtard Daffodill, within which is a middle pointell, compa≈ø≈øed with ≈øix chiues, hauing yellow mealy pendents.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This Daffodill groweth with the other ≈øorts of broad leafed ones, on the Pyrenaean Mountaines, from whence they haue beene brought vnto vs, to furni≈øh our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth early, a moneth before the other ≈øorts of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, that is, in the beginning of March, if the time be milde, which the other before ≈øpoken of doe not.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath no other name that I know, then is expre≈ø≈øed in the title.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus mediocroceus tenuifolius. The ≈ømall Daffodill with a Saffron crown.
div.p: This ≈ømall Daffodill hath foure or fiue narrow leaues about a ≈øpanne long, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke ≈øome nine inches high, bearing at the toppe one ≈ømall white flower, made of ≈øix leaues, with a ≈ømall yellow cup in the middle, ≈øhadowed ouer at the brimmes with a Saffron colour: the roote is ≈ømall, round, and little long withall, couered with a blacki≈øh skinne or coate.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus minimus mediopurpureus. The lea≈øt purple ringed Daffodill.
div.p:
This little Daffodill hath ≈ømall narrow leaues, ≈øhorter by much then any of the purple ringed Daffodils, before de≈øcribed: the ≈øtalke and flower keepe an equall proportion to the re≈øt of the plant, being in forme and colour of the flower, like vnto the
Starre Daffodill before recited, but vnlike in the greatne≈ø≈øe: this al≈øo is to bee ob≈øerued, that the purple colour that circleth the brimmes of the cuppe, is ≈øo ≈ømall, that ≈øometimes it is not well perceiued.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus minimus Iuncifolij flore. The lea≈øt Daffodill of all.
div.p: This lea≈øt Daffodill hath two or three whiti≈øh greene leaues, narrower then the two la≈øt recited Daffodils, and ≈øhorter by halfe, being not aboue two or three inches long, the ≈øtalke likewi≈øe is not aboue three or foure inches high, bearing one ≈øingle flower at the toppe, ≈øomewhat bigger then the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe of the plant ≈øhould ≈øeeme to beare, very like vnto the lea≈øt Ru≈øh Daffodill, and of the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe, or rather ≈øomewhat bigger, being of a faint yellow colour, both leaues, and cup, or crowne, (if you plea≈øe ≈øo to call it); for the middle part is ≈øpread very much, euen to the middle of the leaues almo≈øt, and lyeth flat open vpon the flower: the roote is ≈ømall, euen the ≈ømalle≈øt of any Daffodill, and couered with a blacki≈øh skinne or coate.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the≈øe Daffodils haue beene brought vs from the Pyrenaean Mountaines, among a number of other rare plants, and the la≈øt by a French man, called Francis le Veau, the hone≈øte≈øt roote-gatherer that euer came ouer to vs. The ≈øecond was ≈øent to Mr. Iohn de Franqueuille, before remembred, who imparted it to mee, as hee hath done many other good things; but his naturall place wee know not.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower about the latter end of Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Being brought without names, wee haue giuen them their names according to their face and fa≈øhion, as they are ≈øet downe in their titles.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis minor albus. The little white Autumne Daffodill.
div.p: This little Autumne Daffodill ri≈øeth with his flowers fir≈øt out of the ground, without any leaues at all. It ≈øpringeth vp with one or two ≈øtalkes about a finger long, euery one bearing out of a ≈ømall huske one ≈ømall white flower, laid open abroad like vnto the Starre white Daffodill, before ≈øpoken of: in the middle of the flower is a ≈ømall yellow cup of a meane ≈øize, and after the flower is pa≈øt, there commeth in the ≈øame place a ≈ømall head, containing ≈ømall, round, blacke ≈øeede, like vnto the Autumne Hyacinth: the leaues come vp after the ≈øeede is ripe and gone, being ≈ømall and narrow, not much bigger then the Autumne Hyacinth: the roote is ≈ømall and blacki≈øh on the out≈øide.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This Daffodill groweth in Spaine, where Clu≈øius ≈øaw it, and brought it into the≈øe parts.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the beginning of Autumne, and his ≈øeede is ripe in the end of October in tho≈øe hot Countries, but in ours it will ≈øcarce abide to ≈øhew a flower.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The Spaniards, as Clu≈øius reporteth, call it T ‚Ä¢ nada, and he vpon the ≈øight
1 Narci≈ø≈øus Virgineus. The Virginian Daffodill. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus minimus Iuncifolij flore. The lea≈øt Daffodill of all. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis minor albus. The little white Autumne Daffodill. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus albus Autumnalis medio ob≈øoletus. The white Autumne Daffodill with a ≈øullen crown. 5 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius maximus amplo calice. The great Iunquilia with the large≈øt flower or cup. 6 Narci≈ø≈øus totus albus flore plano Virginianus. The double white Daffodill of Virginia. depiction of flowers
thereof, Narci≈ø≈øus Autumnalis minor albus, and wee in Engli≈øh thereafter, The little white Autumne Daffodill.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus albus Autumnalis medio ob≈øoletus. The white Autumne Daffodill with a ≈øullen crowne.
div.p: This Autumne Daffodill hath two or three leaues at the mo≈øt, and very narrow, ≈øo that ≈øome doe reckon it among the Ru≈øh Daffodils, being ≈øomewhat broad at the bottome, and more pointed at the toppe, betweene the≈øe leaues commeth vp the ≈øtalke, bearing v≈øually two flowers and no more at the toppe, made of ≈øixe white leaues a peece, pointed and not round: the cup is ≈ømall and round, like vnto the cup or crowne of the lea≈øt Ru≈øh Daffodill, of a yellow colour at the bottome, but toward the edge of a dunne or ≈øullen colour.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus angu≈øtifolius luteus ≈øemper florens Caccini. The yellow Italian Daffodill of Caccini.
div.p: This Daffodill beareth a number of ≈ømall, long, narrow, and very greene leaues, broader then the leaues of any Ru≈øh Daffodill, among which ri≈øe vp diuers ≈øtalkes, bearing at the head two or three flowers a peece, each of them being ≈ømall and yellow, the cup or crowne is ≈ømall al≈øo, of a deeper yellow then the flower. The Nobleman of Florence, who fir≈øt ≈øent this plant to Chri≈øtian Porret at Leyden, after the death of Carolus Clu≈øius, writeth that euery ≈øtalke doth beare with him more ≈øtore of flowers, then are formerly ≈øet downe, and that it neuer cea≈øeth to beare flowers, but that after one or moe ≈øtalkes haue been in flower together, and are pa≈øt, there ≈øucceed other in their places.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is naturall of Spain, the naturall place of the other is not known to vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The times of the flowring, are ≈øet downe both in the title and in the de≈øcriptions; the one to be in Autumne, the other to be all the Summer long.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The Latine names are impo≈øed on them, as are fitte≈øt for them, and the la≈øt by that honourable man that ≈øent it, which is mo≈øt fit to continue, and not to bee changed. But wee, to let it bee knowne by an Engli≈øh name to Engli≈øh people, haue entituled it, The yellow Italian Daffodill of Caccini: if any man can giue it a more proper name, I ≈øhall bee therewith right well content.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus angu≈øtifolius, ≈øiue Iuncifolius maximus amplo calice. The great Iunquilia with the large flower or cup.
div.p: Although this Daffodill importeth by his name, not to be of this family, but of the next, con≈øidering it is ≈øo like vnto them, but bigger; yet I haue thought good to place it in the end of the≈øe narrow leafed Daffodils, as being indifferent, whether it ≈øhould bee referred to this or to that. For this carrieth diuers long greene leaues, like vnto the other Ru≈øh Daffodils, but thicker and broader, ≈øo that it may without any great errour, bee reckoned among the≈øe narrow leafed Daffodils, bearing at the toppe two or three very faire large flowers, with a large and more open cuppe, then in any other of the Ru≈øh Daffodils, both of them of a faire yellow colour, yet the cuppe a little deeper then the flower, and a little crumpled about the edges, and hath a pretty ≈øharpe ≈øent: the roote is greater and longer then the other Ru≈øh Daffodill, and couered likewi≈øe with a blacki≈øh coate.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: We haue this in Gardens onely, and haue not heard of his naturall place.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: I leaue it indifferent, as I ≈øaid, whether you will call it Narci≈ø≈øus angu≈øtifolius, or Iuncifolius magno calice, or maximus, becau≈øe it is the greate≈øt of all the re≈øt of that kinde.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus totus albus flore pleno Virginianus. The double white Daffodill of Virginia.
div.p: The roote of this Daffodill, is very like vnto the former ≈øingle Virginia Daffodill, ≈øet forth in the fir≈øt place of this ranke of narrow leafed Daffodils, but that it is a little bigger and rounder, being a little long withall, and blacki≈øh al≈øo on the out≈øide, as that is: from whence ri≈øeth vp two leaues, ≈øomewhat broader then the former: but of a like greenne≈ø≈øe: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp betweene the≈øe two leaues, about a ≈øpan high, or not much higher, bearing one faire double ≈ønow white flower, very like in the fa≈øhion vnto the pale yellow double Daffodill, or ba≈øtard Daffodill of Robinus, hereafter de≈øcribed: For it is in the like manner laid open flat, and compo≈øed of ≈øix rowes of leaues, euery rowe lying in order iu≈øt oppo≈øite, or one before another, whereof tho≈øe ≈øix leaues that make the fir≈øt or outermo≈øt cour≈øe, are the greate≈øt, and all the re≈øt lying, as I ≈øaid, one vpon or before another, are euery rowe ≈ømaller then others from the middle of this flower, thru≈øteth forth a ≈ømall long pointed forke or horne, white as the flower is.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The place is named to be Virginia, but in what part it is not known to vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the end of Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It may be that this doth grow among the former ≈øingle kinde, and called by the ≈øame name Attamu≈øco, for that the plant is not much differing, yet hereof I am not certaine: But we, from the forme and countenance of the plant, doe call it Narci≈ø≈øus Virginianus, The Virginian Daffodill, and becau≈øe it beareth a double flower, it hath the title of double added vnto it.

The third order of Daffodils, I ≈øaid in the beginning, was of Iuncifolios, Ru≈øh Daffodils, which are now next to be entreated of, I ≈øhall herein keepe the ≈øame order I v≈øed in the former; but becau≈øe I finde none of this order, that beare but one flower vpon a ≈øtalke, I mu≈øt begin with tho≈øe that beare many.

div.head: 1. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius albus. The white Iunquilia.
div.p:
This white Ru≈øh Daffodill hath ≈ømall long leaues, a little broader, and of a whiter greene colour then the ordinary yellow Ru≈øh Daffodils: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp halfe a foote high or more, bearing two or three ≈ømall white flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, yet ≈øomewhat bigger then the common yellow Ru≈øh Daffodill, hauing a ≈ømall round cuppe in the middle, white al≈øo as the leaues are. The feede is ≈ømall,
blacke, and round, as other ≈øeedes of Daffodils are: the roote is ≈ømall and round, couered with a blacki≈øh coate.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius albus magno calice. The white Iunquilia with a great cup.
div.p: There is of this kinde another ≈øort, that hath the cup in the middle of the flower, a little larger then the other, but in all other things alike.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius flore albo reflexo. The white turning Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: This turning white Daffodill hath foure or fiue long greene leaues, yet ≈øhorter and broader then the ordinary yellow Iunquilia, and fully as greene al≈øo, from among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈ølender greene ≈øtalke, a foote high, bearing out of a thinne skinnie huske, three or foure, or more ≈ønow white flowers, ≈øtanding vpon long greene foot≈øtalkes, euery flower hanging downe his head, and turning vp his ≈øix narrow and long leaues, euen to the very foot-≈øtalke againe: from the middle of the flower hangeth downe a long round cuppe, as white as the leaues, within which are contained three ≈ømall white chiues, tipt with yellow, and a ≈ømall long pointell, thru≈øting out beyond the brimmes of the cup: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp in their places ≈ømall three ≈øquare heads, wherein is contained very ≈ømall, round, and blacke ≈øhining ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, round, and a little long withall, couered with a blacki≈øh browne coate or skin. The flower is quite without any good ≈øent, or indeed rather none at all.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius flore luteoreflexo. The yellow turning Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this Ru≈øh Daffodill are greater and longer then the former, and of a paler greene colour: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth ≈øomewhat higher, bearing two or three flowers thereon wholly of a gold yellow colour, both the cuppe and the leaues that turne vp againe.

div.head: 4. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius calice albo reflexis folijs luteis. The yellow turning Iunquilia with a white cup.
div.p: This Daffodill hath his long ru≈øh-like leaues ≈øtanding vpright as the former, betweene which ri≈øeth vp a greene ≈øtalke, about a foote high or more, bearing two or three flowers thereon, who≈øe turning leaues are of a faire pale yellow, and the cuppe pale white, and not ≈øo pure a white as the former.

div.head: 5. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius calice luteo reflexis folijs albidis. The white turning Iunquilia with a yellow cup.
div.p: As the la≈øt had the leaues of the flower that turne vp againe yellow, and the cuppe whiti≈øh, ≈øo this hath contrariwi≈øe the turning leaues of a whiti≈øh yellow, and the long cup yellower, el≈øe in his long green leaues, or any other thing, there is ≈ømall difference.

div.head: 6. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus magno calice. The Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill with a great cup.
div.p: This Ru≈øh Daffodill hath bigger leaues, and longer then the ordinary yellow Ru≈øh Daffodill, being a little flat on the one≈øide, and round on the other, but of the ≈øame greenne≈ø≈øe with all the re≈øt: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp two foote high, bearing two, and ≈øometimes three flowers thereon, being of a faire yellow colour, with a large open cup in the middle, of a little deeper yellow colour, like vnto the great Iunquilia with the large flower, before ≈øet downe, whereof this is a kinde, no doubt; but that is larger and greater then this, both in leafe, flower, cup, &c. and this onely ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe in all parts then that.

figure.head: 1 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius albus. The white Iunquilia. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius flore albo reflex ‚Ä¢ . The white turning Iunquilia. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius calice luteo reflexis folijs albis. The yellow turning Iunquilia. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus magno calice. The yellow Iunquilia with a great cuppe. 5 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus maior vulgaris. The ordinary yellow Iunquilia. 6 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius Autum ‚Ä¢ alis flore viridi. The greene Autumne Iunquilia. 7 Narci≈ø≈øus angu≈øtifolius aureus multiplex. The golden double narrow leafed Daffodill. 8 Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius flore pleno. The double Iunquilie.

div.head: 7. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus vulgaris maior. The ordinary Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: This ordinary Ru≈øh Daffodill hath foure or fiue long greene round leaues, like vnto Ru≈øhes, whereof it tooke the name: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, round and greene, a foote and a halfe high very often, bearing at the toppe three or foure flowers all yellow, but much ≈ømaller then the la≈øt, and ≈øo is the cup al≈øo: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall and blacke, inclo≈øed in ≈ømall cornered heads; the roote is blacki≈øh on the out≈øide. The ≈ømell of the flower is very ≈øweete in all the≈øe ≈øorts of Ru≈øh Daffodils.

div.head: 8. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus medius. The ≈ømaller Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this Daffodill are like vnto the former, but ≈ømaller and rounder, the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth not vp ≈øo high, nor are the flowers ≈øo great, but the leaues of the flower are a little rounder, and not ≈øo pointed as in the former, in all things el≈øe alike, ≈øauing le≈ø≈øer.

div.head: 9. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus minor. The lea≈øt Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: This lea≈øt Daffodill hath fiue or ≈øix ≈ømall greene leaues, a little broader, and not ≈øo long as the la≈øt, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke almo≈øt a foote high, bearing one or two ≈ømall flowers at the toppe, of a paler yellow colour then the former, with a yellow open cuppe, or crowne rather in the middle, bigger then in either of the la≈øt two: the roote is very ≈ømall and blacke, like vnto the la≈øt in roundne≈ø≈øe and colour.

div.head: 10. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus albicantibus lineis di≈øtinctus. The yellow Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill with white lines.
div.p: This Ru≈øh Daffodill hath round, greene, and long leaues, like vnto the ordinary Ru≈øh Daffodill, with a ≈øtalke bearing two or three yellow flowers, hauing leaues ≈øomewhat round at the point or end, with a line or ≈øtrake of white in the middle of euerie one of them, the cup is ≈øhort, and crowne fa≈øhion, a little crumpled about the brims: the ≈øeede, roote, or any thing el≈øe differeth not.

div.head: 11. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius Autumnalis flore viridi. The Autumne Ru≈øh Daffodill with a greene flower.
div.p: This ≈øtrange Ru≈øh Daffodill (I call it ≈øtrange, not onely becau≈øe it differeth from all others of this kinde, but al≈øo becau≈øe there are but few in the≈øe parts that haue had it, and fewer that doe ≈øtill enioy it, in that it is peri≈øhed withall that had it) hath but one onely leafe, very long, round, and greene, in all that euer I ≈øaw growing, which beareth no flower while that greene leafe is fre≈øh, and to bee ≈øeene: but afterwards the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp, being like vnto the former greene leafe, round, naked, and greene vp to the toppe, where two or three flowers breake forth out of a ≈ømall thin skinne, euery one con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix ≈ømall and narrow greene leaues, very ≈øharpe pointed at the end, and as it were ending in a ≈ømall pricke or thorne: in the middle whereof is a ≈ømall round cup, or rather crowne, of the ≈øame colour with the leaues and ≈øtalke, which flower ≈ømelleth very ≈øweete, ≈øomewhat like vnto the re≈øt of the Ru≈øh Daffodils: this ≈øheweth not his flower vntill October, and the fro≈øts quickly following after their flowring, cau≈øe them ≈øoone to peri≈øh.

div.head: 12. Narci≈ø≈øus angu≈øtifolius aureus multiplex. The golden double narrow leafed Daffodill.
div.p:
The leaues of this Daffodill are very narrow, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour, not aboue foure or fiue inches long, from among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke about a foote high, bearing at the top one flower, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øome outer leaues, which are of a yellow
colour, and of many other leaues in the middle being ≈ømaller, and ≈øet thicke and round together of a more yellow gold colour, but with ≈øome whiter leaues among them, the middle part a little pointing forth: the flower ≈øtandeth long before it doth perfect his colour, and abideth long in flower before the colour decay: the roote is in fa≈øhion almo≈øt like the ordinary Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill. I acknowledge this Daffodill hath not his proper place; but becau≈øe the figure is ≈øet in this table, let it thus pa≈ø≈øe at this time.

div.head: 13. Narci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus flore pleno. The double Iunquilia, or Ru≈øh Daffodill.
div.p: The double Ru≈øh Daffodill hath his long greene leaues round, like the leaues of the common or ordinary Ru≈øh Daffodill, and of the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe, among which ri≈øeth vp a long ≈ølender greene ≈øtalke, bearing two or three, ≈øeldome more ≈ømall flowers, yellow and double, that is, with diuers rowes of leaues, hauing the yellow cup ≈øuch as is in the ≈øingle flower, broken into ≈ømall ≈øhreads or peeces, running among the leaues of the flower, which peeces in ≈øome flowers are not ≈øo ea≈øily ≈øeene, being ≈ømaller then in others, this beareth no button or head vnder the flower for ≈øeede, his roote is round and blacki≈øh, browne on the out≈øide, ≈øo like vnto the common Ru≈øh Daffodill, that it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to know the one from the other.
There is another of this kinde, who≈øe flowers are ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo double, one,Alter minori flore. two, or three at the mo≈øt vpon a ≈øtalke, and of le≈ø≈øe beauty by much.

div.head: The Place.
