div.p: All the≈øe Ru≈øh Daffodils, doe for the mo≈øt part grow in Spaine and France, and on the Pyrenaean Mountaines, which are betweene Spaine and France, which Mountains are the Nour≈øeries of many of the fine≈øt flowers, that doe adorne the Gardens of the≈øe louers of natures pride, and gathered in part by indu≈øtrious, learned, generous men, inhabiting neare thereunto, and in part by ≈øuch as make a gaine of their labours, be≈øtowed vpon the≈øe things. Onely that with the greene flower was gathered in Barbary, and imparted vnto vs from France.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in the Spring, that is, in March and Aprill, except ≈øuch who≈øe time is ≈øet downe to be in Autumne.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their names are ≈øpecified in their titles, and therefore I ≈øhall not need to ≈øet downe any further repetitions.

To conclude therefore this di≈øcour≈øe of true Daffodils, there remaineth to ≈øpeake of the Sea Daffodils, which (as I ≈øaid in the beginning) is but one, that is frequent, and doth abide with vs. But there bee ≈øome others found about the Cape of good Hope, and in the We≈øt Indies, and brought into the≈øe parts rather for o≈øtentation, then continuance, where they haue flowred onely once (if peraduenture ≈øo often) ≈øo that being ≈øuch ≈øtrangers, of ≈øo remote Countries, and of ≈øo diuers natures, I ≈øhall but ≈øhew you ≈øome of them, rather cur≈øorily then curiou≈øly; and but onely for your ≈øatisfaction, giue you knowledge of two or three of them, that there haue beene ≈øeene ≈øuch in flower, and that they are ≈øcarce to bee ≈øeene againe, except they bee fetcht a new euery yeare that they be ≈øeene.

div.head: Narci≈ø≈øus Marinus, ≈øiue tertius Matthioli. The great white Sea Daffodill, or Matthiolus his third Daffodill.
div.p:
The roote of this Daffodill by long continuance, ≈øtanding in one place without being remoued, groweth to be much greater and larger, then any other Daffodill what≈øoeuer,
and as bigge as any meane Squilla or Sea Onion roote, hauing many long, thicke, and white fibres, or long rootes, diuer≈øly branched, and ≈øpread vnder the vpper part of the earth, be≈øide ≈øome others that grow downward, and peri≈øh not euery yeare, as the fibres of all, or mo≈øt of the other Daffodils doe; and therefore this plant will not thriue, and beare flowers, if it be often tran≈øplanted, but rather de≈øire to abide in one place without remouing, as I ≈øaid, and that not to be ouer≈øhadowed, or couered with other herbes ≈øtanding too neare it, which then will flouri≈øh, and beare aboundantly: from this roote, which is couered with many blacki≈øh coates, ari≈øeth ≈øix or ≈øeuen, or more leaues, twice ≈øo broad almo≈øt, as any of the former Daffodils, but not ≈øo long by halfe as many of them, being but ≈øhort, in compari≈øon of the breadth, and of a white greene colour; from the middle of which leaues, as al≈øo from the ≈øides ≈øometimes, ≈øpringeth vp one or two, or more ≈øtalkes, roundi≈øh and thicke, and ≈øometimes a little flat and cornered, a foote high or ≈øomewhat more, bearing at the toppe, out of a skinnie huske, eight, ten, twelue, or more very large flowers, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix white leaues a peece, ≈øpread or laid open, with a white ≈øhort cuppe or crowne in the middle, lying flat vpon the leaues, cut or diuided into ≈øix corners (and not whole, as the cuppe or crowne of any other ≈øingle Daffodill) from euery of which edges, or corners of this cup or crowne, ≈øtandeth one white long thread, a little crooked or turning vp at the end, tipt with a yellow pendent, and ≈øome other white threads tipt with yellow pendents, ≈øtanding al≈øo in the middle: after the flower is pa≈øt, there come vp great three ≈øquare heads, wherein the ≈øeede is contained, which is great, blacke, and round, like vnto the ≈øeede of other Daffodils, but greater: the flower hath a rea≈øonable good ≈øent, but not very ≈øtrong.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It was fir≈øt found by the Sea ≈øide, in the I≈øle of Sardinia, and on the high Mountaines al≈øo of the ≈øame I≈øle, where it hath borne by report, thirty fiue flowers vpon a ≈øtalke: it groweth likewi≈øe about Illyricum, and in diuers other places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It ≈øpringeth later out of the ground then any other Daffodill, that is to ≈øay, not vntill the later end of March, or beginning of Aprill, and flowreth in the end of May, or the beginning of Iune: the ≈øeede is ripe in the end of Iuly, or beginning of Augu≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt that hath made mention of this Daffodill, was Matthiolus, who placed it in the third place among his Daffodils, and is mo≈øt v≈øually now adayes called, Narci≈ø≈øus tertius Matthioli, Matthiolus his third Daffodill, the rather, becau≈øe Clu≈øius vpon a more mature deliberation, fir≈øt referred it thereunto, but called it at the fir≈øt, Lilionarci≈ø≈øus Hemerocallidis facie, and, as hee ≈øaith, Iacobus Plateau (who fir≈øt ≈øent him the figure hereof, with the de≈øcription) called it Lilionarci≈ø≈øus Orientalis, but Clu≈øius vpon certaine information, that it grew in the places afore≈øaid, mi≈øliked the name of Orientalis, and added Hemerocallis, which yet is not fit, for that his Hemerocallis Valentina, is a plaine Pancration or Sea ba≈øtard Daffodill, who≈øe middle cup is longer then the cup of any true Daffodill, which (as I ≈øaid in the beginning of this Chapter) is the chiefe≈øt note of difference, betweene a true and a ba≈øtard Daffodill. I receiued the ≈øeede of this Daffodill among many other ≈øeedes of rare plants, from the liberality of Mr. Doctor Flud, one of the Phy≈øitians of the Colledge in London, who gathered them in the Vniuet≈øity Garden at Pi≈øa in Italy, and brought them with him, returning home from his trauailes into tho≈øe parts, by the name of Martagon rari≈øsimum, (and hauing ≈øowne them, expected fourteene yeares, before I ≈øaw them beare a flower, which the fir≈øt yeare that it did flower, bore foure ≈øtalkes of
1 Narci≈ø≈øus tertius Matthioli. The great white Sea Daffodill. 2 Narci≈ø≈øus Indicus autumnalis. The Indian Autumne Daffodill. 3 Narci≈ø≈øus marinus Africanus. The Sea Daffodill of Africa. 4 Narci≈ø≈øus marinus exoticus. The ≈øtrange Sea Daffodill. depiction of flowers
flowers, with euery one of them eight or ten flowers on them) which of all other names, doth lea≈øt an≈øwer the forme or qualities of this plant. It may mo≈øt fitly be called Narci≈ø≈øus marinus maximus, in Engli≈øh, The great Sea Daffodill, both becau≈øe it is a true Daffodill, and the greate≈øt of all other, and al≈øo becau≈øe it hath not been found, but in I≈ølands, or el≈øe in other places neare the Sea. Lobelius entituleth it Pancratium Indicum alterum vernum, ≈øiue Narci≈ø≈øus Indicus alter facie Pancratij Mon≈øpeliaci, but all this is wide from the matter, as may ea≈øily be known, by that that hath been ≈øaid before. It is generally (as I ≈øaid before) called of all Narci≈ø≈øus tertius Matthioli, Matthiolus his third Daffodill, which may either ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe with vs, or as I called it, The great Sea Daffodill, which you will, & ≈øo Clu≈øius doth la≈øtly entitle it.

div.head: 1. Pancratium Indicum, aut Narci≈ø≈øus Indicus Autumnalis quorundam Lobelij. The Indian Autumne Daffodill of Lobel.
div.p: This plant hath in my opinion, a farre nearer re≈øemblance vnto an Hyacinthus, then vnto any Daffodill: But becau≈øe Lobel hath ≈øo ≈øet it forth, I will ≈øo publi≈øh it vnto you, leauing it to iudgement. The roote is, as he ≈øaith, a ≈øpan long, and of the thickne≈ø≈øe of a mans arme, couered with many white ≈øhells, whereof the outermo≈øt are of a darke red or Che≈ønut colour: the flowers ri≈øe vp in September, and October, being eight or ten in number, euery one by it ≈øelfe vpon a ≈ømall foot≈øtalke, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, ≈øomewhat long, narrow, and pointed, like vnto the flowers of the Engli≈øh Colchicum, or Medowe Saffron, of a whiti≈øh yellow dunne colour, with ≈øix long threads in the middle: the greene leaues are long and broad, and broad pointed.

div.head: 2. Narci≈ø≈øus Marinus Africanus, ≈øiue Exoticus Lobelij. The Sea Daffodill of Africa.
div.p: The roote of this ≈øtrange plant (which of ≈øome likene≈ø≈øe is called a Daffodill) is very great, made as it were of many ≈øcaly cloues, from whence ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall ≈øhort ≈øtalke, bearing hard aboue the ground two faire broad greene pointed leaues, more long then broad, ≈øo compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalke at the bottome, that it ≈øeemeth to run through them: the ≈øtalke is ≈øpotted with diuers di≈øcoloured ≈øpots, and is bare or naked from the≈øe two leaues vnto the toppe, where it beareth one faire double flower, like vnto a double Auemone, of a delayed reddi≈øh colour, tending to a blu≈øh, with many threads ≈øet about the middle head.

div.head: 3. Narci≈ø≈øus Marinus Exoticus. The ≈øtrange Sea Daffodill
div.p: This ≈øtrange Sea Daffodill, hath fiue or ≈øix large and long leaues of a palegreene colour, from among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtrong and bigge ≈øtalke, bearing at the toppe, out of a thinne ho≈øe or skinne, many very large flowers, made of ≈øix long and pointed leaues a peece, of a blewi≈øh purple colour, with a large round open cup in the middle, of a ≈øadder colour then the leaues: the roote is very great, yet like vnto other great Daffodils, the outer skins whereof are of a darke browne colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The Indian Daffodils grew in the vpper part of Hi≈øpaniola in the We≈øt Indies, and brought hither, where they all ≈øoone peri≈øhed.
The other grew neare the Cape of good Hope, and was brought into the parts of Holland and thereabouts, from whence we had it, & peri≈øhed al≈øo.
The la≈øt is vnknowne where it was gathered.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowred in Autumne, as it is ≈øaid.
The other in the fir≈øt Summer of their bringing.
And ≈øo did the la≈øt, but the ≈øame rootes will not flower with vs againe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: So much hath been ≈øaid of their names in their titles, as hath come to our knowledge; and therefore let that ≈øuffice.

Thus hauing gone through the whole Family of the true Daffodils, (for ≈øo much as hath come to our knowledge) and ≈øet them downe euery one by his name, and in his order; it is fit that we ≈øpeake of their ba≈øtard brethren, and ≈øhew you them al≈øo, in the ≈øame order held with the former, as neare as the plenty of variety herein, which is not the like with the former, will giue leaue, that when you know them both by face and name, you may the better know to place or di≈øtingui≈øh of others, that haue not pa≈ø≈øed vnder this rod.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus aureus Hi≈øpanicus maximus. The great yellow Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: The roote of this kinde of Daffodill is rea≈øonable great, and blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, de≈øiring to be deepe in the ground; and therefore will runne downe, where it will then encrea≈øe into many of-≈øets, from whence ri≈øe vp many thicke, long, and ≈øtiffe leaues, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, among which ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtrong ≈øtalke, ≈øometimes three foote high or better, bearing at the toppe one onely faire great yellow flower, ≈øtanding forth right, and not pendulous, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix ≈øhort and ≈øomewhat broad leaues, with a very great, large, and long trunke, of an equall largene≈ø≈øe, but open at the mouth, and turning vp the brimmes a little, which are ≈øomewhat crumpled: after the flower is pa≈øt, there commeth in the place a three ≈øquare head, containing round blacke ≈øeede, like vnto other Daffodils.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Pyrenaeus Hi≈øpanico & Anglico ≈øimilis. The Mountaine ba≈øtard Daffodill of diuers kindes.
div.p: There is much variety in this kinde of ba≈øtard Daffodill: For one ≈øort hath verie broad and whiti≈øh greene leaues, ≈øomewhat ≈øhort in compari≈øon of others, that are of that breadth: the flower is wholly yellow, but a little paler then the former Spani≈øh kinde, hauing the leaues of his flower long, and ≈øomewhat narrow, ≈øtanding like wings about the middle trunke, which is as long as the leaues, and ≈ømaller then in many other of this kinde, but a little yellower then the wings. Another ≈øort hath narrower green leaues then this la≈øt, and longer, the flower is all yellow, but the trunke is larger, wider, and more open at the mouth then the former, and almo≈øt as large as the former Spani≈øh, but not ≈øo high as the la≈øt. A third hath the wings of the flower of a Strawe colour, but the trunke is long and narrow, of a faire yellow. A fourth hath ≈øuch like flowers, but that it is ≈øhorter, both the wings and the trunke: Some likewi≈øe haue the wings of the flower longer, then the long trunke, and ≈øome ≈øhorter. Some al≈øo are all yellow, and ≈øome haue their wings onely a little more pale or white, like the Engli≈øh kinde: Some againe haue their trunkes long and narrow, others haue them larger and wider open, and crumpled at the brimmes; ≈øo that it is needle≈ø≈øe, to ≈øpend a great deale of time and labour vpon ≈øuch ≈ømally re≈øpected flowers, but that in the beholding of them, we may therein admire the worke of the Creatour, who can frame ≈øuch diuer≈øity in one thing: But this is be≈øide the text, yet not impertinent.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus pallidus praecox. The early Strawe coloured ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p:
The leaues of this Daffodill are of a meane ≈øize, betweene the broade≈øt and the narrower kindes, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, and not very long: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a foot high or more, whereon ≈øtandeth one large great flower, equalling the greate≈øt Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill, before de≈øcribed, in the largene≈ø≈øe of his trunke, and hauing the brimmes turned vp a little, which maketh it ≈øeeme the larger: the wings or outer leaues are in a maner as ≈øhort, as they are in the greate≈øt Spani≈øh kinde, (and not long flagging down, like vnto the Mountain kinds) and ≈øtand ≈øtraight outright: all the whole flower is
of one euen colour, that is, of a fine pale yellow, ≈øomewhat like vnto the colour of a Lemon peele or rinde, but ≈øomewhat whiter, which v≈øually we call a Strawe colour: the greatne≈ø≈øe of the flower, the earline≈ø≈øe of the flowring, and the difference of colour from all the re≈øt of this kinde, hath made me entreate of it apart by it ≈øelfe, as being no le≈ø≈øe worthy.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpaenicus flore albo maior. The great white Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: This ba≈øtard Daffodill hath diuers leaues ri≈øing vp together, long and broad, ≈øomewhat like vnto the fir≈øt Spani≈øh kinde, but a little broader, and of a whiter greene colour, yet not ≈øo white, as in the le≈ø≈øer Spani≈øh white kindes, hereafter de≈øcribed: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtrong ≈øtalke, about two foote high, bearing one white flower at the toppe, bending downe the head, as all the≈øe white kindes doe, but is not of ≈øo pure a white, as the le≈ø≈øer kindes that follow, yet whiter then the greate≈øt white Spani≈øh kinde, next of all to be de≈øcribed: the whole flower, as well trunke as wings, is much larger then the le≈ø≈øer white kindes, and almo≈øt equalling the fir≈øt Spani≈øh yellow, but a little longer and narrower, a little crumpled and turning vp at the brimmes: the head and ≈øeede are like the fir≈øt; the roote is greater and thicker then the fir≈øt Spani≈øh, and doth not encrea≈øe ≈øo much, nor is couered with a blacke, but rather with a whiti≈øh coate.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus maximus albidus. The greate≈øt Spani≈øh white ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: This kinde of ba≈øtard Daffodill is very like the la≈øt mentioned Daffodill, both in leaues and flowers, but larger in both: the flower of this is not full ≈øo white, but hath ≈øome ≈øhew of palene≈ø≈øe therein, and more vpon the fir≈øt opening of the flower then afterwards, and is as great altogether, as the great Spani≈øh yellow, at the lea≈øt with a longer, and ≈øomewhat narrower trunke: the ≈øeede is like vnto the former, and ≈øo is the roote al≈øo, but greater, being white on the out≈øide, and not blacke.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus flore albo medius & minor. The two le≈ø≈øer white Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodils.
div.p: There are two other of the≈øe kindes of white Spani≈øh Daffodils, one greater or le≈ø≈øer then the other, but neither of them ≈øo great as the former. The leaues of both are of a whiti≈øh greene colour, one a little broader then the other: the flowers of both are pure white, and bending downe the heads, that they almo≈øt touch the ≈øtalke againe, the greater flower hath the longer and narrower trunke; and the le≈ø≈øer flower, the ≈øhorter and wider open, yet both a little crumpled at the edges or brimmes: the rootes of both are like one vnto another, but differ in the greatne≈ø≈øe. From the ≈øeede of the≈øe haue ≈øprung much variety, few or none keeping either colour or height with the mother plants.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Anglicus vulgaris. Our common Engli≈øh wilde ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: This ba≈øtard Daffodill is ≈øo common in all England, both in Cop≈øes, Woods, and Orchards, that I might well forbeare the de≈øcription thereof, and e≈øpecially, in that growing wilde, it is of little re≈øpect in our Garden: but yet, left I bee challenged of ignorance in common plants, and in regard of ≈øome variety therein worth the marking, I will ≈øet downe his de≈øcription and variety as briefly as I may: It hath three or foure grayi≈øh greene leaues, long and ≈øomewhat narrow, among which ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, about a ≈øpan high or little higher, bearing at the toppe, out of a skinnie huske, as all other Daffodils haue, one flower (although ≈øometimes I haue ≈øeene two together) ≈øomewhat large, hauing the ≈øix leaues that ≈øtand like wings, of a pale yellow colour, and the long trunke in the middle of a faire yellow, with the edges or brimmes a little crumpled or vneuen: after the flower is pa≈øt, it beareth a round head, ≈øeeming three ≈øquare, containing round blacke ≈øeede; the roote is ≈øomewhat blacki≈øh on the out≈øide.

figure.head:
1 P≈øeud ‚Ä¢ arci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus maximus
‚Ä¢ urcus. The great yellow Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill. 2 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Pyr ‚Ä¢ naeus v ‚Ä¢ iformis. The Mountaine ba≈øtard Daffodill of diuers kindes. 3 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus maior albus The greater white Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill. 4 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus minor albus The le≈ø≈øer Spani≈øh white ba≈øtard Daffodill. 5 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus tub ‚Ä¢ ≈øexangulari. The ≈øix cornered ba≈øtard Daffodill. 6 P≈øeud ‚Ä¢ narci≈ø≈øus maximus aureus, ≈øiue Ro≈øeus Trade≈øcanti. Iohn Trade≈øcants great Ro≈øe Daffodill. 7 P≈øeud ‚Ä¢ narci≈ø≈øus aureus Anglicus maximus. Ma≈øter Wilmers great double Daffodill 8 P≈øeud ‚Ä¢ narci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus aureus flore pleno. The double Spani≈øh Daffodill, or Parkin≈øons double Daffodill. 9 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Gallicus maior flore plen ‚Ä¢ . The greater double French Daffodill. 10 P≈øeudon ‚Ä¢ rci≈ø≈øus Anglicus flore plen ‚Ä¢ . The double Engli≈øh Daffodill, or Gerrards double Daffodill.

div.p: But there is another of this kinde like vnto the former, who≈øe further de≈øcription you haue here before; the wings of which flower are much more white then the former, and in a manner of a milke white colour, the trunke remaining almo≈øt as yellow as the former, and not differing in any thing el≈øe.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus tubo ≈øexangulari. The ≈øix cornered ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: This kinde of Daffodill hath two or three long, and ≈øomewhat broader leaues then the la≈øt, between which commeth forth a ≈øtalke, bearing one flower ≈øomewhat large, hauing the ≈øix outer leaues of a pale yellow colour, and the long trunke plaited or cornered all along vnto the very edge into ≈øix parts, of a little deeper yellow then the wings.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt great Spani≈øh kinde was brought out of Spaine. The re≈øt from the Pyrenaean Mountaines, onely the la≈øt ≈øauing one is plentifull in our owne Countrey, but the white ≈øort of that kinde came with the re≈øt from the ≈øame Mountaines.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The pale or third kinde, and the Engli≈øh bee the mo≈øt early, all the re≈øt flower in Aprill, and the greate≈øt yellow ≈øomewhat earlier, then the other greater or le≈ø≈øer white.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their ≈øeuerall names are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles ≈øufficient to di≈øtingui≈øh them, and therefore there needeth no more to be ≈øaid of them.

div.head: 1. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus aureus maximus flore pleno, ≈øiue Ro≈øeus Trade≈øcanti. The greate≈øt double yellow ba≈øtard Daffodill, or Iohn Trade≈øcant his great Ro≈øe Daffodill.
div.p: This Prince of Daffodils (belongeth primarily to Iohn Trade≈øcant, as the fir≈øt founder thereof, that we know, and may well bee entituled the Glory of Daffodils) hath a great round roote, like vnto other Daffodils, couered with a browni≈øh outer skinne or peeling, from whence ri≈øeth vp foure or fiue ≈øomewhat large and broad leaues, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, yet not fully ≈øo long and large as the next following Daffodill: from the middle whereof ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke almo≈øt as high and great as it, bearing at the toppe (out of a skinnie huske) one faire large great flower (the budde, before it breake open, being ≈øhorter and thicker in the middle, and ending in a longer and ≈øharper point then any of the other Daffodils) very much ≈øpread open, con≈øi≈øting of ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter leaues then the next, but more in number, and thicker and rounder ≈øet together, making it ≈øeeme as great and double as any Prouince Ro≈øe, and intermixt with diuers yellow and pale leaues, as it were in rowes one vnder another. It abideth long in flower, and ≈øpreadeth, by ≈øtanding long, to be the broade≈øt in compa≈ø≈øe of any of the Daffodils, but falleth away at the la≈øt without giuing any ≈øeede, as all double Daffodils doe.

div.head: 2. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus aureus Anglicus maximus. Mr. Wilmers great double Daffodill.
div.p:
The other great double Daffodill doth ≈øo neare re≈øemble our ordinary Engli≈øh double kinde, that I doe not finde therein any greater difference, then the largene≈ø≈øe both of leaues and flowers, &c. and the ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe of growth. It beareth three or foure large, long, and broad leaues, ≈øomewhat longer and broader then the former, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth to bee two foote high, growing (in a fruitfull and fat ≈øoyle) ≈øtrong, and ≈øomewhat round, bearing at the toppe, out of a thin skinne, one great and faire double flower, each leafe whereof is twice as large and
broad as the former, diuer≈øly intermixt with a rowe of paler, and a rowe of deeper yellow leaues, wholly di≈øper≈øed throughout the flower, the pale colour as well as the deeper yellow, in this as in the other ≈ømall Engli≈øh kinde, growing deeper by ≈øtanding: ≈øometimes the leaues hereof are ≈øcattered, and ≈øpread wholly, making it ≈øhew a faire, broad, open flower: and ≈øometimes the outer leaues ≈øtand ≈øeparate from the middle trunke, which is whole and vnbroken, and very thicke of leaues: and ≈øometimes the middle trunke will bee halfe broken, neither expre≈ø≈øing a full open double flower, nor a clo≈øe double trunke, as it is likewi≈øe ≈øeene in the ≈ømall Engli≈øh kinde, as ≈øhall bee declared in his place: this beareth no ≈øeede; the roote hereof is thicke and great, and encrea≈øeth as well as any other Daffodill.

div.head: 3. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus aureus Hi≈øpanicus flore pleno. The great double yellow Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill, or Parkin≈øons Daffodill.
div.p: This double Spani≈øh Daffodill hath diuers leaues ri≈øing from the roote, ≈øtiffer, narrower, and not of ≈øo whiti≈øh a greene colour as the former, but more ≈øullen or grayi≈øh, plainely re≈øembling the leaues of the ≈øingle great kinde, from whence this hath ri≈øen: the ≈øtalke hereof likewi≈øe ri≈øeth almo≈øt as high as it, and neare the height of the la≈øt recited double, bearing one double flower at the toppe, alwayes ≈øpread open, and neuer forming a double trunke like the former, yet not ≈øo faire and large as it, the outermo≈øt leaues whereof being of a greeni≈øh colour at the fir≈øt, and afterward more yellow, doe a little turne them≈øelues backe againe to the ≈øtalke, the other leaues are ≈øome of a pale yellow, and others of a more gold yellow colour, tho≈øe that ≈øtand in the middle are ≈ømaller, and ≈øome of them ≈øhew as if they were hollow trunked, ≈øo that they ≈øeeme to be greeni≈øh, whiti≈øh, yellow, and gold yellow, all mixed one among another: the root is great, round, and whiti≈øh on the in≈øide, couered with darke coloured skinnes or peelings. I thinke none euer had this kinde before my ≈øelfe, nor did I my ≈øelfe euer ≈øee it before the yeare 1618. for it is of mine own rai≈øing and flowring fir≈øt in my Garden.

div.head: 4. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Gallicus maior flore pleno. The greater double French ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: This greater double Daffodill, hath his whiti≈øh greene leaues longer and broader then the ≈ømaller French kinde, hereafter following, to bee de≈øcribed, and broader, longer, and more limber then the double Engli≈øh kinde: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp not much higher, then the ≈ømaller French kinde, but a little bigger, bearing at the top one great double flower, which when it is fully and perfectly blowne open (which is but ≈øeldome; for that it is very tender, the leaues being much thinner, and thereby continually ≈øubiect, vpon any little di≈øtemperature of the time, to cleaue ≈øo fa≈øt one vnto another, that the flower cannot blow open faire) is a faire and a goodly flower, larger by halfe then the ≈ømaller kinde, and fuller of leaues, of the ≈øame pale whiti≈øh yellow, or Lemon colour, with the le≈ø≈øer, or rather a little whiter, and not ≈øet in the ≈øame order of rowes as it is, but more confu≈øedly together, and turning backe the ends of the outermo≈øt leaues to the ≈øtalke againe, and hauing the bottome of the flower on the back≈øide ≈øomewhat greene, neither of which is found in the le≈ø≈øer kinde: the roote is very like vnto the le≈ø≈øer kinde, but a little bigger and longer.

div.head: 5. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Anglicus flore pleno. The double Engli≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill, or Gerrards double Daffodill.
div.p:
The leaues of this double Daffodill are very like vnto the ≈øingle kinde, being of a whiti≈øh greene colour, and ≈øomewhat broad, a little ≈øhorter and narrower, yet ≈øtiffer then the former French kinde: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp about a foote high, bearing at the toppe one very double flower, the outermo≈øt leaues being of the ≈øame pale colour, that is to bee ≈øeene in the wings of the ≈øingle kinde; tho≈øe that ≈øtand next them, are ≈øome as deepe a yellow as the trunke of the ≈øingle, and others of the ≈øame pale colour, with ≈øome greene ≈øtripes on the backe of diuers of the leaues: thus is the whole flower variably intermixt with pale and deepe yellow, and ≈øome greene ≈øtripes among them,
when it is fully open, and the leaues di≈øper≈øed and broken. For ≈øometimes the flower ≈øheweth a clo≈øe and round yellow trunke in the middle, ≈øeparate from the pale outer wings, which trunke is very double, ≈øhewing ≈øome pale leaues within it, di≈øper≈øed among the yellow: And ≈øometimes the trunke is more open, or in part broken, ≈øhewing forth the ≈øame colours intermixt within it: the flower pa≈ø≈øeth away without giuing any ≈øeede, as all other bulbous rootes doe that beare double flowers: the roote is ≈ømall, very like vnto the French double kindes, e≈øpecially the le≈ø≈øer, that it is verie hard to know the one from the other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt and greate≈øt kinde, we had fir≈øt from Iohn Trade≈øcante (as I ≈øaid before) whether rai≈øed from ≈øeed, or gained from beyond Sea, I know not.

The ≈øecond we fir≈øt had from Vincent Sion, borne in Flanders, dwelling on the Banke ≈øide, in his liues time, but now dead; an indu≈øtrious and worthy louer of faire flowers, who cheri≈øhed it in his Garden for many yeares, without bearing of any flowers vntill the yeare 1620. that hauing flowred with him, (and hee not knowing of whom hee receiued it, nor hauing euer ≈øeene the like flower before) he ≈øheweth it to Mr. Iohn de Franqueuille, of whom he ≈øuppo≈øed he had receiued it, (for from beyond Sea he neuer receiued any) who finding it to bee a kinde neuer ≈øeene or knowne to vs before, cau≈øed him to re≈øpect it the more, as it is well worthy. And Mr. George Wilmer of Stratford Bowe E≈øquire, in his liues time hauing likewi≈øe receiued it of him (as my ≈øelfe did al≈øo) would needes appropriate it to him≈øelfe, as if he were the fir≈øt founder thereof, and call it by his owne name Wilmers double Daffodill, which ≈øince hath ≈øo continued.

The third is of mine owne fo≈øtering or rai≈øing, as I ≈øaid before; for a≈ø≈øuredly, it is ri≈øen from the ≈øeede of the great Spani≈øh ≈øingle kinde, which I ≈øowed in mine owne Garden, and cheri≈øhed it, vntill it gaue ≈øuch a flower as is de≈øcribed.
The fourth is not certainly knowne where his originall ≈øhould be: Some thinke it to be of France, and others of Germany.

The la≈øt is a≈ø≈øuredly fir≈øt naturall of our owne Countrey, for Mr. Gerrard fir≈øt di≈øcouered it to the world, finding it in a poore womans Garden in the We≈øt parts of England, where it grew before the woman came to dwell there, and, as I haue heard ≈øince, is naturall of the I≈øle of Wight.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They doe all flower much about one time, that is, from the middle or end of March, as the yeare is forward, vnto the middle of Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Vpon the three fir≈øt I haue impo≈øed the names in Latine, as they are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles: and for the Engli≈øh names, if you plea≈øe, you may let them pa≈ø≈øe likewi≈øe as they are expre≈ø≈øed there al≈øo, that thereby euery one may be truely di≈øtingui≈øhed, and not confounded. The fourth, be≈øides the name in the title, is called of ≈øome Narci≈ø≈øus Germanicus, which whether it be of Germany, or no, I know not; but that the name ≈øhould import ≈øo much. The la≈øt doth v≈øually carry Mr. Gerrards name, and called Gerrards double Daffodill.

div.head: 1. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus augu≈øtifolius flore flaue≈øcente tubo qua≈øi ab≈øci≈ø≈øo. The narrow leafed ba≈øtard Daffodill with the clipt trunke.
div.p:
This kinde of Daffodill hath long and narrow grayi≈øh greene leaues, bearing one ≈øingle flower at the toppe of his ≈øtalke, like vnto the former ≈øingle ba≈øtard kindes, before
≈øpecified, hauing his outer leaues of a pale yellow colour, and his trunke of a deeper yellow: the chiefe differences in this from the former, is in the leaues, being narrow, and then in the trunke of the flower, which is not crumpled or turned vp, as mo≈øt of the other are; and that the brimmes or edges of the flower is as if it had beene clipt off, or cut euen.

div.head: 2. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus medius & minor luteus. The two le≈ø≈øer Spani≈øh yellow ba≈øtard Daffodils.
div.p: The≈øe two le≈ø≈øer kindes of Spani≈øh Daffodils, doe but differ in greatne≈ø≈øe the one from the other, and not in any thing el≈øe; ≈øo that in declaring the one, you may vnder≈øtand the other to bee a little greater. The le≈ø≈øer then hath three or foure narrow ≈øhort whiti≈øh greene leaues, from among which commeth forth a ≈øhort ≈øtalke, not aboue an hand breadth, or halfe a foote high, bearing one ≈øingle flower, not fully ≈øtanding outright, but a little bending downe, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix ≈ømall leaues, ≈øtanding as wings about a ≈ømall, but long trunke, a little crumpled at the brimmes: the whole flower, as well leaues as trunke, are of one deepe yellow colour, like vnto the great Spani≈øh kinde: the roote is but ≈ømall, and couered with a darki≈øh coate. The other is in all parts greater, and (as I ≈øaid) differeth not el≈øe.

div.head: 3. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus luteus minimus. The lea≈øt Spani≈øh yellow ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this ≈ømall kinde are ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter then the former, ≈øeldome exceeding the length of three inches, and very narrow withall, but of the ≈øame grayi≈øh greene colour with the former: euery flower ≈øtandeth vpon a ≈ømall and ≈øhort foote≈øtalke, ≈øcarce ri≈øing aboue the ground; ≈øo that his no≈øe, for the mo≈øt part, doth lye or touch the ground, and is made after the ≈øame fa≈øhion, and of the ≈øame colour with the former, but much ≈ømaller, as his roote is ≈øo likewi≈øe.

div.head: 4. P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Gallicus minor flore pleno. The le≈ø≈øer French double ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: The rootes of this le≈ø≈øer French kinde (if I may lawfully call it, or the greater kinde before ≈øpecified, a ba≈øtard Daffodill; for I ≈øomewhat doubt thereof, in that the flower of either is not made after the fa≈øhion of any of the other ba≈øtard Daffodils, but doth more nearely re≈øemble the forme of the double white Daffodill, expre≈ø≈øed before among the true Daffodils) are like vnto the double Engli≈øh kinde, as al≈øo to the former double greater French kinde, and the leaues are of the ≈øame whiti≈øh greene colour al≈øo, but narrower and not longer: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth a little higher then the Engli≈øh, and not fully ≈øo high as the greater French, bearing one faire double flower thereon, of a pale yellow or Lemon colour, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix rowes of leaues, euery rowe growing ≈ømaller then other vnto the middle, and ≈øo ≈øet and placed, that euery leafe of the flower doth ≈øtand directly almo≈øt in all, one vpon or before another vnto the middle, where the leaues are ≈ømalle≈øt, the outermo≈øt being the greate≈øt, which maketh the flower ≈øeeme the more beautifull: this and the greater kinde hath no trunke, or ≈øhew of any other thing in the middle, as all or mo≈øt of the other former double ba≈øtard Daffodils haue, but are flowers wholly compo≈øed of leaues, ≈øtanding double euen to the middle.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is vndoubtedly a naturall of the Pyrenaean Mountaines.
The Spani≈øh kindes grew in Spaine, and
The French double kinde about Orleance in France, where it is ≈øaid to grow plentifully.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth at the end of March.
The Spani≈øh kindes are the mo≈øt early, flowring betimes in March.
The French double doth flower pre≈øently after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: More cannot bee ≈øaid or added, concerning the names of any of the≈øe Daffodils, then hath been ≈øet downe in their titles: onely the French kinde is mo≈øt v≈øually called Robinus his Daffodill.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius albus. The white ba≈øtard Ru≈øh Daffodill, or Iunquilia.
div.p: This ba≈øtard Ru≈øh Daffodill hath two or three long and very greene leaues, very like vnto the ≈ømall yellow Ru≈øh Daffodill, formerly de≈øcribed, but not altogether ≈øo round, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øhort ≈øtalke, ≈øeldome halfe a foote high, bearing at the toppe, out of a ≈ømall skinnie huske, one ≈ømall white flower, ≈øometime declining to a pale colour, hauing ≈øix ≈ømall and ≈øhort leaues, ≈øtanding about the middle of the trunke, which is long, and much wider open at the mouth, then at the bottome: the ≈ømall outer leaues or wings are a little tending to greene, and the trunke (as I ≈øaid) is either white, or whiti≈øh, hauing the brimmes a little vneuen: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, blacke, and round, like vnto other Ru≈øh Daffodils, but ≈ømaller.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus maior. The greater yellow Iunquilia, or ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p: The leaues of this greater kinde are longer, greater, and a little broader then the former; the ≈øtalke al≈øo is higher, and the flower larger, more open at the mouth and crumpled, then the white, but wholly of a yellow colour: the ≈øeede and the roots are bigger, according to the proportion of the plant.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus minor. The le≈ø≈øer yellow ba≈øtard Iunquilia.
div.p: This is ≈øo like vnto the la≈øt in all things, that I ≈øhall not neede to trouble you with repetitions of the ≈øame things formerly ≈øpoken; the chiefe≈øt difference is the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe of the plant in all parts.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus ≈øerotinus. The late yellow ba≈øtard Iunquilia.
div.p: There is likewi≈øe a third kinde, as great as the greater yellow, and in all his parts expre≈ø≈øing and equalling it, but is accounted the fairer, and flowreth ≈øomewhat later.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The Pyrenaean Hils haue afforded vs all the≈øe varieties, and wee pre≈øerue them carefully; for they are all tender.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All the≈øe flower in Aprill, except the la≈øt, which is a moneth later.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The French and Lowe-Countrey men call them Trompettes, that is, Trumpets, from the forme of the trunke; wee ≈øometimes call them al≈øo by that name, but more v≈øually ba≈øtard Iunquilia's.

div.head: P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus marinus albus, Pancratium vulgo. The white Sea ba≈øtard Daffodill.
div.p:
The Sea ba≈øtard Daffodill (to conclude this Chapter, and the di≈øcour≈øe of Daffodils)
1 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus tubo
‚Ä¢ ua≈øi ab≈øci≈ø≈øo. The ba≈øtard Daffodill with the clipt trunke. 2 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus minor. The le≈ø≈øer Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill. 3 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Hi≈øpanicus minimus. The lea≈øt Spani≈øh ba≈øtard Daffodill. 4 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Gallicus minor flore pleno. The le≈ø≈øer double French ba≈øtard Daffodi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 5 P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ atium flore albo. The white Sea ba≈øtard Daffodil. 6 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus maior. The greater yellow ba≈øtard ‚Ä¢ unquilia 7 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus minor. The le≈ø≈øer yellow ba≈øtard Iunquilia. 8 P≈øeudonarci≈ø≈øus Iuncifolius luteus ≈øerotinus. The late yellow ba≈øtard Iunquitis
‚Ä¢
Leucoium bulbo≈øum pracox maius. The great early bulbous Violet. ‚Ä† Leucoium bulbo≈øum praecox minus. The le≈ø≈øer early bulbous Violet. 10 Leucoium balbo≈øum autumnale. The ≈ømall Autumne bulbous Violet. 11 Leucoium bulbo≈øum maius ≈øerotinum. The great late flowring bulbous Violet. depiction of flowers
hath diuers broad whiti≈øh greene leaues, but not very long, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtiffe round ≈øtalke, at the top whereof breaketh out of a great round skinny huske, fiue or ≈øix flowers, euery one made ≈øomewhat of the fa≈øhion of the great ba≈øtard Ru≈øh Daffodill; but greater, and wholly white; the ≈øix leaues, being larger and longer then in the Ru≈øh kinde, and extending beyond the trunke, are tipt with greene at the point of each leafe, and downe the middle likewi≈øe on the back≈øide. The trunke is longer, larger, and wider open at the mouth, cut in or indented at the brims or edges, and ≈ømall at the bottome, with diuers white threeds in the middle, and is very ≈øweet: vnder the flower is a round greene head, which groweth very great, hauing within it, when it is ripe, flat and blacke ≈øeede: the roote is great and white.

Flore luteo, & flore
‚Ä¢ ubr ‚Ä¢ .It is reported, that there are found other ≈øorts; ≈øome that beare yellow flowers, and others that beate red: but we haue ≈øeene none ≈øuch, and therefore I can ≈øay no more of them.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This kinde groweth neare the Sea ≈øide, both in Spaine, Italy, and France, within the Straights, and for the mo≈øt part, vpon all the Leuant ≈øhoare and I≈ølands al≈øo, but will ≈øeldome either flower, or abide with vs in the≈øe colder Countries, as I haue both ≈øeene by tho≈øe that I receiued from a friend, and heard by others.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the end of Summer, that is, in Augu≈øt and September.

div.head: The Name.
div.p: Diuers doe call it Pancratium, as the learned of Mompeher, and others, with the addition of flore Lilij, after they had left their old errour, in taking it to be Scylla, and v≈øing it for Scylla, in the Trochi≈øces that go into Andromachus Treakle. The learned of Valentia in Spaine, as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, doe call it Hemerocallis, thinking it to be a Lilly; and Clu≈øius doth thereupon call it, Hemerocallis Valentina: but in my opinion, all the≈øe are deceiued in this plant; for it is neither a Lilly, to haue the name of Hemerocallis giuen vnto it, nor Scylla, nor Pancratium, as many doe yet call it: for certainly this is a kinde of Daffodill; the forme both of roote, leafe, and flower, doth a≈ø≈øure me that haue ≈øeene it, and not Pancratium, which (as Dio≈øcorides te≈øtifieth) is a kinde of Scylla, and in his time called Scylla, with a red roote, and a leafe like a Lilly, but longer, and was v≈øed both with the ≈øame preparation and quantity, and for the ≈øame di≈øea≈øes that Scylla was v≈øed, but that his force was weaker: all which doth plainly ≈øhew the errours that many learned men haue been conuer≈øant in, and that all may ≈øee how nece≈ø≈øary the knowledge of Herbari≈øme is to the practice of Phy≈øicke; And le≈øt the roote of this Sea ba≈øtard Daffodill bee v≈øed in the ≈øtead of an whol≈øome remedy, which (as Clu≈øius maketh mention) was deadly to him that did but cut his meate with that knife, which had immediately before cut this roote, and done in malice by him, that knew the force thereof, to kill his fellow, it working the more forceably by the euill attracting quality of the iron.

div.head: The Vertues.of Daffodils in generall.
div.p: How≈øoeuer Dio≈øcorides and others, doe giue vnto ≈øome of them ≈øpeciall properties, both for inward and outward di≈øea≈øes, yet know I not any in the≈øe dayes with vs, that apply any of them as a remedy for any griefe, what≈øoeuer Gerrard or others haue written.

div.head: Leucoium bulbo≈øum. The bulbous Violet.
div.p: HAuing thus ≈øet downe the whole family, both of the true and ba≈øtard Daffodils, I ≈øhould next ≈øet in hand with the Hyacinths; but becau≈øe Leucoium bulbo≈øum, The bulbous Violet is a plant that doth challenge a place next vnto the Daffodils; as mo≈øt nearly partaking with them, and a little with the Hyacinthes, I mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity interpo≈øe them, and ≈øhew their de≈øcriptions and differences, whereof ≈øome are early, of the fir≈øt Spring, others later, and ≈øome of the Autumne.

div.head: Leucoium bulbo≈øum praecox maius. The greater early bulbous Violet.
div.p: This bulbous Violet hath three or foure very greene, broad, flat, and ≈øhort leaues, among which ri≈øeth vp a naked greene ≈øtalke, bearing out of a ≈ømall skinny ho≈øe (as the former Daffodils doe) one white flower, hanging downe his head by a very ≈ømall foot-≈øtalke, made of ≈øix leaues, of an equall length, euery one whereof is tipt at the end with a ≈ømall greeni≈øh yellow ≈øpot: after the flower is pa≈øt, the head or ≈øeed-ve≈ø≈øell groweth to be rea≈øonable great, ≈øomewhat long and round, wherein is contained hard round ≈øeede, which being dry, is cleare, and of a whiti≈øh yellow colour: the roote is ≈øomewhat like a Daffodill roote, and couered with a blacki≈øh out≈øide or skinne.

div.head: Leucoium bulbo≈øum praecox minus. The le≈ø≈øer early bulbous Violet.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer kinde ri≈øeth vp with two narrow grayi≈øh greene leaues, between which commeth forth the ≈øtalke, fiue or ≈øix inches high, bearing one ≈ømall pendulous flower, con≈øi≈øting of three white leaues, which are ≈ømall and pointed, ≈øtanding on the out≈øide, and hauing three other ≈øhorter leaues, which ≈øeeme like a cup in the middle, being each of them round at the ends, and cut in the middle, making the forme of an heart, with a greene tippe or ≈øpot at the broad end or edge: the ≈øeede is whiti≈øh, inclo≈øed in long and round heads, like the former, but le≈ø≈øer: the roote is like a ≈ømall Daffodill, with a blacki≈øh gray coate, and quickly diuideth into many of-≈øets.

There is another of this kinde,Minus Byzantinum. that came among other bulbous rootes from Con≈øtantinople, and differeth in nothing from it, but that it is a little greater, both in root, leafe, and flower.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The two fir≈øt are found in many places of Germany, and Hungary. The third, as I ≈øaid, was brought from Con≈øtantinople.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The two le≈ø≈øer ≈øorts doe mo≈øt commonly flower in February, if the weather be any thing milde, or at the furthe≈øt in the beginning of March, but the fir≈øt is ≈øeldome in flower, before the other be well neare pa≈øt, or altogether.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Lobel and Dodonaeus call the le≈ø≈øer kinde Leucoium triphyllum, and Leuconarci≈ø≈øolirion triphyllum, of the three leaues in the flower. Some doe call it Viola bulbo≈øa alba. The fir≈øt or greater kinde is called by Lobel, Leuconarci≈ø≈øolirion paucioribus floribus; and by Dodonaeus, Leucoium bulbo≈øum hexaphyllum. We doe mo≈øt v≈øually call them, Leucoium bulbo≈øum praecox maius, & minus, The greater, or the le≈ø≈øer early bulbous Violet. In Dutch, Somer Sottekens, and not Drui≈økens, which are Grape-flowers, as ≈øome haue thought.

div.head: 1. Leucoium bulbo≈øum Vernum minimum. The ≈ømall bulbous Violet of the Spring.
div.p:
This ≈ømall Leucoium ≈øendeth forth his ≈ømall and long greene leaues, like haires in Autumne, and before Winter, which abide greene vntill Aprill, and then wither away quite, and about May there ari≈øeth vp a naked ≈ølender ≈øtalke, at the toppe whereof breake forth two ≈ømall white flowers, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, hanging downe their heads, the three inner leaues being a little larger then the three outward, a little
‚Ä¢ ed di≈øh neare the ≈øtalke, and very ≈øweet: the root is ≈ømall and round, and co ‚Ä¢ ered with a darke coate.

div.head: 2. Leucoium bulbo≈øum Autumn ‚Ä¢ le. The ≈ømall Autumne bulbous Violet.
div.p: As the former ≈ømall Leucoium ≈øprang vp with his leaues without flowers in Autumne, ≈øo this contrariwi≈øe, ri≈øeth vp with his ≈ølender browni≈øh ≈øtalke of flowers in Autumne, before any greene leaues appeare, whereon ≈øtand two or three very ≈ømall ≈ønow white pendulous flowers, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues a peece, and a little reddi≈øh at the bottome of the flower next vnto the ≈øtalke, ≈øo like vnto the former, that one would take them to be both one: after which, there grow ≈ømall browne heads, containing ≈ømall, blacke, round ≈øeed; after the flower is pa≈øt, and the ≈øeede is ripening, and ≈øometimes after the heads are ripe, the leaues begin to ≈øpring vp, which when they are full growne, are long, greene, and as ≈ømall, or ≈ømaller then the leaues of the Autumne Hyacinth, which abide all the Winter, and Spring following, and wither away in the beginning of Summer: the roote is ≈ømall, long, and white.

div.head: 3. Leucoium maius bulbo≈øum ≈øerotinum. The great late flowring bulbous Violet.
div.p: The late bulbous Violet hath three or foure broad flat greene leaues, very like vnto the fir≈øt, but longer, among which ri≈øeth vp a flatti≈øh ≈øtalke, being thicker in the middle then at both edges, on the toppe whereof ≈øtand three or foure flowers, hanging downe their heads, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues a peece, all of an equall length and bigne≈ø≈øe, wholly white, except that each leafe hath a greene tippe at the end of them: the ≈øeede hereof is blacke and round; the roote is rea≈øonable great and white.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The two former ≈ømall ones were fir≈øt found in Spaine, and Portugall, and ≈øent to me by Guillaume Boel; but the fir≈øt was ≈øo tender, that ≈øcarce one of a ≈øcore ≈øprang with me, or would abide. The greate≈øt haue beene found wilde in Germany and Au≈øtria.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The ≈ømall ones haue their times expre≈ø≈øed in their titles and de≈øcriptions, the la≈øt flowreth not vntill May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The≈øe names that are ≈øet downe in their titles, doe pa≈ø≈øe with all Herbari≈øts in the≈øe daies.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Wee haue not knowne the≈øe plants v≈øed Phy≈øically, either inwardly or outwardly, to any purpo≈øes in the≈øe dayes.

div.head: Hyacinthus. The Hyacinth or Iacinth.
div.p: THe Iacinths are next to be entreated of, whereof there are many more kindes found out in the≈øe later times, then formerly were knowne, which for order and method ≈øake, I will dige≈øt vnder ≈øeuerall ≈øorts, as neare as I can, that auoiding confu≈øion, by enterlacing one among another, I may the better put euery ≈øort vnder his owne kinde.

div.head: Hyacinthus Indicus maior tubero≈øa radice. The greater Indian knobbed Iacinth.
div.p: I haue thought fitte≈øt to begin with this Iacinth, both becau≈øe it is the greate≈øt and highe≈øt, and al≈øo becau≈øe the flowers hereof are in ≈øome likene≈ø≈øe neare vnto a Daffodill, although his roote be tuberous, and not bulbous as all the re≈øt are. This Indian Iacinth hath a thicke knobbed roote (yet formed into ≈øeuerall heads, ≈øomewhat like vnto bulbous rootes) with many thicke fibres at the bottome of them; from the diuers heads of this roote ari≈øe diuers ≈øtrong and very tall ≈øtalkes, be≈øet with diuers faire, long, and broad leaues, ioyned at the bottome clo≈øe vnto the ≈øtalke, where they are greate≈øt, and grow ≈ømaller to the very end, and tho≈øe that grow higher to the toppe, being ≈ømaller and ≈ømaller, which being broken, there appeare many threeds like wooll in them: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are garni≈øhed with many faire large white flowers, each whereof is compo≈øed of ≈øix leaues, lying ≈øpread open, as the flowers of the white Daffodill, with ≈øome ≈øhort threeds in the middle, and of a very ≈øweete ≈øent, or rather ≈øtrong and headie.

div.head: Hyacinthus Indicus minor tubero≈øa radice. The ≈ømaller Indian knobbed Iacinth.
div.p: The roote of this Iacinth is knobbed, like the roote of Arum or Wake Robin, from whence doe ≈øpring many leaues, lying vpon the ground, and compa≈ø≈øing one another at the bottome, being long and narrow, and hollow guttered to the end, which is ≈ømall and pointed, no le≈ø≈øe woolly, or full of threeds then the former: from the middle of the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, being very long and ≈ølender, three or foure foot long, ≈øo that without it be propped vp, it will bend downe, and lye vpon the ground, whereon are ≈øet at certaine di≈øtances many ≈øhort leaues, being broad at the bottome, where they doe almo≈øt compa≈ø≈øe the ≈øtalke, and are ≈ømaller toward the end where it is ≈øharpe pointed: at the top of the ≈øtalke ≈øtand many flowers, with a ≈ømall peece of a green leafe at the bottome of euery foot-≈øtalke, which ≈øeeme to bee like ≈øo many white Orientall Iacinths, being compo≈øed of ≈øix leaues, which are much thicker then the former, with ≈øix chiues or threeds in the middle, tipt with pale yellow pendents.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They both grow naturally in the We≈øt Indies, from whence being fir≈øt brought into Spaine, haue from thence been di≈øper≈øed vnto diuers louers of plants.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower not in the≈øe cold Countries vntill the middle of Augu≈øt, or not at all, if they bee not carefully pre≈øerued from the iniury of our cold Winters; and then if the precedent Summer be hot, it may be flower a moneth ≈øooner.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Clu≈øius calleth the le≈ø≈øer (for I thinke hee neuer ≈øaw the fir≈øt) Hyacinthus
Indicus tubero≈øa radice, that is in Engli≈øh, The Indian Iacinth with a tuberous roote: Some would call the≈øe Hyacinthus Eriophorus Indicus, that is, The Indian woolly Iacinth, becau≈øe they haue much wooll in them when they are broken; yet ≈øome doe doubt that they are not two plants ≈øeuerall, as of greater and le≈ø≈øer, but that the greatne≈ø≈øe is cau≈øed by the fertility of the ≈øoyle wherein it grew.

div.head: 1. Hyacinthus Botroides maior Mo≈øchatus, ≈øiue Mu≈øcari flore flauo. The great yellow Muske Grape-flower, or yellow Mu≈øcari.
div.p: This Muske Iacinth or Grape-flower, hath fiue or ≈øix leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground in two or three heads, which at the fir≈øt budding or ≈øhooting forth out of the ground, are of a reddi≈øh purple colour, and after become long, thicke, hollow, or guttered on the vpper≈øide, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, and round and darke coloured vnderneath: in the middle of the≈øe heads of leaues, ri≈øe vp one or two hollow weake browni≈øh ≈øtalkes, ≈øometimes lying on the ground with the weight of the flowers, (but e≈øpecially of the ≈øeede) yet for the mo≈øt part ≈øtanding vpright, when they are laden towards the toppe, with many bottle-like flowers, which at their fir≈øt appearing, and vntill the flowers begin to blow open, are of a browne red colour, and when they are blowne, of a faire yellow colour, flowring fir≈øt below, and ≈øo vpwards by degrees, euery one of the≈øe flowers is made like vnto a little pitcher or bottle, being bigge in the belly, and ≈ømall at the mouth, which is round, and a little turned vp, very ≈øweete in ≈ømell, like vnto Muske, whereof it tooke the name Mu≈øcari; after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come three ≈øquare thicke heads, puffed vp as if it were bladders, made of a ≈øpongie ≈øub≈øtance, wherein are here and there placed blacke round ≈øeed: the roote is long, round, and very thicke, and white on the out≈øide, with a little woolline≈ø≈øe on them, being broken, and full of a ≈ølimie iuice, whereunto are annexed thicke, fat, and long fibres, which peri≈øh not as mo≈øt of the other Iacinths; and therefore de≈øireth not to bee often remoued, as the other ≈øorts may.

div.head: 2. Hyacinthus Botroides maior Mo≈øchatus, ≈øeu Mu≈øcari flore cineritio. The A≈øhcoloured Muske Grape-flower, or Mu≈øcari.
div.p: This Mu≈øcari differeth not in rootes, or forme of leaues or flowers from the former, the chiefe differences are the≈øe: the leaues hereof do not appeare ≈øo red at the fir≈øt budding out of the ground, nor are ≈øo darke when they are fully growne; the ≈øtalke al≈øo mo≈øt v≈øually hath more ≈øtore of flowers thereon, the colour whereof at the fir≈øt budding is a little duskie, and when they are full blowne, are of a bleake, yet bright a≈øhcolour, with a little ≈øhew of purple in them, and by long ≈øtanding change a little more gray; being as ≈øweete, or as ≈øome thinke, more ≈øweete then the former: the roote (as I ≈øaid) is like the former, yet yeeldeth more encrea≈øe, and will better endure our cold clymate, although it doth more ≈øeldome giue ripe ≈øeede.

div.head: 3. Hyacinthus Botroides maior Mo≈øchatus, ≈øiue Mu≈øcari flore rubro. The red Muske Grape-flower.
div.p: This kinde (if there be any ≈øuch, for I am in ≈øome doubt thereof) doth chiefly differ in the colour of the flower from the fir≈øt, in that this ≈øhould beare flowers when they are blowne, of a red colour tending to yellowne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: 4. Hyacinthus Botroides maior Mo≈øchatus, ≈øiue Mu≈øcari flore albo. The white Muske Grape-flower.
div.p: This al≈øo is ≈øaid to haue (if there bee ≈øuch an one) his leaues like vnto the ≈øecond kinde, but of a little whiter greene, and the flowers pale, tending to a white: the roots of the≈øe two la≈øt are ≈øaid v≈øually not to grow to be ≈øo great as of the former two.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The rootes of the two fir≈øt ≈øorts, haue been often ≈øent from Con≈øtantinople,
1 Hyacinthus Indicus maior tubero≈øa radice. The greater Indian knobbed Iacinth. 2 Hyacinthus Indicus minor tubero≈øa radice. The le≈ø≈øer Indian knobbed Iacinth. 3 Mu≈øcari flore flauo. The yellow Mu≈øcari. 4 Mu≈øcari flore cineritio. The a≈øhcoloured Mu≈øcari. 5 Hyacinthus Botroides caruleus
‚Ä¢ nus. The skie coloured Grape-flower. 6. Hyacinthus Botroides flore albo. The white Grape flower. 7 Hyacinthus Botroides ramo≈øus. The branched Grape-flower. depiction of flowers
among many other ≈øorts of rootes, and it may be come thither from beyond the Bo≈øphorus in A≈øia; we haue them in our Gardens.

The other two ≈øorts are ≈øprung (it is probable, if they be in rerum natura) from the ≈øeede of the two former; for we could neuer get ≈øuch from Con≈øtantinople, as if the Turkes had neuer knowledge of any ≈øuch.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in March or Aprill, as the yeare is temperate, but the fir≈øt is ≈øoone≈øt vp out of the ground.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The two former haue beene ≈øent from Turkie by the name of Mu≈øchoromi and Dipcadi. Matthiolus calleth it Bulbus vomitorius, ≈øaying that no root doth more prouoke vomit then it. Ca≈øpar Bauhinus doth mo≈øt properly call it Hyacinthus Mo≈øchatus. It is mo≈øt generally called Mu≈øcari, by all Herbari≈øts and Flori≈øts, yet becau≈øe it doth ≈øo neerely re≈øemble the Grape-flower, I haue named it Hyacinthus Botroides maior Mu≈øchatus, to put a difference from the le≈ø≈øer Grape-flowers that follow; in Engli≈øh, The great Muske Grape-flower, or Mu≈øcari.

div.head: Hyacinthus Botroides minor caeruleus ob≈øcurus. The darke blew Grape-flower.
div.p: This Grape-flower hath many ≈ømall, fat, and weake leaues lying vpon the ground, which are ≈øomewhat browni≈øh at their fir≈øt comming vp, and of a ≈øad greene afterwards, hollow on the vpper≈øide, and round vnderneath, among which ri≈øe vp round, ≈ømooth, weake ≈øtalkes, bearing at the toppe many ≈ømall heauie bottle-like flowers, in ≈øhape like the former Mu≈øcari, but very thicke thru≈øt together, ≈ømaller, and of a very darke or blacki≈øh blew colour, of a very ≈øtrong ≈ømell, like vnto Starch when it is new made, and hot: the root is round, and blacki≈øh without, being compa≈ø≈øed with a number of ≈ømall rootes, or of-≈øets round about it, ≈øo that it will quickly choke a ground, if it be ≈øuffered long in it. For which cau≈øe, mo≈øt men doe ca≈øt it into ≈øome by corner, if they meane to pre≈øerue it, or ca≈øt it out of the Garden quite.
Alter maior.There is another of this kinde that is greater, both in leafe and flower, and differeth not in colour or any thing el≈øe.

div.head: Hyacinthus Botroides caeruleus amoenus. The skie coloured Grape-flower.
div.p: This Iacinth ≈øpringeth vp with fewer leaues then the fir≈øt, and not reddi≈øh, but green at his fir≈øt appearing; the leaues, when they are full growne, are long and hollow, like the former, but greener, ≈øhorter, and broader, ≈øtanding vpright, and not lying along vpon the ground as they doe: the flowers grow at the toppe of the ≈øtalke, more ≈øpar≈øedly ≈øet thereon, and not ≈øo thicke together, but like a thinne bunch of grapes, and bottle-like as the former, of a perfect blew or skie-colour, euery flower hauing ≈øome white ≈øpots about the brimmes of them: this hath a very ≈øweet ≈ømell, nothing like the former: this roote is whiter, and doth not ≈øo much encrea≈øe as the former, yet plentifull enough.

div.head: Hyacinthus Botroides ramo≈øus. The branched Grape-flower.
div.p: Of this kinde, there is another found to grow with many branches of flowers, breaking out from the ≈øides of the greater ≈øtalkes or branches: the leaues as all the re≈øt of the plant is greater then the former.

div.head: Hyacinthus Botroides flore albo. The white Grape-flower.
div.p:
The white Grape-flower hath his greene leaues a little whiter, then the blew or
skie coloured Grape-flower, his flowers are very pure white, alike ≈øpar≈øedly ≈øet on the ≈øtalkes, but a little lower and ≈ømaller then it, in all other things there is no difference.

div.head: Hyacinthus Botroides flore albo rubente. The blu≈øh Grape-flower.
div.p: The roote of this Grape-flower groweth greater, then either the skie coloured, or white Grape-flower, and ≈øeldome hath any ≈ømall rootes or of-≈øets, as the other haue: his leaues al≈øo are larger, and ≈øomewhat broader; the flowers are of a pale, or bleake blu≈øh colour out of a white, and are a little larger, and grow a little higher and fuller of flowers then the white.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They naturally grow in many places both of Germany and Hungary; in Spaine likewi≈øe, and on Mount Baldus in Italy, and Narbone in France, about the borders of the fields: we haue them in our Gardens for delight.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe flower from the beginning of March, or ≈øooner ≈øometimes, vntill the beginning of May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are mo≈øt commonly called Botroides, but more truely Botryodes, of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ the Greeke word, which ≈øignifieth a bunch or clu≈øter of grapes: Lobelius calleth the white one, Dipcadi flore albo, transferring the name Dipcadi, whereby the Mu≈øcari is called to this Iacinth, as if they were both one. Their ≈øeuerall names, whereby they are knowne and called, are ≈øet downe in their titles. The Dutchmen call them Driuekens, as I ≈øaid before. Some Engli≈øh Gentlewomen call the white Grape-flower Pearles of Spaine.

div.head: 1. Hyacinthus Como≈øus albus. The white haired Iacinth.
div.p: This Iacinth doth more neerly re≈øemble the Grape-flowers, then the faire haired Iacinths that follow, whereof it beareth the name, in that it hath no haire or threeds at the toppe of the ≈øtalke or ≈øides, as they: and therefore I haue placed it next vnto them, and the other to follow it, as being of another kinde. The root hereof is blacki≈øh, a little long and round, from whence ri≈øe vp three or foure leaues, being ≈ømooth and whiti≈øh, long, narrow, and hollow, like a trough or gutter on the vpper≈øide: among which the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a foote high or more, bearing at the toppe diuers ≈ømall flowers, ≈øomewhat like the former, but not ≈øo thicke ≈øet together, being a little longer, and larger, and wider at the mouth, and as it were diuided into ≈øix edges, of a darke whiti≈øh colour, with ≈øome blacker ≈øpots about the brimmes on the in≈øide: the heads or ≈øeede-ve≈ø≈øels are three ≈øquare, and ≈øomewhat larger, then the heads of any of the former le≈ø≈øer Grape-flowers, wherein is contained round blacke ≈øeede.

div.head: 2. Hyacinthus Como≈øus Byzantinus. The Turkie faire haired Iacinth.
div.p: This other Iacinth which came from Con≈øtantinople, is ≈øomewhat like the former, but that it is bigger, both in roote, and leafe, and flower, and bearing greater ≈øtore of flowers on the head of the ≈øtalke: the lower flowers, although they haue ≈øhort ≈øtalkes at their fir≈øt flowring, yet afterwards the ≈øtalkes grow longer, and tho≈øe that are lower, ≈øtand out further then tho≈øe that are highe≈øt, who≈øe foot-≈øtalkes are ≈øhort, and almo≈øt clo≈øe to the ≈øtemme, and of a more perfect purple then any below, which are of a duskie greeni≈øh purple colour: the whole ≈øtalke of flowers ≈øeem like a Pyramis, broad belowe, and ≈ømall aboue, or as other compare it, to a water ≈øprinkle; yet neither of both the≈øe Iacinths haue any threeds at the tops of the ≈øtalkes, as the other following haue.

div.head: 3. Hyacinthus Como≈øus maior purpureus. The great purple faire haired Iacinth.
div.p: This faire haired Iacinth hath his leaues ≈øofter, longer, broader, and le≈ø≈øe hollow then the former, lying for the mo≈øt part vpon the ground: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp in the mid≈øt of the leaues, being ≈øtronger, higher, and bearing a greater and longer head of flowers al≈øo then they: the flowers of this ≈øtand not vpon ≈øuch long foote-≈øtalkes, but are ≈øhorter below, and clo≈øe almo≈øt to the ≈øtalke aboue, hauing many bright purpli≈øh blew threeds, growing highe≈øt aboue the flowers, as it were in a bu≈øh together, euery one of the≈øe threeds hauing a little head at the end of them, ≈øomewhat like vnto one of the flowers, but much ≈ømaller: the re≈øt of the flowers below this bu≈øh, are of a ≈øadder or deader purple, and not ≈øo bright a colour, and the lowe≈øt wor≈øt of all, rather enclining to a greene, like vnto the la≈øt Turkie kinde: the whole ≈øtalke with the flowers vpon it, doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble a long Pur≈øe ta≈ø≈øell, and thereupon diuers Gentlewomen haue ≈øo named it: the heads and ≈øeede are like vnto the former, but greater: the roote is great and white, with ≈øome redne≈ø≈øe on the out≈øide.

div.head: 4. Hyacinthus Como≈øus ramo≈øus purpureus. The faire haired branched Iacinth.
div.p: The leaues of this Iacinth are broader, ≈øhorter, and greener then of the la≈øt, not lying ≈øo weakly on the ground, but ≈øtanding ≈øomewhat more vpright: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp as high as the former, but branched out on euery ≈øide into many tufts of threeds, with knappes, as it were heads of flowers, at the ends of them, like vnto the head of threeds at the toppe of the former Iacinth, but of a little darker, and not ≈øo faire a blewi≈øh purple colour: this Iacinth doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble the next Curld haire Iacinth, but that the branches are not ≈øo fairely compo≈øed altogether of curled threeds, nor of ≈øo excellent a faire purple or Doue colour, but more duskie by much: the roote is greater and ≈øhorter then of the next, and encrea≈øeth fa≈øter.

div.head: 5. Hyacinthus Pennatus, ≈øiue Como≈øus ramo≈øus elegantior. The faire Curld-haire Iacinth.
div.p: This admirable Iacinth ri≈øeth vp with three or foure leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of the Muske Grape-flower, but le≈ø≈øer; betweene which ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke about a foote high, or ≈øomewhat more, bearing at the toppe a bu≈øh or tuft of flowers, which at the fir≈øt appearing, is like vnto a Cone or Pineapple, and afterwards opening it ≈øelfe, ≈øpreadeth into many branches, yet ≈øtill retaining the forme of a Pyramis, being broad ≈øpread below, and narrow vp aboue: each of the≈øe branches is againe diuided into many tufts of threeds or ≈øtrings, twi≈øted or curled at the ends, and of an excellent purple or Doue colour, both ≈øtalkes and haires. This abideth a great while in his beauty, but afterwards all the≈øe flowers (if you will ≈øo call them) do fall away without any ≈øeede at all, ≈øpending it ≈øelfe as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme in the aboundance of the flowers: the roote is not ≈øo great as the la≈øt, but white on the out≈øide.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The two fir≈øt haue been ≈øent diuers times from Con≈øtantinople, the third is found wilde in many places of Europe, and as well in Germany, as in Italy. The two la≈øt are onely with vs in Gardens, and their naturall places are not knowne vnto vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The three former kindes doe flower in Aprill, the two la≈øt in May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt and ≈øecond haue no other names then are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles.
1 Hyacinthus Como≈øus albus. The white haired Iacinth. 2 Hyacinthus Como≈øus Byzantinus. The Turkie faire haired Iacinth. 3 Hyacinthus Como≈øus maior purpureus. The purple faire haired Iacinth, or Pur≈øe ta≈ø≈øels. 4 Hyacinthus Como≈øus ramo≈øus, ≈øiue Calami≈øtratus. The faire haired branched Iacinth. 5 Hyacinthus Pennatus, ≈øiue Como≈øus elegantior. The faire curld haire Iacinth. depiction of flowers
The third is called of ≈øome onely Hyacinthus maior, and of others Hyacinthus como≈øus maior: We call it in Engli≈øh, The purple faire haired Iacinth, becau≈øe of his tuft of purple threeds, like haires at the toppe, and (as I ≈øaid) of diuers Gentlewomen, purple ta≈ø≈øels. The fourth is called by ≈øome as it is in the title, Hyacinthus como≈øus ramo≈øus, and of others Hyacinthus Calami≈øtratus. And the la≈øt or fifth is diuer≈øly called by diuers, Fabius Columna in his Phytoba≈øanos the ≈øecond part, calleth it Hyacinthus Sanne≈øius, becau≈øe hee fir≈øt ≈øaw it in that Cardinals Garden at Rome. Robin of Paris ≈øent to vs the former of the two la≈øt, by the name of Hyacinthus Pennatus, and Hyacinthus Calami≈øtratus, when as others ≈øent the la≈øt by the name Pennatus, and the other by the name of Calami≈øtratus; but I thinke the name Cincinnatus is more fit and proper for it, in that the curled threeds which ≈øeeme like haires, are better expre≈ø≈øed by the word Cincinnus, then Calamistrum, this ≈øignifying but the bodkin or in≈øtrument wherewith they v≈øe to fri≈øle or curle the haire, and that the bu≈øh of haire it ≈øelfe being curled. Some al≈øo haue giuen to both the≈øe la≈øt the names of Hyacinthus Como≈øus Parna≈øsi, the one fairer then the other. Of all the≈øe names you may v≈øe which you plea≈øe; but for the la≈øt kinde, the name Cincinnatus, as I ≈øaid, is the more proper, but Pennatus is the more common, and Calami≈øtratus for the former of the two la≈øt.

div.head: 1. Hyacinthus Orientalis Brumalis, ≈øiue praecox flore albo. The white Winter Orientall Iacinth.
div.p: This early Iacinth ri≈øeth vp with his greene leaues (which are in all re≈øpects like to the ordinary Orientall Iacinths, but ≈øomewhat narrower) before Winter, and ≈øometimes it is in flower al≈øo before Winter, and is in forme and colour a plaine white Orientall Iacinth, but ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer, differing onely in no other thing, then the time of his flowring, which is alwayes certaine to be long before the other ≈øorts.

div.head: 2. Hyacinthus Orientalis Brumalis, ≈øiue praecox flore purpureo. The purple Winter Orientall Iacinth.
div.p: The difference of colour in this flower cau≈øeth it to bee di≈øtingui≈øhed, for el≈øe it is of the kindred of the Orientall Iacinths, and is, as the former, more early then the re≈øt that follow: Vnder≈øtand then, that this is the ≈øame with the former, but hauing fine blewi≈øh purple flowers.

div.head: 3. Hyacinthus Orientalis maior praecox, dictus Zumbul Indi. The greate≈øt Orientall Iacinth, or Zumbul Indi.
div.p: The roote of this Orientall Iacinth, is v≈øually greater then any other of his kinde, and mo≈øt commonly white on the out≈øide, from whence ri≈øe vp one or two great round ≈øtalkes, ≈øpotted from within the ground, with the lower part of the leaues al≈øo vpward to the middle of the ≈øtalkes, or rather higher, like vnto the ≈øtalkes of Dragons, but darker; being ≈øet among a number of broad, long, and ≈øomewhat hollow greene leaues, almo≈øt as large as the leaues of the white Lilly: at the toppe of the ≈øtalkes ≈øtand more ≈øtore of flowers, then in any other of this kinde, euery flower being as great as the greate≈øt ≈øort of Orientall Iacinths, ending in ≈øix leaues, which turne at the points, of a faire blewi≈øh purple colour, and all ≈øtanding many times on one ≈øide of the ≈øtalkes, and many times on both ≈øides.

div.head: 4. Hyacinthus Orientalis vulgaris diuer≈øorum colorum. The ordinary Orientall Iacinth.
div.p:
The common Orientall Iacinth (I call it common, becau≈øe it is now ≈øo plentifull in all Gardens, that it is almo≈øt not e≈øteemed) hath many greene leaues, long, ≈øomewhat broad and hollow, among which ri≈øeth vp a long greene round ≈øtalke, be≈øet from the middle thereof almo≈øt, with diuers flowers, ≈øtanding on both ≈øides
of the ≈øtalkes, one aboue another vnto the toppe, each whereof next vnto the foote-≈øtalke is long, hollow, round, and clo≈øe, ending in ≈øix ≈ømall leaues laid open, and a little turning at the points, of a very ≈øweete ≈ømell: the colours of the≈øe flowers are diuers, for ≈øome are pure white, without any ≈øhew of other colour in them: another is almo≈øt white, but hauing a ≈øhew of blewne≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially at the brims and bottomes of the flowers. Others againe are of a very faint blu≈øh, tending towards a white: Some are of as deepe a purple as a Violet; others of a purple tending to redne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øome of a paler purple. Some againe are of a faire blew, others more watchet, and ≈øome ≈øo pale a blew, as if it were more white then blew: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there ri≈øe vp great three ≈øquare heads, bearing round blacke ≈øeede, great and ≈øhining: the roote is great, and white on the out≈øide, and oftentimes purpli≈øh al≈øo, flat at the bottome, and ≈ømall at the head.

There is a kinde of the≈øe Iacinths,Flore purpuro violaceo lineis albicantis in dor≈øo. Floribus antror≈øum re≈øpicientibus. Serotinus erectis floribus diuer≈øorum colorum. who≈øe flowers are of a deepe purpli≈øh Violet colour, hauing whiti≈øh lines downe the backe of euery leafe of the flower, which turne them≈øelues a little backwards at the points.
There is another, who≈øe flowers ≈øtand all opening one way, and not on all ≈øides, but are herein like the great Zumbul Indi, before ≈øet out.
There is againe another kinde which flowreth later then all the re≈øt, and the flowers are ≈ømaller, ≈øtanding more vpright, which are either white or blew, or mixt with white and purple.

div.head: 5. Hyacinthus Orientalis folio≈øo caule. The bu≈øhy ≈øtalked Orientall Iacinth.
div.p: This ≈øtrange Iacinth hath his rootes, leaues, and flowers, like vnto the former Orientall Iacinths: the onely difference in this is, that his ≈øtalke is not bare or naked, but hath very narrow long leaues, growing di≈øper≈øedly, and without order, with the flowers thereon, which are blew, and hauing for the mo≈øt part one leafe, and ≈øometimes two at the foote, or ≈øetting on of euery flower, yet ≈øometimes it happeneth, ≈øome flowers to be without any leafe at the bottome, as nature, that is very variable in this plant, li≈øteth to play: the heads and ≈øeede are blacke and round, like the other al≈øo.

div.head: 6. Hyacinthus Orientalis flore duplici. The bleake Orientall Iacinth once double.
div.p: This double Iacinth hath diuers long leaues, like vnto the other Orientall Iacinths, almo≈øt ≈øtanding vpright, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, browni≈øh at the fir≈øt, but growing greene afterwards, bearing many flowers at the toppe, made like the flowers of the former Iacinths, and ending in ≈øix leaues, greene at the fir≈øt, and of a blewi≈øh white when they are open, yet retaining ≈øome ≈øhew of greenne≈ø≈øe in them, the brims of the leaues being white; from the middle of each flower ≈øtandeth forth another ≈ømall flower, con≈øi≈øting of three leaues, of the ≈øame colour with the other flower, but with a greene line on the backe of each of the≈øe inner leaues: in the middle of this little flower, there ≈øtand ≈øome threeds tipt with blacke: the ≈ømell of this flower is not ≈øo ≈øweete as of the forme; the heads, ≈øeede, and rootes are like the former.

div.head: 7. Hyacinthus Orientalis flore pleno caeruleo, vel purpuro vi ‚Ä¢ laceo. The faire double blew, or purple Orientall Iacinth.
div.p: The leaues of the≈øe Iacinths are ≈ømaller, then the leaues of mo≈øt of the other former ≈øorts; the ≈øtalkes are ≈øhorter, and ≈ømaller, bearing but three or foure flowers on the heads of them for the mo≈øt part, which are not compo≈øed like the la≈øt, but are more faire, full, and double of leaues, where they ≈øhew out their full beauties, and of a faire blew colour in ≈øome, and purple in others, ≈ømelling pretty ≈øweete; but the≈øe doe ≈øeldome beare out their flowers faire; and be≈øides, haue diuers other flowers that will be either ≈øingle, or very little double vpon the ≈øame ≈øtalke.

div.head: 8. Hyacinthus Orientalis candidi≈øsimus flore pleno. The pure white double Orientall Iacinth.
div.p:
This double white Iacinth hath his leaues like vnto the ≈øingle white Orientall Iacinth;
his ≈øtalke is likewi≈øe long, ≈ølender, and greene, bearing at the toppe two or three flowers at the mo≈øt, very double and full of leaues, of a pure white colour, without any other mixture therein, hanging downe their heads a little, and are rea≈øonable ≈øweete. I haue this but by relation, not by ≈øight, and therefore I can giue no further a≈ø≈øurance as yet.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Orientall Iacinths, except the la≈øt, haue beene brought out of Turkie, and from Con≈øtantinople: but where their true originall place is, is not as yet vnder≈øtood.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The two fir≈øt (as is ≈øaid) flower the earlie≈øt, ≈øometimes before Chri≈øtmas, but more v≈øually after, and abide a great while in flower, in great beauty, e≈øpecially if the weather be milde, when as few or no other flowers at that time are able to match them. The other greate≈øt kinde flowreth al≈øo earlier then the re≈øt that follow, for the mo≈øt part. The ordinary kindes flower ≈øome in March, and ≈øome in Aprill, and ≈øome ≈øooner al≈øo; and ≈øo doe the double ones likewi≈øe. The bu≈øhy ≈øtalked Iacinth flowreth much about the ≈øame time.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The former two ≈øorts are called Hyacinthus Orientalis Brumalis, and Hyacinthus Orientalis praecox flore albo, or caeruleo. The third is called of many Zumbul Indicum, or Zumbul Indi, and corruptly Simboline; of others, and that more properly, Hyacinthus Orientalis maior praecox. The Turkes doe call all Iacinths Zumbul, and by adding the name of Indi, or Arabi, do ≈øhew from what place they are receiued. In Engli≈øh, The greate≈øt Orientall Iacinth; yet ≈øome doe call it after the Turki≈øh name Zumbul Indi, or Simboline, as is ≈øaid before. The re≈øt haue their names ≈øet downe in their titles, which are mo≈øt fit for them.

div.head: Hyacinthus Hi≈øpanicus minor Orientalis facie. The little Summer Orientall Iacinth.
div.p: This little Iacinth hath foure or fiue long narrow greene leaues, lying vpon the ground, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈ølender ≈ømooth ≈øtalke, about a ≈øpanne high or more, bearing at the toppe many ≈ølender bleake blew flowers,Flore caeruleo. with ≈øome white ≈øtripes and edges to be ≈øeene in mo≈øt of them, fa≈øhioned very like vnto the flowers of the Orientall Iacinth, but much ≈ømaller: the flower hath no ≈øent at all; the ≈øeede is like the ≈øeede of the Engli≈øh Iacinth, or Hare≈ø-bels: the roote is ≈ømall and white.
Flore albo.There is another of this kinde, differing in nothing but in the colour of the flower, which is pure white.

Flore rubente.There is al≈øo another, who≈øe flowers are of a fine delayed red colour, with ≈øome deeper coloured veines, running along the three outer leaues of the flower, differing in no other thing from the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe plants haue been gathered on the Pyrenaean Mountaines, which are next vnto Spaine, from whence, as is often ≈øaid, many rare plants haue likewi≈øe been gathered.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower very late, euen after all or mo≈øt of the Iacinths, in May for the mo≈øt part.

figure.head: 1 Hyacinthus Orientalis brumalis. The Winter Orientall Iacinth. 2 Zumbul Indi. The greate≈øt Orientall Iacinth. 3 Hyacinthus Orientalis vulgaris. The ordinary Orientall Iacinth. 4 Hyacinthus Orientalis folio≈øo caule. The bu≈øhy ≈øtalked Orientall Iacinth. 5 Hyacinthus Orientalis flore dupli ‚Ä¢ j. The Orientall Iacinth once double. 6 Hyacinthus Orientalis flore pleno caeruleo. The faire double blew Orientall Iacinth.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called eyther Hyacinthus Hi≈øpanicus minor Orientalis facie, as it is in the title, or Hyacinthus Orientalis facie, that is to ≈øay, The le≈ø≈øer Spani≈øh Iacinth, like vnto the Orientall: yet ≈øome haue called them, Hyacinthus Orientalis ≈øerotinus minor, The le≈ø≈øer late Orientall Iacinth, that thereby they may be knowne from the re≈øt.

div.head: Hyacinthus Hi≈øpanicus ob≈øoletus. The Spani≈øh dunne coloured Iacinth.
div.p: This Spani≈øh Iacinth ≈øpringeth very late out of the ground, bearing foure or fiue ≈øhort, hollow, and ≈øoft whiti≈øh greene leaues, with a white line in the middle of euery one of them, among which ri≈øe vp one or more ≈øtalkes, bearing diuers flowers at the toppes of them, all looking one way, or ≈øtanding on the one ≈øide, hanging downe their heads, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues, three whereof being the outermo≈øt, lay open their leaues, and turne back the ends a little again: the other three which are innermo≈øt, do as it were clo≈øe together in the middle of the flower, without laying them≈øelues open at all, being a little whiti≈øh at the edges: the whole flower is of a purpli≈øh yellow colour, with ≈øome white and green as it were mixed among it, of no ≈øent at all: it beareth blacke and flat ≈øeede in three ≈øquare, great, and bunched out heads: the roote is rea≈øonable great, and white on the out≈øide, with many ≈øtrong white fibres at it, which peri≈øh not yearely, as the fibres of many other Iacinths doe, and as it ≈øpringeth late, ≈øo it holdeth his greene leaues almo≈øt vntill Winter.
