Mauritanicus.There hath been another hereof brought from about Fez and Marocco in Barbary, which in all re≈øpects was greater, but el≈øe differed little.

Maximus Aethiopicus.There was another al≈øo brought from the Cape of good Hope, who≈øe leaues were ≈øtronger and greener then the former, the ≈øtalke al≈øo thicker, bearing diuers flowers, confu≈øedly ≈øtanding vpon longer foote-≈øtalkes, yet made after the ≈øame fa≈øhion, but that the three inner leaues were whiti≈øh, and dented about the edges, otherwi≈øe the flowers were yellow and greeni≈øh on the in≈øide.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe plants grow in Spaine, Barbary, and Ethiopia, according as their names and de≈øcriptions doe declare.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth not vntill Iune; for, as I ≈øaid, it is very late before it ≈øpringeth vp out of the ground, and holdeth his leaues as is ≈øaid, vntill September, in the meane time the ≈øeede thereof ripeneth.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue their names according to the place of their growing; for one is called Hyacinthus Hi≈øpanicus ob≈øoletioris coloris. The other is called al≈øo Hyacinthus Mauritanicus. And the la≈øt, Hyacinthus Aethiopicus ob≈øoletus. In Engli≈øh, The Spani≈øh, Barbary, or Ethiopian Iacinth, of a dunne or duskie colour.

div.head: Hyacinthus Anglicus Belgicus, vel Hi≈øpanicus. Engli≈øh Hare≈ø-bels, or Spani≈øh Iacinth.
div.p:
Our Engli≈øh Iacinth or Hare≈ø-bels is ≈øo common euery where, that it ≈øcarce needeth any de≈øcription. It beareth diuers long and narrow greene leaues, not ≈øtanding vpright, nor yet fully lying vpon the ground; among which ≈øpringeth vp the ≈øtalke, bearing at the toppe many long and hollow flowers, hanging downe their heads all
forwards for the mo≈øt part, parted at the brimmes into ≈øix parts, turning vp their points a little againe, of a ≈øweeti≈øh, but heady ≈øent, ≈øomewhat like vnto the Grape-flower: the heads for ≈øeede are long and ≈øquare, wherein is much blacke ≈øeede: the colour of the flowers are in ≈øome of a deeper blew, tending to a purple; in others of a paler blew, or of a bleake blew, tending to an a≈øh colour: Some are pure white, and ≈øome are party coloured, blew and white; and ≈øome are of a fine delayed purpli≈øh red or blu≈øh colour, which ≈øome call a peach colour. The rootes of all ≈øorts agree, and are alike, being white and very ≈ølimie; ≈øome whereof will be great and round, others long and ≈ølender, and tho≈øe that lye neare the toppe of the earth bare, will be greene.

div.head: Hyacinthus Hi≈øpanicus maior flore campanulae instar. The greater Spani≈øh bell-flowred Iacinth.
div.p: This Spani≈øh bell-flowred Iacinth, is very like the former Engli≈øh or Spani≈øh Iacinth, but greater in all parts, as well of leaues as flowers, many growing together at the toppe of the ≈øtalke, with many ≈øhort greene leaues among them, hanging downe their heads, with larger, greater, and wider open mouths, like vnto bels, of a darke blew colour, and no good ≈øent.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in many places of England, the Lowe-Countries, as we call them, and Spaine, but the la≈øt chiefly in Spaine.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Aprill for the mo≈øt part, and ≈øometimes in May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Becau≈øe the fir≈øt is more frequent in England, then in Spain, or the Lowe-Countries, it is called with vs Hyacinthus Anglicus, The Engli≈øh Iacinth; but it is al≈øo called as well Belgicus, as Hi≈øpanicus: yet Dodonaeus calleth it Hyacinthus non ≈øcriptus, becau≈øe it was not written of by any Authour before him≈øelfe. It is generally knowne in England by the name of Hare-bels. The other Spani≈øh Iacinth beareth his name in his title.

div.head: Hyacinthus Eriophorus. The Woolly Iacinth.
div.p: This Woolly Iacinth hath many broad, long, and faire greene leaues, very like vnto ≈øome of the Iacinths, but ≈øtiffer, or ≈øtanding more vpright, which being broken, doe yeeld many threeds, as if a little fine cotton wooll were drawne out: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a long greene round ≈øtalke, a foote and a halfe high or more, whereon is ≈øet a great long bu≈øh of flowers, which blowing open by degrees, fir≈øt below, and ≈øo vpwards, are very long in flowring: the toppe of the ≈øtalke, with the flowers, and their little foot≈øtalkes, are all blew, euery flower ≈øtanding outright with his ≈øtalke, and ≈øpreading like a ≈øtarre, diuided into ≈øix leaues, hauing many ≈ømall blew threeds, ≈øtanding about the middle head, which neuer gaue ripe ≈øeede, as farre as I can heare of: the root is white, ≈øomewhat like the root of a Mu≈øcari, but as full of wooll or threeds, or rather more, then the leaues, or any other part of it.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This hath been ≈øent diuers times out of Turkie into England, where it continued a long time as well in my Garden as in others, but ≈øome hard fro≈øty Winters cau≈øed it to peri≈øh with me, and diuers others, yet I haue had it againe from a friend, and doth abide fre≈øh and greene euery yeare in my Garden.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: This flowred in the Garden of Mr. Richard Barne≈øley at Lambeth, onely once in the moneth of May, in the yeare 1606. after hee had there pre≈øerued it a long time: but neither he, nor any el≈øe in England that I know, but tho≈øe that ≈øaw it at that time, euer ≈øaw it beare flower, either before or ≈øince.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called by diuers Bulbus Eriophorus, or Laniferus, that is, Woolly Bulbous; but becau≈øe it is a Iacinth, both in roote, leafe, and flower, and not a Narci≈ø≈øus, or Daffodill, it is called Hyacinthus Eriophorus, or Laniferus, The Woolly Iacinth. It is very likely, that Theophra≈øtus in his ≈øeuenth Book & thirteenth Chapter, did meane this plant, where hee declareth, that garments were made of the woolly ≈øub≈øtance of a bulbous roote, that was taken from between the core or heart of the roote (which, as hee ≈øaith, was v≈øed to be eaten) and the outermo≈øt ≈øhels or peelings; yet Clu≈øius ≈øeemeth to fa≈øten this woolly bulbous of Theophra≈øtus, vpon the next Iacinth of Spaine.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Baeticus maior, vulg√≤ Per√ªanus. The great Spani≈øh Starry Iacinth, or of Peru.
div.p: This Iacinth (the greate≈øt of tho≈øe, who≈øe flowers are ≈øpread like a ≈øtarre, except the two fir≈øt Indians) hath fiue or ≈øix, or more, very broad, and long greene leaues, ≈øpread vpon the ground, round about the roote, which being broken are woolly, or full of threeds, like the former: in the middle of the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øhort ≈øtalke, in compari≈øon of the greatne≈ø≈øe of the plant (for the ≈øtalke of the Orientall Iacinth is ≈øometimes twice ≈øo high, who≈øe roote is not ≈øo great) bearing at the toppe a great head or bu≈øh of flowers, fa≈øhioned in the beginning, before they bee blowne or ≈øeparated, very like to a Cone or Pineapple, and begin to flower belowe, and ≈øo vpwards by degrees, euery flower ≈øtanding vpon a long blacki≈øh blew foote-≈øtalke, which when they are blowne open, are of a perfect blew colour, tending to a Violet, and made of ≈øix ≈ømall leaues, laid open like a ≈øtarre; the threeds likewi≈øe are blewi≈øh, tipt with yellow pendents, ≈øtanding about the middle head, which is of a deeper blew, not hauing any good ≈øent to be perceiued in it, but commendable only for the beauty of the flowers: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come three ≈øquare heads, containing round blacke ≈øeede: the roote is great, and ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh on the out≈øide, with a knobbe or bunch at the lower end of the roote, (which is called the ≈øeate of the roote) like vnto the Mu≈øcari, Scylla, and many other bulbous rootes, at which hang diuers white, thicke, and long fibres, whereby it is fa≈øtened in the ground, which peri≈øh not euery yeare, but abide continually, and therefore doth not de≈øire much remouing.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Baticus, ≈øiue Per√ªanus flore albo. The great white Spani≈øh ≈øtarry Iacinth.
div.p: This other Spani≈øh Iacinth is in mo≈øt parts like vnto the former, but that his leaues are not ≈øo large, nor ≈øo deep a greene: the ≈øtalks of flowers likewi≈øe hath not ≈øo thicke a head, or bu≈øh on it, but fewer and thinner ≈øet: the flowers them≈øelues al≈øo are whiti≈øh, yet hauing a ≈ømall da≈øh of blu≈øh in them: the threeds are whiti≈øh, tipt with yellow pendents: the ≈øeede and rootes are like vnto the former, and herein con≈øi≈øteth the difference betweene this and the other ≈øorts.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Baticus, ≈øiue Per√ªanus flore carneo. The great blu≈øh coloured Spani≈øh Starry Iacinth.
div.p:
This likewi≈øe differeth little from the two former, but onely in the colour of the
1 Hyacinthus Orientalis facie. The little Summer Orientall Iacinth. 2 Hyacinthus Mauritanicus. The Barbary Iacinth. 3 Hyacinthus ob≈øoletus Hi≈øpanicus. The Spani≈øh duskie Iacinth. 4 Hyacinthus Hi≈øpanicus flore campanulae. The greater Spani≈øh bel-flowred Iacinth. 5 Hyacinthus Anglicus. The Engli≈øh Iacinth or Harebels. 6 Hyacinthus Eriophorus. The Woolly Iacinth. 7 Hyacinthus Stellaris Baticus maior, fine Peruanus. The great Spani≈øh Starry Iacinth, or of Peru. depiction of flowers
flowers; for this being found growing among both the other, hath his head of flowers as great and large as the fir≈øt, but the buds of his flowers, before they are open, are of a deepe blu≈øh colour, which being open, are more delayed, and of a plea≈øant pale purple, or blu≈øh colour, ≈øtanding vpon purpli≈øh ≈øtalkes: the heads in the middle are whiti≈øh, and ≈øo are the threeds compa≈ø≈øing it, tipt with yellow.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe doe naturally grow in Spaine, in the Medowes a little off from the Sea, as well in the I≈øland Gades, v≈øually called Cales, as likewi≈øe in other parts along the Sea ≈øide, as one goeth from thence to Porto Santa Maria, which when they be in flower, growing ≈øo thicke together, ≈øeeme to couer the ground, like vnto a tapi≈øtry of diuers colours, as I haue beene credibly enformed by Guillaume Boel, a Freeze-lander borne, often before and hereafter remembred, who being in ≈øearch of rare plants in Spaine, in the yeare of our Lord 1607. after that mo≈øt violent fro≈øty Winter, which peri≈øhed both the rootes of this, and many other fine plants with vs, ≈øent mee ouer ≈øome of the≈øe rootes for my Garden, and affirmed this for a truth, which is here formerly ≈øet downe, and that him≈øelfe gathered tho≈øe he ≈øent mee, and many others in the places named, with his owne hands; but hee ≈øaith, that both that with the white, and with the blu≈øh flowers, are farre more rare then the other.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in May, the ≈øeede is ripe in Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: This hath beene formerly named Eriophorus Peruanus, and Hyacinthus Stellatus Peruanus, The Starry Iacinth of Peru, being thought to haue grown in Peru, a Prouince of the We≈øt Indies; but he that gaue that name fir≈øt vnto it, eyther knew not his naturall place, or willingly impo≈øed that name, to conceale it, or to make it the better e≈øteemed. It is mo≈øt generally receiued by the name Hyacinthus Peruanus, from the fir≈øt impo≈øer thereof, that is, the Iacinth of Peru: but I had rather giue the name agreeing mo≈øt fitly vnto it, and call it as it is indeede Hyacinthus Stellatus Baeticus, The Spani≈øh Starry Iacinth; and becau≈øe it is the greate≈øt that I know hath come from thence, I call it, The great Starry Iacinth of Spaine, or Spani≈øh Iacinth.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus vulgaris, ≈øiue Bifolius Fuch≈øij. The common blew Starry Iacinth.
div.p: This Starry Iacinth (being longe≈øt knowne, and therefore mo≈øt common) ri≈øeth out of the ground, v≈øually but with two browne leaues, yet ≈øometimes with three, inclo≈øing within them the ≈øtalke of flowers, the buds appearing of a darke whiti≈øh colour, as ≈øoone as the leaues open them≈øelues, which leaues being growne, are long, and hollow, of a whiti≈øh greene on the vpper ≈øide, and browne on the vnder ≈øide, and halfe round, the browne ≈øtalke ri≈øing vp higher, beareth fiue or ≈øixe ≈ømall ≈øtarre-like flowers thereon, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues, of a faire deepe blew, tending to a purple. The ≈øeede is yellowi≈øh, and round, contained in round pointed heads, which by rea≈øon of their heauine≈ø≈øe, and the weakne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtalke, lye vpon the ground, and often peri≈øh with wet and fro≈øts, &c. The roote is ≈øomewhat long, and couered with a yellowi≈øh coate.

div.head: Hyacinthus ≈øtellatus flore albo. The white Starry Iacinth.
div.p: The white Starry Iacinth hath his leaues like the former, but greene and fre≈øh, not browne, and a little narrower al≈øo: the buddes for flowers at the fir≈øt appeare a little blu≈øh, which when they are blowne, are white, but yet retaine in them a ≈ømall ≈øhew of that blu≈øh colour.
We haue another, who≈øe flowers are pure white, and ≈ømaller then the other,Flore niueo. the leaues whereof are of a pale fre≈øh greene, and ≈øomewhat narrower.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus flore rubente. The blu≈øh coloured Starry Iacinth.
div.p: The difference in this from the former, is onely in the flowers, which are of a faire blu≈øh colour, much more eminent then in the others, in all things el≈øe alike.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Martius, ≈øiue praecox caeruleus. The early blew Starry Iacinth.
div.p: This Iacinth hath his leaues a little broader, of a fre≈øher greene, and not browne at all, as the fir≈øt blew Iacinth of Fuch≈øius la≈øt remembred: the buds of the flowers, while they are enclo≈øed within the leaues, and after, when the ≈øtalke is gowne vp, doe remaine more blew then the buds of the former: the flowers, when they are blowne open, are like the former, but ≈øomewhat larger, and of a more liuely blew colour: the roote al≈øo is a little whiter on the out≈øide. This doth more ≈øeldome beare ≈øeede then the former.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus praecox flore albo. The white early Starry Iacinth.
div.p: There is al≈øo one other of this kinde, that beareth pure white flowers, the green leafe thereof being a little narrower then the former, and no other difference.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus praecox flore ≈øuaue rubente. The early blu≈øh coloured Starry Iacinth.
div.p: This blu≈øh coloured Iacinth is very rare, but very plea≈øant, his flowers being as large as the fir≈øt of this la≈øt kinde, and ≈øomewhat larger then the blu≈øh of the other kinde: the leaues and rootes differ not from the la≈øt recited Iacinth.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Iacinths haue beene found in the Woods and Mountaines of Germany, Bohemia, and Au≈øtria, as Fuch≈øius and Ge≈øner doe report, and in Naples, as Imperatus and others doe te≈øtifie. Wee cheri≈øh them all with great care in our Gardens, but e≈øpecially the white and the blu≈øh of both kindes, for that they are more tender, and often peri≈øh for want of due regard.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The common kindes, which are fir≈øt expre≈ø≈øed, flower about the middle of February, if the weather bee milde, and the other kindes ≈øometimes a fortnight after, that is, in March, but ordinarily much about the ≈øame time with the former.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called in Latine Hyacinthus Stellatus vulgaris, and Hyacinthus Stellatus bifolius, and Hyacinthus Stellaris Fuch≈øij, and of ≈øome Hyacinthus Stellatus Germanicus; wee might very well call the other kinde, Hyacinthus Stellatus vulgaris alter, but diuers call it Praecox, and ≈øome Martius, as it is in the title. In Engli≈øh they may bee ≈øeuerally called: the fir≈øt, The common; and the other, The early Starry Iacinth (notwith≈øtanding the fir≈øt flowreth before the other) for di≈øtinction ≈øake.

The Hyacinthus ≈øeemeth to be called Vacinium of Virgil in his Eclogues; for hee alwayes reckoneth it among the flowers that were v≈øed to decke Garlands, and neuer among fruits, as ≈øome would haue it. But in that hee calleth it Vacinium nigrum, in ≈øeuerall places, that doth very fitly an≈øwer the
common receiued cu≈øtome of tho≈øe times, that called all deepe blew colours, ≈øuch as are purples, and the like, blacke; for the Violet it ≈øelfe is likewi≈øe called blacke in the ≈øame place, where he calleth the Vacinium blacke; ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth thereby, that he reckoned them to be both of one colour, and we know the colour of the Violet is not blacke, as we doe di≈øtingui≈øh of blacke in the≈øe dayes. But the colour of this Starry Iacinth, being both of ≈øo deepe a purple ≈øometimes, ≈øo neare vnto a violet colour, and al≈øo more frequent, then any other Iacinth with them, in tho≈øe places where Virgil liued, per≈øwadeth me to thinke, that Virgil vnder≈øtood this Starry Iacinth by Vacinium: Let others iudge otherwi≈øe, if they can ≈øhew greater probabilitie.

div.head: 1. Hyacinthus Stellatus Byzantinus nigra radice. The Starry Iacinth of Turkie with the blacke roote.
div.p: This Starry Iacinth of Con≈øtantinople hath three or foure fre≈øh greene, thinne, and long leaues, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the Engli≈øh Iacinth, but not ≈øo long, betweene which ri≈øeth vp a ≈ølender lowe ≈øtalke, bearing fiue or ≈øix ≈ømall flowers, di≈øper≈øedly ≈øet thereon, ≈øpreading open like a ≈øtarre, of a pale or bleake blew colour: the leaues of the flowers are ≈øomewhat long, and ≈øtand as it were ≈øomewhat loo≈øly, one off from another, and not ≈øo compactly together, as the flowers of other kindes: it ≈øeldome beareth ripe ≈øeede with vs, becau≈øe the heads are ≈øo heauie, that lying vpon the ground, they rotte with the wet, or are bitten with the fro≈øts, or both, ≈øo that they ≈øeldome come to good: the roote is ≈ømall in ≈øome, and rea≈øonable bigge in others, round, and long, white within, but couered with deepe reddi≈øh or purpli≈øh peelings, next vnto it, and darker and blacker purple on the out≈øide, with ≈øome long and thicke white fibres, like fingers hanging at the bottome of them, as is to be ≈øeene in many other Iacinths: the roote it ≈øelfe for the mo≈øt part doth runne downewards, ≈øomewhat deep into the ground.

div.head: 2. Hyacinthus Stellatus Byzantinus maior. The greater Starry Iacinth of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This Iacinth may rightly be referred to the former Iacinth of Con≈øtantinople, and called the greater, it is ≈øo like thereunto, that any one that knoweth that, will ≈øoone ≈øay, that this is another of that ≈øort, but greater as it is in all his parts, bearing larger leaues by much, and more ≈øtore, lying vpon the ground round about the roote: it beareth many lowe ≈øtalkes of flowers, as bleake, and ≈øtanding as loo≈øly as the former: onely the roote of this, is not black on the out≈øide, as the other, but three times bigger.

div.head: 3. Hyacinthus Stellatus Byzantinus alter, ≈øi ‚Ä¢ e flore boraginis. The other Starry Iacinth of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This other Iacinth hath for the mo≈øt part onely foure leaues, broader and greener then the fir≈øt, but not ≈øo large or long as the ≈øecond: the ≈øtalke hath fiue or ≈øix flowers vpon it, bigger and rounder ≈øet, like other ≈øtarry Iacinths, of a more perfect or deeper blew then either of the former, hauing a whiti≈øh greene head or vmbone in the middle, be≈øet with ≈øix blew chiues or threeds, tipt with blacke, ≈øo clo≈øly compa≈ø≈øing the vmbone, that the threeds ≈øeeme ≈øo many prickes ≈øtucke into a clubbe or head; ≈øome therefore haue likened it to the flower of Borage, and ≈øo haue called it: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come vp round white heads, wherein is contained round and white ≈øeede: the roote is of a darke whiti≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and ≈øometimes a little reddi≈øh withall.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt and the la≈øt haue beene brought from Con≈øtantinople; the fir≈øt among many other rootes, and the la≈øt by the Lord Zouch, as Lobel witne≈ø≈øeth. The ≈øecond hath been ≈øent vs out of the Lowe-Countries, but from whence they had it, we do not certainly know. They growe with vs in our Gardens ≈øufficiently.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe flower in Aprill, but the fir≈øt is the earlie≈øt of the re≈øt, and is in flower pre≈øently after the early Starry Iacinth, before de≈øcribed.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The former haue their names in their titles, and are not knowne vnto vs by any other names that I know; but as I ≈øaid before, the la≈øt is called by ≈øome, Hyacinthus Boraginis flore. The fir≈øt was ≈øent out of Turkie, by the name of Su≈øam giul, by which name likewi≈øe diuers other things haue beene ≈øent, ≈øo barren and barbarous is the Turki≈øh tongue.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Ae≈øtivus maior. The greater Summer Starry Iacinth.
div.p: This late Iacinth hath diuers narrow greene leaues, lying vpon the ground, ≈øomewhat like the leaues of the Engli≈øh Iacinth, but ≈øtiffer and ≈øtronger; among which ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtiffe ≈øtalke, bearing many flowers at the toppe thereof, and at euery foote-≈øtalke of the flowers a ≈ømall ≈øhort leafe, of a purpli≈øh colour: the flowers are ≈øtarre-like, of a fine delayed purpli≈øh colour, tending to a pale blew or a≈øh colour, ≈øtriped on the backe of euery leafe, and hauing a pointed vmbone in the middle, with ≈øome whiti≈øh purple threeds about it, tipt with blew: the ≈øeede is blacke, round, and ≈øhining, like vnto the ≈øeede of the Engli≈øh Iacinth, but not ≈øo bigge: the roote is round and white, hauing ≈øome long thicke rootes vnder it, be≈øides the fibres, as is v≈øuall in many other Iacinths.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Ae≈øtivus minor. The le≈ø≈øer Summer Starry Iacinth.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer Iacinth hath diuers very long, narrow, and ≈øhining greene leaues, ≈øpread vpon the ground round about the roote, among which ri≈øeth vp a very ≈øhort round ≈øtalke, not aboue two inches high, carrying ≈øix or ≈øeuen ≈ømall flowers thereon, on each ≈øide of the ≈øtalke, like both in forme and colour vnto the greater before de≈øcribed, but le≈ø≈øer by farre: the ≈øeede is blacke, contained in three ≈øquare heads: the roote is ≈ømall and white, couered with a browne coate, and hauing ≈øome ≈øuch thicke rootes among the fibres, as are among the other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Both the≈øe Iacinths grow naturally in Portugall, and from thence haue been brought, by ≈øuch as ≈øeeke out for rare plants, to make a gaine and profit by them.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They both flower in May, and not before: and their ≈øeed is ripe in Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Some doe call the≈øe Hyacinthus Lu≈øitanicus, The Portugall Iacinth. Clu≈øius, who fir≈øt ≈øet out the de≈øcriptions of them, called them as is expre≈ø≈øed in their titles; and therefore we haue after the Latine name giuen their Engli≈øh, according as is ≈øet downe. Or if you plea≈øe, you may call them, The greater and the le≈ø≈øer Portugall Iacinth.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellaris flore cinereo. The a≈øh coloured Starry Iacinth.
div.p:
This a≈øh coloured Iacinth, hath his leaues very like vnto the leaues of the Engli≈øh Iacinth, and ≈øpreading vpon the ground in the ≈øame manner, among which ri≈øe vp one or two ≈øtalkes, ≈øet at the toppe with a number of ≈ømall ≈øtarre-like flowers, bu≈øhing bigger
below then aboue, of a very pale or white blew, tending to an a≈øh colour, and very ≈øweete in ≈ømell: the ≈øeede is blacke and round, like vnto the ≈øeede of the Engli≈øh Iacinth, and ≈øo is the roote, being great, round, and white; ≈øo like, I ≈øay, that it is hard to know the one from the other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The certaine originall places of growing thereof, is not knowne to vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Some doe call this Hyacinthus Someri, Somers Iacinth, becau≈øe as Lobel ≈øaith, he brought it fir≈øt into the Lowe-Countries, eyther from Con≈øtantinople, or out of Italy.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Lilifolio & radice caeruleo. The blew Lilly leafed Starre Iacinth.
div.p: This Iacinth hath ≈øix or ≈øeuen broad greene leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto Lilly leaues, but ≈øhorter (whereof it tooke his name as well as from the roote) ≈øpread vpon the ground, and lying clo≈øe and round: before the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth out from the middle of the≈øe leaues, there doth appeare a deepe hollow place, like a hole, to bee ≈øeene a good while, which at length is filled vp with the ≈øtalke, ri≈øing thence vnto a foote or more high, bearing many ≈øtarre-like flowers at the toppe, of a perfect blew colour, neare vnto a Violet, and ≈øometimes of paler or bleake blew colour, hauing as it were a ≈ømall cuppe in the middle, diuided into ≈øix peeces, without any threeds therein: the ≈øeede is blacke and round, but not ≈øhining: the roote is ≈øomewhat long, bigge belowe, and ≈ømall aboue, like vnto the ≈ømall roote of a Lilly, and compo≈øed of yellow ≈øcales, as a Lilly, but the ≈øcales are greater, and fewer in number.

div.head: Hyacinthus Stellatus Lilifolius albus. The white Lilly leafed Starre Iacinth.
div.p: The likene≈ø≈øe of this Iacinth with the former, cau≈øeth me to be briefe, and not to repeate the ≈øame things againe, that haue already been expre≈ø≈øed: You may therefore vnder≈øtand, that except in the colour of the flower, which in this is white, there is no difference betweene them.

Flore
‚Ä¢ arneo.I heare of one that ≈øhould beare blu≈øh coloured flowers, but I haue not yet ≈øeene any ≈øuch.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe Iacinths haue been gathered on the Pyrenaean Hils, in that part of France that is called Aquitaine, and in ≈øome other places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe flower in Aprill, and ≈øometimes later.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Becau≈øe the roote is ≈øo like vnto a Lilly, as the leafe is al≈øo, it hath mo≈øt properly beene called Hyacinthus Stellatus Lilifolio & radice, or for breuity Lilifolius, that is, The Starry Lilly leafed Iacinth. It is called Sarahug by the Inhabitants where it groweth, as Clu≈øius maketh the report from Venerius, who further faith, that by experience they haue found the cattell to ≈øwell and dye, that haue eaten of the leaues thereof.

figure.head:
1 Hyacinthus ≈øtellatus praecox caruleus. The early blew ≈øtarry Iacinth. 2 Hyacinthus ≈øtellatus pracox albus. The early white ≈øtarry Iacinth. 3 Hyacinthus ≈øtellatus Byzantinus nigra radice. The Turkie ≈øtarry Iacinth with a blacke roote. 4 Hyacinthus Byzantinus alter ≈øiue flore Bor ‚Ä¢ ginis. The other ≈øtarry Iacinth of Con≈øtantinople. 5 Hyacinthus a≈øtibus maior. The greater Summer ≈øtarry Iacinth. 6 Hyacinthus ≈øtellatus flore
‚Ä¢ re ‚Ä¢ . The a≈øh coloured ≈øtarry Iacinth. 7 Hyacinthus ≈øtellatus Lilifolius. The Lilly leafed ≈øtarre Iacinth. 8 Hyacinthus Autumnalis. The Autumne Iacinth. 9 Scilla alba ≈øiue Hyacinthus marinus. The Sea Onion or Squill.

div.head: Hyacinthus Autumnalis maior. The greater Autumne Iacinth.
div.p: The greater Autumne Iacinth hath fiue or ≈øix very long and narrow greene leaues, lying vpon the ground; the ≈øtalkes are ≈øet at the toppe with many ≈øtarre-like flowers, of a pale blewi≈øh purple colour, with ≈øome pale coloured threeds, tipt with blew, ≈øtanding about the head in the middle, which in time growing ripe, containeth therein ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede, and roundi≈øh: the roote is great and white on the out≈øide.

div.head: Hyacinthus Autumnalis minor. The le≈ø≈øer Autumne Iacinth.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer Iacinth hath ≈øuch like long and ≈ømall leaues, but narrower then the former: the ≈øtalke is not full ≈øo high, but beareth as many flowers on it as the other, which are of a pale or bleake purple colour, very like vnto it al≈øo: the roote and ≈øeed are like the former, but ≈ømaller. The≈øe both for the mo≈øt part, beare their flowers and ≈øeede before the greene leaues ri≈øe vp much aboue the ground.
Flore albo.There is a kinde hereof found that beareth white flowers, not differing in any other thing from the ≈ømaller purple kinde la≈øt mentioned.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt and la≈øt are onely kept in Gardens, and not knowne to vs where their naturall place of growing wilde may be.

The ≈øecond groweth wilde in many places of England. I gathered diuers rootes for my Garden, from the foote of a high banke by the Thames ≈øide, at the hither end of Chel≈øey, before you come at the Kings Barge-hou≈øe.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The greate≈øt flowreth in the end of Iuly, and in Augu≈øt.
The other in Augu≈øt and September, you ≈øhall ≈øeldome ≈øee this plant with flowers and greene leaues at one time together.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue their names giuen them, as they are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, by all former Writers, except Dale≈øchampius, or hee that ≈øet forth that great worke printed at Lyons; for hee contendeth with many words, that the≈øe plants can bee no Iacinths, becau≈øe their flowers appeare before their leaues in Autumne, contrary to the true Iacinth, as he ≈øaith: and therefore he would faine haue it referred to Theophrastus bulbus in libro primo cap. 12. and calleth it his Tiphyum mentioned in that place, as al≈øo Bulbus ae≈øtivus Dalechampij. How≈øoeuer the≈øe things may carry ≈øome probability in them, yet the likene≈ø≈øe both of rootes, and flowers e≈øpecially, hath cau≈øed very learned Writers to entitle them as is ≈øet downe, and therefore I may not but let them pa≈ø≈øe in the like manner.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Both the rootes and the leaues of the Iacinths are ≈øomewhat cold and drying, but the ≈øeede much more. It ≈øtayeth the loo≈øne≈ø≈øe of the belly. It is likewi≈øe ≈øaid to hinder young per≈øons from growing ripe too ≈øoone, the roote being drunke in wine. It helpeth them al≈øo who≈øe vrine is ≈øtopt, and is auaileable for the yellow Iaundi≈øe; but as you heare ≈øome are deadly to cattell, I therefore wi≈øh all to bee well adui≈øed which of the≈øe they will v≈øe in any inward phy≈øicke.

div.head: Scilla alba. The Sea Onion or Squill.
div.p:
As I ended the di≈øcour≈øe of both the true and the ba≈øtard Daffodils, with the Sea
kindes of both ≈øorts; ≈øo I thinke it not ami≈ø≈øe, to fini≈øh this of the Iacinths with the de≈øcription of a Sea Iacinth, which (as you ≈øee) I take to be the Scilla, or Sea Onion, all his parts ≈øo nearely re≈øembling a Iacinth, that I know not where to ranke him better then in this place, or rather not any where but here. You ≈øhall haue the de≈øcription thereof, and then let the iudicious pa≈ø≈øe their ≈øentence, as they thinke meete≈øt.

The Squill or Sea Onion (as many doe call it) hath diuers thicke leaues, broad, long, greene and hollowi≈øh in the middle, and with an eminent or ≈øwelling ribbe all along the backe of the leafe, (I relate it as I haue ≈øeene it, hauing ≈øhot forth his leaues in the ≈øhip by the way, as the Mariners that brought diuers rootes from out of the Straights, did ≈øell them to mee and others for our v≈øe) lying vpon the ground, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of a Lilly: the≈øe ≈øpring vp after the flowers are pa≈øt, and the ≈øeed ripe, they abiding all the Winter, and the next Spring, vntill the heate of the Summer hath ≈øpent and con≈øumed them, and then about the end of Augu≈øt, or beginning of September the ≈øtalke with flowers ari≈øeth out of the ground a foote and a halfe high, bearing many ≈øtarre-like flowers on the toppe, in a long ≈øpike one aboue another, flowring by degrees, the lowe≈øt fir≈øt, and ≈øo vpwards, whereby it is long in flowring, very like, as well in forme as bigne≈ø≈øe, to the flowers of the great Starre of Bethlehem (the≈øe flowers I haue likewi≈øe ≈øeene ≈øhooting out of ≈øome of the rootes, that haue been brought in the like manner:) after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp in their places thicke and three ≈øquare heads, wherin is contained ≈øuch like flat, black, and round ≈øeed, as the Spani≈øh duskie Iacinth before de≈øcribed did beare, but greater: the root is great & white, couered with many peelings or couerings, as is plainly enough ≈øeen to any that know them, and that ≈øometimes wee haue had rootes, that haue beene as bigge as a pretty childes head, and ≈øometimes two growing together, each whereof was no le≈ø≈øe then is ≈øaid of the other.

div.head: Scilla rubra ≈øiue Pancratium verum. The red Sea Onion.
div.p: The roote of this Squill, is greater oftentimes then of the former, the outer coates or peelings being reddi≈øh, bearing greater, longer, ≈øtiffer, and more hollow leaues, in a manner vpright: this bringeth ≈øuch a like ≈øtalke and flowers, as the former doth, as Fabianus Ilges, Apothecary to the Duke of Briga, did ≈øignifie by the figure thereof drawne and ≈øent to Clu≈øius.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They grow alwayes neare the Sea, and neuer farre off from it, but often on the very baich of the Sea, where it wa≈øheth ouer them all along the coa≈øts of Spaine, Portugal, and Italy, and within the Straights in many places: it will not abide in any Garden farre from the Sea, no not in Italy, as it is related.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The time wherein they flower, is expre≈ø≈øed to be in Augu≈øt and September: the ≈øeede to be ripe in October and Nouember, and the greene leaues to ≈øpring vp in Nouember and December.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The≈øe are certainly the true kindes of Scilla that ≈øhould bee v≈øed in medicines, although (as Clu≈øius reporteth) the Spaniards forbade him to ta≈øte of the red Squill, as of a mo≈øt ≈øtrong and pre≈øent poi≈øon. Pliny hath made more ≈øorts then can be found out yet to this day with vs: that Scilla that is called Epimenidia, becau≈øe it might be eaten, is thought to be the great Ornithogalum, or Starre of Bethlehem. Pancratium is, I know, and as I ≈øaid before, referred to that kinde of ba≈øtard Sea Daffodill; which is ≈øet forth before in the end of the hi≈øtory of the ba≈øtard Daffodils; and diuers al≈øo would make the Narci≈ø≈øus tertius Matthioli, which I call the true Sea Daffodill, to be a Pancratium; but ≈øeeing Dio≈øcorides (and no other is again≈øt him)
maketh Pancratium to be a kinde of Squill with reddi≈øh rootes, I dare not vphold their opinion again≈øt ≈øuch manife≈øt truth.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Squill or Sea Onion is wholly v≈øed phy≈øically with vs, becau≈øe wee can receiue no plea≈øure from the ≈øight of the flowers. Pliny writeth, that Pithagoras wrote a volume or booke of the properties thereof, for the ≈øingular effects it wrought; which booke is lo≈øt, yet the diuers vertues it hath is recorded by others, to be effectuall for the ≈øpleene, lungs, ≈øtomach, liuer, head and heart; and for drop≈øies, old coughs, Iaundi≈øe, and the wormes; that it cleareth the ≈øight, helpeth the tooth-ache, clean≈øeth the head of ≈øcurfe, and running ≈øores; and is an e≈øpeciall Antidote again≈øt poi≈øon: and therefore is v≈øed as a principall ingredient into the Theriaca Andromachi, which we v≈øually call Venice Treakle. The Apothecaries prepare hereof, both Wine, Vinegar, and Oxymel or Syrupe, which is ≈øingular to extenuate and expectorate tough flegme, which is the cau≈øe of much di≈øquiet in the body, and an hinderer of concoction, or di≈øge≈øtion in the ≈øtomach, be≈øides diuers other wayes, wherein the ≈øcales of the rootes, being dryed, are v≈øed. And Galen hath ≈øufficiently explained the qualities and properties thereof, in his eight Booke of Simples.

div.head: Ornithogalum. Starre of Bethlehem.
div.p: AFter the Family of the Iacinths, mu≈øt needes follow the kindes of Starre-flowers, or Starres of Bethlehem, as they are called, for that they doe ≈øo nearely re≈øemble them, that diuers haue named ≈øome of them Iacinths, and referred them to that kindred: all of them, both in roote, leafe, and flower, come nearer vnto the Iacinths, then vnto any other plant. They ≈øhall therefore bee next de≈øcribed, euery one in their order, the greate≈øt fir≈øt, and the re≈øt following.

div.head: Ornithogalum Arabicum. The great Starre-flower of Arabia.
div.p:
This Arabian Starre-flower hath many broad, and long greene leaues, very like vnto the leaues of the Orientall Iacinth, but lying for the mo≈øt part vpon the ground, among which ri≈øeth vp a round greene ≈øtalke, almo≈øt two foote high, bearing at the toppe diuers large flowers, ≈øtanding vpon long foote-≈øtalkes, and at the bottome of euery one of them a ≈ømall ≈øhort pointed greene leafe: the≈øe flowers are made of ≈øix pure white leaues a peece, laid open as large as an ordinary Daffodill, but of the forme of a Starre Iacinth, or Starre of Bethlehem, which clo≈øe as they doe euery night, and open them≈øelues in the day time, e≈øpecially in the Sunne, the ≈ømell whereof is pretty ≈øweete, but weake: in the middle of the flower is a blacki≈øh head, compo≈øed with ≈øix white threeds, tipt with yellow pendents: the ≈øeede hath not beene ob≈øerued with vs: the roote is great and white, with a flat bottome, very impatient of our cold Winters, ≈øo that it ≈øeldome pro≈øpereth or abideth with vs; for although ≈øometimes it doe abide a Winter in the ground, yet it often lyeth without ≈øpringing blade, or any thing el≈øe a whole yeare, and then peri≈øheth: or if it doe ≈øpring, yet many doe not beare, and mo≈øt after their fir≈øt bearing doe decay and peri≈øh. But if any be de≈øirous, to know how to pre≈øerue the roote of this plant, or of many other bulbous rootes that are tender, ≈øuch as the great double white Daffodill of Con≈øtantinople, and other fine Daffodils, that come from hot Countries; let them keepe this rule: Let either the roote be planted in a large pot, or tubbe of earth, and hou≈øed all the Winter, that ≈øo it may bee defended from the fro≈øts; Or el≈øe (which is the ea≈øier way) keepe the roote out of the ground euery yeare, from September, after the leaues and ≈øtalkes are pa≈øt, vntill February, in
≈øome dry, but not hot or windy place, and then plant it in the ground vnder a South wall, or ≈øuch like defended place, which will ≈øpring, and no doubt pro≈øper well there, in regard the greate≈øt and deepe≈øt fro≈øts are pa≈øt after February, ≈øo that ≈øeldome any great fro≈øts come after, to pierce ≈øo deepe as the roote is to be ≈øet, or thereby to doe any great harme to it in ≈øuch a place.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This hath been often ≈øent out of Turkie, and likewi≈øe out of Italy; I had likewi≈øe two rootes ≈øent mee out of Spaine by Guillaume Boel before remembred, which (as hee ≈øaid) hee gathered there, but they pro≈øpered not with me, for want of the knowledge of the former rule. It may be likely that Arabia is the place, from whence they of Con≈øtantinople receiue it.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in May, if it be of the fir≈øt yeares bringing; or in Iune, if it haue been ordered after the manner before ≈øet downe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath been ≈øent out of Italy by the name of Lilium Alexandrinum, The Lilly of Alexandria, but it hath no affinity with any Lilly. Others call it Hyacinthus Arabicus; and the Italians, Iacintho del pater no≈øtro: but it is no Iacinth neither, although the flowers be like ≈øome of them. Some al≈øo would referre it to a Narci≈ø≈øus or Daffodill, and it doth as little agree with it, as with a Lilly, although his flowers in largene≈ø≈øe and whitene≈ø≈øe re≈øemble a Daffodill. Clu≈øius hath mo≈øt fitly referred it to the ≈øtocke or kindred of Ornithogala, or Starres of Bethlehem, as wee call them in Engli≈øh, and from the Turki≈øh name, Zumbul Arabi, entituled it Ornithogalum Arabicum, although Zumbul, as I haue before declared, is with them, a Iacinth, wee may call it in Engli≈øh, The Arabian Starre-flower, or Starre of Bethlehem, or the great Starre-flower of Arabia.

div.head: 1. Ornithogalum maximum album. The greate≈øt white Starre-flower, or Starre of Bethlehem.
div.p: This great Starre-flower hath many faire, broad, long, and very fre≈øh green leaues, ri≈øing vp very early, and are greater, longer, and greener then the leaues of any Orientall Iacinth, which doe abide greene, from the beginning or middle of Ianuary, or before ≈øometimes, vntill the end of May, at which time they begin to fade, and the ≈øtalke with the head of flowers beginneth to ri≈øe, ≈øo that it will haue either few or no leaues at all, when the flowers are blowne: the ≈øtalke is ≈øtrong, round, and firme, ri≈øing two foote high or more, bearing at the toppe a great bu≈øh of flowers, ≈øeeming at the fir≈øt to be a great greene eare of corne, for it is made ≈øpike-fa≈øhion, which when the flowers are blowne, doth ri≈øe to be very high, ≈ølender or ≈ømall at the head aboue, and broad ≈øpread and bu≈øhing below, ≈øo that it is long in flowring; for they flower below fir≈øt, and ≈øo vpwards by degrees: the≈øe flowers are ≈ønow white, without any line on the back≈øide, and is therein like vnto the former, as al≈øo in whitene≈ø≈øe, but nothing ≈øo large, with a white vmbone or head in the middle, be≈øet with many white threeds, tipt with yellow: the ≈øeede is blacke and round, contained in three ≈øquare heads: the roote is great, thicke, and ≈øhort, and ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh on the out≈øide, with a flat bottome, both like the former, and the next that followeth.

div.head: 2. Ornithogalum maius ≈øpicatum album. The great white ≈øpiked Starre-flower.
div.p:
This ≈øpiked Starre-flower in his growing, is ≈øomewhat like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed,
but ≈øpringeth not vp ≈øo early, nor hath his leaues ≈øo greene, or large, but hath broad, long, whiti≈øh greene hollow leaues, pointed at the end, among which ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, which is ≈øtrong and high, as the former, hauing a great bu≈øh of flowers at the toppe, ≈øtanding ≈øpike-fa≈øhion, ≈øomewhat like the former, flowring in the ≈øame maner by degrees, fir≈øt below, and ≈øo vpwards; but it is not ≈øo thicke ≈øet with flowers, nor ≈øo farre ≈øpread at the bottome as it, the flowers al≈øo are not ≈øo white, and each of the leaues of them haue a greene line downe the backe, leauing the edges on both ≈øides white: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the heads for ≈øeede grow three ≈øquare, like the other, bearing ≈øuch like blacke ≈øeede therein: the roote hereof is v≈øually bigger then the la≈øt, and whiter on the out≈øide.

div.head: 3. Ornithogalum Pannonicum. The Hungarian Starre-flower.
div.p: This Hungarian Starre-flower ≈øhooteth out diuers narrow, long, whiti≈øh greene leaues, ≈øpread vpon the ground before Winter, which are very like vnto the leaues of Gilloflowers, and ≈øo abide aboue ground, hauing a ≈øtalke ri≈øing in the middle of them the next Spring, about halfe a foote high or thereabouts, bearing many white flowers at the toppe, with greene lines downe the backe of them, very like vnto the ordinary Starres of Bethlehem: the roote is greater, thicker, and longer then the ordinary Starres, and for the mo≈øt part, two ioyned together, ≈øomewhat grayi≈øh on the out≈øide.

div.head: 4. Ornithogalum vulgare. The Starre of Bethlehem.
div.p: The ordinary Starre of Bethlehem is ≈øo common, and well knowne in all countries and places, that it is almo≈øt needle≈ø≈øe to de≈øcribe it, hauing many greene leaues with white lines therein, and a few white flowers ≈øet about the toppe of the ≈øtalke, with greeni≈øh lines downe the backe: the roote is whiti≈øh, and encrea≈øeth aboundantly.

div.head: 5. A≈øphodelus bulbo≈øus Galeni, ≈øiue Ornithogalum maius flore ≈øubuire≈øcente. The bulbous A≈øphodill, or greene Starre-flower.
div.p: Diuers haue referred this plant vnto the A≈øphodils, becau≈øe (as I thinke) the flowers hereof are ≈øtraked on the backe, and the leaues long and narrow, like vnto the A≈øphodils; but the roote of this being bulbous, I rather (as ≈øome others doe) ioyne it with the Ornithogala, for they al≈øo haue ≈øtrakes on the backe of the flowers. It hath many whiti≈øh greene leaues, long and narrow, ≈øpread vpon the ground, which ≈øpring vp in the beginning of the yeare, and abide vntill May, and then they withering, the ≈øtalke ≈øpringeth vp almo≈øt as high as the fir≈øt, hauing many pale yellowi≈øh greene flowers, but ≈ømaller, and growing more ≈øpar≈øedly about the ≈øtalke vpon ≈øhort foot-≈øtalkes, but in a rea≈øonable long head ≈øpike-fa≈øhion: the ≈øeede is like vnto the ≈øecond kinde, but ≈ømaller: the roote is ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh, like the fir≈øt great white kinde.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is onely nur≈øed in Gardens, his originall being not well knowne, yet ≈øome attribute it vnto Pannonia or Hungary. The ≈øecond hath been found neare vnto Barcinone, and Toledo in Spaine. The third was found in Hungary by Clu≈øius. Our ordinary euery where in the fields of Italy and France, and (as it is ≈øaid) in England al≈øo. And the la≈øt groweth likewi≈øe by the corne fields in the vpper Hungary.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Aprill and May, and ≈øometimes in Iune.

div.head: The Names.

figure.head: 1 Ornithogalum Arabicum. The great ≈øtarre-flower of Arabia. 2 Ornithogalum maximum album The greate≈øt white ≈øtarre flower. 3 Ornithogalum maius ≈øpicatum album. The great white ≈øpiked ≈øtarre flower. 4 Ornithogalum Pannonicum album. The Hungarian ≈øtarre-flower. 5 A≈øphodalus bulbo≈øus Galeni, ≈øiue Ornithogalum maius ≈øubuire≈øcente flore. The bulbed A≈øphodill, or greene ≈øtarre flower. 6 Ornithogalum Hi≈øpanicum minus. The little ≈øtarre-flower of Spaine. 7 Ornithogalum luteum. The yellow ≈øtarre-flower of Bethlehem. 8 Ornithogalum Neapolitanum. The ≈øtarre-flower of Naples.

div.p: The ≈øecond hath his name in his title, as mo≈øt authors doe ≈øet it downe, yet in the great Herball referred to Dalechampius, it is called Ornithogalum magnum Myconi.
The third hath his name from the place of his birth, and the other from his popularity, yet Dodonaeus calleth it Bulbus Leucanthemos.

The la≈øt is called by diuers A≈øphodelo-hyacinthinus, and Hyacintho-a≈øphodelus Galeni. Dodonaeus calleth it A≈øphodelus faemina, and A≈øphodelus bulbo≈øus. But Lobel, and Gerrard from him, and Dodonaeus, doe make this to haue white flowers, whereas all that I haue ≈øeene, both in mine owne, and in others Gardens, bore greeni≈øh flowers, as Clu≈øius ≈øetteth it truely downe‚ñ™ Lobel ≈øeemeth in the de≈øcription of this, to confound the Ornithogalum of Mompelier with it, and calleth it A≈øphodelus hyacinthinus forte Galeni, and ≈øaith that ≈øome would call it Pancratium Mon≈øpelien≈øe, and A≈øphodelus Galeni. But as I haue ≈øhewed, the Ornithogalum ≈øpicatum and this, doe plainly differ the one from the other, and are not both to be called by one name, nor to be reckoned one, but two di≈øtinct plants.

div.head: Ornithogalum Aethiopicum. The Starre-flower of Aethiopia.
div.p: The leaues of this plant are a foote long, and at the lea≈øt an inch broad, which being broken, are no le≈ø≈øe woolly then the woolly Iacinth: the ≈øtalke is a cubit high, ≈øtrong and greene; from the middle whereof vnto the toppe, ≈øtand large ≈ønow white flowers, vpon long, greene, thicke foot-≈øtalkes, and yellowi≈øh at the bottome of the flower; in the middle whereof ≈øtand ≈øix white threeds, tipt with yellow chiues, compa≈ø≈øing the head, which is three ≈øquare, and long containing the ≈øeede: the roote is thicke and round, ≈øomewhat like the A≈øphodelus Galeni.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This plant was gathered by ≈øome Hollanders, on the We≈øt ≈øide of the Cape of good Hope.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowred about the end of Augu≈øt with tho≈øe that had it.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Becau≈øe it came from that part of the continent beyond the line, which is reckoned a part of Aethiopia, it is thereupon ≈øo called as it is ≈øet downe.

div.head: Ornithogalum Neopolitanum. The Starre-flower of Naples.
div.p:
This beautifull plant ri≈øeth out of the ground very early, with foure or fiue hollow pointed leaues, ≈øtanding round together, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, with a white line downe the middle of euery leafe on the in≈øide, ≈øomewhat narrow, but long, (Fabius Columna ≈øaith, three foot long in Italy, but it is not ≈øo with vs) in the middle of the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, a foote and a halfe high, bearing diuers flowers at the toppe, euery one ≈øtanding in a little cuppe or huske, which is diuided into three or foure parts, hanging downe very long about the heads for ≈øeede: after the flower is pa≈øt, the≈øe flowers doe all hang downe their heads, and open one way, although their little foot-≈øtalkes come forth on all ≈øides of the greater ≈øtalke, being large, and compo≈øed of ≈øix long leaues, of a pure white on the in≈øide, and of a blewi≈øh or whiti≈øh greene colour
on the out≈øide, leauing the edges of euery leafe white on both ≈øides: in the middle of the≈øe flowers ≈øtand other ≈ømall flowers, each of them al≈øo made of ≈øix ≈ømall white leaues a peece, which meeting together, ≈øeeme to make the ≈øhew of a cuppe, within which are contained ≈øix white threeds, tipt with yellow, and a long white pointell in the middle of them, being without any ≈øent at all: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come vp great round heads, which are too heauie for the ≈øtalke to beare; and therefore lye downe vpon the leaues or ground, hauing certaine lines or ≈øtripes on the out≈øide, wherein is contained round, blacke, rough ≈øeede: the roote is great and white, and ≈øomewhat flat at the bottome, as diuers of the≈øe kindes are, and doe multiply as plentifully into ≈ømall bulbes as the common or any other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This Starre-flower groweth in the Medowes in diuers places of Naples, as Fabius Columna, and Ferrantes Imperatus doe te≈øtifie, from whence they haue been ≈øent. And Matthiolus, who ≈øetteth out the figure thereof among his Daffodils, had (it ≈øhould ≈øeeme) ≈øeene it grow with him.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in May, although it begin to ≈øpring out of the ground oftentimes in Nouember, but mo≈øt v≈øually in Ianuary: the ≈øeede is ripe in Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Matthiolus reckoneth this (as is ≈øaid) among the Daffodils, for no other re≈øpect, as I conceiue, then that he accounted the middle flower to bee the cuppe or trunke of a Daffodill, which it doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble, and ≈øetteth it forth in the fourth place, whereupon many doe call it Narci≈ø≈øus quartus Matthioli, The fourth Daffodill of Matthiolus. Fabius Columna calleth it Hyacinthus aruorum Ornithogali flore. Clu≈øius (to whom Imperatus ≈øent it, in ≈øtead of the Arabian which hee de≈øired) calleth it of the place from whence he receiued it, Ornithogalum Neopolitanum, and we thereafter call it in Engli≈øh, The Starre-flower of Naples.

div.head: Ornithogalum Hi≈øpanicum minus. The little Starre-flower of Spaine.
div.p: Clu≈øius hath ≈øet forth this plant among his Ornithogala or Starre-flowers, and although it doth in my minde come nearer to a Hyacinthus, then to Ornithogalum, yet pardon it, and let it pa≈ø≈øe as he doth. From a little round whiti≈øh roote, ≈øpringeth vp in the beginning of the yeare, fiue or ≈øix ≈ømall long green leaues, without any white line in the middle of them, among which ri≈øe vp one or two ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, an hand length high or better, bearing ≈øeuen or eight, or more flowers, growing as it were in a tuft or vmbell, with ≈ømall long leaues at the foote of euery ≈øtalke, the lower flowers being equall in length with the vppermo≈øt, of a pale whiti≈øh blew or a≈øh colour, with a ≈øtrake or line downe the backe of euery leafe of them, with ≈øome white threeds ≈øtanding about a blewi≈øh head in the middle: the≈øe flowers pa≈ø≈øe away quickly, and giue no ≈øeed, ≈øo that it is not knowne what ≈øeede it beareth.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This groweth in Spaine, and from thence hath been brought to vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath no other name then is ≈øet down in the title, being but lately found out.

div.head: 1. Ornithogalum album vnifolium. The white ≈øtarre-flower with one blade.
div.p: This little ≈øtarre-flower I bring into this place, as the fitte≈øt in my opinion where to place it, vntill my minde change to alter it. It hath a very ≈ømall round white roote, from whence ≈øpringeth vp one very long and round greene leafe, like vnto a ru≈øh, but that for about two or three inches aboue the ground, it is a little flat, and from thence ≈øpringeth forth a ≈ømall ≈øtalke not aboue three or foure inches high, bearing at the top thereof three or foure ≈ømall white flowers, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues a peece, within which are ≈øix white chiues, tipt with yellow pendents, ≈øtanding about a ≈ømall three ≈øquare head, that hath a white pointell ≈øticking as it were in the midde≈øt thereof: the flower is pretty and ≈øweete, but not heady.

div.head: Ornithogalum luteum. The yellow Starre of Bethlehem.
div.p: This yellow Starre-flower ri≈øeth vp at the fir≈øt, with one long, round, greeni≈øh leafe, which openeth it ≈øelfe ≈øomewhat aboue the ground, and giueth out another ≈ømall leafe, le≈ø≈øer and ≈øhorter then the fir≈øt, and afterward the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth from thence al≈øo, being foure or fiue inches high, bearing at the toppe three or foure ≈ømall green leaues, and among them foure or fiue ≈ømall yellow ≈øtarre-like flowers, with a greeni≈øh line or ≈øtreake downe the backe of euery leafe, and ≈øome ≈ømall reddi≈øh yellow threeds in the middle: it ≈øeldome giueth ≈øeede: the roote is round, whiti≈øh, and ≈øomewhat cleare, very apt to peri≈øh, if it bee any little while kept dry out of the ground, as I haue twice tryed to my lo≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt grew in Portugall, and Clu≈øius fir≈øt of all others de≈øciphers it.
The other is found in many places both of Germany and Hungary, in the moi≈øter grounds.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth in May: the other in Aprill, and ≈øometimes in March.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Carolus Clu≈øius calleth the fir≈øt Bulbus vnifolius, or Bolbine, but referreth it not to the ≈øtocke or kindred of any plant; but (as you ≈øee) I haue ranked it with the ≈ømall ≈øorts of Ornithogalum, and giue it the name accordingly.

The other is referred for likene≈ø≈øe of forme, and not for colour, vnto the Ornithogala, or Starres of Bethlehem. It is called by Tragus and Fuch≈øius Bulbus ≈øilue≈øtris, becau≈øe of the obuiou≈øne≈ø≈øe. Cordus taketh it to be Si≈øyrinchium. Lacuna calleth it Bulbus e≈øculentus. Lobel and others in the≈øe dayes generally, Ornithogalum luteum, and wee thereafter in Engli≈øh, The yellow Starre-flower, or Starre of Bethlehem.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The fir≈øt kinde being but lately found out, is not knowne to be v≈øed. The rootes of the common or vulgar, are (as Matthiolus ≈øaith) much eaten by poore people in Italy, either rawe or roa≈øted, being ≈øweeter in ta≈øte then any Che≈ønut, and ≈øeruing as well for a nece≈ø≈øary food as for delight. It is doubtfull whether any of the re≈øt may be ≈øo v≈øed; for I know not any in our Land hath made any experience.
There are many other ≈øorts of Starre-flowers, which are fitter for a generall then this Hi≈øtory; and therefore I referre them thereunto.

div.head: Moly. Wilde Garlicke.
div.p: VNto the former Starre-flowers, mu≈øt needes bee ioyned another tribe or kindred, which carry their ≈øtraked flowers Starre-fa≈øhion, not ≈øpikewi≈øe, but in a tuft or vmbell thicke thru≈øt or ≈øet together. And although diuers of them ≈ømell not as the former, but mo≈øt of their fir≈øt Grandfathers hou≈øe, yet all doe not ≈øo; for ≈øome of them are of an excellent ≈øent. Of the whole Family, there are a great many which I mu≈øt leaue, I will onely ≈øelect out a few for this our Garden, who≈øe flowers for their beauty of ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe, forme, or colour, are fit to bee entertained, and take place therein, euery one according to his worth, and are accepted of with the louers of the≈øe delights.

div.head: 1. Moly Homericum, vel potius Theophrasti. The greate≈øt Moly of Homer.
div.p: Homers Moly (for ≈øo it is mo≈øt v≈øually called with vs) ri≈øeth vp mo≈øt commonly with two, and ≈øometimes with three great, thicke, long, and hollow guttured leaues, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, very neare the colour of the Tulipa leafe, hauing ≈øometimes at the end of ≈øome of the leaues, and ≈øometimes apart by it ≈øelfe, a whiti≈øt round ≈ømall button, like vnto a ≈ømall bulbe, the like whereof al≈øo, but greater, doth grow betweene the bottome of the leaues and the ≈øtalke neare the ground, which being planted when it is ripe, will grow into a roote of the ≈øame kinde: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a round, ≈øtrong, and tall ≈øtalke, a yard high or better, bare or naked vnto the toppe, where it beareth a great tuft or vmbell of pale purpli≈øh flowers, all of them almo≈øt ≈øtanding vpon equall foot-≈øtalkes, or not one much higher then another, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, ≈øtriped downe the backe with a ≈ømall pale line, hauing a round head or vmbone with ≈øome threeds about it in the mid≈øt: The≈øe flowers doe abide a great while blowne before they vade, which ≈ømell not very ≈øtrong, like any Onion or Garlicke, but of a faint ≈ømell: and after they are pa≈øt come the ≈øeede, which is blacke, wrapped in white clo≈øe huskes: the roote groweth very great, ≈øometimes bigger then any mans clo≈øed fi≈øt, ≈ømelling ≈øtrong like Garlicke, whiti≈øh on the out≈øide, and greene at the toppe, if it be but a while bare from the earth about it.

div.head: 2. Moly Indicum ≈øiue Caucafon. The Indian Moly.
div.p: The Indian Moly hath ≈øuch like thicke large leaues, as the Homers Moly hath, but ≈øhorter and broader, in the middle whereof ri≈øeth vp a ≈øhort weake ≈øtalke, almo≈øt flat, not hauing any flowers vpon it, but a head or clu≈øter of greeni≈øh ≈øcaly bulbes, inclo≈øed at the fir≈øt in a large thinne skinne, which being open, euery bulbe ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, ≈øtanding clo≈øe one vnto another vpon his foot-≈øtalke, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of an Acorne, which being planted, will grow to bee a plant of his owne kinde: the roote is white and great, couered with a darke coate or skinne, which encrea≈øeth but little vnder ground; but be≈øides that head, it beareth ≈ømall bulbes aboue the ground, at the bottome of the leaues next vnto the ≈øtalke, like vnto the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Both the≈øe doe grow in diuers places of Spaine, Italy, and Greece; for the la≈øt hath been ≈øent out of Turkie among other rootes. Ferrantes Imperatus a learned Apothecary of Naples, ≈øent it to diuers of his friends in the≈øe parts, and hath de≈øcribed it in his naturall hi≈øtory among other plants, printed in the Italian tongue. It grew al≈øo with Iohn Trade≈øcante at Canterbury, who ≈øent me the head of bulbes to ≈øee, and afterwards a roote, to plant it in my Garden.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth in the end of May, and abideth vnto the mid≈øt of Iuly, and ≈øometimes longer. The other beareth his head of bulbes in Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: We haue receiued them by their names expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, yet the la≈øt hath al≈øo been ≈øent by the name of Ornithogalum Italicum, but as all may ea≈øily ≈øee, it is not of that kindred.

div.head: 1. Moly montanum Pannonicum bulbiferum primum. The fir≈øt bulbed Moly of Hungary.
div.p: This fir≈øt Hungarian Moly hath three or foure broad and long greene leaues, folded together at the fir≈øt, which after open them≈øelues, and are carried vp with the ≈øtalke, ≈øtanding thereon one aboue another, which is a foote high; at the toppe whereof doe grow a few ≈øad reddi≈øh bulbes, and betweene them long foot≈øtalkes, bearing flowers of a pale purpli≈øh colour; after which followeth blacke ≈øeede, inclo≈øed in roundi≈øh heads: the roote is not great, but white on the out≈øide, very like vnto the roote of Serpents Moly, hereafter de≈øcribed, encrea≈øing much vnder ground, & ≈ømelling ≈øtrong.

div.head: 2. Moly montanum Pannonicum bulbiferum ≈øecundum. The ≈øecond bulbed Moly of Hungary.
div.p: The ≈øecond Moly hath narrower greene leaues then the former: the ≈øtalke is about the ≈øame height, and beareth at the toppe a great clu≈øter of ≈ømall greene bulbes, which after turne of a darker colour; from among which come forth long foot-≈øtalks, whereon ≈øtand purpli≈øh flowers: the roote is couered with a blacki≈øh purple coate or skinne.

div.head: 3. Moly Serpentinum. Serpents Moly.
div.p: This Moly mu≈øt al≈øo be ioyned vnto the bulbous Molyes, as of kindred with them, yet of greater beauty and delight, becau≈øe the bulbes on the heads of the ≈ømall ≈øtalkes are redder, and more plea≈øant to behold: the ≈øtalke is lower, and his gra≈ø≈øie winding leaues, which turne them≈øelues (whereof it tooke the name) are ≈ømaller, and of a whiter greene colour: it beareth among the bulbes purpli≈øh flowers al≈øo, but more beautifull, the ≈øent whereof is nothing ≈øo ≈øtrong: the roote is ≈ømall, round, and whiti≈øh, encrea≈øing into a number of ≈ømall rootes, no bigger then pea≈øe round about the greater roote.

div.head: 4. Moly caule & folijs triangularibus. The three cornered Moly.
div.p: This three ≈øquare Moly hath foure or fiue long, and ≈øomewhat broad pale greene leaues, flat on the vpper ≈øide, and with a ridge downe the backe of the leafe, which maketh it ≈øeeme three ≈øquare: the ≈øtalke which ri≈øeth vp a foote and a halfe high or better, is three ≈øquare or three cornered al≈øo, bearing at the toppe out of a skinnie huske diuers white flowers, ≈øomewhat large and long, almo≈øt bell-fa≈øhion, with ≈øtripes of greene downe the middle of euery leafe, and a few chiues tipt with yellow in the middle about the head, wherein when it is ripe, is inclo≈øed ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede: the roote is white on the out≈øide, and very like the yellow Moly; both roote, leafe, and flower hath a ≈ømacke, but not very ≈øtrong of Garlicke.

div.head: 5. Moly Narci≈øsinis folijs. Daffodill leafed Moly.
div.p:
This Moly hath many long, narrow, and flat greene leaues, very like vnto the leaues of a Daffodill, from whence it tooke his name (or rather of the early greater Leucoium
1 Moly Homericum vel potius Theophra≈øti. The greate≈øt Moly of Homer. 2 Moly Indicum ≈øiue Caucafon. The Indian Moly. 3 Moly Pannonicum bulbi≈øerum. The bulbed Moly of Hungary. 4 Moly Serpentinum. Serpents Moly. 5 Moly purpureum Neapolitanum The purpli≈øh Moly of Naples. 6 Moly caule & folijs triangularibus. The three cornered Moly. 7 Moly latifolium flore luteo. The yellow Moly. 8 Moly Dio≈øcorideum Hi≈øpanicum The Spani≈øh Moly of Dio≈øcorides. 9 Moly Zibettinum vel Mo≈øchatinum. The ≈øweete ≈ømelling Moly of Mompelier. 10 Moly ≈øer ‚Ä¢ tinum Coniferum. The late Pineapple Moly. depiction of flowers
bulbo≈øum, or bulbed Violet before de≈øcribed, ioyned next vnto the Daffodils, becau≈øe it is ≈øo like them) among which ri≈øeth vp two or three ≈øtalkes ≈øometimes, each of a foot and a halfe high, bearing at the toppe, inclo≈øed in a skinny ho≈øe, as all the Molyes haue, a number of ≈ømall purpli≈øh flowers, which doe not long abide, but quickly fade: the ≈øeede is blacke as others are; the roote is ≈øometimes knobbed, and more often bulbed, hauing in the knobs ≈øome markes of the old ≈øtalkes to be ≈øeene in them, and ≈ømelleth ≈øomewhat like Garlicke, whereby it may be knowne.

div.head: 6. Moly montanum latifolium luteo flore. The yellow Moly.
div.p: The yellow Moly hath but one long and broad leafe when it doth not beare flower, but when it will beare flower, it hath two long and broad leaues, yet one alwaies longer and broader then the other, which are both of the ≈øame colour, and neare the bigne≈ø≈øe of a rea≈øonable Tulipa leafe: betweene the≈øe leaues groweth a ≈ølender ≈øtalke, bearing at the toppe a tuft or vmbell of yellow flowers out of a skinnie ho≈øe, which parteth three wayes, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, laid open like a Starre, with a greeni≈øh backe or out≈øide, and with ≈øome yellow threeds in the middle: the ≈øeede is blacke, like vnto others: the roote is whiti≈øh, two for the mo≈øt part ioyned together, which encrea≈øeth quickly, and ≈ømelleth very ≈øtrong of Garlicke, as both flowers and leaues doe al≈øo.

div.head: 7. Moly Pyrenaeum purpureum. The purple mountaine Moly.
div.p: This purple Moly hath two or three leaues, ≈øomewhat like the former yellow Moly, but not ≈øo broad, nor ≈øo white: the ≈øtalke hath not ≈øo many flowers thereon, but more ≈øparingly, and of an vnplea≈øant purple colour: the roote is whiti≈øh, ≈ømelling ≈øomewhat ≈øtrongly of Garlicke, but quickly peri≈øheth with the extremity of our cold Winters, which it will not abide vnle≈ø≈øe it be defended.

div.head: 8. Moly montanum latifolium purpureum Hi≈øpanicum. The purple Spani≈øh Moly.
div.p: This Moly hath two broad and very long greene leaues, like vnto the yellow Moly, in this, that they doe compa≈ø≈øe one another at the bottome of them, between which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtrong round ≈øtalke, two foote high or more, bearing at the toppe, out of a thinne huske, a number of faire large flowers vpon long foot-≈øtalkes, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues a peece, ≈øpread open like a Starre, of a fine delayed purple or blu≈øh colour, with diuers threeds of the ≈øame colour, tipt with yellow, ≈øtanding about the middle head: betweene the ≈øtalke and the bottome of the leaues it hath ≈øome ≈ømall bulbes growing, which being planted, will ≈øoone ≈øpring and encrea≈øe: the roote al≈øo being ≈ømall and round, with many fibres thereat, hath many ≈ømall bulbes ≈øhooting from them; but neither roote, leafe, nor flower, hath any ill ≈øent of Garlicke at all.

div.head: 9. Moly purpureum Neapolitanum. The purple Moly of Naples.
div.p: The Neapolitan Moly hath three or foure ≈ømall long greene leaues ≈øet vpon the ≈øtalke after it is ri≈øen vp, which beareth a round head of very fine purple flowers, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, but ≈øo clo≈øing together at the edge, that they ≈øeeme like vnto ≈ømall cuppes, neuer laying them≈øelues open, as the other doe; this hath ≈øome ≈øent of his originall, but the roote more then any part el≈øe, which is white and round, quickly encrea≈øing as mo≈øt of the Molyes doe.

div.head: 10. Moly pyxidatum argenteum Hi≈øpanicum. The Spani≈øh ≈øiluer cupped Moly.
div.p:
This Spani≈øh Moly hath two or three very long ru≈øh like leaues, which ri≈øe vp with the ≈øtalke, or rather vani≈øh away when the ≈øtalke is ri≈øen vp to bee three foote high or more, bearing a great head of flowers, ≈øtanding clo≈øe at the fir≈øt, but afterwards ≈øpreading much one from another, euery flower vpon a long foote-≈øtalke, being of a white
≈øiluer colour, with ≈øtripes or lines on euery ≈øide, and fa≈øhioned ≈ømall and hollow, like a cuppe or boxe: the ≈øeede I could neuer ob≈øerue, becau≈øe it flowreth ≈øo late, that the Winter hindereth it from bearing ≈øeede with vs: the roote is ≈ømall and round, white, and in a manner tran≈øparent, at lea≈øt ≈øo ≈øhining, as if it were ≈øo, and encrea≈øeth nothing ≈øo much, as many of the other ≈øorts: this hath no ill ≈øent at all, but rather a pretty ≈ømell, not to bee mi≈øliked.

div.head: 11. Moly ≈øerotinum Coniferum. The late Pineapple Moly.
div.p: This late Moly that was ≈øent me with the la≈øt de≈øcribed, and others al≈øo from Spain, ri≈øeth vp with one long greene leafe, hollow and round vnto the end, towards this end on the one ≈øide, breaketh out a head of flowers, enclo≈øed in a thinne skinne, which after it hath ≈øo ≈øtood a good while, (the leafe in the meane time ri≈øing higher, and growing harder, becommeth the ≈øtalke) breaketh, and ≈øheweth a great bu≈øh or head of buds for flowers, thicke thru≈øt together, fa≈øhioned very like vnto the forme of a Pineapple (from whence I gaue it the name) of the bigne≈øs of a Walnut: after this head hath ≈øtood in this manner a moneth or thereabouts, the flowers ≈øhew them≈øelues to bee of a fine delayed or whiti≈øh purple colour, with diuers ≈øtripes in euery of them, of the ≈øame cup-fa≈øhion with the former, but not opening ≈øo plainly, ≈øo that they cannot bee di≈øcerned to bee open, without good heede and ob≈øeruation. It flowreth ≈øo late in Autumne, that the early fro≈øts doe quickly ≈øpoile the beauty of it, and ≈øoone cau≈øe it to rotte: the roote is ≈ømall and round, and ≈øhining like the la≈øt, very tender al≈øo, as not able to abide our ≈øharpe Winters, which hath cau≈øed it vtterly to peri≈øh with me.

div.head: 12. Moly Dio≈øcorideum. Dio≈øcorides his Moly.
div.p: The roote of this ≈ømall Moly is tran≈øparent within, but couered with a thicke yellowi≈øh skinne, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of an Ha≈øell Nut, or ≈øomewhat bigger, which ≈øendeth forth three or foure narrow gra≈ø≈øie leaues, long and hollow, and a little bending downwards, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈ølender weake ≈øtalke, a foot and a halfe high, bearing at the toppe, out of a thinne skinne, a tuft of milke white flowers, very like vnto tho≈øe of Ram≈øons, which ≈øtand a pretty while in their beauty, and then pa≈ø≈øe away for the mo≈øt part without giuing any ≈øeede: this hath little or no ≈øent of Garlicke.
We haue another of this ≈øort that is le≈ø≈øer, and the flowers rounder pointed.

div.head: 13. Moly Dio≈øcorideum Hi≈øpanicum. The Spani≈øh Moly of Dio≈øcorides.
div.p: This Moly came vnto me among other Molyes from Spaine, and is in all things like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, but fairer, larger, and of much more beauty, as hauing his white flowers twice as great as the former; but (as it ≈øeemeth) very impatient of our Winters, which it could not at any hand endure, but quickly peri≈øhed, as ≈øome others that came with it al≈øo.

div.head: 14. Moly Mo≈øchatinum vel Zibettinum Mon≈øpelien≈øe. The ≈øweete ≈ømelling Moly of Mompelier.
div.p: This ≈øweete Moly, which I haue kept for the la≈øt, to clo≈øe vp your ≈øen≈øes, is the ≈ømalle≈øt, and the fine≈øt of all the re≈øt, hauing foure or fiue ≈ømall greene leaues, almo≈øt as fine as haires, or like the leaues of the Feather-gra≈ø≈øe: the ≈øtalke is about a foote high, bearing fiue or ≈øix or more ≈ømall white flowers, laid open like Starres, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, of an excellent ≈øweete ≈øent, re≈øembling Muske or Ciuet; for diuers haue diuer≈øly cen≈øured of it. It flowreth late in the yeare, ≈øo that if the precedent Summer bee either ouer moi≈øt, or the Autumne ouer early cold, this will not haue that ≈øweete ≈øent, that it will haue in a hot drie time, and be≈øides mu≈øt be carefully re≈øpected: for it will hardly abide the extremity of our ≈øharpe Winters.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The places of the≈øe Molyes, are for the mo≈øt part expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, or in their de≈øcriptions.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The time is ≈øet downe, for the mo≈øt part to bee in Iune and Iuly, the re≈øt later.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: To make further relation of names then are expre≈ø≈øed in their tiles, were needle≈ø≈øe; let the≈øe therefore ≈øuffice.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All the≈øe ≈øorts of Molyes are ≈ømall kindes of wilde Garlicke, and are to be v≈øed for the ≈øame purpo≈øes that the great Garden Garlicke is, although much weaker in their effects. For any other e≈øpeciall property is in any of the≈øe, more than to furni≈øh a Garden of variety, I haue not heard at all.

And thus much may ≈øuffice of the≈øe kindes for our Garden, re≈øeruing manie others that might be ≈øpoken of, to a generall worke, or to my Garden of Simples, which as God ≈øhall enable me, and time giue leaue, may ≈øhew it ≈øelf to the world, to abide the iudicious and criticke cen≈øures of all.

div.head: A≈øphodelus. The A≈øphodill.
div.p: THere remaine ≈øome other flowers, like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, to be ≈øpecified, which although they haue no bulbous rootes, yet I thinke them fitte≈øt to bee here mentioned, that ≈øo I may ioyne tho≈øe of neere≈øt ≈øimilitude together, vntill I haue fini≈øhed the re≈øt that are to follow.

div.head: 1. A≈øphodelus maior albus ramo≈øus. The great white branched A≈øphodill.
div.p: The great white A≈øphodill hath many long, and narrow, hollow three ≈øquare leaues, ≈øharpe pointed, lying vpon the ground round about the roote: the ≈øtalke is ≈ømooth, round, and naked without leaues, which ri≈øeth from the mid≈øt of them, diuided at the toppe into diuers branches, if the plant bee of any long continuance, or el≈øe but into two or three ≈ømall branches, from the ≈øides of the maine great one, whereon doe ≈øtand many large flowers Starre-fa≈øhion, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, whiti≈øh on the in≈øide, and ≈øtraked with a purpli≈øh line downe the back≈øide of euery leafe, hauing in the middle of the flowers ≈øome ≈ømall yellow threeds: the ≈øeede is blacke, and three ≈øquare, greater then the ≈øeede of Bucke wheate, contained in roundi≈øh heads, which open into three parts: the roote is compo≈øed of many tuberous long clogges, thicke≈øt in the middle, and ≈ømaller at both ends, fa≈øtened together at the head, of a darke grayi≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and yellow within.

div.head: 2. A≈øphodelus albus non ramo≈øus. The white vnbranched A≈øpodill.
div.p:
The vnbranched A≈øphodill is like vnto the former, both in leaues and flowers, but that the flowers of this are whiter, and without any line or ≈øtrake on the backe ≈øide,
and the ≈øtalkes are without branches: the rootes likewi≈øe are ≈ømaller, and fewer, but made after the ≈øame fa≈øhion.

div.head: 3. A≈øphodelus maior flore carneo. The blu≈øh coloured A≈øphodill.
div.p: This A≈øphodill is like to the la≈øt in forme of leaues and branches, and differeth in this, that his leaues are marked with ≈øome ≈øpots, and the flowers are of a blu≈øh or fle≈øh colour, in all other things alike.

div.head: 4. A≈øphodelus minimus albus. The lea≈øt white A≈øphodill.
div.p: This lea≈øt A≈øphodill hath foure or fiue very narrow long leaues, yet ≈øeeming three ≈øquare like the greate≈øt, bearing a ≈ømall ≈øtalke, of about a foote high among them, without any branches, and at the toppe a few white flowers, ≈øtraked both within and without, with a purpli≈øh line in the middle of euery leafe. The rootes are ≈øuch like tuberous clogges as are in the former, but much le≈ø≈øer.

div.head: 5. A≈øphodelus albus minor ≈øiue Fi≈øtulo≈øus. The little hollow white A≈øpnodill.
div.p: This little white A≈øphodill hath a number of leaues growing thicke together, thicker and greener then tho≈øe of the ≈ømall yellow A≈øphodill, or Kings Speare next following, among which ri≈øeth vp diuers round ≈øtalkes, bearing flowers from the middle to the toppe, Starre-fa≈øhion, with ≈ømall greene leaues among them, which are white on the in≈øide, and ≈øtriped on the backe with purple lines, like vnto the fir≈øt de≈øcribed: the ≈øeede, and heads containing them, are three ≈øquare, like the ≈øeede of the little yellow A≈øphodill: the rootes of this kinde are not glandulous, as the former, but ≈øtringie, long and white: the whole plant is very impatient of our cold Winters, and quickly peri≈øheth, if it be not carefully pre≈øerued, both from the cold, and much wet in the Winter, by hou≈øing it; and then it will abide many yeares: for it is not an annuall plant, as many haue thought.

div.head: 6. A≈øphodelus luteus minor, ≈øiue Ha≈øtula regia. The ≈ømall yellow A≈øphodill, or Kings ≈øpeare.
div.p: This ≈ømall yellow A≈øphodill, which is v≈øually called the Kings ≈øpeare, hath many long narrow edged leaues, which make them ≈øeeme three ≈øquare, of a blewi≈øh or whiti≈øh greene colour: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp three foote high oftentimes, be≈øet with ≈ømall long leaues vp vnto the very flowers, which grow thicke together ≈øpike-fa≈øhion one aboue another, for a great length, and wholly yellow, laid open like a Starre, ≈øomewhat greater then the la≈øt white A≈øphodill, and ≈ømaller then the fir≈øt, which when they are pa≈øt yeeld round heads, containing blacke cornered ≈øeede, almo≈øt three ≈øquare: the rootes are many long yellow ≈øtrings, which ≈øpreading in the ground, doe much encrea≈øe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe A≈øphodils doe grow naturally in Spaine and France, and from thence were fir≈øt brought vnto vs, to furni≈øh our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All the glandulous rooted A≈øphodils doe flower ≈øome in May, and ≈øome in Iune; but the two la≈øt doe flower, the yellow or la≈øt of them in Iuly, and the former white one in Augu≈øt and September, and vntill the cold and winter hinder it.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Their ≈øeuerall names are giuen them in their titles, as much as is fit for
this di≈øcour≈øe. For to ≈øhew you that the Greekes doe call the ≈øtalke of the great A≈øphodill
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and the Latines Albucum, or what el≈øe belongeth to them, is fitter for another worke, vnto which I leaue them.

The ba≈øtard A≈øphodils ≈øhould follow next in place, if this worke were fit for them; but becau≈øe I haue tyed my ≈øelfe to expre≈ø≈øe onely tho≈øe flowers and plants, that for their beauty, or ≈øent, or both, doe furni≈øh a Garden of Plea≈øure, and they haue none, I leaue them to a generall Hi≈øtory of plants, or that Garden of Simples before ≈øpoken of, and will de≈øcribe the Lilly A≈øphodils, and the Phalangia or Spider-worts, which are remaining of tho≈øe, that ioyne in name or fa≈øhion, and are to be here in≈øerted, before I pa≈ø≈øe to the re≈øt of the bulbous rootes.

div.head: 1. Lilia≈øphodelus phaeniceus. The gold red Day Lilly.
div.p: Becau≈øe the rootes of this and the next, doe ≈øo nearely agree with the two la≈øt recited A≈øphodils, I haue ≈øet them in this place, although ≈øome doe place them next after the Lillies, becau≈øe their flowers doe come neare≈øt in forme vnto Lillies; but whether you will call them A≈øphodils with Lilly flowers, as I thinke it fitte≈øt, or Lillies with A≈øphodill rootes, or Lillies without bulbous rootes, as others doe, I will not contend.

The red Day Lilly hath diuers broad and long fre≈øh greene leaues, folded at the fir≈øt as it were double, which after open, and remaine a little hollow in the middle; among which ri≈øeth vp a naked ≈øtalke three foot high, bearing at the toppe many flowers, one not much di≈øtant from another, and flowring one after another, not hauing lightly aboue one flower blown open in a day, & that but for a day, not la≈øting longer, but clo≈øing at night, and not opening againe; whereupon it had his Engli≈øh name, The Lilly for a day: the≈øe flowers are almo≈øt as large as the flowers of the white Lilly, and made after the ≈øame fa≈øhion, but of a faire gold red, or Orange tawny colour. I could neuer ob≈øerue any ≈øeede to follow the≈øe flowers; for they ≈øeeme the next day after they haue flowred, (except the time be faire and dry) to bee ≈øo rotten, as if they had lyen in wet to rotte them, whereby I thinke no ≈øeede can follow: the rootes are many thicke and long yellow knobbed ≈øtrings, like vnto the ≈ømall yellow A≈øphodill rootes, but ≈øomewhat greater, running vnder ground in like ≈øort, and ≈øhooting young heads round about.

div.head: 2. Lilia≈øhodelus luteus. The yellow Day Lilly.
div.p: I ≈øhall not neede to make a repetition of the de≈øcription of this Day Lilly, hauing giuen you one ≈øo amply before, becau≈øe this doth agree thereunto ≈øo nearely, as that it might ≈øeeme the ≈øame; the≈øe differences onely it hath, the leaues are not fully ≈øo large, nor the flower ≈øo great or ≈øpread open, and the colour thereof is of a faire yellow wholly, and very ≈øweet, which abideth blowne many daies before it fade, and hath giuen blacke round ≈øeede, growing in round heads, like the heads of the ≈ømall yellow A≈øphodill, but not ≈øo great.

Clu≈øius hath ≈øet downe, that it was reported, that there ≈øhould be another Lilia≈øphodill with a white flower, but we can heare of none ≈øuch as yet; but I rather thinke, that they that gaue that report might be mi≈øtaken, in thinking the Sauoye Spider-wort to be a white Lilia≈øphodill, which indeede is ≈øo like, that one not well experienced, or not well regarding it, may ≈øoone take one for another.

div.head: The Place.
