div.p: Their originall is many moi≈øt places in Germany.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in May and Iune.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
They are called by ≈øome Liliago, and Lilium non bulbo≈øum, and Lilia≈øphodelus.
1 A≈øphodelus maior albus ramo≈øus. The great white branched A≈øphodill. 2 A≈øphodelus minor albus ≈øeu fiflulo≈øus. The little hollow white A≈øphodill. 3 A≈øphodelus minor luteus, ≈øiue Ha≈øtula regia. The ≈ømall yellow A≈øphodill, or Kings ≈øpeare. 4 Lilia≈øphodelus luteus. The yellow Day Lilly. 5 Lilia≈øphodelus phaeniceus. The gold red Day Lilly. depiction of flowers
In Engli≈øh we call them both Day Lillies, but the name doth not ≈øo well agree with the la≈øt, as with the fir≈øt, for the cau≈øes aboue ≈øpecified.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The rootes of A≈øphodill hath formerly beene had in great account, but now is vtterly neglected; yet by rea≈øon of their ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe they open and clean≈øe, and therefore ≈øome haue of late v≈øed them for the yellow Iaundi≈øe. The Day Lillies haue no phy≈øicall v≈øe that I know, or haue heard.

div.head: Phalangium. Spider-wort.
div.p: THe≈øe plants doe ≈øo nearely re≈øemble tho≈øe that are la≈øt ≈øet forth, that I thinke none that knowes them, will doubt, but that they mu≈øt follow next vnto them, being ≈øo like vnto them, and therefore of the faire≈øt of this kinde fir≈øt.

div.head: 1. Phalangium Allobrogicum. The Sauoye Spider-wort.
div.p: The Sauoye Spider-wort ≈øpringeth vp with foure or fiue greene leaues, long and narrow, yet broader at the bottome, narrower pointed at the end, and a little hollow in the middle; among which ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtiffe ≈øtalke, a foote and a halfe high, bearing at the toppe one aboue another, ≈øeuen or eight, or more flowers, euery one as large almo≈øt as the yellow Day Lilly la≈øt de≈øcribed, but much greater then in any other of the Spider-worts, of a pure white colour, with ≈øome threeds in the middle, tipt with yellow, and a ≈ømall forked pointell: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels grow almo≈øt three ≈øquare, yet ≈øomewhat round, wherein is contained blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the rootes are many white, round, thicke, brittle ≈øtrings, ioyned together at the head, but are nothing ≈øo long, as the rootes of the other Phalangia or Spider-worts.

div.head: 2. Phalangium maius Italicum. album. The great Italian Spider-wort.
div.p: This great Spider-wort hath diuers long and narrow leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, and not ri≈øing vp as the former, and not ≈øo broad al≈øo as the former, but ≈øomewhat larger then tho≈øe that follow: the ≈øtalke is bigger, but ≈øeldome ri≈øeth vp ≈øo as the next, whereof this is a larger kinde, hauing a long vnbranched ≈øtalke of white flower, laid open like ≈øtarres as it hath, but ≈øomewhat greater: the rootes are long and white, like the next, but ≈øomewhat larger.

div.head: 3. Phalangium non ramo≈øum vulgare. Vnbranched Spider-wort.
div.p: The leaues of this Spider-wort doe ≈øeeme to bee little bigger or longer then the leaues of gra≈ø≈øe, but of a more grayi≈øh green colour, ri≈øing immediately from the head or tuft of rootes; among which ri≈øe vp one or two ≈øtalkes, ≈øometimes two or three foote long, be≈øet toward the toppe with many white Starre-like flowers, which after they are pa≈øt turne into ≈ømall round heads, containing blacke feede, like vnto the ≈øeed of the little yellow A≈øphodill, but le≈ø≈øer: the rootes are long white ≈øtrings, running vnder ground.

div.head: 4. Phalangium ramo≈øum. Branched Spider-wort.
div.p: The branched Spider-wort hath his leaues ≈øomewhat broader then the former, and of a more yellowi≈øh greene colour: the ≈øtalke hereof is diuer≈øly branched at the top, bearing many white flowers, like vnto the former, but ≈ømaller: the ≈øeedes and rootes are like the former in all things.

figure.head: 1 Phalangium Allobrogicum. The Sauoye Spider-wort. 2 Phalangium non ramo≈øum. Vnbranched Spider-wort. 3 Phalangium ramo≈øum. Branched Spider-wort. 4 Phalangium Ephemerum Virginianum. Iohn Trade≈øcante's Spider-wort.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth on the Hils neare vnto Sauoye, from whence diuers, allured with the beauty of the flower, haue brought it into the≈øe parts.
The ≈øecond came vp in my Garden, from the ≈øeede receiued out of Italy. The others grow in Spaine, France, &c.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The vnbranched Spider-wort mo≈øt commonly flowreth before all the other, and the branched a moneth after it: the other two about one time, that is, towards the end of May, and not much after the vnbranched kinde.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt (as I ≈øaid before) hath beene taken to be a white Lillia≈øphodill, and called Lilia≈øphodelus flore albo; but Clu≈øius hath more properly entituled it a Phalangium, and from the place of his originall, gaue him his other denomination, and ≈øo is called of mo≈øt, as is ≈øet downe in the title.

The other haue no other names then are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, but only that Cordus calleth them Liliago; and Dodonaeus, lib. 4. hist. plant. would make the branched kinde to bee Moly alterum Plinij, but without any good ground.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The names Phalangium and Phalangites were impo≈øed on the≈øe plants, becau≈øe they were found effectuall, to cure the poy≈øon of that kinde of Spider, called Phalangium, as al≈øo of Scorpions and other Serpents. Wee doe not know, that any Phy≈øitian hath v≈øed them to any ≈øuch, or any other purpo≈øe in our dayes.

div.head: 5. Phalangium Ephemerum Virginianum Ioannis Trade≈øcant. The ≈øoon fading Spider-wort of Virginia, or Trade≈øcant his Spider-wort.
div.p: This Spider-wort is of late knowledge, and for it the Chri≈øtian world is indebted vnto that painfull indu≈øtrious ≈øearcher, and louer of all natures varieties, Iohn Trade≈øcant (≈øometimes belonging to the right Honourable Lord Robert Earle of Salisbury, Lord Trea≈øurer of England in his time, and then vnto the right Honourable the Lord Wotton at Canterbury in Kent, and la≈øtly vnto the late Duke of Buckingham) who fir≈øt receiued it of a friend, that brought it out of Virginia, thinking it to bee the Silke Gra≈ø≈øe that groweth there, and hath imparted hereof, as of many other things, both to me and others; the de≈øcription whereof is as followeth:

From a ≈øtringie roote, creeping farre vnder ground, and ri≈øing vp againe in many places, ≈øpringeth vp diuers heads of long folded leaues, of a grayi≈øh ouer-worne greene colour, two or three for the mo≈øt part together, and not aboue, compa≈ø≈øing one another at the bottome, and abiding greene in many places all the Winter; otherwhere peri≈øhing, and ri≈øing anew in the Spring, which leaues ri≈øe vp with the great round ≈øtalke, being ≈øet thereon at the ioynts, v≈øually but one at a ioynt, broad at the bottome where they compa≈ø≈øe the ≈øtalke, and ≈ømaller and ≈ømaller to the end: at the vpper ioynt, which is the toppe of the ≈øtalke, there ≈øtand two or three ≈øuch like leaues, but ≈ømaller, from among which breaketh out a dozen, ≈øixteene, or twenty, or more round green heads, hanging downe their heads by little foot-≈øtalkes, which when the flower beginneth to blow open, groweth longer, and ≈øtandeth vpright, hauing three ≈ømall pale greene leaues for a huske, and three other leaues within them for the flower, which lay them≈øelues open flat, of a deepe blew purple colour, hauing an vmbone or ≈ømall head in the middle, clo≈øely ≈øet about with ≈øix reddi≈øh, hairy, or feathered threeds, tipt with yellow pendents: this flower openeth it ≈øelfe in the day, & ≈øhutteth v≈øually at
night, and neuer openeth againe, but peri≈øheth, and then hangeth downe his head againe; the greene huske of three leaues, clo≈øing it ≈øelfe againe into the forme of a head, but greater, as it was before, the middle vmbone growing to bee the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell, wherein is contained ≈ømall, blacki≈øh, long ≈øeede: Seldome ≈øhall any man ≈øee aboue one, or two at the mo≈øt of the≈øe flowers blowne open at one time vpon the ≈øtalke, whereby it ≈øtandeth in flowring a long time, before all the heads haue giuen out their flowers.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This plant groweth in ≈øome parts of Virginia, and was deliuered to Iohn Trade≈øcant.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth from the end of May vntill Iuly, if it haue had greene leaues all the Winter, or otherwi≈øe, vntill the Winter checke his luxuriou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Vnto this plant I confe≈ø≈øe I fir≈øt impo≈øed the name, by con≈øidering duely all the parts thereof, which vntill ≈øome can finde a more proper, I de≈øire may ≈øtill continue, and to call it Ephemerum Virginianum Trade≈øcanti, Iohn Trade≈øcante's Spider-wort of Virginia, or Phalangium Ephemerum Virginianum, The ≈øoone fading or Day Spider-wort of Virginia.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There hath not beene any tryall made of the properties ≈øince wee had it, nor doe we know whether the Indians haue any v≈øe thereof.

div.head: Colchicum. Medowe Saffron.
div.p: TO returne to the re≈øt of the bulbous and tuberous rooted plants, that remaine to bee entreated of, the Colchica or Medowe Saffrons are fir≈øt to bee handled, whereof the≈øe later dayes haue found out more varieties, then formerly were knowne; ≈øome flowring in the Spring, but the mo≈øt in Autumne, and ≈øome bearing double, but the greate≈øt part ≈øingle flowers: whereof euery one in their order, and fir≈øt of our owne Country kindes.

div.head: 1. Colchicum Anglicum album. The white Engli≈øh Medowe Saffron.
div.p:
It is common to all the Medowe Saffrons, except that of the Spring, and one other, to beare their flowers alone in Autumne or later, without any green leaues with them, and afterwards in February, their greene leaues: So that I ≈øhall not neede to make manie de≈øcriptions, but to ≈øhew you the differences that con≈øi≈øt in the leaues, and colours of the flowers; and briefly to pa≈ø≈øe (after I haue giuen you a full de≈øcription of the fir≈øt) from one vnto another, touching onely tho≈øe things that are note worthy. The white Engli≈øh Medowe Saffron then doth beare in Autumne three or foure flowers at the mo≈øt, ≈øtanding ≈øeuerally vpon weake foote-≈øtalkes, a fingers length or more aboue the ground, made of ≈øix white leaues, ≈øomewhat long and narrow, and not ≈øo large as mo≈øt of the other kindes, with ≈øome threeds or chiues in the middle, like vnto the Saffron flowers of the Spring, wherein there is no colour of Saffron, or vertue to that effect: after the flowers are pa≈øt and gone, the leaues doe not pre≈øently follow, but the roote remaineth in the ground without ≈øhew of leafe aboue ground, mo≈øt part of the Winter, and then in February there ≈øpring vp three or foure large and long greene
leaues, when they are fully growne vp, ≈øtanding on the toppe of a round, weake, green, and ≈øhort foote-≈øtalke, ≈øomewhat like the leaues of white Lillies, but not ≈øo large, and in the midde≈øt of the≈øe leaues, after they haue been vp ≈øome time, appeare two or three loo≈øe skinny heads, ≈øtanding in the middle of the leaues vpon ≈øhort, thicke, greene ≈øtalkes, and being ripe, conteine in them round ≈ømall browni≈øh ≈øeede, that lye as it were loo≈øe therein, and when the head is dry, may bee heard to rattle being ≈øhaken: the roote is white within, but couered with a thicke blacki≈øh skinne or coate, hauing one ≈øide thereof at the bottome longer then the other, with an hollowne≈ø≈øe al≈øo on the one ≈øide of that long eminence, where the flowers ri≈øe from the bottome, and ≈øhooting downe from thence a number of white fibres, whereby it is fa≈øtened in the ground: the greene leaues afterwards ri≈øing from the top or head of the roote.

div.head: 2. Colchicum Anglicum purpureum. The purple Engli≈øh Medowe Saffron.
div.p: There is no difference at all in this Medowe Saffron from the former, but only in the colour of the flowers, which as they were wholly white in the former, ≈øo in this they are of a delayed purple colour, with a ≈ømall ≈øhew of veines therein.

div.head: 3. Colchicum Pannonicum album. The white Hungary Medowe Saffron.
div.p: The greate≈øt difference in this Colchicum from the former Engli≈øh white one, is, that it is larger both in roote, leafe, and flower, and be≈øides, hath more ≈øtore of flowers together, and continuing longer in beauty, without fading ≈øo ≈øoone as the former, and are al≈øo ≈øomewhat of a fairer white colour.

div.head: 4. Colchicum Pannonicum purpureum. The purple Hungary Medowe Saffron.
div.p: This purple Medowe Saffron is ≈øomewhat like vnto the white of this kinde, but that it beareth not ≈øo plentifully as the white, nor doth the roote grow ≈øo great; but the flowers are in a manner as large as they, and of the like pale delayed purple colour, or ≈øomewhat deeper, as is in the purple Engli≈øh, with ≈øome veines or markes vpon the flowers, making ≈øome ≈øhew of a checker on the out ≈øide, but not ≈øo con≈øpicuous, as in the true checkerd kindes. Wee haue a kinde hereof is party coloured with white ≈øtreakes and edges, which abide con≈øtant, and hath been rai≈øed from the ≈øeede of the former.

div.head: 5. Colchicum Byzantinum. Medowe Saffron of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This Medowe Saffron of Con≈øtantinople hath his leaues ≈øo broad and large, that hardly could any that neuer ≈øaw it before, iudge it to be a Colchicum; for they are much larger then any Lilly leaues, and of a darke greene colour: the flowers are corre≈øpondent to the leaues, larger and more in number then in any of the former purple kindes, of the ≈øame colour with the la≈øt purple kinde, but of a little deeper purple on the in≈øide, with diuers markes running through the flowers, like vnto it, or vnto checkers, but yet ≈øomewhat more apparantly: the roote is in the middle greater and rounder then the others, with a longer eminence, whereby it may ea≈øily bee knowne from all other ≈øorts.

div.head: 6. Colchicum Lu≈øitanicum Fritillaricum. The checkerd Medowe Saffron of Portugall.
div.p:
The flowers of this Medowe Saffron are larger and longer then the flowers of either the Engli≈øh or Hungarian, and almo≈øt as large as the la≈øt before mentioned, and of the ≈øame colour, but a little deeper, the ≈øpots and markes whereof are ≈øomewhat more ea≈øie to be ≈øeene euen a farre off, like vnto the flower of a Fritillaria, from whence it tooke his ≈øignificatiue name: the leaues of this Medowe Saffron doe ri≈øe vp ≈øooner then in any other of the Autumne kindes; for they are alwayes vp before Winter, and are foure or fiue in number, ≈øhort rather then long, broad belowe, and pointed at the end, canaled or hollow, and ≈øtanding round aboue the ground, one encompa≈ø≈øing another at the bottome, like the great Spani≈øh Starre Iacinth, called the Iacinth of Peru,
1 Colchi um Pannonicum. The Hungarian Medow Saffron. 2 Colchicum Byzantinum. Medowe Saffron of Con≈øtantinople 3 Colchicum ‚Ä¢ u≈øitanicum Fritillaricum. The checkerd Medowe Saffron of Portugall 4 Colchicum Neapolitanum Fritillaricum. The checkerd Medowe Saffron of Naples. 5 Colchicum Fritillaricum Chien≈øe. The checkerd Medowe Saffron of Chio or Sio. 6 Colchicum He ‚Ä¢
modactylum. Phy≈øicall Medowe Saffron. depiction of flowers
but ≈øhorter, and of a pale or grayi≈øh greene colour, differing from the colour of all the other Medowe Saffrons: the roote is like the roote of the Engli≈øh or Hungarian without any difference, but that it groweth ≈øomewhat greater. It is one of the fir≈øt Medowe Saffrons that flower in the Autumne.

div.head: 7. Colchicum Neapolitanum Fritillaricum. The checkerd Medowe Saffron of Naples.
div.p: This checkerd Medowe Saffron of Naples, is very like vnto the la≈øt recited checkerd Saffron of Portugall, but that the flower is ≈øomewhat larger, yet ≈øometimes very little, or not at all: the greate≈øt marke to di≈øtingui≈øh them is, that the flowers of this are of a deeper colour, and ≈øo are the ≈øpots on the flowers likewi≈øe, which are ≈øo con≈øpicuous, that they are di≈øcerned a great way off, more like vnto the flowers of a deepe Fritillaria, then the former, and make a goodlier and a more glorious ≈øhew: the leaues of this doe ri≈øe vp early after the flowers, and are ≈øomewhat longer, of a darker greene colour, yet bending to a grayi≈øh colour as the other, not lying ≈øo neatly or round, but ≈øtand vp one by another, being as it were folded together: neither of both the≈øe la≈øt named checkerd Medowe Saffrons haue giuen any ≈øeede in this Countrey, that euer I could learne or heare of, but are encrea≈øed by the roote, which in this is like the former, but a little bigger.

div.head: 8. Colchicum Fritillaricum Chien≈øe. The checkerd Medowe Saffron of Chio or Sio.
div.p: This mo≈øt beautifull Saffron flower ri≈øeth vp with his flowers in the Autumne, as the others before ≈øpecified doe, although not of ≈øo large a ≈øize, yet farre more plea≈øant and delightfull in the thicke, deepe blew, or purple coloured beautifull ≈øpots therein, which make it excell all others what≈øoeuer: the leaues ri≈øe vp in the Spring, being ≈ømaller then the former, for the mo≈øt part three in number, and of a paler or fre≈øher greene colour, lying clo≈øe vpon the ground, broad at the bottome, a little pointed at the end, and twining or folding them≈øelues in and out at the edges, as if they were indented. I haue not ≈øeene any ≈øeede it hath borne: the roote is like vnto the others of this kinde, but ≈ømall and long, and not ≈øo great: it flowreth later for the mo≈øt part then any of the other, euen not vntill Nouember, and is very hard to be pre≈øerued with vs, in that for the mo≈øt part the roote waxeth le≈ø≈øe and le≈ø≈øe euery yeare, our cold Country being ≈øo contrary vnto his naturall, that it will ≈øcarce ≈øhew his flower; yet when it flowreth any thing early, that it may haue any comfort of a warme Sunne, it is the glorie of all the≈øe kindes.

div.head: 9. Colchicum ver≈øicolor. The party coloured Medowe Saffron.
div.p: The flowers of this Medowe Saffron mo≈øt v≈øually doe not appeare, vntill mo≈øt of the other Autumne ≈øorts are pa≈øt, except the la≈øt, which are very lowe, ≈øcarce ri≈øing with their ≈øtalkes three fingers breadth aboue the ground, but oftentimes halfe hid within the ground: the leaues whereof are ≈ømaller, ≈øhorter, and rounder, then in any of the other before ≈øpecified, ≈øome being altogether white, and others wholly of a very pale purple, or fle≈øh colour; and ≈øome againe parted, the one halfe of a leafe white, and the other halfe of the ≈øame purple, and ≈øometimes ≈øtriped purple and white, in diuers leaues of one and the ≈øame flower: and againe, ≈øome will be the mo≈øt part of the leafe white, and the bottome purple, thus varying as nature li≈øt, that many times from one roote may be ≈øeene to ari≈øe all the≈øe varieties before mentioned: the≈øe flowers doe ≈øtand long before they fade and pa≈ø≈øe away; for I haue ob≈øerued in my Garden ≈øome that haue kept their flower faire vntill the beginning of Ianuary, vntill the extremitie of the Winter fro≈øts and ≈ønowes haue made them hide their heads: the leaues therefore accordingly doe ri≈øe vp after all other, and are of a browni≈øh or darke greene colour at their fir≈øt ≈øpringing vp, which after grow to be of a deepe greene colour: the roote is like the former Engli≈øh or Hungarian kindes, but thicker and greater for the mo≈øt part, and ≈øhorter al≈øo.

div.head: 10. Colchicum variegatum alterum. Another party coloured Medowe Saffron.
div.p: There is another, who≈øe party coloured flowers ri≈øe a little higher, diuer≈øly ≈øtriped and marked, with a deeper purple colour, and a pale or whiti≈øh blu≈øh throughout all the leaues of the flower.

div.head: 11. Colchicum montanum Hi≈øpanicum minus. The little Spani≈øh Medowe Saffron.
div.p: The flowers of this little Medowe Saffron are narrower and ≈ømaller then any of the former, and of a deeper reddi≈øh purple colour then either the Engli≈øh or Hungarian kindes: the greene leaues al≈øo are ≈ømaller then any other, lying on the ground, of a deepe or ≈øad greene colour, ri≈øing vp within a while after the flowers are pa≈øt, and doe abide greene all the Winter long: the roote is ≈ømall and long, according to the re≈øt of the plant, and like in forme to the others.

div.head: 12. Colchicum montanum minus ver≈øicolore flore. The ≈ømall party coloured Medowe Saffron.
div.p: This little kinde differeth not from the Spani≈øh kinde la≈øt ≈øet forth, but in the varietie of the flower, which is as ≈ømall as the former; the three inner leaues being almo≈øt all white, and the three outer leaues ≈øome of them pale or blu≈øh, and ≈øome party coloured, with a little greene on the backe of ≈øome of them.

div.head: 13. Colchicum Hermodactilum. Phy≈øicall Medowe Saffron.
div.p: This Phy≈øicall Medowe Saffron ≈øpringeth vp with his leaues in Autumne, before his flowers appeare beyond the nature of all the former kindes, yet the flower doth, after they are vp, ≈øhew it ≈øelfe in the middle of the greene leaues, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix white leaues, with diuers chiues in the middle, and pa≈ø≈øeth away without giuing any ≈øeede that euer I could ob≈øerue; the greene leaues abide all the Winter and Spring following, decaying about May, and appeare not vntill September, when (as I ≈øaid) the flowers ≈øhew them≈øelues pre≈øently after the leaues are ≈øprung vp.

div.head: 14. Colchicum atropurpureum. The darke purple Medowe Saffron.
div.p: The greate≈øt difference in this kinde con≈øi≈øteth in the flower, which at the fir≈øt appearing is as pale a purple, as the flower of the former Hungarian kinde: but after it hath ≈øtood in flower two or three dayes, it beginneth to change, and will after a while become to bee of a very deepe reddi≈øh purple colour, as al≈øo the little foote-≈øtalke whereon it doth ≈øtand: the flower is of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the Hungarian purple, and ≈øo is the greene leafe: the ≈øeede and roote is like the Engli≈øh purple kinde.

div.head: 15. Colchicum atropurpureum variegatum. The party coloured darke purple Medowe Saffron.
div.p: We haue of late gained another ≈øort of this kinde, differing chiefly in the flower, which is diuer≈øly ≈øtriped thorough euery leafe of the flower, with a paler purple colour, whereby the flower is of great beauty: this might ≈øeeme to bee a degeneration from the former, yet it hath abiden con≈øtant with me diuers yeares, and giueth ≈øeede as plentifully as the former.

div.head: 16. Colchicum flore pleno. Double flowred Medowe Saffron.
div.p:
The double Medowe Saffron is in roote and leafe very like vnto the Engli≈øh kinde: the flowers are of a fine pale or delayed purple colour, con≈øi≈øting of many leaues ≈øet thicke together, which are ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, as in the Engli≈øh flower, being narrow and long, and as it were round at the points, which make a very double flower, hauing
≈øome chiues with their yellow tips, di≈øper≈øed as it were among the leaues in the middle: it flowreth in September, a little after the fir≈øt ≈øhew of the earlier Medowe Saffrons are pa≈øt.

div.head: 17. Colchicum variegatum pleno flore. The party coloured double Medowe Saffron.
div.p: We haue another of the≈øe double kinds (if it be not the very ≈øame with the former, varying in the flower as nature plea≈øeth oftentimes; for I haue this flower in my garden, as I here ≈øet it forth, euery yeare) who≈øe flowers are diuer≈øified in the partition of the colours, as is to be ≈øeene in the ≈øingle party coloured Medowe Saffron before de≈øcribed, hauing ≈øome leaues white, and others pale purple, and ≈øome leaues halfe white and halfe purple, diuer≈øly ≈øet or placed in the double flower, which doth con≈øi≈øt of as many leaues as the former, yet ≈øometime this party coloured flower doth not ≈øhew it ≈øelfe double like the former, but hath two flowers, one ri≈øing out of another, making each of them to be almo≈øt but ≈øingle flowers, con≈øi≈øting of eight or ten leaues a peece: but this diuer≈øity is not con≈øtant; for the ≈øame roote that this yeare appeareth in that manner, the next yeare will returne to his former kinde of double flowers againe.

div.head: 18. Colchicum Vernum. Medowe Saffron of the Spring.
div.p: This Medowe Saffron ri≈øeth vp very early in the yeare, that is, in the end of Ianuarie ≈øometimes, or beginning, or at the furthe≈øt the middle of February, pre≈øently after the deepe Fro≈øts and Snowes are pa≈øt, with his flowers inclo≈øed within three greene leaues, which opening them≈øelues as ≈øoone almo≈øt as they are out of the ground, ≈øhew their buds for flowers within them very white oftentimes, before they open farre, and ≈øometimes al≈øo purpli≈øh at their fir≈øt appearing, which neuer ≈øhew aboue two at the mo≈øt vpon one roote, and neuer ri≈øe aboue the leaues, nor the leaues much higher then they, while they la≈øt: the flower con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øix leaues, long and narrow, euery leafe being diuided, both at the bottome and toppe, each from other, and ioyned together onely in the middle, hauing al≈øo ≈øix chiues, tipt with yellow in the middle, euery chiue being ioyned to a leafe, of a pale red or deepe blu≈øh colour, when it hath ≈øtood a while blowne, and is a ≈ømaller flower then any Medowe Saffron, except the ≈ømall Spani≈øh kindes onely, but continueth in his beauty a good while, if the extremity of ≈øharpe Fro≈øts and Windes doe not ≈øpoile it: the leaues wherein the≈øe flowers are enclo≈øed, at their fir≈øt comming vp, are of a browni≈øh greene colour, which ≈øo abide for a while, e≈øpecially on the out≈øide, but on the in≈øide they are hollow, and of a whiti≈øh or grayi≈øh greene colour, which after the flowers are pa≈øt, grow to bee of the length of a mans longe≈øt finger, and narrow withall: there ri≈øeth vp likewi≈øe in the middle of them the head or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell, which is ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter, and harder then any of the former, wherein is contained ≈ømall round browne ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, ≈øomewhat like vnto the rootes of the former, but ≈øhorter, and not hauing ≈øo long an eminence on the one ≈øide of the bottome.

div.head: 19. Colchicum Vernum atropurpureum. Purple Medowe Saffron of the Spring.
div.p: The flower of this Medowe Saffron, is in the ri≈øing vp of his leaues and flowers together, and in all things el≈øe, like vnto the former, onely the flowers of this ≈øort are at their fir≈øt appearing of a deeper purple colour, and when they are blowne al≈øo are much deeper then the former, diuided in like manner, both at the bottome and toppe as the other, ≈øo that they ≈øeeme, like as if ≈øix loo≈øe leaues were ioyned in the middle part, to make one flower, and hath his ≈ømall chiues tipt with yellow, cleaning in like manner to euery leafe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
All the≈øe Medowe Saffrons, or the mo≈øt part of them, haue their places expre≈ø≈øed in their titles; for ≈øome grow in the fields and medowes of the champion grounds, others on the mountaines and hilly grounds. The Engli≈øh kindes grow in the We≈øt parts, as about Bathe, Bri≈øtow, Warmi≈øter,
1 Colchicum montamum Hi≈øpanicum. The little Spani≈øh Medowe Saffron. 2 Colchicum montanum minus ver≈øicolore flore. The ≈ømall party coloured Medowe Saffron. 3 Colchicum ver≈øicolor. The party coloured Medowe Saffron. 4 Colchicum variegatum alterum. Another party coloured Meadowe Saffron. 5 Colchicum atropurpureum. The darke purple Medowe Saffron. 6 Colchicum atropurpureum variegatum. The variable darke purple Meadowe Saffron. 7 Colchicum vernum, Medowe Saffron of the ≈øpring. 8 Colchicum flore pleno. Double Medowe Saffron. depiction of flowers
and other places al≈øo. The double kindes are thought to come out of Germany.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: Their times likewi≈øe are declared in their ≈øeuerall de≈øcriptions: tho≈øe that are earlie≈øt in Autumne, flower in Augu≈øt and September, the later in October, and the late≈øt in the end of October, and in Nouember. The other are ≈øaid to bee of the Spring, in regard they come after the deepe of Winter (which is mo≈øt v≈øually in December and Ianuary) is pa≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The generall name to all the≈øe plants is Colchicum, whereunto ≈øome haue added Ephemerum, becau≈øe it killeth within one dayes ≈øpace; and ≈øome Strangulatorium. Some haue called them al≈øo Bulbus agre≈øtis, and Filius ante Patrem, The Sonne before the Father, becau≈øe (as they thinke) it giueth ≈øeede before the flower: but that is without due con≈øideration; for the root of this (as of mo≈øt other bulbous plants) after the ≈øtalke of leaues and ≈øeede are dry, and pa≈øt, may be tran≈øplanted, and then it beginneth to ≈øpring and giue flowers before leaues, (and therein onely it is differing from other plants) but the leaues and ≈øeede follow ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely after the flowers, before it may be remoued againe; ≈øo that here is not ≈øeede before flowers, but contrarily flowers vpon the fir≈øt planting or ≈øpringing, and ≈øeede after, as in all other plants, though in a diuers manner.

The Colchicum Hermodactilum may ≈øeeme very likely to bee the Colchicum Orientale of Matthiolus, or the Colchicum Alexandrinum of Lobelius: And ≈øome thinke it to be the true Hermodactilus, and ≈øo call it, but it is not ≈øo. We doe generally call them all in Engli≈øh Medowe Saffrons, or Colchicum, according to the Latine, giuing to euery one his other adiunct to know it by.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: None of the≈øe are v≈øed for any Phy≈øicall re≈øpect, being generally held to be deadly, or dangerous at the lea≈øt. Only the true Hermodactile (if it be of this tribe, and not this which is here expre≈ø≈øed) is of great v≈øe, for paines in the ioynts, and of the hippes, as the Sciatica, and the like, to be taken inwardly. Co≈øtaeus in his Booke of the nature of plants, ≈øaith, that the rootes of our common kindes are very bitter in the Spring of the yeare, and ≈øweet in Autumne, which Camerarius contradicteth, ≈øaying, that he found them bitter in Autumne, which were (as he ≈øaith) giuen by ≈øome impo≈øters to diuers, as an antidote again≈øt the Plague.

div.head: Crocus. Saffron.
div.p:
THere are diuers ≈øorts of Saffrons, whereof many doe
‚Ä¢ ower in the Spring time, and ≈øome in Autumne, among whom there is but one onely kinde, that is called tame or of the Garden, which yeeldeth tho≈øe blades or chiues that are v≈øed in meates and medicines, and many wayes profitable for other re≈øpects, none of the re≈øt, which are all wilde kindes, giuing any blade equall vnto tho≈øe of the tame kinde, or for any other v≈øe, then in regard of their beautifull flowers of ≈øeuerall varieties, and as they haue been carefully ≈øought out, and pre≈øerued by diuers, to furni≈øh a Garden of dainty curio≈øity. To entreate therefore of the≈øe, I mu≈øt, to ob≈øerue an orderly declaration, diuide them into two primary families: the former ≈øhall be of tho≈øe that yeeld their plea≈øant flowers in the Spring of the yeare, and the other that ≈øend out
their colours in the Autumne, among whom that Rex pomarij (as I may ≈øo call it) the tame or manured kinde, properly called of the Garden, is to be comprehended, for that it giueth his plea≈øant flowers at that time among others. I ≈øhall againe di≈øtribute tho≈øe of the Spring time into three chiefe colours, that is, into white, purple, and yellow, and vnder euery one of them, comprehend the ≈øeuerall varieties that doe belong vnto them; which cour≈øe I will al≈øo hold with tho≈øe of the Autumne, that thus being rightly ranked, they may the more orderly be de≈øcribed.

div.head: 1. Crocus Vernus albus purus minor. The ≈ømaller pure white Saffron flower of the Spring.
div.p: This ≈ømall Saffron flower ≈øpringeth vp in the beginning of the yeare, with three or foure ≈ømall greene leaues, ≈øomewhat broader, but much ≈øhorter then the true Saffron leaues, with a white line downe the middle of euery leafe: betweene the≈øe leaues, out of a white skinne, ri≈øeth vp one or two ≈ømall flowers, made of ≈øix leaues a peece, as all the re≈øt in generall are, of a pure white colour, without any mixture in it, which abide not in flower aboue a weeke, or rather le≈ø≈øe, ≈øo ≈øodainly is the plea≈øure of this, and the purple lo≈øt: it flowreth not for the mo≈øt part, vntill a moneth after the yellow Crocus appeareth in flower, and the ordinary ≈øtript Crocus is pa≈øt: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, round, and reddi≈øh, yet not ≈øo red as the ≈øeede of the yellow, contained in three ≈øquare heads, yet ≈øeldome beareth, but encrea≈øeth by the roote plentifully enough, which is ≈ømall, round, and flat at the bottome, ≈øomewhat white on the out≈øide, but whiter within, ≈øhooting out ≈ømall ≈øprouts on euery ≈øide of the roote, which is the be≈øt note to know this kinde and the le≈ø≈øer purple, which are both alike, from all other rootes of Saffron flowers.

div.head: 2. Crocus albus maior multiflorus. The great ≈ønow white Crocus.
div.p: This greater Saffron flower ri≈øeth vp v≈øually with three or foure greene leaues, larger then the former, with a white line in euery one of them: the flowers are greater, and more in number, ri≈øing together, but flowring one after another, of a pure ≈ønow white colour, and abiding but little longer in flower then the former.

div.head: 3. Crocus albus maior alter dictus Ma≈øiacus. The great white Saffron flower or Crocus of Me≈øia.
div.p: This great white Crocus of Me≈øia, ri≈øeth vp out of the ground, almo≈øt as early as the fir≈øt ≈øort of the yellow, with foure or fiue leaues, being very like vnto the leaues of the yellow Crocus, and as large, with white lines in them: the flowers al≈øo are as large as the flowers of the yellow, and many al≈øo ri≈øing one after another like vnto it, but not of ≈øo pure a white colour, as the former or la≈øt de≈øcribed, but rather tending to a Milky or Creame colour: the roote is not couered with any reddi≈øh, but rather pale skinnes or coates.

div.head: 4. Crocus albus Mae≈øiacus fundo violaceo. The great white Crocus of Me≈øia with a blew bottome.
div.p: There is another of this kinde, like vnto the former in all things, ≈øauing that the bottomes of the flowers of this kinde, with ≈øome part of the ≈øtalke next the flower, are of a pale ≈øhining purple colour, and ri≈øing vp a pretty way into the flower; whereas another al≈øo of this kind, hath a little ≈øhew or marke of blew, and not purple, at the bottome of the flower onely, which maketh a difference.

div.head: 5. Crocus albus fundo purpureo. The white Crocus with a purple bottome.
div.p: This Saffron flower is of the ≈øame kinde with the fir≈øt, both in roote, leafe, and flower, in none of them differing from it, but in that the bottome of this flower, with that part of the ≈øhort foote-≈øtalke next vnto it, is of a violet or purple colour, and ≈øometimes hauing here and there ≈øome purple ≈ømall lines, or ≈øpots on the white leaues: it flowreth al≈øo with the fir≈øt white, or ≈øomewhat later.

div.head: 6. Crocus vernus albus ≈øtriatus. The white ≈øtript Crocus.
div.p: This ≈øtript Saffron flower is likewi≈øe neare the ≈øame fir≈øt kind, or fir≈øt white Crocus, hauing the like leaues and flowers, ≈øomewhat larger, but as ≈øoone fading almo≈øt as it: but herein this flower differeth, that it hath pale blewi≈øh lines and ≈øpots in all the leaues thereof, and more principally in the three outer leaues: the root is al≈øo white on the out≈øide, like the fir≈øt white, but greater, with young ones growing round about it.

div.head: 7. Crocus vernus albus polyanthos ver≈øicolor. The greater party coloured white Crocus.
div.p: The greater party coloured Saffron flower, hath his greene leaues like vnto the ≈øecond great white Crocus before mentioned, hauing more flowers then any of the former, except the fir≈øt great white, the leaues whereof haue greater ≈øtripes then the la≈øt recited Crocus, but of a purple Violet colour, making each leafe ≈øeeme oftentimes to haue as much purple as white in them: the roote hereof is ≈øomewhat like the ≈øecond white, but of a little more duskie colour on the out≈øide, and not budding out on the ≈øides at all, or very little.

div.head: 8. Crocus vernus albus ver≈øicolor. The le≈ø≈øer party coloured white Crocus.
div.p: The leaues and flowers of this other party coloured Crocus, are for bigne≈ø≈øe in a manner equall with the la≈øt, but hath not ≈øo many flowers ri≈øing together from the roote: the flower is finely marked with blew ≈øtrakes on the white flower, but nothing ≈øo much as in the former: the roote al≈øo is like the la≈øt.

div.head: 9. Crocus Epi≈øcopalis. The Bi≈øhops Crocus.
div.p: This party coloured or Bi≈øhops Saffron flower, is very like both in leaues and rootes vnto the Neapolitane blew Crocus, but ≈øomewhat greater: the flowers doe abide not ≈øo long time blowne, and hath all the leaues either wholly white, with blew ≈øtripes on both ≈øides of them, or wholly of a fine delayed blew Violet colour, and the three innermo≈øt more blew and finely ≈øtriped, both on the in≈øide and out≈øide of them, and ≈øometimes it hath been ≈øeen to haue three leaues white, and three leaues of a pale blew.

div.head: 10. Crocus vernus ≈øtriatus vulgaris. The ordinary ≈øtript Crocus.
div.p: There is another ≈øort of ≈øtript Saffron flower, which is mo≈øt common and plentifull in mo≈øt Gardens, which I mu≈øt needes bring vnder the ranke of the≈øe white kinds, although it differre very notably, both in roote, leafe, and flower, from all of them: the leaues of this ri≈øe vp ≈øooner then the yellow or white Crocus, lying ≈øpread vpon the ground for the mo≈øt part, but narrower then any of the former: among the≈øe leaues ≈øpring vp diuers flowers, almo≈øt as large as the former great white Crocus, of a very bleake or pale purple colour, tending to white on the in≈øide, and in many almo≈øt white; with ≈øome ≈ømall whiti≈øh chiues tipt with yellow in the middle: the three outer leaues are of a yellowi≈øh white colour on the backe ≈øide of them, ≈øtript euery one of them with three broad ≈øtripes, of a darke murrey or purple colour, and a little ≈øprinkled with ≈øome ≈ømall purple lines, on both ≈øides of tho≈øe ≈øtripes; but on the in≈øide, of the ≈øame pale purple or white colour with the re≈øt: the ≈øeede hereof is ≈øomewhat darker coloured then of the white, and is more liberall in bearing: the roote is differing from all the former, being rounder and bigger then any of them, except the kindes of Mi≈øia, yet ≈øomewhat flat withall, not hauing any ≈øhootes from the ≈øides, but ≈øetting off into rootes plentifully, hauing a round circle compa≈ø≈øing the bottome of the roote, which ea≈øily falleth away, when it is taken vp out of the ground, and couered with a browne coate, ≈øomewhat neare the colour of the yellow Crocus, but not altogether ≈øo bright: it flowreth v≈øually the fir≈øt of all the≈øe ≈øorts, or with the fir≈øt of the early yellowes.

figure.head: 1 Crocus vernus albus minor. The ≈ømall white Saffron flower of the ≈øpring. 2 Crocus vernus Ma≈øiacus albus. The great white Crocus of Mi≈øia. 3 Crocus vernus albus ≈øtriatur. The white ≈øtript Crocus. 4 Crocus vernus albus polyanthos ver≈øicolor. The party coloured white Crocus. 5 Crocus albus fundo purpure ‚Ä¢ . The white Crocus with a purple bottome. 6 Crocus vernus Neapolitanus. The great blew Crocus of Naples. 7 Crocus vernus purpureus maximus. The great purple Crocus. 8 Crocus vernus purpureus ≈øtriatus. The purple ≈øtript Crocus. 9 Crocus vernus purpureus Capillarifolio. The purple Crocus with ≈ømall leaues. 10 Crocus vernus flavus ≈øtriatus. The yellow ≈øtript Crocus. 11 Crocus vernus luteus ver≈øicolor. The cloth of gold Crocus.

div.head: 11. Crocus vernus ≈øtriatus Turcicus. The Turkie ≈øtript Crocus.
div.p: There is another of this kinde, who≈øe flower is a little larger, and of a deeper purple colour, both on the in≈øide and out≈øide; the greene leafe al≈øo is bigger, and of a more whiti≈øh colour.

div.head: 12. Crocus vernus Capillarifolio albus. The white Crocus with ≈ømall leaues.
div.p: This white Crocus is in all things like vnto the purple of the ≈øame kinde, but that the flower of this is wholly white: the full de≈øcription therefore hereof, you ≈øhall haue in that purple with ≈ømall leaues, of this kinde hereafter ≈øet downe, whereunto I referre you.

div.head: 13. Crocus vernus purpureus minor. The ≈ømaller purple Crocus.
div.p: The ≈ømaller purple Saffron flower of the Spring, hath his greene leaues ≈øo like vnto the fir≈øt white flowred Saffron, that they can hardly be di≈øtingui≈øhed, onely they ≈øeem to bee a little narrower: the flower is al≈øo much about the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe, or a little bigger, and ≈øeldome beareth aboue one flower from a roote, euen as the fir≈øt doth, of a deepe purple Violet colour, the bottome of the flower, with the vpper part of the ≈øtalke next thereunto, being of a deeper or blacker purple; in the middle of the flower are ≈øome pale chiues tipt with yellow pendents, and a longer pointell, diuided or forked at the toppe: the roote of this is in all things ≈øo like vnto the fir≈øt white, that it is impo≈ø≈øible for the mo≈øt cunning and conuer≈øant in them, to know the one from the other. This beareth ≈øeede very ≈øparingly, as the white doth, and is reddi≈øh like vnto it, but recompen≈øeth that defect with a plentifull encrea≈øe by the roote: it likewi≈øe flowreth at the very ≈øame time with the white, and endureth as ≈ømall a time.

div.head: 14. Crocus vernus purpureus maximus. The greate≈øt purple Crocus.
div.p: This great purple Crocus is of the ≈øame kinde with the next de≈øcribed, as well in roote as leafe, but greater; for the greene leaues hereof are the greate≈øt and broade≈øt of all other Crocus, with a large white line in the middle of euery one: it ≈øpringeth vp much later then the former, and doth not ≈øhew his flower vntill the other bee pa≈øt a good while: the flowers al≈øo are the large≈øt of all the≈øe Crocus of the Spring time, and equalling, if not ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing that purple kinde that flowreth in Autumne, hereafter ≈øet forth, of a very faire and deepe Violet colour, almo≈øt as deepe as the former: the ≈øeed ve≈ø≈øels are large al≈øo and white, wherein is contained pale reddi≈øh ≈øeede, like vnto the next blew kinde, but ≈øomewhat greater: the roote is (as I ≈øaid before) like vnto the next, that is, flat and round, with a duskie coloured out≈øide, who≈øe head for ≈øpringing in it is as hardly di≈øcerned.

Alter Apicibus albidis.We haue one of this kinde, the toppes onely of who≈øe purple flower are whiti≈øh, for the breadth of halfe the naile of a mans hand, which abideth con≈øtant euery yeare in that manner, and therefore is a difference fit to be remembred.

div.head: 15. Crocus vernus Neapolitanus ≈øiue caeruleus maior. The greater blew Crocus of Naples.
div.p: This great blew Crocus ri≈øeth vp with diuers greene leaues, broader then any of the former (except the la≈øt) with a white line running downe the in≈øide of euery leafe, as in the former, among which ri≈øeth vp, out of diuers great long white skinnes, diuers large flowers, but not fully ≈øo great as the former, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues, of a paler blew or Violet colour then in the former, hauing in the middle of the flowers a few pale threeds, tipt with yellow, and a longer pointell of a gold yellow colour, forked or diuided at the toppe, ≈ømelling ≈øweeter then in the former, and abiding a great while longer, being in flower v≈øually euen with the ≈øtript yellow Crocus, or before the former purple, and yeelding more plenty of ≈øeede: the roote hereof is not very great, but a little darke on the out≈øide, being round and flat withall, that one can hardly know which is the vpper≈øide thereof.

This kinde differeth very little from the former, either in roote, leafe, or flower,Crocus Neapolitanus pracocior. for the bigne≈ø≈øe or colour, but that it ≈øeemeth to be a little bleaker or paler blew, becau≈øe it flowreth a little earlier.

div.head: 16. Crocus vernus purpureus ≈øtriatus. The ≈øtript purple Crocus.
div.p: The leaues of this ≈øtript purple Saffron flower, are as large and broad as the la≈øt, of rather a little longer: the flowers al≈øo are as plentifull, and as large, of a fine delayed purple colour on the out≈øide, with three broad ≈øtrakes or lines downe the backe of the three outer leaues, and of a little deeper purple on the in≈øide, as the other three leaues are al≈øo of a deeper purple colour, and are ≈øtriped with the ≈øame deepe purple about the ground, or bottome of the leaues: this ≈øometimes yeelde three ≈øquare heads, containing in them browni≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is like vnto the la≈øt, and flowreth much about the time of the former.

div.head: 17. Crocus vernus purpureus ver≈øicolor. The ≈øiluer ≈øtript purple Crocus.
div.p: This ≈øtript Saffron flower, is in leaues and flowers ≈øomewhat like vnto the la≈øt ≈øtript purple, but a little ≈ømaller: the flowers are of a little deeper purple through the whole leaues, ≈øtriped with white lines, both on the leaues, and towards the edges, which maketh a peculiar difference from all the re≈øt: the roote of this is not ≈øo flat, though like it, and couered with a darke a≈øh coloured skinne: it flowreth about the ≈øame time.

div.head: 18. Crocus purpureus flammeus maior. The greater purple flame coloured Crocus.
div.p: The greene leaues of this Crocus or Saffron flower, are of a rea≈øonable breadth and length, and of a plea≈øant fre≈øh greenne≈ø≈øe, with a faire broad white line downe the middle of them, but ri≈øing not out of the ground ≈øo early as the next de≈øcribed Crocus: the flowers are likewi≈øe of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe, of a pale purple on the out≈øide, ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh, e≈øpecially the three outer leaues; but on the in≈øide of a deeper purple, and ≈øtriped with great ≈øtripes like flames, hauing ≈øome chiues in the middle, and a longer one al≈øo feathered a little at the toppe: the roote is white on the out≈øide, ≈øomewhat flat and round, but not ≈øo flat as the Neapolitane Crocus before de≈øcribed.

div.head: 19. Crocus purpureus flammeus minor. The le≈ø≈øer purple flame coloured Crocus.
div.p: This Crocus hath almo≈øt as broad and long greene leaues as the former, and of the ≈øame verdure, which ri≈øe vp earlier then it, and is in flower likewi≈øe ≈øomewhat before it, being ≈ømaller for ≈øize by a little, but of as deepe a purple on the out≈øide, as on the in≈øide, flamed with faire broad ≈øtripes from the middle of the leaues, or ≈øomewhat lower vnto the edges: each of the≈øe giue ≈øeed that is of a pale reddi≈øh colour: the root is very like vnto the former, but a little le≈ø≈øer.

div.head: 20. Crocus vernus purpureus Capillarifolio. The purple Crocus with ≈ømall leaues.
div.p:
This ≈ømall kinde of Saffron flower ri≈øeth out of the ground, with two or three long and ≈ømall green leaues, very like vnto the leaues of the fine Fether-Gra≈ø≈øe hereafter de≈øcribed, ≈øtanding vpright at the fir≈øt, but afterwards lying vpon the ground; among which come the flowers, ≈øometimes three, but mo≈øt v≈øually two vpon one ≈øtalke, if the roote be not young, which then will beare but one on a ≈øtalke, which is very ≈øhort, ≈øo that the flowers ≈øcarce ari≈øe aboue the ground, yet laying them≈øelues open in the day time, if it be faire, and the Sunne doe ≈øhine, otherwi≈øe they keepe clo≈øe, and doe not open at all: and after one flower is pa≈øt, which doth not la≈øt aboue three or foure dayes at the mo≈øt, the others follow, which are of a bleake blewi≈øh purple in the middle of the flower, and of a deeper purple towards the ends or points of the leaues, but of a more ≈øullen or darke purple on the out≈øide of them, and yellowi≈øh at the bottome, with ≈øome yellow chiues in the middle: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall and darker coloured then any of the former Crocus, contained al≈øo in ≈ømaller heads, ≈øtanding one by another
vpon the ≈øame ≈øhort foote-≈øtalke, which then ri≈øeth vp a little higher, ≈øhewing the maner of the ≈øtanding of the flowers, which in their flowring time could not ≈øo ea≈øily bee di≈øcerned: the roote is very ≈ømall and round, hauing one ≈øide at the bottome lower then the other, very like the roote of a Colchicum or Medowe Saffron, and ≈øomewhat neare re≈øembling al≈øo the hoofe of an hor≈øe foote, couered with a very thicke skinne, of a darke or blacki≈øh browne colour: this flowreth the la≈øt of all the former ≈øorts of Saffron flowers, euen when they are all pa≈øt.

div.head: 21. Crocus vernus purpureus ≈øtriatus Capillarifolio. The ≈øtript purple Crocus with ≈ømall leaues.
div.p: This ≈ømall ≈øtript purple Saffron flower hath ≈øuch like leaues, as the la≈øt de≈øcribed hath, betweene which ri≈øeth the flower vpon as ≈øhort a foote-≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues like the former, of a faire purple colour on the out≈øide of the three outer leaues, with three lines or ≈øtrakes downe euery leafe, of a deeper purple colour, and on the in≈øide of a paler purple, as the other three leaues are al≈øo, with ≈øome chiues tipt with yellow pendents, and a forked pointell in the middle: the roote of this is ≈øomewhat bigger then the former, and rounder, but couered with as thicke and as browne a skinne: it flowreth about the ≈øame time with the former.

div.head: 22. Crocus vernus luteus ≈øiue Mae≈øiacus. The yellow Crocus.
div.p: The yellow Crocus or Saffron flower, ri≈øeth vp with three or foure leaues out of the ground, being ≈øomewhat neare the breadth of the great purple kindes, with a white line in them, as in mo≈øt of the re≈øt: the flowers ≈øtand in the middle of the≈øe leaues, and are very large, of a gold yellow colour, with ≈øome chiues, and a forked point in the middle: the ≈øeede hereof is of a brighter colour then in any of the other: the roote is great and round, as great or greater then a Wall Nut ≈øometimes, and couered with reddi≈øh skinnes or coates, yeelding more ≈øtore of flowers then mo≈øt of the former, and beginning to blowe with the fir≈øt ≈øorts, or pre≈øently after, but outla≈øt many of them, and are of a plea≈øant good ≈øent.
Flore aureo.Of this kinde we haue ≈øome, who≈øe flowers are of a deeper gold yellow colour then others, ≈øo that they appeare reddi≈øh withall.
Flore pallido.And we haue al≈øo another ≈øort, who≈øe flowers are very pale, betweene a white and a yellow, not differing in any thing el≈øe.
Flore viridante luteo.And another ≈ømaller, who≈øe flower hath a ≈øhew of greenne≈ø≈øe in the yellow, and more greene at the bottome.

div.head: 23. Crocus vernus flavus ≈øtriatus. The yellow ≈øtript Crocus.
div.p: This kinde of yellow ≈øtript Crocus or Saffron flower, ri≈øeth vp with more ≈øtore of narrower and greener leaues then the former, and after the leaues are ≈øpread, there ri≈øe vp many yellow flowers from among them, which are not of ≈øo faire and bright a yellow colour, but more dead and ≈øullen, hauing on the back≈øide of each of the three outtermo≈øt leaues, three ≈ømall ≈øtripes, of an ouer-worne or dull purple colour, with ≈øome chiues and a pointell in the middle: the roote of this kinde, is very like the roote of the former yellow, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter, and couered with the like reddi≈øh skinnes, but a little ≈øadder: it flowreth not ≈øo early as the former yellow, but abideth almo≈øt as long as it.

div.head: 24. Crocus vernus luteus ver≈øicolor primus. The be≈øt cloth of gold Crocus.
div.p:
The faire≈øt cloth of gold Crocus or Saffron flower, ri≈øeth vp very early, euen with the fir≈øt, or the fir≈øt of all other Crocus, with three or foure very narrow and ≈øhort leaues, of a whiter colour then any of the former, which by and by after doe ≈øhew forth the flowers, ri≈øing from among them out of the ≈øame white skinne, which includeth the leaues, but are not ≈øo plentifull as the former yellow, being but two or three at the mo≈øt, of a faire gold yellow colour, yet ≈øomewhat paler then the fir≈øt, hauing
on the backe of euery of the three outer leaues, three faire and great ≈øtripes, of a faire deepe purple colour, with ≈øome ≈ømall lines at the ≈øides or edges of tho≈øe purple ≈øtripes; on the in≈øide of the≈øe flowers, there is no ≈øigne or ≈øhew of any line or ≈øpot, but wholly of a faire gold yellow, with chiues and a fethertopt pointell in the middle: the ≈øeede hereof is like the former, but not ≈øo red: the roote of this kinde is ea≈øily knowne from the roote of any other Saffron flower, becau≈øe the outer peelings or ≈øhels being hard, are as it were netted on the out≈øide, hauing certaine ribbes, ri≈øing vp higher then the re≈øt of the skinnes, diuided in the forme of a net-worke, of a darke browne colour, and is ≈ømaller and rounder then the former yellow, and not encrea≈øing ≈øo plentifully by the roote.

div.head: 25. Crocus vernus luteus ver≈øicolor alter. The ≈øecond cloth of gold, or Duke Crocus.
div.p: There is no difference either in roote, leafe, or colour of flower, or time of flowring in this ≈øort from the la≈øt before mentioned; for the flower of this is of the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe and colour, the only note of difference is in the marking of the three outer leaues, which haue not three ≈øtripes like the former, but are wholly of the ≈øame deepe purple colour on the backe of them, ≈øauing that the edges of them are yellow, which is the forme of a Duke Tulipa, and from thence it tooke the name of a Duke Crocus.

div.head: 26. Crocus vernus ver≈øicolor pallideluteus. The pale cloth of gold Crocus.
div.p: We haue a third ≈øort of this kinde of cloth of gold Crocus, which hath leaues and flowers like the former, but differeth in this, that the colour of the flower is of a paler yellow by much, but ≈øtript in the ≈øame manner as the fir≈øt, but with a fainter purple colour: the roote al≈øo is netted like them, to ≈øhew that this is but a variation of the ≈øame kinde.

div.head: 27. Crocus vernus ver≈øicolor albidoluteus. The cloth of ≈øiluer Crocus.
div.p: The chiefe≈øt note of difference in this Saffron flower is, that being as large a flower as any of the former of this kinde, it is of ≈øo pale a yellowi≈øh white, that it is more white then yellow, which ≈øome doe call a butter colour: the three outer leaues are ≈øtriped on the backe of them, with a paler purple blew ≈øhining colour, the bottome of the flower, and the vpper part of the ≈øtalke, being of the ≈øame purple blew colour: the roote of this is al≈øo netted as the other, to ≈øhew it is a variety of the ≈øame kinde.
And thus much for tho≈øe Saffron flowers that come in the Spring time; now to tho≈øe that flower in Autumne onely: and fir≈øt of the true Saffron.

div.head: 1. Crocus verus ≈øativus Autumnalis. The true Saffron.
div.p: The true Saffron that is v≈øed in meates and medicines, ≈øhooteth out his narrow long greene leaues fir≈øt, and after a while the flowers in the middle of them appeare about the end of Augu≈øt, in September and October, according to the ≈øoile, and climate where they growe; the≈øe flowers are as large as any of the other former or later ≈øorts, compo≈øed of ≈øix leaues a peece, of a murrey or reddi≈øh purple colour, hauing a ≈øhew of blew in them: in the middle of the≈øe flowers there are ≈øome ≈ømall yellow chiues ≈øtanding vpright, which are as vnprofitable, as the chiues in any other of the wilde Saffrons, before or hereafter ≈øpecified; but be≈øides the≈øe, each flower hath two, three, or foure greater and longer chiues, hanging downe vpon or betweene the leaues, which are of a fierie red colour, and are the true blades of Saffron, which are v≈øed phy≈øically or otherwi≈øe, and no other: All the≈øe blades being pickt from the ≈øeuerall flowers, are laid and pre≈ø≈øed together into cakes, and afterwards dryed very warily on a Kill to pre≈øerue them; as they are to be ≈øeene in the ≈øhops where they are ≈øold. I neuer heard that euer it gaue ≈øeede with any: the roote groweth often to be as great, or greater then a green Wall Nut, with the outer ≈øhell on it, couered with a grayi≈øh or a≈øh-coloured skin, which breaketh into long hairie threeds, otherwi≈øe then in any other roote of Crocus.

div.head: 2. Crocus Byzantinus argenteus. The ≈øiluer coloured Autumne Crocus.
div.p: This Saffron flower ≈øpringeth vp in October, and ≈øeldome before, with three or foure ≈øhort greene leaues at the fir≈øt, but growing longer afterwards, and in the mid≈øt of them, pre≈øently after they haue appeared, one flower for the mo≈øt part, and ≈øeldome two, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues, the three outermo≈øt whereof are ≈øomewhat larger then the other three within, and are of a pale bleake blew colour, almo≈øt white, which many call a ≈øiluer colour, the three innermo≈øt being of a purer white, with ≈øome yellow chiues in the middle, and a longer pointell ragged or fethered at the toppe: this very ≈øeldome beareth ≈øeede, but when the yeare falleth out to bee very milde; it is ≈ømall, round, and of a darke colour: the roote is pretty bigge, and rounder then any other Crocus, without any flat bottome, and couered with a darke ru≈ø≈øet skinne.

div.head: 3. Crocus Pyrenaeus purpureus. The purple mountaine Crocus.
div.p: This purple Saffron flower of the Autumne, ri≈øeth vp but with one flower v≈øually, yet ≈øometimes with two one after another, without any leaues at all, in September, or ≈øometimes in Augu≈øt, ≈øtanding vpon a longer foote-≈øtalke then any kinde of Saffron flower, either of the Spring or Autumne, and is as large as the flower of the greate≈øt purple Saffron flower of the Spring, of a very deepe Violet purple colour, which decayeth after it hath ≈øtood blowne three or foure dayes, and becommeth more pale, hauing in the middle ≈øome yellow chiues, and a long fether topt pointell, branched, and ri≈øing ≈øometimes aboue the edges of the flowers: about a moneth after the flowers are pa≈øt, and ≈øometimes not vntill the fir≈øt of the Spring, there ri≈øeth vp three or foure long and broad greene leaues, with a white line in euery one of them, like vnto the fir≈øt purple Vernall kindes, which abide vntill the end of May or Iune: the roote is ≈ømall and white on the out≈øide, ≈øo like vnto the roote of the le≈ø≈øer Vernall purple or white Crocus, that it cannot be di≈øtingui≈øhed, vntill about the end of Augu≈øt, when it doth begin to ≈øhoot, and then by the early ≈øhooting vp a long white ≈øprout for flower, it may be knowne. I neuer could ob≈øerue it to giue any ≈øeede, the Winter (as I thinke) comming on it ≈øo quickly after the flowring, being the cau≈øe to hinder it.

div.head: 4. Crocus montanus Autumnalis. The Autumne mountaine Crocus.
div.p: The mountaine Saffron flower ≈øpringeth vp later then any of the former, and doth not appeare vntill the middle or end of October, when all the flowers of the former are pa≈øt, appearing fir≈øt with three or foure ≈øhort greene leaues, like vnto the Byzantine Crocus, and afterwards the flowers betweene them, which are of a pale or bleake blew tending to a purple, the foote-≈øtalkes of them bring ≈øo ≈øhort, that they ≈øcarce appeare aboue ground at the fir≈øt, but after two or three dayes they grow a little higher: the roote is very great and flat bottomed, couered with a grayi≈øh duskie coate or skinne, and encrea≈øeth very little or ≈øeldome.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The ≈øeuerall places of the≈øe Saffron flowers, are in part ≈øet downe in their titles; the others haue beene found out, ≈øome in one Countrey, and ≈øome in another, as the ≈ømall purple and white, and ≈øtript white in Spaine: the yellow in Me≈øia about Belgrade, the great purple in Italy; and now by ≈øuch friends helpes as haue ≈øent them, they pro≈øper as well in our Gardens, as in their naturall places. Yet I mu≈øt giue you this to vnder≈øtand, that ≈øome of the≈øe formerly expre≈ø≈øed, haue been rai≈øed vp vnto vs by the ≈øowing of their ≈øeede.

div.head: The Time.
div.p:
Their ≈øeuerall times are likewi≈øe expre≈ø≈øed in their de≈øcriptions; for ≈øome ≈øhew forth their plea≈øant flowers in the Spring, wherein for the three fir≈øt
1 Crocus vernus luteus vulgaris. The common yellow ≈øpring Crocus. 2 Crocus verus ≈øativus Autumnalis. The true Saffron. 3 Crocus Byzantinus argenteus. The ≈øiluer coloured Autumne Crocus. 4 Crocus Pyrenaeus purpureus. The purple mountaine Crocus. 5 Crocus montanus Autumnalis. The Autumne mountaine Crocus. 6 Si≈øyrinchium maius. The greater Spani≈øh Nut. depiction of flowers
moneths, our Gardens are furni≈øhed with the varietie of one ≈øort or another: the re≈øt in Autumne, that ≈øo they might procure the more delight, in yeelding their beauty both early and late, when ≈øcarce any other flowers are found to adorne them.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: I ≈øhall not neede to trouble you with an idle tale of the name of Crocus, which were to little purpo≈øe, nor to reiterate the former names impo≈øed vpon them; let it ≈øuffice that the fitte≈øt names are giuen them, that may di≈øtingui≈øh them one from another; onely this I mu≈øt giue you to vnder≈øtand, that the gold yellow Crocus or Saffron flower, is the true Crocus Mae≈øiacus, as I ≈øhewed before; and that neither the yellow ≈øtript, or cloth of gold (which wee ≈øo call after the Dutch name Gaud Laken) is the true Mae≈øiacus, as ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe; and that the great white Saffron flower, by rea≈øon of his likene≈ø≈øe vnto the gold yellow, is called Crocus albus Mae≈øiaci facie, or facie lutei, that is, The white Saffron flower that is like the Mae≈øiacus or yellow.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The true Saffron (for the others are of no v≈øe) which wee call Engli≈øh Saffron, is of very great v≈øe both for inward and outward di≈øea≈øes, and is very cordiall, v≈øed to expell any hurtfull or venemous vapours from the heart, both in the ≈ømall Pockes, Mea≈øels, Plague, Iaundi≈øe, and many other di≈øea≈øes, as al≈øo to ≈øtrengthen and comfort any cold or weake members.

div.head: Si≈øyrinchium. The Spani≈øh Nut.
div.p: I Can doe no otherwi≈øe then make a peculiar Chapter of this plant, becau≈øe it is neither a Crocus, although in the roote it come ≈øomewhat neare vnto that kinde that is netted; but in no other part agreeing with any the delineaments of a Saffron flower, and therefore could not be thru≈øt into the Chapter among≈øt them: neither can I place it in the forefront of the Chapter of the Iris bulbo≈øa, or bulbous Flowerdeluces, becau≈øe it doth not belong to that Family: and although the flower thereof doth mo≈øt re≈øemble a Flowerdeluce, yet in that no other parts thereof doe fitly agree thereunto, I haue rather cho≈øen to ≈øeate it by it ≈øelfe betweene them both, as partaking of both natures, and ≈øo may ≈øerue in ≈øtead of a bridge, to pa≈ø≈øe from the one to the other, that is, from the Crocus or Saffron flower, to the Iris bulbo≈øa or bulbous rooted Flowerdeluce, which ≈øhall follow in the next Chapter by them≈øelues.

The Spani≈øh Nut hath two long and narrow, ≈øoft and ≈ømooth greene leaues, lying for the mo≈øt part vpon the ground, and ≈øometimes ≈øtanding vp, yet bending downewards; betweene the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall ≈øtalke, halfe a foote high, hauing diuers ≈ømooth ≈øoft greene leaues vpon it, as if they were skinnes, through which the ≈øtalke pa≈ø≈øeth; at the toppe whereof ≈øtand diuers flowers, ri≈øing one after another, and not all flowring at once: for ≈øeldome ≈øhall you haue aboue one flower blowne at a time, each whereof doth ≈øo quickly pa≈ø≈øe and fade away, that one may well ≈øay, that it is but one dayes flower, or rather the flower of a few houres: the flower it ≈øelfe hath nine leaues, like vnto a Flowerdeluce, whereof the three that fall downe, haue in each of them a yellow ≈øpot: the other three, which in the Flowerdeluces are hollow and ridged, couering the other three that fall downe, in this ≈øtand vpright, and are parted at the ends: the three that ≈øtand vp in the middle are ≈ømall and ≈øhort; the whole flower is ≈ømaller then any Flowerdeluce, but of ≈øundry colours; for ≈øome are of an excellent skie colour blew, others of a Violet purple, others of a darker purple colour, and ≈øome white, and many others mixed, either pale blew and deepe purple, or white and blew
mixed or ≈øtriped together very variably, quickly fading as I ≈øaid before: the ≈øeede is enclo≈øed in ≈ømall cods, ≈øo thinne and tran≈øparent, that one may ea≈øily ≈øee, and tell the ≈øeeds as they lye, which are of a browni≈øh red colour: the roote is ≈ømall, blacki≈øh and round, wrapped in a thicke skinne or huske, made like vnto a net, or ≈øomewhat like vnto the roote of the cloth of gold Crocus: when the plant is in flower, it is found to haue two rootes one aboue another, whereof the vppermo≈øt is firme and ≈øound, and the vndermo≈øt loo≈øe and ≈øpongie, in like manner as is found in the rootes of diuers Orchides or Satyrions, Bee-flowers and the like, and without any good ta≈øte, or ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe at all, although Clu≈øius ≈øaith otherwi≈øe.

div.head: Si≈øyrinchium Mauritanicum. The Barbary Nut.
div.p: There is another of this kinde, not differing from the former in any other notable part, but in the flower, which in this is of a delayed purpli≈øh red colour, hauing in each of the three lower leaues a white ≈øpot, in ≈øtead of the yellow in the former, but are as ≈øoone fading as they.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The former doe grow very plentifully in many parts both of Spaine and Portugall, where Guillaume Boel, a Dutch man heretofore remembred often in this Booke, found them; of the ≈øundry colours ≈øpecified, whereas Clu≈øius maketh mention but of one colour that he found.

The other was found in that part of Barbary, where Fez and Morocco do ≈øtand, and brought fir≈øt into the Lowe-Countries: but they are both very tender, and will hardly abide the hard Winters of the≈øe colder regions.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth in May and Iune, the la≈øt not vntill Augu≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Si≈øyrinchium is generally impo≈øed vpon this plant, by all authors that haue written thereof, thinking it to bee the right Si≈øyrinchium of Theophra≈øtus: but concerning the Spani≈øh name Nozelha, which Clu≈øius ≈øaith it is called by in Spaine, I haue beene credibly enformed by the aforenamed Boel, that this roote is not ≈øo called in tho≈øe parts; but that the ≈ømall or common ≈øtript Crocus is called Nozelha, which is ≈øweete in ta≈øte, and de≈øired very greedily by the Shepheards and Children, and that the roote of this Si≈øyrinchium or Spani≈øh Nut, is without any ta≈øte, and is not eaten. And againe, that there is not two kindes, although it grow greater, and with more flowers, in tho≈øe places that are neare the Sea, where both the wa≈øhing of the Sea water, and the moi≈øture and ayre of the Sea, cau≈øeth the ground to bee more fertile. This I thought good, from the true relation of a friend, to giue the world to vnder≈øtand, that truth might expell errour.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The≈øe haue not been knowne to bee v≈øed to any Phy≈øicall purpo≈øe, but wholly neglected, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øome may eate them, as Clu≈øius reporteth.

div.head: Iris bulbo≈øa. The bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: THe Flowerdeluces that haue bulbous rootes are of two ≈øorts, the one greater then the other: the greater bearing larger and broader leaues and flowers, and the le≈ø≈øer narrower. But before I giue you the de≈øcriptions of the v≈øuall greater kindes, I mu≈øt needes place one or two in the fore-front that haue no fellowes; the one is called of Clu≈øius, his broad leafed Flowerdeluce, and the other a Per≈øian, ≈øomewhat like vnto it, which although they differ notably from the re≈øt, yet they haue the neare≈øt re≈øemblance vnto tho≈øe greater kindes, that come next after them.

div.head: Iris bulbo≈øa prima latifolia Clu≈øij. Clu≈øius his fir≈øt great bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce hath diuers long and broad leaues, not ≈øtiffe, like all the other, but ≈øoft and greeni≈øh on the vpper≈øide, and whiti≈øh vnderneath; among which ri≈øe vp ≈øometimes ≈øeuerall ≈ømall, ≈øhort, ≈ølender ≈øtalkes, and ≈øometimes but one, not aboue halfe a foote high, bearing at the top one flower a peece, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Flowerdeluce, con≈øi≈øting of nine leaues, whereof tho≈øe three that ≈øtand vpright, are ≈øhorter and more clo≈øed together, then in other ≈øorts of Flowerdeluces; the other three that fall downe, turne vp their ends a little, and tho≈øe three, that in other Flowerdeluces doe couer them at the bottome, ≈øtand like the vpright leaues of other Flowerdeluces, but are parted into two ends, like vnto two ≈ømall eares: the whole flower is of a faire blew, or pale skie colour in mo≈øt, with a long ≈øtripe in the middle of each of the three falling leaues, and in ≈øome white, but more ≈øeldome: the roote is rea≈øonable great, round and white, vnder the blacki≈øh coates wherewith it is couered, hauing many long thicke white rootes in ≈øtead of fibres, which make them ≈øeeme to be A≈øphodill rootes. The flower is very ≈øweete.

div.head: Iris bulbo≈øa Per≈øica. The Per≈øian bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Per≈øian Flowerdeluce is ≈øomewhat like vnto the former, both in roote and in leafe, but that the leaues are ≈øhorter and narrower, and the flower being much about the ≈øame fa≈øhion, is of a pale blew ru≈ø≈øeti≈øh colour, each of the three lower falling leaues are almo≈øt wholly of a browne purple colour, with a yellow ≈øpot in the middle of them: this as it is very rare, ≈øo it ≈øeldome beareth flowers with vs.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in many places of Spaine and Portugall, from whence I and others haue often had it for our Gardens, but by rea≈øon of the tenderne≈ø≈øe thereof, it doth hardly endure the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of our cold Winters, vnle≈ø≈øe it be carefully pre≈øerued.
The other is ≈øaid to come from Per≈øia, and therefore it is ≈øo entituled, and is as tender to be kept as the other.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth mo≈øt v≈øually not vntill May with vs, yet many times ≈øooner: but in Ianuary and February, as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, in the naturall places thereof.
The other is as early oftentimes when it doth flower with vs.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Becau≈øe Clu≈øius by good iudgement referreth the fir≈øt to the greater
kindes of Flowerdeluces, and placeth it in the fore ranke, calling it Iris bulbo≈øa latifolia prima, that is, The fir≈øt broad leafed Flowerdeluce, and all others doe the like, I haue (as you ≈øee) in the like manner put it before all the other, and keepe the ≈øame name. The Spaniards, as he ≈øaith, called it Lirio e≈øpadanal, and they of Corduba, Lirios azules.
The other hath no other name then as it is in the title.

div.head: 1. Iris bulbo≈øa maior ≈øiue Anglica caerulea. The blew Engli≈øh bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This bulbous Flowerdeluce ri≈øeth vp early, euen in Ianuary oftentimes, with fiue or ≈øix long and (narrow, in compari≈øon of any great breadth, but in regard of the other kinde) broad whiti≈øh green leaues, cre≈øted or ≈øtraked on the back≈øide, and halfe round, the in≈øide being hollow like a trough or gutter, white all along the in≈øide of the leafe, and blunt at the end; among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtiffe round ≈øtalke, a cubit or two foot high, at the toppe whereof, out of a skinnie huske, commeth forth one or two flowers, con≈øi≈øting of nine leaues a peece, three whereof that are turned downewards, are larger and broader then the other, hauing in each of them a yellow ≈øpot, about the middle of the leafe, other three are ≈ømall, hollow, ridged or arched, couering the lower part next the ≈øtalke of tho≈øe falling leaues, turning vp their ends, which are diuided into two parts, other three ≈øtand vpright, and are very ≈ømall at the bottome of them, and broader toward the toppe: the whole flower is of a faire blew colour; after the flowers are pa≈øt, come vp three ≈øquare heads, ≈øomewhat long, and lanke, or loo≈øe, containing in them round yellowi≈øh ≈øeede, which when it is ripe, will rattle by the ≈øhaking of the winde in the dry huskes: the roote of this kinde is greater and longer then any of the ≈ømaller kindes with narrow leaues, couered with diuers browne skinnes, which ≈øeeme to be fraught with long threeds like haires, e≈øpecially at the ≈ømall or vpper end of the roote, which thing you ≈øhall not finde in any of the ≈ømaller kindes.

div.head: 2. Iris bulbo≈øa maior purpurea & purpur ‚Ä¢ violacea. The paler or deeper purple great bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The≈øe purple Flowerdeluces differ not from the la≈øt de≈øcribed, either in roote or leafe: the chiefe≈øt difference con≈øi≈øteth in the flowers, which in the≈øe are ≈øomewhat larger then in the former, and in the one of a deepe blew or Violet purple colour, and in the other of a deepe purple colour, in all other things alike.
There is al≈øo another, in all other things like vnto the former, but only in the flower,Flore cinereo. which is of a pale or bleake blew, which we call an a≈øh-colour.

div.head: 3. Iris bulbo≈øa maior purpurea variegata ≈øiue ≈øtriata. The great purple ≈øtript bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: There is another of the purple kinde, who≈øe flower is purple, but with ≈øome veines or ≈øtripes of a deeper Violet colour, diuer≈øly running through the whole leaues of the flower.

And another of that bleake blew or a≈øh-colour,Flore cinereo ≈øtriata purpureo. Flore purpu ‚Ä¢ eo orbe cinereo. with lines and veines of purple in the leaues of the flowers, ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe then other.

And againe another, who≈øe flower is of a purple colour like vnto the ≈øecond, but that round about that yellow ≈øpot, in the middle of each of the three falling leaues (as is v≈øuall in all the bulbous Flowerdeluces) there is a circle of a pale blew or a≈øh-colour, the re≈øt of the leafe remaining purple, as the other parts of the flower is.

div.head: 4. Iris bulbo≈øa maior flore rubente. The great peach coloured bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: There is another of the≈øe greater kindes, more rare then any of the former, not differing in roote, leafe, or flower, from the former, but onely that the flower in this is of a pale reddi≈øh purple colour, comming ≈øomewhat neare vnto the colour of a peach blo≈ø≈øome.

div.head: 5. Iris bulbo≈øa maior ≈øiue latifolia alba. The great white bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The great white bulbous Flowerdeluce, ri≈øeth not vp ≈øo early out of the ground as the blew or purple doth, but about a moneth or more after, who≈øe leaues are ≈øomewhat larger, and broader then of the others: the ≈øtalke is thicker and ≈øhorter, bearing v≈øually two very large and great flowers, one flowring a little before the other, yet oftentimes both in flower together in the end, of a bleake blewi≈øh white colour, which wee call a ≈øiluer colour, while they are in the budde, and before they be blowne open, but then of a purer white, yet with an eye or ≈øhew of that ≈øiluer colour remaining in them, the three falling leaues being very large, and hauing that yellow ≈øpot in the middle of each of them: the ≈øeedes are likewi≈øe inclo≈øed in heads, like vnto the blew or purple kindes, but larger, and are of a reddi≈øh yellow colour like them: the roote likewi≈øe is not differing, but greater.

div.head: 6. Iris bulbo≈øa maior alba variegata. The great white ≈øtript bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This white ≈øtript Flowerdeluce, is in roote, leafe, and flower, and in manner of growing, like vnto the former white Flowerdeluce; the onely difference is in the marking of the flower, being diuers from it: for this hath in the white flower great veines, ≈øtripes, or markes, of a Violet blew colour, di≈øper≈øed through the leaues of the flower very variably, which addeth a ≈øuperexcellent beauty to the flower.

div.head: 7. Iris bulbo≈øa maior ≈øiue latifolia ver≈øicolor. The great party coloured bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p: There is no difference in this from the former, but in the flower, which is of a whiti≈øh colour in the three falling leaues, hauing a circle of a≈øh-colour about the yellow ≈øpot, the three rigged leaues being likewi≈øe whiti≈øh, but ridged and edged with that a≈øh-colour, and the three vpright leaues of a pale blewi≈øh white colour, with ≈øome veines therein of a blewi≈øh purple.

Varietas.There hath beene brought vnto vs diuers rootes of the≈øe kindes, with the dryed flowers remaining on them, wherein there hath beene ≈øeene more varieties, then I can well remember to expre≈ø≈øe, which variety it is very probable, hath ri≈øen by the ≈øowing of the ≈øeeds, as is truely ob≈øerued in the narrower leafed kinde of Flowerdeluce, in the Tulipa, and in ≈øome other plants.

Flore luteo.Wee haue heard of one of this kinde of broad leafed Flowerdeluces, that ≈øhould beare a yellow flower, in the like manner as is to be ≈øeene in the narrow leafed ones: but I haue not ≈øeene any ≈øuch, and therefore I dare report no further of it, vntill time hath di≈øcouered the truth or fal≈øhood of the report.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Lobelius is the fir≈øt reporter, that the blew Flowerdeluce or fir≈øt kinde of the≈øe broad leafed Flowerdeluces, groweth naturally in the We≈øt parts of England; but I am in ≈øome doubt of the truth of that report: for I rather thinke, that ≈øome in their trauels through Spaine, or other parts where it groweth, being delighted with the beauty of the flower, did gather the rootes, and bring them ouer with them, and dwelling in ≈øome of the We≈øt parts of England, planted them, and there encrea≈øing ≈øo plentifully as they doe, they were imparted to many, thereby in time growing common in all Countrey folkes Gardens thereabouts. They grow al≈øo, and all the other, and many more varieties, about Tholou≈øe, from whence Plantinianus Ga≈ø≈øanus both ≈øent and brought vs them, with many other bulbous rootes, and rare plants gathered thereabouts.

figure.head: 1 Iris bulbo≈øa latifolia prima Clu≈øii. Clu≈øius his fir≈øt great bulbous Flowerdeluce. 2 Iris bulbo≈øa maior caerulea ≈øiue Anglica. The great blew or Engli≈øh bulbous Flowerdeluce. 3 Iris bulbo≈øa maior purpurea variegata. The great purple ≈øtript bulbous Flowerdeluce. 4 Iris bulbo≈øa angu≈øtifolia maior alba. The greater white narrow leafed bulbous Flowerdeluce. 5 Iris bulbo≈øa angu≈øtifolia ver≈øicolor. The party coloured narrow leafed bulbous Flowerdeluce. 6 Iris bulbo≈øa angu≈øtifolia Africana. The purple African bulbous narrow leafed Flowerdeluce

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe doe flower v≈øually in the end of May, or beginning of Iune, and their ≈øeede is ripe in the end of Iuly or Augu≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Lobel calleth the fir≈øt Engli≈øh blew Flowerdeluce, Hyacinthus Poetarum flore Iridis, & propter Hyacinthinum colorem, id est violaceum dictus: but I know not any great good ground for it, more then the very colour; for it is neither of the forme of a Lilly, neither hath it tho≈øe mourning markes imprinted in it, which the Poet faineth to bee in his Hyacinth. It is mo≈øt truely called an Iris, or Flowerdeluce (and there is great difference betweene a Lilly and a Flowerdeluce, for the formes of their flowers) becau≈øe it an≈øwereth thereunto very exactly, for the flower, and is therefore called v≈øually by mo≈øt, either Iris bulbo≈øa Anglica, or Iris bulbo≈øa maior ≈øiue latifolia, for a difference betweene it, and the le≈ø≈øer with narrow leaues: In Engli≈øh, eyther The great Engli≈øh bulbous Flowerdeluce, or the great broad leafed bulbous Flowerdeluce, which you will, adding the other name, according to the colour.

And thus much for the≈øe broad leafed bulbous Flowerdeluces, ≈øo much as hath come to our knowledge. Now to the ≈øeuerall varieties of the narrow leafed bulbous Flowerdeluces, ≈øo much likewi≈øe as we haue been acquainted with.

div.head: Iris bulbo≈øa minor ≈øiue angu≈øtifolia alba. The ≈ømaller white or narrow leafed bulbous Flowerdeluce.
