div.p: This fir≈øt Flowerdeluce, which beareth the ≈ømaller flower of the two white ones, that are here to bee de≈øcribed, ≈øpringeth out of the ground alwaies before Winter, which after breaketh forth into foure or fiue ≈ømall and narrow leaues, a foote long or more, of a whiti≈øh greene on the in≈øide, which is hollow and chanalled, and of a blewi≈øh greene colour on the out≈øide, and round withall: the ≈øtalke of this kinde is longer and ≈ølenderer then the former, with ≈øome ≈øhorter leaues vpon it, at the toppe whereof, out of ≈øhort skinny leaues, ≈øtand one or two flowers, ≈ømaller, ≈øhorter, and rounder then the flowers of the former broad leafed Flowerdeluces, but made after the ≈øame proportion with nine leaues, three falling downewards, with a yellow ≈øpot in the middle, other three are made like a long arch, which couer the lower part next the ≈øtalke of tho≈øe falling leaues, and turne vp at the ends of them, where they are diuided into two parts: the other three ≈øtand vpright, betweene each of the three falling leaues, being ≈øomewhat long and narrow: the flower is wholly (≈øauing the yellow ≈øpot) of a pure white colour, yet in ≈øome hauing a ≈øhew of ≈øome blew throughout, and in others towards the bottome of the three vpright leaues: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there ri≈øe vp ≈øo many long cods or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, as there were flowers, which are longer and ≈ømaller then in the former, and a little bending like a Cornet, with three round ≈øquares, and round pointed al≈øo, which diuiding it ≈øelfe when the ≈øeede is ripe into three parts, doe ≈øhew ≈øix ≈øeuerall cells or places, wherein is contained ≈øuch like round reddi≈øh yellow ≈øeedes, but ≈ømaller then the former: the roote is ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter then the former, and without any haires or threeds, couered with browne thin skinnes, and more plentifull in giuing encrea≈øe.

div.head: Iris bulbo≈øa angui≈øtifolia alba flore maiore. The greater white narrow leafed bulbous Flowerdeluce.
div.p:
I ≈øhall not neede to make a ≈øeuerall de≈øcription to euery one of the≈øe Flowerdeluces that follow, for that were but to make often repetition of one thing, which being once done, as it is, may well ≈øerue to expre≈ø≈øe all the re≈øt, and but onely to adde the e≈øpeciall
differences, either in leafe or flower, for bigne≈ø≈øe, colour, or forme, as is expedient to expre≈ø≈øe and di≈øtingui≈øh them ≈øeuerally. This greater white bulbous Flowerdeluce is like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed in all parts, ≈øauing that it is a little larger and higher, both in leafe, ≈øtalke, and flower, and much whiter then any of the≈øe mixed ≈øorts that follow, yet not ≈øo white as the former: the roote hereof is likewi≈øe a little bigger and rounder in the middle.

Albe≈ø ‚Ä¢ ens. Milke white.There is another, who≈øe falling leaues haue a little ≈øhew of yellowne≈ø≈øe in them, and ≈øo are the middle ridges of the arched leaues, but the vpright leaues are more white, not differing in roote or leafe from the fir≈øt white.
Argentea. Siluer colour.And another, who≈øe falls are of a yellowi≈øh white, like the la≈øt, the arched leaues are whiter, and the vpright leaues of a blewi≈øh white, which we call a ≈øiluer colour.

Albida. Whiti≈øh.Another hath the fals yellowi≈øh, and ≈øometimes with a little edge of white about them, and ≈øometimes without; the vpright leaues are whiti≈øh, as the arched leaues are, yet the ridge yellower.

Albida labris luteis. White with yellow fals. Albida angustior. The narrow white.Another hath his fals yellow, and the vpright leaues white, all the≈øe flowers are about the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe with the fir≈øt.

But we haue another, who≈øe flower is ≈ømaller, and almo≈øt as white as the ≈øecond, the lower leaues are ≈ømall, and doe as it were ≈øtand outright, not hauing almo≈øt any fal at all, ≈øo that the yellow ≈øpot ≈øeemeth to be the whole leafe, the arched leaues are not halfe ≈øo large as in the former, and the vpright leaues bowe them≈øelues in the middle, ≈øo that the tops doe as it were meete together.
And another of the ≈øame, who≈øe falling leaues are a little more eminent and yellow, with a yellower ≈øpot.

Aurea ≈øiue lutea Hi≈øpanica. The Spani≈øh yellow.We haue another kinde that is called the Spani≈øh yellow, which ri≈øeth not vp ≈øo high, as ordinarily mo≈øt of the re≈øt doe, and is wholly of a gold yellow colour.
Pallide lutea. Straw colour.There is another, that v≈øually ri≈øeth higher then the former yellow, and is wholly of a pale yellow, but deeper as the ≈øpot.

Albida lutea. Pale Straw colour. Mauritanica flaua ≈øerotina minor. The ≈ømall Barbary yellow. Ver≈øicolor Hi≈øpanica caerulea labris albis. The party coloured Spani≈øhThere is al≈øo another like vnto the pale yellow, but that the falling leaues are whiter then all the re≈øt of the flower.

There is a ≈ømaller or dwarfe kinde, brought from the backe parts of Barbary, neare the Sea, like vnto the yellow, but ≈ømaller and lower, and in ≈øtead of vpright leaues, hath ≈ømall ≈øhort leaues like haires: it flowreth very late, after all others haue almo≈øt giuen their ≈øeede.

We haue another ≈øort is called the party coloured Spani≈øh bulbous Flowerdeluce, who≈øe falling leaues are white, the arched leaues of a whiti≈øh ≈øiluer colour, and the vpright leaues of a fine blewi≈øh purple.

Yet ≈øometimes this doth vary; for the falling leaues will haue either an edge of blew, circling the white leaues, the arched leaues being a little blewer, Diuer≈øitas. The diuer≈øity or variation of this flower. and the vpright leaues more purple.
Or the fals will be almo≈øt wholly blew, edged with a blewer colour, the arched leaues pale blew, and the vpright leaues of a purpli≈øh blew Violet colour.
Or the fals white, the arched leaues pale white, as the vpright leaues are.
Or not of ≈øo faire a blewi≈øh purple, as the fir≈øt ≈øort is.

Some of them al≈øo will haue larger flowers then others, and be more liberall in bearing flowers: for the fir≈øt ≈øort, which is the mo≈øt ordinary, ≈øeldome beareth aboue one flower on a ≈øtalke, yet ≈øometimes two. And of the others there are ≈øome that wil beare v≈øually two and three flowers, yet ≈øome againe will beare but one. All the≈øe kindes ≈ømell ≈øweeter then many of the other, Caerulea ≈øiue purpurea minor Lu≈øitanica praecox. The ≈ømall early purple Portugall. although the mo≈øt part be without ≈øent.

There is another kinde, that is ≈ømaller in all the parts thereof then the former, the ≈øtalke is ≈ølender, and not ≈øo high, bearing at the toppe one or two ≈ømall flowers, all wholly of a faire blewi≈øh purple, with a yellow ≈øpot
in euery one of the three falling leaues, this v≈øually flowreth early, euen with the fir≈øt bulbous Flowerdeluces.

Purpurea maior. The greater purple.We haue another purple, who≈øe flower is larger, and ≈øtalke higher, and is of a very reddi≈øh purple colour, a little aboue the ground, at the foote or bottome of the leaues and ≈øtalke: this flowreth with the later ≈øort of Flowerdeluces.
Purpurea ≈øerotina The late purple.There is another, who≈øe flower is wholly purple, except the yellow ≈øpot, and flowreth later then any of the other purples.

Purpura rube≈øcens labris caeruleis. A reddi≈øh purple with blew fals. Purpura rube≈øcens labris albido caruleis. A reddi≈øh purple with whiti≈øh blew fals. Purpurea labris luteis. Party coloured purple & yellow Purpurea labris ex albido caruleo & luteo mixtis. Party coloured purple with ≈øtript yellow fals. Sub purpurea labris luteis. Pale purple with yellow fals. A paler purple. Subcaerulea labris luteis. Party coloured blew and yellow Cri ‚Ä¢ is coloris el ‚Ä¢
gantioris. A faire haire colour. Altera ob≈øoletior. A dull haire colour.There is yet another purple, who≈øe vpright leaues are of a reddi≈øh purple, and the falling leaues of a blew colour.
And another of a reddi≈øh purple, who≈øe falling leaues are of a whiti≈øh blew colour, in nothing el≈øe differing from the la≈øt.

Another hath his falling leaues of a faire gold yellow, without any ≈øtripe, yet in ≈øome there are veines running through the yellow leaues, and ≈øome haue an edge of a ≈øullen darke colour about them: the vpright leaues in euery of the≈øe, are of a Violet purple.
Another is altogether like this la≈øt, but that the falling leaues are of a pale blew and yellow, trauer≈øing one the other, and the arched leaues of a pale purpli≈øh colour.
Another hath his vpright leaues of a paler purple, and the falling leaues yellow.
And another little differing from it, but that the arched leaues are whiti≈øh.
Another who≈øe vpright leaues are of a pale blew, and the falling leaues yellow.
And another of the ≈øame ≈øort, but of a little paler blew.
We haue another ≈øort, who≈øe vpright leaues are of a faire browni≈øh yellow colour, which ≈øome call a Fuille mort, and others an haire colour; the falling leaues yellow.
And another of the ≈øame colour, but ≈øomewhat deader.

div.head: Iris bulbo≈øa Africana ≈øerpentariae caule. The purple or muricy bulbous Barbary Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce as it is more ≈øtrange (that is, but lately knowne and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by a few) ≈øo it is both more de≈øired, and of more beauty then others. It is in all re≈øpects, of roote, leafe, and flower, for the forme like vnto the middle ≈øort of the≈øe Flowerdeluces, onely the lowe≈øt part of the leaues and ≈øtalke, for an inch or thereabouts, next vnto the ground, are of a reddi≈øh colour, ≈øpotted with many ≈øpots, and the flower, being of a meane ≈øize, is of a deepe purpli≈øh red or murrey colour the whole flower throughout, except the yellow ≈øpot in the middle of the three lower or falling leaues, as is in all others.

Purpura caerulea ob≈øoleta labris fu≈øcis. The duskie party coloured purple.And la≈øtly, there is another ≈øort, which is the greate≈øt of all the≈øe narrow leafed Flowerdeluces, in all the parts of it; for the roote is greater then any of the other, being thicke and ≈øhort: the leaues are broader and longer, but of the ≈øame colour: the ≈øtalke is ≈øtronger and higher then any of them, bearing two or three flowers, larger al≈øo then any of the re≈øt, who≈øe falling leaues are of a duskie yellow, and ≈øometimes with veines and borders about the brimmes, of another dunne colour, yet hauing that yellow ≈øpot that is in all: the arched leaues are of a ≈øullen pale purpli≈øh yellow, and the vpright leaues of a dull or duskie blewi≈øh purple colour: the heads or hornes for ≈øeede are likewi≈øe greater, and ≈øo is the ≈øeede al≈øo a little.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe Flowerdeluces haue had their originall out of Spaine and Portugall, as it is thought, except tho≈øe that haue ri≈øen by the ≈øowing, and tho≈øe which are named of Africa.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe flower in Iune, and ≈øometimes abide vnto Iuly, but v≈øually not ≈øo early as the former broad leafed kindes, and are ≈øoone ≈øpoiled with wet in their flowring.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The ≈øeuerall names, both in Latine and Engli≈øh, are ≈øufficient for them as they are ≈øet downe; for we know no better.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is not any thing extant or to be heard, that any of the≈øe kindes of Flowerdeluces hath been v≈øed to any Phy≈øicall purpo≈øes, and ≈øerue onely to decke vp the Gardens of the curious.

And thus much for the≈øe ≈øorts of bulbous Flowerdeluces, and yet I doubt not, but that there are many differences, which haue ri≈øen by the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede, as many may ob≈øerue from their owne labours, for that euery yeare doth ≈øhew forth ≈øome variety that is not ≈øeene before. And now I will conuert my di≈øcour≈øe a while likewi≈øe, to pa≈ø≈øe through the ≈øeuerall rankes of the other kindes of tuberous rooted Flowerdeluces, called Flagges.

div.head: Iris latifolia tubero≈øa. The Flagge or Flowerdeluce.
div.p: THere are two principall kindes of tuberous or knobby rooted Flowerdeluces, that is, the fall and the dwarfe, or the greater and the le≈ø≈øer; the former called Iris maior or latifolia, and the other Iris minor, or rather Chamaeiris; and each of the≈øe haue their le≈ø≈øer or narrow leafed kindes to bee comprehended vnder them: Of all which in their order. And fir≈øt of that Flowerdeluce, which for his excellent beautie and raritie, de≈øerueth the fir≈øt place.

div.head: Iris Chalcedonica ≈øiue Su≈øiana maior. The great Turkie Flowerdeluce.
div.p:
The great Turkie Flowerdeluce, hath diuers heads of long and broad fre≈øh greene leaues, yet not ≈øo broad as many other of tho≈øe that follow, one folded within another at the bottome, as all other of the≈øe Flowerdeluces are: from the middle of ≈øome one of tho≈øe heads (for euery head of leaues beareth not a flower) ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtiffe ≈øtalke, two foote high, at the toppe whereof ≈øtandeth one flower (for I neuer ob≈øerued it to beare two) the large≈øt almo≈øt, but rare≈øt of all the re≈øt, con≈øi≈øting of nine leaues, like the others that follow, but of the colour almo≈øt of a Snakes skinne, it is ≈øo diuer≈øly ≈øpotted; for the three lower falling leaues are very large, of a deepe or darke purple colour, almo≈øt blacke, full of grayi≈øh ≈øpots, ≈øtrakes, and lines through the whole leaues, with a blacke thrume or freeze in the middle of each of them: the three arched leaues that couer them, are of the ≈øame darke purple colour, yet a little paler at the ≈øides, the three vpper leaues are very large al≈øo, and of the ≈øame colour with the lower leaues, but a little more liuely and fre≈øh, being ≈øpeckled and ≈øtraked with whiter ≈øpots and lines; which leaues being laid in water, will colour the water into a Violet colour, but if a little Allome be put therein, and then wrung or pre≈ø≈øed, and the iuice of the≈øe leaues dryed in the ≈øhadow, will giue a colour almo≈øt as deepe as Indico, and may ≈øerue for ≈øhadowes in limming excellent well: the flower hath no ≈øent that can be perceiued, but is onely commendable for the beauty and rarity thereof: it ≈øeldome beareth ≈øeedes in the≈øe cold Countries, but when it doth, it is contained in great heads,
being browni≈øh and round, but not ≈øo flat as in other ≈øorts, the roots are more browne on the out≈øide, and growing tuberous thicke, as all other that are kept in Gardens.

div.head: Iris Chalcedonica ≈øiue Su≈øiana minor. The le≈ø≈øer Turkie Flowerdeluce.
div.p: There is another hereof little differing, but that the leafe is of a more yellowi≈øh greene colour, and the flower neither ≈øo large or faire, nor of ≈øo per≈øpicuous markes and ≈øpots, nor the colour of that liuely (though darke) lu≈øtre.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe haue been ≈øent out of Turkie diuers times among other things, and it ≈øhould ≈øeeme, that they haue had their originall from about Su≈øis, a chiefe Citie of Per≈øia.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in May mo≈øt v≈øually, before any of the other kindes.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue been ≈øent vnto vs, and vnto diuers other in other parts, from Con≈øtantinople vnder the name of Alaia Su≈øiana, and thereupon it hath been called, both of them and vs, either Iris Chalcedonica, or Su≈øiana, and for di≈øtinction maior or minor: In Engli≈øh, The Turkie Flowerdeluce, or the Ginnie Hen Flowerdeluce, the greater or the le≈ø≈øer.

div.head: Iris alba Florentina. The white Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The great white Flowerdeluce, hath many heads of very broad and flat long leaues, enclo≈øing or folding one within another at the bottome, and after a little diuided one from another toward the top, thin edged, like a ≈øword on both ≈øides, and thicker in the middle: from the middle of ≈øome of the≈øe heads of leaues, ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtiffe ≈øtalk, two or three foot high, bearing at the top one, two, or three large flowers, out of ≈øeuerall huskes or skins, con≈øi≈øting of nine leaues, as all the other do, of a faire white colour, hauing in the middle of each of the three falling leaues, a ≈ømall long yellow frize or thrume, as is mo≈øt v≈øuall in all the ≈øorts of the following Flowerdeluces, both of the greater and ≈ømaller kindes: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come the ≈øeed, inclo≈øed in thicke ≈øhort pods, full fraught or ≈øtored with red roundi≈øh and flat ≈øeede, lying clo≈øe one vpon another: the roote is tuberous or knobby, ≈øhooting out from euery ≈øide ≈øuch like tuberous heads, lying for the mo≈øt part vpon or aboue the ground, and fa≈øtened within the ground with long white ≈øtrings or fibres, which hold them ≈øtrongly, and encrea≈øeth fa≈øt.Flore pallido. There is another like vnto this la≈øt in all things, ≈øauing that the colour of the flower is of a more yellowi≈øh white, which we v≈øually call a Straw colour.

div.head: Iris alba maior Ver≈øicolor. The white party coloured Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This variable Flowerdeluce is like vnto the former, but that the leaues are not ≈øo large and broad, the flower hereof is as large almo≈øt, and as white as the former, but it hath a faire li≈øt or line of a blewi≈øh purple downe the backe of euery one of the three vpright leaues, and likewi≈øe round about the edges, both of the vpper and lower leaues, and al≈øo a little more purpli≈øh vpon the ridge of the arched leaues, that couer the falling leaues: the roote hereof is not ≈øo great as of the former white, but a little ≈ølenderer and browner.

div.head: Iris Dalmatica maior. The great Dalmatian Flowerdeluce.
div.p:
This greater Flowerdeluce of Dalmatia, hath his leaues as large and broad as any of the Flowerdeluces what≈øoeuer, his ≈øtalke and flower doe equall his other proportion,
onely the colour of the flower is differing, being of a faire watchet or bleake blew colour wholly, with the yellow frize or thrum downe the middle of the lower or falling leaues, as before is ≈øaid to be common to all the≈øe ≈øorts of Flowerdeluces; in all other parts it little differeth, ≈øauing onely this is ob≈øerued to haue a ≈ømall ≈øhew of a purpli≈øh red about the bottome of the greene leaues.

div.head: Iris purpurea ≈øiue vulgaris. The common purple Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce, which is mo≈øt common in Gardens, differeth nothing at all from tho≈øe that are formerly de≈øcribed, either in roote, leafe, or flower for the forme of them, but onely that the leaues of this are not ≈øo large as the la≈øt, and the flower it ≈øelfe is of a deep purple or Violet colour, and ≈øometimes a little declining to redne≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially in ≈øome places.

Sometimes this kinde of Flowerdeluce will haue flowers of a paler purple colour,Purpurea pallidior ver≈øicolor. comming neare vnto a blew, and ≈øometimes it will haue veines or ≈øtripes of a deeper blew, or purple, or a≈øh-colour, running through all the vpper and lower leaues.
There is another like vnto this, but more purple in the fals,Caerulea labris purpureis. and more pale in the vpright leaues.

div.head: Iris A≈øiatica caerulea. The blew Flowerdeluce of A≈øia.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce of A≈øia, is in largene≈ø≈øe of leaues like vnto the Dalmatian, but beareth more ≈øtore of flowers on ≈øeuerall branches, which are of a deeper blew colour, and the arched leaues whiti≈øh on the ≈øide, and purpli≈øh on the ridges, but in other things like vnto it.
There is another neare vnto this, but that his leaues are a little narrower,Purpurea. and his flowers a little more purple, e≈øpecially the vpper leaues.

div.head: Iris Dama≈øcena. The Flowerdeluce of Dama≈øco.
div.p: This is likewi≈øe altogether like the Flowerdeluce of A≈øia, but that it hath ≈øome white veines in the vpright leaues.

div.head: Iris Lu≈øitanica biflora. The Portugall Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Portugall Flowerdeluce is very like the common purple Flowerdeluce, but that this is not ≈øo large in leaues, or flowers, and that it doth often flower twice in a yeare, that is, both in the Spring, and in the Autumne againe, and be≈øides, the flowers haue a better or ≈øweeter ≈øent, but of the like purple or Violet colour as it is, and comming forth out of purpli≈øh skins or huskes.

div.head: Iris Camerarij ≈øiue purpurea ver≈øicolor maior. The greater variable coloured purple Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The greater of the variable purple Flowerdeluces, hath very broad leaues, like vnto the leaues of the common purple Flowerdeluce, and ≈øo is the flower al≈øo, but differing in colour, for the three lower leaues are of a deepe purple colour tending to redne≈ø≈øe, the three arched leaues are of the colour with the vpper leaues, which are of a pale or bleake colour tending to yellowne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhadowed ouer with a ≈ømoakie purpli≈øh colour, except the ridges of the arched leaues, which are of a more liuely purple colour.

div.head: Iris purpurea ver≈øicolor minor. The le≈ø≈øer variable purple Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce differeth not in any thing from the la≈øt, but onely that it hath narrower greene leaues, and ≈ømaller and narrower flowers, el≈øe if they be both conferred together, the colours will not ≈øeeme to varie the one from the other any whit at all.

There is another ≈øomewhat neare vnto the≈øe two la≈øt kindes,Altera minus fuliginea. who≈øe huskes from
whence the flowers doe ≈øhoot forth, haue purple veines in them, and to haue the falling purpli≈øh leaues, and the three vpright leaues are not ≈øo ≈ømoakie, yet of a dun purple colour.

div.head: Iris caerulea ver≈øicolor. The blew party coloured Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This party coloured Flowerdeluce hath his leaues of the ≈øame largene≈ø≈øe, with the le≈ø≈øer variable purple Flowerdeluce la≈øt de≈øcribed, and his flowers diuer≈øly marked: for ≈øome haue the fals blew at the edges, and whiti≈øh at the bottome, the arched leaues of a yellowi≈øh white, and the vpright leaues of a whiti≈øh blew, with yellowi≈øh edges. Some againe are of a darker blew, with browni≈øh ≈øpots in them. And ≈øome are ≈øo pale a blew, that we may well call it an a≈øh colour: And la≈øtly, there is another of this ≈øort, who≈øe vpright leaue ‚Ä¢ are of a faire pale blew, with yellowi≈øh edges, and the falling leaues parted into two colours, ≈øometimes equally in the halfe, each ≈øide ≈øutable to the other in colour: And ≈øometimes hauing the one leafe in that manner: And ≈øometimes but with a diuers coloured li≈øt in them; in the other parts both of flower and leafe, like vnto the other.

div.head: Iris lutea variegata. The yellow variable Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This yellow variable Flowerdeluce lo≈øeth his leaues in Winter, contrary to all the former Flowerdeluces, ≈øo that his roote remaineth vnder ground without any ≈øhew of leafe vpon it: but in the beginning of the Spring it ≈øhooteth out faire broad leaues, falling downwards at the points or ends, but ≈øhorter many times then any of the former, and ≈øo is the ≈øtalke likewi≈øe, not ri≈øing much aboue a foote high, whereon are ≈øet two or three large flowers, who≈øe falling leaues are of a reddi≈øh purple colour, the three that ≈øtand vpright of a ≈ømoakie yellow, the arched leaues hauing their ridges of a bleake colour tending to purple, the ≈øides being of the former ≈ømoakie yellow colour, with ≈øome purpli≈øh veines at the foote or bottome of all the leaues: the roote groweth ≈øomewhat more ≈ølender and long vnder ground, and of a darker colour then manie of the other.

Another ≈øort hath the vpright leaues of a rea≈øonable faire yellow, and ≈øtand more vpright, not bowing downe as mo≈øt of the other, and the purple fals haue pale edges. Some haue their greene lea ‚Ä¢ es party coloured,Varietas. white and greene, more or le≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo are the huskes of the flower, the arched leaues yellow, as the vpright leaues are, with purpli≈øh veines at the bottome. And ≈øome haue both the arched and vpright leaues of ≈øo pale a yellow, that we may almo≈øt call it a ≈øtraw colour, but yellower at the bottome, with purple veines, and the falling leaues purple, with two purple ≈øpots in them.

And the≈øe are the ≈øorts of the greater tuberous or Flagge Flowerdeluces that haue come to our knowledge: the next hereunto are the le≈ø≈øer or narrow lea≈øed kindes to be de≈øcribed; and fir≈øt of the greate≈øt of them.

div.head: 1. Iris angu≈øtifolia Tripolitana aurea. The yellow Flowerdeluce of Tripoly.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce I place in the forefront of the narrow leafed Flowerdeluces, for the length of the leaues, compared with the breadth of them; it may fitly bee called a narrow leafed Flowerdeluce, although they be an inch broad, which is broader then any of them that follow, or ≈øome of tho≈øe are ≈øet downe before, but as I ≈øaid, the length make them ≈øeem narrow, and therfore let it take vp his roome in this place, with the de≈øcription that followeth. It beareth leaues a yard long, or not much le≈ø≈øe, and an inch broad, as is ≈øaid before, or more, of a ≈øad greene colour, but not ≈øhining: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp to be foure or Fiue foote high, being ≈øtrong and round, but not very great, bearing at the toppe two or three long and narrow gold yellow flowers, of the fa≈øhion of the bulbous Flowerdeluces, as the next to bee de≈øcribed is, without any mixture or variation therein: the heads for ≈øeede are three ≈øquare, containing within them many flat cornered ≈øeedes: the roote is long and blacki≈øh, like vnto the re≈øt that follow, but greater and fuller.

figure.head: 1 Iris Chalcedonica ≈øiue Su≈øiana maior. The great Turkie Flowerdeluce. 2 Iris alba Florentina. The white Flowerdeluce. 3 Iris latifolia variegata. The variable Flowerdeluce. 4 Chamaeiris latifolia maier. The greater dwarfe Flowerdeluce.

div.head: 2. Iris angustifolia maior caerulea. The greater blew Flowerdeluce with narrow leaues.
div.p: This kinde of Flowerdeluce hath his leaues very long and narrow, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, but neither ≈øo long or broad as the la≈øt, yet broader, thicker and ≈øtiffer then any of the re≈øt with narrow leaues that follow: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth ≈øometimes no higher then the leaues, and ≈øometimes a little higher, bearing diuers flowers at the top, ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely flowring one after another, and are like vnto the flowers of the bulbous Flowerdeluces, but of a light blew colour, and ≈øometimes deeper: after the flowers are pa≈øt, ri≈øe vp ≈øix cornered heads, which open into three parts, wherein is contained browne ≈øeede, almo≈øt round: the roote is ≈ømall, blacki≈øh and hard, ≈øpreading into many long heads, and more clo≈øely growing or matting together.

div.head: 3. Iris angu≈øtifolia purpurea marina. The purple narrow leafed Sea Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Sea Flowerdeluce hath many narrow hard leaues as long as the former, and of a darke greene colour, which doe ≈ømell a little ≈øtrong: the ≈øtalke beareth two or three flowers like the former, but ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe, and of a darke purple or Violet colour: in ≈øeede and roote it is like the former.

div.head: 4. Iris angu≈øtifolia purpurea ver≈øicolor. The variable purple narrow leafed Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The leaues of this Flowerdeluce are very like the former Sea Flowerdeluce, and do a little ≈øtinke like them; the flowers are differing, in that the vpper leaues are wholly purple or violet, and the lower leaues haue white veines, and purple running one among another: the ≈øeede and rootes differ not from the former purple Sea kinde.

div.head: 5. Iris angu≈øtifolia minor Pannonica ≈øiue ver≈øicolor Clu≈øij. The ≈ømall variable Hungarian Flowerdeluce of Clu≈øius.
div.p: This Hungarian Flowerdeluce (fir≈øt found out by Clu≈øius, by him de≈øcribed, and of him tooke the name) ri≈øeth vp with diuers ≈ømall tufts of leaues, very long, narrow, and greene, growing thicke together, e≈øpecially if it abide any time in a place; among which ri≈øeth vp many long round ≈øtalkes, higher then the leaues, bearing two or three, or foure ≈ømall flowers, one aboue another, like the former, but ≈ømaller and of greater beauty: for the lower leaues are variably ≈øtriped with white and purple, without any thrume or fringe at all; the vpper leaues are of a blewi≈øh fine purple or Violet colour, & ≈øo are the arched leaues, yet hauing the edges a little paler: the heads for ≈øeede are ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo cornered as the other, containing ≈øeedes much like the former, but ≈ømaller: the roote is blacke and ≈ømall, growing thicker and clo≈øer together then any other, and ≈øtrongly fa≈øtened in the ground, with a number of hard ≈øtringie rootes: the flowers are of a rea≈øonable good ≈øent.

div.head: 6. Iris angu≈øtifolia maior flore duplici. The greater double blew Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce, differeth not either in roote or leafe from the fir≈øt great blew Flowerdeluce of Clu≈øius, but onely in that the leaues grow thicker together, and that the flowers of this kinde are as it were double with many leaues confu≈øedly ≈øet together, without any di≈øtinct parts of a Flowerdeluce, and of a faire blew colour with many white veines and lines running in the leaues; yet oftentimes the ≈øtalke of flowers hath but two or three ≈ømall flowers di≈øtinctly ≈øet together, ri≈øing as it were out of one huske.

div.head: 7. Iris angu≈øtifolia minor alba Clu≈øij. The ≈ømall white Flowerdeluce of Hungary.
div.p:
This likewi≈øe differeth little from the former Hungarian Flowerdeluce of Clu≈øius,
1 Iris angu≈øtifolia Tripolitana. The yellow Flowerdeluce of Tripoli. 2 Iris angu≈øtifolia maior carulea. The greater blew Flowerdeluce with narrow leaues. 3 Iris angu≈øtifolia minor Pannonica ≈øiue ver≈øicolor Clu≈øti. The ≈ømall variable Hungarian Flowerdeluce o ‚Ä¢ Clu≈øi ‚Ä¢ s. 4 Iris angu≈øtifolia maior flore duplici The greater double blew Flowerdeluce. 5 Chamairis angu≈øtifolia minor. The le≈ø≈øer Gra≈ø≈øe Flowerdeluce. 6 Iris tubero≈øa. The veluet Flowerdeluce. depiction of flowers
but that the leafe is of a little paler greene colour, and the flower is of a faire whiti≈øh colour, with ≈øome purple at the bottome of the leaues.

Next after the≈øe narrow leafed Flowerdeluces, are the greater and ≈ømaller ≈øorts of dwarfe kindes to follow; and la≈øtly, the narrow or gra≈ø≈øe leafed dwarfe kindes, which will fini≈øh this Chapter of Flowerdeluces.

div.head: 1. Chamaeiris latifolia maior alba. The greater white dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This dwarfe Flowerdeluce hath his leaues as broad as ≈øome of the le≈ø≈øer kindes la≈øt mentioned, but not ≈øhorter; the ≈øtalke is very ≈øhort, not aboue halfe a foote high or thereabouts, bearing mo≈øt commonly but one flower, ≈øeldome two, which are in ≈øome of a pure white, in others paler, or ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh through the whole flower, except the yellow frize or thrume in the middle of euery one of the falling leaues: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come forth great heads, containing within them round pale ≈øeed: the roote is ≈ømall, according to the proportion of the plant aboue ground, but made after the fa≈øhion of the greater kindes, with tuberous peeces ≈øpreading from the ≈øides, and ≈øtrong fibres or ≈øtrings, whereby they are fa≈øtened in the ground.

div.head: 2. Chamaeiris latifolia maior purpurea. The greater purple dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: There is no difference either in roote, leafe, or forme of flower in this from the former dwarfe kinde, but onely in the colour of the flower, which in ≈øome is of a very deepe or blacke Violet purple, both the toppes and the fals: in others the Violet purple is more liuely, and in ≈øome the vpper leaues are blew, and the lower leaues purple, yet all of them haue that yellow frize or thrume in the middle of the falling leaues, that the other kindes haue.

Altera.There is another that beareth purple flowers, that might be reckoned, for the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe and ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of his ≈øtalke, to the next kinde, but that the flowers and leaues of this are as large as any of the former kindes of the ≈ømaller Flowerdeluces.

div.head: 3. Chamaeiris latifolia minor alba. The le≈ø≈øer white dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: There is al≈øo another ≈øort of the≈øe Flowerdeluces, who≈øe leaues and flowers are le≈ø≈øe, and wherein there is much variety. The leaues of this kinde, are all for the mo≈øt part ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, narrower, and ≈øhorter then the former: the ≈øtalke with the flower vpon it ≈øcarce ri≈øeth aboue the leaues, ≈øo that in mo≈øt of them it may be rather called a foote-≈øtalke, ≈øuch as the Saffron flowers haue, and are therefore called of manie „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , without ≈øtalkes; the flowers are like vnto the fir≈øt de≈øcribed of the dwarfe kindes, and of a whiti≈øh colour, with a few purpli≈øh lines at the bottome of the vpper leaues, and a li≈øt of greene in the falling leaues.
Strami ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a.Another hath the flowers of a pale yellow, called a Straw colour, with whiti≈øh ≈øtripes and veines in the fals, and purpli≈øh lines at the bottome of the vpper leaues.

div.head: 4. Chamaeiris latifolia minor purpurea. The le≈ø≈øer purple dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The difference of this from the former, con≈øi≈øteth more in the colour then forme of the flower, which is of a deep Violet purple, ≈øometimes paler, and ≈øometimes ≈øo deep, that it almo≈øt ≈øeemeth blacke: And ≈øometimes the fals purpli≈øh, and the vpper leaues blew. Some of the≈øe haue a ≈øweete ≈øent, and ≈øome none.
Caerulea.There is another of a fine pale or delayed blew colour throughout the whole flower.

div.head: 5. Chamaeiris latifolia minor ≈øuaeuerubens. The le≈ø≈øer blu≈øh coloured dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce hath the falling leaues of the flower of a reddi≈øh colour, and the thrumes blew: the vpper and arched leaues of a fine pale red or fle≈øh colour, called a blu≈øh colour; in all other things it differeth not, and ≈ømelleth little or nothing at all.

div.head: 6. Chamaeiris latifolia minor lutea ver≈øicolor. The le≈ø≈øer yellow variable dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The falling leaues of this Flowerdeluce are yellowi≈øh, with purple lines from the middle downewards, ≈øometimes of a deeper, and ≈øometimes of a paler colour, and white thrumes in the middle, the vpper leaues are likewi≈øe of a yellowi≈øh colour, with purple lines in them: And ≈øometimes the yellow colour is paler, and the lines both in the vpper and lower leaues of a dull or dead purple colour.

div.head: 3. Chamaeiris latifolia minor caerulea ver≈øicolor. The le≈ø≈øer blew variable dwarfe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: The vpper leaues of this flower are of a blewi≈øh yellow colour, ≈øpotted with purple in the broad part, and at the bottome very narrow: the falling leaues are ≈øpread ouer with pale purpli≈øh lines, and a ≈ømall ≈øhew of blew about the brimmes: the thrume is yellow at the bottome, and blewi≈øh aboue: the arched leaues are of a blewi≈øh white, being a little deeper on the ridge.
And ≈øometimes the vpper leaues are of a paler blew rather whiti≈øh, with the yellow: both the≈øe haue no ≈øent at all.

div.head: 8. Chamaeiris marina purpurea. The purple dwarfe Sea Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This ≈ømall Flowerdeluce is like vnto the narrow leafed Sea Flowerdeluce before de≈øcribed, both in roote, leafe, and flower, hauing no other difference, but in the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe and lowne≈ø≈øe of the growing, being of the ≈øame purple colour with it.

div.head: 9. Chamaeiris angustifolia maior. The greater Gra≈ø≈øe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Gra≈ø≈øe Flowerdeluce hath many long and narrow darke greene leaues, not ≈øo ≈øtiffe as the former, but lither, and bending their ends downe againe, among which ri≈øe vp diuers ≈øtalkes, bearing at the toppe two or three ≈øweete flowers, as ≈ømall as any of them ≈øet downe before, of a reddi≈øh purple colour, with whiti≈øh yellow and purple ≈øtrakes downe the middle of the falling leaues: the arched leaues are of a hor≈øe fle≈øh colour all along the edges, and purple vpon the ridges and tips that turne vp againe: vnder the≈øe appeare three browne aglets, like vnto birds tongues: the three vpper leaues are ≈ømall and narrow, of a perfect purple or Violet colour: the heads for ≈øeede haue ≈øharper and harder cornered edges then the former: the ≈øeedes are ≈øomewhat grayi≈øh like the former, and ≈øo are the rootes, being ≈ømall, blacke, and hard, growing thicke together, fa≈øtened in the ground with ≈ømall blacki≈øh hard ≈øtrings, which hardly ≈øhoote againe if the roote be remoued.

div.head: 10. Chamaeiris angustifolia minor. The le≈ø≈øer Gra≈ø≈øe Flowerdeluce.
div.p: This Flowerdeluce is in leaues, flowers, and rootes ≈øo like the la≈øt de≈øcribed, that but onely it is ≈ømaller and lower, it is not to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the other. And this may ≈øuffice for the≈øe ≈øorts of Flowerdeluces, that furni≈øh the Gardens of the curious louers of the≈øe varieties of nature, ≈øo farre forth as hath pa≈ø≈øed vnder our knowledge. There are ≈øome other that may be referred hereunto, but they belong to another hi≈øtory; and therefore I make no mention of them in this place.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The places of mo≈øt of the≈øe are ≈øet downe in their ≈øeuerall titles; for ≈øome are out of Turkie, others out of Hungaria, Dalmatia, Illyria, &c. as their names doe import. Tho≈øe that grow by the Sea, are found in Spaine and France.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: Some of the≈øe do flower in Aprill, ≈øome in May, and ≈øome not vntill Iune.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The names expre≈ø≈øed are the fitte≈øt agreeing vnto them, and therefore it is needle≈ø≈øe againe to repeate them. Many of the rootes of the former or greater kindes, being dryed are ≈øweete, yet ≈øome more then other, and ≈øome haue no ≈øent at all: but aboue all the re≈øt, that with the white flower, called of Florence, is accounted of all to be the ≈øweete≈øt root, fit to be v≈øed to make ≈øweete powders, &c. calling it by the name of Orris rootes.

div.head: Iris tubero≈øa. The Veluet Flowerdeluce.
div.p: Vnto the Family of Flowerdeluces, I mu≈øt needes ioyne this peculiar kinde, becau≈øe of the neare re≈øemblance of the flower, although it differ both in roote and leafe; le≈øt therefore it ≈øhould haue no place, let it take vp a roome here in the end of the Flowerdeluces, with this de≈øcription following. It hath many ≈ømall and foure ≈øquare leaues, two foote long and aboue ≈øometimes, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, ≈øtiffe at the fir≈øt, but afterwards growing to their full length, they are weak and bend downe to the ground: out of the middle, as it were of one of the≈øe leaues, breaketh out the ≈øtalke, a foot high and better, with ≈øome leaues thereon, at the toppe whereof, out of a huske ri≈øeth one flower, (I neuer ≈øaw more on a ≈øtalke) con≈øi≈øting of nine leaues, whereof the three that fall downe are of a yellowi≈øh greene colour round about the edges, and in the middle of ≈øo deepe a purple, that it ≈øeemeth to be blacke, re≈øembling blacke Veluet: the three arched leaues, that couer the lower leaues to the halfe, are of the ≈øame greeni≈øh colour that the edges and back≈øide of the lower leaues are: the three vppermo≈øt leaues, if they may be called leaues, or rather ≈øhort peeces like eares, are green al≈øo, but wherein a glimp≈øe of purple may be ≈øeene in them: after the flower is pa≈øt, there followeth a round knob or whiti≈øh ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell, hanging downe by a ≈ømall foote-≈øtalke, from betweene the huske, which is diuided as it were into two leaues, wherein is contained round white ≈øeede. The roote is bunched or knobbed out into long round rootes, like vnto fingers, two or three from one peece, one di≈øtant from another, and one longer then another, for the mo≈øt part of a darki≈øh gray colour, and reddi≈øh withall on the out≈øide, and ≈øomewhat yellowi≈øh within.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It hath beene ≈øent out of Turkie oftentimes (as growing naturally thereabouts) and not knowne to grow naturally any where el≈øe.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Aprill or May, ≈øometimes earlier or later, as the Spring falleth out to be milde or ≈øharpe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Matthiolus contendeth to make it the true Hermodactylus, rather from the ≈øhew of the rootes, which (as is ≈øaid) are like vnto fingers, then from any other good rea≈øon: for the rootes hereof eyther dry or greene, do nothing re≈øemble the true Hermodactyli that are v≈øed in Phy≈øicke, as any that knoweth them may ea≈øily perceiue, either in forme or vertue. It is more truely referred to the Flowerdeluces, and becau≈øe of the tuberous rootes, called Iris tubero≈øa, although all the Flowerdeluces in this Chapter haue tuberous
rootes, yet this much differing from them all. In Engli≈øh it is v≈øually called, The Veluet Flowerdeluce, becau≈øe the three falling leaues ≈øeeme to be like ≈ømooth blacke Veluet.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Both the rootes and the flowers of the great Flowerdeluces, are of great v≈øe for the purging and clean≈øing of many inward, as well as outward di≈øea≈øes, as all Authors in Phy≈øicke doe record. Some haue v≈øed al≈øo the greene rootes to clean≈øe the skinne, but they had neede to be carefull that v≈øe them, le≈øt they take more harme then good by the v≈øe of them. The dryed rootes called Orris (as is ≈øaid) is of much v≈øe to make ≈øweete powders, or other things to perfume apparrell or linnen. The iuice or decoction of the green roots doth procure both neezing to be ≈ønuft vp into the no≈øtrils, and vomiting very ≈øtrongly being taken inwardly.

div.head: Gladiolus. Corne Flagge.
div.p: NExt vnto the Flagges or Flowerdeluces, come the Gladioli or Corne Flagges to bee entreated of, for ≈øome re≈øemblance of the leaues with them. There are hereof diuers ≈øorts, ≈øome bigger and ≈øome le≈ø≈øer, but the chiefe≈øt difference is in the colour of the flowers, and one in the order of the flowers. Of them all in their ≈øeuerall orders.

div.head: Gladiolus Narbonen≈øis. The French Corne Flagge.
div.p: The French Corne Flagge ri≈øeth vp with three or foure broad, long, and ≈øtiffe greene leaues, one as it were out of the ≈øide of another, being ioyned together at the bottome, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of Flowerdeluces, but ≈øtiffer, more full of ribbes, and longer then many of them, and ≈øharper pointed: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp from among the leaues, bearing them on it as it ri≈øeth, hauing at the toppe diuers huskes, out of which come the flowers one aboue another, all of them turning and opening them≈øelues one way, which are long and gaping, like vnto the flowers of Foxegloue, a little arched or bunching vp in the middle, of a faire reddi≈øh purple colour, with two white ≈øpots within the mouth thereof, one on each ≈øide, made like vnto a Lozenge that is ≈øquare and long pointed: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come vp round heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, wherein is contained reddi≈øh flat ≈øeede, like vnto the ≈øeede of the Fritillaria, but thicker and fuller: the roote is ≈øomewhat great, round, flat, and hard, with a ≈øhew as if it were netted, hauing another ≈øhort ≈øpongie one vnder it, which when it hath done bearing, and the ≈øtalke dry, that the roote may be taken vp, ≈øticketh clo≈øe to the bottome, but may be ea≈øily taken away, hauing v≈øually a number of ≈ømall rootes encrea≈øed about it, the lea≈øt whereof will quickly grow, ≈øo that if it be ≈øuffered any long time in a Garden, it will rather choake and pe≈øter it, then be an ornament vnto it.

div.head: Gladiolus Italicus binis floribus ordinibus. The Italian Corne Flagge.
div.p: The Italian Corne Flagge is like vnto the French in roote, leafe, and flower, without any other difference, then that the roote is ≈ømaller and browner, the leafe and ≈øtalke of a darker colour, and the flowers (being of a little darker colour like the former, and ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller) ≈øtand out on both ≈øides of the ≈øtalke.

div.head: Gladiolus Byzantinus. Corne Flagge of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p:
This Corne Flagge that came fir≈øt from Con≈øtantinople, is in all things like vnto the French Corne Flagge la≈øt de≈øcribed, but that it is larger, both in rootes, leaues, and
flowers, and likewi≈øe that the Flowers of this, which ≈øtand not on both ≈øides, are of a deeper red colour, and flower later, after all the re≈øt are pa≈øt: the roote hereof being netted as plainly as any of the former, is as plentifull al≈øo to giue encrea≈øe, but is more tender and le≈ø≈øe able to abide our ≈øharpe cold Winters.

div.head: Gladiolus flore rubente. Blu≈øh Corne Flagge.
div.p: This blu≈øh kinde is like vnto the French Corne Flagge in all re≈øpects, ≈øauing onely that the flowers are of a pale red colour, tending to whitene≈ø≈øe, which wee v≈øually call a blu≈øh colour.

div.head: Gladiolus flore albo. White Corne Flagge.
div.p: This white Corne Flagge al≈øo differeth not from the la≈øt, but onely that the rootes are whiter on the out≈øide, the leaues are greener, without any brownne≈ø≈øe or darkne≈ø≈øe as in the former, and the flowers are ≈ønow white.

div.head: Gladiolus purpureus minor. The ≈ømall purple Corne Flagge.
div.p: This al≈øo differeth not from any of the former, but onely in the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe both of leafe, ≈øtalke, and flowers, which ≈øtand all on the one ≈øide, like vnto the French kinde, and of the ≈øame colour: the roote of this kinde is netted more then any other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They grow in France and Italy, the lea≈øt in Spaine, and the Byzantine, as it is thought, about Con≈øtantinople, being (as is ≈øaid) fir≈øt ≈øent from thence. Iohn Trade≈øcante a≈ø≈øured mee, that hee ≈øaw many acres of ground in Barbary ≈øpread ouer with them.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in Iune and Iuly, and the Byzantine late≈øt, as is ≈øaid before.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath diuers names; for the Latines call it Gladiolus, of the forme of a ≈øword, which the leafe doth re≈øemble. The Romanes Segetalis, becau≈øe it groweth in the Corne fields. Some call it Victorialis rotunda, to put a difference between it, and the longa, which is a kinde of Garlicke. Plinie ≈øaith, that Gladiolus is Cypirus, but to decide that controuer≈øie, and many others, belongeth to another di≈øcour≈øe, this being intended only for plea≈øure. Gerrard mi≈øtaketh the French kinde for the Italian.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The roote being brui≈øed, and applyed with Frankin≈øen≈øe (and often of it ≈øelfe without it) in the manner of a pultis or plai≈øter, is held of diuers to be ≈øingular good to draw out ≈øplinters, thornes, and broken bones out of the fle≈øh. Some take it to be effectuall to ≈øtirre vp Venerie, but I ≈øomewhat doubt thereof: For Galen in his eighth Booke of Simples, giueth vnto it a drawing, dige≈øting, and drying faculty.

figure.head: 1 Gladiolus Narbonen≈øis. The French Corne Flagge. 2 Gladiolus Italicus. The Italian Corne Flagge. 3 Gladiolus Byzantinus. Corne Flagge of Con≈øtantinople. 4 Palma Chri≈øti was. The great male handed Satyrion. 5 Orchis Hermaphroditica candida. The white Butterflie Orchis. 6 Orchis Melitias ≈øiue apifera. The Bee flower or Bee Orchis. 7 Deus Caninus flore purpurante. Dogges tooth Violet with a pale purpli≈øh flower. 8 Deus Caninus flore albo. Dogges tooth Violet with a white flower.

div.head: Orchis ≈øiue Satyrium. Bee flowers.
div.p: ALthough it is not my purpo≈øe in this place, to giue a generall hi≈øtory of all the ≈øorrs of Orchides, Satyrions, and the re≈øt of that kinde; yet becau≈øe many of them are very plea≈øant to behold, and, if they be planted in a conuenient place, will abide ≈øome time in Gardens, ≈øo that there is much plea≈øure taken in them: I ≈øhall intrude ≈øome of them for curio≈øities ≈øake, to make vp the pro≈øpect of natures beautifull variety, and only entreate of a few, leauing the re≈øt to a more ample declaration.

div.head: 1. Satyrium Ba≈øilicum ≈øiue Palma Chri≈øti mas. The greater male handed Satyrion.
div.p: This handed Satyrion hath for the mo≈øt part but three faire large greene leaues, neare vnto the ground, ≈øpotted with ≈ømall blacki≈øh markes: from among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, with ≈øome ≈ømaller leaues thereon, bearing at the toppe a bu≈øh or ≈øpike of flowers, thicke ≈øet together, euery one whereof is made like a body, with the belly broader belowe then aboue, where it hath ≈ømall peeces adioyned vnto it: the flower is of a faire purple colour, ≈øpotted with deeper purple ≈øpots, and hauing ≈ømall peeces like hornes hanging at the backes of the flowers, and a ≈ømall leafe at the bottome of the foote-≈øtalke of euery flower: the rootes are not round, like the other Orchides, but ≈øomewhat long and flat, like a hand, with ≈ømall diui≈øions belowe, hanging downe like the fingers of a hand, cut ≈øhort off by the knockles, two alwayes growing together, with ≈øome ≈ømall fibres or ≈øtrings aboue the heads of the≈øe rootes, at the bottome of the ≈øtalke.

div.head: 2. Satyrium Ba≈øilicum ≈øiue Palma Christi faemina. The female handed Satyrion.
div.p: This female Satyrion hath longer and narrower leaues then the former, and ≈øpotted with more and greater ≈øpots, compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalke at the bottome like the other: this beareth likewi≈øe a bu≈øh of flowers, like vnto the other, but that each of the≈øe haue heads like hoods, whereas the former haue none: in ≈øome they are white with purple ≈øpots, and in others of a reddi≈øh purple, with deep or darke coloured ≈øpots: the roots are alike.

div.head: 3. Orchis Hermaphroditica candida. The white Butterflie Orchis.
div.p: The rootes of this kinde take part with both the ≈øorts of Orchis and Satyrium, being neither altogether round, nor fully handed, and thereupon it tooke the name, to ≈øignifie both kindes: the leaues are two in number, ≈øeldome more, being faire and broad, like vnto the leaues of Lillies, without any ≈øpot at all in them: at the toppe of the ≈øtalke ≈øtand many white flowers, not ≈øo thicke ≈øet as the fir≈øt or ≈øecond, euery one being fa≈øhioned like vnto a white Butterflie, with the wings ≈øpread abroad.

div.head: 4. Orchis Melitias ≈øiue apifera. The Bee flower or Bee Orchis.
div.p: This is a ≈ømall and lowe plant for the mo≈øt part, with three or foure ≈ømall narrow leaues at the bottome: the ≈øtalke is ≈øeldome aboue halfe a foote high, with foure or fiue flowers thereon one aboue another, hauing round bodies, and ≈øomewhat flat, of a kind of yellowi≈øh colour, with purple wings aboue them, ≈øo like vnto an honey Bee, that it might ≈øoone deceiue one that neuer had ≈øeene ≈øuch a flower before: the roots are two together, round and white, hauing a certaine muccilagine≈ø≈øe or clammine≈ø≈øe within them, without any ta≈øte almo≈øt at all, as all or the mo≈øt part of the≈øe kindes haue.

div.head: 5. Orchis Sphegodes. Gnats Satyrion.
div.p:
The leaues of this Orchis are ≈øomewhat larger then of the Bee flower, the ≈øtalke al≈øo
≈øomewhat higher: the flowers are fewer on the toppe, but ≈øomewhat larger then of the Bee flowers, made to the re≈øemblance of a Gnat or great long Flie: the rootes are two round bulbes, as the other are.

div.head: 6. Orchis Myodes. Flie Orchis.
div.p: The Flie Orchis is like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, both in leafe and roote, the difference is in the flower, which is neither ≈øo long as the Gnat Satyrion, nor ≈øo great as the Bee Orchis, but the neather part of the Flie is blacke, with a li≈øt of a≈øh-colour cro≈ø≈øing the backe, with a ≈øhew of legges hanging at it: the naturall Flie ≈øeemeth ≈øo to bee in loue with it, that you ≈øhall ≈øeldome come in the heate of the day, but you ≈øhall finde one ≈øitting clo≈øe thereon.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe grow in many places of England, ≈øome in the Woods, as the Butterflie, and the two former handed Satyrions: others on dry bankes and barren balkes in Kent, and many other places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part in the beginning or middle of May, or thereabouts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their ≈øeuerall names are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, ≈øo much as may ≈øuffice for this di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All the kindes of Orchis are accounted to procure bodily lu≈øt, as well the flowers di≈øtilled, as the rootes prepared.
The rootes boyled in red Wine, and afterwards dryed, are held to bee a ≈øingular good remedie again≈øt the bloody Fire.

div.head: Dens Caninus. Dogs tooth Violet.
div.p: VNto the kindes of Orchides, may fitly be ioyned another plant, which by many is reckoned to be a Satyrium, both from the forme of roote and leafe, and from the efficacy or vertue corre≈øpondent thereunto. And although it cannot be the Satyrium Erythronium of Dio≈øcorides, as ≈øome would entitle it, for that as I haue ≈øhewed before, his Satyrium tryphillum is the Tulipa without all doubt; yet becau≈øe it differeth very notably, and carrieth more beauty and re≈øpect in his flower then they, I ≈øhall entreate thereof in a Chapter by it ≈øelfe, and ≈øet it next vnto them.

div.head: Dens Caninus flore albo. Dogs tooth Violet with a white flower.
div.p:
The white Dogs tooth hath for his roote a white bulbe, long and ≈ømall, yet v≈øually greater then either of the other that follow, bigger belowe then aboue, with a ≈ømall peece adioyning to the bottome of it, from whence ri≈øe vp in the beginning of the Spring, after the Winter fro≈øts are pa≈øt, two leaues for the mo≈øt part (when it will flower, or el≈øe but one, and neuer three together that euer I ≈øaw) clo≈øed together when they fir≈øt come vp out of the ground, which inclo≈øe the flower betweene them: the leaues when they are opened do lay them≈øelues flat on the ground, or not much aboue it, one oppo≈øite vnto the other, with the ≈øtalke and the flower on it ≈øtanding betweene them, which leaues are of a whiti≈øh greene colour, long and narrow, yet broader in the
middle then at both ends, growing le≈ø≈øe by degrees each way, ≈øpotted and ≈øtriped all ouer the leaues with white lines and ≈øpots: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp halfe a foote high or more, bearing at the toppe one flower and no more, hanging downe the head, larger then any of the other of this kinde that follow, made or con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix white long and narrow leaues, turning them≈øelues vp againe, after it hath felt the comfort of the Sunne, that they doe almo≈øt touch the ≈øtalke againe, very like vnto the flowers of Cyclamen or Sowebread: it hath in the middle of the flower ≈øix white chiues, tipt with darke purple pendents, and a white three forked ≈øtile in the middle of them: the flower hath no ≈øent at all, but commendable onely for the beauty and forme thereof: after the flower is pa≈øt, commeth in the place a round head ≈øeeming three ≈øquare, containing therein ≈ømall and yellowi≈øh ≈øeede.

div.head: Dens Caninus flore purpura≈øcente. Dogs tooth with a pale purple flower.
div.p: This other Dogs tooth is like vnto the former, but le≈ø≈øer in all parts, the leafe whereof is not ≈øo long, but broad and ≈øhort, ≈øpotted with darker lines and ≈øpots: the flower is like the other, but ≈ømaller, and of a delayed purple colour, very pale ≈øometimes, and ≈øometimes a little deeper, turning it ≈øelfe as the other, with a circle round about the vmbone or middle, the chiues hereof are not white, but declining to purple: the roote is white, and like vnto the former, but le≈ø≈øer, as is ≈øaid before.

div.head: Dens Caninus flore rubro. Dogs tooth with a red flower.
div.p: This is in all things like vnto the la≈øt, both for forme and bigne≈ø≈øe of flower and leafe: the chiefe difference con≈øi≈øteth in this, that the leaues hereof are of a yellowi≈øh mealy greene colour, ≈øpotted and ≈øtreaked with redder ≈øpots and ≈øtripes, and the flower of a deeper reddi≈øh purple colour, and the chiues al≈øo more purpli≈øh then the la≈øt, in all other things it is alike.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The ≈øorts of Dens Caninus doe growe in diuers places; ≈øome in Italy on the Euganean Hils, others on the Apenine, and ≈øome about Gratz, the chiefe Citie of Stiria, and al≈øo about Bayonne, and in other places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in March mo≈øt v≈øually, and many times in Aprill, according to the ≈øea≈øonablene≈ø≈øe of the yeare.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Clu≈øius did call it fir≈øt Dentali, and Lobel, and from him ≈øome others Satyrium, and Erythronium, but I haue ≈øaid enough hereof in the beginning of the Chapter. It is mo≈øt commonly called Dens Caninus, and we in Engli≈øh, either Dogs tooth, or Dogs tooth Violet. Ge≈øner called it Hermodactylus, and Matthiolus P≈øeudohermodactylus.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The roote hereof is held to bee of more efficacy for venereous effects, then any of the Orchides and Satyrions.
They of Stiria v≈øe the rootes for the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe.

Wee haue had from Virginia a roote ≈øent vnto vs, that wee might well iudge, by the forme and colour thereof being dry, to be either the roote of this, or of an Orchis, which the naturall people hold not onely to be ≈øingular to procure lu≈øt, but hold it as a ≈øecret, loth to reueale it.

div.head: Cyclamen. Sowebread.
div.p: THe likene≈ø≈øe of the flowers, and the ≈øpotting of the leaues of the Dens Caninus, with the≈øe of the Cyclamen or Sowebread, maketh mee ioyne it next thereunto: as al≈øo that after the bulbous rooted plants I might begin with the tuberous that remaine, and make this plant the beginning of them. Of this kinde there are diuers ≈øorts, differing both in forme of leaues and time of flowring: for ≈øome doe flower in the Spring of the yeare, others afterwards in the beginning of Summer: but the mo≈øt number in the end of Summer, or beginning of Autumne or Harue≈øt, whereof ≈øome haue round leaues, others cornered like vnto Iuie, longer or ≈øhorter, greater or ≈ømaller. Of them all in order, and fir≈øt of tho≈øe that come in the Spring.

div.head: 1. Cyclamen Vernum flore purpureo. Purple flowred Sowebread of the Spring.
div.p: This Sowebread hath a ≈ømaller roote then mo≈øt of the others, yet round and blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, as all or mo≈øt of the re≈øt are (I ≈øpeake of them that I haue ≈øeene; for Clu≈øius and others doe report to haue had very great ones) from whence ri≈øe vp diuers round, yet pointed leaues, and ≈øomewhat cornered withall, greene aboue, and ≈øpotted with white ≈øpots circlewi≈øe about the leafe, and reddi≈øh vnderneath, which at their fir≈øt comming vp are folded together; among which come the flowers, of a reddi≈øh purple colour and very ≈øweete, euery one vpon a ≈ømall, long, and ≈ølender reddi≈øh foote-≈øtalke, which hanging downe their heads, turne vp their leaues againe: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the head or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell ≈øhrinketh downe, winding his foote≈øtalke, and coyling it ≈øelfe like a cable, which when it toucheth the ground, there abideth hid among the leaues, till it be growne great and ripe, wherein are contained a few ≈ømall round ≈øeedes, which being pre≈øently ≈øowne, will growe fir≈øt into round rootes, and afterwards from them ≈øhoote forth leaues.

div.head: 2. Cyclamen Vernum flore albo. White flowred Sowebread of the Spring.
div.p: The white flowring Sowebread hath his leaues like the former, but not fully ≈øo much cornered, bearing ≈ømall ≈ønow white flowers, as ≈øweete as the other: and herein con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe≈øt difference, in all other things it is alike.

div.head: 3. Cylamen Vernum Creticum flore albo. White Candy Sowebread of the Spring.
div.p: This Sowebread is ≈øomewhat like the former white kinde, but that the leaues grow much larger and longer, with more corners at the edges, and more eminent ≈øpots on them: the flowers al≈øo ≈øomewhat longer and larger, and herein con≈øi≈øteth the whole difference.

div.head: 4. Cyclamen Ae≈øtivum. Summer Sowebread.
div.p: Summer Sowebread hath round leaues like vnto the Romane Sowebread, but ≈øomewhat cornered, yet with ≈øhorter corners then the Iuie leafed Sowebread, full of white ≈øpots on the vpper≈øide of the leaues, and very purple vnderneath, ≈øometimes they haue fewer ≈øpots, and little or no purple vnderneath: the flowers hereof are as ≈ømall, as purple, and as ≈øweete, as the purple Sowebread of the Spring time: the roote hereof is likewi≈øe ≈ømall, blacke, and round.

div.head: 5. Cyclamen Romanum rotundifolium. Romane Sowebread with round leaues.
div.p:
The Romane Sowebread hath round leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the common Sowebread, but not fully ≈øo round pointed at the ends, a little cornered ≈øometimes al≈øo, or as it were indented, with white ≈øpots round about the middle of the leaues,
and very con≈øpicuous, which make it ≈øeeme the more beautifull: the flowers appeare in Autumne, and are ≈øhorter, and of a deeper purpli≈øh red colour then the Iuie Sowebread, ri≈øing vp before the leaues for the mo≈øt part, or at lea≈øt with them, and little or nothing ≈øweete: the roote is round and blacke, v≈øually not ≈øo flat as it, but growing ≈øometimes to bee greater then any other kinde of Sowebread. There is ≈øometimes ≈øome variety to be ≈øeene, both in the leaues and flowers of this kinde; for that ≈øometime the leaues haue more corners, and either more or le≈ø≈øe ≈øpotted with white: the flowers likewi≈øe of ≈øome are larger or le≈ø≈øer,Varietas. longer or rounder, paler or deeper coloured one then another. This happeneth mo≈øt likely from the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede, cau≈øing the like variety as is ≈øeene in the Iuie leafed Sowebread. It doth al≈øo many times happen from the diuer≈øity of ≈øoyles and countries where they grow: the ≈øeed of this, as of all the re≈øt, is ≈ømall and round, contained in ≈øuch like heads as the former, ≈øtanding almo≈øt like the head of a Snake that is twined or folded within the body thereof. This and the other Autumnall kindes, pre≈øently after their ≈øowing in Autumne, ≈øhoote forth leaues, and ≈øo abide all the Winter, according to their kinde.

div.head: 6. Cyclamen folio hederae autumnale. Iuie leafed Sowebread.
div.p: The Iuie leafed Sowebread groweth in the ≈øame manner that the former doth, that is, bringeth forth flowers with the leaues ≈øometimes, or mo≈øt commonly before them, who≈øe flowers are greater then the common round leafed Sowebread, ≈øomewhat longer then the former Romane or Italian Sowebreads, and of a paler purple colour, almo≈øt blu≈øh, without that ≈øweete ≈øent as is in the fir≈øt kinde of the Spring: the greene leaues hereof are more long then round, pointed at the ends, and hauing al≈øo one or two corners on each ≈øide, ≈øometimes much ≈øpotted on the vpper≈øide with white ≈øpots and marks, and ≈øometimes but a little or not at all; and ≈øo likewi≈øe ≈øometimes more or le≈ø≈øe purple vnderneath: all the leaues and flowers doe ≈øtand v≈øually euery one ≈øeuerally by them≈øelues, vpon their owne ≈ølender foote-≈øtalkes, as mo≈øt of all the other kindes doe:Varietas. but ≈øometimes it happeneth, that both leaues and flowers are found growing from one and the ≈øame ≈øtalke, which I rather take to be accidentall, then naturall ≈øo to continue: the ≈øeede hereof is like the former kindes, which being ≈øowne produceth variety, both in the forme of the leaues, and colour and ≈ømell of the flowers: ≈øome being paler or deeper, and ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe ≈øweete then others: the leaues al≈øo, ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe cornered then others: the root groweth to be great, being round and flat, and of a blacki≈øh browne colour on the out≈øide.

div.head: 7. Cyclamen autumnale hederaefolio flore albo. Iuie leafed Sowebread with white flowers.
div.p: There is one of this kinde, who≈øe leaues are rounder, and not ≈øo much cornered as the former, flowring in Autumne as the la≈øt doth, and who≈øe flowers are wholly white, not hauing any other notable difference therein.

div.head: 8. Cyclamen autumnale angu≈øtifolium. Long leafed Sowebread.
div.p: This kinde of Sowebread may ea≈øily be knowne from all the other kindes, becau≈øe his leafe is longer and narrower then others, fa≈øhioned at the bottome thereof with points, ≈øomewhat like vnto Arum or Wake Robin leaues: the flowers are like the former ≈øorts for forme, but of a purple colour. There is al≈øo another of this kinde in all things like the former, but that the flowers are white.

div.head: 9. Cyclamen Antiochenum Autumnale flore purpureo duplici. Double flowred Sowebread of Antioch.

figure.head:
1 Cyclamen ∆≤ernum flore purpureo. Purple flowred Sowebread of the Spring. 2 Cyclamen a≈øtivum. Summer Sowebread. 3 Folium Cyclaminis Cretici ver
‚Ä¢ alis flore candido. A leafe of Candie Sowebread. 4 Cyclamen Romanum Autumnale. Romane Sowebread of the Autumne. 5 Cyclamen hederafolio Autumnale. Iuie leafed Autumne Sowebread. 6 Folium Cyclaminis Autumnalis flore albo. A leafe of the Autumne Sowebread with a white flower. 7 Folium Cyclaminis angu≈øtifolij Autumnalis. A leafe of the long leafed Sowebread. 8 Cyclamen Antiochenum Autumnale flore amplo purpureo duplici The double flowred Sowebread of Antioch. 9 Cyclamen vulgare folis r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ undo. The common round leafed Sowebread.

div.p: There are of this kinde ≈øome, who≈øe flowers appeare in the Spring, and are as large and double as the former, but of a pure white colour.
There are of the≈øe Sowebreads of Antioch, that haue but ≈øingle flowers, ≈øome appearing in the Spring, and others in Autumne.

div.head: 10. Cyclamen vulgare folio rotundo. The common Sowebread.
div.p: The common Sowebread (which is mo≈øt v≈øed in the Apothecaries Shops) hath many leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, ri≈øing from certaine ≈ømall long heads, that are on the greater round rootes, as v≈øually mo≈øt of the former ≈øorts doe, being in the like manner folded together, and after ≈øpread them≈øelues into round greene leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of A≈øarum, but not ≈øhining, without any white ≈øpots on the vpper≈øide for the mo≈øt part, or but very ≈øeldome, and reddi≈øh or purpli≈øh vnderneath, and very ≈øeldome greener: the flowers ≈øtand vpon ≈ømall foot-≈øtalkes, and ≈øhew them≈øelues open for the mo≈øt part, before any leaues doe appeare, being ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter then tho≈øe with Iuie leaues, and of a pale purple colour, yet ≈øometimes deeper, hanging downe their heads, and turning vp their leaues againe, as all others doe, but more ≈øweete then many other of the Autumne flowers: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come the heads turning or winding them≈øelues downe in like manner as the other do, hauing ≈øuch like ≈øeede, but ≈øomewhat larger, and more vneuen, or not ≈øo round at the lea≈øt: the roote is round, and not flat, of a browner colour, and not ≈øo blacke on the out≈øide as many of the others.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The Sowebreads of the Spring doe both grow on the Pyrenaean Mountaines in Italy, and in Candy, and about Mompelier in France; Antioch in Syria al≈øo hath yeelded ≈øome both of the Spring and Autumne. Tho≈øe with round and Iuie leaues grow in diuers places both of France and Italy: and the common in Germany, and the Lowe-Countries. But that Autumne Sowebread with white flowers, is reported to grow in the Kingdome of Naples. I haue very curiou≈øly enquired of many, if euer they found them in any parts of England, neare or farther off from the places where they dwell: but they haue all affirmed, that they neuer found, or euer heard of any that haue found of any of them. This onely they haue a≈ø≈øured, that there groweth none in the places, where ≈øome haue reported them to grow.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: Tho≈øe of the Spring doe flower about the end of Aprill, or beginning of May. The other of the Summer, about the end of Iune or in Iuly. The re≈øt ≈øome in Augu≈øt, and September, others in October.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The Common Sowebread is called by mo≈øt Writers in Latine, Panis Poreinus, and by that name it is knowne in the Apothecaries ≈øhops, as al≈øo by the name Arthanita, according to which name, they haue an ointment ≈øo called, which is to be made with the iuice hereof. It is al≈øo called by diuers other names, not pertinent for this di≈øcour≈øe. The mo≈øt v≈øuall name, whereby it is knowne to mo≈øt Herbari≈øts, is Cyclamen (which is the Greeke word) or as ≈øome call it Cyclaminus, adding thereunto their other ≈øeuerall titles. In Engli≈øh, Sowebread.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
The leaues and rootes are very effectuall for the ≈øpleene, as the Ointment before remembred plainly proueth, being v≈øed for the ≈øame purpo≈øe,
and that to good effect. It is v≈øed al≈øo for women in long and hard trauels, where there is danger, to accelerate the birth, either the roote or the leafe being applyed. But for any amorous effects, I hold it meere fabulous.

div.head: Anemone. Windeflower and his kindes.
div.p: THe next tuberous rooted plants that are to follow (of right in my opinion) are the Anemones or Windeflowers, and although ≈øome tuberous rooted plants, that is, the A≈øphodils, Spiderworts, and Flowerdeluces haue beene before in≈øerted, it was, both becau≈øe they were in name or forme of flowers ≈øutable to them whom they were ioyned vnto, and al≈øo that they ≈øhould not be ≈øeuered and entreated of in two ≈øeuerall places: the re≈øt are now to follow, at the lea≈øt ≈øo many of them as be beautifull flowers, fit to furni≈øh a Flori≈øts Garden, for natures delight≈øome varieties and excellencies. To di≈øtingui≈øh the Family of Anemones I may, that is, into the wilde kindes, and into the tame or mannured, as they are called, and both of them nour≈øed vp in Gardens; and of them into tho≈øe that haue broader leaues, and into tho≈øe that haue thinner or more iagged leaues: and of each of them, into tho≈øe that beare ≈øingle flowers, and tho≈øe that beare double flowers. But to de≈øcribe the infinite (as I may ≈øo ≈øay) variety of the colours of the flowers, and to giue to each his true di≈øtinction and denomination, Hic labor, hoc opus e≈øt, it farre pa≈ø≈øeth my ability I confe≈ø≈øe, and I thinke would grauell the be≈øt experienced this day in Europe (and the like I ≈øaid concerning Tulipas, it being as contingent to this plant, as is before ≈øaid of the Tulipa, to be without end in yeelding varieties:) for who can ≈øee all the varieties that haue ≈øprung from the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede in all places, ≈øeeing the variety of colours ri≈øen from thence, is according to the variety of ayres & grounds wherein they are ≈øowne, skill al≈øo helping nature in ordering them aright. For the ≈øeede of one and the ≈øame plant ≈øowne in diuers ayres and grounds, doe produce that variety of colours that is much differing one from another; who then can di≈øplay all the mixtures of colours in them, to ≈øet them downe in ≈øo ≈ømall a roome as this Book? Yet as I haue done (in the former part of this Treati≈øe) my good will, to expre≈ø≈øe as many of each kinde haue come to my knowledge, ≈øo if I endeauour the like in this, I hope the courteous wil accept it, and hold me excu≈øed for the re≈øt: otherwi≈øe, if I were or could be ab≈øolute, I ≈øhould take from my ≈øelf and others the hope of future augmentation, or addition of any new, which neuer will be wanting. To begin therefore with the wilde kinds (as they are ≈øo accounted) I ≈øhall fir≈øt entreate of the Pul≈øatillas or Pa≈øque flowers, which are certainly kindes of wilde Anemones, both in leafe and flower, as may well be di≈øcerned by them that are iudicious (although ≈øome learned men haue not ≈øo thought, as appeareth by their writings) the rootes of them making one ≈øpeciall note of difference, from the other ≈øorts of wilde Anemones.

div.head: 1. Pul≈øatilla Anglica purpurea. The purple Pa≈øque flower.
div.p: The Pa≈øque or Pa≈ø≈øe flower which is of our owne Country, hath many leaues lying on the ground, ≈øomewhat rough or hairie, hard in feeling, and finely cut into many ≈ømall leaues, of a darke greene colour, almo≈øt like the leaues of Carrets, but finer and ≈ømaller, from among which ri≈øe vp naked ≈øtalkes, rough or hairie al≈øo, ≈øet about the middle thereof with ≈øome ≈ømall diuided leaues compa≈ø≈øing them, and ri≈øing aboue the≈øe leaues about a ≈øpanne, bearing euery one of them one pendulous flower, made of ≈øix leaues, of a fine Violet purple colour, but ≈øomewhat deepe withall, in the middle whereof ≈øtand many yellow threeds, ≈øet about a middle purple pointell: after the flower is pa≈øt, there commeth vp in the ≈øtead thereof a bu≈øhie head of long ≈øeedes, which are ≈ømall and hoarie, hauing at the end of euery one a ≈ømall haire, which is gray likewi≈øe: the roote is ≈ømall and long, growing downewards into the ground, with a tuft of haire at the head thereof, and not lying or running vnder the vpper cru≈øt thereof, as the other wilde Anemones doe.

div.head: 2. Pul≈øatilla Danica. The Pa≈ø≈øe flower of Denmarke.
div.p: There is another that was brought out of Denmarke, very like vnto the former, but that it is larger both in roote and leafe, and flower al≈øo, which is of a fairer purple colour, not ≈øo deepe, and be≈øides, will better abide to bee mannured then our Engli≈øh kinde will, as my ≈øelfe haue often proued.

Vtriu≈øque flore albo & flore duplici.Of both the≈øe ≈øorts it is ≈øaid, that ≈øome plants haue bin found, that haue borne white flowers. And likewi≈øe one that bore double flowers, that is, with two rowes of leaues.

div.head: 3. Pul≈øatilla flore rubro. The red Pa≈ø≈øe flower.
div.p: Lobel, as I take it, did fir≈øt ≈øet forth this kinde, being brought him from Syria, the leaues whereof are finer cut, the flower ≈ømaller, and with longer leaues, and of a red colour.

div.head: 4. Pul≈øatilla flore luteo. The yellow Pa≈ø≈øe flower.
div.p: The yellow Pa≈ø≈øe flower hath his leaues cut and diuided, very like vnto the leaues of the fir≈øt kinde, but ≈øomewhat more hairie, greene on the vpper≈øide, and hairie vnderneath: the ≈øtalke is round and hoary, the middle whereof is be≈øer with ≈øome ≈ømall leaues, as in the other, from among which ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke of the flower, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues of a very faire yellow colour on the in≈øide, and of a hoary pale yellow on the out≈øide; after which followeth ≈øuch an head of hairie thrummes as in the former: the roote is of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans finger.

div.head: 5. Pul≈øatilla flore albo. The white Pa≈ø≈øe flower.
div.p: The white Pa≈ø≈øe flower (which Clu≈øius maketh a kinde of Anemone, and yet as hee ≈øaith him≈øelfe, doth more nearely re≈øemble the Pul≈øatilla) hath, from among≈øt a tuft or head of haires, which grow at the toppe of a long blacke roote, many leaues ≈øtanding vpon long ≈øtalkes, which are diuided as it were into three wings or parts, and each part finely cut and diuided, like vnto the Pa≈ø≈øe flower of Denmarke, but ≈øomewhat harder in handling, greeni≈øh on the vpper≈øide, and ≈øomewhat gray vnderneath, and very hairie all ouer: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp the ≈øtalkes, be≈øet at the middle of them with three leaues, as finely cut and diuided as tho≈øe belowe, from aboue which ≈øtandeth the flower, being ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo pendulous as the former, but in the like manner con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues, of a ≈ønow white colour on the in≈øide, and a little browner on the out≈øide, with many yellow thrums in the middle: after the flower is pa≈øt, ri≈øeth vp ≈øuch a like hoary head, compo≈øed as it were of many haires, each whereof hath a ≈ømall ≈øeede fa≈øtened vnto it, like as the former Pa≈ø≈øe flowers haue.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is found in many places of England, vpon dry bankes that lye open to the Sunne.

The ≈øecond was fir≈øt brought, as I take it, by Doctor Lobel from Denmarke, & is one of the two kinds, that Clu≈øius ≈øaith are common in Germanie, this bearing a paler purple flower, and more early then the other, which is the ≈øame with our Engli≈øh, who≈øe flower is ≈øo darke, that it almo≈øt ≈øeemeth blacke.
The red kinde, as Lobel ≈øaith, came from Syria.
The yellow Pa≈ø≈øe flower, which Clu≈øius maketh his third wilde Anemone, was found very plentifully growing at the foote of St. Bernards Hill, neare vnto the Cantons of the Switzers.
The white one groweth on the Alpes neare Au≈øtria, in France likewi≈øe, and other places.

figure.head: 1 Pul≈øatilla purpurea cum folio, ≈øemine, & radice. The purple Pa≈øque flower with leafe, ≈øeed, and root. 2 Pul≈øatilla luteo flore. The yellow Pa≈øque flower. 3 Pul≈øatilla rubro Syriaca Lobelij Red Pa≈øque flower of Lobel. 4 Pul≈øatilla rubra Swertij Swertz his red Pa≈øque flower. 5 Pul≈øatilla flore albo. White Pa≈øque flower. 6 Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris alba Matthioli. The wilde white broad leafed Windflower. 7 Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris tenuifolia alba. The wilde ≈øingle white Windflower 8 Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris tenuifolia lutea. The yellow wilde thin leafed Windflower. 9 Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris trifolia Dodonaei. The three-leafed wilde Windflower. 10 Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno albo. The double white wilde Windflower. 11 Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno purpureo. The double purple wilde Windflower. * Semen ≈øeparatim divul≈øum. The ≈øeed ≈øeparated. ‚Ä† Radix cum folio inferiore. The roote with a lower leafe.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All of them doe flower early in the yeare, that is, in the beginning of Aprill, about which time mo≈øt commonly Ea≈øter doth fall.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their proper names are giuen to each in their ≈øeuerall titles, being all of them kindes of wilde Anemones, as I ≈øaid in the beginning of the Chapter, and ≈øo for the mo≈øt part all Authors doe acknowledge them. We call them in Engli≈øh, becau≈øe they flower about Ea≈øter, Pa≈øque Flower, which is the French name for Ea≈øter, or Euphoniae gratia, Pa≈ø≈øe Flower, which may pa≈ø≈øe currant, without any further de≈øcant on the name, or el≈øe Pul≈øatilla, if you will, being growne old by cu≈øtome.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
The ≈øharpe biting and exulcerating quality of this plant, cau≈øeth it to be of little v≈øe, notwith≈øtanding Ioachimus Camerarius ≈øaith in his Hortus Medicus, that in Boru≈ø≈øia, which is a place in Italy, as I take it, the di≈øtilled water hereof is v≈øed with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, to be giuen to them that are troubled with a Tertian Ague; for he ≈øaith that it is medicamentum
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that is, a medicine of force to helpe ob≈øtructions.

div.head: Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris latifolia alba ≈øiue tertia Matthioli. The white wilde broad leafed Windflower.
div.p: This Windflower hath diuers broad greene leaues, cut into diui≈øions, and dented about, very like vnto a broad leafed Crowfoote, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, hauing ≈øome ≈øuch like cut leaues in the middle thereof, as growe below, but ≈ømaller; on the toppe whereof ≈øtandeth one large white flower, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues for the mo≈øt part, with ≈øome yellow threads in the middle, ≈øtanding about ≈øuch a greene head as is in the tame or garden Anemones, which growing greater after the flower is pa≈øt, is compo≈øed of many ≈ømall ≈øeedes, wrapped in white wooll, which as ≈øoone as they are ripe, rai≈øe them≈øelues vp from the bottome of the head, and flye away with the winde, as the other tame or garden kindes doe: the roote is made of a number of long blacke ≈øtrings, encrea≈øing very much by running vnderground, and ≈øhooting vp in diuers places.

div.head: Anemone ≈øiluestris tenuifolia lutea. The yellow wilde thin leafed Windflower.
div.p: The yellow wilde Anemone ri≈øeth vp with one or two ≈ømall round naked ≈øtalkes, bearing about the middle of them, ≈ømall, ≈øoft, and tender iagged leaues, deeply cut in and indented on the edges about, from aboue which doth grow the ≈øtalke, bearing ≈ømall yellow flowers, ≈øtanding vpon weake foote-≈øtalkes, like vnto a ≈ømall Crowfoot, with ≈øome threads in the middle: the roote is long and ≈ømall, ≈øomewhat like vnto the roote of Pollipodie, creeping vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the earth: this kinde is lower, and ≈øpringeth ≈øomewhat earlier then the other wilde kindes that follow.

div.head: Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris tenuifolia alba ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle white thin leafed wilde Windflower.
div.p:
