This white wilde Anemone ri≈øeth vp with diuers leaues vpon ≈øeuerall long ≈øtalkes; which are ≈øomewhat like vnto the former, but that they are ≈øomewhat harder, and not ≈øo long, nor the diui≈øions of the leaues ≈øo finely ≈ønipt about the edges, but a little broader, and deeper cut in on euery ≈øide: the flowers hereof are larger and broader then the former, white on the in≈øide, and a little purpli≈øh on the out≈øide, e≈øpecially at
the bottome of the flower next vnto the ≈øtalke: the roote of this is very like vnto the la≈øt.
There is another of this kinde, who≈øe flowers are purple,Purpurea. in all other things it is like vnto the white.
And likewi≈øe another, with a blu≈øh or carnation coloured flower.Coccinea ≈øiue ≈øuaue rubens.

There is one that is onely nur≈øed vp with vs in Gardens, that is ≈øomewhat like vnto the≈øe former wilde Anemones in roote and leafe, but that the flower of this, being pure white within, and a little purpli≈øh without,Peregrina alba. con≈øi≈øting of eight or nine ≈ømall round pointed leaues, hath ≈øometimes ≈øome leaues vnder the flower, party coloured white and greene: the flower hath likewi≈øe a greene head, like a Strawberry, compa≈ø≈øed about with white threads, tipt with yellow pendents.

And another of the ≈øame kinde with the la≈øt,Peregrina viridis. who≈øe flower con≈øi≈øting of eight o ‚Ä¢ nine leaues, is of a greeni≈øh colour, except the foure outermo≈øt leaues, which are a little purpli≈øh, and diuided at the points into three parts; the middle part is of a greeni≈øh white colour, with a greene head in the middle as the other.

div.head: Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris trifolia Dodonaei. The three leafed wilde Windflower.
div.p: This wilde Anemone hath his rootes very like vnto the former kindes; the leaues are alwaies three ≈øet together at the toppe of ≈ølender ≈øtalkes, being ≈ømall and indented about, very like vnto a three leafed Gra≈ø≈øe, but ≈ømaller: the flower con≈øi≈øteth of eight ≈ømall leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Crowfoote, but of a whiti≈øh purple or blu≈øh colour, with ≈øome white threads, and a greene rough head in the middle.

div.head: Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno albo. The double white wilde Windflower.
div.p: This double kinde is very like vnto the ≈øingle white kinde before de≈øcribed, both in his long running rootes, and thin leaues, but ≈øomewhat larger: the flowers hereof are very thicke and double, although they be ≈ømall, and of a faint ≈øweete ≈øent, very white after it is full blowne for fiue or ≈øix dayes, but afterwards it becommeth a little purpli≈øh on the in≈øide, but more on the out≈øide: this neuer giueth ≈øeede (although it haue a ≈ømall head in the middle) like as many other double flowers doe.

div.head: Anemone ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno purpureo. The double purple wilde Windflower.
div.p: This double purple kinde hath ≈øuch like iagged leaues as the la≈øt de≈øcribed hath, but more hoarie vnderneath: the flower is of a fine light purple toward the points of the leaues, the bottomes being of a deeper purple, but as thicke, and full of leaues as the former, with a greene head in the middle, like vnto the former: this kinde hath ≈ømall greene leaues on the ≈øtalkes vnder the flowers, cut and diuided like the lower leaues.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt broad leafed Anemone groweth in diuers places of Au≈øtria and Hungary. The yellow in diuers woods in Germany, but not in this Countrey that euer I could learne. The other ≈øingle wilde kindes, ≈øome of them are very frequent throughout the mo≈øt places of England, in Woods, Groues, and Orchards. The double kindes were found, as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, in the Lowe-Countries, in a Wood neare Louaine.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower from the end of March (that is the earlie≈øt) and the beginning of Aprill, vntill May, and the double kindes begin within a while after the ≈øingle kinds are pa≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
They are called Ranunculi ≈øiluarum, and Ranunculi nemorum, and as Clu≈øius
would haue them, Leimonia of Theophra≈øtus; they are generally called of mo≈øt Herbari≈øts Anemones ≈øiluestres, Wilde Anemones or Windflowers. The Italians call them Gengeuo ≈øalnatico, that is, Wilde Ginger, becau≈øe the rootes are, be≈øides the forme, being ≈øomewhat like ≈ømall Ginger, of a biting hot and ≈øharpe ta≈øte.

div.head: Anemone Lu≈øitanica ≈øiue horten≈øis latifolia flore ≈øimplici luteo. The ≈øingle Garden yellow Windflower or Anemone.
div.p: This ≈øingle yellow Anemone or Windflower hath diuers broad round leaues, ≈øomewhat diuided and endented withall on the edges, browni≈øh at the fir≈øt ri≈øing vp out of the ground, and almo≈øt folded together, and after of a ≈øad greene on the vpper≈øide, and reddi≈øh vnderneath; among which ri≈øe vp ≈ømall ≈ølender ≈øtalkes, be≈øet at the middle of them with two or three leaues, more cut and diuided then tho≈øe belowe, with ≈ømall yellow flowers at the toppe of them, con≈øi≈øting of ten or twelue leaues a peece, hauing a few yellow threads in the middle of them, ≈øtanding about a ≈ømall greene head, which in time growing ripe hath ≈ømall flat ≈øeede, inclo≈øed within a ≈øoft wooll or downe, which is ea≈øily blowne away with the winde: the roote groweth downeward into the ground, diuer≈øly ≈øpread with branches here and there, of a browni≈øh yellow on the out≈øide, and whiti≈øh within, ≈øo brittle, that it can hardly bee touched without breaking.

div.head: Anemone latifolia flore luteo duplici. The double yellow Anemone or Windflower.
div.p: This double yellow Anemone hath ≈øuch broad round leaues as the ≈øingle kinde hath, but ≈øomewhat larger or ranker: the ≈øtalkes are be≈øet with larger leaues, more deeply cut in on the edges: the flowers are of a more pale yellow, with ≈øome purpli≈øh veines on the out≈øide, and a little round pointed; but they are all on the in≈øide of a faire yellow colour, con≈øi≈øting of two rowes of leaues, whereof the innermo≈øt is the narrower, with a ≈ømall greene head in the middle, compa≈ø≈øed with yellow threads as in the former: the roote is like the roote of the ≈øingle; neither of the≈øe haue any good ≈øent, and this ≈øpringeth vp and flowreth later then the ≈øingle kinde.

div.head: Anemone latifolia purpurea ≈øtellata ≈øiue papaveracea. The purple Starre Anemone or Windflower.
div.p: The fir≈øt leaues of this purple Anemone, which alwayes ≈øpring vp before Winter, (if the roote be not kept too long out of the ground,) are ≈øomewhat like the leaues of Sanicle or Selfe-heale, but the re≈øt that follow are more deeply cut in and iagged; among which ri≈øe vp diuers round ≈øtalkes, be≈øet with iagged leaues as all other Anemones are, aboue which leaues, the ≈øtalkes ri≈øing two or three inches high, beare one flower a peece, compo≈øed of twelue leaues or more, narrow and pointed, of a bleake purple or whiti≈øh a≈øh-colour, ≈øomewhat ≈øhining on the out≈øide, and of a fine purple colour tending to a murrey on the in≈øide, with many blacki≈øh blew threads or thrummes in the middle of the flower, ≈øet about a head, whereon groweth the ≈øeede, which is ≈ømall and blacke, inclo≈øed in ≈øoft wooll or downe, which flieth away with the winde, carrying the ≈øeede with it, if it be not carefully gathered: the roote is blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and white within, tuberous or knobby, with many fibres growing at it.

div.head: Anemone purpurea Stellata altera. Another purple Starre Anemone.
div.p: There is ≈øo great diuer≈øity in the colours of the flowers of the≈øe broad leafed kinds of Anemones or Windflowers, that they can very hardly be expre≈ø≈øed, although in their leaues there is but little or no difference. I ≈øhall not neede therefore to make ≈øeuerall de≈øcriptions of euery one that ≈øhall be ≈øet downe; but it will be ≈øufficient, I thinke, to giue you the di≈øtinctions of the flowers: for as I ≈øaid, therein is the greate≈øt and chiefe≈øt difference. This other Starre Anemone differeth not from the former in leafe or flower, but onely that this is of a more pale ≈øullen colour on the out≈øide, and of a paler purple colour on the in≈øide.

figure.head:
1 Anemone latifolia flore luteo ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle yellow Anemone. 2 Anemone latifolia flore luteo duplici. The double yellow Anemone. 3 Anemone latifolia flore purpureo Stellaeto. The purple Starre Anemone. 4 Anemone latifolia purpurea dilutior. The pale purple Starre Anemone. 5 Anemone latifolia flore miniate dilut ‚Ä¢ . The pale red Anemone. 6 Anemone latifolia coccinea Cardinalis dicta. The Cardinall Anemone. 7 Anemone latifolia incarnata Hi≈øpanica. The Spani≈øh incarnate Anemone. 8 Anemone latifolia Pa ‚Ä¢ o ≈øimplex dicta. The le≈ø≈øer Orenge tawney Anemone. 9 Anemone latifolia flore carneo. The carnation Anemone. 10 Anemone latifolia Arantiaca ≈øiue Pauo maior. The double Orenge tawney Anemone. 11 Anemone Superitica ≈øiue Cypari≈øsia. The double Anemone of Cyprus. 12 Anemone latifolia flore pleno albicante. The double pale blu≈øh Anemone. 13 Anemone Chalcedonica maxima. The great Spani≈øh Marigold Anemone. 14 Anemone Ca ‚Ä¢ umeni ≈øiue Perfica. The double Per≈øian Anemone. ‚Ä¢
Anemon ‚Ä¢ latifolia ra ‚Ä¢ . The roote of a great Anemone.

div.p: Viola purpureaThere is another, who≈øe flower hath eight leaues, as many of them that follow haue (although diuers ≈øorts haue but ≈øix leaues in a flower) and is of a Violet purple, and therefore is called, The Violet purple Anemone.
Varietas.Of all the≈øe three ≈øorts la≈øt de≈øcribed, there be other that differ only in hauing white bottomes, ≈øome ≈ømaller and ≈øome larger.

Purpurea ≈øtriata.There is al≈øo another of the ≈øame Violet purple colour with the former, but a little paler, tending more to redne≈ø≈øe, who≈øe flowers haue many white lines and ≈øtripes through the leaues, and is called, The purple ≈øtript Anemone.

Carnea vivaci≈øsima ≈øimplex.There is another, who≈øe greene leaues are ≈øomewhat larger, and ≈øo is the flower likewi≈øe, con≈øi≈øting of eight leaues, and ≈øometimes of more, of the colour of Carnation ≈øilke, ≈øometimes pale and ≈øometimes deeper, with a whiti≈øh circle about the bottome of the leaues, which circle in ≈øome is larger, and more to be ≈øeene then in others, when the flower layeth it ≈øelfe open with the heate of the Sunne, hauing blewi≈øh threads in the middle. This may be called, the Carnation Anemone,
Perficiviolacea.We haue another, who≈øe flower is betweene a Peach colour and a Violet, which is v≈øually called a Gredeline colour.
Cochenille.And another of a fine reddi≈øh Violet or purple, which we call, The Cochenille Anemone.
Cardinalis.And another of a rich crim≈øon red colour, and may be called, The Cardinall Anemone.
Sanguinea.Another of a deeper, but not ≈øo liuely a red, called, The bloud red Anemone.
Crame≈øina.Another of an ordinary crim≈øon colour, called, The crim≈øon Anemone.
Coccinea.Another of a Stamell colour, neere vnto a Scarlet.
Incarnata.Another of a fine delayed red or fle≈øh colour, and may bee called, The Incarnadine Anemone.
Incarnata Hi≈øpanica.Another who≈øe flower is of a liuely fle≈øh colour, ≈øhadowed with yellow, and may be called, The Spani≈øh Incarnate Anemone.
Rube≈øcens.Another of a faire whiti≈øh red, which we call, The Blu≈øh Anemone.

Mo≈øchutella.Another who≈øe flower con≈øi≈øteth of eight leaues, of a darke whiti≈øh colour, ≈øtript all ouer with veines of a fine blu≈øh colour, the bottomes being white, this may be called, The Nutmegge Anemone.
Enfumata.Another who≈øe flower is of a pale whiti≈øh colour, tending to a gray, ≈øuch as the Monkes and Friers were wont to weare with vs, and is called, A Monkes gray.

Pauo maior ≈øimplici flore.There is another, who≈øe leafe is ≈øomewhat broader then many or mo≈øt of the Anemones, comming neare vnto the leafe of the great double Orenge coloured Anemone; the flower whereof is ≈øingle, con≈øi≈øting of eight large or broad leaues, very neare vnto the ≈øame Orenge colour, that is in the double flower hereafter de≈øcribed, but ≈øomewhat deeper. This is v≈øually called in Latine, Pauo maior ≈øimplici flore, and we in Engli≈øh, The great ≈øingle Orenge tawnie Anemone.
Pauo minor.There is likewi≈øe of this kinde another, who≈øe flower is le≈ø≈øer, and called, The le≈ø≈øer Orenge tawnie Anemone.

Varietas magna ex ≈øeminio.There is be≈øides the≈øe expre≈ø≈øed, ≈øo great a variety of mixt colours in the flowers of this kinde of Anemone with broad leaues, ari≈øing euery yeare from the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede of ≈øome of the choi≈øe≈øt and fitte≈øt for that purpo≈øe, that it is wonderfull to ob≈øerue, not onely the variety of ≈øingle colours, but the mixture of two or three colours in one flower, be≈øides the diuer≈øity of the bottomes of the flowers, ≈øome hauing white or yellowi≈øh bottomes, and ≈øome none, and yet both of the ≈øame colour; and likewi≈øe in the thrums or threads in the middle: But the greate≈øt wonder of beauty is in variety of double flowers, that ari≈øe from among the other ≈øingle ones, ≈øome hauing two or three rowes of leaues in the flowers, and ≈øome ≈øo thicke of leaues as a double Marigold, or double Crowfoote, and of the ≈øame ≈øeuerall colours that are in the ≈øingle flowers, that it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to expre≈ø≈øe them ≈øeuerally, and (as is ≈øaid before) ≈øome falling out to bee double in one yeare, which will proue ≈øingle or le≈ø≈øe double in another,
yet very many abiding con≈øtant double as at the fir≈øt; and therefore let this briefe recitall be ≈øufficient in ≈øtead of a particular of all the colours.

div.head: Anemone Chalcedonica maxima ver≈øicolor. The great double Windflower of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This great Anemone of Con≈øtantinople hath broader and greener leaues then any of the former kindes, and not ≈øo much diuided or cut in at the edges, among which ri≈øe vp one or two ≈øtalkes, (≈øeldome more from one roote) hauing ≈øome leaues about the middle of the ≈øtalke, as other Anemones haue, and bearing at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes one large flower a peece, very double, who≈øe outermo≈øt leaues being broade≈øt, are greeni≈øh at the fir≈øt, but afterwards red, hauing ≈øometimes ≈øome greene abiding ≈øtill in the leaues, and the red ≈øtriped through it: the other leaues which are within the≈øe are ≈ømaller, and of a perfect red colour; the innermo≈øt being ≈ømalle≈øt, are of the ≈øame red colour, but turned ≈øomewhat inward, hauing no thrummes or threads in the middle, as the former haue, and bearing no ≈øeede: the roote is blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and white within, thicke and tuberous as the other kindes, but thicker ≈øet and clo≈øe together, not ≈øhooting any long ≈ølender rootes as others doe. Some Gentlewomen call this Anemone, The Spani≈øh Marigold.

div.head: Anemone Chalcedonica altera ≈øiue Pano maior flore duplici. The great double Orenge tawney Anemone.
div.p: This other great Anemone of Con≈øtantinople hath his large leaues ≈øo like vnto the la≈øt, that one can hardly di≈øtingui≈øh them a≈øunder; the ≈øtalke hath al≈øo ≈øuch like leaues ≈øet vpon it, bearing at the toppe a faire large flower, con≈øi≈øting of many leaues ≈øet in two or three rowes at the mo≈øt, but not ≈øo thicke or double as the la≈øt, yet ≈øeeming to be but one thicke rowe of many ≈ømall and long leaues, of an excellent red or crim≈øon colour, wherein ≈øome yellow is mixed, which maketh that colour is called an Orenge tawney; the bottomes of the leaues are red, compa≈ø≈øed with a whiti≈øh circle, the thrummie head in the middle being be≈øet with many darke blacki≈øh threads: the roote is like the former.

div.head: Anemone Superitica ≈øiue Cypari≈øsia. The double Anemone of Cyprus.
div.p: This Anemone (which the Dutchmen call Superitz, and as I haue beene enformed, came from the I≈øle of Cyprus) hath leaues very like the la≈øt double Anemone, but not altogether ≈øo large: the flower con≈øi≈øteth of ≈ømaller leaues, of colour very neare vnto the la≈øt double Orenge coloured Anemone, but more thicke of leaues, and as double as the fir≈øt, although not ≈øo great a flower, without any head in the middle, or thrums about it as is in the la≈øt, and differeth not in the roote from either of them both.

Somewhat like vnto this kinde, or as it were betweene this and the fir≈øt kinde of the≈øe great double Anemones, we haue diuers other ≈øorts, bearing flowers very thicke and double; ≈øome of them being white, or whiti≈øh, or purple, deeper or paler, and ≈øome of a reddi≈øh colour tending to Scarlet or a Carnation colour, and ≈øome al≈øo of a blu≈øh or fle≈øh colour, and diuers other colours, and all of them continue con≈øtant in their colours.

div.head: Anemone Cacumeni Maringi ≈øiue Per≈øica. The double Per≈øian Anemone.
div.p: This rare Anemone, which is ≈øaid to come out of Per≈øia to Con≈øtantinople, and from thence to vs, is in leafe and roote very like vnto the former double Anemones before de≈øcribed; onely the flower hereof is rather like vnto the ≈øecond great double Orenge coloured Anemone, v≈øually called Pauo maior flore pleno, being compo≈øed of three rowes of leaues, the outtermo≈øt rowe con≈øi≈øting of ten or twelue larger leaues, and tho≈øe more inward le≈ø≈øer and more in number, but all of them variably mixed with white, red, and yellow, hauing the bottomes of the leaues white: but in≈øtead of a middle head with thrums about it, as the other hath, this hath a few narrow leaues, of a deepe yellow colour in the middle of the flower, ≈øtanding vpright.

Hauing thus farre proceeded in the two parts of the kindes of Anemones or Windflowers, it remaineth to entreate of the re≈øt, which is tho≈øe Anemones which haue thin cut leaues, whereof ≈øome haue reckoned vp thirty ≈øorts with ≈øingle flowers, which I confe≈ø≈øe I haue not ≈øeene; but ≈øo many as haue come to my knowledge, I ≈øhall here ≈øet downe.

div.head: Anemone tenuifolia ≈øiue Geranifolia caerulea. The Watchet Anemone or Storkes bill leafed Windflower.
div.p:
This fir≈øt Windflower with thin cut leaues, ri≈øeth not out of the ground vntil the great Winter fro≈øt be pa≈øt, that is, about the middle or end of February, and are ≈øomewhat browni≈ø ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ t their fir≈øt appearing, but afterwards ≈øpread into wings of greene leaues, ≈øom ‚Ä¢ what broader then the re≈øt that follow, diuided into three parts, & each part into
‚Ä¢ ree leaues, euery one cut in about the edges, one ≈øtanding again≈øt another vpon a long ≈ølender foote-≈øtalke, and the end leafe by it ≈øelfe: among the≈øe ri≈øeth vp two or three greene ≈øtalkes, garni≈øhed with ≈øuch like thin leaues as are at the bottome, from aboue which ri≈øe the flowers, but one vpon a ≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of fourteene or fifteene ≈ømall pale blew or watchet leaues, le≈ø≈øer then any of the ≈øingle kindes that follow, compa≈ø≈øing many whiti≈øh threads, and a ≈ømall greene head in the middle, ≈øomewhat like the head of the wilde Crowfoote, wherein is contained ≈øuch like ≈øeede: the roote is blacki≈øh without, thru≈øting out into long tuberous peeces, ≈øomewhat like vnto ≈øome of the broad leafed Anemones.
Alba.Of this kinde there is another, who≈øe leaues are not browne at their fir≈øt ri≈øing, but greene, and the flowers are white, in other things not differing.

div.head: Anemone tenuifolia purpurea vulgaris. The ordinary purple Anemone with thin leaues.
div.p: This purple Anemone which is mo≈øt common, and therefore the le≈ø≈øe regarded, hath many winged leaues ≈øtanding vpon ≈øeuerall ≈øtalkes, cut and diuided into diuers leaues, much like vnto the leaues of a Carrot; among which ri≈øe vp ≈øtalkes with ≈øome leaues thereon (as is v≈øuall to the whole Family of Anemones, both wilde and tame, as is before ≈øaid;) at the toppes whereof ≈øtand the flowers, made of ≈øix leaues mo≈øt v≈øually, but ≈øometimes they will haue ≈øeuen or eight, being very large, and of a perfect purple Violet colour, very faire and liuely: the middle head hath many blacki≈øh thrums or threads about it, which I could neuer ob≈øerue in my Gardens to beare ≈øeed: the roote is ≈ømaller, and more ≈øpreading euery way into ≈ømall long flat tuberous parts, then any other kindes of ≈øingle or double Anemones.

Carnea pallida.There is another very like in leafe and roote vnto the former, but the flower is nothing ≈øo large, and is whiti≈øh, tending to a blu≈øh colour, and of a deeper blu≈øh colour toward the bottome of the flower, with blacki≈øh blew thrums in the middle, and giueth no ≈øeede that I could euer ob≈øerue.

Carnea viuida vnguibus albis.There is likewi≈øe another like vnto the la≈øt in leafe and flower, but that the flower is larger then it, and is of a liuely blu≈øh colour, the leaues hauing white bottomes.
Alba venis purpureis.And another, who≈øe flower is white, with purple coloured veines and ≈øtripes through euery leafe, and is a le≈ø≈øer flower then the other.

div.head: Anemone tenuifolia coccinea ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle Scarlet Anemone with thin leaues.
div.p: The leaues of this Scarlet Windflower are ≈øomewhat like vnto the former, but a little broader, and not ≈øo finely cut and diuided: the flower con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øix rea≈øonable large leaues, of an excellent red colour, which we call a Scarlet; the bottomes of the leaues are large and white, and the thrums or threads in the middle of a blacki≈øh purple colour: the roote is tuberous, but con≈øi≈øting of thicker peeces, ≈øomewhat like vnto the rootes of the broad leafed Anemones, but ≈øomewhat browne, and not ≈øo blacke, and mo≈øt like vnto the roote of the double Scarlet Anemone.

Coccinea ab≈ø
que vnguibus.There is another of this kinde, who≈øe flower is neare vnto the ≈øame colour, but this hath no white bottomes at all in his leaues.
F ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h ‚Ä¢ lo≈øericeo.We haue another which hath as large a flower as any ≈øingle, and is of an Orient deepe red crim≈øon Veluet colour.
Sanguinea.There is another of a deeper red colour, and is called, The bloud red ≈øingle Anemone.
Rubra fundo luteo. Coccinea dilutior.And another, who≈øe flower is red with the bottomes yellow.
Another of a perfect crim≈øon colour, whereof ≈øome haue round pointed leaues, and others ≈øharpe pointed, and ≈øome a little lighter or deeper then others.
Alba ≈øtaminibus purpureis.There is al≈øo one, who≈øe flower is pure white with blewi≈øh purple thrums in the middle.
Carnea Hi≈øpanica.And another, who≈øe flower is very great, of a kinde of ≈øullen blu≈øh colour, but yet plea≈øant, with blewi≈øh threads in the middle.
Alba carneis venis. Alba purpureis vnguibus.And another with blu≈øh veines in euery leafe of the white flower.
And another, the flower whereof is white, the bottomes of the leaues being purple.
Purpura≈øcens.Another who≈øe flower con≈øi≈øteth of many ≈ømall narrow leaues, of a pale purple or blu≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and ≈øomewhat deeper within.

Facie florum pomi ≈øimplex.There is another like in leafe and roote vnto the fir≈øt Scarlet Anemone, but the flower hereof con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øeuen large leaues without any bottomes, of a white colour, hauing edges, and ≈øome large ≈øtripes al≈øo of a carnation or fle≈øh colour to bee ≈øeene in them, marked ≈øomewhat like an Apple blo≈ø≈øome, and thereupon it is called in Latine, Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex alba instar florum pomi, or facie florum pomi, that is to ≈øay in Engli≈øh, The ≈øingle thin leafed Anemone with Apple blo≈ø≈øome flowers.
Multiplex.I haue heard that there is one of this kinde with double flowers.

div.head: 1. Anemone tenuifolia flore coccineo pleno vulgaris. The common double red or Scarlet Anemone.
div.p: The leaues of this double Anemone are very like vnto the leaues of the ≈øingle Scarlet Anemone, but not ≈øo thin cut and diuided as that with the purple flower: the flower hereof when it fir≈øt openeth it ≈øelfe, con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øix and ≈øometimes of ≈øeuen or eight broad leaues, of a deepe red, or excellent Scarlet colour, the middle head being thick clo≈øed, and of a greeni≈øh colour, which after the flower hath ≈øtood blowne ≈øome time, doth gather colour, and openeth it ≈øelfe into many ≈ømall leaues, very thicke, of a more pale red colour, and more Stamell like then the outer leaues: the root of this is thicke and tuberous, very like vnto the root of the ≈øingle Scarlet Anemone.

div.head: 2. Anemone tenuifolia flore coccineo pleno variegata. The party coloured double Crim≈øon Anemone.
div.p: We haue a kinde hereof, varying neither in roote, leafe, or forme of flower from the former, but in the colour, in that this will haue ≈øometimes the outer broad leaues party coloured, with whiti≈øh or blu≈øh coloured great ≈øtreakes in the red leaues both in≈øide and out≈øide; as al≈øo diuers of the middle or inner leaues ≈øtriped in the ≈øame manner: the roote hereof giueth fairer flowers in ≈øome yeares then in others, and ≈øometimes giue flowers all red againe.

div.head: 3. Anemone tenuifolia flore coccineo ≈øaturo pleno. The double crim≈øon Veluet Anemone.
div.p: Wee haue another al≈øo, who≈øe flower is of a deepe Orenge tawny crim≈øon colour, neare vnto the colour of the outer leaues, of the le≈ø≈øer French Marigold, and not differing from the former in any thing el≈øe.

div.head: 4. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno ≈øuauerubente. The greater double blu≈øh Anemone.
div.p:
There is ≈ømall difference to be di≈øcerned, either in the roote or leaues of this from
the former double Scarlet Anemone, ≈øauing that the leaues hereof are a little broader, and ≈øeeme to bee of a little fre≈øher greene colour: the flower of this is as large almo≈øt, and as double as the former, and the inner leaues likewi≈øe almo≈øt as large as they, being of a whiti≈øh or fle≈øh colour at the fir≈øt opening of them, but afterwards become of a mo≈øt liuely blu≈øh colour; the bottomes of the leaues abiding of a deeper blu≈øh, and with long ≈øtanding, the tops of the leaues will turne almo≈øt wholly white againe.

div.head: 5. Anemone tenuifolia flore albo pleno. The double white Anemone.
div.p: This double white Anemone differeth little from the former blu≈øh Anemone, but in that it is ≈ømaller in all the parts thereof, and al≈øo that the flower hereof being wholly of a pure white colour, without any ≈øhew of blu≈øh therein, hath the middle thrummes much ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter then it, and not ri≈øing vp ≈øo high, but ≈øeeme as if they were chipped off euen at the toppes.

div.head: 6. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno albicante. The le≈ø≈øer double blu≈øh Anemone.
div.p: This ≈ømall double blu≈øh Anemone differeth very little from the double white la≈øt recited, but onely in the colour of the flower: for they are both much about the bigne≈ø≈øe one of another, the middle thrums likewi≈øe being as ≈ømall and ≈øhort, and as euen aboue, onely the flower at the fir≈øt opening is almo≈øt white, but afterwards the outer leaues haue a more ≈øhew of blu≈øh in them, and the middle part a little deeper then they.

div.head: 7. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno purpureo violaceo. The double purple Anemone.
div.p: This double purple Anemone is al≈øo of the ≈øame kindred with the fir≈øt double red or Scarlet Anemone for the form or doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower, con≈øi≈øting but of ≈øix or ≈øeuen leaues at the mo≈øt in this our Country, although in the hotter it hath ten or twelue, or more as large leaues for the outer border, and as large ≈ømall leaues for the inner middle al≈øo, and almo≈øt as double, but of a deepe purple tending toward a Violet colour, the outer leaues being not ≈øo deepe as the inner: the roote and leafe commeth neare vnto the ≈øingle purple Anemone before de≈øcribed, but that the roote ≈øpreadeth not ≈øo ≈ømall and ≈øo much.

div.head: 8. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno purpureo caeruleo. The double blew Anemone.
div.p: This Anemone differeth not in any thing from the former double purple, but onely that the flower is paler, and more tending to a blew colour.

div.head: 9. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno ro≈øeo. The double Ro≈øe coloured Anemone.
div.p: The double Ro≈øe coloured Anemone differeth al≈øo in nothing from the former double purple, but onely in the flower, which is ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo thicke and double, and that it is of a reddi≈øh colour, neare vnto the colour of a pale red Ro≈øe, or of a deepe coloured Damaske.

div.head: 10. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno carneo viuaci≈øsimo. The double Carnation Anemone.
div.p: This Anemone, both in roote, leafe, and flower, commeth neare≈øt vnto the former double white Anemone, for the largene≈ø≈øe and doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower, and in the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe of the middle thrums, and euenne≈ø≈øe at the toppes of them, being not ≈øo large and great a flower as the double purple, either in the inner or outter leaues, but yet is very faire, thicke and double, and of a mo≈øt liuely Carnation ≈øilke colour, very deepe, both the outer leaues and middle thrums al≈øo ≈øo bright, that it doth as it were amaze, and yet delight the minde of the beholder, but by long ≈øtanding in the Sun, waxe a little paler, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe away as all the mo≈øt beautifull flowers doe.

figure.head: 1 Anemone tenuifolia fimplex purpurea. The ≈øingle purple Anemone with thin cut leaues. 2 Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex alba pura. The ≈øingle pure white Anemone. 3 Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex cherme≈øina. The ≈øingle bright Crim≈øon Anemone. 4 Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex ≈øanguinea. The ≈øingle bloud red Anemone. 5 Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex facie florum pomi. The ≈øingle Apple bloome Anemone. 6 Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex purpura≈øcens. The ≈øingle purpli≈øh blu≈øh Anemone. 7 Anemone tenuifolia ≈øimplex alba vnguibus carneis. The ≈øingle white Anemone with blu≈øh bottomes 8 Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno coccineo. The double red or ordinary Scarlet Anemone. 9. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno rubr ‚Ä¢ fu≈øca coma Ama ‚Ä¢ antina. The double purple Veluet Anemone. 10 Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno purpuro violaceo. The double blewi≈øh purple Anemone. 11 Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno incarnedini coloris ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ricei vivaci≈øsimi. The double Carnation Anemone, or of a liuely Carnation ≈øilke colour.

div.head: 11. Anemone tenuifolia flore rubrofu≈øco pleno coma Amarantina. The double purple Veluet Anemone.
div.p: This double Veluet Anemone is in all things like the la≈øt de≈øcribed Carnation Anemone, but ≈øomewhat larger, the difference con≈øi≈øteth in the colour of the flower, which in this is of a deep or ≈øad crim≈øon red colour for the outer leaues, and of a deep purple Veluet colour in the middle thrums, re≈øembling the colour of the le≈ø≈øer Amaranthus purpureus, or Purple flower gentle hereafter de≈øcribed, whereof it tooke the name, which middle thrums are as fine and ≈ømall, and as euen at the toppes as the white or la≈øt Carnation Anemones.

div.head: 12. Anemone tenuifolia flore pleno tricolor. The double purple Veluet Anemone of three colours.
div.p: This double Anemone al≈øo is very like the la≈øt de≈øcribed Anemone, but that in the middle of the purple thrums, there thru≈øteth forth a tuft of threads or leaues of a more light crim≈øon colour.

And thus much for the kindes of Anemones or Windflowers, ≈øo farre forth as haue hitherto come to our knowledge; yet I doubt not, but that more varieties haue beene el≈øewhere collected, and will be al≈øo in our Countrey daily and yearly ob≈øerued by diuers, that rai≈øe them vp from ≈øowing the ≈øeede, wherein lyeth a pretty art, not yet familiarly knowne to our Nation, although it be very frequent in the Lowe-Countries, where their indu≈øtry hath bred and nouri≈øhed vp ≈øuch diuer≈øities and varieties, that they haue valued ≈øome Anemones at ≈øuch high rates, as mo≈øt would wonder at, and none of our Nation would purcha≈øe, as I thinke. And I doubt not, if wee would be as curious as they, but that both our ayre and ≈øoyle would produce as great variety, as euer hath been ≈øeene in the Lowe-Countries; which to procure, if any of our Nation will take ≈øo much paines in ≈øowing the ≈øeedes of Anemones, as diuers haue done of Tulipas: I will ≈øet them downe the be≈øt directions for that purpo≈øe that I haue learned, or could by much ≈øearch and tryall attaine vnto; yet I mu≈øt let them vnder≈øtand thus much al≈øo, that there is not ≈øo great variety of double flowers rai≈øed from the ≈øeede of the thin leafed Anemones, as from the broad leafed ones.

Fir≈øt therefore (as I ≈øaid before) concerning Tulipas, there is ≈øome ≈øpeciall choice to be made of ≈øuch flowers, who≈øe ≈øeed is fitte≈øt to be taken. Of the Latifolias, the double Orenge tawney ≈øeede being ≈øowne, yeeldeth pretty varieties, but the purples, and reds, or crim≈øons, either Latifolias or Tenuifolias, yeeld ≈ømall variety, but ≈øuch as draw neare≈øt to their originall, although ≈øome be a little deeper or lighter then others. But the light colours be they which are the chiefe for choice, as white, a≈øh-colour, blu≈øh or carnation, light orenge, ≈øimple or party coloured, ≈øingle or double, if they beare ≈øeede, which mu≈øt bee carefully gathered, and that not before it bee thorough ripe, which you ≈øhall know by the head; for when the ≈øeede with the wolline≈ø≈øe beginneth to ri≈øe a little of it ≈øelfe at the lower end, it mu≈øt bee then quickly gathered, le≈øt the winde carry it all away. After it is thus carefully gathered, it mu≈øt be laid to dry for a weeke or more, which then being gently rubbed with a little dry ≈øand or earth, will cau≈øe the ≈øeede to be ≈øomewhat better ≈øeparated, although not thoroughly from the woolline≈ø≈øe or downe that compa≈ø≈øeth it.

Within a moneth at the mo≈øt after the ≈øeede is thus gathered and prepared, it mu≈øt be ≈øowne; for by that meanes you ≈øhall gaine a yeare in the growing, ouer that you ≈øhould doe if you ≈øowed it in the next Spring.

If there remaine any woolline≈ø≈øe in the ≈øeede, pull it in ≈øunder as well as you can, and then ≈øowe your ≈øeede rea≈øonable thin, and not too thicke, vpon a plaine ≈ømooth bed of fine earth, or rather in pots or tubbes, and after the ≈øowing, ≈øift or gently ≈øtraw ouer them ≈øome fine good fre≈øh mould, about one fingers thickne≈ø≈øe at the mo≈øt for the fir≈øt time: And about a moneth after their fir≈øt ≈øpringing vp, ≈øift or ≈øtraw ouer them in like manner another fingers thickne≈ø≈øe of fine earth, and in the meane time if the weather proue dry, you mu≈øt water them gently and often, but not to ouerglut them with moi≈øture; and thus doing, you ≈øhall haue them ≈øpring vp before Winter, and
grow pretty ≈øtrong, able to abide the ≈øharpe Winter in their nonage, in v≈øing ≈øome little care to couer them loo≈øely with ≈øome fearne, or fur≈øe, or beane hame, or ≈øtraw, or any ≈øuch, which yet mu≈øt not lye clo≈øe vpon them, nor too farre from them neither.

The next Spring after the ≈øowing, if you will, but it is better if you ≈øtay vntill Augu≈øt, you may then remoue them, and ≈øet them in order by rowes, with ≈øufficient di≈øtance one from another, where they may abide, vntill you ≈øee what manner of flower each plant will beare, which you may di≈øpo≈øe of according to your minde.

Many of them being thus ordered (if your mould be fine, loo≈øe, and fre≈øh, not ≈øtonie, clayi≈øh, or from a middin) will beare flowers the ≈øecond yeare after the ≈øowing, and mo≈øt or all of them the third yeare, if the place where you ≈øowe them, be not annoyed with the ≈ømoake of Brewers, Dyers, or Maultkils, which if it be, then will they neuer thriue well.

Thus much haue I thought good to ≈øet downe, to incite ≈øome of our owne Nation to be indu≈øtrious; and to helpe them forward, haue giuen ≈øuch rules of directions, that I doubt not, but they will vpon the tryall and view of the variety, proceede as well in the ≈øowing of Anemones as of Tulipas.

I cannot (Gentlewomen) withhold one other ≈øecret from you, which is to informe you how you may ≈øo order Anemones, that after all others ordinarily are pa≈øt, you may haue them in flower for two or three moneths longer then are to be ≈øeene with any other, that v≈øeth not this cour≈øe I direct you.

The ordinary time to plant Anemones, is mo≈øt commonly in Augu≈øt, which will beare flower ≈øome peraduenture before Winter, but mo≈øt v≈øually in February, March, and Aprill, few or none of them abiding vntill May; but if you will keepe ≈øome roots out of the ground vnplanted, vntill February, March, and Aprill, and plant ≈øome at one time, and ≈øome at another, you ≈øhall haue them beare flower according to their planting, tho≈øe that ≈øhall be planted in February, will flower about the middle or end of May, and ≈øo the re≈øt accordingly after that manner: And thus may you haue the plea≈øure of the≈øe plants out of their naturall ≈øea≈øons, which is not permitted to be enioyed in any other that I know, Nature being not ≈øo prone to bee furthered by art in other things as in this. Yet regard, that in keeping your Anemone rootes out of the ground for this purpo≈øe, you neither keep them too dry, nor yet too moi≈øt, for ≈øprouting or rotting; and in planting them, that you ≈øet them not in too open a ≈øunny place, but where they may be ≈øomewhat ≈øhadowed.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: I ≈øhall not need to ≈øpend much time in relating the ≈øeuerall places of the≈øe Anemones, but onely to declare that the mo≈øt of them that haue not beene rai≈øed from ≈øeed, haue come from Con≈øtantinople to vs; yet the fir≈øt broad leafed or yellow Anemone, was fir≈øt found in Portugall, and from thence brought into the≈øe parts. And the fir≈øt purple Starre Anemone in Germanie, yet was the ≈øame ≈øent among others from Con≈øtantinople al≈øo. And the fir≈øt thin cut leafed Anemone came fir≈øt out of Italy, although many of that ≈øort haue come likewi≈øe from Con≈øtantinople. And ≈øo haue the double red or Scarlet Anemones, and the great double blu≈øh, which I fir≈øt had by the gift of Mr. Humfrey Packington of Worce≈øter≈øhire E≈øquire, at Haruington.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The times of their flowring are ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in the de≈øcriptions, or in the rules for planting.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The Turki≈øh names whereby the great double broad leafed kindes haue beene ≈øent vnto vs, were Gial Catamer, and Giul Catamer lale; And Binizade, Binizante, and Galipoli lale for the thinne cut leafed Anemones. All Authors haue called them Anemones, and are the true Herba venti.
Wee call them in Engli≈øh eyther Anemones, after the Greeke name, or Windflowers, after the Latine.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is little v≈øe of the≈øe in Phy≈øicke in our dayes, eyther for inward or outward di≈øea≈øes; onely the leaues are v≈øed in the Ointment called Marciatum, which is compo≈øed of many other hot herbes, and is v≈øed in cold griefes, to warme and comfort the parts. The roote, by rea≈øon of the ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe, is apt to drawe downe rheume, if it be ta≈øted or chewed in the mouth.

div.head: Aconitum. Wolfebane.
div.p: THere be diuers ≈øorts of Wolfebanes which are not fit for this booke, but are re≈øerued for a generall Hi≈øtory or Garden of Simples, yet among them there are ≈øome, that notwith≈øtanding their euill quality, may for the beauty of their flowers take vp a roome in this Garden, of whom I meane to entreate in this place: And fir≈øt of the Winter Wolfesbane, which for the beauty, as well as the earline≈ø≈øe of his flowers, being the fir≈øt of all other, that ≈øhew them≈øelues after Chri≈øtmas, de≈øerueth a prime place; and therefore for the likene≈ø≈øe of the rootes vnto the Anemones, I ioyne it next vnto them.

div.head: 1. Aconitum Hyemale. The Winters Wolfesbane.
div.p: This little plant thru≈øteth vp diuers leaues out of the ground, in the deepe of Winter oftentimes, if there be any milde weather in Ianaury, but mo≈øt commonly after the deepe fro≈øts, bearing vp many times the ≈ønow vpon the heads of the leaues, which like vnto the Anemone, doe euery leafe ri≈øe from the roote vpon ≈øeuerall ≈øhort foote≈øtalkes, not aboue foure fingers high, ≈øome hauing flowers in the middle of them, (which come vp fir≈øt mo≈øt v≈øually) and ≈øome none, which leaues ≈øtand as it were round, the ≈øtalke ri≈øing vp vnder the middle of the leafe, deeply cut in and ga≈øhed to the middle ≈øtalke almo≈øt, of a very faire deepe greene colour, in the middle whereof, clo≈øe vnto the leafe, ≈øtandeth a ≈ømall yellow flower, made of ≈øix leaues, very like a Crowfoote, with yellow threads in the middle: after the flower is fallen, there ri≈øe vp diuers ≈ømall hornes or cods ≈øet together, wherein are contained whiti≈øh yellow round ≈øeede. The roote is tuberous, ≈øo like both for ≈øhape and colour vnto the rootes of Anemones, that they will ea≈øily deceiue one not well experienced, but that it is browner and ≈ømoother without, and yellow within, if it be broken.

div.head: 2. Aconitum flore albido, ≈øiue Aconitum luteum Ponticum. The whiti≈øh yellow Wolfesbane.
div.p: This Wolfesbane ≈øhooteth not out of the ground vntill the Spring be well begun, and then it ≈øendeth forth great broad greene leaues, deeply cut in about the edges, not much vnlike the leaues of the great wilde Crowfoote, but much greater; from among which leaues ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtrong ≈øtiffe ≈øtalke, three foote high, hauing here and there leaues ≈øet vpon it, like vnto the lowe≈øt, but ≈ømaller; the toppe of the ≈øtalke is diuided into three or foure branches, whereon are ≈øet diuers pale yellow flowers, which turne at the la≈øt to be almo≈øt white, in fa≈øhion like almo≈øt vnto the flowers of the Helmet flower, but much ≈ømaller, and not gaping ≈øo wide open: after the flowers are pa≈øt come vp diuers ≈øhort poddes, wherein is contained blacke ≈øeede: the roote is made of a number of darke browne ≈øtrings, which ≈øpread and fa≈øten them≈øelues ≈øtrongly in the ground.

div.head: 3. Napellus verus flore caeruleo. Blew Helmet flower or Monkes hood.
div.p: The Helmet flower hath diuers leaues of a fre≈øh greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and grayi≈øh vnderneath, much ≈øpread abroad, and cut into many ≈ølits and notches, more then any of the Wolfebanes; the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp two or three foot high, be≈øet to the top with the like leaues, but ≈ømaller: the toppe is ≈øometimes diuided into two or three branches, but more v≈øually without, whereon ≈øtand many large flowers one aboue another, in forme very like vnto a Hood or open Helmet, being compo≈øed of fiue leaues, the vppermo≈øt of which and the greate≈øt, is hollow, like vnto an Helmet or Headpeece, two other ≈ømall leaues are at the ≈øides of the Helmet, clo≈øing it like cheekes, and come ≈øomewhat vnder, and two other which are the ≈ømalle≈øt hang down like labels, or as if a clo≈øe Helmet were opened, and ≈øome peeces hung by, of a perfect or faire blew colour, (but grow darker‚ñ™ hauing ≈øtood long) which cau≈øeth it be ≈øo nouri≈øhed vp in Gardens, that their flowers, as was v≈øuall in former times, and yet is in many Countrey places, may be laid among greene herbes in windowes and roomes for the Summer time: but although their beauty may be entertained for the v≈øes afore≈øaid, yet beware they come not neare your tongue or lippes, le≈øt they tell you to your co≈øt, they are not ≈øo good as they ≈øeeme to be: in the midde≈øt of the flower, when it is open and gapeth wide, are ≈øeene certaine ≈ømall threads like beards, ≈øtanding about a middle head, which when the flower is pa≈øt, groweth into three or foure, or more ≈ømall blacki≈øh pods, containing in them blacke ≈øeede: the rootes are browni≈øh on the out≈øide, and white within, ≈øomewhat bigge and round aboue, and ≈ømall downewards, ≈øomewhat like vnto a ≈ømall ≈øhort Carrot roote, ≈øometimes two being ioyned at the head together. But the name Napellus anciently giuen vnto it, doth ≈øhew they referred the forme of the roote vnto a ≈ømall Turnep.

div.head: Anthora. The whol≈øome Helmet flower, or counterpoi≈øon Monkes hood.
div.p: This whol≈øome plant I thought good to in≈øert, not onely for the forme of the flower, but al≈øo for the excellent properties thereof, as you ≈øhall haue them related hereafter. The rootes hereof are ≈ømall and tuberous, round and ≈øomewhat long, ending for the mo≈øt part in a long fibre, and with ≈øome other ≈ømall threads from the head downeward: from the head whereof ri≈øeth vp diuers greene leaues, euery one ≈øeuerally vpon a ≈øtalke, very much diuided, as finely almo≈øt as the leaues of Larkes heeles or ≈øpurres: among which ri≈øeth vp a hard round ≈øtalke, a foote high and better, with ≈øome ≈øuch leaues thereon as grow belowe, at the toppe whereof ≈øtand many ≈ømall yellowi≈øh flowers, formed very like vnto the former whiti≈øh Wolfesbane, bearing many blacke ≈øeedes in pods afterwards in the like manner.

Many more ≈øorts of varieties of the≈øe kindes there are, but the≈øe onely, as the mo≈øt ≈øpecious, are nour≈øed vp in Flori≈øts Gardens for plea≈øure; the other are kept by ≈øuch as are Catholicke ob≈øeruers of all natures ≈øtore.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe grow naturally on Mountaines, in many ≈øhadowie places of the Alpes, in Germany, and el≈øewhere.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth (as is ≈øaid) in Ianuary, and February, and ≈øometimes vntill March be well ≈øpent, and the ≈øeede is ≈øoone ripe after.
The other three flower not vntill Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is v≈øually called Aconitum hyemale Belgarum. Lobelius calleth it
Bulbo≈øus vnifolius Batrachoides, Aconitum Elleboraceum, and Ranunculus Monophyllos, and ≈øome by other names. Mo≈øt Herbari≈øts call it Aconitum hyemale, and we in Engli≈øh thereafter, Winters Wolfesbane; and of ≈øome, Yellow Aconite.

The ≈øecond is called by mo≈øt Writers, Aconitum luteum Ponticum: Some al≈øo Lupicida, Luparia, and Canicida, of the effect in killing Wolues and Dogs: And ≈øome, becau≈øe the flower is more white then yellow, doe call it Aconitum flore albido, we call it in Engli≈øh, The whiti≈øh yellow Aconite, or Wolfesbane, but ≈øome after the Latine name, The yellow Wolfesbane.
The third is called generally Napellus, and Verus, becau≈øe it is the true Napellus of the ancient Writers, which they ≈øo termed from the forme of a Turnep, called Napus in Latine.

The fourth is called Aconitum Salutiferum, Napellus Moy≈øis, Antora and Anthora, qua≈øi Antithora, that is, the remedy again≈øt the poi≈øonfull herbe Thora, in Engli≈øh according to the title, eyther whol≈øome Helmet flower, or counterpoi≈øon Monkes hood.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Although the fir≈øt three ≈øorts of plants be very poi≈øonfull and deadly, yet there may bee very good v≈øe made of them for ≈øore eyes (being carefully applyed, yet not to all ≈øorts of ≈øore eyes neither without di≈øcretion) if the di≈øtilled water be dropped therein.

The rootes of the counterpoi≈øon Monkes hood are effectuall not onely again≈øt the poi≈øon of the poi≈øonfull Helmet flower, and all others of that kinde, but al≈øo again≈øt the poi≈øon of all venemous bea≈øts, the plague or pe≈øtilence, and other infectious di≈øea≈øes, which rai≈øe ≈øpots, pockes, or markes in the outward skinne, by expelling the poi≈øon from within, and defending the heart as a mo≈øt ≈øoueraigne Cordiall. It is v≈øed al≈øo with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe again≈øt the wormes of the belly, and again≈øt the paines of the Wind collick.

div.head: Ranunculus. The Crowfoote.
div.p: NExt vnto the Aconites, of right are to follow the Ranunculi, or Crowfeete, for the nearene≈ø≈øe both of forme, of leaues, and nature of the plants, although le≈ø≈øe hurtfull, yet all of them for the mo≈øt part being ≈øharpe and exulcerating, and not without ≈øome danger, if any would be too bold with them. The whole Family of the Ranunculi is of a very large extent, and I am con≈øtrained within the limits of a Garden of Plea≈øure; I mu≈øt therefore ≈øelect out onely ≈øuch as are fit for this purpo≈øe, and ≈øet them here downe for your knowledge, leauing the re≈øt for that other generall worke, which time may perfect and bring to light, if the couetous mindes of ≈øome that ≈øhould be mo≈øt affected towards it, doe not hinder it: or if the helpe of generous ≈øpirits would forward it.

div.head: 1. Ranunculus montanus albus humilior. The lowe white mountaine Crowfoot.
div.p: This lowe Crowfoote hath three or foure broad and thicke leaues, almo≈øt round, yet a little cut in and notched about the edges, of a fine greene and ≈øhining colour on the vpper≈øide, and not ≈øo green vnderneath, among which ri≈øeth a ≈ømall ≈øhort ≈øtalke, bearing one ≈ønow white flower on the toppe, made of fiue round pointed leaues, with diuers yellow threads in the middle, ≈øtanding about a greene head, which in time groweth to be full of ≈øeede, in forme like vnto a ≈ømall greene Strawberry: the roote is compo≈øed of many white ≈øtrings.

Duplici flore.There is another of this lowe kinde, who≈øe leaues are ≈øomewhat more deeply cut in on the edges, and the flower larger, and ≈øometimes a little double, as it were with two rowes of leaues, in other things not differing from the former.

div.head: 2. Ranunculus montanus albus maior vel elatior. The great ≈øingle white mountaine Crowfoote.
div.p: The leaues of this Crowfoote are large and greene, cut into three, and ≈øometimes into fiue ≈øpeciall diui≈øions, and each of them be≈øides cut or notched about the edges, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the leaues of the Globe Crowfoote, but larger: the ≈øtalke is two foote and a halfe high, hauing three ≈ømall leaues ≈øet at the ioynt of the ≈øtalke, where it brancheth out into flowers, which ≈øtand foure or fiue together vpon long foote-≈øtalkes, made of fiue white leaues a peece, very ≈øweete, and ≈øomewhat larger then the next white Crowfoote, with ≈øome yellow threads in the middle compa≈ø≈øing a greene head, which bringeth ≈øeede like vnto other wilde Crowfeete: the roote hath many long thicke whiti≈øh ≈øtrings, comming from a thicke head.

div.head: 3. Ranunculus montanus albus minor. The le≈ø≈øer ≈øingle white Crowfoote.
div.p: This Crowefoote hath faire large ≈øpread leaues, cut into fiue diui≈øions, and ≈øomewhat notched about the edges, greene on the vpper≈øide, and paler vnderneath, hauing many veines running through the leaues: the ≈øtalke of this ri≈øeth not ≈øo high as the former, although this be rea≈øonable tall, as being neare two foote high, ≈øpread into many branches, bearing ≈øuch like white flowers, as in the former, but ≈ømaller: the ≈øeede of this is like the former, and ≈øo are the rootes likewi≈øe.

div.head: 4. Ranunculus albus flore pleno. The double white Crowfoot.
div.p: The double white Crowfoote is of the ≈øame kinde with the la≈øt ≈øingle white Crowfoote, hauing ≈øuch like leaues in all re≈øpects: the onely difference is in the flowers, which in this are very thicke and double. Some doe make mention of two ≈øorts of double white Crowfeete, one ≈øomewhat lower then another, and the lower likewi≈øe bearing more ≈øtore of flowers, and more double then the higher: but I confe≈ø≈øe, I haue neuer ≈øeene but one ≈øort of double, which is the ≈øame here expre≈ø≈øed, not growing very high, and rea≈øonably well ≈øtored with flowers.

div.head: 5. Ranunculus praecox Rutaefolio ≈øiue Coriandrifolio. The early Coriander leafed Crowfoote.
div.p: This Crowfoote hath three or foure very greene leaues, cut and diuided into many ≈ømall peeces, like vnto the wing of leaues of Rue, or rather like the lower leaues of the Coriander (for they well re≈øemble either of them) euery of them ≈øtanding vpon a long purpli≈øh ≈øtalke, at the toppe whereof groweth the flower alone, being compo≈øed or made of twelue ≈ømall white leaues, broad pointed, and a little endented at the ends, ≈øomewhat purpli≈øh on the out≈øide, and white on the in≈øide, ≈øu≈øtained by diuers ≈ømall greene leaues, which are in ≈øtead of a cup or huske: in the middle of the flower are many ≈ømall white threads, tipt with yellow pendents, ≈øtanding about a ≈ømall greene head, which after groweth to bee full of ≈øeedes like a Strawberry, which knobs giue ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is white and fibrous.

div.head: 6. Ranunculus Thalictrifolio maior. The great colombine leafed Crowfoot.
div.p: The lower leaues of this Crowfoote haue long ≈øtalkes, and are very like vnto the ≈ømaller leaues of Colombines, or the great Spani≈øh Thalictrum, which hath his leaues very like vnto a Colombine, foure or fiue ri≈øing from the roote: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth about a foote and a halfe high, ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, be≈øet here and there with the like leaues, at the toppe whereof ≈øtand diuers ≈ømall white flowers, made of fiue leaues a peece, with ≈øome pale white threads in the middle: the ≈øeede is round and reddi≈øh, contained in ≈ømall huskes or hornes: the roote is made of a bu≈øh or tuft of white ≈øtrings.

div.head: 7. Ranunculus Thalictrifolio minor A≈øphodeli radice. The ≈ømall white Colombine leafed Crowfoote.
div.p: This ≈ømall Crowfoote hath three or foure winged leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, ≈øtanding vpon long ≈øtalkes, and con≈øi≈øting of many ≈ømall leaues ≈øet together, ≈øpreading from the middle ribbe, euery leafe ≈øomewhat re≈øembling both in ≈øhape and colour the ≈ømalle≈øt and younge≈øt leaues of Colombines: the flowers are white, ≈øtanding at the toppe of the ≈øtalkes, made of fiue round leaues: the root hath three or foure thick, ≈øhort, and round yellowi≈øh clogs hanging at the head, like vnto the A≈øphodill roote. The great Herball of Lyons, that goeth vnder the name of Dale≈øchampius, ≈øaith, that Dr. Myconus found it in Spaine, and ≈øent it vnder the name of Oenanthe; and therefore Ioannes Molineus who is thought to haue compo≈øed that booke, ≈øet it among the vmbelliferous plants, becau≈øe the Oenanthes beare vmbels of flowers and ≈øeede, and haue tuberous or cloggy rootes; but with what iudgement, let others ≈øay, when they haue compared the vmbels of flowers and ≈øeede of the Oenanthes, with the flowers and ≈øeede of this plant, and whether I haue not more properly placed it among the Ranunculi or Crowfeete, and giuen it a denomination agreeable to his forme.

div.head: 8. Ranunculus Globo≈øus. The Globe Crowfoot.
div.p: This Crowfoote (which in the Northerne countries of England where it groweth plentifully, is called Locker goulous) hath many faire, broad, darke greene leaues next the ground, cut into fiue, ≈øixe, or ≈øeuen diui≈øions, and iagged be≈øides at the edges; among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, whereon are ≈øet ≈øuch like leaues as are belowe, but ≈ømaller, diuided toward the toppe into ≈øome branches, on the which ≈øtand ≈øeuerall large yellow flowers, alwayes folded inward, or as a clo≈øe flower neuer blowing open, as other flowers doe, con≈øi≈øting of eleuen leaues for the mo≈øt part, ≈øet or placed in three rowes, with many yellow threads in the middle, ≈øtanding about a greene rough head, which in time groweth to be ≈ømall knops, wherein are contained blacke ≈øeede: the roote is compo≈øed of many blacki≈øh ≈øtrings.

div.head: 9. Ranunculus proten≈øis flore multiplici. The double yellow field Crowfoot.
div.p: There is little or no difference in the leaues of this double Crowfoot, from tho≈øe of the ≈øingle kindes that growe in euery medowe, being large and diuided into foure or fiue parts, and indented about the edges, but they are ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and of a fre≈øher greene: the flowers ≈øtand on many branches, much diuided or ≈øeparated, being not very great, but very thicke and double: the roote runneth and creepeth vnder ground like as the ≈øingle doth.

div.head: 10. Ranunculus Anglicus maximus multiplex. The Garden double yellow Crowfoot or Batchelours buttons.
div.p: This great double Crowfoote, which is common in euery Garden through England, hath many great blacki≈øh greene leaues, iagged and cut into three diui≈øions, each to the middle ribbe: the ≈øtalkes haue ≈øome ≈ømaller leaues on them, and tho≈øe next vnder the branches long and narrow: the flowers are of a greeni≈øh yellow colour, very thicke and double of leaues, in the middle whereof ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall ≈øtalke, bearing another double flower, like to the other, but ≈ømaller: the roote is round, like vnto a ≈ømall white Turnep, with diuers other fibres annexed vnto it.

div.head: 11. Ranunculus Gramineus. Gra≈ø≈øe leafed Crowfoot.
div.p:
The leaues of this Crowfoote are long and narrow, ≈øomewhat like vnto Gra≈ø≈øe, or rather like the leaues of ≈øingle Gilloflowers or Pinckes, being ≈ømall and ≈øharpe pointed, a little hollow, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp diuers ≈ølender ≈øtalkes, bearing one ≈ømall flower at the toppe of each, con≈øi≈øting of fiue yellow
1 Aconitum Hyemale. Winter Wolfesbane. 2 Aconitum flore albido ≈øiue luteum Ponticum. The whiti≈øh yellow Wolfesbane. 3 Napellus verus. Blew Helmets or Monkes hood. 4 Anthora. The counterpoi≈øon Monkes hood. 5 Ranunculus humilis albus ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle white low Crowfoot. 6 Ranunculus humilis albus duplici flore. The double lowe white Crowfoot. 7 Ranunculus Coriandrifolio The early Coriander leafed Crowfoot. 8 Ranunculus montanus elatior albus. The great ≈øingle white mountain Crowfoot. 9 Ranunculus montanus albus flore pleno The double white mountain Crowfoot. 10 Ranunculus Thalictrifolio minor. The le≈ø≈øer Colombine leafed Crowfoot. 11 Ranunculus globo≈øus. The globe Crowfoot. depiction of flowers
leaues, with ≈øome threads in the middle: the roote is compo≈øed of many thicke, long, round white ≈øtrings.
There is another of this kinde that beareth flowers with two rowes of leaues, as if it were double, differing in nothing el≈øe.

div.head: 12. Ranunculus Lu≈øitanicus Autumnalis. The Portugall Autumne Crowfoot.
div.p: This Autumne Crowfoote hath diuers broad round leaues lying on the ground, ≈øet vpon ≈øhort foote-≈øtalkes, of a faire greene colour aboue, and grayi≈øh vnderneath, ≈ønipt all about the edges, hauing many veines in them, and ≈øometimes ≈øwelling as with bli≈øters or bladders on them; from among which ri≈øe vp two or three ≈ølender and hairy ≈øtalkes, bearing but one ≈ømall yellow flower a peece, con≈øi≈øting of fiue and ≈øometimes of ≈øix leaues, and ≈øometimes of ≈øeuen or eight, hauing a few threads in the middle, ≈øet about a ≈ømall greene head, like vnto many of the former Crowfeete, which bringeth ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede: the roote is made of many thicke ≈øhort white ≈øtrings, which ≈øeeme to be grumous or kernelly rootes, but that they are ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and longer then any other of that kinde.

div.head: 13. Ranunculus Creticus latifolius. The broad leafed Candy Crowfoot.
div.p: This Crowfoote of Candy, hath the greate≈øt and broade≈øt leaues of all the ≈øorts of Crowfeete, being almo≈øt round, and without any great diui≈øions, but onely a few notches about the edges here and there, as large or larger ≈øometimes then the palme of a mans hand; among which ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, not very high when it doth fir≈øt flower, but afterwards, as the other flowers doe open them≈øelues, the ≈øtalke groweth to be a foote and a halfe high, or thereabouts, hauing ≈øome leaues on it, deeply cut in or diuided, and bearing many faire yellow flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, being ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh in the middle, when the flower hath ≈øtood blowne a little time: the roote is compo≈øed of a number of ≈ømall kernelly knobs, or long graines, ≈øet thicke together. This flowreth very early, being v≈øually in flower before the end of March, and oftentimes about the middle thereof.

div.head: 14. Ranunculus Creticus albus. The white Candy Crowfoote.
div.p: The leaues of this Crowfoote are very like vnto the leaues of the red Crowfoote of Tripoli or A≈øia, hereafter ≈øet downe, being ≈øomewhat broad and indented about the edges, ≈øome of the leaues being al≈øo cut in or ga≈øhed, thereby making it as it were three diui≈øions, of a pale greene colour, with many white ≈øpots in them: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a foote high, with ≈øome leaues on it, more diuided then the lower, and diuided at the toppe into two and ≈øometimes into three branches, each of them bearing a faire ≈ønow white flower, ≈øomewhat large, included at the fir≈øt in a browni≈øh huske or cup of leaues, which afterwards ≈øtand vnder the flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue white large round pointed leaues, in the middle whereof is ≈øet many blacki≈øh purple thrums, compa≈ø≈øing a ≈ømall long greene head, compo≈øed of many ≈øcales or chaffie whiti≈øh huskes, when they are ripe, which are the ≈øeede, but vnprofitable in all that euer I could ob≈øerue: the rootes are many ≈ømall graines or kernels, ≈øet together as in the former, and much about the ≈øame colour, that is, of a darke or duskie grayi≈øh colour, but much ≈ømaller.

Alba purpureis
‚Ä¢ ris & venis.There is another of this kinde, who≈øe flowers haue purple edges, and ≈øometimes ≈øome veines of the ≈øame purple in the leaues of the flowers, not differing in any other thing from the former.

Alba
‚Ä¢ ris rubris.And another, who≈øe edges of the flowers are of a bright red colour.

div.head: 15. Ranunculus Creticus flore argenteo. The Argentine, or cloth of ≈øiluer Crowfoot.
div.p:
The greene leaues of this Crowfoote are as ≈ømall and thinne, cut in or diuided on the edges, as the la≈øt two ≈øorts; the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp ≈øomewhat higher, and diuided into ≈øome branches, bearing at the toppe of euery of them one flower, ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller then the former, compo≈øed of ≈øix, ≈øeuen, and ≈øometimes of eight ≈ømall round pointed
1 Ranunculus gramineus flore ≈øimpli ‚Ä¢ i & duplici. The ≈øingle and the double gra≈ø≈øe Crowfoot. 2 Ranunculus Lu≈øitanicus Autumnalis. The Portugall Autumne Crowfoot. 3 Ranunculus Creticus latifolius. The broad leafed Candy Crowfoot. 4 Ranunculus Anglicus maximus multiplex. The double Engli≈øh Crowfoot. 5 Ranunculus praeten≈øis flore multiplici. The double yellow field Crowfoot. 6 Ranunculus Creticus albus. The white Candy Crowfoot. 7 Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore albo vel pallido vari ‚Ä¢ . The white or the ≈øtraw coloured Crowfoot with red top ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ r edges. 8 Ranunculus Tripolitanus flore rubro ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle red Crowfoot of Tripoli. 9 Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore rubro ampl ‚Ä¢ . The large ≈øingle red Crowfoot of A≈øia. 10 Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore rubro pleno. The double red Crowfoot of A≈øia. 11 Caltha palu≈øtris flore pleno. Double Mar≈øh Marigold or Batchelours buttons. depiction of flowers
leaues, of a whiti≈øh yellow blu≈øh colour on the in≈øide wholly, except ≈øometimes a little ≈øtript about the edges: but the out≈øide of euery leafe is finely ≈øtript with crim≈øon ≈øtripes, very thicke, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Gilloflower: in the middle ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall blacke head, compa≈ø≈øed about with blacki≈øh blew threads or thrums, which head is as vnfruitfull for ≈øeede in our Countrey as the former. This flower hath no ≈øuch greene leaues vnder it, or to enclo≈øe it before it be blowne open as the former: the rootes are in all things like the former.

div.head: 16. Ranunculus A≈øiaticus ≈øiue Tripolitanus flore rubro. The ≈øingle red Crowfoote of A≈øia or Tripoli.
div.p: The lower leaues of this red Crowfoote are alwayes whole without diui≈øions, being onely ≈øomewhat deeply indented about the edges, but the other that ri≈øe after them are more cut in, ≈øometimes into three, and ≈øometimes into fiue diui≈øions, and notched al≈øo about the edges: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth higher then any of the former, and hath on it two or three ≈ømaller leaues, more cut in and diuided then tho≈øe belowe: at the toppe whereof ≈øtandeth one large flower, made of fiue leaues, euery one being narrower at the bottome then at the toppe, and not ≈øtanding clo≈øe and round one to another, but with a certaine di≈øtance betweene, of a duskie yellowi≈øh red colour on the out≈øide, and of a deepe red on the in≈øide, the middle being ≈øet with many thrums of a darke purple colour: the head for ≈øeede is long, and ≈øcaly or chaffie, and idle in like manner as the re≈øt: the roote is made of many graines or ≈ømall kernels ≈øet together, and clo≈øing at the head, but ≈øpreading it ≈øelfe, if it like the ground, vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the earth into many rootes, encrea≈øing from long ≈øtrings, that runne from the middle of the ≈ømall head of graines, as well as at the head it ≈øelfe.

div.head: 17. Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore amplo rubro. The large ≈øingle red Crowfoot of A≈øia.
div.p: There hath come to vs out of Turkie, together with the former, among many other rootes, vnder the ≈øame title, a differing ≈øort of this Crowfoote, who≈øe leaues weare broader, and much goaler; the flower al≈øo larger, and the leaues thereof broader, ≈øometimes eight in a flower, ≈øtanding round and clo≈øe one to another, which maketh the fairer ≈øhew: in all other things it is like the former.

div.head: 18. Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore rubro vario ≈øimplici. The red ≈øtript ≈øingle Crowfoote of A≈øia.
div.p: This party coloured Crowfoote differeth not eyther in roote or leafe from the former, the chiefe≈øt difference is in the flower, which being red, ≈øomewhat like the former, hath yet ≈øome yellow ≈øtripes or veines through euery leafe, ≈øometimes but little, and ≈øometimes ≈øo much, that it ≈øeemeth to bee party coloured red and yellow: this ≈øort is very tender; for we haue twice had it, and yet peri≈øhed with vs.

div.head: 19. Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore luteo vario ≈øimplici. The yellow ≈øtript ≈øingle Crowfoote of A≈øia.
div.p: There is little difference in the roote of this Crowfoote from the la≈øt de≈øcribed, but the leaues are much different, being very much diuided, and the flower is large, of a fine pale greeni≈øh yellow colour, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix and ≈øeuen, and ≈øometimes of eight or nine round leaues; the toppes whereof haue reddi≈øh ≈øpots, and the edges ≈øometimes al≈øo, with ≈øuch purpli≈øh thrums in the middle that the other haue. None of the≈øe former Crowfeete with kernelly rootes, haue euer beene found to haue giuen ≈øo good ≈øeed in England, as that being ≈øowne, any of them would ≈øpring vp; for hereof tryall hath been often made, but all they haue lo≈øt their labour, that haue be≈øtowed their paines therein, as farre as I know.

div.head: 20. Ranunculus A≈øiaticus flore rubro pleno. The double red Crowfoote of A≈øia.
div.p: The double red Crowfoote hath his rootes and leaues ≈øo like vnto the ≈øingle red kinde, that none can perceiue any difference, or know the one from the other, vntill the budde of the flower doe appeare, which after it is any thing forward, may be perceiued to be greater and fuller then the budde of the ≈øingle kinde. This kinde beareth mo≈øt v≈øually but one faire large double flower on the toppe of the ≈øtalke, compo≈øed of many leaues, ≈øet clo≈øe together in three or foure rowes, of an excellent crim≈øon colour, declining to Scarlet, the outter leaues being larger then the inner; and in ≈øtead of thrummes, hath many ≈ømall leaues ≈øet together: it hath likewi≈øe ≈øix ≈ømall narrow greene leaues on the back≈øide of the flower, where the ≈øtalke is fa≈øtened to the flower.
There is of this double kinde another ≈øort,Polifero flore. who≈øe flower is of the ≈øame colour with the former, but out of the middle of the flower ari≈øeth another double flower, but ≈ømaller.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe plants grow naturally in diuers Countries; ≈øome in France, and Germany, and ≈øome in England, ≈øome in Spaine, Portugall, and Italy, and ≈øome haue been ≈øent out of Turkie from Con≈øtantinople, and ≈øome from other parts, their titles for the mo≈øt part de≈øcrying their Countries.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: Some of them flower early, as is ≈øet downe in their de≈øcriptions, or titles. The others in Aprill and May. The white Candy Crowfoote, and the other ≈øingle and double ≈øorts of A≈øia, about the ≈øame time, or ≈øomewhat later, and one in Autumne, as it is ≈øet downe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The names that are giuen ≈øeuerally to them may well ≈øerue this worke, that thereby they may bee di≈øtingui≈øhed one from another: For to ≈øet downe any further controuer≈øie of names, how fitly or vnfitly they haue beene called, and how variably by diuers former Writers, is fitter for a generall Hi≈øtory, vnto which I leaue what may be ≈øaid, both concerning the≈øe and the re≈øt: Onely this I would giue you to vnder≈øtand, that the Turkie kindes haue been ≈øent to vs vnder the names of Terobolos for the ≈øingle, and Terobolos Catamer lale for the double, and yet oftentimes, tho≈øe that haue been ≈øent for double, haue proued ≈øingle, ≈øo little fidelity is to bee found among them.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All or mo≈øt of the≈øe plants are very ≈øharpe and exulcerating, yet the care and indu≈øtry of diuers learned men haue found many good effects in many of them. For the rootes and leaues both of the wilde kindes, and of ≈øome of the≈øe of the Garden, ≈øtamped and applyed to the wri≈øts, haue driuen away the fits in Feuers. The roote likewi≈øe of the double Engli≈øh kinde is applyed for pe≈øtilent ≈øores, to helpe to breake them, by drawing the venome to the place. They helpe likewi≈øe to take away ≈øcarres and markes in diuers places of the body.

div.head: Caltha palustris flore pleno. Double Mar≈øh Marigold.
div.p: AS an appendix to the Crowfeete, I mu≈øt needes adde this plant, yet ≈øeuerally by it ≈øelfe, becau≈øe both it and his ≈øingle kinde are by mo≈øt adioyned thereunto, for the neare re≈øemblance both in ≈øhape and ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe of quality. The ≈øingle kinde I leaue to the Ditch ≈øides, and moi≈øt grounds about them, as the fitte≈øt places for it, and onely bring the double kinde into my Garden, as fitte≈øt for his goodly proportion and beauty to be entertained, and haue place therein.

The double Mar≈øh Marigold hath many broad and round greene leaues, a little endented about the edges, like vnto the ≈øingle kinde, but not altogether ≈øo large, e≈øpecially in a Garden where it ≈øtandeth not very moi≈øt: the ≈øtalkes are weake, round, hollow, and greene, diuided into three or foure branches at the toppe, with leaues at the ≈øeuerall ioynts, whereon ≈øtand very double flowers, of a gold yellow colour: the fiue outer leaues being larger then any of the re≈øt that are encompa≈ø≈øed by them, which fall away after they haue ≈øtood blowne a great while (for it endureth in flower a moneth or more, e≈øpecially if it ≈øtand in a ≈øhadowie place) without bearing any ≈øeed: the rootes are compo≈øed of many thicke, long, and round whiti≈øh ≈øtrings, which runne downe deep into the ground, and there are fa≈øtened very ≈øtrongly.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This plant groweth naturally in diuers Mar≈øhes, and moi≈øt grounds in Germany, yet in ≈øome more double then in others; it hath long agoe beene cheri≈øhed in our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Aprill or May, as the yeare proueth earlier or later: all his leaues doe in a manner quite peri≈øh in Winter, and ≈øpring anew in the end of February, or thereabouts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: There is great controuer≈øie among the learned about the ≈øingle kinde, but thereof I ≈øhall not neede to ≈øpeake in this place; if God permit I may in a fitter. This is called generally in Latine, Caltha palu≈øtris multiplex, or flore pleno. And wee in Engli≈øh (after the Latine, which take Caltha to be that which wee v≈øually call Calendula, a Marigold) The double Mar≈øh Marigold.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The roote hereof is ≈øharpe, comming neare vnto the quality of the Crowfeete, but for any ≈øpeciall property, I haue not heard or found any.

div.head: Hepatica nobilis ≈øiue trifolia. Noble Liuerwort.
div.p: NExt vnto the Crowfeete are to follow the Hepaticas, becau≈øe of the likene≈ø≈øe with them, ≈øeeming to be ≈ømall Crowfeete in all their parts, but of another and more whol≈øome kinde. Their diuer≈øity among them≈øelues con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in the colour of the flowers, all of them being ≈øingle, except one which is very thicke and double.

div.head: 1. Hepatica flore caeruleo ≈øimplici maior. The great ≈øingle blew Hepatica or noble Liuerwort.
div.p: The flowers of this Hepatica doe ≈øpring vp, blow open, and ≈øometimes ≈øhed and fall away, before any leaues appeare or ≈øpread open. The rootes are compo≈øed of a bu≈øh of blacki≈øh ≈øtrings, from the ≈øeuerall heads or buttons whereof, after the flowers are ri≈øen and blowne, ari≈øe many fre≈øh greene leaues, each ≈øeuerally ≈øtanding vpon his foot-≈øtalke, folded together, and ≈øomewhat browne and hairy at their fir≈øt comming, which after are broad, and diuided at the edges into three parts: the flowers likewi≈øe ≈øtand euery one vpon his owne ≈øeuerall foote-≈øtalke, of the ≈øame height with the leaues for the mo≈øt part, which is about foure or fiue fingers breadth high, made of ≈øix leaues mo≈øt v≈øually, but ≈øometimes it will haue ≈øeuen or eight, of a faire blew colour, with many white chiues or threads in the middle, ≈øtanding about a middle green head or vmbone, which after the flower is fallen groweth greater, and ≈øheweth many ≈ømall graines or ≈øeede ≈øet clo≈øe together (with three ≈ømall greene leaues compa≈ø≈øing them vnderneath, as they did the flower at the bottome) very like the head of ≈øeed of manie Crowfeete.

div.head: 2. Hepatica minor flore pallido caeruleo. The ≈ømall blew Hepatica.
div.p: The leaues of this Hepatica are ≈ømaller by the halfe then the former, and grow more aboundantly, or bu≈øhing thicke together: the flowers (when it ≈øheweth them, for I haue had the plant halfe a ≈øcore yeares, and yet neuer ≈øaw it beare flower aboue once or twice) are of a pale or bleake blew colour, not ≈øo large as the flowers of the former.

div.head: 3. Hepatica flore purpureo. Purple Hepatica or noble Liuerwort.
div.p: This Hepatica is in all things like vnto the fir≈øt, but onely the flowers are of a deeper blew tending to a Violet purple: and therefore I ≈øhall not neede to reiterate the former de≈øcription.

div.head: 4. Hepatica flore albo minor. The le≈ø≈øer white Hepatica.
div.p: The flowers of this Hepatica are wholly white, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the red or purple, and the leaues ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and of a little whiter or paler greene colour, el≈øe in all other things agreeing with the former.

div.head: 5. Hepatica alba magno flore. The great white Hepatica.
div.p: There is no other difference herein from the la≈øt, but that the flower being as white, is as large as the next.

div.head: 6. Hepatica albida ≈øiue argentea. A≈øh-coloured or Argentine Hepatica.
div.p:
Both the leaues and the flowers of this Hepatica are larger then any of the former, except the la≈øt: the flowers hereof at the fir≈øt opening ≈øeeme to bee a of blu≈øh a≈øh-colour, which doe ≈øo abide three or foure dayes, decaying ≈øtill vntill it turne almo≈øt
white, hauing yet ≈øtill a ≈øhew of that blu≈øh a≈øh-colour in them, till the very la≈øt.

div.head: 7. Hepatica alba ≈øtraminibus rubris. White Hepatica with red threads.
div.p: There is no difference between this Hepatica and the fir≈øt white one, ≈øauing that the threads in the middle of the flower, being white, as in the former, are tipt at the ends with a pale reddi≈øh colour, which adde a great beauty to the flowers.

div.head: 8. Hepatica flore rubro. Red Hepatica or noble Liuerwort.
div.p: The leaues of this Hepatica are of a little browner red colour, both at their fir≈øt comming vp, and afterwards, e≈øpecially in the middle of the leafe more then any of the former: the flowers are in forme like vnto the re≈øt, but of a bright blu≈øh, or pale red colour, very plea≈øant to behold, with white threads or chiues in the middle of them.

div.head: 9. Hepatica flore purpureo multiplici ≈øiue pleno. The double purple Hepatica.
div.p: The double Hepatica is in all things like vnto the ≈øingle purple kinde, ≈øauing onely that the leaues are larger, and ≈øtand vpon longer foote-≈øtalkes, and that the flowers are ≈ømall buttons, but very thicke of leaues, and as double as a flower can be, like vnto the double white Crowfoote before de≈øcribed, but not ≈øo bigge, of a deepe blew or purple colour, without any threads or head in the middle, which fall away without giuing any ≈øeede.

div.head: 10. Hepatica flore caeruleo pleno. The double blew Hepatica.
div.p: In the colour of this flower, con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe≈øt difference from the la≈øt, except one may ≈øay it is a little le≈ø≈øe in the bigne≈ø≈øe of the flower, but not in doublene≈ø≈øe of leaues.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe plants with ≈øingle flowers grow naturally in the Woods, and ≈øhadowie Mountaines of Germany in many places, and ≈øome of them in Italy al≈øo. The double kinde likewi≈øe hath been ≈øent from Alphon≈øus Pantius out of Italy, as Clu≈øius reporteth, and was al≈øo found in the Woods, neare the Ca≈øtle of Starnbeg in Au≈øtria, the Lady Heu≈øen≈øtains po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, as the ≈øame Clu≈øius reporteth al≈øo.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe plants doe flower very early, and are of the fir≈øt flowers that ≈øhew them≈øelues pre≈øently after the deepe fro≈øts in Ianuary, ≈øo that next vnto the Winter Wolfesbane, the≈øe making their pride appeare in Winter, are the more welcome early gue≈øts. The double kinde flowreth not altogether ≈øo early, but ≈øheweth his flower, and abideth when the others are pa≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue obtained diuers names; ≈øome calling them Hepatica, Hepatica nobilis, Hepaticum trifolium, Trifolium nobile, Trifolium aureum, and ≈øome Trinitas, and Herba Trinitatis. In Engli≈øh you may call them either Hepatica, after the Latine name, as mo≈øt doe, or Noble Liuerwort, which you plea≈øe.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The≈øe are thought to coole and ≈øtrengthen the liuer, the name importing as much; but I neuer ≈øaw any great v≈øe of them by any the Phy≈øitians of our London Colledge, or effect by them that haue v≈øed them in Phy≈øicke in our Country.

figure.head: 1 Hepatica flore albo amplo ≈øimplici. The large white Hepatica. 2 Hepatica flore rubro ≈øimplici. The red Hepatica. 3 Hepatica flore purpureo pleno. The double purple Hepatica. 4 Geranium tubero≈øum. Knobbed Cranes bill. 5 Geranium Batrachoides flore albo vel caeruleo. The blew or white Crowfoote Cranes bill. 6 Geranium Hematodes. The red Ro≈øe Cranes bill. 7 Geranium Romanum ≈øtriatum. The variable ≈øtript Cranes bill. 8 Geranium Creticum. Candy Cranes bill.

div.head: Geranium. Storkes bill or Cranes bill.
div.p: AS was ≈øaid before concerning the Crowfeet, of their large extent and re≈øtraint, the like may be ≈øaid of the Storkes bils or Cranes bils; for euen of the≈øe as of them, I mu≈øt for this worke ≈øet forth the de≈øcriptions but of a few, and leaue the re≈øt to a generall worke.

div.head: 1. Geranium tubero≈øum vel bulbo≈øum. Bulbous or knobbed Cranes bill.
