div.p: The knobbed Cranes hath three or foure large leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, of a grayi≈øh or rather du≈øty greene colour, euery one of them being as it were of a round forme, but diuided or cut into ≈øix or ≈øeuen long parts or diui≈øions, euen vnto the middle, which maketh it ≈øeeme to be ≈øo many leaues, each of the cuts or diui≈øions being deeply notched or indented on both ≈øides; among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke a foote high or better, bearing thereon diuers pale but bright purple flowers, made of fiue leaues a peece, after which come ≈ømall heads with long pointed beakes, re≈øembling the long bill of a Storke or Crane, or ≈øuch like bird, which after it is ripe, parteth at the bottome where it is bigge≈øt, into foure or fiue ≈øeedes, euery one whereof hath a peece of the beake head fa≈øtened vnto it, and falleth away if it bee not gathered: the roote is tuberous and round, like vnto the roote of the Cyclamen or ordinary Sowbread almo≈øt, but ≈ømaller, and of a darke ru≈ø≈øet colour on the out≈øide, and white within, which doth encrea≈øe vnder ground, by certaine ≈øtrings running from the mother root into ≈ømall round bulbes, like vnto the rootes of the earth Che≈ønut, and will pre≈øently ≈øhoote leaues, and quickly grow to beare flowers, but will not abide to be kept long dry out of the ground, without danger to be vtterly ≈øpoiled.

div.head: Geranium Batrachoides flore caeruleo. The blew Crowfoote Cranes bill.
div.p: This Crowfoote Cranes bill hath many large leaues, cut into fiue or ≈øix parts or diui≈øions, euen to the bottome, and iagged be≈øides on the edges, ≈øet vpon very long ≈ølender foote-≈øtalkes, very like the leaues of the wilde Crowfoot; from among which ri≈øe vp diuers ≈øtalkes with great ioynts, ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, ≈øet with leaues like the former: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are ≈øpread into many branches, whereon ≈øtand diuers flowers, made of fiue leaues a peece, as large as any of the wilde or field Crowfeete, round pointed, of a faire blew or watchet colour, which being pa≈øt, there doe ari≈øe ≈øuch heads or bils, as other of the Cranes bils haue: the roote is compo≈øed of many reddi≈øh ≈øtrings, ≈øpreading in the ground, from a head made of diuers red heads, which lye oftentimes eminent aboue the ground.

div.head: Geranium Batrachoides flore albo. The white Crowfoote Cranes bill.
div.p: This Cranes bill is in leafe and flower altogether like the former, the onely difference betweene them con≈øi≈øteth in the colour of the flower, which in this is wholly white, and as large as the former: but the roote of this hath not ≈øuch red heads as the other hath.

div.head: Geranium Batrachoides flore albo & caeruleo vario. The party coloured Crowfoote Cranes bill.
div.p: The flowers of this Cranes bill are variably ≈øtriped and ≈øpotted, and ≈øometimes diuided, the one halfe of euery leafe being white, and the other halfe blew, ≈øometimes with le≈ø≈øer or greater ≈øpots of blew in the white leafe, very variably, and more in ≈øome years then in others, that it is very hard to expre≈ø≈øe all the varieties that may be ob≈øerued in the flowers, that blow at one time. In all other parts of the plant, it is ≈øo like vnto the former, that vntill it be in flower, the one cannot be knowne from the other.

div.head: 5. Geranium Batrachoides alterum flore purpureo. Purple Crowfoote Cranes bill.
div.p: This purple Cranes bill hath many leaues ri≈øing from the roote, ≈øet vpon long foot-≈øtalkes, ≈øomewhat like vnto the other, yet not ≈øo broad, but more diuided or cut, that is, into ≈øeuen or more ≈ølits, euen to the middle, each whereof is likewi≈øe cut in on the edges more deeply then the former; the ≈øtalkes are ≈øomewhat knobbed at the ioynts, ≈øet with leaues like vnto the lower, and bearing a great tuft of buds at the toppes of the branches, which breake out into faire large flowers, made of fiue purple leaues, which doe ≈øomewhat re≈øemble the flower of a Mallow, before it be too full blowne, each whereof hath a reddi≈øh pointell in the middle, and many ≈ømall threads compa≈ø≈øing it, this vmbell or tuft of buds doe flower by degrees, and not all at once, and euery flower abideth open little more then one day, and then ≈øheddeth, ≈øo that euery day yeeldeth fre≈øh flowers, which becau≈øe they are ≈øo many, are a long while before they are all pa≈øt or ≈øpent: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there ari≈øe ≈ømall beake heads or bils, like vnto the other Cranes bils, with ≈ømall turning ≈øeede: the roote is compo≈øed of a great tuft of ≈øtrings, fa≈øtened to a knobby head.

div.head: 6. Geranium Romanum ver≈øicolor ≈øiue ≈øtriatum. The variable ≈øtript Cranes bill.
div.p: This beautifull Cranes bill hath many broad yellowi≈øh greene leaues ari≈øing from the roote, diuided into fiue or ≈øix parts, but not vnto the middle as the fir≈øt kindes are: each of the≈øe leaues hath a blacki≈øh ≈øpot at the bottome corners of the diui≈øions, the whole leafe as well in forme as colour and ≈øpots, is very like vnto the leafe of the Geranium fu≈øcum, or ≈øpotted Cranes bill, next following to be de≈øcribed, but that the leaues of this are not ≈øo large as the other: from among the≈øe leaues ≈øpring vp ≈øundry ≈øtalkes a foote high and better, ioynted and knobbed here and there, bearing at the tops two or three ≈ømall white flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, ≈øo thickly & variably ≈øtriped with fine ≈ømall reddi≈øh veines, that no green leafe that is of that bigne≈ø≈øe can ≈øhew ≈øo many veines in it, nor ≈øo thick running as euery leafe of this flower doth: in the middle of the flower ≈øtandeth a ≈ømall pointell, which when the flower is pa≈øt doth grow to be the ≈øeed ve≈ø≈øell, wheron is ≈øet diuers ≈ømall ≈øeeds, like vnto the ≈ømall ≈øeedes of other Cranes bils: the root is made of many ≈ømall yellow threads or ≈øtrings.

div.head: 7. Geranium fu≈øcum ≈øiue maculatum. Swart tawny or ≈øpotted Cranes bill.
div.p: The leaues of this Cranes bill are in all points like the la≈øt de≈øcribed, as well in the forme and diui≈øions as colour of the leaues, being of a yellowi≈øh greene colour, but larger and ≈øtronger by much: the ≈øtalkes of this ri≈øe much higher, and are ioynted or knobbed with reddi≈øh knees or ioynts, on the tops whereof ≈øtand not many although large flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, each whereof is round at the end, and a little ≈ønipt round about, and doe bend or turne them≈øelues backe to the ≈øtalkewards, making the middle to be highe≈øt or mo≈øt eminent; the colour of the flower is of a darke or deepe blacki≈øh purple, the bottome of euery leafe being whiter then the re≈øt; it hath al≈øo a middle pointell ≈øtanding out, which afterwards bring forth ≈øeede like vnto others of his kinde: the roote con≈øi≈øteth of diuers great ≈øtrings, ioyned to a knobby head.

div.head: 8. Geranium Hematodes. The red Ro≈øe Cranes bill.
div.p:
This Cranes bill hath diuers leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, very much cut in or diuided into many parts, and each of them againe ≈ølit or cut into two or three peeces, ≈øtanding vpon ≈ølender long foote-≈øtalkes, of a faire greene colour all the Spring and Summer, but reddi≈øh in Autumne: among the≈øe leaues ≈øpring vp ≈ølender and weake ≈øtalkes, be≈øet at euery ioynt (which is ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh) with two leaues for the mo≈øt part, like vnto the lower: the flowers grow ≈øeuerally on the toppe of the ≈øtalkes, and not many together in bunches or branches, as in all other of the Cranes bils, euery flower being as large as a ≈øingle Ro≈øe Campion flower, con≈øi≈øting of fiue large leaues,
of a deeper red colour then in any other Cranes bill at the fir≈øt opening, and will change more blewi≈øh afterwards: when the flower is pa≈øt, there doth ari≈øe ≈øuch like beakes as are in others of the ≈øame kinde, but ≈ømall: the roote is hard, long, and thicke, with diuers branches ≈øpreading from it, of a reddi≈øh yellow colour on the out≈øide, and whiti≈øh within, which abideth and peri≈øheth not, but ≈øhooteth forth ≈øome new greene leaues, which abide all the Winter, although tho≈øe that turne red doe fall away.

div.head: Geranium Creticum. Candy Cranes bill.
div.p: Candy Cranes bill beareth long and tender ≈øtalkes, whereon growe diuers broad and long leaues, cut in or iagged on the edges: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are branched into many flowers, made of fiue leaues of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe, and of a faire blew or watchet colour, with a purpli≈øh pointell in the middle, which being pa≈øt, there follow beake heads like other Cranes bils, but greater, containing larger, greater, and ≈øharper pointed ≈øeede, able to pierce the skinne, if one be not warie of it: the roote is white and long, with ≈øome fibres at it, and peri≈øheth when it hath perfected his ≈øeede, and will ≈øpring of it owne ≈øowing many times, if the Winter be not too ≈øharpe, otherwi≈øe (being annuall) it mu≈øt be ≈øowne in the Spring of the yeare.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Mo≈øt of the≈øe Cranes bils are ≈øtrangers vnto vs by nature, but endenizond in our Engli≈øh Gardens. It hath beene reported vnto mee by ≈øome of good credit, that the ≈øecond or Crowfoot Cranes bill hath been found naturally growing in England, but yet I neuer ≈øaw it, although I haue ≈øeen many ≈øorts of wilde kindes in many places. Matthiolus ≈øaith that the fir≈øt groweth in Dalmatia and Illyria very plentifully. Camerarius, Clu≈øius, and others, that mo≈øt of the re≈øt grow in Germany, Bohemia, Au≈øtria, &c. The la≈øt hath his place recorded in his title.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All the≈øe Cranes bils doe for the mo≈øt part flower in Aprill, and May, and vntill the middle of Iune. The variable or ≈øtript Cranes bill is v≈øually the late≈øt of all the re≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is v≈øually called Geranium tubero≈øum, of ≈øome Geranium bulbo≈øum, of the likene≈ø≈øe of the roote vnto a bulbe: It is without controuer≈øie Geranium primum of Dio≈øcorides. The ≈øecond is called Geranium Gratia Dei, of others, Geranium caeruleum. The blew Cranes bill Lobel calleth it Batrachoides, becau≈øe both leafe and flower are like vnto a Crowfoote; and the affinity with the Cranes bils in the ≈øeede cau≈øeth it rather to be referred to them then to the Crowfeete. The ≈øtript Cranes bill is called by ≈øome Geranium Romanum. The la≈øt ≈øauing one is called Geranium Haematodes, or Sanguineum, of Lobel Geranium Gruinal ‚Ä¢ Haematodes ≈øupinum radice repente. In Engli≈øh it may be called after the Greek and Latine, The bloudy Cranes bill, but I rather call it, The Ro≈øe Cranes bill, becau≈øe the flowers are as large as ≈øingle Ro≈øes, or as the Ro≈øe Campion. Some of them are called in many places of England Ba≈ø≈øinets.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All the kindes of Cranes bils are accounted great wound herbes, and effectuall to ≈øtay bleedings, yet ≈øome more then others. The Emperickes of Germanie, as Camerarius ≈øaith, extoll it wonderfully, for a ≈øingular remedie again≈øt the Stone, both in the reines and bladder.

div.head: Sanicula guttata maior. Spotted Sanicie.
div.p: HAuing long debated with my ≈øelfe, where to place this & the other plants that follow in the two next Chapters, I haue thought it not ami≈ø≈øe for this worke to ≈øet them downe here, both before the Beares eares, which are kindes of Sanicle, as the be≈øt Authors doe hold, and after the Cranes bils, both for ≈øome qualities ≈øomewhat re≈øembling them, and for ≈øome affinity of the flowers with the former.

The ≈øpotted Sanicle hath many ≈ømall round leaues, bluntly endented about the edges, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of our white Saxifrage, of a full greene colour aboue, and whiti≈øh hairy, and ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh withall vnderneath: the ≈øtalkes are ≈øet here and there with the like leaues, ri≈øing a foote and a halfe high or more, very much diuided at the toppe into ≈øundry ≈ømall branches, bearing many very ≈ømall white flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall leaues, wherein are many ≈ømall red ≈øpots to be ≈øeene, as ≈ømall as pins points, of a pretty ≈øweete ≈øent, almo≈øt like Hawthorne flowers, in the middle whereof are many ≈ømall threads compa≈ø≈øing a head, which when it is ripe containeth ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede: the roote is ≈øcaly, or couered with a chaffie matter, hauing many ≈ømall white fibres vnderneath, whereby it is fa≈øtened in the ground.

There is another of this kinde, like both in roote, leafe, and flower to the former,Minor non guttata. the onely difference is, that this is le≈ø≈øer then the former, and hath no ≈øpots in the flower, as the other hath.

We haue al≈øo another ≈ømaller kinde then the la≈øt, both in leafe and flower,Minus guttata. the leaues whereof are ≈ømaller, but rounder, and more finely ≈ønipt or indented about the edge, like the teeth of a fine ≈øawe: the ≈øtalke is little aboue a ≈øpan high, hauing many ≈ømall white flowers ≈øpotted as the fir≈øt, but with fewer ≈øpots.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe growe in the ≈øhadowie Woods of the Alpes, in diuers places, and with vs they more delight in the ≈øhade then the ≈øunne.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All the≈øe Sanicles doe flower in May, and continue flowring vntill Iune, and the ≈øeede ≈øoone ripeneth after: the rootes abide all the Winter, with ≈øome leaues on them, ≈øpringing a fre≈øh in the beginning of the yeare.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The former two are called by Clu≈øius Sanicula montana, and by others Sanicula guttata: by Lobel Geum Alpinum. The third or la≈øt hath been ≈øent vs vnder the name of Sanicula montana altera minor.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The name impo≈øed on the≈øe plants doe certainly a≈ø≈øure vs of their vertues, from the fir≈øt founders, that they are great healers, and from their ta≈øte, that they are great binders.

div.head: Cotyledon altera Matthioli. Spotted Nauelwort.
div.p: THis ≈øpotted Nauelwort, as many doe call it, hath many thicke ≈ømall leaues, not ≈øo broad as long, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, lying on the ground in circles, after the manner of the heads of Hou≈øeleeke, and dented about the edges; from the middle whereof ≈øometimes (for it doth not flower euery yeare in many places) ari≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, ≈øcarce a foote high, be≈øet with ≈øuch like leaues as are belowe, but ≈øomewhat longer: from the middle of the ≈øtalke vp to the top it brancheth forth diuer≈øly, with a leafe at euery ioynt, bearing three or foure flowers on euery branch, con≈øi≈øting of fiue white leaues, ≈øpotted with ≈ømall red ≈øpots, like vnto the ≈øpotted Sanicle, but with fewer and greater ≈øpots, hauing a yellowi≈øh circle or eye in the bottome of euery flower, and many whiti≈øh threads with yellowi≈øh tips in it: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall and blacke, contained in ≈ømall round heads: the roote is ≈ømall, long, and threadie, ≈øhooting out ≈øuch heads of leaues, which abide all the Winter, tho≈øe that beare flower peri≈øhing.

div.head: Cotyledon altera minor. Small dented Nauelwort.
div.p: There is another like vnto that before de≈øcribed in mo≈øt things, the differences be the≈øe: It hath ≈øhorter leaues then the former, and dented about the edges in the like manner: the flowers hereof are white, but greater, made of ≈øix leaues, and mo≈øt v≈øually without any ≈øpots at all in them, ≈øome are ≈øeene to haue ≈øpots al≈øo: the heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels are more cornered then the former.

div.head: Cotyledon altera flore rubro ≈øtellato. Small red flowred Nauelwort.
div.p: This hath al≈øo many heads of leaues, but more open, which are longer, greener, and ≈øharper pointed then eyther of the former, ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh al≈øo, and not dented about the edges, but yet a little rough in handling: the ≈øtalke ari≈øeth from among the leaues, being ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, and the leaues thereon are reddi≈øh pointed, diuided at the toppe into many branches, with diuers flowers thereon, made of twelue ≈ømall long leaues, ≈øtanding like a ≈øtarre, of a reddi≈øh purple colour, with many threads therein, ≈øet about the middle head, which is diuided at the toppe into many ≈ømall ends, like pods or hornes, containing therein very ≈ømall ≈øeede: the root is ≈ømall like the former.

div.head: Sedum ≈øerratum flore rubente maculato. The Princes Feather.
div.p: This kinde of Sengreene is compo≈øed of heads of larger, broader, and thinner leaues then any of the former, of a ≈øadder greene colour, ≈øomewhat vneuenly endented about the edges, and not ≈øo clo≈øe ≈øet together, but ≈øpreading forth into ≈øeuerall heads like as the former ≈øorts doe, although not ≈øo plentifully; from the middle of diuers of which heads ri≈øe vp browni≈øh or reddi≈øh ≈øtalkes, ≈øet with ≈ømaller leaues thereon to the middle thereof, and then brancheth forth into ≈øeuerall ≈øprigs, ≈øet with diuers ≈ømall reddi≈øh flowers con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, the inner≈øide of which are of a pale red, ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh, ≈øpotted with many ≈ømall bloud red ≈øpots, as ≈ømall almo≈øt as pins points, with ≈øome ≈ømall threads in the middle, ≈øtanding about a ≈ømall greene head, which turneth into the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell, parted foure wayes at the head, wherein is contained ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the rootes are ≈ømall threads, which ≈øpread vnder the ground, and ≈øhoote vp ≈øeuerall heads round about it.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe growe in Germany, Hungarie, Au≈øtria, the Alpes, and other ≈øuch like places, where they cleaue to the rocke it ≈øelfe, that hath but a cru≈øt of earth on it to nouri≈øh them. They will abide in Gardens rea≈øonable well, if they be planted in ≈øhadowie places, and not in the ≈øun.

figure.head: 1 Sanicula guttata. Spotted Sanicle. 2 Cotyledon altera Matthioli. Spotted Nauelwort. 3 Cotyledon altera minor. Small dented Nauelwort. 4 Cotyledon altera flore rubro ≈øtellato. Small red flowred Nauelwort. 5 Sedum ≈øerratum flore rubente maculato. The Princes Feather. 6 Soldanella A≈øpina. Blew Moonwort.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part in the end of May, and ≈øometimes ≈øooner or later, as the yeare falleth out.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called by Matthiolus, Cotyledon altera Dio≈øcoridis, and Vmbilicus alter, but it is not the true Cotyledon altera of Dio≈øcorides; for Sedum vulgare maius, Our common Hou≈øeleeke, by the con≈øent of the be≈øt moderne Writers, is the true Cotyledon altera of Dio≈øcorides, or Vmbilicus Veneris alter. I hold it rather to bee a kinde of ≈ømall Hou≈øeleeke, as the other two likewi≈øe are. The ≈øecond is called by ≈øome Aizoum or Sedum minus ≈øerratum. The third hath his name in his title. Wee doe call them Nauelworts in Engli≈øh rather then Hou≈øeleekes, Euphoniae gratia. The la≈øt may be called dented Sengreene with reddi≈øh ≈øpotted flowers, but ≈øome of our Engli≈øh Gentlewomen haue called it, The Princes Feather, which although it be but a by-name, may well ≈øerue for this plant to di≈øtingui≈øh it, and whereby to be knowne.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: They are all held to be cold and moi≈øt, like vnto other Hou≈øeleekes.

div.head: Soldanella Alpina. Mountaine Soldanella or blew Moonewort.
div.p: THis beautifull plant hath many round and hard leaues, ≈øet vpon long foote≈øtalkes, a little vneuenly cut about the edges, greene on the vpper≈øide, and of a grayi≈øh greene vnderneath, and ≈øometime reddi≈øh like the leaues of Sowbread, which becau≈øe they doe ≈øomewhat re≈øemble the leaues of Soldanella marina, which is the Sea Bindweede, tooke the name thereof: the ≈øtalkes are ≈ølender, ≈ømall, round, and reddi≈øh, about a ≈øpan high, bearing foure or fiue flowers at the toppe, euery one hanging downe their heads, like vnto a Bell flower, con≈øi≈øting but of one leafe (as mo≈øt of the Bindweeds doe) plated into fiue folds, each of them ending in a long point, which maketh the flower ≈øeem to haue fiue leaues, each whereof is deeply cut in on the edges, and hauing a round greene head in the middle, with a pricke or pointell at the end thereof: the flower is of a faire blew colour, ≈øometimes deeper or paler, or white, as nature li≈øteth without any ≈ømell at all: the middle head, after the flower is fallen, ri≈øeth to be a long round pod, bearing that pricke it had at the end thereof, wherein is contained ≈ømall greeni≈øh ≈øeede: the roote hath many fibres ≈øhooting from a long round head or roote.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This groweth on the Alpes, which are couered with ≈ønow the greate≈øt part of the yeare, and will hardly abide tran≈øplanting.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: In the naturall places it flowreth not vntill the Summer moneths, Iune, Iuly, and Augu≈øt, after the ≈ønow is melted from the Hils, but being brought into Gardens, it flowreth in the beginning of Aprill, or thereabouts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: This plant, by rea≈øon of the likene≈ø≈øe of leaues with Soldanella, as was before ≈øaid, is called by many Soldanella, but yet is no Bindweede; and therefore I rather call it in Engli≈øh a Mountaine Soldanella, then as Gerrard doth, Mountaine Bindweede. It is likewi≈øe called by ≈øome, Lunaria minor caerulea, The le≈ø≈øer blew Lunary or Moonwort, and ≈øo I would rather haue it called.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: They that impo≈øed the name of Lunaria vpon this plant, ≈øeeme to referre it to the wound or con≈øolidating herbes, but becau≈øe I haue no further relation or experience, I can ≈øay no more thereof vntill tryall hath taught it. Some al≈øo from the name Soldanella, which is giuen it, becau≈øe of the likene≈ø≈øe of the leaues, haue v≈øed it to help the Drop≈øie, for which the Sea plant is thought to be effectuall.

div.head: Auricula Vr≈øi. Beares eares.
div.p: THere are ≈øo many ≈øundry and ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of Beares eares, the variety con≈øi≈øting as well in the differing colours of the flowers, as the forme and colour of the leaues, that I ≈øhall not comprehend and ≈øet downe vnto you all the diuer≈øities by many, that are ri≈øen vp to tho≈øe that haue beene indu≈øtrious in the ≈øowing of the ≈øeedes of the ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of them; yet if you accept of the≈øe that I doe here offer vnto you, I ≈øhall giue you the knowledge of others, as time, occa≈øion, and the view of them ≈øhall enable me. And becau≈øe they are without all que≈øtion kinds of Cow≈ølips, I haue ≈øet them downe before them in the fir≈øt place, as being of more beautie and greater re≈øpect, or at the lea≈øt of more rarity vnto vs. To di≈øpo≈øe them therefore into order, I ≈øhall ranke them vnder three principall colours, that is to ≈øay, Red or Purple, White, and Yellow, and ≈øhew you the varieties of each of them (for ≈øo many as are come to my knowledge) apart by them≈øelues, and not promi≈øcuou≈øly as many others haue done.

div.head: 1. Auricula Vr≈øi flore purpureo. Purple Beares eare, or The Murrey Cow≈ølip.
div.p: This purple Beares eare or Cow≈ølip hath many greene leaues, ≈øomewhat long and ≈ømooth, narrow from the bottome of the leafe to the middle, and broad from thence to the end, being round pointed, and ≈øomewhat ≈ønipt or endented about the edges; in the middle of the≈øe leaues, and ≈øometimes at the ≈øides al≈øo, doe ≈øpring round greene ≈øtalkes foure or fiue fingers high, bearing at the top many flowers, the buds whereof, before they are blowne, are of a very deepe purple colour, and being open, are of a bright, but deepe purple, v≈øually called a Murrey colour, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, cut in at the end as it were into two, with a whiti≈øh ring or circle at the bottome of each flower, ≈øtanding in ≈ømall greene cups, wherein after the flowers are fallen, are contained very ≈ømall heads, not ri≈øing to the height of the cups, bearing a ≈ømall pricke or pointell at the toppe of them, wherein is little blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote hath many whiti≈øh ≈øtrings fa≈øtened to the maine long roote, which is very like vnto a Primro≈øe or Cow≈ølip roote, as it is in all other parts be≈øides.

div.head:
2. Auricula Vr≈øi purpurea ab≈ø
que orbe. The murrey Cow≈ølip without eyes.
div.p:
There is another of this kinde, who≈øe leafe is ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe, as the flower is al≈øo,
but of the ≈øame colour, and ≈øometimes ≈øomewhat redder, tending to a Scarlet, without any circle at the bottome of the flower, in no other things differing from it.

div.head: 3. Auricula Vr≈øi minor flore tannetto. Tawney Beares eares.
div.p: The leaues of this kinde haue a greater ≈øhew of mealine≈ø≈øe to be ≈øeene in them, and not much ≈ømaller then the former, yet ≈ønipt or endented about the ends like vnto them: the flowers are many, of the ≈øame fa≈øhion with the former, but ≈ømaller, each whereof is of as deepe a murrey or tawnie colour when it is blowne, as the buds of the former are before they are blowne, hauing a white circle at the bottome of the flower, and yellowi≈øh in the middle belowe the circle.

div.head: 4. Auricula Vr≈øi flore rubro ≈øaturo orbe luteo. Deepe or bloud red Beares eares with eyes.
div.p: This kinde hath ≈ømall and long greene leaues, nothing mealy, but ≈ønipt about the edges, from the middle of the leaues forwards to the ends: the flowers hereof are of a deepe red colour, tending to a bloud red, with a deepe yellow circle, or rather bottome in the middle.

Auricula Vr≈øi flore rubro ≈øature ab≈øque orbe.There is another of this kinde, who≈øe leaues are ≈øomewhat mealy, and ≈ømaller then any (that I haue ≈øeene) that haue mealy leaues: the flowers are of the ≈øame deepe red colour with the la≈øt de≈øcribed, yet hath no circle or bottome of any other colour at all.

div.head: 5. Auricula Vr≈øi flore purpuro caeruleo. The Violet coloured Beares eare.
div.p: We haue another, who≈øe leaues are ≈øomewhat mealy and large; the flowers whereof are of a paler purple then the fir≈øt, ≈øomewhat tending to a blew.

div.head: 6. Auricula Vr≈øi flore ob≈øoleto magno. The Spaniards blu≈øh Beares eare.
div.p: This great Beares eare hath as large leaues as any other of this kindred what≈øoeuer, and whiti≈øh or mealy withall, ≈øomewhat ≈ønipt about the edges, as many other of them are: the flowers ≈øtand at the toppe of a ≈øtrong and tall ≈øtalke, larger then any of the other that I haue ≈øeene, being of a duskie blu≈øh colour, re≈øembling the blu≈øh of a Spaniard, who≈øe tawney skinne cannot declare ≈øo pure a blu≈øh as the Engli≈øh can; and therefore I haue called it the Spaniards blu≈øh.

div.head: 7. Auricula Vr≈øi flore rubello. Scarlet or light red Beares eares.
div.p: The leaues of this kinde are very like the leaues of the fir≈øt purple kinde, but that they are not ≈øo thicke; of a little paler greene colour, and little or nothing ≈ønipt about the edges: the flowers are of a bright, but pale reddi≈øh colour, not halfe ≈øo deepe as the two la≈øt with white circles in the bottomes of them, in other things this differeth not from others.

div.head: 8. Auricula Vr≈øi Ro≈øeo colore. The Ro≈øe coloured Beares eare.
div.p: We haue another, who≈øe leafe is a little mealy, almo≈øt as large as any of the former, who≈øe flowers are of a light red colour, very neare the colour of an ordinary Damaske Ro≈øe, with a white eye at the bottome.

div.head: 9. Auricula Vr≈øi flore caeruleo folio Boraginis. Blew Beares eares with Borage leaues.
div.p:
This plant is referred to the kindred or family of the Beares eares, onely for the forme of the flower ≈øake, which euen therein it doth not a≈ø≈øimilate to the halfe; but becau≈øe it hath pa≈ø≈øed others with that title, I am content to in≈øert it here, to giue you
1 Auricula Vr≈øi flore purpureo. Purple Cow≈ølips or Beares eares. 2 Auricula Vr≈øi flore
‚Ä¢ annetto. Tawney Beares eare. 3 Auricula Vr≈øi flore & folio Boraginis. Blew Beares eares with Borage leaues. 4 Auricula Vr≈øi flore carneo Blu≈øh Beares eare. 5 Auricula Vr≈øi maxima lutea flore eleganti. The greate≈øt faire yellow Beares eares with eyes. 6 Auricula Vr≈øi altera flore luteo. The yellow Beares eare. 7 Auricula Vr≈øi crinis coloris ≈øiue flore fu≈øco. The haire coloured Beares eare. 8 Cortu≈øa Matthioli. Beares eare Sanicle. depiction of flowers
the knowledge thereof, and rather to ≈øati≈øfie others then my ≈øelfe with the place thereof: the de≈øcription whereof is as followeth: It hath diuers broad rough hairy leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of Borage for the roughne≈ø≈øe, but not for the largene≈ø≈øe; the leaues hereof being ≈øomewhat rent in ≈øome places at the edges: from among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp one, or two, or more browni≈øh, round, and hairy ≈øtalkes, a ≈øpan high or thereabouts, bearing at the toppes three or foure flowers a peece, con≈øi≈øting of fiue large pointed leaues, of a faire blew or light azur colour, with ≈øome ≈ømall yellow threads in the middle, ≈øtanding in ≈ømall greene cups: the roote is long and browni≈øh, hauing many ≈ømall fibres annexed vnto it.

div.head: 10. Auricula Vr≈øi maior flore albo. The great white Beares eare.
div.p: This white Beares eare hath many faire whiti≈øh greene leaues, ≈øomewhat paler then the leaues of any of the kindes of Beares eares, and a little ≈ønipt about the ends, as manie other are: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp ≈øtalkes foure or fiue inches high, bearing at the toppe many flowers like vnto the ≈ømall yellow Beares eare hereafter ≈øet downe, of a pale whiti≈øh colour, tending to yellow at the fir≈øt opening of the flower, which after two or three dayes change into a faire white colour, and ≈øo continue all the while it flowreth: the roote is like the purple kinde, as all or mo≈øt of the re≈øt are, or very little differing.

div.head: 11. Auricula Vr≈øi minor flore albo. The le≈ø≈øer white Beares eare.
div.p: The le≈ø≈øer Beares eare hath ≈ømaller leaues, of a little darker green colour: the ≈øtalke and flowers are likewi≈øe le≈ø≈øer then the former, and haue no ≈øhew of yellowne≈ø≈øe at all, eyther in budde or flower, but is pure white, differing not in other things from the re≈øt.

div.head: 12. Auricula Vr≈øi maxima lutea flore eleganti. The greate≈øt faire yellow Beares eare with eyes.
div.p: This yellow Beares eare hath many faire large thicke leaues, ≈øomewhat mealy or hoary vpon the greenne≈ø≈øe, being larger then any other kinde, except the ≈øixth, and the next yellow that followeth, ≈ømooth about the edges, and without any endenting at all: the ≈øtalke is great, round, and not higher then in other of the former, but bearing manie more flowers thereon then in any other kinde, to the number of thirty many times, ≈øtanding ≈øo round and clo≈øe together, that they ≈øeeme to be a No≈øegay alone, of the ≈øame fa≈øhion with the former, but that the leaues are ≈øhorter and rounder, yet with a notch in the middle like the re≈øt, of a faire yellow colour, neither very pale nor deepe, with a white eye or circle in the bottome, about the middle of euery flower, which giueth it the greater grace: the ≈øeede is of a blacki≈øh browne colour, like vnto others, but contained in greater round heads then any other, with a ≈ømall pointell ≈øticking in the middle: the roote is greater and thicker then any other, with long ≈øtrings or fibres like vnto the other ≈øorts, but greater.

div.head: 13. Auricula Vr≈øi maior lutea folio in cauo. The greater yellow Beares eare.
div.p: This greater yellow Beares eare hath his leaues larger, and more mealy or hoarie then the la≈øt, or any other of the≈øe kindes: the flowers are not ≈øo many, but longer, and not ≈øo thicke thru≈øting together as the fir≈øt, but of a deeper yellow colour, without any eye or circle in the middle.

div.head: 14. Auricula Vr≈øi maior flore pallido. The great Straw coloured Beares eare.
div.p: This hath almo≈øt as mealy leaues as the la≈øt, but nothing ≈øo large; the flowers are of a faire ≈øtrawe colour, with a white circle at the bottome of them, the≈øe three la≈øt haue no ≈øhew or ≈øhadow of any other colour in any part of the edge, as ≈øome others that follow haue.

div.head: 15. Auricula Vr≈øi minor flore pallente. The le≈ø≈øer ≈øtraw coloured Beares eare.
div.p: We haue another, who≈øe leafe is le≈ø≈øe mealy, or rather pale green, and a little mealy withall; the flowers whereof are of a paler yellow colour then the la≈øt, and beareth almo≈øt as many vpon a ≈øtalke as the fir≈øt great yellow.

div.head: 16. Auricula Vr≈øi minor lutea. The le≈ø≈øer yellow Beares eares.
div.p: The leaues of this Beares eare are nothing ≈øo large as either of the three former yellow kindes, but rather of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the fir≈øt white kinde, but yet a little larger, thicker, and longer then it, hauing vnder the greenne≈ø≈øe a ≈ømall ≈øhew of mealine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øomewhat ≈ønipt about the edges: the flowers are of a pale yellow colour, with a little white bottome in them: the ≈øeed and rootes are like vnto the other kindes.

div.head: 17. Auricula Vr≈øi flore flauo. The deepe yellow or Cow≈ølip Beares eare.
div.p: This kinde hath ≈øomewhat larger leaues then the la≈øt, of a yellowi≈øh greene colour, without any mealine≈ø≈øe on them, or endenting about the edges, but ≈ømooth and whole: the flowers are not larger but longer, and not laide open ≈øo fully as the former, but of as deepe a yellow colour as any Cow≈ølip almo≈øt, without any circle in the bottome: neither of the≈øe two la≈øt haue any ≈øhew of other colour then yellow in them, ≈øauing the white in the eye.

div.head: 18. Auricula Vr≈øi ver≈øicolor prima ≈øiue flore rube≈øcente. The blu≈øh Beares eare.
div.p: The blu≈øh Beares eare hath his leaues as large, and as hoary or mealy as the third greater yellow, or ≈øtraw coloured Beares eare; among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke about foure inches high, bearing from ≈øix to twelue, or more faire flowers, ≈øomewhat larger then the ≈ømaller yellow Beares eare before de≈øcribed, hauing the ground of the flower of a darke or dunne yellow colour, ≈øhadowed ouer a little with a ≈øhew of light purple, which therefore we call a blu≈øh colour, the edges of the flower being ript with a little deeper ≈øhew of that purple colour, the bottome of the flower abiding wholly yellow, without any circle, and is of very great beauty, which hath cau≈øed me to place it in the forefront of the variable coloured Beares eares. And although ≈øome might thinke it ≈øhould be placed among the fir≈øt ranke of Beares eares, becau≈øe it is of a blu≈øh colour, yet ≈øeeing it is a≈ø≈øuredly gained from ≈øome of the yellow kindes by ≈øowing the ≈øeede, as many other ≈øorts are, as may be ≈øeene plainly in the ground of the flower, which is yellow, and but ≈øhadowed ouer with purple, yet more then any of the re≈øt that follow; I thinke I haue giuen it his right place: let others of skill & experience be iudges herein.

div.head: 19. Auricula Vr≈øi crinis coloris. Haire coloured Beares eares.
div.p: The leaues of this kinde are more mealy like then the la≈øt blu≈øh kinde, but ≈øomewhat longer and larger, and ≈ønipt about the edges in the ≈øame manner, from the middle of the leafe forwards: the flower is v≈øually of a fine light browne yellow colour, which wee doe v≈øually call an Haire colour, and ≈øometimes browner, the edges of the flower haue a ≈øhew or ≈øhadow of a light purple or blu≈øh about them, but more on the out≈øide then on the in≈øide.

div.head: 20. Auricula Vr≈øi ver≈øicolor lutea. The yellow variable Beares eare.
div.p: This variable Beares eare hath his greene leaues ≈øomewhat like vnto the deepe yellow, or Cow≈ølip Beares eare before de≈øcribed, but ≈øomewhat of a fre≈øher greene, more ≈øhining and ≈ømaller, and ≈ønipt about the edges towards the ends, as many of tho≈øe before are: the flowers are of a faire yellow colour, much laid open when it is full blowne, that it ≈øeemeth almo≈øt flat, da≈øht about the edges onely with purple, being more yellow in the bottome of the flower, then in any other part.

div.head: 21. Auricula Vr≈øi ver≈øicolor lute≈øcente viridi flore. The variable green Beares eare.
div.p: This kinde of Beares eare hath greene leaues, very like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, and ≈ønipt in the like manner about the edges, but in this it differeth, that his leaues do turne or fold them≈øelues a little backwards: the flowers are of a yellowi≈øh greene colour, more clo≈øed then the former, hauing purpli≈øh edges, e≈øpecially after they haue ≈øtood blowne ≈øome time, and haue little or none at the fir≈øt opening: the≈øe haue no circles at all in them.

Many other varieties are to be found, with tho≈øe that are curious con≈øeruers of the≈øe delights of nature, either narurally growing on the mountaines in ≈øeuerall places, from whence they (being ≈øearched out by diuers) haue been taken and brought, or el≈øe rai≈øed from the ≈øeede of ≈øome of them, as it is more probable: for ≈øeuerall varieties haue beene ob≈øerued (and no doubt many of the≈øe before ≈øpecified) to bee gotten by ≈øowing of the ≈øeedes, euery yeare lightly ≈øhewing a diuer≈øity, not ob≈øerued before, either in the leafe, diuers from that from whence it was taken, or in the flowers. I haue onely ≈øet downe tho≈øe that haue come vnder mine owne view, and not any by relation, euen as I doe with all or mo≈øt of the things contained in this worke.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Many of the≈øe goodly plants growe naturally on mountaines, e≈øpecially the Alpes, in diuers places; for ≈øome kindes that growe in ≈øome places, doe not in others, but farre di≈øtant one from the other. There hath likewi≈øe ≈øome beene found on the Pyrenaean mountaines, but that kinde with the blew flower and Borage leafe, hath beene gathered on the mountaines in Spaine, and on the Pyrenaeans next vnto Spaine.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in Aprill and May, and the ≈øeede is ripe in the end of Iune, or beginning of Iuly, and ≈øometimes they will flower againe in the end of Summer, or in Autumne, if the yeare proue temperate, moi≈øt, and rainie.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is very probable, that none of the≈øe plants were euer knowne vnto the ancient Writers, becau≈øe we cannot be a≈ø≈øured, that they may be truely referred vnto any plant that they name, vnle≈ø≈øe we beleeue Fabius Columna, that it ≈øhould be Ali≈øma of Dio≈øcorides, for thereunto hee doth referre it. Diuers of the later Writers haue giuen vnto them diuers names, euery one according to his owne conceit. For Ge≈øner calleth it Lunaria arthritica, and Paralytica Alpina. Matthiolus accounteth it to bee of the kindred of the Sanicles, and ≈øaith, that in his time it was called by diuers Herbari≈øts, Auricula Vr≈øi, which name hath ≈øince bin receiued as mo≈øt v≈øuall. We in Engli≈øh call them Beares eares, according to the Latine, or as they are called by diuers women, French Cow≈ølips; they may be called Mountaine Cow≈ølips, if you will, for to di≈øtingui≈øh betweene them and other Cow≈ølips, whereof the≈øe are ≈øeuerall kindes.

div.head: Sanicula Alpina ≈øiue Cortu≈øa Matthioli. Beares eare Sanicle.
div.p:
I cannot chu≈øe but in≈øert this delicate plant in the end of the Beares eares, for that it is of ≈øo neare affinity, although it differ much in the forme of the leaues, the de≈øcription whereof is in this manner: The leaues that ≈øpring vp fir≈øt are much crumpled, and as it were folded together, which afterwards open them≈øelues into faire, broad, and roundi≈øh leaues, ≈øomewhat rough or hairy, not onely cut into fine diui≈øions, but ≈øomewhat notched al≈øo about the edges, of a darke greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and
more whiti≈øh greene vnderneath; among≈øt the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp one or two naked round ≈øtalkes, fiue or ≈øix inches high, bearing at the toppes diuers ≈ømall flowers, ≈øomewhat ≈øweete, like vnto the fir≈øt purple Beares eare, hanging downe their heads, con≈ø≈øting of fiue ≈ømall pointed leaues a peece, of a darke reddi≈øh purple colour, with a white circle or bottome in the middle, and ≈øome ≈ømall threads therein: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come ≈ømall round heads, ≈øomewhat longer then any of the Beares eares, ≈øtanding vpright vpon their ≈ømall foot-≈øtalkes, wherein is contained ≈ømall round and blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote con≈øi≈øteth of a thicke tuft of ≈ømall whiti≈øh threads, rather then rootes, much enterlaced one among another: the leaues of this plant dye downe euery yeare, and ≈øpring vp a new in the beginning of the yeare, whereas all the Beares eares doe hold their leaues greene all the Winter, e≈øpecially the middlemo≈øt, which ≈øtand like a clo≈øe head, the outermo≈øt for the mo≈øt part peri≈øhing after ≈øeed time.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This groweth in many ≈øhadowie Woods both of Italy and Germany; for both Clu≈øius hath de≈øcribed it, finding it in the Woods of Au≈øtria and Stiria; and Matthiolus ≈øetteth it downe, hauing receiued it from Anthonius Cortu≈øus, who was Pre≈øident of the Garden at Padua, and found it in the woody mountaines of Vicenza, neare vnto Ville≈øtagna, whereon (as Matthiolus ≈øaith) there is found both with white flowers as well as with blew, but ≈øuch with white flowers or blew we neuer could ≈øee or heare further of.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth much about the time of the Beares eares, or rather a little later, and the ≈øeede is ripe with them.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Clu≈øius calleth it Sanicula montana, and Sanicula, Alpina, and referreth it to the Auricula Vr≈øi, or Beares eare, which it doth mo≈øt nearly re≈øemble: but Matthiolus referreth it to the Cariophyllata or Auens, making it to be of that tribe or family, and calleth it Cortu≈øa of him that fir≈øt ≈øent it him. Wee may call it eyther Cortu≈øa, as for the mo≈øt part all Herbari≈øts doe, or Beares eare Sanicle as Gerrard doth.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All the ≈øorts of Beares eares are Cephalicall, that is, conducing helpe for the paines in the head, and for the giddine≈ø≈øe thereof, which may happen, eyther by the ≈øight of ≈øteepe places ≈øubiect to danger, or otherwi≈øe. They are accounted al≈øo to be helping for the Pal≈øey, and ≈øhaking of the ioynts; and al≈øo as a Sanicle or wound-herbe. The leaues of the Cortu≈øa ta≈øte a little hot, and if one of them bee laide whole, without brui≈øing, on the cheeke of any tender skind woman, it will rai≈øe an orient red colour, as if ≈øome fucus had beene laide thereon, which will pa≈ø≈øe away without any manner of harme, or marke where it lay: This is Cortu≈øus his ob≈øeruation. Camerarius in his Hortus Medicus ≈øaith, that an oyle is made thereof, that is admirable for to cure wounds.

div.head: Primula veris & Paraly≈øis. Primro≈øes and Cow≈ølips.
div.p: WE haue ≈øo great variety of Primro≈øes and Cow≈ølips of our owne Country breeding, that ≈øtrangers being much delighted with them, haue beene often furni≈øhed into diuers Countries, to their good content: And that I may ≈øet them downe in ≈øome methodicall manner, as I haue done other things, I will fir≈øt ≈øet downe all the ≈øorts of tho≈øe we call Primro≈øes, both ≈øingle and double, and afterwards the Cow≈ølips with their diuer≈øities, in as ample manner as my knowledge can direct me. And yet I know, that the name of Primula veris or Primro≈øe is indifferently conferred vpon tho≈øe that I di≈øtingui≈øh for Paraly≈øes or Cow≈ølips. I doe therefore for your better vnder≈øtanding of my di≈øtinction betweene Primro≈øes and Cow≈ølips, call tho≈øe onely Primro≈øes that carry but one flower vpon a ≈øtalke, be they ≈øingle or double, except that of Ma≈øter Hesket, and that with double flowers many vpon a ≈øtalke, ≈øet out in Gerards Herball, which is his onely, not found (as I thinke) in rerum natura, I am ≈øure, ≈øuch a one I could neuer heare of: And tho≈øe Cow≈ølips, that beare many flowers vpon a ≈øtalke together con≈øtantly, be they ≈øingle or double al≈øo. I might otherwi≈øe di≈øtingui≈øh them al≈øo by the leafe; that all the Primro≈øes beare their long and large broad yellowi≈øh greene leaues, without ≈øtalkes mo≈øt v≈øually; and all the Cow≈ølips haue ≈ømall ≈øtalkes vnder the leaues, which are ≈ømaller, and of a darker greene, as v≈øually, but that this di≈øtinction is neither ≈øo certaine and generall, nor ≈øo well knowne.

div.head: 1. Primula veris flore albo. The ≈øingle white Primro≈øe.
div.p: The Primro≈øe that groweth vnder euery bu≈øh or hedge, in all or mo≈øt of the Woods, Groues, and Orchards of this Kingdome, I may well leaue to his wilde habitation, being not ≈øo fit for a Garden, and ≈øo well knowne, that I meane not to giue you any further relation thereof: But we haue a kinde hereof which is ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and beareth milke white flowers, without any ≈øhew of yellowne≈ø≈øe in them, and is more v≈øually brought into Gardens for the rarity, and differeth not from the wilde or ordinary kinde, either in roote or leafe, or any thing el≈øe, yet hauing tho≈øe yellow ≈øpots, but ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo deepe, as are in the other wilde kinde.

div.head: 2. Primula veris flore viridi ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle greene Primro≈øe.
div.p: The ≈øingle greene Primro≈øe hath his leaues very like vnto the greater double Primro≈øe, but ≈ømaller, and of a ≈øadder greene colour: the flowers ≈øtand ≈øeuerally vpon long foot-≈øtalkes, as the fir≈øt ≈øingle kinde doth, but larger then they, and more laide open, of the ≈øame, or very neare the ≈øame yellowi≈øh greene colour that the huske is of, ≈øo that at the fir≈øt opening, the huske and the flower ≈øeeme to make one double greene flower, which afterwards ≈øeparating them≈øelues, the ≈øingle flower groweth aboue the huske, and ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe open much more then any other ≈øingle Primro≈øe doth, growing in the end to be of a paler greene colour.

div.head: 3. Primula veris flore viridante & albo ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle greene and white Primro≈øe.
div.p: The leaues of this differ in a manner nothing from the former, neither doth the flower but only in this, that out of the large yellowi≈øh green huskes, which contain the flowers of the former, there commeth forth out of the middle of each of them either a ≈ømall peece of a whiti≈øh flower, or el≈øe a larger, ≈øometimes making vp a whole flower, like an ordinary Primro≈øe.

div.head: 4. Primula veris flore viridi duplici. The double greene Primro≈øe.
div.p:
This double Primro≈øe is in his leaues ≈øo like the former ≈øingle greene kindes, that

The double green Primro≈øe. 4 Primula veris Hesketi. Ma≈øter Heskets double Primro≈øe. 5 Primula veris flore pleno vulgaris. Double Oxelips ho≈øe in ho≈øe. 9 Paraly≈øis flore & calice cri≈øpo. Curld Cow≈ølips or Gaskins. 10 Paraly≈øis minor angu≈øtifolia flore rubro. Red Birds eyen. 11 Paraly≈øis horten≈øis flore pleno vulgaris. Double Paigles. 12 Paraly≈øis ≈øatu ‚Ä¢ . The fooli≈øh Cow≈ølip, or lacke an Apo ‚Ä¢ on hor≈øe backe. 13 Paraly≈øis flore viridi ro≈øeo calami≈øtrate. The double greene feathered Cow≈ølip. depiction of flowers
the one cannot be knowne from the other vntill it come to flower, and then it beareth vpon euery ≈øtalke a double green flower, of a little deeper green colour then the flower of the former ≈øingle kinde con≈øi≈øting but of two rowes of ≈øhort leaues mo≈øt v≈øually, and both of an equall height aboue the huske, abiding a pretty time in flower, e≈øpecially if it ≈øtand in any ≈øhadowed place, or where the Sun may come but a while vnto it.

div.head: 5. Primula veris Hesketi flore multiplici ≈øeparatim diui≈øo. Ma≈øter Heskets double Primro≈øe.
div.p: Ma≈øter Heskets double Primro≈øe is very like vnto the ≈ømall double Primro≈øe, both in leafe, roote, and heigth of growing, the ≈øtalke not ri≈øing much higher then it, but bearing flowers in a farre different manner; for this beareth not only ≈øingle flowers vpon ≈øeuerall ≈øtalkes, but ≈øomtimes two or three ≈øingle flowers vpon one ≈øtalk, and al≈øo at the ≈øame time a bigger ≈øtalke, and ≈øomewhat higher, hauing one greene huske at the toppe thereof, ≈øometimes broken on the one ≈øide, and ≈øometimes whole, in the middle whereof ≈øtandeth ≈øometimes diuers ≈øingle flowers, thru≈øt together, euery flower to be ≈øeene in his proper forme, and ≈øometimes there appeare with ≈øome whole flowers others that are but parts of flowers, as if the flowers were broken in peeces, and thru≈øt into one huske, the leaues of the flowers (being of a white or pale Primro≈øe colour, but a little deeper) ≈øeldome ri≈øing aboue the height of the very huske it ≈øelfe; and ≈øometimes, as I haue ob≈øerued in this plant, it will haue vpon the ≈øame ≈øtalke, that beareth ≈øuch flowers as I haue here de≈øcribed vnto you, a ≈ømall flower or two, making the ≈øtalke ≈øeeme branched into many flowers, whereby you may perceiue, that it will vary into many formes, not abiding con≈øtant in any yeare, as all the other ≈øorts doe.

div.head: 6. Primula horten≈øis flore pleno vulgaris. The ordinary double Primro≈øe.
div.p: The leaues of this Primro≈øe are very large, and like vnto the ≈øingle kind, but ≈øomewhat larger, becau≈øe it groweth in gardens: the flowers doe ≈øtand euery one ≈øeuerally vpon ≈ølender long foote≈øtalkes, as the ≈øingle kinde doth, in greeni≈øh huskes of a pale yellow colour, like vnto the field Primro≈øe, but very thicke and double, and of the ≈øame ≈øweete ≈øent with them.

div.head: 7. Primula veris flore duplici. The ≈ømall double Primro≈øe.
div.p: This Primro≈øe is both in leafe, roote, and flower, altogether like vnto the la≈øt double Primro≈øe, but that it is ≈ømaller in all things; for the flower ri≈øeth not aboue two or three fingers high, and but twice double, that is, with two rowes of leaues, yet of the very ≈øame Primro≈øe colour that the former is of.

div.head: 8. Paraly≈øis vulgaris praten≈øis flore flauo ≈øimplici odorato. The Common field Cow≈ølip.
div.p: The common fielde Cow≈ølip I might well forbeare to ≈øet downe, being ≈øo plentifull in the fields: but becau≈øe many take delight in it, and plant it in their gardens, I will giue you the de≈øcription of it here. It hath diuers green leaues, very like vnto the wilde Primro≈øe, but ≈øhorter, rounder, ≈øtiffer, rougher, more crumpled about the edges, and of a ≈øadder greene colour, euery one ≈øtanding vpon his ≈øtalke, which is an inch or two long: among the leaues ri≈øe vp diuers round ≈øtalkes, a foote or more high, bearing at the toppe many faire yellow ≈øingle flowers, with ≈øpots of a deeper yellow, at the buttome of each leafe, ≈ømelling very ≈øweete. The rootes are like to the other Primro≈øes, hauing many fibres annexed to the great roote.

div.head: 9. Paraly≈øis altera odorata flore pallido polyanthos. The Primro≈øe Cow≈ølip.
div.p:
The leaues of this Cow≈ølip are larger then the ordinary fielde Cow≈ølip, and of a darke yellowi≈øh greene colour: the flowers are many ≈øtanding together, vpon the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, to the number of thirty ≈øometimes vpon one ≈øtalke, as I haue counted them in mine owne Garden, and ≈øometimes more, euery one hauing a longer
foote ≈øtalke then the former, and of as pale a yellowi≈øh colour almo≈øt as the fielde Primro≈øe, with yellow ≈øpots at the bottome of the leaues, as the ordinary hath, and of as ≈øweet a ≈øent.

div.head: 10. Paraly≈øis flore viridante ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle greene Cow≈ølip.
div.p: There is little difference in leafe or roote of this from the fir≈øt Cow≈ølip, the chiefe≈øt varietie in this kinde is this, that the leaues are ≈øomewhat greener, and the flowers being in all re≈øpects like in forme vnto the fir≈øt kinde, but ≈øomewhat larger, are of the ≈øame colour with the greene huskes, or rather a little yellower, and of a very ≈ømall ≈øent; in all other things I finde no diuer≈øitie, but that it ≈øtandeth much longer in flower before it fadeth, e≈øpecially if it ≈øtand out of the Sunne.

div.head: 11. Paraly≈øis flore & calice cri≈øpo. Curl'd Cow≈ølips or Gallegaskins.
div.p: There is another kinde, who≈øe flowers are folded or crumpled at the edges, and the huskes of the flowers bigger than any of the former, more ≈øwelling out in the middle, as it were ribbes, and crumpled on the ≈øides of the huskes, which doe ≈øomewhat re≈øemble mens ho≈øe that they did weare, and tooke the name of Gallegaskins from thence.

div.head: 12. Paraly≈øis flore geminato odorato. Double Cow≈ølips one within another, or Ho≈øe in Ho≈øe.
div.p: The only difference of this kinde from the ordinary field Cow≈ølip is, that it beareth one ≈øingle flower out of another, which is as a greene huske, of the like ≈øent that the fir≈øt hath, or ≈øomewhat weaker.

div.head: 13. Paraly≈øis flore flauo ≈øimplici inodoro ab≈øque calicibus. Single Oxe lippes.
div.p: This kinde of Cow≈ølip hath leaues much like the ordinary kinde, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller: the flowers are yellow like the Cow≈ølip, but ≈ømaller, ≈øtanding many vpon a ≈øtalke, but bare or naked, that is, without any huske to containe them, hauing but little or no ≈øent at all; nor differing in any thing el≈øe from the ordinary Cow≈ølip.

div.head: 14. Paraly≈øis flore geminato inodora. Double Oxelips Ho≈øe in Ho≈øe.
div.p: As the former double Cow≈ølip had his flowers one within another, in the very like manner hath this kinde of Cow≈ølip or Oxelippe, ≈øauing that this hath no huske to containe them, no more then the former ≈øingle Oxelippe hath, ≈øtanding bare or naked, of the very ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe each of them, and of the ≈øame deepe yellow colour with it, hauing as ≈ømall a ≈øent as the former likewi≈øe.
Wee haue another of this kinde, who≈øe leaues are ≈øomewhat larger,Flore pallidiore and ≈øo are the flowers al≈øo, but of a paler yellow colour.

div.head: 15. Paraly≈øis inodora calicibus di≈ø≈øectis. Oxelips with iagged huskes.
div.p: This kinde differeth not from the fir≈øt Oxelip in the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe of the greene leaues, but in the flower, which ≈øtanding many together on a rea≈øonable high ≈øtalke, and being very ≈ømall and yellow, ≈øcarce opening them≈øelues or layde abroade as it, hath a greene huske vnder each flower, but diuided into ≈øixe ≈øeuerall ≈ømall long peeces.

div.head: 16. Paraly≈øis flore fatuo. The Franticke, or Fooli≈øh Cow≈ølip: Or Iacke an apes on hor≈øe backe.
div.p:
Wee haue in our gardens another kinde, not much differing in leaues from the former Cow≈ølip, and is called Fanta≈øticke or Fooli≈øh, becau≈øe it beareth at the toppe of the ≈øtalke a bu≈øh or tuft of ≈ømall long greene leaues, with ≈øome yellow leaues, as it were peeces of flowers broken, and ≈øtanding among the greene leaues. And ≈øometimes
≈øome ≈øtalkes among tho≈øe greene leaues at the toppe (which are a little larger then when it hath but broken peeces of flowers) doe carry whole flowers in huskes like the ≈øingle kinde.

div.head: 17. Paraly≈øis minor flore rubro. Red Birds eyes.
div.p: This little Cow≈ølippe (which will hardly endure in our gardens, for all the care and indu≈øtrie we can v≈øe to keepe it) hath all the Winter long, and vntill the Spring begin to come on, his leaues ≈øo clo≈øed together, that it ≈øeemeth a ≈ømall white head of leaues, which afterwards opening it ≈øelfe, ≈øpreadeth round vpon the ground, and hath ≈ømall long and narrow leaues, ≈ønipt about the edges, of a pale greene colour on the vpper≈øide, & very white or mealy vnderneath, among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp one or two ≈øtalks, ≈ømall & hoary, halfe a foot high, bearing at the top a bu≈øh or tuft of much ≈ømaller flowers, ≈øtanding vpon ≈øhort foot ≈øtalkes, ≈øome what like vnto Cow≈ølips, but more like vnto the Beares eares, of a fine reddi≈øh purple colour, in ≈øome deeper, in others paler, with a yellowi≈øh circle in the bottomes of the flowers, like vnto many of the Beares eares, of a faint or ≈ømall ≈øent: the ≈øeede is ≈ømaller than in any of the former kindes, and ≈øo are the rootes likewi≈øe, being ≈ømall, white and threddy.

div.head: 18. Paralyis minor flore albo. White Birds eyes.
div.p: This kinde differeth very little or nothing from the former, ≈øauing that it ≈øeemeth a little larger both in leafe and flower, and that the flowers hereof are wholly white, without any great appearance of any circle in the bottome of them, vnle≈ø≈øe it be well ob≈øerued, or at lea≈øt being nothing ≈øo con≈øpicuous, as in the former.
Flore geminato.The≈øe two kindes haue ≈øometimes, but very ≈øeldome, from among the middle of the flowers on the ≈øtalke, ≈øent out another ≈ømall ≈øtalke, bearing flowers theron likewi≈øe.

div.head: 19. Paraly≈øis horten≈øis flore pleno. Double Paigles or Cow≈ølips.
div.p: The double Paigle or Cow≈ølip hath ≈ømaller and darker greene leaues then the ≈øingle kinde hath, and longer ≈øtalkes al≈øo whereon the leaues doe ≈øtand: it beareth diuers flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, but not ≈øo many as the ≈øingle kinde, euery one whereof is of a deeper and fairer yellow colour then any of the former, ≈øtanding not much aboue the brimmes of the huskes that hold them, con≈øi≈øting of two or three rowes of leaues ≈øet round together, which maketh it ≈øhew very thicke and double, of a prettie ≈ømall ≈øent, but not heady.

div.head: 20. Paraly≈øis flore viridante pleno. Double greene Cow≈ølips.
div.p: This double greene Cow≈ølip is ≈øo like vnto the ≈øingle greene kinde formerly expre≈ø≈øed, that vntill they be neare flowring, they can hardly be di≈øtingui≈øhed: but when it is in flower, it hath large double flowers, of the ≈øame yellowi≈øh greene colour with the ≈øingle, and more laid open then the former double Paigle.

div.head: 21. Paraly≈øis flore viridante ≈øiue calamistrato. The greene Ro≈øe Cow≈ølip, or double greene feathered Cow≈ølip.
div.p: There is ≈ømall difference in the leaues of this double kinde from the la≈øt, but that they are not of ≈øo darke a greene: the chiefe≈øt difference con≈øi≈øteth in the flowers, which are many, ≈øtanding together at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, but farre differing from all other of the≈øe kindes: for euery flower ≈øtanding vpon his owne ≈øtalke, is compo≈øed of many very ≈ømall and narrow leaues, without any huske to containe them, but ≈øpreading open like a little Ro≈øe, of a pale yellowi≈øh greene colour, and without any ≈øent at all, abiding in flower, e≈øpecially if it ≈øtand in a ≈øhadowie place out of the ≈øunne, aboue two moneths, almo≈øt in as perfect beauty, as in the fir≈øt weeke.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
All the≈øe kindes as they haue been found wilde, growing in diuers places
in England, ≈øo they haue been tran≈øplanted into Gardens, to be there nouri≈øhed for the delight of their louers, where they all abide, and grow fairer then in their naturall places, except the ≈ømall Birds eyes, which will (as I ≈øaid) hardly abide any culture, but groweth plentifully in all the North Countries, in their ≈øqually or wet grounds.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe doe all flower in the Spring of the yeare, ≈øome earlier and ≈øome later, and ≈øome in the mid≈øt of Winter, as they are defended from the colds and fro≈øts, and the mildne≈ø≈øe of the time will permit: yet the Cow≈ølips doe alwayes flower later then the Primro≈øes, and both the ≈øingle and double greene Cow≈ølips late≈øt, as I ≈øaid in their de≈øcriptions, and abide much after all the re≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: All the≈øe plants are called mo≈øt v≈øually in Latine, Primulae veris, Primulae praten≈øes, and Primulae ≈øiluarum, becau≈øe they ≈øhew by their flowring the new Spring to bee comming on, they being as it were the fir≈øt Emba≈ø≈øadours thereof. They haue al≈øo diuers other names, as Herba Paraly≈øis, Arthritica, Herba Sancti Petri, Claues Sancti Petri, Verba≈øculum odoratum, Lunaria arthritica, Phlomis, Ali≈øma ≈øiluarum, and Ali≈ømatis alterum genus, as Fabius Columna calleth them. The Birds eyes are called of Lobel in Latine, Paralytica Alpina, Sanicula angustifolia, making a greater and a le≈ø≈øer. Others call them Sanicula angu≈øtifolia but generally they are called Primula veris minor. I haue (as you ≈øee) placed them with the Cow≈ølips, putting a difference betweene Primro≈øes and Cow≈ølips. And ≈øome haue di≈øtingui≈øhed them, by calling the Cow≈ølips, Primula veris Elatior, that is, the Taller Primro≈øe, and the other Humilis, Lowe or Dwarfe Primro≈øes. In Engli≈øh they haue in like manner diuers names, according to ≈øeuerall Countries, as Primro≈øes, Cow≈ølips, Oxelips, Pal≈øiewort, and Petty Mulleins. The fir≈øt kindes, which are lower then the re≈øt, are generally called by the name of Primro≈øes (as I thinke) throughout England. The other are diuer≈øly named; for in ≈øome Countries they call them Paigles, or Pal≈øieworts, or Petty Mulleins, which are called Cow≈ølips in others. Tho≈øe are v≈øually called Oxelips, who≈øe flowers are naked, or bare without huskes to containe them, being not ≈øo ≈øweete as the Cow≈ølip, yet haue they ≈øome little ≈øent, although the Latine name doth make them to haue none. The Franticke, Fanta≈øticke, or Fooli≈øh Cow≈ølip, in ≈øome places is called by Country people, Iacke an Apes on hor≈øe-backe, which is an v≈øuall name with them, giuen to many other plants, as Dai≈øies, Marigolds, &c. if they be ≈øtrange or fanta≈øticall, differing in the forme from the ordinary kinde of the ≈øingle ones. The ≈ømalle≈øt are v≈øually called through all the North Country, Birds eyen, becau≈øe of the ≈ømall yellow circle in the bottomes of the flowers, re≈øembling the eye of a bird.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Primro≈øes and Cow≈ølips are in a manner wholly v≈øed in Cephalicall di≈øea≈øes, either among other herbes or flowers, or of them≈øelues alone, to ea≈øe paines in the head, and is accounted next vnto Betony, the be≈øt for that purpo≈øe. Experience likewi≈øe hath ≈øhewed, that they are profitable both for the Pal≈øie, and paines of the ioynts, euen as the Beares eares are, which hath cau≈øed the names of Arthritica, Paraly≈øis, and Paralytica, to bee giuen them. The iuice of the flowers is commended to clean≈øe the ≈øpots or marks of the face, whereof ≈øome Gentlewomen haue found good experience.

div.head: Pulmonaria. Lungwort, or Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem.
div.p: ALthough the≈øe plants are generally more v≈øed as Pot-herbes for the Kitchen, then as flowers for delight, yet becau≈øe they are both called Cow≈ølips, and are of like forme, but of much le≈ø≈øe beauty, I haue ioyned them next vnto them, in a di≈øtinct Chapter by them≈øelues, and ≈øo may pa≈ø≈øe at this time.

div.head: 1. Pulmonaria maculo≈øa. Common ≈øpotted Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem.
div.p: The Cow≈ølip of Ieru≈øalem hath many rough, large, and round leaues, but pointed at the ends, ≈øtanding vpon long foot ≈øtalkes, ≈øpotted with many round white ≈øpots on the vpper≈øides of the ≈øad greene or browne leaues, and of a grayer greene vnderneath: among the leaues ≈øpring vp diuers browne ≈øtalkes, a foote high, bearing many flowers at the toppe, very neare re≈øembling the flowers of Cow≈ølips, being of a purple or reddi≈øh colour while they are buds, and of a darke blewi≈øh colour when they are blowne, ≈øtanding in browni≈øh greene huskes, and ≈øometimes it hath beene found with white flowers: when the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp ≈ømall round heads, containing blacke ≈øeed: the roote is compo≈øed of many long and thicke blacke ≈øtrings.

div.head: 2. Pulmonaria altera non maculo≈øa. Vn≈øpotted Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem.
div.p: The leaues of this other kinde are not much vnlike the former, being rough as they are, but ≈ømaller, of a fairer greene colour aboue, and of a whiter greene vnderneath, without any ≈øpots at all vpon the leaues: the flowers al≈øo are like the former, and of the ≈øame colour, but a little more branched vpon the ≈øtalkes then the former: the rootes al≈øo are blacke like vnto them.

div.head: 3. Pulmonaria angu≈øtifolia. Narrow leafed Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem.
div.p: The leaues hereof are ≈øomewhat longer, but not ≈øo broad, and ≈øpotted with whiti≈øh ≈øpots al≈øo as the former: the ≈øtalke hereof is ≈øet with the like long hairy leaues, but ≈ømaller, being a foote high or better, bearing at the toppe many flowers, ≈øtanding in huskes like the fir≈øt, being ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh in the bud, and of a darke purpli≈øh blew colour when they are blowne open: the ≈øeede is like the former, all of them doe well re≈øemble Buglo≈ø≈øe and Comfrey in mo≈øt parts, except the roote, which is not like them, but ≈øtringie, like vnto Cow≈ølips, yet blacke.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem grow naturally in the Woods of Germany, in diuers places, and the fir≈øt kinde in England al≈øo, found out by Iohn Goodier, a great ≈øearcher and louer of plants, dwelling at Maple-durham in Hamp≈øhire.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part very early, that is, in the beginning of Aprill.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
They are generally called in Latine, Pulmonaria, and maculo≈øa, or non maculo≈øa, is added for di≈øtinctions ≈øake. Of ≈øome it is called Symphitum maculo≈øum, that is, ≈øpotted Comfrey. In Engli≈øh it is diuer≈øly called; as ≈øpotted Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem, Sage of Ieru≈øalem, Sage of Bethlehem, Lungwort,
and ≈øpotted Comfrey, and it might bee as fitly called ≈øpotted Buglo≈ø≈øe, whereunto it is as like as vnto Comfrey, as I ≈øaid before.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is much commended of ≈øome, to bee ≈øingular good for vlcered lungs, that are full of rotten matter. As al≈øo for them that ≈øpit bloud, being boyled and drunke. It is of greate≈øt v≈øe for the pot, being generally held to be good, both for the lungs and the heart.

div.head: 1. Buglo≈ø≈øum & Borrago. Buglo≈ø≈øe and Borage.
div.p: ALthough Borage and Buglo≈ø≈øe might as fitly haue been placed, I confe≈ø≈øe, in the Kitchen Garden, in regard they are wholly in a manner ≈øpent for Phy≈øicall properties, or for the Pot, yet becau≈øe anciently they haue been entertained into Gardens of plea≈øure, their flowers hauing been in ≈øome re≈øpect, in that they haue alwaies been enterpo≈øed among the flowers of womens needle-worke, I am more willing to giue them place here, then thru≈øt them into ob≈øcurity, and take ≈øuch of their tribe with them al≈øo as may fit for this place, either for beauty or rarity.

The Garden Buglo≈ø≈øe and Borage are ≈øo well knowne vnto all, that I ≈øhall (I doubt) but ≈øpend time in wa≈øte to de≈øcribe them; yet not v≈øing to pa≈ø≈øe ouer any thing I name and appropriate to this Garden ≈øo ≈øleightly, they are thus to bee knowne: Buglo≈ø≈øe hath many long, narrow, hairy, or rough ≈øad greene leaues, among which ri≈øe vp two or three very high ≈øtalks, branched at the top, whereon ≈øtand many blew flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall round pointed leaues, with a ≈ømall pointell in the middle, which are very ≈ømooth, ≈øhining, and of a reddi≈øh purple while they are buds, and not blowne open, which being fallen, there groweth in the greene huske, wherein the flower ≈øtood, three or foure roundi≈øh blacke ≈øeedes, hauing that thread or pointell ≈øtanding ≈øtill in the middle of them: the roote is blacke without, and whiti≈øh within, long, thicke, and full of ≈ølimie iuice (as the leaues are al≈øo) and peri≈øheth not euery yeare, as the roote of Borage doth.

div.head: 2. Borrago. Borage.
div.p: Borage hath broader, ≈øhorter, greener, and rougher leaues then Buglo≈ø≈øe, the ≈øtalkes hereof are not ≈øo high, but branched into many parts, whereon ≈øtand larger flowers, and more pointed at the end then Buglo≈ø≈øe, and of a paler blew colour for the mo≈øt part (yet ≈øometimes the flowers are reddi≈øh, and ≈øometimes pure white) each of the flowers con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, ≈øtanding in a round hairy whiti≈øh huske, diuided into fiue parts, and haue a ≈ømall vmbone of fiue blacki≈øh threads in the middle, ≈øtanding out pointed at the end, and broad at the bottome: the ≈øeed is like the other: the root is thicker and ≈øhorter then the roote of Buglo≈ø≈øe, ≈øomewhat blacki≈øh without al≈øo, and whiti≈øh within, and peri≈øheth after ≈øeede time, but ri≈øeth of it owne ≈øeede fallen, and ≈øpringeth in the beginning of the yeare.

div.head: 3. Borrago ≈øemper virens. Euerliuing Borage.
div.p: Euerliuing Borage hath many broad greene leaues, and ≈øomewhat rough, more re≈øembling Comfrey then Borage, yet not ≈øo large as either; the ≈øtalkes are not ≈øo high as Borage, and haue many ≈ømall blew flowers on them, very like to the flowers of Buglo≈ø≈øe for the forme, and Borage for the colour: the rootes are blacke, thicker then either of them, ≈øomewhat more ≈øpreading, and not peri≈øhing, hauing greene leaues all the Winter long, and thereupon tooke his name.

div.head: 4. Anchu≈øa. Sea Buglo≈ø≈øe or Alkanet.
div.p: The Sea Buglo≈ø≈øe or Alkanet hath many long, rough, narrow, and dark greene leaues, ≈øpread vpon the ground (yet ≈øome that growe by the Sea ≈øide are rather hoarie and whiti≈øh) among the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke, ≈øpread at the toppe into many branches, whereon ≈øtand the flowers in tufts, like vnto the Garden Buglo≈ø≈øe, or rather Comfrey, but le≈ø≈øer; in ≈øome plants of a reddi≈øh blew colour, and in others more red or purpli≈øh, and in others of a yellowi≈øh colour: after which come the ≈øeedes, very like vnto Buglo≈ø≈øe, but ≈øomewhat longer and paler: the roote of mo≈øt of them being tran≈øplanted, are ≈øomewhat blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, vntill the later end of Summer, and then become more red: for tho≈øe that grow wilde, will be then ≈øo red, that they will giue a very deepe red colour to tho≈øe that handle them, which being dryed keepe that red colour, which is v≈øed to many purpo≈øes; the roote within being white, and hauing no red colour at all.

div.head: 5. Limonium Rauwolfij. Mar≈øh Buglo≈ø≈øe.
div.p: This Limonium (which I referre here to the kindes of Buglo≈ø≈øe, as pre≈øuming it is the fitte≈øt place where to in≈øert it) hath many long, narrow, and ≈øomewhat rough leaues lying vpon the ground, waued or cut in on both ≈øides, like an Indenture, ≈øomewhat like the leaues of Ceterach or Miltwa≈øt, among which ri≈øe vp two or three ≈øtalkes, ≈øomewhat rough al≈øo, and with thin skinnes like wings, indented on both ≈øides thereof al≈øo, like the leaues, hauing three ≈ømall, long, rough, and three ≈øquare leaues at euery ioynt where it brancheth forth; at the toppe whereof ≈øtand many flowers vpon their foote ≈øtalkes, in ≈øuch a manner, as is not ≈øeene in any other plant, that I know: for although that ≈øome of the ≈ømall winged foot ≈øtalkes are ≈øhorter, and ≈øome longer, ≈øtanding as it were flatwi≈øe, or all on one ≈øide, and not round like an vmbell, yet are they euen at the toppe, and not one higher than another; each of which ≈ømall foote ≈øtalkes doe beare foure or fiue greeni≈øh heads or huskes, ioyned together, out of each of which doe ari≈øe other pale or bleake blew ≈øtiffe huskes, as if they were flowers, made as it were of parchment, which hold their colour after they are dry a long time; and out of the≈øe huskes likewi≈øe, doe come (at ≈øeuerall times one after another, and not all at one time or together) white flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall round leaues, with ≈øome white threds in the middle: after the≈øe flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places ≈ømall long ≈øeede, inclo≈øed in many huskes, many of tho≈øe heads being idle, not yeelding any good ≈øeede, but chaffe, e≈øpecially in our Countrey, for the want of ≈øufficient heate of the Sunne, as I take it: the roote is ≈ømall, long, and blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and peri≈øheth at the fir≈øt approach of Winter.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Borage and Buglo≈ø≈øe grow onely in Gardens with vs, and ≈øo doth the Semper virens, his originall being vnknowne vnto vs. Alkanet or Sea Buglo≈ø≈øe groweth neare the Sea, in many places of France, and Spaine, and ≈øome of the kindes al≈øo in England. But the Limonium or Mar≈øhe Buglo≈ø≈øe groweth in Cales, and Malacca in Spaine, and is found al≈øo in Syria, as Rauwolfius relateth: and in other places al≈øo no doubt; for it hath beene ≈øent vs out of Italie, many yeares before eyther Guillaume Boel found it in Cales, or Clu≈øius in Malacca.

div.head: The Time.
div.p:
Borage and Buglo≈ø≈øe doe flower in Iune, and Iuly, and ≈øometimes ≈øooner, and ≈øo doth the euer-liuing or neuer dying Borage, but not as Gerrard ≈øaith, flowring Winter and Summer, whereupon it ≈øhould take his name, but leaueth flowring in Autumne, and abideth greene with his leaues all the Winter,
1 Pulmonaria latifolia maculo≈øa. Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem. 2 Pulmonaria angustifolia. Narrow leafed Cow≈ølips of Ieru≈øalem. 3 Borrago. Borage. 4 Borrago ≈øemper virens. Euerliuing Borage. 5 Anchu≈øa. Sea Buglo≈ø≈øe or Alkanet. 6 Limonium Rauwolfij. Mar≈øh Buglo≈ø≈øe. depiction of flowers
flowring the next Spring following. The other flower not vntill Iuly, and ≈øo continue, e≈øpecially the Mar≈øhe Buglo≈ø≈øe vntill September bee well ≈øpent, and then giueth ≈øeede, if early fro≈øts ouertake it not; for it ≈øeldome commeth to be ripe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Our ordinary Borage by the con≈øent of all the be≈øt moderne Writers, is the true Buglo≈ø≈øum of Dio≈øcorides, and that our Buglo≈ø≈øe was vnknowne to the ancients. The Borago ≈øemper virens, Lobel calleth Buglo≈ø≈øum ≈øemper virens, that is, Euer-liuing, or greene Buglo≈ø≈øe: but it more re≈øembleth Borage then Buglo≈ø≈øe; yet becau≈øe Buglo≈ø≈øe abideth greene, to auoyde that there ≈øhould not be two Buglo≈ø≈øa ≈øemper virentia, I had rather call it Borage then Buglo≈ø≈øe. Anchu≈øa hath diuers names, as Dio≈øcorides ≈øetteth downe. And ≈øome doe call it Fucus herba, from the Greeke word, becau≈øe the roote giuing ≈øo deepe a colour, was v≈øed to dye or paint the skinne. Others call it Buglo≈ø≈øum Hi≈øpanicum, in Engli≈øh Alkanet, and of ≈øome Orchanet, after the French. Limonium was found by Leonhartus Rauwolfius, neere vnto Ioppa, which he ≈øetteth downe in the ≈øecond Chapter of the third booke of his trauayles, and from him fir≈øt knowne to the≈øe parts: I haue, as you ≈øee, referred it to the kindes of Buglo≈ø≈øe, for that the flowers haue ≈øome re≈øemblance vnto them, although I know that Limonium genuinum is referred to the Beetes. Let it therefore here finde a place of re≈øidence, vntill you or I can finde a fitter; and call it as you thinke be≈øt, eyther Limonium as Rauwolfius doth, or Mar≈øhe Buglo≈ø≈øe as I doe, or if you can adde a more proper name, I ≈øhall not be offended.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Borage and Buglo≈ø≈øe are held to bee both temperate herbes, beeing v≈øed both in the pot and in drinkes that are cordiall, e≈øpecially the flowers, which of Gentlewomen are candid for comfitts. The Alkanet is drying, and held to be good for wounds, and if a peece of the roote be put into a little oyle of Peter or Petroleum, it giueth as deepe a colour to the oyle, as the Hypericon doth or can to his oyle, and accounted to be ≈øingular good for a cut or greene wound.
The Limonium hath no v≈øe that wee know, more then for a Garden; yet as Rauwolfius ≈øaith, the Syrians v≈øe the leaues as ≈øallats at the Table.

div.head: Lychnis. Campions.
div.p: THere bee diuers ≈øorts of Campions, as well tame as wilde, and although ≈øome of them that I ≈øhall here entreate of, may peraduenture be found wilde in our owne Countrey, yet in regard of their beautifull flowers, they are to bee re≈øpected, and nour≈øed vp with the re≈øt, to furni≈øh a garden of plea≈øure; as for the wilde kindes, I will leaue them for another di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: 1. Lychnis Coronaria rubra ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle red Ro≈øe Campion.
div.p:
The ≈øingle red Ro≈øe Campion hath diuers thicke, hoary, or woolly long greene leaues, abiding greene all the winter, and in the end of the ≈øpring or beginning of ≈øummer, ≈øhooteth forth two or three hard round woolly ≈øtalkes, with ≈øome ioynts thereon, and at euery ioynt two ≈øuch like hoary greene leaues as tho≈øe below, but ≈ømaller, diuer≈øly branched at the toppe, hauing one flower vpon each ≈øeuerall long foot ≈øtalke,
con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, ≈øomewhat broade and round pointed, of a perfect red crim≈øon colour, ≈øtanding out of a hard long round huske, ridged or cre≈øted in foure or fiue places; after the flowers are fallen there come vp round hard heads, wherein is contained ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeed: the roote is ≈ømall, long and wooddy, with many fibres annexed vnto it, and ≈øhooteth forth anew oftentimes, yet peri≈øheth often al≈øo.

div.head: 2. Lychnis Coronaria alba ≈øimplex. The white Ro≈øe Campion.
div.p: The white Ro≈øe Campion is in all things like the red, but in the colour of the flower, which in this is of a pure white colour.

div.head: 3. Lichnis Coronaria albe≈øcens ≈øiue incarnata maculata & non maculata. The blu≈øh Ro≈øe Campion ≈øpotted and not ≈øpotted.
div.p: Like vnto the former al≈øo are the≈øe other ≈øorts, hauing no other difference to di≈øtingui≈øh them, but the flowers, which are of a pale or bleake whiti≈øh blu≈øh colour, e≈øpecially about the brims, as if a very little red were mixed with a great deale of white, the middle of the flower being more white; the one being ≈øpotted all ouer the flower, with ≈ømall ≈øpots and ≈øtreakes, the other not hauing any ≈øpot at all.

div.head: 4. Lychnis Coronaria rubra multiplex. The double red Ro≈øe Campion.
div.p: The double red Ro≈øe Campion is in all re≈øpects like vnto the ≈øingle red kinde, but that this beareth double flowers, con≈øi≈øting of two or three rowes of leaues at the mo≈øt, which are not ≈øo large as the ≈øingle, and the whole plant is more tender, that is, more apt to peri≈øh, then any of the ≈øingle kindes.

div.head: 5. Lychnis Chalcedonica flore ≈øimplici miniato. Single None≈øuch, or Flower of Bri≈øtow, or Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This Campion of Con≈øtantinople hath many broad and long greene leaues, among which ri≈øe vp ≈øundry ≈øtiffe round hairy ioynted ≈øtalks three foot high, with two leaues euery ioynt: the flowers ≈øtand at the toppes of them, very many together, in a large tuft or vmbell, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall long leaues, broade pointed, and notched-in in the middle, of a bright red orenge colour, which being pa≈øt, there come in their places ≈ømall hard whiti≈øh heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, containing blacke ≈øeede, like vnto the ≈øeede of ≈øweet Williams, and hauing but a ≈ømall ≈øent; the roote is very ≈øtringie, fa≈øtening it ≈øelfe very ≈øtrongly in the ground, whereby it is much encrea≈øed.

Of the ≈øingle kinde there is al≈øo two or three other ≈øorts,Flore albo. differing chiefly in the colour of the flowers. The one is pure white. Another is of a blu≈øh colour wholly,Et carneo. without variation. And a third is very variable; for at the fir≈øt it is of a pale red,Ver≈øicolor. and after a while groweth paler, vntill in the end it become almo≈øt fully white; and all the≈øe diuer≈øities of the flowers are ≈øometimes to bee ≈øeene on one ≈øtalke at one and the ≈øame time.

div.head: 6. Lychnis Chalcedonica flore miniato pleno. Double Flower of Bri≈øtow, or None≈øuch.
div.p: This glorious flower being as rare as it is beautifull, is for rootes beeing ≈øtringie, for leaues and ≈øtalkes being hairy and high, and for the flowers growing in tufts, altogether like the fir≈øt ≈øingle kinde: but herein con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe≈øt difference, that this beareth a larger vmbell or tuft of flowers at the toppe of the ≈øtalke, euery flower con≈øi≈øting of three or foure rowes of leaues, of a deeper orenge colour then it, which addeth the more grace vnto it, but pa≈ø≈øeth away without bearing ≈øeede, as mo≈øt other double flowers doe, yet recompenceth that defect with encrea≈øe from the roote.

div.head: 7. Lychnis plumaria ≈øilue≈øtris ≈øimplex & multiplex. The featherd wilde Campion ≈øingle and double.
div.p:
The leaues of this wilde Campion are ≈øomewhat like the ordinary white wilde
