Campion, but not ≈øo large, or rather re≈øembling the leaues of ≈øweete Williams, but that they grow not ≈øo clo≈øe, nor ≈øo many together: the ≈øtalkes haue ≈ømaller leaues at the ioynts then tho≈øe belowe, and branched at the toppe, with many pale, but bright red flowers, iagged or cut in on the edges, like the feathered Pinke, whereof ≈øome haue taken it to be a kinde, and ≈øome for a kinde of wilde William, but yet is but a wilde Campion, as may be ob≈øerued, both by his huske that beareth the flowers, and by the grayi≈øh roundi≈øh ≈øeede, being not of the Family of Pinkes and Gillowers, but (as I ≈øaid) of the Campions: the roote is full of ≈øtrings or fibres.
Flore pleno.The double kinde is very like vnto the ≈øingle kinde, but that it is lower and ≈ømaller, and the flowers very double.

div.head: 8. Lychnis ≈øiluestris flore pleno rubro. Red Batchelours buttons.
div.p: The double wilde Campion (which of our Countrey Gentlewomen is called Batchelours buttons) is very like both in rootes, leaues, ≈øtalkes, and flowers vnto the ordinary wilde red Campion, but ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer, his flowers are not iagged, but ≈ømooth, and very thicke and double, ≈øo that mo≈øt commonly it breaketh his ≈øhort huske, wherein the flower ≈øtandeth on the one ≈øide, ≈øeldome hauing a whole huske, and are of a reddi≈øh colour.

div.head: 9. Lychnis ≈øilue≈øtris flore albo pleno. White Batchelours buttons.
div.p: As the leaues of the former double Campion was like vnto the ≈øingle kinde that had red flowers, ≈øo this hath his leaues like vnto the ≈øingle white kinde, differing in no other thing from it, but in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flowers, which by rea≈øon of the multiplicity of leaues in them thru≈øting forth together, breaketh his huskes wherein the flowers doe ≈øtand, as the other doth, and hath ≈øcarce one flower in many that is whole.

div.head: 10. Ocymoides arborea ≈øemper virens. Strange Ba≈ø≈øil Campion.
div.p: This Strange Campion (for thereunto it mu≈øt bee referred) ≈øhooteth forth many round, whiti≈øh, wooddy, but brittle ≈øtalkes, whereon ≈øtand diuers long, and ≈øomewhat thicke leaues, ≈øet by couples, narrow at the bottome, and broader toward the point, of a very faire greene and ≈øhining colour, ≈øo that there is more beauty in the greene leaues, which doe ≈øo alwaies abide, then in the flowers, which are of a pale red or blu≈øh colour, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall long broad pointed leaues, notched in the middle, which doe not lye clo≈øe, but loo≈øly as it were hanging ouer the huskes: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come heads that containe blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, hard, white, and threadie.

div.head: 11. Mu≈øcipula Lobelij ≈øiue Ben rubrum Mon≈øpelien≈øium. Lobels Catch Flie.
div.p: I mu≈øt needes in≈øert this ≈ømall plant, to fini≈øh this part of the Campions, whereunto it belongeth, being a pretty toye to furni≈øh and decke out a Garden. It ≈øpringeth vp (if it haue beene once ≈øowne and ≈øuffered to ≈øhed) in the later end of the yeare mo≈øt commonly, or el≈øe in the Spring with fiue or ≈øix ≈ømall leaues, very like vnto the leaues of Pinkes, and of the ≈øame grayi≈øh colour, but a little broader and ≈øhorter, and when it beginneth to ≈øhoote vp for flower, it beareth ≈ømaller leaues on the clammy or vi≈øcous ≈øtalkes (fit to hold any ≈ømall thing that lighteth on it) being broad at the bottome compa≈ø≈øing them, and ≈øtanding two at a ioynt one again≈øt another: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are diuer≈øly branched into ≈øeuerall parts, euery branch hauing diuers ≈ømall red flowers, not notched, but ≈ømooth, ≈øtanding out of ≈ømall, long, round, ≈øtript huskes, which after the flowers are pa≈øt, containe ≈ømall grayi≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, and peri≈øheth after it hath giuen ≈øeede; but ri≈øeth (as is before ≈øaid) of its owne ≈øeede, if it be ≈øuffered to ≈øhed.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The Ro≈øe Campions, Flowers of Bri≈øtow, or None ≈øuch, the Ba≈ø≈øil Campion,
1 Lychnis Coranoria ≈øimplex. Single Ro≈øe Campion. 2 Lychnis Coronaria rubra multiplex. The double red Ro≈øe Campion. 3 Lychnis Chalcedonica ≈øimplex. Single None ≈øuch, or flower of Bri≈øtow. 4 Lychnis Chalcedonica flore pleno Double None ≈øuch, or flower of Bri≈øtow. 5 Lychnis plumaria multiplex. Plea≈øant in ≈øight. 6 Lychnis ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno rubro. Red Batchelours Buttons. 7 Lychnis ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno albo. White Batchelours Buttons. 8 Mu≈øcipula Lobelij. Lobels Catch Flie. depiction of flowers
and the Catch Flie, haue been ≈øent vs from beyond the Seas, and are onely nour≈øed vp in Gardens with vs; the other Campions that are double, haue been naturally ≈øo found double wilde (for no art or indu≈øtry of man, that euer I could be a≈ø≈øured of to be true, be it by neuer ≈øo many repetitions of tran≈øplantations, and planeticall ob≈øeruations (as I haue ≈øaid in he beginning of this worke) could bring any flower, ≈øingle by nature, to become double, notwith≈øtanding many affirmations to that purpo≈øe, but what≈øoeuer hath been found wilde to be double, nature her ≈øelfe, and not art hath ≈øo produced it) and being brought into Gardens, are there encrea≈øed by ≈ølipping, and parting the roote, becau≈øe they giue no ≈øeede.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All of them doe flower in the Summer, yet none before May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt kindes are called Lychnides ≈øatiuae, and coronariae, in Engli≈øh generally Ro≈øe Campions. The next is called Lychnis Chalcedonica, and Byzantina; in Engli≈øh, of ≈øome None≈øuch, and of others Flower of Bri≈øtow, and after the Latine, Flower of Con≈øtantinople, becau≈øe it is thought the ≈øeede was fir≈øt brought from thence; but from whence the double of this kinde came, we cannot tell. The names of the others of this kinde, both ≈øingle and double, are ≈øet downe with their de≈øcriptions. The feathered Campions are called Armoraria praten≈øis, and Flos Cuculi, and of Clu≈øius and others thought to be Odontitis Plinij. Some call them in Engli≈øh Crowflowers, and Cuckowe-Flowers; and ≈øome call the double hereof, The faire Maide of France. The Ba≈ø≈øil Campions were ≈øent ouer among many other ≈øeedes out of Italy, by the name of Ocimoides arborea ≈øemper virens. Arborea, becau≈øe the ≈øtalke is more wooddy and durable then other Campions: And ≈øemper virens, becau≈øe the leaues abide greene Winter and Summer. Clu≈øius calleth it Lychnis ≈øemper virens, becau≈øe it is certainly a Campion. The la≈øt is diuer≈øly called of Authors; Lobel calleth it Mu≈øcipula: Others Armoraria altera: Dodonaeus Armerius flos quartus. Clu≈øius Lychnis ≈øilue≈øtris altera, in his Spani≈øh ob≈øeruations, and prima in his Hi≈øtory of plants, and ≈øaith, the learned of Salmantica in Spaine called it, Ben rubrum, as Lobel ≈øaith, they of Mompelier doe al≈øo: and by that name I receiued it fir≈øt out of Italy. It hath the name of Catch Flie, of Mu≈øcipula the Latine word, becau≈øe the ≈øtalkes in the hot Summer dayes haue a certaine vi≈øcous or clammy humour vpon them, whereby it ea≈øily holdeth (as I ≈øaid before) what≈øoeuer ≈ømall thing, as Flies, &c. lighteth vpon it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We know none in the≈øe dayes, that putteth any of the≈øe to any Phy≈øicall v≈øe, although ≈øome haue in former times.

div.head: Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum. Wall-flowers, or Wall Gilloflowers.
div.p: THere are two ≈øorts of Wall-flowers, the one ≈øingle, the other double, and of each of them there is likewi≈øe ≈øome differences, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in their de≈øcriptions.

div.head: 1. Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum ≈øimplex vulgare. Common ≈øingle Wall-flowers.
div.p: The common ≈øingle Wall-flower which groweth wilde abroad, and yet is brought into Gardens, hath ≈øundry ≈ømall, narrow, long, and darke greene leaues, ≈øet without order vpon ≈ømall round whiti≈øh wooddy ≈øtalkes, which beare at the tops diuers ≈øingle yellow flowers one aboue another, euery one hauing foure leaues a peece, and of a very ≈øweete ≈øent: after which come long pods, containing reddi≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is white, hard and thready.

div.head: 2. Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum ≈øimplex maius. The great ≈øingle Wall-flower.
div.p: There is another ≈øort of ≈øingle Wall-flower, who≈øe leaues as well as flowers are much larger then the former: the leaues being of a darker and ≈øhining greene colour, and the flowers of a very deepe gold yellow colour, and v≈øually broader then a twentie ≈øhilling peece of gold can couer: the ≈øpike or toppe of flowers al≈øo much longer, and abiding longer in flower, and much ≈øweeter likewi≈øe in ≈øent: the pods for ≈øeede are thicker and ≈øhorter, with a ≈ømall point at the end: this is ≈ølower to encrea≈øe into branches, as al≈øo to be encrea≈øed by the branches, and more tender to be pre≈øerued; for the hard fro≈øts doe cau≈øe it to peri≈øh, if it be not defended from them

div.head: 3. Keiri ≈øimplex flore albo. White Wall-flower.
div.p: This Wall-flower hath his leaues as greene as the great kinde, but nothing ≈øo large: the flowers ≈øtand at the toppe, but not in ≈øo long a ≈øpike, and con≈øi≈øteth of foure leaues, of a very white colour, not much larger then the common kinde, and of a faint or weaker ≈øent: the pods are nothing ≈øo great as the former great one: this is more ea≈øie to be propagated and encrea≈øed al≈øo, but yet will require ≈øome care in defending it from the colds of the Winter.

div.head: 4. Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum vulgare flore pleno. Common double Wall-flowers.
div.p: This ordinary double Wall-flower is in leaues and ≈øtalke very like vnto the fir≈øt ≈øingle kinde, but that the leaues hereof are not of ≈øo deepe a greene colour: the flowers ≈øtand at the top of the ≈øtalkes one aboue another, as it were a long ≈øpike, which flower by degrees, the lowe≈øt fir≈øt, and ≈øo vpwards, by which it is a long time in flowring, and is very double, of a gold yellow colour, and very ≈øweete.

div.head: 5. Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum alterum flore pleno. Pale double Wall-flowers.
div.p: Wee haue another ≈øort of this kinde of double Wall-flower, who≈øe double flowers ≈øtand not ≈øpike-fa≈øhion as the former, but more open ≈øpread, and doe all of them blowe open at one time almo≈øt, and not by degrees as the other doth, and is of a paler yellow colour, not differing in any thing el≈øe, except that the greene leaues hereof are of a little paler greene then it.

div.head: 6. Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum maius flore pleno ferrugineo. Double red Wall-flowers.
div.p: We haue al≈øo another ≈øort of double Wall-flower, who≈øe leaues are as greene, and almo≈øt as large as the great ≈øingle yellow kinde, or full as bigge as the leaues of the white Wall-flower: the flowers hereof are not much larger then the ordinary, but are of a darker yellow colour then the great ≈øingle kinde, and of a more browni≈øh or red colour on the vnder≈øide of the leaues, and is as it were ≈øtriped.

div.head: 7. Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium maximum luteum flore pleno. The greate≈øt double yellow Wall-flower.
div.p:
This great double Wall-flower is as yet a ≈øtranger in England, and therefore what I
here write is more vpon relation (which yet I beleeue to be mo≈øt true) then vpon ≈øight and ≈øpeculation. The leaues of this Wall-flower are as greene and as large, if not larger then the great ≈øingle kinde: the flowers al≈øo are of the ≈øame deepe gold yellow colour with it, but much larger then any of the former double kindes, and of as ≈øweet a ≈øent as any, which addeth delight vnto beauty.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt ≈øingle kind is often found growing vpon old wals of Churches, and other hou≈øes in many places of England, and al≈øo among rubbi≈øh and ≈øtones. The ≈øingle white and great yellow, as well as all the other double kindes, are nour≈øed vp in Gardens onely with vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: All the ≈øingle kindes doe flower many times in the end of Autumne, and if the Winter be milde all the Winter long, but e≈øpecially in the moneths of February, March, and Aprill, and vntill the heate of the Spring doe ≈øpend them: but the other double kindes doe not continue flowring in that manner the yeare throughout, although very early ≈øometimes, and very late al≈øo in ≈øome places.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called by diuers names, as Viola lutea, Leucoium luteum, and Keiri, or Cheiri, by which name it is chiefly knowne in our Apothecaries ≈øhops, becau≈øe there is an oyle made thereof called Cheirinum: In Engli≈øh they are v≈øually called in the≈øe parts, Wall-flowers: Others doe call them Bee-flowers; others Wall-Gilloflowers, Winter-Gilloflowers, and yellow Srocke-Gilloflowers; but we haue a kinde of Stocke-Gilloflower that more fitly de≈øerueth that name, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in the Chapter following

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the flowers cau≈øeth them to be generally v≈øed in No≈øegayes, and to decke vp hou≈øes; but phy≈øically they are v≈øed in diuers manners: As a Con≈øerue made of the flowers, is v≈øed for a remedy both for the Appoplexie and Pal≈øie. The di≈øtilled water helpeth well in the like manner. The oyle made of the flowers is heating and re≈øoluing, good to ea≈øe paines of ≈øtrained and pained ≈øinewes.

div.head: Leucoium. Stocke-Gilloflower.
div.p: THere are very many ≈øorts of Stocke-Gilloflowers both ≈øingle and double, ≈øome of the fields and mountaines, others of the Sea mar≈øhes and medowes; and ≈øome nour≈øed vp in Gardens, and there pre≈øerued by ≈øeede or ≈ølippe, as each kinde is apte≈øt to bee ordered. But becau≈øe ≈øome of the≈øe are fitter for a generall Hi≈øtory then for this our Garden of Plea≈øure, both for that diuers haue no good ≈øent, others little or no beauty, and to be entreated of onely for the variety, I ≈øhall ≈øpare ≈øo many of them as are not fit for this worke, and onely ≈øet downe the re≈øt.

div.head: 1. Leucoium ≈øimplex ≈øativum diuer≈øorum colorum. Garden Stocke-Gilloflowers ≈øingle of diuers colours.
div.p:
The≈øe ≈øingle Stocke-Gilloflowers, although they differ in the colour of their flowers,
1 Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum vulgare. Common Wall-flowers. 2 Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum maius ≈øimplex. The great ≈øingle Wall-flower. 3 Keiri ≈øiue Leucoium luteum flore pleno vulgare. Ordinary double Wall-flowers. 4 Keiri maius flore pleno ferrugin ‚Ä¢ o The great double red Wall-flower. 5 Leucoium ≈øativum ≈øimplex. Single Stocke-Gilloflowers. 6 Leucoium ≈øativum ≈øimplex flore ≈øtriato. Single ≈øtript Stocke-Gilloflowers. depiction of flowers
yet are in leafe and manner of growing, one ≈øo like vnto another, that vntill they come to flower, the one cannot be well knowne that beareth red flowers, from another that beareth purple; and therfore one de≈øcription of the plant ≈øhall ≈øerue, with a declaration of the ≈øundry colours of the flowers. It ri≈øeth vp with round whiti≈øh woody ≈øtalkes, two, three, or foure foot high, whereon are ≈øet many long, and not very broad, ≈øo≈øt, and whiti≈øh or grayi≈øh greene leaues, ≈øomewhat round pointed, and parted into diuers branches, at the toppes whereof grow many flowers, one aboue another, ≈ømelling very ≈øweet, con≈øi≈øting of foure ≈ømall, long, and round pointed leaues, ≈øtanding in ≈ømall long huskes, which turne into long and flat pods, ≈øometimes halfe a foote long, wherein is contained flat, round, reddi≈øh ≈øeedes, with grayi≈øh ringes or circles about them, lying flat all along the middle rib of the pod on both ≈øides: the roote is long, white, and woody, ≈øpreading diuers wayes. There is great variety in the colours of the flowers: for ≈øome are wholly of a pure white colour, others of a mo≈øt excellent crim≈øon red colour, others againe of a faire red colour, but not ≈øo bright or liuely as the other, ≈øome al≈øo of a purpli≈øh or violet colour, without any ≈øpot, marke, or line in them at all. There are againe of all the≈øe colours, mixed very variably, as white mixed with ≈ømall or great ≈øpottes, ≈øtrakes or lines of pure or bright red, or darke red, and white with purple ≈øpots and lines; and of eyther of them who≈øe flowers are almo≈øt halfe white, and halfe red, or halfe white, and halfe purple. The red of both ≈øorts, and the purple al≈øo, in the like manner ≈øpotted, ≈øtriped, and marked with white, differing neyther in forme, nor ≈øub≈øtance, in any other point.

div.head: 2. Leucoium ≈øatiuum albido luteum ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle pale yellow Stocke-Gilloflower.
div.p: There is very little difference in this kind from the former, for the manner of growing, or forme of leaues or flower. Only this hath greener leaues, and pale yellow almo≈øt white flowers, in all other things alike: this is of no great regard, but only for rarity, and diuer≈øity from the re≈øt.

div.head: 3. Leucoium Melancholicum. The Melancholick Gentleman.
div.p: This wilde kinde of ≈øtocke gilloflower hath larger, longer and greener leaues then any of the former kindes, vneuenly ga≈øhed or ≈øinuated on both edges lying on the ground, and a little rough or hairy withall: from among which ri≈øe vp the ≈øtalks, a yard high or more, and hairy likewi≈øe, bearing theron here and there ≈øome ≈øuch like leaues as are below, but ≈ømaller, and at the top a great number of flowers, as large or larger then any of the former ≈øingle kindes, made of 4. large leaues a peece al≈øo, ≈øtanding in ≈øuch like long huskes, but of a darke or ≈øullen yellowi≈øh colour: after which come long roundi≈øh pods, wherein lye ≈øomewhat long but rounder and greater ≈øeede then any ≈øtocke gilloflower, and nearer both in pod and ≈øeede vnto the He≈øperis or Dames Violet: this peri≈øheth not v≈øually after ≈øeede bearing, although ≈øometimes it doth.

div.head: 4. Leucoium marinum Syriacum. Leuant ≈øtocke gilloflowers.
div.p: This kind of ≈øtocke gilloflower ri≈øeth vp at the fir≈øt with diuers long and ≈øomewhat broad leaues, a little vneuenly dented or waued on the edges, which ≈øo continue the fir≈øt yeare after the ≈øowing: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp the next yeare to bee two foot high or more, bearing all tho≈øe leaues on it that it fir≈øt had, which then do grow le≈ø≈øe ≈øinuated or waued then before: at the top whereof ≈øtand many flowers, made of foure leaues a peece, of a delayed purple colour, but of a ≈ømall ≈øent which turne into very long and narrow flat pods, wherein are contained flat ≈øeed like the ordinary ≈øtocke gilloflowers, but much larger and of a darke or blacki≈øh browne colour: the root is white, and groweth deepe, ≈øpreading in the ground, but growing woody when it is in ≈øeede, and peri≈øheth afterwards.

div.head: 5. Leucoij alterum genus, flore tam multiplici quam ≈øimplici ex ≈øeminio oriundum. Another ≈øort of Stocke gilloflowers bearing as well double as ≈øingle flowers from ≈øeede.
div.p: This kinde of Stocke gilloflower differeth neyther in forme of leaues, ≈øtalkes, nor flowers from the former, but that it oftentimes groweth much larger and taller; ≈øo that who≈øoeuer ≈øhall ≈øee both the≈øe growing together, ≈øhall ≈øcarce di≈øcerne the difference, onely it beareth flowers, eyther white, red or purple, wholly or entire, that is, of one colour, without mixture of other colour in them (for ≈øo much as euer I haue ob≈øerued, or could vnder≈øtand by others) which are eyther ≈øingle, like vnto the former, or very thicke and double, like vnto the next that followeth; but larger, and growing with more ≈øtore of flowers on the long ≈øtalke. But this you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand withall, that tho≈øe plants that beare double flowers, doe beare no ≈øeede at all, and is very ≈øeldome encrea≈øed by ≈ølipping or cutting, as the next kinde of double is: but the onely way to haue double flowers any yeare, (for this kinde dyeth euery winter, for the mo≈øt part, after it hath borne flowers, and ≈øeldome is pre≈øerued) is to ≈øaue the ≈øeedes of tho≈øe plants of this kinde that beare ≈øingle flowers, for from that ≈øeede will ri≈øe, ≈øome that will beare ≈øingle, and ≈øome double flowers, which cannot bee di≈øtingui≈øhed one from another, I meane which will be ≈øingle and which double, vntill you ≈øee them in flower, or budde at the lea≈øt. And this is the only way to pre≈øerue this kinde: but of the ≈øeed of the former kinde was neuer known any double flowers to ari≈øe, and therefore you mu≈øt be carefull to marke this kinde from the former.

div.head: 6. Leucoium flore pleno diuer≈øorum colorum. Double Stocke Gillowflowers of diuers colours.
div.p: This other kinde of Stock gilloflower that beareth onely double flowers, groweth not ≈øo great, nor ≈øpreadeth his branches ≈øo farre, nor are his leaues ≈øo large, but is in all things ≈ømaller, and lower, and yet is woody, or ≈øhrubby, like the former, bearing his flowers in the like manner, many vpon a long ≈øtalke, one aboue another, and very double, but not ≈øo large as the former double, although it grow in fertile ≈øoyle, which are eyther white, or red, or purple wholly, without any mixture, or el≈øe mixed with ≈øpots and ≈øtripes, as the ≈øingle flowers of the fir≈øt kinde, but more variably, and not in all places alike, neuer bearing ≈øeede, but mu≈øt be encrea≈øed, only by the cutting of the young ≈øproutes or branches, taken in a fit ≈øea≈øon: this kinde peri≈øheth not, as the former double kinde doth, ≈øo as it bee defended in the winter from the extreame fro≈øts, but e≈øpecially from the ≈ønow falling, or at the lea≈øt remaining vpon it.

div.head: 7. Leucoium ≈øatiuum luteum flore pleno. The double yellow Stocke Gilloflower.
div.p: This double yellow Stock gilloflower is a ≈øtranger in England, as far as I can learne, neyther haue I any further familiaritie with him, then by relation from Germany, where it is affirmed to grow only in ≈øome of their gardens, that are curious louers of the≈øe delights, bearing long leaues ≈øomewhat hoary or white, (and not greene like vnto the Wallflower, whereunto el≈øe it might be thought to be referred) like vnto the Stock gilloflowers, as the ≈øtalkes and branches al≈øo are, and bearing faire double flowers, of a faire, but pale yellow colour. The whole plant is tender, as the double Stock gilloflowers are, and mu≈øt be carefully pre≈øerued in the winter from the coldes, or rather more then the la≈øt double, le≈øt it peri≈øh.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The ≈øingle kindes, e≈øpecially ≈øome of them, grow in Italie, and ≈øome in Greece, Candy, and the I≈øles adiacent, as may be gathered out of the ver≈øes in Plutarches Booke De Amore fraterno:
Inter Echinopodas velut, a≈øperam & inter Ononim, Interdum cre≈øcunt mollia Leucoia.
Which ≈øheweth, that the ≈øoft or gentle ≈øtocke gilloflowers doe ≈øometimes grow among rough or prickely Fur≈øe and Cammocke. The other ≈øorts are only to be found in gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in a manner all the yeare throughout in ≈øome places, e≈øpecially ≈øome of the ≈øingle kindes, if they ≈øtand warme, and defended from the windes and cold: the double kindes flower ≈øometimes in Aprill, and more plentifully in May, and Iune; but the double of ≈øeed, flowreth v≈øually late, and keepeth flowring vnto the winter, that the fro≈øtes and colde mi≈øtes doe pull it downe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called Leucoium, & Viola alba: but the name Leucoium (which is in Engli≈øh the white Violet) is referred to diuers plants; we call it in Engli≈øh generally, Stocke gilloflower, (or as others doe, Stocke gillouer) to put a difference betweene them, and the Gilloflowers and Carnations, which are quite of another kindred, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewne in place conuenient.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The≈øe haue no great v≈øe in Phy≈øick that I know: only ≈øome haue v≈øed the leaues of the ≈øingle white flowred kinde with ≈øalt, to be laid to the wre≈øts of them that haue agues, but with what good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe I cannot ≈øay, if it happen well I thinke in one (as many ≈øuch things el≈øe will) it will fayle in a number.

div.head: 1. He≈øperis, ≈øiue Viola Matronalis. Dames Violets, or Queenes Gilloflowers.
div.p: THe ordinary Dames Violets, or Queene Gilloflowers, hath his leaues broader, greener, and ≈øharper pointed, then the Stock gilloflowers, and a little endented about the edges: the ≈øtalkes grow two foot high, bearing many greene leaues vpon them, ≈ømaller then tho≈øe at the bottome, and branched at the toppe, bearing many flowers, in fa≈øhion much like the flowers of ≈øtocke gilloflowers, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues in like manner, but not ≈øo large, of a faint purpli≈øh colour in ≈øome, and in others white, and of a pretty ≈øweet ≈øent, e≈øpecially towards night, but in the day time little or none at all: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there doe come ≈ømall long and round pods, wherein is contained, in two rowes, ≈ømall and long blacke ≈øeede: the roote is wholly compo≈øed of ≈øtringes or fibres, which abide many yeares, and ≈øpringeth fre≈øh ≈øtalks euery yeare, the leaues abiding all the Winter.

div.head: 2. He≈øperis Pannonica. Dames Violets of Hungary.
div.p: The leaues of this Violet are very like the former, but ≈ømoother and thicker, and not at all indented, or cut in on the edges: the flowers are like the former, but of a ≈øullen pale colour, turning them≈øelues, and ≈øeldome lying plaine open, hauing many purple veines, and ≈øtreakes running through the leaues of the flowers, of little or no ≈øent in the day time, but of a very ≈øweete ≈øent in the euening and morning; the ≈øeedes are alike al≈øo, but a little browner.

figure.head: 1 Leucoium Melancholicum. Sullen Stocke-Gilloflowers. 2 Leucoium ≈øativum flore pleno. Double Stocke-Gilloflowers. 3 Leucoium ≈øativum flore pleno vario. Party coloured Stocke-Gilloflowers. 4 Leucoium marinum Syriacum. Leuant Stocke-Gilloflowers. 5 He≈øperis vulgaris. Dames Violets or Winter Gilloflowers. 6 Ly≈øimachia lutea ≈øiliquo≈øa Virginiana. The tree Primro≈øe of Virginia. 7 Viola Lunaris ≈øiue Bolbonach. The white Sattin flower.

div.head: 3. Ly≈øimachia lutea ≈øiliquo≈øa Virgiana. The tree Primro≈øe of Virginia.
div.p: Vnto what tribe or kindred I might referre this plant, I haue ≈øtood long in ≈øu≈øpence, in regard I make no mention of any other Ly≈øimachia in this work: le≈øt therfore it ≈øhould lo≈øe all place, let me ranke it here next vnto the Dames Violets, although I confe≈ø≈øe it hath little affinity with them. The fir≈øt yeare of the ≈øowing the ≈øeede it abideth without any ≈øtalke or flowers lying vpon the ground, with diuers long and narrow pale greene leaues, ≈øpread oftentimes round almo≈øt like a Ro≈øe, the large≈øt leaues being outermo≈øt, and very ≈ømall in the middle: about May the next yeare the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth, which will be in Summer of the height of a man, and of a ≈øtrong bigge ≈øize almo≈øt to a mans thumbe, round from the bottome to the middle, where it groweth cre≈øted vp to the toppe, into as many parts as there are branches of flowers, euery one hauing a ≈ømall leafe at the foote thereof: the flowers ≈øtand in order one aboue another, round about the tops of the ≈øtalks, euery one vpon a ≈øhort foot-≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of foure pale yellow leaues, ≈ømelling ≈øomewhat like vnto a Primro≈øe, as the colour is al≈øo (which hath cau≈øed the name) and ≈øtanding in a greene huske, which parteth it ≈øelfe at the toppe into foure parts or leaues, and turne them≈øelues downewards, lying clo≈øe to the ≈øtalke: the flower hath ≈øome chiues in the middle, which being pa≈øt, there come in their places long and cornered pods, ≈øharpe pointed at the vpper end, and round belowe, opening at the toppe when it is ripe into fiue parts, wherein is contained ≈ømall browni≈øh ≈øeed: the roote is ≈øomewhat great at the head, and wooddy, and branched forth diuer≈øly, which peri≈øheth after it hath borne ≈øeede.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The two fir≈øt grow for the mo≈øt part on Hils and in Woods, but with vs in Gardens onely.
The la≈øt, as may be well vnder≈øtood by the title, came out of Virginia.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in May, Iune, and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name of He≈øperis is impo≈øed by mo≈øt Herbari≈øts vpon the two fir≈øt plants, although it is not certainly knowne to be the ≈øame that Theophra≈øtus doth make mention of, in his ≈øixth Booke and twenty fiue Chapter de cau≈øis plantarum: but becau≈øe this hath the like effects to ≈ømell be≈øt in the euening, it is (as I ≈øaid) impo≈øed vpon it. It is al≈øo called Viola Marina Matronalis, Hyemalis, Dama≈øcena and Mu≈øchatella: In Engli≈øh, Dames Violets, Queens Gilloflowers, and Winter Gilloflowers.

The la≈øt hath his Latine name in the title as is be≈øt agreeing with it, and for the Engli≈øh, although it be too fooli≈øh I confe≈ø≈øe, yet it may pa≈ø≈øe for this time till a fitter be giuen, vnle≈ø≈øe you plea≈øe to follow the Latine, and call it Virginia Loo≈øe-≈øtrife.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: I neuer knew any among vs to v≈øe the≈øe kindes of Violets in Phy≈øicke, although by rea≈øon of the ≈øharpe biting ta≈øte, Dodonaeus accounteth the ordinary ≈øort to be a kinde of Rocket, and ≈øaith it prouoketh ≈øweating, and vrine: and others affirme it to cut, dige≈øt, and clean≈øe tough flegme. The Virginian hath not beene v≈øed by any that I know, either inwardly or outwardly.

div.head: Viola Lunaris ≈øiue Bolbonach. The Sattin flower.
div.p: VNto the kindes of Stocke-Gilloflowers I thinke fitte≈øt to adioyne the≈øe kindes of Sattin-flowers, whereof there are two ≈øorts, one frequent enough in all our Countrie, the other is not ≈øo common.

div.head: 1. Viola Lunaris vulgaris. The common white Sattin flower.
div.p: The fir≈øt of tho≈øe Sattin flowers, which is the mo≈øt common, hath his leaues broad belowe, and pointed at the end, ≈ønipt about the edges, and of a darke greene colour: the ≈øtalkes are round and hard, two foot high, or higher, diuided into many branches, ≈øet with the like leaues, but ≈ømaller: the tops of the branches are be≈øet with many purpli≈øh flowers, like vnto Dames Violets, or Stocke-Gilloflowers, but larger, being of little ≈øent: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places round flat thin cods, of a darke colour on the out≈øide, but hauing a thinne middle skinne, that is white and cleare ≈øhining, like vnto very pure white Sattin it ≈øelfe, whereon lye flat and round browni≈øh ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat thicke and great: the rootes peri≈øh when they haue giuen their ≈øeede, and are ≈øomewhat round, long, and thicke, re≈øembling the rootes of Lilium non bulbo≈øum, or Day Lilly, which are eaten (as diuers other rootes are) for Sallets, both in our owne Country, and in many places be≈øide.

div.head: 2. Viola Lunaris altera ≈øeu peregrina. Long liuing Sattin flower.
div.p: This ≈øecond kinde hath broader and longer leaues then the former, the ≈øtalkes al≈øo are greener and higher, branching into flowers, of a paler purple colour, almo≈øt white, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues in like manner, and ≈ømelling pretty ≈øweete, bearing ≈øuch like pods, but longer and ≈ølenderer then they: the rootes are compo≈øed of many long ≈øtrings, which dye not as the former, but abide, and ≈øhoot out new ≈øtalkes euery yeare.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is (as is ≈øaid) frequent enough in Gardens, and is found wilde in ≈øome places of our owne Country, as Ma≈øter Gerard reporteth, whereof I neuer could be certainly a≈ø≈øured, but I haue had it often ≈øent mee among other ≈øeedes from Italy, and other places. The other is not ≈øo common in Gardens, but found about Watford, as he ≈øaith al≈øo.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Aprill or May, and ≈øometimes more early.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath diuers names, as well in Engli≈øh as in Latine; for it is called mo≈øt v≈øually Bolbonach, and Viola Lunaris: Of ≈øome Viola latifolia, and of others Viola Peregrina, and Lunaria Graeca, Lunaria maior, and Lunaria odorata, and is thought to be Thla≈øpi Crateuae: In Engli≈øh, White Satten, or Satten flower: Of ≈øome it is called Hone≈øty, and Penny-flower.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Some doe v≈øe to eate the young rootes hereof, before they runne vp to flower, as Rampions are eaten with Vinegar and Oyle; but wee know no Phy≈øicall v≈øe they haue.

div.head: Linum ≈øilue≈øtre & Linaria. Wilde Flaxe and Tode Flaxe.
div.p: ALthough neither the manured Line or Flaxe is a plant fit for our Garden, nor many of the wilde ≈øorts, yet there are ≈øome, who≈øe plea≈øant and delightfull a≈øpect doth entertaine the beholders eyes with good content, and tho≈øe I will ≈øet downe here for varietie, and adioyne vnto them ≈øome of the Linarias, or Tode Flaxe, for the neare affinity with them.

div.head: 1. Linum ≈øilue≈øtre flore albo. Wilde Flaxe with a white flower.
div.p: This kinde of wilde Flaxe ri≈øeth vp with diuers ≈ølender branches, a foote high or better, full of leaues, ≈øtanding without order, being broader and longer then the manured Flaxe: the tops of the branches haue diuers faire white flowers on them, compo≈øed of fiue large leaues a peece, with many purple lines or ≈øtrikes in them: the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell as well as the ≈øeede, is like vnto the heads and ≈øeede of the manured Flaxe: the rootes are white ≈øtrings, and abide diuers yeares, ≈øpringing fre≈øh branches and leaues euery yeare, but not vntill the Spring of the yeare.

div.head: 2. Linum ≈øilue≈øtre luteum. Wilde Flaxe with a yellow flower.
div.p: This wilde Flaxe doth ≈øo well re≈øemble a kinde of St. Iohns wort, that it will ≈øoone deceiue one that doth not adui≈øedly regard it: For it hath many reddi≈øh ≈øtalkes, and ≈ømall leaues on them, broader then the former wilde Flaxe, but not ≈øo long, which are well ≈øtored with yellow flowers, as large as the former, made of fiue leaues a peece, which being pa≈øt, there come ≈ømall flatti≈øh heads, containing blacki≈øh ≈øeede, but not ≈øhining like the former: the rootes hereof dye not euery yeare, as many other of the wilde kindes doe, but abide and ≈øhoote out euery yeare.

div.head: 3. Linaria purpurea. Purple Tode Flaxe.
div.p: This purple Tode Flaxe hath diuers thicke, ≈ømall, long, and ≈øomewhat narrowi≈øh leaues, ≈ønipt about the edges, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, from among which ri≈øe vp diuers ≈øtalkes, repleni≈øhed at the tops with many ≈ømall flowers, ≈øtanding together one aboue another ≈øpike-fa≈øhion, which are ≈ømall and ≈øomewhat ≈øweete, while they are fre≈øh, fa≈øhioned ≈øomewhat like the common Tode flaxe that groweth wilde abroad almo≈øt euery where, but much ≈ømaller, with a gaping mouth, but without any crooked ≈øpurre behinde, like vnto them, ≈øometimes of a ≈øad purple neare vnto a Violet, and ≈øometimes of a paler blew colour, hauing a yellow ≈øpot in the middle or gaping place: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come ≈ømall, hard, round heads, wherein are contained ≈ømall, flat, and grayi≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, and peri≈øheth for the mo≈øt part euery yeare, and will ≈øpring againe of it owne ≈øowing, if it be ≈øuffered to ≈øhed it ≈øelfe, yet ≈øome hard Winters haue killed the ≈øeede it ≈øhould ≈øeeme, in that ≈øometimes it faileth to ≈øpring againe, and therefore had neede to be ≈øowne anew in the Spring.

div.head: 4. Linaria purpurea odorata. Sweete purple Tode Flaxe.
div.p:
The lower leaues of this purple Tode Flaxe are nothing like any of the re≈øt, but are long and broad, endented about the edges, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the leaues of the greater wilde white Dai≈øie: the ≈øtalke is ≈øet at the bottome with ≈øuch like leaues, but a little more diuided and cut in, and ≈øtill ≈ømaller and ≈ømaller vpward, ≈øo that the vppermo≈øt leaues are very like the common Tode Flaxe, the toppe whereof is branched, hauing diuers ≈ømall flowers growing along vpon them, in fa≈øhion and colour almo≈øt like the la≈øt de≈øcribed Tode Flaxe, but not altogether ≈øo deepe a purple: the heads and ≈øeedes are very like the former, but that the ≈øeede of this is reddi≈øh: the flowers
1 Linum ≈øilue≈øtre flore albo. Wilde Flaxe with a white flower. 2 Linaria purpurea ≈øiue caerulea. Purple Tode Flaxe. 3 Linaria pupurea odorata. Sweete purple Tode Flaxe. 4 Scoparia ≈øiue Beluidere Italorum Broome Tode Flaxe. 5 Antirrhinum maius. The greater Snapdragon. 6 Chamaenerium flore delphinij. The willowe flower. depiction of flowers
in their naturall hot Countries haue a fine ≈øent, but in the≈øe colder, little or none at all: the rootes are ≈ømall and threadie, and peri≈øh after they haue flowred and ≈øeeded.

div.head: 5. Linaria Valentina. Tode Flaxe of Valentia.
div.p: This Spani≈øh Tode Flaxe hath three or foure thicker and bigger ≈øtalkes then the former, bearing ≈ømall broad leaues, like vnto the ≈ømall Centory, two or three together at a ioynt, round about the lower end of the ≈øtalkes, but without any order vpwards, at the toppes whereof ≈øtand many flowers, in fa≈øhion like vnto the common kinde, and almo≈øt as large, of a faire yellow colour, but the gaping mouth is downie, and the ≈øpurre behinde of a purpli≈øh colour.

div.head: 6. Scoparia ≈øiue Beluidere Italorum. Broome Tode Flaxe.
div.p: Although this plant haue no beautifull flowers, yet becau≈øe the greene plant full of leaues is ≈øo delightfull to behold, being in Italy and other places planted not onely in their Gardens, but ≈øet likewi≈øe in pots to furni≈øh their Windowes, and euen with vs al≈øo hath growne to be ≈øo dainty a greene bu≈øh, that I haue thought it worthy to be among the delights of my Garden; the de≈øcription whereof is as followeth: This plea≈øant Broome Flaxe ri≈øeth vp mo≈øt v≈øually with one ≈øtraight vpright ≈øquare ≈øtalke, three foote and a halfe high or better in our Gardens, branching it ≈øelfe out diuers waies, bearing thereon many long narrow leaues, like the Garden Line or Flaxe, very thicke ≈øet together, like vnto a bu≈øh, or rather like vnto a faire greene Cypre≈ø≈øe tree, growing broad belowe, and ≈øpire-fa≈øhion vpwards, of a very faire greene colour: at the ≈øeuerall ioynts of the branches, towards the tops, and among the leaues, there come forth ≈ømall reddi≈øh flowers, not ea≈øily ≈øeene nor much regarded, being of no beauty, which turne into ≈ømall round blacki≈øh gray ≈øeede: the rootes are a number of blacki≈øh ≈øtrings ≈øet together, and the whole plant peri≈øheth euery yeare at the fir≈øt approach of any cold ayre, as if it neuer had beene ≈øo faire a greene bu≈øh.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe kindes of wilde Flaxe doe growe naturally in diuers places, ≈øome in Germany, ≈øome in Spaine, and ≈øome in Italy. Tho≈øe that delight in the beauty of natures variety, doe pre≈øerue them, to furni≈øh vp the number of plea≈øant a≈øpects.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in the Summer moneths, and ≈øoone after perfect their ≈øeede.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their names are ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, yet I mu≈øt giue you to vnder≈øtand, that the la≈øt is called of ≈øome Linaria magna, and of others O≈øyris.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The wilde Flaxe hath no medecinable vertue appropriate vnto it that is knowne. The Tode Flaxe is accounted to be good, to cau≈øe one to make water.

div.head: Antirrhinum. Snapdragon.
div.p: THere is ≈øome diuer≈øity in the Snapdragons, ≈øome being of a larger, and others of a le≈ø≈øer ≈øtature and bigne≈ø≈øe; and of the larger, ≈øome of one, and ≈øome of another colour, but becau≈øe the ≈ømall kindes are of no beautie, I ≈øhall at this time onely entreate of the greater ≈øorts.

div.head: 1. Antirrhinum album. White Snapdragon.
div.p: The leaues of the≈øe Snapdragons (for I doe vnder one de≈øcription comprehend the re≈øt) are broader, longer, and greener then the leaues of the Garden Flaxe, or of the wilde Flaxe ≈øet confu≈øedly vpon the tender greene branches, which are ≈øpread on all ≈øides, from the very bottome, bearing at the toppes many flowers, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the former Tode Flaxe, but much larger, and without any heele or ≈øpurre, of a faire white colour, with a yellow ≈øpot in the mouth or gaping place: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp in their places hard round ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, fa≈øhioned ≈øomewhat like vnto a Calues head, the ≈ønout being cut off, wherein is contained ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede: the rootes are many white ≈øtrings, which peri≈øh in mo≈øt places after they haue giuen ≈øeede, notwith≈øtanding any care or paines taken with them to pre≈øerue them aliue, and yet they will abide in ≈øome places where they are defended in the Winter.

div.head: 2. Antirrhinum purpureum ≈øiue ro≈øeum. Purple Snapdragon.
div.p: The purple Snapdragon is in ≈øtalkes, leaues, and flowers altogether like the former, and as large and great in euery part, or greater; the only difference is, that this beareth pale Stammell or Ro≈øe coloured flowers, with a yellow ≈øpot in the mouth, and ≈øometimes of a paler colour, almo≈øt blu≈øh.

div.head: 3. Antirrhinum variegatum. Variable Snapdragon.
div.p: This variable kinde is ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe, and tenderer then the la≈øt de≈øcribed, hauing al≈øo a reddi≈øh or blu≈øh coloured flower, le≈ø≈øer then the former, but much bigger then the middle kinde of Snapdragon (which is not ≈øet downe in this worke) the yellow ≈øpot in the mouth of it hath ≈øome white about it, and extending to both ≈øides of the ≈øpot: the heads and ≈øeede are like the former: the rootes are ≈ømaller, but neuer will abide after they haue giuen flowers and ≈øeede.

div.head: 4. Antirrhinum luteum. Yellow Snapdragon.
div.p: There is likewi≈øe another of the≈øe kindes, that beareth leaues as large as any of the former, & very faire yellow flowers, as large likewi≈øe as they, not differing in any thing el≈øe from the fir≈øt; let not any therefore imagine this to be a Linaria or Tode Flaxe: for all parts are an≈øwerable vnto the Snapdragons.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe are nouri≈øhed with vs in our Gardens, although in Spaine and Italy they are found growing wilde.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part the ≈øecond yeare after the ≈øowing, from Aprill vntill Iuly, and the ≈øeede is quickly ripe after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Antirrhinum is v≈øually giuen to this plant, although it fully agreeth not eyther with the de≈øcription of Dio≈øcorides, or Theophra≈øtus: It hath al≈øo diuers other names in Latine, as Orontium, Canis cerebrum Os Leonis, Leo herba, &c. In Engli≈øh Calues ≈ønout, from the forme of the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, and Snapdragon, or Lyons mouth, from the forme of the flowers.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: They are ≈øeldome or neuer v≈øed in Phy≈øicke by any in our dayes.

div.head: Chamaenerium flore delphinij. The Willowe flower.
div.p: THis plant ri≈øeth vp with many ≈øtrong, woddy, round, browni≈øh great ≈øtalkes, three or foure foote high, be≈øet here and there without order, with one broad and long whiti≈øh greene leafe at a ioynt, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Ly≈øimachia, or Willow herbe, as al≈øo vnto a Peach leafe, but larger and longer: at the toppe of the branches ≈øtand many flowers one aboue another, of a pale reddi≈øh purple colour, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, ≈øpread open with an heele or ≈øpurre behinde them, with many yellow threads in the middle, much larger then any flower of the Larkes ≈øpurres, and ≈ømelling ≈øomewhat ≈øweete withall; it beareth a ≈øhew of long pods with ≈øeede, but I could neuer ob≈øerue the ≈øeede: the rootes are like the rootes of Ly≈øimachia, or the ordinary yellow Loo≈øe-≈øtrife, or Willowe herbe, but greater: running and ≈øpreading vnder ground, and ≈øhooting vp in many places, whereby it filleth a ground that it likes quickly: the ≈øtalkes dye downe euery yeare, and ≈øpring againe in many places farre a≈øunder.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Wee haue not knowne where this Willowe flower groweth naturally, but we haue it ≈øtanding in an out corner of our Gardens, to fill vp the number of delightfull flowers.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth not vntill May, and abideth a long while flowring.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It may ≈øeeme to diuers, that this is that plant that Dodonaeus called P≈øeudoly≈øimachium purpureum minus, and Lobel ≈øeemeth by the name of Delphinium buccinum to aime at this plant, but withall calleth it Chamaenerium G ‚Ä¢ ≈øneri, and giueth the ≈øame figure that Dodonaeus hath for his P≈øeudoly≈øimachium: But that is one kinde of plant (which hath ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter ≈øtalkes, and very narrow long leaues, who≈øe flowers ≈øtand vpon long ≈ølender cods, full of downe, with reddi≈øh ≈øeede, like vnto the Ly≈øimachia ≈øiliquo≈øa ≈øiluestris, and rootes that abide many yeares, but creepe not) and this is another, much greater, who≈øe true figure is not extant in any Author that I know. It is v≈øually called Chamaenerium flore delphinij; but the name of Delphinium buccinum in my minde may not ≈øo conueniently be applyed vnto it. It is called in Engli≈øh, The Willowe flower, for the likene≈ø≈øe of the leaues, and the beauty and re≈øpect of the flowers.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is no v≈øe hereof in Phy≈øicke that euer I could learne, but is onely cheri≈øhed among other ≈øorts of flowers, that ≈øerue to decke and ≈øet forth a Garden of varieties.

div.head: Aquilegia. Colombines.
div.p: THere are many ≈øorts of Colombines, as well differing in forme as colour of the flowers, and of them both ≈øingle and double carefully nour≈øed vp in our Gardens, for the delight both of their forme and colours.

div.head: 1. Aquilegia vulgaris flore ≈øimplici. Single Colombines.
div.p: Becau≈øe the whole difference of the≈øe Colombines ≈øtandeth in the varieties of the forme, and colour of the flowers, and little in the leaues, I ≈øhall not neede to make anie repetitions of the de≈øcription of them, ≈øeeing one onely ≈øhall ≈øuffice for each peculiar kinde. The Colombine hath diuers large ≈øpread leaues, ≈øtanding on long ≈øtalkes: euery one diuided in ≈øeuerall partitions, and roundly endented about the edges, in colour ≈øomewhat like the leaues of Celondine, that is, of a darke blewi≈øh greene colour: the ≈øtalkes ri≈øe vp ≈øometimes two or three foote high, diuided v≈øually into many branches, bearing one long diuided leafe at the lower ioynt, aboue which the flowers growe, euery one ≈øtanding on a long ≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of fiue hollow leaues, crooked or horned at the ends, turning backward, the open flower ≈øhewing almo≈øt like vnto a Cinquefoile, but more hollow: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there ari≈øe ≈ømall long cods, foure or fiue together, wherein are contained blacke ≈øhining ≈øeede: the rootes are thicke and round, for a little ≈øpace within the ground, and then diuided into branches, ending in many ≈ømall fibres, abiding many yeares, and ≈øhooting a fre≈øh euery Spring from the round heads, that abide all the Winter. The variety of the colours of the≈øe flowers are very much, for ≈øome are wholly white, ≈øome of a blew or violet colour, others of a blu≈øh or fle≈øh colour, or deepe or pale red, or of a dead purple, or dead murrey colour, as nature li≈øteth to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe.

div.head: 2. Aquilegia vulgaris flore pleno. Double Colombines.
div.p: The double Colombines differ not in leafe or manner of growing from the ≈øingle, ≈øo that vntill they come to flower, they cannot bee di≈øcerned one from another; the onely difference is, it beareth very thicke and double flowers, that is, many horned or crooked hollow leaues ≈øet together, and are not ≈øo large as the leaues of the ≈øingle flowers. The variety of colours in this double kinde is as plentifull, or rather more then in the ≈øingle; for of the≈øe there is party coloured, blew and white, and ≈øpotted very variably, which are not in the ≈øingle kinde, and al≈øo a very deepe red, very thicke and double, but a ≈ømaller flower, and le≈ø≈øe plentifull in bearing then many of the other double ≈øorts. The≈øe double kindes doe giue as good ≈øeede as the ≈øingle kindes doe, which is not ob≈øerued in many other plants.

div.head: 3. Aquilegia inuer≈øis corniculis. Double inuerted Colombines.
div.p:
The≈øe Colombines are not to be di≈øtingui≈øhed eyther in roote, leaues, or ≈øeed from the former, the flowers onely make the difference, which are as double as the former, but that the heeles or hornes of the≈øe are turned inward, and ≈øtand out in the middle of the flowers together: there is not that plentifull variety of colours in this kinde, as there is in the former: for I neuer ≈øaw aboue three or foure ≈øeuerall colours in this
kinde, that is, white, purpli≈øh, reddi≈øh, and a dun or darke ouerworne purpli≈øh colour. The≈øe double flowers doe likewi≈øe turne into pods, bearing ≈øeede, continuing his kind, and not varying into the former.

div.head: 4. Aquilegia Ro≈øea. Ro≈øe Colombines.
div.p: The leaues and other parts of this kinde of Colombine, differ little or nothing from the former, the diuer≈øitie con≈øi≈øteth likewi≈øe in the flowers, which although they ≈øtand in the ≈øame manner ≈øeuerally vpon their ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, ≈øomewhat more ≈øparingly then the former doe, yet they haue no heeles or hornes, eyther inward or outward, or very ≈øeldome, but ≈øtand ≈øometimes but with eight or tenne ≈ømooth ≈ømall plaine leaues, ≈øet in order one by one in a compa≈ø≈øe, in a double rowe, and ≈øometimes with foure or fiue rowes of them, euery one directly before the other, like vnto a ≈ømall thick double Ro≈øe layd open, or a ≈øpread Marigold: yet ≈øometimes it happeneth, that ≈øome of the≈øe flowers will haue two or three of the fir≈øt rowes of leaues without any heele, and the re≈øt that are inward with each of them a peece of a ≈ømall horne at them, as the former haue: the colours of the≈øe flowers are almo≈øt as variable, and as variably mixed as the former double kindes. This likewi≈øe giueth ≈øeede, pre≈øeruing his owne kinde for the mo≈øt part.

div.head: 5. Aquilegia degener. Degenerate Colombines.
div.p: This kinde of Colombine might ≈øeeme to ≈øome, to bee but a ca≈øuall degeneration, and no true naturall kinde, happening by ≈øome cau≈øe of tran≈øplanting, or otherwi≈øe by the art of man: but I haue not ≈øo found it, in that it keepeth, and holdeth his own proper forme, which is like vnto the double Ro≈øe Colombine, but that the outermo≈øt row of leaues are larger then any of the re≈øt inwardes, and is of a greeni≈øh, or el≈øe of a purpli≈øh greene colour, and is not altogether ≈øo apt to giue good ≈øeed like the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The ≈øingle kindes haue beene often found in ≈øome of the wooddy mountaines of Germany, as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, but the double kindes are chiefly cheri≈øhed in gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower not vntill May, and abide not for the mo≈øt part when Iune is pa≈øt, and in the meane time perfecteth their ≈øeede.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Co≈øtaeus doth call this plant Pothos of Theophra≈øtus, which Gaza tran≈ølateth De≈øiderium. Dalechampius vpon Athenaeus, calleth it Dio≈øanthos, or Iouis flos of Theophra≈øtus, who in his ≈øixth Booke and ≈øeuenth Chapter reckoneth them both, that is, Dio≈øanthos and Pathos, to be Summer flowers, but ≈øeuerally. Dodonaeus Leoherba, and Ge≈øner Leonto≈øtomium. Fabius Columna in his Phytoba≈øanos, vnto whom Clu≈øius giueth the greate≈øt approbation, referreth it to the I≈øopyrum of Dio≈øcorides. All later Writers doe generally call it, eyther Aquileia, Aquilina, or Aquilegia; and we in Engli≈øh, generally (I thinke) through the whole Countrey, Colombines. Some doe call the Aquilegia ro≈øea, Aquilegia ≈øtellata, The ≈øtarre Colombine; becau≈øe the leaues of the flowers doe ≈øtand ≈øo directly one by another, be≈øides the doublene≈ø≈øe, that they ≈øomewhat repre≈øent eyther a Ro≈øe or a Starre, and thereupon they giue it the name eyther of a Starre or Ro≈øe.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
Some in Spaine, as Camerarius ≈øaith, v≈øe to eate a peece of the roote hereof
1 Aquilegia ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle Colombine. 2 Aquilegia flore multiplici. The double Colombine. 3 Aquilegia ver≈øicolor. The party coloured Colombine. 4 Aquilegia inuer≈øis corniculis. The double inuerted Colombine. 5 Aquilegia Ro≈øea ≈øiue Stellata. The Ro≈øe or the Starre Colombine. 6 Thalictrum Hi≈øpanicum album. White Spani≈øh tufts. depiction of flowers
fa≈øting, many dayes together, to helpe them that are troubled with the ≈øtone in the kidneyes. Others v≈øe the decoction, of both herbe and roote in wine, with a little Ambargri≈øe, again≈øt tho≈øe kinds of ≈øwounings, which the Greekes call
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . The ≈øeede is v≈øed for the iaundi≈øe, and other obctructions of the liuer. Clu≈øius writeth from the experience of Franci≈øcus Rapard, a chiefe Phy≈øician of Bruges in Flanders, that the ≈øeede beaten and drunke is effectuall to women in trauell of childe, to procure a ≈øpeedy deliuerie, and adui≈øeth a ≈øecond draught thereof ≈øhould be taken if the fir≈øt ≈øucceede not ≈øufficiently.

div.head: Thalictrum Hi≈øpanicum. Spani≈øh Tufts, or Tufted Colombines.
div.p: FRom among the diuer≈øities of this plant, I haue ≈øelected out two ≈øorts for this my garden, as hauing more beautie then all the re≈øt; leauing the other to be entreated of, where all in generall may be included. I haue in this place in≈øerted them, for the likene≈ø≈øe of the leaues only, being in no other part corre≈øpondent, and in a Chapter by them≈øelues, as it is mo≈øt fit.

div.head: Thalictrum Hi≈øpanicum album. White Spani≈øh tufted Colombines.
div.p: The≈øe plants haue both one forme, in roote, leafe and flower, and therefore neede but one de≈øcription. The leaues are both for colour and forme ≈øo like vnto Colombines leaues (although le≈ø≈øer and darker, yet more ≈øpread, and on larger ≈øtalkes) that they may ea≈øily deceiue one, that doth not marke them adui≈øedly; for the leaues are much more diuided, and in ≈ømaller parts, and not ≈øo round at the ends: the ≈øtalkes are round, ≈øtrong, and three foote high at the lea≈øt, branching out into two or three parts, with leaues at the ≈øeuerall ioynts of them, at the toppes whereof ≈øtand many flowers, which are nothing but a number of threads, made like vnto a ≈ømall round tuft, breaking out of a white skinne, or leafe, which inclo≈øeth them, and being vnblowne, ≈øhew like vnto little buttons: the colour of the≈øe threds or tufts in this are whiti≈øh with yellow tips on them, and ≈øomewhat purpli≈øh at the bottome, hauing a ≈øtrong but no good ≈øent, and abiding in their beautie (e≈øpecially if they grow in the ≈øhade, and not too hot in the ≈øun) a great while, and then fall away, like ≈øhort downe or threds: the ≈øeed ve≈ø≈øels are three ≈øquare, containing ≈ømall, long, and round ≈øeede; the rootes are many long yellow ≈øtringes, which endure and encrea≈øe much.

div.head: Thalictrum Montanum purpureum. Purple tufted Colombines.
div.p: This purple tufted Colombine differeth onely from the former, in that it is not ≈øo high nor ≈øo large, and that the colour of the flower or tuft is of a blewi≈øh purple colour with yellow tips, and is much more rare then the other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe grow both in Spaine and Italie.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in the end of May, or in Iune, and ≈øometime later.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Some doe call them Thalietrum, and ≈øome Thalictrum. Others Ruta pa ‚Ä¢ u≈øtris, and Ruta praten≈øis, and ≈øome Rhabarbarum Monachorum, or P≈øeudo-rhabarbarum,
by rea≈øon that the rootes being yellow, haue an opening qualitie, and drying as Rubarbe. In Engli≈øh what other fit Names to giue the≈øe then I haue expre≈ø≈øed in the titles, I know not.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The are a little hot and drying withall, good for old Vlcers, as Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith, to bring them to cicatri≈øing: in Italy they are v≈øed again≈øt the Plague, and in Saxonye again≈øt the Iaundi≈øe, as Camerarius ≈øaith.

div.head: Radix caua. Hollow roote.
div.p: THe likene≈ø≈øe of the leaues likewi≈øe of this plant with Colombines, hath cau≈øed mee to in≈øert it next the other, and although ≈øome of this kinde bee of ≈ømall re≈øpect, being accounted but fooli≈øh, yet let it fill vp a wa≈øte corner, that ≈øo no place be vnfurni≈øhed.

div.head: 1. Radix Caua maior flore albo. The white Hollow roote.
div.p: The leaues of this hollow roote breake not out of the ground, vntill the end of March, or ≈øeldome before, and are both for proportion and colour ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of Colombines, diuided into fiue parts, indented about the edges, ≈øtanding on ≈ømall long foote≈øtalkes of a whiti≈øh greene colour, among which ri≈øe vp the ≈øtalkes, without any leaues from the bottome to the middle, where the flowers ≈øhoote forth one aboue another, with euery one a ≈ømall ≈øhort leafe at the foote thereof, which are long and hollow, with a ≈øpurre behinde it, ≈øomewhat like vnto the flowers of Larckes ≈øpurres, but hauing their bellies ≈øomwhat bigger, and the mouth not ≈øo open, being all of a pure white colour: after the flowers are pa≈øt, ari≈øe ≈ømall long and round cods, wherein are contained round blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is round and great, of a yellowi≈øh browne colour on the out≈øide, and more yellow within, and hollow vnderneath, ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth but a ≈øhell: yet being broken, euery part will grow: it abideth greene aboue ground but a ≈ømall time.

div.head: 2. Radix Caua maior flore carneo. Blu≈øh colourd Hollow roote.
div.p: The blu≈øh Hollow roote is in all things like vnto the former, but onely that the flowers hereof are of a delayed red or purple colour, which we call blu≈øh: and ≈øometimes of a very deepe red or purple colour; but very rare to meete with.

div.head: 3. Radix Caua minor, ≈øeu Capuos fabacea radice. Small hollow roote.
div.p: This ≈ømall kinde hath his leaues of a blewi≈øh greene colour, yet greener and ≈ømaller then the former, growing more thicke together: the flowers are like in proportion vnto the former in all re≈øpects, but le≈ø≈øer, hauing purpli≈øh backes, and white bellyes: ≈øtanding clo≈øer and thicker together vpon the ≈øhort ≈øtalkes: the roote is ≈øolid or firme, round and a little long withall, two being v≈øually ioyned together, yellowi≈øh both within and without: but I haue ≈øeene the dry roots that came from beyond Sea hither, that haue beene as ≈ømall as ha≈øell nuts, and ≈øomewhat flat with the roundne≈ø≈øe, differing from tho≈øe that growe with vs, whether the nature thereof is to alter by manuring, I know not.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The greater kindes Clu≈øius reporteth he found in many places of Hungarie,
and the other parts neere thereunto: the le≈ø≈øer in the lower Germany, or Low Countries, as we call them.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe are mo≈øt truely to bee reckoned Vernall plants, for that they ri≈øe not out of the ground vntill the Spring bee come in, and are gone likewi≈øe before it be pa≈øt, remaining vnder ground all the re≈øt of the yeare, yet the le≈ø≈øer abideth longer aboue ground then the greater.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Concerning the former of the≈øe, there is a controuer≈øie among diuers, whether it ≈øhould be The≈øium of Theophra≈øtus, or Eriphium of Galen, but here is no fit place to trauer≈øe tho≈øe opinions. Some would haue it to bee Corydalis, and ≈øome referre it to Plinie his Capuos Cheledonia, for the likene≈ø≈øe it hath both with Fumeterie and Celandine. It is generally called of all moderne Writers, Radix Caua, and we in Engli≈øh thereafter, Hollow roote. The le≈ø≈øer for the firmene≈ø≈øe of his round roote, is v≈øually called, Capuos fabacea radice, and the Dutch men thereafter, Boonkens Hollwortell: we of the likene≈ø≈øe with the former, doe call it the le≈ø≈øe Hollow roote.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Some by the bitterne≈ø≈øe doe coniecture (for little proofe hath beene had thereof, but in outward ca≈øes) that it clen≈øeth, purgeth, and dryeth withall.

div.head: Delphinium. Larkes heeles.
div.p: OF Larkes heeles there are two principall kindes, the wilde kinde, and the tame or garden; the wilde kinde is of two ≈øorts, one which is with vs nour≈øed vp chiefly in gardens, and is the greate≈øt; the other which is ≈ømaller and lower, often found in our plowed landes, and el≈øewhere: of the former of the≈øe wilde ≈øorts, there are double as well as ≈øingle: and of the tame or more vpright, double al≈øo and ≈øingle: and of each of diuers colours, as ≈øhall be ≈øet downe.

div.head: 1. Delphinium maius ≈øiue vulgare. The ordinary Larkes heeles.
div.p: The common Larkes heele ≈øpreadeth with many branches much more ground then the other, rather leaning or bending downe to the ground, then ≈øtanding vpright, whereon are ≈øet many ≈ømall long greene leaues, finely cut, almo≈øt like Fennell leaues: the branches end in a long ≈øpike of hollow flowers, with a long ≈øpurre behinde them, very like vnto the flowers of the Hollow roote la≈øt de≈øcribed, and are of diuers ≈øeuerall colours, as of a blewi≈øh purple colour, or white, or a≈øh colour or red, paler or deeper,Varietas. as al≈øo party coloured of two colours in a flower: after the flowers are pa≈øt, (which in this kinde abide longer then in the other) there come long round cods, containing very blacke ≈øeede: the root is hard after it groweth vp to ≈øeede, ≈øpreading both abroad and deepe, and peri≈øheth euery yeare, v≈øually rai≈øing it ≈øelfe from it own ≈øowing, as well as from the ≈øeede ≈øowen in the ≈øpring time.

div.head: 2. Delphinium vulgare flore pleno. Double common Larkes heeles.
div.p:
Of this vulgar kinde there is ≈øome difference in the flower, although in nothing el≈øe: the flowers ≈øtand many vpon a ≈øtalke like the former, but euery one of them are as if
three or foure ≈ømall flowers were ioyned together, with euery one his ≈øpurre behinde, the greate≈øt flower being outermo≈øt, and as it were containing the re≈øt, which are of a pale red, or deepe blu≈øh colour: Another of this kinde will beare his flowers with three or foure rowes of leaues in the middle, making a double flower with one ≈øpurre behinde onely: and of this kinde there is both with purple, blew, blu≈øh, and white flowers, and party coloured al≈øo; the≈øe doe all beare ≈øeed like the ≈øingle, wherby it is encrea≈øed euery yeare.

div.head: 3. Delphinium aruen≈øe. Wilde Larkes ≈øpurres.
div.p: This wilde Larkes ≈øpurre hath ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter leaues, ≈ømaller and lower branches, and more thinly or ≈øpar≈øedly growing vpon them, then any of the former: the flowers likewi≈øe are neyther ≈øo large as any of the former, nor ≈øo many growing together, the cods likewi≈øe haue ≈ømaller ≈øeede, and is harder to grow in gardens then any of the former; the mo≈øt v≈øuall colour hereof is a pale reddi≈øh or blu≈øh colour, yet ≈øometimes they are found both white and blew, and ≈øometimes mixt of blew and blu≈øh, variably di≈øpo≈øed, as nature can when ≈øhe li≈øteth; but are much more rare.

div.head: 4. Diphinium elatius flore ≈øimplici diuer≈øorum colorum. Single vpright bearing Larkes heeles of many colours.
div.p: The difference betweene this and the la≈øt is, that the leaues of this are not fully ≈øo greene, nor ≈øo large; the ≈øtalkes grow vpright, to the height of a man, and ≈øometimes higher, hauing ≈øome branches thereon, but fewer then the former, and ≈øtanding likewi≈øe vpright, and not leaning downe as the former: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are better ≈øtored with flowers then the other, being ≈øometimes two foote long and aboue, of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, but not altogether ≈øo large, but of more diuers and ≈øeueral colours, as white, pale, blu≈øh, redde deeper or paler, a≈øhcoloured, purple or violet, and of an ouerworne blewi≈øh purple, or iron colour: for of all the≈øe we haue ≈øimple, without any mixture or ≈øpot: but we haue other ≈øorts, among the ≈øimple colours, that ri≈øe from the ≈øame ≈øeede, and will haue flowers that wil be halfe white, and halfe blu≈øh or purple, or one leafe white, and another blu≈øh or purple, or el≈øe variably mixed and ≈øpotted: the ≈øeede and ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels are like the former but larger and harder.

div.head: 5. Delphinium elatius flore pleno diuer≈øorum colorum. Double vpright Larkes heeles of many colours.
div.p: The≈øe double Larkes heeles cannot bee knowne from the ≈øingle of the ≈øame kinde, vntill they come towards flowring; for there appeare many flowers vpon the ≈øtalkes, in the ≈øame manner, and of as many colours almo≈øt as of the ≈øingle, except the party coloured, which ≈øtand like little double Ro≈øes, layd or ≈øpread broade open, as the Ro≈øe Colombine without any heeles behinde them, very delightfull to behold; con≈øi≈øting of many ≈ømall leaues growing together, and after they are fallen there come vp in their places three or foure ≈ømall cods ≈øet together, wherein is contained here and there (for all are not full of ≈øeede, as the ≈øingle kindes) blacke ≈øeede, like vnto all the re≈øt, but ≈ømaller, which being ≈øowen will bring plants that will beare both ≈øingle and double flowers againe, and it often happeneth, that it variably altereth in colours from it owne ≈øowing: for none of them hold con≈øtantly his owne colour, (≈øo farre as euer I could ob≈øerue) but fall into others as nature plea≈øeth.

div.head: 6. Delphinium Hi≈øpanicum paruum. Spani≈øh wilde Larkes ≈øpurres.
div.p:
This ≈ømall Larkes ≈øpurre of Spaine, hath diuers long and broad leaues next the ground, cut-in on both ≈øides, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leafe of a Scabious, or rather that kinde of Stoebe, which Lobel calleth Crupina, for it doth ≈øomewhat neerly re≈øemble the ≈øame, but that this is ≈ømooth on the edges, and not indented be≈øides the cuts, as the Crupina is, being of a whiti≈øh greene colour, and ≈øomewhat ≈ømooth and ≈øoft in handling: among the leaues ri≈øeth vp a whiti≈øh greene ≈øtalke, hauing many ≈ømaller
leaues vpon it that grow belowe, but not diuided, branching out into many ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, bearing flowers like vnto the wilde Larkes heeles, but ≈ømaller, and of a bl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ke blewi≈øh colour, which being pa≈øt, there come vp two or three ≈ømall cods ioyned together, wherein is blacke ≈øeede, ≈ømaller and rounder then any of the former: the roote is ≈ømall and thready, quickly peri≈øhing with the fir≈øt cold that ouertaketh the plant.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The greate≈øt or fir≈øt wilde kindes growe among corne in many countries beyond the Seas, and where corne hath beene ≈øowne, and for his beauty brought and nouri≈øhed in our Gardens: the le≈ø≈øer wilde kinde in ≈øome fields of our owne Country. The Spani≈øh kinde likewi≈øe in the like places, which I had among many ≈øeedes that Guillaume Boel brought mee out of Spaine. The fir≈øt double and ≈øingle haue been common for many yeares in all countries of this Land, but the tall or vpright ≈øingle kindes haue been entertained but of late yeares. The double kindes are more rare.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe flower in the Summer onely, but the Spani≈øh wilde kinde flowreth very late, ≈øo that oftentimes in our Country, the Winter taketh it before it can giue ripe ≈øeede: the double kindes, as well the vpright as the ordinary or wilde, are very choi≈øe and dainty many times, not yeelding good ≈øeede.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called diuer≈øly by diuers Writers, as Con≈øolida regulis, C ‚Ä¢ lcaris flos; Flos regius, Buccinum Romanorum, and of Matthiolus, Cuminum ≈øilue≈øtre alterum Dio≈øcoridis: but the mo≈øt v≈øuall name with vs is Delphinium: but whether it be the true Delphinium of Dio≈øcorides, or the Poets Hyacinth, or the flower of Aiax, another place is fitter to di≈øcu≈ø≈øe then this. Wee call them in Engli≈øh Larkes heeles, Larkes ≈øpurres, Larkes toes or clawes, and Monkes hoods. The la≈øt or Spani≈øh kinde came to mee vnder the name of Delphinium latifolium trigonum, ≈øo ≈øtiled eyther from the diui≈øion of the leaues, or from the pods, which come v≈øually three together. Bauhinus vpon Matthiolus calleth it, Con≈øolida regalis peregrina paruo flore.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is no v≈øe of any of the≈øe in Phy≈øicke in the≈øe dayes that I know, but are wholly ≈øpent for their flowers ≈øake.

div.head: Bal≈øamina foemina. The Female Bal≈øam Apple.
div.p:
I Haue ≈øet this plant in this place, for ≈øome likene≈ø≈øe of the flower, rather then for any other compari≈øon, euen as I mu≈øt al≈øo with the next that followeth. This plant ri≈øeth vp with a thicke round reddi≈øh ≈øtalke, with great and bunched ioynts, being tender and full of iuice, much like to the ≈øtalke of Pur≈ølane, but much greater, which brancheth it ≈øelfe forth from the very ground, into many ≈øtalkes, bearing thereon manie long greene leaues, ≈ønipt about the edges, very like vnto the Almond or Peach tree leaues; among which from the middle of the ≈øtalkes vpwards round about them, come forth vpon ≈øeuerall ≈ømall ≈øhort foot-≈øtalkes many faire purpli≈øh flowers, of two or three colours in them, fa≈øhioned ≈øomewhat like the former Larkes heeles, or Monks hoods, but that they are larger open at the mouth, and the ≈øpurres behinde crooke or bend downewards: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places round rough
1 Radix Caua maior flore albo. The white flowred Hollow roote. 2 Capn ‚Ä¢ s fabacearadice. The ≈ømall Hollow roote. 3 Delphinium flore ≈øimplici. Single Larkes ≈øpurs. 4 Delphinium vulgare flore medio duplici. Larkes ≈øpurs double in the middle. 5 Delphinium vulgare flore pleno. Common Larks ≈øpurs double. 6 Delphinium elatius flore pleno. Double vpright Larkes ≈øpurs. 7 Delphinium Hi≈øpanicum parvu ‚Ä¢ . Small Spani≈øh Larkes ≈øpurs. 8 Bal≈øamina f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mina. The Female Bal≈øam apple. 9 Na≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tium Indicum. Indian Cre≈ø≈øes, or yellow Larkes ≈øpurs. depiction of flowers
heads, pointed at the end, greene at the fir≈øt, and a little yellower when they bee ripe, containing within them ≈ømall round blacki≈øh ≈øeede, which will ≈øoone skippe out of the heads, if they be but a little hardly pre≈ø≈øed betweene the fingers: the rootes ≈øpread them≈øelues vnder ground very much from the toppe, with a number of ≈ømall fibres annexed thereunto: this is a very tender plant, dying euery yeare, and mu≈øt bee ≈øowne carefully in a pot of earth, and tended and watered in the heate of Summer, and all little enough to bring it to perfection.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Wee haue alwaies had the ≈øeede of this plant ≈øent vs out of Italy, not knowing his originall place.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth from the middle of Iuly, to the end of Augu≈øt: the ≈øeed doth ≈øeldome ripen with vs, e≈øpecially if the Summer be backward, ≈øo that wee are oftentimes to ≈øeeke for new and good ≈øeede from our friends againe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Some v≈øe to call it Charantia foemina, Bal≈øamina foemina, Bal≈øamella, and Anguillara, Herba Sanctae Katharinae. We haue no other Engli≈øh name to call it by, then the Female Bal≈øame Apple, or Bal≈øamina.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Some by rea≈øon of the name, would attribute the property of Balme vnto this plant, but it is not ≈øufficiently knowne to haue any ≈øuch; yet I am well per≈øwaded, there may bee ≈øome extradinary quality in ≈øo beautifull a plant, which yet lyeth hid from vs.

div.head: Nasturtium Indicum. Indian Cre≈ø≈øes, or yellow Larkes heeles.
div.p:
THe likene≈ø≈øe (as I ≈øaid before) of this flower likewi≈øe, hauing ≈øpurres or heeles maketh me ioyne it with the re≈øt, which is of ≈øo great beauty and ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe withall, that my Garden of delight cannot bee vnfurni≈øhed of it. This faire plant ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe into very many long trayling branches, enterlaced one within another very confu≈øedly (yet doth it not winde it ≈øelfe with any cla≈øpers about either pole or any other thing, but if you will haue it abide clo≈øe thereunto, you mu≈øt tye it, or el≈øe it will lye vpon the ground) foure or fiue foot in length at the lea≈øt, wherby it taketh vp a great deale of ground: the leaues are ≈ømooth, greene, and as round as the Penniwort that groweth on the ground, without any cut or inci≈øure therein at all in any part, the ≈øtalkes whereof ≈øtand in the middle of each leafe, and ≈øtand at euery ioynt of the ≈øtalke, where they are a little reddi≈øh, and knobbed or bunched out: the flowers are of an excellent gold yellow colour, and grow all along the≈øe ≈øtalkes, almo≈øt at euery ioynt with the leaues, vpon pretty long foote-≈øtalkes, which are compo≈øed of fiue leaues, not hollow or gaping, but ≈øtanding open each leafe apart by it ≈øelfe, two of them, that be larger and longer then the other, ≈øtand aboue, and the other two that are le≈ø≈øer belowe, which are a little iagged or bearded on both ≈øides, and the fift lowe≈øt: in the middle of each of the three lower leaues (yet ≈øometimes it is but in two of them) there is a little long ≈øpot or ≈øtreake, of an excellent crim≈øon colour, with a long heele or ≈øpurre behinde hanging downe: the whole flower hath a fine ≈ømall ≈øent, very plea≈øing, which being placed in the middle of ≈øome Carnations or Gilloflowers
(for they are in flower at the ≈øame time) make a delicate Tu≈ø≈øimu≈ø≈øie, as they call it, or No≈øegay, both for ≈øight and ≈øent: After the flower is pa≈øt, come the ≈øeede, which are rough or vneuen, round, greeni≈øh yellow heads, ≈øometimes but one, and ≈øometimes two or three ≈øtanding together vpon one ≈øtalke, bare or naked of them≈øelues, without any huske, containing a white pulpy kernell: the rootes are ≈ømall, and ≈øpreading vnder ground, which peri≈øh with the fir≈øt fro≈øts, and mu≈øt be ≈øowne a new euery yeare; yet there needeth no bed of hor≈øe-dung for the matter: the naturall ground will be ≈øufficient, ≈øo as you defend it a little from tho≈øe fro≈øts, that may ≈øpoile it when it is newly ≈øprung vp, or being yet tender.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This goodly plant was fir≈øt found in the We≈øt Indies, and from thence ≈øent into Sp ‚Ä¢ ine vnto Monardus and others, from whence all other parts haue receiued it. It is now very familiar in mo≈øt Gardens of any curio≈øity, where it yearly giueth ripe ≈øeed, except the yeare be very vnkindly.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth ≈øometimes in Iune, but v≈øually in Iuly (if it be well defended and in any good ground) and ≈øo continueth flowring, vntill the cold fro≈øts and mi≈øtes in the middle or end of October, doe checke the luxurious nature thereof, and in the meane time the ≈øeede is ripe, which will quickly fall downe on the ground, where for the mo≈øt part the be≈øt is gathered.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Some doe reckon this plant among the Clematides or Convolvuli, the Clamberers or Bind weedes; but (as I ≈øaid) it hath no cla≈øpers, neither doth it winde it ≈øelfe: but by rea≈øon of the number of his branches, that run one within another, it may ≈øeeme to climbe vp by a pole or ≈øticke, which yet doth but onely clo≈øe it, as hauing ≈øomething whereon to leane or re≈øt his branches. Monardus and others call it Flos ≈øanguineus, of the red ≈øpots in the flowers, as al≈øo Mastnerzo de las Indias, which is Na≈øturtium Indicum, by which name it is now generally knowne and called, and wee thereafter in Engli≈øh, Indian Cre≈ø≈øes, yet it may bee called from the forme of the flowers onely, Yellow Larkes heeles.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Spaniards and others v≈øe the leaues hereof in ≈øtead of ordinary Cre≈ø≈øes, becau≈øe the ta≈øte is ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe agreeing thereunto, but other Phy≈øicall properties I haue heard of none attributed to it.

div.head: Viola. Violets.
div.p: THe Garden Violets (for the Wilde I leaue to their owne place) are ≈øo well knowne vnto all, that either keepe a Garden, or hath but once come into it, that I ≈øhall (I thinke) but lo≈øe labour and time to de≈øcribe that which is ≈øo common. Yet becau≈øe it is not onely a choi≈øe flower of delight, notwith≈øtanding the popularity, and that I let not pa≈ø≈øe any thing without his particular de≈øcription, I mu≈øt al≈øo doe ≈øo by this. And hereunto I mu≈øt adde that kinde of Violet, which, although it want that ≈ømell of the other, goeth beyond it in variety of dainty colours, called Viola tricolor & flammea, or Harts ea≈øes.

div.head: 1. Viola ≈øimplex Martia. Single March Violets.
div.p: The ≈øingle Garden Violet hath many round greene leaues, finely ≈ønipt or dented about the edges, ≈øtanding vpon ≈øeuerall ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, ≈øet at diuers places of the many creeping branches, which as they runne, doe here and there take roote in the ground, bearing thereon many flowers ≈øeuerally at the ioynts of the leaues, which con≈øi≈øt of fiue ≈ømall leaues, with a ≈øhort round tayle or ≈øpurre behinde, of a perfect blew purple colour, and of a very ≈øweete ≈øent, it bringeth forth round ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øtanding likewi≈øe vpon their ≈øeuerall ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, wherein is contained round white ≈øeede: but the≈øe heads ri≈øe not from where the flowers grew, as in all other plants that I know, but apart by them≈øelues, and being ≈øowne, will produce others like vnto it ≈øelfe, whereby there may be made a more ≈øpeedy encrea≈øe to plant a Garden (as I haue done) or any other place, then by ≈ølipping, as is the v≈øuall manner: the rootes ≈øpread both deepe and wide, taking ≈øtrong hold in the ground.
Flore albo.Of this kinde there is another that beareth white flowers, not differing in ≈ømell or any thing el≈øe from the former.
Flore ob≈øoleto.And al≈øo another, that beareth flowers of a dead or ≈øad reddi≈øh colour, in all other things alike, ≈øauing that this hath not altogether ≈øo good a ≈øent as the other.

div.head: 2. Viola Martia flore multiplici. Double March Violets.
div.p: There is no difference betweene this Violet and the former, in any other thing then in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flowers, which haue ≈øo many leaues ≈øet and thru≈øt together, that they are like vnto hard buttons. There is of this double kinde both white and purple, as in the ≈øingle; but the white ≈øort is ≈øeldome ≈øo thicke and double as the purple: but of the red colour to be double I neuer heard.

div.head: 3. Viola flammea ≈øiue tricolor. Harts ea≈øes or Pan≈øies.
div.p: The Harts ea≈øe hath his leaues longer, and more endented or cut in on the edges then the Violet hath, and ≈øomewhat round withall: the ≈øtalkes are vpright, yet weake, and ready to fall downe, and lye vpon the ground, ≈øet here and there with the like leaues, from whence come forth the flowers, of little or no ≈øent at all, made like vnto a Violet, yet more open, and with larger leaues; but ≈øo variably mixed with blew or purple, white and yellow, that it is hard to ≈øet downe all the varieties: For ≈øome flowers will be more white, and but ≈øome ≈øpots of purple or blew in the two vpper leaues, and the lower leaues with ≈øome ≈øtripes of yellow in the middle: others will haue more purple in them then any other colour, both in the vpper and lower leaues, the ≈øide leaues blew, and the middle yellow, and others white and blew with yellow ≈øtripes, as nature li≈øteth to di≈øtribute their colours: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, whiti≈øh, and round, contained in ≈ømall round heads: the roote peri≈øheth euery yeare, and rai≈øeth it ≈øelfe vp plentifully by it owne ≈øowing, if it be ≈øuffered.

div.head: 4. Viola tricolor flore duplici. Double Harts ea≈øe.
div.p: We haue in our Gardens another ≈øort, that beareth flowers with more leaues then the former, making it ≈øeeme to be twice double, and that onely in Autumne; for the fir≈øt flowers are ≈øingle that come in Summer: This is of that ≈øort that beareth purple flowers: And it is to be ob≈øerued, that the ≈øeed of this kinde will not all bring double flowers, but only ≈øome, if the ground be fit and liking, ≈øo that if you haue once had of this double kinde, you ≈øhall ≈øeldome mi≈ø≈øe to haue double flowers againe euery yeare of it owne growing or ≈øowing.

div.head: 5. Viola flammea luteae maxima. The great yellow Pan≈øie.
div.p:
