There is one other kinde of Harts ea≈øe, that decketh vp our Gardens not to be forgotten, who≈øe leaues and flowers are like the former, but more plentifull in ≈øtalkes and branches, and better abideth our Winters: the flowers are larger then any of the
former, of a faire pale yellow colour, with ≈øome yellower ≈øtripes now and then about the middle; for it is ≈øometimes without any ≈øtripes, and al≈øo of a little deeper yellow colour: this is to bee encrea≈øed by ≈ølips, which will ≈øoone comprehend in a moi≈øt or moi≈øtened ground, for that I neuer could ob≈øerue that it bore ≈øeede.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe plants were fir≈øt wilde, and by manuring brought to be both fairer in colour, and peraduenture of a better ≈øent then when they grew wilde.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Violets flower in March, and ≈øometimes earlier, and if the yeare be temperate and milde, in Autumne againe. The double Violets, as they are later before they flower then the ≈øingle, ≈øo they hold their flowers longer. The Harts ea≈øe flowreth ≈øeldome vntill May; but then ≈øome will abide to flower vntill the end of Autumne almo≈øt, e≈øpecially if the fro≈øts be not early.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The Violet is called Viola nigra, purpurea, and Martia: In Engli≈øh, Violets, March Violets, and purple Violets. The Harts ea≈øe is called Viola flammea, Viola tricolor, Viola multicolor, and of ≈øome, Iacea, Flos trinitatis, and Herba clauellata: In Engli≈øh, Harts ea≈øe, and Pan≈øies, of the French name Pen≈øees. Some giue it fooli≈øh names, as Loue in idlene≈ø≈øe, Cull mee to you, and Three faces in a hood. The great yellow Harts ea≈øe is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it is like in forme, and is the greate≈øt of all other, although it haue not that diuer≈øity of colours in it that the other haue.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The properties of Violets are ≈øufficiently knowne to all, to coole and moi≈øten: I ≈øhall forbeare to recite the many vertues that may be ≈øet downe, and onely let you know, that they haue in them an opening or purging quality, being taken either fre≈øh and greene, or dryed, and made into powder, e≈øpecially the flowers; the dryed leaues will doe the like, but in greater quantity. Co≈øtaeus in his booke of the nature of all plants ≈øaith, that the di≈øtilled water of Harts ea≈øe, is commended in the French di≈øea≈øe, to be profitable, being taken for nine dayes or more, and ≈øweating vpon it, which how true it is, I know not, and wi≈øh ≈øome better experience were made of it, before we put any great confidence in that a≈ø≈øertion.

div.head: Epimedium. Barrenwort.
div.p:
THis pretty plant ri≈øeth vp out of the ground with vpright, hard, round, ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, a foote and a halfe high, or not two foote high at the highe≈øt, diuided into three branches for the mo≈øt part, each branch whereof is againe diuided for the mo≈øt part into three other branches, and each of them beare three leaues (≈øeldome either more or le≈ø≈øe) ≈øet together, yet each vpon his owne foote-≈øtalke, each leafe being broad, round, and pointed at the end, ≈øomewhat hard or dry in feeling, hayrie, or as it were prickly about the edges, but very tenderly, without harme, of a light greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and a little whiter vnderneath: from the middle of the ≈øtemme or ≈øtalke of leaues doth likewi≈øe come forth another long ≈øtalke, not much higher then tho≈øe with the leaues on them, diuided into other branches, each
whereof hath likewi≈øe three flowers, each vpon his owne foote≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of eight ≈ømall leaues a peece, yet ≈øeeming to be but of foure leaus ≈øpread or layd open flat, for that the foure vppermo≈øt, which are the ≈ømaller and being yellow, doe lye ≈øo clo≈øe on the foure vndermo≈øt, wch are a little broader and red, that they ≈øhew as if they were yellow flowers with red edges, hauing yellow thredstipt with greene, ≈øtanding in the middle of the flowers: the vnder≈øide of the lower leaues are of a pale yellowi≈øh red, ≈øtriped with white lines: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come ≈ømall long pods, wherin are contained flat reddi≈øh ≈øeede: the rootes are ≈ømall, reddi≈øh and hard, ≈øpreading, branching and enterlacing them≈øelues very much, and is fit to be placed on ≈øome ≈øhady ≈øide of a garden: the whole plant is rather of a ≈øtrong then any good ≈øent, yet is cheri≈øhed for the plea≈øant varietie of the flowers.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Cae≈øalpinus ≈øaith it groweth on the mountaines of Liguria, that is nigh vnto Ligorne, in the Florentine Dominion. Cametarius ≈øaith, nigh vnto Vicenzo in Italie. Bauhinus on the Euganian hils, nigh vnto Padoa, and in Romania in ≈øhadowie wet grounds.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth from Iune vntill the end of Iuly, and to the middle of Augu≈øt, if it ≈øtand, as I ≈øaid it is fitte≈øt, in a ≈øhadowie place.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is of mo≈øt Writers accepted for the true Epimedium of Dio≈øcorides, though he ≈øaith it is without flower or ≈øeede, being therein eyther mi≈øtaken, or mi≈ø-informed, as he was al≈øo in Dictamnus of Candy, and diuers other plants. From the triple triplicitie of the ≈øtanding of the ≈øtalkes and leaues, and quadriplicitie of the flowers, it might receiue another name in Engli≈øh then is already impo≈øed vpon it: but le≈øt I might be thought to be ≈øingular or full of noueltie, let it pa≈ø≈øe with the name Barrenwort, as it is in the title.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is thought of diuers to agree in the propertie of cau≈øing barrenne≈ø≈øe, as the ancients doe record of Epimedium.

div.head: Papauer ≈øatiuum. Garden Poppies.
div.p: OF Poppies there are a great many ≈øorts, both wilde and tame, but becau≈øe our Garden doth entertaine none, but tho≈øe of beautie and re≈øpect, I wil onely giue you here a few double ones, and leaue the re≈øt to a general ≈øuruey.

div.head: 1. Papauer multiplex album. Double white Poppies.
div.p:
The double white Poppy hath diuers broade, and long whiti≈øh greene leaues, giuing milke (as all the re≈øt of the plant aboue ground doth, where≈øoeuer it is broken) very much rent or torne in on the ≈øides, and notched or indented be≈øides, compa≈ø≈øing at the bottome of them a hard round brittle whiti≈øh greene ≈øtalke, branched towards the toppe, bearing one faire large great flower on the head of euery branch, which before it breaketh out, is contained within a thin skinne, and being blowne open is very thick of leaues, and double, ≈øomewhat iagged at the ends, and of a white colour; in the
1 Viola Martia ≈øimplex. Single March Violets. 2 Viola Martia multiplex. Double March Violets. 3 Viola flammea ≈øiue tricolor. Ordinary garden Pan≈øies or Harts ea≈øe. 4 Viola flammea lutea magna. Great yellow Pan≈øies. 5 Viola tri ‚Ä¢ olor d ‚Ä¢ ple ‚Ä¢
Double Pan ‚Ä¢ ies or Harts ea≈øes. 6 Epimedium. Barrenwort. 7 Papauer ≈øativum flore pl ‚Ä¢ no. Double garden Poppies. 8 Papauer ≈øativum flore ple ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ laciv ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
feathere ‚Ä¢ Poppie ‚Ä¢ . 9 Nigella Hi≈øpanica flore amplo. Spani≈øh Nigella or Fenell flower. 10 Nigella multiplex caerulea Double blew Nigella or Fenell flower. 11 Nigella duplex flore albo. Double white Nigella. 12 Ptarmica flore pleno. Double wilde Pelletory. depiction of flowers
middle whereof ≈øtandeth a round head or bowle, with a ≈øtriped crowne on the heade of it, very like a ≈øtarre, compa≈ø≈øed about with ≈øome threds, wherein when it is ripe, is contained ≈ømall, round, white ≈øeede. di≈øpo≈øed into ≈øeuerall cels: the roote is hard, wooddy, and long, peri≈øhing euery yeare, and mu≈øt bee new ≈øowne euery Spring, if they doe not ≈øpring of their own ≈øowing, which if it doe, the flowers are ≈øeldome ≈øo faire and double as they that are ≈øowne in the Spring: the whole plant is of a ≈øtrong heady ≈ømell.

div.head: 2. Papauer multiplex rube≈øcens. Double red or blu≈øh Poppies.
div.p: This other kind of double Poppy differeth not in any other thing from the former, but only in the colour of the flowers, which are of a bright red, tending to a blu≈øh colour, parted, paned or ≈øtriped in many places with white, and exceedingly more iagged then the former, almo≈øt like a feather at the ends, the bottomes of all the leaues being white: the ≈øeede hereof is white as the former, which is not ≈øo in any other Poppie, that beareth not a full white flower.

div.head: 3. Papauer multiplex nigrum ≈øiue purpureum. Double purple or murry Poppies.
div.p: This kinde varyeth both in flowers and ≈øeede, although neyther in leaues or any other thing from the fir≈øt: the flowers are thicke and double, and ≈øomewhat iagged at the ends, in ≈øome more, in ≈øome le≈ø≈øe, eyther red or blu≈øh, or purpli≈øh red, more or le≈ø≈øe, or of a ≈øad murrey or tawney, with browne, or blacke, or tawny bottomes: the ≈øeede is eyther of a grayi≈øh blew colour, or in others more blacki≈øh.

div.head: 4. Papauer Rhaas flore multiplici. The double red field Poppie.
div.p: This double Poppie is like the wilde or fielde Poppie, which is well knowne to all to haue longer, narrower, and more iagged greene leaues then the former, the ≈øtalkes more hairy, and the flower of a deepe yellowi≈øh red colour, knowne to all. Now this differeth in nothing from it, but in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower, which is very thicke and double, but not ≈øo large as the former. This ri≈øeth of ≈øeede in the like manner as they doe, and ≈øo to bee pre≈øerued.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: From what place they haue beene fir≈øt gathered naturally I cannot a≈ø≈øure you, but we haue had them often and long time in our gardens, being ≈øent from Italie and other places. The double wilde kindes came from Con≈øtantinople, which whether it groweth neere vnto it or further off, we cannot tell as yet.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in the beginning or middle of Iune at the furthe≈øt, the ≈øeede is ripe within a ≈ømall while after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The generall knowne name to all, is Papauer, Poppie: the ≈øeuerall di≈øtinctions are according to their colours. Yet our Engli≈øh Gentlewomen in ≈øome places, call it by a by-name, Ione ≈øiluer pinne: ≈øubauditur, Faire without and fowle within.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
It is not vnknowne, I ≈øuppo≈øe to any, that Poppie procureth ≈øleepe, for which cau≈øe it is wholly and onely v≈øed, as I thinke: but the water of the
wilde Poppies, be≈øides that it is of great v≈øe in Pleure≈øies, and Rheumatick-or thinner Di≈øtillations, is found by daily experience, to bee a ≈øoueraigne remedy again≈øt ≈øurfeits; yet ≈øome doe attribute this propertie to the water of the wilde Poppies.

div.head: Nigella. The Fenell flower, or Nigella.
div.p: AMong the many ≈øorts of Nigella, both wilde and tame, both ≈øingle and double, I will onely ≈øet downe three ≈øorts, to be nour≈øed vp in this garden, referring the re≈øt to a Phy≈øicke garden, or a generall Hi≈øtorie, which may comprehend all.

div.head: 1. Nigella Hi≈øpanica flore ≈øimplici. The great Spani≈øh Nigella.
div.p: Spani≈øh Nigella ri≈øeth vp with diuers greene leaues, ≈øo finely cut, and into ≈øo many parts, that they are finer then Fenell, and diuided ≈øomewhat like the leaues of Larkes heeles, among which ri≈øe vp ≈øtalkes, with many ≈øuch like leaues vpon them, branched into three or foure parts, at the toppe of each whereof ≈øtandeth one faire large flower, like vnto other ≈øingle Nigella's, con≈øi≈øting of fiue or ≈øix leaues ≈øometimes, of a bleake blew, or of a purpli≈øh blew colour, with a greene head in the middle, compa≈ø≈øed about with ≈øeuen or eight ≈ømall blewi≈øh greene flowers, or peeces of flowers rather, made like gaping hoodes, with euery of them a yellowi≈øh line thwart or cro≈ø≈øe the middle of them, with ≈øome threds al≈øo ≈øtanding by them: after the flower is pa≈øt the head groweth greater, hauing ≈øixe, ≈øeuen or eight hornes as it were at the toppe, greater and longer, and ≈øtanding clo≈øer together then any other Nigella, ≈øpreading very like a ≈øtarre, or the crowne of the Poppy head, but larger and longer, each whereof being folded together, openeth a little when the head is ripe, which is greater aboue, and ≈ømaller below, and not ≈øo round as the others are, containing within them ≈ømall yellowi≈øh greene ≈øeede, or not ≈øo blacke as the other ≈øorts: the rootes are ≈ømall and yellow, peri≈øhing euery yeare as the others likewi≈øe doe.

div.head: 2. Nigella Dama≈øcena flore multiplici. Double blew Nigella, or The Fenell flower.
div.p: The double Nigella is in leaues, ≈øtalkes and rootes, very like vnto the former Nigella, ≈øo that the one can very hardly bee di≈øcerned from the other before this ri≈øe vp to flower, except it be that the leaues hereof are not fully ≈øo large as they: the flower con≈øi≈øteth of three or foure rowes of leaues, layde one vpon another, of a pale blew colour, with a greene round head compa≈ø≈øed with diuers ≈øhort threads in the middle, and hauing fiue or ≈øixe ≈øuch ≈ømall greene Fenell-like leaues vnder the flower, to beare it vp (as it were) below, which adde a greater grace to the flowers, which at the fir≈øt ≈øheweth ≈øometimes white, but changeth quickely after: the horned heads hereof are like vnto the heads of the other wilde kinde, which are ≈øomewhat rounder and greater, hauing within them blacke vneuen ≈øeedes, but without any ≈øent.

div.head: 3. Nigella Catrina flore albo multiplici. Double white Nigella.
div.p: This double white Nigella hath ≈øuch like leaues as the la≈øt hath, but ≈øomewhat larger, of a yellower greene colour, and not ≈øo finely cut and iagged: the flowers are ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øe, and le≈ø≈øer double then the former, and in colour white, hauing no greene leaues vnder the flower, as the former hath, the head whereof in the middle is very like the head of the la≈øt double kinde, but not ≈øo great, wherein is contained black ≈øeede for the mo≈øt part, and ≈øweete like the Romane Nigella, which only is ≈øweet be≈øides this: yet ≈øometimes it is not ≈øo blacke, but rather a little more white or yellowi≈øh: the roote is yellow, and peri≈øheth as the others euery yeare.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe, and the re≈øt be found wilde in diuers Countreyes, as France, Spaine, Italie, &c. but wee onely cheri≈øh them in our Gardens for our delight.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in the end of Iune, and in Iuly, or thereabouts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called Melanthium, Gith, and Nigella, and of ≈øome Flos Diuae Catherinae. We may either call them Nigella according to the Latine name, or the Fenell flower, as ≈øome doe, becau≈øe the double blew Nigella hath ≈ømall Fenell-like leaues bearing vp the flower, as I ≈øhewed before in the de≈øcription.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The≈øe Nigella's are nothing ≈øo hot in qualitie as the ≈øingle Romane kind is, as may well be knowne by the ≈ømell of the ≈øeede thereof, and therefore are not fit to be v≈øed in the ≈øteed of it, as many ignorant per≈øons v≈øe to doe: for the ≈øingle Romane ≈øeede is v≈øed to helpe paines, and cold di≈øtillations in the head, and to dry vp the rheume. Pena ≈øaith, that the pre≈ø≈øed oyle of the ≈øeede as well taken inwardly as v≈øed outwardly is an excellent remedy for the hardne≈ø≈øe and ≈øwelling of the ≈øpleene.

div.head: Ptarmica ≈øilue≈øtris flore pleno. Double wilde Pelletory.
div.p: THe double wilde Pelletorie hath ≈øtraight and ≈ølender ≈øtalkes, be≈øet with long and narrow leaues, ≈ønipt round about the edges, in all points like vnto the ≈øingle wilde kinde, that groweth common with vs almo≈øt euery where: on the toppes of the ≈øtalkes ≈øtand foure or fiue, or more white flowers, one aboue another, with a greene leafe at the bottome of the foote≈øtalke of euery one of them, beeing ≈ømall, thicke, and very double, with a little yellowi≈øhne≈ø≈øe in the middle of euery flower, like both for forme and colour vnto the flower of the double Featherfew, but ≈ømaller: the rootes are many long ≈øtrings, running here and there in the ground: this hath no ≈ømell at all, but is delight≈øome only for the double white flowers.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It is only cheri≈øhed in ≈øome few Gardens, for it is very rare.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the end of Iune or thereabouts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called of mo≈øt Ptarmica, or Sternutamenteria, of his qualitie to prouoke nee≈øing; and of ≈øome Pyrethrum, of the hot biting ta≈øte. We v≈øually call it Double wilde Pelletorie, and ≈øome Snee≈øewort, but Elleborus albus is v≈øually ≈øo called, and I would not two things ≈øhould be called by one name, for the mi≈øtaking and mi≈ø-u≈øing of them.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The properties hereof, no doubt, may well bee referred to the ≈øingle kinde, beeing of the ≈øame qualitie, yet as I take it, a little more milde and temperate.

div.head: Parthenium flore pleno. Double Featherfew.
div.p: FEatherfew that beareth double flowers is ≈øo like vnto the ≈øingle kinde, that the one cannot be di≈øcerned from the other, vntill it come to flower, bearing broad, pale or fre≈øh greene leaues, much cut in on the ≈øides: the ≈øtalkes haue ≈øuch like leaues on them as grow below, from the toppes whereof come forth many double white flowers, like vnto the flowers of the former wilde Pelletory, but larger, and like al≈øo vnto the flowers of the double Camomill: the ≈øent whereof is as ≈øtrong as of the ≈øingle.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: We haue this kinde only in Gardens, and as it is thought by others, is peculiar only to our owne Countrey.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the end of May, and in Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called diuer≈øly by diuers: Some thinke it to be Parthenium of Dio≈øcorides, but not of Galen; for his Parthenium is a ≈øweet herbe, and is thought to bee Amaracus, that is Marierome: others call it Matricaria; and ≈øome Amarella. Gaza tran≈ølateth it Muraleum, Theoph. lib. 7. cap. 7. It is generally in the≈øe parts of our Country called Double Feaverfew, or Featherfew.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is an≈øwerable to all the properties of the ≈øingle kinde which is v≈øed for womens di≈øea≈øes, to procure their monthly cour≈øes chiefly. It is held to bee a ≈øpeciall remedy to helpe tho≈øe that haue taken Opium too liberally. In Italy ≈øome v≈øe to eate the ≈øingle kinde among other greene herbes, as Camerarius ≈øaith, but e≈øpecially fryed with egges, and ≈øo it wholly lo≈øeth his ≈øtrong and bitter ta≈øte.

div.head: Chamaemaelum. Camomill.
div.p: OVr ordinary Camomill is well knowne to all, to haue many ≈ømal trayling branches, ≈øet with very fine ≈ømal leaues, bu≈øhing and ≈øpreading thicke ouer the ground, taking roote ≈øtill as it ≈øpreadeth: the toppes of the branches haue white flowers, with yellow thrummes in the middle, very like vnto the Featherfew, before de≈øcribed, but ≈øomewhat greater, not ≈øo hard, but more ≈øoft and gentle in handling, and the whole herbe to be of a very ≈øweet ≈øent.

div.head: 1. Chamaemaelum nudum. Naked Camomill.
div.p: We haue another ≈øort of Camomill in ≈øome Gardens, but very rare, like vnto the former, but that it is whiter, finer, and ≈ømaller, and rai≈øeth, it ≈øelfe vp a little higher, and beareth naked flowers; that is, without that border of white leaues that is in the former, and con≈øi≈øteth onely of a yellow round thrummie head, ≈ømelling almo≈øt as ≈øweete as the former.

div.head: 2. Chamaemaelum flore pleno. Double flowred Camomill.
div.p: The double Camomill groweth with his leaues vpon the ground, as the other ≈øingle kinde doth, but of a little fre≈øher greene colour, and larger withall: the ≈øtalkes with the flowers on them, doe rai≈øe them≈øelues vp a little higher then the ordinary, and bearing one or two flowers vpon a ≈øtalk, which are compo≈øed of many white leaues ≈øet together in diuers rowes, which make a fine double flower, with a little yellow ≈øpot in the middle for the mo≈øt part of euery one, and are much larger then any ≈øingle kinde, ≈ømelling better, and more plea≈øing then the ordinary: this doth creepe vpon the ground as the other, but is more tender to be kept in the Winter. Yet if you ≈øaue the flowers hereof (and ≈øo will the double Featherfew al≈øo) when they haue ≈øtood long, and ready to fade, and keepe them dry vntill the Spring, and then breaking them or pulling them to peeces, ≈øowe them, there will ≈øpring vp from them Camomill, and al≈øo Featherfew, that will againe beare double flowers.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Our ordinary Camomill groweth wilde in many places of our Country, and as well neare London as in other places. The others are onely found in our Gardens, where they are cheri≈øhed. Bauhinus ≈øaith, that the double flowred Camomill is found wilde about Orleance in France.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The double kinde is v≈øually in flower in Iune, before the ordinary kinde, and mo≈øt commonly pa≈øt before it flowreth, which is not vntill Iuly or Augu≈øt. The naked Camomill flowreth betweene them both, or later.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Camomill is called Anthemis, Leucanthemis, and Leucanthemum, of the whitene≈ø≈øe of the flowers; and Chamaemaelum of the corrupted Italian name Camomilla. Some call the naked Camomill, Chry≈øanthemum odoratum. The double Camomill is called by ≈øome Chamaemaelum Romanum flore multiplici.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Camomill is put to diuers and ≈øundry v≈øes, both for plea≈øure and profit, both for inward and outward di≈øea≈øes, both for the ≈øicke and the ≈øound, in bathings to comfort and ≈øtrengthen the ≈øound, and to ea≈øe paines in the di≈øea≈øed, as al≈øo in many other formes applyed outwardly. The flowers boyled in Po≈ø≈øet drinke prouoketh ≈øweat, and helpeth to expell colds, aches, and other griefes. A Syrupe made of the iuice of the double Camomill, with the flowers and white wine, as Bauhinus ≈øaith, is v≈øed by ≈øome again≈øt the Iaundi≈øe and Drop≈øie, cau≈øed by the euill di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øplene.

figure.head: 1 Parthenium flore pleno. Double Featherfew. 2. Chamaemaelum nudum. Naked Camomill. 3 Chamaemaelum flore pleno. Double Camomill. 4 Pyrethrum officinarum Pelletory of Spaine. 5 Flos Adonis flore rubro & flore luteo. Adonis flower both red & yellow. 6 H ‚Ä¢ lle ‚Ä¢ orus niger feru ‚Ä¢ aceus ≈øiue Buphthalmum. The great Oxe eye or the great yellow Anemone. 7 Buphthalmum vulgare. The common yellow Oxe eye.

div.head: Pyrethrum officinarum. Pelletory of Spaine.
div.p: I Mu≈øt needes adioyne vnto the Camomils this fine and tender plant, for ≈øome neare re≈øemblance it hath with them in face, though not in quality. It is a ≈ømall and lowe plant, bearing many fine greene leaues vpon his ≈ølender branches, which leane or lye down vpon the ground, diuided into many parts, yet ≈øomewhat larger and broader then Camomill, the ≈øtalkes whereof are bigger, and more iuicie then it: the flowers that ≈øtand at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are ≈øingle, but much larger then any Camomill flower, hauing a pale or border of many leaues, white on the vpper≈øide, and reddi≈øh vnderneath, ≈øet about the yellow middle thrumme; but not ≈øtanding ≈øo clo≈øe together ioyning at the bottome, as the Camomill flowers doe, but more ≈øeuered one from another: it beareth ≈ømall whiti≈øh ≈øeede, which is hardly found and di≈øcerned from the chaffe: the roote is long, and growing downe right, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans finger or thumbe in our Countrey, but not halfe ≈øo great where it groweth naturally, with ≈øome fibres and branches from the ≈øides thereof, of a very hot, ≈øharpe, and biting ta≈øte, drawing much water into the mouth, after it hath been chewed a while: the plant with vs is very tender, and will hardly or not at all endure the hardne≈ø≈øe and extremities of our Winters, vnle≈ø≈øe it be very carefully pre≈øerued.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It groweth in Spaine wilde in many places, and in other hot Countries, where it may feele no fro≈øts to cau≈øe it peri≈øh.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth ≈øo late with vs, that it is not vntill Augu≈øt, that oftentimes we cannot gather ripe ≈øeedes from it, before it peri≈øh.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Pyrethrum (taken from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that is, ignis, fire) is giuen to this plant, becau≈øe of the heate thereof, and that the roote is ≈øomewhat like in ≈øhew, but ≈øpecially in property vnto the true Pyrethrum of Dio≈øcorides, which is an vmbelliferous plant, who≈øe rootes are greater, and more feruent a great deale, and haue a hayrie bu≈øh or toppe as Meum, and many other vmbelliferous plants haue. It is al≈øo called in Latine, Saliuaris, of the effect in drawing much moi≈øture into the mouth, to be ≈øpit out. We doe v≈øually call it Pelletory of Spaine.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is in a manner wholly ≈øpent to draw rheume from the teeth, by chewing it in the mouth, thereby to ea≈øe the tooth-ach, and likewi≈øe from the head, in the paines thereof.

div.head: Flos Adonis flore rubro. Red Adonis flower.
div.p: ADonis flower may well be accounted a kinde of Camomill, although it hath ≈øome e≈øpeciall differences, hauing many long branches of leaues lying vpon the ground, and ≈øome ri≈øing vp with the ≈øtalke, ≈øo finely cut and iagged, that they much re≈øemble the leaues of Mayweed, or of the former Nigella: at the top of the ≈øtalkes, which ri≈øe a foote high or better, ≈øtand ≈ømall red flowers, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix or eight round leaues, hauing a greene head in the middle, ≈øet about with many blacki≈øh threads, without any ≈ømell at all: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there grow vp heads with many roundi≈øh white ≈øeedes at the toppes of them, ≈øet clo≈øe together, very like vnto the heads of ≈øeede of the great Oxe eye, ≈øet downe in the next Chapter, but ≈ømaller: the rootes are ≈ømall and thready, peri≈øhing euery yeare, but ri≈øing of his owne ≈øeede againe, many times before Winter, which will abide vntill the next yeare.
Yellow Adonis flower is like vnto the red, but that the flower is ≈øomewhat larger,Flore luteo. and of a faire yellow colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth wilde in the corn fields in many places of our own country, as well as in others, and is brought into Gardens for the beauties ≈øake of the flower. The yellow is a ≈øtranger, but nour≈øed in our Gardens with other rarities.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in May or Iune, as the yeare falleth out to be early or late: the ≈øeed is ≈øoone ripe after, and will quickly fall away, if it be not gathered.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Some haue taken the red kinde to be a kinde of Anemone; other to be Eranthemum of Dio≈øcorides: the mo≈øt v≈øuall name now with vs is Flos Adonis, and Flos Adonidis: In Engli≈øh, where it groweth wilde, they call it red Maythes, as they call the Mayweede, white Maythes; and ≈øome of our Engli≈øh Gentlewomen call it Ro≈øarubie: we v≈øually call it Adonis flower.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It hath been certainly tryed by experience, that the ≈øeed of red Adonis flower drunke in wine, is good to ea≈øe the paines of the Collicke and Stone.

div.head: Buphthalmum. Oxe eye.
div.p: VNder the name Buphthalmum, or Oxe eye, are comprehended two or three ≈øeuerall plants, each differing from other, both in face and property, yet becau≈øe they all beare one generall name, I thinke fitte≈øt to compri≈øe them all in one Chapter, and fir≈øt of that which in leafe & ≈øeed commeth neare≈øt to the Adonis flower.

div.head: 1. Buphthalmum maius ≈øiue Helleborus niger ferulac ‚Ä¢ us. Great Oxe eye, or ‚Ä¢ he yellow Anemone.
div.p:
This great Oxe eye is a beautifull plant, hauing many branches of greene leaues
leaning or lying vpon the ground for the mo≈øt part, yet ≈øome ≈øtanding vpright, which are as fine, but ≈øhorter then Fenell; ≈øome of them ending in a ≈ømall tuft of green leaues, and ≈øome hauing at the toppes of them one large flower apeece, ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh or browni≈øh on the out≈øide, while they are in bud, and a while after, and being open, ≈øhew them≈øelues to con≈øi≈øt of twelue or fourteene long leaues, of a faire ≈øhining yellow colour, ≈øet in order round about a greene head, with yellow thrums in the middle, laying them≈øelues open in the ≈øunne, or a faire day, but el≈øe remaining clo≈øe: after the flower is pa≈øt, the head growing greater, ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe compact of many round whiti≈øh ≈øeede, very like vnto the head of ≈øeede of the Adonis flower la≈øt de≈øcribed, but much greater: the rootes are many long blacki≈øh fibres or ≈øtrings, ≈øet together at the head, very like vnto the rootes of the le≈ø≈øer blacke Hellebor or Bearefoote, but ≈øomewhat harder, ≈øtiffer, or more brittle, and ≈øeeming without moi≈øture in them, which abide and encrea≈øe euery yeare.

div.head: 2. Buphthalmum minus, ≈øeu Anthemis flore luteo. Small Oxe eye.
div.p: This plant might ≈øeeme to be referred to the Camomils, but that it is not ≈øweete, or to the Corne-Marigolds, but that the ≈øtalkes and leaues are not edible: it is therefore put vnder the Oxe eyes, and ≈øo we will de≈øcribe it; hauing many weake branches lying vpon the ground, be≈øet with winged leaues, very finely cut and iagged, ≈øomewhat like vnto Mayweede, but a little larger: the flowers are like vnto the Corne Marigold, and larger then any Camomill, being wholly yellow, as well the pale or border of leaues, as the middle thrummes: the rootes are ≈øomewhat tough and long.

div.head: 3. Buphthalmum vulgare. Common Oxe eye.
div.p: This Oxe eye ri≈øeth vp with hard round ≈øtalkes, a foote and a halfe high, hauing many winged leaues vpon them, made of diuers long and ≈øomething broad leaues, ≈ønipt about the edges, ≈øet together ≈øomewhat like vnto Tan≈øie, but ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo much winged: the flowers ≈øtand at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, of a full yellow colour, both the outer leaues and the middle thrum, and not altogether ≈øo large as the la≈øt: the rootes of this kinde peri≈øh euery yeare, and require a new ≈øowing againe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in diuers places of Au≈øtria, Bohemia, and tho≈øe parts, it hath beene likewi≈øe brought out of Spaine. The ≈øecond in Prouence, a country in France. The la≈øt in diuers places, as well of Au≈øtria as Morauia, and about Mentz and Norimberg, as Clu≈øius ≈øetteth downe. We haue them in our Gardens, but the fir≈øt is of the greate≈øt re≈øpect and beauty.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth betimes, oftentimes in March, or at the furthe≈øt in Apill; the ≈øeede is ripe in May, and mu≈øt be quickly gathered, le≈øt it bee lo≈øt. The other two flower not vntill Iune.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is called Buphthalmum of Dodonaeus, P≈øeudohelleborus of Matthiolus, Helleborus niger ferulaceus Theophrasti by Lobel, of ≈øome others Elleborus niger verus, v≈øing it for the true blacke Ellebor, but it is much differing, as well in face as properties. Of others Se≈øamoides minus. Some haue thought it to be a yellow Anemone, that haue looked on it without further iudgement, and by that name is mo≈øt v≈øually knowne to mo≈øt of our Engli≈øh Gentlewomen that know it. But it may mo≈øt fitly be called a Buphthalmum, as Dodonaeus doth, and Hi≈øpanicum or Au≈øtriacum, for di≈øtinctions ≈øake. We doe mo≈øt v≈øually call it Helleborus niger ferulaceus, as Lobel doth: Bauhinus
calleth it Helleborus niger tenuifolius Buphthalmi flore. The ≈øecond is called Buphthalmum Narbonen≈øe: In Engli≈øh, The French, or le≈ø≈øer Oxe eye, as the fir≈øt is called, The Great Oxe eye. The la≈øt, The common Oxe eye.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The fir≈øt hath been v≈øed in diuers places for the true blacke Ellebor, but now is ≈øufficiently knowne to haue been an errour; but what Phy≈øicall property it hath, other then Matthiolus hath expre≈ø≈øed, to be v≈øed as Setterwort for cattell, when they rowell them, to put or draw the rootes hereof through the hole they make in the dewe lappe, or other places, for their coughes or other di≈øea≈øes, I know not, or haue heard or read of any. The others likewi≈øe haue little or no v≈øe in Phy≈øicke now a dayes that I know.

div.head: Chry≈øanthemum. Corne Marigold.
div.p: ALthough the ≈øorts of Corne Marigolds, which are many, are fitter for another then this worke, and for a Catholicke Garden of Simples, then this of Plea≈øure and Delight for faire Flowers: yet giue me leaue to bring in a couple: the one for a corner or by-place, the other for your choi≈øe≈øt, or vnder a defenced wall, in regard of his ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe.

div.head: 1. Chry≈øanthemum Creticum. Corne Marigold of Candy.
div.p: This faire Corne Marigold hath for the mo≈øt part one vpright ≈øtalke, two foote high, whereon are ≈øet many winged leaues, at euery ioynt one, diuided and cut into diuers parts, and they againe parted into ≈øeuerall peeces or leaues: the flowers growe at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, ri≈øing out of a ≈øcaly head, compo≈øed of ten or twelue large leaues, of a faire, but pale yellow colour, and more pale almo≈øt white at the bottome of the leaues, round about the yellow thrumme in the middle, being both larger and ≈øweeter then any of the other Corne Marigolds: the ≈øeede is whiti≈øh and chaffie: the roote peri≈øheth euery yeare.

div.head: 2. Chry≈øanthemum Per√ºuianum, ≈øiue Flos Solis. The golden flower of Peru, or the Flower of the Sunne.
div.p:
This goodly and ≈øtately plant, wherewith euery one is now adayes familiar, being of many ≈øorts, both higher and lower (with one ≈øtalke, without branches, or with many branches, with a blacke, or with a white ≈øeede, yet differing not in forme of leaues or flowers one from another, but in the greatne≈ø≈øe or ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe) ri≈øeth vp at the fir≈øt like vnto a Pompion with two leaues, and after two, or foure more leaues are come forth, it ri≈øeth vp into a great ≈øtalke, bearing the leaues on it at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances on all ≈øides thereof, one aboue another vnto the very toppe, being ≈øometimes, and in ≈øome places, ≈øeuen, eight, or ten foote high, which leaues ≈øtanding out from the ≈øtemme or ≈øtalke vpon their ≈øeuerall great ribbed foote-≈øtalkes, are very large, broad belowe, and pointed at the end, round, hard, rough, of a ≈øad greene colour, and bending downewards: at the topped of the ≈øtalke ≈øtandeth one great, large, and broad flower, bowing downe the head vnto the Sunne, and breaking forth from a great head, made of ≈øcaly greene leaues, like vnto a great ≈øingle Marigold, hauing a border of manie long yellow leaues, ≈øet about a great round yellow thrumme, as it were in the middle, which are very like vnto ≈øhort heads of flowers, vnder euery one whereof there is a ≈øeede, larger then any ≈øeede of the Thi≈øtles, yet ≈øomewhat like, and le≈ø≈øer, and rounder then any Gourd ≈øeede, ≈øet in ≈øo clo≈øe and curious a manner, that when the ≈øeede is taken out, the head with the hollow places or cels thereof, ≈øeemeth very like vnto an hony combe; which ≈øeede is in ≈øome plants very blacke, in the hotter countries, or very
white, and great, or large, but with vs is neither ≈øo large, blacke, or white; but ≈øometimes blacki≈øh or grayi≈øh. Some ≈øort ri≈øeth not vp halfe the height that others doe, and ≈øome againe beare but one ≈øtemme or ≈øtalke, with a flower at the toppe thereof; and others two or three, or more ≈ømall branches, with euery one his flower at the end; and ≈øome ≈øo full of branches from the very ground almo≈øt, that I haue accounted three≈øcore branches round about the middle ≈øtalke of one plant, the lowe≈øt neare two yards long, others aboue them a yard and a halfe, or a yard long, with euery one his flower thereon; but all ≈ømaller then tho≈øe that beare but one or two flowers, and le≈ø≈øer al≈øo for the mo≈øt part then the flower on the middle ≈øtalke it ≈øelfe. The whole plant, and euery part thereof aboue ground hath a ≈øtrong re≈øinous ≈øent of Turpentine, and the heads and middle parts of the flowers doe oftentimes (and ≈øometimes the ioynts of the ≈øtalke where the leaues ≈øtand) ≈øweat out a mo≈øt fine thin & cleare Ro≈ø≈øin or Turpentine, but in ≈ømall quantity, and as it were in drops, in the heate and dry time of the year, ≈øo like both in colour, ≈ømell, and ta≈øte vnto cleare Venice Turpentine, that it cannot be knowne from it: the roote is ≈øtrongly fa≈øtened in the ground by ≈øome greater roots branching out, and a number of ≈ømall ≈øtrings, which growe not deepe, but keepe vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the earth, and de≈øireth much moi≈øture, yet dyeth euery yeare with the fir≈øt fro≈øts, and mu≈øt be new ≈øowne in the beginning of the Spring.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Their places are ≈øet downe in their titles, the one to come out of Candy, the other out of Peru, a Prouince in the We≈øt Indies.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth in Iune, the other later, as not vntill Augu≈øt, and ≈øometimes ≈øo late, that the early fro≈øts taking it, neuer ≈øuffer it to come to ripene≈øs.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt hath his name in his title. The ≈øecond, be≈øides the names ≈øet downe, is called of ≈øome Planta maxima, Flos Maximus, Sol Indianus, but the mo≈øt v≈øuall with vs is, Flos Solis: In Engli≈øh, The Sunne Flower, or Flower of the Sunne.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is no v≈øe of either in Phy≈øicke with vs, but that ≈øometimes the heads of the Sunne Flower are dre≈ø≈øed, and eaten as Hartichokes are, and are accounted of ≈øome to be good meate, but they are too ≈øtrong for my ta≈øte.

div.head: Calendula. Marigolds.
div.p: SOme haue reckoned vp many ≈øorts of Marigolds, I had rather make but two, the ≈øingle and the double; for doubtle≈ø≈øe, tho≈øe that be mo≈øt double, ri≈øe from the be≈øt ≈øeede, which are the middlemo≈øt of the great double, and ≈øome will be le≈ø≈øe double, who≈øe ≈øeede is greater then the re≈øt, according to the ground where it groweth; as al≈øo tho≈øe that be of a paler colour, doe come of the ≈øeed of the yellower ≈øort.

div.head: 1. Calendula maxima. The great Garden Marigold.
div.p:
The Garden Marigold hath round greene ≈øtalkes, branching out from the ground into many parts, whereon are ≈øet long flat greene leaues, broader and rounder at the
1 Chry≈øanthemum Creticum. Corne Marigolds of Candy. 2 Flos Solis. The Flower of the Sunne. 3 Calendula. Marigolds. 4 A
‚Ä¢ ter Atticus ≈øiue Italorum. The purple Marigold. 5 Pilo≈ø ‚Ä¢ lla maior. Golden Mou≈øe-eare. 6 Scor≈øonera Hi≈øpanica. Spani≈øh Vipers gra≈ø≈øe. 7 Tragopogon. Goates beard, or goe to bed at noone. depiction of flowers
point then any where el≈øe, and ≈ømaller al≈øo at the ≈øetting to of the ≈øtalke, where it compa≈ø≈øeth it about: the flowers are ≈øometimes very thicke and double (breaking out of a ≈øcaly clammy greene head) compo≈øed of many rowes of leaues, ≈øet ≈øo clo≈øe together one within another, that no middle thrume can bee ≈øeene, and ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øe double, hauing a ≈ømall browne ≈øpot of a thrume in the middle: and ≈øometimes but of two or three rowes of leaues, with a large browne thrume in the middle; euery one whereof is ≈øomewhat broader at the point, and nicked into two or three corners, of an excellent faire deepe gold yellow colour in ≈øome, and paler in others, and of a pretty ≈øtrong and re≈øinous ≈øweete ≈øent: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there ≈øucceede heads of crooked ≈øeede, turning inward, the outermo≈øt bigge≈øt, and the innermo≈øt lea≈øt: the roote is white, and ≈øpreadeth in the ground, and in ≈øome places will abide after the ≈øeeding, but for the mo≈øt part peri≈øheth, and ri≈øeth againe of his owne feede. Sometimes this Marigold doth degenerate, and beareth many ≈ømall flowers vpon ≈øhort ≈øtalkes, compa≈ø≈øing the middle flower: but this happeneth but ≈øeldome, and therefore accounted but lu≈øus naturae, a play of nature, which ≈øhe worketh in diuers other plants be≈øides.

div.head: 2. Calendula ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle Marigold.
div.p: There is no difference betweene this and the former, but that the flowers are ≈øingle, con≈øi≈øting of one rowe of leaues, of the ≈øame colour; eyther paler or deeper yellow, ≈øtanding about a great browne thrumme in the middle: the ≈øeed likewi≈øe is alike, but for the mo≈øt part greater then in the double kindes.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Our Gardens are the chiefe places for the double flowers to grow in; for we know not of any other naturall place: but the ≈øingle kinde hath beene found wilde in Spaine, from whence I received ≈øeede, gathered by Guillaume Boel, in his time a very curious, and cunning ≈øearcher of ≈øimples.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower all the ≈øummer long, and ≈øometimes euen in winter, if it be milde, and chiefly at the beginning of tho≈øe monethes, as it is thought.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called Caltha of diuers, and taken to be that Caltha, wherof both Virgil and Columella haue written. Others doe call them Calendula, of the Kalendes, that is the fir≈øt day of the monthes, wherein they are thought chiefly to flower; and thereupon the Italians call them, Fiori di ogni me≈øe, that is, The Flowers of euery moneth: We cal them in Engli≈øh generally, eyther Golds, or Marigolds.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The herbe and flowers are of great v≈øe with vs among other pot-herbes; and the flowers eyther greene or dryed, are often v≈øed in po≈ø≈øets, broths, and drinkes, as a comforter of the heart and ≈øpirits, and to expel any malignant or pe≈øtilential quality, gathered neere thereunto. The Syrupe and Con≈øerue made of the fre≈øh flowers, are v≈øed for the ≈øame purpo≈øes to good effect.

div.head: Aster. Starre-wort.
div.p: DIo≈øcorides and other of the ancient Writers, haue ≈øet forth but one kinde of Starre-wort, which they call Aster Atticus, of the place no doubt, where the greate≈øt plentie was found, which was the Countrey of Athens: the later Writers haue found out many other plants which they referre to this kinde, calling them by the ≈øame name. It is not my purpo≈øe to entreate of them all, neyther doth this garden fitly agree with them: I ≈øhall therefore ≈øelect out one or two from the re≈øt, and giue you the knowledge of them, leauing the re≈øt to their proper place.

div.head: 1. Aster Atticus flore luteo. Yellow Starre-wort.
div.p: This Starre-wort ri≈øeth vp with two or three rough hairy ≈øtalkes, a foote and a halfe high, with long, rough or hairie, browni≈øh, darke greene leaues on them, diuided into two or three branches: at the toppe of euery one whereof ≈øtandeth a flat ≈øcaly head, compa≈ø≈øed vnderneath with fiue or ≈øixe long, browne, rough greene leaues, ≈øtanding like a Starre, the flower it ≈øelfe ≈øtanding in the middle thereof, made as a border of narrow, long, pale yellow leaues, ≈øet with a browni≈øh yellow thrume: the roote dyeth euery yeare, hauing giuen his flower.

div.head: 2. A≈øter Atticus Italorum flore purpureo. Purple Italian Starre-wort.
div.p: This Italian Starre-wort hath many wooddy, round brittle ≈øtalkes, ri≈øing from the roote, ≈øomewhat higher then the former, ≈øometimes ≈øtanding vpright, and otherwhiles leaning downewards, whereon are ≈øet many ≈øomewhat hard, and rough long leaues, round pointed, without order vp to the toppe, where it is diuided into ≈øeuerall branches, whereon ≈øtand the flowers, made like vnto a ≈øingle Marigold, with a border of blewi≈øh purple leaues, ≈øet about a browne middle thrume, the heads ≈øu≈øtaining the flowers, are compo≈øed of diuers ≈øcaly greene leaues, as is to be ≈øeene in the Knapweedes or Matfelons, which after the flowers are pa≈øt yeelde a certaine downe, wherein lye ≈ømall blacke and flat ≈øeedes, ≈øomewhat like vnto Lettice ≈øeede, which are carried away with the winde: the roote is compo≈øed of many white ≈øtrings, which peri≈øheth not as the former, but abideth, and ≈øpringeth afre≈øh euery yeare.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is found in Spaine, as Clu≈øius, and in France, as Lobel ≈øay. The other hath beene found in many places in Germany, and Au≈øtria: in Italie al≈øo, and other places; we haue it plentifully in our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth in Summer. And the other not vntill Augu≈øt or September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is called A≈øter Atticus flore luteo, Buhonium, & Inguinalis, and of many is taken to be the true A≈øter Atticus of Dio≈øcorides: yet Matthiolus thinketh not ≈øo, for diuers good rea≈øons, which hee ≈øetteth downe in the Chapter of A≈øter Atticus, as any man may vnder≈øtand, if they will but reade the place, which is too long to bee in≈øerted here. The other is thought by Matthiolus, to bee the truer A≈øter Atticus, (vnto whom I mu≈øt al≈øo con≈øent) and con≈øtantly al≈øo affirmed to be the Amellus Virgilij, as may be ≈øeene in the ≈øame place: but it is v≈øually called at this day, A≈øter Italorum flore caeruleo or
purpureo. Their Engli≈øh names are ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in their titles, yet ≈øome call the la≈øt, The purple Marigold, becau≈øe it is ≈øo like vnto one in form.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: They are held, if they bee the right, to bee good for the biting of a mad dogge, the greene herbe being beaten with old hogs grea≈øe, and applyed; as al≈øo for ≈øwolne throats: It is likewi≈øe v≈øed for botches that happen in the groine, as the name doth import.

div.head: Pilo≈øella maior. Golden Mou≈øe-eare.
div.p: SOme re≈øemblance that the flowers of this plant hath with the former Golds, maketh me to in≈øert it in this place, although I know it agreeth not in any other part, yet for the plea≈øant a≈øpect thereof, it mu≈øt bee in this my garden, who≈øe de≈øcription is as followeth: It hath many broade greene leaues ≈øpread vpon the ground, ≈øpotted with pale ≈øpots, yet more con≈øpicuous at ≈øometimes then at other; ≈øomewhat hairy both on the vpper and vnder≈øide, in the middle of the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp one, two or more blacki≈øh hairy ≈øtalkes, two foote high at the lea≈øt, bare or naked vp to the top, where it beareth an vmbell, or ≈øhort tuft of flowers, ≈øet clo≈øe together vpon ≈øhort ≈øtalkes, of the forme or fa≈øhion of the Haukeweedes, or common Mou≈øe-eare, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, of a deep gold yellow, or orenge tawney colour, with ≈øome yellow threds in the middle, of little or no ≈øent at all: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the heads carry ≈ømall, ≈øhort, blacke ≈øeede, with a light downie matter on them, ready to bee carried away with the winde, as many other plants are, when they be ripe: the rootes ≈øpread vnder ground, and ≈øhoote vp in diuers other places, whereby it much encrea≈øeth, e≈øpecially if it be ≈øet in any moi≈øt or ≈øhadowie place.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It groweth in the ≈øhadowie woods of France, by Lions, and Mompelier, as Lobell te≈øtifieth: we keepe it in our gardens, and rather in a ≈øhadowie then ≈øunnie place.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Somer, and ≈øometimes againe in September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called by Lobell, Pulmonaria Gallorum Hieratij facie: and the Herbari≈øts of France take it to be the true Pulmonaria of Tragus. Others call it Hieratium flore aureo. Pelleterius Hieratium Indicum. Some Pilo≈øella, or Auricula muris maior flore aureo. And ≈øome Chondrilla flore aureo. Dalechamptus would haue it to bee Corchorus, but farre vnfitly. The fitte≈øt Engli≈øh name we can giue it, is Golden Mou≈øe-eare, which may endure vntill a fitter bee impo≈øed on it: for the name of Grim the Collier, whereby it is called of many is both idle and fooli≈øh.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The French according to the name v≈øe it for the defects of the lunges, but with what good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe I know not.

div.head: Scor≈øonera. Vipers gra≈ø≈øe.
div.p: ALthough there be foure or fiue ≈øorts of Scor≈øonera, yet I ≈øhall here de≈øire you to be con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t with the knowledge only of a couple.

div.head: 1. Scor≈øonera Hi≈øpanica maior. The greater Spani≈øh Vipers gra≈ø≈øe.
div.p: This Spani≈øh Vipers gra≈ø≈øe hath diuers long, and ≈øomewhat broad leaues, hard and crumpled on the edges, and ≈øometimes vneuenly cut in or indented al≈øo, of a blewi≈øh greene colour: among which ri≈øeth vp one ≈øtalke, and no more for the mo≈øt part, two foote high or thereabouts, hauing here and there ≈øome narrower long leaues thereon then tho≈øe below: the toppe of the ≈øtalke brancheth it ≈øelfe forth into other parts, euery one bearing a long ≈øcaly head, from out of the toppe whereof ri≈øeth a faire large double flower, of a pale yellow colour, much like vnto the flower of yellow Goates beard, but a little le≈ø≈øer, which being pa≈øt, the ≈øeede ≈øucceedeth, being long, whiti≈øh and rough, inclo≈øed with much downe, and among them many other long ≈ømooth ≈øeedes, which are limber and idle, and are carryed away at the will of the winde: the roote is long, thicke and round, brittle and blacke, with a certaine roughne≈ø≈øe on the out≈øide: but very white within, yeelding a milkie liquor being broken, as euery other part of the plant doth be≈øides, yet the roote more then any other part, and abideth many yeares without peri≈øhing.

div.head: 2. Scor≈øonera Pannonica purpurea. Purple flowred Vipers gra≈ø≈øe.
div.p: This purple flowred Vipers gra≈ø≈øe hath long and narrow leaues, of the ≈øame blewi≈øh greene colour with the former: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp a foote and a halfe high, with a few ≈øuch like leaues, but ≈øhorter thereon, breaking at the toppe into two or three parts, bearing on each of them one flower, fa≈øhioned like the former, and ≈øtanding in the like ≈øcaly knoppe or head, but of a blewi≈øh purple colour, not fully ≈øo large, of the ≈øweete≈øt ≈øent of any of this kinde, comming neere≈øt vnto the ≈ømell of a delicate perfume.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is of Spaine. The other of Hungarie and Au≈øtrich: which now furni≈øh our gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in the beginning of May: the ≈øeede is ≈øoone ripe after, and then peri≈øhing downe to the roote for that yeare, ≈øpringeth afre≈øh before Winter againe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called after the Spani≈øh name Scor≈øonera, which is in Latine Viperaria, of ≈øome Viperina, and Serpentina: Wee call them in Engli≈øh Vipers gra≈ø≈øe, or Scor≈øonera.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Manardus as I thinke fir≈øt wrote hereof, and ≈øaith that it hath been found to cure them that are bitten of a Viper, or other ≈øuch like venemous Creature. The rootes hereof being pre≈øerued with ≈øugar, as I haue done often, doe eate almo≈øt as delicate as the Eringus roote, and no doubt is good to comforr and ≈øtrengthen the heart, and vitall ≈øpirits. Some that haue v≈øed the pre≈øerued roote haue found it effectuall to expelling winde out of the ≈øtomacke, and to helpe ≈øwounings and faintne≈ø≈øe of the heart.

div.head: Tragopogon. Goates beard.
div.p: I Mu≈øt in this place ≈øet downe but two ≈øorts of Goates beards; the one blew or a≈øh-colour, the other red or purple, and leaue the other kindes: ≈øome to bee ≈øpoken of in the Kitchin Garden, and others in a Phy≈øicall Garden.

div.head: 1. Tragopogon flore caeruleo. Blew Goates beard.
div.p: All the Goates beards haue long, narrow, and ≈øomewhat hollow whiti≈øh greene leaues, with a white line downe the middle of euery one on the vpper≈øide: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp greater and ≈øtronger then the Vipers gra≈ø≈øe, bearing at the toppe a great long head or huske, compo≈øed of nine or ten long narrow leaues, the ≈øharpe points or ends whereof ri≈øe vp aboue the flower in the middle, which is thicke and double, ≈øomewhat broad and large ≈øpread, of a blewi≈øh a≈øh-colour, with ≈øome whiti≈øh threads among them, ≈øhutting or clo≈øing it ≈øelfe within the greene huske euery day, that it abideth blowing, vntill about noone, and opening not it ≈øelfe againe vntill the next morning: the head or huske, after the flower is pa≈øt, and the ≈øeede neare ripe, openeth it ≈øelfe; the long leaues thereof, which clo≈øed not before now, falling downe round about the ≈øtalke, and ≈øhewing the ≈øeede, ≈øtanding at the fir≈øt clo≈øe together, and the doune at the toppe of them: but after they haue ≈øtood a while, it ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe round, and is ready to be carried away with the winde, if it be not gathered: the ≈øeede it ≈øelfe is long, round, and rough, like the ≈øeede of the Vipers gra≈ø≈øe, but greater and blacker: the roote is long, and not very great, but peri≈øheth as ≈øoone as it hath borne ≈øeede, and ≈øpringeth of the fallen ≈øeede, that yeare remaining greene all Winter, and flowring the next yeare following: the whole yeeldeth milke as the former, but ≈øomewhat more bitter and binding.

div.head: 2. Tragopogon purpureum. Purple Goates beard.
div.p: There is little difference in this kind from the former, but that it is a little larger, both in the leafe, and head that beareth the ≈øeed: the flowers al≈øo are a little larger, and ≈øpread more, of a darke reddi≈øh purple colour, with ≈øome yellow du≈øt as it were ca≈øt vpon it, e≈øpecially about the ends: the roote peri≈øheth in the like manner as the other.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Both the≈øe haue been ≈øent vs from the parts beyond the Seas, I haue had them from Italy, where no doubt they grow naturally wilde, as the yellow doth with vs: they are kept in our Gardens for their plea≈øant flowers.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in May and Iune: the ≈øeede is ripe in Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their generall name is after the Greeke word Tragopogon, which is in Latine, Barbahirti: In Engli≈øh, Goates beard; the head of ≈øeede when it is readie to bee carried away with the winde, cau≈øing that name for the re≈øemblance: and becau≈øe the flower doth euery day clo≈øe it ≈øelfe at noone (as I ≈øaid before) and openeth not againe vntill the next Sunne, ≈øome haue fitly called it, Goe to bed at noone.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
The rootes of the≈øe kindes are a little more bitter and more binding al≈øo
then the yellow kinde expre≈ø≈øed in the Kitchin Garden; and therefore fitter for medicine then for meate, but yet is v≈øed as the yellow kinde is, which is more fit for meate then medicine. The di≈øtilled water is good to wa≈øh old ≈øores and wounds.

div.head: Flos Africanus. The French Marigold.
div.p: OF the French or African Marigolds there are three kindes as principall, and of each of them both with ≈øingle and double flowers: of the≈øe, ≈øome diuer≈øity is ob≈øerued in the colour of the flowers, as well as in the forme or largene≈ø≈øe, ≈øo that as you may here ≈øee, I haue expre≈ø≈øed eight differences, and Fabius Columna nine or ten, in regard hee maketh a diuer≈øity of the paler and deeper yellow colour: and although the le≈ø≈øer kinde, becau≈øe of its euill ≈øent, is held dangerous, yet for the beauty of the flower it findeth roome in Gardens.

div.head: 1. Flos Africanus maior ≈øiue maximus multiplex. The great double French Marigold.
div.p: This goodly double flower, which is the grace and glory of a Garden in the time of his beauty, ri≈øeth vp with a ≈øtraight and hard round greene ≈øtalke, hauing ≈øome cre≈øts or edges all along the ≈øtalke, be≈øet with long winged leaues, euery one whereof is like vnto the leafe of an A≈øh, being compo≈øed of many long and narrow leaues, ≈ønipt about the edges, ≈øtanding by couples one again≈øt another, with an odde one at the end, of a darke or full greene colour: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth to be three or foure foote high, and diuideth it ≈øelfe from the middle thereof into many branches, ≈øet with ≈øuch like leaues to the toppes of them, euery one bearing one great double flower, of a gold yellow colour aboue, and paler vnderneath, yet ≈øome are of a pale yellow, and ≈øome betweene both and all the≈øe ri≈øing from one and the ≈øame ≈øeede: the flower, before it be blowne open, hath all the leaues hollow; but when it is full blowne open, it ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe larger then any Prouince Ro≈øe, or equall vnto it at the lea≈øt, if it be in good earth, and ri≈øeth out of a long greene huske, ≈øtriped or furrowed, wherein after the flower is pa≈øt, (which ≈øtandeth in his full beauty a moneth, and oftentimes more, and being gathered, may be pre≈øerued in his full beauty for two moneths after, if it be ≈øet in water) ≈øtandeth the ≈øeede, ≈øet thicke and clo≈øe together vpright, which is blacke, ≈øomewhat flat and long: the roote is full of ≈ømall ≈øtrings, whereby it ≈øtrongly comprehendeth in the ground: the flower of this, as well as the ≈øingle, is of the very ≈ømell of new waxe, or of an honie combe, and not of that poi≈øonfull ≈øent of the ≈ømaller kindes.

div.head: 2. Flos Africanus maior ≈øimplex. The great ≈øingle French Marigold.
div.p: This ≈øingle Marigold is in all things ≈øo like vnto the former, that it is hard to di≈øcerne it from the double, but by the flowers, onely the ≈øtalke will be browner then the double; and to my be≈øt ob≈øeruation, hath and doth euery yeare ri≈øe from the ≈øeede of the double flower: ≈øo that when they are in flower, you may ≈øee the difference (or not much before, when they are in bud) this ≈øingle flower euer appearing with thrums in the middle, and the leaues, which are the border or pale ≈øtanding about them, ≈øhewing hollow or fi≈øtulous, which after lay them≈øelues flat and open (and the double flower appearing with all his leaues folded clo≈øe together, without any thrum at all) and are of a deeper or paler colour, as in the double.

div.head: 3. Flos Africanus fistulo≈øo flore ≈øimplex & multiplex. Single and double French Marigolds with hollow leafed flowers.
div.p:
As the former two greate≈øt ≈øorts haue ri≈øen from the ≈øeede of one and the ≈øame (I
meane the pod of double flowers) ≈øo doe the≈øe al≈øo, not differing from it in any thing, but that they are lower, and haue ≈ømaller greene leaues, and that the flower al≈øo being ≈ømaller, hath euery leafe abiding hollow, like vnto an hollow pipe, broad open at the mouth, and is of as deepe a yellow colour for the mo≈øt part as the deepe≈øt of the former, yet ≈øometimes pale al≈øo.

div.head: 4. Flos Africanus minor multiplex. The le≈ø≈øer double French Marigold.
div.p: The le≈ø≈øer double French Marigold hath his leaues in all things like vnto the former, but ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer, which are ≈øet vpon round browne ≈øtalkes, not ≈øo ≈øtiffe or vpright, but bowing and bending diuers wayes, and ≈øometimes leaning or lying vpon the ground: the ≈øtalkes are branched out diuer≈øly, whereon are ≈øet very faire double flowers like the former, and in the like greene huskes, but ≈ømaller, and in ≈øome the outermo≈øt leaues will be larger then any of the re≈øt, and of a deeper Orenge colour, almo≈øt crim≈øon, the innermo≈øt being of a deepe gold yellow colour, tending to crim≈øon: the whole flower is ≈ømaller, and of a ≈øtronger and more vnplea≈øant ≈øauour, ≈øo that but for the beautifull colour, and doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower, plea≈øant to the eye, and not to any other ≈øen≈øe, this kinde would finde roome in few Gardens: the rootes and ≈øeedes are like the former, but le≈ø≈øer.

div.head: 5. Flos Africanus minor ≈øimplex. The ≈ømall ≈øingle French Marigold.
div.p: This ≈øingle kinde doth follow after the la≈øt in all manner of proportion, both of ≈øtalkes, leaues, ≈øeedes, and rootes: the flowers onely of this are ≈øingle, hauing fiue or ≈øix broad leaues, of a deepe yellow crim≈øon colour, with deepe yellow thrummes in the middle, and of as ≈øtrong a ≈øtinking ≈øent, or more then the la≈øt.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They growe naturally in Africa, and e≈øpecially in the parts about Tunis, and where old Carthage ≈øtood, from whence long agoe they were brought into Europe, where they are onely kept in Gardens, being ≈øowne for the mo≈øt part euery yeare, vnle≈ø≈øe in ≈øome milde Winters. The la≈øt ≈øingle and double kindes (as being more hardy) haue ≈øometimes endured: but that kinde with hollow leafed flowers, as Fabius Columna ≈øetteth it downe, is accounted to come from Mexico in America.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower not vntill the end of Summer, e≈øpecially the greater kindes: but the le≈ø≈øer, if they abide all the Winter, doe flower more early.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue been diuer≈øly named by diuers men: Some calling them Caryophyllus Indicus, that is, Indian Gilloflowers, and Tanacetum Per√ºvianum, Tan≈øie of Peru, as if it grew in Peru, a Prouince of America; and Flos Indicus, as a flower of the Indies; but it hath not beene knowne to haue beene brought from thence. Others would haue it to be Othonna of Plinie, and others; ≈øome to be Lycoper≈øicum of Galen. It is called, and that more truely, Flos Tuneten≈øis, Flos Africanus, and Caltha Africana, that is, the flower of Tunis, the flower of Africa, the Marigold of Africa, and peraduenture Pedna Paenorum. We in Engli≈øh mo≈øt v≈øually call them, French Marigolds, with their ≈øeuerall di≈øtinctions of greater or ≈ømaller, double or ≈øingle. To that with hollow leafed flowers, Fabius Columna giueth the name of Fi≈øtilu≈øo flore, and I ≈øo continue it.
