div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We know no v≈øe they haue in Phy≈øicke, but are cheri≈øhed in Gardens for their beautifull flowers ≈øake.

div.head: Caryophyllus horten≈øis. Carnations and Gilloflowers.
div.p: TO auoide confu≈øion, I mu≈øt diuide Gilloflowers from Pinkes, and intreate of them in ≈øeuerall Chapters. Of tho≈øe that are called Carnations or Gilloflowers, as of the greater kinde, in this Chapter; and of Pinkes, as well double as ≈øingle, in the next. But the number of them is ≈øo great, that to giue ≈øeuerall de≈øcriptions to them all were endle≈ø≈øe, at the lea≈øt needle≈ø≈øe: I will therefore ≈øet downe onely the de≈øcriptions of three (for vnto the≈øe three may be referred all the other ≈øorts) for their fa≈øhion and manner of growing, and giue you the ≈øeuerall names (as they are v≈øually called with vs) of the re≈øt, with their variety and mixture of colours in the flowers, wherein con≈øi≈øteth a chiefe difference. I account tho≈øe that are called Carnations to be the greate≈øt, both for leafe and flower, and Gilloflowers for the mo≈øt part to bee le≈ø≈øer in both; and therefore will giue you each de≈øcription apart, and the Orenge tawnie or yellow Gilloflower likewi≈øe by it ≈øelfe, as differing very notably from all the re≈øt.

div.head: 1. Caryophyllus maximus Harwicen≈øis ≈øiue Anglicus. The great Harwich or old Engli≈øh Carnation.
div.p: I take this goodly great old Engli≈øh Carnation, as a pre≈øident for the de≈øcription of all the re≈øt of the greate≈øt ≈øorts, which for his beauty and ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe is worthy of a prime place, hauing beene alwayes very hardly pre≈øerued in the Winter; and therefore not ≈øo frequent as the other Carnations or Gilloflowers. It ri≈øeth vp with a great thicke round ≈øtalke, diuided into ≈øeuerall branches, ≈øomewhat thickly ≈øet with ioynts, and at euery ioynt two long greene rather then whiti≈øh leaues, ≈øomewhat broader then Gilloflower leaues, turning or winding two or three times round (in ≈øome other ≈øorts of Carnations they are plaine, but bending the points downewards, and in ≈øome al≈øo of a darke reddi≈øh greene colour, and in others not ≈øo darke, but rather of a whiti≈øh greene colour:) the flowers ≈øtand at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes in long, great, and round greene huskes, which are diuided into fiue points, out of which ri≈øe many long and broad pointed leaues, deeply iagged at the ends, ≈øet in order round and comely, making a gallant great double flower, of a deepe Carnation colour, almo≈øt red, ≈øpotted with many blu≈øh ≈øpots and ≈øtrakes, ≈øome greater and ≈øome le≈ø≈øer, of an excellent ≈øoft ≈øweete ≈øent, neither too quicke as many others of the≈øe kinds are, nor yet too dull, and with two whiti≈øh crooked threads like hornes in the middle: this kinde neuer beareth many flowers, but as it is ≈ølow in growing, ≈øo in bearing, not to be often handled, which ≈øheweth a kinde of ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe, fit to pre≈øerue the opinion of magnificence: the roote is branched into diuers great, long, wooddy rootes, with many ≈ømall fibres annexed vnto them.

div.head: 2. Caryophyllus horten≈øis flore pleno rubro. The red or Cloue Gilloflower.
div.p:
The red Cloue Gilloflower, which I take as a pre≈øident for the ≈øecond ≈øort, which are Gilloflowers, grow like vnto the Carnations, but not ≈øo thicke ≈øet with ioynts and leaues: the ≈øtalkes are more, the leaues are narrower and whiter for the mo≈øt part, and in ≈øome doe as well a little turne: the flowers are ≈ømaller, yet very thicke and double in mo≈øt, and the greene huskes wherein they ≈øtand are ≈ømaller likewi≈øe then the former: the ends of the leaues in this flower, as in all the re≈øt, are dented or iagged, yet in ≈øome more then in others; ≈øome al≈øo hauing two ≈ømall white threads, crooked at the ends like hornes, in the middle of the flower, when as diuers other haue none. The≈øe
1 Caryophyllus maximus rubro varius. The great old Carnation or gray Hulo. 2 Caryophyllus maior rubro & albo varius. The white Carnation. 3 Caryophyllus albo rubeus. The Camber≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or the Poole flower. 4 Caryophyllus C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tij ≈øtriatus. The faire made of Kent. 5 Caryophyllus Saba ‚Ä¢ dicus carn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The blu≈øh Sauadge. 6 Caryophyllus Xera ‚Ä¢ pelinus. The Gredeline Carnation. 7 Caryophyllus dictus Grimelo. The Grimelo or Prince. 8 Caryophyllus albus maior. The great white Gilloflower. 6 Elegans H ‚Ä¢ roina Brad≈øhawij. Ma≈øter Brad≈øh ‚Ä¢ wes dainty Lady. depiction of flowers
kindes, and e≈øpecially this that hath a deepe red crim≈øon coloured flower, doe endure the cold of our winters, and with le≈ø≈øe care is pre≈øerued: the≈øe ≈øorts as well as the former doe very ≈øeldome giue any ≈øeede, as far as I could euer ob≈øerue or learne.

div.head: 3. Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus flore pleno miniato. The yellow or Orenge tawny Gilloflower.
div.p: This Gilloflower hath his ≈øtalkes next vnto the ground, thicker ≈øet, and with ≈ømaller or narrower leaues then the former for the mo≈øt part: the flowers are like vnto the Cloue Gilloflowers, and about the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe and doublene≈ø≈øe mo≈øt v≈øually, yet in ≈øome much greater then in others; but of a pale yellowi≈øh Carnation colour, tending to an Orenge, with two ≈ømall white threds, crooked at the ends in the middle, yet ≈øome haue none, of a weaker ≈øent then the Cloue Gilloflower: this kinde is more apt to beare ≈øeede then any other, which is ≈ømall, black, flat, and long, and being ≈øowen, yeelde wonderfull varieties both of ≈øingle and double flowers: ≈øome being of a lighter or deeper colour then the mother plants: ≈øome with ≈øtripes in mo≈øt of the leaues: Others are ≈øtriped or ≈øpotted, like a ≈øpeckled Carnation or Gilloflower, in diuers ≈øorts, both ≈øingle and double: Some againe are wholly of the ≈øame colour, like the mother plant, and are eyther more or le≈ø≈øe double then it, or el≈øe are ≈øingle with one row of leaues, like vnto a Pinck; and ≈øome of the≈øe likewi≈øe eyther wholly of a crim≈øon red, deeper or lighter, or variably ≈øpotted, double or ≈øingle as a Pinck, or blu≈øh eyther ≈øingle or double, and but very ≈øeldome white: yet all of them in their greene leaues little or nothing varying or differing.

list.head: Cariophylli maximi. CARNATIONS.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus dictus Hulo rubro-varius.
list.item: THe gray Hulo hath as large leaues as the former old Carnation, and as deepely iagged on the edges: it hath a great high ≈øtalke, whereon ≈øtand the flowers, of a deepe red colour, ≈øtriped and ≈øpeckled very clo≈øe together with a darki≈øh white colour.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus dictus Hulo ruber non variatus.
list.item: The red Hulo is al≈øo a faire great flower, of a ≈øtamell colour, deeply iagged as the former, and groweth very comely without any ≈øpot at all in it, ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth to bee but a ≈øtamell Gilloflower, ≈øaue that it is much greater.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus dictus Hulo caeruleo purpureus.
list.item: The blew Hulo is a goodly faire flower, being of a faire purpli≈øh murrey colour, curiou≈øly marbled with white, but ≈øo ≈ømally to be di≈øcerned, that it ≈øeemeth only purple, it hath ≈øo much the Ma≈øtrie in it; it re≈øembleth the Bra≈ø≈øill, but that it is much bigger.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus dictus Grimelo ≈øiue Princeps.
list.item: The Grimelo or Prince is a faire flower al≈øo, as large as any Chry≈øtall or larger, being of a faire crim≈øon colour, equally for the mo≈øt part ≈øtriped with white, or rather more white then red, thorough euery leafe from the bottome, and ≈øtandeth comely.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Incarnadinus albus.
list.item: The white Carnation or Delicate, is a goodly delightfull fair flower in his pride and perfection, that is, when it is both marbled and flaked, or ≈øtriped and ≈øpeckled with white vpon an incarnate crim≈øon colour, beeing a very comely flower, but abideth not con≈øtant, changing oftentimes to haue no flakes or ≈øtrakes of white, but marbled or ≈øpeckled wholly.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Incarnadinus Gallicus.
list.item: The French Carnation is very like vnto the white Carnation, but that it hath more ≈øpecks, and fewer ≈øtripes or flakes of white in the red, which hath the ma≈øtrie of the white.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Incarnadinus grandi ‚Ä¢ .
list.item:
The ground Carnation (if it be not the ≈øame with the graund or great old Carnation fir≈øt ≈øet downe, as the alteration but of one letter giueth the coniecture) is a thicke flower, but ≈øpreadeth
not his leaues abroade as others doe, hauing the middle ≈øtanding higher then the outer leaues, and turning vp their brimmes or edges; it is a ≈øad flower, with few ≈øtripes or ≈øpots in it: it is very ≈øubiect to breake the pod, that the flower ≈øeldome commeth faire and right; the greene leaues are as great as the Hulo or Lombard red.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Chry≈øtallinus.
list.item: The Chry≈øtall or Chry≈øtalline (for they are both one, how≈øoeuer ≈øome would make them differ) is a very delicate flower when it is well marked, but it is incon≈øtant in the markes, being ≈øometimes more ≈øtriped with white and crim≈øon red, and ≈øometimes le≈ø≈øe or little or nothing at all, and changing al≈øo ≈øometimes to be wholly red, or wholly blu≈øh.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus flore rubro.
list.item: The red Chry≈øtall, which is the red hereof changed, is the mo≈øt orient flower of all other red Gilloflowers, becau≈øe it is both the greate≈øt, as comming from the Chry≈øtall, as al≈øo that the red hereof is a mo≈øt excellent crim≈øon.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus dictus Fragrans.
list.item: The Fragrant is a faire flower, and thought to come from the Chry≈øtall, being as large, but of a blu≈øh red colour, ≈øpotted with ≈ømall ≈øpeckes, no bigger then pinnes points, but not ≈øo thicke as in the Pageant.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Sabaudicus varius.
list.item: The ≈øtript Sauadge is for forme and bigne≈ø≈øe equall with the Chry≈øtall or White Carnation, but as incon≈øtant as eyther of them, changing into red or blu≈øh; ≈øo that few branches with flowers containe their true mixtures, which are a whiti≈øh blu≈øh, fairely ≈øtriped with a crim≈øon red colour, thicke and ≈øhort, with ≈øome ≈øpots al≈øo among.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Sabaudicus carneus.
list.item: The blu≈øh Sauadge is the ≈øame with the former, the ≈øame root of the ≈øtript Sauadge, as I ≈øaid before, yeelding one ≈øide or part who≈øe flowers will be eyther wholly blu≈øh, or hauing ≈øome ≈ømall ≈øpots, or ≈øometimes few or none in them.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Sabaudicus ruber.
list.item: The red Sauadge is as the blu≈øh, when the colour of the flower is wholly red without any ≈øtripes or ≈øpots in them, and ≈øo abideth long; yet it is ≈øometimes ≈øeene, that the ≈øame ≈øide, or part, or roote being ≈øeparate from the fir≈øt or mother plant, will giue ≈øtriped and well marked flowers againe.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Oxonien≈øis.
list.item: The Oxeford Carnation is very like vnto the French Carnation, both for forme, largene≈ø≈øe and colour: but that this is of a ≈øadder red colour, ≈øo finely marbled with white thereon, that the red hauing the mai≈øtry, ≈øheweth a very ≈øad flower, not hauing any flakes or ≈øtripes at all in it.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Regius, ≈øiue Bri≈øtolien≈øis maior.
list.item: The Kings Carnation or ordinary Bri≈øtow, is a rea≈øonable great flower, deepely iagged, of a ≈øad red, very ≈ømally ≈øtriped and ≈øpeckled with white: ≈øome of the leaues of the flower on the one ≈øide will turne vp their brimmes or edges: the greene leafe is very large.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Granaten≈øis.
list.item: The greate≈øt Granado is a very faire large flower, bigger then the Chry≈øtall, and almo≈øt as bigge as the blew Hulo: it is almo≈øt equally diuided and ≈øtript with purple and white, but the purple is ≈øadder then in the ordinary Granado Gilloflower, el≈øe it might bee ≈øaid it were the ≈øame, but greater. Diuers haue taken this flower to bee the Gran Pere, but you ≈øhall haue the difference ≈øhewed you in the next en≈øuing flower.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Gran Pere dictus.
list.item: The Gran Pere is a fair great flower, and comely for the forme, but of no great beautie for colour, becau≈øe although it be ≈øtript red and white like the Queenes Gilloflower, yet the red is ≈øo ≈øad that it taketh away all the delight to the flower.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Camber≈øine dictus.
list.item:
The Camber≈øine is a great flower and a faire, beeing a redde flower, well marked or ≈øtriped with white, ≈øomewhat like vnto a
Sauadge, ≈øay ≈øome, but that the red is not crim≈øon as the Sauadge; others ≈øay the Daintie, but not ≈øo comely: the leaues of the flowers are many, and thru≈øt together, without any due forme of ≈øpreading.
list.label: Caryophyllus maximus Longobardicus ruber.
list.item: The great Lombard red is a great ≈øad red flower, ≈øo double and thick of leaues, that it mo≈øt v≈øually breaketh the pod, and ≈øeldome ≈øheweth one flower among twenty perfect: the blades or greene leaues are as large as the Hulo.

list.head: Caryophylli majores. GILLOFLOWERS.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior We≈øtmin≈øterien≈øis.
list.item: THe lu≈øtie Gallant or We≈øtmin≈øter (≈øome make them to be one flower, and others to bee two, one bigger then the other) at the fir≈øt blowing open of the flower ≈øheweth to be of a rea≈øonable ≈øize and comeline≈ø≈øe, but after it hath ≈øtood blowen ≈øome time it ≈øheweth ≈ømaller and thinner: it is of a bright red colour, much ≈øtriped and ≈øpeckled with white.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Bri≈øtolien≈øis purpureus.
list.item: The Bri≈øtow blew hath greene leaues, ≈øo large, that it would ≈øeeme to bring a greater flower then it doth, yet the flower is of a rea≈øonable ≈øize, and very like vnto the ordinary Granado Gilloflower, ≈øtriped and flaked in the ≈øame manner, but that the white of this is purer then that, and the purple is more light, and tending to a blew: this doth not abide con≈øtant, but changeth into purple or blu≈øh.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Bri≈øtolien≈øis carneus.
list.item: The Bri≈øtow blu≈øh is very like the la≈øt both in leafe and flower, the colour only ≈øheweth the difference, which ≈øeldome varyeth to be ≈øpotted, or change colour.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Dorobornien≈øis ruber.
list.item: The red Douer is a rea≈øonable great Gilloflower and con≈øtant, being of a faire red thicke poudered with white ≈øpots, and ≈øeemeth ≈øomewhat like vnto the ground Carnation.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Dorobornien≈øis dil ‚Ä¢ tus ≈øiue albus.
list.item: The light or white Douer is for forme and all other things more comely then the former, the colour of the flower is blu≈øh, thicke ≈øpotted with very ≈ømall ≈øpots, that it ≈øeemeth all gray, and is very delightfull.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Cantii.
list.item: The faire maide of Kent, or Ruffling Robin is a very beautiful flower, and as large as the white Carnation almo≈øt: the flower is white, thicke poudered with purple, wherein the white hath the ma≈øtrie by much, which maketh it the more plea≈øant.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Regineus.
list.item: The Queenes Gilloflower is a rea≈øonable faire Gilloflower although very common, ≈øtriped red and white, ≈øome great and ≈øome ≈ømall with long ≈øtripes.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior elegans.
list.item: The Daintie is a comely fine flower, although it be not great, and for the ≈ømallne≈ø≈øe and thinne≈ø≈øe of the flower being red ≈øo finely marked, ≈øtriped and ≈øpeckled, that for the liueline≈ø≈øe of the colours it is much de≈øired, beeing inferiour to very few Gilloflowers.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior Bra≈øilien≈øis.
list.item: The Bra≈ø≈øill Gilloflower is but of a meane ≈øize, being of a ≈øad purple colour, thicke poudered and ≈øpeckled with white, the purple herein hath the ma≈øtrie, which maketh it ≈øhew the ≈øadder, it is vncon≈øtant, varying much and often to bee all purple: the greene leaues lye matting on the ground.
list.label:
Caryophyllus maior Gran ‚Ä¢
ten≈øis.
list.item: The Granado Gilloflower is purple and white, flaked and ≈øtriped very much: this is al≈øo much ≈øubiect to change purple. There is a greater and a le≈ø≈øer of this kinde, be≈øides the greate≈øt that is formerly de≈øcribed.
list.label: Caryophyllus Turcicus.
list.item: The Turkie Gilloflower is but a ≈ømall flower, but of great delight, by rea≈øon of the well marking of the flower, being mo≈øt v≈øually equally ≈øtriped with red and white.
list.label: Caryophyllus Cambren≈øis Poole.
list.item: The Poole flower, growing naturally vpon the rockes neare Cog≈øhot Ca≈øtle in the I≈øle of Wight, is a ≈ømall flower, but very plea≈øant to the eye, by rea≈øon of the comely proportion thereof; it is of a bright pale red, thicke ≈øpeckled, and very ≈ømall with white, that it ≈øeemeth to bee but one colour, the leaues of the flower are but ≈ømally iagged about: it is con≈øtant.
list.label: Caryophyllus Pegma dilutior.
list.item: The light or pale Pageant is a flower of a middle ≈øize, very plea≈øant to behold, and is both con≈øtant and comely, and but that it is ≈øo common, would be of much more re≈øpect then it is: the flower is of a pale bright purple, thicke poudered, and very euenly with white, which hath the ma≈øtery, and maketh it the more gracefull.
list.label: Caryophyllus Pegma≈øaturatior.
list.item: The ≈øad Pageant is the ≈øame with the former in forme and bigne≈ø≈øe, the difference in colour is, that the purple hath the ma≈øtery, which maketh it ≈øo ≈øad, that it doth re≈øemble the Bra≈ø≈øill for colour, but is not ≈øo bigge by halfe.
list.label: Caryophyllus Heroina dictus elegans Magi≈øtri Brad≈øhawij.
list.item: Ma≈øter Brad≈øhawe his dainty Lady may bee well reckoned among the≈øe ≈øorts of Gilloflowers, and compare for neatene≈ø≈øe with mo≈øt of them: the flower is very neate, though ≈ømall, with a fine ≈ømall iagge, and of a fine white colour on the vnder≈øide of all the leaues, as al≈øo all the whole iagge for a pretty compa≈ø≈øe, and the bottome or middle part of the flower on the vpper≈øide al≈øo: but each leafe is of a fine bright pale red colour on the vpper≈øide, from the edge to the middle, which mixture is of wonderfull great delight.
list.label: Caryophyllus albus optimus maior Londinen≈øis & alius.
list.item: The be≈øt white Gilloflower groweth vpright, and very double, the blades growe vpright al≈øo, and crawle not on the ground. The London white is greater and whiter then the other ordinary white, being wholly of one colour.
list.label: Caryophyllus maior rubens & minor.
list.item: The ≈øtamell Gilloflower is well knowne to all, not to differ from the ordinary red or cloue Gilloflower, but only in being of a brighter or light red colour: there is both a greater and a le≈ø≈øer of this kinde.
list.label: Caryophyllus purpureus maior & minor.
list.item: The purple Gilloflower a greater and a le≈ø≈øe: the ≈øtalke is ≈øo ≈ølender, and the leaues vpon them ≈øo many and thicke, that they lye and traile on the ground: th ‚Ä¢ greate≈øt is almo≈øt as bigge as a Chry≈øtall, but not ≈øo double: the le≈ø≈øe hath a ≈ømaller flower.
list.label: Caryophyllus Per≈øico violaceus.
list.item: The Gredeline Gilloflower is a very neate and hand≈øome flower, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the Cloue red Gilloflower, of a fine pale reddi≈øh purple or peach colour, enclining to a blew or violet, which is that colour is v≈øually called a gredeline colour: it hath no affinity with eyther Purple, Granado, or Pageant.
list.label: Caryophyllus purpuro caeruleus.
list.item: The blew Gilloflower is neither very double nor great, yet round and hand≈øome, with a deepe iagge at the edge, and is of an exceeding deepe purple colour, tending to a tawnie: this differeth from all other ≈øorts, in that the leafe is as greene as gra≈ø≈øe, and the ≈øtalkes many times red or purple: by the greene leaues it may be knowne in the Winter, as well as in the Summer.
list.label: Caryophyllus carneus.
list.item: The blu≈øh Gilloflower differeth not from the red or ≈øtamell, but only in the colour of the flower, which is blu≈øh.
list.label: Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus maximus Wittie.
list.item:
Iohn Wittie his great tawny Gilloflower is for forme of growing, in leafe and flower altogether like vnto the ordinary tawny, the flower onely, becau≈øe it is the faire≈øt and greate≈øt that any other
hath nour≈øed vp, maketh the difference, as al≈øo that it is of a faire deepe ≈øcarlet colour.

div.p: There are al≈øo diuers other Tawnies, either lighter or ≈øadder, either le≈ø≈øe or more double, that they cannot be numbered, and all ri≈øing (as I ≈øaid before) from ≈øowing the ≈øeede of ≈øome of them: be≈øides the diuer≈øities of other colours both ≈øimple and mixed, euery yeare and place yeelding ≈øome variety was not ≈øeen with them before: I ≈øhall neede but onely to giue you the names of ≈øome of them we haue abiding with vs, I meane ≈øuch as haue receiued names, and leaue the re≈øt to euery ones particular denomination.

Of Blu≈øhes there are many ≈øorts, as the deepe blu≈øh, the pale blu≈øh, the Infanta blu≈øh, a blu≈øh enclining to a red, a great blu≈øh, the faire≈øt and mo≈øt double of all the other blu≈øhes, and many others both ≈øingle and double.

Of Reds likewi≈øe there are ≈øome varieties, but not ≈øo many as of the other colours; for they are mo≈øt dead or deepe reds, and few of a bright red or ≈øtamell colour; and they are ≈øingle like Pinkes, either ≈øtriped or ≈øpeckled, or more double ≈øtriped and ≈øpeckled variably, or el≈øe
There are neither purple nor white that ri≈øe from this ≈øeede that I haue ob≈øerued, except one white in one place.

list.label: Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus ≈øtriatus.
list.item: The ≈øtriped Tawny are either greater or le≈ø≈øer, deeper or lighter flowers twenty ≈øorts and aboue, and all ≈øtriped with ≈ømaller or larger ≈øtripes, or equally diuided, of a deeper or lighter colour: and ≈øome al≈øo for the very ≈øhape or forme will bee more neate, clo≈øe, and round; others more loo≈øe, vnequall, and ≈øpar≈øed.
list.label:
Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rinor-amulus.
list.item: The marbled Tawny hath not ≈øo many varieties as the ≈øtriped, but is of as great beauty and delight as it, or more: the flowers are greater or ≈ømaller, deeper or lighter coloured one then another, and the veines or markes more con≈øpicuous, or more frequent in ≈øome then in others: but the mo≈øt beautifull that euer I did ≈øee was with Ma≈øter Ralph Truggie, which I mu≈øt needes therefore call
list.label: Heroina Rodolphi florum Imperatoris.
list.item: Ma≈øter Tuggies Prince≈ø≈øe, which is the greate≈øt and faire≈øt of all the≈øe ≈øorts of variable tawnies, or ≈øeed flowers, being as large fully as the Prince or Chry≈øtall, or ≈øomething greater, ≈øtanding comely and round, not loo≈øe or ≈øhaken, or breaking the pod as ≈øome other ≈øorts will; the marking of the flower is in this manner: It i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yf a ≈øtamell colour, ≈øtriped and marbled with white ≈øtripes and veines quite through euery leafe, which are as deeply iagged as the Hulo: ≈øometimes it hath more red then white, and ≈øometimes more white then red, and ≈øometimes ≈øo equally marked, that you cannot di≈øcerne which hath the ma≈øtery; yet which of the≈øe hath the predominance, ≈øtill the flower is very beautifull, and exceeding delight≈øome.
list.label: Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus a≈ø≈øulo≈øus
list.item: The Flaked Tawny is another diuer≈øity of the≈øe variable or mixt coloured flowers, being of a pale reddi≈øh colour, flaked with white, not alwaies downeright, but often thwart the leaues, ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe then others; the marking of them is much like vnto the Chry≈øtall: the≈øe al≈øo as well as others will be greater or ≈ømaller, and of greater or le≈ø≈øe beauty then others.
list.label: Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus plumatus.
list.item: The Feathered Tawny is more rare to meete with then many of the other; for mo≈øt v≈øually it is a faire large flower and double, equalling the Lumbard red in his perfection: the colour hereof is v≈øually a ≈øcarlet, little deeper or paler, mo≈øt curiou≈øly feathered and ≈øtreamed with white through the whole leafe.
list.label: Caryophyllus Sile≈øiacus punctatus.
list.item:
The Speckled Tawny is of diuers ≈øorts, ≈øome bigger, ≈øome

The Granpere or greate≈øt Granado. 8 Caryophyllus paramanus. The Dainty. 9 Caryophyllus Sile≈ø ‚Ä¢ acus maximus „Äà‚óä„Äâ Ioan ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

le≈ø≈øe, ≈øome more, and ≈øome le≈ø≈øe ≈øpotted then others: V≈øually it is a deepe ≈øcarlet, ≈øpeckled or ≈øpotted with white, hauing al≈øo ≈øome ≈øtripes among the leaues.
list.label: Caryophyllus ro≈øeus rotundus Magi≈øtri Tuggie.
list.item: Ma≈øter Tuggie his Ro≈øe Gilloflower is of the kindred of the≈øe Tawnies, being rai≈øed from the ≈øeede of ≈øome of them, and onely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by him that is the mo≈øt indu≈øtrious pre≈øeruer of all natures beauties, being a different ≈øort from all other, in that it hath round leaues, without any iagge at all on the edges, of a fine ≈øtamell full colour, without any ≈øpot or ≈øtrake therin, very like vnto a ≈ømall Ro≈øe, or rather much like vnto the red Ro≈øe Campion, both for forme, colour, and roundne≈ø≈øe, but larger for ≈øize.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe are nouri≈øhed with vs in Gardens, none of their naturall places being knowne, except one before recited, and the yellow which is Sile≈øia; many of them being hardly pre≈øerued and encrea≈øed.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower not vntill the heate of the yeare, which is in Iuly (vnle≈ø≈øe it be an extraordinary occa≈øion) and continue flowring, vntill the colds of the Autumne checke them, or vntill they haue wholly out ≈øpent them≈øelues, and are v≈øually encrea≈øed by the ≈ølips.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Mo≈øt of our later Writers doe call them by one generall name, Caryophyllus ≈øativus, and flos Caryophylleus, adding thereunto maximus, when wee meane Carnations, and maior when we would expre≈ø≈øe Gilloflowers, which name is taken from Cloues, in that the ≈øent of the ordinary red Gilloflower e≈øpecially doth re≈øemble them. Diuers other ≈øeuerall names haue beene formerly giuen them, as Vetonica, or Betonica altera, or Vetonica altilis, and coronaria. Herba Tunica, Viola Dama≈øcena, Ocellus Dama≈øcenus, and Barbaricus. Of ≈øome Cantabrica Plinij. Some thinke they were vnknowne to the Ancients, and ≈øome would haue them to be Iphium of Theophra≈øtus, wherof he maketh mention in his ≈øixth and ≈øeuenth Chapters of his ≈øixth booke, among Garland and Summer flowers; others to be his Dios anthos, or Io ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ flos, mentioned in the former, and in other places. We call them in Engli≈øh (as I ≈øaid before) the greate≈øt kindes, Carnations, and the others Gilloflowers (qua≈øi Iuly flowers) as they are ≈øeuerally expre≈ø≈øed.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The red or Cloue Gilloflower is mo≈øt v≈øed in Phy≈øicke in our Apothecaries ≈øhops, none of the other being accepted of or v≈øed (and yet I doubt not, but all of them might ≈øerue, and to good purpo≈øe, although not to giue ≈øo gallant a tincture to a Syrupe as the ordinary red will doe) and is accounted to be very Cordiall.

div.head: Caryophylli ≈øilue≈øtres. Pinkes.
div.p:
THere remaine diuers ≈øorts of wilde or ≈ømall Gilloflowers (which wee v≈øually call Pinkes) to be entreated of, ≈øome bearing ≈øingle, and ≈øome double flowers, ≈øome ≈ømooth, almo≈øt without any deepe dents on the edges, and ≈øome iagged, or as it were feathered. Some growing vpright like vnto Gilloflowers, others creeping
1 Caryophyllus ≈øilue≈øtris ≈øimplex. The v≈øuall ≈øingle Pinke. 2 Caryophyllus multiplex ≈øilue≈øtris. Double Pinkes. 3 Cariophyllus ≈øilue≈øtris plumamarius. Feathered or iagged Pinkes. 4 Caryophyllus Stellatus. Starre Pinkes. 5 Caryophyllus re ‚Ä¢ ens. Matted Pinkes. 6 Caryophyllus mediterraneus. The great Thi≈øtle or Sea Gilloflower. 7 Caryophyllus m ‚Ä¢ rinus. The ordinary Thi≈øtle or Sea Cu≈øhion. depiction of flowers
or ≈øpreading vnder the toppe or cru≈øt of the ground, ≈øome of one colour, ≈øome of another, and many of diuers colours: As I haue formerly done with the Gilloflowers, ≈øo mu≈øt I doe with the≈øe that are entertained in our Gardens, onely giue you the de≈øcriptions of ≈øome three or foure of them, according to their variety, and the names of the re≈øt, with their di≈øtinctions.

div.head: 1. Caryophyllus minor ≈øiluestris multiplex & ≈øimplex. Double and ≈øingle Pinkes.
div.p: The ≈øingle and double Pinkes are for forme and manner of growing, in all parts like vnto the Gilloflowers before de≈øcribed, ≈øauing onely that their leaues are ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter, in ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe then in others, and ≈øo are the flowers al≈øo: the ≈øingle kindes con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues v≈øually (≈øeldome ≈øix) round pointed, and a little ≈ønipt for the mo≈øt part about the edges, with ≈øome threads in the middle, either crooked or ≈øtraight: the double kindes being le≈ø≈øer, and le≈ø≈øe double then the Gilloflowers, hauing their leaues a little ≈ønipt or endented about the edges, and of diuers ≈øeuerall colours as ≈øhall hereafter be ≈øet downe, and of as fragrant a ≈øent, e≈øpecially ≈øome of them as they: the rootes are long and ≈øpreading, ≈øomewhat hard and wooddy.

div.head: 2. Caryophyllus plumarius. Feathered or iagged Pinkes.
div.p: The iagged Pinkes haue ≈øuch like ≈øtalkes and l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ues as the former haue, but ≈øomewhat ≈øhorter and ≈ømaller, or gra≈ø≈øe-like, and of a whiti≈øh or grayi≈øh greene colour likewi≈øe: the flowers ≈øtand in the like manner at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, in long, round, ≈ølender, greene huskes, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, very much cut in on the edges, and iagged almo≈øt like a feather, of a light red, or bright purple colour, with two white threads ≈øtanding in the middle, crooked like a horne at the end, and are of a very good ≈øent. Some of the≈øe haue not tho≈øe two crooked threads or hornes in the middle, but haue in their ≈øtead many ≈ømall threads, not crooked at all: the ≈øeedes of them all are like vnto the ≈øeedes of Gilloflowers, or the other Pinkes, that is, ≈ømall, blacke, long, and flat: the rootes are ≈ømall and wooddy likewi≈øe.

div.head: 3. Caryophyllus plumarius albus orbe rubro ≈øiue Stellatus. Starre Pinkes.
div.p: Of this kinde there is another ≈øort, bearing flowers almo≈øt as deeply cut or iagged as the former, of a faire white colour, hauing a ring or circle of red about the bottome or lower part of the leaues, and are as ≈øweete as the former: this being ≈øowne of ≈øeede doth not giue the ≈øtarre of ≈øo bright a red colour, but becommeth more dunne.

div.head: 4. Caryophyllus plumarius Au≈øtriacus ≈øiue Superba Au≈øtriaca. The feathered Pinke of Au≈øtria.
div.p: This kinde of Pinke hath his fir≈øt or lower leaues, ≈øomewhat broader and greener then any of the former Pinkes, being both for breadth and greenne≈ø≈øe more like vnto the Sweete Iohns, which ≈øhall bee de≈øcribed in the next Chapter: the leaues on the ≈øtalkes are ≈ømaller, ≈øtanding by couples at euery ioynt, at the toppes whereof ≈øtand ≈øuch like iagged flowers as the la≈øt de≈øcribed, and as large, but more deeply cut in or iagged round about, ≈øome of them of a purpli≈øh colour, but the mo≈øt ordinary with vs are pure white, and of a mo≈øt fragrant ≈øent, comforting the ≈øpirits and ≈øen≈øes a farre off: the ≈øeedes and rootes are like vnto the former. Some haue mi≈øtaken a kinde of wilde Campion, growing in our Woods, and by the paths ≈øides in Horn≈øie Parke, and other places, to be this feathered Pinke: but the flowers declare the difference ≈øufficiently.

div.head: 5. Caryophyllus minor repens ≈øimplex & multiplex. Single and double matted Pinkes.
div.p:
The matted Pinke is the ≈ømalle≈øt, both for leafe and flower of all other Pinkes that are nouri≈øhed in Gardens, hauing many ≈øhort and ≈ømall gra≈ø≈øie greene leaues vpon the
≈øtalkes, which as they grow and lye vpon the ground (and not ≈øtanding ≈øo vpright as the former) doe take roote againe, whereby it quickly ≈øpreadeth, and couereth a great deale of ground in a li ‚Ä¢ tle ≈øpace: the flowers are ≈ømall and round, a little ≈ønipt about the edges, whereof ≈øome are white, and ≈øome red, and ≈øome are white ≈øpotted with red, and ≈øome red
‚Ä¢ Potted with white, all of them being ≈øingle flowers. But there is another of this kinde, not differing in leafe, but in flower: for that the fir≈øt flowers are but once double, or of two rowes of leaues, of a fine reddi≈øh colour, ≈øpotted with ≈øiluer ≈øpots: but tho≈øe that follow, are ≈øo thicke and double, that they oftentimes doe breake the pod or huske; being not altogether of ≈øo deepe a red colour, but more pale.

div.head: 6. Caryophyllus Meditterraneus ≈øiue Marinus maior. Great Sea Gilloflower or Great Thrift.
div.p: Vnto the≈øe kindes of Pinkes I mu≈øt needs adde, not only your ordinary Thrift (which is more frequent in gardens, to empale or border a knot, becau≈øe it abideth greene Winter and Summer, and that by cutting, it may grow thick, and be kept in what form one li≈øt, rather then for any beautie of the flowers) but another greater kinde, which is of as great beautie and delight almo≈øt as any of the former Pinkes, as well for that the leaues are like vnto Gilloflowers, being longer and larger then any Pinkes, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour like vnto th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , not growing long or by couples vpon the ≈øtalkes as Pinkes and Gilloflowers do, but tufting clo≈øe vpon the ground, like vnto the common Thrift: as al≈øo that the ≈øtalkes, ri≈øing from among the leaues (being ≈øometimes two foote high (as I haue ob≈øerued in my garden) are yet ≈øo ≈ølender and weake, that they are ≈øcarce able to beare the heads of flowers, naked or bare, both of leaues and ioynts, ≈øauing only in one place, where at the ioynt each ≈øtalke hath two ≈ømall and very ≈øhort leaues, not ri≈øing vpwards as in all other Gilloflowers, Pinkes, and other herbes, but growing downewards) and doe beare each of them a tuft or vmbell of ≈ømall purpli≈øh, or blu≈øh coloured flowers, at the toppes them ≈øtanding ≈øomewhat like vnto ≈øweete Williams, but more roundly together, each flower con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall, round, ≈øtiffe or hardi≈øh leaues, as if they were made of paper, the bottome or middle being hollow, not blowing all at once as the ordinary Thrift, but for the mo≈øt part one after another, not ≈øhewing v≈øually aboue foure or fiue flowers open at one time (≈øo farre as I could ob≈øerue in the plants that I kept) ≈øo that it was long before the whole tuft of flowers were pa≈øt; but yet the hoter and dryer the times was, the ≈øooner it would be gone: the ≈øeede I haue not perfectly ob≈øerued, but as I remember, it was ≈øomewhat like vnto the ≈øeede of Scabious; I am ≈øure nothing like vnto Gilloflowers or Pinkes: the roote is ≈øomewhat great, long and hard, and not ≈øo much ≈øpreading in the ground as Gilloflowers or Pinkes.

div.head: Caryophyllus Marinus. Thrift, or Sea Cu≈øhion.
div.p: Our common Thrift is well knowne vnto all, to haue many ≈øhort and hard greene leaues, ≈ømaller then many of the gra≈ø≈øes, growing thicke together, and ≈øpreading vpon the ground: the ≈øtalkes are naked of leaues a ≈øpanne high, bearing a ≈ømall tuft of light purple, or blu≈øh coloured flowers, ≈øtanding round and clo≈øe thru≈øting together.

list.head: Double Pinkes.
list.item: THe double white Pinke is onely with more leaues in it then the ≈øingle, which maketh the difference.
The double red Pinke is in the ≈øame manner double, differing from the ≈øingle of the ≈øame colour.

The double purple Pinke differeth not
from the ≈øingle purple for colour, but only in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower.
The Granado Pinke differeth not from the Gilloflower of the ≈øame name, but in the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe both of leaues and flower.
The double Matted Pinke is before de≈øcribed.

The double blu≈øh Pinke is almo≈øt as great as the ordinary blu≈øh Gilloflower, and ≈øome haue taken it for one, but the greene leaues are almo≈øt as ≈ømall as Pinks, and therefore I referre it to them.

list.head: Single Pinkes.
list.item: THe ≈øingle white ordinary Pinke hath a ≈øingle white flower of fiue leaues, finely iagged about the edges.
The ≈øingle red Pink is like the white, but that the leaues are not ≈øo much iagged, and the flower is of a pale purpli≈øh red colour.
The ≈øingle purple Pinke is of a faire purple colour, like almo≈øt vnto the purple Gilloflower.
The great blu≈øh Pinke hath broader and larger leaues in the flower then any other Pinke, and of a faire blu≈øh colour.
The white Feathered Pinke hath the edges of the flower more finely and deeply cut in then the former.
The red or light purple feathered Pinke is like the former feathered Pinke, but only differeth in colour.
The Starre Pinke is a faire flower, finely iagged on the edges, with a faire red circle at the lower end of the leaues on the in≈øide.

The white featherd Pinke of Au≈øtria is de≈øcribed before. The purple featherd Pinke of Au≈øtria is ≈øo likewi≈øe. The ≈øingle matted Pinke is before de≈øcribed. The ≈øpeckled Pinke is a ≈ømall flower hauing ≈ømall ≈øpots of red here and there di≈øper≈øed ouer the white flower.
Tho≈øe ≈øingle flowers being like vnto Pinkes that ri≈øe from the ≈øowing of the orenge tawney, I bring not into this cla≈øsis, hauing already ≈øpoken of them in the precedent Chapter.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe are all like as the former, nouri≈øhed in Gardens with vs, although many of them are found wilde in many places of Au≈øtria, Hungarie, and Germany, on the mountaines, and in many other places, as Clu≈øius recordeth. The ordinary Thrift groweth in the ≈øalt Mar≈øhes at Chattam by Roche≈øter, and in many other places in England: but the great kinde was gathered in Spaine, by Guillaume Boel that painefull ≈øearcher of ≈øimples, and the ≈øeede thereof imparted to me, from whence I had diuers plants, but one yeare after another they all peri≈øhed,

div.head: The Time.
div.p: Many of the≈øe Pinkes both ≈øingle and double, doe flower before any Gilloflower, and ≈øo continue vntill Augu≈øt, and ≈øome, mo≈øt of the Summer and Autumne.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The ≈øeuerall titles that are giuen to the≈øe Pinkes, may ≈øuffice for their particular names: and for their generall they haue beene expre≈ø≈øed in the former Chapter, beeing of the ≈øame kindred, but that they are ≈ømaller, and more frequently found wilde. The two ≈øorts of Thrift are called Caryophyllus Marinus. The greater, Maior & Mediterraneus; In Engli≈øh, The greater or Leuant Thrift, or Sea Gilloflower. The le≈ø≈øer Minimus, and is accounted of ≈øome to be a gra≈ø≈øe, and therefore called Gramen Marinum & Polyanthemum; In Engli≈øh, Thrift, Sea gra≈ø≈øe, and our Ladies Cu≈øhion, or Sea Cu≈øhion.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is thought by diuers, that their vertues are an≈øwerable to the Gilloflowers, yet as they are of little v≈øe with vs, ≈øo I thinke of as ≈ømall effect.

div.head: Armerius. Sweet Iohns, and ≈øweet Williams.
div.p: THe≈øe kindes of flowers as they come neere≈øt vnto Pinkes and Gilloflowers, though manife≈øtly differing, ≈øo it is fitte≈øt to place them next vnto them in a peculiar Chapter.

div.head: 1. Armerius angustifolius rubens ≈øimplex. Single red ≈øweete Iohns.
div.p: The ≈øweete Iohn hath his leaues broader, ≈øhorter and greener then any of the former Gilloflowers, but narrower then ≈øweete Williams, ≈øet by couples, at the ioynts of the ≈øtalkes, which are ≈øhorter then mo≈øt of the former, and not aboue a foote and a halfe high, at the tops whereof ≈øtand many ≈ømall flowers, like vnto ≈ømall Pinkes, but ≈øtanding clo≈øer together, and in ≈øhorter huskes, made of fiue leaues, ≈ømaller then mo≈øt of them, and more deeply iagged then the Williams, of a red colour in the middle, and white at the edges, but of a ≈ømall or ≈øoft ≈øent, and not all flowring at once, but by degrees: the ≈øeede is blacke, ≈øomewhat like vnto the ≈øeede of Pinkes, the roote is di≈øper≈øed diuer≈øly, with many ≈ømall fibres annexed vnto it.

div.head: 2. Armerius angu≈øtifolius albus ≈øimplex. Single white ≈øweet Iohns.
div.p: This white Iohn differeth not in any thing from the former, but onely that the leafe doth neuer change browni≈øh, and that the flower is of a faire white colour, without any mixture.

div.head: 3. Armerius angustifolius duplex. Double ≈øweet Iohns.
div.p: There is of both tho≈øe former kindes, ≈øome who≈øe flowers are once double, that is, con≈øi≈øting of two or three rowes of leaues, and the edges not ≈øo deepely iagged; not differing in any thing el≈øe.

div.head: 4. Armerius latifolius ≈øimplex flore rubro. Single red ≈øweet Williams.
div.p: The ≈øweet Williams doe all of them ≈øpread into many very long trayling branches, with leaues lying on the ground, in the very like manner that the ≈øweet Iohns doe: the chiefe differences betweene them are, that the≈øe haue broader, and darker greene leaues, ≈øomewhat browni≈øh, e≈øpecially towards the points, and that the flowers ≈øtand thicker and clo≈øer, and more in number together, in the head or tuft, hauing many ≈ømall pointed leaues among them, but harmle≈ø≈øe, as all men know; the colour of the flower is of a deep red, without any mixture or ≈øpot at all.

div.head: 5. Armerius latifolius flore rubro multiplici. Double red ≈øweete Williams.
div.p: The double kinde differeth not from the ≈øingle kinde of the ≈øame colour, but only in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flowers, which are with two rowes of leaues in euery flower.

div.head: 6. Armerius latifolius variegatus ≈øiue ver≈øicolor. Speckled ≈øweete Williams, or London pride.
div.p:
The≈øe ≈øpotted Williams are very like the fir≈øt red Williams, in the forme or maner of growing, hauing leaues as broade, and browne ≈øometimes as they, the flowers ≈øtand as thicke or thicker, clu≈øtring together, but of very variable colours: for ≈øome flowers will be of a fine delayed red, with few markes or ≈øpots vpon them, and others
will bee full peckled or ≈øprinkled with white or ≈øiluer ≈øpots, circlewi≈øe about the middle of the flowers, and ≈øome will haue many ≈øpecks or ≈øpots vpon them di≈øper≈øed: all the≈øe flowers are not blowne at one time, but ≈øome are flowring, when others are decaying, ≈øo that abiding long in their pride, they become of the more re≈øpect: The ≈øeede is blacke, as all the re≈øt, and not to be di≈øtingui≈øhed one from another: the roots are ≈øome long, and ≈øome ≈ømall and threddy, running vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the earth.

div.head: 7. Armerius latifolius flore rubro ≈øaturoholo≈øerice ‚Ä¢ . Sweet Williams of a deepe red or murrey colour.
div.p: The leaues of this kinde ≈øeeme to be a little larger, and the ioints a little redder then the former, but in the flower con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe≈øt difference, which is of a deepe red, or murrey purple colour, like vnto veluet of that colour, without any ≈øpots, but ≈ømooth, and as it were ≈øoft in handling, hauing an eye or circle in the middle, at the bottome of the leaues.

div.head: 8. Armerius latifolius ≈øimplex flore albo. Single white ≈øweete Williams.
div.p: The white kinde differeth not in forme, but in colour from the former, the leaues are not browne at all, but of a fre≈øh greene colour, and the flowers are wholly white, or el≈øe they are all one.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe for the mo≈øt part grow wilde in Italie, and other places: we haue them in our Gardens, where they are cheri≈øhed for their beautifull varietie.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all generally doe flower before the Gilloflowers or Pinkes, or with the fir≈øt of them: their ≈øeede is ripe in Iune and Iuly, and doe all well abide the extremitie of our colde≈øt winters.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They all generally are called Armerius, or Armeria, as ≈øome doe write, and di≈øtingui≈øhed as they are in their titles: Yet ≈øome haue called them Vetonica agre≈øtis, and others Herba Tunica, Scarlatea, & Caryophyllus ≈øilue≈øtris: Wee doe in Engli≈øh in mo≈øt places, call the fir≈øt or narrower leafed kindes, Sweet Iohns, and all the re≈øt Sweete Williams; yet in ≈øome places they call the broader leafed kindes that are not ≈øpotted, Tolmeiners, and London tufts: but the ≈øpeckled kinde is termed by our Engli≈øh Gentlewomen, for the mo≈øt part, London pride.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We haue not knowne any of the≈øe v≈øed in Phy≈øicke.

div.head: Bellis. Dai≈øie.
div.p: THere be diuers ≈øorts of Dai≈øies, both great and ≈ømall, both ≈øingle and double, both wilde growing abroade in the fieldes, and el≈øewhere, and manured growing only in Gardens: of all which I intend not to entreate, but of tho≈øe that are of mo≈øt beautie and re≈øpect, and leaue the re≈øt to their proper place.

Sp ‚Ä¢ tted ≈øweet Williams or pride of London. 5 Armerius latifolius multiplex Double ≈øweet Willia ‚Ä¢ s 6 B ‚Ä¢ llis ho ‚Ä¢ ten≈øis minor mu ‚Ä¢ tiplex Double Garden Dai≈øies. 7 Bell ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ minor ho ‚Ä¢ ten≈øis flore vario. Double red Dai≈øies
„Äà‚óä„Äâ 8 Bellis minor horten≈øis prolifera. Double fruitfull Dai≈øies or lacke an Apes on hor≈øebacke. 9 Bellis caru ‚Ä¢ ea ≈øiue Globularia. Double blew Dai≈øies or blew Globeflower. 10 Bellis lutea montana ≈øiue Globularia lutea monta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Double yellow Da ‚Ä¢ ≈øies or yellow Globeflower.

div.head: 1. Bellis maior flore albo pleno. The great double white Dai≈øie.
div.p: The great Dai≈øie with the double white flower, is in all things ≈øo like vnto the great ≈øingle kinde, that groweth by the high wayes, and in diuers medowes and fields, that there is no difference but in the flower, which is double. It hath many long, and ≈øomewhat broad leaues lying vpon the ground, deepely cut in on both ≈øides, ≈øomewhat like vnto an oaken leafe; but tho≈øe that are on the ≈øtalkes are ≈øhorter, narrower, and not ≈øo deeply cut in, but onely notched on the edges: the flowers at the toppe are (as I ≈øaid) white and double, con≈øi≈øting of diuers rowes of leaues, being greater in compa≈ø≈øe then any of the double Dai≈øies that follow, but nothing ≈øo double of leaues.

div.head: 2. Bellis minor flore rubro ≈øimplici. Single red Dai≈øies.
div.p: This ≈øingle Dai≈øie (like as all the re≈øt of the ≈ømall Dai≈øies) hath many ≈ømooth, greene, round pointed leaues lying on the ground, a little ≈ønipt about the edges; from among which ri≈øe many ≈ølender round foote-≈øtalkes, rather then ≈øtalkes or ≈øtems, about an hand breadth high at the mo≈øt, and oftentimes not halfe ≈øo high, bearing one flower a peece, con≈øi≈øting of many ≈ømall leaues, as a pale or border ≈øet about a middle thrumme: the leaues of this kinde are almo≈øt wholly red, whereas in the wilde they are white or whiti≈øh, enclining to red on the edges, the middle being yellow in both ≈øorts: the rootes are many ≈ømall white threads or ≈øtrings.

div.head: 3. Bellis minor horten≈øis flore pleno variorum colorum. Double Garden Dai≈øies of diuers colours.
div.p: The leaues of all the double Dai≈øies are in forme like vnto the ≈øingle ones, but that they are ≈ømaller, and little or nothing ≈ønipt or notched about the edges: the ≈ømall ≈øtalkes likewi≈øe are ≈ømaller and lower, but bearing as double flowers as any that growe on the ground, being compo≈øed of many ≈ømall leaues, thicke thru≈øt together, of diuers colours; for ≈øome are wholly of a pure white, others haue a little red, either di≈øper≈øed vpon the white leaues, or on the edges, and ≈øometimes on the backes of the leaues: ≈øome againe ≈øeeme to be of a whiti≈øh red, or more red then white, when as indeede they are white leaues di≈øper≈øed among the red; others of a deepe or darke red colour, and ≈øome are ≈øpeckled or ≈øtriped with white and red through the whole flower: and ≈øome the leaues will bee red on the vpper≈øide, and white vnderneath; and ≈øome al≈øo (but tho≈øe are very rare) are of a greeni≈øh colour.

div.head: 4. Bellis minor horten≈øis prolifera. Double double Dai≈øies or childing Dai≈øies.
div.p: There is no difference either in leafe or roote in this kinde from the former double Dai≈øies: the chiefe≈øt variety con≈øi≈øteth in this, that it beareth many ≈ømall double flowers, ≈øtanding vpon very ≈øhort ≈øtalkes round about the middle flower, which is v≈øually as great and double as any of the other double kindes, and is either wholly of a deepe red colour, or ≈øpeckled white and red as in ≈øome of the former kindes, or el≈øe greeni≈øh, all the ≈ømall flowers about it being of the ≈øame colour with the middlemo≈øt.

div.head: 5. Bellis caerulea ≈øiue Globularia. Blew Dai≈øies.
div.p: The likene≈ø≈øe and affinity that this plant hath with the former, both in the forme of leafe and flower, as al≈øo in the name, hath cau≈øed me to in≈øert it, and another rare plant of the ≈øame kinde, in this place, although they be very rare to be met with in our Engli≈øh Gardens. This beareth many narrower, ≈øhorter, and blacker greene leaues then the former, lying round about vpon the ground; among which ri≈øe vp ≈ølender, but ≈øtiffe and hard ≈øtalks, halfe a foot high or more, ≈øet here and there with ≈ømall leaues, and at the top a ≈ømall round head, compo≈øed of many ≈ømall blew leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the head of a Scabious: It hath bin found likewi≈øe with a white head of flowers: the roote is hard and ≈øtringie: the whole plant is of a bitter ta≈øte.

div.head: 6. Globularia lutea montana. Yellow Dai≈øies.
div.p: This mountaine yellow Dai≈øie or Globe-flower hath many thicke, ≈ømooth, round pointed leaues, ≈øpread vpon the ground like the former; among which ≈øpring diuers ≈ømall round ru≈øhie ≈øtalkes, a foote high, bearing about the middle of them two ≈ømall leaues at the ioynts, and at the toppes round heads of flowers thru≈øt thicke together, ≈øtanding in purpli≈øh huskes, euery of which flowers do blow or ≈øpread into fiue leaues, ≈øtarre-fa≈øhion, and of a faire yellow colour, ≈ømelling like vnto broome flowers, with many ≈ømall threads in the middle compa≈ø≈øing a flat pointell, horned or bended two wayes: after the flowers are pa≈øt ri≈øe vp the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, which are round, ≈øwelling out in the middle, and diuided into foure parts at the toppes, containing within them round, flat, blacke ≈øeede, with a ≈ømall cut or notch in them: the roote is a finger long, round and hard, with a thicke barke, and a woddy pith in the middle, of a ≈øharpe drying ta≈øte and ≈øtrong ≈øent: the leaues are al≈øo ≈øharpe, but bitter.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The ≈ømall Dai≈øies are all planted, and found onely in Gardens, and will require to be replanted often, le≈øt they degenerate into ≈øingle flowers, or at lea≈øt into le≈ø≈øe double. The blew Dai≈øie is naturall of Mompelier in France, and on the mountaines in many places of Italy, as al≈øo the yellow kinde in the Kingdome of Naples.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Dai≈øies flower betimes in the Spring, and la≈øt vntill May, but the la≈øt two flower not vntill Augu≈øt or September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are v≈øually called in Latine Bellides, and in Engli≈øh Dai≈øies. Some call them Herba Margarita, and Primula veris, as it is likely after the Italian names, of Marguerite, and Fior di prima vera gentile. The French call them Pa≈øquettes, and Marguerites, and the Fruitfull ≈øort, or tho≈øe that beare ≈ømall flowers about the middle one, Margueritons: our Engli≈øh women call them Iacke an Apes on hor≈øe-backe, as they doe Marigolds before recited, or childing Dai≈øies: but the Phy≈øitians and Apothecaries doe in generall call them, e≈øpecially the ≈øingle or Field kindes, Con≈øolida minor. The blew Dai≈øie is called Bellis caerulea, and Globularia, of ≈øome Scabio≈øae pumilum genus. The Italians call it Botanaria, becau≈øe the heads are found like buttons. The yellow, Globularia montana, is onely de≈øcribed by Fabius Columna, in his la≈øt part of Phytoba≈øanos, and by him referred vnto the former Globularia, althougb it differ in ≈øome notable points from it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The properties of Dai≈øies are certainly to binde, and the roote e≈øpecially being dryed, they are v≈øed in medicines to that purpo≈øe. They are al≈øo of ≈øpeciall account among tho≈øe herbes, that are v≈øed for wounds in the head.

div.head: Scabio≈øa. Scabious.
div.p: THe ≈øorts of Scabious being many, yeeld not flowers of beauty or re≈øpect, fit to bee cheri≈øhed in this our Garden of delight; and therefore I leaue them to the Fields and Woods, there to abide. I haue onely two or three ≈øtrangers to bring to your acquaintance, which are worthy this place.

div.head: 1. Scabio≈øa flore albo. White flowred Scabious.
div.p: This white Scabious hath many long leaues, very much iagged or ga≈øht in on both ≈øides, of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe, being neither ≈øo large as many of the field, nor ≈øo ≈ømall as any of the ≈ømall kindes: the ≈øtalkes ri≈øe about a foote and a halfe high, or ≈øomewhat higher, at the tops whereof grow round heads, thicke ≈øet with flowers, like in all points vnto the field Scabious, but of a milke white colour.

div.head: 2. Scabio≈øa rubra Au≈øtriaca. Red Scabious of Au≈øtria.
div.p: This red Scabious hath many leaues lying vpon the ground, very like vnto Deuils bit, but not ≈øo large, being ≈øhorter and ≈ønipt, not ga≈øhed about the edges, of a light greene colour; yet (there is another of a darker greene colour, who≈øe flower is of a deeper red) the ≈øtalkes haue diuers ≈øuch leaues on them, ≈øet by couples at the ioynts as grow belowe, and at the tops ≈ømall heads of flowers, each con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, the bigge≈øt flowers ≈øtanding round about in the outer compa≈ø≈øe, as is v≈øuall almo≈øt in all the kinds of Scabious‚ñ™ or a fine light purple or red colour: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come the ≈øeede, which is ≈øomewhat long and round, ≈øet with certaine haires at the head thereof, like vnto a Starre: the roote is compo≈øed of a number of ≈ølender ≈øtrings, fa≈øtened at the head.

div.head: 3. Scabio≈øa rubra Indica. Red flowred Indian Scabious.
div.p: This (reputed Indian) Scabious hath many large faire greene leaues lying on the ground, iagged or cut in on both ≈øides to the middle ribbe, euery peece whereof is narrower then that at the end, which is the broade≈øt: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp ≈øundry ≈ølender and weake ≈øtalkes, yet ≈øtanding vpright for the mo≈øt part, ≈øet with ≈ømaller and more iagged leaues at certaine di≈øtances, two or three at euery ioynt, branching forth at the toppe into other ≈ømaller branches, bearing euery one head of flowers, like in forme vnto other Scabiou≈øes, but of an excellent deepe red crim≈øon colour (and ≈øometimes more pale or delayed) of no ≈øent at all: after which doe come ≈ømall roundi≈øh ≈øeede, like vnto the field Scabious: the roote is long and round, compa≈ø≈øed with a great many ≈ømall ≈øtrings, and peri≈øheth v≈øually as ≈øoone as it hath borne out his flowers and ≈øeede: otherwi≈øe if it doe not flower the fir≈øt yeare of the ≈øowing, if it be carefully defended from the extremity of Winter, it will flower the ≈øooner the next yeare, as I my ≈øelfe haue often found by experience.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is ≈øometimes found wilde in our owne Countrey, but it is very gea≈øon, and hath been ≈øent among other rare ≈øeedes from Italy.
The ≈øecond was fir≈øt found and written of by Clu≈øius, in Pannonia and Au≈øtria, where it is very plentifull.
The third hath been ≈øent both from Spain & Italy, and is verily thought to grow naturally in both tho≈øe parts.

figure.head:
1 Scabio≈øa flore albo. White flowred Scabious. 2 Scabio≈øa rubra Au≈øtriaca. Red Scabious of Au≈øtria. 3 Scabio≈øa rubra Indica. Red flowred Indian Scabious. 4 Cyanus vulgaris minor. Corn-flower of diuers colours. 5 Cyanus
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ticus, Spani≈øh Corn-flower. 6 Cyanus floridus Turcicus. The braue Sultans flower. 7 Carthamus ≈øativus. Spani≈øh Saffron.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt and ≈øecond flower earlier then the la≈øt, for that it flowreth not vntill September or October, (vnle≈ø≈øe it be not apt to beare the fir≈øt yeare as I before ≈øaid) ≈øo that many times (if none be more forward) it peri≈øheth without bearing ripe ≈øeede, whereby we are oftentimes to ≈øeeke new ≈øeede from our friends in other parts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They haue all one generall name of Scabious, di≈øtingui≈øhed eyther by their flower, or place of growing, as in their titles: yet the la≈øt is called of diuers Scabio≈øa exotica, becau≈øe they thinke the name Indica, is not truely impo≈øed vpon it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Whether the≈øe kindes haue any of the vertues of the other wilde kinds, I know none haue made any experience, and therefore I can ≈øay no more of them.

div.head: Cyanus. Corne flower, or blew Bottles.
div.p: VNder the name of Cyanus are comprehended, not onely tho≈øe plants which from the excellent blew colour of their flower ‚Ä¢ (furni≈øhing or rather pe≈øtering the Corne fieldes) haue peculiarly obtained that name, and which doth much vary al≈øo, in the colour of the flowers, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed; but ≈øome other plants al≈øo for their neere re≈øemblance, but with ≈øeuerall di≈øtinctions. The Cyanus maior, Ptarmica Austriaca, Ptarmica Imperati, and many others which may be adioyned vnto them, do more fitly belong to the Garden of Simples, whereunto I leaue them, and will here only entreate of tho≈øe that may mo≈øt plea≈øe the delight of our Gentle Flori≈øts, in that I labour and ≈øtriue, to furni≈øh this our garden, with the chiefe≈øt choy≈øe of natures beauties and delights.

div.head: 1. Cyanus vulgaris diuer≈øorum colorum. Corne flower of diuers colours.
div.p:
All the≈øe ≈øorts of Corne flowers are for the mo≈øt part alike, both in leaues and flowers one vnto another for the forme: the difference betweene them con≈øi≈øteth in the varying colour of the flowers: For the leaues are long, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour, deeply cut in on the edges in ≈øome places, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of a Scabious: the ≈øtalkes are two foote high or better, be≈øet with ≈øuch like leaues but ≈ømaller, and little or nothing ≈ølit on the edges: the toppes are branched, bearing many ≈ømal greene ≈øcaly heads, out of which ri≈øe flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue or ≈øixe, or more long and hollow leaues, ≈ømall at the bottome, and opening wider and greater at the brims, notched or cut in on the edges, and ≈øtanding round about many ≈ømall threds in the middle: the colours of the≈øe flowers are diuers, and very variable; for ≈øome are wholly blew, or white, or blu≈øh, or of a ≈øad, or light purple, or of a light or dead red, or of an ouerworne purple colour, or el≈øe mixed of the≈øe colours, as ≈øome, the edges white, and the re≈øt blew or purple, or the edges blew or purple, and the re≈øt of the flower white, or ≈øtriped, ≈øpotted, or halfed, the one part of one colour, and the other of another, the threds likewi≈øe in the middle varying in many of them; for ≈øome will haue the middle thrume of a deeper purple then the outer leaues, and ≈øome haue white or blu≈øh leaues, the middle thrume being reddi≈øh, deeper or paler: After the flowers are pa≈øt, there come ≈ømall, hard, white and ≈øhining ≈øeede in tho≈øe heads, wrapped
or ≈øet among a deale of flockie matter, as is mo≈øt v≈øuall, in all plants that beare ≈øcaly heads: the rootes are long and hard, peri≈øhing euery yeare when it hath giuen ≈øeede.

div.head: 2. Cyanus floridus Turcicus. The Sultans flower.
div.p: As a kinde of the≈øe Corne flowers, I mu≈øt needes adioyne another ≈øtranger, of much beautie, and but lately obtained from Con≈øtantinople, where, becau≈øe (as it is ≈øaid) the great Turke, as we call him, ≈øaw it abroade, liked it, and wore it him≈øelfe; all his va≈ø≈øals haue had it in great regard, and hath been obtained from them, by ≈øome that haue ≈øent it into the≈øe parts. The leaues whereof are greener, and not only ga≈øhed, but finely ≈ønipt on the edges: the ≈øtalkes are three foote high, garni≈øhed with the like leaues as are below, and branched as the former, bearing large ≈øcaly heads, and ≈øuch like flowers but larger, hauing eight or nine of tho≈øe hollow gaping leaues in euery flower, ≈øtanding about the middle threds (if it be planted in good and fertile ground and be well watered, for it ≈øoone ≈øtarueth and peri≈øheth with drought) the circling leaues are of a fine delayed purple or blu≈øh colour, very beautifull to behold; the ≈øeede of this is ≈ømaller and blacker, and not enclo≈øed in ≈øo much dounie ≈øub≈øtance, as the former (yet in our Countrey the ≈øeede is not ≈øo blacke, as it came vnto vs, but more gray) the roote peri≈øheth likewi≈øe euery yeere.

div.head: 3. Cyanus Baeticus ≈øupinus. The Spani≈øh Corne-flower.
div.p: This Spani≈øh kinde hath many ≈øquare low bending or creeping ≈øtalkes, not ≈øtanding ≈øo vpright as the former, but branching out more diuer≈øly; ≈øo that one plant will take vp a great deale of ground: the leaues are broader then any of the re≈øt, ≈øofter al≈øo, of a pale or whiti≈øh greene colour, and not much ga≈øhed on the edges: the flowers ≈øtand in bigger heads, with foure or fiue leaues vnder euery head, and are of a light pale purple or blu≈øh colour; after which come ≈øeede, but not ≈øo plentifully, yet wrapped in a great deale of flockie matter, more then any: the roote groweth downe deepe into the ground, but peri≈øheth euery yeare as they doe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt or former kindes, grow many times in the Corne fields of our own Countrey, as well as of others, e≈øpecially that ≈øort with a blew flower: but the other ≈øorts or colours are not ≈øo frequent, but are nouri≈øhed in gardens, where they will vary wonderfully.
The ≈øecond as is before ≈øet downe, groweth in Turkie: and the la≈øt in Spaine, found out and fir≈øt ≈øent to vs by that indu≈øtrious ≈øearcher of ≈øimples, Guillaume Boel before remembred.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt doe flower in the end of Iune, and in Iuly, and ≈øomtimes ≈øooner. The other two later, and not vntill Augu≈øt mo≈øt commonly, and the ≈øeede is ≈øoone ripe after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is generally called Cyanus, and ≈øome following the Ditch name, call it Flos frumenti. The olde Writers gaue it the name of Bapti ≈øaecuba, which is almo≈øt worne out. We doe call them in Engli≈øh, Blew Bottles, and in ≈øome places, Corne flowers, after the Ditch names. The ≈øecond hath beene ≈øent by the name of Ambreboi, which whether it be a Turkie or Arabian name, I know not. I haue called it from the place, from whence we had it, Turcicus, and for his beauty, Floridus. The Turkes them≈øelues as I vnder≈øtand, doe call it The Sultans flower, and I haue done ≈øo likewi≈øe, that it may bee di≈øtingui≈øhed from all the other kindes, or el≈øe you may call it,
The Turkey blu≈øh Corne flower, which you plea≈øe. The l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt was ≈øent by the name of Iacea Baetica, but I had rather to referre it to the Cyanus, or Corne flowers, becau≈øe the flowers are like vnto the Corne flowers, and not vnto the Iaceas or Knapweedes.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The≈øe had no v≈øe in Phy≈øicke in Galen and Dio≈øcorides time, in that (as it is thought) they haue made no mention of them: We in the≈øe dayes doe chiefly v≈øe the fir≈øt kindes (as al≈øo the greater ≈øort) as a cooling Cordiall, and commended by ≈øome to be a remedy, not onely again≈øt the plague and pe≈øtilentiall di≈øea≈øes, but again≈øt the poi≈øon of Scorpions and Spiders.

div.head: Iacea Marina Baetica. Spani≈øh Sea Knapweede.
div.p: THere are a great many ≈øorts of Knapweedes, yet none of them all fit for this our Garden, but this only ≈øtranger, which I haue beene bold to thru≈øt in here, for that it hath ≈øuch like gaping or open flowers, as the former Corne flowers haue, but notably differing, and therefore de≈øerueth a peculiar Chapter, as partaking both with Cyanus and Iacea. It hath many long and narrow leaues vneuenly dented or waued on both edges (and not notched, ga≈øhed or indented, as many other herbes are) being thicke, fle≈øhie and brittle, a little hairy, and of an ouerworne darke greene colour, among which ri≈øe lowe weake ≈øtalkes, with ≈øuch like leaues as grow at the bottome, but ≈ømaller, bearing but here and there a flower, of a bright reddi≈øh purple colour, like in forme vnto the Corne flowers, but much larger, with many threds or thrumes in the middle of the ≈øame colour, ≈øtanding vp higher then any of the former: this flower ri≈øeth out of a large ≈øcaly head, all ≈øet ouer with ≈ømall ≈øharpe (but harmele≈ø≈øe) white prickles: the ≈øeedes are blacki≈øh, like vnto the Knapweedes, and larger then any of the former Corne flowers: the roote is great and thicke, growing deepe into the ground, fle≈øhie and full of a ≈ølimie or clammy iuice, and ea≈øie to bee broken, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and whiti≈øh within, enduring many yeares, like as the other Knapweedes, or Matfelons doe, growing in time to be very thicke and great.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It groweth naturally by the Sea ≈øide in Spaine, from whence I receiued the ≈øeedes of Guillaume Boel, and did abide well in my garden a long time, but is now peri≈øhed.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the beginning of Iuly, or thereabouts, and continueth not long in flower: but the head abideth a great while, and is of ≈øome beauty after the flower is pa≈øt; yet ≈øeldome giueth good ≈øeed with vs.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It hath no other name then is ≈øet down in the title, being altogether a Noueli≈øt, and not now to be ≈øeene with any ≈øauing my ≈øelfe.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We haue not yet known any v≈øe hereof in Phy≈øick.

div.head: Cnicus ≈øiuc Carthamus ≈øativus. Ba≈øtard or Spani≈øh Saffron.
div.p: THere are two or three ≈øorts of Cnicus or ba≈øtard Saffrons which I pa≈ø≈øe ouer, as not fit for this Garden, and onely ≈øet downe this kinde, who≈øe flowers are of a fairer and more liuely colour in our Country, then any hath come ouer from Spaine, where they manure it for the profit they make thereof, ≈øeruing for the dying of Silke e≈øpecially, and tran≈øporting great quantities to diuers Countries. It hath large broad leaues, without any prickes at all vpon them in our Country, growing vpon the ≈øtalke, which is ≈øtrong, hard, and round, with ≈øhorter leaues thereon vp to the toppe, where they are a little ≈øharpe pointed, and prickly about the edges ≈øometimes, which ≈øtalke ri≈øeth three or foure foote high, and brancheth it ≈øelfe toward the toppe, bearing at the end of euery branch one great open ≈øcaly head, out of which thru≈øteth out many gold yellow threads, of a mo≈øt orient ≈øhining colour, which being gathered in a dry time, and kept dry, will abide in the ≈øame delicate colour that it bare when it was fre≈øh, for a very long time after: when the flowers pa≈øt, the ≈øeede when it is come to maturity, which is very ≈øeldome with vs, is white and hard, ≈øomewhat long, round, and a little cornered: the roote is long, great, and wooddy, and peri≈øheth quickly with the fir≈øt fro≈øts.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It groweth in Spaine, and other hot Countries, but not wilde, for that it is accounted of the old Writers, Theophra≈øtus and Dio≈øcorides, to be a manured plant.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth with vs not vntill Augu≈øt, or September ≈øometimes, ≈øo that it hardly giueth ripe ≈øeede (as I ≈øaid) neither is it of that force to purge, which groweth in the≈øe colder Countries, as that which commeth from Spaine, and other places.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Cnicus is deriued from the Greekes, and Carthamus from the Arabians, yet ≈øtill ≈øativus is added vnto it, to ≈øhew it is no wilde, but a manured plant, and ≈øowne euery where that wee know. Of ≈øome it is called Crocus horten≈øis, and Sara≈øenicus, from the Italians which ≈øo call it. We call it in Engli≈øh Ba≈øtard Saffron, Spani≈øh Saffron, and Catalonia Saffron.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The flowers are v≈øed in colouring meates, where it groweth beyond Sea, and al≈øo for the dying of Silkes: the kernels of the ≈øeede are onely v≈øed in Phy≈øicke with vs, and ≈øerueth well to purge melancholicke humours.

div.head: Carduus. Thi≈øtles.
div.p:
YOu may ≈øomewhat maruaile, to ≈øee mee curious to plant Thi≈øtles in my Garden, when as you might well ≈øay, they are rather plagues then plea≈øures, and more trouble to weede them out, then to cheri≈øh them vp, if I made therein no di≈øtinction or choi≈øe; but when you haue viewed them well which I bring in, I will
then abide your cen≈øure, if they be not worthy of ≈øome place, although it be but a corner of the Garden, where ≈øomething mu≈øt needes be to fill vp roome. Some of them are ≈ømooth, and without prickes at all, ≈øome at the heads onely, and ≈øome all ouer; but yet not without ≈øome e≈øpeciall note or marke worthy of re≈øpect: Out of this di≈øcour≈øe I leaue the Artichoke, with all his kindes, and re≈øerue them for our Kitchin Garden, becau≈øe (as all know) they are for the plea≈øure of the ta≈øte, and not of the ≈ømell or ≈øight.

div.head: 1. Acanthus ≈øativus. Garden Beares breech.
div.p: The leaues of this kinde of ≈ømooth thi≈øtle (as it is accounted) are almo≈øt as large as the leaues of the Artichoke, but not ≈øo ≈øharp pointed, very deeply cut in and ga≈øhed on both edges, of a ≈øad green & ≈øhining colour on the vpper≈øide, and of a yellowi≈øh green vnderneath, with a great thicke rib in the middle, which ≈øpread them≈øelues about the root, taking vp a great deale of ground. After this plant hath ≈øtood long in one place, and well defended from the iniury of the cold, it ≈øendeth forth from among the leaues one or more great and ≈øtrong ≈øtalkes, three or foure foote high, without any branch at all, bearing from the middle to the top many flowers one aboue another, ≈øpike-fa≈øhion round about the ≈øtalke, with ≈ømaller but not diuided greene leaues at euery flower, which is white, and fa≈øhioned ≈øomewhat like vnto a gaping mouth; after which come broad, flat, thicke, round, browni≈øh yellow ≈øeede (as I haue well ob≈øerued by them haue beene ≈øent me out of Spaine, and which haue ≈øprung vp, and doe grow with me; for in our Countrey I could neuer ob≈øerue any ≈øeede to haue growne ripe) the rootes are compo≈øed of many great and thicke long ≈øtrings, which ≈øpread farre in and vnder the ground, ≈øomewhat darki≈øh on the out≈øide, and whiti≈øh within, full of a clammy moi≈øture (whereby it ≈øheweth to haue much life) and doe endure our Winters, if they be not too much expo≈øed to the ≈øharpe violence thereof, which then it will not endure, as I haue often found by experience.

div.head: 2. Acanthus ≈øilue≈øtris. Wilde or prickly Beares breech.
div.p: This prickly Thi≈øtle hath diuers long greeni≈øh leaues lying on the ground, much narrower then the former, but cut in on both ≈øides, thicke ≈øet with many white prickes and thornes on the edges: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth not vp ≈øo high, bearing diuers ≈øuch like thornie leaues on them, with ≈øuch a like head of flowers on it as the former hath: but the ≈øeede hereof (as it hath come to vs from Italy and other places, for I neuer ≈øaw it beare ≈øeed here in this Country) is blacke and round, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a ≈ømall pea≈øe: the roote abideth rea≈øonable well, if it be defended ≈øomewhat from the extremity of our Winters, or el≈øe it will peri≈øh.

div.head: 3. Eringium Pannonicum ≈øiue Montanum. Hungary Sea Holly.
div.p: The lower leaues of this Thi≈øtle that lye on the ground, are ≈øomewhat large, round, and broad, hard in handling, and a little ≈ønipt about the edges, euery one ≈øtanding vpon a long foote-≈øtalke: but tho≈øe that growe vpon the ≈øtalke, which is ≈øtiffe, two or three foote high, haue no foote-≈øtalke, but encompa≈ø≈øe it, two being ≈øet at euery ioynt, the toppe whereof is diuided into diuers branches, bearing ≈ømall round rough heads, with ≈ømaller and more prickly leaues vnder them, and more cut in on the ≈øides then tho≈øe belowe: out of the≈øe heads ri≈øe many blew flowers, the foote-≈øtalkes of the flowers, together with the toppes of the branches, are likewi≈øe blew and tran≈øparent, or ≈øhining.

Flore albo.We haue another of this kinde, the whole toppes of the ≈øtalkes, with the heads and branches, are more white then blew: the ≈øeede contained in the≈øe heads are white, flat, and as it were chaffie: the roote is great and whiti≈øh, ≈øpreading farre into many branches, and ≈øomewhat ≈øweete in ta≈øte, like the ordinary Sea Holly rootes.

div.head: 4. Carduus mollis. The gentle Thi≈øtle.
div.p:
The leaues of this ≈øoft and gentle Thi≈øtle that are next vnto the ground, are greene
1
‚Ä¢ canthus ≈øativus. Garden Beares breech. 2 Acanthus ≈øilue≈øtris. Wilde Beares breech. 3 Eringium Pann ‚Ä¢ nicum Mountaine Sea Holly. 4 Carlina humilis. The lowe Carline Thi≈øtle. 5 Carduus ≈øphaerocephalus maior. The greater Globe-Thi≈øtle. 6 Carduus ≈øphaerocephalus minor. The le≈ø≈øer Globe-Thi≈øtle. 7 Carduus Eriocaphalus. The Friers crowne. 8 Fraxinella. Ba≈øtard Dittanie. depiction of flowers
on the vpper≈øide, and hoary vnderneath, broad at the bottome, ≈øomewhat long pointed, and vneuenly notched about the edges, with ≈øome ≈øoft hairie prickles, not hurting the handler, euery one ≈øtanding vpon a ≈øhort foote-≈øtalke; tho≈øe that growe about the middle ≈øtalke are like the former, but ≈ømaller and narrower, and tho≈øe next the toppe ≈ømalle≈øt, where it diuideth it ≈øelfe into ≈ømall branches, bearing long and ≈øcaly heads, out of which breake many reddi≈øh purple threads: the ≈øeede is whiti≈øh and hard, almo≈øt as great as the ≈øeede of the greater Centory: the roote is blacki≈øh, ≈øpreading vnder the ground, with many ≈ømall fibres fa≈øtened vnto it, and abideth a great while.

div.head: 5. Carlina humilis. The lowe Carline Thi≈øtle.
div.p: This lowe Thi≈øtle hath many iagged leaues, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, armed with ≈ømall ≈øharp white prickles round about the edges, lying round about the root vpon the ground, in the middle whereof ri≈øeth vp a large head, without any ≈øtalke vnder it, compa≈ø≈øed about with many ≈ømall and long prickly leaues, from among which the flower ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, compo≈øed of many thin, long, whiti≈øh, hard ≈øhining leaues, ≈øtanding about the middle, which is flat and yellow, made of many thrums or threads like ≈ømall flowers, wherein lye ≈ømall long ≈øeede, of a whiti≈øh or ≈øiluer colour: the roote is ≈øomewhat aromaticall, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, ≈ømall and long, growing downewards into the ground. There is another of this kinde that beareth a higher ≈øtalke, and a redder flower, but there is a manife≈øt difference betweene them.

div.head: 6. Carduus Sphaerocephalus ≈øiue Globo≈øus maior. The greater Globe Thi≈øtle.
div.p: The greate≈øt of the≈øe beautifull Thi≈øtles, hath at the fir≈øt many large and long leaues lying on the ground, very much cut in and diuided in many places, euen to the middle ribbe, ≈øet with ≈ømall ≈øharpe (but not very ≈øtrong) thornes or prickles at euery corner of the edges, greene on the vpper≈øide, and whiti≈øh vnderneath: from the middle of the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a round ≈øtiffe ≈øtalke, three foote and a halfe high, or more, ≈øet without order with ≈øuch like leaues, bearing at the toppe of euery branch a round hard great head, con≈øi≈øting of a number of ≈øharpe bearded huskes, compact or ≈øet clo≈øe together, of a blewi≈øh greene colour, out of euery one of which huskes ≈øtart ≈ømall whiti≈øh blew flowers, with white threads in the middle of them, and ri≈øing aboue them, ≈øo that the heads when they are in full flower, make a fine ≈øhew, much delighting the ≈øpectators: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the ≈øeede encrea≈øeth in euery one, or the mo≈øt part of the bearded huskes, which doe ≈øtill hold their round forme, vntill that being ripe it openeth it ≈øelfe, and the huskes ea≈øily fall away one from another, containing within them a long whiti≈øh kernell: the roote is great and long, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and dyeth euery yeare when it hath borne ≈øeede.

div.head: 7. Carduus Globo≈øus minor. The le≈ø≈øer Globe Thi≈øtle.
div.p: The le≈ø≈øer kinde hath long narrow leaues, whiter then the former, but cut in and ga≈øhed on the edges very much with ≈øome ≈ømall prickes on them; the ≈øtalke is not halfe ≈øo long, nor the heads halfe ≈øo great, but as round, and with as blew flowers as the greater: this ≈øeldome giueth ripe ≈øeede, but recompen≈øeth that fault, in that the roote peri≈øheth not as the former, but abideth many yeares.

div.head: 8. Carduus Eriocephalus ≈øiue Tomento≈øus. The Friers Crowne.
div.p:
This woolly Thi≈øtle hath many large and long leaues lying on the ground, cut in on both ≈øides into many diui≈øions, which are likewi≈øe ≈øomewhat vnequally cut in or diuided againe, hauing ≈øharpe white prickles at euery corner of the diui≈øions, of a dead or ≈øad greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and ≈øomewhat woolly withall, and grayi≈øh vnderneath: the ≈øtalke is ≈øtrong and tall, foure or fiue foote high at the lea≈øt, branching out into diuers parts, euery where be≈øet with ≈øuch like leaues as growe below; at the toppe of euery branch there breaketh out a great whiti≈øh round prickly head, flatti≈øh at the toppe, ≈øo thicke ≈øet with wooll, that the prickles ≈øeeme but ≈ømall ≈øpots or haires,
and doth ≈øo well re≈øemble the bald crowne of a Frier, not onely before it be in flower, but e≈øpecially after it hath done flowring, that thereupon it de≈øeruedly receiued the name of the Friers Crowne Thi≈øtle: out of the≈øe heads ri≈øeth forth a purple thrumme, ≈øuch as is to be ≈øeene in many other wilde Thi≈øtles, which when they are ripe, are full of a flockie or woolly ≈øub≈øtance, which breake at the toppe ≈øhedding it, and the ≈øeede which is blacki≈øh, flat, and ≈ømooth: the roote is great and thicke, enduring for ≈øome yeares, yet ≈øometimes peri≈øhing, if it be too much expo≈øed to the violence of the fro≈øts in Winter.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth naturally in Spaine, Italy, and France, and in many other hot Countries, and growe onely in Gardens in the≈øe colder climates, and there cheri≈øhed for the beautifull a≈øpect both of the greene plants, and of the ≈øtalkes when they are in flower. The Carline Thi≈øtle is found both in Germany and Italy in many places, and as it is reported, in ≈øome places of the We≈øt parts in England. The others are found ≈øome in France, ≈øome in Hungary, and on the Alpes, and the la≈øt in Spaine.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They doe all flower in the Summer moneths, ≈øome a little earlier or later then others.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called Acanthus ≈øativus (becau≈øe the other that is prickly, is called ≈øilue≈øtris or ≈øpino≈øus) and Branea vr≈øina; In Engli≈øh, Branck vrfine, and Beares breech. The third is called Eringium montanum, Alpinum, and Pannonicum latifolium: In Engli≈øh, Mountaine or Hungary Sea Holly. The fourth is called Carduus mollis, The gentle Thi≈øtle, becau≈øe it hath no harmfull prickles, although it ≈øeeme at the fir≈øt ≈øhew to be a Thi≈øtle. The fifth is called of diuers Chamaeleo albus, and Carlina, as if they were both but one plant; but Fabius Columna hath in my iudgement very learnedly de≈øcided that controuer≈øie, making Carlina to be Ixine of Theophra≈øtus, and Chamaeleo another differing Thi≈øtle, which Gaza tran≈ølateth Vernilago. We call it in Engli≈øh, The Carline Thi≈øtle. The other haue their names in their titles, as much as is conuenient for this di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: The Vertues.
