div.p: The fir≈øt hath alwaies been v≈øed Phy≈øically, as a mollifying herbe among others of the like ≈ølimie matter in Gli≈øters, to open the body; yet Lob ‚Ä¢ l ≈øeemeth to make no difference in the v≈øe of them both (that is, the prickly as well as the ≈ømooth.) The Carline Thi≈øtle is thought to bee good again≈øt poy≈øons and infection. The re≈øt are not v≈øed by any that I know.

div.head: Fraxinella. Ba≈øtard Dittany.
div.p: HAuing fini≈øhed tho≈øe plea≈øing Thi≈øtles, I come to other plants of more gentle handling, and fir≈øt bring to your con≈øideration this ba≈øtard Dittany, whereof there are found out two e≈øpeciall kindes, the one with a reddi≈øh, the other with a whiti≈øh flower, and each of the≈øe hath his diuer≈øity, as ≈øhall be pre≈øently declared.

div.head: 1. Fraxinella flore rubente. Ba≈øtard Dittany with a reddi≈øh flower.
div.p:
This goodly plant ri≈øeth vp with diuers round, hard, browni≈øh ≈øtalkes, neare two
foote high, the lower parts whereof are furni≈øhed with many winged leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto Liquerice, or a ≈ømall young A≈øhe tree, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeuen, nine, or eleuen leaues ≈øet together, which are ≈øomewhat large and long, hard and rough in handling, of a darki≈øh greene colour, and of an vnplea≈øant ≈øtrong re≈øinous ≈øent: the vpper parts of the ≈øtalkes are furni≈øhed with many flowers, growing ≈øpike fa≈øhion, at certaine di≈øtances one aboue another, con≈øi≈øting of fiue long leaues a peece, whereof foure that ≈øtand on the two ≈øides, are ≈øomewhat bending vpwards, and the fift hanging downe, but turning vp the end of the leafe a little againe, of a faint or pale red colour, ≈øtriped through euery leafe with a deeper red colour, and hauing in the middle a ta≈ø≈øell of fiue or ≈øix long purpli≈øh threds, that bowe downe with the lower leafe, and turne vp al≈øo the ends againe, with a little free≈øe or thrume at the ends of euery one: after the flowers are pa≈øt, ari≈øe hard, ≈øtiffe, rough, clammy huskes, horned or pointed at the end, foure or fiue ≈øtanding together, ≈øomewhat like the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels of the Wolfes-banes, or Colombines, but greater, thicker and harder, wherein is contained round ≈øhining blacke ≈øeede, greater then any Colombine ≈øeede by much, and ≈ømaller then Peony ≈øeede: the roote is white, large, and ≈øpreading many wayes vnder ground, if it ≈øtand long: the whole plant, as well roots as leaues and flowers, are of a ≈øtrong ≈øent, not ≈øo plea≈øing for the ≈ømell, as the flowers are beautifull to the ≈øight.

div.head: 2. Fraxinella flore rubro. Ba≈øtard Dittaine with a red flower.
div.p: This differeth not from the former eyther in roote, leafe or flower for the forme, but that the ≈øtalkes and leaues are of a darker greene colour, and that the flowers are of a deeper red colour, (and growing in a little longer ≈øpike) wherein the difference chiefly con≈øi≈øteth, which is ≈øufficient to di≈øtingui≈øh them.

div.head: 3. Fraxinella flore albo. Ba≈øtard Dittanie with a white flower.
div.p: The white flowred Fraxinella hath his leaues and ≈øtalkes of a fre≈øher greene colour then any of the former; and the flowers are of a pure white colour, in forme differing nothing at all from the other.

div.head: 4. Fraxinella flore albo caeruleo. Ba≈øtard Dittanie with an a≈øh coloured flower.
div.p: The colour of the flower of this Fraxinella onely putteth the difference betweene this, and the la≈øt recited with a white flower: for this beareth very pale, or whiti≈øh blew flower, tending to an a≈øh colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe kindes are found growing naturally, in many places both of Germany, and Italie: and that with the white flower, about Franckford, which being ≈øent me, peri≈øhed by the way by long and euill carriage.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Iune and Iuly, and the ≈øeede is ripe in Augu≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Fraxinella is mo≈øt generally impo≈øed on tho≈øe plants, becau≈øe of the re≈øemblance of them vnto young A≈øhes, in their winged leaues. Yet ≈øome doe call them Dictamus albus, or Dictamnus albus, and Diptamus albus, as a difference from the Dictamnus Creticus, which is a farre differing plant. Some would haue it to be Tragium of Dio≈øcorides, but be≈øide other things wherein this differeth from Tragium, this yeeldeth no milkie iuice, as Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith Tragium doth: We in Engli≈øh doe eyther call it Fraxinella, or after the other corrupted name of Dictamus, Ba≈øtard Dittanie.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is held to be profitable again≈øt the ≈øtingings of Serpents, again≈øt contagious and pe≈øtilent di≈øea≈øes, to bring downe the feminine cour≈øes, for the paines of the belly and the ≈øtone, and in Epilepticall di≈øea≈øes, and other cold paines of the braines: the roote is the mo≈øt effectuall for all the≈øe, yet the ≈øeede is ≈øometimes v≈øed.

div.head: Legumina. Pul≈øe.
div.p: IF I ≈øhould de≈øcribe vnto you all the kindes of Pul≈øe, I ≈øhould vnfold a little world of varieties therein, more knowne and found out in the≈øe dayes, then at any time before, but that mu≈øt bee a part of a greater worke, which will abide a longer time before it ≈øee the light. I ≈øhall only ≈øelect tho≈øe that are fit for this garden, and ≈øet them downe for your con≈øideration. All ≈øorts of Pul≈øe may be reduced vnder two generall heads, that is, of Beanes and Pea≈øe, of each whereof there is both tame and wilde: Of Beanes, be≈øides the tame or v≈øuall garden Beane, and the French or Kidney Beane, (whereof I meane to entreate in my Kitchen garden, as pertinent thereto) there is the Lupine or flat Beane, whereof I meane to entreate here, and the blacke Beane and others which mu≈øt bee re≈øerued for the Phy≈øicke Garden. And of the kindes of Pea≈øe ≈øome are fit for this Garden; (whereunto I will adioyne two or three other plants as neere≈øt of affinitie, the flowers of ≈øome, and the fruit of others being delightfull to many, and therefore fit for this garden) ≈øome for the Kitchen, the re≈øt for the Phy≈øicke garden. And fir≈øt of Lupines or flat Beanes, accepted as delightfull to many, and therefore fit for this garden.

div.head: 1. Lupinus ≈øativus albus. The white garden Lupine.
div.p: The garden Lupine ri≈øeth vp with a great round ≈øtalke, hollow and ≈øomewhat woolly, with diuers branches, whereon grow vpon long foote≈øtalkes many broade leaues, diuided into ≈øeuen or nine parts, or ≈ømaller leaues, equally ≈øtanding round about, as it were in a circle, of a whiti≈øh greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and more wholly vnderneath: the flowers ≈øtand many together at ≈øeuerall ioynts, both of the greater ≈øtalke, and the branches, like vnto beanes, and of a white colour in ≈øome places, and in others of a very bleake blew tending to white: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places, long, broade, and flat rough cods, wherein are contained round and flat ≈øeede, yellowi≈øh on the in≈øide, and couered with a tough white skin, and very bitter in ta≈øte: the rootes are not very great, but full of ≈ømall fibres, whereby it fa≈øteneth it ≈øelfe ≈øtrongly in the ground, yet peri≈øheth euery yeare, as all the re≈øt of the≈øe kindes doe.

div.head: 2. Lupinus caeruleus maximus. The greater blew Lupine.
div.p: The Stemme or ≈øtalke of this Lupine is greater then the la≈øt before recited, as al≈øo the leaues more ≈øoft and woolly, and the flowers are of a mo≈øt perfect blew colour, with ≈øome white ≈øpots in the middle: the long rough greeni≈øh cods are very great and large, wherein are contained hard, flat and round ≈øeede, not ≈øo white on the out≈øide as the former, but ≈øomewhat yellower, greater al≈øo, and more rough or hard in handling.

div.head: 3. Lupinus caeruleus minor. The le≈ø≈øer blew Lupine.
div.p:
This kinde of wilde Lupine differeth not in the forme of leafe or flower from the former, but only that it is much ≈ømaller, the leaues are greener, and haue fewer diui≈øions in them: the flower is of as deepe a blew colour as the la≈øt; the cods likewi≈øe are ≈ømall and long, containing ≈ømall round ≈øeede, not ≈øo flat as the former, but more
di≈øcoloured or ≈øpotted on the out≈øide,Minimus. then the greater kinde is. There is a le≈ø≈øer kind then this, not differing in any thing from this, but that it is le≈ø≈øer.

div.head: 4. Lupinus flore luteo. The yellow Lupine.
div.p: The yellow Lupine groweth not v≈øually ≈øo high, but with larger leaues then the ≈ømall blew Lupine; the flowers grow in two or three rundles or tufts, round about the ≈øtalke and the branches at the ioynts, of a delicate fine yellow colour, like in fa≈øhion vnto the other kindes, being larger then the la≈øt, but nothing ≈øo large as the greater kindes, and of a fine ≈ømall ≈øent: the ≈øeede is round, and not flat, but much about the forme and bigne≈ø≈øe of the ≈ømall blew, or ≈øomewhat bigger, of a whiti≈øh colour on the out≈øide, ≈øpotted with many ≈øpots.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in many places of Greece, and the Ea≈øterne Countries beyond it, where it hath beene anciently cheri≈øhed for their foode, being often watered to take away the bitterne≈ø≈øe. It groweth al≈øo in the≈øe We≈øtern parts, but ≈øtill where it is planted. The great blew Lupine is thought to come from beyond the parts of Per≈øia, in Caramania. The le≈ø≈øer blew is found very plentifully wilde, in many places both of Spaine and Italy. The la≈øt hath beene brought vs likewi≈øe out of Spaine, whereas it is thought it groweth naturally. They all grow now in the gardens of tho≈øe, that are curious louers of the≈øe delights.

div.head: The Time.
div.p:
They flower in Summer, and their ≈øeede is
‚Ä¢ ipe quickly after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are generally called Lupini. Plautus in his time ≈øaith, they were v≈øed in Comedies in ≈øtead of money, when in any Scene thereof there was any ≈øhew of payment, and therefore he calleth them Aurum Comicum. And Horace hath this Ver≈øe, Nec tamen ignorant, quid distent aera Lupinis, to ≈øhew that counterfeit money (≈øuch as counters are with vs, or as the≈øe Lupines were v≈øed in tho≈øe times) was ea≈øily knowne from true and currant coine. In Engli≈øh wee v≈øually call them after the Latine name, Lupines; and ≈øome after the Dutch name, Figge-beanes, becau≈øe they are flat and round as a Figge that is pre≈ø≈øed; and ≈øome Flat-beanes for the ≈øame rea≈øon. Some haue called the yellow Lupine, Spani≈øh Violets: but other fooli≈øh names haue beene giuen it, as Virginia Ro≈øes, and the like, by knaui≈øh Gardiners and others, to deceiue men, and make them beleeue they were the finders out, or great pre≈øeruers of rarities, of no other purpo≈øe, but to cheate men of their money: as you would therefore auoyde knaues and deceiuers, beware of the≈øe manner of people, whereof the skirts of our towne are too pitifully pe≈øtered.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The fir≈øt or ordinary Lupine doth ≈øcoure and clean≈øe the skin from ≈øpots, morphew, blew markes, and other di≈øcolourings thereof, beeing v≈øed eyther in a decoction or pont ‚Ä¢ er. Wee ≈øeldome v≈øe it in inward medicines, not that it is dangerous, but of neglect, for formerly it hath beene much v≈øed for the wormes, &c.

figure.head:
1 Lupinus maior. The great Lupine. 2 Lupinus lut ‚Ä¢ us. The yellow Lupine. 3 Lathyrus laetifolius ≈øeu Pi≈øum pere ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Pea≈øe euerla≈øting 4 Pi≈øu ‚Ä¢ quadratum. The crim≈øon blo≈ø≈øomd or ≈øquare Pea≈øe. 5 Medica cochleatae vulgaris Snailes or Barbary buttons. 6 Medica ≈øpino≈øae. Prickly Snailes. 7 Medica ≈øpino≈øa altera. Another ≈øort o ‚Ä¢ prickly Snailes. 8 Medica folliculo lato. Broad buttons o ‚Ä¢ Snailes. 9 Medica Lunata. Halfe Moons. 10 Ho
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ clypeatum. The red Sattin flower, or French Hony≈øuckle. 11 Scorpioides minus. The le≈ø≈øer Caterpiller. 12 Scorpioides maius. The greater Caterpiller. 13 Orobus Venetus. Blew vpright Pea≈øe euerla≈øting.

div.head: 1. Lathyrus latifolius, ≈øiue Pi≈øum perenne. Pea≈øe euerla≈øting.
div.p: This kinde of wilde Pea≈øe that abideth long, and groweth euery yeare greater then other, ≈øpringeth vp with many broade trayling branches, winged as it were on both the ≈øides, diuer≈øly diuided into other ≈ømaller branches, at the ≈øeuerall ioynts whereof ≈øtand two hard, not broad, but ≈øomewhat long greene leaues, and diuers twining cla≈øpers, in ≈øundry places with the leaues, from betweene the branches and the leaues, at the ioynts towards the toppes, come forth diuers purpli≈øh pea≈øe like blo≈ø≈øomes, ≈øtanding on a long ≈øtemme or ≈øtalke, very beautifull to behold, and of a pretty ≈øent or ≈ømell: after which come ≈ømall, long, thin, flat, hard skind cods, containing ≈ømall round blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is great and thicke, growing downe deepe into the ground, of the thickne≈ø≈øe ≈øometimes of a mans arme, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and whiti≈øh within, with ≈øome branches and a few fibres annexed thereunto.

div.head: 2. Orobus Venetus. Blew vpright euerla≈øting Pea≈øe.
div.p: This pretty kinde of Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øome beareth diuers ≈ølender, but vpright greene branches ≈øomewhat cornered, two foote high or thereabouts, hauing at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances on both ≈øides of them certaine winged leaues, ≈øet together vpon long foote≈øtalkes one again≈øt another, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix or eight leaues, ≈øomewhat broade and pointed, and without any odde one at the end: at the ioynts toward the toppes, between the leaues and the ≈øtalkes, come forth many flowers ≈øet together at the end of a pretty long foote≈øtalke, of the fa≈øhion of the former Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øome, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and of a purpli≈øh violet colour: after which come ≈ølender and long pointed pods rounder then they, wherein is contained ≈ømall round grayi≈øh pea≈øe: the roote is blacke, hard or woody, abiding after ≈øeede bearing as the former doth, and ≈øhooting afre≈øh euery yeare.

div.head: 3. Lathyrus annuus ≈øiliquis orobi. Partie coloured Cichelings.
div.p: This ≈ømall Pul≈øe or wild Pea≈øe, hath two or three long ≈ølender winged branches, with ≈ømaller leaues theron then the former, and without any cla≈øpers at all on them: the flowers ≈øtand ≈øingle, euery one by it ≈øelfe, or two at the mo≈øt together, the middle leaues whereof that clo≈øe together are white, and the vpper leaues of a reddi≈øh purple colour: after which come long round flatti≈øh cods, bunched out in the ≈øeuerall places where the ≈øeedes lye, like vnto the cods of Orobus or the bitter Vetch, but greater: the roote is ≈ømall and dyeth euery yeare.

div.head: 4. Pi≈øum quadratum. The crim≈øon blo≈ø≈øomd or ≈øquare codded Pea≈øe.
div.p: This pretty kinde of Pul≈øe might very well for the forme of the leaues, be referred to the kindes of Lotus or Trefoiles: but becau≈øe I haue none of that kindred to entreate of in this Worke, I haue thought fitte≈øt to place it here before the Medica's, becau≈øe both pods and ≈øeedes are like al≈øo. It hath three or foure ≈ømall weake ≈øtalkes, diuided into many branches, hauing two ≈øtalkes of leaues at euery ioynt, and three ≈ømall ≈øoft leaues ≈øtanding on a very ≈ømall ≈øtalke, comming from the ioynts: the flowers ≈øtand for the mo≈øt part two together, of a perfect red or crim≈øon colour, like in forme almo≈øt vnto a Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øome; after which come long thicke and round cods, with two skinnes or filmes, running all along the cod at the backe or vpper≈øide, and two other ≈øuch like filmes, all along the belly or vnder ≈øide, which make it ≈øeeme foure ≈øquare, wherein there lye round di≈øcoloured Pea≈øe, ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller and harder then ordinary Pea≈øe: the roote is ≈ømall and peri≈øheth euery yeare.

div.head: 5. Medica Cochleata vulgaris. Snailes or Barbary buttons.
div.p:
The plant that beareth the≈øe pretty toyes for Gentlewomen, is ≈øomewhat like vnto a Three leafed gra≈ø≈øe or Trefoile, hauing many long trayling branches lying vpon the ground, whereon at diuers places are three ≈ømall greene leaues, ≈øet together at the end of a little foote≈øtalke, each of them a little ≈ønipt about the edges: at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances,
from the middle of the≈øe branches to the ends of them, come forth the flowers, two for the mo≈øt part ≈øtanding together vpon a little foot≈øtalke, which are of a pale yellow colour, very ≈ømall, and of the forme of a Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øome: after which come ≈ømooth heads, which are turned or writhen round, almo≈øt like a Snaile, hard and greene at the fir≈øt, ≈øomewhat like a greene button (from the formes of both which came their names) but afterwards growing whiter, more ≈øoft and open, wherein lyeth yellowi≈øh round and flat ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat like vnto the Kidney beane: the roote is ≈ømall and ≈øtringie, dying downe euery yeare, and mu≈øt be new ≈øowne in the ≈øpring, if you de≈øire to haue it.

div.head: 6. Medica ≈øpino≈øa maior. Prickly or thorny Snailes, or Buttons.
div.p: This kinde of Medica is in all things very like vnto the former, both in the long trayling branches, & three leaues alwaies growing together, but a little greater pale yellow flowers, and crooked or winding heads: but herein chiefly con≈øi≈øteth the difference, that this kinde hath his heads or buttons harder, a little greater, more clo≈øed together, and ≈øet with ≈øhort and ≈øomewhat hard prickles, all the head ouer, which being pulled open, haue tho≈øe prickles ≈øtanding on each ≈øide of the filme or skinne, whereof the head con≈øi≈øteth, ≈øomewhat like vnto a fi≈øh bone, and in this kinde goeth all one way; in which are contained ≈øuch like ≈øeedes for the forme, as are in the former, but great and blacke, and ≈øhining withall.

div.head: 7. Medica ≈øpino≈øa altera. Small thorney Buttons, or Snailes.
div.p: This other kinde is al≈øo like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed in all other things, except in the heads or buttons, which are a little ≈ømaller, but ≈øet with longer and ≈øofter prickes vpon the filmes, and may ea≈øily bee di≈øcerned to goe both forwards and backewards, one enterlacing within another, wherein are contained ≈øuch like flat and blacke ≈øhining ≈øeede, made after the fa≈øhion of a kidney, as are in the former, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller: the roote peri≈øheth in like manner euery yeare.

div.head: 8. Medica lata. Broade Buttons.
div.p: This kinde differeth not from the fir≈øt in leafe or flower, the fruite onely hereof is broade and flat, and not ≈øo much twined as it.

div.head: 9. Medica Lunata. Halfe Moones.
div.p: This is al≈øo a kinde of the≈øe Medicke fodders, hauing a trefoyle leafe and yellow flowers like the former ≈øorts, but both ≈øomewhat larger, the chiefe≈øt different con≈øi≈øteth in the head or fruite, which is broade and flat, and not twined like the re≈øt, but abideth halfe clo≈øed, re≈øembling a halfe Moone (and thereupon hath a≈ø≈øumed both the Latine and Engli≈øh name) wherein is contained flat ≈øeede, kidney fa≈øhion like the former.

div.head: 10. Hedy≈øarum clypeatum. The red Sattin flower.
div.p:
This red flowred Fitchling, hath many ≈øtalkes of winged faire greene leaues, that is, of many ≈øet on both ≈øides a middle ribbe, whereof that at the end is the greate≈øt of the re≈øt: from the ioynts where the leaues ≈øtand, come forth pretty long ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, bearing on them very many flowers, vp to the toppe one aboue another, of an excellent ≈øhining red or crim≈øon colour, very like vnto Sattin of that colour, and ≈øometimes of a white colour, (as Ma≈øter William Coys, a Gentleman of good re≈øpect in E≈ø≈øex, a great and ancient louer and cheri≈øher of the≈øe delights, and of all other rare plants, in his life time a≈ø≈øured me, he had growing in his garden at Stubbers by North Okenden) which are ≈øomewhat large, and more clo≈øed together, almo≈øt flat and not open, as in mo≈øt of the other ≈øorts: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come rough, flat, round huskes, ≈øomewhat like vnto the old fa≈øhioned round bucklers without pikes, three or foure ≈øtanding one vpon or aboue another, wherein are contained
≈ømall browni≈øh ≈øeede: the roote peri≈øheth the ≈øame yeare it beareth ≈øeede, for oftentimes it flowreth not the fir≈øt yeare it is ≈øowne.

div.head: 11. Scorpioides maius & minus. Great and ≈ømall Caterpillers.
div.p: Vnder one de≈øcription I comprehend both the≈øe ≈øorts of Scorpions gra≈ø≈øe, or Caterpillers, or Wormes, as they are called by many, whereof the greater hath been known but of late yeares; and ioyne them to the≈øe pul≈øes, not hauing a fitter place where to in≈øert them. It is but a ≈ømall low plant, with branches lying vpon the ground, and ≈øomewhat long, broad, and hard leaues theron, among which come forth ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, bearing at the end for the mo≈øt part, two ≈ømall pale yellowi≈øh flowers, like vnto Tares or Vetches, but ≈ømaller, which turne into writhed or crooked tough cods; in the greater ≈øort they are much thicker, rounder and whiter, and le≈ø≈øer wound or turned together then in the ≈ømaller, which are ≈ølenderer, more winding, yet not clo≈øing like vnto the Snailes, and blacker more like vnto a Caterpiller then the other, wherein are contained browni≈øh yellow ≈øeede, much like vnto a Medica: the rootes of both are ≈ømall and fibrous, peri≈øhing euery yeare.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe are found ≈øeuerally in diuers and ≈øeuerall places, but wee ≈øow and plant them v≈øually to furni≈øh our gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They doe all flower about the moneths of Iune and Iuly, and their ≈øeede is ripe ≈øoone after: but the ≈øecond is earlier then the re≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called Clymenum of Matthiolus, and Lathyris of Lobel and others: but Lathyris in Greeke is Cataputia in Latine, which is our Spurge, farre differing from this Pul≈øe; and therefore Lathyrus is more proper to di≈øtingui≈øh them a≈øunder, that two plants ≈øo farre vnlike ≈øhould not bee called by one name: this is al≈øo called Lathyrus latifolius, becau≈øe there is another called augu≈øtifolius, that differeth from it al≈øo: It is mo≈øt v≈øually called with vs, Pi≈øum perenne, and in Engli≈øh Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øome, or Pea≈øe euerla≈øting. The ≈øecond is called by Clu≈øius, Orobus venetus, becau≈øe it was ≈øent him from Venice, with another of the ≈øame kinde that bore white flowers; yet differeth but little or nothing from that kinde he found in Hungary, that I thinke the ≈øeuerall places of their growing only cau≈øe them to beare ≈øeuerall names, and to be the ≈øame in deede. Although I yeeld vnto Clu≈øius the Latine name which doth not ≈øufficiently content mee; yet I haue thought good to giue it a differing Engli≈øh name, according as it is in the title. The third, becau≈øe I fir≈øt receiued it among other ≈øeeds from Spaine, I haue giuen it the name, as it is entituled. The fourth is called of ≈øome Sand ‚Ä¢ lida Cretica, & Lotus ≈øiliquo≈øus flore rubello, Lotus tetragonolobus, Pi≈øum rubrum, & Pi≈øum quadratum: We v≈øually call it in Engli≈øh, Crim≈øon Pea≈øe, or ≈øquare Pea≈øe. The Medica Cochleata is called of Dodonaeus Trifolium Cochleatum, but not iudged to be the true Medica. Wee call it in Engli≈øh, Medick fodder, Snailes Clauer, or as it is in the title, and ≈øo the re≈øt of the Medica's accordingly. The Hedy≈øarum clypeatum or Securidaca is called of Dodonaeus Onobrichis altera, and we in Engli≈øh for the likene≈ø≈øe, The red Sattin flower, although ≈øome fooli≈øhly call it, the red or French Hony≈øuckle. The la≈øt is called by Lobel, Scorpioides bupleurifolio, I haue called it minus, becau≈øe the greate≈øt ≈øort which came to me out of Spaine was not knowne vnto him: in Engli≈øh they are generally called Caterpillers.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Medica's are generally thought to feede cattell fat much more then the Medow Trefoile, or Clauer gra≈ø≈øe, and therefore I haue known diuers Gentlemen that haue plowed vp ≈øome of their pa≈øture grounds, and ≈øowen them with the ≈øeedes of ≈øome Medica's to make the experience. All the other ≈øorts are plea≈øures to delight the curious, and not any way profitable in Phy≈øicke that I know.

div.head: Paeonia. Peonie.
div.p: THere are two principall kindes of Peonie, that is to ≈øay, the Male and the Female. Of the male kinde, I haue onely known one ≈øort, but of the Female a great many; which are thus to be di≈øtingui≈øhed. The Male his leafe is whole, without any particular diui≈øion, notch or dent on the edge, & his rootes long & round, diuided into many branches, ≈øomewhat like to the rootes of Gentian or Elecampane, and not tuberous at all. The Female of all ≈øorts hath the leaues diuided or cut in on the edges, more or le≈ø≈øe, and hath alwaies tuberous rootes, that is, like clogs or A≈øphodill rootes, with many great thick round peeces hanging, or growing at the end of ≈ømaller ≈øtrings, and all ioyned to the toppe of the maine roote.

div.head: 1. Paeonia mas. The Male Peonie.
div.p: The Male Peonie ri≈øeth vp with many browni≈øh ≈øtalkes, whereon doe grow winged leaues, that is, many faire greene, and ≈øometimes reddi≈øh leaues, one ≈øet again≈øt another vpon a ≈øtalke, without any particular diui≈øion in the leafe at all: the flowers ≈øtand at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, con≈øi≈øting of fiue or ≈øix broade leaues, of a faire purpli≈øh red colour, with many yellow threds in the middle, ≈øtanding about the head, which after ri≈øeth to be the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, diuided into two, three or foure rough crooked pods like hornes, which when they are ful ripe, open and turn them≈øelues down one edge to another backeward, ≈øhewing within them diuers round black ≈øhining ≈øeede, which are the true ≈øeede, being full and good, and hauing al≈øo many red or crim≈øon graines, which are lancke and idle, intermixed among the blacke, as if they are good ≈øeede, whereby it maketh a very pretty ≈øhew: the roots are great, thick and long, ≈øpreading in the ground, and running downe rea≈øonable deepe.

div.head: 2. Paeonia faemina vulgaris flore ≈øimplici. The ordinary ≈øingle Female Peonie.
div.p: This ordinary Female Peonie hath many ≈øtalkes, with more ≈øtore of leaues on them then the Male kinde hath, the leaues al≈øo are not ≈øo large, but diuided or nicked diuer≈øly on the edges, ≈øome with great and deepe, and others with ≈ømaller cuts or diui≈øions, and of a darke or dead greene colour: the flowers are of a ≈øtrong heady ≈øent, mo≈øt v≈øually ≈ømaller then the male, and of a more purple tending to a murrey colour, with yellow thrumes about the head in the middle, as the male kinde hath: the heads or hornes with ≈øeed are like al≈øo but ≈ømaller, the ≈øeede al≈øo is blacke, but le≈ø≈øe ≈øhining: the rootes con≈øi≈øt, as I ≈øaid, of many thicke and ≈øhort tuberous clogs, fa≈øtened at the ends of long ≈øtrings, and all from the head of the roote, which is thicke and ≈øhort, and tuberous al≈øo, of the ≈øame or the like ≈øent with the male.

div.head: 3. Paeonia faemina vulgaris flore pleno rubro. The double red Peonie.
div.p:
This double Peonie as well as the former ≈øingle, is ≈øo frequent in euerie Garden of note, through euery Countrey, that it is almo≈øt labour in vaine
to de≈øcribe it: but yet becau≈øe I v≈øe not to pa≈ø≈øe ouer any plant ≈øo ≈ølightly, I will ≈øet down the de≈øcription briefly, in regard it is ≈øo common. It is very like vnto the former ≈øingle female Peony, both in ≈øtalkes and leaues, but that it groweth ≈øomewhat higher, and the leaues are of a fre≈øher greene colour: the flowers at the tops of the ≈øtalkes are very large, thicke, and double (no flower that I know ≈øo faire, great, and double; but not abiding blowne aboue eight or ten daies) of a more reddi≈øh purple colour then the former female kinde, and of a ≈øweeter ≈øent: after the≈øe flowers are pa≈øt, ≈øometimes come good ≈øeed, which being ≈øowne, bring forth ≈øome ≈øingle flowers, and ≈øome double: the rootes are tuberous, like vnto the former female.

div.head: 4. Paeonia faemina flore carneo ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle blu≈øh Peony.
div.p: The ≈øingle blu≈øh Peony hath his ≈øtalkes higher, and his leaues of a paler or whiter greene colour then the double blu≈øh, and more white vnderneath (≈øo that it is very probable it is of another kinde, and not ri≈øen from the ≈øeede of the double blu≈øh, as ≈øome might thinke) with many veines, that are ≈øomewhat di≈øcoloured from the colour of the leafe running through them: the flowers are very large and ≈øingle, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues for the mo≈øt part, of a pale fle≈øh or blu≈øh colour, with an eye of yellow di≈øper≈øed or mixed therewith, hauing many whiti≈øh threads, tipt with yellow pendents ≈øtanding about the middle head: the rootes are like the other female Peonies.

div.head: 5. Paeonia faemina flore pleno albicante. The double blu≈øh Peony.
div.p: The double blu≈øh Peony hath not his ≈øtalkes ≈øo high as the double red, but ≈øomewhat lower and ≈øtiffer, bearing ≈øuch like winged leaues, cut in or diuided here and there in the edges, as all the≈øe female kindes are, but not ≈øo large as the la≈øt: the flowers are ≈ømaller, and le≈ø≈øe double by a good deale then the former double red, of a faint ≈øhining crim≈øon colour at the fir≈øt opening, but decaying or waxing paler euery day: ≈øo that after it hath ≈øtood long (for this flower ≈øheddeth not his leaues in a great while) it will change ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh; and therefore diuers haue ignorantly called it, the double white Peony: the ≈øeedes, which ≈øometimes it beareth, and rootes, are like vnto the former female kindes, but ≈øomewhat longer, and of a brighter colour on the out≈øide.

div.head: 6. Paeonia faemina Byzantina. The ≈øingle red Peony of Con≈øtantinople.
div.p: This red Peony of Con≈øtantinople is very like in all things vnto the double red Peonie, but that the flowers hereof are ≈øingle, and as large as the la≈øt, and that is larger then either the ≈øingle female, or the male kinde, con≈øi≈øting of eight leaues, of a deeper red colour then either the ≈øingle or double Peonies, and not purpli≈øh at all, but rather of the colour of an ordinary red Tulipa, ≈øtanding clo≈øe and round together: the roots of this kinde haue longer clogs, and not ≈øo ≈øhort as of the ordinary female kinde, and of a paler colour on the out≈øide.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Peonies haue beene ≈øent or brought from diuers parts beyond the Seas; they are endenized in our Gardens, where wee cheri≈øh them for the beauty and delight of their goodly flowers, as well as for their Phy≈øicall vertues.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in May, but ≈øome (as I ≈øaid) abide a ≈ømall time, and others many weekes.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The name Paeonia is of all the later Writers generally giuen to the≈øe plants, although they haue had diuers other names giuen by the elder Writers, as Ro≈øae fatuina, Idaeus dactylus, Aglaophotis, and others, whereof to ≈øet
1 Paeonia ma ‚Ä¢ cum ≈øemine. The male Peony & the ≈øeed. 2 Paeonia faemina Byzantina. The female red Peony of Con≈øtantinople. 3 Paeonia faemina flore pleno vulgaris. The ordinary double Peony. 4 Paeonia flore pleno albicante. The double white Peony: 5 Helleborus vernus atrorubente flore. The early
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ite Ellebor with a darke red flower. 6 Helleborus niger verus. The Chri≈øtmas flower. 7 Calceolus Mariae. Our Ladies Slipper. depiction of flowers
downe the cau≈øes, rea≈øons, and errours, were to ≈øpend more time then I intend for this worke. Wee call them in Engli≈øh, Peonie, and di≈øtingui≈øh them according to their titles.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The male Peony roote is farre aboue all the re≈øt a mo≈øt ≈øingular approued remedy for all Epilepticall di≈øea≈øes, in Engli≈øh, The falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe (and more e≈øpecially the greene roote then the dry) if the di≈øea≈øe be not too inueterate, to be boyled and drunke, as al≈øo to hang about the neckes of the younger ≈øort that are troubled herewith, as I haue found it ≈øufficiently experimented on many by diuers. The ≈øeede likewi≈øe is of e≈øpeciall v≈øe for women, for the ri≈øing of the mother. The ≈øeede of the female kinde, as well as the rootes, are mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øold, and may in want of the other be (and ≈øo are generally) v≈øed.

div.head: Helleborus niger. Beares foote.
div.p: THere are three ≈øorts of blacke Hellebor or Beares foote, one that is the true and right kinde, who≈øe flowers haue the mo≈øt beautifull a≈øpect, and the time of his flowring mo≈øt rare, that is, in the deepe of Winter about Chri≈øtmas, when no other can bee ≈øeene vpon the ground: and two other that are wilde or ba≈øtard kindes, brought into many Gardens for their Phy≈øicall properties; but I will only ioyne one of them with the true kinde in this worke, and leaue the other for another.

div.head: 1. Helleborus niger verus. The true blacke Hellebor, or Chri≈øtmas flower.
div.p: The true blacke Hellebor (or Beare foote as ≈øome would call it, but that name doth more fitly agree with the other two ba≈øtard kindes) hath many faire greene leaues ri≈øing from the roote, each of them ≈øtanding on a thicke round fle≈øhly ≈øtiffe green ≈øtalke, about an hand breadth high from the ground, diuided into ≈øeuen, eight, or nine parts or leaues, and each of them nicked or dented, from the middle of the leafe to the pointward on both ≈øides, abiding all the Winter, at which time the flowers ri≈øe vp on ≈øuch ≈øhort thicke ≈øtalkes as the leaues ≈øtand on, euery one by it ≈øelfe, without any leafe thereon for the mo≈øt part, or very ≈øeldome hauing one ≈ømall ≈øhort leafe not much vnder the flower, and very little higher then the leaues them≈øelues, con≈øi≈øting of fiue broad white leaues, like vnto a great white ≈øingle Ro≈øe (which ≈øometimes change to be either le≈ø≈øe or more purple about the edges, as the weather or time of continuance doth effect) with many pale yellow thrummes in the middle, ≈øtanding about a greene head, which after groweth to haue diuers cods ≈øet together, pointed at the ends like hornes, ≈øomewhat like the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels of the Aconitum hyemale, but greater & thicker, wherein is contained long, round, and blacki≈øh ≈øeede, like the ≈øeede of the ba≈øtard kindes: the rootes are a number of browni≈øh ≈øtrings running downe deepe into the ground, and fa≈øtened to a thicke head, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a finger at the toppe manie times, and ≈ømaller ≈øtill downewards.

div.head: 2. Hellebora≈øter minor. The le≈ø≈øer ba≈øtard blacke Hellebor, or Beare foote.
div.p:
The ≈ømaller Beare foote is in mo≈øt things like vnto the former true blacke Hellebor; for it beareth al≈øo many leaues vpon ≈øhort ≈øtalkes, diuided into many leaues al≈øo, but each of them are long and narrow, of a blacker greene colour, ≈ønipt or dented on both edges, which feele ≈øomewhat hard or ≈øharpe like prickes, and peri≈øh euery yeare, but ri≈øe againe the next Spring: the flowers hereof ≈øtand on higher ≈øtalkes, with ≈øome leaues on them al≈øo, although but very few, and are of a pale greene colour, like in
forme vnto the flowers of the former, but ≈ømaller, hauing al≈øo many greeni≈øh yellow threads or thrums in the middle, and ≈øuch like heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, and blacki≈øh ≈øeed: the rootes are ≈øtringie and blacki≈øh like the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth onely in the Gardens of tho≈øe that are curious, and delight in all ≈øorts of beautifull flowers in our Countrey, but wilde in many places of Germany, Italy, Greece, &c.

The other groweth wilde in many places of England, as well as the other greater ≈øort, which is not here de≈øcribed; for be≈øides diuers places within eight or ten miles from London, I haue ≈øeen it in the Woods of Northampton≈øhire, and in other places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the≈øe plants doth flower in the end of December, and beginning of Ianuary mo≈øt v≈øually, and the other a moneth or two after, and ≈øometime more.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called Helleborus, or Elleborus niger verus, and is the fame that both Theophra≈øtus and Dio≈øcorides haue written of, and which was called Melampodion, of Melampus the Goateheard, that purged and cured the mad or melancholicke daughters of Praetus with the rootes thereof. Dodonaeus calleth it Veratrum nigrum primum, and the other ≈øecundum: Wee call it in Engli≈øh, The true blacke Hellebor, or the Chri≈øtmas flower, becau≈øe (as I ≈øaid) it is mo≈øt commonly in flower at or before Chri≈øtmas. The ≈øecond is a ba≈øtard or wilde kinde thereof, it ≈øo nearely re≈øembleth the true, and is called of mo≈øt of the later Writers, P≈øeudoelleborus niger minor, or Hellebora≈øter minor, for a di≈øtinction betweene it and the greater, which is not here de≈øcribed: and is called in Engli≈øh, The ≈ømaller or le≈ø≈øer Beare foote, and mo≈øt v≈øed in Phy≈øicke, becau≈øe it is more plentifull, yet is more churli≈øh and ≈øtrong in operation then the true or former kinde.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The rootes of both the≈øe kindes are ≈øafe medecines, being rightly prepared, to be v≈øed for all Melancholicke di≈øea≈øes, what≈øoeuer others may feare or write, and may be without danger applied, ≈øo as care and skill, and not temerary ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe doe order and di≈øpo≈øe of them.
The powder of the dryed leaues, e≈øpecially of the ba≈øtard kinde, is a ≈øure remedy to kill the wormes in children, moderately taken.

div.head: Elleborus albus. White Ellebor or Nee≈øewort.
div.p: THere are two ≈øorts of great white Ellebors or Nee≈øeworts, whereas there was but one kinde knowne to the Ancients; the other being found out of later dayes: And although neither of both the≈øe haue any beauty in their flowers, yet becau≈øe their leaues, being faire and large, haue a goodly pro≈øpect, I haue in≈øerted them in this place, that this Garden ≈øhould not be vnfurni≈øhed of them, and you not vnacquainted with them.

div.head: 1. Elleborus albus vulgaris. White Ellebor or Nee≈øing roote.
div.p: The fir≈øt great white Ellebor ri≈øeth at the fir≈øt out of the ground, with a whiti≈øh greene great round head, which growing vp, openeth it ≈øelfe into many goodly faire large greene leaues, plaited or ribbed with eminent ribbes all along the leaues, compa≈ø≈øing one another at the bottome, in the middle whereof ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke three foot high or better, with diuers ≈øuch like leaues thereon, but ≈ømaller to the middle thereof; from whence to the toppe it is diuided into many branches, hauing many ≈ømall yellowi≈øh, or whiti≈øh greene ≈øtarre-like flowers all along vpon them, which after turne into ≈ømall, long, three ≈øquare whiti≈øh ≈øeede, ≈øtanding naked, without any huske to containe them, although ≈øome haue written otherwi≈øe: the roote is thicke and rea≈øonable great at the head, hauing a number of great white ≈øtrings running downe deepe into the ground, whereby it is ≈øtrongly fa≈øtened.

div.head: 2. Elleborus albus praecox ≈øiue atrorubente flore. The early white Ellebor with reddi≈øh flowers.
div.p: This other Ellebor is very like the former, but that it ≈øpringeth vp a moneth at the lea≈øt before it, and that the leaues are not fully ≈øo thicke or ≈øo much plaited, but as large or larger, and doe ≈øooner peri≈øh and fall away from the plant: the ≈øtalke hereof is as high as the former, bearing ≈øuch like ≈øtarry flowers, but of a darke or blacki≈øh red colour: the ≈øeede is like the other: the roote hath no ≈øuch head as the other (≈øo farre as I haue ob≈øerued, both by mine own and others plants) but hath many long white ≈øtrings fa≈øtened to the top, which is as it were a long bulbous ≈øcaly head, out of which ≈øpring the leaues.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in many places of Germany, as al≈øo in ≈øome parts of Ru≈ø≈øia, in that aboundance, by the relation of that worthy, curious, and diligent ≈øearcher and pre≈øeruer of all natures rarities and varieties, my very good friend, Iohn Trade≈øcante, often heretofore remembred, that, as hee ≈øaid, a good ≈øhip might be loaden with the rootes hereof, which hee ≈øaw in an I≈øland there.
The other likewi≈øe groweth in the vpland wooddy grounds of Germanie, and other the parts thereabouts.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt ≈øpringeth vp in the end or middle of March, and flowreth in Iune. The ≈øecond ≈øpringeth in February, but flowreth not vntill Iune.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called Elleborus albus, or Helleborus albus, the letter H, as all Schollers know, being but a≈øpirationis nota: and Veratrum album flore viridante, of ≈øome Sanguis Herculis. The other is called Elleborus albus praecox, and flore atrorubente, or atropurpurante. We call the fir≈øt in Engli≈øh, White Ellebor, Nee≈øewort, or Nee≈øing roote, becau≈øe the powder of the roote is v≈øed to procure nee≈øing; and I call it the greater, in regard of tho≈øe in the next Chapter. The other hath his name according to the Latine title, mo≈øt proper for it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
The force of purging is farre greater in the roote of this Ellebor, then in the former; and therefore is not carele≈øly to bee v≈øed, without extreame danger; yet in contumatious and ≈øtubborne di≈øea≈øes it may bee v≈øed with
good caution and aduice. There is a Syrupe or Oxymel made hereof in the Apothecaries ≈øhops, which as it is dangerous for gentle and tender bodies, ≈øo it may be very effectuall in ≈øtronger con≈øtitutions. Pau≈øanias in Phocicis, recordeth a notable ≈øtratagem that Solon v≈øed in be≈øieging the Citie of Cirrheus, viz. That hauing cut off the riuer Pli≈øtus from running into the Citie, he cau≈øed a great many of the≈øe rootes to be put into a quantity thereof, which after they had ≈øteeped long enough therein, and was ≈øufficiently infected therewith, he let pa≈ø≈øe into the Citie againe: whereof when they had greedily drunke, they grew ≈øo weake and feeble by the ≈øuperpurgation thereof, that they were forced to leaue their wals vnmand, and not guarded, whereby the Amphyctions their enemies became ma≈øters of their Citie. The like ≈øtratagems are ≈øet downe by diuers others Authors, performed by the helpe of other herbes.

div.head: Elleborine. Small or wilde white Ellebor.
div.p: THe likene≈ø≈øe of the leaues of the≈øe plants, rather then any other faculty with the former white Ellebor, hath cau≈øed them to be called Elleborine, as if they were ≈ømaller white Ellebors. And I for the ≈øame cau≈øe haue ioyned them next, whereof there are found many ≈øorts: One which is the greater kinde, is of greate≈øt beauty; the other which are le≈ø≈øer differ not much one from another, more then in the colour of the flowers, whereof I will onely take three, being of the mo≈øt beautie, and leaue the re≈øt to another worke.

div.head: 1. Helleborine vel Elleborine maior, ≈øiue Calceolus Mariae. Our Ladies Slipper.
div.p: This mo≈øt beautifull plant of all the≈øe kindes, ri≈øeth vp with diuers ≈øtalkes, a foote and a halfe high at the mo≈øt, bearing on each ≈øide of them broad greene leaues, ≈øomewhat like in forme vnto the leaues of the white Ellebor, but ≈ømaller and not ≈øo ribbed, compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalke at the lower end; at the tops of the ≈øtalkes come forth one, or two, or three flowers at the mo≈øt, one aboue another, vpon ≈ømall ≈øhort foote-≈øtalkes, with a ≈ømall leafe at the foote of euery ≈øtalke: each of the≈øe flowers are of a long ouall forme, that is, more long then round, and hollow withall, e≈øpecially at the vpper part, the lower being round and ≈øwelling like a belly: at the hollow part there are two ≈ømall peeces like eares or flippers, that at the fir≈øt doe couer the hollow part, and after ≈øtand apart one from another, all which are of a fine pale yellow colour, in all that I haue ≈øeene (yet it is ≈øaid there are ≈øome found, that are more browne or tending to purple) there are likewi≈øe foure long, narrow, darke coloured leaues the ≈øetting on of the flower vnto the ≈øtalke, wherein as it were the flower at the fir≈øt ≈øtandeth: the whole flower is of a pretty ≈ømall ≈øent: the ≈øeede is very ≈ømall, very like vnto the ≈øeede of the Orchides or Satyrions, and contained in ≈øuch like long pods, but bigger: the roots are compo≈øed of a number of ≈øtrings enterlacing them≈øelues one within another, lying within the vpper cru≈øt of the earth, & not ≈øpreading deep, of a darke browni≈øh colour.

div.head: 2. Elleborine minor flore albo. The ≈ømall or wilde white Ellebor with a white flower.
div.p:
This ≈ømaller wilde white Ellebor ri≈øeth vp in the like manner vnto the former, and not much lower, bearing ≈øuch like leaues, but ≈ømaller, and of a whiter greene colour, almo≈øt of the colour and fa≈øhion of the leaues of Lilly Conually; the top of the ≈øtalke hath many more flowers, but le≈ø≈øer, growing together, ≈øpike-fa≈øhion, with ≈ømall ≈øhort leaues at the ≈øtalke of euery flower, which con≈øi≈øteth of fiue ≈ømall white leaues, with a ≈ømall clo≈øe hood in the middle, without any ≈øent at all: the ≈øeede and ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels are
like vnto the former, but ≈ømaller: the rootes are many ≈ømall ≈øtrings, di≈øper≈øing them≈øelues in the ground.

div.head: 3. Elleborine minor flore purpurante. The ≈ømall or wilde white Ellebor with blu≈øh flowers.
div.p: The leaues of this kinde are like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, but ≈øomewhat narrower: the ≈øtalkes and flowers are alike, but ≈ømaller al≈øo, and of a pale purpli≈øh or blu≈øh colour, which cau≈øeth the difference.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in very many places of Germany, and in other Countries al≈øo. It groweth likewi≈øe in Lanca≈øhire, neare vpon the border of Yorke≈øhire, in a wood or place called the Helkes, which is three miles from Ingleborough, the highe≈øt Hill in England, and not farre from Ingleton, as I am enformed by a courteous Gentlewoman, a great louer of the≈øe delights, called Mi≈øtris Thoma≈øin Tun≈øtall, who dwelleth at Bull-banke, neare Hornby Ca≈øtle in tho≈øe parts, and who hath often ≈øent mee vp the rootes to London, which haue borne faire flowers in my Garden. The ≈øecond groweth in many places of England, and with the ≈øame Gentlewoman al≈øo before remembred, who ≈øent me one plant of this kinde with the other. The la≈øt I haue not yet knowne to growe in England; but no doubt many things doe lye hid, and not ob≈øerued, which in time may bee di≈øcouered, if our Country Gentlemen and women, and others, in their ≈øeuerall places where they dwell, would be more carefull and diligent, and be aduerti≈øed either by them≈øelues, or by others capable and fit to be imployed, as occa≈øion and time might ≈øerue, to finde out ≈øuch plants as growe in any the circuits or limits of their habitations, or in their trauels, as their plea≈øures or affaires leade them. And becau≈øe ignorance is the chiefe cau≈øe of neglect of many rare things, which happen to their view at ≈øometimes, which are not to be ≈øeene againe peraduenture, or not in many yeares after, I would heartily adui≈øe all men of meanes, to be ≈øtirred vp to bend their mindes, and ≈øpend a little more time and trauell in the≈øe delights of herbes and flowers, then they haue formerly done, which are not onely harmle≈ø≈øe, but plea≈øurable in their time, and profitable in their v≈øe. And if any would be better enformed, and certified of ≈øuch things they know not, I would be willing and ready to my be≈øt skill to aduerti≈øe them, that ≈øhall ≈øend any thing vp to me where I dwell in London. Thus farre I haue digre≈ø≈øed from the matter in hand, and yet not without ≈øome good v≈øe I hope, that others may make of it.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The two fir≈øt flower earlier then the la≈øt, and both the fir≈øt about one time, that is, in the end of Aprill, or beginning of May. The la≈øt in the end of May, or in Iune.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called Elleborine recentiorum maior, and Calceolus Mariae: Of ≈øome thought to be Co≈ømo≈øandalos, becau≈øe it is Sandali forma. In Engli≈øh‚ñ™ we call it our Ladies Slipper, after the Dutch name. The other two le≈ø≈øer kin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ haue their names in their titles: I haue thought it fit to adde the title of ≈ømall white Ellebors vnto the≈øe, for the forme ≈øake, as is before ≈øaid.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is no v≈øe of the≈øe in Phy≈øicke in our dayes that I know.

div.head: Lilium Conuallium. Lilly Conually.
div.p: THe remembrance of the Conuall Lilly, ≈øpoken of in the precedent Chapter, hath cau≈øed me to in≈øert the≈øe plants among the re≈øt, although differing both in face and properties; but le≈øt it ≈øhould lo≈øe all place, let it keepe this. It is of two ≈øorts, differing chiefly in the colour of the flowers, the one being white, and the other reddi≈øh, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in their de≈øcriptions following.

div.head: 1. Lilium Conuall ‚Ä¢ um flore albo. The white Lilly Conually.
div.p: The white Conuall or May Lilly, hath three or foure leaues ri≈øing together from the roote, one enclo≈øed within another, each whereof when it is open is long and broad, of a grayi≈øh ≈øhining greene colour, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the leaues of the former wilde Nee≈øewort, at the ≈øide whereof, and ≈øometime from the middle of them, ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall ≈øhort naked foote-≈øtalke, an hand breadth high or ≈øomewhat more, bearing at the toppe one aboue another many ≈ømall white flowers, like little hollow bottles with open mouths, nicked or cut into fiue or ≈øix notches, turning all downewards one way, or on one ≈øide of the ≈øtalke, of a very ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈øent, and comfortable for the memory and ≈øen≈øes, which turne into ≈ømall red berries, like vnto A≈øparagus, wherein is contained hard white ≈øeede: the rootes runne vnder ground, creeping euery way, con≈øi≈øting of many ≈ømall white ≈øtrings.

div.head: 2. Lilium Conuallium flore rubente. May Lillies with red flowers.
div.p: This other May Lilly differeth neither in roote, leafe, nor forme of flower from that before, but onely in the colour of the flower, which is of a fine pale red colour, being in my iudgement not altogether ≈øo ≈øweet as the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth aboundantly in many places of England. The other is a ≈øtranger, and groweth only in the Gardens of tho≈øe that are curious louers of rarities.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They both flower in May, and the berries are ripe in Augu≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The Latines haue no other name for this plant but Lilium Conuallium, although ≈øome would haue it to be Lilium vernum of Theophra≈øtus, and others Oenanthe of the ≈øame Author. Ge≈øner thinketh it to be Callionymus. Lonicerus to be Cacalia, and Fuch≈øius to be Ephemerum non lethale: but they are all for the mo≈øt part mi≈øtaken. We call it in Engli≈øh Lilly Conually, May Lilly, and of ≈øome Liriconfancie.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The flowers of the white kinde are often v≈øed with tho≈øe things that help to ≈øtrengthen the memory, and to procure ea≈øe to Apoplecticke per≈øons. Camerarius ≈øetteth downe the manner of making an oyle of the flowers hereof, which he ≈øaith is very effectuall to ea≈øe the paines of the Goute, and ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes, to be v≈øed outwardly, which is thus: Hauing filled a gla≈ø≈øe with the flowers, and being well ≈øtopped, ≈øet it for a moneths ≈øpace in an Ants hill, and after being drayned cleare, ≈øet it by to v≈øe.

div.head: Gentiana. Gentian or Fell-wort.
div.p: THere are diuers ≈øorts of Gentians or Fell-wortes, ≈øome greater, others le≈ø≈øer, and ≈øome very ≈ømall; many of them haue very beautifull flowers, but becau≈øe ≈øome are very ≈øuddenly pa≈øt, before one would thinke they were blowne open, and others will abide no culture and manuring, I will onely ≈øet forth vnto you two of the greater ≈øorts, and three of the le≈ø≈øer kindes, as fitte≈øt, and more familiarly furni≈øhing our gardens, leauing the re≈øt to their wilde habitations, and to bee comprehended in a generall Worke.

div.head: 1. Gentiana maior flore flauo. The great Gentian.
div.p: The great Gentian ri≈øeth vp at the fir≈øt, with a long, round and pointed head of leaues, clo≈øing one another, which after opening them≈øelues, lye vpon the ground, and are faire, long and broad, ≈øomewhat plaited or ribbed like vnto the leaues of white Ellebor or Nee≈øeworte, but not ≈øo fairely or eminently plaited, neyther ≈øo ≈øtiffe, but rather re≈øembling the leaues of a great Plantane: from among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtiffe round ≈øtalke, three foote high or better, full of ioynts, hauing two ≈øuch leaues, but narrower and ≈ømaller at euery ioynt, ≈øo compa≈ø≈øing about the ≈øtalke at the lower end of them, that they will almo≈øt hold water that falleth into them: from the middle of the ≈øtalke to the toppe, it is garni≈øhed with many coronets or rundles of flowers, with two ≈øuch greene leaues likewi≈øe at euery ioynt, and wherein the flowers doe ≈øtand, which are yellow, layd open like ≈øtarres, and ri≈øing out of ≈ømall greeni≈øh huskes, with ≈øome threds in the middle of them, but of no ≈øent at all, yet ≈øtately to behold, both for the order, height and proportion of the plant: the ≈øeede is browne and flat, contained in round heads, ≈øomewhat like vnto the ≈øeede of the Fritillaria, or checkerd Daffodill, but browner: the rootes are great, thicke and long, yellow, and exceeding bitter.

div.head: 2. Gentiana maior folio A≈øclepiadis. Swallow-wort Gentian.
div.p: This kinde of Gentian hath many ≈øtalkes ri≈øing from the roote, neere two foote high, whereon grow many faire pale greene leaues, ≈øet by couples, with three ribs in euery one of them, and doe ≈øomewhat re≈øemble the leaues of A≈øclepias or Swallow-wort, that is, broade at the bottome, and ≈øharpe at the point: the flowers grow at the ≈øeuerall ioynts of the ≈øtalkes, from the middle vpwards, two or three together, which are long and hollow, like vnto a bell flower, ending in fiue corners, or pointed leaues, and folded before they are open, as the flowers of the Bindeweedes are, of a faire blew colour, ≈øometimes deeper, and ≈øometimes paler: the heads or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels haue two points or hornes at the toppes, and containe within them flat grayi≈øh ≈øeed, like vnto the former, but le≈ø≈øe: the rootes hereof are nothing ≈øo great as the former, but are yellow, ≈ømall and long, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans thumbe.

div.head: 3. Gentiana minor Cruciata. Cro≈ø≈øe-wort Gentian.
div.p:
This ≈ømall Gentian hath many branches lying vpon the ground, ≈øcarce lifting them≈øelues vpright, and full of ioynts, whereat grow v≈øually foure leaues, one op ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ vnto another, in manner of a Cro≈ø≈øe, from whence it tooke his name, in ≈øhape v ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ vnto Saponaria or Sopewort, but ≈øhorter, and of a darker greene colour: at the tops of the ≈øtalkes ≈øtand many flowers, thick thru≈øting together, and likewi≈øe at the next ioynt vnderneath, euery one of them ≈øtanding in a darke blewi≈øh greene huske, and con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall leaues, the points or ends whereof only appeare aboue the huskes wherein they ≈øtand, and are hardly to be ≈øeene, but that they are of a fine pale blew colour, and that many grow together: the ≈øeed is ≈ømall and brown, hard, and ≈øomewhat
