Autumne Gentian. 6 Sapanaria flore duplici. Double flowred Sopewort. 7 Plantago Ro≈øea. Ro≈øe Platane. depiction of flowers
like vnto the ≈øeed of the Marian Violets, or Couentry bels: the roots are ≈ømall and whiti≈øh, di≈øper≈øing them≈øelues diuer≈øly in the ground, of as bitter a ta≈øte almo≈øt as the re≈øt.

div.head: 4. Gentianella Verna. Small Gentian of the Spring.
div.p: The ≈ømall Gentian of the Spring hath diuers ≈ømall hard greene leaues, lying vpon the ground, as it were in heads or tufts, ≈øomewhat broad below, and pointed at the end, with fiue ribs or veines therein, as con≈øpicuous as in the former Gentians, among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall ≈øhort ≈øtalke, with ≈øome ≈ømaller leaues thereon, at the toppe whereof ≈øtandeth one faire, large, hollow flower, made bell fa≈øhion, with wide open brimmes, ending in fiue corners or diui≈øions, of the mo≈øt excellent deepe blew colour that can be ≈øeene in any flower, with ≈øome what ≈øpots in the bottome on the in≈øide: after the flower is pa≈øt, there appeare long and round pods, wherein are contained ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the rootes are ≈ømall, long, pale yellow ≈øtrings, which ≈øhoot forth here and there diuers heads of leaues, and thereby encrea≈øe rea≈øonable well, if it finde a fit place, and ground to grow, or el≈øe will not be nour≈øed vp, with all the care and diligence can be v≈øed: the whole plant is bitter, but not ≈øo ≈øtrong as the former.

div.head: 5. Gentiana Autumnalis ≈øiue Pneumonanthe. Calathian Violet or Autumne Gentian.
div.p:
This Gentian that flowreth in Autumne, hath in ≈øome places higher ≈øtalkes then in others, with many leaues thereon, ≈øet by couples as in other Gentians, but long and narrow, yet ≈øhewing the three ribbes or veines that are in each of them: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are furni≈øhed euery one with a flower or two, of an excellent
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ urple colour, ending in fiue corners, and ≈øtanding in long huskes: the rootes are ≈øomewhat great at the top, and ≈øpreading into many ≈ømall yellow ≈øtrings, bitter as the re≈øt are.

div.head: 6. Saponaria flore duplici. Double flowred Sopeworte.
div.p: Vnto the≈øe kindes of Gentians, I mu≈øt needes adde the≈øe following plants, for that the former is of ≈øome neere re≈øemblance in leafe with ≈øome of the former. And becau≈øe the ordinary Sopeworte or Brui≈øeworte with ≈øingle flowers is often planted in Gardens, and the flowers ≈øerue to decke both the garden and the hou≈øe; I may vnder the one de≈øcribe them both: for this with double flowers is farre more rare, and of greater beautie. It hath many long and ≈ølender round ≈øtalkes, ≈øcarce able to ≈øu≈øtaine them≈øelues, and ≈øtand vpright, being ful of ioynts and ribbed leaues at them, euery one ≈øomewhat like a ≈ømall Gentian or Plantane leafe: at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes ≈øtand many flowers, con≈øi≈øting of two or three rowes of leaues, of a whiti≈øh or pale purple colour, and of a ≈øtrong ≈øweet ≈øent, ≈øomewhat like the ≈ømell of Ia≈ømin flowers, ≈øtanding in long and thicke pale greene huskes, which fall away without giuing any ≈øeede, as mo≈øt other double flowers doe that encrea≈øe by the roote, which ≈øpreadeth within the ground, and ri≈øeth vp in ≈øundry di≈øtant places like the ≈øingle.

div.head: 7 Plantago Ro≈øea. Ro≈øe Plantane.
div.p:
This other plant is in all things like vnto the ordinary Plantane or Ribworte, that groweth wilde abroade in many places, who≈øe leaues are very large: but in ≈øtead of the long ≈ølender ≈øpike, or eare that the ordinary hath, this hath eyther a thicke long ≈øpike of ≈ømall greene leaues vpon ≈øhort ≈øtalkes, or el≈ø ‚Ä¢ a number of ≈øuch ≈ømall g ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ leaues layd round-wi≈øe like vnto a Ro≈øe, and ≈øometime ‚Ä¢ both the≈øe may be ≈øeen ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ one and the ≈øame roote, at one and the ≈øame time, which abide a great while fre≈ø ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the roote, and ≈øometims al≈øo giueth ≈øeede, e≈øpecially from the more long and ≈ølender ≈øpikes.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
Some of the≈øe Gentians grow on the toppes of hils, and ≈øome on the ≈øides and foote of them in Germany and other Countreyes: ≈øome of them al≈øo vpon barren heaths in tho≈øe places, as al≈øo in our owne Countrey, e≈øpecially
the Autumne Gentian, and as it is reported, the Vernall likewi≈øe. The ≈øingle or ordinary Sopeworte is found wilde in many places with vs, but the double came to vs from beyond the Sea, and ‚Ä¢ s ≈øcarce known or heard of in England. The Ro≈øe Plantaine hath beene long in England, but whether naturall thereof or no, I am not a≈ø≈øured.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part in Iune and Iuly, but the ≈ømall Gentian of the Spring flowreth ≈øomewhat earlier, and that of the Autumne in Augu≈øt and September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Gentiana is the generall name giuen to the Gentians. We call them in Engli≈øh Gentian, Fellworte, Bitterwort, and Baldmoney. Saponarta taketh his name from the ≈øcouring qualitie it hath: Wee call it in Engli≈øh Sopewort, and in ≈øome places Brui≈øewort. Some haue thought it to bee Struthium of Dio≈øcorides, or at lea≈øt haue v≈øed it for the ≈øame cau≈øes, but therein they are greatly d ‚Ä¢ ceiued, as Matthiolus hath very well ob≈øerued thereon, and ≈øo is Dodonaeus, that thought it to be Ali≈øma. The Ro≈øe Plantaine is ≈øo called of the double ≈øpikes it carrieth.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The wonderfull whol≈øomne≈ø≈øe of Gentian cannot bee ea≈øily knowne to vs, by rea≈øon our daintie ta≈øtes refu≈øe to take thereof, for the bitterne≈ø≈øe ≈øake: but otherwi≈øe it would vndoubtedly worke admirable cures, both for the liuer, ≈øtomacke and lunges. It is al≈øo a ≈øpeciall counterpoi≈øon again≈øt any infection, as al≈øo again≈øt the violence of a mad dogges tooth: wilde Sopewort is v≈øed in many places, to ≈øcoure the countrey womens treen, and pewter ve≈ø≈øels, and phy≈øically ≈øome make great boa≈øt to performe admirable cures in Hydropicall di≈øea≈øes, becau≈øe it is diureticall, and in Lue Veneria, when other Mercuriall medicines haue failed. The Ro≈øe Plantaine no doubt hath the ≈øame qualities that the ordinary hath.

div.head: Campanula. Bell-flowers.
div.p: VNder the title of Bell-flowers are to bee comprehended in this Chapter, not only tho≈øe that are ordinarily called Campanula, but Viola Mariana, and Trachelium al≈øo, whereof the one is called Couentry, the other Canterbury Bells.

div.head: 1. Campanula Per≈øicifolio alba, vel caerulea. Peach-leafed Bell-flowers white or blew.
div.p:
The Peach-leafed Bell-flower hath many tufts, or branches of leaues lying vpon the g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d, which are long and narrow, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leafe of an Almond or P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch tree, being finely nicked about the edges, and of a ≈øad greene colour, from among which ri≈øe vp diuers ≈øtalkes, two foote high or more, ≈øet with leaues to the middle, and from thence vpwards, with many flowers ≈øtanding on ≈øeuerall ≈ømall foote≈øtalkes, one aboue another, with a ≈ømall leafe at the foote of euery one: the flowers ≈øtand in ≈ømall greene huskes, being ≈ømall and round at the bottome, but wider open at the brimme, and ending in fiue corners, with a three forked clapper in the middle, ≈øet about with ≈øome ≈ømall threds tipt with yellow, which flowers in ≈øome plants are pure
white, and in others of a pale blew or watchet colour, hauing little or no ≈øent at all: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, and contained in round flat heads, or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels: the roote is very ≈ømall, white and threddy, creeping vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the ground, ≈øo that oftentimes the heat and drought of the Summer wil goe near to parch and wither it vtterly: it requireth therefore to be planted in ≈øome ≈øhadowie place.

div.head: 2. Campanula maior, ≈øiue Pyramidalis. Th ‚Ä¢ great or ≈øteeple Bell-flower.
div.p: This great Bell-flower hath diuers ≈øtalkes, three foote high or better, whereon grow diuers ≈ømooth, darke, greene leaues, broade at the bottome, and ≈ømall at the point, ≈øomewhat vneuenly notched about the edges, and ≈øtanding vpon longer foote≈øtalkes below then tho≈øe aboue: the flowers are blew, and in ≈øome white, not ≈øo great or large as the former, but neare of the ‚Ä¢ ame fa≈øhion, growing thicker and more plentifully together, with ≈ømaller leaues among them, bu≈øhing thicke below, and ri≈øing ≈ømaller and thinner vp to the toppe, in fa≈øhion of a Pyramis or ≈øpeere Steeple: the roote is thicke and whiti≈øh, yeelding more ≈øtore of milke being broken (as the leaues and ≈øtalks al≈øo doe) then any other of the Bell-flowers, euery one whereof doe yeelde milke, ≈øome more and ≈øome le≈ø≈øe.

div.head: 3. Viola Mariana flore albido vel purpureo. Couentry Bels white or purple.
div.p: The leaues of Couentry Bels are of a pale or fre≈øh greene colour, long, and narrow next vnto the bottome, and broader from the middle to the end, and ≈øomewhat round pointed, a little hairy all ouer, and ≈ønipt about the edges: the ≈øtalkes ri≈øe vp the yeare after the ≈øowing, being ≈øomewhat hairy al≈øo, and branching forth from the roote, into diuers parts, whereon ≈øtand diuers leaues, ≈ømaller then the former, and of a darker greene colour: at the end of euery branch ≈øtand the flowers, in greene huskes, from whence come large, round, hollow Bels, ≈øwelling out in the middle, and ri≈øing ≈øomewhat aboue it, like the necke of a pot, and then ending in fiue corners, which are either of a faire or faint white, or of a pale blew purpli≈øh colour, and ≈øometimes of a deeper purple or violet: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there ri≈øe vp great ≈øquare, or cornered ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, wherein is contained in diuers diui≈øions, ≈ømall, hard, ≈øhining, browne, flat ≈øeeds: the roote is white, and being young as in the fir≈øt yeares ≈øowing, is tender, and often eaten as other Rampions are; but the next yeare, when it runneth vp to ≈øeede, it groweth hard, and peri≈øheth: ≈øo that it is to be continued by euery other yeares ≈øowing.

div.head: 4. Trachelium maius flore albo vel purpureo. Great Canterbury Bels white or purple.
div.p: The greater Canterbury Bels, or Throateworte, hath many large rough leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto Nettle leaues, being broad and round at the bottome, and pointed at the end, notched or dented on the edges, and euery one ≈øtanding on a long foot≈øtalk: among the≈øe leaues ri≈øe vp diuers ≈øquare rough ≈øtalkes, diuided at the toppe into diuers branches, whereon grow the like leaues as grow below, but le≈ø≈øer; toward the ends of the branches ≈øtand the flowers, mixed with ≈øome longer leaues, euery one in his ≈øeuerall huske, which are hollow, long and round, like a bell or cup, wide open at the mouth, and cut at the brimme into fiue corners, or diui≈øions, ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer then the Couentry Bels, in ≈øome of a pure white, and others of a faire deepe purple violet col ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and ≈øometimes paler: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come ≈ømaller and rounder he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ then in the former, containing flat ≈øeede, but blacker, and not ≈øo redde as the la ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ : the roote is hard and white, di≈øper≈øing it ≈øelfe into many branches vnder ground, not peri≈øhing euery yeare as the former (although it lo≈øeth all the leaues in winter) but abiding many yeares, and encrea≈øing into diuers heades or knobs, from whence ≈øpring new leaues and branches.

figure.head: 1 Campanula per≈øicifolia. Peach leafed Bell-flower. 2 Trachelium maius ≈øimplex. Canterbury Bels. * Trachelium flore duplici. Double Canterbury Bels. 3 Viola Mariana. Couentry Bels. 4 Trachelium Giganteum. Giants Throatewort. 5 Trachelium minus. The le≈ø≈øer Throatewort. 6 Trachel ‚Ä¢ um Americanum ≈øiue Cardinalis planta. The rich crim≈øon Cardinals flower.

div.head: 5. Trachelium maius flore duplici albo & caeruleo. Canterbury Bels with double flowers both white and blew.
div.p: Of this kinde of Throateworte or Canterbury Bels, there is another ≈øort, not differing in any thing from the former, but in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower: For there is of both the kindes, one that beareth double white flowers, and the other blew: Of each whereof I receiued plants from friends beyond the Sea, which grow well with me.

div.head: 6. Trachelium Giganteum flore purpurante. Pale purple Giants Throateworte.
div.p: This Bell-flower, although it hath a Gigantine name, yet did I neuer perceiue it in my Garden, to ri≈øe vp h gher then the former, the epithite beeing in my per≈øwa≈øion, only giuen for difference ≈øake: the leaues whereof are not ≈øo rough, but as large, and dented about the edges, ≈øomewhat larger pointed, and of a fre≈øher greene colour: the ≈øtalkes beare ≈øuch like leaues on them, but more thinly or di≈øper≈øedly ≈øet, hauing a flower at the ≈øetting on of euery one of the leaues, from the middle vpwards, and are ≈øomewhat like the great Throateworte in forme‚ñ™ but of a pale or bleake reddi≈øh purple colour, turning the brims or corners a little backwards, with a forked clapper in the middle, ≈øufficient eminent and yellow: the ≈øeede hereof is white, and plentifull in the heads, which will abide all the winter vpon the ≈øtalkes, vntill all the ≈øeede being ≈øhed, the heads remaining ≈øeeme like torne rags, or like thin peeces of skin, eaten with wormes: the roote is greate, thicke and white, abiding long without peri≈øhing.
Flore albo.There is another which differeth not any thing but in the flower, which is white.

div.head: 7. Trachelium minus flore albo & purpureo. Small Throateworte or Canterbury Bells both white and purple.
div.p: The le≈ø≈øer Throateworte hath ≈ømaller leaues, nothing ≈øo broade or hard as the former great kinde, but long, and little or nothing dented about the edges: the ≈øtalkes are ≈øquare and browni≈øh, if it beare purple flowers, and greene if it beare white flowers, which in forme are alike, and grow in a bu≈øh or tuft, thicke ≈øet together, more then any of the former, and ≈ømaller al≈øo, being not much bigger then the flowers of the fielde, or garden Rampions: the roote is la≈øting, and ≈øhooteth afre≈øh euery yeare.

div.head: 8. Trachelium Americarum flore ruberrimo, ≈øiue Planta Cardinalis. The rich crim≈øon Cardinals flower.
div.p: This braue plant, from a white roote ≈øpreading diuers wayes vnder ground, ≈øendeth forth many greene leaues, ≈øpread round about the head thereof, each whereof is ≈øomewhat broade and long, and pointed at the end, finely al≈øo ≈ønipt about the edges: from the middle whereof ari≈øeth vp a round hollow ≈øtalke, two foote high at the lea≈øt, be≈øet with diuers ≈øuch leaues as grow below, but longer below then aboue, and branching out at the toppe aboundantly, euery branch bearing diuers greene leaues on them, and one at the foote of euery of them al≈øo, the toppes whereof doe end in a great large tuft of flowers, with a ≈ømall greene leafe at the foote of the ≈øtalke of euery flower, each foote≈øtalke being about an inch long, bearing a round greene huske, diuided into fiue long leaues or points turned downwards, and in the mid≈øt of euery of them a mo≈øt rich crim≈øon coloured flower, ending in fiue long narrow leaues, ≈øtanding all of t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m foreright, but three of them falling downe, with a long vmbone ≈øet as it were at the backe of them, bigger below, and ≈ømaller aboue, and at the toppe a ≈ømall head, being of a little paler colour then the flower, but of no ≈øent or ≈ømell at all, commendable only for the great bu≈øh of ≈øo orient red crim≈øon flowers: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the ≈øeede commeth in ≈ømall heads, clo≈øed within tho≈øe greene husks that held the flowers, which is very like vnto the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels of the Viola Mariana, or Couentry Bels, and is ≈ømall and browni≈øh.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Bell-flowers do grow in our Gardens, where they are cheri≈øhed for the beautie of their flowers. The Couentry Bels doe not grow wilde in any of the parts about Couentry, as I am credibly informed by a faithfull Apothecary dwelling there, called Ma≈øter Brian Ball, but are nour≈øed in Gardens with them, as they are in other places. The la≈øt groweth neere the riuer of Canada, where the French plantation in America is ≈øeated.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower from May vntill the end of Iuly or Augu≈øt, and in the mean time the ≈øeed is ripe: But the Peache-leafed Bell-flowers, for the mo≈øt part, flower earlier then the other.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is generally called Campanula Per≈øicifolia, in Engli≈øh Peach-leafed Bell-flower. The ≈øecond is called Campanula maior, Campanula lacte≈øcens Pyramidalis, and Pyramidalis Lutetiana of Lobel, in Engli≈øh, Great or Steeple Bell-flower. The third is v≈øually called Viola Mariana, and of ≈øome Viola Marina. Lobel putteth a doubt whether it be not Medium of Dio≈øcorides, as Matthiolus and others doe thinke; but in my opinion the thickne≈ø≈øe of the roote, as the text hath it, contradicteth all the re≈øt. We call it generally in Engli≈øh Couentry Bels. Some call it Marian, and ≈øome Mercuries Violets. The fourth and fift are called Trachelium or Ceruicaria, of ≈øome Vvularia, becau≈øe many haue v≈øed it to good purpo≈øe, for the paines of the Vvula, or Throate: Yet there is another plant, called al≈øo by ≈øome Vvularia, which is Hippoglo≈ø≈øum, Hor≈øe tongue, or Double tongue. The ≈øixt hath his title to de≈øcipher it out ≈øufficiently, as is declared. The ≈øeuenth is called Trachelium minus, and Ceruiaria minor, of ≈øome Saponaria altera; in Engli≈øh, Small Throateworte, or Small Canterbury Bels. The la≈øt hath his name in the title, as it is called in France, from whence I receiued plants for my Garden with the Latine name: but I haue giuen it in Engli≈øh.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Peach-Bels as well as the others may ≈øafely bee v≈øed in gargles and lotions for the mouth, throate, or other parts, as occa≈øion ≈øerueth. The rootes of many of them, while they are young, are often eaten in ≈øallets by diuers beyond the Seas.

div.head: Campana Caerulea ≈øiue Convolvulus Caeruleus. Blew Bell flowers, or blew Bindeweede.
div.p: THere are two other kindes of Bell-flowers, much differing from the Tribe or Familie of the former, becau≈øe of their climbing or winding qualitie, which I mu≈øt needes place next them, for the likene≈ø≈øe of the flowers, although otherwi≈øe they might haue beene placed with the other clamberers that follow. Of the≈øe there is a greater, and a le≈ø≈øer, and of each likewi≈øe ≈øome difference, as ≈øhall be declared.

div.head: 1. Convolvulus caeruleus maior rotundifolius. The greater blew Bindweede, or Bell-flower with round leaues.
div.p: This goodly plant ri≈øeth vp with many long and winding branches, whereby it climbeth and windeth vpon any poles, herbes, or trees, that ≈øtand neare it within a great compa≈ø≈øe, alwaies winding it ≈øelfe contrary to the cour≈øe of the Sunne: on the≈øe branches doe growe many faire great round leaues, and pointed at the end, like vnto a Violet leafe in ≈øhape, but much greater, of a ≈øad greene colour: at the ioynts of the branches, where the leaues are ≈øet, come forth flowers on pretty long ≈øtalkes, two or three together at a place, which are long, and pointed almo≈øt like a finger, while they are buds, and not blowne open, and of a pale whiti≈øh blew colour, but being blowne open, are great and large bels, with broad open mouths or brims ending in fiue corners, and ≈ømall at the bottome, ≈øtanding in ≈ømall greene huskes of fine leaues: the≈øe flowers are of a very deepe azure or blew colour, tending to a purple, very glorious to behold, opening for the mo≈øt part in the euening, abiding ≈øo all the night and the next morning, vntill the Sunne begin to growe ≈øomewhat hot vpon them, and then doe clo≈øe, neuer opening more: the plant carrieth ≈øo many flowers, if it ≈øtand in a warme place, that it will be repleni≈øhed plentifully, vntill the cold ayres and euenings ≈øtay the luxury thereof: after the flowers are pa≈øt, the ≈øtalkes whereon the flowers did ≈øtand, bend downwards, and beare within the huskes three or foure blacke ≈øeedes, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a Tare or thereabouts: the rootes are ≈øtringy, and peri≈øh euery yeare.

div.head: 2. Convolvulus trifolius ≈øiue hederaceus purpureus. The greater purple Bindeweede, or Bell-flower with cornered leaues.
div.p: The growing and forme of this Bindeweede or Bell-flower, is all one with the former, the chiefe≈øt differences con≈øi≈øting in the forme of the leafe, which in this is three cornered, like vnto an Iuie leafe with corners; and in the flower, which is of a deeper blew, tending more to a deepe purple Violet, and ≈øomewhat more reddi≈øh in the fiue plaites of each flower, as al≈øo in the bottomes of the flowers.

div.head: 3. Convolvulus tenuifolius Americanus. The red Bell-flower of America.
div.p: Although this rare plant (becau≈øe wee ≈øeldome haue it, and can as hardly keepe it) be ≈øcarce knowne in the≈øe cold Countries, yet I could not but make mention of it, to incite tho≈øe that haue conueniencie to keepe it, to be furni≈øhed of it. It ≈øpringeth vp at the fir≈øt from the ≈øeede with two leaues, with two long forked ends, which abide a long time before they peri≈øh, betweene which ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke or ≈øtemme, branching forth diuers waies, being of a browni≈øh colour, which windeth it ≈øelfe as the former great Bell-flower doth, whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall ioynts diuers winged leaues, that is to ≈øay, many ≈ømall narrow and long leaues ≈øet on both ≈øides of the middle ribbe, and one at the end: from the≈øe ioynts ari≈øe long ≈øtalkes, at the ends whereof ≈øtand two or three ≈ømall, long, hollow flowers, fa≈øhioned very like vnto the flowers of a Bindeweede, or the flowers of Tabacco, and ending in the like manner in fiue points, but not ≈øo much laide open, being of a bright red colour, plaited as the Bindeweedes or Bell-flowers before they be open; with ≈øome few threads in the middle, which turne into long pointed cods, wherein is contained long and blacke ≈øeede, ta≈øting hot like Pepper: the roote is ≈ømall and ≈øtringy, peri≈øhing euery yeare, and with vs will ≈øeldome come to flower, becau≈øe our cold nights and fro≈øts come ≈øo ≈øoone, before it cannot haue comfort enough of the Sun to ripen it.

div.head: 4. Convolvulus caeruleus minor Hi≈øpanicus. The Spani≈øh ≈ømall blew Bindeweede.
div.p:
This ≈ømall Bindeweede hath ≈ømall long leaues, ≈øomewhat broader then the next that followeth, and not ≈øo broad as the common ≈ømall Bindeweede (that groweth
euery where wilde on the bankes of fields abroad) ≈øet vpon the ≈ømall trayling branches, which growe aboue two or three foote high: from the middle of the≈øe branches, and ≈øo vnto the toppes of them, come forth the flowers at the ioynts with the leaues, folded together at the fir≈øt into fiue plaites, which open into ≈øo many corners, of a mo≈øt excellent faire skie coloured blew (≈øo plea≈øant to behold, that often it amazeth the ≈øpectator) with white bottomes, and yellowi≈øh in the middle, which turne into ≈ømall round white heads, wherein are contained ≈ømall blacki≈øh cornered ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat like the former, but ≈ømaller: the roote is ≈ømall and threddy, peri≈øhing as the former euery yeare: this neuer windeth it ≈øelfe about any thing, but leaneth by rea≈øon of the weakne≈ø≈øe of the branches, and dyeth euery yeare after ≈øeede time, and not to be ≈øowne againe vntill the next Spring.

div.head: 5. Convolvulus purpureus Spicaefolius. Lauander leafed Bindeweede.
div.p: This ≈ømall purple Bindeweede, where it naturally groweth, is rather a plague then a plea≈øure, to what≈øoeuer groweth with it in the fields; yet the beauty of the flower hath cau≈øed it to be receiued into Gardens, bearing longer and ≈ømaller leaues then the la≈øt, and ≈øuch like ≈ømall Bell-flowers, but of a ≈øad purple colour: the roote is li ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng, as the common kinds are, and ≈øpringeth againe where it hath been once ≈øowne, without feare of peri≈øhing.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt two greater kindes haue beene ≈øent vs out of Italy, but whether they had them from the Ea≈øt Indies, or from ≈øome of the Ea≈øterne Countries on this ≈øide, wee know not: but they thriue rea≈øonable well in our Country, if the yeare be any thing kindly. The next came out of America, as his name te≈øtifieth. The le≈ø≈øer blew kinde groweth naturally in many places both of Spaine and Portugall (from whence I fir≈øt receiued ≈øeedes from Guillaume Boel, heretofore remembred.) The la≈øt groweth wilde in the fields, about Dunmowe in E≈ø≈øex, and in many other places of our owne Countrey likewi≈øe.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The three fir≈øt greater kindes flower not vntill the end of Augu≈øt, or thereabouts, and the ≈øeede ripeneth in September, if the colds and fro≈øts come not on too ≈øpeedily. The le≈ø≈øer kindes flower in Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is called of ≈øome Campana Lazura, as the Italians doe call it, or Campana caerulea, of others Convolvulus caeruleas maior, ≈øiue Indicus, and Flos noctis. Of ≈øome Nil Auicennae. The ≈øecond is called Convolvulus trifolius, or haederaceus, for the di≈øtinction of the leaues. In Engli≈øh wee call them eyther Great blew Bell-flowers, or more v≈øually, Great blew Bindeweedes. That of America is diuer≈øly called by diuers. It is called Quamoclit of the Indians, and by that name it was ≈øent to Ioachinus Camerarius out of Italy, where it is ≈øo called ≈øtill, as Fabius Columna ≈øetteth it downe, and as my ≈øelfe al≈øo can witne≈ø≈øe it, from thence being ≈øo ≈øent vnto mee: but Andraeas Cae≈øalpinus calleth it, Ia≈øminum folio Millefolij, ≈øuppo≈øing it to be a Ia≈ømine. Camerarius ≈øaith, it may not vnfitly be called Convolvulus tenuifolius, accounting it a kinde of Bindeweede. Columna entituleth it Convolvulus pennatus exoticus rarior, and ≈øaith it cannot bee referred to any other kinde of plant then to the Bindeweedes. Hee that publi≈øhed the Curae po≈øteriores of Clu≈øius, giueth it the name of Ia≈øminum Americanum, which I would doe al≈øo, if I thought it might belong to that Family; but ≈øeeing the face and forme of the plant better agreeing with the Bindeweedes or Bell-flowers,
I haue (as you ≈øee) in≈øerted it among them, and giuen it that name may bee mo≈øt fit for it, e≈øpecially becau≈øe it is but an annuall plant. The le≈ø≈øer kindes haue their names ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in their titles.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We know of no v≈øe the≈øe haue in Phy≈øicke with vs, although if the fir≈øt be Nil of Auicen, both he and Serapio ≈øay it purgeth ≈øtrongly.

div.head: Stramonium. Thorne-Apple.
div.p: VNto the Bell-flowers, I mu≈øt adioyne three other plants, in the three ≈øeuerall Chapters following, for ≈øome affinity of the flowers: and fir≈øt of the Thorne-Apples, whereof there are two e≈øpeciall kindes, that is, a greater and a le≈ø≈øer, and of each ≈øome diuer≈øity, as ≈øhall be ≈øet downe.

div.head: 1. Stramonium maius album. The great white flowred Thorne-Apple.
div.p: The greater Thorne-Apple hath a great, ≈øtrong, round greene ≈øtalke, as high as any man, if it be planted in good ground, and of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans wre≈øt almo≈øt at the bottome, ≈øpreading out at the toppe into many branches, whereon ≈øtand many very large and broad darke greene leaues, cut in very deeply on the edges, and hauing manie points or corners therein: the flowers come forth at the ioynts, betweene two branches towards the toppe of them, being very large, long, and wide open, ending in fiue points or corners, longer and larger then any other Bell-flowers what≈øoeuer: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come the fruit, which are thorny long heads, more prickly and greene then the le≈ø≈øer kindes, which being ripe openeth it ≈øelfe into three or foure parts, hauing a number of flat blacki≈øh ≈øeede within them: the roote is aboundant in fibres, whereby it ≈øtrongly taketh hold in the ground, but peri≈øheth with the fir≈øt fro≈øts; yet the ≈øeede that is ≈øhed when the fruit is ripe, commeth vp the next yeare.

div.head: 2. Stramonium maius purpureum. The great purple flowred Thorne-Apple.
div.p: This purple Thorne-Apple is in largene≈ø≈øe of leaues, thickne≈ø≈øe and height of ≈øtalke, greatne≈ø≈øe and forme of flowers and fruit, euery way equall and corre≈øpondent vnto the former, the chiefe differences be the≈øe: the ≈øtalke is of a darke purple colour; the leaues are of a darker greene, ≈øomewhat purpli≈øh, and the flowers are of light purple or pale Doue colour, enclining to white, and whiter at the bottome.

div.head: 3. Stramonium minus ≈øeu Nux Metel flore albo. The ≈ømaller Thorne-Apple with a white flower.
div.p:
The ≈ømaller Thorne-Apple ri≈øeth vp with one round ≈øtalke, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans finger, and neuer much aboue two foote high with vs, bearing a few large, broad, ≈ømooth leaues thereon, without any branches at all, which are vneuenly rent or
„Äà‚óä„Äâ about the edges, with many ribs, and ≈ømaller veines running through them, yet le≈ø≈øer by much then the greater kinde: at the ioynts where the leaues ≈øtand, come forth long and large white flowers, with broad or wide open brims, folded together before their opening, as the other former Bell-flowers or Bindeweedes, but hauing their fiue corners more pointed or horned then either they, or the former Thorne-Apples: after the flowers are pa≈øt, ≈øucceed ≈ømall fruit, rounder and harder, ≈øet with harder, but blunt prickes then the former, wherein is contained browni≈øh yellow flat ≈øeede,

The Spani≈øh ≈ømall blew Bindweed. 4 Stramonium maius ≈øeu pomum ≈øpino≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The great Thorne Apple. 5 Datura ≈øeu Stramonium minus. The ≈ømall Thorne-Apple. 6 Stramonium flore duplici. The double flowred Thorne-Apple. 7 Stramonium f ‚Ä¢ ore gemi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to. Double Thorne-Apple one out of another 8 Tabacco latifolium. Broad leafed Tabacco. 9 Mirabilia Pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ na. The Merua ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of the world. depiction of flowers
≈øticking to the inward pulpe: the roote is not very great, but full of ≈øtrings, and quickly peri≈øheth with the fir≈øt fro≈øts.

div.head: 4. Stramonium minus flore geminato purpurante. The ≈ømall double flowred purple Thorne-Apple.
div.p: In the flower of this plant, con≈øi≈øteth the chiefe≈øt difference from the former, which is as large as the la≈øt, pointed into more hornes or corners, and beareth two flowers, ≈øtanding in one huske, one of them ri≈øing out from the middle of the other, like vnto tho≈øe kindes of Cow≈ølips and Oxelips, called double, or Ho≈øe in ho≈øe, before de≈øcribed, which are of a pale purpli≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and almo≈øt white within: the fruit is round like the la≈øt, and beareth ≈øuch like ≈øeede, ≈øo that vntill it bee in flower, their difference can hardly bee di≈øcerned: this is more tender then the la≈øt, although euen it is ≈øo tender, that it ≈øeldome beareth ripe ≈øeede with vs.

Flore duplici.Sometimes (for I think it is not another kind) the flower will haue as it were double rowes of leaues, clo≈øe ≈øet together, and not con≈øi≈øting of two, ri≈øing ≈øo di≈øtinctly one aboue another.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe kindes haue been brought or ≈øent vs out of Turkie and Egypt; but Garcias, and Chri≈øtopherus Aco≈øta, with others, affirme that they grow in the Ea≈øt Indies. The le≈ø≈øer kindes are very rare with vs, becau≈øe they ≈øeldome come to maturity; and therefore we are ≈øtill to ≈øeeke of new ≈øeede to ≈øowe. The greater kindes are plentifull enough in our Gardens, and will well abide, and giue ripe fruit.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The ≈ømaller kindes flower later then the greater; and therefore their fruit are the ≈øooner ≈øpoiled with the cold ayres, dewes, and fro≈øts, that come at the latter end of the yeare: but the greater kinds neuer mi≈ø≈øe lightly to ripen.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Both the greater and ≈ømaller kindes are generally called Stramonium, Stramonia, Pomum ≈øpino≈øum, and Datura. Bauhinus vpon Matthiolus his Comentaries on Dio≈øcorides, calleth it Solanum faetidum ≈øpino≈øum. Some learned men haue referred it to Nux Metel, of the Arabian Authors. Wee call them generally in Engli≈øh, Thorne-Apples, and di≈øtingui≈øh them by their titles of greater and le≈ø≈øer, ≈øingle and double.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Ea≈øt Indian la≈øciuious women performe ≈øtrange acts with the ≈øeed (of the ≈ømaller kinde, as I ≈øuppo≈øe, or it may be of either) giuing it their hu≈øbands to drinke. The whole plant, but e≈øpecially the ≈øeed, is of a very cold and ≈øoporiferous quality, procuring ≈øleep and di≈øtraction of ≈øen≈øes. A few of the ≈øeeds ≈øteeped and giuen in drinke, will cau≈øe them that take it to ≈øeem ≈øtarke drunke or dead drunke, which fit will within a few houres we are away, and they recouer their ≈øen≈øes againe, as a drunken man ray≈øed after ≈øleep from his wine. It may therefore (in my opinion) be of ≈øafe and good v≈øe to one, that is to haue a legge or an arme cut off, or to be cut for the ≈øtone, or ≈øome other ≈øuch like cure to be performed, to take away the ≈øen≈øe of paine for the time of doing it; otherwi≈øe I hold it not fit to be v≈øed without great caution. But the greene leaues of the greater kindes (as al≈øo of the le≈ø≈øer, but that with vs they are not ≈øo plentifull) are by tryed experience, found to be excellent good for any ≈øcalded or burned part, as al≈øo to take away any hot inflammations, being made vp into a ≈øalue or ointment with ≈øuet, waxe, and ro≈ø≈øin, &c. or with Axungia, that is, Hogs larde.

div.head: Tabacco. Indian Henbane, or Tabacco.
div.p: THere hath beene formerly but three kindes of Tabacco knowne vnto vs, two of them called Indian, and the third Engli≈øh Tabacco. In the≈øe later yeares, we haue had in our gardens about London (before the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of the planting) three or foure other ≈øorts at the lea≈øt, and all of the Indian kinde, hauing ≈øome e≈øpeciall difference, eyther in leafe, or flower, or both: And in regard the flowers of ≈øome of the≈øe carry a pretty ≈øhew, I ≈øhall only entreate of them, and not of the Engli≈øh kind.

div.head: Tabacco latifolium. Broade leafed Tabacco.
div.p: The great Indian Tabacco hath many very large, long, thicke, fat and faire greene leaues, ≈øtanding foreright for the mo≈øt part, and compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalkes at the bottome of them, being ≈øomewhat pointed at the end: the ≈øtalke is greene and round, ≈øixe or ≈øeuen foote high at ≈øometimes, and in ≈øome places, in others not pa≈øt three or foure foote high, diuided towards the toppe into many branches, with leaues at euery ioynt, and at the toppes of the branches many flowers, the bottomes hereof are long and hollow, and the toppes plaited or folded before they are open, but being open, are diuided ≈øometimes into foure, or more v≈øually into fiue corners, ≈øomewhat like vnto other of the Bell-flowers, but lying a little flatter open, of a light carnation colour. The ≈øeede is very ≈ømall and browne, contained in round heads, that are clammy while they are greene, and pointed at the end: the roote is great, whiti≈øh, and woody at the head, di≈øper≈øing many long branches, and ≈ømall fibres vnder the ground, whereby it is ≈øtrongly fa≈øtened, but peri≈øheth with our violent fro≈øts in the winter, if it be left abroad in the garden, but if it be hou≈øed, or ≈øafely prouided for again≈øt the fro≈øtes, the rootes will liue, and ≈øpring afre≈øh the next yeare.

There is of this kinde another ≈øort, who≈øe leaues are as large and long as the former, but thicker, and of a more dead greene colour, hanging downe to the ground-ward, and ≈øcarce any ≈øtanding forth-right, as the former, vnle≈ø≈øe they bee very young: the flowers of this kinde are almo≈øt whole, without any great ≈øhew of corners at the brims or edges, in all other things there is no difference.

There is another, who≈øe large and thicke flat leaues doe compa≈ø≈øe the ≈øtalke at the bottome, and are as it were folded together one ≈øide vnto another: the flowers are of a deeper blu≈øh, or carnation colour, and with longer points and corners then in any of the former; and in the≈øe two things con≈øi≈øteth the difference from the others, and is called Verines Tabacco.

Another hath his leaues not ≈øo large and long as the fir≈øt, and the≈øe haue ≈øhort foote≈øtalkes, whereon they ≈øtand, and doe not compa≈ø≈øe the ≈øtalke as the other doe: the flower hereof is like the fir≈øt, but ≈ømaller, and of a little paler colour.

div.head: Tabacco angu≈øtifolium. Narrow leafed Tabacco.
div.p: This kinde of Tabacco hath ≈øomewhat lower, and ≈ømaller ≈øtalkes, then any of the former: the leaues hereof are ≈ømaller and narrower, and not altogether ≈øo thicke, but more pointed, and euery one ≈øtanding vpon a foot≈øtalke, an inch and a halfe long at the lea≈øt: the flowers hereof ≈øtand thicker together, vpon the ≈ømall branches, ≈øomewhat larger, of a deeper blu≈øh colour, and more eminent corners then in any the former: the ≈øeed and roots are alike, and peri≈øh in like manner, vnle≈ø≈øe it be brought into a cellar, or other ≈øuch couert, to defend it from the extremitie of the Winter.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
America or the We≈øt Indies is the place where all the≈øe kindes doe grow naturally, ≈øome in one place, and ≈øome in another, as in Peru, Trinidado,
Hi≈øpaniola, and almo≈øt in euery Iland and Countrey of the continent thereof: with vs they are cheri≈øhed in gardens, as well for the medicinable qualities, as for the beauty of the flowers.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Augu≈øt, ≈øeldome before, and the ≈øeede is ripe quickly after. If it once ≈øowe it ≈øelfe in a Garden, it will giue next year after young plants: but for the mo≈øt part they will ≈øpring vp late, and therefore they that would haue them more early, haue ≈øowen the ≈øeede vpon a bed of dung, and tran≈øplanted them afterwards.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: This plant hath gotten many names. The Indians call it in ≈øome places Petum, in others Picielt, and Perebecenu ‚Ä¢ , as Ouiedus and others doe relate. The Spaniards in the Indies fir≈øt called it Tabacco, of an Iland where plenty of it grew. It hath in Chri≈øtendome receiued diuers other names, as Nicotiana, of one Nicot a French man, who ≈øeeing it in Portugall, ≈øent it to the French Queene, from whom it receiued the name of Herba Regina. Lobel calleth it Sancta herba, & Sana ≈øancta Indorum. Some haue adiudged it to be an Hio≈øcyamus, and therefore call it Peruvianus. The mo≈øt v≈øuall name wherby we call it in Engli≈øh, is Tabacco.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The herbe is, out of que≈øtion, an excellent helpe and remedy for diuers di≈øea≈øes, if it were rightly ordered and applyed, but the continuall abu≈øe thereof in ≈øo many, doth almo≈øt aboli≈øh all good v≈øe in any. Notwith≈øtanding if men would apply their wits to the finding out of the vertues, I make no doubt but many ≈øtrange cures would bee performed by it, both inward and outward. For outward application, a Salue made hereof (as is before recited of the Thorne apple leaues) cureth vlcers, and wounds of hard curation: And for inward helpes, a Syrupe made of the iuice and ≈øugar, or honey, procureth a gentle vomit (but the dryed leafe infu≈øed in wine much more) and is effectuall in a≈øtmaticall di≈øea≈øes, if it bee carefully giuen. And likewi≈øe clean≈øeth cankers and fi≈øtulaes admirably, as hath beene found by late experience. The a≈øhes of Tabacco is often v≈øed, and with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, for cuts in the hands, or other places, and for other ≈ømall greene wounds.

div.head: Mirabilia Peruviana. The Meruaile of Peru.
div.p: THis plant yeeldeth in our Gardens fiue or ≈øixe ≈øeuerall varieties of beautifull flowers, as pure white, pure yellow, pure red, white and red ≈øpotted, and red and yellow ≈øpotted. But be≈øides the≈øe, I haue had ≈øome other ≈øorts, among which was one, of a pale purple or peach colour: all which, comming vnto mee out of Spaine with many other, ≈øeedes in an vnkindly yeare (an early winter following a cold ≈øummer) peri≈øhed with mee; yet I plainely might di≈øcerne by their leaues, and manner of growing, to be diuers from them that we now haue and keepe. I ≈øhall need therefore (becau≈øe the chiefe≈øt difference con≈øi≈øteth almo≈øt in the flowers) to giue only one de≈øcription of the plant, and therein ≈øhew the varieties as is before declared.

div.head: Admirabilis. The Meruaile of the World.
div.p:
The ≈øtalke of this meruellous plant is great and thick, bigger then any mans thumbe,
bunched out or ≈øwelling at euery ioynt, in ≈øome the ≈øtalkes will bee of a faire greene colour, and tho≈øe will bring white, or white and red flowers: in others they will bee reddi≈øh, and more at the ioynts, and tho≈øe giue red flowers; and in ≈øome of a darker greene colour, which giue yellow flowers; the ≈øtalkes and ioynts of tho≈øe that will giue red and yellow flowers ≈øpotted, are ≈øomewhat browni≈øh, but not ≈øo red as tho≈øe that giue wholly red flowers: vpon the≈øe ≈øtalkes that ≈øpread into many branches, doe grow at the ioynts vpon ≈øeuerall foote≈øtalkes, faire greene leaues; broad at the ≈øtalke, and pointed at the end: at the ioynts likewi≈øe toward the vpper part of the branches, at the foote of the leaues, come forth ≈øeuerall flowers vpon ≈øhort foote≈øtalkes, euery one being ≈ømall, long and hollow from the bottome to the brimme, which is broade ≈øpread open, and round, and con≈øi≈øt but of one leafe without diui≈øion, like vnto a Bell flower, but not cornered at all: which flowers, as I ≈øaid, are of diuers colours, and diuer≈øly marked and ≈øpotted, ≈øome being wholly white, without any ≈øpot in them for the mo≈øt part, through all the flowers of the plant; ≈øo likewi≈øe ≈øome being yellow, and ≈øome wholly red; ≈øome plants againe being mixed and ≈øpotted, ≈øo variably either white and red, or purple, (except here and there ≈øome may chance to be wholly white, or red or purple among the re≈øt) or red and yellow through the whole plant, (except as before ≈øome may chance in this kinde to be eyther wholly red, or wholly yellow) that you ≈øhall hardly finde two or three flowers in a hundred, that will bee alike ≈øpotted and marked, without ≈øome diuer≈øitie, and ≈øo likewi≈øe euery day, as long as they blow, which is vntill the winters, or rather autumnes cold bla≈øtes do ≈øtay their willing pronene≈ø≈øe to flower: And I haue often al≈øo ob≈øerued, that one ≈øide of a plant will giue fairer varieties then another, which is mo≈øt commonly the Ea≈øterne, as the more temperate and ≈øhadowie ≈øide. All the≈øe flowers doe open for the mo≈øt part, in the euening, or in the night time, and ≈øo ≈øtand blowne open, vntill the next mornings ≈øun beginne to grow warme vpon them, which then clo≈øe them≈øelues together, all the brims of the flowers ≈øhrinking into the middle of the long necke, much like vnto the blew Bindeweede, which in a manner doth ≈øo clo≈øe vp at the ≈øunnes warme heate: or el≈øe if the day be temperate and milde, without any ≈øunne ≈øhining vpon them, the flowers will not clo≈øe vp for the mo≈øt part of that day, or vntill toward night: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come ≈øeuerall ≈øeedes, that is, but one at a place as the flowers ≈øtood before, of the bigne≈ø≈øe (≈øometimes) of ≈ømall pea≈øe, but not ≈øo round, ≈øtanding within the greene huskes, wherein the flowers ≈øtood before, being a little flat at the toppe, like a crowne or head, and round where it is fa≈øtened in the cup, of a blacke colour when it is ripe, but el≈øe greene all the while it groweth on the ≈øtalke, and being ripe is ≈øoone ≈øhaken downe with the wind, or any other light ≈øhaking: the roote is long and round, greater at the head, and ≈ømaller downwards to the end, like vnto a Reddi≈øh, ≈øpreading into two or three, or more branches, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide and whiti≈øh within. The≈øe rootes I haue often pre≈øerued by art a winter, two or three (for they will peri≈øh if they be left out in the garden, vnle≈ø≈øe it be vnder a hou≈øe ≈øide) becau≈øe many times, the yeare not falling out kindely, the plants giue not ripe ≈øeede, and ≈øo we ≈øhould be to ≈øeeke both of ≈øeede to ≈øow, and of rootes to ≈øet, if this or the like art to keep them, were not v≈øed; which is in this manner: Within a while after the fir≈øt fro≈øts haue taken the plants, that the leaues wither and fall, digge vp the rootes whole, and lay them in a dry place for three or foure dayes, that the ≈øuperfluous moy≈øture on the out≈øide, may be ≈øpent and dryed, which done, wrap them vp ≈øeuerally in two or three browne papers, and lay them by in a boxe, che≈øt or tub, in ≈øome conuenient place of the hou≈øe all the winter time, where no winde or moi≈øt ayre may come vnto them; and thus you ≈øhall haue the≈øe rootes to ≈øpring a fre≈øh the next yeare, if you plant them in the beginning of March, as I haue ≈øufficiently tryed. But ≈øome haue tryed to put them vp into a barrell or firkin of ≈øand, or a≈øhes, which is al≈øo good if the ≈øand and a≈øhes be thorough dry, but if it bee any thing moi≈øt, or if they giue againe in the winter, as it is v≈øuall, they haue found the moi≈øture of the rootes, or of the ≈øand, or both, to putrefie the rootes, that they haue beene nothing worth, when they haue taken them forth. Take this note al≈øo for the ≈øowing of your ≈øeede, that if you would haue variable flowers, and not all of one colour, you mu≈øt choo≈øe out ≈øuch flowers as be variable while they grow, that you may haue the ≈øeede of them: for if the flowers bee of one entire colour, you ≈øhall haue for the mo≈øt part from tho≈øe ≈øeedes, plants that will bring flowers all of that colour, whether it be white, red or yellow.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe plants grow naturally in the We≈øt Indies, where there is a perpetuall ≈øummer, or at the lea≈øt no cold fro≈øty winters, from whence the ≈øeede hath been ≈øent into the≈øe parts of Europe, and are di≈øper≈øed into euery garden almo≈øt of note.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe plants flower from the end of Iuly ≈øometimes, or Augu≈øt, vntill the fro≈øts, and cold ayres of the euenings in October, pull them down, and in the meane time the ≈øeed is ripe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Wee haue not receiued the ≈øeedes of this plant vnder any other name, then Mirabilia Peruviana, or Admirabilis planta. In Engli≈øh wee call them, The meruaile of Peru, or the meruaile of the world: yet ≈øome Authors haue called it Gel≈øeminum, or Ia≈øminum rubrum, & Indicum: and Bauhinus Solanum Mexiocanum flore magno.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We haue not knowne any v≈øe hereof in Phy≈øicke.

div.head: Malua. Mallowes.
div.p: OF the kindred of Mallowes there are a great number, ≈øome of the gardens, others wilde, ≈øome with ≈øingle flowers, others with double, ≈øome with whole leaues, others with cut or diuided: to entreate of them all is not my purpo≈øe, nor the ≈øcope of this worke, but onely of ≈øuch who≈øe flowers, hauing beautie and re≈øpect, are fit to furni≈øh this garden, as ornaments thereunto. And fir≈øt of tho≈øe ≈øingle kindes, who≈øe flowers come neere≈øt vnto the fa≈øhion of the former Bell-flowers, and after to the double ones, which for their brauery, are entertained euery where into euery Countrey womans garden.

div.head: 1. Malua Hi≈øpanica flore carneo amplo. The Spani≈øh blu≈øh Mallow.
div.p: The Spani≈øh Mallow is in forme and manner of growing, very like vnto our common fielde Mallow, hauing vpright ≈øtalkes two or three foote high, ≈øpread into diuers branches, and from the bottome to the toppe, be≈øet with round leaues, like vnto our Mallowes, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, rounder, and le≈ø≈øe diuided, yet larger below then aboue: the flowers are plentifully growing vpon the ≈ømall branches, folding or writhing their leaues one about another before they bee blowne, and being open con≈øi≈øt of fiue leaues, with a long forked clapper therein, of the ≈øame colour with the flower: the chiefe≈øt difference from the common con≈øi≈øteth in this, that the leaues of the≈øe flowers are longer, and more wide open at the brimmes (almo≈øt like a Bell-flower) and of a faire blu≈øh or light carnation colour, clo≈øing at night, and opening all the day: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come ≈øuch like round heads, with ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede, like vnto the common kinde, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller: the roote is ≈ømall and long, and peri≈øheth euery yeare.

div.head: 2. Alcea vulgaris flore carneo. Vervaine Mallow with blu≈øh flowers.
div.p:
There is a Mallow that hath long ≈øtalkes, and flowers like vnto the common wilde
1 Malua Hi≈øpanica flore carneo amplo. The Spani≈øh Mallow. 2 Alcea Veneta. The Venice Mallow. 3 Alcea Americana. Thorney Mallow. 4 Alcea Aeg ‚Ä¢ ptiae. The Mallow of Egypt. 5 Althaea
‚Ä¢ rutex. The ≈øhrubbe Mallow. 6 Malua horten≈øis ≈øimplex. Single Hollihockes. 7 Malua ro≈øea multiplex. Double Hollihockes. depiction of flowers
Mallow, and of the ≈øame deepe colour with it, ≈øo that you can hardly know it from the ordinary kinde, which is found growing wilde together with it, but onely by the leafe, which is as round and as large as the former, but cut into many fine diui≈øions, euen to the ≈øtalke that vpholdeth it, that it ≈øeemeth to con≈øi≈øt onely of ragges, or peeces of leaues: Of this kinde I take a plante for this garden, growing in all re≈øpects like vnto it, but differing onely in the colour of the flowers, which are of the ≈øame blu≈øh or light carnation colour, or not much differing from the former Spani≈øh kinde, with ≈øome veines therein of a deeper colour: the root hereof liueth, as the root of the common wilde kinde doth.

div.head: 3. Alcea peregrina ≈øiue ve≈øicaria. Venice Mallow, or Good night at noone.
div.p: The Venice Mallow hath long and weake ≈øtalkes, mo≈øt v≈øually lying or leaning vpon the ground, hauing here and there vpon them long leaues and ≈øomewhat broad, cut in or ga≈øhed very deepely on both edges, that it ≈øeemeth as if they were diuers leaues ≈øet together, euery one ≈øtanding on a long foote≈øtalke: at the ioynts of the≈øe ≈øtalkes, where the leaues are ≈øet, come forth ≈øeuerall flowers, ≈øtanding vpon long foot≈øtalkes, which are ≈øomewhat larger then any of the former flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, ≈ømall at the bottome, and wide at the brimmes, of a whiti≈øh colour tending to a blu≈øh, and ≈øometimes all white, with ≈øpots at the bottomes of the leaues on the in≈øide, of a very deepe purple or murrey colour, which addeth a great grace to the flower, and hauing al≈øo a long pe≈øtle or clapper in the middle, as yellow as gold: the≈øe flowers are ≈øo quickly faded and gone, that you ≈øhall hardly ≈øee any of them blowne open, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee betimes in the morning before the Sunne doe grow warme vpon them, for as ≈øoone as it feeleth the Sunnes warme heate, it clo≈øeth vp and neuer openeth againe, ≈øo that you ≈øhall very ≈øeldome ≈øee a flower blowne open in the day time, after nine a clocke in the morning: after the≈øe flowers are pa≈øt, there ri≈øe vp in their places thinne, round, ≈øhining or tran≈øparent bladders, pointed at the toppe, and ribbed down all along, wherein are contained ≈ømall, round, blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is long and ≈ømall, and peri≈øheth euery yeare.

div.head: 4. Alcea frutico≈øa pentaphyllea. Cinquefoile Mallow.
div.p: The ≈øtalkes of this Mallow are very long, hard or wooddy, more then of any of the other Mallowes: at the lower part whereof, and vp to the middle, ≈øtand diuers leaues vpon long foote≈øtalkes, parted or diuided into fiue parts or leaues, and dented about the edges; but vpwards from the middle to the toppe, the leaues haue but three diui≈øions: among the≈øe leaues ≈øtand large wide open flowers, of the colour of the common Mallow: the ≈øeede is ≈ømaller then in any other Mallow, but the rootes are great and long, ≈øpreading in the ground like vnto the roots of Mar≈øh Mallowes, ≈øpringing vp afre≈øh euery yeare from the roote.

div.head: 5. Sabdarifa ≈øeu Alcea Americana. Thorney Mallowe.
div.p:
This Thorney Mallowe hath greene leaues next vnto the ground, that are almo≈øt round, but pointed at the end, and dented very much about the edges; the other leaues that growe vpon the ≈øtalke are diuided into three parts, like vnto a trefoile, and ≈øome of them into fiue diui≈øions, all of them dented about the edges: the ≈øtalke is reddi≈øh, with ≈øome harmele≈ø≈øe prickles in ≈øundry places thereon, and ri≈øeth vp three or foure foote high in a good ground, a fit place, and a kindly yeare, bearing plenty of flowers vpon the ≈øtalkes, one at the foote of euery leafe, the toppe it ≈øelfe ending in a long ≈øpike, as it were of buddes and leaues together: the flowers are of a very pale yellow, tending to a white colour, ≈øpotted in the bottome of each of the fiue leaues, with a deepe purple ≈øpot, broad at the lower part, and ending in a point about the middle of the leafe, which are quickly fading, and not abiding aboue one day, with a long pe≈øtle in the middle diuided at the toppe: after the flower is pa≈øt, commeth vp a ≈øhort prickly podde, ≈øet within a ≈ømall greene huske or cup that bore the flower, wherein is contained
whiti≈øh, or rather browni≈øh yellow ≈øeede, flat and ≈øomewhat round, like vnto the ≈øeedes of Hollyhocke: the roote is ≈øtringie, and quickly peri≈øheth; for it will hardly endure in our cold Country to giue flowers, much le≈ø≈øe ≈øeede, vnle≈ø≈øe (as I ≈øaid before) it happen in a kindly yeare, and be well planted and tended.

div.head: 6. Bamia ≈øeu Alcea Aegyptia. The Mallow of Egypt.
div.p: This Mallow is al≈øo as tender to nour≈øe vp as the la≈øt, hauing the lower leaues broad like a Mar≈øh Mallow, and of a fre≈øh greene colour; but tho≈øe that growe vpon the ≈øtalke, and vp to the toppe, are diuided into fiue parts or points, but are not cut in to the middle ribbe, like the former Thorney Mallow, yet dented about the edges like vnto them: the flowers growe at the ≈øetting to of the leaues, like vnto a Mallow for forme, but of a whiti≈øh colour; after which come long fiue ≈øquare pointed pods, with hard ≈øhels, wherein are contained round blacki≈øh gray ≈øeede, as bigge as a Vetch or bigger: the roote peri≈øheth quickly with vs, euen with the fir≈øt fro≈øts.

div.head: 7. Althaea frutex flore albo vel purpureo. Shrubbe Mallow with a white or purple flower.
div.p: There are diuers ≈øorts of ≈øhrubbe Mallowes, whereof ≈øome that haue their ≈øtemmes or ≈øtalkes le≈ø≈øe wooddy, dye downe to the ground euery yeare, and others that abide alwayes, are more wooddy: Of the former ≈øorts I intend not to ≈øpeake, referring them to a fitter place; and of the other, I will onely giue you the knowledge of one or two in this place, although I doe acknowledge their fitte≈øt place had been to be among the ≈øhrubbes; but becau≈øe they are Mallowes, I pray let them pa≈ø≈øe with the re≈øt of their kindred, and their de≈øcriptions in this manner: The≈øe wooddy kindes of ≈øhrub Mallowes haue ≈øomewhat large, long, and diuided leaues, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, ≈øoft al≈øo, and as it were woolly in handling, ≈øet di≈øper≈øedly on the whiti≈øh hard or wooddy ≈øtalkes: their flowers are large, like vnto a ≈øingle Ro≈øe or Hollyhocke, in the one being white with purple ≈øpots in the bottome; in the other either of a deepe red colour, or el≈øe of a paler purple, with a deeper bottome, and with veines running in euery leafe: they are ≈øomewhat tender, and would not be ≈øuffered to be vncouered in the Winter time, or yet abroad in the Garden, but kept in a large pot or tubbe, in the hou≈øe or in a warme cellar, if you would haue them to thriue.

div.head: 8. Malua horten≈øis ro≈øea ≈øimplex & multiplex diuer≈øorum colorum. Hollihockes ≈øingle and double of ≈øeuerall colours.
div.p: I ≈øhall not neede to make many de≈øcriptions of Hollihockes, in regard the greate≈øt difference con≈øi≈øteth in the flowers, which are in ≈øome ≈øingle, in ≈øome double, in ≈øome of one colour, and in others of other colours: for the lowe≈øt leaues of Hollihockes are all round, and ≈øomewhat large, with many corners, but not cut in or diuided, ≈øoft in handling; but tho≈øe that growe vp higher are much more diuided into many corners: the ≈øtalkes ≈øometimes growe like a tree, at the lea≈øt higher then any man, with diuers ≈øuch diuided leaues on them, and flowers from the middle to the toppe, where they ≈øtand as it were a long ≈øpike of leaues and buds for flowers together: the flowers are of diuers colours, both ≈øingle and double, as pure white, and pale blu≈øh, almo≈øt like a white, and more blu≈øh, fre≈øh and liuely, of a Ro≈øe colour, Scarlet, and a deeper red like a crim≈øon, and of a darke red like blacke bloud; the≈øe are the mo≈øt e≈øpeciall colours both of ≈øingle and double flowers that I haue ≈øeene: the ≈øingle flowers con≈øi≈øt of fiue broad and round leaues, ≈øtanding round like vnto ≈øingle Ro≈øes, with a middle long ≈øtile, and ≈øome chiues aboue them: the double flowers are like vnto double Ro≈øes, very thicke, ≈øo that no ≈øtile or vmbone is ≈øeene in the middle, and the outermo≈øt rowe of leaues in the flowers are large≈øt, the innermo≈øt being ≈ømaller and thicke ≈øet together: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp as well in the double as ≈øingle, flat round heads, like flat cakes, round about the bottomes whereof growe flat whiti≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is long and great at the head, white and tough, like the roote of the common Mallowes, but greater, and will rea≈øonably well abide the Winter.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth wilde in Spaine. The ≈øecond in our owne Countrey. The third is thought to growe in Italy and Venice; but Lobel denieth it, ≈øaying, that it is there onely in Gardens, and is more plentifull in the≈øe parts then with them. The fourth Clu≈øius ≈øaith he found in many places of Germany. The fifth is ≈øuppo≈øed to be fir≈øt brought out of the We≈øt Indies, but an Arabicke name being giuen it, maketh me ≈øomewhat doubtfull how to beleeue it. The ≈øixth groweth in Egypt, where it is of great v≈øe, as Pro≈øper Alpinus hath ≈øet downe in his Booke of Egyptian plants. The ≈øeuenth groweth in ≈øome parts both of Spaine and France. The la≈øt is not found but in Gardens euery where.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt, ≈øecond, third, fourth, and la≈øt, doe flower from Iune vntill the end of Iuly and Augu≈øt. The re≈øt flower very late, many times not vntill September or October.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt and ≈øecond haue their names ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in their titles. The third is diuer≈øly called, as Malua horaria, Alcea ve≈øicaria, Alcea Veneta, Alcea Peregrina, and of Matthiolus, Hypecoum. The mo≈øt v≈øuall Engli≈øh name is Venice Mallow. The fourth is called Alcea frutico≈øa pentaphyllea, and Cannabinifolio, or Pentaphyllifolio: In Engli≈øh, Cinquefoile Mallow. The fifth hath been ≈øent vnder the name of Sabdarifa, and Sabdariffa, and (as I ≈øaid) is thought to be brought from America, and therefore it beareth the name of that Country. The ≈øixth is called in Egypt, Bamia, or Bammia, and by that name ≈øent with the addition del Cayro vnto it: In Engli≈øh, Egyptian Mallow, or Mallow of Egypt. The ≈øeuenth is called Althaea frutex, and of ≈øome Althaea arborea: In Engli≈øh, Shrubbe Mallow, becau≈øe his ≈øtemme is wooddie, and abideth as ≈øhrubbes and trees doe. The eight and la≈øt is called Malua horten≈øis, Malua Ro≈øea, and of ≈øome Ro≈øa vltra marina: In Engli≈øh, of ≈øome Hockes, and v≈øually Hollihockes.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All ≈øorts of Mallowes, by rea≈øon of their vi≈øcous or ≈ølimie quality, doe helpe to make the body ≈øoluble, being v≈øed inwardly, and thereby helpe al≈øo to ea≈øe the paines of the ≈øtone and grauell, cau≈øing them to be the more ea≈øily voided: being outwardly applyed, they mollifie hard tumors, and helpe to ea≈øe paines in diuers parts of the body; yet tho≈øe that are of mo≈øt v≈øe, are mo≈øt common. The re≈øt are but taken vpon credit.

div.head: Amaranthus. Flower-gentle.
div.p: WE haue foure or fiue ≈øorts of Flower-gentle to trimme vp this our Garden withall, which doe differ very notably one from another, as ≈øhall be declared in their ≈øeuerall de≈øcriptions; ≈øome of which are very tender, and mu≈øt be carefully regarded, and all little enough to cau≈øe them beare ≈øeede with vs, or el≈øe wee ≈øhall bee to ≈øeeke euery yeare: others are hardy enough, and will hardly be lo≈øt out of the Garden.

div.head: 1. Amaranthus purpureus minor. The ≈ømall purple Flower-gentle.
div.p: This gallant purple Veluet flower, or Flower-gentle, hath a cre≈øted ≈øtalke two foote high or more, purpli≈øh at the bottome, but greene to the toppe, whereout groweth many ≈ømall branches, the leaues on the ≈øtalkes and branches are ≈øomewhat broad at the bottome, and ≈øharpe pointed, of a full greene colour, and often ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh withall, like in forme vnto the leaues of Blites (whereof this and the re≈øt are accounted ≈øpecies, or ≈øorts) or ≈ømall Beetes: the flowers are long, ≈øpikie, ≈øoft, and gentle tufts of haires, many as it were growing together, broad at the bottome, and ≈ømall vp at the toppe, pyramis or ≈øteeple-fa≈øhion, of ≈øo excellent a ≈øhining deepe purple colour, tending to a murrey, that in the mo≈øt excellent coloured Veluet, cannot be ≈øeene a more orient colour, (and I thinke from this re≈øpect, the French call it Pa≈ø≈øe velours, that is to ≈øay, pa≈ø≈øing Veluet in colour) without any ≈ømell at all, which being brui≈øed giueth the ≈øame excellent purple colour on paper, and being gathered in his full ≈øtrength and beauty, will abide a great time (if it be kept out of the winde and ≈øunne in a dry place) in the ≈øame grace and colour: among the≈øe tufts lye the ≈øeede ≈øcattered, which is ≈ømall, very blacke, and ≈øhining: the rootes are a few threddy ≈øtrings, which quickly peri≈øh, as the whole plant doth, at the fir≈øt approach of Winter weather.

div.head: 2. Amaranthus Coccineus. Scarlet Flower-gentle.
div.p: The leaues of this Flower-gentle are longer, and ≈øomewhat narrower then the former; the ≈øtalke groweth ≈øomewhat higher, bearing his long tufts at ≈øeuerall leaues, as al≈øo at the toppe of the ≈øtalkes, many being ≈øet together, but ≈øeparate one from another, and each bowing or bending downe his head, like vnto a Feather, ≈øuch as is worn in our Gallants and Gentlewomens heads, of an excellent bloudy Scarlet colour: the ≈øeede is blacke, like vnto the former: the roote peri≈øheth quicklier, becau≈øe it is more tender.

div.head: 3. Amaranthus tricolor. Spotted or variable Flower-gentle.
div.p: The chiefe≈øt beauty of this plant con≈øi≈øteth in the leaues, and not in the flowers; for they are ≈ømall tufts growing all along the ≈øtalke, which is nothing ≈øo high as the former, e≈øpecially with vs, and at the ioynts with the leaues: the leaues hereof are of the ≈øame fa≈øhion that the former are, and pointed al≈øo; but euery leafe is to be ≈øeene parted into greene, red, and yellow, very orient and fre≈øh (e≈øpecially if it come to his full perfection, which is in hot and dry weather) diuided not all alike, but in ≈øome leaues, where the red or yellow is, there will be greene, and ≈øo varying, that it is very plea≈øant to behold: the ≈øeede hereof is blacke and ≈øhining, not to bee knowne from the former.

div.head: 4. Amaranthus Carnea ≈øpica. Carnation Flower-gentle.
div.p: There is another more rare then all the re≈øt, who≈øe leaues are ≈øomewhat longer, and narrower then the fir≈øt, and like vnto the ≈øecond kinde: the ≈øpikes are ≈øhort, many ≈øet together, like branches full of heads or eares of corne, euery one whereof hath ≈øome long haires ≈øticking out from them, of a deep blu≈øh, tending to a carnation colour.

div.head: 5. Amaranthus purpureus maior panniculis ≈øpar≈øis. Great Floramour, or purple Flower-gentle.
div.p:
The great Floramour hath one thicke, tall, cre≈øted, browne red ≈øtalke, fiue or ≈øix foote high, from whence ≈øpring many great broad leaues, like vnto the former for the forme, but much larger & redder for the mo≈øt part, e≈øpecially the lowe≈øt, which brancheth forth into diuers parts, & from between the≈øe leaues, & the ≈øtalks or branches, as al≈øo at the tops of them, ≈øtand long, ≈øpikie, round, & ≈øomewhat flat tufts, of a more reddi≈øh purple colour then the fir≈øt, and diuided al≈øo into ≈øeuerall parts, wherin when they
are full ripe, are to be ≈øeen an innumerable company of white ≈øeed, ≈øtanding out among the ≈øhort thrums, and do then ea≈øily fall away with a little touching; euery one of the ‚Ä¢ e white ≈øeed hath as it were an hole halfe bored through therin: the root is a great bu≈øh of ≈øtrings, ≈øpreading in the ground, whereby it is ≈øtrongly fa≈øtened, yet peri≈øheth euery yeare, after it hath giuen his ≈øeede.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe plants growe in the Ea≈øterne Countries, as Per≈øia, Syria, Arabia, &c. except the greate≈øt, which hath been brought out of the We≈øt Indies, where it is much v≈øed, e≈øpecially the ≈øeede: they are all, except it, nour≈øed vp with much care in our Gardens, and yet in a backward or cold yeare they will not thriue, for that they de≈øire much heate: but the greate≈øt doth alwayes giue ripe ≈øeede euery yeare.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They beare their gallant tufts or ≈øpikes for the mo≈øt part in Augu≈øt, and ≈øome not vntill September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Amaranthus is giuen to all the≈øe plants, taken from the Greeke word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , non marce≈øcens, or non ≈øene≈øcens, that is, neuer waxing old, and is often al≈øo impo≈øed on other plants, who haue the ≈øame property, that is, that their flowers being gathered in a fit ≈øea≈øon, will retaine their natiue colour a long time, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in the Chapter following. Diuers do thinke the fir≈øt to be Phlox, or Flamma of Theophra≈øtus. The third is called Gelo≈øia, or Celo≈øia of Tragus. Spigelius in his I≈øagoges ≈øaith, it is generally taken to be Sophonia, whereof Plinie maketh mention; and Lobel, to bee the Per≈øians Theombroton of Plinie. The Italians, from whom I had it (by the meanes of Mr. Doctor Iohn More, as I haue had many other rare ≈øimples) call it, Blito di tre colori, A three coloured Blite. The fifth, which is the greate≈øt, hath been ≈øent from the We≈øt Indies by the name of Quin√ºa, as Clu≈øius reporteth. The name Flower-gentle in Engli≈øh, and Floramour, which is the French, of Flos amoris, and Pa≈ø≈øe velours, as is before ≈øaid, or Veluet flower, according to the Italian, Fior veluto, are equally giuen to all the≈øe plants, with their ≈øeuerall di≈øtinctions, as they are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Diuers ≈øuppo≈øe the flowers of the≈øe plants doe helpe to ≈øtay the fluxe of bloud in man or woman, becau≈øe that other things that are red or purple doe performe the ≈øame. But Galen di≈øproueth that opinion very notably, in lib. 2. & 4. de ≈øimpl. medicament. facultatibus.

div.head: Helichry≈øum, ≈øiue Amaranthus luteus. Golden Flower-gentle, Goldilockes, or Gold-flower.
div.p:
THe propinquity of property (as I before ≈øaid) hath cau≈øed the affinity in name, and ≈øo in neighbourhood in the≈øe plants, wherein there are ≈øome diuer≈øity; and although they differ from them before in many notable points, yet they all agree with them≈øelues in the golden, or ≈øiluer heads or tufts they beare; and therefore I
1 Amaranthus purpureus maior. The great purple Flower-gentle. 2 Amaranthus purpureus minor. The le≈ø≈øer purple Flower-gentle. 3 Amaranthu ‚Ä¢ tricolor. Variable Flower-gentle. 4 Amaranthus Coccineus. Scarlet Flower gentle. 5 Amaranthus carnea ≈øpica. Carnation Flower-gentle. 6 Chry≈ø ‚Ä¢ come. Golden Ca≈ø≈øidonie. 7 Heliochry≈øum Creticum. Candy Goldilockes. 8 Gnaphal ‚Ä¢ um Americanum. Liuelong or Life euerla≈øting. 9 Gnaphalium mo ‚Ä¢ tanu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Cats foote. 10 Gnaphalium ro≈ø ‚Ä¢ um. The Cotton Ro≈øe. depiction of flowers
haue compri≈øed them in one Chapter, and will begin with that which commeth neare≈øt vnto the Helichry≈øum of Dio≈øcorides, or Aurelia (as Gaza tran≈ølateth it) of Theophra≈øtus.

div.head: 1. Heliochry≈øum. The Golden flower of life.
div.p: This fir≈øt Golden tuft ri≈øeth vp with many hard, round, white ≈øtalkes, a foote and a halfe high, whereon at certaine di≈øtances ≈øtand many fine cut leaues, or rather one leafe cut into many ≈ømall fine parts, almo≈øt as ≈ømall as Fenell, but grayi≈øh, like vnto the Cud-weedes or Cotton-weedes (whereof certainly the≈øe are ≈øpeciall kindes) at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes ≈øtand many round flowers, of a pale gold colour, in an vmbell clo≈øe together, yet euery flower vpon his owne ≈øtalke, and all of an euen height, which will keepe the colour, being gathered, and kept dry for a long time after, and are of a hot and quicke ≈øent: the roote is ≈ømall and wooddy, ≈øpreading vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the earth, and liueth long in his owne naturall place, but very hardly endureth the cold of our Winters, vnle≈ø≈øe they be milde, or it be well defended.

div.head: 2. Helichry≈øum Creticum. Candy Goldilockes.
div.p: Candy Goldilockes hath two or three ≈ømall ≈ølender white branches, ≈øet here and there very ≈øcatteringly, with ≈ømall, long, and narrow hoary leaues, hauing yellow heads of flowers at the tops made into vmbels or tufts, not ≈øo round and euen as the former, but longwi≈øe one aboue another, the heads being made as it were of ≈øcales, loo≈øly, and not ≈øo clo≈øely ≈øet together, as in the next following, which when they are full ripe, doe pa≈ø≈øe into doune, and are blowne away with the winde, hauing a ≈ømall reddi≈øh ≈øeede at the end; but will abide a long time, as the other in his beauty, being gathered in time, as the re≈øt will doe.

div.head: 3. Helichry≈øum Orientale ≈øiue Amaranthus luteus. Golden Flower-gentle.
div.p: This mo≈øt beautifull plant is very like vnto the former Candy Goldilockes la≈øt de≈øcribed, but growing vp higher, with many more branches, and more hoary, white, and woolly, hauing al≈øo long and narrow white leaues, but ≈øomewhat broader, and thicker ≈øet on the branches: the tufts of flowers or vmbels likewi≈øe doe con≈øi≈øt of longer and larger heads, more ≈øcaly, and clo≈øer compact together, of an excellent pale gold yellow colour, and ≈øhining, with ≈øome yellow threads or thrummes in the middle: the roote dyeth not euery yeare, but liueth long, e≈øpecially in the South and Ea≈øt Countries, where no colds or fro≈øts are felt; but will require extraordinary care and keeping, and yet ≈øcarce ≈øufficient to pre≈øerue it in the≈øe cold Countries.

div.head: 4. Chry≈øocome ≈øiue Staechas Citrina. Golden tufts or Golden Ca≈ø≈øidony.
div.p: This Golden flower is ≈øomewhat like the former of the≈øe two la≈øt de≈øcribed, hauing hoary ≈øtalkes and leaues, ≈øtanding confu≈øedly on them, being long, and narrower then any of the former: the tops of the ≈øtalkes are diuided into many parts, each bearing a ≈ømall long yellow head or flower at the toppe, with ≈øome yellow thrummes in them, which heads being many, are diffu≈øedly ≈øet together, like a loo≈øe or ≈øpar≈øed vmbell, keeping their colour long before they wither, and when they are ripe, haue thinne ≈ømall reddi≈øh ≈øeede, like Mariorome ≈øeede, but ≈ømaller; the roote is ≈ømall and blacke: the whole plant, as well leaues and flowers, as rootes, are of a ≈øtrong ≈øharpe ≈øent, yet plea≈øant.

div.head: 5. Argyrocome ≈øiue Gnaphalium Americanum. Liue long or Life euerla≈øting.
div.p:
This ≈øiluer tuft or Indian Cotton weede, hath many white heads of leafes at their fir≈øt ≈øpringing out of the ground, couered with a hoary woolline≈ø≈øe like cotton, which ri≈øing into hard, thicke round ≈øtalkes, containe ≈øtill the ≈øame hoarine≈ø≈øe vpon them, as al≈øo vpon the long and narrow leaues which are ≈øet thereon, e≈øpecially on the vnder
≈øide, for the vpper ≈øides are of a darke ≈øhining greene colour: the ≈øtalkes are diuided at the toppe into many ≈ømall branches, each whereof haue many ≈øcaly tufted heads ≈øet together, couered ouer with cotton before their opening, and then di≈ø≈øeuering one from another, abiding very white on the out≈øide, when they are fully growne, but with a ≈ømall yellow thrume in the midde of euery flower, which in time turne into yellow doune, apt to be blowne away with euery winde: the roots are long and black on the out≈øide, creeping vnder ground very much.

div.head: 6. Gnaphalium montanum flore albo & flore purpureo. White and purple Catsfoote.
div.p: This ≈ømall Cudweede or Cottonweede, hath many ≈ømall white woolly leaues growing from the roote, which is compo≈øed of a few ≈ømall blacki≈øh threds, and lying vpon the ground ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of a ≈ømall Mou≈øe eare, but ≈ømaller; from among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall ≈øtalke of halfe a foote high or thereabouts, be≈øet here and there with ≈øome few leaues, at the top whereof commeth forth a tuft of ≈ømall flowers, ≈øet clo≈øe together, in ≈øome of a pure white, in others of a purple or reddi≈øh colour, in ≈øome of a pale red or blu≈øh, and in others of a white and purple mixt together which for the beauty is much commended and de≈øired, but will hardly abide to be kept in Gardens, ≈øo vnwilling they are to leaue their naturall abiding.

div.head: 7. Gnaphalium Ro≈øeum. The Cotton Ro≈øe.
div.p: This little ro≈øe Cotton weede hath many ≈øuch like woolly leaues, growing as the former from the roote vpon ≈ømall ≈øhort branches, not full an hand breadth high, in fa≈øhion ≈øomewhat like vnto Day≈øie leaues, but le≈ø≈øer, and round pointed: at the toppe of euery ≈øtalke or branch, ≈øtandeth one flower, compo≈øed of two rowes of ≈ømall white leaues, layd open like a Starre or a Ro≈øe, as it beareth the name, hauing a round head in the middle made of many yellow threds or thrumes, which falling away, there ri≈øeth vp a ≈ømall round head, full of ≈ømall ≈øeedes: the root is ≈ømall, long and threddy.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The foure fir≈øt plants doe grow naturally in many of the hot Countries of Europe, as Spaine, Italie, and Prouince in France; as al≈øo in Candy, Barbary, and other places, and mu≈øt be carefully kept with vs in the winter time. The Liue long was brought out of the We≈øt Indies, and groweth plentifully in our gardens. The two la≈øt doe grow as well in the colder Countries of Germany, as in France and other places.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in the end of September, if they will ≈øhew out their beauty at all with vs, for ≈øometimes it is ≈øo late, that they haue no faire colour at all, e≈øpecially the foure fir≈øt ≈øorts.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Variable and many are the names that ≈øeuerall Writers do call the≈øe foure fir≈øt ≈øorts of plants, as Helichry≈øum, Heliochry≈øum, or Elichrylum. Eliochry≈øum, Chry≈øocome, Coma aurea, Amaranthus luteus, Stoechas Citrina, and Aurelia, with others, needle≈ø≈øe here to be recited: it is ≈øufficient for this worke, to giue you knowledge that their names are ≈øufficient as they are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles: The fift is called Gnaphalium by Carolus Clu≈øius, from the likene≈ø≈øe of the vmbels or tufts of heads, though greater and white: for as I ≈øaid before, the Cotton weedes are of kindred with the golden tufts: It hath been called by our Engli≈øh Gentlewomen, Liue long, and Life euerla≈øting, becau≈øe of the durabilitie of the flowers in their beautie. The two la≈øt are called
Gnaphalium, according to their titles; and in Engli≈øh they may pa≈ø≈øe vnder tho≈øe names are ≈øet downe with them.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The foure fir≈øt are accounted to bee hot and dry, and the three la≈øt to bee cold and dry: yet all of them may to ≈øome good purpo≈øe bee applyed to rheumaticke heads. The former foure are likewi≈øe v≈øed to cau≈øe vrine, and in baths to comfort and heate cold parts. They are al≈øo layd in che≈øts and wardrobes, to keepe garments from moths; and are worne in the heads and armes of Gentiles and others, for their beautifull a≈øpect.

div.head: Canna Indica. The Indian flowring Reede.
div.p: THere are two kindes or ≈øorts of this beautifull plant, the one with a red flower, the other with a yellow, ≈øpotted with reddi≈øh ≈øpots, both which in ≈øome kindly yeares haue borne their braue flowers, but neuer any ripe ≈øeede, and doth not abide the extremities of our winters, eyther abroade or vnder couert, vnle≈ø≈øe it meete with a ≈øtoue or hot-hou≈øe, ≈øuch as are v≈øed in Germany, or ≈øuch other like place: For neyther hou≈øe nor cellar will pre≈øerue it, for want of heate.

div.head: Canna Indica flore rubro. Red flowred Indian Reede.
div.p: This beautifull plant ri≈øeth vp with faire greene, large, broade leaues, euery one ri≈øing out of the middle of the other, and are folded together, or writhed like vnto a paper Coffin (as they call it) ≈øuch as Comfitmakers and Grocers v≈øe, to put in their Comfits and Spices, and being ≈øpread open, another ri≈øeth from the bottome thereof, folded in the ≈øame manner, which are ≈øet at the ioynts of the ≈øtalke when it is ri≈øen vp, like vnto our water Reede, and growing (if it runne vp for flower) to be three or foure foote high, as I haue ob≈øerued in mine owne garden: the flowers grow at the toppe of the ≈øtalke one aboue another, which before their opening are long, ≈ømall, round, and pointed at the end, very like vnto the claw of a Craui≈øe or Sea-Crab, and of the ≈øame red or crim≈øon colour, but being open, are very like vnto the flower of Gladiolus or Corne-flagge, but of a more orient colour then at the fir≈øt, and ≈øtanding in a rough huske, wherein afterwards ≈øtandeth a three ≈øquare head, containing therein round blacke ≈øeede, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a pea≈øe: the roote is white and tuberous, growing into many knobs, from whence ari≈øe ≈øuch other leaues and ≈øtalkes, whereby it encrea≈øeth very much, if it be righrly kept and defended.

div.head: Canna Indica flore flauo punctato. Yellow ≈øpotted Indian Reede.
div.p: This Reede groweth vp with leaues and flowers, in all points ≈øo like vnto the former, that it cannot bee knowne from it, vntill it come to flower, which is of a yellow colour, ≈øpotted with reddi≈øh ≈øpots, without any other difference.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe plants grow naturally in the We≈øt Indies, from whence they were fir≈øt ≈øent into Spaine, and Portugall, where Clu≈øius ≈øaith he ≈øaw them planted by the hou≈øes ≈øides, flowring in winter, which might be in tho≈øe warme Countreyes. We pre≈øerue them with great care in our gardens, for the beautifull a≈øpect of their flowers.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower not with vs vntill the end, or middle of Augu≈øt, at the ≈øoone≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called of ≈øome Canna Indica, and Arundo Indica, of others Cannacorus, and of ≈øome Flos Cancri, becau≈øe the colour of the flowers, as well as the forme of the buds, are ≈øo like vnto a Sea-Crabs cle, or claw.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is not any v≈øe of the≈øe in Phy≈øicke that I know.

div.head: Mandragoras. Mandrake.
div.p: THe Mandrake is di≈øtingui≈øhed into two kindes, the male and the female; the male hath two ≈øorts, the one differing from the other, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed; but of the female I know but one: The male is frequent in many gardens, but the female, in that it is more tender and rare, is nour≈øed vp but in a few.

div.head: Manadrgoras mas. The male Mandrake.
div.p:
