The male Mandrake thru≈øteth vp many leaues together out of the ground, which being full growne, are faire, large and greene, lying round about the roote, and are larger and longer then the greate≈øt leaues of any Lettice, whereunto it is likened by Dio≈øcorides and others: from the middle, among the≈øe leaues, ri≈øe vp many flowers, euery one vpon a long ≈ølender ≈øtalke, ≈øtanding in a whiti≈øh greene huske, con≈øi≈øting of fiue pretty large round pointed leaues, of a greeni≈øh white colour, which turne into ≈ømall round apples, greene at the fir≈øt, and of a pale red colour when they are ripe, very ≈ømooth and ≈øhining on the out≈øide, and of a heady or ≈øtrong ≈øtuffing ≈ømell, wherein is contained round whiti≈øh flat ≈øeede: the roote is long and thicke, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and white within, con≈øi≈øting many times but of one long roote, and ≈øometimes diuided into two branches a little below the head, and ≈øometimes into three or more, as nature li≈øteth to be≈øtow vpon it, as my ≈øelfe haue often ≈øeene, by the tran≈øplanting of many, as al≈øo by breaking and cutting off of many parts of the rootes, but neuer found harme by ≈øo doing, as many idle tales haue beene ≈øet downe in writing, and deliuered al≈øo by report, of much danger to happen to ≈øuch, as ≈øhould digge them vp or breake them; neyther haue I euer ≈øeene any forme of man like or woman like parts, in the rootes of any: but as I ≈øaid, it hath oftentimes two maine rootes running down-right into the ground, and ≈øometimes three, and ≈øometimes but one, as it likewi≈øe often happeneth to Par≈øneps, Carrots, or the like. But many cunning counterfeit rootes haue bin ≈øhaped to ≈øuch formes, and publickly expo≈øed to the view of all that would ≈øee them, and haue been tolerated by the chiefe Magi≈øtrates of the Citie, notwith≈øtanding that they haue beene informed that ≈øuch practices were ‚Ä¢ eer ‚Ä¢ deceit, and vn≈øufferable; whether this happened through their ouer
‚Ä¢ re ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ litie of the thing, or of the per≈øons, or through an opinion that the information o ‚Ä¢ the truth ro≈øe vpon enuy, I know not, I leaue that to the ≈øearcher of all hearts. But this you may bee bold to re≈øt vpon, and a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelues, that ≈øuch formes as haue bin publickly expo≈øed to ‚Ä¢ e ≈øeene, were neuer ≈øo formed by nature, but only by the art and cunning of knaues and deceiuers‚ñ™ and let this be your Gale ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
again≈øt all ≈øuch vaine, idle and ridiculous toyes of mens inuentions.

There is likewi≈øe another ≈øort of the≈øe male Mandrakes, which I fir≈øt ≈øaw at Canterbury, with my very louing and kinde friende Iohn Trade≈øcante, in the garden of the Lord Wotton, who≈øe gardiner he was at that time; the leaues whereof were of a more grayi≈øh greene colour, and ≈øomewhat folded together, when as the former kind that grew hard by it, was of the ≈øame forme that is before de≈øcribed, and ordinary in all others: but whether the apples were differing from the other, I know not, nor did they remember that euer it had borne any.

div.head: Mandragoras faemina. The female Mandrake.
div.p: The female Mandrake doth likewi≈øe put vp many leaues together, from the head of the roote, but they are nothing ≈øo large, and are of a darker greene colour, narrower al≈øo and ≈øhining, more crumpled, and of a ≈øtronger ≈øent: the flowers are many, ri≈øing vp in the middle of the leaues, vpon ≈ølender ≈øtalkes, as in the male kind, but of a blewi≈øh purple colour, which turne into ≈ømall round fruite or apples, and not long like a peare (as Clu≈øius reporteth that ≈øaw them naturally growing in Spaine) greene at the fir≈øt, and of a pale yellowi≈øh colour, when they arc full ripe; of a more plea≈øing, or if you will, of a le≈ø≈øe heady ≈øent then the apples of the male, wherein is contained ≈øuch like ≈øeede, but ≈ømaller and blacker: the rootes are like the former, blacke without and white within, and diuided in the ≈øame manner as the male is, ≈øometimes with more, and ≈øometimes with fewer parts or branches.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They grow in many places of Italie, as Matthiolus reporteth, but e≈øpecially on Mount Garganus in Apulia. Clu≈øius ≈øaith hee found the female in many wet grounds of Spaine, as al≈øo in the borders of tho≈øe medowes that lye neere vnto riuers and water cour≈øes. The male is cheri≈øhed in many Gardens, for plea≈øure as well as for v≈øe: but the female as is ≈øaid, is both very rare, and farre more tender.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Male flowreth in March, and the fruit is ripe in Iuly. The Female, if it be well pre≈øerued, flowreth not vntill Augu≈øt, or September; ≈øo that without extraordinary care, we neuer ≈øee the fruite thereof in our gardens.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Mandragoras mas is called albus, as the Faemina is called niger, which titles of blacke and white, are referred vnto the colour of the leaues: the female is called al≈øo Thridacias, from the likene≈ø≈øe of Lettice, whereunto they ≈øay in forme it doth carry ≈øome ≈øimilitude. Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith, that in his time the male was called M ‚Ä¢ rion, and both of them Antimelum, and Circaea. Wee call them in Engli≈øh, The male, and the female Mandrake.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
The leaues haue a cooling and drying qualitie, fit for the oyntment Pop ‚Ä¢ leo ‚Ä¢ , wherein it is put. But the Apples haue a ≈øoporiferous propertie, as Leuinus Lemnius maketh mention in his Herball to the Bible, of an experiment of his owne. Be≈øides, as Dio≈øcorides fir≈øt, and then Serapio, Auicen, Paulus Aegineta, and others al≈øo do declare, they conduce much to the cooling and clean≈øing of an hot matrix. And it is probable, that Rachel knowing that they might be profitable for her hot and dry body, was the more earne≈øt with Lea ‚Ä¢ for her Sonne Rubens Apples, as it is ≈øet downe Gene≈øis 30. ver≈øe 14. The ≈øtrong ≈øent of the≈øe apples is remembred al≈øo, Cant. 7.13. although ≈øome would diuert the ≈øignification of the Hebrew word, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ,
vnto Violets, or ≈øome other ≈øweet flowers, in the former place of Gene≈øis, and the fruit of Mu≈øa, or Adams Apples in this place of the Canticles. Hamilcar the Carthaginian Captaine is ≈øaid to haue infected the wine of the Lybians (his enemies again≈øt whom he fought) with the apples of Mandrake, whereby they being made exceeding drow≈øie, he obtained a famous victory ouer them.

div.head: Pomum Amoris. Loue Apples.
div.p:
ALthough the beautie of this plant con≈øi≈øteth not in the flower, but fruit, yet giue m ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ eaue to in≈øert it here, le≈øt otherwi≈øe it haue no place: whereof there are two e≈øpeciall ≈øorts, which wee comprehend in one Chapter, and di≈øtingui≈øh them by maius and minus, greater and ≈ømaller: yet of the greater kinde, we haue nour≈øed vp in our Gardens two ≈øorts, that differ only in the colour of the fruite, and in nothing el≈øe.

div.head: Pomum Amoris maius fructu rubro. Great Apple of Loue the ordinary red ≈øort.
div.p: This greater kinde of Loue Apples, which hath beene mo≈øt frequently cheri≈øhed with vs, hath diuers long and trayling branches, leaning or ≈øpreading vpon the ground, not able to ≈øu≈øtaine them≈øelues, whereon doe grow many long winged leaues, that is, many leaues ≈øet on both ≈øides, and all along a middle ribbe, ≈øome being greater, and others le≈ø≈øe, iagged al≈øo and dented about the edges, of a grayi≈øh ouer worme greene colour, ≈øomewhat rough or hairy in handling, from among the leaues and the branches come forth long ≈øtalkes, with diuers flowers ≈øet thereon, vpon ≈øeuerall ≈øhort foot≈øtalks, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixe, and ≈øometimes of eight ≈ømall long yellow leaues, with a middle pricke or vmbone, which after the flowers are fallen, ri≈øeth to be the fruite, which are of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a ≈ømall or meane Pippin, vneuenly bunched out in diuers places, and ≈øcarce any full round without bunches, of a faire pale reddi≈øh colour, or ≈øomewhat deeper, like vnto an Orenge, full of a ≈ølimie iuice and watery pulpe, wherein the ≈øeede lyeth, which is white, flat and ≈øomewhat rough: the roote ≈øhooteth with many ≈ømall ≈øtrings and bigger branches vnderground, but peri≈øheth at the fir≈øt feeling of our winter weather. The fruite hereof by often ≈øowing it in our Land, is become much ≈ømaller then I haue here de≈øcribed it: but was at the fir≈øt, and ≈øo for two or three yeares after, as bigge as I haue related it.

div.head: Pomum Amoris maius fructu lute ‚Ä¢ . Yellow Amorous Apples.
div.p: Of the ≈øame kinde is this other ≈øort of Amorous Apples, differing in nothing but the colour of the fruite, which is of a pale yellow colour, hauing bunches or lobes in the ≈øame manner, and ≈øeede al≈øo like the former.

div.head: Pomum Amoris minus, ≈øiue Mala Ethiopica parua. Small Loue Apples.
div.p: The ≈ømall Apples of Loue in the very like manner, haue long weake trayling branches, be≈øet with ≈øuch like lea ‚Ä¢ es as the greater kinde hath, but ≈ømaller in euery part: the flowers al≈øo ≈øtand many together on a long ≈øtalke, and yellow as the former, but much ≈ømaller: the fruite are ≈ømall, round, yellowi≈øh red berries, not much bigger then great grapes, wherein are contained white flat ≈øeede, like the other, but ≈ømaller: the roote peri≈øheth in like manner euery yeare, and therefore mu≈øt bee new ≈øowen euery ≈øpring, if you will haue the plea≈øure of their ≈øight in the garden; yet ≈øome yeares I haue known them ri≈øe of their owne ≈øowing in my garden.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They growe naturally in the hot Countries of Barbary, and Ethiopia; yet ≈øome report them to be fir≈øt brought from Peru, a Prouince of the We≈øt Indies. Wee onely haue them for curio≈øity in our Gardens, and for the amorous a≈øpect or beauty of the fruit.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Iuly and Augu≈øt, and their fruit is ripe in the middle or end of September for the mo≈øt part.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is named diuer≈øly by diuers Authors; for Lobel, Camerarius, and others, call them Poma amoris. Dodonaeus Aurea Mala. Ge≈ønerus fir≈øt, and Bauhinus after him, make it to be a kinde of Solanum Pomiferum. Anguillara taketh it to be Lycoper≈øicum of Galen. Others thinke it to bee Glaucium of Dio≈øcorides. The la≈øt is called Mala Aethiopica parua, and by that title was fir≈øt ≈øent vnto vs, as if the former were of the ≈øame kinde and country. We call them in Engli≈øh, Apples of Loue, Loue-Apples, Golden Apples, or Amorous Apples, and all as much to one purpo≈øe as another, more then for their beautifull a≈øpect.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: In the hot Countries where they naturally growe, they are much eaten of the people, to coole and quench the heate and thir≈øt of their hot ≈øtomaches. The Apples al≈øo boyled, or infu≈øed in oyle in the ≈øunne, is thought to be good to cure the itch, a≈ø≈øuredly it will allay the heate thereof.

div.head: Digitalis. Foxegloue.
div.p: THere are three principall ≈øorts of Foxegloues; a greater, a middle or meane ≈øort, and a le≈ø≈øer, and of them, three e≈øpeciall colours, that is, purple, white, and yellow; the common purple kinde that groweth abroad in the fields, I leaue to his wilde habitation: and of the re≈øt as followeth.

div.head: 1. Digitalis maxima ferruginea. Dun coloured Foxegloues.
div.p: The leaues of this Foxegloue are long and large, of a grayi≈øh green colour, finely cut or dented about the edges, like the teeth of a fine ≈øawe; among which commeth vp a ≈øtrong tall ≈øtalke, which when it was full growne, and with ripe ≈øeede thereon, I haue mea≈øured to be ≈øeuen foot high at the lea≈øt, wheron grow an innumerable company (as I may ≈øo ≈øay, in re≈øpect of the aboundance) of flowers, nothing ≈øo large as the common purple kinde, that groweth wilde euery wherein our owne Countrey, and of a kinde of browne or yellowi≈øh dunne colour, with a long lippe at euery flower; after them come ≈øeede, like the common kinde, but in ≈ømaller heads: the rootes are ≈øtringie like the ordinary, but doe v≈øually peri≈øh, or ≈øeldome abide after it hath giuen ≈øeed.

div.head: 2. Digitalis maior flore caruco. Blu≈øh coloured Foxegloues.
div.p:
This kinde of Foxegloues hath rea≈øonable large leaues, yet not altogether ≈øo large
1 Ca ‚Ä¢ na Indica. The Indian Red. 2 Mandragoras mas. The male Mandrake. 3 Pomum amoris maius. Great Apples of loue. 4 Digitalis mai ‚Ä¢ r flore luteo amplo. The great yellow Foxegloue. 5. Digitalis media flore luteo rubente. Orenge tawny Foxegloues. 6 Digitalis maxima ferr ‚Ä¢ ginea. Dun coloured Foxegloues. depiction of flowers
as the common field kinde: the flowers are al≈øo ≈ømaller then the common ≈øort, but of a blu≈øh colour.

div.head: 3. Digitalis media flore luteo rubente. Orenge tawnie Foxegloue.
div.p: As this Foxegloue is none of the greate≈øt, ≈øo al≈øo is it none of the ≈ømalle≈øt; but a ≈øort betweene both, hauing leaues in ≈øome proportion corre≈øpondent to the le≈ø≈øer yellow Foxegloue, but not ≈øo large as the le≈ø≈øer white: the flowers are long and narrow, almo≈øt as large as the la≈øt white, but nothing ≈øo large as the fir≈øt white, of a faire yellowi≈øh browne colour, as if the yellow were ouer≈øhadowed with a reddi≈øh colour, and is that colour wee v≈øually call an Orenge tawnie colour: the ≈øeede is like the former: the rootes peri≈øh euery yeare that they beare ≈øeede, which is v≈øually the ≈øecond yeare of the ≈øpringing.

div.head: 4. Digitalis maior alba. The greater white Foxegloue.
div.p: This white Foxegloue is in all things ≈øo like vnto the purple wilde kinde, that it can hardly be di≈øtingui≈øhed from it, vnle≈ø≈øe it be in the fre≈øher greenne≈ø≈øe and largene≈ø≈øe of the leaues: the flowers are as great in a manner as the purple, but wholly white, without any ≈øpot in them: the ≈øeed and other things agree in all points.

div.head: 5. Digitalis alba altera ≈øeu minor. The le≈ø≈øer white Foxegloue.
div.p: We haue in our Gardens another ≈øort of white Foxegloue, who≈øe leaues are like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, but not altogether ≈øo long or large, and of a darker greene colour: the ≈øtalke groweth not ≈øo high, as not full three foote: the flowers are pure white, fa≈øhioned like vnto the former, but not ≈øo great or large, in all other things alike: the rootes hereof did abide ≈øometime in our Gardens, but ≈øince peri≈øhed, and the ≈øeede al≈øo, ≈øince when we neuer could obtaine from any our friends of that kinde againe.

div.head: 6. Digitalis maior lutea flore amplo. The great yellow Foxegloue.
div.p: The leaues of this greater yellow Foxegloue, are in forme ≈øomewhat like vnto the common purple kinde, but not altogether ≈øo large: the ≈øtalke groweth to bee three or foure foote high, whereon ≈øtand many long hollow pendulous flowers, in ≈øhape like the ordinary purple‚ñ™ but ≈øomewhat ≈øhorter, and more large and open at the brimmes, of a faire yellow colour, wherein are long threads, like as in the others: the roote hereof is greater at the head, and more wooddy then any of the re≈øt, with many ≈ømaller fibres, ≈øpreading them≈øelues in the ground, and abideth almo≈øt as well as our common purple kinde.

div.head: 7. Digitalis minor lutea ≈øiue pallida. The ≈ømall pale yellow Foxegloue.
div.p: This ≈ømall pale yellow Foxegloue hath ≈øomewhat ≈øhort, broad, ≈ømooth and darke greene leaues, ≈ønipt or dented about the edges very finely: the ≈øtalke is two foot high, be≈øet with ≈øuch like leaues, but le≈ø≈øer: the flowers are moe in number then in any of the re≈øt, except the fir≈øt and greate≈øt, and growe along the vpper part of the ≈øtalke, being long and hollow, like the other, but very ≈ømall, and of a pale yellow colour almo≈øt white: the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels are ≈ømall like the former, wherein are contained ≈øeede like the re≈øt, but ≈ømaller: the rootes are ≈øtringy, but durable, and ≈øeldome peri≈øh with any iniury of the extreame≈øt fro≈øts.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The great white kinde hath been often, and in many places found wilde in our owne Country, among or hard by the common purple kinde. All the re≈øt are ≈øtrangers, but cheri≈øhed in our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Iune and Iuly, and ≈øome in Augu≈øt, their ≈øeede becomming ripe quickly after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Onely the name Digitalis, is of all Writers giuen vnto the≈øe plants; for it is not knowne to bee remembred of any of the old Authors. Wee call them generally in Engli≈øh, Foxegloue; but ≈øome (as thinking it to bee too fooli≈øh a name) doe call them Finger-flowers, becau≈øe they are like vnto the fingers of a gloue, the ends cut off.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Foxegloues are not v≈øed in Phy≈øicke by any iudicious man that I know; yet ≈øome Italians of Bononia, as Camerarius ≈øaith, in his time v≈øed it as a wound herbe.

div.head: Verba≈øcum. Mullein.
div.p: THere be diuers kindes of Mullein, as white Mullein, blacke Mullein, wooddy Mullein, ba≈øe Mullein, Moth Mullein, and Ethiopian Mullein, all which to di≈øtingui≈øh or to de≈øcribe, is neither my purpo≈øe, nor the intent of this worke, which is to ≈øtore a Garden with flowers of delight, and ≈øeque≈øter others not worthy of that honour. Tho≈øe that are fit to bee brought to your con≈øideration in this place, are fir≈øt, the Blattarias, or Moth Mulleins, and then the wooddy Mullein, which otherwi≈øe is called French Sage, and la≈øtly, the Ethiopian Mullein, who≈øe beauty con≈øi≈øteth not in the flower, but in the whole plant; yet if it plea≈øe you not, take it according to his Country for a Moore, an Infidell, a Slaue, and ≈øo v≈øe it.

div.head: 1. Blattaria lutea odorata. Sweete yellow Moth Mullein.
div.p: The yellow Moth Mullein who≈øe flower is ≈øweete, hath many hard grayi≈øh greene leaues lying on the ground, ≈øomewhat long and broad, and pointed at the end: the ≈øtalks are two or three foot high, with ≈øome leaues on them, & branching out from the middle vpwards into many long branches, ≈øtored with many ≈ømall pale yellow flowers, of a pretty ≈øweete ≈øent, ≈øomewhat ≈øtronger then in the other ≈øorts, which ≈øeldome giueth ≈øeede, but abideth in the roote, liuing many yeares, which few or none of the others doe.

div.head: 2. Blattaria lutea maior ≈øiue Hi≈øpanica. The great yellow Moth Mullein.
div.p: This Spani≈øh kinde hath larger and greener leaues then the former, and rounder and larger then the next that followeth: the ≈øtalke is higher then in any of the Moth Mulleins, being for the mo≈øt part foure or fiue foote high, whereon toward the toppe growe many goodly yellow flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, as all the re≈øt doe, not ≈øo thicke ≈øet as the former, but much larger, with ≈øome ≈ømall purpli≈øh threads in the middle: the ends whereof are fa≈øhioned ≈øomewhat like as if a Flie were creeping vp the flower, which turne into round heads, ≈øometimes two or three or more ≈øtanding together, but v≈øually one, wherein lye ≈ømall duskie ≈øeed: the roote is not great nor full of threads, and doth peri≈øh mo≈øt v≈øually hauing giuen ≈øeede, except the Winter bee very milde.

div.head: 3. Blattaria lutea altera vulgatior. The ordinary yellow Moth Mullein.
div.p: This yellow Moth Mullein (which is the mo≈øt frequent in our Gardens) hath longer, and narrower leaues then any of the former, and roundly notched or dented on the edges, of a darke greene colour: the ≈øtalke is ≈øometimes branched, but mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øingle, whereon ≈øtand many gold yellow flowers, not fully ≈øo large as the Spani≈øh kinde, but with the like purple threads in the middle: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, and contained in the like round heads, but alwaies euery one ≈øingle by it ≈øelfe: the roote peri≈øheth euery yeare that it beareth ≈øeede.

div.head: 4. Blattaria flore luteo purpura≈øcente. Cloth of gold Moth Mullein.
div.p: The greate≈øt point of difference betweene this and the la≈øt de≈øcribed, con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in the colour of the flower, which in this is of the colour of cloth of gold, that is, the ground yellow, and ouer≈øhadowed with a bright crim≈øon colour, which is a fine colour of much delight: the threads in the middle are not ≈øo purple red as in the former, but much about the colour of the flower: this is not ≈øo willing to giue ≈øeede, and will as hardly abide in the roote, and hath out of que≈øtion ri≈øen from the ≈øeede of the former.

div.head: 5. Blattaria flore albo. White Moth Mullein.
div.p: The leaues of the white Moth Mullein are ≈øomewhat like vnto the yellow, yet not altogether ≈øo much roundly notched about the edges, but rather a little dented, with ≈øharper notches: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth as high as the yellow, and hath now and then ≈øome branches about it: the flowers hereof are pure white, as large and great as the ordinary yellow, or ≈øomewhat larger, with the like purple threads in the middle, as are in the yellow: the ≈øeed is like the other; the root peri≈øheth in like maner, and will not endure.

div.head: 6. Blattaria flore purpureo. Purple Moth Mullein.
div.p: The Purple Moth Mullein hath his leaues lying on the ground, broader and ≈øhorter then any of the other, of a more grayi≈øh greene colour, and without any denting for the mo≈øt part about the edges, ≈øharpe pointed al≈øo at the end of the leafe; among the leaues ri≈øeth vp the ≈øtalke, not ≈øo high as either the white or the yellow, and many times branched, bearing many flowers thereon, of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, and no whit ≈ømaller, of a faire deepe blewi≈øh colour tending to redne≈ø≈øe, the threads in the middle of the flowers being yellow: the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels hereof are ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller then any of the former, except the fir≈øt ≈øweete yellow kinde: the roote hereof is long, thicke, and blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, abiding very well from yeare to yeare, and ri≈øeth well al≈øo from the ≈øowing of the ≈øeede.

div.head: 7. Blattaria flore caeruleo. Blew Moth Mullein.
div.p: This blew Moth Mullein is in all re≈øpects like vnto the former purple kinde, ≈øauing onely in the colour of the flower, which is of a blewi≈øh violet colour, and is not much inferiour either in greatne≈ø≈øe of the plant, or in the largene≈ø≈øe of the flower, vnto the former purple kinde, and endureth many yeares in the like manner. And the≈øe be all the ≈øorts of this kinde of Moth Mullein, that I haue ≈øeene and nour≈øed vp for this my Garden, without interpo≈øing any vnknowne, not ≈øeene, or vnworthy.

div.head: 8. Verba≈øcum ≈øilue≈øtre ≈øiue quartum Matthioli. Wooddy Mullein or French Sage.
div.p:
Wooddy Mullein or French Sage, hath diuers wooddy branches two or three foot high, very hoary or white, whereon at ≈øeuerall ioynts ≈øtand diuers thicke leaues, white al≈øo and hoary, long, ≈øomewhat broad, round pointed, and rough, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the leaues of Sage in the forme and roughne≈ø≈øe, but not in the ≈øent, whereof our
people gaue it the name of Sage, calling it French Sage (when as it is as great a ≈øtranger in France as in England, yet they doe with this as with many other things, calling them French, which come from beyond the Seas; as for example, all or mo≈øt of our bulbous flowers, they call French flowers, &c.) at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes and branches, at certaine di≈øtances, are placed round about them many gaping flowers, like vnto the flowers of Sage, but yellow: after which now and then come ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat bigger then the Moth Mulleins, and le≈ø≈øe then the next Mullein of Ethiopia: the roote is wooddy at the toppe, with diuers blacki≈øh ≈øtrings growing from it, and endureth as well aboue ground with his leaues, as vnder it with his rootes.

div.head: 9. Aethiopis. Ethiopian Mullein.
div.p: This Mullein of Ethiopia hath many great, broad, and large leaues lying on the ground, rent or torne in diuers of them very much on the ≈øides, of ≈øo hoary a white greene colour, that it farre pa≈ø≈øeth any of the white Mulleins, that growe wilde abroad in our owne Country; for they are of a yellowi≈øh white hoarine≈ø≈øe, nothing ≈øo plea≈øant to looke on as this: in the middle of the≈øe leaues ri≈øeth vp a ≈øquare ≈øtrong ≈øtalke, foure or fiue foote high, ≈øet full of ≈øuch like leaues as growe belowe, but much le≈ø≈øer, and le≈ø≈øer ≈øtill vp to the toppe, all hoary and woolly, as the re≈øt, and diuided into manie branches, ≈øpreading farre, and taking vp a great compa≈ø≈øe of ground, more then any one roote of Garden Clary, or other ≈øuch like plant: at each of the ≈øtalkes and branches are ≈øet two ≈ømall leaues, and with them, round about the ≈øtalkes, ≈øtand many ≈ømall gaping flowers, of a pale bleake blew colour: the ≈øeede is almo≈øt as large as Garden Clary ≈øeede, and of the ≈øame forme and colour: the roote is wooddy, and peri≈øheth as ≈øoone as it hath borne ≈øeede, which is v≈øually the ≈øecond yeare after the ≈øowing; for the fir≈øt yeare it ≈øeldome runneth vp to flower.

div.head: 10. Lamium Pannonicum ≈øiue Galeop≈øis Pannonica. Hungary dead Nettle or the Dragon flower.
div.p: Let mee thru≈øt this plant into this place, rather then make a peculiar Chapter, becau≈øe I haue no other of the ≈øame ≈øtocke or kindred to be ioyned with it, and is a pretty ornament in a Garden. The leaues whereof are very large, round, and great, rough or full of veines, which make it ≈øeeme crumpled, dented or deepely notched about the edges, and of a very darke greene colour, and ≈øometimes browni≈øh, or of a darke reddi≈øh colour withall, euery one ≈øtanding on a long foote-≈øtalke, very like in forme vnto the great white Arch-Angell leaues, but farre larger and blacker: the ≈øtalkes are great and foure ≈øquare, hauing leaues and flowers ≈øtanding round about them at the ioynts like coronets, which flowers are very great, long, and wide gaping open, of a darke red or purple colour, with ≈øome whitene≈ø≈øe or ≈øpots in the iawes, and ≈øome hairine≈ø≈øe al≈øo on the ≈øides, which ≈øtand in full flower two or three moneths mo≈øt v≈øually, and ≈øometimes longer, after which come browni≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is a great tuft or bu≈øh of long whiti≈øh ≈øtrings, and encrea≈øeth euery yeare, not fearing the greate≈øt iniuries of our colde≈øt and extreame≈øt Winters.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe plants are ≈øtrangers in our Countrey, and onely pre≈øerued in Gardens, to furni≈øh them with variety; but (as I ≈øaid) the cloth of gold Moth Mullein hath been rai≈øed from ≈øeed in our owne Country.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The la≈øt flowreth fir≈øt, before all the re≈øt, beginning in Aprill. The Moth Mulleins in May and Iune. The French Sage in Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
All the ≈øorts of Blattaria may bee comprehended vnder the kindes of
Verba≈øcum nigrum, as any one but meanely exerci≈øed in the knowledge of plants, may di≈øcerne. And although Plinie ≈øaith, that Moths doe mo≈øt frequently haunt where Blattaria either groweth, or is laid, yet it is not ob≈øerued ≈øufficiently in our Country ≈øo to doe, notwith≈øtanding the name of Moth Mullein is generally giuen them. The la≈øt is generally called with vs Lamium Pannonicum, but certainely it is the Galeo≈øis maxima Pannonica of Clu≈øius.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Other qualities I haue not found hath been allotted vnto the Blattaria or Moth Mullein, then tho≈øe of Plinie, to engender Moths. Wee v≈øe none of the≈øe plants in Phy≈øicke in the≈øe daies.

div.head: Valeriana. Valerian.
div.p: THe many ≈øorts of Valerian (or Set-wall as many doe call them) are fitter for a generall worke, or a generall Phy≈øicall Garden of Simples, then this of delightfull flowers. I will therefore ≈øelect out a few, worthy of the place, and offer them to your con≈øiderations.

div.head: 1. Valeriana rubra Dodonaei. Red Valerian.
div.p: This Valerian hath diuers hard, but brittle whiti≈øh greene ≈øtalkes, ri≈øing from the roote, full of tuberous or ≈øwelling ioynts, whereat ≈øtand two leaues, on each ≈øide one, and now and then ≈øome ≈ømall leaues from betweene them, which are ≈øomewhat long and narrow, broade≈øt in the middle, and ≈ømall at both ends, without either diui≈øion or inci≈øure on the edges, of a pale greene colour: the ≈øtalkes are branched at the top into diuers parts, at the ends whereof ≈øtand many flowers together, as it were in an vmbell or tuft, ≈øomewhat like vnto the flowers of our ordinary Valerian, but with longer neckes, and of a fine red colour, very plea≈øant to behold, but of no ≈øent of any Valerian: after the≈øe flowers haue ≈øtood blowne a very great while, they ≈øodainely fall away, and the ≈øeede is ripe very quickly after, which is whiti≈øh, ≈øtanding vpon the branches naked, as the Valerians doe, and very like vnto them, with a little white doune at the end of euery one of them, whereby they are ≈øoone carried away with the winde: the roote is great, thicke, and white, continuing long, and ≈øhooting out new branches euery yeare, and ≈ømelling ≈øomewhat like a Valerian.

div.head: 2. Nardus Montana tubero≈øa. Knobbed Mountaine Valerian.
div.p: This kinde of Valerian or Spiknard, if you will ≈øo call it, hath his fir≈øt leaues lying on the ground, without any diui≈øion in them at all, being ≈ømooth, and of a dark greene colour, which ≈øo abide all the winter; but tho≈øe that ≈øpring vp after, and when it runneth vp to flower, are cut in on the edges, very like vnto the iagged leaues of the great garden Valerian, and ≈øo the elder they grow, the more cut and iagged they are: the ≈øtalke and flowers are very like the ≈øtalke with flowers of the garden Valerian, but of a darke or deepe red colour, and more ≈øtore of them thru≈øt together, by double the number almo≈øt: the ≈øeede is like the ≈øeede of the great Valerian: the root is tuberous, or knobbed in many parts, round about, aboue and below al≈øo, with ≈øome fibres ≈øhooting from them, whereby it is encrea≈øed, and ≈ømelleth very like the roote of the garden Setwall, or not altogether ≈øo ≈øtrong.

figure.head:
1 Blattaria flore albo. Moth Mullein with a white flower. 2 Blattaria flore purpureo‚ñ™ Moth Mullein with a purple flower. 3 Verba≈øcum
‚Ä¢ uertum Matthioli. French Sage. 4 Aethiopis. Ethiopian Mullein. 5 Valeriana rubra Dodonaei. Red Valerian. 6 Valeriana Graeca. Greek Valerian. 7 Lamium Pannoni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m. Hungary dead Nettle. 8 Cardamine flore pleno. Double Cuckowe flower or Ladies ≈ømocks.

div.head: 3. Valeriana Graeca. Greeke Valerian.
div.p: The Greek Valerian hath many winged leaues lying vpon the ground, that is, many ≈ømall leaues ≈øet on both ≈øides of a middle ribbe, very like vnto the wilde Valerian, that groweth by the ditch ≈øides, but much ≈ømaller and tenderer, among which ri≈øe vp one or two round brittle ≈øtalkes, two foote high or thereabouts, whereon are ≈øet at the ioynts, ≈øuch like leaues as grow below, but ≈ømaller: the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are diuided into many ≈ømall branches, thicke ≈øet together, full with flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall round leaues a peece, layd open like vnto the Cinquefoile flower, with ≈øome white threds in the middle, tipt with yellow pendents: the colour of the≈øe flowers in ≈øome plants, is of a faire bleake blew colour, and in others pure white: And I doe heare of one beyond the Seas (if the report bee true, for I haue not ≈øeene ≈øuch a one) which ≈øhould beare red flowers: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp in their places ≈ømall hard huskes or heads, containing ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeedes: the roote is compo≈øed of a number of ≈ømall long blacki≈øh threds, fa≈øtened together at the head, without any ≈øent at all of a Valerian, eyther in roote or leafe; and why it ≈øhould bee called a Valerian I ≈øee no great rea≈øon, for it agreeth with none of them, in flower or ≈øeede, and but onely with the wilde Valerian in leafe, as I ≈øaid before: but as it is, we ≈øo giue it you, and for the flowers ≈øake is receiued into our gardens, to helpe to fill vp the number of natures rarities and varieties.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: All the≈øe Valerians are ≈øtrangers, but endenizond for their beauties ≈øake in our Gardens. The Mountaine Valerian I had of the liberalitie of my louing friend Iohn Trade≈øcante, who in his trauaile, and ≈øearch of natures varieties, met with it, and imparted thereof vnto me.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in the Summer moneths, and ≈øeed quickly after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is generally called of mo≈øt, Valeriana rubra Dodonaei, who ≈øaith al≈øo that ≈øome would haue it to be Behen rubrum. Some call it Valerianthon, others make it a kinde of Ocimastrum, and ≈øome Saponaria altera, with other names, which are to no great purpo≈øe to ≈øet downe in this place, it beeing fitter for a generall worke to di≈øcu≈ø≈øe of names, wherein both reading, knowledge and iudgement mu≈øt bee ≈øhewen, to correct errours, and ≈øet downe the truth, that one may re≈øt thereon. The others haue their names in their titles ≈øufficient to di≈øtingui≈øh them.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Mountaine Valerian is of all the the re≈øt here ≈øet downe of mo≈øt v≈øe in Phy≈øicke, the re≈øt hauing little or none that I know, although it be much weaker then the great garden kinde, or the Indian Nardus, in who≈øe ≈øteed anciently it was v≈øed, in oyles, oyntments, &c.

div.head: Cardamine. Cuckow flowers, or Ladies ≈ømockes.
div.p: OF the common ≈øorts of Cuckow flowers that grow by ditch-≈øides, or in moi≈øt medowes, & wet grounds, it is not my purpo≈øe here to write, but of one or two other, the mo≈øt ≈øpecious or faire of all the tribe, that doe be≈øt befit this garden.

div.head: 1. Cardamine flore pleno. Double Cuckow flowers.
div.p: The double Cardamine hath a few winged leaues, weake and tender, lying on the ground, very like vnto the ≈øingle medow kinde; from among which ri≈øeth vp a round greene ≈øtalke, ≈øet here and there, with the like leaues that grow below, the top wherof hath a few branches, whereon ≈øtand diuers flowers, euery one vpon a ≈ømall foote≈øtalk, con≈øi≈øting of many ≈ømall whiti≈øh round leaues, a little da≈øht ouer with a ≈øhew of blu≈øh, ≈øet round together, which make a double flower: the roote creepeth vnder ground, ≈øending forth ≈ømall white fibres, and ≈øhooteth vp in diuers places.

div.head: 2. Cardamine trifolia. Trefoile Ladies ≈ømockes.
div.p: This ≈ømall plant hath diuers hard, darke round greene leaues, ≈øomewhat vneuen about the edges, alwayes three ≈øet together on a blacki≈øh ≈ømall foot≈øtalke, among which ri≈øe vp ≈ømall round blacki≈øh ≈øtalkes, halfe a foote high, with three ≈ømall leaues at the ioynts, where they branch forth; at the toppes whereof ≈øtand many flowers, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues a peece, of a whiti≈øh or blu≈øh colour very pale: after which come vp ≈ømall, thicke and long pods, wherein is contained ≈ømall round ≈øeede: the root is compo≈øed of many white threds, from the heads whereof runne out ≈ømall ≈øtrings, of a dark purple colour, whereby it encrea≈øeth.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt with the double flower is found in diuers places of our owne Countrey, as neere Micham about eight miles from London; al≈øo in Lanca≈øhire, from whence I receiued a plant, which peri≈øhed, but was found by the indu≈øtrie of a worthy Gentlewoman, dwelling in tho≈øe parts heretofore remembred, called Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe Thoma≈øin Tun≈øtall, a great louer of the≈øe delights. The other was ≈øent me by my e≈øpecial good friend Iohn Trade≈øcante, who brought it among other dainty plants from beyond the Seas, and imparted thereof a roote to me.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The la≈øt mo≈øt v≈øually flowreth before the former, yet not much differing, that is, in the end of Aprill or in May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is a double kinde of that plant, that growing wilde abroade, is v≈øually called Cardamine altera, and Si≈øymbrium alterum of Dio≈øcorides, and of ≈øome Flos cuculi, but not fitly; for that name is more v≈øually giuen vnto the wilde featherd Campions, both ≈øingle and double, as is before expre≈ø≈øed: yet for want of a fitter name, wee may call it in Engli≈øh, eyther Cuckowe flower, or Ladyes ≈ømockes, which you will. The ≈øecond hath beene ≈øent vnder the name of Sanicula trifolia, but the mo≈øt frequent name now receiued, is Cardamine trifolia, and in Engli≈øh Trefoile Ladies ≈øpockes.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The double Ladies ≈ømockes are of the ≈øame qualitie with the ≈øingle, and is thought to be as effectuall as Watercre≈ø≈øes. The propertie of the other I thinke is not much knowne, although ≈øome would make it a wound herbe.

div.head: Thla≈øpi Creticum. Candy Tufts.
div.p: OF the many ≈øorts of Thla≈øpi it is not the ≈øcope of this worke to relate, I will ≈øelect but onely two or three, which for their beautie are fit to bee in≈øerted into this garden.

div.head: Thla≈øpi Creticum vmbellatum flore albo & purpureo. Candy Tufts white and purple.
div.p: This ≈ømall plant ri≈øeth ≈øeldome aboue a foote and a halfe high, hauing ≈ømall, narrow, long and whiti≈øh greene leaues, notched or dented with three or foure notches on each ≈øide, from the middle to the point-wards; from among which ri≈øe vp the ≈øtalkes, branched from the bottome almo≈øt into diuers ≈ømall branches, at the toppes whereof ≈øtand many ≈ømall flowers, thick thru≈øt together in an vmbell or tuft, making them ≈øeeme to be ≈ømall, round, double flowers of many leaues, when as euery flower is ≈øingle, and ≈øtandeth a part by it ≈øelfe, of a faire white colour in ≈øome plants, without any ≈øpot, and in others with a purpli≈øh ≈øpot in the centre or middle, as if ≈øome of the middle leaues were purple, in others againe the whole flower is purpli≈øh all ouer, which make a pretty ≈øhew in a garden: the ≈øeede is contained in many ≈ømall and flat ≈øeed ve≈ø≈øels, which ≈øtand together in an vmbell, as the flowers did, in which are contained ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh ≈øeede, like vnto ≈øome other ≈øorts of Thla≈øpi, called Treakle Mu≈øtards: the roote is ≈ømall and hard, and peri≈øheth euery yeare hauing giuen ≈øeede.

Thla≈øpi Marinum Baticum.We haue another ≈øort, who≈øe leaues before it ≈øendeth forth any ≈øtalke, are a little toothed, or finely dented about the edges, and brancheth not ≈øo much out, but carryeth an vmbell of purpli≈øh flowers like vnto the former, and paler yellow ≈øeede.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe doe grow in Spaine and Candie, not farre from the Sea ≈øide.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The≈øe Thla≈øpi giue not their flowers vntill the end of Iune, or beginning of Iuly, and the ≈øeed is ripe ≈øoone after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is named by ≈øome, Draba, or Arabis, as Dodonaeus, but Draba is another plant differing much from this. Wee call one ≈øort, Thla≈øpi Creticum, and the other Thla≈øpi Baticum marinum, becau≈øe the one came from Spaine, and the other from Candy; we giue it in Engli≈øh, the name of Tufts, becau≈øe it doth fit the forme of the flowers be≈øt, although ordinarily all the Thla≈øpi are Engli≈øhed Wilde Mu≈øtardes.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Candy, or Spani≈øh Tufts, is not ≈øo ≈øharpe biting in ta≈øte, as ≈øome other of the Thla≈øpies are, and therefore is not to be v≈øed in medicines, where Thla≈øpi ≈øhould be in the ≈øtead thereof.

div.head: Clematis. Clamberers, or Creepers.
div.p: HAuing ≈øhewed you all my ≈øtore of herbes bearing fine flowers, let mee now bring to your con≈øideration the re≈øt of tho≈øe plants, be they Shrubs or Trees, that are cheri≈øhed in our garden, for the beauty of their flowers chiefly, or for ≈øome other beautifull re≈øpect: and fir≈øt I will begin with ≈øuch as creepe on the ground, without climing, and then ≈øuch as clime vp by poles, or other things, that are ≈øet or grow neere them, fit to make Bowers, and Arbours, or el≈øe are like them in forme, in name, or ≈øome other ≈øuch qualitie or propertie.

div.head: 1. Clematis Daphnoides, ≈øiue Vinca peruinca ≈øimplex minor diuer≈øorum colorum. Single Perwinkle of diuers colours.
div.p: The ≈ømaller Perwinkle which not onely groweth wilde in many places, but is mo≈øt v≈øuall in our Gardens, hath diuers creeping branches, trayling or running vpon the ground, ≈øhooting out ≈ømall fibres at the ioynts, as it creepeth, taking thereby hold in the ground, and rooteth in diuers places: at the ioynts of the≈øe branches ≈øtand two ≈ømall darke greene ≈øhining leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto ≈ømall Baye leaues, but ≈ømaller, and at the ioynts likewi≈øe with the leaues, come forth the flowers, one at a ioynt, ≈øtanding vpon a tender foote≈øtalke, being ≈øomewhat long and hollow, parted at the brims, ≈øometimes into foure leaues, and ≈øometimes into fiue, the mo≈øt ordinary ≈øort is of a pale or bleake blew colour, but ≈øome are pure white, and ≈øome of a darke reddi≈øh purple colour: the root is in the body of it, little bigger then a ru≈øh, bu≈øhing in the ground, and creeping with his branches farre about, taking roote in many places, whereby it quickely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth a great compa≈ø≈øe; and is therefore mo≈øt v≈øually, planted vnder hedges, or where it may haue roome to runne.

div.head: 2. Vinca peruinca flore duplici purpureo. Double purple Perwinkle.
div.p: The double Perwinkle is like vnto the former ≈øingle kinde, in all things except in the flower, which is of that darke reddi≈øh purple colour that is in one of the ≈øingle kindes; but this hath another row of leaues within the flower, ≈øo that the two rowes of leaues cau≈øeth it to be called double, but the leaues of the≈øe are le≈ø≈øer then the ≈øingle. I haue heard of one with a double white flower, but I haue not yet ≈øeene it.

div.head: 3. Clematis Daphnoides ≈øiue Peruinca maior. The greater Perwinkle.
div.p: This greater Perwinkle is ≈øomewhat like the former, but greater, yet his branches creepe not in that manner, but ≈øtand more vpright, or le≈ø≈øe creeping at the lea≈øt: the leaues al≈øo hereof ≈øtand by couples at the ioynts, but they are broader and larger by the halfe: the flowers are larger, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues that are blew, a little deeper then the former blew: this plant is farre tenderer to keepe then the other, and therefore would ≈øtand warme, as well as in a moi≈øt ≈øhadowie place.

div.head: 4. Clematis altera ≈øiue vrens flore albo. Burning Clamberer, or Virgins Bower.
div.p:
This Cau≈øticke or burning Climer, hath very long and climing tender branches, yet ≈øomewhat woody below, which winde about tho≈øe things that ≈øtand neere it, couered with a browni≈øh greene barke, from the ioynts whereof ≈øhoote forth many winged leaues, con≈øi≈øting for the mo≈øt part of fiue ≈øingle leaues, that is, two and two together, and one at the end, which are a little cut in or notched on the edges here and
there, but euery part of them is le≈ø≈øer then the leaues of the next following Climer, without any cla≈øping tendrels to winde about any thing at all: towards the vpper part of the branches, with the ≈øaid leaues, come forth long ≈øtalks, wheron ≈øtand many white flowers clu≈øtering together, opening the brims into ≈øixe or eight ≈ømall leaues, ≈øpreading like a ≈øtarre, very ≈øweet of ≈ømell, or rather of a ≈øtrong heady ≈øent, which after turne into flatti≈øh and blacki≈øh ≈øeede, plumed at the head, which plume or feather flyeth away with the winde after it hath ≈øtood long, and leaueth the ≈øeede naked or bare: the roote is white and thicke, fle≈øhie and tender, or ea≈øie to be broken, as my ≈øelfe can well te≈øtifie, in that de≈øiring to take a ≈øucker from the roote, I could not handle it ≈øo tenderly, but that it broke notwith≈øtanding all my care. Ma≈øter Gerard in his Herball maketh mention of one of this kinde with double white flowers, which hee ≈øaith he recouered from the ≈øeede was ≈øent him from Argentine, that is Strasborough, whereof hee ≈øetteth forth the figure with double flowers: but I neuer ≈øaw any ≈øuch with him, neither did I euer heare of any of this kinde with double flowers. Clu≈øius indeed ≈øaith, that hee receiued from a friend ≈øome ≈øeede vnder the name of Clematis flore albo pleno: but he doubteth whether there bee any ≈øuch: the plants that ≈øprang with him from that ≈øeede, were like vnto the vpright kinde called Flammila Matthioli, or Iouis cresta, as he there ≈øaith: but a≈ø≈øuredly I haue beene informed from ≈øome of my e≈øpeciall friends beyond Sea, that they haue a double white Clematis, and haue promi≈øed to ≈øend it; but whether it will be of the climing or vpright ≈øort, I cannot tell vntill I ≈øee it: but ≈øurely I doe much doubt whether the double will giue any good ≈øeede.

div.head: 5. Clematis altera ≈øiue peregrina flore rubro. Red Ladies Bower.
div.p: This Climer hath many limber and weake climing branches like the former, couered with a browne thin outer barke, and greene vnderneath: the leaues ≈øtand at the ioynts, con≈øi≈øting but of three leaues or parts, whereof ≈øome are notched on one ≈øide, and ≈øome on both, without any cla≈øping tendrels al≈øo, but winding with his branches about any thing ≈øtandeth next vnto it: the flowers in like manner come from the ≈øame ioynts with the leaues, but not ≈øo many together as the former vpon long foot≈øtalkes, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues a peece, ≈øtanding like a cro≈ø≈øe, of a darke red colour; the ≈øeed is flat and round, and pointed at the end, three or foure or more ≈øtanding clo≈øe together vpon one ≈øtalk, without any doune vpon them at all, as in the former: the roots are a bundell of browni≈øh yellow ≈øtrong ≈øtrings, running down deep into the ground, from a bigge head aboue.

div.head: 6. Clematis peregrina flore purpureo ≈øimplici. Single purple Ladies Bower.
div.p: This Ladies Bower differeth in nothing from the la≈øt de≈øcribed, but onely in the colour of the flower, which is of a ≈øad blewi≈øh purple colour; ≈øo that the one is not po≈ø≈øible to be known from the other, vntill they be in flower.

div.head: 7. Clematis peregrina flore purpureo pleno. Double flowred purple Ladies Bower.
div.p: This double Clematis hath branches and leaues ≈øo neere re≈øembling the ≈øingle kinds, that there can be knowne no difference, vnle≈ø≈øe it be, that this groweth more goale and great, and yeeldeth both more ≈øtore of branches from the ground, and more ≈øpreading aboue: the chiefe≈øt marke to di≈øtingui≈øh it is the flower, which in this is very thicke and double, con≈øi≈øting of a number of ≈ømaller leaues, ≈øet clo≈øe together in order in the middle, the foure outermo≈øt leaues that encompa≈ø≈øe them, being much broader and larger then any of the inward, but all of a dull or ≈øad blewi≈øh purple colour, the points or ends of the leaues ≈øeeming a little darker then the middle of them: this beareth no ≈øeede that euer I could ≈øee, heare of, or learne by any of credit, that haue nour≈øed it a great while; and therefore the tales of fal≈øe deceitfull gardiners, and others, that diliuer ≈øuch for truth, to deceiue per≈øons ignorant thereof, mu≈øt not bee credulou≈øly entertained.

In the great booke of the Garden of the Bi≈øhop of Ey≈øtot (which place is neere vnto Noremberg) in Germany, I reade of a Clematis of this former kinde,Clematis peregrina flore carnec caeru ‚Ä¢ eo. who≈øe figure is thereto al≈øo annexed, with double flowers of an incarnate, or pale purple tending to a blu≈øh colour, whereof I haue not heard from any other place.

div.head: 8. Flammula Iouis erecta. Vpright Virgins Bower.
div.p: This kinde of Clematis hath diuers more vpright ≈øtalkes then any of the foure la≈øt de≈øcribed, ≈øometimes foure or fiue foote high, or more; yet leaning or bending a little, ≈øo that it had ≈øome neede of ≈øu≈øtaining, couered with a browni≈øh barke; from whence come forth on all ≈øides diuers winged leaues, con≈øi≈øting of fiue or ≈øeuen leaues, ≈øet on both ≈øides of a middle ribbe, whereof one is at the end: the tops of the ≈øtalkes are diuided into many branches, bearing many white ≈øweet ≈ømelling flowers on them, like in fa≈øhion vnto the white Virgins Bower; after which come ≈øuch like feather topt ≈øeede, which remaine and ≈øhew them≈øelues, being flat like the other, when the plumes are blowne abroad: the roote ≈øpreadeth in the ground from a thicke head, into many long ≈øtrings, and fa≈øteneth it ≈øelfe ≈øtrongly in the earth; but all the ≈øtalkes dye downe euery yeare, and ≈øpring afre≈øh in the beginning of the next.

div.head: 9. Clematis caerulea Pannonica. The Hungarian Climer.
div.p: The ≈øtalks of this plant ≈øtand vpright, & are foure ≈øquare, bearing at euery ioynt two leaues, which at the fir≈øt are clo≈øed together, and after they are open, are ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of A≈øclepias, or Swallow-wort: from the tops of the ≈øtalks, and ≈øometimes al≈øo from the ≈øides by the leaues commeth forth one flower, bending the head downward, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues, ≈øomewhat long & narrow, ≈øtanding like a cro≈ø≈øe, and turning vp their ends a little againe, of a faire blew or skie colour, with a thicke pale yellow ≈øhort thrumme, made like a head in the middle: after the flower is pa≈øt, the head turneth into ≈øuch a like round feather topt ball, as is to be ≈øeene in the Trauellers ioy, or Viorna (as it is called) that groweth plentifully in Kent, and in other places by the way ≈øides, and in the hedges, wherein is included ≈øuch like flat ≈øeede. The≈øe ≈øtalkes (like as the la≈øt) dye downe to the ground euery yeare, and ri≈øe againe in the Spring following, ≈øhooting out new branches, and therby encrea≈øeth in the root.

div.head: 10. Maracoc ≈øiue Clematis Virginiana. The Virginia Climer.
div.p:
Becau≈øe this braue and too much de≈øired plant doth in ≈øome things re≈øemble the former Climers, ≈øo that vnto what other family or kindred I might better conioyne it I know not; let me I pray in≈øert it in the end of their Chapter, with this de≈øcription. It ri≈øeth out of the ground (very late in the yeare, about the beginning of May, if it be a plant hath ri≈øen from the ≈øeed of our owne ≈øowing, and if it be an old one, ≈øuch as hath been brought to vs from Virginia, not till the end thereof) with a round ≈øtalke, not aboue a yard and a halfe high (in any that I haue ≈øeene) but in hotter Countries, as ≈øome Authors haue ≈øet it downe, much higher, bearing one leafe at euery ioynt, which from the ground to the middle thereof hath no cla≈øpers, but from thence vpwards hath at the ≈øame ioynt with the leafe both a ≈ømall twining cla≈øper, like vnto a Vine, and a flower al≈øo: euery leafe is broad at the ≈øtalke thereof, and diuided about the middle on both ≈øides, making it ≈øomewhat re≈øemble a Figge leafe, ending in three points, whereof the middlemo≈øt is longe≈øt: the bud of the flower, before it doe open, is very like vnto the head or ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell of the ordinary ≈øingle Nigella, hauing at the head or top fiue ≈ømall crooked hornes, which when this bud openeth, are the ends or points of fiue leaues, that are white on the in≈øide, and lay them≈øelues flat, like vnto an Anemone, and are a little hollow like a ≈øcoope at the end, with fiue other ≈ømaller leaues, and whiter then they lying betweene them, which were hid in the bud before it opened, ≈øo that this flower being full blowne open, con≈øi≈øteth of ten white leaues, laide in order round one by another: from the bottome of the≈øe leaues on the in≈øide, ri≈øe diuers twined threads, which ≈øpread and lay them≈øelues all ouer the≈øe white leaues, reaching beyond the points of them a little, and are of a reddi≈øh peach colour: towards the bottomes
likewi≈øe of the≈øe white leaues there are two red circles, about the breadth of an Oten ≈øtrawe, one di≈øtant from another (and in ≈øome flowers there is but one circle ≈øeen) which adde a great grace vnto the flower; for the white leaues ≈øhew their colour through the peach coloured threads, and the≈øe red circles or rings vpon them being al≈øo per≈øpicuous, make a tripartite ≈øhew
The Ie≈øuites Figure of the Maracoc.
GRANADILLVS FRVTEX INDICVS CHRISTI PASSIONIS IMAGO. depiction of flowers of colours mo≈øt delightfull: the middle part of this flower is hollow, and yellowi≈øh; in the bottome whereof ri≈øeth vp an vmbone, or round ≈øtile, ≈øomewhat bigge, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, ≈øpotted with reddi≈øh ≈øpots like the ≈øtalkes of Dragons, with fiue round threads or chiues, ≈øpotted in the like manner, and tipt at the ends with yellow pendents, ≈øtanding about the middle part of the ≈øaid vmbone, and from thence ri≈øing higher, endeth in three long crooked hornes mo≈øt v≈øually (but ≈øometimes in foure, as hath beene ob≈øerued in Rome by Dr. Aldine, that ≈øet forth ≈øome principall things of Cardinall Farne≈øius his Garden) ≈øpotted like the re≈øt, hauing three round greene buttons at their ends: the≈øe flowers are of a comfortable ≈øweete ≈øent, very acceptable, which peri≈øh without yeelding fruit with vs, becau≈øe it flowreth ≈øo late: but in the naturall place, and in hot Countries, it beareth a ≈ømall round whiti≈øh fruit, with a crowne at the toppe thereof, wherein is contained (while it is fre≈øh, and before it be ouer dried) a ≈øweet liquor, but when it is dry, the ≈øeede within it, which is ≈ømall, flat, ≈øomewhat rough and blacke, will make a ratling noi≈øe: the rootes are compo≈øed of a number of exceeding long and round yellowi≈øh browne ≈øtrings, ≈øpreading farre abroad vnder the ground (I haue ≈øeene ≈øome rootes that haue beene brought ouer, that were as long as any rootes of Sar≈øa parilla, and a great deale bigger, which to be hand≈øomely laid into the ground, were faine to be coyled like a cable) and ≈øhooting vp in ≈øeuerall places a good di≈øtance one from another, whereby it may be well encrea≈øed.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt blew Perwinkle groweth in many Woods and Orchards, by the hedge ≈øides in England, and ≈øo doth the white here and there, but the other ≈øingle and double purple are in our Gardens onely. The great Perwinkle groweth in Prouence of France, in Spaine, and Italy, and other hot Countries, where al≈øo growe all the twining Clamberers, as well ≈øingle as double: but both the vpright ones doe growe in Hungary and thereabouts. The ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing delight of all flowers came from Virginia. Wee pre≈øerue them all in our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Perwinkles doe flower in March and Aprill. The Climers not vntill the end of Iune, or in Iuly, and ≈øometimes in Augu≈øt. The Virginian ≈øomewhat later in Augu≈øt; yet ≈øometimes I haue knowne the flower to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe in Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is out of que≈øtion the fir≈øt Clematis of Dio≈øcorides, and called of
1 Thal≈øpi Creticum. Candy tufts. 2 Vinca peruinca flore ≈øimplici. Single Perwinkle. 3 Vinca peruinca flore duplici. Double Perwinkle. 4 Flammula Matthioli. Vpright Virgins Bower. 5 Clematis peregrina flore ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle Ladies Bower. 6 Clematis peregrina flore pleno purpureo. Double flowred Ladies Bower. 7 Maracoc ≈øiue Clematis Virginiana. The Virginian Climer. depiction of flowers
many Clematis Daphnoides (but not that plant that is ≈øimply called Daphnoides, for that is Laureola) and is v≈øually called Vinca pervinca: but it is not Chamaedaphne, for that is another plant, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in his place; ≈øome call it Centunculus: In Engli≈øh wee call it Perwinkle. The other is Clematis altera of Dio≈øcorides, and is called al≈øo Clematis peregrina, who≈øe di≈øtinctions are ≈øet downe in their titles: In Engli≈øh, Ladies Bower, or Virgins Bower, becau≈øe they are fit to growe by Arbours, to couer them. The fir≈øt vpright Clamberer is called, and that rightly of ≈øome, Clematis erecta, or ≈øurrecta. Of others, Flammula frutex, and Flammula Iouis, or ≈øurrecta: In Engli≈øh, Vpright Virgins Bower. The next is called by Clu≈øius, Clematis Pannonica caerulea, who thought it to be Climeni ≈øpecies, by the relation of others, at the fir≈øt, but after entituled it, Clematis: In Engli≈øh, the Hungarian Climer. The la≈øt may be called in Latine, Clematis Virginiana: In Engli≈øh, The Virgin or Virginian Climer; of the Virginians, Maracoc: of the Spaniards in the We≈øt Indies Granadillo, becau≈øe the fruit (as is before ≈øaid) is in ≈øome fa≈øhion like a ≈ømall Pomegranate on the out≈øide; yet the ≈øeede within is flatti≈øh, round, and blacki≈øh. Some ≈øuper≈øtitious Ie≈øu-ite would faine make men beleeue, that in the flower of this plant are to be ≈øeene all the markes of our Sauiours Pa≈ø≈øion; and therefore call it Flos Pa≈øsionis: and to that end haue cau≈øed figures to be drawne, and printed, with all the parts proportioned out, as thornes, nailes, ≈øpeare, whippe, pillar, &c. in it, and all as true as the Sea burnes, which you may well perceiue by the true figure, taken to the life of the plant, compared with the figures ≈øet forth by the Ie≈øuites, which I haue placed here likewi≈øe for euery one to ≈øee: but the≈øe bee their aduantagious lies (which with them are tolerable, or rather pious and meritorious) wherewith they v≈øe to in≈øtruct their people; but I dare ≈øay, God neuer willed his Prie≈øts to in≈øtruct his people with lyes: for they come from the Diuell, the author of them. But you may ≈øay I am be≈øide my Text, and I am in doubt you will thinke, I am in this be≈øides my ≈øelfe, and ≈øo nothing to be beleeued herein that I ≈øay. For, for the mo≈øt part, it is an inherent errour in all of that ≈øide, to beleeue nothing, be it neuer ≈øo true, that any of our ≈øide ≈øhall affirme, that contrarieth the a≈ø≈øertions of any of their Fathers, as they call them: but I mu≈øt referre them to God, and hee knoweth the truth, and will reforme or deforme them in his time. In regard whereof I could not but ≈øpeake (the occa≈øion being thus offered) again≈øt ≈øuch an erroneous opinion (which euen Dr. Aldine at Rome, before remembred, di≈øproued, and contraried both the ≈øaid figures and name) and ≈øeek to di≈øproue it, as doth (I ≈øay not almo≈øt, but I am affraid altogether) leade many to adore the very picture of ≈øuch things, as are but the fictions of ≈øuper≈øtitious brains: for the flower it ≈øelfe is farre differing from their figure, as both Aldine in the afore≈øaid booke, and Robinus at Paris in his Theatrum Florae, doe ≈øet forth; the flowers and leaues being drawne to the life, and there exhibited, which I hope may ≈øatisfie all men, that will not be perpetually ob≈øtinate and contentious.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Co≈øtaeus ≈øaith hee hath often ≈øeene, that the leaues of Perwinkle held in the mouth, hath ≈øtayed the bleeding at the no≈øe. The French doe v≈øe it to ≈øtay the men≈øtruall fluxes. The other are cau≈øticke plants, that is, fiery hot, and bli≈øtering the skinne; and therefore (as Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith) is profitable to take away the ≈øcur≈øe, leprye, or ≈øuch like deformities of the skin. What property that of Virginia hath, is not knowne to any with vs I thinke, more then that the liquor in the greene fruit is plea≈øant in ta≈øte; but a≈ø≈øuredly it cannot be without ≈øome ≈øpeciall properties, if they were knowne.

div.head: Chamaelaea. Dwarfe Spurge Oliue, or Dwarfe Baye.
div.p: I Haue three ≈øorts of Chamaelaea to bring to your con≈øideration, euery one differing notably from other; two of them of great beauty in their flowers, as well as in the whole plant: the third abiding with greene leaues, although it haue no beauty in the flower, yet worthy of the place it holds. And vnto the≈øe I mu≈øt adioyne another plant, as comming neare≈øt vnto them in the brauery of the flowers.

div.head: 1. Chamaelaea Germanica ≈øiue Mezereon floribus dilutioris coloris & ≈øaturatioris. Dwarfe Baye, or flowring Spurge Oliue.
div.p: We haue two ≈øorts of this Spurge Oliue or Dwafe Baye, differing onely in the colour of the flowers. They both ri≈øe vp with a thicke wooddy ≈øtemme, fiue or ≈øix foot high ≈øometimes, or more, and of the thickne≈ø≈øe (if they be very old) of a mans wre≈øt at the ground, ≈øpreading into many flexible long branches, couered with a tough grayi≈øh barke, be≈øet with ≈ømall long leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto Priuet leaues, but ≈ømaller and paler, and in a manner round pointed: the flowers are ≈ømall, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues, many growing together ≈øometimes, and breaking out of the branches by them≈øelues: in the one ≈øort of a pale red at the fir≈øt blowing, and more white afterwards; the other of a deeper red in the blo≈ø≈øome, and continuing of a deeper red colour all the time of the flowring, both of them very ≈øweete in ≈ømell: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come the berries, which are greene at the fir≈øt, and very red afterwards, turning blacki≈øh red, if they ≈øtand too long vpon the branches: the rootes ≈øpread into many tough long branches, couered with a yellowi≈øh barke.

div.head: 2. Chamaelaea Alpina. Mountaine Spurge Oliue.
div.p: This Mountaine Laurell ri≈øeth vp with a ≈ømall wooddy ≈øtemme, three or foure foot high, or more, branching forth towards the vpper parts into many ≈ølender and tough branches, couered with a rough hoary greene barke, be≈øet at the ends thereof with flatter, fuller, and ≈ømaller round pointed leaues then the former, of a grayi≈øh greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and hoary vnderneath, which abide on the branches in Winter, and fall not away as the former: the flowers are many ≈øet together at the ends of the branches, greater then the former, and con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues a peece, of a light blu≈øh colour, ≈øtanding in ≈ømall grayi≈øh huskes, of little or no ≈øent at all: the fruit followeth, which are ≈ømall long graines or berries, of an excellent red colour, which afterwards turne blacke: the roote is long, and ≈øpreadeth about vnder the vpper part of the earth.

div.head: 3. Chamaelaea tricoccos. Widowe Wayle.
div.p: This three berried Spurge Oliue hath no great ≈øtemme at all, but the whole plant ≈øpreadeth from the ground into many flexible tough greene branches, whereon are ≈øet diuers narrow, long, darke greene leaues all along the branches, which abide greene all the Winter: the flowers are very ≈ømall, ≈øcarce to be ≈øeene, and come forth between the leaues and the ≈øtalke, of a pale yellow colour, made of three leaues; after which come ≈ømall blacki≈øh berries, three v≈øually ≈øet together: the roote ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe in the ground not very farre, being hard and wooddy, and often dyeth, if it bee not well defended from the extremity of our ≈øharpe Winters.

div.head: 4. Cneorum Matthioli. Small Rocke Ro≈øes.
div.p:
I was long in doubt in what place I ≈øhould di≈øpo≈øe of this plant, whether among the Campions, as Bauhinus, or among the≈øe, as Clu≈øius doth; but le≈øt my Gorden ≈øhould want it wholly, let it take vp roome for this time here. This gallant plant hath diuers
long, weake, ≈ølender, but yet tough branches lying vpon the ground, diuided v≈øually into other ≈ømaller branches, whereon growe many, ≈ømall, long, and ≈øomewhat thicke leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of the former Mezereon, ≈øet without any order to the very tops, from whence doe come forth a tuft of many ≈ømall flowers together, made or con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues a peece, of a bright red or carnation colour, and very ≈øweete withall, which turne into ≈ømall round whiti≈øh berries, wherein is contained ≈ømall round ≈øeede, couered with a grayi≈øh coate or skinne: the roote is long and yellowi≈øh, ≈øpreading diuers wayes vnder the ground, and abideth many yeares ≈øhooting forth new branches.
Flore albo.It hath beene ob≈øerued in ≈øome of the≈øe plants, to bring forth white flowers, not differing in any thing el≈øe.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt ≈øorts growe plentifully in many places of Germany. The ≈øecond in the mountaines by Sauoye. The third in Prouence and Spaine. The la≈øt in diuers parts of Germany, Bohemia, and Au≈øtria, and about Franckford.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The two fir≈øt ≈øorts are mo≈øt v≈øually in flower about Chri≈øtmas, or in Ianuary, if the weather be not violent, and ≈øometimes not vntill February. The ≈øecond flowreth not vntill Aprill. The third in May. The berries of them ripen ≈øome in Iune and Iuly; ≈øome in Augu≈øt and September, as their flowring is earlier or later. The la≈øt flowreth as well in the Spring as in Autumne, ≈øo apt and plentifull it is in bearing, and the ≈øeede at both times doth ripen ≈øoone after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is called of ≈øome Chamaelaea, with this addition Germanica, that it may differ from the third, which is the true Chamaelaea of Dio≈øcorides, as all the be≈øt Authors doe agree, and is al≈øo called Piper montanum of the Italians. It is generally called Mezereon, and is indeede the true Mezereon of the Arabians, and ≈øo v≈øed in our Apothecaries ≈øhops, where≈øoeuer the Arabians Mezereon is appointed, although the Arabians are ≈øo intricate and vncertaine in the de≈øcriptions of their plants, confounding Chamaelaea and Thymaelaea together. Matthiolus maketh it to be Daphnoides of Dio≈øcorides; but in my opinion he is therein mi≈øtaken: for all our be≈øt moderne Writers doe account our Laureola, which hath blacke berries, to bee the true Daphnoides: the errour of his Countrey might peraduenture drawe him thereunto; but if hee had better con≈øidered the text of Dio≈øcorides, that giueth black berries to Daphnoides, and red to Chamaedaphne, he would not ≈øo haue written; and truly, I ≈øhould thinke (as Lobel doth) with better rea≈øon, that this Chamaelaea were Dio≈øcorides Chamaedaphne, then hee to ≈øay it were Daphnoides: for the de≈øcription of Chamaedaphne, may in all parts be very fitly applyed to this Chamaelaea: and euen the≈øe words, Semen annexum folijs, wherein may be the greate≈øt doubt in the de≈øcription, may not vnfitly bee con≈øtrued, that as is ≈øeene in the plant, the berries growe at the foote of the leaues, about the branches: the faculties indeede that Dio≈øcorides giueth to Chamaedaphne, are (if any repugnancie be) the greate≈øt let or hinderance, that this Chamaelaea ≈øhould not be it: but I leaue the di≈øcu≈ø≈øing of the≈øe and others of the like nature, to our learned Phy≈øitians; for I deale not ≈øo much with vertues as with de≈øcriptions. The ≈øecond is called of Lobel Chamaelaea Alpina incana, of Clu≈øius Chamaelaea ≈øecunda, and ≈øaith hee had it out of Italy. Wee may call it in Engli≈øh, Mountaine Spurge Oliue, as it is in the de≈øcription, or Mountaine Laurell, which you will. The la≈øt hath the name of Cneorum, fir≈øt giuen it by Matthiolus, which ≈øince is continued by all others. Bauhinus (as I ≈øaid) referreth it to the Mountaine Campions, but Clu≈øius
1 Chamaelaea Germanica ≈øeu Mezereon. Mezereon or Dwarfe Bay. 2 Chamaelaea Alpina. Mountain Spurge Oliue. 3 Cneorum Matthioli. Small Rocke Roles. 4 Laurus Tinus ≈øiue ≈øilue≈øtris. The wild Bay tree. 5 Oleander ≈øiue Laurus Ro≈øea. The Ro≈øe Bay tree. 6 Laurocera≈øus. The Bay Cherrie tree. depiction of flowers
(as I doe) to the kindes of Chamaelaea or Thymaelaea. For want of an Engli≈øh name I haue (as you ≈øee, and that is according to the name the Germane women, as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, doe call it) entituled it the Small Rocke Ro≈øe; which may abide vntill a fitter may be conferred vpon it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: All the≈øe plants except the la≈øt, as well leaues as berries, are violent purgers, and therefore great caution is to bee had in the v≈øe of them. The la≈øt hath not beene applyed for any di≈øea≈øe that I know.

div.head: Laurus. The Bay Tree.
div.p: MY meaning is not to make any de≈øcription of our ordinary Bayes in this place (for as all may very well know, they may be for an Orchard or Courtyard, and not for this Garden) but of two or three other kindes, who≈øe beautifull a≈øpect haue cau≈øed them to be worthy of a place therein: the one is called Laurus Tinus, The wilde Baye: the other Laurus Ro≈øea or Oleander, The Ro≈øe Bay: and a third is Laurocera≈øus, The Cherry Bay; which may haue not onely ≈øome re≈øpect for his long bu≈øh of ≈øweet ≈ømelling flowers, but e≈øpecially for the comely ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe of his gallant euer fre≈øh greene leaues; and the rather, becau≈øe with vs in mo≈øt places, it doth but frute≈øcere, v≈øe to bee Shrub high, not arbore≈øcere, Tree high, which is the more fit for this Garden.

div.head: 1. Laurus Tinus ≈øiue ≈øilue≈øtris. The wilde Bay tree.
div.p: This wilde Baye groweth ≈øeldome to bee a tree of any height, but abideth for the mo≈øt part low, ≈øhooting forth diuers ≈ølender branches, whereon at euery ioynt ≈øtand two leaues, long, ≈ømooth, and of a darke greene colour, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of the Female Cornell tree, or between that and Baye leaues: at the toppes of the branches ≈øtand many ≈ømall white ≈øweete ≈ømelling flowers, thru≈øting together, as it were in an vmbell or tuft, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, the edges whereof haue a ≈øhew of a wa≈øh purple, or light blu≈øh in them, which for the mo≈øt part fall away without bearing any perfect ripe fruit in our Countrey: Yet ≈øometimes it hath ≈ømall black berries, as if they were good, but are not. In his naturall place it beareth ≈ømall, round, hard and pointed berries, of a ≈øhining blacke colour, for ≈øuch haue come often to my hands (yet Clu≈øius writeth they are blew); but I could neuer ≈øee any ≈øpring that I put into the ground. This that I here de≈øcribe, ≈øeemeth to me to be neither of both tho≈øe that Clu≈øius ≈øaw growing in Spain and Potugall, but that other, that (as he ≈øaith) ≈øprang in the low Countreyes of Italian ≈øeede.

div.head: 2. Laurus Ro≈øea ≈øiue Oleander. The Ro≈øe Bay.
div.p:
Of the Ro≈øe Bay there are two ≈øorts, one bearing crim≈øon coloured flowers, which is more frequent, and the other white, which is more rare. They are ≈øo like in all other things, that they neede but one de≈øcription for both. The ≈øtemme or trunke is many times with vs as bigge at the bottome as a good mans thumbe, but growing vp ≈ømaller, it diuideth it ≈øelfe into branches, three for the mo≈øt part comming from one ioynt or place, and tho≈øe branches againe doe likewi≈øe diuide them≈øelues into three other, and ≈øo by degrees from three to three, as long as it groweth: the lowe≈øt of the≈øe are bare of leaues, hauing ≈øhed or lo≈øt them by the cold of winters, keeping onely leaues on the vppermo≈øt branches, which are long, and ≈øomewhat narrow, like in forme vnto Peach leaues, but thicker, harder, and of a darke greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and
yellowi≈øh greene vnderneath: at the tops of the young branches come forth the flowers, which in the one ≈øort before they are open, are of an excellent bright crim≈øon colour, and being blowen, con≈øi≈øt of foure long and narrow leaues, round pointed, ≈øomewhat twining them≈øelues, of a paler red colour, almo≈øt tending to blu≈øh, and in the other are white, the greene leaues al≈øo being of a little fre≈øher colour: after the flowers are pa≈øt, in the hot countries, but neuer in ours, there come vp long bending or crooked flat pods, who≈øe outward ≈øhell is hard, almo≈øt woody, and of a browne colour, wherein is contained ≈ømall flat browni≈øh ≈øeede, wrapped in a great deale of a browni≈øh yellow doune, as fine almo≈øt as ≈øilke, ≈øomewhat like vnto the huskes of A≈øclepias, or Periploca, but larger, flatter and harder; as my ≈øelfe can te≈øtifie, who had ≈øome of the pods of this Ro≈øe bay, brought mee out of Spaine, by Ma≈øter Doctor Iohn More, the ≈øeedes whereof I ≈øowed, and had diuers plants that I rai≈øed vp vnto a rea≈øonable height, but they require, as well old as young, to bee defended from the colde of our winters.

div.head: 3. Laurocera≈øus. The Bay Cherry.
div.p: This beautifull Bay in his naturall place of growing, groweth to bee a tree of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe and height, and oftentimes with vs al≈øo if it bee pruined from the lower branches; but more v≈øually in the≈øe colder Countries, it groweth as a ≈øhrub or hedge bu≈øh, ≈øhooting forth many branches, whereof the greater and lower are couered with a darke grayi≈øh greene barke, but the young ones are very greene, whereon are ≈øet many goodly, faire, large, thicke and long leaues, a little dented about the edges, of a more excellent fre≈øh ≈øhining greene colour, and farre larger then any Bay leafe, and compared by many to the leaues of the Pomeritron tree (which becau≈øe wee haue none in our Countrey, cannot be ≈øo well known) both for colour and largene≈ø≈øe, which yeeld a mo≈øt gracefull a≈øpect: it beareth long ≈øtalkes of whiti≈øh flowers, at the ioynts of the leaues both along the branches and towards the ends of them al≈øo, like vnto the Birds Cherry or Padus Theophrasti, which the French men call Putier & Ceri≈øier blanc, but larger and greater, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues with many threds in the middle: after which commeth the fruite or berries, as large or great as Flanders Cherries, many growing together one by another on a long ≈øtalke, as the flowers did, which are very blacke and ≈øhining on the out≈øide, with a little point at the end, and rea≈øonable ≈øweete in ta≈øte, wherein is contained a hard round ≈øtone, very like vnto a Cherry ≈øtone, as I haue ob≈øerued as well by tho≈øe I receiued out of Italie, as by them I had of Ma≈øter Iames Cole a Merchant of London lately decea≈øed, which grew at his hou≈øe in Highgate, where there is a faire tree which hee defended from the bitterne≈ø≈øe of the weather in winter by ca≈øting a blanket ouer the toppe thereof euery yeare, thereby the better to pre≈øerue it.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is not certainly knowne from whence it came, and is communicated by the ≈øuckers it yeeldeth. The ≈øecond groweth in Spaine, Italie, Grece, and many other places: that with white flowers is recorded by Bellonius, to grow in Candy. The la≈øt, as Matthiolus, and after him Clu≈øius report, came fir≈øt from Con≈øtantinople: I had a plant hereof by the friendly gift of Ma≈øter Iames Cole, the Merchant before remembred, a great louer of all rarities, who had it growing with him at his countrey hou≈øe in Highgate afore≈øaid, where it hath flowred diuers times, and borne ripe fruit al≈øo.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth many times in the end of the yeare before Chri≈øtmas, and often al≈øo in Ianuary, but the mo≈øt kindly time is in March and Aprill, when the flowers are ≈øweete≈øt. The ≈øecond flowreth not vntill Iuly. The la≈øt in May, and the fruit is ripe in Augu≈øt and September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called Laurus ≈øiluestris, and Laurus Tinus: in Engli≈øh Wilde Bay, or Sweete flowring Bay. The ≈øecond is called Laurus Ro≈øea, Oleander, Nerium, and Rhododendros: in Engli≈øh The Ro≈øe Bay, and Oleander. The la≈øt was ≈øent by the name of Trebezon Curma≈øi, that is to ≈øay, Dactylus Trapezuntina, but not hauing any affinitie with any kinde of Date, Bellonius as I thinke fir≈øt named it Laurocera≈øus, and Cera≈øus Trapezuntina. Dalechampius thinketh it to bee Lotus Aphricana, but Clu≈øius refuteth it. Tho≈øe ≈øtones or kernels that were ≈øent me out of Italie, came by the name of Laurus Regia, The Kings Bay. Wee may mo≈øt properly call it according to the Latine name in the title, The Cherry bay, or Bay Cherry, becau≈øe his leaues are like vnto Bay-leaues, and both flowers and fruit like vnto the Birdes Cherry or Clu≈øter Cherry, for the manner of the growing; and therfore I might more fitly I confe≈ø≈øe haue placed it in my Orchard among the ≈øorts of Cherries: but the beautifulne≈ø≈øe of the plant cau≈øed mee rather to in≈øert it here.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The wilde Bay hath no propertie allotted vnto it in Phy≈øicke, for that it is not to be endured, the berries being chewed declare it to be ≈øo violent hot and choking. The Ro≈øe Bay is ≈øaid by Dio≈øcorides, to be death to all foure footed bea≈øts, but contrariwi≈øe to man it is a remedie again≈øt the poi≈øon of Serpents, but e≈øpecially if Rue bee added vnto it. The Cherry Bay is not knowne with vs to what phy≈øicke v≈øe it may be applyed.

div.head: Cera≈øus flore multiplici. The Ro≈øe or double blo≈ø≈øomd Cherry. Malus flore multiplici. The double blo≈ø≈øomd Apple tree. And Malus Per≈øica flore multiplici. The double blo≈ø≈øomd Peach tree.
div.p: THe beautifull ≈øhew of the≈øe three ≈øorts of flowers, hath made me to in≈øert them into this garden, in that for their worthine≈ø≈øe I am vnwilling to bee without them, although the re≈øt of their kindes I haue transferred into the Orchard, where among other fruit trees, they ≈øhall be remembred: for all the≈øe here ≈øet downe, ≈øeldome or neuer beare any fruite, and therefore more fit for a Garden of flowers, then an Orchard of fruite.

div.head: Cera≈øus flore pleno vel multiplici. The Ro≈øe Cherry, or double blo≈ø≈øomd Cherry.
div.p: The double blo≈ø≈øomed Cherry tree is of two ≈øorts for the flower, but not differing in any other part, from the ordinary Engli≈øh or Flanders Cherry tree, growing in the very like manner: the difference con≈øi≈øteth in this, that the one of the≈øe two ≈øorts hath white flowers le≈ø≈øe double, that is, of two rowes or more of leaues, and the other more double, or with more rowes of leaues, and be≈øides I haue ob≈øerued in this greater double blo≈ø≈øomd Cherry, that ≈øome yeares mo≈øt of the flowers haue had another ≈ømaller and double flower, ri≈øing vp out of the middle of the other, like as is to bee ≈øeene in the double Engli≈øh Crow-foote, and double redde Ranunculus or Crowfoote, before de≈øcribed: this I ≈øay doth not happen euery yeare, but ≈øometimes. Sometimes al≈øo the≈øe trees will giue a few berries, here and there ≈øcattered, and that with le≈ø≈øe double flowers more often, which are like vnto our Engli≈øh Cherries both for ta≈øte and bigne≈ø≈øe. The≈øe be very fit to be ≈øet by Arbours.

figure.head: 1 Cera≈øus flore pleno. The double blo≈ø≈øomd Cherry tree. 2 Malus flore multiplici The double blo≈ø≈øomd Apple tree. 3 Malus Per≈øica flore pleno. The double blo≈ø≈øomd Peach tree. 4 Periclymenum perfoliatum. Double Honi≈øuckle. 5 Periclymenum rectum. Vpright Honi≈øuckle.

div.head: Malus flore multiplici. The double blo≈ø≈øomd Apple tree.
div.p: This double blo≈ø≈øomd Apple tree is altogether like vnto our ordinary Pippin tree in body, branch and lea≈øe, the only difference is in the flower, which is altogether whiti≈øh, ≈øauing that the inner leaues towards the middle are more reddi≈øh, but as double and thicke as our double Damaske Ro≈øes, which fall away without bearing fruit.

div.head: Malus Per≈øica flore multiplici. The double blo≈ø≈øomd Peach tree.
div.p: This Peach tree for the manner of growing, is ≈øo like vnto an ordinary Peach tree, that vntill you ≈øee it in blo≈ø≈øome you can perceiue no difference: the flower is of the ≈øame colour with the blo≈ø≈øomes of the Peach, but con≈øi≈øting of three or foure, or more rowes of leaues, which fall often away likewi≈øe without bearing any fruite; but after it hath abiden ≈øome yeares in a place doth forme into fruite, e≈øpecially being planted again≈øt a wall.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Both the Cherry trees are frequent in many places of England, nour≈øed for their plea≈øant flowers. The Apple is as yet a ≈øtranger. And the Peach hath not been ≈øeen or knowne, long before the writing hereof.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in April & May, which are the times of their other kinds.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their names are al≈øo ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed to know them by.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Cherries, Peaches and Apples, are recorded in our Orchard, and there you ≈øhall finde the properties of their fruit: for in that the≈øe beare none or very few, their blo≈ø≈øomes are of mo≈øt v≈øe to grace and decke the per≈øons of tho≈øe that will weare or beare them.

div.head: Periclymenum. Hony≈øuckles.
div.p: THe Honi≈øuckle that groweth wilde in euery hedge, although it be very ≈øweete, yet doe I not bring into my garden, but let it re≈øt in his owne place, to ≈øerue their ≈øen≈øes that trauell by it, or haue no garden.
