I haue three other that furni≈øh my Garden, one that is called double, who≈øe branches ≈øpreade far, and being very fit for an arbour will ≈øoone couer it: the other two ≈øtand vpright, and ≈øpreade not any way far, yet their flowers declaring them to be Honi≈øuckles, but of le≈ø≈øe delight, I con≈øort them with the other.

div.head: Periclymenum perfoliatum ≈øiue Italicum. The double Honi≈øuckle.
div.p:
The truncke or body of the double Honi≈øuckle, is oftentimes of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a good ≈øtaffe, running out into many long ≈øpreading branches, couered with a whiti≈øh barke, which had neede of ≈øome thing to ≈øu≈øtaine them, or el≈øe they will fall down to the ground (and therefore it is v≈øually planted at an arbour, that it may run thereon,
or again≈øt a hou≈øe wall, and fa≈øtened thereto in diuers places with nailes) from whence ≈øpring forth at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances, and at the ioynts, two leaues, being like in forme vnto the wilde Honi≈øuckles, and round pointed for the mo≈øt part; the≈øe branches diuiding them≈øelues diuers wayes, haue at the roppes of them many flowers, ≈øet at certaine di≈øtances one aboue another, with two greene leaues at euery place, where the flowers doe ≈øtand, ioyned ≈øo clo≈øe at the bottome, and ≈øo round and hollow in the middle, that it ≈øeemeth like a hollow cuppe or ≈øawcer of flowers: the flowers ≈øtand round about the middle of the≈øe cuppes or ≈øawcers, being long, hollow, and of a whiti≈øh yellow colour, with open mouthes da≈øht ouer with a light ≈øhew of purple, and ≈øome threds within them, very ≈øweet in ≈ømell, like both in forme and colour vnto the common Honi≈øuckles, but that the≈øe cuppes with the flowers in them are two or three ≈øtanding one aboue another (which make a far better ≈øhew then the common, which come forth all at the heade of the branches, without any greene leaues or cuppes vnder them) and therefore the≈øe were called double Honi≈øuckles.

div.head: Periclymenum rectum fructu rubro. Red Honi≈øuckles.
div.p: This vpright Woodbinde hath a ≈øtraight woody ≈øtemme, diuided into ≈øeuerall branches, about three or foure foote high, couered with a very thinne whiti≈øh barke, whereon ≈øtand two leaues together at the ioynts, being le≈ø≈øer then the former, ≈ømooth and plaine, and a little pointed: the flowers come forth vpon ≈ølender long foot≈øtalks at the ioynts where the leaues ≈øtand, alwayes two ≈øet together, and neuer more, but ≈øeldome one alone, which are much ≈ømaller then the former, but of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, with a little button at the foote of the flower; the buds of the flowers before they are open are very reddi≈øh, but being open are not ≈øo red, but tending to a kinde of yellowi≈øh blu≈øh colour: after which come in their places two ≈ømall red berries, the one withered for the mo≈øt part, or at lea≈øt ≈ømaller then the other, but (as Clu≈øius ≈øaith) in their naturall places they are both full and of one bigne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Periclymenum rectum fructu caeruleo. Blew berried Honi≈øuckles.
div.p: This other vpright Woodbinde groweth vp as high as the former, or rather ≈øomewhat higher, couered with a blacki≈øh rugged barke, chapping in diuers places, the younger branches whereof are ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, and couered with an hoary doune: the leaues ≈øtand two together at the ioints, ≈øomewhat larger then the former, and more whiti≈øh vnderneath: the flowers are likewi≈øe two ≈øtanding together, at the end of a ≈ølender foote≈øtalke, of a pale yellowi≈øh colour when they are blowne, but more reddi≈øh in the bud: the berries ≈øtand two together as the former, of a darke blewi≈øh colour when they are fully ripe, and full of a red liquour or iuice, of a plea≈øant ta≈øte, which doth not only dye the hands of them that gather them, but ≈øerueth for a dying colour to the inhabitants where they grow plentifully, wherein are contained many flat ≈øeede: The roote is woody as the former is.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The firw groweth in Italie, Spaine, and Prouence of France, but not in the colder countreyes, vnle≈ø≈øe it be there planted, as is mo≈øt frequent in our countrey. The others grow in Au≈øtria, and Stiria, as Clufius ≈øaith, and are entertained into their gardens onely that are curious.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth v≈øually in Aprill, the re≈øt in May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt is called Periclymenum, Caprifolium perfoliatum, and Italicum, as a difference from the common kinde: In Engli≈øh Double Woodbinde,
or double Honi≈øuckles. The others, as they are rare, and little knowne, ≈øo are their names al≈øo: yet according to their Latine, I haue giuen them Engli≈øh names.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The double Honi≈øuckle is as effectuall in all things, as the ≈øingle wilde kinde, and be≈øides, is an e≈øpeciall good wound herbe for the head or other parts. I haue not knowne the vpright kindes v≈øed in Phy≈øicke.

div.head: Ia≈øminum ≈øiue Gel≈øeminum. Ia≈ømine or Ge≈ømine.
div.p: WE haue but one ≈øort of true Ia≈ømine ordinarily in our Gardens throughout the whole Land; but there is another greater ≈øort, which is farre more tender, brought out of Spaine, and will hardly endure any long time with vs, vnle≈ø≈øe it be very carefully pre≈øerued. Wee haue a third kinde called a yellow Ia≈ømine, but differeth much from their tribe in many notable points: but becau≈øe the flowers haue ≈øome likene≈ø≈øe with the flowers of the true Ia≈ømine, it hath been v≈øually called a Ia≈ømine; and therefore I am content for this Garden to conioyne them in one Chapter.

div.head: 1. Ia≈øminum album. The white Ia≈ømine.
div.p: The white Ia≈ømine hath many twiggy flexible greene branches, comming forth of the ≈øundry bigger boughes or ≈øtems, that ri≈øe from the roote, which are couered with a grayi≈øh darke coloured barke, hauing a white pith within it like the Elder, but not ≈øo much: the winged leaues ≈øtand alwaies two together at the ioynts, being made of manie ≈ømall and pointed leaues, ≈øet on each ≈øide of a middle ribbe, ≈øix mo≈øt v≈øually on both ≈øides, with one at the end, which is larger, more pointed then any of the re≈øt, and of a darke greene colour: at the toppes of the young branches ≈øtand diuers flowers together, as it were in an vmbell or ruft, each whereof ≈øtandeth on a long greene ≈øtalke, comming out of a ≈ømall huske, being ≈ømall, long, and hollow belowe, opening into fiue white ≈ømall, pointed leaues, of a very ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈ømell, which fall away without bearing any fruit at all, that euer I could learne in our Country; but in the hot Countries where it is naturall, it is ≈øaid to beare flat fruit, like Lupines: the rootes ≈øpread farre and deepe, and are long and hard to growe, vntill they haue taken ≈øtrong hold in the ground.

div.head: 2. Ia≈øminum Catalonicum. The Spani≈øh Ia≈ømine.
div.p: This Catalonia Ia≈ømine groweth lower then the former, neuer ri≈øing halfe ≈øo high, and hath ≈ølender long greene branches, ri≈øing from the toppe of the wooddy ≈øtemme, with ≈øuch like leaues ≈øet on them as the former, but ≈øomewhat ≈øhorter and larger: the flowers al≈øo are like vnto the former, and ≈øtand in the ≈øame manner at the end of the branches, but are much larger, being of a blu≈øh colour before they are blowne, and white with blu≈øh edges when they are open, exceeding ≈øweete of ≈ømell, more ≈øtrong then the former.

div.head: 3. Ia≈øminum luteum, ≈øiue Trifolium fruticans alijs Polemonium. The yellow Ia≈ømine.
div.p:
This that is called the yellow Ia≈ømine, hath many long ≈ølender twiggy branches ri≈øing from the roote, greene at the fir≈øt, and couered with a darke grayi≈øh barke afterwards, whereon are ≈øet at certaine di≈øtances, three ≈ømall darke greene leaues together, the end leafe being alwaies the bigge≈øt: at the ioynts where the leaues come forth,
≈øtand long ≈øtalkes, bearing long hollow flowers, ending in fiue, and ≈øome in ≈øix leaues, very like vnto the flowers of the fir≈øt Ia≈ømine, but yellow, whereupon it is v≈øually called the Yellow Ia≈ømine: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places round blacke ≈øhining berries, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a great Pea≈øe, or bigger, full of a purpli≈øh iuyce, which will dye ones fingers that brui≈øe them but a little: the roote is tough, and white, creeping farre about vnder the ground, ≈øhooting forth plentifully, whereby it greatly encrea≈øeth.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt is verily thought to haue been fir≈øt brought to Spaine out of Syria, or thereabouts, and from Spaine to vs, and is to be ≈øeene very often, and in many of our Country Gardens. The ≈øecond hath his breeding in Spaine al≈øo, but whether it be his originall place we know not, and is ≈øcarce yet made well acquainted with our Engli≈øh ayre. The third groweth plentifully about Mompelier, and will well abide in our London Gardens, and any where el≈øe.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth not vntill the end of Iuly. The ≈øecond ≈øomewhat earlier. The third in Iuly al≈øo.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is generally called Ia≈øminum album, and Gel≈øeminum album: In Engli≈øh, The white Ia≈ømine. The ≈øecond hath his name in his title, as much as may be ≈øaid of it. The third hath been taken of ≈øome to be a Cyti≈øus, others iudge it to be Polemonium, but the true≈øt name is Trifolium fruticans, although many call it Ia≈øminum luteum: In Engli≈øh mo≈øt v≈øually, The yellow Ia≈ømine, for the rea≈øons afore≈øaid; or el≈øe after the Latine name, Shrubbie Trefoile, or Make-bate.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The white Ia≈ømines haue beene in all times accepted into outward medicines, eyther for the plea≈øure of the ≈øweete ≈øent, or profit of the warming properties. And is in the≈øe dayes onely v≈øed as an ornament in Gardens, or for ≈øent of the flowers in the hou≈øe, &c. The yellow Ia≈ømine, although ≈øome haue adiudged it to be the Polemonium of Dio≈øcorides, yet it is not v≈øed to tho≈øe purpo≈øes by any that I know.

div.head: Syringa. The Pipe tree.
div.p: VNder the name of Syringa, is contained two ≈øpeciall kinds of Shrubs or Trees, differing one from another; namely, the Lilac of Matthiolus, which is called Syringa caerulea, and is of two or three ≈øorts: And the Syringa alba, which al≈øo is of two ≈øorts, as ≈øhall bee declared.

div.head: 1. Lilac ≈øiue Syringa caerulea. The blew Pipe tree.
div.p:
The blew Pipe tree ri≈øeth ≈øometimes to be a great tree, as high and bigge in the bodie as a rea≈øonable Apple tree (as I haue in ≈øome places ≈øeene and ob≈øerued) but mo≈øt v≈øually groweth lower, with many twigs or branches ri≈øing from the roote, hauing as much pith in the middle of them as the Elder hath, couered with a grayi≈øh greene
barke, but darker in the elder branches, with ioynts ≈øet at a good di≈øtance one from another, and two leaues at euery ioynt, which are large, broad, and pointed at the ends, many of them turning or folding both the ≈øides inward, and ≈øtanding on long foote-≈øtalkes: at the toppes of the branches come forth many flowers, growing ≈øpike-fa≈øhion, that is, a long branch of flowers vpon a ≈øtalke, each of the≈øe flowers are ≈ømall, long, and hollow belowe, ending aboue in a pale blewi≈øh flower, con≈øi≈øting of foure ≈ømall leaues, of a pretty ≈ømall ≈øent: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come ≈øometimes (but it is not often in our Country, vnle≈ø≈øe the tree haue ≈øtood long, and is grown great, the ≈øuckers being continually taken away, that it may growe the better) long and flat cods, con≈øi≈øting as it were of two ≈øides, a thin skinne being in the mid≈øt, wherein are contained two long flatti≈øh red ≈øeede: the rootes are ≈øtrong, and growe deepe in the ground.

div.head: 2. Syringa flore lacteo ≈øiue argenteo. The ≈øiluer coloured Pipe tree.
div.p: This Pipe tree differeth not from the former blew Pipe tree, either in ≈øtemme or branches, either in leaues or flowers, or manner of growing, but onely in the colour of the flower, which in this is of a milke, or ≈øiluer colour, which is a kinde of white, wherein there is a thinne wa≈øh, or light ≈øhew of blew ≈øhed therein, comming ≈øomewhat neare vnto an a≈øh-colour.

div.head: 3. Lilac lacimatis folijs. The blew Pipe tree with cut leaues.
div.p: This Pipe tree ≈øhould not differ from the fir≈øt in any other thing then in the leaues, which are ≈øaid to be cut in on the edges into ≈øeuerall parts, as the relation is giuen √† viris fide dignis; for as yet I neuer ≈øaw any ≈øuch; but I here am bold to ≈øet it downe, to induce and prouoke ≈øome louer of plants to obtaine it for his plea≈øure, and others al≈øo.

div.head: 4. Syringa flore albo ≈øimplici. The ≈øingle white Pipe tree.
div.p: The ≈øingle white Pipe tree or bu≈øh, neuer commeth to that height of the former, but abideth alwaies like a hedge tree or bu≈øh, full of ≈øhootes or ≈øuckers from the roote, much more then the former: the young ≈øhootes hereof are reddi≈øh on the out≈øide, and afterward reddi≈øh at the ioynts, and grayi≈øh all the re≈øt ouer: the young as well as the old branches, haue ≈øome pith in the middle of them, like as the Elder hath: the leaues ≈øtand two at a ioynt, ≈øomewhat like the former, but more rugged or crumpled, as al≈øo a little pointed, and dented about the edges: the flowers growe at the toppes of the branches, diuers ≈øtanding together, con≈øi≈øting of foure white leaues, like vnto ≈ømall Muske Ro≈øes, and of the ≈øame creame colour, as I may call it, with many ≈ømall yellowi≈øh threads in the middle, and are of a ≈øtrong, full, or heady ≈øent, not plea≈øing to a great many, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtrange quickne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øent: the fruit followeth, being flat at the head, with many leafie ≈øhels or ≈øcales compa≈ø≈øing it, wherein is enclo≈øed ≈ømall long ≈øeede: the rootes runne not deepe, but ≈øpread vnder the ground, with many fibres annexed vnto them.

div.head: 5. Syringa Arabica flore albo duplici. The double white Pipe tree.
div.p:
This Pipe tree hath diuers long and ≈ølender branches, whereon growe large leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of the former ≈øingle white kinde, but not ≈øo rough or hard, and not at all dented about the edges, two alwaies ≈øtanding one again≈øt another at euery ioynt of the ≈øtalke, but ≈øet or di≈øpo≈øed on contrary ≈øides, and not all vpon one ≈øide; at the ends whereof come forth diuers flowers, euery one ≈øtanding on his owne foote-≈øtalke, the ho≈øe or huske being long and hollow, like vnto the white Ia≈ømine, and the flowers therin con≈øi≈øting of a double rowe of white and round pointed leaues, fiue or ≈øix in a rowe, with ≈øome yellowne≈ø≈øe in the middle, which is hollow, of a very ≈øtrong and heady ≈øweet ≈øent, and abiding a long time flowring, e≈øpecially in the hotter Countries, but is very tender, and not able to abide any the lea≈øt cold weather with vs;
1 I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ minum album vulgare.
‚Ä¢ he ordinary white Ia≈ømin ‚Ä¢ . 2 Ia≈øminum Americanum ≈øiue Convolvulus Americanus. The Ia≈ømine or Bindweed of America. 3 Ie≈øminum luto ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ vulgar ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ he yellow Ia≈ømine. 4 Lilac ≈øeu Syringa carulea. The blew Pipe tree. 5 Syringa alba vulgaris. The ≈øingle white Syringa or Pipe tree. 6 Syringa flore albo duplici. The double white Syringa. 7 Sambucus ro≈øea. The Elder or Gelder Role. depiction of flowers
for the cold windes will (as I vnder≈øtand) greatly mole≈øt it: and therefore mu≈øt as charily be kept as Orenge trees with vs, if wee will haue it to abide.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in Arabia (as Matthiolus thinketh, that had it from Con≈øtantinople.) We haue it plentifully in our Gardens. The ≈øecond and third are ≈øtrangers with vs as yet. The fourth is as frequent as the fir≈øt, or rather more, but his originall is not knowne. The la≈øt hath his originall from Arabia, as his name importeth.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and third flower in Aprill, the other two not vntill May.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called of Matthiolus Lilac, and by that name is mo≈øt v≈øually called in all parts. It is al≈øo called Syringa caerulea, becau≈øe it commeth neare≈øt vnto tho≈øe woods, which for their pithy ≈øub≈øtance, were made hollow into pipes. It is called of all in Engli≈øh, The blew Pipe tree. It ≈øeemeth likely, that Petrus Bellonius in his third Booke and fiftieth Chapter of his ob≈øeruations (making mention of a ≈øhrubbe that the Turkes haue, with Iuie leaues alwaies greene, bearing blew or violet coloured flowers on a long ≈øtalke, of the bigne≈ø≈øe and fa≈øhion of a Foxe taile, and thereupon called in their language a Foxe taile) doth vnder≈øtand this plant here expre≈ø≈øed. The certainty whereof might ea≈øily be knowne, if any of our Merchants there re≈øiding, would but call for ≈øuch a ≈øhrubbe, by the name of a Foxe taile in the Turki≈øh tongue, and take care to ≈øend a young roote, in a ≈ømall tubbe or basket with earth by Sea, vnto vs here at London, which would be performed with a very little paines and co≈øt. The ≈øecond and third, as kindes thereof, haue their names in their titles. The fourth is called by Clu≈øius and others, Frutex Coronarius; ≈øome doe call it Lilac flore albo, but that name is not proper, in that it doth confound both kindes together. Lobel calleth it Syringa Italica. It is now generally called of all Syringa alba, that is in Engli≈øh, The white Pipe tree. Some would haue it to bee O≈øtrys of Theophra≈øtus, but Clu≈øius hath ≈øufficiently cleared that doubt. Of others Ligustrum Orientale, which it cannot be neither; for the Cyprus of Plinie is Dio≈øcorides his Ligu≈øtrum, which may be called Orientale, in that it is mo≈øt proper to the Ea≈øterne Countries, and is very ≈øweete, who≈øe ≈øeede is like vnto Coriander ≈øeede. The la≈øt is called by diuers Syringa Arabica flore albo duplici, as mo≈øt fitly agreeing thereunto. Of Ba≈øilius Be≈ølerus that ≈øet forth the great booke of the Bi≈øhop of Ey≈øtot in Germany his Garden, Syringa Italica flore albo pleno, becau≈øe, as it is likely, hee had it from Italy. It is very likely, that Pro≈øper Alpinus in his booke of Egyptian plants, doth meane this plant, which hee there calleth Sambach, ≈øiue Ia≈øminum Arabicum. Matthaeus Caccini of Florence in his letter to Clu≈øius entituleth it Syringa Arabica, ≈øiue Ia≈øminum Arabicum, ≈øiue Ia≈øminum ex Gine, whereby hee declareth that it may not vnfitly be referred to either of them both. We may call it in Engli≈øh as it is in the title, The double white Pipe tree.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: We haue no v≈øe of the≈øe in Phy≈øicke that I know, although Pro≈øper Alpinus ≈øaith, the double white Pipe tree is much v≈øed in Egypt, to help women in their trauailes of childbirth.

div.head: Sambucus Ro≈øea. The Elder or Gelder Ro≈øe.
div.p: ALthough there be diuers kindes of Elders, yet there is but one kinde of Elder Ro≈øe, whereof I meane to intreate in this Chapter, being of neare affinity in ≈øome things vnto the former Pipe trees, and which for the beauty of it de≈øerueth to be remembred among the delights of a Garden.

div.head: Sambucus Ro≈øea. The Gelder Ro≈øe.
div.p: The Gelder Ro≈øe (as it is called) groweth to a rea≈øonable height, ≈øtanding like a tree, with a trunke as bigge as any mans arme, couered with a darke grayi≈øh barke, ≈øomewhat rugged and very knotty: the younger branches are ≈ømooth and white, with a pithy ≈øub≈øtance in the middle, as the Elders haue, to ≈øhew that it is a kind thereof, whereon are ≈øet broad leaues, diuided into three parts or diui≈øions, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Vine leafe, but ≈ømaller, and more rugged or crumpled, iagged or cut al≈øo about the edges: at the toppes of euery one of the young branches, mo≈øt v≈øually commeth forth a great tuft, or ball as it were, of many white flowers, ≈øet ≈øo clo≈øe together, that there can be no di≈øtinction of any ≈øeuerall flower ≈øeene, nor doth it ≈øeeme like the double flower of any other plant, that hath many rowes of leaues ≈øet together, but is a clu≈øter of white leaued flowers ≈øet together vpon the ≈øtalke that vpholdeth them, of a ≈ømall ≈øent, which fall away without bearing any fruit in our Country, that euer I could ob≈øerue or learne: The roote ≈øpreadeth neither farre nor deepe, but ≈øhooteth many ≈ømall rootes and fibres, whereby it is fa≈øtened in the ground, and draweth nouri≈øhment to it, and ≈øometimes yeeldeth ≈øuckers from it.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It ≈øhould ≈øeeme, that the naturall place of this Elder is wet and moi≈øt grounds, becau≈øe it is ≈øo like vnto the Mar≈øh Elder, which is the ≈øingle kind hereof. It is onely nour≈øed vp in Gardens in all our Country.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in May, much about the time of the double Peony flower, both which being ≈øet together, make a plea≈øant variety, to decke vp the windowes of a hou≈øe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is generally called Sambucus Ro≈øea: In Engli≈øh, The Elder Ro≈øe, and more commonly after the Dutch name, the Gelder Ro≈øe. Dalechampius ≈øeemeth to make it Thraupalus of Theophra≈øtus, or rather the ≈øingle Mar≈øh Elder; for I thinke this double kinde was not knowne in Theophra≈øtus his time.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is not applyed to any Phy≈øicall v≈øe that I know.

div.head: Ro≈øa. The Ro≈øe tree or bu≈øh.
div.p: THe great varietie of Ro≈øes is much to be admired, beeing more then is to bee ≈øeene in any other ≈øhrubby plant that I know, both for colour, forme and ≈ømell. I haue to furni≈øh this garden thirty ≈øorts at the lea≈øt, euery one notably differing from the other, and all fit to be here entertained: for there are ≈øome other, that being wilde and of no beautie or ≈ømell, we forbeare, and leaue to their wilde habitations. To di≈øtingui≈øh them by their colours, as white, red, incarnate, and yellow, were a way that many might take, but I hold it not ≈øo conuenient for diuers re≈øpects: for ≈øo I ≈øhould confound tho≈øe of diuers ≈øorts one among another, and I ≈øhould not keepe that methode which to me ≈øeemeth mo≈øt conuenient, which is, to place and ranke euery kinde, whether ≈øingle or double, one next vnto the other, that ≈øo you may the better vnder≈øtand their varieties and differences: I will therefore beginne with the mo≈øt ancient, and knowne Ro≈øes to our Countrey, whether naturall or no I know not, but a≈ø≈øumed by our precedent Kings of all others, to bee cogni≈øances of their dignitie, the white Ro≈øe and the red, whom ≈øhall follow the damaske, of the fine≈øt ≈øent, and mo≈øt v≈øe of all the other ≈øorts, and the re≈øt in their order.

div.head: 1. Ro≈øa Anglica alba. The Engli≈øh white Ro≈øe.
div.p: The white Ro≈øe is of two kindes, the one more thicke and double then the other: The one ri≈øeth vp in ≈øome ≈øhadowie places, vnto eight or ten foote high, with a ≈øtocke of a great bigne≈ø≈øe for a Ro≈øe. The other growing ≈øeldome higher then a Damaske Ro≈øe. Some doe iudge both the≈øe to be but one kinde, the diuer≈øitie happening by the ayre, or ground, or both. Both the≈øe Ro≈øes haue ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller and whiter greene leaues then in many other Ro≈øes, fiue mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øet on a ≈øtalke, and more white vnderneath, as al≈øo a whiter greene barke, armed with ≈øharpe thornes or prickles, whereby they are ≈øoone known from other Ro≈øes, although the one not ≈øo ea≈øily from the other: the flowers in the one are whiti≈øh, with an eye or ≈øhew of a blu≈øh, e≈øpecially towards the ground or bottome of the flower, very thicke double, and clo≈øe ≈øet together, and for the mo≈øt part not opening it ≈øelfe ≈øo largely and fully as eyther the Red or Damaske Ro≈øe. The other more white, le≈ø≈øe thicke and double, and opening it ≈øelfe more, and ≈øome ≈øo little double as but of two or three rowes, that they might be held to be ≈øingle, yet all of little or no ≈ømell at all. To de≈øcribe you all the ≈øeuerall parts of the Ro≈øe, as the bud, the beards, the threds &c. were needle≈ø≈øe, they are ≈øo conuer≈øant in euery ones hand, that I ≈øhall not neede but to touch the mo≈øt ≈øpeciall parts of the varieties of them, and leaue a more exact relation of all things incident vnto them, vnto a generall worke.

div.head: 2. Ro≈øa Incarnata. The Carnation Ro≈øe.
div.p: The Carnation Ro≈øe is in mo≈øt things like vnto the le≈ø≈øer white ro≈øe, both for the growing of the ≈øtocke, and bigne≈ø≈øe of the flower, but that it is more ≈øpreade abroade when it is blown then the white is, and is of a pale blu≈øh colour all the flower thoroughout, of as ≈ømall a ≈øent as the white one is almo≈øt.

Ro≈øa Belgica ≈øiue Vitrea.This kinde of Ro≈øe is not very great, but very thicke and double, and is very variable in the flowers, in that they will be ≈øo different one from another: ≈øome being paler then others, and ≈øome as it were bla≈øted, which commeth not ca≈øually, but naturally to this ro≈øe: but the be≈øt flowers (whereof there will bee ≈øtill ≈øome) will be of a bright pale murrey colour, neere vnto the Veluet ro≈øe, but nothing ≈øo darke a colour.

div.head: 3. Ro≈øa Anglica rubra. The Engli≈øh red Ro≈øe.
div.p:
The red Ro≈øe (which I call Engli≈øh, not only for the rea≈øon before expre≈ø≈øed, but becau≈øe
(as I take it) this Ro≈øe is more frequent and v≈øed in England, then in other places) neuer groweth ≈øo high as the damaske Ro≈øe bu≈øh, but mo≈øt v≈øually abideth low, and ≈øhooteth forth many branches from the roote (and is but ≈øeldome ≈øuffered to grow vp as the damaske Ro≈øe into ≈øtandards) with a greene barke, thinner ≈øet with prickles, and larger and greener leaues on the vpper≈øide then in the white, yet with an eye of white vpon them, fiue likewi≈øe mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øet vpon a ≈øtalke, and grayi≈øh or whiti≈øh vnderneath. The Ro≈øes or Flowers doe very much vary, according to their ≈øite and abiding; for ≈øome are of an orient, red or deepe crim≈øon colour, and very double (although neuer ≈øo double as the white) which when it is full blowne hath the large≈øt leaues of any other Ro≈øe; ≈øome of them againe are paler, tending ≈øomewhat to a damaske; and ≈øome are of ≈øo pale a red, as that it is rather of the colour of the canker Ro≈øe, yet all for the mo≈øt part with larger leaues then the damaske, and with many more yellow threds in the middle: the ≈øent hereof is much better then in the white, but not comparable to the excellencie of the damaske Ro≈øe, yet this Ro≈øe being well dryed and well kept, will hold both colour and ≈øent longer then the damaske, bee it neuer ≈øo well kept.

div.head: 4. Ro≈øa Dama≈øcena. The Damaske Ro≈øe.
div.p: The Damaske Ro≈øe bu≈øh is more v≈øually nour≈øed vp to a competent height to ≈øtand alone, (which we call Standards) then any other Ro≈øe: the barke both of the ≈øtocke and branches, is not fully ≈øo greene as the red or white Ro≈øe: the leaues are greene with an eye of white vpon them, ≈øo like vnto the red Ro≈øe, that there is no great difference betweene them, but that the leaues of the red Ro≈øe ≈øeeme to bee of a darker greene. The flowers are of a fine deepe blu≈øh colour, as all know, with ≈øome pale yellow threds in the middle, and are not ≈øo thicke and double as the white, nor being blowne, with ≈øo large and great leaues as the red, but of the mo≈øt excellent ≈øweet plea≈øant ≈øent, far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing all other Ro≈øes or Flowers, being neyther heady nor too ≈øtrong, nor ≈øtuffing or vnplea≈øant ≈øweet, as many other flowers.

div.head: 5. Ro≈øa Prouincialis ≈øiue Hollandica Dama≈øcena. The great double Damaske Prouince or Holland Ro≈øe.
div.p: This Ro≈øe (that ≈øome call Centifolia Batauica incarnata) hath his barke of a reddi≈øh or browne colour, whereby it is ≈øoone di≈øcerned from other Ro≈øes. The leaues are likewi≈øe more reddi≈øh then in others, and ≈øomewhat larger, it v≈øually groweth very like the Damaske ro≈øe, and much to the ≈øame height: the flowers or ro≈øes are of the ≈øame deepe blu≈øh colour that the damaske ro≈øes are, or rather ≈øomewhat deeper, but much thicker, broader, and more double, or fuller of leaues by three parts almo≈øt, the outer leaues turning them≈øelues backe, when the flower hath ≈øtood long blowne, the middle part it ≈øelfe (which in all other ro≈øes almo≈øt haue ≈øome yellow threds in them to be ≈øeene) being folded hard with ≈ømall leaues, without any yellow almo≈øt at all to be ≈øeene, the ≈øent whereof commeth neere≈øt vnto the damaske ro≈øe, but yet is ≈øhort of it by much, how≈øoeuer many doe thinke it as good as the damask, and to that end I haue known ≈øome Gentlewomen haue cau≈øed all their damaske ≈øtockes to bee grafted with prouince Ro≈øes, hoping to haue as good water, and more ≈øtore of them then of damask Ro≈øes; but in my opinion it is not of halfe ≈øo good a ≈øent as the water of damaske Ro≈øes: let euery one follow their own fancie.

div.head: 6. Ro≈øa Prouincialis rubra. The red Prouince Ro≈øe.
div.p:
As the former was called incarnata, ≈øo this is called Batauica centifolia rubra, the difference being not very great: the ≈øtemme or ≈øtocke, and the branches al≈øo in this, ≈øeeming not to be ≈øo great but greener, the barke being not ≈øo red; the leaues of the ≈øame largene≈ø≈øe with the former damaske Prouince. The flowers are not altogether ≈øo large, thicke and double, and of a little deeper damaske or blu≈øh colour, turning to a red Ro≈øe, but not comming neere the full colour of the be≈øt red Ro≈øe, of a ≈øent not ≈øo ≈øweete as the damaske Prouince, but comming ≈øomewhat neere the ≈øent of the ordinary
red ro≈øe, yet exceeding it. This ro≈øe is not ≈øo plentifull in bearing as the damaske Prouince.

div.head: 7. Ro≈øa Prouincialis alba. The white Prouince Ro≈øe.
div.p: It is ≈øaid of diuers, that there is a white Prouince Ro≈øe, whereof I am not ocuiatus te≈øtis, and therfore I dare not giue it you for a certaintie, and indeed I haue ≈øome doubt, that it is the greater and more double white ro≈øe, whereof I gaue you the knowledge in the beginning: when I am my ≈øelfe better ≈øatisfied, I ≈øhall bee ready to ≈øatisfie others.

div.head: 8. Ro≈øa ver≈øicolor. The party coloured Ro≈øe, of ≈øome Yorke and Lanca≈øter.
div.p: This Ro≈øe in the forme and order of the growing, is neere≈øt vnto the ordinary damaske ro≈øe, both for ≈øtemme, branch, leafe and flower: the difference con≈øi≈øting in this, that the flower (being of the ≈øame largene≈ø≈øe and doublene≈ø≈øe as the damask ro≈øe) hath the one halfe of it, ≈øometimes of a pale whiti≈øh colour, and the other halfe, of a paler damaske colour then the ordinary; this happeneth ≈øo many times, and ≈øometimes al≈øo the flower hath diuers ≈øtripes, and markes in it, as one leafe white, or ≈øtriped with white, and the other halfe blu≈øh, or ≈øtriped with blu≈øh, ≈øometimes al≈øo all ≈øtriped, or ≈øpotted ouer, and other times little or no ≈øtripes or markes at all, as nature li≈øteth to play with varieties, in this as in other flowers: yet this I haue ob≈øerued, that the longer it abideth blowen open in the ≈øun, the paler and the fewer ≈øtripes, markes or ≈øpots will be ≈øeene in it: the ≈ømell whereof is of a weake damaske ro≈øe ≈øent.

div.head: 9. Ro≈øea Chry≈øtallina. The Chry≈øtall Ro≈øe.
div.p: This Ro≈øe is very like vnto the la≈øt de≈øcribed, both for ≈øtocke, branch and leafe: the flower hereof is not much different from it, being no great large or double Ro≈øe, but of a meane ≈øize, ≈øtriped and marked with a deeper blu≈øh or red, vpon the pale coloured leafe, that it ≈øeemeth in the marking and beauty thereof, to bee of as much delight as the Chry≈øtall Gilloflower: this, euen like the former, ≈øoone fadeth and pa≈ø≈øeth away, not yeelding any great ≈øtore of flowers any yeare.

div.head: 10. Ro≈øa rubra humilis ≈øiue pumilio. The dwarfe red Ro≈øe, or Gilloflower Ro≈øe.
div.p: This Ro≈øe groweth alwayes low and ≈ømall, otherwi≈øe in mo≈øt re≈øpects like vnto the ordinary redde Ro≈øe, and with few or no thornes vpon it: the Flowers or Ro≈øes are double, thicke, ≈ømall and clo≈øe, not ≈øo much ≈øpread open as the ordinary red, but ≈øomewhat like vnto the fir≈øt double white Ro≈øe before expre≈ø≈øed; yet in ≈øome places I haue ≈øeene them more layde open then the≈øe, as they grew in my garden, being ≈øo euen at the toppes of the leaues, as if they had been clipt off with a paire of ≈øheeres, and are not fully of ≈øo red a colour as the red Prouince Ro≈øe, and of as ≈ømall or weak ≈øent as the ordinary red Ro≈øe, or not ≈øo much.

div.head: 11. Ro≈øa Francafurten≈øis. The Franckford Ro≈øe.
div.p: The young ≈øhootes of this Ro≈øe are couered with a pale purpli≈øh barke, ≈øet with a number of ≈ømall prickes like haires, and the elder haue but very few thornes: the flower or ro≈øe it ≈øelfe hath a very great bud or button vnder it, more then in any other ro≈øe, and is thicke and double as a red ro≈øe, but ≈øo ≈øtrongly ≈øwelling in the bud, that many of them breake before they can be full blowen, and then they are of a pale red ro≈øe colour, that is, betweene a red and a damaske, with a very thicke broade and hard vmbone of ≈øhort yellow threds or thrumes in the middle, the huske of the flower hauing long ends, which are called the beards of the ro≈øe, which in all other are iagged in ≈øome of them, in this hath no iagge at all: the ≈ømell is neere≈øt vnto a red Ro≈øe.

Ro≈øa Dama≈øcena. The Damaske Ro≈øe. 2 Ro≈øa Prouincialis ≈øiue Hollandica. The great Prouince Ro≈øe. 3 Ro≈øe Francafurten≈øis. The Franckford Ro≈øe. 4 Ro≈øa rubra humilis. The dwarfered Ro≈øe. 5 Ro≈øa Hungarica. The Hungarian Ro≈øe. 6 Ro≈øa lutea multiplex. The great double yellow Ro≈øe.

div.head: 12. Ro≈øa Hungarica. The Hungarian Ro≈øe.
div.p: The Hungarian Ro≈øe hath greene ≈øhootes ≈ølenderly ≈øet with prickes, and ≈øeldome groweth higher then ordinarily the red Ro≈øe doth; the ≈øtemme or ≈øtocke being much about that bigne≈ø≈øe: the flower or ro≈øe is as great, thicke and double, as the ordinary red Ro≈øe, and of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, of a paler red colour, and beeing neerely looked vpon is finely ≈øpotted with faint ≈øpots, as it were ≈øpreade ouer the red; the ≈ømell wherof is ≈øomewhat better then the ≈ømell of the ordinary red Ro≈øe of the be≈øt kinde.

div.head: 13. Ro≈øa Holo≈øerica ≈øimplex & multiplex. The Veluet Ro≈øe ≈øingle and double.
div.p: The old ≈øtemme or ≈øtock of the veluet Ro≈øe is couered with a dark coloured barke, and the young ≈øhootes of a ≈øad greene with very few or no thornes at all vpon them: the leaues are of a ≈øadder greene colour then in mo≈øt ≈øorts of Ro≈øes, and very often ≈øeuen on a ≈øtalke, many of the re≈øt hauing but fiue: the Ro≈øe is eyther ≈øingle or double: the ≈øingle is a broade ≈øpread flower, con≈øi≈øting of fiue or ≈øixe broade leaues with many yellow threds in the middle: the double hath two rowes of leaues, the one large, which are outermo≈øt, the other ≈ømaller within, of a very deepe red crim≈øon colour like vnto crim≈øon veluet, with many yellow threds al≈øo in the middle; and yet for all the double rowe of leaues, the≈øe Ro≈øes ≈øtand but like ≈øingle flowers: but there is another double kinde that is more double then this la≈øt, con≈øi≈øting oftentimes of ≈øixteene leaues or more in a flower, and mo≈øt of them of an equall bigne≈ø≈øe, of the colour of the fir≈øt ≈øingle ro≈øe of this kinde, or ≈øomewhat fre≈øher; but all of them of a ≈ømaller ≈øent then the ordinary red Ro≈øe.

div.head: 14. Ro≈øa ≈øine ≈øpinis ≈øimplex & multiplex. The Ro≈øe without thornes ≈øingle and double.
div.p: The Ro≈øe without thornes hath diuers greene ≈ømooth ≈øhootes, ri≈øing from the root, without any pricke or thorne at all vpon them, eyther young or old: the leaues are not fully ≈øo large as of the red ro≈øe: the flowers or ro≈øes are not much bigger then tho≈øe of the double Cinamon Ro≈øe, thicke ≈øet together and ≈øhort, of a pale red Ro≈øe colour, with diuers pale coloured ve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es through euery leafe of the flower, which hath cau≈øed ≈øome to call it The marbled Ro≈øe, and is of a ≈ømall ≈øent, not fully equall to the red Ro≈øe. The ≈øingle of this kinde differeth not in any other thing from the former, then in the doublene≈ø≈øe or ≈øinglene≈ø≈øe of the flowers, which in this are not halfe ≈øo double, nor yet fully ≈øingle, and are of a paler red colour.
Ro≈øa ≈øine ≈øpina flore albo.I haue heard likewi≈øe of a white Ro≈øe of this kinde, but I haue ≈øeene none ≈øuch as yet, and therefore I can ≈øay no more thereof.

div.head: 15. Ro≈øa Cinamomea ≈øimplex & multiplex. The Cinamon Ro≈øe ≈øingle and double.
div.p: The ≈øingle Cinamon Ro≈øe hath his ≈øhootes ≈øomewhat red, yet not ≈øo red as the double kinde, armed with great thornes, like almo≈øt vnto the Eglantine bu≈øh, thereby ≈øhowing, as well by the multiplicitie of his ≈øhootes, as the quickne≈ø≈øe and height of his ≈øhooting, his wilde nature: On the ≈øtemme and branches ≈øtand winged leaues, ≈øometimes ≈øeuen or more together, which are ≈ømall and greene, yet like vnto other Ro≈øes. The Ro≈øes are ≈øingle, of fiue leaues a peece, ≈øomewhat large, and of a pale red colour, like vnto the double kinde, which is in ≈øhootes redder, and in all other things like vnto the ≈øingle, but bearing ≈ømall, ≈øhort, thicke and double Ro≈øes, ≈øomewhat like vnto the Ro≈øe without thornes, but a little le≈ø≈øer, of a paler red colour at the end of the leaues, and ≈øomewhat redder and brighter toward the middle of them, with many yellow ≈øhort thrumes; the ≈ømall ≈øent of Cinamon that is found in the flowers hath cau≈øed it to beare the name.

div.head: 16. Ro≈øalutea ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle yellow Ro≈øe.
div.p: This ≈øingle yellow Ro≈øe is planted rather for variety then any other good v≈øe. It often groweth to a good height, his ≈øtemme being great and wooddy, with few or no prickes vpon the old wood, but with a number of ≈ømall prickes like haires, thicke ≈øet, vpon the younger branches, of a darke colour ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, the barke of the young ≈øhootes being of a ≈øad greene reddi≈øh colour: the leaues of this Ro≈øe bu≈øh are ≈ømaller, rounder pointed, of a paler greene colour, yet finely ≈ønipt about the edges, and more in number, that is, ≈øeuen or nine on a ≈øtalke or ribbe, then in any other Garden kinde, except the double of the ≈øame kinde that followeth next: the flower is a ≈ømall ≈øingle Ro≈øe, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, not ≈øo large as the ≈øingle Spani≈øh Muske Ro≈øe, but ≈øomewhat bigger then the Eglantine or ≈øweete Briar Ro≈øe, of a fine pale yellow colour, without any great ≈øent at all while it is fre≈øh, but a little more, yet ≈ømall and weake when it is dryed.

div.head: 17. Ro≈øa lutea multiplex ≈øiue flore pleno. The double yellow Ro≈øe.
div.p: The double yellow Ro≈øe is of great account, both for the rarity, and doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower, and had it ≈øent to the re≈øt, would of all other be of highe≈øt e≈øteeme. The ≈øtemme or ≈øtocke, the young ≈øhoots or branches, the ≈ømall hairy prickes, and the ≈ømall winged leaues, are in all parts like vnto the former ≈øingle kinde; the chiefe≈øt difference con≈øi≈øteth in the doublene≈ø≈øe of the flower or Ro≈øe, which is ≈øo thicke and double, that very often it breaketh out on one ≈øide or another, and but a few of them abiding whole and faire in our Countrey, the cau≈øe whereof wee doe imagine to bee the much moi≈øture of our Countrey, and the time of flowring being ≈øubiect to much raine and ≈øhowers; many therefore doe either plant it again≈øt a wall, or other wayes defend it by couering: againe, it is ≈øo plentifull in young ≈øhootes or branches, as al≈øo in flowers at the toppe of euery branch, which are ≈ømall and weake for the mo≈øt part, that they are not able to bring all the flowers to ripene≈ø≈øe; and therefore mo≈øt of them fall or wither away without comming to perfection (the remedy that many doe v≈øe for this inconuenience la≈øt recited is, that they nippe away mo≈øt of the buds, leauing but ≈øome few vpon it, that ≈øo the vigour of the plant may be collected into a few flowers, whereby they may the better come to perfection, and yet euen thus it is hardly effected) which are of a yellowi≈øh greene colour in the bud, and before they be blowne open, but then are of a faire yellow colour, very full of leaues, with many ≈øhort haires rather then leaues in the middle, and hauing ≈øhort, round, greene, ≈ømooth buttons, almo≈øt flat vnder them: the flower being faire blowne open, doth ≈øcarce giue place for largene≈ø≈øe, thickne≈ø≈øe, and doublene≈ø≈øe, vnto the great Prouence or Holland Ro≈øe. This Ro≈øe bu≈øh or plant is very tender with vs here about London, and will require ≈øome more care and keeping then the ≈øingle of this kinde, which is hardy enough; for I haue lo≈øt many my ≈øelfe, and I know but a few about this towne that can nour≈øe it vp kindly, to beare or ≈øcarce to abide without peri≈øhing; but abideth well in euery free aire of all or the mo≈øt parts of this Kingdome: but (as I heare) not ≈øo well in the North.

div.head: 18. Ro≈øa Mo≈øchata ≈øimplex & multiplex. The Muske Ro≈øe ≈øingle and double.
div.p:
The Muske Ro≈øe both ≈øingle and double, ri≈øe vp oftentimes to a very great height, that it ouergroweth any arbour in a Garden, or being ≈øet by an hou≈øe ≈øide, to bee ten or twelue foote high, or more, but more e≈øpecially the ≈øingle kinde, with many green farre ≈øpread branches, armed with a few ≈øharpe great thornes, as the wilder ≈øorts of Ro≈øes are, whereof the≈øe are accounted to be kindes, hauing ≈ømall darke greene leaues on them, not much bigger then the leaues of Eglantine: the flowers come forth at the toppes of the branches, many together as it were in an vmbell or tuft, which for the mo≈øt part doe flower all at a time, or not long one after another, euery one ≈øtanding on a pretty long ≈øtalke, and are of a pale whiti≈øh or creame colour, both the ≈øingle and
the double; the ≈øingle being ≈ømall flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, with many yellow threads in the middle: and the double bearing more double flowers, as if they were once or twice more double then the ≈øingle, with yellow thrummes al≈øo in the middle, both of them of a very ≈øweete and plea≈øing ≈ømell, re≈øembling Muske: ≈øome there be that haue auouched, that the chiefe≈øt ≈øent of tho≈øe Ro≈øes con≈øi≈øteth not in the leaues, but in the threads of the flowers.

div.head: 19. Ro≈øa Mo≈øchata multiplex altera: alijs Dama≈øcena alba, vel veri≈øimilior Cinamomea flore pleno albo. The double white Damaske Muske Ro≈øe.
div.p: This other kinde of Muske Ro≈øe (which with ≈øome is called the white Damaske Muske, but more truely the double white Cinamon Ro≈øe) hath his ≈øtemme and branches al≈øo ≈øhorter then the former, but as greene: the leaues are ≈øomewhat larger, and of a whiter greene colour; the flowers al≈øo are ≈øomewhat larger then the former double kinde, but ≈øtanding in vmbels after the ≈øame manner, or ≈øomewhat thicker, and of the ≈øame whiti≈øh colour, or a little whiter, and ≈øomewhat, although but a little, neare the ≈ømell of the other, but nothing ≈øo ≈øtrong. This flowreth at the time of other Ro≈øes, or ≈øomewhat later, yet much before the former two ≈øorts of Muske Ro≈øes, which flower not vntill the end of Summer, and in Autumne; both which things, that is, the time of the flowring, and the ≈øent being both different, ≈øhew plainly it cannot be of the tribe of Muske Ro≈øes.

div.head: 20. Ro≈øa Hi≈øpanica Mo≈øchata ≈øimplex. The Spani≈øh Muske Ro≈øe.
div.p: This Spani≈øh Ro≈øe ri≈øeth to the height of the Eglantine, and ≈øometimes higher, with diuers great greene branches, the leaues whereof are larger and greener then of the former kindes: the flowers are ≈øingle Ro≈øes, con≈øi≈øting of fiue whiter leaues then in any of the former Muske Ro≈øes, and much larger, hauing ≈øometimes an eye of a blu≈øh in the white, of a very ≈øweete ≈ømell, comming neare≈øt vnto the la≈øt recited Muske Ro≈øe, as al≈øo for the time of the flowring.

div.head: 21. Ro≈øa Pomifera maior. The great Apple Ro≈øe.
div.p: The ≈øtemme or ≈øtocke of this Ro≈øe is great, couered with a darke grayi≈øh barke, but the younger branches are ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, armed here and there with great and ≈øharpe thornes, but nothing ≈øo great or plentifull as in the Eglantine, although it be a wilde kinde: the leaues are of a whiti≈øh greene colour, almo≈øt like vnto the fir≈øt white Ro≈øe, and fiue alwaies ≈øet together, but ≈øeldome ≈øeuen: the flowers are ≈ømall and ≈øingle, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, without any ≈øent, or very little, and little bigger then tho≈øe of the Eglantine bu≈øh, and of the very ≈øame deepe blu≈øh colour, euery one ≈øtanding vpon a rough or prickly button, bearded in the manner of other Ro≈øes, which when the flowers are fallen growe great, ≈øomewhat long and round, peare-fa≈øhion, bearing the beards on the tops of them; and being full ripe are very red, keeping the ≈ømall prickles ≈øtill on them, wherein are many white, hard, and roundi≈øh ≈øeedes, very like vnto the ≈øeede of the Heppes or Eglantine berries, lying in a ≈øoft pulpe, like vnto the Hawthorne berries or Hawes: the whole beauty of this plant con≈øi≈øteth more in the gracefull a≈øpect of the red apples or fruit hanging vpon the bu≈øhes, then in the flowers, or any other thing. It ≈øeemeth to be the ≈øame that Clu≈øius calleth Ro≈øa Pumila, but that with me it groweth much higher and greater then he ≈øaith his doth.

div.head: 22. Ro≈øa ≈øilue≈øtris odora ≈øiue Eglenteria ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle Eglantine or ≈øweete Briar bu≈øh.
div.p:
The ≈øweete Briar or Eglantine Ro≈øe is ≈øo well knowne, being not onely planted in Gardens, for the ≈øweetene≈ø≈øe of the leaues, but growing wilde in many woods and hedges, that I thinke it lo≈øt time to de≈øcribe it; for that all know it hath exceeding long greene ≈øhootes, armed with the cruelle≈øt ≈øharpe and ≈øtrong thornes, and thicker ≈øet
1
‚Ä¢ o≈øa ≈øine ≈øpinis multiplex. The double Ro≈øe without thorns. 2 Ro≈øa Cinamomea flore pleno. The double Cinamon Ro≈øe. 3 Ro≈øa Holo≈øerica ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle Veluet Ro≈øe. 4 Ro≈øa Holo≈øerica duplex. The double Veluet Ro≈øe. 5 Ro≈øa M ‚Ä¢ ≈øchata multiplex. The double Muske Ro≈øe. 6 Ro≈øa Mo≈øchata Hi≈øpanica ≈øimplex. The ≈øingle Spani≈øh Muske Ro≈øe. 7 Ro≈øa Pomiferae maior. The great Apple Ro≈øe. 8 Ro≈øa ≈øilue≈øtris ≈øiue Eglanteria duplex. The double Eglantine Ro≈øe. depiction of flowers
then is in any Ro≈øe either wilde or tame: the leaues are ≈ømaller then in mo≈øt of tho≈øe that are nour≈øed vp in Gardens, ≈øeuen or nine mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øet together on a
‚Ä¢ ibbe or ≈øtalke, very greene and ≈øweete in ≈ømell, aboue the leaues of any other kinde of Ro≈øe: the flowers are ≈ømall ≈øingle blu≈øh Ro≈øes, of little or no ≈øent at all, which turne into reddi≈øh berries, ≈øtuffed within with a dounie or flocky matter or ≈øub≈øtance, wherein doth lye white hard ≈øeede.

div.head: 23. Ro≈øa ≈øilue≈øtris odora ≈øiue Eglenteria flore duplici. The double Eglantine.
div.p: The double Eglantine is in all the places that I haue ≈øeene it a grafted Ro≈øe, (but I doubt not, but that his originall was naturall, and that it may be made naturall againe, as diuers other Ro≈øes are.) It groweth and ≈øpreadeth very well, and with a great head of branches, whereon ≈øtand ≈øuch like leaues as are in the ≈øingle kinde, but a little larger, not ≈ømelling fully ≈øo ≈øweete as it: the flowers are ≈øomewhat bigger then the ≈øingle, but not much, hauing but one other rowe of leaues onely more then the former, which are ≈ømaller, and the outer leaues larger, but of the ≈øame pale reddi≈øh purple colour, and ≈ømelleth ≈øomewhat better then the ≈øingle.

div.head: 24. Ro≈øa ≈øemper virens. The euer greene Ro≈øe bu≈øh.
div.p: This Ro≈øe or bu≈øh is very like vnto a wilde ≈øingle Eglantine bu≈øh in many re≈øpects, hauing many very long greene branches, but more ≈ølender and weake, ≈øo that many times they bead downe againe, not able to ≈øu≈øtaine them≈øelues without ≈øome helpe, and armed with hooked thornes as other Ro≈øes be; the winged leaues con≈øi≈øt of ≈øeuen for the mo≈øt part, whereof tho≈øe two that are lowe≈øt and oppo≈øite, are ≈ømalle≈øt, the next two bigger then they, the third couple bigger then any of the re≈øt belowe, and the end leafe bigge≈øt of all: this proportion generally it holdeth in euery winged leafe through the whole plant, which at the fir≈øt comming forth are ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh, with the young branch that ≈øhooteth out with them, but being full growne, are of a deepe greene colour, and ≈øomewhat ≈øhining, dented about the edges, and fall not away from the branches as other Ro≈øes doe, but abide thereon for the mo≈øt part all the Winter: the flowers ≈øtand foure or fiue together at the tops of the branches, being ≈øingle Ro≈øes, made of fiue leaues a peece, of a pure white colour, much larger then the ordinary Muske Ro≈øe, and of a fine ≈øent, comming neare≈øt thereunto, with many yellow chiues or threads in the middle.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Some of the≈øe Ro≈øes had their originall, as is thought in England, as the fir≈øt and ≈øecond; for the≈øe dryed red Ro≈øes that come ouer to vs from beyond the Seas, are not of the kinde of our red Ro≈øe, as may well be perceiued by them that will compare our Engli≈øh dryed leaues with tho≈øe. Some in Germany, Spaine, and Italy. Some againe in Turkie, as the double yellow Ro≈øe, which fir≈øt was procured to be brought into England, by Ma≈øter Nicholas Lete, a worthy Merchant of London, and a great louer of flowers, from Con≈øtantinople, which (as wee heare) was fir≈øt brought thither from Syria; but peri≈øhed quickly both with him, and with all other to whom hee imparted it: yet afterwards it was ≈øent to Ma≈øter Iohn de Franqueuille, a Merchant al≈øo of London, and a great louer of all rare plants, as well as flowers, from which is ≈øprung the greate≈øt ≈øtore, that is now flouri≈øhing in this Kingdome.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Cinamon Ro≈øe is the earlie≈øt for the mo≈øt part, which flowreth with vs about the middle of May, and ≈øometimes in the beginning. The ordinary Muske Ro≈øes both ≈øingle and double flower late≈øt, as is ≈øaid. All the other flower much about one time, in the beginning of Iune, or there abouts, and continue flowring all that moneth, and the next throughout for the mo≈øt part, and the red vntill Augu≈øt be halfe pa≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The ≈øeuerall names, whereby they are mo≈øt commonly knowne vnto vs in this Countrey, are expre≈ø≈øed in their titles; but they are much differing from what they are called in other Countries neare vnto vs, which to compare, conferre, and agree together, were a worke of more paines then v≈øe: But to proportion them vnto the names ≈øet downe by Theophra≈øtus, Pliny, and the re≈øt of the ancient Authors, were a worke, wherein I might be ≈øure not to e≈øcape without falling into errour, as I verily beleeue many others haue done, that haue vndertaken to doe it: I will therefore for this worke de≈øire that you will re≈øt contented, with ≈øo much as hath already been deliuered, and expect an exact definition and complete ≈øatisfaction by ≈øuch a methodicall cour≈øe as a generall Hi≈øtory will require, to be performed by them that ≈øhall publi≈øh it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Ro≈øe is of exceeding great v≈øe with vs; for the Damaske Ro≈øe (be≈øides the ≈øuperexcellent ≈øweete water it yeeldeth being di≈øtilled, or the perfume of the leaues being dryed, ≈øeruing to fill ≈øweete bags) ≈øerueth to cau≈øe ≈øolublene≈ø≈øe of the body, made into a Syrupe, or pre≈øerued with Sugar moi≈øt or dry candid. The Damaske Prouince Ro≈øe, is not onely for ≈øent neare≈øt of all other Ro≈øes vnto the Damaske, but in the operation of ≈øolubility al≈øo. The red Ro≈øe hath many Phy≈øicall v≈øes much more then any other, ≈øeruing for many ≈øorts of compo≈øitions, both cordiall and cooling, both binding and loo≈øing. The white Ro≈øe is much v≈øed for the cooling of heate in the eyes: diuers doe make an excellent yellow colour of the iuyce of white Ro≈øes, wherein ≈øome Allome is di≈ø≈øolued, to paint or colour flowers or pictures, or any other ≈øuch things. There is little v≈øe of any other ≈øort of Ro≈øes; yet ≈øome affirme, that the Muske Ro≈øes are as ≈øtrong in operation to open or loo≈øen the belly as the Damaske Ro≈øe or Prouince.

div.head: Ci≈øtus. The Holly Ro≈øe or Sage Ro≈øe.
div.p: THere are three principall kindes of Ci≈øtus, the male, the female, and the gumme or ≈øweete ≈ømelling Ci≈øtus bearing Ladanum, called Ledon. Of each of the≈øe three there are al≈øo diuers ≈øorts: Of them all to intreate in this worke is not my minde, I will onely ≈øelect out of the multitude ≈øome few that are fit for this our Garden, and leaue the re≈øt to a greater.

div.head: 1. Ci≈øtus mas. The male Holly Ro≈øe or Sage Ro≈øe.
div.p:
The male Ci≈øtus that is mo≈øt familiar vnto our Countrey, I meane that will be≈øt abide, is a ≈ømall ≈øhrubby plant, growing ≈øeldome aboue three or foure foote high with vs, hauing many ≈ølender brittle wooddy branches, couered with a whiti≈øh barke, whereon are ≈øet many whiti≈øh greene leaues, long and ≈øomewhat narrow, crumpled or wrinckled as it were with veines, and ≈øomewhat hard in handling, e≈øpecially the old ones; for the young ones are ≈øofter, ≈øomewhat like vnto Sage leaues for the forme and colour, but much ≈ømaller, two alwaies ≈øet together at a ioynt: the flowers ≈øtand at the toppe of the branches, three or foure together vpon ≈øeuerall ≈ølender foot≈øtalkes, con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall round leaues a peece, ≈øomewhat like vnto a ≈ømall ≈øingle Ro≈øe, of a fine reddi≈øh purple colour, with many yellow threads in the middle, without
any ≈øent at all, and quickly fading or falling away, abiding ≈øeldome one whole day blowne at the mo≈øt: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp round hard hairie heads in their places, containing ≈ømall browni≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is wooddy, and will abide ≈øome yeares with vs, if there be ≈øome care had to keepe it from the extreamity of our Winters fro≈øtes, which both this, and many of the other ≈øorts and kinds, will not abide doe what we can.

div.head: 2. Ci≈øtus faemina. The female Holly Ro≈øe.
div.p: The female Holly Ro≈øe groweth lower, and ≈ømaller then the former male kinde, hauing blacki≈øh branches, le≈ø≈øe woody, but not le≈ø≈øe brittle then it: the leaues are ≈øomewhat rounder and greener, but a little hard or rough withall, growing in the ≈øame manner vpon the branches by couples: the flowers grow at the toppes of the branches, like vnto the former, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, but ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer, and wholly white, with yellow threds in the middle, as quickly fading, and of as little ≈øent as the former: the heads and ≈øeede are ≈øomewhat bigger then in the former.

div.head: 3. Chamaecistus Fri≈øicus. The dwarfe Holly Ro≈øe of Fri≈øeland.
div.p: This dwarfe Ci≈øtus is a ≈ømall low plant, hauing diuers ≈øhootes from the rootes, full of leaues that are long and narrow, very like vnto the leaues of the French Spikenard or Spica Celtica; from among which leaues ≈øhoote forth ≈øhort ≈øtalkes, not aboue a ≈øpan high, with a few ≈ømaller leaues thereon; and at the toppes diuers ≈ømall flowers one aboue another, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix ≈ømall round leaues, of a yellow colour, hauing two circles of reddi≈øh ≈øpots round about the bottome of the leaues, a little di≈øtant one from another, which adde much grace to the flower: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places ≈ømall round heads, being two forked at the end, containing within them ≈ømall browni≈øh chaffie ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall and ≈ølender, with many fibres thereat creeping vnder ground, and ≈øhooting forth in diuers places, whereby it much encrea≈øeth: the whole plant, and euery part of it, ≈ømelleth ≈øtrong without any plea≈øant ≈øent.

div.head: 4. Cistus annuus. The Holly Ro≈øe of a yeare.
div.p: This ≈ømall Ci≈øtus that endureth but a year (and will require to be ≈øowne euery year, if ye will haue it) ri≈øeth vp with ≈øtraight, but ≈ølender hard ≈øtalkes, ≈øet here and there confu≈øedly with long and narrow greeni≈øh leaues, very like vnto the leaues of the Gum Ci≈øtus or Ledon, being a little clammy withall: at the toppe of the ≈øtalkes, and at the ioynts with the leaues, ≈øtand two or three pale yellow flowers, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, with a reddi≈øh ≈øpot neere the bottome of euery leafe of the flower, as quickely fading as any of the former: after which follow ≈ømall three ≈øquare heades, containing ≈ømall ≈øeede, like vnto the fir≈øt female kinde, but ≈øomewhat paler or yellower: the root is ≈ømall and woody, and peri≈øheth as ≈øoone as it hath borne ≈øeede.

div.head: 5. Cistus Ledon. The Gum Ci≈øtus, or Sweete Holly Ro≈øe.
div.p:
This ≈øweete Holly Ro≈øe or Gum Ci≈øtus, ri≈øeth higher, and ≈øpreadeth larger then the former male kind doth, with many blacki≈øh woody branches, whereon are ≈øet diuers long and narrow darke greene leaues, but whiti≈øh vnderneath, two alwayes ≈øtanding together at a ioint, both ≈øtalks and leaues bedeawed as it were continually with a clammy ≈øweete moi≈øture (which in the hot Countries is both more plentifull, and more ≈øweet then in ours) almo≈øt tran≈øparent, and which being gathered by the inhabitants, with certaine in≈øtruments for that purpo≈øe (which in ≈øome places are leather thongs, drawne ouer the bu≈øhes, and after ≈øcraped off from the thongs againe, and put together) is that kind of blacke ≈øweet gum, which is called Ladanum in the Apothecaries ≈øhops: at the tops of the branches ≈øtand ≈øingle white flowers, like vnto ≈øingle Ro≈øes, being larger then in any of the former kindes, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues, whereof euery one hath at the bottome a dark purpli≈øh ≈øpot, broad below, and ≈ømall pointed vpwards, with ≈øome yellow threds in the middle: after which are pa≈øt, there ari≈øe cornered
1 Ci≈øtus mas The male Holly Ro≈øe. 2 Chamaecistus Fri≈øucus. The dwarfe Holly Ro≈øe of Fri≈øia. 3 Ci≈øtus Ledon. The ≈øweet Holly Ro≈øe or gumme Ci≈øtus. 4 Ledum Alpinum. The mountaine Holly Ro≈øe. 5 Ledum Sile≈øiacum. The ≈øweet Mary Ro≈øe of Sile≈øia. 6 Ro≈ømarinum aureum. Gilded Ro≈øemary. depiction of flowers
heads, containing ≈øuch ≈ømall browni≈øh ≈øeede as is in the former male kinde: the roote is woody, and ≈øpreadeth vnder ground, abiding ≈øome yeares, if it be placed vnder a wall, where it may bee defended from the windes that often breake it, and from the extremitie of our winters, and e≈øpecially the ≈ønow, if it lye vpon it, which quickly cau≈øeth it to peri≈øh.

div.head: 6. Ledum Alpinum ≈øeu Ro≈øa Alpina. The Mountaine ≈øweet Holly Ro≈øe.
div.p: The fragrant ≈ømell with properties corre≈øpondent of two other plants, cau≈øeth me to in≈øert them in this Chapter, and to bring them to your knowledge, as well worthy a fit place in our Garden. The fir≈øt of them hath diuers flender woody branches, two foote high or thereabouts, couered with a grayi≈øh coloured barke, and many times leaning downe to the ground, whereby it taketh roote againe: vpon the≈øe branches grow many thicke, ≈øhort, hard greene leaues, thicke ≈øet together, confu≈øedly without order, ≈øometimes whiti≈øh vnderneath, and ≈øometimes yellowi≈øh: the toppes of the branches are loden with many flowers, which cau≈øe them to bend downwards, being long, hollow and reddi≈øh, opening into fiue corners, ≈øpotted on the out≈øide with many white ≈øpots, and of a paler red colour on the in≈øide, of a fine ≈øweet ≈øent: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there follow ≈ømall heads, containing ≈ømall browni≈øh ≈øeede: the root is long, hard and woody, abiding better if it comprehend in the ground, then ≈øome of the former, becau≈øe his originall is out of a colder country.

div.head: 7. Ledum Sile≈øiacum. The ≈øweete Mary Ro≈øe, or Ro≈øemary of Sile≈øia.
div.p: This other ≈øweete plante ri≈øeth vp with woody a≈øh-coloured branches two foote high or more, which ≈øhoote forth other branches, of a reddi≈øh or purpli≈øh colour, couered with a browni≈øh yellow hoarine≈ø≈øe, on which are ≈øet many narrow long greene leaues, like vnto Ro≈øemary leaues, but couered with the like hoarine≈ø≈øe as the ≈øtalks are (e≈øpecially in the naturall places, but not ≈øo much being tran≈øplanted) and folding the ≈øides of the leaues ≈øo clo≈øe together, that they ≈øeeme nothing but ribbes, or ≈øtalkes, of an excellent ≈øweet and plea≈øant ≈øent; at the ends of the branches there grow certaine browni≈øh ≈øcaly heads, made of many ≈ømall leaues ≈øet thicke together, out of which breake forth many flowers, ≈øtanding in a tuft together, yet ≈øeuerally euery one vpon his owne foot≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of fiue white leaues, with certaine white threds in the middle, ≈ømelling very ≈øweete: after which ri≈øe ≈ømall greene heads, ≈øpotted with browni≈øh ≈øpots, wherein is contained very ≈ømall, long, yellowi≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is hard and woodie.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt, ≈øecond, fourth and fifth, grow in the hot Countries, as Italie, Spaine, &c. The third, and the two la≈øt in the colder Countries, as Fri≈øeland, Germanie, Bohemia.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They do all flower in the Summer moneths of Iune, Iuly and Augu≈øt, and their ≈øeede is ripe quickly after.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The fir≈øt, ≈øecond, fourth and fift, haue their names ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in their de≈øcriptions. The third was ≈øent vnto Clu≈øius, vnder the name of Herculus Fri≈øicus, becau≈øe of the ≈øtrong ≈øent: but he referreth it to the kinds of Chamaeci≈øtus, that is, dwarfe or low Cistus, both for the low growth, and for the flowers and ≈øeede ≈øake. The ≈øixt is diuer≈øly called; for Clu≈øius calleth it Ledum Alpinum: others, Nerium Alpinum, making it to bee a Ro≈øe Bay.
Ge≈øner according to the Countrey peoples name, Ro≈øa Alpina, and Ro≈øa Montana. Lobel calleth it Bal≈øamum Alpinum, of the fragrant ≈ømell it hath, and Chamaerbododendros Chamaelaeae folio. And ≈øome haue called it Euonymus, without all manner of iudgement. In Engli≈øh wee may call it, The Mountaine Ro≈øe, vntill a fitter name be giuen it. The la≈øt is called of Matthiolus, Ro≈ømarinum ≈øilue≈øtre, but of Clu≈øius Ledum, referring it to their kindred; and Sile≈øiacum, becau≈øe he found it in that Countrey; or for di≈øtinction ≈øake, as he ≈øaith, it may bee called, Ledum folijs Ro≈ømarini, or Ledum Bohemicum. Cordus, as it ≈øeemeth in his Hi≈øtory of Plants, calleth it Chamaepeuce, as though he did account it a kinde of low Pine, or Pitch tree.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and fift, are very a≈øtringent, effectuall for all ≈øorts of fluxes of humours. The ≈øweet Gum called Ladanum, made artificially into oyle, is of ≈øingular v≈øe for Alopecia, or falling of the haire. The ≈øeed of the fourth is much commended again≈øt the ≈øtone of the Kidneyes. The ≈øweete Ro≈øemary of Sile≈øia is v≈øed of the inhabitants, where it naturally groweth, again≈øt the ≈øhrinking of ≈øinewes, crampes, or other ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes, wherof their daily experience makes it familiar, being v≈øed in bathing or otherwi≈øe.

div.head: Ro≈ømarinum. Ro≈øemary.
div.p: THere hath beene v≈øually knowne but one ≈øort of Ro≈øemary, which is frequent through all this Country: but there are ≈øome other ≈øorts not ≈øo well known; the one is called Gilded Ro≈øemary; the other broadeleafed Ro≈øemary; a third I will adioyne, as more rare then all the other, called Double flowred Ro≈ømary, becau≈øe few haue heard thereof, much le≈ø≈øe ≈øeene it, and my ≈øelfe am not well acquainted with it, but am bold to deliuer it vpon credit.

div.head: 1. Libanotis Coronaria ≈øiue Ro≈ømarinum vulgare. Our Common Ro≈ømary.
div.p: This common Ro≈øemary is ≈øo well knowne through all our Land, being in euery womans garden, that it were ≈øufficient but to name it as an ornament among other ≈øweete herbes and flowers in our Garden, ≈øeeing euery one can de≈øcribe it: but that I may ≈øay ≈øomething of it, It is well ob≈øerued, as well in this our Land (where it hath been planted in Noblemens, and great mens gardens again≈øt bricke wals, and there continued long) as beyond the Seas, in the naturall places where it groweth, that it ri≈øeth vp in time vnto a very great height, with a great and woody ≈øtemme (of that compa≈ø≈øe, that (being clouen out into thin boards) it hath ≈øerued to make lutes, or ≈øuch like in≈øtruments, and here with vs Carpenters rules, and to diuers other purpo≈øes) branching out into diuers and ≈øundry armes that extend a great way, and from them againe into many other ≈ømaller branches, wheron are ≈øet at ≈øeueral di≈øtances, at the ioynts, many very narrow long leaues, greene aboue, and whiti≈øh vnderneath; among which come forth towards the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, diuers ≈øweet gaping flowers, of a pale or bleake blewi≈øh colour, many ≈øet together, ≈øtanding in whiti≈øh huskes; the ≈øeed is ≈ømall and red, but thereof ≈øeldome doth any plants ari≈øe that will abide without extraordinary care; for although it will ≈øpring of the ≈øeede rea≈øonable well, yet it is ≈øo ≈ømall and tender the fir≈øt yeare, that a ≈øharpe winter killeth it quickly, vnle≈ø≈øe it be very well defended: the whole plant as well leaues as flowers, ≈ømelleth exceeding ≈øweete.

div.head: 2. Ro≈ømarinum ≈øtriatum, ≈øiue aureum. Gilded Ro≈øemary.
div.p:
This Ro≈øemary differeth not from the former, in forme or manner of growing, nor
in the forme or colour of the flower, but only in the leaues, which are edged, or ≈øtriped, or pointed with a faire gold yellow colour, which ≈øo continueth all the yeare throughout, yet fre≈øher and fairer in Summer then in Winter; for then it will looke of a deader colour, yet ≈øo, that it may be di≈øcerned to be of two colours, green & yellow.

div.head: 3. Ro≈ømarinum latifolium. Broade leafed Ro≈øemary.
div.p: This broad leafed Ro≈øemary groweth in the ≈øame manner that the former doth, but that we haue not ≈øeene it in our Countrey ≈øince we had it to grow ≈øo great, or with ≈øuch woody ≈øtemmes: the leaues ≈øtand together vpon the long branches after the ≈øame fa≈øhion, but larger, broader and greener then the other, and little or nothing whiti≈øh vnderneath: the flowers likewi≈øe are of the ≈øame forme and colour with the ordinary but larger, and herein con≈øi≈øteth the difference.

div.head: 4. Ro≈ømarinum flore duplici. Double flowred Ro≈ømary.
div.p: The double flowred Ro≈ømary thus far differeth from the former, that it hath ≈øtronger ≈øtalkes, not ≈øo ea≈øie to breake, fairer, bigger and larger leaues, of a faire greene colour, and the flowers are double, as the Larkes heele or ≈øpurre: This I haue onely by relation, which I pray you accept, vntill I may by ≈øight better enforme you.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Our ordinary Ro≈ømary groweth in Spaine, and Prouence of France, and in others of tho≈øe hot Countryes, neere the Sea ≈øide. It will not abide (vnle≈ø≈øe kept in ≈øtoues) in many places of Germany, Denmarke, and tho≈øe colder Countries. And in ≈øome extreame hard winters, it hath well neere peri≈øhed here in England with vs, at the lea≈øt in many places: but by ≈ølipping it is v≈øually, and yearly encrea≈øed, to repleni≈øh any garden.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth oftentimes twice in the yeare; in the Spring fir≈øt, from April vntill the end of May or Iune, and in Augu≈øt and September after, if the yeare before haue been temperate.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Ro≈ømary is called of the ancient Writers, Libanotis, but with this di≈øtinction, Stephanomatica, that is, Coronaria, becau≈øe there were other plants called Libanotis, that were for other v≈øes, as this for garlands, where flowers and ≈øweete herbes were put together. The Latines call it Ro≈ømarinum. Some would make it to be Cneorum nigrum of Theophra≈øtus, as they would make Lauander to bee his Cneorum album, but Matthiolus hath ≈øufficiently confuted that errour.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
Ro≈ømary is almo≈øt of as great v≈øe as Bayes, or any other herbe both for inward and outward remedies, and as well for ciuill as phy≈øicall purpo≈øes. Inwardly for the head and heart; outwardly for the ≈øinewes and ioynts: for ciuill v≈øes, as all doe know, at weddings, funerals, &c. to be≈øtow among friends: and the phy≈øicall are ≈øo many, that you might bee as well tyred in the reading, as I in the writing, if I ≈øhould ≈øet down all that might be ≈øaid of it. I will therefore onely giue you a ta≈øte of ≈øome, de≈øiring you will be content therewith. There is an excellent oyle drawne from the flowers alone by the heate of the Sunne, auaileable for many di≈øea≈øes both inward and outward, and accounted a ≈øoueraigne Bal≈øame: it is al≈øo good to helpe dimne≈ø≈øe
of ≈øight, and to take away ≈øpots, markes and ≈øcarres from the skin; and is made in this manner. Take a quantitie of the flowers of Ro≈øemary, according to your owne will eyther more or le≈ø≈øe, put them into a ≈øtrong gla≈ø≈øe clo≈øe ≈øtopped, ≈øet them in hot hor≈øe dung to dige≈øt for fourteene dayes, which then being taken forth of the dung, and vn≈øtopped, tye a fine linnen cloth ouer the mouth, and turne downe the mouth thereof into the mouth of another ≈øtrong gla≈ø≈øe, which being ≈øet in the hot Sun, an oyle will di≈øtill downe into the lower gla≈ø≈øe; which pre≈øerue as precious for the v≈øes before recited, and many more, as experience by practice may enforme diuers.

There is another oyle Chymically drawne, auaileable in the like manner for many the ≈øame inward and outward di≈øea≈øes, viz. for the heart, rheumaticke braines, and to ≈øtrengthen the memory, outwardly to warme and comfort cold benummed ≈øinewes, whereof many of good iudgement haue had much experience.

div.head: Myrtus. The Mirtle tree or bu≈øh.
div.p: IN the hot Countreyes, there haue been many ≈øorts of Mirtles found out, naturally growing there, which will not fructifie in this of ours, nor yet abide without extraordinary care, and conueniencie withall, to pre≈øerue them from the ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe of our winters. I ≈øhall only bring you to view three ≈øorts in this my Garden, the one with a greater, the other two with le≈ø≈øer leaues, as the remainder of others which wee haue had, and which are pre≈øerued from time to time, not without much paine and trouble.

div.head: 1. Myrtus latifolia. The greater leafed Mirtle.
div.p: The broader leafed Mirtle ri≈øeth vp to the height of foure or fiue foote at the mo≈øt with vs, full of branches and leaues growing like a ≈ømall bu≈øh, the ≈øtemme and elder branches whereof are couered with a dark coloured bark, but the young with a green, and ≈øome with a red, e≈øpecially vpon the fir≈øt ≈øhooting forth, whereon are ≈øet many fre≈øh greene leaues, very ≈øweet in ≈ømell, and very plea≈øant to behold, ≈øo neer re≈øembling the leaues of the Pomegranate tree that groweth with vs, that they ≈øoone deceiue many that are not expert therein, being ≈øomewhat broade and long, and pointed at the ends, abiding alwaies green: at the ioynts of the branches where the leaues ≈øtand, come forth the flowers vpon ≈ømall foote≈øtalkes, euery one by it ≈øelfe con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall white leaues, with white threds in the middle, ≈ømelling al≈øo very ≈øweet: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there doe ari≈øe in the hot Countries, where they are naturall, round blacke berries, when they are ripe, wherein are contained many hard white crooked ≈øeedes, but neuer in this Countrey, as I ≈øaid before: the roote di≈øper≈øeth it ≈øelfe into many branches, with many fibres annexed thereto.

div.head: 2. Myrtus minor, ≈øeu minore folio. The ≈ømaller leafed Mirtle.
div.p: The ≈ømaller leafed Mirtle is a low ≈øhrub or bu≈øh, like vnto the former, but ≈øcarce ri≈øing ≈øo high, with branches ≈øpreading about the ≈øtemme, much thicker ≈øet with leaues then the former, ≈ømaller al≈øo, and pointed at the ends, of a little deeper greene colour, abiding greene al≈øo winter and ≈øummer, and very ≈øweete likewi≈øe: the flowers are white like vnto the former, and as ≈øweete, but ≈øhew not them≈øelues ≈øo plentifull on the branches: the fruit is blacke in his naturall places, with ≈øeedes therein as the former.

div.head: 3. Myrtus minor rotundiore folio. Boxe Mirtle.
div.p:
Wee haue another ≈øort of this ≈ømall kinde of Mirtle, ≈øo like vnto the former both for ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe, deepe greene colour of the leaues, and thicke growing of the branches,
that it will be thought of mo≈øt, without good heede, and comparing the one with the other, to be the very ≈øame with the former: but if it bee well viewed, it will ≈øhew, by the roundne≈ø≈øe at the ends of the leaues very like vnto the ≈ømall Boxe leaues, to be another differing kinde, although in nothing el≈øe. Wee nour≈øe them with great care, for the beautifull a≈øpect, ≈øweete ≈øent and raritie, as delights and ornaments for a garden of plea≈øure, wherein nothing ≈øhould be wanting that art, care and co≈øt might produce and pre≈øerue: as al≈øo to ≈øet among other euer greene plants to ≈øort with them.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe, and many other ≈øorts of Mirtles grow in Spaine, Portugall, Italie, and other hot Countries in great aboundance, where they make their hedges of them: wee (as I ≈øaid) keepe them in this Countrey, with very great care and diligence.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The Mirtles doe flower very late with vs, not vntill Augu≈øt at the ≈øoone≈øt, which is the cau≈øe of their not fructifying.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: They are called in Latine Myrtus, and in Engli≈øh Mirtle tree, without any other diuer≈øitie of names, for the generall title. Yet the ≈øeuerall kindes haue had ≈øeuerall denominations, in Plinies time, and others, as Romana, Coningala, Terentina, Egyptia, alba, nigra, &c. which haue noted the differences, euen then well ob≈øerued.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The Mirtle is of an a≈øtringent qualitie, and wholly v≈øed for ≈øuch purpo≈øes.

div.head: Malus Punica ≈øiue Granata. The Pomegranet tree.
div.p: THere are two kindes of Pomegranet trees, The one tame or manured, bearing fruit, which is di≈øtingui≈øhed of ≈øome into two ≈øorts, of others into three, that is, into ≈øower, and ≈øweet, and into ≈øower ≈øweete. The other wilde, which beareth no fruite, becau≈øe it beareth double flowers, like as the Cherry, Apple, and Peach tree with double blo≈ø≈øomes, before de≈øcribed, and is al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed into two ≈øorts, the one bearing larger, the other le≈ø≈øer flowers. Of the manured kinde wee haue onely one ≈øort (≈øo farre as we know) for it neuer beareth ripe fruit in this our Countrey) which for the beautifull a≈øpect, both of the greene verdure of the leaues, and faire proportion and colour of the flowers, as al≈øo for the raritie, are nour≈øed in ≈øome few of their gardens that delight in ≈øuch rarities: for in regard of the tenderne≈ø≈øe, there is neede of diligent care, that is, to plant it again≈øt a brick wall, and defend it conueniently from the ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe of our winters, to giue his Ma≈øter ≈øome plea≈øure in ≈øeeing it beare flowers: And of the double kinde we haue as yet obtained but one ≈øort, although I ≈øhall giue you the knowledge and de≈øcription of another.

div.head: 1. Malus Punica ≈øatina. The tame Pomegranet tree.
div.p:
This Pomegranet tree groweth not very high in his naturall places, and with vs ≈øomtimes it ≈øhooteth forth from the roote many browni≈øh twigges or branches, or if it bee pruned from them, and ≈øuffered to grow vp, it ri≈øeth to bee ≈øeuen or eight foote high,
1 Myrus latifoli ‚Ä¢ maier. The b ‚Ä¢ oad leafed Myrtle. 2 Myrtu ‚Ä¢ augu≈øtifolia minor. The ≈ømall leafed Myrtle. 3 Myrtus bu ‚Ä¢ ifo ‚Ä¢ ia minor. The Boxe leafed Myrtle. 4 Malus Granatus ≈øimplici flore. The ordinary Pomegranet tree. 5 Balan≈øtium Romamum ≈øeu minus. The le≈ø≈øer double flowred Pomegranet tree. 6 Balau≈øtium maius ≈øiue Cyprium. The greater double flowred Pomegranet. 7 P≈øeudocap≈øicum ≈øeu Amonium Plinij. The Winter Cherry tree. 8 Ficus Indica cum ≈øuo fractu. The Indian Figgetree and his fruit. depiction of flowers
≈øpreading into many ≈ømall and ≈ølender branches, here and there ≈øet with thornes, and with many very faire greene ≈øhining leaues, like informe and bigne≈ø≈øe vnto the leaues of the larger Myrtle before de≈øcribed, euery one hauing a ≈ømall reddi≈øh foote-≈øtalke vpon the≈øe branches: among the leaues come forth here and there, long, hard, and hollow reddi≈øh cups, diuided at the brimmes, wherein doe ≈øtand large ≈øingle flowers, euery one con≈øi≈øting of one whole leafe, ≈ømaller at the bottome then at the brimme, like bels, diuided as it were at the edges into fiue or ≈øix parts, of an orient red or crim≈øon colour in the hotter Countries; but in this it is much more delayed, and tendeth neare vnto a blu≈øh, with diuers threads in the middle. The fruit is great and round, hauing as it were a crowne on the head of it, with a thicke tough hard skinne or rinde, of a browni≈øh red colour on the out≈øide, and yellow within, ≈øtuffed or packt full of ≈ømall graines, euery one encompa≈øt with a thin skin, wherein is contained a cleare red iuyce or liquor, either of a ≈øweet (as I ≈øaid before) or ≈øower ta≈øte, or betweene them both of a winie ta≈øte: the roote di≈øper≈øeth it ≈øelfe very much vnderground.

div.head: 2. Balau≈øtium maius ≈øiue Malus Punica ≈øilue≈øtris maior. The greater wilde or double blo≈ø≈øomd Pomegranet tree.
div.p: The wilde Pomegranet is like vnto the tame in the number of purpli≈øh branches, hauing thornes, and ≈øhining faire greene leaues, ≈øomewhat larger then the former: from the branches likewi≈øe ≈øhoote forth flowers, farre more beautifull then tho≈øe of the tame or manured ≈øort, becau≈øe they are double, and as large as a double Prouince Ro≈øe, or rather more double, of an excellent bright crim≈øon colour, tending to a ≈øilken carnation, ≈øtanding in browni≈øh cups or huskes, diuided at the brims v≈øually into foure or fiue ≈øeuerall points, like vnto the former, but that in this kinde there neuer followeth any fruit, no not in the Country, where it is naturally wilde.

div.head: 3. Balaustium minus. The ≈ømaller wilde Pomegranet tree.
div.p: This ≈ømaller kinde differeth from the former in his leaues, being of a darker greene colour, but not in the height of the ≈øtemme, or purpli≈øhne≈ø≈øe of his branches, or thorns vpon them; for this doth ≈øhew it ≈øelfe more like vnto a wilde kind then it: the flowers hereof are much ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo thicke and double, of a deeper or ≈øadder red Orenge tawny colour, ≈øet al≈øo in ≈øuch like cups or huskes.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The tame or manured kinde groweth plentifully in Spaine, Portugall, and Italy, and other in other warme and hot countries. Wee (as I ≈øaid before) pre≈øerue it with great care. The wilde I thinke was neuer ≈øeene in England, before Iohn Trade≈øcante my very louing good friend brought it from the parts beyond the Seas, and planted it in his Lords Garden at Canterbury.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower very late with vs, that is, not vntill the middle or end of Augu≈øt, and the cold euenings or fro≈øts comming ≈øo ≈øoone vpon it, doth not onely hinder it from bearing, but many times the ≈øharpe winters ≈øo pinch it, that it withereth it downe to the ground, ≈øo that oftentimes it hardly ≈øpringeth againe.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
The name Malus Punica for the tree, and Malum Punicum for the fruit, or Malus Granata, and Malum Granatum, is the common name giuen vnto this tree, which is called in Engli≈øh the Pomegarnet or Pomegranet tree. The flowers of the tame kinde are called Cytini, as Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith, although Plinie ≈øeemeth either to make Cytinus to be the flower of the wilde kinde, or
