Balaustium to be the flower of both tame and wilde kinde: but properly, as I take it, Cytinus is the cup wherein the flower as well of the came as wilde kinde doth ≈øtand; for vnto the ≈øimilitude of them, both the flowers of A≈øarum, and the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels of Hyo≈øciamus are compared and re≈øembled, and not vnto the whole flower: the barke or rinde of the fruit is called of diuers Sidion, and in the Apothecaries ≈øhops P≈øidium, and cortex Granatarum. The wilde kinde is called Malus Punica ≈øiluestris: In Engli≈øh, The wilde Pomegranet tree; the flower thereof is properly called Balau≈øtium. The le≈ø≈øer kind is v≈øually called Balau≈øtium Romanum, as the greater is called Creticum and Cyprinum, becau≈øe they growe in Candy and Cyprus.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The v≈øe of all the≈øe Pomegranets is very much in Phy≈øicke, to coole and binde all fluxibility both of body and humours: they are al≈øo of ≈øingular effect in all vlcers of the mouth, and other parts of the body, both of man and woman. There is no part of them but is applyed for ≈øome of the≈øe re≈øpects. The rinde al≈øo of the Pomegranet is v≈øed of diuers in ≈øtead of Gaules, to make the be≈øt ≈øort of writing Inke, which is durable to the worlds end.

div.head: Amonum Plinij ≈øeu P≈øeudocap≈øicum. Tree Night ≈øhade or the Winter Cherry tree.
div.p: I Haue adioyned this plant, for the plea≈øurable beauty of the greene leaues, and red berries. It groweth vp to be a yard or foure foote high at the mo≈øt, hauing a ≈ømall wooddy ≈øtemme or ≈øtocke, as bigge as ones finger or thumbe, couered with a whiti≈øh greene barke, ≈øet full of greene branches, and faire greene leaues, ≈øomewhat vneuen ≈øometimes on the edges, narrower then any Night ≈øhade leaues, and very neare re≈øembling the leaues of the Cap≈øicum, or Ginny pepper, but ≈ømaller and narrower, falling away in the Winter, and ≈øhooting fre≈øh in the Spring of the yeare: the flowers growe often two or three together, at the ioynts of the branches with the leaues, being white, opening ≈øtarre-fa≈øhion, and ≈øometimes turning them≈øelues backe, with a yellow pointell in the middle, very like vnto the flowers of Night ≈øhade: after the flowers are pa≈øt, come forth in their ≈øtead ≈ømall greene buttons, which after turne to be plea≈øant round red berries, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of ≈ømall Cherries when they are ripe, which with vs v≈øually ripen not vntill the Winter, or about Chri≈øtmas, wherein are contained many ≈ømall whiti≈øh ≈øeede that are flat: all the whole plant, as well leaues and flowers as ≈øeede, are without either ≈ømell or ta≈øte: the roote hath many yellowi≈øh ≈øtrings and fibres annexed vnto it.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The originall place hereof is not well knowne, but is thought to bee the We≈øt Indies. It hath been planted of long time in mo≈øt of the≈øe Countries, where it abideth rea≈øonable well, ≈øo that ≈øome care bee had thereof in the extreamity of the Winter.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth ≈øometimes in Iune, but v≈øually in Iuly and Augu≈øt, and the fruit is not ripe (as is ≈øaid) vntill the Winter.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: This plant hath diuers names; for it is thought to be that kinde of Amomum that Plinie ≈øetteth downe. Dodonaeus calleth it P≈øeudocapficum, for ≈øome likene≈ø≈øe in the leafe and fruit vnto the ≈ømall Cap≈øicum or Ginnie Pepper, although much vnlike in the ta≈øte and property. Others doe call it Strichnodendron, that is, Solanum arbore≈øcens, and wee in Engli≈øh according thereunto, Tree Night ≈øhade. But ≈øome Latine a≈ø≈øes corrupting the Latine word Amomum, doe call it the Mumme tree. Dalechampius calleth it Solanum Americum, ≈øeu Indicum, and ≈øaith the Spaniards call it in their tongue, Guindas de las Indias, that is, Cera≈øa Indiana, Indian Cherries, which if any would follow, I would not bee much again≈øt it: but many Gentlewomen doe call them Winter Cherries, becau≈øe the fruit is not throughly ripe vntill Winter.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: I finde no Phy≈øicall property allotted vnto it, more then that by rea≈øon of the in≈øipidity, it is held to be cooling.

div.head: Ficus Indica minor. The ≈ømaller Indian Figge tree.
div.p:
THis Indian Figge tree, if you will call it a tree (becau≈øe in our Country it is not ≈øo, although it groweth in the naturall hot Countries from a wooddy ≈øtemme or body into leaues) is a plant con≈øi≈øting only of leaues, one ≈øpringing out of another, into many branches of leaues, and all of them growing out of one leafe, put into the ground halfe way, which taking roote, all the re≈øt ri≈øe out thereof, tho≈øe belowe for the mo≈øt part being larger then tho≈øe aboue; yet all of them ≈øomewhat long, flat, and round pointed, of the thickne≈ø≈øe of a finger v≈øually, and ≈ømalle≈øt at the lower end, where they are ioyned or ≈øpring out of the other leaues, hauing at their fir≈øt breaking out a ≈øhew of ≈ømall, red, or browne prickes, thicke ≈øet ouer all the vpper ≈øide of the leaues, but with vs falling away quickly, leauing onely the markes where they ≈øtood: but they haue be≈øides this ≈øhew of great prickes, a few very fine, and ≈ømall, hard, white, and ≈øharpe, almo≈øt in≈øen≈øible prickes, being not ≈øo bigge as haires on the vnder≈øide, which will often ≈øticke in their fingers that handle them vnadui≈øedly, neither are they to be di≈øcerned vnle≈ø≈øe one look preci≈øely for them: the leaues on the vnder≈øide hauing none of tho≈øe other great pricks or marks at all, being of a faire fre≈øh pale green colour: out of the vppermo≈øt leaues breake forth certaine greene heads, very like vnto leaues (≈øo that many are deceiued, thinking them to be leaues, vntill they marke them better, and be better experienced in them) but that they growe round and not flat, and are broad at the toppe; for that out of the tops of euery of them ≈øhooteth out a pale yellow flower, con≈øi≈øting of two rowes of leaues, each containing fiue leaues a peece, laid open with certaine yellow threads, tipt with red in the middle: this greene head, vntill the flower be pa≈øt, is not of halfe that bigne≈ø≈øe that it attaineth vnto after, yet ≈øeldome or neuer commeth vnto perfection with vs, being long and round, like vnto a Figge, ≈ømall belowe, and greater aboue, bearing vpon the flat or broad head the marke of the flower; ≈øome holding ≈øtill on them the dryed leaues, and others hauing lo≈øt them, ≈øhew the hollowne≈ø≈øe which they haue in the toppe or middle of the head, the ≈øides round about being rai≈øed or ≈øtanding vp higher: this head or figge in our Country abideth greene on the out≈øide, and little or nothing reddi≈øh within (although it abide all the Winter, and the Summer following, as ≈øometimes it doth) for want of that heate and comfort of the Sunne it hath in his naturall place, where it groweth
reddi≈øh on the out≈øide, and containing within it a bloudy red clammy iuyce, making the vrine of them that eate of them as red as bloud, which many ≈øeeing, were in doubt of them≈øelues, le≈øt their vrine were not very bloud; of what ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, like a figge, in the naturall places, I am not well a≈ø≈øured, yet affirmed: but tho≈øe that haue beene brought vnto me, who≈øe colour on the out≈øide was greeni≈øh, were of a reddi≈øh purple within, and contained within them round, ≈ømall, hard ≈øeede, the ta≈øte was flat, wateri≈øh, or in≈øipide: the roote is neither great, nor di≈øper≈øeth it ≈øelfe very deepe or farre, but ≈øhooteth many ≈ømall rootes vnder the vpper cru≈øt of the earth.

There is a greater kinde hereof, who≈øe leaues are twice or thrice as bigge, which hauing been often brought vs, will ≈øeldome abide more then one Summer with vs, our Winters alwaies rotting the leaues, that it could not be longer kept.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This Indian Figge tree groweth di≈øper≈øedly in many places of America, generally called the We≈øt Indies: The greater kinde in the more remote and hot Countries, as Mexico, Florida, &c. and in the Bermudas or Summer I≈ølands, from whence wee haue often had it. The le≈ø≈øer in Virginia, and tho≈øe other Countries that are nearer vnto vs, which better endureth with vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth with vs ≈øometimes in May, or Iune; but (as I ≈øaid) the fruit neuer commeth to perfection in this Country.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Diuers doe take it to bee Opuntia Plinij, whereof hee ≈øpeaketh in the 21. Booke and 17. Chapter of his Naturall Hi≈øtory: but he there ≈øaith, Opuntia is an herbe, ≈øweete and plea≈øant to be eaten, and that it is a wonder that the roote ≈øhould come from the leafe, and ≈øo to growe; which words although they de≈øcipher out the manner of the growing of this plant, yet becau≈øe this is a kinde of tree, and not an herbe, nor to be eaten, it cannot bee the ≈øame: but e≈øpecially becau≈øe there is an herbe which groweth in the ≈øame manner, or very neare vnto it, one leafe ≈øtanding on the toppe or ≈øide of another, being a Sea plant, fit to be eaten with vinegar and oyle (as many other herbes are that growe in the ≈øalt mar≈øhes, or neare the Sea, whereof Sea Pur≈ølane is one) which Clu≈øius calleth Lychen Marinus, and (as Clu≈øius ≈øaith) Cortu≈øus very fitly called Opuntia marina, and out of doubt is the verie ≈øame Opuntia that Theophra≈øtus maketh mention of, and Plinie out of him. Our Engli≈øh people in Virginia, and the Bermuda I≈øland, where it groweth plentifully, becau≈øe of the form of the fruit, which is ≈øomewhat like to a Peare, & not being ≈øo familiarly acquainted with the growing of Figs, ≈øent it vnto vs by the name of the prickly Peare, from which name many haue ≈øuppo≈øed it to be a Peare indeede, but were therein deceiued.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is no other e≈øpeciall property giuen hereunto, by any that haue written of the We≈øt Indies, then of the colouring of the vrine, as is before ≈øaid.

div.head: Yuca ≈øiue Iucca. The ≈øuppo≈øed Indian Iucca.
div.p: THis rare Indian plant hath a great thicke tuberous roote (≈øpreading in time into many tuberous heads) from the head whereof ≈øhooteth forth many long, hard, and guttured leaues, very ≈øharpe pointed, compa≈ø≈øing as it were one another at the bottome, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, which doe not fall away, but abide euer greene on the plant; from the middle whereof ≈øpringeth forth (now and then, but not euery yeare) a ≈øtrong round ≈øtalke, diuided into diuers branches, whereon ≈øtand diuers white, and ≈øomewhat large flowers, hanging downe their heads, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix leaues, with diuers veines, of a weake reddi≈øh or blu≈øh colour, ≈øpread on the backe of the three outer leaues, e≈øpecially from the middle of the leaues to the bottome, and not ri≈øing to the edge of the leafe of any flower, which fall away without bearing any ≈øeede in our Country, as farre as euer could be ob≈øerued either in the plant that Ma≈øter Gerard kept a long time by him, or by Robinus at Paris his plant, which Ma≈øter Gerard ≈øent vnto him, or yet by that plant, that Ve≈øpa≈øian Robin the ≈øonne of old Robin ≈øent vnto Ma≈øter Iohn de Franqueuille, and now abideth and flouri≈øheth in my Garden.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It was fir≈øt brought into England (as Ma≈øter Gerard ≈øaith) from the We≈øt Indies, by a ≈øeruant of Ma≈øter Thomas Edwards, an Apothecary of Exeter, and imparted to him, who kept it vnto his death: but peri≈øhed with him that got it from his widow, intending to ≈øend it to his Country hou≈øe.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth not vntill Iuly, and the flowers fall away ≈øodainely, after they haue beene blowne open a while.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Ma≈øter Gerard fir≈øt as I thinke called it Iucca, ≈øuppo≈øing it to bee the true Yuca of Theuet, wherewith the Indians make bread, called Ca≈ø≈øaua: but the true Iucca is de≈øcribed to haue a leafe diuided into ≈øeuen or nine parts, which this hath not: Yet not knowing by what better name to call it, let it hold ≈øtill his fir≈øt impo≈øition, vntill a fitter may be giuen it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Wee haue not heard of any, that hath either read, heard, or experimented the faculties hereof, nor yet whether it hath good or euill ta≈øte; for being rare, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed but by a few, they that haue it are loth to cut any thereof, for feare of ≈øpoiling and lo≈øing the whole roote.

Some haue affirmed, that in ≈øome parts of Turkie, where as they ≈øay this plant groweth, they make a kinde of cloth from the threads are found running through the leaues; but I finde the threads are ≈øo ≈øtrong and hard, that this cannot be that plant the relators meane is v≈øed in that manner.

figure.head: 1 Yuca ≈øiue Iucca. The Indian Iucca. 2 Arbor vita. The tree of life. 3 Arbor Iuda. Iudas tree. 4 Laburnum. Beane Trefoile. 5 Cyti≈øus. Tree Trefoile.

div.head: Arbor vitae. The tree of life.
div.p: THe tree of life ri≈øeth vp in ≈øome places where it hath ≈øtood long, to be a tree of a rea≈øonable great bigne≈ø≈øe and height, couered with a redder barke then any other tree in our Country that I know, the wood whereof is firme and hard, and ≈øpreadeth abroad many armes and branches, which againe ≈øend forth many ≈ømaller twigges, bending downewards; from which twiggy or ≈ølender branches, being flat them≈øelues like the leaues, come forth on both ≈øides many flat winged leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto Sauine, being ≈øhort and ≈ømall, but not pricking, ≈øeeming as if they were brayded or folded like vnto a lace or point, of a darke yellowi≈øh greene colour, abiding greene on the branches Winter and Summer, of a ≈øtrong re≈øinous ta≈øte, not plea≈øing to mo≈øt, but in ≈øome ready to procure ca≈øting, yet very cordiall and pectorall al≈øo to them that can endure it: at the toppes of the branches ≈øtand ≈ømall yellowi≈øh dounie flowers, ≈øet in ≈ømall ≈øcaly heads, wherein lye ≈ømall, long, browni≈øh ≈øeede, which ripen well in many places, and being ≈øowne, doe ≈øpring and bring forth plants, which with ≈øome ≈ømall care will abide the extreame≈øt Winters we haue.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt or originall place where it naturally groweth, as farre as I can learne or vnder≈øtand, is that part of America which the French doe in habite, about the riuer of Canada, which is at the backe of Virginia Northward, and as it ≈øeemeth, fir≈øt brought by them from thence into Europe, in the time of Francis the fir≈øt French King, where it hath ≈øo plentifully encrea≈øed, and ≈øo largely beene di≈øtributed, that now few Gardens of re≈øpect, either in France, Germany, the Lowe-Countries, or England, are without it.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the end of May, and in Iune; the fruit is ripe in the end of Augu≈øt and Sptember.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: All the Writers that haue written of it, ≈øince it was fir≈øt knowne, haue made it to be Thuyae genus, a kinde of Thuya, which Theophra≈øtus compareth vnto a Cypre≈ø≈øe tree, in his fifth Book and fifth Chapter: but Omne ≈øimile non e≈øt idem, and although it haue ≈øome likene≈ø≈øe, yet I verily beleeue it is proprium ≈øui genus, a proper kinde of it owne, not to bee paralleld with any other. For wee finde but very few trees, herbes, or plants in America, like vnto tho≈øe that growe in Europe, the hither part of Africa, or in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, as experience te≈øtifieth. Some would make it to be Cedrus Lycia, but ≈øo it cannot be. The French that fir≈øt brought it, called it Arbor vitae, with what rea≈øon or vpon what ground I know not: but euer ≈øince it hath continued vnder the title of the Tree of life.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p:
It hath beene found by often experience, that the leaues hereof chewed in the morning fa≈øting, for ≈øome few dayes together, haue done much good to diuers, that haue beene troubled with ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of breath, and to helpe to expectorate thinne purulentous matter ≈øtuffing the lungs. Other properties I haue not heard that it hath; but doubtle≈ø≈øe, the hot re≈øinous ≈ømell and
ta≈øte it hath, both while it is fre≈øh, and after it hath beene long kept dry, doth euidently declare his tenuity of parts, a dige≈øting and clean≈øing quality it is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with, which if any indu≈øtrious would make tryall, hee ≈øhould finde the effects.

div.head: Arbor Iudae. Iudas tree.
div.p: IVdas tree ri≈øeth vp in ≈øome places, where it ≈øtandeth open from a wall, and alone free from other trees (as in a Garden at Batther≈øey, which ≈øometimes agoe belonged to Ma≈øter Morgan, Apothecary to the late Queene Elizabeth of famous memory) to be a very great and tall tree, exceeding any Apple tree in height, and equall in bigne≈ø≈øe of body thereunto (as my ≈øelfe can te≈øtifie, being an eye witne≈ø≈øe thereof) when as it had many ≈øtalkes of flowers, being in the bud, breaking out of the body of the tree through the barke in diuers places, when as there was no bough or branch near them by a yard at the lea≈øt, or yet any leafe vpon the tree, which they gathered to put among other flowers, for No≈øegayes) and in other places it groweth to bee but an hedge bu≈øh, or plant, with many ≈øuckers and ≈øhootes from belowe, couered with a darke reddi≈øh barke, the young branches being more red or purpli≈øh: the flowers on the branches come forth before any ≈øhew or budding of leaues, three or foure ≈øtanding together vpon a ≈ømall foote-≈øtalke, which are in fa≈øhion like vnto Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øomes, but of an excellent deepe purpli≈øh crim≈øon colour: after which come in their places ≈øo many long, flat, large, and thinne cods, of a browni≈øh colour, wherein are contained ≈ømall, blacki≈øh browne, flat, and hard ≈øeede: the roote is great, and runneth both deepe, and farre ≈øpreading in the earth: the leaues come forth by them≈øelues, euery one ≈øtanding on a long ≈øtalke, being hard & very round, like vnto the leafe of the large≈øt A≈øarum, but not ≈øo thick, of a whiti≈øh green on the vpper ≈øide, and grayi≈øh vnderneath, which fall away euery yeare, and ≈øpring a fre≈øh after the Spring is well come in, and the buds of flowers are ≈øprung.

There is another of this kinde, growing in ≈øome places very high,Flore albe. ≈øomewhat like the former, and in other places al≈øo full of twiggy branches, which are greener then the former, as the leaues are likewi≈øe: the flowers of this kinde are wholly white, and the cods nothing ≈øo red or browne, in all other things agreeing together.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The former groweth plentifully in many places of Spaine, Italy, Prouence in France, and in many other places. The other hath beene ≈øent vs out of Italy many times, and the ≈øeede hath ≈øprung very well with vs, but it is ≈øomewhat tender to keepe in the Winter.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The flowers (as I ≈øaid) appeare before the leaues, and come forth in Aprill and May, and often ≈øooner al≈øo, the leaues following ≈øhortly after; but neither of them beareth perfect ≈øeede in our Country, that euer I could learne, or know by mine owne or others experience.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
Some would referre this to Cercis, whereof Theophra≈øtus maketh mention in his fir≈øt Booke and eighteenth Chapter, among tho≈øe trees that beare their fruit in cods, like as Pul≈øe doe: and hee remembreth it againe in the fourteenth Chapter of his third Booke, and maketh it not vnlike the white
Poplar tree, both in greatne≈ø≈øe and whitene≈ø≈øe of the branches, with the leafe of an Iuie, without corners on the one part, cornered on the other, and ≈øharpe pointed, greene on both ≈øides almo≈øt alike, hauing ≈øo ≈ølender long foote≈øtalkes that the leaues cannot ≈øtand forthright, but bend downwards, with a more rugged barke then the white Poplar tree. Clu≈øius thinketh this large de≈øcription is but an ample de≈øcription of the third kinde of Poplar, called Lybica, the A≈øpen tree, which Gaza tran≈ølateth Alpina: but who ≈øo will well con≈øider it, ≈øhall finde it neyther an≈øwerable to any Poplar tree, in that it beareth not cods as Cercis doth; nor vnto this Arbor Iudae, becau≈øe it beareth not white branches. Clu≈øius ≈øaith al≈øo, that the learned of Mompelier in his time, referred it to Colytea of Theophra≈øtus in his third booke and ≈øeuenteenth chapter, where he doth liken it to the leaues of the broade≈øt leafed Bay tree, but larger and rounder, green on the vpper≈øide, and whiti≈øh vnderneath, and whereunto (as he ≈øaith) Theophra≈øtus giueth cods in the fourteenth chapter of the ≈øame third booke: and by the contracting of their de≈øcriptions both together, ≈øaith, they agree vnto this Iudas tree. But I find ≈øome doubts and differences in the≈øe places: for the Colutaea that Dio≈øcorides mentioneth in the ≈øaid fourteenth chapter of his third booke, hath (as he ≈øaith there) a leafe like vnto the Willow, and therefore cannot bee the ≈øame Colutaea mentioned in the ≈øeuenteenth chapter of the ≈øame third book, which hath a broade Bay leafe: indeede hee giueth ≈øeede in cods: but that with broade Bay leaues is (as he ≈øaith) without eyther flower or fruite; and be≈øides all this, he ≈øaith the rootes are very yellow, which is not to bee found in this Arbor Iudae, or Iudas tree: let others now iudge if the≈øe things can bee well reconciled together. Some haue for the likene≈ø≈øe of the cods vnto Beane cods, called it Fabago. And Clu≈øius called it Siliqua ≈øilue≈øtris. It is generally in the≈øe dayes called Arbor Iudae, and in Engli≈øh after the Latine name, vntill a fitter may be had, Iudas tree.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is nothing extant in any Author of any Phy≈øicall v≈øe it hath, neyther hath any later experience found out any.

div.head: Laburnum. Beane Trefoile.
div.p: THere be three ≈øorts of the≈øe codded trees or plants, one neere re≈øembling another, whereof Anagyris of Dio≈øcorides is one. The other two are called Laburnum; the larger whereof Matthiolus calleth Anagyris altera, and ≈øo doe ≈øome others al≈øo: the third is of the ≈øame kinde with the ≈øecond, but ≈ømaller. I ≈øhall not for this our Garden trouble you or my ≈øelfe with any more of them then one, which is the le≈ø≈øer of the two Liburnum, in that it is more frequent, and that it will far better abide then the Anagyris, which is ≈øo tender, that it will hardly endure the winters of our Countrey: and the greater Laburnum is not ≈øo ea≈øily to be had.

div.head: Laburnum. Beane Trefoile.
div.p:
This codded tree ri≈øeth vp with vs like vnto a tall tree, with a rea≈øonable great body, if it abide any long time in a place, couered with a ≈ømooth greene barke; the branches are very long, greene, pliant, and bending any way, whereon are ≈øet here and there diuers leaues, three alwaies ≈øtanding together vpon a long ≈øtalk, being ≈øomwhat long, and not very narrow, pointed at the ends, greene on the vpper≈øide, and of a ≈øiluer ≈øhining colour vnderneath, without any ≈ømell at all: at the ioynts of the≈øe branches, where the leaues ≈øtand, come forth many flowers, much like vnto broome flowers, but not ≈øo
large or open, growing about a very long branch or ≈øtalke, ≈øometimes a good ≈øpan or more in length, and of a faire yellow colour, but not very deepe; after which come flatthin cods, not very long or broade, but as tough and hard as the cods of Broome; wherein are contained blacki≈øh ≈øeede, like, but much le≈ø≈øe then the ≈øeede of Anagyris vera (which are as big as a kidney beane, purpli≈øh and ≈øpotted): the roote thru≈øteth down deepe into the ground, ≈øpreading al≈øo farre, and is of a yellowi≈øh colour.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This tree groweth naturally in many of the woods of Italie, and vpon the Alpes al≈øo, and is therefore ≈øtill accounted to be that Laburnum that Plinie calleth Arbor Alpina. It groweth in many gardens with vs.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in May, the fruit or cods, and the ≈øeedes therein are ripe in the end of Augu≈øt, or in September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: This tree (as I ≈øaid before) is called of Matthiolus Anagyris altera, ≈øiue ≈øecunda, of Cordus, Ge≈øner and others, e≈øpecially of mo≈øt now adayes, Laburnum. It is probable in my opinion, that this ≈øhould bee that Colutaea of Theophra≈øtus, mentioned in the fourteenth Chapter of his third book with the leafe of a Willow; for if you take any one leafe by it ≈øelfe, it may well re≈øemble a Willow leafe both for forme and colour, and beareth ≈ømall ≈øeed in cods like vnto pul≈øe as that doth. Of ≈øome it hath beene taken for a kinde of Cyti≈øus, but not truely. We call it in Engli≈øh, Beane Trefoile, in regard of his cods and ≈øeede therein, ≈øomewhat like vnto Kidney Beanes, and of the leaues, three alwayes ≈øtanding together, vntill a more proper name may bee giuen it.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is no v≈øe hereof in Phy≈øicke with vs, nor in the naturall place of the growing, ≈øaue only to prouoke a vomit, which it will doe very ≈øtrongly.

div.head: Cyti≈øus. Tree Trefoile.
div.p: THere are ≈øo many ≈øorts of Cyti≈øus or Tree trefoiles, that if I ≈øhould relate them all, I ≈øhould weary the Reader to ouerlooke them, whereof the mo≈øt part pertaine rather to a generall worke then to this ab≈øtract. I ≈øhall not therefore trouble you with any ≈øuperfluous, but only with two, which we haue nour≈øed vp to furni≈øh wa≈øte places in a garden.

div.head: Cyti≈øus Maranthae. Horned Tree Trefoile.
div.p:
This Tree Trefoile which is held of mo≈øt Herbari≈øts to bee the true Cyti≈øus of Dio≈øcorides, ri≈øeth vp to the height of a man at the mo≈øt, with a body of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans thumbe, couered with a whiti≈øh bark, breaking forth into many whiti≈øh branches ≈øpreading farre, be≈øet in many places with ≈ømall leaues, three alwayes ≈øet together vpon a ≈ømall ≈øhort foote≈øtalke, which are rounder, and whiter then the leaues of Beane Trefoile: at the ends of the branches for the mo≈øt part, come forth the flowers three or foure togethers, of a fine gold colour, and of the fa≈øhion of Broome flowers, but
not ≈øo large: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come in their places crooked flat thinne cods, of the fa≈øhion of a halfe moone, or crooked horne, whiti≈øh when they are ripe, wherein are contained blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is hard and woody, ≈øpreading diuers wayes vnder the ground: the whole plant hath a pretty ≈ømall hot ≈øent.

div.head: Cyti≈øus vulgatior. The common Tree Trefoile.
div.p: This Cyti≈øus is the mo≈øt common in this Land, of any the other ≈øorts of tree trefoiles, hauing a blacki≈øh colourd barke, the ≈øtemme or body whereof is larger then the former, both for height and ≈øpreading, bearing al≈øo three leaues together, but ≈ømaller and greener then the former: the flowers are ≈ømaller, but of the ≈øame fa≈øhion and colour: the cods blacki≈øh and thin, and not very long, or great, but le≈ø≈øer then Broome cods, wherein there lyeth ≈ømall blacki≈øh hard ≈øeede: the roote is diuer≈øly di≈øper≈øed in the ground.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth in the kingdome of Naples, and no doubt in many other places of Italie, as Matthiolus ≈øaith. The other groweth in diuers places of France.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower for the mo≈øt part in May or Iune: the ≈øeede is ripe in Augu≈øt or September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt (as I ≈øaid) is thought of mo≈øt to be the true Cyti≈øus of Dio≈øcorides, and as is thought, was in the≈øe later dayes fir≈øt found by Bartholomaeus Maranta of Naples, who ≈øent it fir≈øt to Matthiolus, and thereupon hath euer ≈øince beene called after his name, Cyti≈øus Maranthae. Some doe call it Cyti≈øus Lunatus, becau≈øe the cods are made ≈øomewhat like vnto an halfe Moone. We call it in Engli≈øh, Horned Tree Trefoile. The other is called Cyti≈øus vulgaris or vulgatior; in Engli≈øh, The common Tree Trefoile, becau≈øe we haue not any other ≈øo common.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The chiefe≈øt vertues that are appropriate to the≈øe plants, are to procure milke in womens brea≈øts, to fatten pullen, ≈øheep &c. and to be good for bees.

div.head: Colutaea. The Ba≈øtard Sena Tree.
div.p: WEe haue in our Gardens two or three ≈øorts of the Ba≈øtard Sena tree; a greater as I may ≈øo call it, and two le≈ø≈øer: the one with round thin tran≈øparent skins like bladders, wherein are the ≈øeede: the others with long round cods, the one bunched out or ≈øwelling in diuers places, like vnto a Scorpions tale, wherein is the ≈øeede, and the other very like vnto it, but ≈ømaller.

div.head: 1. Colutaea Ve≈øicaria. The greater Ba≈øtard Sena with bladders.
div.p:
This ≈øhrub or tree, or ≈øhrubby tree, which you plea≈øe to call it, ri≈øeth vp to the height of a pretty tree, the ≈øtemme or ≈øtock being ≈øometimes of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans arme, couered with a blacki≈øh greene rugged barke, the wood whereof is harder then of an
Elder, but with an hollowne≈ø≈øe like a pith in the heart or middle of the branches, which are diuided many wayes, and whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances, diuers winged leaues, compo≈øed of many ≈ømall round pointed, or rather flat pointed leaues, one ≈øet again≈øt another, like vnto Licoris, or the Hatcher Fitch; among the≈øe leaues come forth the flowers, in fa≈øhion like vnto Broome flowers, and as large, of a very yellow colour: after which appeare cleare thinne ≈øwelling cods like vnto thinne tran≈øparent bladders, wherein are contained blacke ≈øeede, ≈øet vpon a middle ribbe or ≈øinew in the middle of the bladder, which if it be a little cru≈øhed betweene the fingers, will giue a cracke, like as a bladder full of winde. The roote groweth branched and woody.

div.head: 2. Colutaea Scorpioides maior. The greater Scorpion podded Ba≈øtard Sena.
div.p: This Ba≈øtard Sena groweth nothing ≈øo great or tall, but ≈øhooteth out diuer≈øly, like vnto a ≈øhrub, with many ≈øhoots ≈øpringing from the root: the branches are greener, but more rugged, hauing a white barke on the be≈øt part of the elder growne branches; for the young are greene, and haue ≈øuch like winged leaues ≈øet on them as are to be ≈øeen in the former, but ≈ømaller, greener, and more pointed: the flowers are yellow, but much ≈ømaller, fa≈øhioned ≈øomewhat like vnto the former, with a reddi≈øh ≈øtripe downe the backe of the vppermo≈øt leafe: the long cods that follow are ≈ømall, long and round, di≈øtingui≈øhed into many diui≈øions or dents, like vnto a Scorpions tayle, from whence hath ri≈øen the name: in the≈øe ≈øeuerall diui≈øions lye ≈øeuerall blacke ≈øeede, like vnto the ≈øeede of Fenigrecke: the roote is white and long, but not ≈øo woody as the former.

div.head: 3. Colutaea Scorpioides minor. The le≈ø≈øer Scorpion Ba≈øtard Sena.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer Ba≈øtard Sena is in all things like the former, but ≈øomewhat lower, and ≈ømaller both in leafe, flower, and cods of ≈øeede, which haue not ≈øuch eminent bunches on the cods to be ≈øeene as the former.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: They grow as Matthiolus ≈øaith about Trent in Italie, and in other places: the former is frequent enough through all our Countrey, but the others are more rare.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower about the middle or end of May, and their ≈øeede is ripe in Augu≈øt. The bladders of the fir≈øt will abide a great while on the tree, if they be ≈øuffered, and vntill the winde cau≈øe them to rattle, and afterwards the skins opening, the ≈øeed will fall away.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The name Colutaea is impo≈øed on them, and by the iudgement of mo≈øt writers, the fir≈øt is taken to bee that Colutaea of Lipara that Theophra≈øtus maketh mention of, in the ≈øeuenteenth chapter of his third booke. But I ≈øhould rather thinke that the Scorpioides were the truer Colutaea of Theophra≈øtus, becau≈øe the long pods thereof are more properly to bee accounted ≈øiliquae, then the former which are ve≈øicae tumentes, windy bladders, and not ≈øiliquae: and no doubt but Theophra≈øtus would haue giuen ≈øome peculiar note of difference if he had meant tho≈øe bladders, and not the≈øe cods. Let others of iudgement be vmpeeres in this ca≈øe; although I know the currant of writers ≈øince Matthiolus, doe all hold the former Colutaea veficaria to be the true Colutaea Liparae of Theophra≈øtus. Wee call it in Engli≈øh, Ba≈øtard Sena, from Ruellius, who as I thinke fir≈øt called it Sena, from the forme of the leaues. The ≈øecond and third (as I ≈øaid before) from the forme of the cods receiued their names, as it is in the titles and de≈øcriptions; yet they may as properly be called Siliquo≈øae, for that their fruite are long cods.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Theophra≈øtus ≈øaith it doth wonderfully helpe to fatten ≈øheepe: But ≈øure it is found by experience, that if it be giuen to man it cau≈øeth ≈øtrong ca≈øtings both vpwards and downwards; and therefore let euery one beware that they v≈øe not this in ≈øteede of good Sena, le≈øt they feele to their co≈øt the force thereof.

div.head: Spartum Hi≈øpanicum frutex. Spani≈øh Broome.
div.p: ALthough Clu≈øius and others haue found diuers ≈øorts of this ≈øhrubby Spartum or Spani≈øh Broome, yet becau≈øe our Climate will nour≈øe vp none of them, and euen this very hardly, I ≈øhall leaue all others, and de≈øcribe vnto you this one only in this manner: Spani≈øh Broome groweth to bee fiue or ≈øixe foote high, with a woody ≈øtemme below, couered with a darke gray, or a≈øh-coloured barke, and hauing aboue many pliant, long and ≈ølender greene twigs, whereon in the beginning of the yeare are ≈øet many ≈ømall long greene leaues, which fall away quickly, not abiding long on; towards the tops of the≈øe branches grow the flowers, fa≈øhioned like vnto Broom flowers, but larger, as yellow as they, and ≈ømelling very well; after which come ≈ømall long cods, cre≈øted at the backe, wherein is contained blacki≈øh flat ≈øeede, fa≈øhioned very like vnto the Kidney beanes: the roote is woody, di≈øper≈øing it ≈øelfe diuers waies.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This groweth naturally in many places of France, Spaine and Italie, wee haue it as an ornament in our Gardens, among other delightfull plaats, to plea≈øe the ≈øen≈øes of ≈øight and ≈ømelling.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in the end of May, or beginning of Iune, and beareth ≈øeede, which ripeneth not with vs vntill it be late.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called Spartium Graecorum, and Spartum frutex, to di≈øtingui≈øh it from the ≈øedge or ru≈øh, that is ≈øo called al≈øo. Of ≈øome it is called Genista, and thought not to differ from the other Geni≈øta, but they are much deceiued; for euen in Spaine and Italie, the ordinary Ganista or Broome groweth with it, which is not pliant, and fit to binde Vines, or ≈øuch like things withall as this is.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: There is little v≈øe hereof in Phy≈øicke, by rea≈øon of the dangerous qualitie of vomiting, which it doth procure to them that take it inwardly: but being applyed outwardly, it is found to helpe the Sciatica, or paine of the hippes.

figure.head: 1 Co ‚Ä¢ utaea vulgaris. Ordinary ba≈øtard Sene. 2 Periploca recta Virginiana. Virginian Silke. 3 Colutae ‚Ä¢ Scorpicides. Scorpion ba≈øtard Sene. 4 Spartum Hi≈øpanicum. Spani≈øh Broome. 5 Ligu≈øtrum. Priuet. 6 Saluia variegata. Party coloured Sage. 7 Maiorana auroa. G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ded Matierome.

div.head: Periploca recta Virginiana. Virginian Silke.
div.p: LE≈øt this ≈øtranger ≈øhould finde no ho≈øpitality with vs, being ≈øo beautifull a plant, or not finde place in this Garden, let him be here receiued, although with the la≈øt, rather then not at all. It ri≈øeth vp with one or more ≈øtrong and round ≈øtalkes, three or foure foote high, whereon are ≈øet at the ≈øeuerall ioynts thereof two faire, long, and broad leaues, round pointed, with many veines therein, growing clo≈øe to the ≈øtemme, without any foote-≈øtalke: at the tops of the ≈øtalkes, and ≈øometimes at the ioynts of the leaues, groweth forth a great bu≈øh of flowers out of a thinne skinne, to the number of twenty, and ≈øometimes thirty or forty, euery one with a long foote-≈øtalke, hanging downe their heads for the mo≈øt part, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are outermo≈øt, euery one ≈øtanding within a ≈ømall huske of greene leaues, turned to the ≈øtalkeward, like vnto the Ly≈øimachia flower of Virginia before de≈øcribed, and each of them con≈øi≈øting of fiue ≈ømall leaues a peece, of a pale purpli≈øh colour on the vpper≈øide, and of a pale yellowi≈øh purple vnderneath, both ≈øides of each leafe being as it were folded together, making them ≈øeeme hollow and pointed, with a few ≈øhort chiues in the middle: after which come long and crooked pointed cods ≈øtanding vpright, wherein are contained flat browni≈øh ≈øeede, di≈øper≈øedly lying within a great deale of fine, ≈øoft, and whiti≈øh browne ≈øilke, very like vnto the cods, ≈øeede, and ≈øilke of A≈øclepias, or Swallow-wort, but that the cods are greater and more crooked, and harder al≈øo in the outer ≈øhell: the roote is long and white, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans thumbe, running vnder ground very far, and ≈øhooting vp in diuers places, the heads being ≈øet full of ≈ømall white grumes or knots, yeelding forth many branches, if it ≈øtand any time in a place: the whole plant, as well leaues as ≈øtalkes, being broken, yeeld a pale milke.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It came to me from Virginia, where it groweth aboundantly, being rai≈øed vp from the ≈øeede I receiued.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Iuly, and the ≈øeede is ripe in Augu≈øt.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
It may ≈øeeme very probable to many, that this plant is the ≈øame that Pro≈øper Alpinus in the twenty fift Chapter of his Booke of Egyptian plants, nameth Beidel≈øar; and Honorius Bellus in his third and fourth Epi≈øtles vnto Clu≈øius (which are at the end of his Hi≈øtory of plants) calleth O≈ø≈øar frutex: And Clu≈øius him≈øelfe in the ≈øame Booke calleth Apocynum Syriacum, Palastinum, and Aegyptiacum, becau≈øe this agreeth with theirs in very many and notable parts; yet verily I thinke this plant is not the ≈øame, but rather another kinde of it ≈øelfe: Fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is not frutex, a ≈øhrub or wooddy plant, nor keepeth his leaues all the yeare, but lo≈øeth both leaues and ≈øtalks, dying down to the ground euery yeare: Secondly, the milke is not cau≈øticke or violent, as Alpinus and Bellus ≈øay O≈ø≈øar is: Thirdly, the cods are more crooked then tho≈øe of Clu≈øius, or of Alpinus, which Honorius Bellus acknowledgeth to be right, although greater then tho≈øe he had out of Egypt: And la≈øtly, the rootes of the≈øe doe runne, whereof none of them make any mention. Gerard in his Herball giueth a rude figure of the plant, but a very true figure of the cods with ≈øeede, and ≈øaith the Virginians call it Wi≈øanck, and referreth it to the A≈øclepias, for the likene≈ø≈øe of the cods ≈øtuffed with
≈øilken doune. But what rea≈øon Ca≈øpar Bauhinus in his Pinax Theatri Botanici had, to call it (for it is Clu≈øius his Apocynum Syriacum) by the name of Lapathum Aegyptiacum lacte≈øcens ≈øiliqua A≈øclepiadis, I know none in the world: for but that he would ≈øhew an extreame ≈øingularity in giuing names to plants, contrary to all others (which is very frequent with him) how could he thinke, that this plant could haue any likene≈ø≈øe or corre≈øpondencie, with any of the kindes of Dockes, that euer he had ≈øeene, read, or heard of, in face, or ≈øhew of leaues, flowers, or ≈øeede; but e≈øpecially in giuing milke. I haue you ≈øee (and that not without iu≈øt and euident cau≈øe) giuen it a differing Latine name from Gerard, becau≈øe the A≈øclepias giueth no milke, but the Periploca or Apocymum doth; and therefore fitter to be referred to this then to that. And becau≈øe it ≈øhould not want an Engli≈øh name an≈øwerable to ≈øome peculiar property thereof, I haue from the ≈øilken doune called it Virginian Silke: but I know there is another plant growing in Virginia‚ñ™ called Silke Gra≈ø≈øe, which is much differing from this.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: I know not of any in our Land hath made any tryall of the properties hereof. Captaine Iohn Smith in his booke of the di≈øcouery and de≈øcription of Virginia, ≈øaith, that the Virginians v≈øe the rootes hereof (if his be the ≈øame with this) being brui≈øed and applyed to cure their hurts & di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: Ligu≈øtrum. Primme or Priuet.
div.p: BEcau≈øe the v≈øe of this plant is ≈øo much, and ≈øo frequent throughout all this Land, although for no other purpo≈øe but to make hedges or arbours in Gardens, &c. whereunto it is ≈øo apt, that no other can be like vnto it, to bee cut, lead, and drawne into what forme one will, either of bea≈øts, birds, or men armed, or otherwi≈øe: I could not forget it, although it be ≈øo well knowne vnto all, to be an hedge bu≈øh growing from a wooddy white roote, ≈øpreading much within the ground, and bearing manie long, tough, and plyant ≈øprigs and branches, whereon are ≈øet long, narrow, and pointed ≈øad greene leaues by couples at euery ioynt: at the tops whereof breake forth great tufts of ≈øweete ≈ømelling white flowers, which when they are fallen, turne into ≈ømall blacke berries, hauing a purple iuyce within them, and ≈ømall ≈øeede, flat on the one ≈øide, with an hole or dent therein: this is ≈øeene in tho≈øe branches that are not cut, but ≈øuffered to beare out their flowers and fruit.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: This bu≈øh groweth as plentifully in the Woods of our owne Countrey, as in any other beyond the Seas.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth ≈øometimes in Iune, and in Iuly; the fruit is ripe in Augu≈øt and a September.

div.head: The Names.
div.p:
There is great controuer≈øie among the moderne Writers concerning this plant, ≈øome taking it to be „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ of Dio≈øcorides, other to be Phillyrea of Dio≈øcorides, which followeth next after Cyprus. Plinie maketh mention of Cyprus in two places; in the one he ≈øaith, Cyprus hath the leafe of Ziziphus,
or the Iuiube tree: in the other he ≈øaith, that certain do affirme, that the Cyprus of the Ea≈øt Country, and the Ligustrum of Italy is one and the ≈øame plant: whereby you may plainly ≈øee, that our Priuet which is Ligu≈øtrum, cannot be that Cyprus of Plinie with Iuiube leaues: Be≈øides, both Dio≈øcorides & Plinie ≈øay, that Cyprus is a tree; but all know that Ligu≈øtrum, Priuet, is but an hedge bu≈øh: Againe, Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith, that the leaues of Cyprus giue a red colour, but Priuet giueth none. Bellonius and Pro≈øper Alpinus haue both recorded, that the true Cyprus of Dio≈øcorides groweth plentifully in Egypt, Syria, and tho≈øe Ea≈øterne Countries, and nour≈øed vp al≈øo in Con≈øtantinople, and other parts of Greece, being a merchandi≈øe of much worth, in that they tran≈øport the leaues, and young branches dryed, which laid in water giue a yellow colour, wherewith the Turki≈øh women colour the nailes of their hands, and ≈øome other parts of their bodies likewi≈øe, delighting much therein: and that it is not our Ligu≈øtrum, or Priuet, becau≈øe Cyprus beareth round white ≈øeede, like Coriander ≈øeede, and the leaues abide greene alwaies vpon the tree, which groweth (if it bee not cut or pruined) to the height of the Pomegranet tree. I haue (I confe≈ø≈øe) beyond the limits I ≈øet for this worke ≈øpoken concerning our Priuet, becau≈øe I haue had the ≈øeede of the true Cyprus of Dio≈øcorides ≈øent mee, which was much differing from our Priuet, and although it ≈øprang vp, yet would not abide any time, whereas if it had beene our Priuet, it would haue beene familiar enough to our Countrey.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is of ≈ømall v≈øe in phy≈øicke, yet ≈øome doe v≈øe the leaues in Lotions, that ≈øerue to coole and dry fluxes or ≈øores in diuers parts.

div.head: Saluia variegata. Party coloured Sage. And Maiorana ver≈øicolor ≈øiue aurea. Yellow or golden Marierome.
div.p: VNto all the≈øe flowers of beauty and rarity, I mu≈øt adioyne two other plants, who≈øe beauty con≈øi≈øteth in their leaues, and not in their flowers: as al≈øo to ≈øeparate them from the others of their tribe, to place them here in one Chapter, before the ≈øweete herbes that ≈øhall follow, as is fitte≈øt to furni≈øh this our Garden of plea≈øure. This kinde of Sage groweth with branches and leaues, very like the ordinary Sage, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, the chiefe≈øt difference con≈øi≈øteth in the colour of the leaues, being diuer≈øly marked and ≈øpotted with white and red among the greene: for vpon one branch you ≈øhall haue the leaues ≈øeuerally marked one from another, as the one halfe of the leafe white, and the other halfe greene, with red ≈øhadowed ouer them both, or more white then greene, with ≈øome red in it, either parted or ≈øhadowed, or da≈øht here and there, or more greene then white, and red therein, eyther in the middle or end of the leafe, or more or le≈ø≈øe parted or ≈øtriped with white and red in the greene, or el≈øe ≈øometimes wholly greene the whole branch together, as nature li≈øteth to play with ≈øuch varieties: which manner of growing ri≈øing from one and the ≈øame plant, becau≈øe it is the more variable, is the more delightfull and much re≈øpected.

There is another ≈øpeckled Sage parted with white and greene, but it is nothing of that beauty to this, becau≈øe this hath three colours euidently to bee di≈øcerned in euery leafe almo≈øt, the red adding a ≈øuperaboundant grace to the re≈øt.

div.head: Maiorana aurea ≈øiue ver≈øicolor. Yellow or golden Marierome.
div.p:
This kinde of Marierome belongeth to that ≈øort is called in Latine Maiorana latifolia,
which Lobel ≈øetteth forth for Hy≈ø≈øopus Graecorum genuina: In Engli≈øh Winter Marierome, or pot Marierome: for it hath broader and greater leaues then the ≈øweete Marierome, and a different vmbell or tuft of flowers. The difference of this from that ≈øet forth in the Kitchin Garden, con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in the leaues, which are in Summer wholly yellow in ≈øome, or but a little greene, or parted with yellow and greene more or le≈ø≈øe, as nature li≈øteth to play: but in Winter they are of a darke or dead greene colour, yet recouering it ≈øelfe againe: the ≈øent hereof is all one with the pot Marierome.
Wee haue another parted with white and greene, much after the manner with the former.
The Place, Time, Names, and Vertues of both the≈øe plants, ≈øhall be declared where the others of their kindes are ≈øpecified hereafter, and in the Kitchen Garden; for they differ not in properties.

div.head: Lauendula. Lauender Spike.
div.p: AFter all the≈øe faire and ≈øweete flowers before ≈øpecified, I mu≈øt needes adde a few ≈øweete herbes, both to accompli≈øh this Garden, and to plea≈øe your ≈øen≈øes, by placing them in your No≈øegayes, or el≈øe where, as you li≈øt. And although I bring them in the end or la≈øt place, yet are they not of the lea≈øt account.

div.head: 1. Lauendula maior. Garden Lauender.
div.p: Our ordinary Garden Lauender ri≈øeth vp with a hard wooddy ≈øtemme aboue the ground, parted into many ≈ømall branches, whereon are ≈øet whiti≈øh, long, and narrow leaues, by couples one again≈øt another; from among which ri≈øeth vp naked ≈øquare ≈øtalkes, with two leaues at a ioynt, and at the toppe diuers ≈ømall huskes ≈øtanding round about them, formed in long and round heads or ≈øpikes, with purple gaping flowers ≈øpringing out of each of them: the roote is wooddy, and ≈øpreadeth in the ground: The whole plant is of a ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈øent, but the heads of flowers much more, and more piercing the ≈øen≈øes, which are much v≈øed to bee put among linnen and apparrell.

There is a kinde hereof that beareth white flowers, and ≈øomewhat broader leaues,Flore albo. but it is very rare, and ≈øeene but in few places with vs, becau≈øe it is more tender, and will not ≈øo well endure our cold Winters.

div.head: 2. Lauendula minor ≈øen Spica. Small Lauender or Spike.
div.p: The Spike or ≈ømall Lauender is very like vnto the former, but groweth not ≈øo high, neither is the head or ≈øpike ≈øo great and long, but ≈øhorter and ≈ømaller, and of a more purpli≈øh colour in the flower: the leaues al≈øo are a little harder, whiter, and ≈øhorter then the former; the ≈øent al≈øo is ≈øomewhat ≈øharper and ≈øtronger. This is not ≈øo frequent as the fir≈øt, and is nouri≈øhed but in ≈øome places that are warme, and where they delight in rare herbes and plants.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Lauender groweth in Spaine aboundantly, in many places ≈øo wilde, and little regarded, that many haue gone, and abiden there to di≈øtill the oyle thereof whereof great quantity now commeth ouer from thence vnto vs: and al≈øo in Lanquedocke, and Prouence in France.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth early in tho≈øe hot Countries, but with vs not vntill Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called of ≈øome Nardus Italica, and Lauendula, the greater is called Faemina, and the le≈ø≈øer Mas. We doe call them generally Lauender, or Lauender Spike, and the le≈ø≈øer Spike, without any other addition.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: Lauender is little v≈øed in inward phy≈øicke, but outwardly; the oyle for cold and benummed parts, and is almo≈øt wholly ≈øpent with vs, for to perfume linnen, apparrell, gloues, leather, &c. and the dryed flowers to comfort and dry vp the moi≈øture of a cold braine.

div.head: Staechas. Sticadoue, Ca≈ø≈øidony, or French Lauender.
div.p: CA≈ø≈øidony that groweth in the Gardens of our Countrey, may peraduenture ≈øomewhat differ in colour, as well as in ≈øtrength, from that which groweth in hotter Countries; but as it is with vs, it is more tender a great deale then Lauender, and groweth rather like an herbe then a bu≈øh or ≈øhrub, not aboue a foote and a halfe high, or thereabouts, hauing many narrow long greene leaues like Lauender, but ≈øofter and ≈ømaller, ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances together about the ≈øtalkes, which ≈øpread abroad into branches: at the tops whereof ≈øtand long and round, and ≈øometimes foure ≈øquare heads, of a darke greeni≈øh purple colour, compact of many ≈øcales ≈øet together; from among which come forth the flowers, of a blewi≈øh purple colour, after which follow ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øels, which are ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh when they are ripe, containing blacki≈øh browne ≈øeede within them: the roote is ≈øomewhat wooddy, and will hardly abide the iniuries of our cold Winters, except in ≈øome places onely, or before it haue flowred: The whole plant is ≈øomewhat ≈øweete, but nothing ≈øo much as Lauender.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: Ca≈ø≈øidony groweth in the I≈ølands Staechades, which are ouer again≈øt Mar≈øelles, and in Arabia al≈øo: we keep it with great care in our Gardens.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth the next yeare after it is ≈øowne, in the end of May, which is a moneth before any Lauender.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: It is called of ≈øome Lauendula ≈øilue≈øtris, but mo≈øt v≈øually Staechas: in Engli≈øh, of ≈øome Stickadoue, or French Lauender; and in many parts of England, Ca≈ø≈øidony.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: It is of much more v≈øe in phy≈øicke then Lauender, and is much v≈øed for old paines in the head. It is al≈øo held to be good for to open ob≈øtructions, to expell melancholy, to clean≈øe and ≈øtrengthen the liuer, and other inward parts, and to be a Pectorall al≈øo.

div.head: Abrotanum faemina ≈øiue Santolina. Lauender Cotton.
div.p: THis Lauender Cotton hath many wooddy, but brittle branches, hoary or of a whiti≈øh colour, whereon are ≈øet many leaues, which are little, long, and foure ≈øquare, dented or notched on all edges, and whiti≈øh al≈øo: at the tops of the≈øe branches ≈øtand naked ≈øtalkes, bearing on euery one of them a larger yellow head or flower, then eyther Tan≈øie or Maudeline, whereunto they are ≈øomewhat like, wherein is contained ≈ømall darke coloured ≈øeede: the roote is hard, and ≈øpreadeth abroad with many fibres: the whole plant is of a ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈øent, but not vnplea≈øant, and is in many places planted in Gardens, to border knots with, for which it will abide to be cut into what forme you thinke be≈øt; for it groweth thicke and bu≈øhy, very fit for ≈øuch workes, be≈øides the comely ≈øhew the plant it ≈øelfe thus wrought doth yeeld, being alwayes greene, and of a ≈øweet ≈øent; but becau≈øe it quickly groweth great, and will ≈øoon runne out of forme, it mu≈øt be euery ≈øecond or third yeare taken vp, and new planted.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: It is onely planted in Gardens with vs, for the v≈øes afore≈øaid e≈øpecially.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: It flowreth in Iuly, and ≈øtandeth long in the hot time of the yeare in his colour, and ≈øo will doe, if it be gathered before it haue ≈øtood ouer long.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Diuers doe call it as Matthiolus doth, Abrotanum faemina, and Santolina; and ≈øome call it Chamaecypari≈ø≈øus, becau≈øe the leaues thereof, are ≈øomewhat like the leaues of the Cypre≈ø≈øe tree: Wee call it in Engli≈øh generally Lauender Cotton.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: This is v≈øually put among other hot herbes, eyther into bathes, ointments, or other things, that are v≈øed for cold cau≈øes. The ≈øeede al≈øo is much v≈øed for the wormes.

div.head: Ocimum. Ba≈ø≈øill.
div.p: BA≈ø≈øill is of two ≈øorts (be≈øides other kindes) for this our Garden, the one whereof is greater, the other le≈ø≈øe in euery part thereof, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed.

div.head: 1. Ocimum Citratum. Common Ba≈ø≈øill.
div.p:
Our ordinary Garden Ba≈ø≈øill hath one ≈øtalke ri≈øing from the root, diuer≈øly branched out, whereon are ≈øet two leaues alwayes at a ioynt, which are broad, ≈øomewhat round, and pointed, of a pale greene colour, but fre≈øh, a little ≈ønipt or dented about the edges, and of a ≈øtrong or heady ≈øent, ≈øomewhat like a Pomecitron, as many haue compared it, and thereof call it Citratum: the flowers are ≈ømall and white, ≈øtanding at the tops of the branches, with two ≈ømal leaues at euery ioynt vnder them, in ≈øome plants green, in others
browne vnder them: after which commeth blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the roote peri≈øheth at the fir≈øt approach of winter weather, and is to be new ≈øowen euery yeare.

div.head: 2. Ocimum minimum ≈øiue Gariophyllatum. Bu≈øh Ba≈øill.
div.p: The bu≈øh Ba≈øill groweth not altogether ≈øo high, but is thicker ≈øpreade out into branches, whereon grow ≈ømaller leaues, and thicker ≈øet then the former, but of a more excellent and plea≈øant ≈ømell by much: the flowers are white like the former, and the ≈øeede blacke al≈øo like it, and peri≈øheth as ≈øuddenly, or rather ≈øooner then it, ≈øo that it requireth more paines to get it, and more care to nour≈øe it, becau≈øe we ≈øeldome or neuer haue any ≈øeede of it.

div.head: Ocimum Indicum. Indian Ba≈øill.
div.p: The Indian Ba≈øill hath a ≈øquare reddi≈øh greene ≈øtalke, a foote high or better, from the ioynts whereof ≈øpreade out many branches, with broade fat leaues ≈øet thereon, two alwayes together at the ioynt, one again≈øt another, as other Ba≈øils haue, but ≈øomewhat deepely cut in on the edges, and oftentimes a little crumpled, ≈øtanding vpon long reddi≈øh foote≈øtalkes, of a darke purple colour, ≈øpotted with deeper purple ≈øpots, in ≈øome greater, in others le≈ø≈øer: the flowers ≈øtand at the tops of the ≈øtalkes ≈øpike-fa≈øhion, which are of a white colour, with reddi≈øh ≈øtripes and veines running through them, ≈øet or placed in darke purple coloured huskes: the ≈øeede is greater and rounder then the former, and ≈øomewhat long withall: the roote peri≈øheth in like manner as the other former doe. The whole plant ≈ømelleth ≈øtrong, like vnto the other Ba≈øils.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The two la≈øt ≈øorts of Ba≈øils are greater ≈øtrangers in our Country then the fir≈øt which is frequent, and only ≈øowen and planted in curious gardens. The la≈øt came fir≈øt out of the We≈øt Indies.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They all flower in Augu≈øt, or Iuly at the ≈øoone≈øt, and that but by degrees, and not all at once.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is v≈øually called Ocimum vulgare, or vulgatius, and Ocimum Citratum. In Engli≈øh, Common or Garden Ba≈øill. The other is called Ocimum minimum, or Gariophyllatum, Cloue Ba≈øill, or Bu≈øh Ba≈øill. The la≈øt eyther of his place, or forme of his leaues, being ≈øpotted and curled, or all, is called Ocimum Indicum maculatum, latifolium & cri≈øpum. In Engli≈øh according to the Latine, Indian Ba≈øill, broade leafed Ba≈øill, ≈øpotted or curled Ba≈øill, which you plea≈øe.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The ordinary Ba≈øill is in a manner wholly ≈øpent to make ≈øweet, or wa≈øhing waters, among other ≈øweet herbes, yet ≈øometimes it is put into no≈øegayes. The Phy≈øicall properties are, to procure a cheerefull and merry heart, whervnto the ≈øeede is chiefly v≈øed in pouder, &c. and is mo≈øt v≈øed to that, and to no other purpo≈øe.

figure.head: 1 Santolina. Lauender Cotton. 2 Lauendula. Lauender Spike. 3 Stoechas. Ca≈ø≈øidony. 4 Chamaed ‚Ä¢ ys. Germander. 5 Ocimum minus. F ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ba≈ø≈øill. 6 Marum. Herbe Ma≈øticke. 7 Maio ‚Ä¢ ana. Sweete Marietome.

div.head: Maiorana. Sweete Marierome.
div.p: WEe haue many ≈øorts of Marierome; ≈øome that are ≈øweete, and but Summer plants; others that are greater and not ≈øo ≈øweet; and ≈øome al≈øo that are wilde. Of all the≈øe I will onely ≈øelect ≈øome of the choi≈øe≈øt that are fit for this place, and leaue the other for the next garden, and the garden of ≈øimples, or a generall worke: yet hereunto I will adioyne another ≈øweete plant called Ma≈øticke, as participating neerer with them then with Time, whereunto many doe referre it.

div.head: 1. Maiorana maior aestina. Common ≈øweet Marierome.
div.p: The ≈øweet Marierome that is mo≈øt ftequently ≈øowen in our Country, is a low herbe little aboue a foote high when it is at the highe≈øt, full of branches, and ≈ømall whiti≈øh ≈øoft roundi≈øh leaues, ≈ømelling very ≈øweet: at the toppes of the branches ≈øtand diuers ≈ømall ≈øcaly heads, like vnto knots, (and therefore of ≈øome called knotted Marierome) of a whiti≈øh greene colour, out of which come here and there ≈ømall white flowers, and afterwards ≈ømall reddi≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is compo≈øed of many ≈ømall threds or ≈øtrings, which peri≈øh with the whole plant euery yeare.

div.head: 2. Maiorana tenuifolia. Marierome gentle.
div.p: This Marierome hath likewi≈øe diuers ≈ømall branches, growing low, and not higher then the former, but hauing finer and ≈ømaller leaues, hoary and ≈øoft, but much ≈øweeter: the heads are like vnto the former, and ≈øo are the flowers and ≈øeede, and the whole plant abiding but a Summer in the like manner.

div.head: 3. Marum. Herbe Ma≈øticke.
div.p: The neerer re≈øemblance that this herbe hath with Marierome then with Tyme (as I ≈øaid before) hath made me place it next vnto the ≈ømall ≈øweet Marierome. It ri≈øeth vp with a greater, and a more woody ≈øtalke then Marierome, two foote high or better in ≈øome places, where it liketh the ground and ayre, branching out on all ≈øides towards the vpper part, leauing the ≈øtemme bare below, if it bee old, otherwi≈øe being young, thinly furni≈øhing the branches from the bottome with ≈ømall greene leaues, bigger then the leaues of any Tyme, and comming neere vnto the bigne≈ø≈øe and forme of the la≈øt recited finer Marierome, but of a greener colour: at the toppes of the branches ≈øtand ≈ømall white flowers on a head, which afterwards turne into a loo≈øe tuft of a long white hoary matter, like vnto ≈øoft doune, with ≈øome leaues vnderneath and about it, which abide not long on the ≈øtalkes, but are blowne away with the winde: the ≈øeede is ≈øo ≈ømall if it haue any, that I haue not ob≈øerued it: the roote is threddy: the whole plant is of a ≈øweete re≈øinous ≈øent, ≈øtronger then the Marierome, and abideth our winters, if it be carefully planted and regarded.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The ≈øweete Marieromes grow naturally in hot Countreyes: the fir≈øt in Spaine &c. the ≈øecond is thought to come out of Syria, or Per≈øia fir≈øt into Italie, where they much e≈øteeme it, and plant it curiou≈øly and carefully in pots, and ≈øet them in their windowes, beeing much delighted therewith for the ≈øweet ≈øent it hath. The fir≈øt is v≈øually ≈øowen euery yeare in mo≈øt gardens with vs: but the ≈øecond is very rare and daintie, and mu≈øt as daintely be pre≈øerued, being more tender then the former. The herbe Ma≈øticke is thought to be fir≈øt brought out of Candie, Clu≈øius ≈øaith he found it in Spaine: It is planted by ≈ølippes, (and not ≈øowen) in many gardens, and is much replanted
for increa≈øe, but pro≈øpereth onely, or more frequently, in loamie or clay grounds then in any other ≈øoyle.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The ≈øweete Marieromes beare their knots or ≈øcaly heads in the end of Iuly, or in Augu≈øt. Herbe Ma≈øticke in Iune many times, or in the beginning of Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the two ≈øweet Marieromes called Maiorana in Latine √† maiore cura, is taken of mo≈øt writers to be the Amaracus or Samp≈øuchum of Dio≈øcorides, Theophra≈øtus and Plinie, although Galen doth ≈øeem a little to di≈ø≈øent therefrom. The other ≈øweet Marierome hath his name in his title as much as can be ≈øaid of it. The next is thought by the be≈øt of the moderne Writers to be the true Marum that Galen preferreth for the excellent ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, before the former Marierome in making the Oleum, or vnguentum Amaricinum, and ≈øeemeth to incline to their opinion that thought Amaracus was deriued from Marum. It is the ≈øame al≈øo that Galen and others of the ancient Writers make mention of, to go into the compo≈øition of the Trochi≈øci Hedychroi, as well as Amaracus among the ingredients of the Theriaca Andromachi. In Engli≈øh we call it Ma≈øticke ≈øimply, or Herbe Ma≈øtick, both to di≈øtingui≈øh it from that Tyme that is called Ma≈øticke Tyme, and from the Ma≈øticke Tree, or Gum, ≈øo called. Some of later times, and Clu≈øius with them, haue thought this to be Dio≈øcorides his Tragoriganum, which doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble it: but there is another plant that Matthiolus ≈øetteth forth for Marum, that in Lobels opinion and mine is the true≈øt Tragoriganum, and this the true≈øt Marum.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The ≈øweete Marieromes are not onely much v≈øed to plea≈øe the outward ≈øen≈øes in no≈øegayes, and in the windowes of hou≈øes, as al≈øo in ≈øweete pouders, ≈øweete bags, and ≈øweete wa≈øhing waters, but are al≈øo of much v≈øe in Phy≈øicke, both to comfort the outward members, or parts of the body, and the inward al≈øo: to prouoke vrine being ≈øtopped, and to ea≈øe the paines thereof, and to cau≈øe the feminine cour≈øes. Herbe Ma≈øticke is of greater force to helpe the ≈øtopping of vrine, then the Marierome, and is put into Antidotes, as a remedie again≈øt the poy≈øon of venemous Bea≈øts.

div.head: Thymum. Tyme.
div.p: THere are many kindes of Tyme, as they are v≈øually called with vs, ≈øome are called of the garden, and others wilde, which yet for their ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe are brought into gardens, as Muske Tyme, and Lemon Tyme; and ≈øome for their beauty, as embroidered or gold yellow Tyme, and white Tyme. But the true Tyme of the ancient Writers, called Capitatum, as a ≈øpeciall note of di≈øtinction from all other kindes of Tyme, is very rare to be ≈øeene with vs here in England, by rea≈øon of the tenderne≈ø≈øe, that it will not abide our Winters. And all the other ≈øorts that with vs are called garden Tymes, are indeede but kindes of wilde Tyme, although in the defect or want of the true Tyme, they are v≈øed in the ≈øtead of it. With the Tymes I mu≈øt doe as I did with the Marieromes in the Chapter before, that is, re≈øerue the mo≈øt common in v≈øe, for the common v≈øe of the Kitchen, and ≈øhew you only tho≈øe here, that are not put to that v≈øe: and fir≈øt with the true Tyme, becau≈øe it is knowne but to a few.

div.head: 1. Thymum legitimum capitatum. The true Tyme.
div.p: The true Tyme is a very tender plant, hauing hard and hoary brittle branches, ≈øpreading from a ≈ømall wooddy ≈øtemme, about a foote and a halfe high, whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall ioynts, and by ≈øpaces, many ≈ømall, long, whiti≈øh, or hoary greene leaues, of a quicke ≈øent and ta≈øte: at the tops of the branches ≈øtand ≈ømall long whiti≈øh greene heads, ≈øomewhat like vnto the heads of Stoechas, made as it were of many leaues or ≈øcales, out of which ≈øtart forth ≈ømall purpli≈øh flowers (and in ≈øome white, as Bellonius ≈øaith) after which commeth ≈ømall ≈øeede, that ≈øoone falleth out, and if it be not carefully gathered, is ≈øoone lo≈øt, which made (I thinke) Theophra≈øtus to write, that this Tyme was to be ≈øowne of the flowers, as not hauing any other ≈øeede: the root is ≈ømall and wooddy. This holdeth not his leaues in Winter, no not about Seuill in Spaine, where it groweth aboundantly, as Clu≈øius recordeth, finding it there naked or ≈øpoiled of leaues. And will not abide our Winters, but peri≈øheth wholly, roote and all.

div.head: 2. Serpillum horten≈øe ≈øiue maius. Garden wilde Tyme.
div.p: The wilde Tyme that is cheri≈øhed in gardens groweth vpright, but yet is lowe, with diuers ≈ølender branches, and ≈ømall round greene leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto ≈ømall fine Marierome, and ≈ømelling ≈øomewhat like vnto it: the flowers growe in roundels at the toppes of the branches, of a purpli≈øh colour: And in another of this kinde they are of a pure white colour.
There is another al≈øo like hereunto, that ≈ømelleth ≈øomewhat like vnto Muske; and therefore called Muske Tyme, who≈øe greene leaues are not ≈øo ≈ømall as the former, but larger and longer.

div.head: 3. Serpillum Citratum. Lemon Tyme.
div.p: The wilde Tyme that ≈ømelleth like vnto a Pomecitron or Lemon, hath many weake branches trayling on the ground, like vnto the fir≈øt de≈øcribed wilde Tyme, with ≈ømall darke greene leaues, thinly or ≈øpar≈øedly ≈øet on them, and ≈ømelling like vnto a Lemon, with whiti≈øh flowers at the toppes in roundels or ≈øpikes.

div.head: 4. Serpillum aureum ≈øiue verficolor. Guilded or embroidered Tyme.
div.p: This kinde of wilde Tyme hath ≈ømall hard branches lying or leaning to the ground, with ≈ømall party coloured leaues vpon them, diuided into ≈øtripes or edges, of a gold yellow colour, the re≈øt of the leafe abiding greene, which for the variable mixture or placing of the yellow, hath cau≈øed it to be called embroidered or guilded Tyme.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The fir≈øt groweth as is ≈øaid before, about Seuill in Spaine, in very great aboundance as Clu≈øius ≈øaith; and as Bellonius ≈øaith, very plentifully on the mountaines through all Greece. The others growe ≈øome in this Country, and ≈øome in others: but wee pre≈øerue them with all the care wee can in our gardens, for the ≈øweete and plea≈øant ≈øents and varieties they yeeld.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt flowreth not vntill Augu≈øt; the re≈øt in Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: Their names are ≈øeuerally ≈øet downe in their titles, as is ≈øufficient to di≈øtingui≈øh them; and therefore I ≈øhall not neede to trouble you any further with them.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The true Tyme is a ≈øpeciall helpe to melancholicke and ≈øpleneticke di≈øea≈øes, as al≈øo to flatulent humours, either in the vpper or lower parts of the body. The oyle that is Chimically drawne out of ordinary Tyme, is v≈øed (as the whole herbe is, in the ≈øtead of the true) in pils for the head and ≈øtomach. It is al≈øo much v≈øed for the toothach, as many other ≈øuch like hot oyles are.

div.head: Hy≈ø≈øopus. Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: THere are many varieties of Hy≈ø≈øope, be≈øide the common or ordinary, which I re≈øerue for the Kitchen garden, and intend onely in this place to giue you the knowledge of ≈øome more rare: viz. of ≈øuch as are nour≈øed vp by tho≈øe that are curious, and fit for this garden: for there are ≈øome other, that mu≈øt be remembred in the Phy≈øicke garden, or garden of Simples, or el≈øe in a generall worke.

div.head: 1. Hy≈ø≈øopus folijs niueis. White Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: This white Hy≈ø≈øope is of the ≈øame kinde and ≈ømell with the common Hy≈ø≈øope; but differeth, in that this many times hath diuers leaues, that are wholly of a white colour, with part of the ≈øtalke al≈øo: others are parted, the one halfe white, the other halfe greene, and ≈øome are wholly greene, or with ≈øome ≈øpots or ≈øtripes of white within the greene, which makes it delightfull to mo≈øt Gentlewomen.

div.head: 2. Hy≈ø≈øopus folijs cinereis. Ru≈ø≈øet Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: As the la≈øt hath party coloured leaues, white and greene, ≈øo this hath his leaues of an a≈øh-colour, which of ≈øome is called ru≈ø≈øet; and hath no other difference either in forme or ≈ømell.

div.head: 3. Hy≈ø≈øopus aureus. Yellow or golden Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: All the leaues of this Hy≈ø≈øope are wholly yellow, or but a little greene in them, and are of ≈øo plea≈øant a colour, e≈øpecially in Summer, that they prouoke many Gentlewomen to weare them in their heads, and on their armes, with as much delight as many fine flowers can giue: but in Winter their beautifull colour is much decayed, being of a whiti≈øh greene, yet recouer them≈øelues againe the next Summer.

div.head: 4. Hy≈ø≈øopus ≈øurculis den≈øis. Double Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: As this kinde of Hy≈ø≈øope groweth lower then the former or ordinary kinde, ≈øo it hath more branches, ≈ølenderer, and not ≈øo wooddy, leaning ≈øomewhat downe toward the ground, ≈øo wonderfully thicke ≈øet with leaues, that are like vnto the other, but of a darker greene colour, and ≈øomewhat thicker withall, that it is the onely fine ≈øweete herbe, that I know fitte≈øt (if any be minded to plant herbes) to ≈øet or border a knot of herbes or flowers, becau≈øe it will well abide, and not growe too wooddy or great, nor be thinne of leaues in one part, when it is thicke in another, ≈øo that it may be kept with cutting as ≈ømooth and plaine as a table. If it be ≈øuffered to growe vp of it ≈øelfe alone, it ri≈øeth with leaues as before is ≈øpecified, and flowreth as the common doth, and of the: ≈øame ≈øent al≈øo, not differing in any thing, but in the thickne≈ø≈øe of the leaues on the ≈øtalkes and branches, and the aptne≈ø≈øe to be ordered as the keeper plea≈øeth.

div.head: Chamaedrys. Germander.
div.p: Le≈øt Germander ≈øhould be vtterly forgotten, as not worthy of our Garden, ≈øeeing many (as I ≈øaid in my treati≈øe or introduction to this Garden) doe border knots therewith: let me at the leaft giue it a place, although the la≈øt, being more v≈øed as a ≈øtrewing herbe for the hou≈øe, then for any other v≈øe. It is (I thinke) ≈øufficiently knowne to haue many branches, with ≈ømall and ≈øomewhat round endented leaues on them, and purpli≈øh gaping flowers: the rootes ≈øpreading far abroad, and ri≈øing vp againe in many places.

div.head: The Place.
div.p: The≈øe Hy≈ø≈øopes haue beene mo≈øt of them nour≈øed vp of long time in our Engli≈øh Gardens, but from whence their fir≈øt originall ≈øhould be, is not well knowne. The Germander al≈øo is onely in Gardens, and not wilde.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: They flower in Iune and Iuly.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The ≈øeuerall names whereby they are knowne to vs, are ≈øet forth in their titles; and therefore I neede not here ≈øay more of them then onely this, that neyther they here ≈øet downe, nor the common or ordinary ≈øort, nor any of the re≈øt not here expre≈ø≈øed, are any of them the true Hy≈ø≈øope of the ancient Greeke Writers, but ≈øuppo≈øititiae, v≈øed in the ≈øtead thereof. The Germander, from the forme of the leaues like vnto ≈ømall oaken leaues, had the name Chamaedrys giuen it, which ≈øignifieth a dwarfe Oake.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The common Hy≈ø≈øope is much v≈øed in all pectorall medicines, to cut fleagme, and to cau≈øe it ea≈øily to be auoided. It is v≈øed of many people in the Country, to be laid vnto cuts or fre≈øh wounds, being brui≈øed, and applyed eyther alone, or with a little Sugar. It is much v≈øed as a ≈øweet herbe, to be in the windowes of an hou≈øe. I finde it much commended again≈øt the Falling Sickne≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially being made into Pils after this manner: Of Hy≈ø≈øope, Horhound, and Ca≈øtor, of each halfe a dramme, of Peony rootes (the male kinde is onely fit to be v≈øed for this purpo≈øe) two drams, of A≈ø≈øa faetida one ≈øcruple: Let them be beaten, and made into pils with the iuyce of Hy≈ø≈øope; which being taken for ≈øeuen dayes together at night going to bed, is held to be effectual to giue much ea≈øe, if not thoroughly to cure tho≈øe that are troubled with that di≈øea≈øe. The v≈øe of Germander ordinarily is as Tyme, Hy≈ø≈øope, and other ≈øuch herbes, to border a knot, whereunto it is often appropriate, and the rather, that it might be cut to ≈øerue (as I ≈øaid) for a ≈øtrewing herbe for the hou≈øe among others. For the phy≈øicall v≈øe it ≈øerueth in di≈øea≈øes of the ≈øplene, and the ≈øtopping of vrine, and to procure womens cour≈øes.

Thus haue I led you through all my Garden of Plea≈øure, and ≈øhewed you all the varieties of nature nour≈øed therein, pointing vnto them, and de≈øcribing them one after another. And now la≈øtly (according to the v≈øe of our old ancient Fathers) I bring you to re≈øt on the Gra≈ø≈øe, which yet ≈øhall not be without ≈øome delight, and that not the lea≈øt of all the re≈øt.

figure.head: 1 Thymum legitimum. The true Tyme. 2 Serpillum maius borten≈øe. Garcen walde Tyme. 3 Serpillum Citratum. Lemon Tyme. 4 Hy≈ø≈øopus verfi ‚Ä¢ olo ≈øiue aureus. Golden Hy≈ø≈øope. 5 Chamaedrys. Germander. 6 Spartum Au≈øtriacum ≈øiue Gramen plumarium minus. The le≈ø≈øer feather Gra≈ø≈øe. 7 Gramen ≈øtriatum vel ≈øulcatum Painted Gra≈ø≈øe or Ladies Laces.

div.head: Gramina. Gra≈ø≈øes.
div.p: THere are among an infinite number (as I may ≈øo ≈øay) of Gra≈ø≈øes, a few onely which I thinke fit to be planted in this Garden, both for the rarity of them, and al≈øo for your delight, and the excellent beauty that is in them aboue many other plants. One of them hath long agoe bin re≈øpected, and cheri≈øhed in the country gardens of many Gentlewomen, and others. The others are knowne but vnto a few.

div.head: 1. Gramen ≈øtriatum. Painted Gra≈ø≈øe or Ladies laces.
div.p: This kinde of Gra≈ø≈øe hath many ≈øtiffe, hard, round ≈øtalkes, full of ioynts, whereon are ≈øet at euery ioynt one long leafe, ≈øomewhat broad at the bottome, where it compa≈ø≈øeth the ≈øtalke, and ≈ømaller to the end, where it is ≈øharpe pointed, hard or rough in handling, and ≈øtriped all the length of the leafe with white ≈øtreakes or lines, that they ≈øeeme party coloured laces of white and greene: the tops of the ≈øtalkes are furni≈øhed with long ≈øpikie tufts, like vnto the tufts of Couch Gra≈ø≈øe: the rootes are ≈ømall, white, and threddy, like the rootes of other Gra≈ø≈øes.

div.head: 2. Gramen Plumarium minus. The le≈ø≈øer Feather-Gra≈ø≈øe.
div.p: This le≈ø≈øer Feather-Gra≈ø≈øe hath many ≈ømall, round, and very long leaues or blades, growing in tufts, much finer and ≈ømaller then any other Gra≈ø≈øe that I know, being almo≈øt like vnto haires, and of a fre≈øh greene colour in Summer, but changing into gray, like old hay in Winter, being indeede all dead, and neuer reuiuing; yet hardly to be plucked away vntill the Spring, and then other greene leaues or ru≈øhes ri≈øe vp by them, and in their ≈øtead, and are aboue a foote in length: from the middle of the≈øe tufts come forth rounder and bigger ru≈øhes, which are the ≈øtalkes, and which haue a chaffie round eare about the middle thereof, which when it is full growne, is ≈øomewhat higher then the toppes of the leaues or ru≈øhes, opening it ≈øelfe (being before clo≈øe) at the top, and ≈øhewing forth three or foure long ayles or beards, one aboue another, which bend them≈øelues a little downewards (if they ≈øtand ouer long before they are gathered, and will fall off, and be blowne away with the winde) being ≈øo finely feathered on both ≈øides, all the length of the beard, and of a pale or grayi≈øh colour, that no feather in the taile of the Bird of Paradi≈øe can be finer, or to be compared with them, hauing ≈øticking at the end of euery one of them, within the eare, a ≈ømall, long, whiti≈øh, round, hard, and very ≈øharpe pointed graine, like vnto an oaten graine, that part of the ≈øtalke of the feather that is next vnder it, and aboue the ≈øeede for ≈øome two or three inches, being ≈øtiffe and hard, and twining or curling it ≈øelfe, if it be ≈øuffered to ≈øtand too long, or to fall away, otherwi≈øe being ≈øtraight as the feather it ≈øelfe: the roote is compo≈øed of many long, hard, ≈ømall threddy ≈øtrings, which runne deepe and far, and will not willingly be remoued, in that it gaineth ≈øtrength euery yeare by ≈øtanding.

div.head: 3. Gramen Plumarium maius. The greater Feather-Gra≈ø≈øe.
div.p: The greater Feather-Gra≈ø≈øe is like vnto the le≈ø≈øer, but that both the leaues and the feathers are greater, and nothing ≈øo fine, gro≈ø≈øer al≈øo, and of le≈ø≈øe beauty and re≈øpect, though whiter then it; and therefore is not ≈øo much regarded: for I haue knowne, that many Gentlewomen haue v≈øed the former le≈ø≈øer kinde, being tyed in tufts, to ≈øet them in ≈øtead of feathers about their beds, where they haue lyen after childe-bearing, and at other times al≈øo, when as they haue been much admited of the Ladies and Gentles that haue come to vi≈øit them.

div.head: The Place.
div.p:
The fir≈øt of the≈øe Gra≈ø≈øes, as Lobel ≈øaith, groweth naturally in the woods and hils of Sauoy. It hath long agoe beene receiued into our Engli≈øh gardens.
The ≈øecond, as Clu≈øius ≈øaith, in Au≈øtria, from whence al≈øo (as I take it) the greater came, and are both in the gardens of tho≈øe, that are curious ob≈øeruers of the≈øe delights.

div.head: The Time.
div.p: The fir≈øt is in its pride for the leaues all the Spring and Summer, yeelding his bu≈øh in Iune. The other giue their feather-like ≈øprigs in Iuly and Augu≈øt, and quickly (as I ≈øaid) are ≈øhed, if they be not carefully gathered.

div.head: The Names.
div.p: The fir≈øt is called by Lobel Gramen ≈øulcatum, or ≈øtrutum album; of others Gramen pictum. The French call it Aiguellettes d'armes, of the fa≈øhion that their En≈øignes, Pennons, or Streamers v≈øed in wars were of, that is, like vnto a party coloured curtaine. In Engli≈øh v≈øually Ladies laces, and Painted Gra≈ø≈øe. The fir≈øt of the other two is called Gramen plumarium or plumo≈øum, and minus is added for the di≈øtinction of it. Clu≈øius calleth it Spartum Au≈øtriacum, of the likene≈ø≈øe and place where he found it. The la≈øt is called Gramen plumarium, or plumo≈øum mains, The greater Feather-Gra≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The Vertues.
div.p: The≈øe kindes of Gra≈ø≈øes are not in any time or place that I doe heare of applyed to any Phy≈øicall v≈øe; and therefore of them I will ≈øay no more: but here I will end the prime part of this worke.

div.head: THE ORDERING OF THE KITCHEN GARDEN.
CHAP. I. The ≈øituation of a Kitchen Garden, or Garden of Herbes, and what ≈øort of manure is fitte≈øt to helpe the decaying of the ≈øoyle thereof.
div.p:
HAuing giuen you the be≈øt rules and in≈øtructions that I can for your flower Garden, and all the flowers that are fit to furni≈øh it, I now proceede to your herbe garden, which is not of the lea≈øt re≈øpect belonging to any mans hou≈øe, nor vtterly to bee neglected for the many vtilities are to be had from it, both for the Ma≈øters profit and plea≈øure, and the meynies content and nouri≈øhment: all which if I ≈øhould here ≈øet down, I had a large field to wander in, and matter ≈øufficient to entreat of, but this worke permitteth not that libertie: and I thinke there are but few but eyther know it already, or conceiue it ≈øufficiently in their minds. Pa≈ø≈øing therefore no further in ≈øuch di≈øcour≈øes, I come to the matter in hand, which is to ≈øhew you where the fitte≈øt place is for an herbe garden.
