As before I ≈øhewed you that the beautie of any worthy hou≈øe is much the more commended for the plea≈øant ≈øituation of the garden of flowers, or of plea≈øure, to be in the ≈øight and full pro≈øpect of all the chiefe and choi≈øe≈øt roomes of the hou≈øe; ≈øo contrariwi≈øe, your herbe garden ≈øhould bee on the one or other ≈øide of the hou≈øe, and tho≈øe be≈øt and choy≈øe roomes: for the many different ≈øents that ari≈øe from the herbes, as Cabbages, Onions, &c. are ≈øcarce well plea≈øing to perfume the lodgings of any hou≈øe; and the many ouertures and breaches as it were of many of the beds thereof, which mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily bee, are al≈øo as little plea≈øant to the ≈øight. But for priuate mens hou≈øes, who mu≈øt like their habitations as they fall vnto them, and cannot haue time or meanes to alter them, they mu≈øt make a vertue of nece≈ø≈øity, and conuert their places to their be≈øt aduantage, by making their profit their chiefe≈øt plea≈øure, and making one place ≈øerue for all v≈øes. The choyce of ground for this Garden, is (as I ≈øaid before) where it is fat, fertill and good, there needeth the le≈ø≈øe labour and co≈øt: and contrariwi≈øe, where it is cold, wet, dry or barren, there mu≈øt bee the more helpes ≈øtill added to keepe it in heart. For this Garden by rea≈øon of the much and continuall ≈øtirring therein, the herbes and rootes drawing out the ≈øub≈øtance of the fertilitie thereof more aboundantly then in the former, mu≈øt be continually holpen with ≈øoyle, or el≈øe few things of goodne≈ø≈øe or worth will come forward therein. The ≈øtable ≈øoyle of hor≈øes is be≈øt and more proper for any colde grounds, for being the hotte≈øt, it will cau≈øe any the ≈øeedes for this Garden to pro≈øper well, and be more forward then in any other ground that is not ≈øo holpen. The ≈øtable ≈øoyle of Cattell is of a colder and moi≈øter nature, and is therefore more proper for
the hot ≈øandy or grauelly grounds, and although it bee longer before it bee brought to mould then that of hor≈øes, yet it will outla≈øt it more then twice ≈øo long. Let euery one therefore take according to the nature of the ground ≈øuch helpes as are mo≈øt fit and conuenient, as I haue here and before ≈øhewed. But I doe here ingenuou≈øly confe≈ø≈øe my opinion of the≈øe forcings and helpings of ground, that how≈øoeuer it doth much good to ≈øome particular things, which becau≈øe they delight in heate, and cannot be brought to perfection without it in this our Countrey, which is colder then their naturall from whence they are brought, mu≈øt therfore haue artificiall helpes to forward them; yet for many other things the compo≈øt doth much alter and abate the naturall vigour, and quickene≈ø≈øe of ta≈øte, that is perceiued in them that grow in a naturall fat or ≈øandy ≈øoile that is not ≈øo holpen.

div.head: CHAP. II. The forme of a Garden of herbes for nece≈ø≈øary v≈øes, with the ordering thereof.
div.p: AS our former Garden of plea≈øure is wholly formable in euery part with ≈øquares, trayles, and knots, and to bee ≈øtill maintained in their due forme and beautie: ≈øo on the contrary ≈øide this Garden cannot long con≈øerue any forme, for that euery part thereof is ≈øubiect to mutation and alteration. For although it is conuenient that many herbes doe grow by them≈øelues on beds, ca≈øt out into ≈øome proportion fit for them, as Tyme, Hi≈ø≈øope, Sage, &c. yet many others may bee ≈øowen together on a plot of ground of that largene≈ø≈øe that may ≈øerue euery mans particular v≈øe as he ≈øhall haue occa≈øion to employ it, as Reddi≈øh, Lettice and Onions, which after they are growne vp together may be drawne vp and taken away, as there is occa≈øion to ≈øpend them: but Carrots or Par≈øneps being ≈øowen with others mu≈øt bee ≈øuffered to grow la≈øt, becau≈øe they require a longer time before they be fit to be taken vp. Other herbes require ≈øome large compa≈ø≈øe of ground whereon they may grow of them≈øelues without any other herbes growing among them, as Artichokes, Cowcumbers, Melons, Pompions. And ≈øome will doe ≈øo with their Cabbages al≈øo, but the be≈øt and mo≈øt frugall way now v≈øed, is to plant them round about the border of your plot or ground whereon you plant Cowcumbers, Pompions, or other things, in that by this meanes ≈øo much ground will be well ≈øaued, and the other things be no whit hindered thereby, which el≈øe a great deale of ground mu≈øt be employed for them apart. So that by this that I haue here ≈øaid, you may perceiue the forme of this Garden is for the mo≈øt part, to bee ≈øtill out of forme and order, in that the continuall taking vp of the herbes and rootes that are ≈øowen and planted, cau≈øeth the beds or parts of this Garden to lye broken, di≈ømembered, and out of the order that at the fir≈øt it was put into. Remember herewithall that (as I ≈øaid before) this Garden requireth the continuall helpe of ≈øoyle to be brought into it, in that the plenty of the≈øe manner of herbes and rootes doe ≈øo much wa≈øte the fertilitie and fatne≈ø≈øe of the ground, that without continuall refre≈øhing it would quickly become ≈øo poore and barren, that it would not yeelde the worth of the ≈øeede. The ordinary time to ≈øoyle a Garden, is to bring in manure or dung before Chri≈øtmas, and eyther bury it ≈øome ≈ømall depth, not too deepe, or el≈øe to lay it vpon the ground that the winter fro≈øtes may pierce it, and then turne it ≈øhallow into the ground to ≈øow your ≈øeeds in the Spring.

div.head: CHAP. III. How to order diuers Garden herbes, both for their ≈øowing, ≈øpending, and gathering of the ≈øeede.
div.p:
OVr chiefe≈øt and greate≈øt Gardiners now adaies, doe ≈øo prouide for them≈øelues euery yeare, that from their owne grounds they gather the ≈øeede of many herbes that they ≈øowe againe: for hauing gained the be≈øt kind of diuers herbes, they will be ≈øtill furni≈øhed with the ≈øame, and be not to ≈øeeke euery yeare for new that oftentimes will not yeelde them halfe the profit that their choyce ≈øeede will: I ≈øay of many herbes, but not of all; for the be≈øt of them all hath not ground ≈øufficient for all ≈øorts, nor will our climate bring ≈øome to that perfection that other forraine doth, and therefore the ≈øeede of ≈øome things are continually brought from beyond Sea vnto vs. And againe although our chiefe Gardiners doe ≈øtill prouide their owne ≈øeede of diuers things from their owne ground, becau≈øe as I ≈øaid it is of the be≈øt kinde, yet you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand al≈øo, that good ≈øtore of the ≈øame ≈øortes of ≈øeeds are brought from beyond the Seas, for that which is gathered in this Land is not ≈øufficient to ≈øerue euery mans v≈øe in the whole Kingdome by many parts; yet ≈øtill it is true, that our Engli≈øh ≈øeede of many things is better then any that commeth from beyond the Seas: as for example, Reddi≈øh, Lettice, Carrots, Par≈øneps, Turneps, Cabbages, and Leekes, of all which I intend to write in this place; for the≈øe are by them ≈øo husbanded, that they doe not ≈øow their owne grounds with any other ≈øeede of the≈øe ≈øorts but their owne: which that you may know the manner how to doe, I will here ≈øet it downe, that euery one may haue the be≈øt directions if they will follow them. Of Reddi≈øh there are two ≈øorts, one more early then the other: they v≈øe therfore to ≈øow their early Reddi≈øh fir≈øt, that they may haue the earlie≈øt profit of them, which is more worth in one fortnight, then in a moneth after. And to effect this they haue ≈øome artificiall helps al≈øo; which are the≈øe: They v≈øe to digge vp a large plot of ground where they intend to ≈øow their ≈øeede a little before or after Chri≈øtmas, ca≈øting it into high balkes or ridges fiue or ≈øixe foote a≈øunder, which they ≈øuffer to lye and take all the extreame fro≈øts in Ianuary to mellow the earth, and when the fro≈øtes are pa≈øt, they then beginne to bring into it good ≈øtore of fre≈øh ≈øtable dung, which they laye neyther too deepe nor too thicke, and couer it with the mould a hand breadth thickne≈ø≈øe aboue the dung, which doth giue ≈øuch a warmth and comfort to what≈øoeuer is ≈øowen thereon, that it forceth it forward much ≈øooner then any other way can doe: And to preuent both the fro≈øtes, and the cold bitter windes which often ≈øpoyle their ≈øeede new ≈øprung vp, they v≈øe to ≈øet great high and large mattes made of reedes, tyed together, and fa≈øtened vnto ≈øtrong ≈øtakes, thru≈øt into the ground to keepe them vp from falling, or being blowne down with the winde; which mattes they place on the North and Ea≈øt ≈øide to breake the force of the≈øe winds, and are ≈øo ≈øure and ≈øafe a defence, that a bricke wall cannot better defend any thing vnder it, then this fence will. In this manner they doe euery yeare to bring forward their ≈øeede to gaine the more by them, and they that will haue Reddi≈øh early, mu≈øt take the ≈øame cour≈øe. The other ≈øort of Reddi≈øh for the mo≈øt part is ≈øowen in Februarie, a fortnight after the other at the lea≈øt, and likewi≈øe euery moneth after vnto September, that they may haue young continually. For the blacke Reddi≈øh, although many in many places doe ≈øowe it in the ≈øame time, and in the ≈øame manner that the ordinary is ≈øowen, yet the nature thereof is to runne vp to ≈øeede more ≈øpeedily then the other, if it haue ≈øo rich ground to grow vpon, and therefore the be≈øt time to ≈øow it is in Augu≈øt, that ≈øo it may abide all winter, wherein is the chiefe≈øt time for the ≈øpending thereof, and to keepe it vntill the beginning of the next yeare from running vp to ≈øeede the gathering whereof, as al≈øo of the other ≈øort, is all after one manner, that is, to be pulled vp when the pods change whiti≈øh, and then hanged vpon bu≈øhes, pales, or ≈øuch other thing, vntill they bee thorough dry, and then beaten or thra≈øhed out vpon a ≈ømooth plancher, or vpon clothes, as euery ones ≈øtore is, and their conueniencie. Lettice is ≈øowen oftentimes with the early Reddi≈øh, in the ≈øame manner before ≈øaid, that they may haue Lettice likewi≈øe as early as the time of the year will permit them, which
they pull vp where they grow too thicke, ≈øpending them fir≈øt, and ≈øo taking, vp from time to time, vntill they ≈øtand two foote in ≈øunder one from another, and beginne to ≈øpindle and ≈øhoote vp for ≈øeede. In this is v≈øed ≈øome arte to make the plants ≈øtrong to giue the better ≈øeede without danger of rotting or ≈øpoyling with the wet, which often happeneth to tho≈øe about whom this caution is not ob≈øerued: Before your Lettice is ≈øhot vp, marke out the choy≈øe≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt plantes which are fitte≈øt to grow for ≈øeede, and from tho≈øe when they are a foote high, ≈øtrippe away with your hand the leaues that grow lowe≈øt vpon the ≈øtalke next the ground, which might rot, ≈øpoyle or hinder them from bearing ≈øo good ≈øeede; which when it is neere to be ripe, the ≈øtalkes mu≈øt be cut off about the middle, and layde vpon mats or clothes in the Sunne, that it may there fully ripen and be gathered; for it would be blowne away with the winde if it ≈øhould be ≈øuffered to abide on the ≈øtalkes long. Par≈øneps mu≈øt be ≈øowen on a deep trenched mellow ground, otherwi≈øe they may run to ≈øeede the fir≈øt yeare, which then are nothing worth: or el≈øe the rootes will be ≈ømall ≈øtaruelings and ≈øhort, and runne into many ≈øpires or branches, whereby they will not bee of halfe the worth. Some v≈øe to ≈øow them in Augu≈øt and September, that ≈øo they may bee well growne to ≈øerue to ≈øpend in Lent following, but their be≈øt time is in February, that the Summers growth may make them the fairer and greater. When they runne vp to ≈øeede, you ≈øhall take the principall or middle heades, for tho≈øe carry the Ma≈øter ≈øeede, which is the be≈øt, and will produce the faire≈øt rootes againe. You ≈øhall hardly haue all the ≈øeede ripe at one in≈øtant, for v≈øually the chiefe≈øt heads will be fallen before the other are ripe: you mu≈øt therefore ≈øtill looke them ouer, and cut them as they ripen. Carrots are v≈øually ≈øowen in March and Aprill, and if it chance that ≈øome of them doe runne vp for ≈øeede the ≈øame year, they are to be weeded out, for neyther the ≈øeed nor roots of them are good: You mu≈øt likewi≈øe pull them vp when they are too thicke, if you will haue them grow fair, or for ≈øeed, that they may grow at the lea≈øt three or foure foot in ≈øunder: the ≈øtalkes of Carrots are limber, and fall downe to the ground; they mu≈øt therefore be ≈øu≈øtained by poles layde acro≈ø≈øe on ≈øtalkes thru≈øt into the ground, and tyed to the poles and ≈øtalkes to keepe them vp from rotting or ≈øpoyling vpon the ground: the ≈øeed hereof is not all ripe at once, but mu≈øt be tended and gathered as it ripeneth, and layd to dry in ≈øome dry chamber or floore, and then beaten out with a ≈øtick, and winnowed from the refu≈øe. Turneps are ≈øowne by them≈øelues vpon a good ground in the end of Iuly, and beginning of Augu≈øt, to haue their rootes be≈øt to ≈øpend in winter; for it often happeneth that tho≈øe ≈øeedes of Turneps that are ≈øowen in the Spring, runne vp to ≈øeede the ≈øame yeare, and then it is not accounted good. Many doe v≈øe to ≈øow Turneps on tho≈øe grounds from whence the ≈øame yeare they haue taken off Reddi≈øh and Lettice, to make the greater profit of the ground, by hauing two crops of increa≈øe in one yeare. The ≈øtalkes of Turneps will bend downe to the ground, as Carrots doe, but yet mu≈øt not be bound or ordered in that manner, but ≈øuffered to grow without ≈øtaking or binding, ≈øo as they grow of ≈øome good di≈øtance in ≈øunder: when the ≈øeede beginneth to grow ripe, be very carefull to pre≈øerue it from the birds, which will be mo≈øt bu≈øie to deuour them. You ≈øhall vnder≈øtand likewi≈øe that many doe account the be≈øt way to haue the faire≈øt and mo≈øt principall ≈øeede from all the≈øe fore-recited herbes, that after they are ≈øowen, and ri≈øen to a rea≈øonable growth, they be tran≈øplanted into fre≈øh ground. Cabbages al≈øo are not only ≈øowen for the v≈øe of their heads to ≈øpend for meat, but to gather their ≈øeede likewi≈øe, which how≈øoeuer ≈øome haue endeauoured to doe, yet few haue gained good ≈øeede, becau≈øe our ≈øharpe hard fro≈øtes in winter haue ≈øpoyled and rotted their ≈øtockes they pre≈øerued for the purpo≈øe; but others haue found out a better and a more ≈øure way, which is, to take vp your ≈øtocks that are fitte≈øt to be pre≈øerued, and bring them into the hou≈øe, and there wrap them eyther in clothes, or other things to defend them from the cold, and hang them vp in a dry place, vntill the beginning of March following, then planting them in the ground, and a little defend them at the fir≈øt with ≈øtraw ca≈øt ouer them from the cold nights, thereby you may be ≈øure to haue perfect good ≈øeede, if your kinde be of the be≈øt: Sowe your ≈øeed in the moneths of February or March, and tran≈øplant them in May where they may ≈øtand to grow for your v≈øe, but be carefull to kill the wormes or Caterpillers that el≈øe will deuoure all your leaues, and be carefull al≈øo that none of the leaues bee broken in the planting, or otherwi≈øe rubbed, for that oftentimes hindereth the well clo≈øing of them. Leekes are
for the mo≈øt part wholly nour≈øed vp from the ≈øeede that is here gathered; and becau≈øe there is not ≈øo much ≈øtore of them either ≈øowne or ≈øpent, as there is of Onions by the twentieth part, we are ≈øtill the more carefull to be prouided from our owne labours; yet there be diuers Gardiners in this Kingdome, that doe gather ≈øome ≈ømall quantity of Onion ≈øeede al≈øo for their owne or their priuate friends ≈øpending. The ≈øowing of them both is much about one time and manner, yet mo≈øt v≈øually Leeks are ≈øowne later then Onions, and both before the end of March at the furthe≈øt; yet ≈øome ≈øowe Onions from the end of Iuly to the beginning of September, for their Winter proui≈øion. Tho≈øe that are ≈øowne in the Spring, are to be taken vp and tran≈øplanted on a fre≈øh bed prepared for the purpo≈øe, or el≈øe they will hardly abide a Winter; but hauing taken roote before Winter, they will beare good ≈øeede in the Summer following: You mu≈øt ≈øtake both your Leekes and your Onion beds, and with poles laid a cro≈ø≈øe, binde your lopple headed ≈øtalkes vnto them, on high as well as belowe, or el≈øe the winde and their owne weight will beare them downe to the ground, and ≈øpoile your ≈øeede. You mu≈øt thinne them, that is, pull vp continually after they are fir≈øt ≈øprung vp tho≈øe that growe too thicke, as you doe with all the other herbes before ≈øpoken of, that they may haue the more roome to thriue. Of all the≈øe herbes and rootes before ≈øpoken of, you mu≈øt take the likelie≈øt and faire≈øt to keepe for your ≈øeede; for if you ≈øhould not take the be≈øt, what hope of good ≈øeede can you expect? The time for the ≈øpending of the≈øe herbes and rootes, not particularly mentioned, is vntill they begin to runne vp for ≈øeede, or vntill they are to be tran≈øplanted for ≈øeede, or el≈øe vntill Winter, while they are good, as euery one ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. How to order Artichokes, Melons, Cowcumbers, and Pompions.
div.p:
THere are certaine other herbes to be ≈øpoken of, which are wholly nour≈øed vp for their fruit ≈øake, of whom I ≈øhall not need to ≈øay much, being they are ≈øo frequent in euery place. Artichokes being planted of faire and large ≈ølips, taken from the roote in September and October (yet not too late) will mo≈øt of them beare fruit the next yeare, ≈øo that they be planted in well dunged ground, and the earth rai≈øed vp like vnto an Anthill round about each roote, to defend them the better from the extreame fro≈øts in Winter. Others plant ≈ølips in March and Aprill, or ≈øooner, but although ≈øome of them will beare fruit the ≈øame yeare, yet all will not. And indeede many doe rather choo≈øe to plant in the ≈øpring then in the fall, for that oftentimes an extreame hard Winter following the new ≈øetting of ≈ølips, when they haue not taken ≈øufficient heart and roote in the ground, doth vtterly pierce and peri≈øh them, when as they that are ≈øet in the Spring haue the whole Summers growth, to make them ≈øtrong before they feele any ≈øharpe fro≈øts, which by that time they are the better able to beare. Muske Melons haue beene begun to bee nour≈øed vp but of late dayes in this Land, wherein although many haue tryed and endeauoured to bring them to perfection, yet few haue attained vnto it: but tho≈øe rules and orders which the be≈øt and skilfulle≈øt haue v≈øed, I will here ≈øet downe, that who ≈øo will, may haue as good and ripe Melons as any other in this Land. The fir≈øt thing you are to looke vnto, is to prouide you a peece of ground fit for the purpo≈øe, which is either a ≈øloping or ≈øheluing banke, lying open and oppo≈øite to the South Sunne, or ≈øome other fit place not ≈øheluing, and this ground al≈øo you mu≈øt ≈øo prepare, that all the art you can v≈øe about it to make it rich is little enough; and therefore you mu≈øt rai≈øe it with meere ≈øtable ≈øoyle, thorough rotten & well turned vp, that it may be at the lea≈øt three foote deepe thereof, which you mu≈øt ca≈øt al≈øo into high beds or balkes, with deepe trenches or furrowes betweene, ≈øo as the ridges may be at the lea≈øt a foot and a halfe higher then the furrowes; for otherwi≈øe it is not po≈ø≈øible to haue good Melons growe ripe. The choi≈øe of your ≈øeede al≈øo is another thing of e≈øpeciall regard, and the be≈øt is held to be Spani≈øh, and not French, which hauing once gained, be ≈øure to haue ≈øtill of the ≈øame while they la≈øt
good, that you may haue the ≈øeede of your owne ripe Melons from them that haue eaten them, or ≈øaue ≈øome of the be≈øt your ≈øelfe for the purpo≈øe. I ≈øay while they la≈øt good; for many are of opinion, that no ≈øeede of Muske Melons gathered in England, will endure good to ≈øowe againe here aboue the third yeare, but ≈øtill they mu≈øt be renewed from whence you had your choi≈øe≈øt before. Then hauing prepared a hot bed of dung in Aprill, ≈øet your ≈øeedes therein to rai≈øe them vp, and couer them, and order them with as great care or greater then Cowcumbers, &c. are v≈øed, that when they are ready, they may be tran≈øplanted vpon the beds or balkes of that ground you had before prepared for them, and ≈øet them at the lea≈øt two yards in ≈øunder, euery one as it were in a hole, with a circle of dung about them, which vpon the ≈øetting being watered with water that hath ≈øtood in the Sunne a day or two, and ≈øo as often as neede is to water, couer them with ≈øtrawe (≈øome v≈øe great hollow gla≈ø≈øes like vnto bell heads) or ≈øome ≈øuch other things, to defend them both from the cold euenings or dayes, and the heate of the Sunne, while they are young and new planted. There are ≈øome that take vpon them great skill, that mi≈ølike of the rai≈øing vp of Melons, as they doe al≈øo of Cowcumbers, on a hot bed of hor≈øe dung, but will put two or three ≈øeedes in a place in the very ground where they ≈øhall ≈øtand and growe, and thinke without that former manner of forcing them forwards, that this their manner of planting will bring them on fa≈øt and ≈øure enough, in that they will plucke away ≈øome of the wor≈øt and weake≈øt, if too many ri≈øe vp together in a place; but let them know for certaine, that how≈øoeuer for Cowcumbers their purpo≈øe and order may doe rea≈øonable well, where the ground is rich and good, and where they ≈øtriue not to haue them ≈øo early, as they that v≈øe the other way, for Muske Melons, which are a more tender fruit, requiring greater care and trouble in the nour≈øing, and greater and ≈øtronger heate for the ripening, they mu≈øt in our cold climate haue all the art v≈øed vnto them that may be, to bring them on the more early, and haue the more comfort of the Sunne to ripen them kindly, or el≈øe they will not bee worth the labour and ground. After you haue planted them as afore≈øaid, ≈øome of good skill doe adui≈øe, that you be carefull in any dry ≈øea≈øon, to giue them water twice or thrice euery weeke while they are young, but more afterward when they are more growne, and that in the morning e≈øpecially, yea and when the fruit is growne ≈øomewhat great, to water the fruit it ≈øelfe with a watering pot in the heate of the day, is of ≈øo good effect, that it ripeneth them much fa≈øter, and will giue them the better ta≈øte and ≈ømell, as they ≈øay. To take likewi≈øe the fruit, and gather it at the full time of his ripene≈ø≈øe is no ≈ømall art; for if it be gathered before his due time to be pre≈øently eaten, it will be hard and greene, and not eate kindly; and likewi≈øe if it be ≈øuffered too long, the whole goodne≈ø≈øe will be lo≈øt: You ≈øhall therefore know, that it is full time to gather them to ≈øpend pre≈øently, when they begin to looke a little yellowi≈øh on the out≈øide, and doe ≈ømell full and ≈øtrong; but if you be to ≈øend them farre off, or keepe them long vpon any occa≈øion, you ≈øhall then gather them ≈øo much the earlier, that according to the time of the carriage and ≈øpending, they may ripen in the lying, being kept dry, and couered with woollen clothes: When you cut one to eate, you ≈øhall know it to be ripe and good, if the ≈øeede and pulpe about them in the middle be very wateri≈øh, and will ea≈øily be ≈øeparated from the meate, and likewi≈øe if the meate looke yellow, and be mellow, and not hard or greene, and ta≈øte full and plea≈øant, and not wateri≈øh: The v≈øuall manner to eate them is with pepper and ≈øalt, being pared and ≈øliced, and to drowne them in wine, for feare of doing more harme. Cowcumbers and Pompions, after they are nour≈øed vp in the bed of hot dung, are to be ≈øeuerally tran≈øplanted, each of them on a large plot of ground, a good di≈øtance in ≈øunder: but the Pompions more, becau≈øe their branches take vp a great deale more ground, & be≈øides, will require a great deale more watering, becau≈øe the fruit is greater. And thus haue you the ordering of tho≈øe fruits which are of much e≈øteeme, e≈øpecially the two former, with all the better ≈øort of per≈øons; and the third kinde is not wholly refu≈øed of any, although it ≈øerueth mo≈øt vually for the meaner and poorer ≈øort of people, after the fir≈øt early ripe are ≈øpent.

div.head: CHAP. V. The ordering of diuers ≈øorts of herbes for the pot, for meate, and for the table.
div.p: TYme, Sauory, and Hy≈ø≈øope, are v≈øually ≈øowne in the Spring on beds by them≈øelues, euerie one a part; but they that make a gaine by ≈øelling to others the young rootes, to ≈øet the knots or borders of Gardens, doe for the mo≈øt part ≈øowe them in Iuly and Augu≈øt, that ≈øo being ≈øprung vp before Winter, they will be the fitter to be taken vp in the Spring following, to ≈øerue any mans v≈øe that would haue them. Sage, Lauender, and Ro≈øemary, are altogether ≈øet in the Spring, by ≈ølipping the old ≈øtalkes, and taking the younge≈øt and likelie≈øt of them, thru≈øting them either twined or otherwi≈øe halfe a foote deepe into the ground, and well watered vpon the ≈øetting; if any ≈øea≈øonable weather doe follow, there is no doubt of their well thriuing: the hot Sunne and piercing drying Windes are the greate≈øt hinderances to them; and therefore I doe adui≈øe none to ≈øet too ≈øoone in the Spring, nor yet in Autumne, as many doe practi≈øe: for I could neuer ≈øee ≈øuch come to good, for the extremity of the Winter comming vpon them ≈øo ≈øoone after their ≈øetting, will not ≈øuffer their young ≈øhootes to abide, not hauing taken ≈øufficient ≈øtrength in the ground, to maintain them≈øelues again≈øt ≈øuch violence, which doth often pierce the ≈øtronge≈øt plants. Marierome and Ba≈ø≈øill are ≈øowne in the Spring, yet not too early; for they are tender plants, and doe not ≈øpring vntill the weather bee ≈øomewhat warme: but Ba≈ø≈øill would bee ≈øowne dry, and not haue any water of two or three daies after the ≈øowing, el≈øe the ≈øeede will turne to a gelly in the ground. Some v≈øe to ≈øowe the ≈øeed of Ro≈øemary, but it ≈øeldome abideth the fir≈øt Winter, becau≈øe the young plants being ≈ømall, and not of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength, cannot abide the ≈øharpne≈ø ‚Ä¢ e of ≈øome Winters, notwith≈øtanding the couering of them, which killeth many old plants; but the v≈øuall way is to ≈ølippe and ≈øet, and ≈øo they thriue well. Many doe v≈øe to ≈øowe all or the mo≈øt ≈øorts of Pot-herbes together on one plot of ground, that they neede not to goe farre to gather all the ≈øorts they would v≈øe. There are many ≈øorts of them well knowne vnto all, yet few or none doe v≈øe all ≈øorts, but as euery one liketh; ≈øome v≈øe tho≈øe that others refu≈øe, and ≈øome e≈øteem tho≈øe not to bee whole≈øome and of a good relli≈øh, which others make no ≈øcruple of. The names of them are as followeth, and a ≈øhort relation of their ≈øowing or planting.
Ro≈øemary, Tyme, and Sauorie are ≈øpoken of before, and Onions and Leekes.
Mints are to bee ≈øet with their rootes in ≈øome by-place, for that their rootes doe creepe ≈øo farre vnder ground, that they quickly fill vp the places neare adioyning, if they be not puld vp.
Clarie is to be fowne, and ≈øeedeth and dyeth the next yeare, the herbe is ≈øtrong, and therefore a little thereof is ≈øufficient.
Nep is ≈øowne, and dyeth often after ≈øeeding, few doe v≈øe it, and that but a little at a time: both it and Clarie are more v≈øed in Tan≈øies then in Broths.
Co≈øtmarie is to be ≈øet of rootes, the leaues are v≈øed with ≈øome in their Broths, but with more in their Ale.
Pot Marierome is ≈øet of rootes, being ≈øeparated in ≈øunder.
Penniroyall is to be ≈øet of the ≈ømall heads that haue rootes, it creepeth and ≈øpreadeth quickly.
All i≈øanders are to be ≈øowne of ≈øeede, the tops of the rootes with the greene leaues are v≈øed in Lent e≈øpecially.
Par≈øley is a common herbe, and is ≈øowne of ≈øeede, it ≈øeedeth the next yeare and dyeth: the rootes are more v≈øed in broths then the leaues, and the leaues almo≈øt with all ≈øorts of meates.
Fennell is ≈øowne of ≈øeede, and abideth many yeares yeelding ≈øeede: the rootes al≈øo are v≈øed in broths, and the leaues more ≈øeldome, yet ≈øerue to trimme vp many fi≈øh meates.
Borage is ≈øowne of ≈øeede, and dyeth the next yeare after, yet once being ≈øuffered to ≈øeede in a Garden, will ≈øtill come of it owne ≈øhedding.
Buglo≈ø≈øe commeth of ≈øeede, but abideth many yeares after it hath giuen ≈øeede, if it ≈øtand not in the colde≈øt place of the Garden.
Marigolds are ≈øowne of ≈øeede, and may be after tran≈øplanted, they abide two or three yeares, if they be not ≈øet in too cold a place: the leaues and flowers are both v≈øed.
Langedebeefe is ≈øowne of ≈øeede, which ≈øhedding it ≈øelfe will hardly be de≈øtroyed in a Garden.
Arrach is to be ≈øowne of ≈øeede, this likewi≈øe will ri≈øe euery yeare of it owne ≈øeed, if it be ≈øuffered to ≈øhed it ≈øelfe.
Beetes are ≈øowne of ≈øeede, and abideth ≈øome yeares after, ≈øtill giuing ≈øeede.
Blites are v≈øed but in ≈øome places; for there is a generall opinion held of them, that they are naught for the eyes: they are ≈øowne euery yeare of ≈øeede.
Bloodwort once ≈øowne abideth many yeares, if the extremity of the fro≈øts kill it not, and ≈øeedeth plentifully.
Patience is of the ≈øame nature, and v≈øed in the ≈øame manner.
French Mallowes are to be ≈øowne of ≈øeede, and will come of it owne ≈øowing, if it be ≈øuffered to ≈øhed it ≈øelfe.
Ciues are planted onely by parting the rootes; for it neuer giueth any ≈øeede at all.
Garlicke is ordered in the ≈øame manner, by parting and planting the rootes euerie yeare.
The≈øe be all the ≈øorts are v≈øed with vs for that purpo≈øe, whereas I ≈øaid before, none v≈øeth all, but euery one will v≈øe tho≈øe they like be≈øt: and ≈øo much ≈øhall ≈øuffice for potherbes.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The manner and ordering of many ≈øorts of herbes and rootes for Sallets.
div.p:
IF I ≈øhould ≈øet downe all the ≈øorts of herbes that are v≈øually gathered for Sallets, I ≈øhould not onely ≈øpeake of Garden herbes, but of many herbes, &c. that growe wilde in the fields, or el≈øe be but weedes in a Garden; for the v≈øuall manner with many, is to take the young buds and leaues of euery thing almo≈øt that groweth, as well in the Garden as in the Fields, and put them all together, that the ta≈øte of the one may amend the relli≈øh of the other: But I will only ≈øhew you tho≈øe that are ≈øown or planted in gardens for that purpo≈øe. A≈øparagus is a principall & delectable Sallet herbe, who≈øe young ≈øhootes when they are a good handfull high aboue the ground, are cut an inch within the ground, which being boyled, are eaten with a little vinegar and butter, as a Sallet of great delight. Their ordering with the be≈øt Gardiners is on this wi≈øe: When you haue prouided ≈øeede of the be≈øt kinde, you mu≈øt ≈øowe it either before Chri≈øtmas, as mo≈øt doe, or before the end of February; the later you ≈øowe, the later and the more hardly will they ≈øpring: after they are growne vp, they are to be tran≈øplanted in Autumne on a bed well trenched in with dung; for el≈øe they will not bee worth your labour, and ≈øet about a foote di≈øtance in ≈øunder, and looke that the more carefull you are in the replanting of them, the better they will thriue, and the ≈øooner great: after fiue or ≈øix yeares ≈øtanding they v≈øually doe decay; and therefore they that ≈øtriue to haue continually faire and great heads, doe from ≈øeede rai≈øe vp young for their ≈øtore. You mu≈øt likewi≈øe ≈øee that you cut not your heads or young ≈øhoote too nigh, or too much, that is, to take away too many heads from a roote, but to leaue a ≈øufficient number vncut, otherwi≈øe it will kill the heart of your rootes the ≈øooner, cau≈øing them to dye, or to giue very ≈ømall heads or ≈øhootes; for you may well con≈øider with your ≈øelfe, that if the roote haue not head enough left it aboue the ground to ≈øhoote greene this yeare, it will not, nor cannot pro≈øper vnder ground to giue encrea≈øe the next yeare. The ordering of Lettice I haue ≈øpoken of before, and ≈øhall not neede here to repeate what hath beene already ≈øaid, but referre you thereunto for the ≈øowing, planting, &c. onely I will here ≈øhew you the manner of ordering them for Sallets. There are ≈øome ≈øorts of Lettice that growe very great, and clo≈øe their heads, which are called Cabbage
Lettice, both ordinary and extraordinary, and there are other ≈øorts of great Lettice that are open, and clo≈øe not, or cabbage not at all, which yet are of an excellent kinde, if they be v≈øed after that e≈øpeciall manner is fit for them, which is, That when they are planted (for after they are ≈øowne, they mu≈øt be tran≈øplanted) of a rea≈øonable di≈øtance in ≈øunder, and growne to be of ≈øome bigne≈ø≈øe, euery one of them mu≈øt bee tyed together with ba≈øt or thread toward the toppes of the leaues, that by this meanes all the inner leaues may growe whiti≈øh, which then are to be cut vp and v≈øed: for the keeping of the leaues clo≈øe doth make them ta≈øte delicately, and to bee very tender. And the≈øe ≈øorts of Lettice for the mo≈øt part are ≈øpent after Summer is pa≈øt, when other Lettice are not to be had. Lambes Lettice or Corne Sallet is an herbe, which abiding all Winter, is the fir≈øt Sallet herbe of the yeare that is v≈øed before any ordinarie Lettice is ready; it is therefore v≈øually ≈øowne in Augu≈øt, when the ≈øeede thereof is ripe. Pur≈ølane is a Summer Sallet herbe, and is to be ≈øowne in the Spring, yet ≈øomewhat late, becau≈øe it is tender, and ioyeth in warmth; and therefore diuers haue ≈øowne it vpon tho≈øe beddes of dung, whereon they nour≈øed vp their Cowcumbers, &c. after they are taken away, which being well and often watered, hath yeelded Sallet vntill the end of the yeare. Spinach is ≈øowne in the Spring, of all for the mo≈øt part that v≈øe it, but yet if it be ≈øowne in Summer it will abide greene all the Winter, and then ≈øeedeth quickly: it is a Sallet that hath little or no ta≈øte at all therein, like as Lettice and Pur≈ølane; and therefore Cookes know how to make many a good di≈øh of meate with it, by putting Sugar and Spice thereto. Coleworts are of diuers kinds, and although ≈øome of them are wholly ≈øpent among the poorer ≈øort of people, yet ≈øome kindes of them may be dre≈ø≈øed and ordered as may delight a curious palate, which is, that being boyled tender, the middle ribs are taken cold, and laid in di≈øhes, and vinegar and oyle poured thereon, and ≈øo eaten. Coleflowers are to be had in this Countrey but very ≈øeldome, for that it is hard to meete with good ≈øeede: it mu≈øt bee ≈øowne on beds of dung to force it forward, or el≈øe it would peri≈øh with the fro≈øt before it had giuen his head of flowers, and tran≈øplanted into verie good and rich ground, le≈øt you lo≈øe the benefit of your labours. Endiue is of two ≈øorts, the ordinary, and another that hath the edges of the leaues curld or crumpled; it is to be whited, to make it the more dainty Sallet, which is v≈øually done in this manner: After they are grown to ≈øome rea≈øonable greatne≈ø≈øe (but in any ca≈øe before they ≈øhoote forth a ≈øtalke in the mid≈øt for ≈øeede) they are to be taken vp, and the rootes being cut away, lay them to dry or wither for three or foure houres, and then bury them in ≈øand, ≈øo as none of them lye one vpon another, or if you can, one to touch another, which by this meanes will change whiti≈øh, and thereby become verie tender, and is a Sallet both for Autumne and Winter. Succorie is v≈øed by ≈øome in the ≈øame manner, but becau≈øe it is more bitter then Endiue, it is not ≈øo generally v≈øed, or rather v≈øed but of a verie few: and whereas Endiue will ≈øeede the ≈øame yeare it is ≈øowne, and then dye, Succorie abideth manie yeares, the bitterne≈ø≈øe thereof cau≈øing it to be more Phy≈øicall to open ob≈øtructions; and therefore the flowers pickled vp, as diuers other flowers are v≈øed to be now adaies, make a delicate Sallet at all times when there is occa≈øion to v≈øe them. Of red Beetes, the rootes are onely v≈øed both boyled and eaten cold with vinegar and oyle, and is al≈øo v≈øed to trimme vp or garni≈øh forth manie ≈øorts of di≈øhes of meate: the ≈øeede of the be≈øt kinde will not abide good with vs aboue three yeares, but will degenerate and growe wor≈øe; and therefore tho≈øe that delight therein mu≈øt be curious, to be prouided from beyond Sea, that they may haue ≈øuch as will giue delight. Sorrell is an herbe ≈øo common, and the v≈øe ≈øo well knowne, both for ≈øawce, and to ≈øea≈øon broths and meates for the ≈øound as well as ≈øicke per≈øons, that I ≈øhall not neede to ≈øay anie more thereof. Cheruill is a Sallet herbe of much v≈øe, both with French and Dutch, who doe much more delight in herbes of ≈øtronger ta≈øte then the Engli≈øh doe: it is ≈øowne early, and v≈øed but a while, becau≈øe it quickly runneth vp to ≈øeede. Sweete Cheruill, or as ≈øome call it, Sweete Cis, is ≈øo like in ta≈øte vnto Ani≈øe ≈øeede, that it much delighteth the ta≈øte among other herbes in a Sallet: the ≈øeede is long, thicke, blacke, and cornered, and mu≈øt be ≈øowne in the end of Autumne, that it may lye in the ground all the Winter, and then it will ≈øhoote out in the Spring, or el≈øe if it be ≈øowne in the Spring, it will not ≈øpring vp that yeare vntill the next: the leaues (as I ≈øaid before) are v≈øed among other herbes: the rootes likewi≈øe are not onely cordiall, but al≈øo held to be pre≈øeruatiue again≈øt the Plague, either greene, dryed, or pre≈øeru ‚Ä¢ d
with ≈øugar. Rampion rootes are a kinde of Sallet with a great many, being boyled tender, and eaten cold with vinegar and pepper. Cre≈ø≈øes is an herbe of ea≈øie and quick growth, and while it is young eaten eyther alone, or with par≈øley and other herbes: it is of a ≈øtrong ta≈øte to them that are not accu≈øtomed thereunto, but it is much v≈øed of ≈øtrangers. Rocket is of the ≈øame nature and qualitie, but ≈øomewhat ≈øtronger in ta≈øte: they are both ≈øowen in the Spring, and ri≈øe, ≈øeede and dye the ≈øame yeare. Tarragon is an herbe of as ≈øtrong a ta≈øte as eyther Rocket or Cre≈ø≈øes, it abideth and dyeth not euery yeare, nor yet giueth ripe ≈øeede (as far as euer could bee found with vs) any yeare, but maketh ≈øufficient increa≈øe within the ground, ≈øpreading his roots all abroad a great way off. Mu≈øtard is a common ≈øawce both with fi≈øh and fle≈øh, and the ≈øeed thereof (and no part of the plant be≈øides) is well knowne how to be v≈øed being grownded, as euery one I thinke knoweth. The rootes of hor≈øe Radi≈øh likewi≈øe beeing grownd like Mu≈øtard, is v≈øed both of ≈øtrangers and our owne nation, as ≈øawce for fi≈øh. Tan≈øie is of great v≈øe, almo≈øt with all manner of per≈øons in the Spring of the yeare: it is more v≈øually planted of the rootes then otherwi≈øe; for in that the rootes ≈øpread far and neere they may be ea≈øily taken away, without any hurt to the re≈øt of the rootes. Burnet, although it be more v≈øed in wine in the Summer time then any way el≈øe, yet it is likewi≈øe made a ≈øallet herbe with many, to amend the har≈øh or weak relli≈øh of ≈øome other herbs. Skirrets are better to be ≈øowen of the ≈øeed then planted from the roots, and will come on more ≈øpeedily, and be fairer rootes: they are as often eaten cold as a Sallet, being boyled and the pith taken out, as ≈øtewed with butter and eaten warme. Let not Par≈øley and Fenell be forgotten among your other Sallet herbes, wherof I haue ≈øpoken before, and therefore need ≈øay no more of them. The flowers of Marigolds pickt cleane from the heads, and pickled vp again≈øt winter, make an excellent Sallet when no flowers are to be had in a garden. Cloue Gilloflowers likewi≈øe pre≈øerued or pickled vp in the ≈øame manner (which is ≈øtratum ≈øuper ≈øtratum, a lay of flowers, and then ≈øtrawed ouer with fine dry and poudered Sugar, and ≈øo lay after lay ≈øtrawed ouer, vntill the pot bee full you meane to keepe them in, and after filled vp or couered ouer with vinegar) make a Sallet now adayes in the highe≈øt e≈øteeme with Gentles and Ladies of the greate≈øt note: the planting and ordering of them both is ≈øpoken of ≈øeuerally in their proper places. Goates bearbe that groweth in Gardens only, as well as that which groweth wilde in Medowes, &c. bearing a yellow flower, are v≈øed as a Sallet, the rootes beeing boyled and pared are eaten cold with vinegar, oyle and pepper; or el≈øe ≈øtewed with butter and eaten warme as Skirrets, Par≈øneps &c. And thus haue you here ≈øet downe all tho≈øe mo≈øt v≈øuall Sallets are v≈øed in this Kingdome: I ≈øay the mo≈øt v≈øuall, or that are nour≈øed vp in Gardens; for I know there are ≈øome other wilde herbes and rootes, as Dandelion &c. but they are v≈øed onely of ≈øtrangers, and of tho≈øe who≈øe curio≈øitie ≈øearcheth out the whole worke of nature to ≈øatisfie their de≈øires.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of diuers Phy≈øicall herbes fit to be planted in Gardens, to ≈øerue for the e≈øpeciall v≈øes of a familie.
div.p:
HAuing thus ≈øhewed you all the herbes that are mo≈øt v≈øually planted in Kitchen Gardens for ordinary v≈øes, let mee al≈øo adde a few other that are al≈øo nour≈øed vp by many in their Gardens, to pre≈øerue health, and helpe to cure ≈øuch ≈ømall di≈øea≈øes as are often within the compa≈ø≈øe of the Gentlewomens skils, who, to helpe their owne family, and their poore neighbours that are farre remote from Phy≈øitians and Chirurgions, take much paines both to doe good vnto them, and to plant tho≈øe herbes that are conducing to their de≈øires. And although I doe recite ≈øome that are mentioned in other places, yet I thought it meete to remember them altogether in one place. Angelica, the garden kinde, is ≈øo good an herbe, that there is no part thereof but is of much v≈øe, and all cordiall and pre≈øeruatiue from infectious or contagious di≈øea≈øes, whether you will di≈øtill the water of the herbe, or pre≈øerue or candie the rootes or the greene ≈øtalkes, or v≈øe the ≈øeede in pouder or in di≈øtillations, or decoctions with other things: it is ≈øowen of ≈øeede, and will abide vntill
it giue ≈øeede, and then dyeth. Rue or Herbe grace is a ≈øtrong herbe, yet v≈øed inwardly again≈øt the plague as an Antidote with Figs and Wall-nuts, and helpeth much again≈øt windy bodies: outwardly it is v≈øed to bee layde to the wre≈øtes of the hands, to driue away agues: it is more v≈øually planted of ≈ølips then rai≈øed from ≈øeede, and abideth long if ≈øharpe fro≈øtes kill it not. Dragons being di≈øtilled are held to be good to expell any euill thing from the heart: they are altogether planted of the rootes. Setwall, Valerian, or Capons tayle, the herbe often, but the roote much better, is v≈øed to prouoke ≈øweating, thereby to expell euill vapours that might annoy the heart: it is only planted of the rootes when they are taken vp, and the young replanted. A≈øarabacca, the leaues are often v≈øed to procure vomiting being ≈øtamped, and the ≈øtrained iuice to a little quantitie, put into a draught of ale and drunke, thereby to ea≈øe the ≈øtomacke of many euill and gro≈ø≈øe humours that there lye and offend it; diuers al≈øo take the leaues and rootes a little boyled in wine, with a little ≈øpice added thereunto, to expell both tertian and quartan agues: the rootes of our Engli≈øh growing is more auaileable for the≈øe purpo≈øes then any outlandi≈øh: it is planted by the roote; for I could neuer ≈øee it ≈øpring of ≈øeede. Ma≈øterwort commeth ≈øomewhat neere in propertie vnto Angelica, and be≈øides very effectuall to di≈øper≈øe winde in the bodie, whether of the collicke or otherwi≈øe; as al≈øo very profitable to comfort in all cold cau≈øes: it yeeldeth ≈øeede, but yet is more v≈øually planted from the rootes being parted. Balme is a cordiall herbe both in ≈ømell and ta≈øte, and is wholly v≈øed for tho≈øe purpo≈øes, that is, to comfort the heart being di≈øtilled into water either ≈øimple or compound, or the herbe dryed and v≈øed: it is ≈øet of the rootes being parted, becau≈øe it giueth no ≈øeede that euer I could ob≈øerue. Camomill is a common herbe well knowne, and is planted of the rootes in alleyes, in walkes, and on bankes to ≈øit on, for that the more it is troden on, and pre≈ø≈øed downe in dry weather, the clo≈øer it groweth, and the better it will thriue: the v≈øe thereof is very much, both to warme and comfort, and to ea≈øe paines being applyed outwardly after many fa≈øhions: the decoction al≈øo of the flowers prouoketh ≈øweat, and they are much v≈øed again≈øt agues. Featherfew is an herbe of greater v≈øe for women then for men, to di≈ø≈øolue flatulent or windy humours, which cau≈øeth the paines of the mother: ≈øome v≈øe to take the iuice thereof in drinke for agues: it is as well ≈øowen of the ≈øeede as planted of the rootes. Co≈øtmary is v≈øed among tho≈øe herbes that are put in o ‚Ä¢ le to cau≈øe it haue a good relli≈øh, and to be ≈øomewhat phy≈øicall in the moneth of May, and doth helpe to prouoke vrine: it is ≈øet of the rootes being parted. Maudlin is held to be a principall good herbe to open and clean≈øe the liuer, and for that purpo≈øe is v≈øed many wayes, as in ale, in tan≈øies, and in broths &c. the ≈øeed al≈øo is v≈øed, and ≈øo is the herbe al≈øo ≈øometimes, to kill the wormes in children: it is ≈øowen of the ≈øeede, and planted al≈øo of the ≈øeparated rootes. Ca≈ø≈øidonie is a ≈ømall kinde of Lauender, but differing both in forme and qualitie: it is much v≈øed for the head to ea≈øe paines thereof, as al≈øo put among other things to purge melancholicke di≈øea≈øes: it is ≈øowen of ≈øeede, and abideth not a winter vnle≈ø≈øe it bee well defended, and yet hardly giueth ripe ≈øeede againe with vs. Smallage is a great opening herbe, and much more then eyther Par≈øley or Fenell, and the rootes of them all are often v≈øed together in medicines: it is ≈øowen of ≈øeede, and will not bee wanting in a Garden if once you ≈øuffer it to ≈øow it ≈øelfe. Cardus Benedictus, or the Ble≈ø≈øed Thi≈øtle, is much v≈øed in the time of any infection or plague, as al≈øo to expell any euill ≈øymptome from the heart at all other times. It is v≈øed likewi≈øe to be boyled in po≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢ drink, & giuen to them that haue an ague, to help to cure it by ≈øweating or otherwi≈øe. It is v≈øually ≈øowen of ≈øeed, and dyeth when it hath giuen ≈øeed. Winter Cherries are likewi≈øe nur≈øed vp in diuers gardens, for that their propertie is to giue helpe to them that are troubled eyther with the ≈øtopping or heate of their vrine the herbe and berries are often di≈øtilled, but the berries alone are more often v≈øed: after it is once planted in a garden it will runne vnder ground, & abide well enough, Celondine is held to bee good for the iaundi≈øe, it is much v≈øed for to cleere dim eyes, eyther the iuice or the water dropped into them: it is ≈øowen of ≈øeede, and being once brought into a garden, will hardly be weeded out; the ≈øeede that ≈øheddeth will ≈øo ≈øow it ≈øelfe, and therefore ≈øome corner in a garden is the fitte≈øt place for it. Tabacco is of two ≈øorts, and both v≈øed to be planted in Gardens, yet the Engli≈øh kinde (as it is called) is more to be found in our Countrey Gardens then the Indian ≈øort: the leaues of both ≈øorts indifferently, that is, of eyther of which is next at hand, being ≈øtamped and boyled
eyther by it ≈øelfe, or with other herbes in oyle or hogs ≈øuet, doe make an excellent ≈øalue for greene wounds, and al≈øo to clen≈øe old vlcers or ≈øores; the iuice of the greene leaues drunke in ale, or a dryed leafe ≈øteeped in wine or ale for a night, and the wine or ale drunke in the morning, prouoketh to ca≈øt, but the dryed leafe much ≈øtronger then the greene: they are ≈øowen of ≈øeede, but the Indian kinde is more tender, and will not abide a winter with vs abroade. Spurge that v≈øually groweth in Gardens, is a violent purger, and therefore it is needfull to be very carefull how it is v≈øed: the ≈øeede is more ordinarily v≈øed then any other part of the plant, which purgeth by vomiting in ≈øome, and both vpwards and downwards in many; the iuice of the herbe, but e≈øpecially the milke thereof, is v≈øed to kill wartes: it is ≈øowen of ≈øeede, and when it doth once ≈øhed it ≈øelfe, it will ≈øtill continue ≈øpringing of the fallen ≈øeede. Bearefoote is ≈øowen of ≈øeed, and will hardly abide tran≈øplanting vnle≈ø≈øe it bee while it is young; yet abideth diuers yeares, if it ≈øtand not in too cold a place. This I ≈øpeake of the greater kinde; for the lower ≈ømall wilde kind (which is the mo≈øt ordinary in this land) will neuer decay: the leaues are ≈øometimes v≈øed greene, but mo≈øt v≈øually dryed and poudered, and giuen in drinke to them that haue the wormes: it purgeth melancholy, but e≈øpecially the roots. In many Countries of this Land, and el≈øewhere, they v≈øe to thru≈øt the ≈øtalk of the great kinde through the eare or dewlap of Kine and Cattell, to cure them of many di≈øea≈øes. Salomons Seale, or (as ≈øome call it) Ladder to heauen, although it doth grow wilde in many places of this Land, yet is planted in Gardens: it is accounted an excellent wound herbe to con≈øolidate, and binde, in≈øomuch that many v≈øe it with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to cure ruptures, and to ≈øtay both the white and the red fluxe in women: it is planted altogether of the rootes, for I could neuer finde it ≈øpring from the ≈øeede, it is ≈øo ≈øtrong. Comfry likewi≈øe is found growing wilde in many places by ditch ≈øides, and in moi≈øt places, and therefore requireth ≈øome moi≈øt places of the garden: it is wholly v≈øed for knitting, binding, and con≈øolidating fluxes and wounds, to be applyed either inwardly or outwardly: The rootes are ≈øtronger for tho≈øe purpo≈øes then any other parts of the plant. Licoris is much v≈øed now adaies to bee planted in great quantitie, euen to fill many acres of ground, whereof ri≈øeth a great deale of profit to tho≈øe that know how to order it, and haue fit grounds for it to thriue in; for euery ground will not be aduantagious: It will require a very rich, deepe and mellow ground, eyther naturall or artificiall; but for a priuate hou≈øe where a ≈ømall quantitie will ≈øerue, there needeth not ≈øo much curio≈øitie: it is v≈øually planted of the top heads, when the lower rootes (which are the Licoris that is v≈øed) and the runners are cut from them. Some v≈øe to make an ordinary drinke or beuerage of Licoris, boyled in water as our v≈øuall ale or beere is with malt, which fermented with barme in the ≈øame manner, and tunned vp, ≈øerueth in ≈øtead thereof, as I am credibly informed: It is otherwi≈øe in a manner wholly ≈øpent for colds, coughes and rheumes, to expectorate flegme, but v≈øed in diuers formes, as in iuice, in decoctions, ≈øyrrups, roules, trochi≈øces, and the greene or dryed roote of it ≈øelfe.

And the≈øe are the mo≈øt ordinary Phy≈øicall herbes that are v≈øed to be planted in gardens for the v≈øe of any Country familie, that is (as I ≈øaid before) farre remote from Phy≈øitians or Cbirurgions abidings, that they may v≈øe as occa≈øion ≈øerueth for them≈øelues or their neighbours, and by a little care and paines in the applying may doe a great deale of good, and ≈øometimes to them that haue not wherewith to ≈øpend on them≈øelues, much le≈ø≈øe on Phy≈øitians or Chirurgions, or if they haue, may oftentimes receiue le≈ø≈øe good at their hands then at others that are taught by experience in their owne families, to be the more able to giue helpe to others.

div.head: THE KITCHEN GARDEN. THE SECOND PART,
div.p: COntaining as well all ≈øorts of herbes, as rootes and fruits, that are v≈øually planted in Gardens, to ≈øerue for the v≈øe of the Table whether of the poore or rich of our Countrey: but herein I intend not to bring any fruite bearing trees, ≈øhrubbes, or bu≈øhes; for I re≈øerue them for my Orchard, wherin they ≈øhal be ≈øet forth. So that in the≈øe three parts, I ≈øuppo≈øe the exqui≈øite ornament of any worthy hou≈øe is con≈øummate for the exteriour bounds, the benefit of their riches extending al≈øo to the furni≈øhing of the mo≈øt worthy inward parts thereof: but becau≈øe many take plea≈øure in the ≈øight and knowledge of other herbes that are Phy≈øicall, and much more in their properties and vertues, if vnto the≈øe three I ≈øhould adde a Phy≈øicke Garden, or Garden of Simples, there would be a quadripartite complement, of what≈øoeuer arte or nature, nece≈ø≈øitie or delight could affect: which to effect (as many my friends haue intreated it at my hands) will require more paines and time then all this worke together: yet to ≈øatisfie their de≈øires and all others herein, that would bee enformed in the truth, and reformed of the many errours and ≈ølips ≈øet forth and publi≈øhed heretofore of plants by diuers, I ≈øhall (God a≈ø≈øi≈øting and granting life) labour to performe, that it may ≈øhew it ≈øelfe to the light in due conueniencie, if the≈øe bee well and gratefully accepted. And becau≈øe I ended with ≈øome ≈øweete herbes in the former part, I will in this part beginne with the re≈øt, which I re≈øerued for this place, as fitter for the pot and kitchen then for the hand or bo≈øome, and ≈øo de≈øcend to other herbes that are for meat or ≈øallets: and after them to tho≈øe rootes that are to be eaten, as meate or as ≈øallets: and la≈øtly the fruits that grow neere, or vpon the ground, or not much aboue it; as the Artichoke, &c. in which I make a ≈øhorter de≈øcription then I did in the former, rather endeauouring to ≈øhew what they are, and whereunto they are v≈øed, then the whole varietie or any exact declaration: which methode, although in ≈øome ≈øort it may bee fitting for this purpo≈øe, yet it is not for an hi≈øtory or herball: I ≈øhall therefore require their good acceptance for who≈øe ≈øake I doe it, not doubting, but that I, or others, if they write againe of this ≈øubiect, may poli≈øh and amende what formerly hath beene eyther mi≈ø ≈øet, or not ≈øo thoroughly expre≈ø≈øed, be≈øides ≈øome additions of new conceits; ≈øeeing I treade out a new path, and therefore tho≈øe that follow may the ea≈øilier ≈øee the Meanders, and ≈øo goe on in a direct line.

div.head: Maiorana latifolia, ≈øiue maior Anglica. Winter, or pot Marierome.
div.p: WInter Marierome is a ≈ømall bu≈øhie herbe like vnto ≈øweete Marierome, being parted or diuided into many branches, whereon doe grow broader and greener leaues, ≈øet by couples, with ≈øome ≈ømall leaues likewi≈øe at the ≈øeuerall ioynts all along the branches: at the tops whereof grow a number of ≈ømall purpli≈øh white flowers ≈øet together in a tuft, which turne into ≈ømall and round ≈øeed, bigger then ≈øweet Marierome ≈øeede: the whole plant is of a ≈ømall and fine ≈øent, but much inferiour to the other, and is nothing ≈øo bitter as the ≈øweete Marierome, and thereby both the fitter and more willingly v≈øed for meates: the roote is white and threddy, and peri≈øheth not as the former, but abideth many yeares.

div.head: The V≈øe of winter Marierome.
div.p: The v≈øe of this Marierome is more frequent in our Land then in others, being put among other pot-herbes and far≈øing (or fa≈øeting herbes as they are called) and may to good profit bee applyed in inward as well as outward griefes for to comfort the parts, although weaker in effect then ≈øweete Marieromes.

div.head: Thymum vulgatius ≈øiue durius. Ordinary Garden Tyme.
div.p: THe ordinary Garden Tyme is a ≈ømall low wooddy plant with brittle branches, and ≈ømall hard greene leaues, as euery one knoweth, hauing ≈ømall white purpli≈øh flowers, ≈øtanding round about the tops of the ≈øtalkes: the ≈øeed is ≈ømall and browne, darker then Marierome ≈øeed: the root is woody, and abideth well diuers Winters.

div.head: Thymum latifolium. Ma≈øticke Tyme.
div.p: This Tyme hath neyther ≈øo wooddy branches, nor ≈øo hard leaues, but groweth lower, more ≈øpreading, and with ≈øomewhat broader leaues: the flowers are of a purpli≈øh white colour, ≈øtanding in roundles round about the ≈øtalkes, at the ioynts with leaues at them likewi≈øe. This Tyme endureth better and longer then the former, and by ≈øpreading it ≈øelfe more then the former, is the more apt to bee propagated by ≈ølipping, becau≈øe it hath beene ≈øeldome ≈øeene to giue ≈øeede: It is not ≈øo quicke in ≈øent or ta≈øte as the former, but is fitter to ≈øet any border or knot in a garden, and is for the mo≈øt part wholly employed to ≈øuch v≈øes.

div.head: The V≈øe of Tyme.
div.p:
To ≈øet downe all the particular v≈øes whereunto Tyme is applyed, were to weary both the Writer and Reader; I will but only note out a few: for be≈øides the phy≈øicall v≈øes to many purpo≈øes, for the head, ≈øtomacke, ≈øpleene, &c. there is no herbe almo≈øt of more v≈øe, in the hou≈øes both of high and low, rich and poore, both for inward and outward occa≈øions; outwardly for bathings among other hot herbes, and among other ≈øweete herbes for ≈øtrewings: inwardly in mo≈øt ≈øorts of broths, with Ro≈ømary, as al≈øo with other fa≈øeting (or rather far≈øing) herbes, and to make ≈øawce for diuers ≈øorts both fi≈øh and fle≈øh, as to ≈øtuffe the belly of a Goo≈øe to bee ro≈øted, and after put into the ≈øawce, and the pouder with breade to ≈øtrew on meate when it
1 Ma ‚Ä¢ orana maior Anglica. Pot Marierome. 2 Thymum vulgatius. Garden Tyme. 3 Satureia. Sauorie. 4 Hy≈ø≈øopus. Hy≈ø≈øope. 5 Pulegium. Penniroyall. 6 Saluia maior. Common Sage. 7 Saluia minor pr ‚Ä¢ nata. Sage of vertue. depiction of plants
is ro≈øted, and ≈øo likewi≈øe on ro≈øted or fryed fi≈øh. It is held by diuers to bee a ≈øpeedy remedy again≈øt the ≈øting of a Bee, being brui≈øed and layd thereon.

div.head: Satureia ≈øiue Thymbra. Sauorie.
div.p: THere are two ≈øorts of of Sauory, the one called Summer, and the other Winter Sauorie: The Summer Sauory is a ≈ømall tender herbe, growing not aboue a foote and a halfe high, or thereabouts, ri≈øing vp with diuers brittle branches, ≈ølenderly or ≈øpar≈øedly ≈øet with ≈ømall long leaues, ≈øoft in handling, at euery ioynt a couple, one again≈øt another, of a plea≈øant ≈øtrong and quicke ≈øent and ta≈øte: the flowers are ≈ømall and purpli≈øh, growing at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, with two ≈ømall long leaues at the ioynts vnder them: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, and of a darke colour, bigger then Tyme ≈øeede by the halfe: the roote is wooddy, and hath many ≈øtrings, peri≈øhing euery yeare wholly, and mu≈øt bee new ≈øowen againe, if any will haue it.

The Winter Sauorie is a ≈ømall low bu≈øhie herbe, very like vnto Hy≈ø≈øope, but not aboue a foote high, with diuers ≈ømall hard branches, and hard darke green leaues thereon, thicker ≈øet together then the former by much, and as thicke as common Hy≈ø≈øope, ≈øometimes with foure leaues or more at a ioynt, of a rea≈øonable ≈øtrong ≈øent, yet not ≈øo ≈øtrong or quicke as the former: the flowers are of a pale purpli≈øh colour, ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, with leaues at the ioynts al≈øo with them, like the former: the roote is woody, with diuers ≈ømall ≈øtrings thereat, and abideth all the winter with his greene leaues: it is more v≈øually encrea≈øed by ≈ølipping or diuiding the roote, and new ≈øetting it ≈øeuerally againe in the Spring, then by ≈øowing the ≈øeed.

div.head: The V≈øe of Sauorie.
div.p: The Summer Sauorie is v≈øed in other Countryes much more then with vs in their ordinary diets, as condiment or ≈øawce to their meates, ≈øometimes of it ≈øelfe, and ≈øometimes with other herbes, and ≈øometimes ≈øtrewed or layde vpon the di≈øhes as we doe Par≈øley, as al≈øo with beanes and pea≈øe, ri≈øe and wheate; and ≈øometimes the dryed herbe boyled among pea≈øe to make pottage.

The Winter Sauorie is one of the (far≈øing) fa≈øeting herbes as they call them, and ≈øo is the Summer Sauorie al≈øo ≈øometimes. This is v≈øed al≈øo in the ≈øame manner that the Summer Sauorie is, ≈øet downe before, and to the ≈øame purpo≈øes: as al≈øo to put into puddings, ≈øaw≈øages, and ≈øuch like kindes of meates. Some doe v≈øe the pouder of the herbe dryed (as I ≈øayd before of Tyme) to mixe with grated bread, to breade their meate, be it fi≈øh or fle≈øh, to giue it the quicker relli≈øh. They are both effectuall to expell winde.

div.head: Hy≈ø≈øopus. Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: GArden Hy≈ø≈øope is ≈øo well knowne to all that haue beene in a Garden, that I ≈øhall but actum agere, to be≈øtow any time thereon, being a ≈ømall bu≈øhie plant, not ri≈øing aboue two foote high, with many branches, woody below, and tender aboue, whereon are ≈øet at certaine di≈øtances, ≈øundry ≈ømall, long and narrow greene leaues: at the toppe of euery ≈øtalke ≈øtand blewi≈øh purple gaping flowers, one aboue another in a long ≈øpike or eare: after which followeth the ≈øeede, which is ≈ømall and blacki≈øh: the rootes are compo≈øed of many threddy ≈øtrings; the whole plant is of a ≈øtrong ≈øweet ≈øent.

div.head: The V≈øe of Hy≈ø≈øope.
div.p: Hy≈ø≈øope is much v≈øed in Pti≈øans and other drinkes, to help to expectorate flegme. It is many Countrey peoples medicine for a cut or greene wound, being brui≈øed with ≈øugar and applyed. I finde it is al≈øo much commended again≈øt the falling ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially being made into pils after the manner before rehear≈øed. It is accounted a ≈øpeciall remedy again≈øt the ≈øting or biting of an Adder, if the place be rubbed with Hy≈ø≈øope, brui≈øed and mixed with honey, ≈øalt and cummin ≈øeede. A decoction thereof with oyle, and annointed, taketh away the itching and tingling of the head, and vermine al≈øo breeding therein. An oyle made of the herbe and flowers, being annointed, doth comfort benummed ≈øinewes and ioynts.

div.head: Pulegium. Pennyroyall.
div.p: PEnnyroyall al≈øo is an herbe ≈øo well knowne, that I ≈øhall not neede to ≈øpend much time in the de≈øcription of it: hauing many weake round ≈øtalkes, diuided into ≈øundry branches, rather leaning or lying vpon the ground then ≈øtanding vpright, whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall ioynts, ≈ømall roundi≈øh darke greene leaues: the flowers are purpli≈øh that grow in gardens, yet ≈øome that grow wilde are white, or more white then purple, ≈øet in roundles about the tops of the branches; the ≈øtalkes ≈øhoote forth ≈ømall fibres or rootes at the ioynts, as it lyeth vpon the ground, thereby fa≈øtening it ≈øelfe therein, and quickly increa≈øeth, and ouer-runneth any ground, e≈øpecially in the ≈øhade or any moi≈øt place, and is replanted by breaking the ≈øprouted ≈øtalkes, and ≈øo quickely groweth.
Other ≈øorts of Pennyroyall are fit for the Phy≈øicke Garden, or Garden of Simples.

div.head: The V≈øe of Pennyroyall.
div.p: It is very good and whole≈øome for the lunges, to expell cold thin flegme, and afterwards to warme and dry it vp: and is al≈øo of the like propertie as Mintes, to comfort the ≈øtomacke, and ≈øtay vomiting. It is al≈øo v≈øed in womens baths and wa≈øhings: and in mens al≈øo to comfort the ≈øinewes. It is yet to this day, as it hath beene in former times, v≈øed to bee put into puddings, and ≈øuch like meates of all ≈øorts, and therefore in diuers places they know it by no other name then Pudding-gra≈ø≈øe.

The former age of our great Grandfathers, had all the≈øe hot herbes in much and familiar v≈øe, both for their meates and medicines, and therewith pre≈øerued them≈øelues in long life and much health: but this delicate age of ours, which is not plea≈øed with any thing almo≈øt, be it meat or medicine, that is not plea≈øant to the palate, doth wholly refu≈øe the≈øe almo≈øt, and therefore cannot be partaker of the benefit of them.

div.head: Salvia. Sage.
div.p:
THere are two e≈øpeciall kindes of Sage nour≈øed vp in our Gardens, for our ordinary v≈øe, whereof I intend to write in this place, leauing the re≈øt to his fitter place. Our ordinary Sage is reckoned to bee of two ≈øorts, white and red,
both of them bearing many foure ≈øquare wooddy ≈øtalkes, in ≈øome whiter, in others redder, as the leaues are al≈øo, ≈øtanding by couples at the ioynts, being long, rough, and wrinkled, of a ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈øent: at the tops of the ≈øtalkes come forth the flowers, ≈øet at certaine ≈øpaces one aboue another, which are long and gaping, like vnto the flowers of Clary, or dead Nettles, but of a blewi≈øh purple colour; after which come ≈ømall round ≈øeede in the huske that bore the flower: the roote is wooddy, with diuers ≈øtrings at it: It is more v≈øually planted of the ≈ølips, pricked in the Spring time into the ground, then of the ≈øeed.

div.head: Saluia minor ≈øiue pinnata. Small Sage or Sage of vertue.
div.p: The le≈ø≈øer Sage is in all things like vnto the former white Sage, but that his branches are long and ≈ølender, and the leaues much ≈ømaller, hauing for the mo≈øt part at the bottome of each ≈øide of the leafe a peece of a leafe, which maketh it ≈øhew like finns or eares: the flowers al≈øo are of a blewi≈øh purple colour, but le≈ø≈øer. Of this kinde there is one that beareth white flowers.

div.head: The V≈øe of Sage.
div.p: Sage is much v≈øed of many in the moneth of May fa≈øting, with butter and Par≈øley, and is held of mo≈øt much to conduce to the health of mans body.

It is al≈øo much v≈øed among other good herbes to bee tund vp with Ale, which thereupon is termed Sage Ale, whereof many barrels full are made, and drunke in the ≈øaid moneth chiefly for the purpo≈øe afore recited: and al≈øo for teeming women, to helpe them the better forward in their childe bearing, if there be feare of abortion or mi≈øcarrying.

It is al≈øo v≈øed to be boyled among other herbes, to make Gargles or waters to wa≈øh ≈øore mouths and throates: As al≈øo among other herbes, that ≈øerue as bathings, to wa≈øh mens legs or bodies in the Summer time, to comfort nature, and warme and ≈øtrengthen aged cold ≈øinewes, and lengthen the ≈øtrength of the younger.

The Kitchen v≈øe is either to boyle it with a Calues head, and being minced, to be put with the braines, vinegar and pepper, to ≈øerue as an ordinary ≈øawce thereunto: Or being beaten and iuyced (rather then minced as manie doe) is put to a ro≈øted Pigges braines, with Currans for ≈øawce thereunto. It is in ≈ømall quantity (in regard of the ≈øtrong ta≈øte thereof) put among other fa≈øting herbes, to ≈øerue as ≈øawce for peeces of Veale, when they are far≈øed or ≈øtuffed therewith, and ro≈øted, which they call Olliues.
For all the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, the ≈ømall Sage is accounted to be of the more force and vertue.

div.head: Horminum ≈øativum. Garden Clary.
div.p: THere is but one ≈øort of Garden Clary, though many wilde, which hath foure ≈øquares ≈øtalks, with broad rough wrinkled whiti≈øh leaues, ≈øomewhat vneuenly cut in on the edges, and of a ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈øent, growing ≈øome next the ground, & ≈øome by couples vpon the ≈øtalkes: the flowers growe at certaine di≈øtances, with two ≈ømall leaues at the ioynts vnder them, ≈øomewhat like vnto the flowers of Sage, but le≈ø≈øer, and of a very whiti≈øh or bleake blew colour: the ≈øeede is of a blacki≈øh browne colour, ≈øomewhat flat, and not ≈øo round as the wilde: the rootes ≈øpread not farre, and peri≈øh euery yeare that they beare flowers and ≈øeede. It is altogether to bee ≈øowne of ≈øeed in the Spring time, yet ≈øometimes it will ri≈øe of it owne ≈øowing.

div.head: The V≈øe of Clary.
div.p: The mo≈øt frequent and common v≈øe of Clary, is for men or women that haue weake backes, to helpe to comfort and ≈øtrengthen the raines, being made into Tan≈øies and eaten, or otherwi≈øe. The ≈øeede is v≈øed of ≈øome to be put into the corner of the eye, if any mote or other thing haue happened into it: but a≈ø≈øuredly although this may peraduenture doe ≈øome good, yet the ≈øeede of the wilde will doe much more. The leaues taken dry, and dipped into a batter made of the yolkes of egges, flower, and a little milke, and then fryed with butter vntill they be cri≈øpe, ≈øerue for a di≈øh of meate accepted with manie, vnplea≈øant to none.

div.head: Nepeta. Nep.
div.p: ALthough tho≈øe that are Herbari≈øts do know three ≈øorts of Nep, a greater & two le≈ø≈øer, yet becau≈øe the le≈ø≈øer are not v≈øuall, but in the Gardens of tho≈øe that delight in natures varieties, I do not here ≈øhew you them. That which is v≈øuall (and called of manie Cat Mint) beareth ≈øquare ≈øtalkes, but not ≈øo great as Clarie, hauing two leaues at euery ioynt, ≈øomewhat like vnto Balme or Speare Mintes, but whiter, ≈øofter, and longer, and nicked about the edges, of a ≈øtrong ≈øent, but nothing ≈øo ≈øtrong as Clary: the flowers growe at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes, as it were in long ≈øpikes or heads, ≈øomewhat clo≈øe together, yet compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalkes at certaine ioynts, of a whiti≈øh colour, for forme and bigne≈ø≈øe like vnto Balme, or ≈øomewhat bigger: the rootes are compo≈øed of a number of ≈øtrings, which dye not, but keepe greene leaues vpon them all the Winter, and ≈øhoote anew in the Spring. It is propagated both by the ≈øeede, and by ≈ølipping the rootes.

div.head: The V≈øe of Nep.
div.p: Nep is much v≈øed of women either in baths or drinkes to procure their feminine cour≈øes: as al≈øo with Clarie, being fryed into Tan≈øies, to ≈øtrengthen their backes. It is much commended of ≈øome, if the iuyce thereof be drunke with wine, to helpe tho≈øe that are brui≈øed by ≈øome fall, or other accident. A decoction of Nep is auaileable to cure the ≈øcabbe in the head, or other places of the body.

div.head: Meli≈ø≈øa. Baulme.
div.p: THe Garden Baulme which is of common knowne v≈øe, hath diuers ≈øquare blacki≈øh greene ≈øtalkes, and round, hard, darke, greene pointed leaues, growing thereon by couples, a little notched about the edges, of a plea≈øant ≈øweete ≈øent, drawing neare≈øt to the ≈øent of a Lemon or Citron; and therefore of ≈øome called Citrago: the flowers growe about the toppes of the ≈øtalkes at certaine di≈øtances, being ≈ømall and gaping, of a pale carnation colour, almo≈øt white: the rootes fa≈øten them≈øelues ≈øtrongly in the ground, and endure many yeares, and is encrea≈øed by diuiding the rootes; for the leaues dye downe to the ground euery yeare, leauing no ≈øhew of leafe or ≈øtalke in the Winter.

div.head: The V≈øe of Baulme.
div.p: Baulme is often v≈øed among other hot and ≈øweete herbes, to make baths and wa≈øhings for mens bodies or legges, in the Summer time, to warme and comfort the veines and ≈øinewes, to very good purpo≈øe and effect, and hath in former ages beene of much more v≈øe then now adaies. It is al≈øo v≈øed by diuers to be ≈øtilled, being ≈øteeped in Ale, to make a Baulme water, after the manner they haue beene taught, which they keepe by them, to v≈øe in the ≈øtead of Aqua vitae, when they haue any occa≈øion for their owne or their neighbours Families, in ≈øuddaine qualmes or pa≈ø≈øions of the heart: but if they had a little better direction (for this is ≈øomewhat too rude) it would doe them more good that take it: For the herbe without all que≈øtion is an excellent helpe to comfort the heart, as the very ≈ømell may induce any ≈øo to beleeue. It is al≈øo good to heale greene wounds, being made into ≈øalues: and I verily thinke, that our forefathers hearing of the healing and comfortable properties of the true naturall Baulme, and finding this herbe to be ≈øo effectuall, gaue it the name of Baulme, in imitation of his properties and vertues. It is al≈øo an herbe wherein Bees doe much delight, as hath beene found by experience of tho≈øe that haue kept great ≈øtore; if the Hiues bee rubbed on the in≈øide with ≈øome thereof, and as they thinke it draweth others by the ≈ømell thereof to re≈øort thither. Plinie ≈øaith, it is a pre≈øent remedy again≈øt the ≈øtinging of Bees.

div.head: Mentha. Mintes.
div.p: THere are diuers ≈øorts of Mints, both of the garden, and wilde, of the woods, mountaines, and ≈øtanding pooles or waters: but I will onely in this place bring to your remembrance two or three ≈øorts of the mo≈øt v≈øuall that are kept in gardens, for the v≈øes whereunto they are proper.

Red Mint or browne Mint hath ≈øquare browni≈øh ≈øtalkes, with ≈øomewhat long and round pointed leaues, nicked about the edges, of a darke greene colour, ≈øet by couples at euery ioynt, and of a rea≈øonable good ≈øent: the flowers of this kinde are reddi≈øh, ≈øtanding about the toppes of the ≈øtalkes at di≈øtances: the rootes runne creeping in the ground, and as the re≈øt, will hardly be cleared out of a garden, being once therein, in that the ≈ømalle≈øt peece thereof will growe and encrea≈øe apace.

Speare Mint hath a ≈øquare greene ≈øtalke, with longer and greener leaues then the former, ≈øet by couples, of a better and more comfortable ≈øent, and therefore of much more v≈øe then any other: the flowers hereof growe in long eares or ≈øpikes, of a pale red or blu≈øh colour: the rootes creepe in the ground like the other.

Party coloured or white Mint hath ≈øquare greene ≈øtalkes and leaues, ≈øomewhat larger then Speare Mint, and more nicked in the edges, whereof many are parted, halfe white and halfe greene, and ≈øome more white then greene, or more green then white, as nature li≈øteth: the flowers ≈øtand in long heads clo≈øe ≈øet together, of a blu≈øh colour: the rootes creepe as the re≈øt doe.

div.head: The V≈øe of Mintes.
div.p: Mintes are oftentimes v≈øed in baths, with Baulme and other herbes, as a helpe to comfort and ≈øtrengthen the nerues and ≈øinewes.

figure.head: 1 Horminum ≈øativum. Garden Clary. 2 Nepeta. Nep. 3 Meli≈ø≈øa. Baulme. 4 Mentha ≈øatiua. Garden Mintes. 5 Bal≈øamita mas, ≈øeu Cestus hortorum. Co≈øtmary. 6 Ageratum. Maudeline.

div.p: It is v≈øed to be boyled with Mackarell, and other fi≈øh.
Being dryed, is often and much v≈øed with Penniroyall, to bee put into puddings: as al≈øo among pea≈øe that are boyled for pottage.
Where Dockes are not ready at hand, they v≈øe to brui≈øe Mintes, and lay them vpon any place that is ≈øtung with Bees, Wa≈øpes, or ≈øuch like, and that to good purpo≈øe.

div.head: Bal≈øamita mas & faemina, ≈øeu Co≈øtus hortorum maior & minor. Co≈øtmary and Maudeline.
div.p: CO≈øtmary or Alecoa≈øt is a ≈øweet herbe, bearing many broad and long pale green leaues, ≈ønipped about the edges, euery one vpon a long foote-≈øtalke; among which ri≈øe vp many round greene ≈øtalkes, with ≈øuch like leaues on them, but le≈ø≈øer vp to the toppe, where it ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe into three or foure branches, euery one bearing an vmbell or tuft of gold yellow flowers, ≈øomewhat like vnto Tan≈øie flowers, but le≈ø≈øer, which turne into ≈ømall heads, containing ≈ømall flat long ≈øeede: the roote is ≈øomewhat hard and ≈øtringy, and being diuided, is replanted in the Spring of the yeare for increa≈øe.

Maudeline hath ≈øomewhat long and narrow leaues, ≈ønipt about the edges: the ≈øtalks are two foot high, bearing many yellow flowers on the tops of the branches, in an vmbell or tuft like vnto Tan≈øie: the whole herbe is ≈øweete, and ≈øomewhat bitter, and is replanted by flipping.

div.head: The V≈øe of Co≈øtmary and Maudeline.
div.p: Co≈øtmary is of e≈øpeciall v≈øe in the Spring of the yeare, among other ≈øuch like herbes, to make Sage Ale, and thereupon I thinke it tooke the name of Alecoa≈øt.
It is al≈øo v≈øed to be put among other ≈øweete herbes, to make ≈øweete wa≈øhing water, whereof there is great ≈øtore ≈øpent.

The leaues haue an e≈øpeciall vertue to comfort both the ≈øtomack and heart, and to warme and dry a moi≈øt braine. The ≈øeede is much v≈øed in the Country, to be giuen to children for the wormes, in the ≈øtead of worm≈øeed, and ≈øo is the ≈øeede of Maudeline al≈øo.

Maudeline is much v≈øed with Co≈øtmary and other ≈øweet herbes, to make ≈øweete wa≈øhing water: the flowers al≈øo are tyed vp with ≈ømall bundels of Lauender toppes, the≈øe being put in the middle of them, to lye vpon the toppes of beds, pre≈ø≈øes, &c. for the ≈øweete ≈øent and ≈øauour it ca≈øteth. It is generally accounted of our Apothecaries to be the true Eupatorium of Auicen, and the true Ageratum of Dio≈øcorides; but Dodonaeus ≈øeemeth to contradict both.

div.head: Tanacetum vulgare & cri≈øpum. Tan≈øie.
div.p:
OVr Garden Tan≈øie hath many hard greene leaues, or rather wings of leaues; for they are many ≈ømall ones, ≈øet one again≈øt another all along a middle ribbe or ≈øtalke, and ≈ønipt about the edges: in ≈øome the leaues ≈øtand clo≈øer and thicker, and ≈øomewhat crumpled, which hath cau≈øed it to be called double or curld Tan≈øie,
in others thinner and more ≈øpar≈øedly: It ri≈øeth vp with many hard ≈øtalks, whereon growe at the tops vpon the ≈øeuerall ≈ømall branches gold yellow flowers like buttons, which being gathered in their prime, will hold the colour fre≈øh a long time: the ≈øeede is ≈ømall, and as it were chaffie: the roote creepeth vnder ground, and ≈øhooteth vp againe in diuers places: the whole herbe, both leaues and flowers, are of a ≈øharpe, ≈øtrong, bitter ≈ømell and ta≈øte, but yet plea≈øant, and well to be endured.

div.head: The V≈øe of Tan≈øie.
div.p: The leaues of Tan≈øie are v≈øed while they are young, either ≈øhred ≈ømall with other herbes, or el≈øe the iuyce of it and other herbes fit for the purpo≈øe, beaten with egges, and fryed into cakes (in Lent and the Spring of the yeare) which are v≈øually called Tan≈øies, and are often eaten, being taken to be very good for the ≈øtomack, to helpe to dige≈øt from thence bad humours that cleaue thereunto: As al≈øo for weak raines and kidneyes, when the vrine pa≈ø≈øeth away by drops: This is thought to be of more v≈øe for men then for women. The ≈øeed is much commended again≈øt all ≈øorts of wormes in children.

div.head: Pimpinella ≈øiue Sangui≈øorba. Burnet.
div.p: BVrnet hath many winged leaues lying vpon the ground, made of many ≈ømall, round, yet pointed greene leaues, finely nicked on the edges, one ≈øet again≈øt another all along a middle ribbe, and one at the end thereof; from among which ri≈øe vp diuers round, and ≈øometimes cre≈øted browne ≈øtalkes, with ≈øome few ≈øuch like leaues on them as growe belowe, but ≈ømaller: at the toppes of the ≈øtalkes growe ≈ømall browne heads or knaps, which ≈øhoote forth ≈ømall purpli≈øh flowers, turning into long and browni≈øh, but a little cornered ≈øeede: the roote groweth downe deepe, being ≈ømall and browni≈øh: the whole plant is of a ≈øtipticke or binding ta≈øte or quality, but of a fine quicke ≈øent, almo≈øt like Baulme.

div.head: The V≈øe of Burnet.
div.p: The greate≈øt v≈øe that Burnet is commonly put vnto, is to put a few leaues into a cup with Claret wine, which is pre≈øently to be drunke, and giueth a plea≈øant quicke ta≈øte thereunto, very delightfull to the palate, and is accounted a helpe to make the heart merrie. It is ≈øometimes al≈øo while it is young, put among other Sallet herbes, to giue a finer relli≈øh thereunto. It is al≈øo v≈øed in vulnerary drinkes, and to ≈øtay fluxes and bleedings, for which purpo≈øes it is much commended. It hath beene al≈øo much commended in contagious and pe≈øtilentiall agues.

div.head: Hippolapathum ≈øativum, ≈øiue Rhabarbarum Monachorum. Monkes Rubarbe or Patience.
div.p:
GArden Patience is a kinde of Docke in all the parts thereof, but that it is larger and taller then many others, with large and long greene leaues, a great, ≈øtrong, and high ≈øtalke, with reddi≈øh or purpli≈øh flowers, and three ≈øquare ≈øeede, like as all other Dockes haue: the roote is great and yellow, not hauing any ≈øhew of fle≈øh coloured veines therein, no more then the other kinde with great round thin leaues,
commonly called Hippolapathum rotundifolium, Ba≈øtard Rubarbe, or Monkes Rubarbe, the properties of both which are of very weake effect: but I haue a kinde of round leafed Dock growing in my Garden, which was ≈øent me from beyond Sea by a worthy Gentleman, Mr. Dr. Matth.
