Li≈øter, one of the Kings Phy≈øitians, with this title, Rhaponticum verum, and fir≈øt grew with me, before it was euer ≈øeen or known el≈øewhere in England, wch by proof I haue found to be ≈øo like vnto the true Rubarbe, or the Rha of Pontus, both for forme and colour, that I dare ≈øay it is the very true Rubarbe, our climate only making it le≈ø≈øe ≈øtrong in working, le≈ø≈øe heauy, and le≈ø≈øe bitter in ta≈øte: For this hath great and thicke rootes, as diuer≈øly di≈øcoloured with fle≈øh coloured veines as the true Rubarbe, as I haue to ≈øhew to any that are de≈øirous to ≈øee and know it; and al≈øo other ≈ømaller ≈øprayes or branches of rootes, ≈øpreading from the maine great roote, which ≈ømaller branches may well be compared to the Rhaponticum which the Merchants haue brought vs, which we haue ≈øeene to be longer and ≈ølenderer then Rubarbe, but of the very ≈øame colour: this beareth ≈øo goodly large leaues, that it is a great beauty in a garden to behold them: for I haue mea≈øured the ≈øtalke of the leafe at the bottome next the roote to bee of the bigne≈ø≈øe of any mans thumbe; and from the roote to the leafe it ≈øelfe, to bee two foote in length, and ≈øometimes more; and likewi≈øe the leafe it ≈øelfe, from the lower end where it is ioyned to the ≈øtalke, to the end or point thereof, to bee al≈øo two foote in length, and ≈øometimes more; and al≈øo in the broade≈øt part of the leafe, to be two foote or more ouer in breadth: it beareth whiti≈øh flowers, contrary to all other Dockes, and three ≈øquare browni≈øh ≈øeede as other Dockes doe, but bigger, and therefore a≈ø≈øuredly it is a Docke, and the true Rubarbe of the Arabians, or at the lea≈øt the true Rhaponticum of the Ancients. The figure of the whole plant I haue cau≈øed to be cut, with a dryed roote as it grew in my garden by it ≈øelfe, and haue in≈øerted it here, both becau≈øe Matthiolus giueth a fal≈øe figure of the true Rubarbe, and that this hath not been expre≈ø≈øed and ≈øet forth by any before.

div.head: The V≈øe of Patience, and of the Rubarbe.
div.p: The leaues of Patience are often, and of many v≈øed for a pot-herbe, and ≈øeldome to any other purpo≈øe: the roote is often v≈øed in Diet-beere, or ale, or in other drinkes made by decoction, to helpe to purge the liuer, and clen≈øe the blood. The other Rubarbe or Rhaponticum, wherof I make mention, and giue you here the figure, I haue tryed, and found by experience to purge gently, without that a≈øtriction that is in the true Rubarbe is brought vs from the Ea≈øt Indies, or China, and is al≈øo le≈ø≈øe bitter in ta≈øte; whereby I coniecture it may bee v≈øed in hot and feaueri≈øh bodies more effectually, becau≈øe it doth not binde after the purging, as the Ea≈øt India Rubarbe doth: but this mu≈øt bee giuen in double quantitie to the other, and then no doubt it will doe as well: The leaues haue a fine acide ta≈øte: A ≈øyrrupe therefore made with the iuice and ≈øugar, cannot but be very effectuall in deiected appetites, and hot fits of agues; as al≈øo to helpe to open ob≈øtructions of the liuer, as diuers haue often tryed, and found auaileable by experience.

div.head: Lapathum ≈øanguineum. Blood-wort.
div.p:
AMong the ≈øorts of pot-herbes Blood-worte hath alwayes beene accounted a principall one, although I doe not ≈øee any great rea≈øon therein, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing there is a greater efficacie of binding in this Docke, then in any of the other: but as common v≈øe hath receiued it, ≈øo I here ≈øet it downe. Blood-worte is out of the ≈øorts of Dockes, and hath long leaues like vnto the ≈ømaller yellow Docke, but ≈øtriped with red veines, and ouer-≈øhadowed with red vpon the greene leafe, that it ≈øeemeth almo≈øt wholly red ≈øometimes: the ≈øtalke is reddi≈øh, bearing ≈øuch leaues, but
1 Tanacetum. Tan≈øie. 2 Pimpinella. Burnet. 3 Rhaponticum verum ≈øeu potius Rhabarbarum verum. True Raponticke or rather true Rubarbe. 4 Lapithum ≈øativum ≈øeu Patientia. Monkes Rubarbe or Patience. 5 Lapathum ≈øanguineum. Bloudwort. 6 Aceto≈øa. Sorrell. depiction of plants
≈ømaller vp to the toppe, where it is diuided into diuers ≈ømall branches, whereon grow purpli≈øh flowers, and three ≈øquare darke red ≈øeede, like vnto others: the roots are not great, but ≈øomewhat long, and very red, abiding many yeares, yet ≈øometimes ≈øpoiled with the extremitie of winter.

div.head: The V≈øe of Blood-worte.
div.p: The whole and onely v≈øe of the herbe almo≈øt, ≈øerueth for the pot, among other herbes, and, as I ≈øaid before, is accounted a mo≈øt e≈øpeciall one for that purpo≈øe. The ≈øeede therof is much commended for any fluxe in man or woman, to be inwardly taken, and ≈øo no doubt is the roote, being of a ≈øtipticke qualitie.

div.head: Oxalis ≈øiue Aceto≈øa. Sorrell.
div.p: SOrrell mu≈øt needes bee reckoned with the Dockes, for that it is ≈øo like vnto them in all things, and is of many called the ≈øower Docke. Of Sorrels there are many ≈øorts, but I ≈øhall not trouble you with any other in this place, then the common Garden Sorrell, which is mo≈øt knowne, and of greate≈øt v≈øe with vs; which hath tender greene long leaues full of iuice, broade, and bicorned as it were, next vnto the ≈øtalke, like as Arrach, Spinach, and our Engli≈øh Mercurie haue, of a ≈øharpe ≈øower ta≈øte: the ≈øtalkes are ≈ølender, bearing purpli≈øh long heads, wherein lye three ≈øquare ≈øhining browne ≈øeede, like, but le≈ø≈øer then the other: the root is ≈ømaller then any of the other Dockes, but browne, and full of ≈øtrings, and abideth without decaying, hauing greene leaues all the winter, except in the very extremitie thereof, which often taketh away all or mo≈øt of his leaues.

div.head: The V≈øe of Sorrell.
div.p: Sorrell is much v≈øed in ≈øawces, both for the whole, and the ≈øicke, cooling the hot liuers, and ≈øtomackes of the ≈øicke, and procuring vnto them an appetite vnto meate, when their ≈øpirits are almo≈øt ≈øpent with the violence of their furious or fierie fits; and is al≈øo of a plea≈øant relli≈øh for the whole, in quickning vp a dull ≈øtomacke that is ouer-loaden with euery daies plenty of di≈øhes. It is diuers waies dre≈ø≈øed by Cooks, to plea≈øe their Ma≈øters ≈øtomacks.

div.head: Buglo≈ø≈øum luteum, ≈øiue Lingua Bouis. Langdebeefe.
div.p:
VNto this place may well bee referred our ordinary Borage and Buglo≈ø≈øe, ≈øet forth in the former Booke, in regard of the properties whereunto they are much employed, that is, to ≈øerue the pot among other herbes, as is ≈øufficiently knowne vnto all. And yet I confe≈ø≈øe, that this herbe (although it bee called Buglo≈ø≈øum luteum, as if it were a kind of Buglo≈ø≈øe) hath no corre≈øpondency with Buglo≈ø≈øe or Borage in any part, ≈øauing only a little in the leafe; & our Borage or Buglo≈ø≈øe might more fitly, according to the Greeke name, bee called Oxe tongue or Langdebeefe; and this might in my iudgement more aptly be referred to the kinds of Hieratium Hawkeweed, whereunto it neere≈øt approacheth: but as it is commonly receiued, ≈øo take it in this place, vntill it come to receiue the place is proper for it. It hath diuers broad and long darke green leaues, lying vpon the ground, very rough in handling, full of ≈ømall haires or prickes, ready to enter into the hands of any that handle it; among which ri≈øeth
1 Lingua bouis ≈øiue Buglo≈ø≈øum luteum. Langdebeefe. 2 Atriplex ≈øiue Olus aureum. Arrach. 3 Blitum. Blites. 4 Beta. Beetes. 5 Hippo≈øelinum ≈øiue Olus atrum. Alli≈øanders. 6 Selinum dulce. Sweete Par≈øley. depiction of plants
vp a round greene hairy or prickly ≈øtalk, bearing at the toppe, among a few ≈ømall green leaues, diuers ≈ømall yellow flowers in rough heads, which turne into doune, containing within them browne yellowi≈øh ≈ømall long ≈øeedes, ≈øomewhat like vnto the ≈øeede of Hawkeweede: the roote is wooddy, which peri≈øheth quickly after it hath borne ≈øeed; but is tender while it is young.

div.head: The V≈øe of Langdebeefe.
div.p: The leaues are onely v≈øed in all places that I know, or euer could learne, for an herbe for the pot among others, and is thought to bee good to loo≈øen the belly.

div.head: Atriplex ≈øiue Olus Aureum. Arrach.
div.p: THere be diuers kindes of Arrach, or Orach, as ≈øome doe call them; ≈øome of the Garden, whereof I meane to entreate in this place; others wilde of the Fieldes, &c. and others of the Sea, which are not to bee ≈øpoken of in this worke, but referred to a generall hi≈øtorie. The white garden Arrach, or Orach, hath diuers leaues, ≈øtanding vpon their ≈øeuerall foote≈øtalkes, broade at the bottome, ending in two points like an arrow, with two feathers at the head, and ≈ømall pointed at the end of the leafe, of a whiti≈øh yellow greene colour, and as it were ≈øtrewed ouer with flower or meale, e≈øpecially while they are young: the ≈øtalke likewi≈øe is mealy, bearing many branches with ≈ømall yellow flowers on them, which turne into ≈ømall leafie ≈øeeds: the rooote groweth ≈øomewhat deepe in the ground, with many ≈ømall threds fa≈øtened thereto: it quickly ≈øpringeth vp of the ≈øeede, groweth great, and fadeth away as ≈øoon as it hath borne ≈øeede.
The purple Arrach is in all things like vnto the white, ≈øauing onely in the colour of the leafe, ≈øtalke, ≈øeede, &c. which are all of a mealy du≈øty purpli≈øh colour.

div.head: The V≈øe of Arrach.
div.p: Arrach is cold and moi≈øt, and of a lubricke or ≈ølippery qualitie, whereby it quickely pa≈ø≈øeth through the ≈øtomacke and belly, and maketh it ≈øoluble, and is of many v≈øed for that purpo≈øe, being boyled and buttered, or put among other herbes into the pot to make pottage.

There are many di≈øhes of meate made with them while they are young, for being almo≈øt without ≈øauour of them≈øelues, they are the more conuertible into what relli≈øh any one will make them with Sugar, Spice &c.

div.head: Blitum. Blites.
div.p:
THere be diuers ≈øorts of Blites, ≈øome whereof I haue entreated in the former part of this worke, vnder the title of Amaranthus, Flower gentle: others that are nour≈øed vp in Gardens, I will ≈øet forth in this place, which are onely two, that haue come to my knowledge, that is, the white and the red, and are of a qualitie as neere vnto Arrach as vnto Beetes, participating of both, and therefore I haue placed them betwixt them. The white Blite hath leaues ≈øomewhat like vnto Beetes, but ≈ømaller, rounder, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour, euery one ≈øtanding vpon a ≈ømall long foote≈øtalke: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp two or three foote high, with many ≈øuch like leaues thereon: the flowers grow at the top in long round tufts or clu≈øters, wherein are contained
≈ømall round ≈øeede: the roote is very full of threds or ≈øtrings.
The red Blite is in all things like the white, but that his leaues and tufted heades are exceeding red at the fir≈øt, and after turne more purpli≈øh.

div.head: The V≈øe of Blites.
div.p: Blites are v≈øed as Arrach, eyther boyled of it ≈øelfe or ≈øtewed, which they call Loblolly, or among other herbes to bee put into the pot; and yet ≈øome doe vtterly refu≈øe it, becau≈øe in diuers it prouoketh ca≈øtings. It is altogether in≈øipide or without ta≈øte, but yet by rea≈øon of the moi≈øt ≈ølipperie qualitie it hath, it helpeth to loo≈øen the belly. The vn≈øauorine≈ø≈øe whereof hath in many Countries growne into a prouerbe, or by-word, to call dull, ≈ølow, or lazie per≈øons by that name: They are accounted more hurtfull to the ≈øtomacke, and ≈øo to the head and eyes, then other herbes, and therefore they are the le≈ø≈øe v≈øed.

div.head: Beta. Beetes.
div.p: THere are many diuer≈øities of Beetes, ≈øome growing naturally in our own Country, others brought from beyond Sea; whereof ≈øome are white, ≈øome greene, ≈øome yellow, ≈øome red: the leaues of ≈øome are of v≈øe only, and the root not v≈øed: others the roote is only v≈øed, and not the leaues: and ≈øome againe, both roote and leafe. The ancient Authors, as by their workes appeare, knew but two ≈øorts, the white and the blacke Beete, whereof the white is ≈øufficiently known, and was of them termed Sicula, of the later Phy≈øitians Sicla, becau≈øe it was thought fir≈øt to be brought from Sicilie: the blacke abideth ≈øome controuer≈øie; ≈øome thinking that our common greene Beete, becau≈øe it is of a darke greene colour, was that they called the blacke Beete; others that our ≈ømall red Beete, which is of a darke red colour, was their black Beete, which in my opinion is the more likely: But to come to the matter in hand, and giue you the de≈øcriptions of them which are in v≈øe with vs, and leaue controuer≈øies to ≈øuch a worke as is fit for them, wherein all ≈øuch matters may be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed at large.

The common white Beete hath many great leaues next the ground (in ≈øome hot Countries growing to be three foote long, and very broade, in our Countrey they are very large, but nothing neere that proportion) of a whiti≈øh greene colour; the ≈øtalke is great, ≈øtrong, and ribbed or cre≈øted, bearing great ≈øtore of leaues vpon it vp to the very toppe almo≈øt: the flowers grow in very long tufts, ≈ømall at the ends, and turning down their heads, which are ≈ømall pale greeni≈øh yellow burres, giuing cornered prickly ≈øeede: the roote is great, long and hard, when it hath giuen ≈øeede, of no v≈øe at all, but abideth a former winter with leaues vpon it, as all other ≈øorts following do‚ñ™

The common red Beet differeth not from the white Beete, but only that it is not ≈øo great, and both the leaues and rootes are ≈øomewhat red: the leaues bee in ≈øome more red then in others, which haue but red veines or ≈øtrakes in them, in ≈øome al≈øo of a fre≈øh red, in others very darke red: the roote hereof is red, ≈øpongy, and not v≈øed to bee eaten.

The common greene Beete is al≈øo like vnto the white Beete, but of a darke greene colour. This hath beene found neere the ≈øalt Mar≈øhes by Roche≈øter, in the foote-way going from the Lady Leve≈øons hou≈øe thither, by a worthy, diligent and painefull ob≈øeruer and pre≈øeruer both of plants and all other natures varieties, often remembred before in this worke, called Iohn Trade≈øcante, who there finding it, gaue me the knowledge thereof, and I haue vpon his report ≈øet it here down in this manner:

The Romane red Beete, called Beta rapo≈øa, is both for leafe and roote the mo≈øt excellent Beete of all others: his rootes bee as great as the Carrot, exceeding red both within and without, very ≈øweete and good, fit to bee eaten: this Beete groweth higher then the la≈øt red Beete, who≈øe rootes are not v≈øed to bee eaten: the leaues likewi≈øe
are better of ta≈øte, and of as red a colour as the former red Beete: the roote is ≈øometimes ≈øhort like a Turnep, whereof it took the name of Rapa or rapo≈øa; and ≈øometimes as I ≈øaid before, like a Carrot and long: the ≈øeede is all one with the le≈ø≈øer red Beete.

The Italian Beete is of much re≈øpect, who≈øe faire greene leaues are very large and great, with great white ribbes and veines therein: the ≈øtalke in the Summer time, when it is growen vp to any height, is ≈øix ≈øquare in ≈øhew, and yellowi≈øh withall, as the heades with ≈øeede vpon them ≈øeeme likewi≈øe.

The great red Beete that Ma≈øter Lete a Merchant of London gaue vnto Ma≈øter Gerrard, as he ≈øetteth it downe in his Herball, ≈øeemeth to bee the red kinde of the la≈øt remembred Beete, who≈øe great ribbes as he ≈øaith, are as great as the middle ribbe of the Cabbage leafe, and as good to bee eaten, who≈øe ≈øtalke ro≈øe with him to the height of eight cubits, and bore plenty of ≈øeede.

div.head: The V≈øe of Beetes.
div.p: Beetes, both white, greene and red, are put into the pot among other herbes, to make pottage, as is commonly known vnto all, and are al≈øo boyled whole, both in France v≈øually with mo≈øt of their boyled meates, and in our Countrey, with diuers that delight in eating of herbes.

The Italian Beete, and ≈øo likewi≈øe the la≈øt red Beete with great ribbes, are boyled, and the ribbes eaten in ≈øallets with oyle, vinegar and pepper, and is accounted a rare kinde of ≈øallet, and very delicate.

The roote of the common red Beete with ≈øome, but more e≈øpecially the Romane red Beete, is of much v≈øe among Cookes to trimme or ≈øet out their di≈øhes of meate, being cut out into diuers formes and fa≈øhions, and is grown of late dayes into a great cu≈øtome of ≈øeruice, both for fi≈øh and fle≈øh.

The rootes of the Romane red Beete being boyled, are eaten of diuers while they are hot with a little oyle and vinegar, and is accounted a delicate ≈øallet for the winter; and being cold they are ≈øo v≈øed and eaten likewi≈øe.

The leaues are much v≈øed to mollifie and open the belly, being v≈øed in the decoction of Gli≈øters. The roote of the white kinde ≈øcraped, and made vp with a little honey and ≈øalt, rubbed on and layd on the belly, prouoketh to the ≈øtoole. The v≈øe of eating Beetes is likewi≈øe held to bee helpefull to ≈øpleneticke per≈øons.

div.head: Hippo≈øelinum, ≈øiue Olus atrum. Ali≈øanders.
div.p: ALi≈øanders hath beene in former times thought to be the true Macedonian Par≈øley, and in that errour many doe yet continue: but this place giueth not leaue to di≈øcu≈ø≈øe that doubt: but I mu≈øt here only ≈øhew you, what it is, and to what v≈øe it is put ordinarily for the Kitchen. The leaues of Ali≈øanders are winged or cut into many parts, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling Smallage, but greater, broader, and more cut in about the edges: the ≈øtalkes are round and great, two foote high or better, bearing diuers leaues on them, and at the toppe ≈øpokie roundles of white flowers on ≈øeuerall ≈ømall branches, which turne into blacke ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat cornered or cre≈øted, of an aromaticall bitter ta≈øte: the roote is blacke without, and white within, and abideth well the fir≈øt year of the ≈øowing, peri≈øhing after it hath borne ≈øeed.

div.head: The V≈øe of Ali≈øanders.
div.p:
The tops of the rootes, with the lower part of the ≈øtalkes of Ali≈øanders, are v≈øed in Lent e≈øpecially, and Spring of the yeare, to make broth, which although it be a little bitter, yet it is both whol≈øome, and plea≈øing to a great
many, by rea≈øon of the aromaticall or ≈øpicie ta≈øte, warming and comforting the ≈øtomack, and helping it dige≈øt the many wateri≈øh and flegmaticke meates are in tho≈øe times much eaten. The rootes al≈øo either rawe or boyled are often eaten with oyle and vinegar. The ≈øeede is more v≈øed phy≈øically then the roote, or any other part, and is effectuall to prouoke plenty of vrine in them that pi≈ø≈øe by drops, or haue the Strangury: It helpeth womens cour≈øes, and warmeth their benummed bodies or members, that haue endured fierce cold daies and nights, being boyled and drunke.

div.head: Selinum dulce. Sweete Par≈øley or ≈øweete Smallage.
div.p: THis kinde of ≈øweete Par≈øley or Smallage, which ≈øoeuer you plea≈øe to call it; for it re≈øembleth Smallage as well in the largene≈ø≈øe of the leaues, as in the ta≈øte, yet ≈øweeter and plea≈øanter, is (as I take it) in this like vnto ≈øweete Fennell (that hath his ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe from his naturall ≈øoyle and clymate; for how≈øoeuer it bee rea≈øonable ≈øweet the fir≈øt yeare it is ≈øowne with vs, yet it quickly doth degenerate, and becommeth no better then our ordinarie Fennell afterwards). The fir≈øt yeare it is ≈øowne and planted with vs (and the fir≈øt that euer I ≈øaw, was in a Venetian Amba≈ø≈øadours Garden in the Spittle yard, neare Bi≈øhops gate ≈øtreete) is ≈øo ≈øweete and plea≈øant, e≈øpecially while it is young, as if Sugar had beene mingled with it: but after it is growne vp high and large, it hath a ≈øtronger ta≈øte of Smalladge, and ≈øo likewi≈øe much more the next yeare; that it groweth from the ≈øeed was gathered here: the leaues are many, ≈øpreading farre about the roote, broader and of a fre≈øher greene colour then our ordinary Smalladge, and vpon longer ≈øtalkes: the ≈øeed is as plentifull as Par≈øley, being ≈ømall and very like vnto it, but darker of colour.

div.head: The V≈øe of ≈øweete Par≈øley.
div.p: The Venetians v≈øe to prepare it for meate many waies, both the herbe and the roote eaten rawe, as many other herbes and rootes are, or boyled or fryed to be eaten with meate, or the dryed herbe poudered and ≈øtrewed vpon meate; but mo≈øt v≈øually either whited, and ≈øo eaten rawe with pepper and oyle, as a dainty Sallet of it ≈øelfe, or a little boyled or ≈øtewed: the ta≈øte of the herbe being a little warming, but the ≈øeede much more, helpeth cold windy ≈øtomackes to dige≈øt their meate, and to expell winde.

div.head: Petro≈øolinum & Apium. Par≈øley and Smalledge.
div.p: WE haue three ≈øorts of Par≈øley in our Gardens, and but one of Smalladge: Our common Par≈øley, Curld Par≈øley, and Virginia Par≈øley; which la≈øt, although it be but of late knowne, yet it is now almo≈øt growne common, and of as good v≈øe as the other with diuers. Our common Par≈øley is ≈øo well knowne, that it is almo≈øt needle≈ø≈øe to de≈øcribe it, hauing diuers fre≈øh greene leaues, three alwaies placed together on a ≈øtalke, and ≈ønipt about the edges, and three ≈øtalkes of leaues for the mo≈øt part growing together: the ≈øtalkes growe three or foure foote high or better, bearing ≈øpikie heads of white flowers, which turne into ≈ømall ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe and hot in ta≈øte: the roote is long and white.
Curld Par≈øley hath his leaues curled or crumpled on the edges, and therein is the onely difference from the former.

Virginia Par≈øley is in his leafe altogether like vnto common Par≈øley for the forme, con≈øi≈øting of three leaues ≈øet together, but that the leaues are as large as Smallage leaues, but of a pale or whiti≈øh greene colour, and of the ≈øame ta≈øte of our common Par≈øley: the ≈øeede hereof is as the leaues, twice if not thrice as bigge as the ordinary Par≈øley, and peri≈øheth when it hath giuen ≈øeede, abiding v≈øually the fir≈øt yeare of the ≈øowing.
Smallage is in forme ≈øomewhat like vnto Par≈øley, but greater and greener, and le≈ø≈øe plea≈øant, or rather more bitter in ta≈øte: the ≈øeede is ≈ømaller, and the root more ≈øtringy.

div.head: The V≈øe of Par≈øley.
div.p: Par≈øley is much v≈øed in all ≈øorts of meates, both boyled, roa≈øted, fryed, ≈øtewed, &c. and being greene it ≈øerueth to lay vpon ≈øundry meates, as al≈øo to draw meate withall. It is al≈øo ≈øhred and ≈øtopped into poudered beefe, as al≈øo into legges of Mutton, with a little beefe ≈øuet among it, &c.
The rootes are often v≈øed to be put into broth, to helpe to open ob≈øtructions of the liuer, reines, and other parts, helping much to procure vrine.

The rootes likewi≈øe boyled or ≈øtewed with a legge of Mutton, ≈øtopped with Par≈øley as afore≈øaid, is very good meate, and of very good relli≈øh, as I haue proued by the ta≈øte; but the rootes mu≈øt bee young, and of the fir≈øt yeares growth, and they will haue their operation to cau≈øe vrine.
The ≈øeed al≈øo is v≈øed for the ≈øame cau≈øe, when any are troubled with the ≈øtone, or grauell, to open the pa≈ø≈øages of vrine.

Although Smallage groweth in many places wilde in moi≈øt grounds, yet it is al≈øo much planted in Gardens, and although his euill ta≈øte and ≈øauour doth cau≈øe it not to be accepted into meates as Par≈øley, yet it is not without many ≈øpeciall good properties, both for outward and inward di≈øea≈øes, to helpe to open ob≈øtructions, and prouoke vrine. The iuyce clean≈øeth vlcers; and the leaues boyled with Hogs grea≈øe, healeth felons on the ioynts of the fingers.

div.head: Foeniculum. Fenell.
div.p: THere are three ≈øorts of Fenell, whereof two are ≈øweete. The one of them is the ordinary ≈øweete Fenell, who≈øe ≈øeedes are larger and yellower then the common, and which (as I ≈øaid before in the Chapter of ≈øweete Par≈øley) doth ≈øoone degenerate in this our Country into the common. The other ≈øweete Fenell is not much knowne, and called Cardus Fenell by tho≈øe that ≈øent it out of Italy, who≈øe leaues are more thicke and bu≈øhie then any of the other. Our common Fenell, whereof there is greene and red, hath many faire and large ≈øpread leaues, finely cut and diuided into many ≈ømall, long, greene, or reddi≈øh leaues, yet the thicker tufted the branches be, the ≈øhorter are the leaues: the ≈øtalkes are round, with diuers ioynts and leaues at them, growing fiue or ≈øix foot high, bearing at the top many ≈øpoakie rundels of yellow flowers: the Common, I meane, doth turne into a darke grayi≈øh flat ≈øeede, and the Sweete into larger and yellower: the roote is great, long, and white, and endureth diuers yeares.

div.head: The V≈øe of Fenell.
div.p:
Fenell is of great v≈øe to trimme vp, and ≈øtrowe vpon fi≈øh, as al≈øo to boyle or put among fi≈øh of diuers ≈øorts, Cowcumbers pickled, and other fruits, &c. The rootes are v≈øed with Par≈øley rootes, to be boyled in broths and drinkes to open ob≈øtructions. The ≈øeed is of much v≈øe with other things to expell winde. The ≈øeede al≈øo is much v≈øed to be put into Pippin pies, and diuers
1 Petro≈øolinum. Par≈øley. 2 Atium. Smallage. 3 Foeniculum. Fenell. 4 Anethum. Dill. 5 Myrrhis ≈øiue Ce ‚Ä¢ efolium magnum. Sweete Cheruill. 6 Cerefolium vulgare. Common Cheruil ‚Ä¢ . depiction of plants
other ≈øuch baked fruits, as al≈øo into bread, to giue it the better relli≈øh.

The ≈øweete Cardus Fenell being ≈øent by Sir Henry Wotton to Iohn Trade≈øcante, had likewi≈øe a large direction with it how to dre≈ø≈øe it; for they v≈øe to white it after it hath been tran≈øplanted for their v≈øes, which by rea≈øon of the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe by nature, and the tenderne≈ø≈øe by art, cau≈øeth it to be the more delightfull to the ta≈øte, e≈øpecially with them that are accu≈øtomed to feede on greene herbes.

div.head: Anethum. Dill.
div.p: DIll doth much growe wilde, but becau≈øe in many places it cannot be had, it is therefore ≈øowne in Gardens for the v≈øes whereunto it ≈øerueth. It is a ≈ømaller herbe then Fenell, but very like, hauing fine cut leaues, not ≈øo large, but ≈øhorter, ≈ømaller, and of a ≈øtronger and quicker ta≈øte: the ≈øtalke is ≈ømaller al≈øo, and with few ioynts and leaues on them, bearing ≈øpoakie tufts of yellow flowers, which turne into thinne, ≈ømall, and flat ≈øeedes: the roote peri≈øheth euery yeare, and ri≈øeth againe for the mo≈øt part of it owne ≈øowing.

div.head: The V≈øe of Dill.
div.p: The leaues of Dill are much v≈øed in ≈øome places with Fi≈øh, as they doe Fenell; but becau≈øe it is ≈øo ≈øtrong many doe refu≈øe it.
It is al≈øo put among pickled Cowcumbers, wherewith it doth very well agree, giuing vnto the cold fruit a pretty ≈øpicie ta≈øte or relli≈øh.
It being ≈øtronger then Fenell, is of the more force to expell winde in the body. Some v≈øe to eate the ≈øeed to ≈øtay the Hickocke.

div.head: Myrrhis ≈øiue Cerefolium maius & vulgare. Sweet Cheruill and ordinary Cheruill.
div.p: THe great or ≈øweete Cheruill (which of ≈øome is called Sweete Cicely) hath diuers great and faire ≈øpread winged leaues, con≈øi≈øting of many leaues ≈øet together, deeply cut in the edges, and euery one al≈øo dented about, very like, and re≈øembling the leaues of Hemlockes, but of ≈øo plea≈øant a ta≈øte, that one would verily thinke, he chewed the leaues or ≈øeedes of Ani≈øeedes in his mouth: The ≈øtalke is rea≈øonable great, and ≈øomewhat cornered or cre≈øted about three or foure foote high, at the toppe whereof ≈øtand many white ≈øpoakie tufts of flowers, which change into browne long cornered great ≈øeede, two alwaies ioyned together: the roote is great, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and white within, with diuers fibres annexed vnto it, and peri≈øheth not, but abideth many yeares, and is of a ≈øweete, plea≈øant, and ≈øpicie hot ta≈øte, delightfull vnto many.

The common Cheruill is a ≈ømall herbe, with ≈ølender leaues, finely cut into long peeces, at the fir≈øt of a pale yellowi≈øh greene colour, but when the ≈øtalke is growne vp to ≈øeede, both ≈øtalkes and leaues become of a darke red colour: the flowers are white, ≈øtanding vpon ≈øcattered or thin ≈øpread tufts, which turne into ≈ømall, long, round, and ≈øharpe pointed ≈øeedes, of a browni≈øh blacke colour: the roote is ≈ømall, with diuers long ≈ølender white ≈øtrings, and peri≈øheth euery yeare.

div.head: The V≈øes of the≈øe Cheruils.
div.p: The common Cheruill is much v≈øed of the French and Dutch people, to bee boyled or ≈øtewed in a pipkin, eyther by it ≈øelfe, or with other herbes, whereof they make a Loblolly, and ≈øo eate it. It is v≈øed as a pot-herbe with vs.

Sweete Cheruill, gathered while it is young, and put among other herbes for a ≈øallet, addeth a meruellous good relli≈øh to all the re≈øt. Some commend the greene ≈øeedes ≈øliced and put in a ≈øallet of herbes, and eaten with vinegar and oyle, to comfort the cold ≈øtomacke of the aged. The roots are v≈øed by diuers, being boyled, and after eaten with oyle and vinegar, as an excellent ≈øallet for the ≈øame purpo≈øe. The pre≈øerued or candid rootes are of ≈øingular good v≈øe to warme and comfort a cold flegmaticke ≈øtomack, and is thought to be a good pre≈øeruatiue in the time of the plague.

div.head: Malua Cri≈øpa. French Mallowes.
div.p: THe curld or French Mallow groweth vp with an vpright greene round ≈øtalke, as high v≈øually as any man, whereon from all ≈øides grow forth round whiti≈øh greene leaues, curld or crumpled about the edges, like a ruffe, el≈øe very like vnto an ordinary great Mallow leafe: the flowers grow both vpon the ≈øtalke, and on the other branches that ≈øpring from them, being ≈ømall and white; after which come ≈ømall ca≈øes with blacke ≈øeede like the other Mallowes: the roote peri≈øheth when it hath borne ≈øeede, but abideth v≈øually the fir≈øt yeare, and the ≈øecond runneth vp to flower and ≈øeede.

div.head: The V≈øe of French Mallowes.
div.p: It is much v≈øed as a pot-herbe, e≈øpecially when there is cau≈øe to moue the belly downward, which by his ≈ølippery qualitie it doth helpe forward. It hath beene in times pa≈øt, and ≈øo is to this day in ≈øome places, v≈øed to be boyled or ≈øtewed, eyther by it ≈øelfe with butter, or with other herbes, and ≈øo eaten.

div.head: Imtubum. Succorie and Endiue.
div.p: I Put both Succorie and Endiue into one chapter and de≈øcription, becau≈øe they are both of one kindred; and although they differ a little the one from the other, yet they agree both in this, that they are eaten eyther greene or whited, of many.

Endiue, the ≈ømooth as well as the curld, beareth a longer and a larger leafe then Succorie, and abideth but one yeare, quickely running vp to ≈øtalke and ≈øeede, and then peri≈øheth: whereas Succorie abideth many years, and hath long and narrower leaues, ≈øomewhat more cut in, or torne on the edges: both of them haue blew flowers, and the ≈øeede of the ≈ømooth or ordinary Endiue is ≈øo like vnto the Succorie, that it is very hard to di≈øtingui≈øh them a≈øunder by ≈øight; but the curld Endiue giueth blacki≈øh and flat ≈øeede, very like vnto blacke Lettice feede: the rootes of the Endiue peri≈øh, but the Succorie abideth.

div.head: The V≈øe of Succory and Endiue.
div.p:
Although Succorie bee ≈øomewhat more bitter in ta≈øte then the Endiues,
yet it is oftentimes, and of many eaten greene, but more v≈øually being buried a while in ≈øand, that it may grow white, which cau≈øeth it to lo≈øe both ≈øome part of the bitterne≈ø≈øe, as al≈øo to bee the more tender in the eating; and Horace ≈øheweth it to be v≈øed in his time, in the 32. Ode of his fir≈øt Book, where he ≈øaith, Me pa≈øcunt Oliuae, me Cithorea leue≈ø
que Maluae. Endiue being whited in the ≈øame, or any other manner, is much v≈øed in winter, as a ≈øallet herbe with great delight; but the curld Endiue is both farre the fairer, and the tenderer for that purpo≈øe.

div.head: Spinachia, ≈øiue Olus Hi≈øpanicum. Spinach.
div.p: SPinach or Spinage is of three ≈øorts (yet ≈øome doe reckon of foure, accounting that herbe that beareth no ≈øeede to be a ≈øort of it ≈øelfe, when it is but an accident of nature, as it falleth out in Hempe, Mercury, and diuers other herbes) two that bear prickly ≈øeed, the one much greater then the other: the third that beareth a ≈ømooth ≈øeede, which is more daintie, and nour≈øed vp but in few Gardens: The common Spinach which is the le≈ø≈øer of the two prickly ≈øorts, hath long greene leaues, broad at the ≈øtalke, and rent, or torne as it were into foure corners, and ≈øharpe pointed at the ends: it quickly runneth vp to ≈øtalke, if it be ≈øowen in the Spring time; but el≈øe, if at the end of Summer, it will abide all the winter green, and then ≈øuddenly in the very beginning of the Spring, runne vp to ≈øtalke, bearing many leaues both below and at the toppe, where there doth appeare many ≈ømal greeni≈øh flowers in clu≈øters, and after them prickly ≈øeede: The other greater ≈øort that hath prickly ≈øeede, is in all things like the former, but larger both in ≈øtalke, leafe and ≈øeede. The ≈ømooth Spinach hath broader, and a little rounder pointed leaues then the fir≈øt, e≈øpecially the lower leaues; for tho≈øe that grow vpwards vpon the ≈øtalke, are more pointed, and as it were three ≈øquare, of as darke a greene colour as the former: at the ≈øeuerall ioynts of the ≈øtalkes and branches, ≈øtand clu≈øtering many ≈ømall greeni≈øh flowers, which turne into clu≈øters of round whiti≈øh ≈øeede, without any prickles at all vpon them: the roote is long, white and ≈ømall, like vnto the other, with many fibres at it: If it be often cut, it will grow the thicker, or el≈øe ≈øpindle vp very thinly, and with but few leaues vpon the ≈øtalke.

div.head: The V≈øe of Spinage.
div.p: Spinage is an herbe fit for ≈øallets, and for diuers other purpo≈øes for the table only; for it is not knowne to bee v≈øed Phy≈øically at all. Many Engli≈øh that haue learned it of the Dutch people, doe ≈øtew the herbe in a pot or pipkin, without any other moi≈øture then it owne, and after the moi≈øture is a little pre≈ø≈øed from it, they put butter, and a little ≈øpice vnto it, and make therewith a di≈øh that many delight to eate of. It is v≈øed likewi≈øe to be made into Tartes, and many other varieties of di≈øhes, as Gentlewomen and their Cookes can better tell then my ≈øelfe; vnto whom I leaue the further ordering of the≈øe herbes, and all other fruits and rootes of this Garden: For I intend only to giue you the knowledge of them, with ≈øome briefe notes for their v≈øe, and no more.

figure.head: 1 Malua cri≈øpa. French Mallowes. 2 Endiuia. Endiue. 3 Cichorium. Succory. 4 Spinachia. Spinach. 5 Lactuca cri≈øpa. Curld Lettice. 6 Lactuca parula. An open Lettice. 7 Lactuca capitata vulgaris. Ordinary cabbage Lettice. 8 Lactuca capitata Romana. The great Romane cabbage Lettice. 9 Lactuca ag ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ina. Corne Sallet or Lambes Lettice.

div.head: Lactuca. Lettice.
div.p: THere are ≈øo many ≈øorts, and ≈øo great diuer≈øitie of Lettice, that I doubt I ≈øhall ≈øcarce be beleeued of a great many. For I doe in this Chapter reckon vp vnto you eleauen or twelue differing ≈øorts; ≈øome of little v≈øe, others of more, being more common and vulgar; and ≈øome that are of excellent v≈øe and ≈øeruice, which are more rare, and require more knowledge and care for the ordering of them, as al≈øo for their time of ≈øpending, as ≈øome in the ≈øpring, ≈øome in ≈øummer, others in autumne, and ≈øome being whited for the winter. For all the≈øe ≈øorts I ≈øhall not neede many de≈øcriptions, but only ≈øhew you which doe cabbage, and which are loo≈øe, which of of them are great or ≈ømall, white, greene or red, and which of them beare white ≈øeeds, and which of them blacke. And la≈øtly I haue thought good to adde another Sallet herbe, which becau≈øe it is called Lambes Lettice of many, or Corne Sallet of others, is put in only to fill vp a number in this Chapter, and that I mu≈øt ≈øpeake of it, and not that I thinke it to be any of the kindes of Lettice.

All ≈øorts of Lettice, after a while that they haue clo≈øed them≈øelues, if they bee of the Cabbage kindes, or otherwi≈øe being loo≈øe, and neuer clo≈øing, ≈øend forth from among the middle of their leaues a round ≈øtalke (in ≈øome greater, in others le≈ø≈øer, according to their kinde) full of leaues like vnto the lower, branching at the toppe into ≈øundry parts, whereon grow diuers ≈ømall ≈øtar-like flowers, of a pale yellowi≈øh colour; after which come ≈øeede, eyther white or blacki≈øh, as the plant yeeldeth, whereat hangeth ≈øome ≈ømall peece of a cottony doune, wherewith the whole head is ≈øtored, and is carried away with the winde, if it be not gathered in time: the roote is ≈øomewhat long and white, with ≈øome fibres at it, and peri≈øheth quickely after the ≈øeede is ripe.

The Romane red Lettice is the be≈øt and greate≈øt of all the re≈øt. For Iohn Trade≈øcante that fir≈øt, as I thinke, brought it into England, and ≈øowed it, did write vnto mee, that after one of them had been bound and whited, when the refu≈øe was cut away, the re≈øt weighed ≈øeuenteene ounces: this hath blacke ≈øeede.
The white Romane Lettice is like vnto it, hauing long leaues like a Tea≈øell, it is in goodne≈ø≈øe next vnto the red, but mu≈øt be whited, that it may eate kindly: the ≈øeede hereof is white.
The Virginia Lettice hath ≈øingle and very broade reddi≈øh leaues, and is not of any great regard, and therefore is kept but of a few: it beareth blacke ≈øeede.
The common Lumbard Lettice that is loo≈øe, and another kinde thereof that doth ≈øomewhat cabbage, haue both white ≈øeedes.

The Venice Lettice is an excellent Cabbage Lettice, and is be≈øt to bee ≈øowen after Mid≈øummer for lateward Lettice; they be ≈øometimes as great as the crowne of a mans hatt: the ≈øeede hereof is white, and groweth to be of a meane height.
Our common Cabbage Lettice is well known, and beareth blacke ≈øeede.
The curld Lettice which is open, and differeth but little from Endiue, beareth black ≈øeede.

Another ≈øort of curld Lettice doth cabbage, and is called Flanders Cropers, or Cropers of Bruges; this groweth lowe≈øt, and hath the ≈ømalle≈øt head, but very hard and round, and white while it groweth: the ≈øeed is blacke.
A kinde of Romane Lettice is of a darke green colour, growing as low as the Venice Lettice, and is an excellent kinde, bearing blacke ≈øeede.

And la≈øtly our winter Lettice is wonderfull hardy to endure our cold: It is but ≈øingle, and mu≈øt be ≈øowen at Michaelmas, but will be very good, before any of the other good ≈øorts ≈øowen in the Spring, will be ready to be v≈øed, and beareth white ≈øeed.

To in≈øtruct a nouice (for I teach not a Gardiner of knowledge) how to gather his ≈øeede that it may be good, is in this manner: Let him marke out tho≈øe plants that hee meaneth ≈øhall run vp for ≈øeede, which mu≈øt be the mo≈øt likely; & after they haue begun to ≈øhoote forth ≈øtalkes, ≈øtrip away the lower leaues, for two or three hands breadth aboue the ground, that thereby in taking away the lowe≈øt leaues, the ≈øtalke doe not rot, nor the ≈øeed be hindered in the ripening.

There are two manner of wayes to whiten Lettice to make them eate the more tender: the one is by ray≈øing vp earth like moale hils, round about the plants while they are growing, which will make them grow white: the other is by tying vp all the loo≈øe leaues round together while it groweth, that ≈øo the clo≈øe tying may make it grow white, and thereby be the more tender.

Lambes Lettice or Corne Sallet is a ≈ømall plant while it is young, growing clo≈øe vpon the ground, with many whiti≈øh greene, long and narrow, round pointed leaues, all the winter, and in the beginning of the ≈øpring (if it bee ≈øowen in autumne, as it is v≈øuall to ≈øerue for an early ≈øallet) ri≈øeth vp with ≈ømall round ≈øtalkes, with two leaues at euery ioynt, branching forth at the toppe, and bearing tufts of ≈ømall bleake blew flowers, which turne into ≈ømall round whiti≈øh ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall and long, with ≈øome ≈ømall threds hanging thereat: the whole plant is of a wateri≈øh ta≈øte, almo≈øt in≈øipide.

div.head: The V≈øe of Lettice.
div.p: All ≈øorts of Lettice are ≈øpent in ≈øallets, with oyle and vinegar, or as euery one plea≈øe, for the mo≈øt part, while they are fre≈øh and greene, or whited, as is declared of ≈øome of the ≈øorts before, to cau≈øe them to eate the more delicate and tender. They are al≈øo boyled, to ≈øerue for many ≈øorts of di≈øhes of meate, as the Cookes know be≈øt.
They all coole a hot and fainting ≈øtomacke.

The iuice of Lettice applyed with oyle of Ro≈øes to the foreheads of the ≈øicke and weake wanting ≈øleepe, procureth re≈øt, and taketh away paines in the head: bound likewi≈øe to the cods, it helpeth tho≈øe that are troubled with the Colts euill. If a little camphire be added, it re≈øtraineth immoderate lu≈øt: but it is hurtfull to ≈øuch as are troubled with the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of breath.
Lambes Lettice is wholly ≈øpent for ≈øallets, in the beginning of the yeare, as I ≈øaid, before any almo≈øt of the other ≈øorts of Lettice are to be had.

div.head: Portulaca. Pur≈ølane.
div.p: PVr≈ølane hath many thicke round ≈øhining red ≈øtalkes, full of iuice, lying vpon the ground for the mo≈øt part; whereon are ≈øet diuers long, thicke, pale green leaues, ≈øometimes alone by them≈øelues, and ≈øometimes many ≈ømall ones together with them; among which grow ≈ømall yellow flowers, which ≈øtand in little greene huskes, containing blacke ≈øeede: the roote is ≈ømall, and peri≈øheth euery yeare, and mu≈øt be new ≈øowen in Aprill, in the alleyes of the Garden betweene the beds, as ≈øome haue heretofore v≈øed, where it may haue the more moi≈øture, or, as I haue ≈øeene in ≈øome Gardens, vpon tho≈øe beds of dung that Gardiners haue v≈øed to nour≈øe vp their Cowcumbers, Melons, and Pompions, whereon after they haue beene taken away, they haue ≈øowen Pur≈ølane, where if it be much watered, the warmth of the dung, and the water giuen it, the Pur≈ølane hath grown great and large, and continued vntill winter.

div.head: The V≈øe of Pur≈ølane.
div.p: It is v≈øed as Lettice in ≈øallets, to coole hot and faint ≈øtomackes in the hot time of the yeare, but afterwards if only for delight, it is not good to bee too prodigall in the v≈øe thereof.
The ≈øeede of Pur≈ølane doth coole much any inflammation inward or outward, and doth a little binde withall.

div.head: Dracoherba ≈øiue Tarchon & Dracunculus horten≈øis. Tarragon.
div.p: TArragon hath long and narrow darke greene leaues, growing on ≈ølender and brittle round ≈øtalkes, two or three foote high, at the tops whereof grow forth long ≈ølender ≈øpikes of ≈ømall yellowi≈øh flowers, which ≈øeldome giue any good ≈øeede, but a du≈øtie or chaffie matter, which flieth away with the winde: the roote is white, and creepeth about vnder ground, whereby it much encrea≈øeth: the whole herbe is of a hot and biting ta≈øte.

div.head: The V≈øe of Tarragon.
div.p: It is altogether v≈øed among other cold herbes, to temper their coldne≈ø≈øe, and they to temper its heate, ≈øo to giue the better relli≈øh vnto the Sallet; but many doe not like the ta≈øte thereof, and ≈øo refu≈øe it.

There are ≈øome Authors that haue held Tarragon not to be an herbe of it owne kinde, but that it was fir≈øt produced, by putting the ≈øeede of Lin or Flaxe into the roote of an Onion, being opened and ≈øo ≈øet into the ground, which when it hath ≈øprung, hath brought forth this herbe Tarragon, which ab≈øurd and idle opinion, Matthiolus by certaine experience ≈øaith, hath been found fal≈øe.

div.head: Nasturtium horten≈øe. Garden Cre≈ø≈øes.
div.p: GArden Cre≈ø≈øes growe vp to the height of two foote or thereabouts, hauing many ≈ømall, whiti≈øh, broad, endented, torne leaues, ≈øet together vpon a middle ribbe next the ground, but tho≈øe that growe higher vpon the ≈øtalkes are ≈ømaller and longer: the tops of the ≈øtalkes are ≈øtored with white flowers, which turne into flat pods or pouches, like vnto Shepheard pur≈øe, wherein is contained flat reddi≈øh ≈øeede: the roote peri≈øheth euery yeare: the ta≈øte both of leaues and ≈øeedes are ≈øomewhat ≈øtrong, hot, and bitter.

div.head: The V≈øe of Cre≈ø≈øes.
div.p: The Dutchmen and others v≈øe to eate Cre≈ø≈øes familiarly with their butter and bread, as al≈øo ≈øtewed or boyled, either alone or with other herbes, whereof they make a Hotch potch, and ≈øo eate it. Wee doe eate it mixed among Lettice or Pur≈ølane, and ≈øometimes with Tarragon or Rocket, with oyle and vinegar and a little ≈øalt, and in that manner it is very ≈øauoury to ≈øome mens ≈øtomackes.

The v≈øe of Cre≈ø≈øes phy≈øically is, it helpeth to expectorate tough flegme, as al≈øo for the paines of the brea≈øt; and as it is thought taketh away ≈øpots, being laid to with vinegar. The ≈øeede is giuen of many to children for the wormes.

figure.head: 1 Portulaca. Pur≈ølane. 2 Dracho herba ≈øeu Tarchon. Tarragon. 3 Eruca ≈øatiua. Garden Rocket. 4 Na≈øturtium ≈øativum. Garden Cre≈ø≈øe. 5 Sinapi. Mu≈øtard. 6 A≈øparagus. A≈øparagus or Sperage.

div.head: Eruca ≈øatiua. Garden Rocket.
div.p: OVr Garden Rocket is but a wilde kinde brought into Gardens; for the true Romane Rocket hath larger leaues; this hath many long leaues, much torne or rent on the edges, ≈ømaller and narrower then the Romane kinde: the flowers hereof are of a pale yellowi≈øh colour, whereas the true is whiti≈øh, con≈øi≈øting of foure leaues: the ≈øeede of this is reddi≈øh, contained in ≈ømaller and longer pods then the true, which are ≈øhorter and thicker, and the ≈øeede of a whiti≈øh yellow colour: the rootes of both peri≈øh as ≈øoone as they haue giuen ≈øeede. Some haue taken one ≈øort of the wilde kinde for Mu≈øtard, and haue v≈øed the ≈øeede for the ≈øame purpo≈øe.

div.head: The V≈øe of Rocket.
div.p: It is for the mo≈øt part eaten with Lettice, Pur≈ølane, or ≈øuch cold herbes, and not alone, becau≈øe of its heate and ≈øtrength; but that with the white ≈øeede is milder. The ≈øeede of Rocket is good to prouoke vrine, and to ≈øtirre vp bodily lu≈øt.
The ≈øeede brui≈øed, and mixed with a little vinegar, and of the gall of an Oxe, clean≈øeth the face of freckles, ≈øpots, and blew markes, that come by beatings, fals, or otherwaies.
Matthiolus ≈øaith, that the leaues boyled, and giuen with ≈øome Sugar to little children, cureth them of the cough.
The ≈øeede is held to be helpfull to ≈øpleneticke per≈øons; as al≈øo to kill the wormes of the belly.

div.head: Sinapi ≈øativum. Garden Mu≈øtard.
div.p: THe Mu≈øtard that is mo≈øt v≈øuall in this Country, how≈øoeuer diuers doe for their priuate v≈øes ≈øowe it in their Gardens or Orchards, in ≈øome conuenient corner, yet the ≈øame is found wilde al≈øo abroad in many places. It hath many rough long diuided leaues, of an ouerworne greene colour: the ≈øtalke is diuided at the toppe into diuers branches, whereon growe diuers pale yellow flowers, in a great length, which turne into ≈ømall long pods, wherein is contained blacki≈øh ≈øeede, inclining to redne≈ø≈øe, of a fiery ≈øharpe ta≈øte: the roote is tough and white, running deepe into the ground, with many ≈ømall fibres at it.

div.head: The V≈øe of Mu≈øtard.
div.p: The ≈øeede hereof grownd between two ≈øtones, fitted for the purpo≈øe, and called a Querne, with ≈øome good vinegar added vnto it, to make it liquid and running, is that kinde of Mu≈øtard that is v≈øually made of all ≈øorts, to ≈øerue as ≈øawce both for fi≈øh and fle≈øh.

The ≈øame liquid Mu≈øtard is of good v≈øe, being fre≈øh, for Epilepticke per≈øons, to warme and quicken tho≈øe dull ≈øpirits that are ≈øopite and ≈øcarce appeare, if it be applyed both inwardly and outwardly.
It is with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe al≈øo giuen to tho≈øe that haue ≈øhort breathes, and troubled with a cough in the lungs.

div.head: A≈øparagus. Sperage or A≈øparagus.
div.p: ASparagus ri≈øeth vp at the fir≈øt with diuers whiti≈øh greene ≈øcaly heads, very brittle or ea≈øie to breake while they are young, which afterwards ri≈øe vp into very long and ≈ølender greene ≈øtalkes, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of an ordinary riding wand at the bottome of mo≈øt, or bigger or le≈ø≈øer, as the rootes are of growth, on which are ≈øet diuers branches of greene leaues, ≈øhorter and ≈ømaller then Fennell vp to the toppe, at the ioynts whereof come forth ≈ømall mo≈ø≈øie yellowi≈øh flowers, which turne into round berries, greene at the fir≈øt, and of an excellent red colour when they are ripe, ≈øhewing as if they were beades of Corrall, wherein are contained exceeding hard and blacke ≈øeede: the rootes are di≈øper≈øed from a ≈øpongious head into many long, thicke, and round ≈øtrings, whereby it ≈øucketh much nouri≈øhment out of the ground, and encrea≈øeth plentifully thereby.
We haue another kinde hereof that is of much greater account, becau≈øe the ≈øhootes are larger, whiter, and being dre≈ø≈øed ta≈øte more ≈øweete and plea≈øant, without any other difference.

div.head: The V≈øe of A≈øparagus.
div.p: The fir≈øt ≈øhootes or heads of A≈øparagus are a Sallet of as much e≈øteeme with all ≈øorts of per≈øons, as any other what≈øoeuer, being boyled tender, and eaten with butter, vinegar, and pepper, or oyle and vinegar, or as euery ones manner doth plea≈øe; and are almo≈øt wholly ≈øpent for the plea≈øure of the pallate. It is ≈øpecially good to prouoke vrine, and for tho≈øe that are troubled with the ≈øtone or grauell in the reines or kidneyes, becau≈øe it doth a little open and clean≈øe tho≈øe parts.

div.head: Bra≈øsica. Cabbages and Coleworts.
div.p: THere is greater diuer≈øity in the forme and colour of the leaues of this plant, then there is in any other that I know groweth vpon the ground. But this place requireth not the knowledge of all ≈øorts which might be ≈øhewen, many of them being of no v≈øe with vs for the table, but for delight, to behold the wonderfull variety of the workes of God herein. I will here therefore ≈øhew you onely tho≈øe ≈øorts that are ordinary in mo≈øt Gardens, and ≈øome that are rare, receiued into ≈øome e≈øpeciall Gardens: And fir≈øt of Cabbages, and then of Coleworts.

Our ordinary Cabbage that clo≈øeth hard and round, hath at the fir≈øt great large thicke leaues, of a grayi≈øh greene colour, with thicke great ribbes, and lye open mo≈øt part of the Summer without clo≈øing, but toward the end of Summer, being growne to haue many leaues, it then beginneth to growe clo≈øe and round in the middle, and as it clo≈øeth, the leaues growe white inward; yet there be ≈øome kindes that will neuer be ≈øo clo≈øe as the≈øe, but will remaine halfe open, which wee doe not account to be ≈øo good as the other: in the middle of this head, the next yeare after the ≈øowing, in other Countries e≈øpecially, and ≈øometimes in ours, if the Winter be milde, as may be ≈øeene in diuers Gardens (but to preuent the danger of our Winter fro≈øts, our Gardiners now doe v≈øe to take vp diuers Cabbages with their rootes, and tying a cloth or ≈øome ≈øuch thing about the rootes, doe hang them vp in their hou≈øes, where they may be defended from cold, and then ≈øet them againe after the fro≈øts are pa≈øt) and then there ≈øhooteth out a great thicke ≈øtalke, diuided at the toppe into many branches, bearing thereon diuers ≈ømall flowers, ≈øometime white, but mo≈øt commonly yellow, made of foure leaues, which turne into long, round, and pointed pods, containing therein ≈ømall
round ≈øeede, like vnto Turnep ≈øeede: the roote ≈øpreadeth not farre nor deepe, and dyeth v≈øually in any great fro≈øte; for a ≈ømall fro≈øt maketh the Cabbage eate the tenderer.

The red Cabbage is like vnto the white, la≈øt ≈øpoken of, but differing in colour and greatne≈ø≈øe; for it is ≈øeldome found ≈øo great as the white, and the colour of the leaues is very variable, as being in ≈øome ≈øtript with red, in others more red, or very deepe red or purple.
The ≈øugar loafe Cabbage, ≈øo called becau≈øe it is ≈ømaller at the toppe then it is at the bottome, and is of two ≈øorts, the one white, the other greene.

The Sauoy Cabbadge, one is of a deepe greene coloured leafe, and curld when it is to be gathered; the other is yellowi≈øh: neyther of both the≈øe doe clo≈øe ≈øo well as the fir≈øt, but yet are v≈øed of ≈øome, and accounted good.

The Cole flower is a kinde of Coleworte, who≈øe leaues are large, and like the Cabbage leaues, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and endented about the edges, in the middle wherof, ≈øometimes in the beginning of Autumne, and ≈øometimes much ≈øooner, there appeareth a hard head of whiti≈øh yellow tufts of flowers, clo≈øely thru≈øt together, but neuer open, nor ≈øpreading much with vs, which then is fitte≈øt to be v≈øed, the green leaues being cut away clo≈øe to the head: this hath a much plea≈øanter ta≈øte then eyther the Coleworte, or Cabbage of any kinde, and is therefore of the more regard and re≈øpect at good mens tables.
The ordinary Coleworte is ≈øufficiently knowne not to clo≈øe or cabbage, and giueth ≈øeede plentifully enough.

The other Colewortes that are nour≈øed vp with tho≈øe that delight in curio≈øities, be≈øides the afore≈øaid ordinary greene, which is much v≈øed of Dutchmen, and other ≈øtrangers, are the≈øe: The Curld Coleworte eyther wholly of a greene colour, or of diuers colours in one plant, as white, yellow, red, purple or crim≈øon, ≈øo variably mixed, the leaues being curld on the edges, like a ruffe band, that it is very beautifull to behold.
There is al≈øo another curld Colewort of le≈ø≈øe beauty and re≈øpect, being but a little curld on the edges, who≈øe leaues are white, edged with red, or green edged with white.
Two other there are, the one of a popingaye greene colour: the other of a fine deepe greene, like vnto the Sauoyes.

Then there is the Cole rape, which is al≈øo a kinde of Coleworte, that beareth a white heade, or headed ≈øtalke aboue the ground, as bigge as a rea≈øonable Turnep, but longer, and from the toppe thereof ≈øpringeth out diuers great leaues, like vnto Colewortes; among which ri≈øe diuers ≈øtalkes that beare yellow flowers, and ≈øeede in pods, almo≈øt as ≈ømall as Mu≈øtard ≈øeede: the roote is ≈øomewhat long, and very bu≈øhie with threds.

div.head: The V≈øe of Cabbages and Colewortes.
div.p: They are mo≈øt v≈øually boyled in poudered beefe broth vntil they be tender, and then eaten with much fat put among them.
The great ribs of the Popingay, and deepe greene Colewortes, beeing boyled and layde into di≈øhes, are ≈øerued to the table with oyle and vinegar in the Lent time for very good ≈øallets.

In the cold Countries of Ru≈ø≈øia and Mu≈øcouia, they pouder vp a number of Cabbages, which ≈øerue them, e≈øpecially the poorer ≈øort, for their mo≈øt ordinary foode in winter; and although they ≈øtinke mo≈øt grieuou≈øly, yet to them they are accounted good meate.

figure.head: 1 Bra≈øsica capitata. Clo≈øe Cabbage. 2 Bra≈øsica patula. Open Cabbage. 3 Bra≈øsica Sabaudica cri≈ø ‚Ä¢ a. Curld Sauoye Colewort. 4 Caulis florida. Cole flower. 5 Caulis cri≈øpa. Curld Colewort. 6 Caulis cri≈øpa variata. Changeable curld Colewort. 7 Rapocaulis. Cole rape.

div.head: Si≈øarum. Skirrets.
div.p: AFter all the herbes before rehear≈øed, fit for ≈øallets, or otherwi≈øe to bee eaten, there mu≈øt follow ≈øuch rootes as are v≈øed to the ≈øame purpo≈øe: and fir≈øt, Skirrets haue many leaues next the ground, compo≈øed of many ≈ømall ≈ømooth green leaues, ≈øet each again≈øt other vpon a middle ribbe, and euery one ≈ønipt about the edges: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp two or three foote high, ≈øet with the like leaues, hauing at the toppe ≈øpoakie tufts of white flowers, which turne into ≈ømall ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat bigger and darker then Par≈øley ≈øeede: the rootes be many growing together at one head, beeing long, ≈ølender, & rugged or vneuen, of a whiti≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and more white within, hauing in the middle of the roote a long ≈ømall hard pith or ≈øtring: the≈øe heads are v≈øually taken vp in February and March, or ≈øooner if any ≈øo plea≈øe, the greater number of them being broken off to bee v≈øed, the re≈øt are planted againe after the heads are ≈øeparated, and hereby they are encrea≈øed euery yeare by many; but it is now adayes more ≈øowen of the ≈øeed, which come forwards well enough if the ground be fat and good.

div.head: The V≈øe of Skirrets.
div.p: The rootes being boyled, peeled and pithed, are ≈øtewed with butter, pepper and ≈øalt, and ≈øo eaten; or as others v≈øe them, to roule them in flower, and fry them with butter, after they haue beene boyled, peeled and pithed: each way, or any way that men plea≈øe to v≈øe them, they may finde their ta≈øte to be very plea≈øant, far beyond any Par≈ønep, as all agree that ta≈øte them.

Some doe v≈øe al≈øo to eate them as a ≈øallet, colde with vinegar, oyle, &c. being fir≈øt boyled and dre≈ø≈øed as before ≈øaid. They doe helpe to prouoke vrine, and as is thought, to procure bodily lu≈øt, in that they are a little windy.

div.head: Pastinaca ≈øatiua latifolia. Par≈øneps.
div.p: THe common garden Par≈ønep hath diuers large winged leaues lying vpon the ground, that is, many leaues ≈øet one by another on both ≈øides of a middle ≈øtalk, ≈øomewhat like as the Skirret hath, but much larger, and clo≈øer ≈øet: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp great and tall, fiue or ≈øix foot high ≈øomtimes, with many ≈øuch leaues thereon at ≈øeuerall ioynts; the top whereof is ≈øpread into diuers branches, whereon ≈øtand ≈øpoakie rundles of yellow flowers, which turne into browni≈øh flat ≈øeede: the root is long, great and white, very plea≈øant to bee eaten, and the more plea≈øant if it grow in a fat ≈øandy ≈øoyle.

figure.head: 1 Si≈øarum. Skirrits. 2 Pa≈øtinaca latifolia. Par≈øneps. 3 Pa≈øtinaca tenuifolia. Carrets. 4 Rapu ‚Ä¢ . Turneps. 5 Napus ≈øaetivus. Narewes. 6 Raphanus niger. Blacke Raddi≈øh. 7 Raphanus vulgaris. Common. Raddi≈øh.

div.p: Moreouer the wilde kinde, which groweth in many places of England (and wherof in ≈øome places there might be gathered a quarter ≈øacke full of the ≈øeede) if it be ≈øowen in Gardens, and there well ordered, will proue as good as the former kinde of Garden Par≈øneps.

div.head: The V≈øe of Par≈øneps.
div.p: The Par≈ønep root is a great nouri≈øher, and is much more v≈øed in the time of Lent, being boyled and ≈øtewed with butter, then in any othertime of the yeare; yet it is very good all the winter long. The ≈øeede helpeth to di≈ø≈øolue winde, and to prouoke vrine.

div.head: Pastina ≈øatiua tenuifolia. Carrots.
div.p: THe Carrot hath many winged leaues, ri≈øing from the head of the roote, which are much cut and diuided into many other leaues, and they al≈øo cut and diuided into many parts, of a deepe greene colour, ≈øome whereof in Autumne will turne to be of a fine red or purple (the beautie whereof allureth many Gentlewomen oftentimes to gather the leaues, and ≈øticke them in their hats or heads, or pin them on their armes in ≈øtead of feathers): the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp among the leaues, bearing many likewi≈øe vpon it, but nothing ≈øo high as the Par≈ønep, being about three foote high, bearing many ≈øpoakie tufts of white flowers, which turne into ≈ømall rough ≈øeede, as if it were hairy, ≈ømelling rea≈øonable well if it bee rubbed: the roote is round and long, thicke aboue and ≈ømall below, eyther red or yellow, eyther ≈øhorter or longer, according to his kinde; for there is one kinde, who≈øe roote is wholly red quite thoroughout; another who≈øe roote is red without for a pretty way inward, but the middle is yellow.

Then there is the yellow, which is of two ≈øorts, both long and ≈øhort: One of the long yellow ≈øorts, which is of a pale yellow, hath the greate≈øt and longe≈øt roote, and likewi≈øe the greate≈øt head of greene, and is for the mo≈øt part the wor≈øt, being ≈øpongy, and not firme.
The other is of a deepe gold yellow colour, and is the be≈øt, hauing a ≈ømaller head, or tuft of greene leaues vpon it.
The ≈øhorte rootes are likewi≈øe di≈øtingui≈øhed, into pale and deepe yellow colours.

div.head: The V≈øe of Carrots.
div.p: All the≈øe ≈øorts being boyled in the broth of beefe, eyther fre≈øh or ≈øalt, but more v≈øually of ≈øalted beefe, are eaten with great plea≈øure, becau≈øe of the ≈øweetene≈ø≈øe of them: but they nouri≈øh le≈ø≈øe then Par≈øneps or Skirrets.
I haue not often knowne the ≈øeede of this Garden kinde to bee v≈øed in Phy≈øicke: but the wilde kinde is often and much v≈øed to expell winde, &c.

div.head: Rapum horten≈øe. Turneps.
div.p: THere are diuers ≈øorts of Turneps, as white, yellow, and red: the white are the mo≈øt common, and they are of two kinds, the one much ≈øweeter then the other.
The yellow and the red are more rare, and nour≈øed vp only by tho≈øe that are curious: as al≈øo the Navewe, which is ≈øeene but with very few.

The ordinary Garden Turnep hath many large, and long rough greene leaues, with deepe and vneuen ga≈øhes on both ≈øides of them: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp among the leaues about two foote high, ≈øpread at the toppe into many branches, bearing theron yellow flowers, which turne into long pods, with blacki≈øh round ≈øeede in them: the roote is round and white, ≈øome greater, ≈øome ≈ømaller; the be≈øt kinde is knowne to be flat, with a ≈ømall pigges tale-like roote vnderneath it; the wor≈øer kinde which is more common in many places of this land, both North and We≈øt, is round, and not flat, with a greater pigges tayle-like roote vnderneath.

The yellow kinde doth often grow very great, it is hardly di≈øcerned from the ordinary kinde while it groweth, but by the greatne≈ø≈øe and ≈øpreading of the leaues beeing boyled, the roote changeth more yellow, ≈øomewhat neare the colour of a Carrot.

The red Turnep groweth v≈øually greater then any of the other, e≈øpecially in a good ground, being of a faire red colour on the out≈øide, but being pared, as white as any other on the in≈øide. This, as Matthiolus ≈øaith, doth grow in the Countrey of Anania, where hee hath ≈øeene an infinite number of them that haue waighed fifty pound a peece, and in ≈øome places hee ≈øaith, a hundred pound a peece, both which we would thinke to be incredible, but that we ≈øee the kind is greatly giuen to grow, and in warme Countries they may ≈øo thriue, that the bulke or bigne≈ø≈øe of the roote may ≈øo farre pa≈ø≈øe the growth of our Countrey, as that it may ri≈øe to that quantity aboue ≈øpecified.

The Navew gentle is of two kindes, a ≈ømaller and a greater; the ≈ømaller is v≈øually called in France, Navean de Cane, the roote is ≈øomewhat long with the roundne≈ø≈øe; this kinde is twice as bigge as a mans thumbe, and many of them le≈ø≈øe: The other is long and great, almo≈øt as big as the ≈øhort Carrot, but for the mo≈øt part of an vneuen length, and roundne≈ø≈øe vnto the very end, where it ≈øpreadeth into diuers ≈ømall long fibres: neyther of them doth differ much from the Turnep, in leafe, flower or ≈øeed.

div.head: The V≈øe of Turneps.
div.p: Being boyled in ≈øalt broth, they all of them eate mo≈øt kindly, and by rea≈øon of their ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe are much e≈øteemed, and often ≈øeene as a di≈øh at good mens tables: but the greater quantitie of them are ≈øpent at poore mens fea≈øts. They nouri≈øh much, and engender moi≈øt and loo≈øe fle≈øh, and are very windy. The ≈øeede of the Navew gentle is (as I take it) called of Andromachus in the compo≈øition of his Treakle, Bunias dulcis: for Dio≈øcorides and Plinie doe both ≈øay, that the ≈øeede of the tame Bunias or Napus is put into Antidotes, and not the ≈øeede of the wilde, which is more ≈øharpe and bitter; neyther the ≈øeede of the Turnep, which is called in Greeke „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ in Latine Rapum, becau≈øe the ≈øeede is not ≈øweete.

div.head: Raphanus. Raddi≈øh.
div.p: THere are two principall kindes of Garden Raddi≈øh, the one is blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and the otherwhite; and of both the≈øe there is ≈øome diui≈øion againe, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed. Dittander and hor≈øe Raddi≈øh be reckoned kinds thereof.

The ordinary Raddi≈øh hath long leaues, vneuenly ga≈øhed on both ≈øides, the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp to the height of three or foure foote, bearing many purpli≈øh flowers at the top, made of foure leaues a peece, which turne into thicke and ≈øhort pods, wherein are contained round ≈øeede, greater then Turnep or Coleworte ≈øeede, and of a pale reddi≈øh colour: the roote is long, white, and of a reddi≈øh purple colour on the out≈øide toward the toppe of it, and of a ≈øharpe biting ta≈øte.
There is a ≈ømall kind of Raddi≈øh that commeth earlier then the former, that we haue had out of the low Countries, not differing in any thing el≈øe.

The blacke Raddi≈øh I haue had brought me out of the lowe Countries, where they ≈øell them in ≈øome places by the pound, and is accounted with them a rare winter ≈øallet:
the roote of the be≈øt kinde is blacki≈øh on the out≈øide (and yet the ≈øeede gathered from ≈øuch an one, hath after the ≈øowing againe, giuen rootes, whereof ≈øome haue beene blacke, but the mo≈øt part white on the out≈øide) and white within, great and round at the head, almo≈øt like a Turnep, but ending ≈øhorter then a Raddi≈øh, and longer then a Turnep, almo≈øt peare-fa≈øhion, of a firmer and harder ≈øub≈øtance then the ordinary Raddi≈øh, but no le≈ø≈øe ≈øharpe and biting, and ≈øomewhat ≈øtrong withall; the leaues are ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and with deeper ga≈øhes, the flower and ≈øeede are like the former, but ≈ømaller.

Another ≈øort of blacke Raddi≈øh is like in leafe and ≈øeede to the former, but the flower is of a lighter purple colour: the roote is longer and ≈ømaller, and changeth al≈øo to bee white as the former doth, ≈øo that I thinke they haue both ri≈øen from one kinde.

The Hor≈øe Raddi≈øh is a kinde of wilde Raddi≈øh, but brought into Gardens for the v≈øe of it, and hath great large and long greene leaues, which are not ≈øo much diuided, but dented about the edges: the roote is long and great, much ≈øtronger in ta≈øte then the former, and abideth diuers yeares, ≈øpreading with branches vnder ground.

Dittander is likewi≈øe a wilde kinde hereof, hauing long pointed blewi≈øh greene leaues, and a roote that creepeth much vnder ground: I confe≈ø≈øe this might haue bin placed among the herbes, becau≈øe the leaues and not the rootes are v≈øed; but let it pa≈ø≈øe now with the kindes of Raddi≈øh.

div.head: The V≈øe of the≈øe Raddi≈øhes.
div.p: Raddi≈øhes doe ≈øerue v≈øually as a ≈øtimulum before meat, giuing an appetite thereunto; the poore eate them alone with bread and ≈øalt. Some that are early ≈øowen, are eaten in Aprill, or ≈øooner if the ≈øea≈øon permit; others come later; and ≈øome are ≈øowen late to ≈øerue for the end of Summer: but (as of all things el≈øe) the earlier are the more accepted.

The blacke Raddi≈øhes are mo≈øt v≈øed in the winter, (yet ≈øome in their naturall and not forc'd grounds, haue their rootes good mo≈øt part of the Summer) and therefore mu≈øt bee ≈øowen after Mid≈øomer; for if they ≈øhould bee ≈øowen earlier, they would pre≈øently runne vp to ≈øtalke and ≈øeed, and ≈øo lo≈øe the benefit of the roote. The Phy≈øicall propertie is, it is often v≈øed in medicines that helpe to breake the ≈øtone, and to auoyde grauell.
The Hor≈øe Raddi≈øh is v≈øed Phy≈øically, very much in Melancholicke, Spleneticke and Scorbuticke di≈øea≈øes. And ≈øome v≈øe to make a kinde of Mu≈øtard with the rootes, and eate it with fi≈øh.
Dittander or Pepperworte is v≈øed of ≈øome cold churli≈øh ≈øtomackes, as a ≈øawce or ≈øallet ≈øometimes to their meate, but it is too hot, bitter and ≈øtrong for weake and tender ≈øtomackes.

Our Gardiners about London v≈øe great fences of reede tyed together, which ≈øeemeth to bee a mat ≈øet vpright, and is as good as a wall to defend the cold from tho≈øe things that would be defended, and to bring them forwards the earlier.

div.head: Cepa. Onions.
div.p: WEe haue diuers ≈øorts of Onions, both white and red, flat, round and long, as ≈øhall be pre≈øently ≈øhewed: but I will doe with the≈øe as I doe with the re≈øt, only giue you one de≈øcription for them all, and afterwards their ≈øeuerall names and varieties, as they are to be known by.

figure.head: 1 Raphanus ru ‚Ä¢ acanus. Hor≈øe Raddi≈øh. 2 Lepidium ≈øiue Piperitis. Dittander. 3 Cepae rotun ‚Ä¢ ae Round Onions. 4 Cepae longae. Long Onions. 5 Porrum. Leekes 6 Allium. Garlicke. 7 Rapun ‚Ä¢ ulus. Rampions. 8 Tragopogon. Goates b ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ d.

div.p: The red flat kinde is mo≈øt v≈øually with vs the ≈øtronge≈øt of them all, yet I haue had a great red Onion brought mee from beyond Sea, that was as great almo≈øt as two mens fi≈øtes, flat and red quite thoroughout, and very plea≈øant both to ≈ømell vnto, and to eate, but did quickly degenerate; ≈øo that we plainly ≈øee, that the ≈øoyle and climate doth giue great alteration to plants of all ≈øorts.
The long kinde wee call St. Omers Onions, and corruptly among the vulgar, St. Thomas Onions.
The other red kinde we call Strasborough Onions, who≈øe out≈øide onely is red, and are very ≈øharpe and fierce.
The white Onions both long and flat, are like vnto Chalke-≈øtones lying vpon the ground, when they are ripe and fit to be gathered.

And la≈øtly, there is the Spani≈øh Onion, both long and flat, very ≈øweete, and eaten by many like an apple, but as Iohn Trade≈øcante ≈øaith, who hath beene in Spaine, that the Spaniards them≈øelues doe not eate them ≈øo familiarly, as they doe tho≈øe white Onions that come out of our owne Countrey, which they haue there more plentifully then their ≈øweete Onions.

div.head: The V≈øe of Onions.
div.p: Onions are v≈øed many wayes, as ≈øliced and put into pottage, or boyled and peeled and layde in di≈øhes for ≈øallets at ≈øupper, or ≈øliced and put into water, for a ≈øawce for mutton or oy≈øters, or into meate roa≈øted being ≈øtuffed with Par≈øly, and ≈øo many waies that I cannot recount them, euery one plea≈øing them≈øelues, according to their order, manner or delight.

The iuice of Onions is much v≈øed to be applyed to any burnings with fire, or with Gun-pouder, or to any ≈øcaldings with water or oyle, and is mo≈øt familiar for the Country, where vpon ≈øuch ≈øudden occa≈øions they haue not a more fit or ≈øpeedy remedie at hand: The ≈øtrong ≈ømell of Onions, and ≈øo al≈øo of Garlicke and Leekes, is quite taken away from offending the head or eyes, by the eating of Par≈øley leaues after them.

div.head: Porrum. Leekes.
div.p: THere be likewi≈øe ≈øundry ≈øorts of Leekes, both great and ≈ømall. Leekes are very like vnto Onions, hauing long green hollow-like leaues, flatti≈øh on the one ≈øide, and with a ridge or cre≈øt on the backe ≈øide: if they bee ≈øuffered to grow vncut, then in the ≈øecond or third yeare after the ≈øowing, they will ≈øend forth a round and ≈ølender ≈øtalke, euen quite thoroughout, and not ≈øwollen or bigger in the middle like the Onion, bearing at the toppe a head of purpli≈øh flowers, and blacke ≈øeede after them, very like vnto Onion ≈øeede, that it is hard to di≈øtingui≈øh them: the root is long and white, with a great bu≈øh of fibres hanging at it, which they call the beards.
The vn≈øet Leeke hath longer and ≈ølenderer roots then the other, which being tran≈øplanted, groweth thicker and greater.
The French Leeke, which is called the Vine Leeke, is the be≈øt of all others.
Our common kinde is of two ≈øorts, one greater then another.
Another ≈øort encrea≈øeth altogether by the roote, as Garlicke doth.
And then Ciues, which are the ≈ømalle≈øt, and encrea≈øe aboundantly only by the root.

Some doe account Scalions to be rather a kinde of Onions then Leekes, and call them Cepa A≈øcalonica, or A≈øcalonitides, which will quickly ≈øpend it ≈øelfe, if it be ≈øuffered to be vncut; but all Authors affirme, that there is no wilde kinde of Onion, vnle≈ø≈øe they would haue it to be Gethyum, whereof Theophra≈øtus maketh mention, ≈øaying, that it hath a long necke (and ≈øo the≈øe Scalions haue) and was al≈øo of ≈øome called Gethyllides, which antiquity accounted to be dedicated to Latona, the mother of Apollo, becau≈øe when ≈øhe was bigge with childe of Apollo, ≈øhe longed for the≈øe Leekes.

div.head: The V≈øe of Leekes.
div.p: The old World, as wee finde in Scripture, in the time of the children of I≈øraels being in Egypt, and no doubt long before, fed much vpon Leekes, Onions, and Garlicke boyled with fle≈øh; and the antiquity of the Gentiles relate the ≈øame manner of feeding on them, to be in all Countries the like, which how≈øoeuer our dainty age now refu≈øeth wholly, in all ≈øorts except the poore≈øt; yet Mu≈øcouia and Ru≈ø≈øia v≈øe them, and the Turkes to this day, (as Bellonius writeth) ob≈øerue to haue them among their di≈øhes at their tables, yea although they be Ba≈øhas, Cades, or Vaiuodas, that is to ≈øay, Lords, Iudges, or Gouernours of countries and places. They are v≈øed with vs al≈øo ≈øometimes in Lent to make pottage, and is a great and generall feeding in Wales with the vulgar Gentlemen.

Onions boyled or ro≈øted vnder the embers, and mixed with ≈øugar and butter, are good for tho≈øe that are troubled with coughes, ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of breath, and whee≈øing. An Onion made hollow at the bottome, and ≈øome good Treakle put into it, with a little iuyce of Citrons (or Lemons in the ≈øtead thereof) being well baked together vnder the embers, after the hole is ≈øtopped againe, and then ≈øtrained forth, and giuen to one that hath the plague, is very helpefull, ≈øo as hee be laid to ≈øweate vpon it.
Ciues are v≈øed as well to be ≈øhred among other herbes for the pot, as to be put into a Sallet among other herbs, to giue it a quicker relli≈øh.

Leekes are held to free the che≈øt and lungs from much corruption and rotten flegme, that ≈øticketh fa≈øt therein, and hard to be auoided, as al≈øo for them that through hoar≈øene≈ø≈øe haue lo≈øt their voice, if they be eyther taken rawe, or boyled with broth of barley, or ≈øome ≈øuch other ≈øupping, fit and conducing thereunto. And baked vnder hot embers is a remedy again≈øt a ≈øurfeit of Mu≈øhromes.
The greene blades of Leekes being boyled and applyed warme to the Hemorrhoides or piles, when they are ≈øwolne and painfull, giue a great deale of ca≈øe.

div.head: Allium. Garlicke.
div.p: I Haue ≈øpoken of diuers ≈øorts of Garlicke called Moly, in the former booke: I ≈øhall neede in this place to ≈øhew onely tho≈øe kindes, that this Garden nour≈øeth vp, and leaue the re≈øt to his fit time and place.

Garlicke hath many long greene leaues, like vnto Onions, but much larger, and not hollow at all as Onions are: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth vp to be about three foote high, bearing ≈øuch a head at the toppe thereof as Onions and Leekes doe, with purpli≈øh flowers, and blacke ≈øeede like Leekes: the roote is white within, couered ouer with many purpli≈øh
skins, and is diuided into many parts or cloues, which ≈øerue both to ≈øet againe for increa≈øe, and al≈øo to v≈øe as neede ≈øhall require, and is of a very ≈øtrong ≈ømell and ta≈øte, as euery one knoweth, pa≈ø≈øing either Onions or Leekes, but exceeding whol≈øome withall for them that can take it.

div.head: Allium Vr≈øinum. Ram≈øons.
div.p: Ram≈øons are another kinde of Garlicke, and hath two or three faire broad leaues, of a fre≈øh or light greene colour, pointed at the end: the ≈øtalke groweth about an hand length high, bearing many ≈ømall and pure white ≈øtarre-like flowers at the toppe, and afterwards ≈ømall, blacke, and ≈ømooth round ≈øeede: the roote is al≈øo diuided into many parts, whereby it is much encrea≈øed, and is much milder then the former, both in ≈ømell and ta≈øte.

div.head: The V≈øe of Garlicke.
div.p: It being well boyled in ≈øalt broth, is often eaten of them that haue ≈øtrong ≈øtomackes, but will not brooke in a weake and tender ≈øtomacke.

It is accounted, and ≈øo called in diuers Countries, The poore mans Treakle, that is, a remedy for all di≈øea≈øes. It is neuer eaten rawe of any man that I know, as other of the rootes afore≈øaid, but ≈øodden alwaies and ≈øo taken.
Ram≈øons are oftentimes eaten with bread and butter, and otherwi≈øe al≈øo, as euery mans affection and cour≈øe of life leadeth him to v≈øe.

div.head: Rapunculus ≈øiue Rapuntium. Rampions.
div.p: GArden Rampions are of two ≈øorts, the one greater, the other le≈ø≈øer: the leaues of Rampions are in the one ≈øomewhat broad like a Beete, in the other ≈øomewhat long and narrow, and a little broader at the end, of a light greene colour, lying flat vpon the ground all the fir≈øt winter, or yeare of the ≈øpringing, and the next Spring ≈øhooteth forth ≈øtalkes two or three foote high, bearing at the toppe, in the bigger ≈øort, a long ≈ølender ≈øpike of ≈ømall horned or crooked flowers, which open their brimmes into foure leaues; in the le≈ø≈øer many ≈ømall purpli≈øh bels, ≈øtanding vpon ≈øeuerall ≈ømall foote-≈øtalkes, which turne into heads, bearing ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeede: the root is white, branched into two or three rootes, of the bigne≈ø≈øe and length of a mans finger or thumbe.

div.head: The V≈øe of Rampions.
div.p: The rootes of both are v≈øed for Sallets, being boyled, and then eaten with oyle and vinegar, a little ≈øalt and pepper.

div.head: Tragopogon. Goates beard.
div.p:
GOates beard hath many long and narrow leaues, broader at the bottome, and ≈øharper at the end, with a ridge downe the backe of the leafe, and of a pale greene colour; among which ri≈øeth vp a ≈øtalke of two or three foote high, ≈ømooth and hollow, bearing thereon many ≈øuch like leaues, but ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter, and at the toppe thereof on euery branch a great double yellow flower, like almo≈øt vnto the flower of a Dandelion, which turneth into a head, ≈øtored with doune, and long whiti≈øh ≈øeede therein, hauing on the head of euery one ≈øome part of the doune,
and is carried away with the winde if it bee neglected: the roote is long and round, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Par≈ønep, but farre ≈ømaller, blacki≈øh on the out≈øide, and white within, yeelding a milkie iuyce being broken, as all the re≈øt of the plant doth, and of a very good and plea≈øant ta≈øte. This kinde, as al≈øo another with narrower leaues, almo≈øt like gra≈ø≈øe, growe wilde abroad in many places, but are brought into diuers Gardens. The other two kindes formerly de≈øcribed in the fir≈øt part, the one with a purple flower, and the otherwith an a≈øh-coloured, haue ≈øuch rootes as the≈øe here de≈øcribed, and may ≈øerue al≈øo to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, being of equall goodne≈ø≈øe, if any will v≈øe them in the ≈øame manner; that is, while they are young, and of the fir≈øt yeares ≈øowing, el≈øe they all growe hard, in running vp to ≈øeede.

div.head: The V≈øe of Goates beard.
div.p: If the rootes of any of the≈øe kindes being young, be boyled and dre≈ø≈øed as a Par≈ønep, they make a plea≈øant di≈øh of meate, farre pa≈ø≈øing the Par≈ønep in many mens iudgements, and that with yellow flowers to be the be≈øt.
They are of excellent v≈øe being in this manner prepared, or after any other fit and conuenient way, to ≈øtrengthen tho≈øe that are macilent, or growing into any con≈øumption.

div.head: Carum. Carawayes.
div.p: CArawayes hath many very fine cut and diuided leaues lying on the ground, being alwaies greene, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the leaues of Carrots, but thinner, and more finely cut, of a quicke, hot, and ≈øpicie ta≈øte: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth not much higher then the Carrot ≈øtalke, bearing ≈øome leaues at the ioynts along the ≈øtalke to the toppe, where it brancheth into three or foure parts, bearing ≈øpoakie vmbels of white flowers, which turne into ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeede, ≈ømaller then Ani≈øeede, and of a hotter and quicker ta≈øte: the roote is whiti≈øh, like vnto a Par≈ønep, but much ≈ømaller, more ≈øpreading vnder ground, and a little quicke in ta≈øte, as all the re≈øt of the plant is, and abideth long after it hath giuen ≈øeede.

div.head: The V≈øe of Carawayes.
div.p: The rootes of Carawayes being boyled may be eaten as Carrots, and by rea≈øon of the ≈øpicie ta≈øte doth warme and comfort a cold weake ≈øtomacke, helping to di≈ø≈øolue winde (whereas Carrots engender it) and to prouoke vrine, and is a very welcome and delightfull di≈øh to a great many, yet they are ≈øomewhat ≈øtronger in ta≈øte then Par≈øneps.
The ≈øeede is much v≈øed to bee put among baked fruit, or into bread, cakes, &c. to giue them a relli≈øh, and to helpe to dige≈øt winde in them are ≈øubiect thereunto.
