It is al≈øo made into Comfits, and put into Trageas, or as we call them in Engli≈øh, Dredges, that are taken for the cold and winde in the body, as al≈øo are ≈øerued to the table with fruit.

div.head: Pappas ≈øine Battatas. Potatoes.
div.p: THree ≈øorts of Potatoes are well knowne vnto vs, but the fourth I re≈øt doubtfull of, and dare not affirme it vpon ≈øuch termes as are giuen vnto it, vntill I may be better informed by mine owne ≈øight.

The Spani≈øh kinde hath (in the I≈ølands where they growe, either naturally, or planted for increa≈øe, profit, and v≈øe of the Spaniards that nour≈øe them) many firme and verie ≈øweete rootes, like in ≈øhape and forme vnto A≈øphodill rootes, but much greater and longer, of a pale browne on the out≈øide, and white within, ≈øet together at one head; from whence ri≈øe vp many long branches, which by rea≈øon of their weight and weakne≈ø≈øe, cannot ≈øtand of them≈øelues, but traile on the ground a yard and a halfe in length at the lea≈øt (I relate it, as it hath growne with vs, but in what other forme, for flower or fruit, we know not) whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances, broad and in a manner three ≈øquare leaues, ≈øomewhat like triangled Iuie leaues, of a darke greene colour, the two ≈øides whereof are broad and round, and the middle pointed at the end, ≈øtanding rea≈øonable clo≈øe together: thus much we haue ≈øeene growe with vs, and no more: the roote rather decaying then increa≈øing in our country.

The Potatoes of Virginia, which ≈øome fooli≈øhly call the Apples of youth, is another kinde of plant, differing much from the former, ≈øauing in the colour and ta≈øte of the roote, hauing many weake and ≈øomewhat flexible branches, leaning a little downwards, or ea≈øily borne downe with the winde or other thing, be≈øet with many winged leaues, of a darke grayi≈øh greene colour, whereof diuers are ≈ømaller, and ≈øome greater then others: the flowers growe many together vpon a long ≈øtalke, comming forth from betweene the leaues and the great ≈øtalkes, euery one ≈øeuerally vpon a ≈øhort foot≈øtalke, ≈øomewhat like the flower of Tabacco for the forme, being one whole leafe ≈øix cornered at the brimmes, but ≈øomewhat larger, and of a pale blewi≈øh purple colour, or pale doue colour, and in ≈øome almo≈øt white, with ≈øome red threads in the middle, ≈øtanding about a thicke gold yellow pointell, tipped with greene at the end: after the flowers are pa≈øt, there come vp in their places ≈ømall round fruit, as bigge as a Dam≈øon or Bulleis, greene at the fir≈øt, and ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh afterwards, with many white ≈øeedes therein, like vnto Night≈øhade: the rootes are rounder and much ≈ømaller then the former, and ≈øome much greater then others, di≈øper≈øed vnder ground by many ≈ømall threads or ≈øtrings from the rootes, of the ≈øame light browne colour on the out≈øide, and white within, as they, and neare of the ≈øame ta≈øte, but not altogether ≈øo plea≈øant.

figure.head: 1 Carum. Carawayes. 2 Battatas Hi≈øoanorum. Spani≈øh Potatoes. 3 Papas ≈øeu Battatas Virginianorum. Virginia Potatoes. 4 Battatas de Canada. Potatoes of Canada, or Artichokes of Ieru≈øalem.

div.head: The V≈øe of all the≈øe Potato's.
div.p: The Spani≈øh Potato's are roa≈øted vnder the embers, and being pared or peeled and ≈øliced, are put into ≈øacke with a little ≈øugar, or without, and is delicate to be eaten.
They are v≈øed to be baked with Marrow, Sugar, Spice, and other things in Pyes, which are a daintie and co≈øtly di≈øh for the table.
The Comfit-makers pre≈øerue them, and candy them as diuers other things, and ≈øo ordered, is very delicate, fit to accompany ≈øuch other banquetting di≈øhes.
The Virginia Potato's being dre≈ø≈øed after all the≈øe waies before ≈øpecified, maketh almo≈øt as delicate meate as the former.

The Potato's of Canada are by rea≈øon of their great increa≈øing, growne to be ≈øo common here with vs at London, that euen the mo≈øt vulgar begin to de≈øpi≈øe them, whereas when they were fir≈øt receiued among vs, they were dainties for a Queene.

Being put into ≈øeething water they are ≈øoone boyled tender, which after they bee peeled, ≈øliced and ≈øtewed with butter, and a little wine, was a di≈øh for a Queene, beeing as plea≈øant as the bottome of an Artichoke: but the too frequent v≈øe, e≈øpecially being ≈øo plentifull and cheape, hath rather bred a loathing then a liking of them.

div.head: Cinara. Artichokes.
div.p: THe fruits that grow vpon or neere the ground, are next to be entreated of, and fir≈øt of Artichokes, whereof there be diuers kindes, ≈øome accounted tame and of the Garden, others wilde and of late planted in Gardens, Orchards or Fieldes, of purpo≈øe to be meate for men.

figure.head:
1 Cinara≈øatiua rubra. The red Artichoke. 2 Cinara ≈øatiua alba. The wh ‚Ä¢ te Artichoke. 3 Cinara patala. The French Artichoke. 4 Ci
‚Ä¢ ara
‚Ä¢ lue≈øtis. The Thi≈øtle Artichoke. 5 Carduus e≈øculentas. The Chardon.

div.p: The white Artichoke is in all things like the red, but that the head is of a whiti≈øh a≈øhe colour, like the leaues, whereas the former is reddi≈øh.
We haue al≈øo another, who≈øe head is greene, and very ≈øharpe vpwards, and is common in many places.
Wee haue had al≈øo another kinde in former times that grew as high as any man, and branched into diuers ≈øtalkes, euery one bearing a head thereon, almo≈øt as bigge as the fir≈øt.
There is another kinde, called the Muske Artichoke, which groweth like the French kinde, but is much better in ≈øpending, although it haue a le≈ø≈øer bottome.

The French Artichoke hath a white head, the ≈øcales whereof ≈øtand ≈øtaring far a≈øunder one from another at the ends, which are ≈øharpe: this is well known by this qualitie, that while it is hot after it is boyled, it ≈øwelleth ≈øo ≈øtrong, that one would verily thinke it had bin boyled in ≈øtinking water, which was brought ouer after a great fro≈øte that had well nigh con≈øumed our be≈øt kindes, and are now almo≈øt cleane ca≈øt out again, none being willing to haue it take vp the roome of better.

There is a lowe kinde that groweth much about Paris, which the French e≈øteeme more then any other, and is lower then the former French kinde, the head whereof as well as the leaues, is of a fre≈øher greene colour, almo≈øt yellowi≈øh.
Then there is the Thi≈øtle Artichoke, which is almo≈øt a wilde kinde, and groweth ≈ømaller, with a more open and prickly head then any of the former.

And la≈øtly, the Chardon as they call it, becau≈øe it is almo≈øt of the forme and nature of a Thi≈øtle, or wilde Artichoke. This groweth high, and full of ≈øharpe prickles, of a grayi≈øh colour. Iohn Trade≈øcante a≈ø≈øured mee, hee ≈øaw three acres of Land about Bru≈ø≈øels planted with this kinde, which the owner whited like Endiue, and then ≈øold them in the winter: Wee cannot yet finde the true manner of dre≈ø≈øing them, that our Countrey may take delight therein.

All the≈øe kindes are encrea≈øed by ≈ølipping the young ≈øhootes from the root, which being replanted in February, March, or Aprill, haue the ≈øame yeare many times, but the next at the mo≈øt, borne good heads.

Wee finde by dayly experience, that our Engli≈øh red Artichoke is in our Countrey the mo≈øt delicate meate of any of the other, and therefore diuers thinking it to bee a ≈øeuerall kinde, haue ≈øent them into Italie, France, and the Lowe Countries, where they haue not abode in their goodne≈ø≈øe aboue two yeare, but that they haue degenerated; ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth, that our ≈øoyle and climate hath the preheminence to nouri≈øh vp this plant to his highe≈øt excellencie.

div.head: The V≈øe of Artichokes.
div.p: The manner of preparing them for the Table is well knowne to the younge≈øt Hou≈øewife I thinke, to bee boyled in faire water, and a little ≈øalt, vntill they bee tender, and afterwardes a little vinegar and pepper, put to the butter, poured vpon them for the ≈øawce, and ≈øo are ≈øerued to the Table.
They v≈øe likewi≈øe to take the boyled bottomes to make Pyes, which is a delicate kinde of baked meate.
The Chardon is eaten rawe of diuers, with vinegar and oyle, pepper and ≈øalt, all of them, or ≈øome, as euery one liketh for their delight.

div.head: Fabae & Pha≈øeoli. Garden and French Beanes.
div.p: THe Garden Beane is of two colours, red or blacke, and white, yet both ri≈øe from one; the ≈ømall or fielde Beanes I make no mention of in this place; but the French or Kidney Beane is almo≈øt of infinite ≈øorts and colours: we doe not for all that intend to trouble you in this place, with the knowledge or relation of any more then is fit for a Garden of that nature, that I haue propounded it in the beginning.

Our ordinary Beanes, ≈øeruing for foode for the poorer ≈øort for the mo≈øt part, are planted as well in fieldes as in gardens, becau≈øe the quantity of them that are ≈øpent taketh vp many acres of land to be planted in, and ri≈øe vp with one, two or three ≈øtalks, according to the fertilitie of the ≈øoyle, being ≈ømooth and ≈øquare, higher then any man oftentimes, whereon are ≈øet at certaine di≈øtances, from the very bottome almo≈øt to the toppe, two long ≈ømooth fle≈øhy and thicke leaues almo≈øt round, one ≈øtanding by another at the end of a ≈ømall foote≈øtalke: betweene the≈øe leaues and the ≈øtalke, come forth diuers flowers, all of them looking one way for the mo≈øt part, which are clo≈øe a little turned vp at the brimmes, white and ≈øpotted with a blacki≈øh ≈øpot in the middle of them, and ≈øomwhat purpli≈øh at the foot or bottome, of the forme almo≈øt of Broome or Pea≈øe flowers, many of which that grow vpward toward the toppe, doe ≈øeldome beare fruit, and therefore are gathered to di≈øtill, and the toppes of the ≈øtalkes cut off, to cau≈øe the re≈øt to thriue the better; after which grow vp long great ≈ømooth greene pods, greater then in any other kinde of Pul≈øe, which grow blacke when they are ripe, and containe within them two, three or foure Beanes, which are ≈øomewhat flat and round, eyther white or reddi≈øh, which being full ripe grow blacki≈øh: the roote hath diuers fibres annexed vnto the maine roote, which dyeth euery yeare.

The French or Kidney Beane ri≈øeth vp at the fir≈øt but with one ≈øtalke, which afterwards diuideth it ≈øelfe into many armes or branches, euery one of them being ≈øo weak, that without they be ≈øu≈øtained with ≈øtickes or poles, whereon with their winding and cla≈øpers they take hold, they would lye fruitle≈ø≈øe vpon the ground: vpon the≈øe branches grow forth at ≈øeuerall places long foote≈øtalkes, with euery of them three broade, round and pointed greene leaues at the end of them, towards the tops whereof come forth diuers flowers, made like vnto Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øomes, of the ≈øame colour for the mo≈øt part that the fruit will be of, that is to ≈øay, eyther white, or yellow, or red, or blacki≈øh, or of a deepe purple &c. but white is mo≈øt v≈øuall for our Garden; after which come long and ≈ølender flat pods, ≈øome crooked, and ≈øome ≈øtraight, with a ≈øtring as it were running downe the backe thereof, wherein are contained flatti≈øh round fruit, made to the fa≈øhion of a kidney: the roote is long, and ≈øpreadeth with many fibres annexed vnto it, peri≈øhing euery yeare.

div.head: The V≈øe of the≈øe Beanes.
div.p: The Garden Beanes ≈øerue (as I ≈øaid before) more for the v≈øe of the poore then of the rich: I ≈øhall therefore only ≈øhew you the order the poore take with them, and leaue curio≈øity to them that will be≈øtow time vpon them. They are only boyled in faire water and a little ≈øalt, and afterwards ≈øtewed with ≈øome butter, a little vinegar and pepper being put vnto them, and ≈øo eaten: or el≈øe eaten alone after they are boyled without any other ≈øawce. The water of the blo≈ø≈øomes di≈øtilled, is v≈øed to take away ≈øpots, and to cleer the skin. The water of the greene huskes or cods is good for the ≈øtone.

The Kidney Beanes boyled in water huske and all, onely the ends cut off, and the ≈øtring taken away, and ≈øtewed with butter &c. are e≈øteemed more ≈øauory meate to many mens pallates, then the former, and are a di≈øh more oftentimes at rich mens Tables then at the poore.

div.head: Pi≈øum. Pea≈øe.
div.p: THere is a very great variety of manured Pea≈øe known to vs, and I think more in our Country then in others, whereof ≈øome pro≈øper better in one ground and country, and ≈øome in others: I ≈øhall giue you the de≈øcription of one alone for all the re≈øt, and recite vnto you the names of the re≈øt.

Garden Pea≈øe are for the mo≈øt part the greate≈øt and ≈øweete≈øt kinds, and are ≈øu≈øtained with ≈øtakes or bu≈øhes. The Field Pea≈øe are not ≈øo v≈øed, but growe without any ≈øuch adoe. They ≈øpring vp with long, weake, hollow, and brittle (while they are young and greene) whiti≈øh greene ≈øtalkes, branched into diuers parts, and at euery ioynt where it parteth one broad round leafe compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalke about, ≈øo that it commeth as it were thorough it: the leaues are winged, made of diuers ≈ømall leaues ≈øet to a middle ribbe, of a whiti≈øh greene colour, with cla≈øpers at the ends of the leaues, whereby it taketh hold of what≈øoeuer ≈øtandeth next vnto it: betweene the leaues and the ≈øtalkes come forth the flowers, ≈øtanding two or three together, euery one by it ≈øelfe on his owne ≈øeuerall ≈øtalke, which are either wholly white, or purple, or mixed white and purple, or purple and blew: the fruit are long, and ≈øomewhat round cods, whereof ≈øome are greater, others le≈ø≈øer, ≈øome thicke and ≈øhort, ≈øome plaine and ≈ømooth, others a little crooked at the ends; wherein al≈øo are contained diuers formes of fruit or pea≈øe; ≈øome being round, others cornered, ≈øome ≈ømall, ≈øome great, ≈øome white, others gray, and ≈øome ≈øpotted: the roote is ≈ømall, and quickly peri≈øheth.

The kindes of Pea≈øe are the≈øe:
The Rounciuall.
The greene Ha≈øting.
The Sugar Pea≈øe.
The ≈øpotted Pea≈øe.
The gray Pea≈øe.
The white Ha≈øting.
The Pea≈øe without skins.
The Scotti≈øh or tufted Pea≈øe, which ≈øome call the Ro≈øe Pea≈øe, is a good white Pea≈øe fit to be eaten.

The early or French Pea≈øe, which ≈øome call Fulham Pea≈øe, becau≈øe tho≈øe grounds thereabouts doe bring them ≈øoone≈øt forward for any quantity, although ≈øometimes they mi≈øcarry by their ha≈øte and earline≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Cicer Arietinum. Rams Ciches.
div.p: This is a kinde of Pul≈øe, ≈øo much v≈øed in Spaine, that it is v≈øually one of their daintie di≈øhes at all their fea≈øts: They are of two ≈øorts, white and red; the white is onely v≈øed for meate, the other for medicine. It beareth many vpright branches with winged leaues, many ≈øet together, being ≈ømall, almo≈øt round, and dented about the edges: the flowers are either white or purple, according to the colour of the Pea≈øe which follow, and are ≈øomewhat round at the head, but cornered and pointed at the end, one or two at the mo≈øt in a ≈ømall roundi≈øh cod.

div.head: The V≈øe of Pea≈øe.
div.p: Pea≈øe of all or the mo≈øt of the≈øe ≈øorts, are either v≈øed when they are greene, and be a di≈øh of meate for the table of the rich as well as the poore, yet euery one ob≈øeruing his time, and the kinde: the faire≈øt, ≈øweete≈øt, younge≈øt, and earlie≈øt for the better ≈øort, the later and meaner kindes for the meaner, who doe not giue the deere≈øt price: Or

figure.head: 1 Faba≈øatiua. Garden Beanes. 2 Pha≈øeoli ≈øatiui. French Beanes. 3 Pi≈øum vulga ‚Ä¢ e. Garden Pea≈øe. 4 Pi≈øum vmbellatum ≈øiue Ro≈øeum. Ro≈øe Pea≈øe or Scotti≈øh Pea≈øe. 5 Pi≈øum Saccharatum. Sugar Pea≈øe. 6 Pi≈øum maculatum. Spotted Pea≈øe. 7 Cicer Arietinum. Rams Ciches or Cicers.

div.p: It is much v≈øed likewi≈øe at Sea for them that goe long voyages, and is for change, becau≈øe it is fre≈øh, a welcome diet to mo≈øt per≈øons therein.

The Rams Ciches the Spaniards call Grauancos, and Garauancillos, and eate them boyled and ≈øtewed as the mo≈øt dainty kinde of Pea≈øe that are, they are of a very good relli≈øh, and doe nouri≈øh much; but yet are not without that windy quality that all ≈øorts of Pul≈øe are ≈øubiect vnto: they increa≈øe bodily lu≈øt much more then any other ≈øorts, and as it is thought, doth helpe to encrea≈øe ≈øeede.

div.head: Cucumer. The Cowcumber.
div.p: OF Cowcumbers there are diuers ≈øorts, differing chiefly in the forme and colour of the fruit, and not in the forme of the plant; therefore one de≈øcription ≈øhall ≈øerue in ≈øtead of all the re≈øt.

The Cowcumber bringeth forth many trailing rough greene branches lying on the ground, all along whereof growe ≈øeuerall leaues, which are rough, broad, vneuen at the edges, and pointed at the ends, with long crooked tendrels comming forth at the ≈øame ioynt with the leafe, but on the other ≈øide therof: between the ≈øtalks & the leaues at the ioynts come forth the flowers ≈øeuerally, euery one ≈øtanding on a ≈øhort foot-≈øtalke, opening it ≈øelfe into fiue leaues, of a yellowi≈øh colour, at the bottome whereof groweth the fruit, long and greene at the fir≈øt, but when it is thorough ripe, a little yellowi≈øh, hauing many furrowes, and vneuen bunches all the length of it, wherein is a white firme ≈øub≈øtance next vnto the skin, and a cleare pulpe or watery ≈øub≈øtance, with white flat ≈øeede lying di≈øper≈øed through it: the roote is long and white, with diuers fibres at it.

div.head: The kindes.
div.p: The fir≈øt de≈øcribed is called, The long greene Cowcumber.
There is another is called, The ≈øhort Cowcumber, being ≈øhort, and of an equall bigne≈ø≈øe in the body thereof, and of an vnequall bigne≈ø≈øe at both ends.

The long Yellow, which is yellowi≈øh from the beginning, and more yellow when it is ripe, and hath beene mea≈øured to be thirteene inches long: but this is not that ≈ømall long Cowcumber, called of the Latines, Cucumis anguinus.
Another kinde is early ripe, called The French kinde.
The Dant≈øicke kinde beareth but ≈ømall fruit, growing on ≈øhort branches or runners: the pickled Cowcumbers that are v≈øually ≈øold are of this kind.
The Mu≈øcouie kinde is the ≈ømalle≈øt of all other, yet knowne, and beareth not aboue foure or fiue at the mo≈øt on a roote, which are no bigger then ≈ømall Lemons.

div.head: The V≈øe of Cowcumbers.
div.p: Some v≈øe to ca≈øt a little ≈øalt on their ≈øliced Cowcumbers, and let them ≈øtand halfe an houre or more in a di≈øh, and then poure away the water that commeth from them by the ≈øalt, and after put vinegar, oyle, &c. thereon, as euery one liketh: this is done, to take away the ouermuch wateri≈øhne≈ø≈øe and coldne≈ø≈øe of the Cowcumbers.
In many countries they v≈øe to eate Cowcumbers as wee doe Apples or Peares, paring and giuing ≈ølices of them, as we would to our friends of ≈øome dainty Apple or Peare.

The pickled Cowcumbers that come from beyond Sea, are much v≈øed
with vs for ≈øawce to meate all the Winter long. Some haue ≈øtriuen to equall them, by pickling vp our Cowcumbers at the later end of the yeare, when they are cheape≈øt, taking the little ones and ≈øcalding them thoroughly well, which after they put in brine, with ≈øome Dill or Fenell leaues and ≈øtalkes: but the≈øe are nothing comparable to the former, wee either mi≈ø≈øing of the right and orderly pickling of them, or the kinde it ≈øelfe differing much from ours (as I ≈øaid of the Dant≈øicke kinde) for ours are neither ≈øo tender and firme, nor ≈øo ≈øauoury as the other.

The rawe or greene Cowcumbers are fitte≈øt for the hotter time of the yeare, and for hot ≈øtomackes, and not to be v≈øed in colder weather or cold ≈øtomackes, by rea≈øon of the coldne≈ø≈øe, whereby many haue been ouertaken.
The ≈øeede is v≈øed phy≈øically in many medicines that ≈øerue to coole, and a little to make the pa≈ø≈øages of vrine ≈ølippery, and to giue ea≈øe to hot di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: Melo. Milions or Muske Melons.
div.p: THere bee diuers ≈øorts of Melons found out at this day, differing much in the goodne≈ø≈øe of ta≈øte one from another. This Countrey hath not had vntill of late yeares the skill to nour≈øe them vp kindly, but now there are many that are ≈øo well experienced therein, and haue their ground ≈øo well prepared, as that they will not mi≈ø≈øe any yeare, if it be not too extreme vnkindly, to haue many ripe ones in a rea≈øonable time: yet ≈øome will be later then others alwayes.

The Melon is certainly a kinde of Cowcumber, it doth ≈øo neare re≈øemble it, both in the manner of his growing, hauing rough trailing branches, rough vneuen leaues, and yellow flowers: after which come the fruit, which is rounder, thicker, bigger, more rugged, and ≈øpotted on the out≈øide then the Cowcumber, of a ru≈ø≈øet colour, and greene vnderneath, which when it groweth full ripe, will change a little yellowi≈øh, being as deepe furrowed and ribbed as they, and be≈øides hauing chaps or rifts in diuers places of the rinde: the inward hard ≈øub≈øtance is yellow, which onely is eaten: the ≈øeede which is bigger, and a little yellower then the Cowcumber, lying in the middle onely among the moi≈øter pulpe: the ≈ømell and changing of his colour, fore-≈øhew their ripene≈ø≈øe to them that are experienced: the roote is long, with many fibres at it. The fruit requireth much watering in the hot time of the day, to cau≈øe them to ripen the ≈øooner, as I haue ob≈øerued by diuers of the be≈øt skill therein.

div.head: The V≈øe of the kindes of Melons.
div.p: The be≈øt Melon feede doe come to vs out of Spaine, ≈øome haue come out of Turkie, but they haue been nothing ≈øo good and kindly.
Some are called Sugar Melons, others Peare Melons, and others Muske Melons.

They haue beene formerly only eaten by great per≈øonages, becau≈øe the fruit was not only delicate but rare; and therfore diuers were brought from France, and ≈øince were nour≈øed vp by the Kings or Noblemens Gardiners onely, to ≈øerue for their Ma≈øters delight: but now diuers others that haue skill and conueniencie of ground for them, doe plant them and make them more common.

They paire away the outer rinde, and cut out the inward pulpe where the ≈øeede lyeth, ≈ølice the yellow firme inward rinde or ≈øub≈øtance, & ≈øo eate it with ≈øalt and pepper (and good ≈øtore of wine, or el≈øe it will hardly di≈øge≈øt) for this is firmer, & hath not that moi≈øture in it that the Cowcumbers haue. It is al≈øo more delicate, and of more worth, which recompen≈øeth the paine.
The ≈øeed of the≈øe Melons are v≈øed as Cowcumbers phy≈øically, and together with them mo≈øt v≈øually.

div.head: Pepo. Pompions.
div.p: WE haue but one kinde of Pompion (as I take it) in all our Gardens, notwith≈øtanding the diuer≈øities of bigne≈ø≈øe and colour.

The Pompion or great Melon (or as ≈øome call it Milion) creepeth vpon the ground (if nothing bee by it whreeon it may take hold and climbe) with very great, ribbed, rough, and prickly branches, whereon are ≈øet very large rough leaues, cut in on the edges with deepe ga≈øhes, and dented be≈øides, with many cla≈øpers al≈øo, which winde about euery thing they meete withall: the flowers are great and large, hollow and yellow, diuided at the brims into fiue parts, at the bottome of which, as it is in the re≈øt, groweth the fruit, which is very great, ≈øometimes of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans body, and oftentimes le≈ø≈øe, in ≈øome ribbed or bunched, in others plaine, and either long or round, either green or yellow, or gray, as Nature li≈øteth to ≈øhew her ≈øelfe; for it is but wa≈øte time, to recite all the formes and colours may be ob≈øerued in them: the inner rinde next vnto the outer is yellowi≈øh and firme: the ≈øeede is great, flat, and white, lying in the middle of the watery pulpe: the roote is of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans thumbe or greater, di≈øper≈øed vnder ground with many ≈ømall fibres ioyned thereunto.
Gourds are kindes of Melons; but becau≈øe wee haue no v≈øe of them, wee leaue them vnto their fit place.

div.head: The V≈øe of Pompions.
div.p: They are boyled in faire water and ≈øalt, or in powdered beefe broth, or ≈øometimes in milke, and ≈øo eaten, or el≈øe buttered. They v≈øe likewi≈øe to take out the inner watery ≈øub≈øtance with the ≈øeedes, and fill vp the place with Pippins, and hauing laid on the couer which they cut off from the toppe, to take out the pulpe, they bake them together, and the poore of the Citie, as well as the Country people, doe eate thereof, as of a dainty di≈øh.
The ≈øeede hereof, as well as of Cowcumbers and Melons, are cooling, and ≈øerue for emul≈øions in the like manner for Almond milkes, &c. for tho≈øe are troubled with the ≈øtone.

div.head: Fragaria. Strawberries.
div.p: THere be diuers ≈øorts of Strawberries, whereof tho≈øe that are nour≈øed vp in Gardens or Orchards I intend to giue you the knowledge in this place, and leaue the other to a fitter; yet I mu≈øt needs ≈øhew you of one of the wilde ≈øorts, which for his ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe is worthy of this Garden: And I mu≈øt al≈øo enforme you, that the wilde Strawberry that groweth in the Woods is our Garden Strawberry, but bettered by the ≈øoyle and tran≈øplanting.

The greate≈øt Muske Melon. 5 Pepo. The Pompion. 6 Fraga vulgaris. Common Strawberries. 7 Fraga Bohemica maxima. The great Bohemia Strawberries. 8 Fraga acu≈øeata. The prickly Strawberry.

div.p: The white Strawberry differeth not from the red, but in the colour of the fruite, which is whiter then the former when it is thorough ripe, enclining to redne≈ø≈øe.
The greene Strawberry likewi≈øe differeth not, but that the fruit is green on all ≈øides when it is ripe, ≈øaue on that ≈øide the Sun lyeth vpon it, and there it is ≈øomewhat red.

The Virginia Strawberry carryeth the greate≈øt leafe of any other, except the Bohemian, but ≈øcarce can one Strawberry be ≈øeene ripe among a number of plants; I thinke the rea≈øon thereof to be the want of skill, or indu≈øtry to order it aright. For the Bohemia, and all other Strawberries will not beare kindly, if you ≈øuffer them to grow with many ≈øtrings, and therefore they are ≈øtill cut away.

There is another very like vnto this, that Iohn Trade≈øcante brought with him from Bru≈ø≈øels long agoe, and in ≈øeuen yeares could neuer ≈øee one berry ripe on all ≈øides, but ≈øtill the better part rotten, although it would euery yeare flower abundantly, and beare very large leaues.

The Bohemia Strawberry hath beene with vs but of late dayes, but is the goodlie≈øt and greate≈øt, both for leafe next to the Virginian, and for beauty farre ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing all; for ≈øome of the berries haue beene mea≈øured to bee neere fiue inches about. Ma≈øter Que≈øter the Po≈øtma≈øter fir≈øt brought them ouer into our Country, as I vnder≈øtand, but I know no man ≈øo indu≈øtrious in the carefull planting and bringing them to perfection in that plentifull maner, as Ma≈øter Vincent Sion who dwelt on the Banck ≈øide, neer the old Paris garden ≈øtaires, who from ≈øeuen rootes, as hee affirmed to me, in one yeare and a halfe, planted halfe an acree of ground with the increa≈øe from them, be≈øides tho≈øe he gaue away to his friends, and with him I haue ≈øeene ≈øuch, and of that bigne≈ø≈øe before mentioned.

One Strawberry more I promi≈øed to ≈øhew you, which although it be a wilde kinde, and of no v≈øe for meate, yet I would not let this di≈øcour≈øe pa≈ø≈øe, without giuing you the knowledge of it. It is in leafe much like vnto the ordinary, but differeth in that the flower, if it haue any, is greene, or rather it beareth a ≈ømall head of greene leaues, many ≈øet thicke together like vnto a double ruffe, in the mid≈øt whereof ≈øtandeth the fruit, which when it is ripe, ≈øheweth to be ≈øoft and ≈øomwhat reddi≈øh, like vnto a Strawberry, but with many ≈ømall harmle≈ø≈øe prickles on them, which may be eaten and chewed in the mouth without any maner of offence, and is ≈øomewhat plea≈øant like a Strawberry: it is no great bearer, but tho≈øe it doth beare, are ≈øet at the toppes of the ≈øtalks clo≈øe together, plea≈øant to behold, and fit for a Gentlewoman to weare on her arme, &c. as a raritie in ≈øtead of a flower.

div.head: The V≈øe of Strawberries.
div.p: The leaues of Strawberries are alwaies v≈øed among other herbes in cooling drinkes, as al≈øo in lotions, and gargles for the mouth and throate: the rootes are ≈øometimes added to make it the more effectuall, and withall ≈øomwhat the more binding.

The berries them≈øelues are often brought to the Table as a reare ≈øeruice, whereunto claret wine, creame or milke is added with ≈øugar, as euery one liketh; as al≈øo at other times, both with the better and meaner ≈øort, and are a good cooling and plea≈øant di≈øh in the hot Summer ≈øea≈øon.
The water di≈øtilled of the berries, is good for the pa≈ø≈øions of the heart, cau≈øed by the perturbation of the ≈øpirits, being eyther drunke alone, or in wine; and maketh the heart merry.
Some doe hold that the water helpeth to clen≈øe the face from ≈øpots, and to adde ≈øome cleerene≈ø≈øe to the skinne.

div.head: Angelica. Garden Angelica.
div.p: HAuing thus furni≈øhed you out a Kitchen Garden with all ≈øorts of herbes, roots & fruits fit for it, and for any mans priuate v≈øe, as I did at the fir≈øt appropriate it; let me a little tran≈øcend, and for the profit & v≈øe of Country Gentlewomen and others, furni≈øh them with ≈øome few other herbes, of the mo≈øt e≈øpeciall v≈øe for tho≈øe ≈øhall need them, to be planted at hand in their Gardens, to ≈øpend as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerue, and fir≈øt of Angelica.

Angelica hath great and long winged leaues, made of many broade greene ones, diuided one from another vpon the ≈øtalk, which is three foot long or better ≈øomtimes, among which ri≈øe vp great thicke and hollow ≈øtalkes with ≈øome few ioynts, whereat doth alwayes ≈øtand two long leaues compa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtalke at the bottome, in ≈øome places at the ioynts ≈øpring out other ≈øtalkes or branches, bearing ≈øuch like leaues but ≈ømaller, and at the tops very large vmbels of white flowers, that turne into whiti≈øh ≈øeede ≈øomewhat thicke: the roote groweth great with many branches at it, but quickly peri≈øheth after it hath borne ≈øeede: to pre≈øerue the roote therefore the better, they v≈øe to cut it often in the yeare, thereby to hinder the running vp to ≈øeede: the whole plant, both leafe, roote and ≈øeede, is of an excellent comfortable ≈øent, ≈øauour and ta≈øte.

div.head: The V≈øe of Angelica.
div.p: The di≈øtilled water of Angelica, eyther ≈øimple or compound, is of e≈øpeciall v≈øe in deliquium animi, vel cordis tremores & pa≈øsiones, that is, ≈øwounings, when the ≈øpirits are ouercome and faint, or tremblings and pa≈ø≈øions of the heart, to expell any windy or noy≈øome vapours from it. The green ≈øtalkes or the young rootes being pre≈øerued or candied, are very effectuall to comfort and warme a colde and weake ≈øtomacke: and in the time of infection is of excellent good v≈øe to pre≈øerue the ≈øpirits and heart from infection. The dryed roote made into pouder, and taken in wine or other drinke, will abate the rage of lu≈øt in young per≈øons, as I haue it related vnto me vpon credit: A Syrupe made thereof in this manner, is very profitable to expectorate flegme out of the che≈øt and lunges, and to procure a ≈øweete breath. Into the greene ≈øtalke of Angelica as it ≈øtandeth growing, make a great ga≈øhe or inci≈øion, wherein put a quantitie of fine white Sugar, letting it there abide for three dayes, and after take it forth by cutting a hole at the next ioynt vnder the cut, where the Syrupe re≈øteth, or cut off the ≈øtalke, and turne it downe, that the Syrupe may drayne forth; which keepe for a mo≈øt delicate medicine.

div.head: Dracunculus horten≈øis ≈øiue Serpentaria. Dragons.
div.p: DRagons ri≈øeth out of the ground with a bare or naked round whiti≈øh ≈øtalke, ≈øpotted very much with purpli≈øh ≈øpots and ≈øtrakes, bearing at the toppe therof a few greene leaues very much diuided on all ≈øides, ≈øtanding vpon long foote≈øtalkes, in the middle whereof (if the roote be old enough) commeth forth a great long huske or ho≈øe, green on the out≈øide, and of a darke purpli≈øh colour on the in≈øide, with a ≈ølender long reddi≈øh pe≈øtell or clapper in the middle: the roote is great, round, flat and whiti≈øh on the out≈øide, and whiter within, very like vnto the rootes of Arum, or Wakerobin, and ta≈øting ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe like it.

div.head: The V≈øe of Dragons.
div.p: The chiefe v≈øe whereunto Dragons are applyed, is, that according to an old receiued cu≈øtome and tradition (and not the iudgement of any learned Author) the di≈øtilled water is giuen with Mithridatum or Treakle to expell noy≈øome and pe≈øtilentiall vapours from the heart.

div.head: Ruta. Garden Rue, or Herbe Grace.
div.p: GArden Rue or Herbe Grace groweth vp with hard whiti≈øh wooddy ≈øtalkes, whereon are ≈øet diuers branches of leaues, being diuided into many ≈ømall ones, which are ≈øomewhat thicke and round pointed, of a blewi≈øh greene colour: the flowers ≈øtand at the tops of the ≈øtalkes con≈øi≈øting of foure ≈ømall yellow leaues, with a greene button in the middle, and diuers ≈ømall yellow threds about it, which growing ripe, containe within them ≈ømall blacke ≈øeede: the roote is white and wooddy, ≈øpreading farre in the ground.

div.head: The V≈øe of Rue.
div.p: The many good properties whereunto Rue ≈øerueth, hath I thinke in former times cau≈øed the Engli≈øh name of Herbe Grace to be giuen vnto it. For without doubt it is a mo≈øt whole≈øome herbe, although bitter and ≈øtrong, and could our dainty ≈øtomackes brooke the v≈øe thereof, it would worke admirable effects being carefully and skilfully applyed, as time and occa≈øion did require: but not vndi≈øcreetly or hand ouer head, as many v≈øe to doe that haue no skill. Some doe rippe vp a beade rowle of the vertues of Rue, as Macer the Poet and others, in whom you ≈øhall finde them ≈øet downe, to bee good for the head, eyes, brea≈øt, liuer, heart, ≈øpleene, &c. In ≈øome places they v≈øe to boyle the leaues of Rue, and keep them in pickle, to eate them as Sampire for the helpe of weake eyes. It is very auaileable in gli≈øters or drinkes again≈øt the winde or the collicke, and to procure vrine that is ≈øtayed by the paines therof. The di≈øtilled water is often v≈øed for the ≈øame purpo≈øes afore≈øaid: but beware of the too frequent or ouermuch v≈øe thereof, becau≈øe it heateth exceedingly, and wa≈øteth nature mightily.

div.head: Carduus Benedictus. The Ble≈ø≈øed Thi≈øtle.
div.p: CArduus benedictus or the ble≈ø≈øed Thi≈øtle, hath many weake tender branches lying for the mo≈øt part on the ground, whereon are ≈øet long and narrow leaues, much cut in or waued about the edges, hairy or rough in handling, yet without any hard or ≈øharpe thornes or prickles at all, that the tendere≈øt hand may touch them without harme: but tho≈øe that grow toward the toppes of the ≈øtalkes are ≈øomewhat more prickly, and the heads which grow on the tops of the ≈øeuerall branches are ≈øomewhat ≈øharpe, ≈øet with prickles like a Thi≈øtle: the flower is yellow, and the ≈øeede lying within the woolly or flocky doune like to all other thi≈øtles, are blacki≈øh, long and round, with a few haires on the head of them: the roote is white, and peri≈øheth euery yeare after it hath giuen ≈øeede.

div.head: The V≈øe of the ble≈ø≈øed Thi≈øtle.
div.p:
The di≈øtilled water hereof is much v≈øed to be drunke again≈øt agues of all ≈øortes, eyther pe≈øtilentiall or humorall, of long continuance or of le≈ø≈øe:
1 Angellica. Angellica. 2 Dracuncu ‚Ä¢ us borten≈øis. Dragons. 3
‚Ä¢ uta borten≈øis. Garden R ‚Ä¢ e, or Herbegrace. 4 Carduits benedict. b ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øed Thi≈øtle. 5 Alkakengi ≈øu ‚Ä¢ e Solanum Halic ‚Ä¢ cabum & Ve≈øicatium, Winter Che ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 6 A≈øarum A≈øarabacca. 7 Liqueritia.

but the decoction of the herbe giuen in due time, hath the more forcible operation: it helpeth to expell wormes, becau≈øe of the bitterne≈ø≈øe, and is thereby al≈øo a friend to the ≈øtomack ouercharged with chollar, and to clen≈øe the liuer: it prouoketh ≈øweate and vrine, is helpefull to them are troubled with the ≈øtone, and to ea≈øe paines in the ≈øides.

div.head: Solanum veficarium, ≈øiue Alkakengi. Winter Cherries.
div.p: THe Winter Cherry hath a running or creeping roote in the ground, of the bigne≈ø≈øe wany times of ones little finger, ≈øhooting forth at ≈øeuerall ioynts in ≈øeuerall places, whereby it quickly ≈øpreadeth a great compa≈ø≈øe of ground: the ≈øtalke ri≈øeth not aboue a yard high, whereon are ≈øet many broade and long greene leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of Night≈øhade, but larger: at the ioynts whereof come forth whiti≈øh flowers made of fiue leaues a peece, which after turne into green berries, inclo≈øed with thin skins or bladders, which change to bee reddi≈øh when they grow ripe, the berry likewi≈øe being reddi≈øh, and as large as a Cherry, wherein are contained many flat and yellowi≈øh ≈øeed lying within the pulpe: which being gathered and ≈øtrung vp, are kept all the yeare to be v≈øed vpon occa≈øion.

div.head: The V≈øe of Winter Cherries.
div.p: The di≈øtilled water of the herbe and fruit together, is often taken of them that are troubled with the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe or difficultie of vrine, and with the ≈øtone in the kidneyes, or grauel in the bladder: but the berries them≈øelues either greene or dryed boyled eyther in broth, in wine, or in water, is much more effectuall: It is likewi≈øe conducing to open ob≈øtructions of the liuer, &c. and thereby to helpe the yellow Iaundi≈øe.

div.head: A≈øarum. A≈øarabacca.
div.p: A Sarabacca, from a ≈ømall creeping roote ≈øet with many fibres, ≈øhooteth forth diuers heads, and from euery of them ≈øundry leaues, euery one ≈øtanding vpon a long greene ≈øtalke, which are round, thicke, and of a very ≈øad or darke greene colour, and ≈øhining withall: from the rootes likewi≈øe ≈øpring vp ≈øhort ≈øtalkes, not fully foure fingers high, at the toppe of euery one of which ≈øtandeth the flower, in fa≈øhion very like the ≈øeede ve≈ø≈øell of Henbane ≈øeede, of a greeni≈øh purple colour, which changeth not his forme, but groweth in time to containe therein ≈ømall cornered ≈øeed: the greene leaues abide all the winter many times, but v≈øually ≈øheddeth them in winter, and recouereth fre≈øh in the ≈øpring.

div.head: The V≈øe of A≈øarabacca.
div.p: The leaues are much and often v≈øed to procure vomits, fiue or ≈øeuen of them brui≈øed, and the iuice of them drunke in ale or wine. An extract made of the leaues with wine artificially performed, might bee kept all the yeare thorough, to bee v≈øed vpon any pre≈øent occa≈øion, the quantitie to bee proportioned according to the con≈øtitution of the patient. The roote worketh not ≈øo ≈øtrongly by vomit, as the leaues, yet is often v≈øed for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, and be≈øides is held auaileable to prouoke vrine, to open ob≈øtructions in the liuer and ≈øpleene, and is put among diners other ≈øimples, both into Mithridatum and Andromachus Treakle, which is v≈øually called Venice Treakle. A dram of the dryed roots in pouder giuen in white wine a little before the fit of an ague, taketh away the ≈øhaking fit, & therby cau≈øe the hot fit to be the more remi≈ø≈øe, and in twice taking expell it quite.

div.head: Glycyrrhiza ≈øiue Liqueritia. Licorice.
div.p: ALthough there are two ≈øorts of Licorice ≈øet downe by diuers Authors, yet becau≈øe this Land familiarly is acquainted but with one ≈øort, I ≈øhall not neede for this Garden, to make any further relation of that is vnknowne, but onely of that ≈øort which is ≈øufficiently frequent with vs. It ri≈øeth vp with diuers wooddy ≈øtalks, whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances many winged leaues, that is to ≈øay, many narrow long greene leaues ≈øet together on both ≈øides of the ≈øtalke, and an odde one at the end, very well re≈øembling a young A≈øhe tree ≈øprung vp from the ≈øeede: this by many yeares continuance in a place without remouing, and not el≈øe, will bring forth flowers many ≈øtanding together ≈øpike-fa≈øhion one aboue another vpon the ≈øtalkes, of the forme of Pea≈øe blo≈ø≈øomes, but of a very pale or bleake blew colour, which turne into long ≈øomewhat flat and ≈ømooth cods, wherein is contained ≈ømall round hard ≈øeede: the roote runneth downe exceeding deep into the ground, with diuers other ≈ømaller roots and fibres growing with them, and ≈øhoote out ≈øuckers from the maine rootes all about, whereby it is much encrea≈øed, of a browni≈øh colour on the out≈øide, and yellow within, of a farre more weake ≈øweete ta≈øte, yet far more plea≈øing to vs then that Licorice that is brought vs from beyond Sea; becau≈øe that, being of a ≈øtronger ≈øweet ta≈øte hath a bitterne≈ø≈øe ioyned with it, which maketh it the le≈ø≈øe plea≈øing and acceptable to mo≈øt.

div.head: The V≈øe of Licorice.
div.p: Our Engli≈øh Licorice is now adaies of more familiar v≈øe (as I ≈øaid before) then the outlandi≈øh, and is wholly ≈øpent and v≈øed to helpe to dige≈øt and expectorate flegme out of the che≈øt and lunges, and doth allay the ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe or ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe thereof. It is good al≈øo for tho≈øe are troubled with ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of breath, and for all ≈øorts of coughes. The iuice of Licorice artificially made with Hy≈ø≈øope water, ≈øerueth very well for all the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid. It being di≈ø≈øolued with Gum Tragacanth in Ro≈øe water, is an excellent Lohoc or licking medicine to breake flegme, and to expectorate it, as al≈øo to avoyde thin frothy matter, or thin ≈øalt flegme, which often fretteth the lunges. It doth al≈øo lenifie exulcerated kidneyes, or the bladder, and helpeth to heale them. It is held al≈øo good for tho≈øe that cannot make their water but by drops, or a ≈ømall deale at a time.
The dryed root finely minced, is a ≈øpeciall ingredient into all Trageas or Dredges, ≈øeruing for the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, but the v≈øe of them is almo≈øt wholly left now adaies with all ≈øorts.

Thus haue I ≈øhewed you not only the herbes, rootes and fruites, nour≈øed vp in this Garden, but ≈øuch herbes as are of mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary v≈øes for the Country Gentlewomens hou≈øes: And now I will ≈øhew you the Orchard al≈øo.

div.head: THE ORDERING OF THE ORCHARD. The third part, or ORCHARD.
CHAP. I. The ≈øituation of an Orchard for fruit-bearing trees, and how to amend the defects of many grounds.
div.p:
AS I haue done in the two former parts of this Treati≈øe, ≈øo I meane to proceede in this; fir≈øt to ≈øet downe the ≈øituation of an Orchard, and then other things in order: And fir≈øt, I hold that an Orchard which is, or ≈øhould bee of ≈øome rea≈øonable large extent, ≈øhould be ≈øo placed, that the hou≈øe ≈øhould haue the Garden of flowers iu≈øt before it open vpon the South, and the Kitchen Garden on the one ≈øide thereof, ≈øhould al≈øo haue the Orchard on the other ≈øide of the Garden of Plea≈øure, for many good rea≈øons: Fir≈øt, for that the fruit trees being grown great and tall, will be a great ≈øhelter from the North and Ea≈øt windes, which may offend your chiefe≈øt Garden, and although that your Orchard ≈øtand a little bleake vpon the windes, yet trees rather endure the≈øe ≈øtrong bitter bla≈øts, then other ≈ømaller and more tender ≈øhrubs and herbes can doe. Secondly, if your Orchard ≈øhould ≈øtand behinde your Garden of flowers more Southward, it would ≈øhadow too much of the Garden, and be≈øides, would ≈øo binde in the North and Ea≈øt, and North and We≈øt windes vpon the Garden, that it would ≈øpoile many tender things therein, and ≈øo much abate the edge of your plea≈øure thereof, that you would willingly wi≈øh to haue no Orchard, rather then that it ≈øhould ≈øo much annoy you by the ≈øo ill ≈øtanding thereof. Thirdly, the falling leaues being ≈øtill blowne with the winde ≈øo aboundantly into the Garden, would either ≈øpoile many things, or haue one daily and continuall attending thereon, to clean≈øe and ≈øweepe them away. Or el≈øe to auoide the≈øe great inconueniences, appoint out an Orchard the farther off, and ≈øet a greater di≈øtance of ground betweene. For the ground or ≈øoile of the Orchard, what I haue ≈øpoken concerning the former Garden for the bettering of the ≈øeuerall grounds, may very well ≈øerue and be applyed to this purpo≈øe. But ob≈øerue this, that whereas your Gardens before ≈øpoken of may be turned vp, manured, and bettered with ≈øoile if they growe out of heart, your Orchard is not ≈øo ea≈øily done, but mu≈øt abide many yeares without altering; and therefore if the ground be barren, or not good, it had the more neede to bee amended, or wholly made good, before you make an Orchard of it; yet ≈øome there be
that doe appoint, that where euery tree ≈øhould bee ≈øet, you onely digge that place to make it good: but you mu≈øt know, that the rootes of trees runne further after a little times ≈øtanding, then the fir≈øt compa≈ø≈øe they are ≈øet in; and therefore a little compa≈ø≈øe of ground can maintaine them but a little while, and that when the rootes are runne beyond that ≈ømall compa≈ø≈øe wherein they were fir≈øt ≈øet, and that they are come to the barren or bad ground, they can thriue no better then if they had beene ≈øet in that ground at the fir≈øt, and if you ≈øhould afterwards digge beyond that compa≈ø≈øe, intending to make the ground better further off, you ≈øhould much hurt the ≈øpreading rootes, and put your trees in danger: the ≈øituation of hils in many places is grauelly or chalky, which is not good for trees, becau≈øe they are both too ≈øtonie, and lacke mellow earth, wherein a tree doth mo≈øt ioy and pro≈øper, and want moi≈øture al≈øo (which is the life of all trees) becau≈øe of the quicke de≈øcent of raine to the lower grounds: and be≈øides all the≈øe inconueniences there is one more; your trees planted either on hils or hill ≈øides, are more ≈øubiect to the fury and force of windes to be ouerturned, then tho≈øe that growe in the lower grounds; for the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt forcible windes come not v≈øually out of the North Ea≈øt parts, where you prouide be≈øt defence, but from the South and We≈øt, whence you looke for the be≈øt comfort of the Sunne. To helpe therefore manie of the inconueniences of the hils ≈øides, it were fit to cau≈øe manie leauels to bee made thereon, by rai≈øing the lower grounds with good earth, and ≈øu≈øtaining them with bricke or ≈øtone wals, which although chargeable, will counteruaile your co≈øt, be≈øide the plea≈øure of the walkes, and pro≈øpect of ≈øo worthy a worke. The plaine or leuell grounds as they are the mo≈øt frequent, ≈øo they are the mo≈øt commendable for an Orchard, becau≈øe the moulds or earths are more rich, or may better and ≈øooner be made ≈øo; and therefore the profits are the more may be rai≈øed from them. A ≈øtiffe clay doth nouri≈øh trees well, by rea≈øon it containeth moi≈øture; but in regard of the coldne≈ø≈øe thereof, it killeth for the mo≈øt part all tender and early things therein: ≈øea-cole a≈øhes therefore, bucke a≈øhes, ≈øtreete ≈øoyle, chaulke after it hath lyen abroad and been broken with many yeares fro≈øts and raine, and ≈øheepes dung, are the mo≈øt proper and fitte≈øt manure to helpe this kinde of ≈øoyle. The dry ≈øandy ≈øoile, and grauelly ground are on the contrary ≈øide as bad, by rea≈øon of too much heate and lacke of moi≈øture: the dung of kine or cattell in good quantity be≈øtowed thereon, will much helpe them. The amending or bettering of other ≈øorts of grounds is ≈øet down toward the end of the fir≈øt Chapter of the fir≈øt part of this worke, wherevnto I will referre you, not willing to repeate againe the ≈øame things there ≈øet downe. The be≈øt way to auoide and amend the inconueniences of high, boi≈øterous, and cold windes, is to plant Walnut trees, Elmes, Oakes or A≈øhes, a good di≈øtance without the compa≈ø≈øe of your Orchard, which after they are growne great, will bee a great ≈øafeguard thereunto, by breaking the violence of the windes from it. And if the ≈øoyle of your Orchard want moi≈øture, the conueying of the ≈øinke of the hou≈øe, as al≈øo any other draine of water thereinto, if it may be, will much helpe it.

div.head: CHAP. II. The forme of an Orchard, both ordinary, and of more grace and rarity.
div.p:
ACcording to the ≈øituation of mens grounds, ≈øo mu≈øt the plantation of them of nece≈ø≈øitie be al≈øo; and if the ground be in forme, you ≈øhall haue a formall Orchard: if otherwi≈øe, it can haue little grace or forme. And indeed in the elder ages there was ≈ømall care or heede taken for the formality; for euery tree for the mo≈øt part was planted without order, euen where the ma≈øter or keeper found a vacant place to plant them in, ≈øo that oftentimes the ill placing of trees without ≈øufficient ≈øpace betweene them, and negligence in not looking to vphold them, procured more wa≈øte and ≈øpoile of fruit, then any accident of winde or weather could doe. Orchards in mo≈øt places haue not bricke or ≈øtone wals to ≈øecure them, becau≈øe the extent thereof being
larger then of a Garden, would require more co≈øt, which euery one cannot vndergoe; and therefore mud wals, or at the be≈øt a quicke ≈øet hedge, is the ordinary and mo≈øt v≈øuall defence it findeth almo≈øt in all places: but with tho≈øe that are of ability to compa≈ø≈øe it with bricke or ≈øtone wals, the gaining of ground, and profit of the fruit trees planted there again≈øt, will in ≈øhort time recompen≈øe that charge. If you make a doubt how to be ≈øure that your Orchard wall ≈øhall haue ≈øufficient comfort of the Sunne to ripen the fruits, in regard the trees in the Orchard being ≈øo nigh thereunto, and ≈øo high withall, will ≈øo much ≈øhadow the wall, that nothing will ripen well, becau≈øe it will want the comfort of the Sunne: you may follow this rule and aduice, to remedy tho≈øe inconueniences. Hauing an Orchard containing one acre of ground, two, three, or more, or le≈ø≈øe, walled about, you may ≈øo order it, by leauing a broad and large walke betweene the wall and it, containing twenty or twenty foure foote (or yards if you will) that the wall ≈øhall not be hindered of the Sun, but haue ≈øufficient comfort for your trees, notwith≈øtanding the height of them, the di≈øtance betweene them and the wall being a ≈øufficient ≈øpace for their ≈øhadow to fall into: and by compa≈ø≈øing your Orchard on the in≈øide with a hedge
diagram of planting scheme (wherein may bee planted all ≈øorts of low ≈øhrubs or bu≈øhes, as Ro≈øes, Cornellian Cherry trees pla≈øhed lowe, Goo≈øeberries, Curran trees, or the like) you may enclo≈øe your walke, and keepe both it and your Orchard in better forme and manner, then if it lay open. For the placing of your trees in this Orchard, fir≈øt for the wals: Tho≈øe ≈øides that lye open to the South & Southwe≈øt Sunne, are fitte≈øt to bee planted with your tendere≈øt and earlie≈øt fruits, as Apricockes, Peaches, Nectarius, and May or early Cherries: the Ea≈øt, North and We≈øt, for Plums and Quinces, as you ≈øhall like be≈øt to place them. And for the Orchard it ≈øelfe, the ordinary manner is to place them without regard of mea≈øure or difference, as Peares among Apples, and Plums among Cherries promi≈øcuou≈øly; but ≈øome keepe both a di≈øtance and a diui≈øion for euery ≈øort, without intermingling: yet the mo≈øt gracefull Orchard containeth them all, with ≈øome others, ≈øo as they be placed that one doe not hinder or ≈øpoile another; and therefore to de≈øcribe you the modell of an Orchard, both rare for comeline≈ø≈øe in the proportion, and plea≈øing for the profitablene≈ø≈øe in the v≈øe, and al≈øo durable for continuance, regard this figure is here placed for your direction, where you mu≈øt ob≈øerue, that your trees are here ≈øet in ≈øuch an equall di≈øtance one from another euery way, & as is fitte≈øt for them, that when they are grown great, the greater branches ≈øhall not gall or rubbe one again≈øt another; for which purpo≈øe twenty or ≈øixteene foot is the lea≈øt to be allowed for the di≈øtance euery way of your trees, & being ≈øet in rowes euery one in the middle di≈øtance, will be the mo≈øt gracefull for the plantation, and be≈øides, giue you way ≈øufficient to pa≈ø≈øe through them, to pruine, loppe, or dre≈ø≈øe them, as need ≈øhall require, and may al≈øo bee brought (if you plea≈øe) to that gracefull delight, that euery alley or di≈øtance may be formed like an arch, the branches of either ≈øide meeting to be enterlaced together. Now for the ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of fruit trees that you ≈øhall place in this modell, your be≈øt direction is to ≈øet Dam≈øons, Bulleis, and your taler growing Plums on the out≈øide, and your lower Plums, Cherries, and Apples on the in≈øide, hauing regard, that you place no Peare tree to the Sunward, of any other tree, le≈øt it ouer≈øhadow
them: Let your Peare trees therefore be placed behinde, or on the one ≈øide of your lower trees, that they may be as it were a ≈øhelter or defence on the North & Ea≈øt ≈øide. Thus may you al≈øo plant Apples among Plums and Cherries, ≈øo as you ≈øuffer not one to ouer-growe or ouer-toppe another; for by pruning, lopping, and ≈øhredding tho≈øe that growe too fa≈øt for their fellowes, you may ≈øtill keepe your trees in ≈øuch a conformity, as may be both mo≈øt comely for the ≈øight, and mo≈øt profitable for the yeelding of greater and better ≈øtore of fruit. Other ≈øorts of fruit trees you may mixe among the≈øe, if you plea≈øe, as Filberds, Cornellian Cherries in ≈øtanderds, and Medlers: but Seruice trees, Baye trees, and others of that high ≈øort, mu≈øt be ≈øet to guard the re≈øt. Thus haue I giuen you the faire≈øt forme could as yet be deui≈øed; and from this patterne, if you doe not follow it preci≈øely, yet by it you may proportion your Orchard, be it large or little, be it walled or hedged.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of a nour≈øery for trees, both from ≈øowing the kernels, and planting fit ≈øtockes to graft vpon.
div.p:
ALthough I know the greater ≈øort (I meane the Nobility and better part of the Gentrie of this Land) doe not intend to keepe a Nur≈øery, to rai≈øe vp tho≈øe trees that they meane to plant their wals or Orchards withall, but to buy them already grafted to their hands of them that make their liuing of it: yet becau≈øe many Gentlemen and others are much delighted to be≈øtowe their paines in grafting them≈øelues, and e≈øteeme their owne labours and handie worke farre aboue other mens: for their incouragement and ≈øatisfaction, I will here ≈øet downe ≈øome conuenient directions, to enable them to rai≈øe an Orchard of all ≈øorts of fruits quickly, both by ≈øowing the kernels or ≈øtones of fruit, and by making choi≈øe of the be≈øt ≈øorts of ≈øtockes to graft on: Fir≈øt therefore to begin with Cherries; If you will make a Nur≈øery, wherein you may bee ≈øtored with plenty of ≈øtockes in a little ≈øpace, take what quantitie you thinke good of ordinarie wilde blacke Cherrie ≈øtones, clean≈øed from the berries, and ≈øowe them, or pricke them in one by one on a peece of ground well turned vp, and large enough for the quantitie of ≈øtones you will be≈øtowe thereon, from the mid≈øt of Augu≈øt vnto the end of September, which when they are two or three yeares old, according to their growth, you may remoue them, and ≈øet them anew in ≈øome orderly rowes, hauing pruned their tops and their rootes, which at the next yeares growth after the new planting in any good ground, or at the ≈øecond, will be of ≈øufficient bigne≈ø≈øe to graft vpon in the bud what ≈øorts of Cherries you thinke be≈øt: and it is fitte≈øt to graft them thus young, that pruning your ≈øtockes to rai≈øe them high, you may graft them at fiue or ≈øix foote high, or higher, or lower, as you ≈øhall ≈øee good, and being thus grafted in the bud, will both more ≈øpeedily and ≈øafely bring forward your grafts, and with le≈ø≈øe danger of lo≈øing your ≈øtockes, then by grafting them in the ≈øtocke: for if the bud take not by inoculating the fir≈øt yeare, yet your tree is not lo≈øt, nor put in any hazzard of lo≈ø≈øe; but may be grafted anew the yeare following, if you will, in another place thereof, whereas if you graft in the ≈øtocke, and it doe not take, it is a great chance if the ≈øtocke dye not wholly, or at lea≈øt be not ≈øo weakened both in ≈øtrength and height, that it will not bee fit to bee grafted a yeare or two after. In the ≈øame manner as you doe with the blacke, you may deale with the ordinary Engli≈øh red Cherrie ≈øtones, or kernels, but they are not ≈øo apt to growe ≈øo ≈øtraight and high, nor in ≈øo ≈øhort a time as the blacke Cherrie ≈øtones are, and be≈øides are ≈øubiect in time to bring out ≈øuckers from the rootes, to the hinderance of the ≈øtockes and grafts, or at the lea≈øt to the deformitie of your Orchard, and more trouble to the Gardiner, to pull or digge them away. Plumme ≈øtones may bee ordered in this manner likewi≈øe, but you mu≈øt make choi≈øe of your Plums; for although euery Plumme is not ≈øo fit for this purpo≈øe, as the white Peare Plumme, becau≈øe it groweth the goale≈øt and free≈øt, the barke being ≈ømooth and apte≈øt to be rai≈øed, that they may be grafted vpon; yet diuers other Plummes may be taken, if they be not at hand, or to be had, as the blacke and red Peare Plumme, the
white and red Wheate Plumme, becau≈øe they are neare≈øt in goodne≈ø≈øe vnto it. Peach ≈øtones will be ≈øoone rai≈øed vp to graft other ≈øorts of Peaches or Nectorins vpon, but the nature of the Peach roote being ≈øpongie, is not to abide long. As for Almonds, they will be rai≈øed from their ≈øtones to be trees of them≈øelues; but they will hardly abide the remouing, and le≈ø≈øe to bee grafted vpon. Apricocke ≈øtones are the wor≈øt to deale withall of any ≈øort of ≈øtone fruit; for although the Apricocke branches are the fitte≈øt ≈øtockes to graft Nectorins of the be≈øt ≈øorts vpon, yet tho≈øe that are rai≈øed from the kernels or ≈øtones will neuer thriue to be brought on for this purpo≈øe; but will ≈øtarue and dye, or hardly grow in a long time to be a ≈øtraight and fit ≈øtocke to be grafted, if it be once remoued. Your Cornellian Cherrie trees are wholly, or for the mo≈øt part rai≈øed from the ≈øtones or kernels; yet I know diuers doe increa≈øe them, by laying in their lowe≈øt branches to take roote: and thus much for ≈øtone fruits. Now for Apples and Peares, to be dealt withall in the ≈øame manner as afore≈øaid. They v≈øe to take the pre≈ø≈øing of Crabs whereas Veriuyce is made, as al≈øo of Cidar and Perry where they are made, and ≈øowing them, doe rai≈øe vp great ≈øtore of ≈øtockes; for although the beating of the fruit doth ≈øpoile many kernels, yet there will bee enough left that were neuer toucht, and that will ≈øpring: the Crabbe ≈øtockes ≈øome preferre for the fitte≈øt, but I am ≈øure, that the better Apple and Peare kernels will growe fairer, ≈øtraighter, quicklier, and better to be grafted on. You mu≈øt remember, that after two or three yeares you take vp the≈øe ≈øtockes, and when you haue pruned both toppe and roote, to ≈øet them againe in a thinner and fitter order, to be afterwards grafted in the bud while they are young, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew you by and by, or in the ≈øtocke if you will ≈øuffer them to growe greater. Now likewi≈øe to know which are the fitte≈øt ≈øtockes of all ≈øorts to choo≈øe, thereon to graft euery of the≈øe ≈øorts of fruits, is a point of ≈øome skill indeede; and therefore ob≈øerue them as I doe here ≈øet them downe: for bee you a≈ø≈øured, that they are certaine rules, and knowne experiences, whereunto you may tru≈øt without being deceiued. Your blacke Cherrie ≈øtockes (as I ≈øaid before) are the fitte≈øt and be≈øt for all ≈øorts of Cherries long to abide and pro≈øper, and euen May or early Cherry will abide or liue longer, being grafted thereon, either in the budde or in the ≈øtocke, then on the ordinary red Cherry ≈øtocke; but the red Cherry ≈øtocke is in a manner the onely tree that mo≈øt Nur≈øery men doe take to graft May Cherries on in the ≈øtocke (for it is but a late experience of many, to graft May Cherries in the bud) many al≈øo doe graft May Cherries on Ga≈øcoigne Cherry ≈øtockes, which doe not onely thrine well, but endure longer then vpon any ordinay Cherry ≈øtocke: For indeede the May Cherries that are grafted vpon ordinary red Cherrie ≈øtockes, will hardly hold aboue a dozen yeares bearing well, although they come forwarder at the fir≈øt, that is, doe beare ≈øooner then tho≈øe that are grafted on Ga≈øcoigne or blacke Cherry ≈øtockes; but as they are earlier in bearing, ≈øo they are ≈øooner ≈øpent, and the Ga≈øcoigne and blacke Cherry ≈øtockes that are longer in comming forward, will la≈øt twice or thrice their time; but many more grafts will mi≈ø≈øe in grafting of the≈øe, then of tho≈øe red Cherry ≈øtockes, and be≈øides, the natures of the Ga≈øcoigne and blacke Cherry ≈øtockes are to ri≈øe higher, and make a goodlier tree then the ordinary red ≈øtocke will, which for the mo≈øt part ≈øpreadeth wide, but ri≈øeth not very high. The Engli≈øh red Cherry ≈øtocke will ≈øerue very well to graft any other ≈øort of Cherry vpon, and is v≈øed in mo≈øt places of this Land, and I know no other greater inconuenience in it, then that it ≈øhooteth out many ≈øuckers from the roote, which yet by looking vnto may ≈øoone bee remoued from doing any harme, and that it will not la≈øt ≈øo long as the Ga≈øcoigne or blacke Cherry ≈øtocke will. May Cherries thus grafted lowe, doe mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øerue to be planted again≈øt a wall, to bring on the fruit the earlier; yet ≈øome graft them high vpon ≈øtandards, although not many, and it is, I thinke, rather curio≈øity (if they that doe it haue any wals) then anie other matter that cau≈øeth them thus to doe: for the fruit is naturally ≈ømall, though early, and the ≈øtandard Cherries are alwaies later then the wall Cherries, ≈øo that if they can ≈øpare any roome for them at their wals, they will not plant many in ≈øtandards. Now concerning Plummes (as I ≈øaid before) for the ≈øowing or ≈øetting of the ≈øtones, ≈øo I ≈øay here for their choi≈øe in grafting of them, either in the budde or ≈øtocke. The white Peare Plumme ≈øtocke, and the other there mentioned, but e≈øpecially the white Peare Plumme is the goodlie≈øt, free≈øt, and fitte≈øt of all the re≈øt, as well to graft all ≈øort of Plummes vpon, as al≈øo to graft Apricockes, which can be hand≈øomely, and to any
good purpo≈øe grafted vpon no other Plum ≈øtocke, to ri≈øe to bee worth the labour and paine. All ≈øorts of Plums may be grafted in the ≈øtocke, and ≈øo may they al≈øo in the bud; for I know none of them that will refu≈øe to be grafted in the bud, if a cunning hand performe it well; that is, to take off your bud cleanely and well, when you haue made choice of a fit cyon: for, as I ≈øhal ≈øhew you anon, it is no ≈ømall peece of cunning to chu≈øe your cyon that it may yeeld fit buds to graft withall, for euery plum is not of a like aptnes to yeeld them: But Apricocks cannot be grafted in the ≈øtock for any thing that euer I could heare or learne, but only in the bud, and therefore let your Plum ≈øtocke bee of a rea≈øonable ≈øize for Apricockes e≈øpecially, and not too ≈ømall, that the graft ouergrow not the ≈øtocke, and that the ≈øtocke bee large enough to nouri≈øh the graft. As your Plum ≈øtockes ≈øerue to graft both Apricockes and Plummes, ≈øo doe they ≈øerue al≈øo very well to graft Peaches of all ≈øorts; and although Peach ≈øtockes will ≈øerue to be grafted with Peaches againe, yet the Peach ≈øtocke (as I ≈øaid before) will not endure ≈øo long as the Plumme ≈øtocke, and therefore ≈øerueth but for nece≈ø≈øity if Plum ≈øtocks be not ready, or at hand, or for the pre≈øent time, or that they afterwards may graft that ≈øort of Peach on a Plumme ≈øtocke: for many might lo≈øe a good fruit, if when they meete with it, and haue not Plumme ≈øtockes ready to graft it on, they could not be a≈ø≈øured that it would take vpon another Peach ≈øtocke or branch, or on the branch of an Apricocke eyther. Plumme ≈øtockes will ≈øerue likewi≈øe very well for ≈øome ≈øorts of Nectorins; I ≈øay, for ≈øome ≈øorts, and not for all: the greene and the yellow Nectorin will be≈øt thriue to be grafted immediately on a Plumme ≈øtocke; but the other two ≈øorts of red Nectorins mu≈øt not be immediately grafted on the Plumme ≈øtocke, but vpon a branch of an Apricocke that hath beene formerly grafted on a Plumme ≈øtocke, the nature of the≈øe Nectorins being found by experience to be ≈øo contrary to the Plum ≈øtocke, that it will ≈øterue it, and both dye within a yeare, two or three at the mo≈øt: Diuers haue tryed to graft the≈øe red Nectorins vpon Peach ≈øtockes, and they haue endured well a while; but ≈øeeing the Peach ≈øtocke will not la≈øt long it ≈øelfe, being ouerweake, how can it hold ≈øo ≈øtrong a nature as the≈øe red Nectorins, which will (as I ≈øaid before) ≈øterue a Plum ≈øtocke that is ≈øufficient durable for any other Plumme?

Apricocke ≈øtockes from the ≈øtones are hardly nur≈øed vp, and wor≈øe to be remoued, and if a red Nectorin ≈øhould be grafted on an Apricock ray≈øed from the ≈øtone, and not remoued, I doubt it might happen with it as it doth with many other trees rai≈øed from ≈øtones or kernels, and not remoued, that they would hardly beare fruit: for the nature of mo≈øt trees rai≈øed from ≈øtones or kernels, and not remoued, is to ≈øend great downeright rootes, and not to ≈øpread many forwards; ≈øo that if they be not cut away that others may ≈øpreade abroad, I haue ≈øeldome ≈øeene or known any of them to beare in any rea≈øonable time; and therefore in remouing, the≈øe great downe-right rootes are alwayes ≈øhred away, and thereby made fit to ≈øhoote others forwards. Hereby you may perceiue, that the≈øe red Nectorins will not abide to bee grafted vpon any other ≈øtocke well, then vpon an Apricocke branch, although the green and the yellow (as I ≈øaid before) will well endure and thriue vpon Plums. The ≈øuckers or ≈øhootes both of Plums and Cherries that ri≈øe from their rootes, eyther neare their ≈øtockes, or farther off, ≈øo that they bee taken with ≈øome ≈ømall rootes to them, will ≈øerue to bee ≈øtockes, and will come forward quickly; but if the ≈øuckers haue no ≈ømall roots whereby they may comprehend in the ground, it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible it ≈øhould hold or abide. There is another way to ray≈øe vp eyther ≈øtockes to graft on, or trees without grafting, which is, by circumci≈øing a faire and fit branch in this manner: About Mid≈øomer, when the ≈øappe is thoroughly ri≈øen (or before if the yeare be forward) they v≈øe to binde a good quantity of clay round about a faire and ≈øtraight branch, of a rea≈øonable good ≈øize or bigne≈ø≈øe, with ≈øome conuenient bands, whether it be ropes of hey, or of any other thing, about an handfull aboue the ioynt, where the branch ≈øpreadeth from the tree, and cutting the barke thereof round about vnder the place where the clay is bound, the ≈øap is hereby hindered from ri≈øing, or de≈øcending further then that place ≈øo circumci≈øed, whereby it will ≈øhoote out ≈ømall knubs and rootes into the clay, which they ≈øuffer ≈øo to abide vntill the beginning of winter, whenas with a fine Sawe they cut off that branch where it was circumci≈øed, and afterwardes place it in the ground where they would haue it to grow, and ≈øtake it, and binde it fa≈øt, which will ≈øhoote forth rootes, and will become eyther a faire tree to beare fruite without grafting, or el≈øe a fit ≈øtocke to graft on according
to the kinde: but oftentimes this kinde of propagation mi≈ø≈øeth, in that it ≈øendeth not forth rootes ≈øufficient to cau≈øe it to abide any long time. Let me yet before I leaue this narration of Plummes, giue you one admonition more, that vpon what≈øoeuer Plumme ≈øtocke you doe graft, yet vpon a Dam≈øon ≈øtocke that you neuer ≈øtriue to graft, for it (aboue all other ≈øorts of Plumme ≈øtockes) will neuer giue you a tree worth your labour. It remaineth only of ≈øtone fruit, that I ≈øpeake of Cornelles, which as yet I neuer ≈øaw grafted vpon any ≈øtocke, being as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme vtterly repugnant to the nature thereof, to abide grafting, but is wholly ray≈øed vp (as I ≈øaid before) eyther from the ≈øtones, or from the ≈øuckers or layers. For Peares and Apples your v≈øuall ≈øtockes to graft on are (as I ≈øaid before, ≈øpeaking of the nur≈øing vp of trees from the kernels) your Crabbe ≈øtockes, and they bee accepted in euery Countrey of this Land as they may conueniently be had, yet many doe take the ≈øtockes of better fruit, whether they bee ≈øuckers, or ≈øtockes ray≈øed from the kernels (and the mo≈øt common and knowne way of grafting, is in the ≈øtocke for all ≈øorts of them, although ≈øome doe v≈øe whipping, packing on, or inci≈øing, as euery one li≈øt to call it: but now we doe in many places begin to deale with Peares and Apples as with other ≈øtone fruit, that is, graft them all in the bud, which is found the mo≈øt compendious and ≈øafe≈øt way both to pre≈øerue your ≈øtocke from peri≈øhing, and to bring them the ≈øooner to couer the ≈øtock, as al≈øo to make the goodlier and ≈øtraighter tree, being grafted at what height you plea≈øe:) for tho≈øe ≈øtockes that are ray≈øed from the kernels of good fruit (which are for the mo≈øt part ea≈øily knowne from others, in that they want tho≈øe thornes or prickles the wilde kindes are armed withall:) I ≈øay for the mo≈øt part; for I know that the kernels of ≈øome good fruite hath giuen ≈øtockes with prickles on them (which, as I thinke, was becau≈øe that good fruite was taken from a wilde ≈øtocke that had not beene long enough grafted to alter his wilde nature; for the longer a tree is grafted, the more ≈øtrength the fruite taketh from the graft, and the le≈ø≈øe ≈øtill from the ≈øtocke) being ≈ømoother and fairer then the wilde kinds, mu≈øt needes make a goodlier tree, and will not alter any whit the ta≈øte of your fruit that is grafted thereon, but rather adde ≈øome better relli≈øh thereunto; for the Crabbe ≈øtockes yeelding har≈øh fruite, mu≈øt giue part of their nature to the grafts are ≈øet thereon, and therefore the ta≈øte or relli≈øh, as well as ≈øome other naturall properties of mo≈øt fruits, are ≈øomewhat altered by the ≈øtocke. Another thing I would willingly giue you to vnder≈øtand concerning your fruits and ≈øtockes, that whereas diuers for curio≈øity and to try experiments haue grafted Cherries vpon Plumme ≈øtockes, or Plums on Cherry ≈øtockes, Apples vpon Peare ≈øtockes, and Peares vpon Apple ≈øtockes, ≈øome of the≈øe haue held the graft a yeare, two or three peraduenture, but I neuer knew that euer they held long, or to beare fruite, much le≈ø≈øe to abide or doe well: be≈øtow not therefore your paines and time on ≈øuch contrary natures, vnle≈ø≈øe it be for curio≈øitie, as others haue done: Yet I know that they that graft peares on a white thorne ≈øtocke haue had their grafts ≈øeeme to thriue well, and continue long, but I haue ≈øeldome ≈øeene the fruite thereof an≈øwerable to the naturall wilde Peare ≈øtocke; yet the Medlar is knowne to thriue be≈øt on a white thorne. And la≈øtly, whereas diuers doe affirme that they may haue not only good ≈øtockes to graft vpon, but al≈øo faire trees to bear ≈øtore of fruit from the kernels of Peares or Apples being prickt into the ground, and ≈øuffered to grow without remouing, and then eyther grafted or ≈øuffered to grow into great trees vngrafted; and for their bearing of fruite, a≈ø≈øigne a dozen or twenty yeares from the fir≈øt ≈øetting of the kernels, and abiding vngrafted, I haue not ≈øeene or heard that experience to hold certaine, or if it ≈øhould be ≈øo, yet it is too long time lo≈øt, and too much fruit al≈øo, to waite twenty yeares for that profit may be gained in a great deale of le≈ø≈øe time, and with more certainty. Vnto the≈øe in≈øtructions let mee adde al≈øo one more, which is not much known and v≈øed, and that is, to haue fruit within foure or fiue years from the fir≈øt ≈øowing of your ≈øtones or kernels in this manner: After your ≈øtones or kernels are two or three yeares old, take the faire≈øt toppe or branch, and graft it as you would doe any other cyon taken from a bearing tree, and looke what rare fruite, eyther Peare or Apple, the kernell was of that you ≈øowed, or Peach or Plum &c. the ≈øtone was ≈øet, ≈øuch fruite ≈øhall you haue within two or three yeares at the mo≈øt after the grafting, if it take, and the ≈øtocke be good. And thus may you ≈øee fruit in farre le≈ø≈øe time then to ≈øtay vntill the tree from a kernell or ≈øtone beareth fruit of it ≈øelfe.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. The diuers manners of grafting all ≈øorts of fruits v≈øed in our Land.
div.p: THe mo≈øt v≈øuall manner of grafting in the ≈øtocke is ≈øo common and well known in this Land to euery one that hath any thing to doe with trees or an Orchard, that I think I ≈øhall take vpon mee a needle≈ø≈øe worke to ≈øet downe that is ≈øo well knowne to mo≈øt; yet how common ≈øoeuer it is, ≈øome directions may profit euery one, without which it is not ea≈øily learned. And I doe not ≈øo much ≈øpend my time and paines herein for their ≈øakes that haue knowledge, but for ≈øuch as not knowing would faine be taught priuately, I meane, to reade the rules of the arte ≈øet downe in priuate, when they would refu≈øe to learne of a Gardiner, or other by ≈øight: and yet I di≈øcommend not that way vnto them to learne by ≈øight; for one may ≈øee more in an in≈øtant by ≈øight, then he ≈øhall learn by his own practice in a great while, e≈øpecially if he be a little practi≈øed before he ≈øee a cunning hand to doe it. There are many other kindes of grafting, which ≈øhall be ≈øpoken of hereafter, and peraduenture euen they that know it well, may learne ≈øomething they knew not before.

1. The grafting in the ≈øtocke, is, to ≈øet the ≈øprigge of a good fruit into the body or ≈øtocke of another tree, bee it wilde or other, bee it young or old, to cau≈øe that tree to bring forth ≈øuch fruit as the tree bore from whence you took the ≈øprigge, and not ≈øuch as the ≈øtocke or tree would haue borne, if it had not beene grafted, and is performed in this manner: Looke what tree or ≈øtocke you will chu≈øe to graft on, you mu≈øt with a ≈ømall fine ≈øawe and very ≈øharpe, whip off, or cut off the head or toppe thereof at what height you eyther thinke be≈øt for your purpo≈øe, or conueni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t for the tree: for if you graft a great tree, you cannot without endangering the whole, cut it downe ≈øo low to the ground, as you may without danger doe a ≈ømall tree, or one that is of a rea≈øonable ≈øize; and yet the lower or neerer the ground you graft a young tree, the ≈øafer it is both for your ≈øtocke and graft, becau≈øe the ≈øappe ≈øhall not a≈øcend high, but ≈øoone giue vigour to the graft to take and ≈øhoote quickly: After you haue cut off the toppe of your ≈øtocke, cut or ≈ømooth the head thereof with a ≈øharpe knife, that it may be as plaine and ≈ømooth as you can, and then cleaue it with a hammer or mallet, and with a ≈øtrong knife, cleauer or che≈ø≈øell, either in the middle of it if it be ≈ømall, or of a rea≈øonable ≈øize, or on the ≈øides an inch or more within the barke, if it be great: into both ≈øides of the cleft put your grafts, or into one if the ≈øtocke bee ≈ømaller; which grafts mu≈øt bee made fit for the purpo≈øe on this fa≈øhion: Hauing made choi≈øe of your grafts from the toppe branches e≈øpecially, or from the ≈øides of that tree wherof you would haue the fruit, and that they be of a rea≈øonable good ≈øize, not too ≈ømall or too great for your ≈øtockes, and of one or the ≈øame yeares ≈øhoote; (and yet many doe cut an inch or more of the olde wood with the ≈øprigge of the la≈øt yeares growth, and ≈øo graft the old and young together (but both are good, and the old wood no better then the young) cut your graft not too long, but with two, three or foure eyes or buds at the mo≈øt, which at the lower or bigger end for an inch long or more (for the greater ≈øtockes, and an inch or le≈ø≈øe for the le≈ø≈øer ≈øort) mu≈øt be ≈øo cut, that it be very thin on the one ≈øide from the ≈øhoulders downward, and thicker on the other, and thin al≈øo at the end, that it may goe downe clo≈øe into the cleft, and re≈øt at the ≈øhoulders on the head of the ≈øtocke: but take heede that in cutting your grafts your knife bee very ≈øharpe that you doe not ray≈øe any of the barke, eyther at the ≈øides or the end, for feare of lo≈øing both your paines and graft, and ≈øtocke too peraduenture; and let not your grafts bee made long before you ≈øet them, or el≈øe put the ends of them in water to keepe them fre≈øh and cleane: when you ≈øet them you mu≈øt open the cleft of your ≈øtocke with a wedge or che≈ø≈øell as mo≈øt doe, that the graft may goe ea≈øily into it, and that the barke of both graft and ≈øtocke may ioyne clo≈øe the one to the other, which without ≈øtirring or di≈øplacing mu≈øt bee ≈øo left in the cleft, and the wedge or che≈ø≈øell gently pulled forth; but becau≈øe in the doing hereof con≈øi≈øteth in a manner the whole lo≈ø≈øe or gaine of your paines, graft and ≈øtocke, to preuent which inconuenience I doe v≈øe an iron In≈øtrument, the forme whereof is ≈øhowne in the following
page, marked with the letter A, crooked at both ends, and broade like vnto a che≈ø≈øell, the one bigger, and the other le≈ø≈øer, to fit all ≈øorts of ≈øtockes, and the iron handle ≈øomewhat long betweene them both, that being thru≈øt or knocked downe into the cleft, you may with your left hand open it as wide as is fit to let in your graft, without ≈øtrayning, which being placed, this iron may bee pulled or knocked vp againe without any mouing of your graft: when you haue thus done, you mu≈øt lay a good handfull or more (according to the bigne≈ø≈øe of your ≈øtocke) of ≈øoft and well moi≈øtned clay or loame, well tempered together with ≈øhort cut hey or hor≈øe dung, vpon the head of your ≈øtocke, as lowe or ≈øomewhat lower then the cleft, to keepe out all winde, raine or ayre from your graft vntill Mid≈øomer at the lea≈øt, that the graft be ≈øhot forth ≈øomewhat ≈øtrongly, which then if you plea≈øe may be remoued, and the cleft at the head only filled with a little clay to keepe out earewigs, or other things that may hurt your graft.

list.item: A. The Iron In≈øtrument with che≈ø≈øels at each end, the one bigger and the other le≈ø≈øer, to keepe the cleft of the Tree open vntill the graft bee placed in the ≈øtocke, which with a knock vpwards will be ea≈øily taken away.
B. The ≈ømall Penne-knife with a broad and thinne ended hafte, to rai≈øe the ≈øides both of the bud and the down-right ≈ølit in the body or arme of a Tree to be grafted in the bud.
C. A pen or quil cut halfe round to take off a bud from the branch.
D. An Iuory In≈øtrument made to the ≈øame fa≈øhion.
E. A ≈øhielde of bra≈ø≈øe made hollow before to be put into the ≈ølit, to keepe it open vntill the bud be put into its place.
F. The manner of grafting called inci≈øing or ≈øplicing.
G. A Ladder made with a ≈øtoole at the toppe, to ≈øerue both to graft higher or lower, and al≈øo to gather fruit without ≈øpoyling or hurting any buddes or branches of Trees.
1. The fir≈øt ≈ølit in the body or arme of a Tree to be grafted in the bud with the cro≈ø≈øe cut at the head.
2. The ≈øame ≈ølit opened on both ≈øides, ready to receiue the budde ≈øhould be put therein: the≈øe ≈ømall peeces ≈øerue as well as trees to ≈øhew the manner and order of the grafting.
3. The branch of a Tree with one budde cut ready to be taken off, and another not yet touched.
4. The bud cleane taken off from the branch, both the fore≈øide and back≈øide.
5. The graft or bud now put into the ≈øtocke or tree you intend to be grafted: but the binding thereof is omitted.

figure.figDesc: diagram of grafting tools and techniques

div.p:
2. Inarching is another manner of grafting in the ≈øtocke, and is more trouble≈øome, and more ca≈øuall al≈øo then the former, and is rather a curio≈øity then any way of good ≈øpeede, certainety or profit, and therefore v≈øed but of a few. Yet to ≈øhew you, the
