manner thereof, it is thus: Hauing a tree well growne, bee it high or low, yet the lower the better, with young branches well ≈øpread, they v≈øe to ≈øet ≈øtockes round about it, or on the one ≈øide as you plea≈øe; into which ≈øtockes they ingraft the young branches of the well growne tree as they are growing (before they cut them from the tree) by bowing downe the branch they intend to graft, and putting it into the ≈øtocke, hauing fir≈øt cut off the head thereof, and cut a notch in the middle of the head a little ≈ølope on both ≈øides, wherein the branch mu≈øt be fitted: let the branch be cut thinne on the vnder≈øide, only of that length as may ≈øuffice to fit the notch in the ≈øtocke, leauing about halfe a yarde length of the branch, to ri≈øe aboue or beyond the ≈øtocke, which beeing bound on, and clayed ouer or couered with red or greene ≈øoft waxe, they let ≈øo abide, that if it take in the ≈øtocke they cut off the branch a little below the grafting place in Nouember following, and remouing the ≈øtocke, they haue thus gained a grafted and growne tree the fir≈øt yeare: but it is v≈øually ≈øeene, that where one branch taketh, three doe mi≈ø≈øe: yet this manner of grafting was much in v≈øe for May Cherries, when they were fir≈øt known to vs, and the way thought to be a rare manner of grafting to encrea≈øe them, vntill a better way was found out, which now is ≈øo common and good al≈øo, that this is not now ≈øcarce thought vpon.

3. Another kinde of grafting in the ≈øtocke is called of ≈øome whipping, of ≈øome ≈øplicing, of others inci≈øing, and of others packing on (and as I heare, is much v≈øed in the We≈øt parts e≈øpecially, and al≈øo in the North parts of this Land) and is performed in this manner: Take and ≈ølice the branch of a tree (≈øo as the branch be not too bigge) or el≈øe a young tree of two, or three, or foure yeares growth at the mo≈øt, quite off ≈ølope wi≈øe, about an inch and a halfe long or more, and cut a deep notch in the middle thereof, then fit into it a graft iu≈øt of that ≈øize or bigne≈ø≈øe, cut on both ≈øides with ≈øhoulders, and thin at the end, that it may ioyne clo≈øe in the notch, and neyther bigger or le≈ø≈øer, but that the barke of the one may bee fitted iu≈øt to the barke of the other, the figure wherof is expre≈ø≈øed at the letters E.F. which ≈øhew the one to be with a ≈øhoulder & the other without; binde them gently together with ba≈øt, and put clay or waxe ouer the place, vntill it be taken: this is much v≈øed of late dayes for ≈øuch young trees as are ri≈øen of ≈øtones or kernels after the ≈øecond or third yeares growth, and thriue very well in that it not only ≈øaueth much time, but diuers checks by remouing and grafting.

4. Inoculating or grafting in the budde is another manner of grafting, which is the taking of a budde from one tree, and putting it into the barke of another tree, to the end, that thereby you may haue of the ≈øame kinde of fruit the tree bare from whence the budde was taken; and although it bee ≈øufficiently knowne in many places of this Land, yet as I vnder≈øtand, good Gardiners in the North parts, and likewi≈øe in ≈øome other places, can ≈øcarce tell what it meaneth, or at the lea≈øt how to doe it well. It is performed after a different fa≈øhion from the former, although they all tend vnto one end, which is the propagating of trees. You mu≈øt for this purpo≈øe ob≈øerue, that for tho≈øe trees you would graft, either with, or vpon, you choo≈øe a fit time in Summer, when the ≈øappe is well ri≈øen, and your graft well ≈øhot, that the barke will ri≈øe ea≈øily and cleanly, both of ≈øtocke and graft, which time I cannot appoint, becau≈øe both the years doe differ in earline≈ø≈øe, and the ≈øeuerall parts or countries of this Land likewi≈øe one from another, but mo≈øt v≈øually in the≈øe Southerne parts, from the beginning of Iune vnto the end of it, or to the middle of Iuly, or either ≈øomewhat before or after. Fir≈øt (as I ≈øaid) hauing taken the fitte≈øt time of the yeare, you mu≈øt take e≈øpeciall care, that your grafts be well growne, and of the ≈øame yeares ≈øhoote, and al≈øo that the buds or eyes haue but ≈øingle leaues at them, as neare as you can: for I would vtterly refu≈øe tho≈øe buds that haue aboue two leaues as vnprofitable, either in Peaches or any other fruit; and therefore ≈øee that your grafts or cyons bee taken from the chiefe≈øt place of the tree, that is, either from the toppe, or from a ≈øunnie ≈øide thereof, and not from the contrarie ≈øide if you may otherwi≈øe, nor from any vnder-boughes; for ≈øeeing your graft is ≈øo ≈ømall a thing, you had neede take the more care that it be the be≈øt and faire≈øt. You mu≈øt to take off this eye or budde from the ≈øprigge, haue a ≈ømall ≈øharpe pen-knife, the end of the haft being made flat and thinne, like a che≈ø≈øell or wedge, the figure whereof is ≈øet forth at the letter B, and a pen or goo≈øe quill cut, to be le≈ø≈øe then halfe round, and to be broad at the end, but not ≈øharpe pointed like a penne, or el≈øe ≈øuch a peece of bone or Iuorie made in that fa≈øhion as the quill is, to bee thinne, hollow, or
halfe round, the figures of both which are marked with the letters C, D. with your knife cut the barke of the bud (hauing fir≈øt cut off the leafe, leauing onely the ≈øhort foote-≈øtalke thereof at the bud) about a ≈øtrawes breadth aboue the eye thereof halfe round, and then from that round or ouerthwart cut, with your knife cut it downe on both ≈øides of the eye, clo≈øe to the bud ≈ølopewi≈øe about an inch long or thereabouts, that it bee broad at the head aboue the eye, and pointing at the end like a ≈øheild or ≈øcutcheon; and then cutting away the re≈øt of the barke from about it, with the thinne flat end of the haft of your knife rai≈øe vp both ≈øides of your bud a little, and with your quill or bone put vnder the barke, rai≈øe your budde, and thru≈øt it quite off, beginning at the toppe or head of your eye; but ≈øee that you thru≈øt it off clo≈øe to the wood of the branch or ≈øprigge, and that you doe not leaue the eye of the budde behinde ≈øticking vpon the branch; for if that eye be left or lo≈øt, your bud is worth nothing; you mu≈øt ca≈øt it away, and cut another that may haue that eye abiding within the budde on the in≈øide: you may perceiue if that eye be wanting, if you ≈øee an emptie hole in the place where the eye ≈øhould be, to fill it vp on the in≈øide thereof; thus hauing taken off your bud well and cleanly, which is ≈øet forth vnto you at the figures 3 and 4. pre≈øently ≈øet it on the tree you would graft (for your ≈ømall bud can abide no delay, le≈øt by taking the ayre too long it become dry, and nothing worth) in this manner: Cut the barke of your tree you would graft in a ≈ømooth place, at what height you plea≈øe, fir≈øt aboue or ouerthwart, and then downe right in the middle thereof, more then an inch long, the figure whereof you ≈øhall haue at the figure 1. and then rai≈øe vp both ≈øides of the barke, fir≈øt one, and then another, with the flat and thinne haft end of your knife, a prettie way inwards (for if the barke will not ri≈øe ea≈øily, the ≈øtocke is not then fit to graft vpon) put in your budde into the cleft with the point downewards, holding the ≈øtalke of the leafe that is with the budde betweene your fingers of the one hand, and opening the cleft with the flat end of your knife with the other hand, that the head of your bud may be put clo≈øe vnder the ouerthwart cut in the ≈øtocke or tree (which mu≈øt not be rai≈øed or ≈øtirred as the ≈øides are) & the eye of the bud ≈øtand iu≈øt in the middle of the ≈ølit that is downeright, and then clo≈øing the barke of the ≈øtocke or tree ≈øoftly vnto the bud thus put in with your fingers, let it be bound gently with a ≈ømall long peece of ba≈øte, or other ≈øuch like ≈øoft thing, fir≈øt aboue the eye, & then compa≈ø≈øing it belowe as clo≈øe as you can, but not too hard in any ca≈øe, vntil you haue bound it all ouer the ≈ølit you made, e≈øpecially the lower end, le≈øt any winde get in to dry and ≈øpoile it; and hauing tyed both ends thereof fa≈øt, leaue it ≈øo for a fornight or ≈øomewhat more, in which ≈øpace it will take and hold, if it be well done, which you ≈øhall perceiue, if the bud abide green, and turne not blacke, when you haue vnloo≈øed the tying; for if it hold fa≈øt to the tree, and be fre≈øh and good, tye it vp gently againe, and ≈øo leaue it for a fortnight longer, or a moneth if you will, and then you may take away your binding cleane: this budde will (if no other mi≈øchance happen vnto it) ≈øpring and ≈øhoote forth the next yeare, (and ≈øometimes the ≈øame yeare, but that is ≈øeldome) and therefore in the beginning of the yeare, cut off the head of the grafted tree about an handfull aboue the grafted place, vntill the graft be growne ≈øtrong, and then cut it off clo≈øe, that the head may be couered with the graft, and doe not ≈øuffer any buds to ≈øprout be≈øides the graft, either aboue or belowe it. If you graft diuers buds vpon one ≈øtocke (which is the be≈øt way) let that onely remaine and abide that ≈øhooteth be≈øt forth, and rubbe off, or take away the other: the ≈øeuerall parts of this grafting I haue cau≈øed to be expre≈ø≈øed for your further information.

5. Grafting in the ≈øcutcheon is accounted another kinde of grafting, and differeth verie little from grafting in the budde: the difference chiefly con≈øi≈øteth in this, that in ≈øtead of the downe right ≈ølit, and that aboue ouerthwart, they take away iu≈øt ≈øo much barke of the great tree, as your bud is in bigne≈ø≈øe, which v≈øually is a little larger then the former, and placing it therein, they binde it as formerly is ≈øaid: ≈øome v≈øe for this purpo≈øe a paire of compa≈ø≈øes, to giue the true mea≈øure both of bud and ≈øtocke; this manner of grafting is mo≈øt v≈øed vpon greater trees, who≈øe young branches are too high to graft vpon in the former maner, and who≈øe tops they cut off (for the mo≈øt part) at the latter end of the next yeare after the bud is taken: both the≈øe waies were inuented to ≈øaue the lo≈ø≈øe of trees, which are more endangered by grafting in the ≈øtocke,
then any of the≈øe waies; and be≈øides, by the≈øe waies you may graft at a farre grea height without lo≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the manner of grafting and propagating all ≈øorts of Ro≈øes.
div.p: HAuing now ≈øpoken of the grafting of trees, let mee adioyne the properties of Ro≈øes, which although they better fit a Garden then an Orchard, yet I could not in a fitter place expre≈ø≈øe them then here, both for the name and affinity of grafting, & becau≈øe I do not expre≈ø≈øe it in the fir≈øt part. All ≈øorts of Ro≈øes may be grafted (although all ≈øorts are not, ≈øome ≈øeruing rather for ≈øtockes for others to be grafted on) as ea≈øily as any other tree, & is only performed, by inoculating in the ≈øame maner I haue ≈øet downe in the former Chapter of grafting trees in the bud; for both ≈øtocke and budde mu≈øt bee dealt with after the ≈øame fa≈øhion. And although ≈øome haue boa≈øted of grafting Ro≈øes by ≈ølicing or whipping, as they call it, or in the ≈øtocke, after the fir≈øt manner, ≈øet downe in the former Chapter, yet I thinke it rather a bragge, not hauing ≈øeene or heard any true effect proceede from that relation. The ≈øweete Briar or Eglantine, the white and the Damaske Ro≈øes, are the chiefe≈øt ≈øtockes to graft vpon. And if you graft lowe or neare the ground, you may by laying downe that graft within the ground, after it hath bin ≈øhot out well, and of a years growth, by pinning it fa≈øt downe with ≈øhort ≈øtickes, a thwart or acro≈ø≈øe, cau≈øe that grafted branch, by taking roote, to become a naturall Ro≈øe, ≈øuch as the graft was, which being ≈øeparated and tran≈øplanted after it hath taken root wel, will pro≈øper as well as any naturall ≈øucker. And in this maner, by laying downe branchese at length into the ground, if they be full of ≈øpreading ≈ømall branches, you may increa≈øe all ≈øorts of Ro≈øes quickly and plentifully; for they will ≈øhoote forth rootes at the ioynt of euery branch: But as for the manner of grafting white Ro≈øes or Damaske vpon Broome ≈øtalkes or Barbary bu≈øhes, to cau≈øe them to bring forth double yellow Ro≈øes, or vpon a Willowe, to beare greene Ro≈øes, they are all idle conceits, as impo≈ø≈øible to be effected, as other things, whereof I haue ≈øpoken in the ninth Chapter of my fir≈øt part, concerning a Garden of flowers, vnto which I referre you to be ≈øatisfied with the rea≈øons there alledged. And it is the more needle≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe we haue a naturall double yellow Ro≈øe of it owne growing. The ≈øowing of the ≈øeedes of Ro≈øes (which are ≈øometimes found vpon mo≈øt ≈øorts of Ro≈øes, although not euery yeare, and in euerie place) hath bin formerly much v≈øed; but now the laying downe of the young ≈øhootes is a way for increa≈øe ≈øo much v≈øed, being ≈øafe and verie ≈øpeedie to take, e≈øpecially for tho≈øe Ro≈øes that are not ≈øo apt to giue ≈øuckers, that it hath almo≈øt taken quite away the v≈øe of ≈øowing of the ≈øeedes of Ro≈øes, which yet if anie one bee di≈øpo≈øed to make the triall, they mu≈øt gather the ≈øeede out of the round heads, from among≈øt the doune, wherein they lye verie like vnto the berries of the Eglantine or ≈øweete Briar bu≈øh, and e≈øpecially of tho≈øe Ro≈øes that bee of the more ≈øingle kindes, which are more apt to giue berries for ≈øeed then the more double, although ≈øometimes the double Ro≈øes yeeld the like heads or berries. Their time of ≈øowing is in the end of September (yet ≈øome re≈øerue them vntill February) and their manner of nour≈øing is to bee tran≈øplanted, after the fir≈øt or ≈øecond yeares growth, and tended carefully, that while they are young they be not lo≈øt for want of moi≈øture in the dry time of Summer.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Certaine rules and ob≈øeruations in and after grafting, not remembred in the former Chapter.
div.p:
THe time of ≈øome manners of grafting being not mentioned before, mu≈øt here be ≈øpoken of. For the grafting of all ≈øorts of trees in the ≈øtocke, the mo≈øt v≈øuall time is from the middle of February vntill the middle of March, as the yeare and the countrie is more forward or backward, with vs about London wee neuer pa≈ø≈øe midde March: but becau≈øe the May Cherrie is fir≈øt ripe, and therefore of a very forward nature, it doth require to be grafted ≈øomewhat ≈øooner then others. The time of gathering likewi≈øe, or cutting your grafts for grafting in the ≈øtocke, is to be ob≈øerued, that they bee not long gathered before they bee grafted, for feare of being too dry, which I commend, how≈øoeuer diuers ≈øay, if they be long kept they are not the wor≈øe; and therefore if you be forced to haue your grafts from farre, or by ≈øome other chance to keepe them long, be carefull to keepe them moi≈øt, by keeping their ends ≈øtucke in moi≈øt clay; but if neare hand, neglect no time I ≈øay after the cutting of them for their grafting, but either the ≈øame, or the next day, or verie ≈øpeedily after, in the meane time being put into the ground to keepe them fre≈øh. The grafts taken from old trees, becau≈øe they are ≈øtronger, and ≈øhoote forth ≈øooner, are to bee ≈øooner grafted then tho≈øe that are taken from younger trees: of a good branch may bee made two, and ≈øometimes three grafts ≈øufficient for anie rea≈øonable ≈øtocke. For whipping, the time is ≈øomewhat later then grafting in the ≈øtocke, becau≈øe it is performed on younger trees, which (as I ≈øaid before) doe not ≈øo early bud or ≈øhoote forth as the elder. Inarching likewi≈øe is performed much about the later end of the grafting time in the ≈øtocke; for being both kindes thereof they require the ≈øame time of the yeare. The times of the other manners of graftings are before expre≈ø≈øed, to bee when they haue ≈øhot forth young branches, from whence your buds mu≈øt be taken; and therefore need not here againe to be repeated. If a graft in the ≈øtocke doth happen not to ≈øhoote forth when others do (≈øo as it holdeth green) it may perchance ≈øhoot out a moneth or two after, & do well, or el≈øe after Mid≈øummer, when a ≈øecond time of ≈øhooting, or the after Spring appeareth: but haue an e≈øpeciall care, that you take not ≈øuch a graft that ≈øhal haue nothing but buds for flowers vpon it, and not an eye or bud for leaues (which you mu≈øt be carefull to di≈øtingui≈øh) for ≈øuch a graft after it hath ≈øhot out the flowers mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie dye, not hauing wherewith to maintaine it ≈øelfe. Al≈øo if your good graft doe mi≈ø≈øe, and not take, it doth hazzard your ≈øtocke at the fir≈øt time, yet manie ≈øtockes doe recouer to be grafted the ≈øecond time; but twice to faile is deadly, which is not ≈øo in the inoculating of buds in the greene tree: for if you faile therein three, or three times three, yet euerie wound being ≈ømall, and the tree ≈øtill growing greene, will quickly recouer it, and not be afterwards ≈øeen. Some v≈øe to graft in the ≈øtocke the ≈øame yeare they remoue the ≈øtocke, to ≈øaue time, & a ≈øecond checke by grafting; but I like better both in grafting in the ≈øtocke, and in the bud al≈øo, that your trees might be planted in the places where you would haue them growe, for a yeare or two at the lea≈øt before you graft them, that after grafting there ≈øhould be no remouall, I neede not be tedious, not yet I hope verie ≈øollicitous to remember many other triuiall, or at the lea≈øt common knowne things in this matter. Fir≈øt, for the time to remoue trees, young or old, grafted or vngrafted, to be from a fortnight after Michaelmas vntill Candlemas, or if neede be, ≈øomewhat after, yet the ≈øooner your remoue is, the better your trees will thriue, except it be in a very moi≈øt ground. For the manner or way to ≈øet them: viz. in the high and dry grounds ≈øet them deeper, both to haue the more moi≈øture, and to be the better defended from windes; and in the lower and moi≈øter grounds ≈øhallower, and that the earth be mellow, well turned vp, and that the finer earth bee put among the ≈ømall rootes, wherein they may ≈øpread, and afterwards gently troden downe, that no hollowne≈ø≈øe remaine among the rootes: as al≈øo that after ≈øetting (if the time be not ouermoi≈øt) there may be ≈øome water powred to the rootes, to moi≈øten and fa≈øten them the better; and in the dry time of Summer, after the ≈øetting, let them not want moi≈øture, if you will
haue them thriue and pro≈øper; for the want thereof at that time, hath often Killed manie a likely tree. To ≈øtake and fence them al≈øo if neede bee after they are new ≈øet, and ≈øo to continue for two or three yeares after, is verie expedient, le≈øt windes or other ca≈øualties ≈øpoile your paines, and ouerthrow your hopes. And likewi≈øe to defend your grafts from birds lighting on them, to breake or di≈øplace them, to ≈øticke ≈øome prickes or ≈øharpe pointed ≈øtickes longer then your graft into your clay, that ≈øo they may be a ≈øure defence of it: As al≈øo to tye ≈øome woollen cloathes about the lower end of your ≈øtockes, or thru≈øt in ≈øome thornes into the ground about the rootes, to defend them from hauing their barkes eaten by
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nies, er hurt by ≈øome other noi≈øome vermine.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Ob≈øeruations for the dre≈øsing and well keeping of Trees and an Orchard in good order.
div.p:
THere are two manner of waies to dre≈ø≈øe and keepe trees in good order, that they may bee both gracefull and fruitfull; the one is for wall-trees, the other is for ≈øtandards: for as their formes are different, ≈øo is their keeping or ordering. Wall trees, becau≈øe they are grafted lowe, and that their branches mu≈øt be pla≈øht or tackt vnto the wall to fa≈øten them, are to be ≈øo kept, that all their branches may be ≈øuffered to growe, that ≈øhoote forth on eithet ≈øide of the bodie, and led either along the wall, or vpright, and one to lappe ouer or vnder another as is convenient, and ≈øtill with peeces of li≈øts, parings of felt, peeces of ≈øoft leather, or other ≈øuch like ≈øoft thing compa≈ø≈øing the armes or branches, fa≈øtened with ≈ømall or great nailes, as neede requireth, to the wals, onely tho≈øe buds or branches are to be nipped or cut off, that ≈øhoot forward, and will not ≈øo hand≈øomely be brought into conformity, as is fitting; yet if the branches growe too thicke, to hinder the good of the re≈øt, or too high for the wall, they may, nay they mu≈øt be cut away or lopped off: and if anie dead branches al≈øo happen to be on the trees, they mu≈øt be cut away, that the re≈øt may haue the more libertie to thriue. Diuers al≈øo by carefully nipping away the wa≈øte and ≈øuperfluous buds, doe keepe their trees in conformity, without much cutting. The time to pruine or pla≈øh, or tye vp wall trees, is v≈øually from the fall of the leafe, to the beginning of the yeare, when they begin to blo≈ø≈øome, and mo≈øt e≈øpecially a little before or after Chri≈øtmas: but in any ca≈øe not too late, for feare of rubbing off their buds. Some I know doe pla≈øh and tye vp their wall trees after bearing time, while the leaues are greene, and their rea≈øon is, the buds are not ≈øo ea≈øie or apt to bee rubbed from the branches at that time, as at Chri≈øtmas, when they are more growne: but the leaues mu≈øt needes be very cumber≈øome, to hinder much both the orderly placing, and clo≈øe fa≈øtening of them to the wall. This labour you mu≈øt performe euery yeare in its due time; for if you ≈øhall neglect and ouer≈ølip it, you ≈øhall haue much more trouble, to bring them into a fit order againe, then at the fir≈øt. The ≈øtandard trees in an Orchard mu≈øt be kept in another order; for whereas the former are ≈øuffered to ≈øpread at large, the≈øe mu≈øt be pruined both from ≈øuperfluous branches that ouerload the trees, & make them le≈ø≈øe fruitfull, as well as le≈ø≈øe ≈øightly, and the vnder or water boughes likewi≈øe, that drawe much nouri≈øhment from the trees, and yet them≈øelues little the better for it, I meane to giue fruit. If therefore your Orchard con≈øi≈øt of young trees, with a little care and paines it may bee kept in that comely order and proportion it was fir≈øt de≈øtined vnto; but if it con≈øi≈øt of old growne trees, they will not without a great deale of care and paines be brought into ≈øuch conformitie, as is befitting good and comely trees: for the marke of tho≈øe boughes or branches that are cut off from young trees, will quickly be healed againe, the barke growing quickly ouer them, whereby they are not wor≈øe for their cutting; but an old tree if you cut off a bough, you mu≈øt cut it clo≈øe and cleanly, and lay a ≈øearcloth of tallow, waxe, and a little pitch melted together vpon the place, to keepe off both the winde, ≈øunne, and raine, vntill the barke haue couered it ouer againe: and in this manner you mu≈øt deale withall ≈øuch ≈øhort ≈øtumps of branches, as are either broken ≈øhort off with the winde, or by carele≈øne≈ø≈øe of
want of skill, or el≈øe ≈øuch armes or branches as are broken off clo≈øe, or ≈øliued from the body of the tree: for the raine beating and falling into ≈øuch a place, will in ≈øhort time rotte your tree, or put it in danger, be≈øides the deformity. Some v≈øe to fill vp ≈øuch an hole with well tempered clay, and tacke a cloth or a peece of leather ouer it vntill it be recouered, and this is al≈øo not ami≈ø≈øe. Your young trees, if they ≈øtand in anie good ground, will bee plentifull enough in ≈øhooting forth branches; bee carefull therefore if they growe too thicke, that you pruine away ≈øuch as growe too clo≈øe (and will, if they be ≈øuffered, ≈øpoile one another) as they may be be≈øt ≈øpared, that ≈øo the ≈øunne, ayre, and raine may haue free acce≈ø≈øe to all your branches, which will make them beare the more plentifully, and ripen them the ≈øooner and the more kindly. If anie boughes growe at the toppe too high, cut them al≈øo away, that your trees may rather ≈øpread then growe too high. And ≈øo likewi≈øe for the vnder boughes, or anie other that by the weight of fruit fall or hang downe, cut them off at the halfe, and they will afterwards ri≈øe and ≈øhoote vpwards. You ≈øhall ob≈øerue, that at all tho≈øe places where anie branches haue been cut away, the ≈øappe will euer bee readie to put forth: if therefore you would haue no more branches ri≈øe from that place, rubbe off or nippe off ≈øuch buddes as are not to your minde, when they are new ≈øhot: and thus you may keep your trees in good order with a little paines, after you haue thus pruined and dre≈ø≈øed them. One other thing I would aduerti≈øe you of, and that is how to pre≈øerue a fainting or decaying tree which is readie to peri≈øh, if it be not gone too farre or pa≈øt cure, take a good quantitie of oxe or hor≈øe bloud, mixe therewith a rea≈øonable quantitie of ≈øheepe or pigeons dung, which being laid to the roote, will by the often raines and much watering recouer it ≈øelfe, if there bee anie po≈ø≈øibilitie; but this mu≈øt bee done in Ianuarie or Februarie at the furthe≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Diuers other ob≈øeruations to be remembred in the well keeping of an Orchard.
div.p:
THere be diuers other things to be mentioned, whereof care mu≈øt be had, either to doe or auoide, which I thinke fit in this Chapter promi≈øcuou≈øly to ≈øet down, that there may be nothing wanting to furni≈øh you with ≈øufficient knowledge of the care, paines, and ca≈øualties that befall an Orchard: for it hath many enemies, and euery one laboureth as much as in them lye, to ≈øpoile you of your plea≈øure, or profit, or both, which mu≈øt bee both ≈øpeedily and carefully preuented and helped; and they are the≈øe: Mo≈ø≈øe, Caterpillars, Ants, Earwigs, Snailes, Moales, and Birds. If Mo≈ø≈øe begin to ouergrowe your trees, looke to it betimes, le≈øt it make your trees barren: Some v≈øe to hacke, and cro≈ø≈øehacke, or cut the barke of the bodies of their trees, to cau≈øe it fall away; but I feare it may endanger your trees. Others do either rubbe it off with a haire cloth, or with a long peece of wood formed like a knife, at the end of a long ≈øticke or pole, which if it bee v≈øed cautelou≈øly without hurting the buds, I like better. Caterpillars, ≈øome ≈ømoake them with burning wet ≈øtrawe or hay, or ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe vnder the trees; but I doe not greatly like of that way: others cut off the boughes whereon they breed, and tread them vnder their feete, but that will ≈øpoile too manie branches; and ≈øome kill them with their hands: but ≈øome doe v≈øe a new deui≈øed way, that is, a pompe made of lattin or tin, ≈øpout-fa≈øhion, which being ≈øet in a tubbe of water vnder or neare your trees, they will cau≈øe the water to ri≈øe through it with ≈øuch a force, and through the branches, that it will wa≈øh them off quickly. To de≈øtroy Ants, that eate your fruit before and when it is ripe, ≈øome v≈øe to annoint the bodies of their trees with tarre, that they may not creepe vp on the branches; but if that doe not helpe, or you will not v≈øe it, you mu≈øt be carefull to finde out their hill, and turne it vp, pouring in ≈øcalding water, either in Summer, but e≈øpecially if you can in Winter, and that will ≈øurely de≈øtroy them. I haue ≈øpoken of Earwigs in the fir≈øt part of this worke, entreating of the annoyances of Gilloflowers, and therefore I referre you thereunto: yet one way more I
will here relate which ≈øome doe v≈øe, and that is with hollow canes of halfe a yard long or more, open at both ends for them to creepe in, and ≈øtucke or laid among the branches of your trees, will ≈øoone drawe into them many Earwigs, which you may ≈øoone kill, by knocking the cane a little vpon the ground, and treading on them with your foote. Snailes mu≈øt be taken with your hands, and that euerie day, e≈øpecially in the morning when they will be creeping abroad. Moales by running vnder your trees make them le≈ø≈øe fruitfull, and al≈øo put them in danger to be blowne downe, by leauing the ground hollow, that thereby the rootes haue not that ≈øtrength in the ground, both to ≈øhoote and to hold, that otherwi≈øe they might haue. Some haue v≈øed to put Garlicke, and other ≈øuch like things into their holes, thinking thereby to driue them away, but to no purpo≈øe: others haue tryed manie other waies; but no way doth auaile anie thing, but killing them either with a Moale ≈øpade, or a trappe made for the purpo≈øe as manie doe know: and they mu≈øt bee watched at their principall hill, and trenched round, and ≈øo to be caught. Birds are another enemie both to your trees and fruit; for the Bullfinch will de≈øtroy all your ≈øtone fruit in the budde, before they flower, if you ≈øuffer them, and Crowes, &c. when your Cherries are ripe: for the ≈ømaller birds, Lime twigs ≈øet either neare your trees, or at the next water where they drinke, will helpe to catch them and de≈øtroy them. And for the greater birds, a ≈øtone bowe, a birding or fowling peece will helpe to le≈ø≈øen their number, and make the re≈øt more quiet: or a mill with a clacke to ≈øcarre them away, vntill your fruit be gathered. Some other annoyances there are, as ≈øuckers that ri≈øe from the rootes of your trees, which mu≈øt be taken away euerie yeare, and not ≈øuffered to growe anie thing great, for feare of robbing your trees of their liuelihood. Barke bound, is when a tree doth not ≈øhoote and encrea≈øe, by rea≈øon the barke is as it were drie, and will not ≈øuffer the ≈øappe to pa≈ø≈øe vnto the branches: take a knife therefore, and ≈ølit the barke downe almo≈øt all the length of the tree in two or three places, and it will remedy that euill, and the tree will thriue and come forward the better after. Barke pilled is another euill that happeneth to ≈øome trees, as well young as old, either by rea≈øon of ca≈øuall hurts, or by the gnawing of bea≈øts, how≈øoeuer it bee, if it bee anie great hurt, lay a plai≈øter thereon made of tallow, tarre, and a little pitch, and binde it thereto, letting it ≈øo abide vntill the wound bee healed: yet ≈øome doe only apply a little clay or loame bound on with ropes of hay. The Canker is a ≈øhrewd di≈øea≈øe when it happeneth to a tree; for it will eate the barke round, and ≈øo kill the very heart in a little ≈øpace. It mu≈øt be looked vnto in time before it hath runne too farre; mo≈øt men doe wholly cut away as much as is fretted with the Canker, and then dre≈ø≈øe it, or wet it with vinegar or Cowes pi≈ø≈øe, or Cowes dung and vrine, &c. vntill it be de≈øtroyed, and after healed againe with your ≈øalue before appointed. There are yet ≈øome other enemies to an Orchard: for if your fence be not of bricke or ≈øtone, but either a mudde wall, or a quicke ≈øet or dead hedge, then looke to it the more carefully, and preuent the comming in of either hor≈øe, or kine, ≈øheepe, goates, or deere, hare, or conie; for ≈øome of them will breake through or ouer to barke your trees, and the lea≈øt hole almo≈øt in the hedge will giue admittance to hares and conies to doe the like. To preuent all which, your care mu≈øt be continuall to watch them or auoide them, and to ≈øtoppe vp their entrance. A dogge is a good ≈øeruant for many ≈øuch purpo≈øes, and ≈øo is a ≈øtone bowe, and a peece to make v≈øe of as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerue. But if you will take that medicine for a Canker ≈øpoken of before, which is Cowes dung and vrine mixed together, and with a bru≈øh wa≈øh your trees often to a rea≈øonable height, will keepe hares and conies from eating or barking your trees. Great and cold windes doe often make a great ≈øpoile in an Orchard, but great trees planted without the compa≈ø≈øe thereof, as Wall-nuts, Oakes, Elmes, A≈øhes, and the like, will ≈øtand it in great ≈øtead, to defend it both early and late. Thus haue I ≈øhewed you mo≈øt of the euils that may happen to an Orchard, and the meanes to helpe them, and becau≈øe the number is great and daily growing, the care and paines mu≈øt be continuall, the more earne≈øt and diligent, le≈øt you lo≈øe that in a moment that hath been growing many yeares, or at the lea≈øt the profit or beauty of ≈øome yeares fruit.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The manner and way how to plant, order, and keepe other trees that beare greene leaues continually.
div.p:
THe way to order tho≈øe trees that beare their leaues greene continually, is differing from all others that doe not ≈øo: for neyther are they to bee planted or remoued at the time that all other trees are ≈øet, nor doe they require that manner of dre≈ø≈øing, pruining and keeping, that others doe. And although many ignorant per≈øons and Gardiners doe remoue Bay trees, and are ≈øo likewi≈øe per≈øwaded that all other trees of that nature, that is, that carry their greene leaues continually, may bee remoued in Autumne or Winter, as well as all other trees may bee; yet it is certaine it is a great chance if they doe thriue and pro≈øper that are ≈øet at that time, or rather it is found by experience, that ≈øcarce one of ten pro≈øpereth well that are ≈øo ordered. Now in regard that there be diuers trees and ≈øhrubs mentioned here in this booke that beare euer greene leaues, wherein there is very great beauty, and many take plea≈øure in them; as the ordinary Bay, the Ro≈øe Bay, and the Cherry Bay trees, the Indian Figge, the Cypre≈ø≈øe, the Pine tree, the Mirtle and dwarfe Boxe, and many others; I will here ≈øhew you how to plant and order them, as is fitte≈øt for them. For in that they doe not ≈øhed their greene leaues in winter as other trees doe, you may in rea≈øon be per≈øwaded that they are of another nature; and ≈øo they are indeede: for ≈øeeing they all grow naturally in warme Countries, and are from thence brought vnto vs, we mu≈øt both plant them in a warmer place, and tran≈øplant them in a warmer time then other trees be, or el≈øe it is a great hazzard if they doe not peri≈øh and dye, the cold and fro≈øts in the winter being able to pierce them through, if they ≈øhould bee tran≈øplanted in winter, before they haue taken roote. You mu≈øt ob≈øerue and take this therefore for a certaine rule, that you alwaies remoue ≈øuch trees or ≈øhrubbes as are euer greene in the ≈øpring of the yeare, and at no time el≈øe if you will doe well, that is, from the end of March, or beginning of Aprill, vnto the middle or end of May, e≈øpecially your more dainty and tender plants, ≈øhadowing them al≈øo for a while from the heate of the Sun, and giuing them a little water vpon their planting or tran≈øplanting; but ≈øuch water as hath not pre≈øently been drawn from a Well or Pumpe, for that will go neer to kill any plant, but ≈øuch water as hath ≈øtood in the open ayre for a day at the lea≈øt, if not two or three. Yet for dwarfe Boxe I confe≈ø≈øe it may endure one moneth to be earlier planted then the re≈øt, becau≈øe it is both a more hardy and lowe plant, and thereby not ≈øo much ≈øubiect to the extremitie of the colde: but if you ≈øhould plant it before winter, the fro≈øts would rai≈øe it out of the ground, becau≈øe it cannot ≈øo ≈øoone at that time of the yeare take roote, and thereby put it in danger to be lo≈øt. Moreouer all of them will not abide the extremitie of our winter fro≈øts, and therefore you mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity hou≈øe ≈øome of them, as the Ro≈øe Bay, Mirtle, and ≈øome others, but the other ≈øorts being ≈øet where they may bee ≈øomewhat defended from the cold windes, fro≈øtes, and ≈ønow in winter, with ≈øome couering or ≈øhelter for the time, will rea≈øonably well endure and beare their fruit, or the mo≈øt of them. If any be de≈øirous to be furni≈øhed with ≈øtore of the≈øe kinds of trees that will be nour≈øed vp in our Country, he may by ≈øowing the ≈øeed of them in ≈øquare or long woodden boxes or che≈øts made for that purpo≈øe, gaine plenty of them: but hee mu≈øt be carefull to couer them in winter with ≈øome ≈øtraw or fearne, or beane hame, or ≈øuch like thing layd vpon cro≈ø≈øe ≈øticks to beare it vp from the plants, and after two or three yeares that they are growne ≈øomewhat great and ≈øtrong, they may bee tran≈øplanted into ≈øuch places you meane they ≈øhall abide: yet it is not ami≈ø≈øe to defend them the fir≈øt yeare after they are tran≈øplanted, for their more ≈øecuritie: the ≈øeedes that are mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øowen with vs, are, the Cypre≈ø≈øe tree, the Pine tree, the Baye, the Pyracantha or prickly Corall tree, and the Mirtle: the Ro≈øe Bay I haue had al≈øo ri≈øen from the ≈øeede that was fre≈øh, and brought me from Spaine. But as for Orenge trees, becau≈øe they are ≈øo hardly pre≈øerued in this our cold climate (vnle≈ø≈øe it bee with ≈øome that doe be≈øtow the hou≈øing of them, be≈øides a great deale more of care and re≈øpect vnto them) from the bitterne≈ø≈øe of our cold long winter weather (although their
kernels being put into the ground in the Spring or Summer, and if care bee had of them and conuenient keeping, will abide, and by grafting the good fruite on the crab ≈øtocke they may bee in time nur≈øed vp) I doe not make any other e≈øpeciall account of them, nor giue you any further relation of their ordering. Now for the ordering of the≈øe trees after they are eyther planted of young ≈øets, or tran≈øplanted from the ≈øeede, it is thus: Fir≈øt for Bay trees, the mo≈øt v≈øuall way is to let them grow vp high to bee trees, and many plant them on the North or Ea≈øt ≈øide of their hou≈øes that they may not bee ≈øcorched with the Sunne; but the bitter winters which we often haue, doe pinch them ≈øhrewdly, in≈øomuch that it killeth euen well growne trees ≈øometimes downe to the roote: but ≈øome doe make a hedge of them being planted in order, and keep them low by lopping of them continually, which will make them bu≈øh and ≈øpread. The Cypre≈ø≈øe tree is neuer lopped, but ≈øuffered to grow with all the branches from a foote aboue the ground, if it may be, ≈øtraight vpright; for that is his natiue grace and greate≈øt beautie, and therefore the more branches doe dye that they mu≈øt bee cut away, the more you deforme his propertie. The Pine tree may be v≈øed in the ≈øame manner, but yet it wil better endure to ≈øu≈øtaine pruining then the Cypre≈ø≈øe, without any ≈øuch deformitie. The Laurocera≈øus or Cherry Bay may be diuer≈øly formed, that is, it may be either made to grow into a tall tree by ≈øhredding ≈øtill away the vnder branches, or el≈øe by ≈øuffering all the branches to grow to be a low or hedge bu≈øh, & both by the ≈øuckers and by laying downe the lower branches into the earth, you may ≈øoone haue much increa≈øe; but this way will cau≈øe it to bee the longer before it beare anie fruit. The Ro≈øe Baye will verie hardlie bee encrea≈øed either by ≈øuckers or by layers, but mu≈øt bee ≈øuffered to grow without lopping, topping or cutting. The Pyracantha or Prickly Corall tree may bee made to grow into a rea≈øonable tall tree by ≈øhredding away the lower branches, or it may be ≈øuffered to grow lowe into an hedge bu≈øh, by ≈øuffering all the branches to grow continually, you may al≈øo propagate it by the ≈øuckers, or by laying downe the lower branches. The Myrtle of all ≈øorts abideth a low bu≈øh ≈øpreading his branches full of ≈øweete leaues and flowers, without anie great encrea≈øe of it ≈øelfe, yet ≈øometimes it giueth ≈øuckers or ≈øhootes from the rootes: but for the more ≈øpeedie propagating of them, ≈øome doe put the cuttings of them into the earth, and thereby increa≈øe them. There are ≈øome other trees that are not of any great re≈øpect, as the Yew tree, and the Savine bu≈øh, both which may be encrea≈øed by the cuttings, and therefore I need not make any further relation or amplification of them, and to ≈øay thus much of them all, is (I thinke) ≈øufficient for this Worke.

div.head: CHAP. X. The ordering, curing, and propagating Vines of all ≈øorts.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt places of this countrie there is ≈ømall care or paines taken about the ordering of Vines: it ≈øufficeth for the mo≈øt part with them that haue anie, to make a frame for it to ≈øpread vpon aboue a mans height, or to tacke it to a wall or window, &c. and ≈øo to let it hang downe with the branches and fruit, vntill the weight thereof, and the force of windes doe teare it downe oftentimes, and ≈øpoile the grapes: and this way doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble that cour≈øe that the Vineyard keepers ob≈øerue in the hot countries of Syria, Spaine, and Italy, and in the furthe≈øt parts of France as I hear likewi≈øe: for in mo≈øt of the≈øe hot countries they v≈øe to plant an Oliue betweene two Vines, and let them runne thereupon. But manie of the other parts of France, &c. doe not ≈øuffer anie trees to growe among their Vines; and therefore they plant them thicke, and pruine them much and often, and keepe them lowe in compari≈øon of the other way, fa≈øtening them to pearches or poles to hold them vp. And according to that fa≈øhion many haue aduentured to make Vineyards in England, not onely in the≈øe later daies, but in ancient times, as may wel witne≈ø≈øe the ≈øundrie places in this Land, entituled by the name of Vineyards; and I haue read, that manie Mona≈øteries in this Kingdome hauing Vineyards, had as much wine made therefrom, as ≈øufficed their couents yeare by yeare: but long ≈øince they haue been de≈øtroyed, and the knowledge how to order a Vineyard is al≈øo vtterly peri≈øhed with them. For although diuers, both Nobles
and Gentlemen, haue in the≈øe later times endeauoured to plant and make Vineyards, and to that purpo≈øe haue cau≈øed French men, being skilfull in keeping and dre≈ø≈øing of Vines, to be brought ouer to performe it, yet either their skill failed them, or their Vines were not good, or (the mo≈øt likely) the ≈øoile was not fitting; for they could neuer make anie wine that was worth the drinking, being ≈øo ≈ømall and heartle≈ø≈øe, that they ≈øoone gaue ouer their practice. And indeede the ≈øoile is a maine matter to bee chiefly con≈øidered to ≈øeate a Vineyard vpon: for euen in France and other hot countries, according to the nature of the ≈øoile, ≈øo is the relli≈øh, ≈øtrength, and durabilitie of the wine. Now although I think it a fruitle≈ø≈øe labour for any man to ≈øtriue in the≈øe daies to make a good Vineyard in England, in regard not only of the want of knowledge, to make choi≈øe of the fitte≈øt ground for ≈øuch Vines as you would plant therupon, but al≈øo of the true maner of ordering them in our country; but mo≈øt chiefly & aboue all others, that our years in the≈øe times do not fal out to be ≈øo kindly and hot, to ripen the grapes, to make anie good wine as formerly they haue done; yet I thinke it not ami≈ø≈øe, to giue you in≈øtructions how to order ≈øuch Vines as you may nour≈øe vp for the plea≈øure of the fruit, to eate the grapes being ripe, or to pre≈øerue and keepe them to bee eaten almo≈øt all the winter following: And this may be done without any great or extraordinarie paines. Some doe make a lowe wall, and plant their Vines again≈øt it, and keepe them much about the height thereof, not ≈øuffering them to ri≈øe much higher: but if the high bricke or ≈øtone wals of your Garden or Orchard haue buttre≈ø≈øes thereat, or if you cau≈øe ≈øuch to bee made, that they bee ≈øomewhat broade forwards, you may the more conueniently plant Vines of diuers ≈øorts at them, and by ≈øticking down a couple of good ≈øtakes at euery buttre≈ø≈øe, of eight or ten foot high aboue ground, tacking a few lathes acro≈ø≈øe vpon tho≈øe ≈øtakes, you may therunto tye your Vines, & carry them theron at your plea≈øure: but you mu≈øt be carefull to cut them euery year, but not too late, and ≈øo keepe them downe, and from farre ≈øpreading, that they neuer runne much beyond the frame which you ≈øet at the buttre≈ø≈øes: as al≈øo in your cutting you neuer leaue too many ioynts, nor yet too few, but at the third or fourth ioint at the mo≈øt cut them off. I doe adui≈øe you to the≈øe frames made with ≈øtakes and lathes, for the better ripening of your grapes: for in the blooming time, if the branches of your vines bee too neare the wall, the reflection of the Sunne in the day time, and the colde in the night, doe oftentimes ≈øpoile a great deale of fruit, by piercing and withering the tender foot-≈øtalkes of the grapes, before they are formed, whereas when the blo≈ø≈øomes are pa≈øt, and the fruit growing of ≈øome bigne≈ø≈øe, then all the heate and reflection you can giue them is fit, and therefore cut away ≈øome of the branches with the leaues, to admit the more Sunne to ripen the fruit. For the diuers ≈øorts of grapes I haue ≈øet them downe in the Booke following, with briefe notes vpon euerie of them, whether white or blacke, ≈ømall or great, early or late ripe; ≈øo that I neede not here make the ≈øame relation again. There doth happen ≈øome di≈øea≈øes to Vines ≈øometimes, which that you may helpe, I thinke it conuenient to informe you what they are, and how to remedy them when you ≈øhall be troubled with any ≈øuch. The fir≈øt is a luxurious ≈øpreading of branches and but little or no fruit: for remedie whereof, cut the branches ≈øomewhat more neere then v≈øuall, and bare the roote, but take heed of wounding or hurting it, and in the hole put either ≈øome good old rotten ≈øtable dung of Hor≈øes, of el≈øe ≈øome Oxe blood new taken from the bea≈øts, and that in the middle of Ianuarie or beginning of Februarie, which being well tempered and turned in with the earth, let it ≈øo abide, which no doubt, when the comfort of the blood or dung is well ≈øoaked to the bottome by the raines that fall thereon, will cau≈øe your Vine to fructifie againe. Another fault is, when a Vine doth not bring the fruit to ripene≈ø≈øe, but either it withereth before it be growne of any bigne≈ø≈øe, or pre≈øently after the blooming: the place or the earth where ≈øuch a Vine ≈øtandeth, a≈ø≈øuredly is too cold, and therefore if the fault bee not in the place, which cannot bee helped without remouing to a better, digge out a good quantity of that earth, and put into the place thereof ≈øome good fre≈øh ground well heartned with dung, and ≈øome ≈øand mixed therewith (but not ≈øalt or ≈øalt water, as ≈øome doe adui≈øe, nor yet vrine, as others would haue) and this will hearten and ≈øtrengthen your Vine to beare out the frut vnto maturitie. When the leaues of a Vine in the end of Summer or in Autumne, vntimely doe turne either yellow or red, it is a great ≈øigne the earth is
too hot and drie; you mu≈øt therefore in ≈øtead of dung and ≈øand, as in the former defect is ≈øaid, put in ≈øome fre≈øh loame or ≈øhort clay, well mixed together with ≈øome of the earth, and ≈øo let them abide, that the fro≈øts may mellow them. And la≈øtly, a Vine ≈øometimes beareth ≈øome ≈øtore of grapes, but they are too many for it to bring to ripene≈ø≈øe; you ≈øhall therefore helpe ≈øuch a Vine (which no doubt is of ≈øome excellent kinde, for they are mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øubiect to this fault) by nipping away the blo≈ø≈øomes from the branches, and leauing but one or two bunches at the mo≈øt vpon a branch, vntill the Vine be growne older, and thereby ≈øtronger, and by this meane inured to beare out all the grapes to ripene≈ø≈øe. The≈øe be all the di≈øea≈øes I know doe happen to Vines: for the bleeding of a Vine it ≈øeldome happeneth of it ≈øelfe, but commeth either by cutting it vntimely, that is, too late in the yeare, (for after Ianuarie, if you will be well adui≈øed, cut not any Vine) or by ≈øome ca≈øuall or wilfull breaking of an arme or a branch. This bleeding in ≈øome is vnto death, in others it ≈øtayeth after a certaine ≈øpace of it ≈øelfe: To helpe this inconuenience, ≈øome haue ≈øeared the place where it bleedeth with an hot iron, which in many haue done but a little good; others haue bound the barke clo≈øe with packe-thred to ≈øtay it; and ≈øome haue tied ouer the place, being fir≈øt dried as well as may bee, a plai≈øter made with waxe ro≈ø≈øen and turpentine while it is warme. Now for the propagating of them: You mu≈øt take the faire≈øt and goale≈øt ≈øhot branches of one yeares growth, and cut them off with a peece of the old wood vnto it, and the≈øe being put into the ground before the end of Ianuarie at the furthe≈øt, will ≈øhoote forth, and take roote, and ≈øo become Vines of the ≈øame kinde from whence you tooke them. This is the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy way to haue increa≈øe: for the laying downe of branches to take roote, doth not yeelde ≈øuch ≈øtore ≈øo plentifully, nor doe ≈øuckers ri≈øe from the rootes ≈øo aboundantly; yet both the≈øe waies doe yeelde Vines, that being taken from the old ≈øtockes will become young plants, fit to bee di≈øpo≈øed of as any ≈øhall thinke meete.

div.head: CHAP. XI. The way to order and pre≈øerue grapes, fit to be eaten almost all the Winter long, and ≈øometimes vnto the Spring.
div.p:
ALthough it bee common and v≈øuall in the parts beyond the Sea to dry their grapes in the Sunne, thereby to pre≈øerue them all the year, as the Rai≈øins of the Sunne are, which cannot bee done in our Countrie for the want of ≈øufficient heate thereof at that time: or otherwi≈øe to ≈øcald them in hot water (as I heare) and afterwards to dry them, and ≈øo keepe them all the yeare, as our Malaga Rai≈øins are prepared that are packed vp into Frayles: yet I doe intend to ≈øhew you ≈øome other waies to pre≈øerue the grapes of our Countrie fre≈øh, that they may be eaten in the winter both before and after Chri≈øtmas with as much delight and plea≈øure almo≈øt, as when they were new gathered. One way is, when you haue gathered your grapes you intend to keepe, which mu≈øt be in a dry time, and that all the ≈øhrunke, dried, or euill grapes in euery bunch be picked away, and hauing prouided a ve≈ø≈øell to hold them, be it of wood or ≈øtone which you will, and a ≈øufficient quantitie of faire and cleane drie ≈øand; make ≈øtratum ≈øuper ≈øtratum of your grapes and the ≈øand, that is, a lay of ≈øand in the bottome fir≈øt, and a lay of grapes vpon them, and a lay or ≈øtrowing againe of ≈øand vpon tho≈øe grapes, ≈øo that the ≈øand may couer euery lay of grapes a fingers breadth in thickne≈ø≈øe, which being done one vpon another vntill the ve≈ø≈øell be full, and a lay of ≈øand vppermo≈øt, let the ve≈ø≈øell be ≈øtopped clo≈øe, and ≈øet by vntill you plea≈øe to ≈øpend them, being kept in ≈øome drie place and in no ≈øellar: let them bee wa≈øhed cleane in faire water to take away the ≈øand from ≈øo many you will ≈øpend at a time. Another way is (which Camerarius ≈øetteth downe he was informed the Turkes v≈øe to keepe grapes all the winter vnto the next ≈øummer) to take ≈øo much meale of Mu≈øtard ≈øeede, as will ≈øerue to ≈øtrow vpon grapes, vntill they haue filled their ve≈ø≈øels, whereon afterwards they poure new wine before it hath boiled, to fill vp their ve≈ø≈øels therwith, and being ≈øtopped vp clo≈øe, they keepe them a certaine time, and ≈øelling them with their liquour to them that will
v≈øe them, they doe wa≈øh the ≈øeedes or meale from them when they v≈øe them. Another way is, that hauing gathered the faire≈øt ripe grapes, they are to be ca≈øt vpon threds or ≈øtrings that are fa≈øtened at both ends to the ≈øide walks of a chamber, neere vnto the ≈øeeling thereof, that no one bunch touch another, which will bee ≈øo kept a great while, yet the chamber mu≈øt be well defended from the fro≈øts, and cold windes that pierce in at the windowes, le≈øt they peri≈øh the ≈øooner: and ≈øome will dippe the ends of the branches they hang vp fir≈øt in molten pitch, thinking by ≈øearing vp the ends to keepe the bunches the better; but I doe not ≈øee any great likelihood therein. Your chamber or clo≈øet you appoint out for this purpo≈øe mu≈øt al≈øo bee kept ≈øomewhat warme, but e≈øpecially in the more cold and fro≈øtie time of the yeare, le≈øt it ≈øpoile all your co≈øt and paines, and fru≈øtrate you of all your hopes: but although the fro≈øts ≈øhould pierce and ≈øpoile ≈øome of the grapes on a bunch, yet if you be carefull to keepe the place warme, the fewer will be ≈øpoiled. And thus haue I ≈øhewed you the be≈øt directions to order this Orchard rightly, and all the waies I know are v≈øed in our Countrie to keep grapes good anie long time after the gathering, in regard wee haue not that comfort of a hotter Sun to pre≈øerue them by its heate.
The fruits them≈øelues ≈øhall follow euerie one in their order; the lower ≈øhrubbes or bu≈øhes fir≈øt, and the greater afterwards.

div.head: THE THIRD PART CALLED THE ORCHARD,
div.p: COntaining all ≈øorts of trees bearing fruit for mans v≈øe to eate, proper and fit for to plant an Orchard in our climate and countrie: I bound it with this limitation, becau≈øe both Dates, Oliues, and oother fruits, are planted in the Orchards of Spaine, Italy, and other hot countries, which will not abide in ours. Yet herein I will declare what≈øoeuer Art, ≈øtriuing with Nature, can cau≈øe to pro≈øper with vs, that who≈øoeuer will, may ≈øee what can bee effected in our countrie. And fir≈øt to begin with the lower ≈øhrubbes or bu≈øhes, and after a≈øcend to the higher trees.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Rubus Idaeus. Ra≈øpis.
div.p: THe Ra≈øpis berrie is of two ≈øorts, white and red, not differing in the forme either of bu≈øh, leafe, or berry, but onely in the colour and ta≈øte of the fruit. The Ra≈øpis bu≈øh hath tender whiti≈øh ≈øtemmes, with reddi≈øh ≈ømall prickes like haires ≈øet round about them, e≈øpecially at the fir≈øt when they are young; but when they grow old they become more wooddy and firme, without any ≈øhew of thornes or prickles vpon them, and hath onely a little hairine≈ø≈øe that couereth them: the leaues are ≈øomewhat rough or rugged, and wrinkled, ≈øtanding three or fiue vpon a ≈øtalke, ≈øomewhat like vnto Ro≈øes, but greater, and of a grayer greene colour: the flowers are ≈ømall, made of fine whiti≈øh round leaues, with a da≈øh as it were of blu≈øh ca≈øt ouer them, many ≈øtanding together, yet euery one vpon his owne ≈øtalke, at the tops of the branches; after which come vp ≈ømall berries, ≈øomewhat bigger then Strawberries, and longer, either red or white, made of many graines, more eminent then in the Strawberry, with a kinde of dounine≈ø≈øe ca≈øt ouer them, of a plea≈øant ta≈øte, yet ≈øomewhat ≈øowre, and nothing ≈øo plea≈øant as the Strawberrie. The white Ra≈øpis is a little more plea≈øant then the red, wherein there is ≈ømall ≈øeede inclo≈øed: the rootes creepe vnder ground verie farre, and ≈øhoote vp againe in many places, much encrea≈øing thereby.
There is another who≈øe ≈øtemme and branches are wholly without prickles: the fruit is red, and ≈øomewhat longer, and a little more ≈øharpe.

div.head: The V≈øe of Ra≈øpis.
div.p: The leaues of Ra≈øpis may be v≈øed for want of Bramble leaues in gargles, and other decoctions that are cooling and drying, although not fully to that effect.
The Con≈øerue or Syrupe made of the berries, is effectuall to coole an hot ≈øtomacke, helping to refre≈øh and quicken vp tho≈øe that are ouercome with faintne≈ø≈øe.
The berries are eaten in the Summer time, as an afternoones di≈øh, to plea≈øe the ta≈øte of the ≈øicke as well as the ≈øound.
The iuyce and the di≈øtilled water of the berries are verie comfortable and cordiall.

It is generally held of many, but how true I know not, that the red wine that is v≈øually ≈øold at the Vintners, is made of the berries of Ra≈øpis that grow in colder countries, which giueth it a kinde of har≈øhne≈ø≈øe: And al≈øo that of the ≈øame berries growing in hotter climates, which giueth vnto the wine a more plea≈øant ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, is made that wine which the Vintners call Alligant: but we haue a Vine or Grape come to vs vnder the name of the Alligant Grape, as you ≈øhall finde it ≈øet downe hereafter among the Grapes; and therefore it is likely to be but an opinion, and no truth in this, as it may be al≈øo in the other.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Ribes rubra, alba, nigra. Currans red, white, and blacke.
div.p: THe bu≈øhes that beare tho≈øe berries, which are v≈øually called red Currans, are not tho≈øe Currans either blew or red, that are ≈øold at the Grocers, nor any kind thereof; for that they are the grapes of a certaine Vine, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed by and by: but a farre differing kinde of berry, whereof there are three ≈øorts, red, white, and blacke.

The red Curran bu≈øh is of two ≈øorts, and groweth to the height of a man, hauing ≈øometimes a ≈øtemme of two inches thickne≈ø≈øe, and diuers armes and branches, couered with a ≈ømooth, darke, browni≈øh barke, without anie pricke or thorne at all vpon anie part thereof, whereon doe growe large cornered blacki≈øh greene leaues, cut in on the edges, ≈øeeming to be made of fiue parts, almo≈øt like a Vine leafe, the ends a little pointing out, and ≈øtanding one aboue another on both ≈øides of the branches: the flowers are little and hollow, comming forth at the ioynts of the leaues, growing many together on a long ≈øtalke, hanging downe aboue a fingers length, and of an herbie colour: after which come ≈ømall round fruit or berries, greene at the fir≈øt, and red as a Cherry when they are ripe, of a plea≈øant and tart ta≈øte: the other differeth not in anie other thing then in the berries, being twice as bigge as the former: the roote is wooddy, and ≈øpreadeth diuer≈øly.

The white Curran bu≈øh ri≈øeth v≈øually both higher then the red, and ≈øtraighter or more vpright, bigger al≈øo in the ≈øtemme, and couered with a whiter barke: the leaues are cornered, ≈øomewhat like the former, but not ≈øo large: the flowers are ≈ømall and hollow like the other, hanging downe in the ≈øame manner on long ≈øtalkes, being of a whiter colour: the berries likewi≈øe growe on the long ≈øtalkes, ≈øomewhat thicker ≈øet together, and of a cleare white colour, with a little blacke head, ≈øo tran≈øparent that the ≈øeedes may be ea≈øily ≈øeene thorough them, and of a more plea≈øant winie ta≈øte then the red by much.

The blacke Curran bu≈øh ri≈øeth higher then the white, with more plentifull branches, and more pliant and twiggie: the ≈øtemme and the elder branches being couered with a browni≈øh barke, and the younger with a paler: the flowers are al≈øo like vnto little bottles as the others be, of a greeni≈øh purple colour, which turne into blacke berries, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the ≈ømaller red Currans: the leaues are ≈øomewhat like vnto the leaues of the red Currans, but not ≈øo large: both branches, leaues, and fruit haue a kind of ≈øtinking ≈øent with them, yet they are not vnwhol≈øome, but the berries are eaten of many, without offending either ta≈øte or ≈ømell.

div.head: The V≈øe of Currans.

figure.head: 1 Rubus Idaeus. The Ra≈øpis. 2 Ribes fructu rubro vel albo. White or red Currans. 3 Gro≈ø≈øularia vulgaris. The ordinary Goo≈øeberry 4 Gro≈ø≈øularia fructu rubro. The great red Goo≈øeberry. 5 Gro≈ø≈øularia aculeata. The prickly Goo≈øeberry. 6 Oxyaecantha ≈øeu Berberis. The Barbary bu≈øh. 7 Auellana Byzantina. The Filberd of Con≈øtantinople. 8 Auellana rubra no≈øtras. The be≈øt red Filberd.

div.p: The white Currans, by rea≈øon of the more plea≈øant winie ta≈øte, are more accepted and de≈øired, as al≈øo becau≈øe they are more daintie, and le≈ø≈øe common.
Some v≈øe both the leaues and berries of the blacke Currans in ≈øawces, and other meates, and are well plea≈øed both with the ≈øauour and ta≈øte thereof, although many mi≈ølike it.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Vva Cri≈øpa ≈øiue Gro≈ø≈øularia. Goo≈øeberries or Feaberries.
div.p: WEe haue diuers ≈øorts of Goo≈øeberries, be≈øides the common kinde, which is of three ≈øorts, ≈ømall, great, and long. For wee haue three red Goo≈øeberries, a blew and a greene.

The common Goo≈øeberrie, or Feaberrie bu≈øh, as it is called in diuers Countries of England, hath oftentimes a great ≈øtemme, couered with a ≈ømooth darke coloured bark, without anie thorne thereon, but the elder branches haue here and there ≈øome on them, and the younger are whiti≈øh, armed with verie ≈øharpe and cruell crooked thorns, which no mans hand can well auoide that doth handle them, whereon are ≈øet verie greene and ≈ømall cornered leaues cut in, of the fa≈øhion almo≈øt of Smallage, or Hawthorne leaues, but broad at the ≈øtalke: the flowers come forth ≈øingle, at euerie ioynt of the leafe one or two, of a purpli≈øh greene colour, hollow and turning vp the brims a little: the berries follow, bearing the flowers on the heads of them, which are of a pale greene at the fir≈øt, and of a greeni≈øh yellow colour when they are ripe, ≈øtriped in diuers places, and cleare, almo≈øt tran≈øparent, in which the ≈øeede lyeth. In ≈øome the≈øe berries are ≈ømall and round; in others much greater; a third is great, but longer then the other: all of them haue a plea≈øant winie ta≈øte, acceptable to the ≈øtomacke of anie (but the long kinde hath both the thicker skin, and the wor≈øer ta≈øte of the other) and none haue been di≈øtempered by the eating of them, that euer I could heare of.

The fir≈øt of the red Goo≈øeberries is better knowne I thinke then the re≈øt, and by rea≈øon of the ≈ømall bearing not much regarded; the ≈øtemme is ≈øomewhat bigge, and couered with a ≈ømooth darke coloured barke, the younger branches are whiter, and without anie thorne or pricke at all, ≈øo long, weake, ≈ømall, and ≈ølender, that they lye vpon the ground, and will there roote againe: the leaues are like vnto the former Goo≈øeberries, but larger: the flowers and berries ≈øtand ≈øingle, and not manie to bee found anie yeare vpon them, but are ≈øomewhat long, and are as great as the ordinarie Goo≈øeberry, of a darke browni≈øh red colour, almo≈øt blacki≈øh when they are ripe, and of a ≈øweeti≈øh ta≈øte, but without any great delight.

The ≈øecond red Goo≈øeberry ri≈øeth vp with a more ≈øtraight ≈øtemme, couered with a browni≈øh barke; the young branches are ≈øtraight likewi≈øe, and whiti≈øh, and grow not ≈øo thicke vpon it as the former red kinde, and without any thorne al≈øo vpon them: the leaues are like vnto the former red, but ≈ømaller: the berries ≈øtand ≈øingly at the leaues as Goo≈øeberries doe, and are of a fine red colour when they are ripe, but change with ≈øtanding to be of a darker red colour, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the ≈ømall ordinary Goo≈øeberry, of a pretty tart ta≈øte, and ≈øomewhat ≈øweete withall.

The third red Goo≈øeberry which is the greate≈øt, and knowne but vnto few, is ≈øo like vnto the common great Goo≈øeberry, that it is hardly di≈øtingui≈øhed: the fruit or berries grow as plentifully on the branches as the ordinary, and are as great & round as the great ordinary kinde, but reddi≈øh, and ≈øome of them paler, with red ≈øtripes.

The blew Goo≈øeberry ri≈øeth vp to bee a bu≈øh like vnto the red Curran, and of the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe and height, with broader and redder leaues at the fir≈øt ≈øhooting out, then the ≈øecond red Goo≈øeberry: the berries are more ≈øparingly ≈øet on the branches, then on the ≈ømall red, and much about the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe, or rather le≈ø≈øer, of the colour of a Dam≈øon, with an ouer≈øhadowing of a blewi≈øh colour vpon them, as the Dam≈øon hath, before it be handled or wiped away.

The greene prickly Goo≈øeberry is very like vnto the ordinary Goo≈øeberry in ≈øtemme and branches, but that they are not ≈øtored with ≈øo many ≈øharpe prickles; but the young ≈øhootes are more plentifull in ≈ømall prickles about, and the greene leafe is a little ≈ømaller: the flowers are alike, and ≈øo are the berries, being of a middle ≈øize, and not very great, greene when they are thorough ripe as well as before, but mellower, and hauing a few ≈ømall ≈øhort prickles, like ≈ømall ≈øhort haires vpon them, which are harmle≈ø≈øe, and without danger to anie the mo≈øt dainty and tender palate that is, and of a verie good plea≈øant ta≈øte. The ≈øeede hereof hath produced bu≈øhes bearing berries, hauing few or no prickles vpon them.

div.head: The V≈øe of Goo≈øeberries.
div.p: The berries of the ordinary Goo≈øeberries, while they are ≈ømall, greene, and hard, are much v≈øed to bee boyled or ≈øcalded to make ≈øawce, both for fi≈øh and fle≈øh of diuers ≈øorts, for the ≈øicke ≈øometimes as well as the ≈øound, as al≈øo before they be neere ripe, to bake into tarts, or otherwi≈øe, after manie fa≈øhions, as the cunning of the Cooke, or the plea≈øure of his commanders will appoint. They are a fit di≈øh for women with childe to ≈øtay their longings, and to procure an appetite vnto meate.

The other ≈øorts are not v≈øed in Cookery that I know, but ≈øerue to bee eaten at plea≈øure; but in regard they are not ≈øo tart before maturity as the former, they are not put to tho≈øe v≈øes they be.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
Oxyacantha, ≈øed potius Berberis. Barberries.
div.p: THe Barberry bu≈øh groweth oftentimes with very high ≈øtemmes, almo≈øt two mens height, but v≈øually ≈øomewhat lower, with manie ≈øhootes from the roote, couered with a whiti≈øh rinde or barke, and yellow vnderneath, the wood being white and pithy in the middle: the leaues are ≈ømall, long, and very greene, nicked or finely dented about the edges, with three ≈ømall white ≈øharpe thornes, for the mo≈øt part ≈øet together at the ≈øetting on of the leaues: the flowers doe growe vpon long clu≈øtering ≈øtalkes, ≈ømall, round, and yellow, ≈øweete in ≈ømell white they are fre≈øh, which turne into ≈ømall, long, and round berries, white at the fir≈øt, and very red when they are ripe, of a ≈øharpe ≈øowre ta≈øte, fit to ≈øet their teeth on edge that eate them: the roote is yellow, ≈øpreading far vnder the vpper part of the ground, but not very deepe.

There is (as it is thought) another kinde, who≈øe berries are thrice as bigge as the former, which I confe≈ø≈øe I haue not ≈øeene, and know not whether it be true or no: for it may peraduenture be but the ≈øame, the goodne≈ø≈øe of the ground and ayre where they growe, and the youngne≈ø≈øe of the bu≈øhes cau≈øing that largene≈ø≈øe, as I haue ob≈øerued in the ≈øame kinde, to yeeld greater berries.

There is ≈øaid to be al≈øo another kinde, who≈øe berries ≈øhould be without ≈øtones or ≈øeede within them, not differing el≈øe in anie thing from the former: but becau≈øe I haue long heard of it, and cannot vnder≈øtand by all the inquirie I haue made, that any hath ≈øeene ≈øuch a fruit, I re≈øt doubtfull of it.

div.head: The V≈øe of Barberries.
div.p: Some doe v≈øe the leaues of Barberries in the ≈øtead of Sorrell, to make ≈øawce for meate, and by rea≈øon of their ≈øowrene≈ø≈øe are of the ≈øame quality.

The berries are v≈øed to be pickled, to ≈øerue to trimme or ≈øet out di≈øhes of fi≈øh and fle≈øh in broth, or otherwi≈øe, as al≈øo ≈øometime to bee boyled in the broth, to giue it a ≈øharpe relli≈øh, and many other wayes, as a Ma≈øter Cooke can better tell then my ≈øelfe.
The berries are pre≈øerued and con≈øerued to giue to ≈øicke bodies, to helpe to coole any heate in the ≈øtomacke or mouth, and quicken the appetite.
The depurate iuyce is a fine men≈øtrue to di≈ø≈øolue many things, and to verie good purpo≈øe, if it be cunningly handled by an Arti≈øt.

The yellow inner barke of the branches, or of the rootes, are v≈øed to be boyled in Ale, or other drinkes, to be giuen to tho≈øe that haue the yellow iaundi≈øe: As al≈øo for them that haue anie fluxes of choller, to helpe to ≈øtay and binde.

Clu≈øius ≈øetteth downe a ≈øecret that hee had of a friend, of a cleane differing propertie, which was, that if the yellow barke were laid in ≈øteepe in white wine for the ≈øpace of three houres, and afterwards drunke, it would purge one very wonderfully.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Nux Auellana. The Filberd.
div.p: THe Filberd tree that is planted in Orchards, is very like vnto the Ha≈øell nut tree that groweth wilde in the woods, growing vpright, parted into many boughes and tough plyable twigges, without knots, couered with a browni≈øh, ≈øpeckled, ≈ømooth, thinne rinde, and greene vnderneath: the leaues are broad, large, wrinkled, and full of veines, cut in on the edges into deepe dents, but not into any ga≈øhes, of a darke greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and of a grayi≈øh a≈øh colour vnderneath: it hath ≈ømall and long catkins in ≈øtead of flowers, that come forth in the Winter, when as they are firme and clo≈øe, and in the Spring open them≈øelues ≈øomewhat more, growing longer, and of a browni≈øh yellow colour: the nuts come not vpon tho≈øe ≈øtalkes that bore tho≈øe catkins, but by them≈øelues, and are wholly inclo≈øed in long, thicke, rough huskes, bearded as it were at the vpper ends, or cut into diuers long iagges, much more then the wood nut: the nut hath a thinne and ≈øomewhat hard ≈øhell, but not ≈øo thicke and hard as the wood nut, in ≈øome longer then in other, and in the long kinde, one hath the skinne white that couereth the kernels, and another red.

There is another ≈øort of the round kinde that came from Con≈øtantinople, who≈øe huske is more cut, torne, or iagged, both aboue and belowe, then any of our country; the barke al≈øo is whiter, and more rugged then ours, and the leaues ≈øomewhat larger.

We haue had from Virginia Ha≈øell nuts, that haue beene ≈ømaller, rounder, browner, thinner ≈øheld, and more pointed at the end then ours: I know not if any hath planted of them, or if they differ in leafe or any thing el≈øe.

div.head: The V≈øe of Filberds.
div.p: Filberds are eaten as the be≈øt kinde of Ha≈øell nuts, at bankets among other dainty fruits, according to the ≈øea≈øon of the yeare, or otherwi≈øe, as euery one plea≈øe: But Macer hath a Ver≈øe, expre≈ø≈øing prettily the nature of the≈øe nuts, which is, Ex minimis nucibus nulli datur e≈øca ≈øalubris. that is, There is no whol≈øome food or nouri≈øhment had from the≈øe ≈ømall kinde of nuts.

Yet they are v≈øed ≈øometime phy≈øically to be re≈øted, and made into a Lohoc or Electuary, that is v≈øed for the cough or cold. And it is thought of ≈øome, that Mithridates meant the kernels of the≈øe nuts, to be v≈øed with Figs and Rue for his Antidote, and not of Walnuts.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Vitis. The Vine.
div.p: THere is ≈øo great diuer≈øities of Grapes, and ≈øo con≈øequently of Vines that bear them, that I cannot giue you names to all that here grow with vs: for Iohn Trade≈øcante my verie good friend, ≈øo often before remembred, hath a≈ø≈øured me, that he hath twentie ≈øorts growing with him, that hee neuer knew how or by what name to call them. One de≈øcription therefore ≈øhall ≈øerue (as I v≈øe to doe in ≈øuch varieties) for all the re≈øt, with the names afterwards, of as many as we can giue, and the ≈øeuerall formes, colours and proportions of the grapes.

The manured Vine, in the places where it hath abiden long time, groweth to haue a great bodie, ≈øtemme or trunke, ≈øometimes of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans arme, ≈øleeue and all, ≈øpreading branches if it bee ≈øuffered without end or mea≈øure, but v≈øually ≈øtored with many armes or branches, both old and new, but weake, and therefore mu≈øt bee ≈øu≈øtained; whereof the old are couered with a thin ≈øcaly rinde, which will often chap and peele off of it ≈øelfe; the younge≈øt being of a reddi≈øh colour, ≈ømooth and firme, with a hollowne≈ø≈øe or pith in the middle: from the ioints of the young branches, and ≈øometimes from the bodie of the elder, breake out on euerie ≈øide broade greene leaues, cut on the edges into fiue diui≈øions for the mo≈øt part, and be≈øides notched or dented about: right again≈øt the leafe, and likewi≈øe at other ioynts of the branches, come forth long twining or cla≈øping tendrels, winding them≈øelues about any thing ≈øtandeth next vnto them: at the bottome of the≈øe leaues come forth clu≈øters of ≈ømall greeni≈øh yellow bloomes or flowers, and after them the berries, growing in the ≈øame manner in clu≈øters, but of diuers formes, colours, ta≈øtes and greatne≈ø≈øe. For ≈øome grapes are great, others le≈ø≈øe, ≈øome very ≈ømall (as the Currans that the Grocers ≈øell) ≈øome white, ≈øome red, blew, blacke, or partie-coloured, ≈øome are are as it were ≈øquare, others round: ≈øome the clu≈øters are clo≈øe, others open, ≈øome are ≈øweete, others ≈øower or har≈øh, or of ≈øome other mixed ta≈øte; euerie one differing from others, verie notably either in ta≈øte, colour or forme; within euerie one of which grapes, (and yet there is a grape without ≈øtones) are contained one, two, or more kernels or ≈øtones, ≈øome of them being ≈ømal, others greater: the rootes ≈øpread far and deepe. They that keepe their Vines in the be≈øt order, doe cut them low, not ≈øuffering them to grow high, or with too many branches, whereby they grow the better, take vp the le≈ø≈øer roome, and bring their grapes fairer and ≈øweeter.

div.head: The kinds of Vines and Grapes.
div.p: Our ordinarie Grape both white and red, which excelleth Crabs for veriuice, and is not fit for wine with vs.
The white Mu≈øcadine Grape is a verie great Grape, ≈øweete and firme, ≈øome of the bunches haue weighed ≈øixe pound, and ≈øome of the grapes halfe an ounce.
The redde Mu≈øcadine is as great as the white, and chiefly differeth in colour.
The Burlet is a very great white Grape, but fitter for veriuice then wine for the mo≈øt part; yet when a hot yeare happeneth fit for it, the Grape is plea≈øant.
The little blacke Grape that is ripe very early.

The Rai≈øin of the Sunne Grape is a very great Grape, and very great clu≈øters, of a reddi≈øh colour when it is ripe with vs, yet in an extraordinarie hot yeare, it hath got a little blewne≈ø≈øe ca≈øt ouer it by the heat: but naturally verie blew.

The Curran Grape (or the Grape of Corinth) is the lea≈øt Grape of all, and beareth both few, and verie ≈øeldome with vs, but in rea≈øonable great clu≈øters, and of a blacki≈øh blew colour, when they are ripe with vs, and very
≈øweete. There is another ≈øort of them that are red or browne, and of a ≈øower ta≈øte, nothing ≈øo ≈øweete.
The Greeke wine Grape is a blacki≈øh Grape, and very ≈øweete.
The Frontignack is a white Grape, of a verie ≈øweete and delicate ta≈øte, as the wine declareth, that ≈ømelleth as it were of Muske.
The ≈øquare Grape is reported to bear a Grape not fully round, but ≈øided, or as it were ≈øquare, whereby it became ≈øo called.

The Dama≈øco Grape is a great white grape, very ≈øweete, and is the true Vva Zibeba, that the Apothecaries ≈øhould v≈øe in the Trochi≈øci Ciphi: and ≈øuch wee haue had in former times come ouer vnto vs in great, long and round white boxes, containing halfe an hundred weight a peece.
The Ru≈ø≈øet Grape is a rea≈øonable faire grape, exceeding ≈øweet and whiti≈øh, with a thicke skinne, cru≈øted ouer with a ≈øhew of a≈øh colour.
The white long Grape is like vnto a Pigeons egge, or as it were pointed pendent like a Pearle.

The partie-coloured Grape is a rea≈øonable great Grape, and di≈øcoloured when it is ripe, ≈øometimes the whole bunches, and ≈øometimes but ≈øome of the grapes being parted whiti≈øh, and blacke halfe through, verie variably.
The Rheni≈øh wine Grape is a white Grape, and endureth the cold of winter when it commeth earely, more then the Mu≈øcadine before ≈øet downe, and is nothing ≈øo ≈øweete.
The White wine Grape is verie like vnto the Rhine Grape, the ≈øoile only and climate adding more ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe vnto the one then to the other.

The Claret wine Grape is altogether like the white Grape, but that it is not white, but of a reddi≈øh colour, which lying brui≈øed vpon the skins before they are pre≈ø≈øed, giue that Claret tincture to the wine.
The Teint is a Grape of a deeper or darker colour, who≈øe iuice is of ≈øo deepe a colour, that it ≈øerueth to colour other wine.
The Bur≈øarobe is a faire ≈øweete white Grape of much e≈øteeme about Paris.
The Alligant is a verie ≈øweete Grape, giuing ≈øo deep and liuely a coloured red wine, that no other what≈øoeuer is comparable to it, and therfore v≈øually called Spaniards blood.
The blew or blacke Grape of Orleans is another blacke Grape, giuing a darke coloured ≈øweete wine much commended in tho≈øe parts.
The Grape without ≈øtones is al≈øo a kinde by it ≈øelfe, and groweth naturally neere A≈øcalon, as Brochard affirmeth, the wine whereof is redde, and of a good ta≈øte.

The Virginia Vine, whereof I mu≈øt needes make mention among other Vines, beareth ≈ømall Grapes without any great ≈øtore of iuice therein, and the ≈øtone within it bigger then in any other Grape: naturally it runneth on the ground, and beareth little.

div.head: The V≈øe of Vines, Grapes, and other parts that come of them.
div.p: The greene leaues of the Vine are cooling and binding, and therefore good to put among other herbes that make gargles and lotions for ≈øore mouthes.
And al≈øo to put into the broths and drinke of tho≈øe that haue hot burning feauers, or any other inflammation.
They ≈øtay (as it is held for true) womens longings, if they be either taken inwardly, or applyed outwardly.

Wine is v≈øually taken both for drinke and medicine, and is often put into ≈øawces, broths, cawdles, and gellies that are giuen to the ≈øicke. As al≈øo into diuers Phy≈øicall drinkes, to be as a vehiculum for the properties of the ingredients.
It is di≈øtilled likewi≈øe after diners manners, with diuers things, for diuers & ≈øundry waters to drinke, & for diuers purpo≈øes both inward and outward.

figure.head: 1 Vuae nigrae minores. The ≈ømall blacke Grape. 2 Vuae caeruleae maiores. The great blew Grape. 3 Vuae Mo≈øchatellinae. The Mu≈øcadine Grape. 4 Vuae Suraten≈øes. The Burlet Grape. 5 Vuae in≈øold ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The Ray≈øins of the tunne Grape. 6 Ficus. The Figge tree.

div.p: Al≈øo di≈øtilled of it ≈øelfe, is called Spirit of wine, which ≈øerueth to di≈ø≈øolue, and to draw out the tincture of diuers things, and for many other purpo≈øes.
The iuice or veriuice that is made of greene hard grapes, before they be ripe, is v≈øed of the Apothecaries to be made into a Syrupe, that is very good to coole and refre≈øh a faint ≈øtomacke.
And being made of the riper grapes is the be≈øt veriuice, farre exceeding that which is made of crabs, to be kept all the yeare, to be put both into meates and medicines.

The grapes of the be≈øt ≈øorts of Vines are pre≈ø≈øed into wine by ≈øome in the≈øe dayes with vs, and much more as I verily beleeue in times pa≈øt, as by the name of Vineyard giuen to many places in this Kingdome, e≈øpecially where Abbies and Mona≈øteries ≈øtood, may bee coniectured: but the wine of late made hath beene but ≈ømall, and not durable, like that which commeth from beyond Sea, whether our vnkindly yeares, or the want of skill, or a conuenient place for a Vineyard be the cau≈øe, I cannot well tell you.
Grapes of all ≈øorts are familiarly eaten when they are ripe, of the ≈øicke ≈øometimes as well as the ≈øound.

The dryed grapes which we call great Ray≈øins, and the Currans which we call ≈ømall Ray≈øins, are much v≈øed both for meates, broths, and ≈øawces, in diuers manners, as this Countrey in generall aboue any other, wherein many thou≈øands of Frailesfull, Pipes, Hogs-heads, and Buts full are ≈øpent yearly, that it breedeth a wonder in them of tho≈øe parts where they growe and prouide them, how we could ≈øpend ≈øo many.
The Ray≈øins of the Sunne are the be≈øt dryed grapes, next vnto the Dama≈øco, and are very whol≈øome to eate fa≈øting, both to nouri≈øh, and to helpe to loo≈øen the belly.
The dryed Lees of wine called Argoll or Tartar, is put to the v≈øe of the Gold≈ømith, Dyer, and Apothecary, who doe all v≈øe it in ≈øeuerall manners, uery one in his art.
Of it the Apothecaries make Cremer Tartari, a fine medicine to bee v≈øed, as the Phy≈øitian can be≈øt appoint, and doth helpe to purge humours by the ≈øtoole.

Thereof likewi≈øe they make a kinde of water or oyle, fit to bee v≈øed, to take away freckles, ≈øpots, or any ≈øuch deformities of the face or skinne, and to make it ≈ømooth. It cau≈øeth likewi≈øe haire to growe more aboundantly in tho≈øe places where it naturally ≈øhould growe.

The liquor of the Vine that runneth forth when it is cut, is commended to be good again≈øt the ≈øtone where≈øoeuer it be; but that liquor that is taken from the end of the branches when they are burnt, is mo≈øt effectuall to take away ≈øpots and markes, ring-wormes and tetters in any place.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Ficus. The Figge tree.
