div.p: THe Figge trees that are nour≈øed vp in our country are of three ≈øorts, whereof two are high; the one bearing again≈øt a wall goodly ≈øweete and delicate Figs, called Figs of Algarua, and is blewi≈øh when it is ripe: the other tall kinde is nothing ≈øo good, neither doth beare ripe Figges ≈øo kindly and well, and peraduenture may be the white ordinary kinde that commeth from Spaine. The third is a dwarfe kinde of Figge tree, not growing much higher then to a mans body or ≈øhoulders, bearing excellent good Figges and blew, but not ≈øo large as the fir≈øt kinde.

The Figge trees of all the≈øe three kindes are in leaues and growing one like vnto another, ≈øauing for their height, colour, and ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the fruit, hauing many armes or branches, hollow or pithy in the middle, bearing very large leaues, and ≈øomewhat thicke, diuided ≈øometimes into three, but v≈øually into fiue ≈øections, of a darke greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and whiti≈øh vnderneath, yeelding a milkie iuyce when it is
broken, as the branches al≈øo or the figges when they are greene: the fruit breaketh out from the branches without anie blo≈ø≈øome, contrary to all other trees of our Orchard, being round and long, fa≈øhioned very like vnto a ≈ømall Peare, full of ≈ømall white grains or kernels within it, of a very ≈øweete ta≈øte when it is ripe, and very mellow or ≈øoft, that it can hardly be carried farre without brui≈øing.

The other two ≈øorts you may ea≈øily know and vnder≈øtand, by ≈øo much as hath been ≈øaid of them. Take only this more of the Figge tree, That if you plant it not again≈øt a bricke wall, or the wal of an hou≈øe, &c. it will not ripen ≈øo kindly. The dwarfe Figge tree is more tender, and is therefore planted in great ≈øquare tubs, to be remoued into the ≈øunne in the Summer time, and into the hou≈øe in Winter.

div.head: The V≈øe of Figges.
div.p: Figges are ≈øerued to the table with Ray≈øins of the Sunne, and blanched Almonds, for a Lenten di≈øh.

The Figs that growe with vs when they are ripe, and fre≈øh gathered, are eaten of diuers with a little ≈øalt and pepper, as a dainty banquet to entertaine a freind, which ≈øeldome pa≈ø≈øeth without a cup of wine to wa≈øh them downe.

In Italy (as I haue beene enformed by diuers Gentlemen that haue liued there to ≈øtudy phy≈øicke) they eate them in the ≈øame manner, but dare not eate many for feare of a feuer to follow, they doe account them to be ≈øuch breeders of bloud, and heaters of it likewi≈øe.
The Figges that are brought vs from Spaine, are v≈øed to make Pti≈øan drinkes, and diuers other things, that are giuen them that haue coughes or colds.
It is one of the ingredients al≈øo with Nuts and Rice, into Mithridates counterpoi≈øon.
The ≈ømall Figges that growe with vs, and will not ripen, are pre≈øerued by the Comfitmakers, and candid al≈øo, to ≈øerue as other moi≈øt or candid banquetting ≈øtuffe.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Sorbus. The Seruice tree.
div.p: THere are two kindes of Seruice trees that are planted in Orchards with vs, and there is al≈øo a wilde kinde like vnto the later of them, with A≈øhen leaues, found in the woods growing of it ≈øelfe, who≈øe fruit is not gathered, nor v≈øed to bee eaten of any but birds. And there is another kinde al≈øo growing wilde abroad in many places, taken by the Country people where it groweth, to be a Seruice tree, and is called in Latine, Aria Theophrasti, whole leaues are large, ≈øomewhat like Nut tree leaues, but greene aboue, and grayi≈øh vnderneath: ≈øome doe v≈øe the fruit as Seruices, and for the ≈øame purpo≈øes to good effect, yet both of the≈øe wilde kindes wee leaue for another worke, and here declare vnto you onely tho≈øe two ≈øorts are nour≈øed vp in our Orchards.

The more common or ordinary Seruice tree with vs, is a rea≈øonable great tree, couered with a ≈ømooth barke, ≈øpread into many great armes, whereon are ≈øet large leaues, very much cut in on the edges, almo≈øt like vnto a Vine leafe, or rather like vnto that kind of Maple, that is v≈øually called the Sycomore tree with vs: the flowers are white, and growe many clu≈øtering together, which after bring forth ≈ømall browne berries when they are ripe, of the bigne≈ø≈øe almo≈øt of Ha≈øell nuts, with a ≈ømall tuft, as if it were a crowne on the head, wherein are ≈ømall blacke kernels.

The other kinde, which is more rare with vs, and brought into this Land by Iohn Trade≈øcante, heretofore often remembred, hath diuers winged leaues, many ≈øet together like vnto an A≈øhen leafe, but ≈ømaller, and euery one endented about the edges: the flowers growe in long clu≈øters, but nothing ≈øo many, or ≈øo clo≈øe ≈øet as the wilde kinde: the fruit of this tree is in ≈øome round like an Apple, and in others a little longer
like a Peare, but of a more plea≈øant ta≈øte then the ordinarie kinde, when they are ripe and mellowed, as they v≈øe to doe with both the≈øe kindes, and with Medlars.

div.head: The V≈øe of Seruices.
div.p: They are gathered when they growe to be neare ripe (and that is neuer before they haue felt ≈øome fro≈øts) and being tyed together, are either hung vp in ≈øome warme roome, to ripen them thoroughly, that they may bee eaten, or (as ≈øome v≈øe to doe) lay them in ≈øtrawe, chaffe, or branne, to ripen them.

They are binding, fit to be taken of them that haue any ≈øcouring or laske, to helpe to ≈øtay the fluxe; but take heed, le≈øt if you binde too much, more paine and danger may come thereof then of the ≈øcouring.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Me≈øpilus. The Medlar tree.
div.p: THere are three ≈øorts of Medlers: The greater and the le≈ø≈øer Engli≈øh, and the Neapolitan.

The great and the ≈ømall Engli≈øh Medlar differ not one from the other in any thing, but in the ≈øize of the fruit, except that the ≈ømall kinde hath ≈øome prickes or thornes vpon it, which the great one hath not, bearing diuers boughes or armes, from whence breake forth diuers branches, whereon are ≈øet long and ≈øomewhat narrow leaues, many ≈øtanding together; in the middle whereof, at the end of the branch, commeth the flower, which is great and white, made of fiue leaues, broad at the ends, with a nicke in the middle of euery one; after which commeth the fruit, being round, and of a pale browni≈øh colour, bearing a crowne of tho≈øe ≈ømall leaues at the toppe, which were the huske of the flower before, the middle thereof being ≈øomewhat hollow, and is har≈øh, able to choake any that ≈øhall eate it before it be made mellow, wherein there are certaine flat and hard kernels.

The Medlar of Naples groweth likewi≈øe to bee a rea≈øonable great tree, ≈øpreading forth armes and branches, whereon are ≈øet many ga≈øhed leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto Hawthorne leaues, but greater, and likewi≈øe diuers thornes in many places: the flowers are of an herbie greene colour, and ≈ømall, which turne into ≈ømaller fruit then the former, and rounder al≈øo, but with a ≈ømall head or crowne at the toppe like vnto it, and is of a more ≈øweete and plea≈øant ta≈øte then the other, with three ≈øeeds only therein ordinarily.

div.head: The V≈øe of Medlars.
div.p: Medlars are v≈øed in the ≈øame manner that Seruices are, that is, to be eaten when they are mellowed, and are for the ≈øame purpo≈øes to binde the body when there is a cau≈øe: yet they as well as the Seruices, are often eaten by them that haue no neede of binding, and but onely for the plea≈øant ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of them when they are made mellow, and ≈øometimes come as a di≈øh of ripe fruit at their fit ≈øea≈øon, to be ≈øerued with other ≈øorts to the table.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Lotus. The Lote or Nettle tree.

figure.head: 1 Sorbus legitima. The true Seruice tree. 2 Sorbus vulgaris ≈øiue Torminalis. The ordinary Seruice tree. 3 Me≈øpilus vulgaris. The common Me ‚Ä¢ lar tree 4 Me≈øpilus Aronia. The Medlar of Naples. 5 Lotus arbor. The Nettle tree. 6 Lotus ∆≤irginiana. The Pi≈øhamin or Virginia Plumme. 7 Cornus mas. The Cornell Cherry tree.

div.p: The fir≈øt or true Lote tree groweth to be a tree of a great height, who≈øe bodie and elder branches are couered with a ≈ømooth darke greene barke, the leaues are ≈øomewhat rough in handling, of a darke greene colour, long pointed, and ≈øomewhat deepe dented about the edges, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Nettle leafe, and oftentimes growe yellow toward Autumne: the flowers ≈øtand here and there ≈øcattered vpon the branches; after which come round berries like vnto Cherries, hanging downewards vpon long foot-≈øtalkes, greene at the fir≈øt, and whiti≈øh afterwards; but when they are ripe they become reddi≈øh, and if they be ≈øuffered to hang too long on the branches, they grow blacki≈øh, of a plea≈øant au≈øtere ta≈øte, not to be mi≈øliked, wherein is a hard round ≈øtone.

The ≈øecond, which is a ba≈øtard kinde, and called Guatacum Pataninum, groweth to bee a faire tree, with a ≈ømooth darke greene barke, ≈øhooting out many faire great boughes, and al≈øo ≈ølender greene branches, be≈øet with faire broad greene leaues, almo≈øt like vnto the leaues of the Cornell tree, but larger: the flowers growe along the branches clo≈øe vnto them, without any or with a very ≈øhort foote-≈øtalke con≈øi≈øting of foure greene leaues, which are as the huske, containing within it a purpli≈øh flower, made of foure leaues ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh: the fruit ≈øtandeth in the middle of the green huske, greene at the fir≈øt, and very har≈øh, but red and round when it is ripe, and ≈øomewhat like a Plumme, with a ≈ømall point or pricke at the head thereof, and of a rea≈øonable plea≈øant ta≈øte or relli≈øh, wherein are contained flat and thicke browne ≈øeeds or kernels, like vnto the kernels of Ca≈øsia Fistula, ≈øomewhat hard, and not ≈øo ≈øtonie, but that it may ≈øomewhat ea≈øily be cut with a knife.

The third is called in Virginia Pi≈øhamin, The Virginia Plumme (if it be not all one with the former Guaiacana, whereof I am more then halfe per≈øwaded) hath growne with vs of the kernels that were ≈øent out of Virginia, into great trees, who≈øe wood is very hard and brittle, and ≈øomewhat white withall: the branches are many, and grow ≈ølender to the end, couered with a very thinne greeni≈øh bark, whereon doe grow many faire broad greene leaues, without dent or notch on the edges, and ≈øo like vnto the former Guaiacum, that I verily thinke it (as I before ≈øaid) to bee the ≈øame. It hath not yet borne flower or fruit in our Countrey that I can vnder≈øtand: but the fruit, as it was ≈øent to vs, is in forme and bigne≈ø≈øe like vnto a Date, couered with a blacki≈øh skinne, ≈øet in a huske of foure hard leaues, very firme like vnto a Date, and almo≈øt as ≈øweete, with great flat and thicke kernels within them, very like vnto the former, but larger.

div.head: The V≈øe of the≈øe Lote trees.
div.p: The fir≈øt ≈øort is eaten as an helper to coole and binde the body: the la≈øt, as Captaine Smith relateth in the di≈øcouery of Virginia, if the fruit be eaten while it is greene, and not ripe, is able by the har≈øh and binding ta≈øte and quality to draw ones mouth awry (euen as it is ≈øaid of the former Guaiacana) but when it is thorough ripe it is plea≈øant, as I ≈øaid before.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Cornus mas. The Cornell tree.
div.p: THe Cornell tree that is planted in Orchards, being the male (for the female is an hedge bu≈øh) is of two ≈øorts, the one bearing red, the other whiter berries, which is very rare yet in our country, and not differing el≈øe.

It groweth to a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe and height, yet neuer to any great tree, the wood whereof is very hard, like vnto horne, and thereof it obtained the name: the body and branches are couered with a rugged barke, and ≈øpreadeth rea≈øonable well, hauing ≈øomewhat ≈ømooth leaues, full of veines, plaine, and not dented on the edges: the flowers are many ≈ømall yellow tufts, as it were of ≈øhort haires or threads ≈øet together, which come forth before any leafe, and fall away likewi≈øe before any leafe bee much open: the fruit are long and round berries, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of ≈ømall Oliues, with an
hard round ≈øtone within them, like vnto an Oliue ≈øtone, and are of a yellowi≈øh red when they are ripe, of a rea≈øonable plea≈øant ta≈øte, yet ≈øomewhat au≈øtere withall.
The white (as I ≈øaid) is like vnto the red, but onely that his fruit is more white when it is ripe.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Cornelles.
div.p: They helpe to binde the body, and to ≈øtay laskes, and by rea≈øon of the plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe in them when they are ripe, they are much de≈øired.
They are al≈øo pre≈øerued and eaten, both for rarity and delight, and for the purpo≈øe afore≈øaid.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Cera≈øus. The Cherry tree.
div.p: THere are ≈øo many varieties and differences of Cherries, that I know not well how to expre≈ø≈øe them vnto you, without a large relation of their ≈øeuerall formes. I will therefore endeauour after one generall de≈øcription (as my cu≈øtome is in many other the like variable fruits) to giue as briefe and ≈øhort notes vpon all the re≈øt, as I can both for leafe and fruit, that ≈øo you may the better know what the fruit is, when you haue the name.

The Engli≈øh Cherrie tree groweth in time to be of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe and height, ≈øpreading great armes, and al≈øo ≈ømall twiggy branches plentifully; the leaues whereof are not varie large or long, but nicked or dented about the edges: the flowers come forth two or three or foure at the mo≈øt together, at a knot or ioynt, euerie one by it ≈øelfe, vpon his owne ≈ømall and long foote≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of fiue white leaues, with ≈øome threds in the middle; after which come round berries, greene at the fir≈øt, and red when they are through ripe, of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe, and of a plea≈øant ≈øweete ta≈øte, ≈øomew hat tart withall, with a hard white ≈øtone within it, who≈øe kernell is ≈øomewhat bitter, but not vnplea≈øant.
The Flanders Cherrie differeth not from the Engli≈øh, but that it is ≈øomewhat larger, and the Cherry ≈øomewhat greater and ≈øweeter, and not ≈øo ≈øower.

The early Flanders Cherry is more rathe or early ripe, almo≈øt as ≈øoone as the May Cherry, e≈øpecially planted again≈øt a wall, and of many fal≈øe knaues or Gardiners are ≈øold for May Cherrie trees.
The May Cherrie in a ≈øtandard beareth ripe fruite later then planted again≈øt a wall, where the berries will be red in the verie beginning of May ≈øometimes.

The Arch-Dukes Cherrie is one of the faire≈øt and be≈øt cherries wee haue, being of a very red colour when it is ripe, and a little long more then round, and ≈øomewhat pointed at the end, of the be≈øt relli≈øh of any Cherrie what≈øoeuer, and of a firme ≈øub≈øtance; ≈øcarce one of twentie of our Nur≈øerie men doe ≈øell the right, but giue one for another: for it is an inherent qualitie almo≈øt hereditarie with mo≈øt of them, to ≈øell any man an ordinary fruit for what≈øoeuer rare fruit he ≈øhall aske for: ≈øo little they are to be tru≈øted.

The ounce Cherrie hath the greate≈øt and broade≈øt leafe of any other cherrie, but beareth the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øtore of cherries euerie yeare that any doth, and yet blo≈ø≈øometh well: the fruit al≈øo is nothing an≈øwerable to the name being not verie great, of a pale yellowi≈øh red, neere the colour of Amber, and therefore ≈øome haue called it, the Amber Cherrie.

The great leafed Cherrie is thought of diuers to bee the Ounce Cherrie, becau≈øe it hath almo≈øt as great a leafe as the former: but the fruit of this al≈øo doth not an≈øwer the expectation of ≈øo great a leafe, being but of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe, and a ≈ømall bearer, yet of a pale reddi≈øh colour.

The true Ga≈øcoign Cherry is known but to a few; for our Nur≈øery men do ≈øo change the names of mo≈øt fruits they ≈øell, that they deliuer but very few true names to any: In former times before our wilde blacke Cherrie was found to grow plentifully in our owne woods in many places of this Land, the French continually ≈øtored vs with wilde ≈øtockes to graft vpon, which then were called Ga≈øcoigne ≈øtocks, but ≈øince they haue ≈øo
termed another red Cherrie, and obtruded it vpon their cu≈øtomers: but the true is one of our late ripe white Cherries, euen as Gerard ≈øaith, it is a great cherrie and ≈øpotted: and this is that Cherrie I ≈øo commend to be a fit ≈øtocke to graft May cherries vpon.

The Morello Cherrie is of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe, of a darke red colour when they are full ripe, and hang long on, of a ≈øweeti≈øh ≈øower ta≈øte, the pulpe or ≈øub≈øtance is red, and ≈øomewhat firme: if they be dryed they will haue a fine ≈øharpe or ≈øower ta≈øte very delectable.
The Hartlippe Cherrie is ≈øo called of the place where the be≈øt of this kinde is nour≈øed vp, being betweene Sitting bourne and Chattam in Kent, and is the bigge≈øt of our Engli≈øh kindes.

The ≈ømaller Lacure or Hart Cherrie is a rea≈øonable faire Cherrie, full aboue, and a little pointing downward, after the fa≈øhion of an heart, as it is v≈øually painted, blacki≈øh when it is full ripe, and le≈ø≈øer then the next.

The great Lacure or Hart Cherrie differeth not in forme, but in greatne≈ø≈øe, being v≈øually twice as great as the former, and of a reddi≈øh blacke colour al≈øo: both of them are of a firme ≈øub≈øtance, and rea≈øonable ≈øweete. Some doe call the white cherrie, the White hart cherrie.

The Luke Wardes Cherrie hath a rea≈øonable large leafe, and a larger flower then many other: the cherries grow with long ≈øtalkes, and a ≈øtone of a meane ≈øize within them, of a darke reddi≈øh colour when they are full ripe, of a rea≈øonable good relli≈øh, and beareth well.

The Corone Cherrie hath a leafe little differing from the Luke Wardes cherrie; the fruit when it is ripe, is of a faire deepe red colour, of a good bigne≈ø≈øe, and of a verie good ta≈øte, neither verie ≈øweete or ≈øower: the pulpe or iuice will ≈øtaine the hands.

The Vrinall Cherrie in a mo≈øt fruitfull yeare is a ≈ømall bearer, hauing many yeares none, and the be≈øt but a few; yet doth blo≈ø≈øome plentifully euery yeare for the mo≈øt part: the cherrie is long and round, like vnto an Vrinall, from whence it tooke his name; reddi≈øh when it is full ripe, and of an indifferent ≈øweete relli≈øh.

The Agriot Cherrie is but a ≈ømall Cherrie, of a deepe redde colour when it is ripe, which is late; of a fine ≈øharpe ta≈øte, mo≈øt plea≈øant and whol≈øome to the ≈øtomacke of all other cherries, as well while they are fre≈øh as being dryed, which manner they much v≈øe in France, and keepe them for the v≈øe both of the ≈øicke and ≈øound at all times.
The Biguarre Cherrie is a fair cherrie, much ≈øpotted with white ≈øpots vpon the pale red berry, and ≈øometimes di≈øcoloured halfe white and halfe reddi≈øh, of a rea≈øonable good relli≈øh.

The Morocco Cherrie hath a large white blo≈ø≈øome, and an indifferent big berrie, long and round, with a long ≈øtalke of a darke reddi≈øh purple colour, a little tending to a blew when it is full ripe, of a firme ≈øub≈øtance: the iuice is of a blacki≈øh red, di≈øcolouring the hands or lips, and of a plea≈øant ta≈øte: Some doe thinke that this and the Morello be both one.
The Naples Cherrie is al≈øo thought to bee all one with the Morello or Morocco.

The white Spani≈øh Cherrie is an indifferent good bearer, the leafe and blo≈ø≈øome ≈øomewhat large, and like the Luke Wardes cherrie: the cherries are rea≈øonable faire berries, with long ≈øtalkes and great ≈øtones, white on the out≈øide, with ≈øome redne≈ø≈øe, on the one ≈øide of a firme ≈øub≈øtance, and rea≈øonable ≈øweet, but with a little aciditie, and is one of the late ripe ones: But there is another late ripe white Cherry, which ≈øome call the Ga≈øcoigne, before remembred.

The Flanders clu≈øter Cherrie is of two ≈øorts, one greater then another: the greater kinde hath an indifferent large leafe; the blo≈ø≈øomes haue many threds within them, ≈øhewing as it were many parts, which after turne into clu≈øters of berries, foure, fiue or ≈øixe together, and but with one ≈øtalke vnder them, as if they grew one out of another, and ≈øometimes they will beare but two or three, and mo≈øt of them but one cherry on a ≈øtalke, which are red when they are ripe, very tender, and wateri≈øh ≈øweete in eating.
The le≈ø≈øer is in all things like the greater, but ≈ømaller, which maketh the difference.

The wilde clu≈øter or birds clu≈øter Cherry beareth many blo≈ø≈øomes ≈øet all along the ≈øtalkes, and cherries after them in the ≈øame maner, like long thinne bunch of grapes, and therefore called of ≈øome the Grape cherry: there are of them both red and blacke.

figure.head:
1 Cera≈øus pracox. The May Cherry. 2 Cera≈øus Batanica. The Flanders Cherry. 3 Cera≈øus hi≈øpanica fiue alba. The white Cherry. 4 Cera≈øus plat ‚Ä¢
phyllos. The great leafed Cherry. 5 Cera≈øus Luca Wards. Luke Wards Cherry. 6 Cera≈øus Neapolita ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The Naples Cherry. 7 Cera≈øus Cora ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ta. The Heart Cherry. 8 Cera≈øus maculata. The bignarre or ≈øpotted Cherry. 9 Cera≈øus a ‚Ä¢ ium recemo≈øa. The wilde clu≈øter Cherry. 10 Cera≈øus Corymbifera. The Flanders clu≈øter Cherry. 11 Cera≈øus Archiducu. The Archdukes Cherry. 12 Chamacera≈øus. The dwarfe Cheryy.

div.p: The ≈øoft ≈øheld Cherrie is a ≈ømall red cherrie when it is ripe, hauing the ≈øtone within it ≈øo ≈øoft and tender, that it may ea≈øily be broken in the eating of the cherrie.

Iohn Trade≈øcantes Cherrie is mo≈øt v≈øually ≈øold by our Nur≈øery Gardiners, for the Archdukes cherrie, becau≈øe they haue more plenty thereof, and will better be increa≈øed, and becau≈øe it is ≈øo faire and good a cherrie that it may be obtruded without much di≈øcontent: it is a rea≈øonable good bearer, a faire great berrie, deepe coloured, and a little pointed.

The Baccalaos or New-found-land Cherrie hath a ≈øhining long leafe, mo≈øt like vnto a Peach lea≈øe, the blo≈ø≈øomes come very many together as it werein an vmbell, which is ≈øuch a clu≈øter as is neither like the Flanders clu≈øter, nor the wilde clu≈øter cherrie blo≈ø≈øome: it bringeth forth berries ≈øtanding in the ≈øame manner euerie one vpon his own foote≈øtalke, being no bigger then the large≈øt berrie of the red Curran tree or bu≈øh, of a pale or wateri≈øh red colour when it is ripe.

The ≈øtrange long clu≈øter Cherrie, or Padus Theophrasti Dalechampio is reckoned by the Author of that great Herball that goeth vnder his name, among the ≈øorts of cherries; and ≈øo mu≈øt I vntill a fitter place be found for it. It groweth in time to be a great tree, with a ≈øad coloured barke both on the bodie and branches, whereon doe grow many leaues, ≈øomewhat broade, ≈øhorter, harder, and a little more crumpled then any cherrie leafe: the blo≈ø≈øomes are very ≈ømall, and of a pale or whiti≈øh colour, ≈ømelling very ≈øweete and ≈øtrong, or rather heady, like Orenge flowers, growing on ≈ømall long branches, very like the toppe of flowers vpon the Laburnum or Beane trefoile trees: after which come ≈ømall blacke berries, growing together all along the long ≈øtalke, like vnto the wilde clu≈øter or birds cherrie mentioned before, but not much bigger then tares, with ≈ømall ≈øtones within them, and little or no ≈øu≈øtance vpon them: the French call the tree Putier, becau≈øe the wood thereof ≈øtinketh, and make it to be wonderfull that the blo≈ø≈øomes of the tree ≈øhould be ≈øo ≈øweete, and the wood ≈øo ≈øtinking.
The Cullen Cherrie is a darke red cherrie like the Agriot, which they of tho≈øe parts neere Cullen and Vtrecht &c. v≈øe to put into their drinke, to giue it the deeper colour.

The great Hungarian Cherrie of Zwerts is like both in leafe and fruite vnto the Morello cherrie, but much greater and fairer, and a far better bearer: for from a ≈ømall branch hath beene gathered a pound of cherries, and this is v≈øuall continually, and not accidentally, mo≈øt of them foure inches in compa≈ø≈øe about, and very many of them more of a faire deepe red colour, and very ≈øweete, excelling the Arch-Dukes cherry, or any other what≈øoeuer.

The Cameleon or ≈øtrange changeable Cherry de≈øeruedly hath this name, although of mine owne impo≈øition, not only becau≈øe it beareth v≈øually both blo≈ø≈øomes, greene and ripe fruit at one time thereupon, but that the fruit will be of many formes; ≈øome round, ≈øome as it were ≈øquare, and ≈øome bunched forth on one ≈øide or another, abiding con≈øtant in no fa≈øhion, but for the mo≈øt part ≈øhewing forth all the≈øe diuer≈øities euerie yeare growing vpon it: the fruit is of a very red colour, and good ta≈øte.

The great Ro≈øe Cherry, or double blo≈ø≈øomd Cherry differeth not in anything from the Engli≈øh Cherrie, but only in the blo≈ø≈øomes, which are very thicke of white leaues, as great and double as the double white Crowfoote, before remembred, and ≈øomtimes out of the middle of them will ≈øpring another ≈ømaller flower, but double al≈øo; this ≈øeldome beareth fruit, but when it doth I ≈øuppo≈øe it commeth from tho≈øe blo≈ø≈øomes are the lea≈øt double, and is red, no bigger then our ordinary Engli≈øh cherrie.

The le≈ø≈øer Ro≈øe or double blo≈ø≈øomd Cherrie beareth double flowers al≈øo, but not ≈øo thicke and double as the former; but beareth fruit more plentifully, of the ≈øame colour and bigne≈ø≈øe with the former.
The Dwarfe Cherrie is of two ≈øorts; one who≈øe branches fall downe low, round about the body of it, with ≈ømall greene leaues, and fruit as ≈ømall, of a deep red colour.

The other, who≈øe branches, although ≈ømall, grow more vpright, hauing greener ≈øhining leaues: the fruit is little bigger then the former, red al≈øo when it is ripe, with a little point at the end: both of them of a ≈øweetith relli≈øh, but more ≈øower.

The great bearing Cherry of Ma≈øter Millen is a rea≈øonable great red cherry, bearing very plentifully, although it bee planted again≈øt a North wall, yet it will bee late ripe, but of an indifferent ≈øweet and good relli≈øh.
The long finger Cherry is another ≈ømall long red one, being long & round like a finger, wherof it took the name: this is not the Vrinall cherry before, but differing from it.

div.head: The V≈øe of Cherries.
div.p: All the≈øe ≈øorts of Cherries ≈øerue wholly to plea≈øe the palate, and are eaten at all times, both before and after meales.
All Cherries are cold, yet the ≈øower more then the ≈øweete; and although the ≈øweete doe mo≈øt plea≈øe, yet the ≈øower are more whol≈øome, if there bee regard taken in the v≈øing.

The Agriot or ≈øower Cherries are in France much v≈øed to bee dryed (as is ≈øaid before) as Pruines are, and ≈øo ≈øerue to mini≈øtred to be the ≈øick in all hot di≈øea≈øes, as feuers &c. being both boyled in their drinkes, and taken now and then of them≈øelues, which by rea≈øon of their tartne≈ø≈øe, doe plea≈øe the ≈øtomacke pa≈ø≈øing well.

The Gum of the Cherrie tree is commended to bee good for tho≈øe are troubled with the grauell or ≈øtone. It is al≈øo good for the cough being di≈ø≈øolued in liquour, and ≈øtirreth vp an appetite. The di≈øtilled water of the blacke Cherries, the ≈øtones being broken among them, is v≈øed for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, for the grauell, ≈øtone, and winde.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Prunus. The Plumme tree.
div.p: THere are many more varieties of Plummes then of Cherries, ≈øo that I mu≈øt follow the ≈øame order with the≈øe that I did with them, euen giue you their names apart, with briefe notes vpon them, and one de≈øcription to ≈øerue for all the re≈øt. And in this recitall I ≈øhall leaue out the Apricockes which are certainly a kind of Plum, of an e≈øpeciall difference, and not of a Peach, as Galen and ≈øome others haue thought, and ≈øet them in a chapter by them≈øelues, and only in this ≈øee down tho≈øe fruits are v≈øually called Plums.

The Plum tree (e≈øpecially diuers of them) ri≈øeth in time to bee a rea≈øonable tall and great tree, who≈øe bodie and greater armes are couered with a more rugged barke, yet in ≈øome more or le≈ø≈øe, the younger branches being ≈ømooth in all, the leaues are ≈øomewhat rounder then tho≈øe of the Cherrie tree, and much differing among them≈øelues, ≈øome being longer, or larger, or rounder then others, and many that are exerci≈øed herein, can tell by the leafe what Plum the tree beareth (I ≈øpeake this of many, not of all) as in many Cherries they can doe the like: the flowers are white, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues: the fruit is as variable in forme, as in ta≈øte or colour, ≈øome being ovall or Peare fa≈øhion or Almond like, or ≈øphericall or round, ≈øome firme, ≈øome ≈øoft and wateri≈øh, ≈øome ≈øweete, ≈øome ≈øower or har≈øh, or differing from all the≈øe ta≈øtes: and ≈øome white, others blacke, ≈øome red, others yellow, ≈øome purple, others blew, as they ≈øhall bee briefly ≈øet downe vnto you in the following lines, where I meane not to in≈øert any the wilde or hedge fruit, but tho≈øe only are fit for an Orchard, to be ≈øtored with good fruit: and of all which ≈øorts, the choy≈øe≈øt for goodne≈ø≈øe, and rare≈øt for knowledge, are to be had of my very good friend Ma≈øter Iohn Trade≈øcante, who hath wonderfully laboured to obtaine all the rare≈øt fruits hee can heare off in any place of Chri≈øtendome, Turky, yea or the whole world; as al≈øo with Ma≈øter Iohn Millen, dwelling in Olde ≈øtreete, who from Iohn Trade≈øcante and all others that haue had good fruit, hath ≈øtored him≈øelfe with the be≈øt only, and he can ≈øufficiently furni≈øh any.
The Amber Primordian Plumme is an indifferent faire Plumme, early ripe, of a pale yellowi≈øh colour, and of a wateri≈øh ta≈øte, not plea≈øing.
The red Primordian Plumme is of a rea≈øonable ≈øize, long and round, reddi≈øh on the out≈øide, of a more dry ta≈øte, and ripe with the fir≈øt ≈øorts in the beginning of Augu≈øt.
The blew Primordian is a ≈ømall plumme, almo≈øt like the Dama≈øcene, and is ≈øubiect to drop off from the tree before it be ripe.
The white Date Plum is no very good plum.
The red Date plumme is a great long red pointed plumme, and late ripe, little better then the white.
The blacke Mu≈ø≈øell plumme is a good plumme, rea≈øonable drye, and ta≈øteth well.
The red Mu≈ø≈øell Plumme is ≈øomewhat flat as well as round, of a very good ta≈øte, and is ripe about the middle of Augu≈øt.
The white Mu≈ø≈øell plumme is like the redde, but ≈øomewhat ≈ømaller, and of a whiti≈øh greene colour, but not ≈øo well ta≈øted.
The Imperiall plum is a great long reddi≈øh plum, very wateri≈øh, and ripeneth ≈øomewhat late.
The Gaunt plum is a great round reddi≈øh plum, ripe ≈øomewhat late, and eateth wateri≈øh.
The red Pe≈øcod plum is a rea≈øonable good plum.
The white Pe≈øcod plum is a rea≈øonable good relli≈øhed plumme, but ≈øomewhat wateri≈øh.
The greene Pe≈øcod plum is a rea≈øonable big and long pointed plum, and ripe in the beginning of September.
The Orenge plum is a yellowi≈øh plum, moi≈øt, and ≈øomewhat ≈øweeti≈øh.
The Morocco plumme is blacke like a Dam≈øon, well ta≈øted, and ≈øomewhat drye in eating.
The Dine plum is a late ripe plum, great and whiti≈øh, ≈øpeckled all ouer.
The Turkie plum is a large long blacki≈øh plum, and ≈øomewhat flat like the Mu≈ø≈øell plum, a well relli≈øhed dry plum.
The Nutmeg plumme is no bigger then a Dam≈øon, and is of a greeni≈øh yellow colour when it is ripe, which is with vs about Bartholmew tide, and is a good plum.
The Perdigon plumme is a dainty good plumme, early blacki≈øh, and well relli≈øhed.
The Verdoch plum is a great fine greene ≈øhining plum fit to pre≈øerue.
The Ienua plum is the white Date plum, before remembred.
The Barberry plum is a great early blacke plum, and well ta≈øted.

The Pruneola plum is a ≈ømall white plum, of a fine tart ta≈øte: it was wont to bee v≈øually brought ouer in ≈ømall round boxes, and ≈øold mo≈øt commonly at the Comfitmakers, (cut in twaine, the ≈øtone ca≈øt away) at a very deere rate: the tree groweth and beareth well with vs.
The Shepway Bulleis is of a darke blewi≈øh brown colour, of a larger ≈øize then the ordinary, and of a ≈øharpe ta≈øte, but not ≈øo good as the common.
The white and the blacke Bulleis are common in mo≈øt Countries, being ≈ømall round plums, le≈ø≈øer then Dam≈øons, ≈øharper in ta≈øte, and later ripe.
The Flu≈øhing Bulleis groweth with his fruite thicke clu≈øtring together like grapes.
The Winter Creke is the late≈øt ripe plum of all ≈øorts, it groweth plentifully about Bi≈øhops Hatfield.
The white Peare plum early ripe, is of a pale yellowi≈øh greene colour.
The late ripe white Peare plum is a greater and longer plum, greeni≈øh white, and is not ripe vntill it be neere the end of September, both wateri≈øh plums.
The blacke Peare plum is like vnto the white Peare plumme, but that the colour is blacki≈øh when it is ripe, and is of a very good relli≈øh, more firme and drye then the other.
The red Peare plumme is of the ≈øame fa≈øhion and goodne≈ø≈øe, but is the wor≈øt of the three.
The white Wheate plum is a wateri≈øh ful≈øome plum.
The red Wheate plum is like the other for ta≈øte.
The Bowle plum is flat and round, yet flatter on the one ≈øide then on the other, which cau≈øed the name, and is a very good relli≈øhed blacke plum.
The Friars plumme is a very good plum, well ta≈øted, and comming cleane from the ≈øtone, being blacke when it is ripe, and ≈øome whiti≈øh ≈øpots vpon it.
The Catalonia plum is a very good plum.
The don Alteza is al≈øo a very good plum.
The Mu≈øcadine plum, ≈øome call the Queene mother plumme, and ≈øome the Cherry plum, is a faire red plum, of a rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe, and ripe about Bartholmew tide.

figure.head: 1 Prunum Imperiale. The Imperiall Plum. 2 Prunum Tureicum. The Turkey Plum. 3 Prunum pracox rubrum. The red Primordian Plum. 4 Prunum Mytellinum. The Mu≈ø≈øell Plum. 5 Prunum Ambarinum. The Amber Plum. 6 Prunum Regineum. The Queen mother Plum. 7 Prunum viride. The green Oy≈øterly Plum. 8 Prunum Arantiacum. The Orenge Plum. 9 Prunum Myri≈øticum. The Nutmeg Plum. 10 Prunum Siliquo≈øum. The Pe≈øcod Plum. 11 Prunum Gandanen≈øe. The Ganat Plum. 12 Prunum Dactylites. The Date Plum. 13 Prunum Pyrinum praecox. The early Peare Plum.

div.p: The Cherry plum remembred before, ≈øpeaking of the Mu≈øcadine plum, is a very good plum, but ≈ømall.

The Amber plum is a round plum, as yellow on the out≈øide almo≈øt as yellow waxe, of a ≈øowre vnplea≈øant ta≈øte that which I ta≈øted, but I thinke it was not the right; for I haue ≈øeene and ta≈øted another of the ≈øame bigne≈ø≈øe, of a paler colour, farre better relli≈øhed, and a firmer ≈øub≈øtance, comming cleane from the ≈øtone like an Apricocke.

The Apricocke plum is a good plum when it is in its perfection, but that is ≈øeldome; for it doth mo≈øt v≈øually cracke, thereby dimini≈øhing much of its goodne≈ø≈øe, and be≈øides yeeldeth gumme at the crackes.
The Ea≈øon plum is a little red plum, but very good in ta≈øte.
The Violet plum is a ≈ømall and long blacki≈øh blew plum, ripe about Bartholomew tide, a very good dry eating fruit.
The Grape plum is the Flu≈øhing Bulleis before remembred
The Dennie plum is called al≈øo the Che≈øton, or the Friars plum before remembred.
The Damaske Violet plum, or Queen mother plum ≈øpoken of before.
The blacke Dama≈øcene plum is a very good dry plum, and of a darkeblew colour when it is ripe.
The white Dam≈øon is nothing ≈øo well relli≈øhed as the other.
The great Dam≈øon or Damaske plum is greater then the ordinary Dam≈øon, and ≈øweeter in ta≈øte.
The blew Dam≈øon well knowne, a good fruit.
The Coferers plum is flat, like vnto a Peare plum, it is early ripe and blacke, of a very good relli≈øh.
The Margate plum the wor≈øt of an hundred.
The green Oy≈øterly plum is a rea≈øonable great plum, of a whiti≈øh green colour when it is ripe, of a moi≈øt and ≈øweete ta≈øte, rea≈øonable good.

The red Mirobalane plum groweth to be a great tree quickly, ≈øpreading very thicke and farre, very like the blacke Thorne or Sloe bu≈øh: the fruit is red, earlier ripe, and of a better ta≈øte then the white.

The white Mirobalane plum is in mo≈øt things like the former red, but the fruit is of a whiti≈øh yellow colour, and very plea≈øant, e≈øpecially if it be not ouer ripe: both the≈øe had need to be pla≈øhed again≈øt a wall, or el≈øe they will hardly beare ripe fruit.
The Oliue plum is very like a greene Oliue, both for colour and bigne≈ø≈øe, and groweth lowe on a ≈ømall bu≈øhing tree, and ripeneth late, but is the be≈øt of all the ≈øorts of greene plums.
The white diapred plum of Malta, ≈øcarce knowne to any in our Land but Iohn Trade≈øcante, is a very good plum, and ≈øtriped all ouer like diaper, and thereby ≈øo called.
The blacke diapred plum is like the Dama≈øcene plum, being blacke with ≈øpots, as ≈ømall as pins points vpon it, of a very good relli≈øh.
The Peake plum is a long whiti≈øh plum, and very good.

The Pi≈øhamin or Virginia plum is called a plum, but vtterly differeth from all ≈øorts of plums, the de≈øcription whereof may truely enforme you, as it is ≈øet downe in the tenth Chapter going before, whereunto I referre you.

div.head: The V≈øe of Plums.
div.p: The great Damaske or Dam≈øon Plummes are dryed in France in great quantities, and brought ouer vnto vs in Hogs-heads, and other great ve≈ø≈øels, and are tho≈øe Prunes that are v≈øually ≈øold at the Grocers, vnder the name of Damaske Prunes: the blacke Bulleis al≈øo are tho≈øe (being dryed in the ≈øame manner) that they call French Prunes, and by their tartne≈ø≈øe are thought to binde, as the other, being ≈øweet, to loo≈øen the body.

The Bruneola Plumme, by rea≈øon of his plea≈øant tartne≈ø≈øe, is much accounted of, and being dryed, the ≈øtones taken from them, are brought ouer to vs in ≈ømall boxes, and ≈øold deere at the Comfitmakers, where they very often accompany all other ≈øorts of banquetting ≈øtuffes.

Some of the≈øe Plums, becau≈øe of their firmne≈ø≈øe, are vndoubtedly more whol≈øome then others that are ≈øweete and wateri≈øh, and cau≈øele≈ø≈øe offence in their ≈øtomackes that eate them; and therefore are pre≈øerued with Sugar, to be kept all the yeare. None of them all is v≈øed in medicines ≈øo much as the great Dam≈øon or Damaske Prune, although all of them for the mo≈øt part doe coole, lenifie, and draw forth choller, and thereby are fitted to be v≈øed of ≈øuch as haue chollericke Agues.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
Mala Armeniaca ≈øiue Praecocia. Apricockes.
div.p: THe Apricocke (as I ≈øaid) is without que≈øtion a kinde of Plumme, rather then a Peach, both the flower being white, and the ≈øtone of the fruit ≈ømooth al≈øo, like a Plumme, and yet becau≈øe of the excellencie of the fruit, and the difference therein from all other Plummes, I haue thought it meete to entreate thereof by it ≈øelfe, and ≈øhew you the varieties haue been ob≈øerued in the≈øe times.

The Apricocke tree ri≈øeth vp to a very great height, either ≈øtanding by it ≈øelfe (where it beareth not ≈øo kindly, and very little in our country) or planted again≈øt a wall, as it is mo≈øt v≈øuall, hauing a great ≈øtemme or body, and likewi≈øe many great armes or branches, couered with a ≈ømooth barke: the leaues are large, broad, and almo≈øt round, but pointed at the ends, and finely dented about the edges: the flowers are white, as the Plumme tree blo≈ø≈øomes, but ≈øomewhat larger, and rounder ≈øet: the fruit is round, with a cleft on the one ≈øide, ≈øomewhat like vnto a Peach, being of a yellowi≈øh colour as well on the in≈øide as out≈øide, of a firme or fa≈øt ≈øub≈øtance, and dry, not ouermoi≈øt in the eating, and very plea≈øant in ta≈øte, containing within it a broad and flat ≈øtone, ≈øomewhat round and ≈ømooth, not rugged as the Peach ≈øtone, with a plea≈øant ≈øweete kernell (yet ≈øome haue reported, that there is ≈øuch as haue their kernels bitter, which I did neuer ≈øee or know) and is ripe almo≈øt with our fir≈øt or earlie≈øt Plummes, and thereof it tooke the name of Pracox; and it may bee was the earlie≈øt of all others was then knowne, when that name was giuen.
The great Apricocke, which ≈øome call the long Apricocke, is the greate≈øt and faire≈øt of all the re≈øt.

The ≈ømaller Apricocke, which ≈øome call the ≈ømall round Apricocke, is thought to be ≈ømall, becau≈øe it fir≈øt ≈øprang from a ≈øtone: but that is not ≈øo; for the kinde it ≈øelfe being inoculated, will bee alwaies ≈ømall, and neuer halfe ≈øo faire and great as the former.

The white Apricocke hath his leaues more folded together, as if it were halfe double: it beareth but ≈øeldome, and very few, which differ not from the ordinary, but in being more white, without any red when it is ripe.

The Ma≈øcoline Apricocke hath a finer greene leafe, and thinner then the former, and beareth very ≈øeldome any ≈øtore of fruit, which differeth in nothing from the fir≈øt, but that it is a little more delicate.
The long Ma≈øcoline Apricocke hath his fruit growing a little longer then the former, and differeth in nothing el≈øe.

The Argier Apricocke is a ≈ømaller fruit then any of the other, and yellow, but as ≈øweete and delicate as any of them, hauing a blacki≈øh ≈øtone within it, little bigger then a Lacure Cherry ≈øtone: this with many other ≈øorts Iohn Trade≈øcante brought with him returning from the Argier voyage, whither hee went voluntary with the Fleete, that went again≈øt the Pyrates in the yeare 1620.

div.head: The V≈øe of Apricockes.
div.p: Apricockes are eaten oftentimes in the ≈øame manner that other dainty Plummes are, betweene meales of them≈øelues, or among other fruit at banquets.
They are al≈øo pre≈øerued and candid, as it plea≈øeth Gentlewomen to be≈øtowe their time and charge, or the Comfitmaker to ≈øort among other candid fruits.
Some likewi≈øe dry them, like vnto Peares, Apples, Dam≈øons, and other Plummes.

Matthiolus doth wonderfully commend the oyle drawne from the kernels of the ≈øtones, to annoint the inflamed haemorrhoides or piles, the ≈øwellings of vlcers, the roughne≈ø≈øe of the tongue and throate, and likewi≈øe the paines of the eares.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Mala Per≈øica. Peaches.
div.p: AS Iordered the Cherries and Plummes, ≈øo I intend to deale with Peaches, becau≈øe their varieties are many, and more knowne in the≈øe dayes then in former times: but becau≈øe the Nectorin is a differing kinde of Peach, I mu≈øt deale with it as I did with the Apricocke among the Plummes, that is, place it in a Chapter by it ≈øelfe.

The Peach tree of it ≈øelfe groweth not v≈øually altogether ≈øo great, or high as the Apricocke, becau≈øe it is le≈ø≈øe durable, but yet ≈øpreadeth with faire great branches, from whence ≈øpring ≈ømaller and ≈ølenderer reddi≈øh twigges, whereon are ≈øet long narrow greene leaues, dented about the edges: the blo≈ø≈øomes are greater then of any Plumme, of a deepe blu≈øh or light purple colour: after which commeth the fruit, which is round, and ≈øometimes as great as a rea≈øonable Apple or Pippin (I ≈øpeake of ≈øome ≈øorts; for there be ≈øome kindes that are much ≈ømaller) with a furrow or cleft on the one ≈øide, and couered with a free≈øe or cotton on the out≈øide, of colour either ru≈ø≈øet, or red, or yellow, or of a blacki≈øh red colour; of differing ≈øub≈øtances and ta≈øtes al≈øo, ≈øome being firme, others wateri≈øh, ≈øome cleauing fa≈øt to the ≈øtone on the in≈øide, others parting from it more or le≈ø≈øe ea≈øily, one excelling another very farre, wherein is contained a rugged ≈øtone, with many chinkes or clefts in it, the kernell whereof is bitter: the roots growe neither deepe nor farre; and therefore are ≈øubiect to the winds, ≈øtanding alone, and not again≈øt a wall. It ≈øooner waxeth old and decayeth, being ≈øprung of a ≈øtone, then being inoculated on a Plumme ≈øtocke, whereby it is more durable.
The great white Peach is white on the out≈øide as the meate is al≈øo, and is a good well relli≈øhed fruit.
The ≈ømall white Peach is all one with the greater, but differeth in ≈øize.

The Carnation Peach is of three ≈øorts, two are round, and the third long; they are all of a whiti≈øh colour, ≈øhadowed ouer with red, and more red on the ≈øide is next the ≈øunne: the le≈ø≈øer round is the more common, and the later ripe.
The grand Carnation Peach is like the former round Peach, but greater, and is as late ripe, that is, in the beginning of September.
The red Peach is an exceeding well relli≈øhed fruit.
The ru≈ø≈øet Peach is one of the mo≈øt ordinary Peaches in the Kingdome, being of a ru≈ø≈øet colour on the out≈øide, and but of a rea≈øonable relli≈øh, farre meaner then many other.
The I≈øland Peach is a faire Peach, and of a very good relli≈øh.
The Newington Peach is a very good Peach, and of an excellent good relli≈øh, being of a whiti≈øh greene colour on the out≈øide, yet halfe reddi≈øh, and is ripe about Bartholmew tide.
The yellow Peach is of a deepe yellow colour; there be hereof diuers ≈øorts, ≈øome good and ≈øome bad.
The St. Iames Peach is the ≈øame with the Queenes Peach, here belowe ≈øet downe, although ≈øome would make them differing.

The Melocotone Peach is a yellow faire Peach, but differing from the former yellow both in forme and ta≈øte, in that this hath a ≈ømall crooked end or point for the mo≈øt part, it is ripe before them, and better relli≈øhed then any of them.

figure.head: 1 Malus Armeni ‚Ä¢ ea fiue Pracociae. The Apricoeke. 2 Malus Per≈øica Melocotonea. The Melocotone Peach. 3 Per≈øica Mo≈øchatellina. The Nutmeg Peach 4 Perfleanigra. The blacke Peach. 5 Perfica Caemea longa. The long Carnation Peach. 6 Perfica Reginea. The Queenes Peach. 7 Amygalalus. The Almond. 8 Perficadu Treas. The Peach du Troas. 9 Nuciperfica rubra optima. The be≈øt Romane red Nectorin. 10. Nuciperfica rubra altera. The ba≈øtard red Nectoria with a pincking bl ‚Ä¢ ≈øtome.

div.p: The Peach du Troas is a long and great withi≈øh yellow Peach, red on the out≈øide; early ripe, and is another kinde of Nutmeg Peach.
The Queenes Peach is a faire great yellowi≈øh browne Peach, ≈øhadowed as it were ouer with deepe red, and is ripe at Bartholmew tide, of a very plea≈øant good ta≈øte.
The Romane Peach is a very good Peach, and well pulli≈øhed.
The Dura≈øme or Spani≈øh Peach is of a darke yellowi≈øh red colour on the out≈øide, and white within.
The blacke Peach is a great large Perch, of a very darke browne colour on the out≈øide, it is of a wateri≈øh ta≈øte, and late ripe.
The Alberza Peach is late ripe, and of a rea≈øonable good ta≈øte.

The Almond Peach, ≈øo called, becau≈øe the kernell of the ≈øtone is ≈øweete, like the Almond, and the fruit al≈øo ≈øomewhat pointed like the Almond in the huske; it is early ripe, and like the Newington Peach, but le≈ø≈øer.
The Man Peach is of two ≈øorts, the one longer then the other, both of them are good Peaches, but the ≈øhorter is the better relli≈øhed.
The Cherry Peach is a ≈ømall Peach, but well ta≈øted.

The Nutmeg Peach is of two ≈øorts, one that will be hard when it is ripe, and eateth not ≈øo plea≈øantly as the other, which will bee ≈øoft and mellow; they are both ≈ømall Peaches, hauing very little or no re≈øemblance at all to a Nutmeg, except in being a little longer then round, and are early ripe.
Many other ≈øorts of Peaches there are, whereunto wee can giue no e≈øpeciall name; and therefore I pa≈ø≈øe them ouer in ≈øilence.

div.head: The V≈øe of Peaches.
div.p: Tho≈øe Peaches that are very moi≈øt and wateri≈øh (as many of them are) and not firme, doe ≈øoone putrefie in the ≈øtomacke, cau≈øing ≈øurfeits oftentimes; and therefore euery one had neede bee carefull, what and in what manner they eate them: yet they are much and often well accepted with all the Gentry of the Kingdome.

The leaues, becau≈øe of their bitterne≈ø≈øe, ≈øerue well being boyled in Ale or Milke, to be giuen vnto children that haue wormes, to help to kill them, and doe gently open the belly, if there be a ≈øufficient quantity v≈øed.
The flowers haue the like operation, that is, to purge the body ≈øomewhat more forceably then Damaske Ro≈øes; a Syrupe therefore made of the flowers is very good.

The kernels of the Peach ≈øtones are oftentimes v≈øed to be giuen to them that cannot well make water, or are trouble d with the ≈øtone; for it openeth the ≈øtoppings of the vritory pa≈ø≈øages, whereby much ea≈øe en≈øueth.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Nuciper≈øica. Nectorins.
div.p: I Pre≈øume that the name Nuciper≈øica, doth mo≈øt rightly belong vnto that kinde of Peach, which we call Nectorins, and although they haue beene with vs not many yeares, yet haue they beene knowne both in Italy to Matthiolus, and others before him, who it ≈øeemeth knew no other then the yellow Nectorin, as Dalechampius al≈øo: But we at this day doe know fiue ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of Nectorins, as they ≈øhall be pre≈øently ≈øet downe; and as in the former fruits, ≈øo in this, I will giue you the de≈øcription of one, and briefe notes of the re≈øt.

The Nectorin is a tree of no great bigne≈ø≈øe, mo≈øt v≈øually le≈ø≈øer then the Peach tree, his body and elder boughes being whiti≈øh, the younger branches very red, whereon grow narrow long greene leaues, ≈øo like vnto Peach leaues, that none can well di≈øtingui≈øh them, vnle≈ø≈øe it be in this, that they are ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer: the blo≈ø≈øomes are all reddi≈øh, as the Peach, but one of a differing fa≈øhion from all the other, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew you by and by: the fruit that followeth is ≈ømaller, rounder, and ≈ømoother then Peaches, without any cleft on the ≈øide, and without any douny cotton or freeze at all; and
herein is like vnto the outer greene rinde of the Wallnut, whereof as I am per≈øwaded it tooke the name, of a fa≈øt and firme meate, and very delicate in ta≈øte, e≈øpecially the be≈øt kindes, with a rugged ≈øtone within it, and a bitter kernell.

The Muske Nectorin, ≈øo called, be cau≈øe it being a kinde of the be≈øt red Nectorins, both ≈ømelleth and eateth as if the fruit were ≈øteeped in Muske: ≈øome thinke that this and the next Romane Nectorin are all one.

The Romane red Nectorin, or clu≈øter Nectorin, hath a large or great purpli≈øh blo≈ø≈øome, like vnto a Peach, reddi≈øh at the bottome on the out≈øide, and greeni≈øh within: the fruit is of a fine red colour on the out≈øide, and groweth in clu≈øters, two or three at a ioynt together, of an excellent good ta≈øte.

The ba≈øtard red Nectorin hath a ≈ømaller or pincking blo≈ø≈øome, more like threads then leaues, neither ≈øo large nor open as the former, and yellowi≈øh within at the bottome: the fruit is red on the out≈øide, and groweth neuer but one at a ioynt; it is a good fruit, but eateth a little more rawi≈øh then the other, euen when it is full ripe.
The yellow Nectorin is of two ≈øorts, the one an excellent fruit, mellow, and of a very good relli≈øh; the other hard, and no way comparable to it.

The greene Nectorin, great and ≈ømall; for ≈øuch I haue ≈øeene abiding con≈øtant, although both planted in one ground: they are both of one goodne≈ø≈øe, and accounted with mo≈øt to be the be≈øtrelli≈øhed Nectorin of all others.
The white Nectorin is ≈øaid to bee differing from the other, in that it will bee more white on the out≈øide when it is ripe, then either the yellow or greene: but I haue not yet ≈øeene it.

div.head: The V≈øe of Nectorins.
div.p: The fruit is more firme then the Peach, and more delectable in ta≈øte; and is therefore of more e≈øteeme, and that worthily.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Amygdala. Almonds.
div.p: THe Almond al≈øo may be reckoned vnto the ≈øtock or kindred of the Peaches, it is ≈øo like both in leafe and blo≈ø≈øome, and ≈øomewhat al≈øo in the fruit, for the outward forme, although it hath onely a dry skinne, and no pulpe or meate to bee eaten: but the kernell of the ≈øtone or ≈øhell, which is called the Almond, maketh recompen≈øe of that defect, whereof ≈øome are ≈øweete, ≈øome bitter, ≈øome great, ≈øome ≈ømall, ≈øome long, and ≈øome ≈øhort.

The Almond tree groweth vpright, higher and greater then any Peach; and is therefore v≈øually planted by it ≈øelfe, and not again≈øt a wall, who≈øe body ≈øometime exceedeth any mans fadome, whereby it ≈øheweth to be of longer continuance, bearing large armes, and ≈ømaller branches al≈øo, but brittle, whereon are ≈øet long and narrow leaues, like vnto the Peach tree: the blo≈ø≈øomes are purpli≈øh, like vnto Peach blo≈øoms, but paler: the fruit is ≈øomewhat like a Peach for the forme of the skinne or out≈øide, which is rough, but not with any ≈øuch cleft therein, or with any pulpe or meate fit to bee eaten, but is a thicke dry skinne when it is ripe, couering the ≈øtone or ≈øhell, which is ≈ømooth and not rugged, and is either long and great, or ≈ømall, or thicke and ≈øhort, according as the nut or kernell within it is, which is ≈øweete both in the greater and ≈ømaller, and onely one ≈ømaller kinde which is bitter: yet this I haue ob≈øerued, that all the Almond trees that I haue ≈øeene growe in England, both of the ≈øweete and bitter kindes, beare Almonds thicke and ≈øhort, and not long, as that ≈øort which is called the Iorden Almond.

div.head: The V≈øe of Almonds.
div.p:
They are v≈øed many wayes, and for many purpo≈øes, either eaten alone with Figges, or Ray≈øins of the Sunne, or made into pa≈øte with Sugar and Ro≈øewater for Marchpanes, or put among Floure, Egges, and Sugar, to
make Mackerons, or cru≈øted ouer with Sugar, to make Comfits, or mixed with Ro≈øewater and Sugar, to make Butter, or with Barley water, to make Milke, and many other waies, as euery one li≈øt, that hath skill in ≈øuch things.

The oyle al≈øo Almonds is v≈øed many waies, both inwardly and outwardly, for many purpo≈øes; as the oyle of ≈øweete Almonds mixt with poudered white Sugar Candy, for coughes and hoar≈øene≈ø≈øe, and to be drunk alone, or with ≈øome other thing (as the Syrupe of Mar≈øh Mallowes) for the ≈øtone to open and lenifie the pa≈ø≈øages, and make them ≈ølipperie, that the ≈øtone may pa≈ø≈øet the ea≈øier. And al≈øo for women in Child bed after their ≈øore trauell. And outwardly either by it ≈øelfe, or with oyle of Tartar to make a creame, to lenifie the skin, parched with the winde or otherwi≈øe, or to annoint the ≈øtomacke either alone, or with other things to helpe a cold.

The oyle of bitter Almonds is much v≈øed to be dropped into their eares that are hard of hearing, to helpe to open them. And as it is thought, doth more ≈øcoure and clean≈øe the skin then the ≈øweet oyle doth, and is therefore more v≈øed of many for that purpo≈øe, as the Almonds them≈øelues are.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Mala Arantia. Orenges.
div.p: I Bring here to your con≈øideration, as you ≈øee, the Orenge tree alone, without mentioning the Citron or Lemmon trees, in regard of the experience we haue ≈øeen made of them in diuers places: For the Orenge tree hath abiden with ≈øome extraordinary looking and tending of it, when as neither of the other would by any meanes be pre≈øerued any longtime. If therefore any be de≈øirous to keepe this tree, he mu≈øt ≈øo prouide for it, that it be pre≈øerued from any cold, either in the winter or ≈øpring, and expo≈øed to the comfort of the ≈øunne in ≈øummer. And for that purpo≈øe ≈øome keepe them in great ≈øquare boxes, and lift them to and fro by iron hooks on the ≈øides, or cau≈øe them to be rowled by trundels, or ≈ømall wheeles vnder them, to place them in an hou≈øe, or clo≈øe gallerie for the winter time: others plant them again≈øt a bricke wall in the ground, and defend them by a ≈øhed of boardes, couered ouer with ≈øeare-cloth in the winter, and by the warmth of a ≈øtoue, or other ≈øuch thing, giue them ≈øome comfort in the colder times: but no tent or meane proui≈øion will pre≈øerue them.

The Orenge tree in the warme Countries groweth very high, but with vs (or el≈øe it is a dwarfe kinde there of) ri≈øeth not very high: the barke of the elder ≈øtemmes being of a darke colour, and the young branches very greene, whereon grow here and there ≈øome few thornes: the leaues are faire, large, and very greene, in forme almo≈øt like a Bay leafe, but that it hath a ≈ømall eare, or peece of a leafe, fa≈øhioned like vnto an heart vnder euery one of them, with many ≈ømall holes to be ≈øeene in them, if you hold them vp betweene you and the light, of a ≈øweet but ≈øtrong ≈ømell, naturally not falling away, but alwaies abiding on, or vntill new be come vp, bearing greene leaues continually: the flowers are whiti≈øh, of a very ≈øtrong and heady ≈øent; after which come ≈ømall round fruit, greene at the fir≈øt, while they are ≈ømall, and not neere maturitie, but being grown and ripe, are (as all men know) red on the out ≈øide, ≈øome more pale then others, and ≈øome kindes of a deeper yellowi≈øh red, according to the climate, and as it receiueth the heate of the ≈øunne, wherein is contained ≈øower or ≈øweete iuice, and thicke white kernels among it: it beareth in the warme Countries both blo≈ø≈øomes and greene fruit continually vpon it, and ripe fruit al≈øo with them for the be≈øt part of the yeare, but e≈øpecially in Autumne and Winter.

div.head: The V≈øe of Orenges.
div.p: Orenges are v≈øed as ≈øawce for many ≈øorts of meates, in re≈øpect of their ≈øweete ≈øowerne≈ø≈øe, giuing a relli≈øh of delight, wherein≈øoeuer they are v≈øed.
The inner pulpe or iuice doth ≈øerue in agues and hot di≈øea≈øes, and in Summer to coole the heate of deiected ≈øtomackes, or fainting ≈øpirits.

all. 9 Malum Kentij ad ferue≈øcondum. The Kenti≈øh Codlin. 10 Malum Regineum ≈øpurium. The Bardfield Quining.

div.p: The dryed rinde, by rea≈øon of the ≈øweete and ≈øtrong ≈øent, ≈øerueth to bee put among other things to make ≈øweet pouthers.

The outer rindes, when they are clen≈øed from all the inner pulpe and skins, are pre≈øerued in Sugar, after the bitterne≈ø≈øe by often ≈øteepings hath been taken away, & do ≈øerue either as Succots, and banquetting ≈øtuffes, or as ornaments to ≈øet out di≈øhes for the table, or to giue a relli≈øh vnto meats, whether baked or boyled: Phy≈øically they helpe to warme a cold ≈øtomack, and to dige≈øt or breake winde therein: or they are candid with Sugar, and ≈øerue with other dryed Iunquets.
The water of Orange flowers is oftentimes v≈øed as a great per≈øume for glones, to wa≈øhe them, or in ≈øtead of Ro≈øe-water to mixe with other things.
It is v≈øed to bee drunke by ≈øome, to preuent or to helpe any pe≈øtilentiall feuer.
The oyntment that is made of the flowers, is very comfortable both for the ≈øtomache, again≈øt the could or cough, or for the head, for paines and di≈øine≈ø≈øe.

The kernels or ≈øeede beeing ca≈øt into the ground in the ≈øpring time, will quickely grow vp, (but will not abide the winter with vs, to bee kept for growing trees) and when they are of a finger length high, being pluckt vp, and put among ≈øallats, will giue them a maruellous fine aromaticke or ≈øpicy ta≈øte, very acceptable.
The ≈øeed or kernels are a little cordiall, although nothing ≈øo much as the kernels of the Pomecitron.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Poma. Apples.
div.p: THe ≈øorts of Apples are ≈øo many, and infinite almo≈øt as I may ≈øay, that I cannot giue you the names of all, though I haue endeauoured to giue a great many, and I thinke it almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible for any one, to attaine to the full perfection of knowledge herein, not onely in regard of the multiplicitie of fa≈øhions, colours and ta≈øtes, but in that ≈øome are more familiar to one Countrey then to another, being of a better or wor≈øe ta≈øte in one place then in another, and therefore diuer≈øly called: I will therefore as I haue done before, giue you the de≈øcription of the Tree in generall, as al≈øo of the Paradi≈øe or dwarfe Apple, becau≈øe of ≈øome e≈øpeciall difference, and afterwards the names of as many, with their fa≈øhions, as haue come to my knowledge, either by ≈øight or relation: for I doe confe≈ø≈øe I haue not ≈øeene all that I here ≈øet downe, but v≈øe the helpe of ≈øome friends, and therefore if it happen that the ≈øeuerall names doe not an≈øwer vnto ≈øeuerall ≈øorts, but that the ≈øame fruit may bee called by one name in one Country, that is called by another el≈øewhere, excu≈øe it I pray you; for in ≈øuch a number, ≈øuch a fault may e≈øcape vnknowne.

The Apple tree for the mo≈øt part is neyther very high, great or ≈øtraight, but rather v≈øually boweth and ≈øpreadeth (although in ≈øome places it groweth fairer and ≈øtraighter then in others) hauing long and great armes or boughes, and from them ≈ømaller branches, whereon doe grow ≈øomewhat broade, and long greene leaues, nicked about the edges: the flowers are large and white, with blu≈øh coloured ≈øides, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues: the fruit (as I ≈øaid) is of diuers formes, colours and ta≈øtes, and likewi≈øe of a very variable durabilitie; for ≈øome mu≈øt be eaten pre≈øently after they are gathered, and they are for the mo≈øt part the earlie≈øt ripe; others will abide longer vpon the trees, before they bee fit to be gathered; ≈øome al≈øo will be ≈øo hard when others are gathered, that they will not be fit to be eaten, for one, two or three months after they bee gathered; and ≈øome will abide good but one, two or three moneths, and no more; and ≈øome will be be≈øt, after a quarter or halfe a yeares lying, vnto the end of that yeare or the next. The Paradi≈øe or dwarfe Apple tree groweth nothing ≈øo high as the former, and many times not much higher then a man may reach, hauing leaues and flowers altogether like the other, the fruit is a faire yellow Apple, and rea≈øonable great, but very light and ≈øpongy or loo≈øe, and of a bitteri≈øh ≈øweet ta≈øte, nothing plea≈øant. And the≈øe faults al≈øo
are incident vnto this tree, that both bodie and branches are much ≈øubiect vnto cancker, which will quickely eate it round, and kill it; be≈øides it will haue many bunches, or tuberous ≈øwellings in many places, which grow as it were ≈øcabby or tough, and will ≈øoone cau≈øe it to peri≈øh: the roote ≈øendeth forth many ≈øhootes and ≈øuck ‚Ä¢ rs, whereby it may be much increa≈øed. But this benefit may be had of it, to recompence the former faults, That being a dwarfe Tree, what≈øoeuer fruit ≈øhall bee grafted on it, will keepe the graft low like vnto it ≈øelfe, and yet beare fruit rea≈øonable well. And this is a pretty way to haue Pippins, Pomewaters, or any other ≈øort of Apples (as I haue had my ≈øelfe, and al≈øo ≈øeene with others) growing low, that if any will, they may make a hedge rowe of the≈øe low fruits, planted in an Orchard all along by a walke ≈øide: but take this Caueat, if you will auoide the danger of the cancker and knots, which ≈øpoile the tree, to graft it hard vnto the ground, that therby you may giue as little of the nature of the ≈øtock thereunto as po≈ø≈øibly you can, which wil vndoubtedly help it very much.

div.head: The kindes or ≈øorts of Apples.
div.p: The Summer pippin is a very good apple fir≈øt ripe, and therefore to bee fir≈øt ≈øpent, becau≈øe it will not abide ≈øo long as the other.
The French pippin is al≈øo a good fruit and yellow.
The Golding pippin is the greate≈øt and be≈øt of all ≈øorts of pippins.
The Ru≈ø≈øet pippin is as good an apple as mo≈øt of the other ≈øorts of pippins.
The ≈øpotted pippin is the mo≈øt durable pippin of all the other ≈øorts.
The ordinary yellow pippin is like the other, and as good; for indeed I know no ≈øort of pippins but are excellent good well relli≈øhed fruites.
The great pearemaine differeth little either in ta≈øte or durabilitie from the pippin, and therefore next vnto it is accounted the be≈øt of all apples.

The ≈øummer pearemaine is of equall goodne≈ø≈øe with the former, or rather a little more plea≈øing, e≈øpecially for the time of its eating, which will not bee ≈øo long la≈øting, but is ≈øpent and gone when the other beginneth to be good to eate.

The Ru≈ø≈øetting is al≈øo a firme and a very good apple, not ≈øo wateri≈øh as the pippin or pearemaine, and will la≈øt the be≈øt part of the year, but will be very mellow at the la≈øt, or rather halfe dryed.
The Broading is a very good apple.

The Pomewater is an excellent good and great whiti≈øh apple, full of ≈øap or moi≈øture, ≈øomewhat plea≈øant ≈øharpe, but a little bitter withall: it will not la≈øt long, the winter fro≈øts ≈øoone cau≈øing it to rot, and peri≈øh.
The Flower of Kent is a faire yellowi≈øh greene apple both good and great.
The Gilloflower apple is a fine apple, and finely ≈øpotted.

The Marligo is the ≈øame, that is called the Marigold apple, it is a middle ≈øized apple, very yellow on the out≈øide, ≈øhadowed ouer as it were with red, and more red on one ≈øide, a rea≈øonable well relli≈øhed fruit.
The Blandrill is a good apple.
The Dauie Gentle is a very good apple
The Gruntlin is ≈øomewhat a long apple, ≈ømaller at the crowne then at the ≈øtalke, and is a rea≈øonable good apple.
The gray Co≈øterd is a good great apple, ≈øomewhat whiti≈øh on the out≈øide, and abideth the winter.
The greene Co≈øterd is like the other, but greener on the out≈øide continually.
The Haruy apple is a faire great goodly apple, and very well relli≈øhed.
The Dow≈øe apple is a ≈øweeti≈øh apple not much accounted of.
The Pome-paris is a very good apple.
The Belle boon of two ≈øorts winter and ≈øummer, both of them good apples, and fair fruit to look on, being yellow and of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe.
The pound Royall is a very great apple, of a very good and ≈øharpe ta≈øte.
The Doues Bill a ≈ømall apple.
The Deu≈øan or apple Iohn is a delicate fine fruit, well relli≈øhed when it beginneth to be fit to be eaten, and endureth good longer then any other apple.
The Ma≈øter William is greater then a pippin, but of no very good relli≈øh.
The Ma≈øter Iohn is a better ta≈øted apple then the other by much.
The Spicing is a well ta≈øted fruite.

list.item: Pome de Rambures all faire and good apples brought from France.
Pome de Capanda all faire and good apples brought from France.
Pome de Calual all faire and good apples brought from France.

div.p: The Queene apple is of two ≈øorts, both of them great faire red apples, and well relli≈øhed, but the greater is the be≈øt.
The Ba≈øtard Queene apple is like the other for forme and colour, but not ≈øo good in ta≈øte: ≈øome call this the bardfield Queening.
The Boughton or greening is a very good and well ta≈øted apple.
The Leathercoate apple is a good winter apple, of no great bigne≈ø≈øe, but of a very good and ≈øharpe ta≈øte.
The Pot apple is a plaine Country apple.
The Cow≈ønout is no very good fruit.
The Gildiling apple is a yellow one, not much accounted.
The Cats head apple tooke the name of the likene≈ø≈øe, and is a rea≈øonable good apple and great.
The Kenti≈øh Codlin is a faire great greeni≈øh apple, very good to eate when it is ripe; but the be≈øt to coddle of all other apples.
The Stoken apple is a rea≈øonable good apple.
The Geneting apple is a very plea≈øant and good apple.
The Worce≈øter apple is a very good apple, as bigge as a Pomewater.
Donime Couadis is a French apple, and of a good relli≈øh.
The French Goodwin is a very good apple.
The old wife is a very good, and well relli≈øhed apple.
The towne Crab is an hard apple, not ≈øo good to be eaten rawe as roa≈øted, but excellent to make Cider.
The Virgilling apple is a rea≈øonable good apple.
The Crowes egge is no good relli≈øhed fruit, but nour≈øed vp in ≈øome places of the common people.
The Sugar apple is ≈øo called of the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe.
Sops in wine is ≈øo named both of the plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of the fruit, and beautie of the apple.
The womans brea≈øt apple is a great apple.
The blacke apple or pippin is a very good eating apple, and very like a Pearemaine, both for forme and bigne≈ø≈øe, but of a blacke ≈øooty colour.
Tweenty ≈øorts of Sweetings and none good.
The Peare apple is a ≈ømall fruit, but well relli≈øhed being ripe, and is for ≈øhape very like vnto a ≈ømall ≈øhort Peare, and greene.
The Paradi≈øe apple is a faire goodly yellow apple, but light and ≈øpongy, and of a bitteri≈øh ≈øweet ta≈øte, not to be commended.

The apple without blo≈ø≈øome, ≈øo called becau≈øe although it haue a ≈ømall ≈øhew of a blo≈ø≈øome, yet they are but ≈ømall threds rather than leaues, neuer ≈øhewing to bee like a flower, and therefore termed without blo≈ø≈øome: the apple is neyther good eating nor baking fruit.
Wildings and Crabs are without number or v≈øe in our Orchard, being to be had out of the woods, fields and hedges rather then any where el≈øe.

div.head: The V≈øe of Apples.
div.p: The be≈øt ≈øorts of Apples ≈øerue at the la≈øt cour≈øe for the table, in mo≈øt mens hou≈øes of account, where, if there grow any rare or excellent fruit, it is then ≈øet forth to be ≈øeene and ta≈øted.

Diuers other ≈øorts ≈øerue to bake, either for the Ma≈øters Table, or the meynes ≈øu≈øtenance, either in pyes or pans, or el≈øe ≈øtewed in di≈øhes with Ro≈øewater and Sugar, and Cinamon or Ginger ca≈øt vpon.

Some kinds are fitte≈øt to roa≈øt in the winter time, to warme a cup of wine, ale or beere; or to be eaten alone, for the nature of ≈øome fruit is neuer ≈øo good, or worth the eating, as when they are roa≈øted.
Some ≈øorts are fitte≈øt to ≈øcald for Codlins, and are taken to coole the ≈øtomacke, as well as to plea≈øe the ta≈øte, hauing Ro≈øewater and Sugar put to them.

Some ≈øorts are be≈øt to make Cider of, as in the We≈øt Countrey of England great quantities, yea many Hog≈øheads and Tunnes full are made, e≈øpecially to bee carried to the Sea in long voyages, and is found by experience to bee of excellent v≈øe, to mixe with water for beuerage. It is v≈øually ≈øeene that tho≈øe fruits that are neither fit to eate raw, roa≈øted, nor baked, are fitte≈øt for Cider, and make the be≈øt.
The iuice of Apples likewi≈øe, as of pippins, and pearemaines, is of very good v≈øe in Melancholicke di≈øea≈øes, helping to procure mirth, and to expell heauine≈ø≈øe.
The di≈øtilled water of the ≈øame Apples is of the like effect.

There is a fine ≈øweet oyntment made of Apples called Pomatum, which is much v≈øed to helpe chapt lips, or hands, or for the face, or any other part of the skinne that is rough with winde, or any other accident, to ≈øupple them, and make them ≈ømooth.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Cydonia. Quinces.
div.p: WEe haue ≈øome diuer≈øities of Quinces, although not many, yet more then our elder times were acquainted with, which ≈øhall be here expre≈ø≈øed.

The Quince tree groweth oftentimes to the height and bigne≈ø≈øe of a good Apple tree, but more v≈øually lower, with crooked and ≈øpreading armes and branches farre abroad, the leaues are ≈øomewhat round, and like the leaues of the Apple tree, but thicker, harder, fuller of veines, and white on the vnder≈øide: the blo≈ø≈øomes or flowers are white, now and then da≈øht ouer with blu≈øh, being large and open, like vnto a ≈øingle Ro≈øe: the fruit followeth, which when it is ripe is yellow, and couered with a white cotton or freeze, which in the younger is thicker and more plentifull, but waxeth le≈ø≈øe and le≈ø≈øe, as the fruit ripeneth, being bunched out many times in ≈øeuerall places, and round, e≈øpecially about the head, ≈øome greater, others ≈ømaller, ≈øome round like an Apple, others long like a Peare, of a ≈øtrong heady ≈øent, accounted not whol≈øome or long to be endured, and of no durabilitie to keepe, in the middle whereof is a core, with many blacki≈øh ≈øeedes or kernels therein, lying clo≈øe together in cels, and compa≈ø≈øed with a kinde of clearegelly, which is ea≈øier ≈øeene in the ≈øcalded fruit, then in the raw.

The Engli≈øh Quince is the ordinarie Apple Quince, ≈øet downe before, and is of ≈øo har≈øh a ta≈øte being greene, that no man can endure to eate it rawe, but eyther boyled, ≈øtewed, roa≈øted or baked; all which waies it is very good.

The Portingall Apple Quince is a great yellow Quince, ≈øeldome comming to bee whole and faire without chapping; this is ≈øo plea≈øant being fre≈øh gathered, that it may be eaten like vnto an Apple without offence.

The Portingall Peare Quince is not fit to be eaten rawe like the former, but mu≈øt be v≈øed after ≈øome of the waies the Engli≈øh Quince is appointed, and ≈øo it will make more dainty di≈øhes then the Engli≈øh, becau≈øe it is le≈ø≈øe har≈øh, will bee more tender, and take le≈ø≈øe ≈øugar for the ordering then the Engli≈øh kinde.
The Barbary Quince is like in goodne≈ø≈øe vnto the Portingall Quince la≈øt ≈øpoken of, but le≈ø≈øer in bigne≈ø≈øe.
The Lyons Quince.
The Brun≈øwicke Quince.

div.head: The V≈øe of Quinces.
div.p:
There is no fruit growing in this Land that is of ≈øo many excellent v≈øes as this, ≈øeruing as well to make many di≈øhes of meate for the table, as for
banquets, and much more for the Phy≈øicall vertues, whereof to write at large is neither conuenient for mee, nor for this worke: I will onely briefly recite ≈øome, as it were to giue you a ta≈øte of that plenty remaineth therein, to bee conuerted into ≈øundry formes: as fir≈øt for the table, while they are fre≈øh (and all the yeare long after being pickled vp) to be baked, as a dainty di≈øh, being well and orderly cookt. And being pre≈øerued whole in Sugar, either white or red, ≈øerue likewi≈øe, not onely as an after di≈øh to clo≈øe vp the ≈øtomacke, but is placed among other Pre≈øerues by Ladies and Gentlewomen, and be≈øtowed on their friends to entertaine them, and among other ≈øorts of Pre≈øerues at Banquets. Codiniacke al≈øo and Marmilade, Ielly and Pa≈øte, are all made of Quinces, chiefly for delight and plea≈øure, although they haue al≈øo with them ≈øome phy≈øicall properties.
We haue for the v≈øe of phy≈øicke, both Iuyce and Syrupe, both Con≈øerue and Condite, both binding and loo≈øening medicines, both inward and outward, and all made of Quinces.
The Ielly or Muccilage of the ≈øeedes, is often v≈øed to be laid vpon womens brea≈øts, to heale them being ≈øore or rawe, by their childrens default giuing them ≈øucke.

Athenaeus reciteth in his third booke, that one Philarchus found, that the ≈ømell of Quinces tooke away the ≈øtrength of a certaine poi≈øon, called Phariacum. And the Spaniards haue al≈øo found, that the ≈øtrength of the iuyce of white Ellebor (which the Hunters v≈øe as a poy≈øon to dippe their arrow heads in, that they ≈øhoote at wilde bea≈øts to kill them) is quite taken away, if it ≈øtand within the compa≈ø≈øe of the ≈ømell of Quinces. And al≈øo that Grapes, being hung vp to bee kept, and ≈øpent in Winter, doe quickly rot with the ≈ømell of a Quince.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Pyra. Peares.
div.p: THe variety of peares is as much or more then of apples, and I thinke it is as hard in this, as before in apples, for any to be ≈øo exqui≈øite, as that hee could number vp all the ≈øorts that are to be had: for wee haue in our country ≈øo manie, as I ≈øhall giue you the names of by and by, and are hitherto come to our knowledge: but I verily beleeue that there be many, both in our country, and in others, that we haue not yet knowne or heard of; for euery yeare almo≈øt wee attaine to the knowledge of ≈øome, we knew not of before. Take therefore, according to the manner before held, the de≈øcription of one, with the ≈øeuerall names of the re≈øt, vntill a more exact di≈øcour≈øe be had of them, euery one apart.

The Peare tree groweth more ≈ølowly, but higher, and more vpright then the apple tree, and not le≈ø≈øe in the bulke of the body: his branches ≈øpread not ≈øo farre or wide, but growe vprighter and clo≈øer: the leaues are ≈øomewhat broader and rounder, greene aboue, and whiter vnderneath then tho≈øe of the apple tree: the flowers are whiter and greater: the fruit is longer then round for the mo≈øt part, ≈ømaller at the ≈øtalke, and greater at the head, of ≈øo many differing formes, colours, and ta≈øtes, that hardly can one di≈øtingui≈øh rightly between them, the times al≈øo being as variable in the gathering and ≈øpending of them, as in apples: the roote groweth deeper then the apple tree, and therefore abideth longer, and giueth a fa≈øter, clo≈øer, & ≈ømoother gentle wood, ea≈øie to be wrought vpon.

div.head: The kindes of Peares.
div.p: The Summer bon Chretien is ≈øomewhat a long peare, with a greene and yellow ru≈ø≈øeti≈øh coate, and will haue ≈øometimes red ≈øides; it is ripe at Michaelmas: ≈øome v≈øe to dry them as they doe Prunes, and keepe them all the yeare after. I haue not ≈øeene or heard any more Summer kindes hereof then this one, and needeth no wall to nour≈øe it as the other.

figure.head: 1 Malus Cotouo ‚Ä¢ . The Quince tree. 2 Cydonium Lu ‚Ä¢ itanicum. The Portingall Quince. 3 Pyrus. The Peare tree. 4 Pyrum Pompeianum, ≈øiue Cucume ‚Ä¢ inum hyemale. The Winter Bon Chretien. 5 Pyrum pictum vel ≈øtriatum. The painted or ≈øtriped Peare of ‚Ä¢ eru≈øalem. 6 Pyrum Palatinal ‚Ä¢ . The Burgomot Peare. 7 Pyrum Cucumerinum ≈øiue Pompeianum ae≈øtivum. The Summer Bon Chretien. 8 Pyrum ∆≤olemam. The be≈øt Warden. 9 Pyrum Librale. The ocua ‚Ä¢ Peare. 10 Pyrum Wind≈øorianum. The Wind≈øor Peare. 11 Pyrum Cucumerinum. The Gratio≈øa Peare. 12 Pyrum Caryophyllatum. The Gilloflower Peare.

div.p: The Winter bon Chretien is of many ≈øorts, ≈øome greater, others le≈ø≈øer, and all good; but the greate≈øt and be≈øt is that kinde that groweth at Syon: All the kinds of this Winter fruit mu≈øt be planted again≈øt a wall, or el≈øe they will both ≈øeldome beare, and bring fewer al≈øo to ripene≈ø≈øe, comparable to the wall fruit: the kindes al≈øo are according to their la≈øting; for ≈øome will endure good much longer then others.
The Summer Bergomot is an excellent well relli≈øhed peare, flatti≈øh, & ≈øhort, not long like others, of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe, and of a darke yellowi≈øh greene colour on the out≈øide.

The Winter Bergomot is of two or three ≈øorts, being all of them ≈ømall fruit, ≈øomewhat greener on the out≈øide then the Summer kindes; all of them very delicate and good in their due time: for ≈øome will not be fit to bee eaten when others are will-nigh ≈øpent, euery of them outla≈øting another by a moneth or more.
The Diego peare is but a ≈ømall peare, but an excellent well relli≈øhed fruit, ta≈øting as if Maske had been put among it; many of them growe together, as it were in clu≈øters.
The Duetete or double headed peare, ≈øo called of the forme, is a very good peare, not very great, of a ru≈ø≈øetti≈øh browne colour on the out≈øide.
The Primating peare is a good moi≈øt peare, and early ripe.
The Geneting peare is a very good early ripe peare.
The greene Che≈øill is a delicate mellow peare, euen melting as it were in the mouth of the eater, although greeni≈øh on the out≈øide.
The Catherine peare is knowne to all I thinke to be a yellow red ≈øided peare, of a full wateri≈øh ≈øweete ta≈øte, and ripe with the foremo≈øt.
The King Catherine is greater then the other, and of the ≈øame goodne≈ø≈øe, or rather better.
The Ru≈ø≈øet Catherine is a very good middle ≈øized peare.

The Wind≈øor peare is an excellent good peare, well knowne to mo≈øt per≈øons, and of a rea≈øonable greatne≈ø≈øe: it will beare fruit ≈øome times twice in a yeare (and as it is ≈øaid) three times in ≈øome places.
The Norwich peare is of two ≈øorts, Summer and Winter, both of them good fruit, each in their ≈øea≈øon.
The Wor≈øter peare is blacki≈øh, a farre better peare to bake (when as it will be like a Warden, and as good) then to eate rawe; yet ≈øo it is not to be mi≈øliked.
The Muske peare is like vnto a Catherine peare for bigne≈ø≈øe, colour, and forme; but farre more excellent in ta≈øte, as the very name importeth.
The Ro≈øewater peare is a goodly faire peare, and of a delicate ta≈øte.
The Sugar peare is an early peare, very ≈øweete, but wateri≈øh.
The Summer Popperin both of them are very good firme dry peares, ≈øomewhat ≈øpotted, and browni≈øh on the out≈øide.
The Winter Popperin both of them are very good firme dry peares, ≈øomewhat ≈øpotted, and browni≈øh on the out≈øide.
The greene Popperin is a winter fruit, of equall goodne≈ø≈øe with the former.

The Soueraingne peare, that which I haue ≈øeene and ta≈øted, and ≈øo termed vnto me, was a ≈ømall browni≈øh yellow peare, but of a mo≈øt dainty ta≈øte; but ≈øome doe take a kind of Bon Chretien, called the Elizabeth peare, to be the Soueraigne peare; how truely let others iudge.
The Kings peare is a very good and well ta≈øted peare.
The peare Royall is a great peare, and of a good relli≈øh.
The Warwicke peare is a rea≈øonable faire and good peare.
The Greenfield peare is a very good peare, of a middle ≈øize.
