The Lewes peare is a browni≈øh greene peare, ripe about the end of September, a rea≈øonable well relli≈øhed fruit, and very moi≈øt.

The Bi≈øhop peare is a middle ≈øized peare, of a rea≈øonable good ta≈øte, not very wateri≈øh; but this property is oftentimes ≈øeene in it, that before the fruit is gathered, (but more v≈øually tho≈øe that fall of them≈øelues, and the re≈øt within a while after they are gathered) it will be rotten at the core, when there wil not be a ≈øpot or blemi≈øh to be ≈øeene on the out≈øide, or in all the peare, vntill you come neare the core.
The Wilford peare is a good and a faire peare.
The Bell peare a very good greene peare.
The Portingall peare is a great peare, but more goodly in ≈øhew then good indeed.
The Gratiola peare is a kinde of Bon Chretien, called the Cowcumber peare, or Spinola's peare.
The Rowling peare is a good peare, but hard, and not good before it bee a little rowled or brui≈øed, to make it eate the more mellow.
The Pimpe peare is as great as the Wind≈øor peare, but rounder, and of a very good relli≈øh.
The Turnep peare is a hard winter peare, not ≈øo good to eate rawe, as it is to bake.
The Arundell peare is mo≈øt plentifull in Suffolke, and there commended to be a verie good peare.
The Berry peare is a Summer peare, rea≈øonable faire and great, and of ≈øo good and whol≈øome a ta≈øte, that few or none take harme by eating neuer ≈øo many of them.
The Sand peare is a rea≈øonable good peare, but ≈ømall.
The Morley peare is a very good peare, like in forme and colour vnto the Wind≈øor, but ≈øomewhat grayer.
The peare pricke is very like vnto the Greenfield peare, being both faire, great, and good.
The good Rewell is a rea≈øonable great peare, as good to bake as to eate rawe, and both wayes it is a good fruit.
The Hawkes bill peare is of a middle ≈øize, ≈øomewhat like vnto the Rowling peare.
The Petworth peare is a winter peare, and is great, ≈øomewhat long, faire, and good.
The Slipper peare is a rea≈øonable good peare.
The Robert peare is a very good peare, plentifull in Suffolke and Norfolke.
The pound peare is a rea≈øonable good peare, both to eate rawe, and to bake.

The ten pound peare, or the hundred pound peare, the true≈øt and be≈øt, is the be≈øt Bon Chretien of Syon, ≈øo called, becau≈øe the grafts co≈øt the Ma≈øter ≈øo much the fetching by the me≈ø≈øengers expences, when he brought nothing el≈øe.
The Gilloflower peare is a winter peare, faire in ≈øhew, but hard, and not fit to bee eaten rawe, but very good to bake.
The peare Couteau is neither good one way nor other.
The Bin≈øce peare is a rea≈øonable good winter peare, of a ru≈ø≈øeti≈øh colour, and a ≈ømall fruit: but will abide good a long while.
The Pucell is a greene peare, of an indifferent good ta≈øte.
The blacke Sorrell is a rea≈øonable great long peare, of a darke red colour on the out≈øide.
The red Sorrell is of a redder colour, el≈øe like the other.
The Surrine is no very good peare.
The Summer Ha≈øting is a little greene peare, of an indifferent good relli≈øh.
Peare Gergonell is an early peare, ≈øomewhat long, and of a very plea≈øant ta≈øte.
The white Genneting is a rea≈øonable good peare, yet not equall to the other.
The Sweater is ≈øomewhat like the Wind≈øor for colour and bigne≈ø≈øe, but nothing neare of ≈øo good a ta≈øte.
The bloud red peare is of a darke red colour on the out≈øide, but piercing very little into the inner pulpe.
The Hony peare is a long greene Summer peare.
The Winter peare is of many ≈øorts, but this is onely ≈øo called, to bee di≈øtingui≈øhed from all other Winter peares, which haue ≈øeuerall names giuen them, and is a very good peare.
The Warden or Luke Wards peare of two ≈øorts, both white and red, both great and ≈ømall.
The Spani≈øh Warden is greater then either of both the former, and better al≈øo.

The peare of Ieru≈øalem, or the ≈øtript peare, who≈øe barke while it is young, is as plainly ≈øeene to be ≈øtript with greene, red, and yellow, as the fruit it ≈øelfe is al≈øo, and is of a very good ta≈øte: being baked al≈øo, it is as red as the be≈øt Warden, whereof Ma≈øter William Ward of E≈ø≈øex hath a≈ø≈øured mee, who is the chiefe keeper of the Kings Granary at Whitehall.
Hereof likewi≈øe there is a wilde kinde no bigger then ones thumbe, and ≈øtriped in the like manner, but much more.

The Choke peares, and other wilde peares, both great and ≈ømall, as they are not to furni≈øh our Orchard, but the Woods, Forre≈øts, Fields, and Hedges, ≈øo wee leaue them to their naturall places, and to them that keep them, and make good v≈øe of them.

div.head: The V≈øe of Peares.
div.p:
The mo≈øt excellent ≈øorts of Peares, ≈øerue (is I ≈øaid before of Apples) to
make an after-cour≈øe for their ma≈øters table, where the goodne≈ø≈øe of his Orchard is tryed. They are dryed al≈øo, and ≈øo are an excellent repa≈øte, if they be of the be≈øt kindes, fit for the purpo≈øe.
They are eaten familiarly of all ≈øorts of people, of ≈øome for delight, and of others for nouri≈øhment, being baked, ≈øtewed, or ≈øcalded.

The red Warden and the Spani≈øh Warden are reckoned among the mo≈øt excellent of Peares, either to bake or to roa≈øt, for the ≈øicke or for the ≈øound: And indeede, the Quince and the Warden are the two onely fruits are permitted to the ≈øicke, to eate at any time.
Perry, which is the iuyce of Peares pre≈ø≈øed out, is a drinke much e≈øteemed as well as Cyder, to be both drunke at home, and carried to the Sea, and found to be of good v≈øe in long voyages.

The Perry made of Choke Peares, notwith≈øtanding the har≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and euill ta≈øte, both of the fruit when it is greene, as al≈øo of the iuyce when it is new made, doth yet after a few moneths become as milde and plea≈øant as wine, and will hardly bee knowne by the ≈øight or ta≈øte from it: this hath beene found true by often experience; and therefore wee may admire the goodne≈ø≈øe of God, that hath giuen ≈øuch facility to ≈øo wilde fruits, altogether thought v≈øele≈ø≈øe, to become v≈øefull, and apply the benefit thereof both to the comfort of our ≈øoules and bodies.

For the Phy≈øicall properties, if we doe as Galen teacheth vs, in ≈øecundo Alimentorum, referre the qualities of Peares to their ≈øeuerall ta≈øtes, as before he had done in Apples, we ≈øhall not neede to make a new worke; tho≈øe that are har≈øh and ≈øowre doe coole and binde, ≈øweet do nouri≈øh and warme, and tho≈øe betweene the≈øe, to haue middle vertues, an≈øwerable to their temperatures, &c.
Much more might be ≈øaid, both of this and the other kinds of fruits; but let this ≈øuffice for this place and worke, vntill a more exact be accompli≈øhed.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Nux Iuglans. The Wallnut.
div.p: ALthough the Wallnut tree bee often planted in the middle of great Courtyards, where by rea≈øon of his great ≈øpreading armes it taketh vp a great deale of roome, his ≈øhadow reaching farre, ≈øo that ≈øcarce any thing can well grow neare it; yet becau≈øe it is likewi≈øe planted in fit places or corners of Orchards, and that it beareth fruit or nuts, often brought to the table, e≈øpecially while they are fre≈øhe≈øt, ≈øweete≈øt, and fitte≈øt to be eaten, let not my Orchard want his company, or you the knowledge of it. Some doe thinke that there are many ≈øorts of them, becau≈øe ≈øome are much greater then others, and ≈øome longer then others, and ≈øome haue a more frangible ≈øhell then others; but I am certainly per≈øwaded, that the ≈øoyle and climate where they grow, are the whole and onely cau≈øe of the varieties and differences. Indeed Virginia hath ≈øent vnto vs two ≈øorts of Wallnuts, the one blacke, the other white, whereof as yet wee haue no further knowledge. And I know that Clu≈øius reporteth, he tooke vp at a banquet a long Wallnut, differing in forme and tenderne≈ø≈øe of ≈øhell from others, which being ≈øet, grew and bore farre tenderer leaues then the other, and a little ≈ønipt about the edges, which (as I ≈øaid) might alter with the ≈øoyle and climate: and be≈øides you may ob≈øerue, that many of Clu≈øius differences are very nice, and ≈øo I leaue it.

The Wallnut tree groweth very high and great, with a large and thicke body or trunke, couered with a thicke clouen whiti≈øh greene barke, tending to an a≈øh-colour; the armes are great, and ≈øpread farre, breaking out into ≈ømaller branches, whereon doe grow long & large leaues, fiue or ≈øeuen ≈øet together one again≈øt another, with an odde one at the end, ≈øomewhat like vnto A≈øhen leaues, but farre larger, and not ≈øo many on a ≈øtalke, ≈ømooth, and ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh at the fir≈øt ≈øpringing, and tender al≈øo, of a rea≈øonable good ≈øent, but more ≈øtrong and headie when they growe old: the fruit or nut is great and round, growing clo≈øe to the ≈øtalkes of the leaues, either by couples or by
three ≈øet together, couered with a double ≈øhell, that is to ≈øay, with a greene thicke and ≈øoft outer rinde, and an inner hard ≈øhell, within which the white kernell is contained, couered with a thinne yellow rinde or peeling, which is more ea≈øily peeled away while it is greene then afterwards, and is as it were parted into foure quarters, with a thinne wooddy peece parting it at the head, very ≈øweete and plea≈øant while it is fre≈øh, and for a while after the gathering; but the elder they growe, the harder and more oily: the catkins or blowings are long and yellow, made of many ≈øcaly leaues ≈øet clo≈øe together, which come forth early in the Spring, and when they open and fall away, vpon their ≈øtalkes ari≈øe certaine ≈ømall flowers, which turne into ≈øo many nuts.

div.head: The V≈øe of Wallnuts.
div.p: They are often ≈øerued to the table with other fruits while they abide fre≈øh and ≈øweete; and therefore many to keepe them fre≈øh a long time haue deui≈øed many wayes, as to put them into great pots, and bury them in the ground, and ≈øo take them out as they ≈øpend them, which is a very good way, and will keepe them long.
The ≈ømall young nuts while they are tender, being pre≈øerued or candid, are v≈øed among other ≈øorts of candid fruits, that ≈øerue at banquets.
The iuyce of the outer greene huskes are held to be a ≈øoueraigne remedy again≈øt either poy≈øon, or plague, or pe≈øtilentiall feuer.
The di≈øtilled water of the huskes drunke with a little vinegar, if the fits growe hot and tedious, is an approued remedy for the ≈øame.
The water di≈øtilled from the leaues, is effectuall to be applyed to fluent or running vlcers, to dry and binde the humours.
Some haue v≈øed the pouder of the catkins in white wine, for the ≈øuffocation or ≈øtrangling of the mother.

The oyle of Wallnuts is v≈øed to varni≈øh Ioyners workes. As al≈øo is accounted farre to excell Lin≈øeede oyle, to mixe a white colour withall, that the colour bee not dimmed. It is of excellent v≈øe for the coldne≈ø≈øe, hardne≈ø≈øe and contracting of the ≈øinewes and ioynts, to warme, ≈øupple, and to extend them.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Castanea Equina. The Hor≈øe Che≈ønut.
div.p: ALthough the ordinary Che≈ønut is not a tree planted in Orchards, but left to Woods, Parkes, and other ≈øuch like places; yet wee haue another ≈øort which wee haue nour≈øed vp from the nuts ≈øent vs from Turky, of a greater and more plea≈øant a≈øpect for the faire leaues, and of as good v≈øe for the fruit. It groweth in time to be a great tree, ≈øpreading with great armes and branches, whereon are ≈øet at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances goodly faire great greene leaues, diuided into ≈øix, ≈øeuen, or nine parts or leaues, euery one of them nicked about the edges, very like vnto the leaues of Ricnus, or Palma Christi, and almo≈øt as great: it beareth at the ends of the branches many flowers ≈øet together vpon a long ≈øtalke, con≈øi≈øting of foure white leaues a peece, with many threads in the middle, which afterwards turne into nuts, like vnto the ordinary Che≈ønuts, but ≈øet in rougher and more prickly huskes: the nuts them≈øelues being rounder and blacker, with a white ≈øpot at the head of each, formed ≈øomewhat like an heart, and of a little ≈øweeter ta≈øte.

div.head: The V≈øe of this Che≈ønut.
div.p: It ≈øerueth to binde and ≈øtop any maner of fluxe, be it of bloud or humours, either of the belly or ≈øtomacke; as al≈øo the much ≈øpitting of bloud. They are roa≈øted and eaten as the ordinary ≈øort, to make them ta≈øte the better.
They are v≈øually in Turkie giuen to hor≈øes in their prouender, to cure them of coughes, and helpe them being broken winded.

div.head: Morus. The Mulberrie.
div.p: THere are two ≈øorts of Mulberries ≈øufficiently known to mo≈øt, the blacki≈øh and the white: but wee haue had brought vs from Virginia another ≈øort, which is of greater re≈øpect then eyther of the other two, not onely in regard of the ratitie, but of the v≈øe, as you ≈øhall pre≈øently vnder≈øtand.

div.head: 1. Morus nigra. The blacke Mulberrie.
div.p: The blacke Mulberrie tree groweth oftentimes tall and great, and oftentimes al≈øo crooked, and ≈øpreading abroade, rather then high; for it is ≈øubiect to abide what forme you will conforme it vnto: if by ≈øuffering it to grow, it will mount vp, and if you will binde it, or pla≈øh the boughes, they will ≈øo abide, and be carried ouer arbours, or other things as you will haue it. The bodie groweth in time to bee very great, couered with a rugged or thicke barke, the armes or branches being ≈ømoother, whereon doe grow round thicke leaues pointed at the ends, and nicked about the edges, and in ≈øome there are to be ≈øeene deep ga≈øhes, making it ≈øeeme ≈øomewhat like the Vine leafe: the flowers are certaine ≈øhort dounie catkings, which turne into greene berries at the fir≈øt, afterwards red, and when they are full ripe blacke, made of many graines ≈øet together, like vnto the blacke berrie, but longer and greater: before they are ripe, they haue an au≈øtere and har≈øh ta≈øte, but when they are full ripe, they are more ≈øweete and plea≈øant; the iuice whereof is ≈øo red, that it will ≈øtaine the hands of them that handle and eate them.

div.head: 2. Morus alba. The white Mulberrie.
div.p: The white Mulberrie tree groweth not with vs to that greatne≈ø≈øe or bulke of bodie that the blacke doth, but runneth vp higher, ≈ølenderer, more knotty, hard and brittle, with thinner ≈øpreade armes and branches: the leaues are like the former, but not ≈øo thicke ≈øet on the branches, nor ≈øo hard in handling, a little paler al≈øo, hauing ≈øomewhat longer ≈øtalkes: the fruit is ≈ømaller and clo≈øer ≈øet together, greene, and ≈øomewhat har≈øh before they be ripe, but of a wonderfull ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, almo≈øt ready to procure loathing when they are thorough ripe, and white, with ≈øuch like ≈øeede in them as in the former, but ≈ømaller.

div.head: 3. Morus Virginiana. The Virginia Mulberrie.
div.p: The Virginia Mulberry tree groweth quickely with vs to be a very great tree, ≈øpreading many armes and branches, whereon grow faire great leaues, very like vnto the leaues of the white Mulberrie tree: the berry or fruit is longer and redder then either of the other, and of a very plea≈øant ta≈øte.

div.head: The V≈øe of Mulberries.

figure.head: 1 Nux Iuglans. The Wallnut. 2 Ca≈øtanea equina. The hor≈øe Che≈ønut. 3 Morus nigra-vel alba. The Mulberry. 4 Morus Vi ‚Ä¢ giniana The Virginia Mulberry. 5 Laurus vulgaris. The ordinary Bay tree, 6 Laurea Cera≈øus Virginiana, The Virginia Cherry Bay.

div.p: Mulberries are not much de≈øired to be eaten, although they be ≈øomewhat plea≈øant, both for that they ≈øtaine their fingers and lips that eate them, and doe quickly putrefie in the ≈øtomacke, if they bee not taken before meate.

They haue yet a Phy≈øicall v≈øe, which is by rea≈øon of the a≈øtringent quality while they are red, and before they bee ripe, for ≈øore mouthes and throats, or the like, whereunto al≈øo the Syrup, called Diamoron, is effectuall.

div.head: Corollarium. A COROLEARIE To this Orchard.
div.p: THere are certaine other trees that beare no fruit fit to bee eaten, which yet are often ≈øeene planted in Orchards, and other fit and conuenient places bout an hou≈øe, whereof ≈øome are of e≈øpeciall v≈øe, as the Bay tree &c. others for their beauty and ≈øhadow are fit for walkes or arbours; ≈øome being euer green are mo≈øt fit for hedge-rowes; and ≈øome others more for their raritie then for any other great v≈øe, wherof I thought good to entreat apart by them≈øelues, and bring them after the fruit trees of this Orchard, as an ornament to accompli≈øh the ≈øame.

div.head: 1. Laurus. The Bay tree.
div.p: THere are to bee reckoned vp fiue kindes of Bay trees, three whereof haue been entreated of in the fir≈øt part, a fourth wee will only bring hereto your con≈øideration, which is that kinde that is v≈øually planted in euery mans yard or orchard, for their v≈øe throughout the whole land, the other we will leaue to bee con≈øidered of in that place is fit for it.

The Bay tree ri≈øeth vp oftentimes to carry the face of a tree of a meane bigne≈ø≈øe in our Countrey (although much greater in the hoter) and oftentimes ≈øhooteth vp with many ≈øuckers from the roote, ≈øhewing it ≈øelfe more like to a tall ≈øhrubbe or hedgebu≈øh, then a tree, hauing many branches, the young ones whereof are ≈øometimes reddi≈øh, but mo≈øt v≈øually of a light or fre≈øh greene colour, when the ≈øtemme and elder boughes are couered with a darke greene barke: the leaues are ≈øomewhat broad, and long pointed as it were at both the ends, hard and ≈øometimes crumpled on the edges, of a darke greene colour aboue, and of a yellowi≈øh greene vnderneath, in ≈ømell ≈øweet, in ta≈øte bitter, and abiding euer greene: the flowers are yellow and mo≈ø≈øie, which turne into berries that are a little long as well as round, who≈øe ≈øhell or outermo≈øt peele is greene at the fir≈øt, and blacke when it is ripe; wherein is contained an hard bitter kernell, which cleaueth in two parts.

div.head: The V≈øe of Bayes.
div.p:
The Bay leaues are of as nece≈ø≈øary v≈øe as any other in Garden or Orchard; for they ≈øerue both for plea≈øure and profit, both for ornament and for v≈øe, both for hone≈øt Ciuill v≈øes, and for Phy≈øicke, yea both for the ≈øicke and for the ≈øound, both for the liuing and for the dead: And ≈øo much might be ≈øaid of this one tree, that if it were all told, would as well weary the Reader, as the Relater: but to explaine my ≈øelfe; It ≈øerueth to adorne the hou≈øe of God as well as of man: to procure warmth, comfort and ≈øtrength to the limmes of men and women, by bathings and annoyntings outward, and by drinkes &c. inward to the ≈øtomacke, and other parts: to ≈øea≈øon ve≈ø≈øels &c. wherein are pre≈øerued our meates, as well as our drinkes: to crowne or encircle
as with a garland, the heads of the liuing, and to ≈øticke and decke forth the bodies of the dead: ≈øo that from the cradle to the graue we haue ≈øtill v≈øe of it, we haue ≈øtill neede of it.
The berries likewi≈øe ≈øerue for ≈øtitches inward, and for paines outward, that come of cold eyther in the ioynts, ≈øinewes, or other places.

div.head: 2. Laurea Cera≈øus, ≈øiue Laurus Virginiana. The Virginian Bay, or Cherry Baye.
div.p: THis Virginian (whether you will call it a Baye, or a Cherrie, or a Cherrie Bay, I leaue it to euery ones free will and iudgement, but yet I thinke I may as well call it a Bay as others a Cherrie, neither of them being an≈øwerable to the tree, which neyther beareth ≈øuch berries as are like Cherries, neither beareth euer greene leaues like the Bay: if it may therefore bee called the Virginia Cherry Bay, for a di≈øtinction from the former Bay Cherry that beareth faire blacke Cherries, it will more fitly agree thereunto, vntill a more proper may be impo≈øed) ri≈øeth vp to be a tree of a rea≈øonable height, the ≈øtemme or bodie thereof being almo≈øt as great as a mans legge, ≈øpreading forth into diuers armes or boughes, and they againe into diuers ≈ømall branches, whereon are ≈øet without order diuers faire broade greene leaues, ≈øomewhat like vnto the former Bay leaues, but more limber and gentle, and not ≈øo hard in handling, broader al≈øo, and for the mo≈øt part ending in a point, but in many ≈øomewhat round pointed, very finely notched or toothed about the edges, of a bitter ta≈øte, very neere re≈øembling the ta≈øte of the Bay leafe, but of little or no ≈øent at all, either greene or dryed, which fall away euery autumne, and ≈øpring a fre≈øh euery yeare: the blo≈ø≈øomes are ≈ømall and white, many growing together vpon a long ≈øtalke, ≈øomewhat like the Bird Cherry blo≈ø≈øomes, but ≈ømaller, and come forth at the ends of the young branches, which after turne into ≈ømall berries, euery one ≈øet in a ≈ømall cup or huske, greene at the fir≈øt, and blacke when they are ripe, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a ≈ømall pea≈øe, of a ≈øtrong bitter ta≈øte, and ≈øomewhat aromaticall withall, but without any fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance like a Cherry at all vpon it; for it is altogether like a berry.

div.head: The V≈øe of this Virginia Cherry Bay.
div.p: Being a ≈øtranger in our Land, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed but of a very few, I doe not heare that there hath beene any triall made thereof what properties are in it: let this therefore ≈øuffice for this pre≈øent, to haue ≈øhewed you the de≈øcription and forme thereof, vntill we can learne further of his v≈øes.

div.head: 3. Pinus. The Pine tree.
div.p: MY purpo≈øe in this place is not to ≈øhew you all the diuer≈øities of Pine trees, or of the re≈øt that follow, but of that one kinde is planted in many places of our Land for ornament and delight, and there doth rea≈øonably well abide: take it therefore into this Orchard, for the raritie and beautie of it, though we haue little other v≈øe of it.

The Pine tree groweth with vs, though ≈ølowely, to a very great height in many places, with a great ≈øtraight bodie, couered with a grayi≈øh greene barke, the younger branches are ≈øet round about, with very narrow long whiti≈øh greene leaues, which fall away from the elder, but abide on the younger, being both winter and ≈øummer alwaies greene. It hath growing in ≈øundry places on the branches, certaine great hard wooddy clogs (called of ≈øome apples, of others nuts) compo≈øed of many hard wooddy ≈øcales, or tuberous knobs, which abide for the mo≈øt part alwaies greene in our Countrey, and hardly become browni≈øh, as in other Countries, where they haue more heat and comfort of the Sun, and where the ≈øcales open them≈øelues; wherein are contained white long and round kernels, very ≈øweete while they are fre≈øh, but quickely growing oylely and rancide.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Pine apples and kernels.
div.p: The Cones or Apples are v≈øed of diuers Vintners in this City, being painted, to expre≈ø≈øe a bunch of grapes, whereunto they are very like, and are hung vp in their bu≈øhes, as al≈øo to fa≈øten keyes vnto them, as is ≈øeene in many places.

The kernels within the hard ≈øhels, while they are fre≈øh or newly taken out, are v≈øed many waies, both with Apothecaries, Comfit-makers, and Cookes: for of them are made medicines, good to lenifie the pipes and pa≈ø≈øages of the lungs and throate, when it is hoar≈øe. Of them are made Comfits, Pa≈øtes, Marchpanes, and diuers other ≈øuch like: And with them a cunning Cooke can make diuers Keck ≈øho≈øes for his Ma≈øters table.

Matthiolus commendeth the water of the greene apples di≈øtilled, to take away the wrinkles in the face, to abate the ouer-≈øwelling brea≈øts of Maidens, by fomenting them after with linnen clothes, wet in the water; and to re≈øtore ≈øuch as are raui≈øht into better termes.

div.head: 4. Abies. The Firre tree.
div.p: THe Firre tree groweth naturally higher then any other tree in the≈øe parts of Chri≈øtendome where no Cedars grow, and euen equalling or ouer-topping the Pine: the ≈øtemme or bodie is bare without branches for a great height, if they bee elder trees, and then branching forth at one place of the bodie foure wayes in manner of a cro≈ø≈øe, tho≈øe boughes againe hauing two branches at euery ioynt, on which are ≈øet on all ≈øides very thicke together many ≈ømall narrow long hard whiti≈øh greene leaues, and while they are young tending to yellowne≈ø≈øe, but nothing ≈øo long or hard or ≈øharpe pointed as the Pine tree leaues, growing ≈ømaller and ≈øhorter to the end of the branches: the bloomings are certaine ≈ømall long ≈øcaly catkins, of a yellowi≈øh colour, comming forth at the ioynts of the branches, which fall away: the cones are ≈ømaller and longer then of the Pine tree, wherein are ≈ømall three ≈øquare ≈øeede contained, not halfe ≈øo big as the Pine kernels.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Firre tree.
div.p: The v≈øe of this tree is growne with vs of late daies to bee more frequent for the building of hou≈øes then euer before: for hereof (namely of Deale timber and Deale boords) are framed many hou≈øes, and their floores, without the helpe of any other timber or boord of any other tree almo≈øt; as al≈øo for many other workes and purpo≈øes. The yellow Ro≈ø≈øen that is v≈øed as well to make ≈øalues as for many other common v≈øes, is taken from this tree, as the Pitch is both from the Pitch and Pine trees, and is boyled to make it to bee hard, but was at the fir≈øt a yellow thin cleere Turpentine, and is that be≈øt ≈øort of common Turpentine is altogether in v≈øe with vs, as al≈øo another more thicke, whiti≈øh, and troubled, both which are v≈øed in ≈øalues, both for man and bea≈øt (but not inwardly as the cleere white Venice Turpentine is) and ≈øerueth both to draw, clean≈øe and heale. Dodonaeus ≈øeemeth to ≈øay, that the cleere white Turpentine, called Venice Turpentine, is drawn from the Firre: but Matthiolus confuteth that opinion, which Ful≈øius al≈øo held before him.

div.head: 5. Ilex arbor. The euer-greene Oake.
div.p:
THe Ilex or euer-greene Oake ri≈øeth in time to be a very great tree, but very long and ≈ølow in growing (as is to be ≈øeene in the Kings priuy Garden at Whitehall, growing iu≈øt again≈øt the backe gate that openeth into the way going to We≈øtmin≈øter, and in ≈øome other places) ≈øpreading many fair large great armes and branches, whereon are ≈øet ≈ømall and hard greene leaues, ≈øomewhat endented or cornered, and
1 Piaus The Pine tree. 2 Abies. The Firre tree. 3 Ilex. The euer greene Oake. 4 Cupre≈ø≈øus. The Cipre≈ø≈øe tree. 5 Arbutus. The Strawberry tree. 6 Alaternus. The euer greene Priuet. depiction of trees
prickly on the edges, e≈øpecially in the young trees, and ≈øometimes on tho≈øe branches that are young and newly ≈øprung forth from the elder rootes, but el≈øe in a manner all ≈ømooth in the elder growne, abiding greene all the winter as well as ≈øummer, and are of a grayi≈øh greene on the vnder≈øide. It beareth in the ≈øpring time certaine ≈ølender long branches (like as other Okes doe) with ≈ømall yellowi≈øh mo≈ø≈øie flowers on them, which fall away, and are vnprofitable, the acornes not growing from tho≈øe places, but from others which are like vnto tho≈øe of our ordinary Oake, but ≈ømaller and blacker, and ≈øet in a more rugged huske or cuppe. This and no other kinde of Ilex doe I know to grow in all our land in any Garden or Orchard: for that kind with long and narrower leaues, and not prickly, growing ≈øo plentifully as Matthiolus ≈øaith in Tu≈øcane, I haue not ≈øeen: and it is very probable to bee the ≈øame that Plinie remembreth to haue the leafe of an Oliue; but not as ≈øome would haue it, that Smilax Theophra≈øtus maketh mention of in his third Booke and ≈øixteenth Chapter of his Hi≈øtorie of Plants, which the Arcadians ≈øo called, and had the leafe of the Ilex, but not prickly: for Theophra≈øtus ≈øaith, the timber of Smilax is ≈ømooth and ≈øoft, and this of the Ilex is harder, and ≈øtronger then an Oake.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Ilex or euer-greene Oake.
div.p: Seeing this is to be accounted among the kindes of Oake (and all Oakes by Dio≈øcorides his opinion are binding) it is al≈øo of the ≈øame qualitie, but a little weaker, and may ≈øerue to ≈øtrengthen weake members. The young tops and leaues are al≈øo v≈øed in gargles for the mouth and throate.

div.head: 6 Cupre≈ø≈øus. The Cypre≈ø≈øe tree.
div.p: THe Cypre≈ø≈øe tree that is nour≈øed vp by vs, in our Country, doth grow in tho≈øe places where it hath beene long planted, to a very great height, who≈øe bodie and boughes are couered with a reddi≈øh a≈øh-coloured bark; the branches grow not ≈øpreading, but vpright clo≈øe vnto the bodie, bu≈øhing thicke below, and ≈ømall vpwards, ≈øpire fa≈øhion, tho≈øe below reaching neere halfe the way to them aboue, whereon doe grow euer greene leaues, ≈ømall, long and flat, of a re≈øinous ≈øweete ≈ømell, and ≈øtrong ta≈øte, ≈øomewhat bitter: the fruit, which are called nuts, grow here and there among the boughes, ≈øticking clo≈øe vnto them, which are ≈ømall, and clouen into diuers parts, but clo≈øe while they are young, of a ru≈ø≈øeti≈øh browne colour; wherein are contained ≈ømall browne ≈øeede, but not ≈øo ≈ømall as motes in the Sunne, as Matthiolus and others make them to be.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Cypre≈ø≈øe tree.
div.p: For the goodly proportion this tree beareth, as al≈øo for his euer-greene head, it is and hath beene of great account with all Princes, both beyond, and on this ≈øide of the Sea, to plant them in rowes on both ≈øides of ≈øome ≈øpatious walke, which by rea≈øon of their high growing, and little ≈øpreading, mu≈øt be planted the thicker together, and ≈øo they giue a goodly, plea≈øant and ≈øweet ≈øhadow: or el≈øe alone, if they haue not many, in the middle of ≈øome quarter, or as they thinke meete. The wood thereof is firme and durable, or neuer decaying, of a brown yellow colour, and of a ≈øtrong ≈øweete ≈ømell, whereof Che≈øts or Boxes are made to keepe apparell, linnen, furres, and other things, to pre≈øerue them from moths, and to giue them a good ≈ømell.

Many Phy≈øicall properties, both wood, leaues and nuts haue, which here is not my purpo≈øe to vnfold, but only to tell you, that the leaues being boyled in wine, and drunke, helpe the difficultie of making vrine, and that the nuts are binding, fit to bee v≈øed to ≈øtay fluxes or laskes, and good al≈øo for ruptures.

div.head: 7. Arbutus. The Strawberry tree.
div.p: THe Strawberry tree groweth but ≈ølowly, and ri≈øeth not to the height of any great tree, no not in France, Italy, or Spaine: and with vs the coldne≈ø≈øe of our country doth the more abate his vigour, ≈øo that it ≈øeldome ri≈øeth to the height of a man: the barke of the body is rough, and ≈ømooth in the younger branches: the leaues are faire and greene, very like vnto Baye leaues, finely dented or ≈ønipped about the edges, abiding alwayes greene thereon both Winter and Summer: the flowers come forth at the end of the branches vpon long ≈øtalkes, not clu≈øtering thicke together, but in long bunches, and are ≈ømall, white, and hollow, like a little bottle, or the flower of Lilly Conually, which after turne into rough or rugged berries, mo≈øt like vnto Strawberries (which hath giuen the name to the tree) ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh when they are ripe, of a har≈øh ta≈øte, nothing plea≈øant, wherein are contained many ≈ømall ≈øeedes: It hardly bringeth his fruit to ripene≈ø≈øe in our countrey; for in their naturall places they ripen not vntill Winter, which there is much milder then with vs.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Strawberry tree.
div.p: Amatus Lu≈øitanus I thinke is the fir≈øt that euer recorded, that the water di≈øtilled from the leaues and flowers hereof, ≈øhould bee very powerfull again≈øt the plague and poy≈øons: for all the ancient Writers doe report, that the fruit hereof being eaten, is an enemy to the ≈øtomacke and head. And Clu≈øius likewi≈øe ≈øetteth downe, that at Li≈øhbone, and other places in Portingall where they are frequent, they are chiefly eaten, but of the poorer ≈øort, women and boyes. They are ≈øomewhat a≈øtringent or binding, and therefore may well ≈øerue for fluxes. It is chiefly nour≈øed with vs for the beauty and rarene≈ø≈øe of the tree; for that it beareth his leaues alwayes green.

div.head: 8. Alaternus. The euer greene Priuet.
div.p: THe tree which we haue growing in our country called Alaternus, groweth not to be a tree of any height; but abiding lowe, ≈øpreadeth forth many branches, whereon are ≈øet diuers ≈ømall and hard greene leaues, ≈øomewhat round for the forme, and endented a little by the edges: it beareth many ≈ømall whiti≈øh greene flowers at the ioynts of the ≈øtalkes, and ≈øetting on of the lower leaues clu≈øtering thicke together, which after turne into ≈ømall blacke berries, wherein are contained many ≈ømall graines or ≈øeedes: the beauty and verdure of the≈øe leaues abiding ≈øo fre≈øh all the yeare, doth cau≈øe it to be of the greater re≈øpect; and therefore findeth place in their Gardens onely, that are curious con≈øeruers of all natures beauties.

div.head: The V≈øe of the euer greene Priuet.
div.p: It is ≈øeldome v≈øed for any Phy≈øicall property, neither with vs, nor in the places where it is naturall and plentifull: but as Clu≈øius reporteth, hee learned that the Portingall Fi≈øhermen do dye their nets red with the decoction of the barke hereof, and that the Dyers in tho≈øe parts doe v≈øe the ≈ømall peeces of the wood to ≈øtrike a blacki≈øh blew colour.

div.head: 9. Celastrus Theophrasti Clu≈øio. Clu≈øius his Cela≈øtrus.
div.p:
ALthough the Collectour (who is thought to be Ioannes Molineus of the great Herball or Hi≈øtory of plants, and generally bearing Dale≈øchampius name, becau≈øe the finding and relation of diuers herbes therein expre≈ø≈øed, is appropiate to him, and printed at Lyons) of all our moderne Writers doth fir≈øt of all others appoint the Cela≈øtrus, whereof Theophra≈øtus onely among all the ancient Writers of
plants maketh mention, to be the fir≈øt Alaternus that Clu≈øius hath ≈øet forth in his Hi≈øtory of rarer plants: yet I finde, that Clu≈øius him≈øelfe before his death doth appropiate that Cela≈øtrus of Theophra≈øtus to another plant, growing in the Garden at Leyden, which formerly of diuers had beene taken to be a kinde of Laurus Tinus, or the wilde Baye; but he impugning that opinion for diuers re≈øpects, decyphreth out that Leyden tree in the ≈øame manner that I doe: and becau≈øe it is not onely faire, in bearing his leaues alwayes greene, but rare al≈øo, being nour≈øed vp in our Land in very few places, but principally with a good old Lady, the widow of Sir Iohn Leu≈øon, dwelling neere Roche≈øter in Kent; I thought it fit to commend it for an ornament, to adorne this our Garden and Orchard. It groweth vp to the height of a rea≈øonable tree, the body whereof is couered with a darke coloured barke, as the elder branches are in like manner; the younger branches being greene, whereon are ≈øet diuers leaues thicke together, two alwayes at a ioynt, one again≈øt another, of a ≈øad but faire greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and paler vnderneath, which are little or nothing at all ≈ønipped about the edges, as large as the leaues of the Laurus Tinus, or wilde Baye tree: at the end of the young branches breake forth between the leaues diuers ≈ømall ≈øtalkes, with foure or fiue flowers on each of them, of a yellowi≈øh greene colour, which turne into ≈ømall berries, of the bigne≈ø≈øe of blacke Cherries, greene at the fir≈øt, and red when they begin to be ripe, but growing blacke if they hang too long vpon the branches, wherein is contained a hard ≈øhell, and a white hard kernell within it, couered with a yellowi≈øh skin. This abideth (as I ≈øaid before) with greene leaues as well Winter as Summer; and therefore fitte≈øt to be planted among other of the ≈øame nature, to make an euer greene hedge.

div.head: The V≈øe of Clu≈øius his Cela≈øtrus.
div.p: Being ≈øo great a ≈øtranger in this part of the Chri≈øtian world, I know none hath made tryall of what property it is, but that the ta≈øte of the leaues is ≈øomewhat bitter.

div.head: 10. Pyracantha. The euer greene Hawthorne, or prickly Corall tree.
div.p: THis euer greene ≈øhrubbe is ≈øo fine an ornament to a Garden or Orchard, either to be nour≈øed vp into a ≈ømall tree by it ≈øelfe, by pruining and taking away the ≈øuckers and vnder branches, or by ≈øuffering it to grow with ≈øuckers, thicke and pla≈øhing the branches into a hedge, for that it is plyable to be ordered either way; that I could not but giue you the knowledge thereof, with the de≈øcription in this manner. The younger branches are couered with a ≈ømooth darke blewi≈øh greene barke, and the elder with a more a≈øh coloured, thicke ≈øet with leaues without order, ≈øome greater and others ≈ømaller, ≈øomewhat like both in forme and bigne≈ø≈øe vnto the leaues of the Barberry tree, but ≈øomewhat larger, and more ≈ønipt about the edges, of a deeper green colour al≈øo, and with ≈ømall long thornes ≈øcattered here & there vpon the branches: the flowers come forth as well at the ends of the branches, as at diuers places at the ioynts of the leaues, ≈øtanding thicke together, of a pale whiti≈øh colour, a little da≈øht ouer with a ≈øhew of blu≈øh, con≈øi≈øting of fiue leaues a peece, with ≈øome ≈ømall threads in the middle, which turne into berries, very like vnto Hawthorne berries, but much redder and dryer, almo≈øt like poli≈øhed Corall, wherein are contained foure or fiue ≈ømall yellowi≈øh white three ≈øquare ≈øeede, ≈øomewhat ≈øhining. It is thought to be the Oxyacantha of Dio≈øcorides; but ≈øeeing Dio≈øcorides doth explaine the forme of the leafe in his Chapter of Medlars, which he concealed in the Chapter of Oxyacantha, it cannot be the ≈øame: for Me≈øpilus Anthedon of Theophra≈øtus, or Aronia of Dio≈øcorides, hath the leafe of Oxyacantha, as Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith, or of Smalladge, as Theophra≈øtus, which cannot agree to this Thorne; but doth mo≈øt liuely delineate out our white Thorne or Hawthorne, that now there is no doubt, but that Oxyacantha of Dio≈øcorides is the Hawthorne tree or bu≈øh.

div.head: The V≈øe of this Corall tree.
div.p:
Although Lobel maketh mention of this tree to grow both in Italy, and
1 Cela≈øtrus Theophra≈øti Clufio. Clu≈øius his Cela≈øtrus. 2 Pyracantha. The euer green prickly Corall tree, 3 Taxus. The Yewe tree. 4 Buxus arbor. The Boxe tree 5 Buxus humilis. The lowe or dwarfe Boxe. 6 Sabina. The Sauine tree. 7 Paliurus. Chri≈øts thorne. 8 Larix. The Larch tree. depiction of trees
Prouence in France, in ≈øome of their hedges, yet he ≈øaith it is neglected in the naturall places, and to be of no v≈øe with them: neither doe I heare, that it is applyed to any Phy≈øicall v≈øe with vs, but (as I before ≈øaid) it is pre≈øerued with diuers as an ornament to a Garden or Orchard, by rea≈øon of his euer greene leaues, and red berries among them, being a plea≈øant ≈øpectacle, and fit to be brought into the forme of an hedge, as one plea≈øe to lead it.

div.head: 11. Taxus. The Yewe tree.
div.p: THe Yewe tree groweth with vs in many places to bee a rea≈øonable great tree, but in hoter countries much bigger, couered with a reddi≈øh gray ≈øcaly barke; the younger branches are reddi≈øh likewi≈øe, whereon grow many winged leaues, that is, many narrow long darke greene leaues, ≈øet on both ≈øides of a long ≈øtalke or branch, neuer dying or falling away, but abiding on perpetually, except it be on the elder boughes: the flowers are ≈ømall, growing by the leaues, which turne into round red berries, like vnto red A≈øparagus berries, in ta≈øte ≈øweeti≈øh, with a little bitterne≈ø≈øe, and cau≈øing no harme to them for any thing hath been knowne in our country,

div.head: The V≈øe of the Yewe tree.
div.p: It is found planted both in the corners of Orchards, and again≈øt the windowes of Hou≈øes, to be both a ≈øhadow and an ornament, in being alwayes greene, and to decke vp Hou≈øes in Winter: but ancient Writers haue euer reckoned it to be dangerous at the lea≈øt, if not deadly.

div.head: 12. Buxus. The Boxe tree.
div.p: THe Boxe tree in ≈øome places is a rea≈øonable tall tree, yet growing ≈ølowly; the trunke or body whereof is of the bigne≈ø≈øe of a mans thigh, which is the bigge≈øt that euer I ≈øaw: but ≈øometimes, and in other places it groweth much lower, v≈øually not aboue a yard, or a yard and a halfe high, on the backe ≈øides of many Hou≈øes, and in the Orchards likewi≈øe: the leaues are ≈ømall, thicke and hard, and ≈øtill the greater or le≈ø≈øer the tree is, the greater or le≈ø≈øer are the leaues, round pointed, and of a fre≈øh ≈øhining greene colour: the flowers are ≈ømall and greeni≈øh, which turne into heads or berries, with foure hornes, whitti≈øh on the out≈øide, and with reddi≈øh ≈øeede within them.

Buxus aureus. Gilded Boxe.There is another kinde hereof but lately come to our knowledge, which differeth not in any thing from the former, but onely that all the leaues haue a yellow li≈øt or gard about the edge of them on the vpper≈øide, and none on the lower, which maketh it ≈øeeme very beautifull; and is therefore called gilded Boxe.

Buxus humilis. Dwarfe Boxe.We haue yet another kinde of Boxe, growing ≈ømall and lowe, not aboue halfe a foote, or a foote high at the mo≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe it be neglected, which then doth grow a little more ≈øhrubby, bearing the like leaues, but ≈ømaller, according to the growth, and of a deeper greene colour: I could neuer know that this kinde euer bore flower or ≈øeede, but is propagated by ≈ølipping the roote, which encrea≈øeth very much.

div.head: The V≈øe of Boxe.
div.p: The wood of the Boxe tree is v≈øed in many kindes of ≈ømall works among Turners, becau≈øe it is hard, clo≈øe, and firme, and as ≈øome haue ≈øaid, the roots much more, in regard of the diuers waues and crooked veines running through it. It hath no Phy≈øicall v≈øe among the mo≈øt and be≈øt Phy≈øitians, although ≈øome haue reported it to ≈øtay fluxes, and to be as good as the wood of Guaiacum, or Lignum vitae for the French di≈øea≈øe. The leaues and branches ≈øerue both Summer and Winter to decke vp hou≈øes; and are many times giuen to hor≈øes for the bots.

The lowe or dwarfe Boxe is of excellent v≈øe to border vp a knot, or the
long beds in a Garden, being a maruailous fine ornament thereunto, in regard it both groweth lowe, is euer greene, and by cutting may bee kept in what maner euery one plea≈øe, as I haue before ≈øpoken more largely.

div.head: 13. Sabina. The Sauine tree or bu≈øh.
div.p: THe Sauine tree or bu≈øh that is mo≈øt v≈øuall in our country, is a ≈ømall lowe bu≈øh, not ≈øo high as a man in any place, nor ≈øo bigge in the ≈øtemme or trunke as a mans arme, with many crooked bending boughes and branches, whereon are ≈øet many ≈ømall, ≈øhort, hard, and prickly leaues, of a darke green colour, fre≈øh and green both Winter and Summer: it is reported, that in the naturall places it beareth ≈ømall blacke berries, like vnto Iuniper, but with vs it was neuer knowne to beare any.

div.head: The V≈øe of Sauine.
div.p: It is planted in out-yards, back≈øides, or voide places of Orchards, as well to ca≈øt clothes thereon to dry, as for medicines both for men and hor≈øes: being made into an oyle, it is good to annoint childrens bellies for to kill the Wormes: and the powder thereof mixed with Hogs grea≈øe, to annoint the running ≈øores or ≈øcabs in their heads; but beware how you giue it inwardly to men, women, or children. It is often put into hor≈øes drenches, to helpe to cure them of the bots, and other di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: 14. Paliurus. Chri≈øts thorne.
div.p: THis thorny ≈øhrubbe (wherewith as it is thought, our Sauiour Chri≈øt was crowned, becau≈øe as tho≈øe that haue trauelled through Pale≈øtina and Iudaea, doe report no other thorne doth grow therein ≈øo frequent, or ≈øo apt to be writhed) ri≈øeth in ≈øome places to a rea≈øonable height, but in our country ≈øeldome exceedeth the height of a man, bearing many ≈ølender branches, full of leaues, ≈øet on either ≈øide thereof one by one, which are ≈øomewhat broad and round, yet pointed, and full of veines, thicke ≈øet al≈øo with ≈ømall thornes, euen at the foote of euery branch, and at the foote of euery leafe one or two, ≈øome ≈øtanding vpright, others a little bending downe: the flowers are ≈ømall and yellow, ≈øtanding for the mo≈øt part at the end of the branches, many growing vpon a long ≈øtalke, which after turne into round, flat, and hard ≈øhelly fruit, yet couered with a ≈øoft fle≈øhy skinne, within which are included two or three hard, ≈ømall, and browne flat ≈øeeds, lying in ≈øeuerall partitions. The leaues hereof fall away euery yeare, and ≈øpring forth a fre≈øh againe the next May following. The rarity and beauty of this ≈øhrubbe, but chiefly (as I thinke) the name hath cau≈øed this to be much accounted of with all louers of plants.

div.head: The V≈øe of Chri≈øts thorne.
div.p: Wee haue ≈øo few of the≈øe ≈øhrubbes growing in our country, and tho≈øe that are, doe, for any thing I can vnder≈øtand, neuer beare fruit with vs; that there is no other v≈øe made hereof then to delight the owners: but this is certainly receiued for the Paliurus of Dio≈øcorides and Theophra≈øtus, and thought al≈øo by Matthiolus to be the very true Rhamnus tertius of Dio≈øcorides. Matthiolus al≈øo ≈øeemeth to contradict the opinion is held by the Phy≈øitians of Mompelier, and others, that it cannot be the Paliurus of Theophra≈øtus. It is held to be effectuall to helpe to breake the ≈øtone, both in the bladder, reines, and kidneyes: the leaues and young branches haue an a≈øtringent quality, and good again≈øt poy≈øons and the bitings of ≈øerpents.

div.head: 15. Larix. The Larch tree.
div.p: THe Larch tree, where it naturally groweth, ri≈øeth vp to be as tall as the Pine or Firre tree, but in our Land being rare, and nour≈øed vp but with a few, and tho≈øe onely louers of rarities, it groweth both ≈ølowly, and becommeth not high: the barke hereof is very rugged and thicke, the boughes and branches grow one aboue another in a very comely order, hauing diuers ≈ømall yellowi≈øh knobs or bunches ≈øet thereon at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances; from whence doe yearely ≈øhoote forth many ≈ømall, long, and narrow ≈ømooth leaues together, both ≈øhorter and ≈ømaller, and not ≈øo hard or ≈øharpe pointed as either the Pine or Firre tree leaues, which doe not abide the Winter as they doe, but fall away euery yeare, as other trees which ≈øhed their leaues, and gaine fre≈øh euery Spring: the blo≈ø≈øomes are very beautifull and delectable, being of an excellent fine crim≈øon colour, which ≈øtanding among the greene leaues, allure the eyes of the beholders to regard it with the more de≈øire: it al≈øo beareth in the naturall places (but not in our Land that I could heare) ≈ømall ≈øoft cones or fruit, ≈øomewhat like vnto Cypre≈ø≈øe nuts, when they are greene and clo≈øe.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Larch tree.
div.p: The coles of the wood hereof (becau≈øe it is ≈øo hard and durable as none more) is held to be of mo≈øt force being fired, to cau≈øe the Iron oare to melt, which none other would doe ≈øo well. Matthiolus conte≈øteth again≈øt Fuch≈øius, for deeming the Venice Turpentine to be the liquid Ro≈ø≈øen of the Firre tree, which he a≈ø≈øureth vpon his owne experience and certaine knowledge, to be drawne from this Larch tree, and none other; which cleere Turpintine is altogether v≈øed inwardly, and no other, except that of the true Turpintine tree, and is very effectuall to clean≈øe the reines, kidneyes, and bladder, both of grauell and the ≈øtone, and to prouoke vrine: it is al≈øo of e≈øpeciall property for the gonorrhaea, or running of the reines, as it is called, with ≈øome powder of white Amber mixed therewith, taken for certaine dayes together. Taken al≈øo in an Electuary, it is ≈øingular good for to expectorate rotten flegme, and to helpe the con≈øumption of the lungs. It is v≈øed in plai≈øters and ≈øalues, as the be≈øt ≈øort of Turpintine. The Agaricke that is v≈øed in phy≈øicke, is taken from the bodies and armes of this tree. And Matthiolus doth much in≈øi≈øt again≈øt Bra≈øauolus, that thought other trees had produced Agaricke, affirming them to be hard Fungi, or Mu≈øhroms (≈øuch as wee call Touch-wood) wherwith many v≈øe to take fire, ≈øtrooke thereinto from ≈øteele.

div.head: 16. Tilia. The Line or Linden tree.
div.p: THere are two ≈øorts of Line trees, the male and the female; but becau≈øe the male is rare to be ≈øeene, and the female is more familiar, I will onely giue you the de≈øcription of the female, and leaue the other.

The female Line tree groweth exceeding high and great, like vnto an Elme, with many large ≈øpreading boughes, couered with a ≈ømooth barke, the innermo≈øt being very plyant and bending from whence come ≈ømaller branches, all of them ≈øo plyable, that they may bee led or carried into any forme you plea≈øe: the leaues thereon are very faire, broad, and round, ≈øomewhat like vnto Elme leaues, but fairer, ≈ømoother, and of a fre≈øher greene colour, dented finely about the edges, and ending in a ≈øharpe point: the flowers are white, and of a good ≈ømell, many ≈øtanding together at the top of a ≈øtalke, which runneth all along the middle ribbe of a ≈ømall long whiti≈øh leafe; after which come ≈ømall round berries, wherein is contained ≈ømall blacki≈øh ≈øeede: this tree is wholly neglected by tho≈øe that haue them, or dwell neere them, becau≈øe they ≈øuppo≈øe it to be fruitle≈ø≈øe, in regard it beareth chaffie huskes, which in many places fall away, without giuing ripe ≈øeede.

figure.head:
1 Tilia faemina. The Line or Linden tree. 2 Tamari≈øcus. The Tamariske tree. 3 Acer maius latifolium. The Sycomore tree. 4
‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ hylodendron. The bladder nut. 5 Rhus Myrtifolia. The Mirtle leafed-Sumach. 6 Rhus Virginiana. The Bucks horne tree. 7 Vitis ≈øeu Potius Hedera Virginen≈øis. The Virginia Vine or rather Iuie.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Line tree.
div.p: It is planted both to make goodly Arbours, and Summer banquetting hou≈øes, either belowe vpon the ground, the boughes ≈øeruing very hand≈øomely to pla≈øh round about it, or vp higher, for a ≈øecond aboue it, and a third al≈øo: for the more it is depre≈ø≈øed, the better it will grow. And I haue ≈øeene at Cobham in Kent, a tall or great bodied Line tree, bare without boughes for eight foote high, and then the branches were ≈øpread round about ≈øo orderly, as if it were done by art, and brought to compa≈ø≈øe that middle Arbour: And from tho≈øe boughes the body was bare againe for eight or nine foote (wherein might bee placed halfe an hundred men at the lea≈øt, as there might be likewi≈øe in that vnderneath this) & then another rowe of branches to encompa≈ø≈øe a third Arbour, with ≈øtayres made for the purpo≈øe to this and that vnderneath it: vpon the boughes were laid boards to tread vpon, which was the goodlie≈øt ≈øpectacle mine eyes euer beheld for one tree to carry.

The coles of the wood are the be≈øt to make Gunpowder. And being kindled, and quenched in vinegar, are good to di≈ø≈øolue clotted bloud in tho≈øe that are brui≈øed with a fall. The inner barke being ≈øteeped in water yeeldeth a ≈ølimie iuyce, which is found by experience, to be very profitable for them that haue been burnt with fire.

div.head: 17. Tamarix. Tamariske tree.
div.p: THe Tamariske tree that is common in our country, although in ≈øome places it doth not grow great, yet I haue ≈øeene it in ≈øome other, to be as great as a great apple tree in the body, bearing great arms; from who≈øe ≈ømaller branches ≈øpring forth young ≈ølender red ≈øhootes, ≈øet with many very fine, ≈ømall, and ≈øhort leaues, a little cri≈øped, like vnto the leaues of Sauine, not hard or rough, but ≈øoft and greene: the flowers be white mo≈ø≈øie threads, which turne into dounie ≈øeede, that is carried away with the winde.

Tamari≈øcus folijs ablidis. White Tamariske. There is another kinde hereof very beautifull and rare, not to be ≈øeene in this Land I thinke, but with Mr. William Ward, the Kings ≈øeruant in his Granary, before remembred, who brought me a ≈ømall twigge to ≈øee from his hou≈øe at Boram in E≈ø≈øex, who≈øe branches are all red while they are young, and all the leaues white, abiding ≈øo all the Summer long, without changing into any ≈øhew of greene like the other, and ≈øo abideth con≈øtant yeare after yeare, yet ≈øhedding the leaues in Winter like the other.

div.head: The V≈øe of Tamariske.
div.p: The greate≈øt v≈øe of Tamariske is for ≈øpleneticke di≈øea≈øes, either the leaues or the barke made into drinkes; or the wood made into ≈ømall Cans or Cups to drinke in.

div.head: 18. Acer maius latifolium. The great Maple or Sycomore tree.
div.p: THe Sycomore tree, as we v≈øually call it (and is the greate≈øt kind of Maple, cheri≈øhed in our Land onely in Orchards, or el≈øewhere for ≈øhade and walkes, both here in England, and in ≈øome other countries al≈øo) groweth quickly to bee a faire ≈øpreading great tree, with many boughes and branches, who≈øe barke is ≈øomewhat ≈ømooth: the leaues are very great, large, and ≈ømooth, cut into foure or fiue diui≈øions, and ending into ≈øo many corners, euery one ≈øtanding on a long reddi≈øh ≈øtalke: the bloomings are of a yellowi≈øh greene colour, growing many together on each ≈øide of a long ≈øtalke, which afrer turne into long and broad winged ≈øeede, two alwaies ≈øtanding together on a ≈øtalke, and bunched out in the middle, where the ≈øeed or kernell lyeth, very like vnto the common Maple growing wilde abroad, but many more together, and larger.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Sycomore tree.
div.p: It is altogether planted for ≈øhady walkes, and hath no other v≈øe with vs that I know.

div.head: 19. Nux Ve≈øicaria. The bladder Nut.
div.p: THis tree groweth not very high, but is of a meane ≈øtature, when it is pre≈øerued and pruined to grow vpright, or el≈øe it ≈øhooteth forth many twigges from the rootes, and ≈øo is fit to plant in a hedge rowe, as it is v≈øed in ≈øome places: the body and armes are couered with a whiti≈øh greene barke: the branches and leaues on them are like vnto the Elder, hauing three or fiue leaues ≈øet one again≈øt another, with one of them at the end, each whereof is nicked or dented about the edges: the flowers are ≈øweete and white, many growing together on a long ≈øtalke, hanging downeward, in forme re≈øembling a ≈ømall Daffodill, hauing a ≈ømall round cup in the middle, and leaues about it: after which come the fruit, inclo≈øed in ru≈ø≈øeti≈øh greene bladders, containing one or two browni≈øh nuts, le≈ø≈øer then Ha≈øell nuts, who≈øe outer ≈øhell is not hard and woody, like the ≈øhell of a nut, but tough, and hard withall, not ea≈øie to breake, within which is a greene kernell, ≈øweeti≈øh at the fir≈øt, but loth≈øome afterwards, ready to procure ca≈øting, and yet liked of ≈øome people, who can well endure to eate them.

div.head: The V≈øe of the Bladder Nut.
div.p: The greate≈øt v≈øe that I know the tree or his fruit is put vnto, is, that it is receiued into an Orchard, either for the rarity of the kinde, being ≈øuffered to grow into a tree, or (as I ≈øaid before) to make an hedge, being let grow into ≈øuckers.
Some Quack≈øaluers haue v≈øed the≈øe nuts as a medicine of rare vertue for the ≈øtone, but what good they haue done, I neuer yet could learne.

div.head: 20. Rhus Myrtifolia. The Mirtle leafed Sumach.
div.p: THis lowe ≈øhrubbe groweth ≈øeldome to the height of a man, hauing many ≈ølender branches, and long winged leaues ≈øet thereon, euery one whereof is of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the broad or large Mirtle leafe, and ≈øet by couples all the length of the ribbe, running through the middle of them. It beareth diuers flowers at the tops of the branches, made of many purple threads, which turne into ≈ømall blacke berries, wherein are contained ≈ømall, white, and rough ≈øeed, ≈øomewhat like vnto Grape kernels or ≈øtones. This v≈øeth to dye down to the ground in my Garden euery Winter, and ri≈øe vp again euery Spring, whether the nature thereof were ≈øo, or the coldne≈ø≈øe of our climate the cau≈øe therof, I am not well a≈ø≈øured. It is al≈øo rare, and to be ≈øeen but with a few.

div.head: The V≈øe of this Sumach.
div.p: It is v≈øed to thicken or tanne leather or hides, in the ≈øame manner that the ordinary Sumach doth; as al≈øo to ≈øtay fluxes both in men and women.

div.head: 21. Rhus Virginiana. The Virginia Sumach, or Buckes horne tree of Virginia.
div.p:
THis ≈øtrange tree becommeth in ≈øome places to bee of a rea≈øonable height and bigne≈ø≈øe, the wood whereof is white, ≈øoft, and pithy in the middle, like vnto an Elder, couered with a darke coloured barke, ≈øomewhat ≈ømooth: the young branches that are of the la≈øt yeares growth are ≈øomewhat reddi≈øh or browne, very ≈øoft
and ≈ømooth in handling, and ≈øo like vnto the Veluet head of a Deere, that if one were cut off from the tree, and ≈øhewed by it ≈øelfe, it might ≈øoone deceiue a right good Woodman, and as they grow ≈øeeme mo≈øt like thereunto, yeelding a yellowi≈øh milke when it is broken, which in a ≈ømall time becommeth thicke like a gumme: the leaues grow without order on the branches, but are them≈øelues ≈øet in a ≈øeemly order on each ≈øide of a middle ribbe, ≈øeuen, nine, ten, or more on a ≈øide, and one at the end, each whereof are ≈øomewhat broad and long, of a darke greene colour on the vpper≈øide, and paler greene vnderneath, finely ≈ønipped or toothed round about the edges: at the ends of the branches come forth long and thicke browne tufts, very ≈øoft, and as it were woolly in handling, made all of ≈øhort threads or thrums; from among which appeare many ≈ømall flowers, much more red or crim≈øon then the tufts, which turne into a very ≈ømall ≈øeede: the roote ≈øhooteth forth young ≈øuckers farre away, and round about, whereby it is mightily encrea≈øed.

div.head: The V≈øe of this Sumach.
div.p: It is onely kept as a rarity and ornament to a Garden or Orchard, no bodie, that I can heare of, hauing made any tryall of the Phy≈øicall properties.

div.head: 22. Vitis, ≈øeu potius Hedera Virginen≈øis. The Virginia Vine, or rather Iuie.
div.p: THis ≈ølender, but tall climing Virginia Vine (as it was fir≈øt called; but Iuie, as it doth better re≈øemble) ri≈øeth out of the ground with diuers ≈øtems, none much bigger then a mans thumbe, many le≈ø≈øe; from whence ≈øhoote forth many long weake branches, not able to ≈øtand vpright, vnle≈ø≈øe they be ≈øu≈øtained: yet planted neere vnto a wall or pale, the branches at ≈øeuerall di≈øtances of the leaues will ≈øhoote forth ≈ømall ≈øhort tendrels, not twining them≈øelues about any thing, but ending into foure, fiue, or ≈øix, or more ≈ømall ≈øhort and ≈øomewhat broad clawes, which will fa≈øten like a hand with fingers ≈øo clo≈øe thereunto, that it will bring part of the wall, morter, or board away with it, if it be pulled from it, and thereby ≈øtay it ≈øelfe, to climbe vp to the toppe of the highe≈øt chimney of a hou≈øe, being planted thereat: the leaues are crumpled, or rather folded together at the fir≈øt comming forth, and very red, which after growing forth, are very faire, large, and greene, diuided into foure, fiue, ≈øix, or ≈øeuen leaues, ≈øtanding together vpon a ≈ømall foote-≈øtalke, ≈øet without order on the branches, at the ends whereof, as al≈øo at other places ≈øometime, come forth diuers ≈øhort tufts of buds for flowers; but we could neuer ≈øee them open them≈øelues, to ≈øhew what manner of flower it would be, or what fruit would follow in our country: the roote ≈øpreadeth here and there, and not very deepe.

div.head: The V≈øe of this Virginian.
div.p: We know of no other v≈øe, but to furni≈øh a Garden, and to encrea≈øe the number of rarities.

And thus haue I fini≈øhed this worke, and furni≈øhed it with what≈øoeuer Art and Nature concurring, could effect to bring delight to tho≈øe that liue in our Climate, and take plea≈øure in ≈øuch things; which how well or ill done, I mu≈øt abide euery ones cen≈øure: the iudicious and courteous I onely re≈øpect, let Momus bite his lips, and eate his heart; and ≈øo Farewell.
